title: Gravediggers Union Puts Off a Walkout
description: Leaders of the union representing 1,800 cemetery workers yesterday postponed until at least Jan. 15 a threatened strike that would have affected 70 cemeteries in the metropolitan area.

title: Pabst Is Closing Illinois Brewery
description: The Pabst Brewing Company, the nation's fourth-largest brewery, said that it would begin closing its Peoria Heights, Ill., brewery in early January.

title: International
description: Around the World 2 Israeli Cabinet secretary submits resignation 3 Polish leader reported to ban anti-Semitic broadcasts 4 Relief officials visit Poland to check distribution 5 White House expects Allied back- ing on sanctions 6 Government/Politics Washington lawyer named to head Legal Corporation 8 Reagan seeking to replace com- missioner before term ends 13 Ex-C.I.A. chief to pay U.S. $10,000 in settlement on book 24 New Jersey laying off 468 state employees 26 Republican leaders resist a quick nomination for Regan 26 Subway crime in city rose sharply in last 2 months 27 Washington Talk Briefing 8 Not a creature was stirring in capital, except secretaries 8 The Home Section Home The season of the artful splurge 9

title: Sears, Goldman Trade Securities
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company said that it had exchanged about 1.6 million shares of its common stock for $40.5 million of its debentures owned by Goldman, Sachs & Company, and that, separately, it had sold about $1.3 billion of revolving chargeaccount balances.

title:
SPORTS OF THE TIMES;
BOWLS OF BOODLE
description: SO happy New Year, and if the eyes shade toward vermilion, don't let anybody tell you it's the wages of sin. Explain that 1 5 unbroken hours of foot ball on the tube did it.

title: CABARET: MARCIA LEWIS, COMIC
description: When Marcia Lewis, a short, round woman with a mad gleam in her eyes, first presented her cabaret act five years ago at Brothers and Sisters, she introduced a series of comic characters in sketches and monologues that provided her with a steady succession of very funny episodes, interspersed with an occasional straight song for a change of pace.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: INCUBATOR FOR COMICS

title: CORRECTION
description: The Sports of The Times column on Wednesday incorrectly described the experiment in which the Entertainment and Sports Programming Network televised horse races from Santa Anita last weekend. The network had never planned to televise Sunday's races.

title: Richard Praises Gretzky
description: It was the last regular-season scoring record he held - 50 goals in 50 games - but Maurice Richard said today he knew that a scorer like Wayne Gretzky would break it one day. ''I knew it when they extended the National Hockey League to 12 or 15 teams,'' Richard, a former star for the Montreal Canadiens, said.

title: Arts Groups May Apply For $200,000 in Grants
description: The City Department of Community Affairs has $200,000 in community-development block grants to give to nonprofit arts organizations.

title: POLES ARE URGED TO PRESERVE THE 'NATIONAL ACCORD'
description: Poland's head of state, Henryk Jablonski, called on the Polish nation in a New Year's message tonight to preserve the sense of ''national accord'' that he said grew from the Solidarity trade union movement founded last year.

title: INTERNATIONAL CLINICAL LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
TURMOIL IN TELEX BUSINESS
description: In 1943, the telegraph business was divided into two camps. The Western Union Telegraph Company had a monopoly in the United States, and a handful of international carriers controlled the transmission of messages between the United States and other countries.

title: RELIEF OFFICIALS VISIT POLAND TO CHECK DISTRIBUTION
description: American relief agencies, concerned over th e effect of martial law on the distribution of their aid in Poland, h ave begun sending representatives there to insure that the supp lies are reaching the people for whom they are intended.

title: THE CONSTRAINTS OF POWER
description: It hasn't been a good year and there is little to offer beyond blind hope as assurance that l982 will be much better.

title: BETTER BIRTH CONTROL PILL SEEN
description: Scientists today reported successful tests of a synthetic brain hormone that may lead to a ''once-a-month'' birth control pill for women that avoids the side effects of current contraceptives.

title: PLAN ON FINANCING PAY IS CHALLENGED
description: As part of his effort to bring the 1982 budget deficit below $100 billion, David A. Stockman, the Budget Director, is seeking to force each Federal agency to finance more than half of a pay increase for its workers out of its general funds.

title: Milwaukee Officers Face Trial on Beating Charge
description: Three police officers have been ordered to stand trial on charges that they beat a man on a South Side street Oct. 8.

title: FLASH FIRES OF RUMOR KEEP HAITIAN CAMP ON EDGE
description: A snake, sometimes merely a searing bite from a deer fly, can spark a stampede in a cattle holding pen. Something unfamiliar brought into a henhouse - a pipe elbow or a hank of rope are enough to do the trick - will spook chickens into riot. The flashpoint is even lower at a detention facility for illegal aliens here: a rumor is enough to drive people wild.

title: No Headline
description: The beer will flow Friday night during the Orange Bowl game.

title: Byrne Camp, 41, Conductor,; Chorale Leader and Teacher
description: Byrne Camp, choral conductor and leader of the Byrne Camp Chorale, died Sunday at Presbyterian Hospital in Manhattan. He was 41 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Thais Report Sinking A Cambodian Gunboat
description: Thailand said today that Thai Navy vessels sank a Cambodian gunboat on Monday in Thai waters, killing eight crewmen. Cambodia insisted that the vessel was in Cambodian waters, and said that two Thai warships sailed 10 miles inside Cambodian territory to attack the boat, which was believed to belong to the Vietnamese-supported Government.

title: Socal, Conoco Swap Holdings
description: The Conoco unit of the E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company and the Standard Oil Company of California said they had traded substantial coal and oil shale properties in a move designed to push each company into a new area of domestic energy resources.

title: ISRAELI CABINET OFFICIAL, ON TRIAL, RESIGNS
description: The secretary of the Israeli Cabinet, who is on trial for giving sensitive information to a journalist, submitted his resignation today.

title: FREEDOM NEWSPAPERS CHIEF
description: Clarence Harrison Hoiles, chairman of the board of Freedom Newspapers Inc., died today after a brief illness. He was 76 years old.

title: A 'GARDEN' CONVERSION IN BAYSIDE
description: ALTHOUGH firm figures are not available, real estate experts agree that in recent years the conversion of garden apartments to either cooperative or condominium ownership has become well established in Queens, the section of New York City where they are most ubiquitous.

title: CHINA TELLS U.S. ARMS TO TAIWAN ARE CRUCIAL TEST
description: China publicly warned the United States today not to sell more arms to Taiwan. It called the issue a ''severe test'' of whether Washington valued its relations with Peking.

title: U.S. AND BELL SEEK AGAIN TO RESOLVE ANTITRUST DISPUTE
description: The Justice Department, in an unexpected turn, said today that it was trying to settle its antitrust suit against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company out of court.

title: No Headline
description: BOY FROM UKRAINE WON'T DEPART U.S.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: FRIDAY, JANUARY 1, 1982 Companies

title: HERS
description: IN 1968 Eldridge Cleaver announced in ''Soul on Ice'' that ''there is a war going on between the black man and the black woman'' and that the black woman was the enemy of the black man and the ''silent ally, indirectly but effectively, of the white man.'' Whatever the black woman's feelings, she most certainly was not on the black man's side. For Mr. Cleaver there may well have been a war going on between black men and black women, but it was not nearly as interesting as the war between black men and white men.

title: BRIEFING
description: FOR one brief schmaltzy moment each year, the Washington rat race turns into a waltz. In what is now the capital's most clamorous way of welcoming the New Year, the Grand Foyer at the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts is turned into a vast citizens' ballroom where 6,000 or so people spend a few hours dancing, sipping, or simply watching others dance and sip, and generally sharing in the grand racket as the old year ends with a whirl in three-quarter time. They do so to string music played by Alexander Schneider & Friends, an ad hoc, first-chair gathering of celebrated chamber artists. The Schneider friends begin by presenting an entertainment bargain in the center's Concert Hall, ''A Night in Old Vienna'' -Mozart, Schubert, Strauss at $7.50 a ticket - then move into the Grand Foyer for free midnight waltzing. The celebration is open to anyone with a ticket stub from the major New Year's Eve events at the Kennedy Center: ballet, theater, opera and the Vienna concert. But it is Mr. Schneider & Friends who are the hottest New Year's Eve ticket in town. This year, the Old Vienna concert went on sale on Thanksgiving and all tickets were sold out within hours, snapped up like new leases on life.

title: U.S. Customs to Return Artifacts to Mexico
description: The United States Customs Service announced today that it would return several valuable pre-Columbian artifacts to Mexico on Tuesday. A Customs officer had seized the items at the San Francisco International Airport in April 1980, when the importer failed to declare them.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I hope you all remember that first you are human beings and Poles and only second the executors of orders, that none should allow themselves to be used for fratricide, when you have to pay the highest price. I wish the time will come when you will not be used against your own society, when instead of being tools in the hands of the criminal authorities waging a war against the nation, you will become its real defenders.'' - Zbigniew Bujak, a Solidarity leader. (6:1.)

title: Man Kills Dying Brother, Then Himself at Hospital
description: An elderly man shot and killed his brother, who was dying of cancer in a hospital room, then emptied the pistol into his own chest, killing himself, according to the Chattanooga police.

title: ISRAEL'S POLICY ON SYRIA TALKS
description: Israel has asserted that its annexation of the Golan Heights has not changed its willingness to negotiate with Syria over territory seized in the 1967 war.

title: GUA RDIAN ANGEL IS KILLED BY AN OFFICER IN NEWARK
description: A Newark police officer investigating a burglary last night shot and killed a member of the Guardian Angels who according to those on patrol with him had rushed to the scene of the burglary to offer his aid.

title: Field Cat Wins the Display at the Wire
description: The longest stakes race of the year was dec ided by a few whiskers yesterday as Field Cat nosed out Peat Moss in the last stride to win the $84,900 Display Handicap at Aqueduct.

title: RANGERS GET FTOREK FOR GILLIS, TALAFOUS
description: Robbie Ftorek, the newest Ranger, will have to compete for a regular job, Coach Herb Brooks said yesterday. The Rangers confirmed a report of Wednesday night when they announced that they had acquired Ftorek, a scorer and playmaker, from the Quebec Nordiques in a trade for two forwards, Dean Talafous and Jere Gillis. The Rangers also disclosed that Ed Hospodar had suffered a broken bone in his upper jaw when he was punched by Clark Gillies of the Islanders in Wednesday night's game, won by the Rangers, 6-4, at Madison Square Garden. Hospodar, a defenseman whose play has been improving, is expected to miss six weeks.

title: Key Rates
description: * Rates are before any surchages on loans to large banks that are frequent borrowers.+ Maximum rate payable by savings institutions.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Suit on Brain Damage Caused By Jail Fall Ends for $200,000
description: A man who suffered permanent brain damage after falling from a top bunk in the Orange County jail has won $200,000 in an out-of-court settlement.

title: PENTAGON TO USE A MINUTEMAN SITE FOR 40 MX MISSILES
description: The Reagan Administration has once again changed its plans for deploying the new MX missile, announcing today that at least 40 of them would be placed in existing silos on one of six Minuteman missile fields in the northern high plains.

title: THE ADVANTAGES OF SALVAGING HOLIDAY GREENERY
description: FORLORN summer window boxes or bare spots in the garden are quickly turned green again by recycled branches from your Christmas tree. Rather than tossing it out unceremoniously after the holidays, consider the many new uses for its boughs.

title: Output of Steel Off 4% in China
description: China's steel output fell 4 percent in 1981 but was still 8.2 percent over the state target, despite strict curbs on production, according to official figures released today by the New China News Agency.

title: 2 Guatemala Policemen Slain
description: Two traffic policemen were killed today by men in a car who opened fire on them with submachine guns, police sources said. They said the gunmen took the policemen's weapons and sped away.

title: Suffolk Downs Records First Triple Dead Heat
description: The 1981 racing season ended at Suffolk Downs today with the first triple dead heat in the track's 47-year history.

title: Warner Wants to Make Bowl His Fiesta
description: It was puzzling to tell how Curt Warner, the junior tailback from Penn State, was feeling. The twitch in his muscular shoulders could have come from the weight-lifting that he had completed after practice. Or he might have been nervous about revealing a private thought.

title: HANAUER & CO. NAMES PRESIDENT AND CHAIRMAN
description: John T. Feeney, 37, has been elected president of J.B. Hanauer & Company, a leading municipal bond firm. He succeeds Melvin A. Glucksman, 44, who moved into the vacant post of chairman of the firm, which is based in Livingston, N.J.

title: ALLEN'S 'ANSWER' TO THE CORRUPTERS
description: To the Editor:

title: TV Networks Shift Prime-Time Shows
description: TV, second to CBS-TV in the prime-time audience popularity ratings, is changing its schedule. ''Open All Night'' and ''Making a Living'' will be broadcast for the last time Jan. 9.

title: Mugabe Will Step Up Land Redistribution
description: Prime Minister Robert Mugabe promised today to step up the redistribution of white-owned farmland among the country's rural blacks.

title: An Off-Duty Detective Shot on Brooklyn Street
description: An off-duty New York City police detective who apparently stopped his car to aid a woman in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn early yesterday morning was s et upon by two men who shot him twice inthe back with his own gun.

title: Sabres 4, North Stars 2
description: BUFFALO (AP) - Gil Perreault and his linemates, Dale McCourt and Mike Foligno, scored a goal each for Buffalo.

title: BANKER'S NOTE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
No Headline
description: The so-called umbrella theory, under which the Soviet Union would come to the aid of East-bloc countries with debt problems, has lost much of its validity, Hans Friderichs, a spokesman for the management board of the Dresdner Bank, said in an article released today.

title: NO FULL BUS SERVICE YET FOR WHEELCHAIR USERS
description: To the Editor:

title: OFFICIAL SAYS POLAND WILL PAY ITS DEBTS
description: Deputy Prime Minister Mieczyslaw Rakowski of Poland said today that his country fully intends to pay its debts to Western commercial banks, including some $500 million in interest arrears that the Poles had promised to pay this week, a West German official reported.

title: Edmondson Eliminates McNamara in Australia
description: Mark Edmondson moved into the semifinals of the Australian Open with a straight-set victory over Peter McNamara of Australia today.

title: POP: GANG OF FOUR AND BUSH TETRAS
description: For connoisseurs of post-punk grimness with a danceable beat, the teaming of England's Gang of Four with New York's Bush Tetras at Roseland on Tuesday made for a tantalizing bill.

title: No Headline
description: The average seven-day yield for major money funds slipped to 11.84 percent from 11.97 percent during the latest week, according to Donoghue's Money Fund Report, a private organization that reported Wednesday that there was a $1.3 billion decline in the funds for the latest week.

title: Asia-Pacific Region Gets News Agency
description: The Asia-Pacific News Network, formed by the 23-member Organization of Asia-Pacific News Agencies, began operating officially today.

title: REDLAW INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Yr to Sept 30
description: All figures are in Canadian dollars; the company is also listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange

title: Broyles Likes Idea Of Preseason Bowl
description: A plan for a preseason major-college football game at Giants Stadium between two of the top-ranked teams received enthusiastic support today from Frank Broyles, a member of the N.C.A.A. committee that must approve the plan.

title: Mortgage P ayment Lag
description: Mortgage loan delinquencies at the nation's savings and loan associations increased slightly in November but remained well below levels in the mid-1970's recession, an industry association said today.

title: SECOND TIME AROUND FOR A BROWNSTONE
description: BUYING and renovating dilapidated brownstones on one of the treelined blocks off Central Park West was so popular in the late 1960's and early 70's that it came to typify a particular West Side style in housing - one that combined sensitive restoration with inventive use of small space.

title: Geography
description: Ghana is a country of 92,100 square miles on the west coast of Africa. It is bordered by the Ivory Coast, Upper Volta and Togo.

title: Reece Better; May Not Start
description: When the Giants play the 49ers at San Francisco in a National Conference semifinal Sunday, Beasley Reece's role will likely be that of sideline spectator.

title: FIREPLACE ACCESSORIES
description: AFIRE in the fireplace adds warmth and sparkle to a room in winter. We have found items to help keep the fireplace in working order.

title: McLouth to Keep Utility Services
description: The McLouth Steel Corporation, which filed for protection from its creditors under Federal bankruptcy laws on Dec. 8, was told by a Federal judge that it can keep its electric and gas service even though it owes almost $17 million to two utilities.

title: POLES REACTING TO ARMY WITH MIXED FEELINGS. . .
description: The other day a Polish housewife looked out her window and saw three soldiers manning a roadblock, swinging their arms and stamping on the packed snow to try to get warm. She promptly made a pot of coffee and took it to them.

title: Dell Books Gets Editor
description: Susan Moldow, executive editor of Avon Books, has been named editor in chief of Dell Books, effective Jan. 25. Dell Books is the paperback arm of the Dell Publishing Company, a subsidiary of Doubleday. Miss Moldow, who had been at Pocket Books, the Literary Guild and Doubleday before joining Avon in 1976, will fill the position formerly held by Linda Grey, who is now editorial director of Bantam Books.

title: REAGAN BID TO UNSEAT DEMOCRAT STIRS DISPUTE
description: The Reagan Administration's efforts to replace a Democratic member of the Federal Parole Commission before his term expires is touching off a fight with Congress over politicalpatronage.

title: Hofer Has Knee Surgery
description: Paul Hofer, the 49er running back, has undergone minor surgery on his injured right knee, and doctors found damage that led to speculation that his pro football career may be over.

title: HOLLYMATIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including $46,000 tax credit...C-Including $24,000 tax credit

title: ADOLPH TOIGO, EX-CHAIRMAN OF ADVERTISING AGENCY, DIES
description: Adolph J. Toigo, former chairman of Lennen & Newell, once one of the country's largest advertising agencies, died Wednesday in Cedar Manor Nursing Home in Ossining, N.Y. He was 76 years old.

title: AN ODE TO '82
description: It's New Year's Day, day number one, The day to dream of what's to come, To grasp the crystal ball and view Events to pass in '82. What will happen to the city? What will happen to the state? What will happen to New Jersey? What's the tristate region's fate? New York City has a Mayor Name of Edward Irving Koch. Some say he's the city savior, Others say he talks too much. New York City has a Council, How it fell into a trap! Redrew its lines, but in the process Drew itself right off the map. Is there still a City Council? Are the new lines intact and well? We must ask Justice Department. Only it's empowered to tell. Meanwhile, we'll have public hearings. Let the Council chamber ring! As the people voice their feelings About gerrymandering. Also in the City Council Were some Councilmen at Large. Court says they are now illegal. What will happen to their charge? Oh, that poor old City Council, What a mess it now is in. Bet it wishes it had never Started on redistrictin'.

title: SUICIDE THREAT PROMPTS HELP
description: State officials said today that they had found a 36-year-old unemployed father who wrote a letter to a newspaper threatening to k ill himself on Ne w Year's Eve so his family would qualify for welfare.

title: LIFE IN TAMPA: YEAR'S END OFFERS REMINDERS OF HOW AREA HAS CHANGED
description: People in New England, and even in northern Alabama, where the earth sometimes crunches underfoot at this time of year, harbor a certain snobbery about the Christmas season in Florida, as if a warm sense of communion and rejoicing could not exist so far south of cold and snow, as if jingle bells signaled only the arrival of the ice cream wagon on the beach.

title: RED BRIGADES GIVE DOZIER PHOTO TO U.S. PAPER
description: The kidnappers of Brig. Gen. James L. Dozier issued a photograph of their prisoner and two stenciled documents to an American news organization here today.

title: THE SEASON OF THE ARTFUL SPLURGE: CONFESSIONS FROM 7 BIG SPENDERS
description: CONTRARY to conventional wisdom, the Season of Self-Indulgence is not over; it is merely taking a rest. True, when the first tangible reminders of December's lavish giving and profligate good-willtoward-men begin to trickle in this month, shouts of, ''Charge it!'' may temporarily fade to whimpers of, ''I'll never spend again.''

title: THE YOUNG ARE REMEMBERED IN DONATIONS FOR THE NEEDIEST
description: Since few images rouse the impulse for giving like the thought of a forlorn child at the holiday season, many contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund ask that their gifts be used in ways that will benefit the poor children of the city.

title: COURTS AND PRISONS: AN EXPANDING ROLE SETS OFF CONTROVERSY
description: The courts, which have always been responsible for deciding who should go to prisons, are making more and more decisions about how prisons should be run as well.

title: PUT AN MX MISSILE WHERE YOUR SENATOR IS
description: -Fear runs rampant in Congress that we are behind the Russians in nuclear strength and the ability to deliver nuclear strikes. Moreover, the race to build weapons--any weapons, at any cost--lacks a sense of responsibility on the part of those voti ng forthe weapons.

title: Clampett's Record 63 Gains Lead By Stroke
description: Bobby Clampett set one of two course records today with an eight-under-par 63 and took the lead after the second round of the $150,000 Spalding Invitational pro-am golf tournament.

title: NAVY BUYS USED SHIPS FOR 'SEALIFT'
description: The Navy will convert three container ships now berthed in the New York area into support vessels for the Rapid Deployment Force in the Middle East, military officials have announced.

title: Second Time Around
description: The Cleveland Browns, who need defensive help, want to talk with Tom Cousineau of the Montreal Alouettes. And the Green Bay Packers are looking for some way to capitalize on their investment in Bruce Clark of the Toronto Argonauts. Cousineau, a former Ohio State linebacker, was drafted by the Buffalo Bills in 1979 but joined the Canadian Football League because of the bigger contract offered by the Alouettes. The Bills retain negotiation rights to Cousineau, and now Art Modell, owner of the Browns, is waiting for the end of Buffalo's season ''to see what would be involved in getting the right to negotiate with him.'' Cousineau said that he would like to return to his native Cleveland but that he wanted to be free to ''consider other possibilities that might be open to me now.'' In Green Bay, the Packers' coach, Bart Starr, said his club had ''a great deal invested'' in Clark, a former Penn State defensive lineman who was drafted in 1980. Clark rejected a Packer offer in 1980 and went to Canada. The Packers hold exclusive rights to him until the collegiate draft is held next April, and they could sign him or trade him.

title: Money Funds Off $2 Billion
description: Assets of the nation's money market funds declined $2 billion in the week ended Wednesday, the second consecutive weekly decline, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday. The funds' assets now stand at $182.5 billion after an average weekly increase this year of $2.3 billion.

title: XOIL ENERGY RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Yr to Aug 31
3 Poles Defect in Canada
description: The first mate of a Polish freighter, his wife and child applied for political asylum in Canada today in this port on the St. Lawrence River. Pawel Urbanska, 3O years old, his wife, Lydia, also 3O, and 3-year-old Mickal ''will probably be granted asylum,'' an immigration official said.

title: Meat Output in U.S. May Slip
description: Meat production in the United States will decline slightly in 1982, contributing to moderate price increases for consumers, a leading trade group forecast today.

title: SUBWAY CRIME IN CITY ROSE AT YEAR'S END
description: Reported subway crime increased sharply in November and December over the same months a year ago, a rise attributed by the transit police in part to roving groups of youths who slide in and out of court.

title: JARUZELSKI IS SAID TO BAN ANTI-SEMITIC BROADCASTS
description: Anti-Semitic material, much of it thinly disguised, has occasionally been broadcast in Poland since martial law was imposed Dec. 13.

title: COVERING A BIG NUCLEAR BET
description: Should Nine Mile Point - Unit Two, the big nuclear power plant under construction near Oswego, N.Y., be completed? The private u tilities say we will need the electric gener ation capacity. Conservation-minded environmentalists say the re are cheaper alternatives.

title: DOCTOR'S AIDE FOUND BEATEN AT MONTEFIORE HOSPITAL OFFICE
description: A physician's assistant was found severely beaten in an administrative office at Montefiore Hospital and Medical Center in the Bronx last night, the police said. She was reported to be undergoing surgery for severe head injuries late last night, a spokesman for the hospital said.

title: IF YOUTH PROGRAMS LOSE 'TALENT SEARCH'
description: To the Editor:

title: GRETZKY FEAT DAZZLES FOES, PARENTS
description: Bobby Clar ke of the Philadelphia Flyers slumped on a bench in the dressing roo m Wednesday night, trying to find the words to describe the late st scoring feat of 20-year-old Wayne Gretzky of the Edmonton Oil ers.

title: 41 Tanker Scrappings
description: The continuing worldwide oil glut means that more than 41 very large crude carriers, the largest category of oil tanker, are likely to be scrapped during 1982, the International Association of Independent Tanker Owners said here today. In 1981, 41 such tankers, an average of 11 years old each, were scrapped, the organiz ation said.

title: STSC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
LAW ON SMOKE DETECTOR FOR APARTMENTS IN EFFECT
description: The new city law requiring smoke detectors in individual apartments takes effect today. The city's Acting Health Commissioner, Dr. Margaret T. Grossi, said this week that the kind of detector used mattered less than ''any delay in installation.'' Delay, she said, ''is the real safety hazard.''

title: REAGAN CHOOSES LAWYER AS CHIEF OF LEGAL AI D AGENCY FOR THE POOR
description: A Washington lawyer who reportedly recommended abolishing the Legal Services Corporation last year was named by President Reagan today to head the agency, which provides legal aid to the poor.

title: TUNISIA STRUGGL ES TO DEVELOP FISHING
description: Increased poaching by Italian fishing boats, the authorities here complain, is undermining Tunisia's efforts to develop its fishing industry.

title: Cleveland Fed Selection
description: J. L. Jackson, an executive of the DiamondShamrock Corp oration of Lexington, Ky., has been reappointed chairmanof the Federa l Reserve Bank of Cleveland, the bank announced today. Mr. Jackson, 49 years old, executive vice president of the Dallasbased c onglomerate and president of its coal subsidiary in Kentucky, was reappointed to a one-year term by the Federal Reserve System's boar d of governors in Washington, D.C. The board also named William H. Kn oell, president and chief executive of the Cyclops Corporation o f Pittsburgh, to another one-year term as deputy chairman of t he Cleveland bank.

title: Agency in Justice Dept.  To Shut Down April 15
description: The Law Enforcement Assistance Administration, a keystone of the Nixon Administration's efforts to combat crime, will close down April 15, the Justice Department said Wednesday.

title: French Philosopher Is Seized in Prague
description: Jacques Derrida, a French philosopher, was arrested Monday in Prague for alleged drug smuggling, official sources said today.

title: DOW UP 1.90, TO 875, FINISHING THE YEAR WITH 89-POINT LOSS
description: Stock prices drifted higher yesterday in lackluster trading, closing out a year in which the Dow Jones industrial average pierced the 1, 000 mark but finally finished lower und er the weight of high interest rates and the recession.

title: I.R.A. SUSPECT SENT TO IRELAND
description: Desmond Mackin, a suspected member of the outlawed Irish Republican Army who was deported from the United States, arrived in Ireland today and was allowed to enter the country unhindered.

title: Mail System Gains in Court
description: A Federal judge today rejected a Justice Department request to block the Postal Service from starting an electronic mail service on Monday, but the Government filed further court action to delay the new service.

title: STAGE: STRINDBERG AND O'NEILL ONE-ACTS
description: Mrs. X, the married actress in ''The Stronger,'' accuses her silent rival of ''staring my thoughts out of me,'' as the line reads in George Springer's translation of the Strindberg one-act play. That sentiment - silence as a catalyst for confession - echoes through ''The Stronger,'' and also through Eugene O'Neill's ''Hughie.'' The two are on a double bill at the South Street Theater, a compatible pairing of plays performed by an assured quartet of actors.

title: Mindszenty Group Seeks to Halt 'Reds'
description: The Cardinal Mindszenty Foundation has asked Paramount Pictures to withdraw ''Reds.'' The 22-year-old St. Louis foundation charges that the film ''falsely portrays the Communist system as benevolent and falsely portrays the Communist state as a workers' paradise.''

title: Hoagy Carmichael Rites Set Monday in Bloomington, Ind.
description: Hoagy Carmichael, Hollywood's archetypical saloon piano player whose real-life hits included ''Stardust'' and ''Georgia on My Mind,'' will be buried Monday in his hometown of Bloomington, Ind.

title: REQUIRED READING; It Is Hereby Resolved
description: Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, press release of budgetary New Year's resolutions for the Federal Government: Revenue Sharing: With a projected $150 to $175 billion Fiscal Year 1983 deficit, the Federal Government has no revenue to share. Yet this 'Put it on the Stump and Run' program to the cities continues.

title: REGAN BID FOR GOVERNOR MEETS INITIAL RESISTANCE
description: The effort by State Comptroller Edward V. Regan and George L. Clark Jr., the Republican state chairman, to nail down the Republican gubernatorial nomination for Mr. Regan quickly is meeting resistance among major Republican county chairmen, a check of Republican leaders showed yesterday.

title: STOCKS BUFFETED WORLDWIDE
description: The world's major stock markets, battered by high interest rates and recession, found it rough going last year. Although three foreign exchanges managed to shrug off any blows and finish higher, three others ended 1981 sharply lower while one remained stagnant.

title: TOP OFFICERS ARE SHIFTED AT VENTURE
description: Julian Seeherman, the 52-year-old vice chairman of Venture Stores Inc., has been appointed president of the discount-store chain, effective Feb. 1.

title: ALVINA KRAUSE, 88, PROFESSOR OF DRAMA TAUGHT MANY STARS
description: Alvina Krause, a professor of drama at Northwestern University for 33 years, whose students included such future stars as Patricia Neal, Charlton Heston and Jennifer Jones, died of heart failure yesterday in her home in Bloomburg, Penn. She was 88 years o ld.

title: MACE FOR THE PEOPLE
description: To the Editor:

title:
NEWS OF MUSIC;
THE PERIPATETIC LEONARD BERNSTEIN
description: Leonard Bernstein, whose travels as composer and conductor find him flying from New York to Paris, Vienna and Tel Aviv with the frequency of a diplomat, appears to be converting some of that peripatetic energy into teaching. He recently finished leading a two-week seminar in musical theater at New York University, and has just been appointed to head, with Daniel Lewis, a new summer institute for young orchestral musicians and conductors at the Hollywood Bowl, under the auspices of the Los Angeles Philharmonic.

title: Cowboys Cut Into Cotton Bowl Attention
description: The Dallas Cowboys and Thomas (Hollywood) Henderson have somewhat upstaged Friday's Cotton Bowl game between Alabama and Texas.

title: COLBY TO PAY C.I.A. $10,000, SETTLING DISPUTE
description: William E. Colby, former Director of Central Intelligence, has agreed to pay $10,000 to the Government to avoid being sued for breaking a secrecy agreement involving a book about the Central Intelligence Agency, the Justice Department announced today.

title: CLEARING THE RECORD
description: The worst mistake made in this space during 1981, to judge by protesting readers' mail, was not in my judgment a mistake at all. That's a new twist for the usual year-end ''pardon me'' column, and delays embarrassing confession for a few more paragraphs.
To the Editor:

title: GOVERNMENT SERVICES SAVINGS & LOAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Including $4.4 million net gain on the sale of property... C-Net loss

title: Faberge Sells Brut's Assets
description: Faberge Inc., a major producer of perfumes and hair-care products, announced the sale of nearly all the assets of its entertainment subsidiary, Brut Productions, to the Turner Broadcasting System Inc., parent company of the nationwide Cable News Network.

title: LEWIS ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MORE THAN 100,000 MAY LOSE FOOD AID IN THE CITY THIS YEAR
description: More than 100,000 children and adults in New York City are likely to lose Federal assistance this year from one or more of a complex of programs that have grown up alongside the food stamp program, according to local officials and groups concerned about nutrition.

title: Books of The Times
description: SOULS AND BODIES. By David Lodge. William Morrow. 244 pages. $12.50.

title: S.E.C. Censure Of Shearson
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today censured Shearson/American Express Inc. in connection with allegations that the investment firm failed to adequately supervise two salesmen in a Shearson office in California in the mid-1970s.

title: Mayor Koch in the Lions' Cage
description: On New Year's Day four years ago, many clever people looked at Edward Irving Koch the way one watches a rookie lion tamer stride into the cage. The city was in bad trouble; did he really know how bad? Every forecast showed gaps in the budget even wider than the potholes in the streets. So much office space was vacant that even newer buildings were going into foreclosure. Layoffs were not merely causing temporary unemployment; businesses were moving or closing down forever. The Mayor, ebullient, apparently indifferent to danger, charged into the cage , demonstrating a gift for off-the-cuff ripostes and an endearing ina bility to keep quiet simply because saying something wasrisky. He soo n became a living logo of the city. The tilt of the shiny head, t he shoulder shrug, the questions used to answer questions - a ll symbolized New York's reviving cockiness.

title: POLI RESIGNS POST WITH CONTROLLERS
description: Robert E. Poli quit today as president of the Professional Air Traffic Controllers Organization, saying he hoped his departure would soothe enmity over the union's illegal strike and prompt President Reagan to rehire 11,500 dismissed members.

title: VIDEOTAPE UNIFORMITY DISCUSSED
description: The five major manufacturers of videotape recorders have been discussing for several months the idea of setting uniform standards for their products, the Sony Corporation said today.

title: NOVEMBER FACTORY ORDERS UP
description: New orders placed with the nation's factories rose two-tenths of 1 percent in November, the first gain since July and an encouraging sign for the slumping economy, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: AULD LANG SYNE - 153 B.C., THAT IS
description: I set my clock back one hour in October because the Congress said I should. I'll set my clock forward in the spring whenever the Congress decides I should. I celebrate Thanksgiving on the fourth Thursday in November because the Congress resolved that I should. I observe Veterans Day instead of Armistice Day, and wish George Washington a happy birthday on a Monday because the Congress voted that I should.

title: Israelis Honor Sadat
description: The late Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt, the first Arab leader to recognize Israel, was voted ''Man of the Year'' for 1981 by Israelis in a public opinion poll published today. Mr. Sadat, who was assassinated last October, was picked by a majority of the respondents in a survey of 1,200 Israelis published by the newspaper Haaretz.

title: SECRETARIES IN CHARGE FOR HOLIDAYS
description: ''He's out in California,'' said the secretary in Alexander M. Haig Jr.'s office. ''He'll be out until M onday,'' said the secretary in Michael K. Deaver's offi ce. ''He's away on vacation,'' said the secretary in the office of Howard H. Bak er Jr. Mr. Baker, the Senate majority leader, was in Puerto Rico. Thomas P. O'Neill Jr ., the Speaker of the House, was in Boston. James A. Baker 3d, the White House chief of staff, was in Texas. And Donald T.Regan, the Tr easury Secretary, was in Florida.

title: France-Tunisia Link
description: Cables de Lyon S.A. and CIT-Alcatel S.A., both units of the Cie Generale d'Electricite Group of France, said today that they had been awarded a contract valued at 200 million francs, or about $34.8 million, to establish a direct telephone link between Tunisia and France. The link will be by undersea cable carrying 2,600 lines and should be in service by late 1983, they said.

title: REPORT FINDS HIGH U.S. AID FOR HEALTH CARE OF WEALTHY
description: The Government spends as much on health care for the rich as it does for the poor when tax breaks for insurance and medical payments are taken into account, a Feder al study said to day.

title: A CURE FOR SOCIAL SECURITY LIES BEYOND POLITICS
description: To the Editor:

title: The Textile Industry's New Clothes
description: Free governments in the industrialized world do not act free when it comes to the textile trade. More often than not, they do the bidding of domestic textile producers and unions that want protection from foreign competition. Consumers have paid the price: their clothes and materials cost more than they should; their economies perform less efficiently than they could.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Agfa-Gevaert Graphics Inc. said its cash tender offer for up to 1,100,000 common shares of Compugraphic Corp. at $14 a share has been extended until Jan. 29.

title: NEW YEAR'S DAY
description: Parking - Alternate-side regulations suspended. Sunday regulations in effect. Sanitation - No collections; no street cleaning.

title: 51 of 60 in Jury Pool C hosen in Atlanta Trial
description: The murder trial of Wayne B. Williams was adjourned for the New Year's weekend today after defense attorneys and prosecutors agreed on 51 of the 60 persons who will make up the jury pool.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: THE National Electric Code requires that in new homes all outdoor receptacles, bathroom receptacles and swimming pool equipment be protected by a special device called a ground fault circuit interrupter. It recommends that this protection be added to receptacles in laundries, kitchens and workshops - wherever tools or appliances might be used in a damp area.

title: ...AND MANY SEE A LONG STRUGGLE
description: Many Poles believe that resistance to the martial law Government will take the form of a long, drawn-out struggle involving industrial sabotage, intermittent strikes and some sort of underground organization.

title: SYRIA IS AN UNLIKELY KEY TO MIDEAST PEACE
description: To the Editor:

title: Body Is Found in Beirut
description: Rescue workers recovered another body today from the ruins of the Iraqi Embassy, demolished in a huge explosion on Dec. 15, security sources said. At least 36 people died in the blast and 13 are still missing.

title: BRIDGE: Sometimes a 'Magic Show' Fools Kibitzers and Rivals
description: In a technical way, bridge players occasionally put on a magic show. And although it does not attract a Broadway-sized audience, and sometimes indeed no audience at all, the magic effect can baffle the kibitzer and confound the opposition.

title: ARTS AGENCY AIDS FILM PRESERVATION
description: The National Endowment for the Arts has awarded $426,375 in challenge grants for film-preservation projects to eight nonprofit organizations, three of them in New York.

title: HOW DID WE GO WRONG?
description: THE economists who gathered in Washington this week for their annual meetings were even more depressed about the state of their profession than about the state of the economy.

title: MOBIL GOES TO APPEALS COURT IN ATTEMPT TO BLOCK U.S. STEEL
description: The Mobil Corporation returned to a Federal appea ls court today to ask for an emergency order that would block the Uni ted States Steel Corporation from buying control of the Marathon Oil Company next week.

title: CLEMSON SEEKS TO HOLD ON
description: Jeff Davis, Clemson's all-America linebacker, has heard all the talk he cares to hear. He has heard from rival players who say they refuse to believe that an Atlantic Coast Conference school can finish the season ranked No.1 in the wire-service polls, and from reporters who have never passed over the orange tiger paws that line the highways that lead into Clemson, S.C.

title: Ballesteros Leads by Shot
description: Severiano Ballesteros, the last man to finish, dropped a 10-foot birdie putt on the 18th hole today to break a four-way tie and take the first-round lead in the richest tournament in the history of golf.

title: TEAMMATES AT IOWA FROM WORLDS APART
description: Iowa's Rose Bowl game today in Pasadena, Calif., against Washingtonwill signal t he end of Brad Webb's season and, in all likelihood, hisfootball care er. It is Iowa's other defensive end, Webb's good friend Andre Tippett, an all-American from Newark, who seems a cinch for the pros.

title: Short in Stature, Long on Humor
description: Since minimum height restrictions for police officers have been eased in Florida, smaller men and women have been turning up on the job. One of the shortest is Ray Bedal who works for the Metro-Dade Police Department, which patrols the Miami suburbs. Mr. Bedal, who is 29 years old and just over 5 feet tall, is the shortest of the 1,735 officers on the Metro-Dade force.

title: Nippon Steel Gets Bethlehem License
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation, the nation's second-largest producer, said that it had licensed the Nippon Steel Corporation to produce and market a patented, aluminium-zinc alloy-coated sheet steel.

title: REAGAN PLAYS GOLF BEFORE BIG PARTY
description: President Reagan played golf today and then prepared to welcome the new year with 90 friends and senior members of his Administration at a private dinner and dancing party at the 200-acre estate of Walter and Leonore Annenberg here.

title: REQUIRED READING
description: A Woman Is ...

title: Uganda Said to Crack Down On Insurgents' Sympathizers
description: The Government of President Milton Obote appears to have launched a concerted crackdown on civil servants and others believed to be sympathetic to guerrillas, reliable sources said today.

title: Creditor Plan For Cooper-Jarrett
description: Cooper-Jarrett Inc., a trucking concern now operating under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act, said that Judge Vincent Commisa in Federal Bankruptcy Court had approved a debtor-in-possession creditor arrangement between the company and the Continental Illinois Bank and Trust Company of Chicago.

title: THE POLISH AIRWAVES: PRESIDENT ASKS WHETHER THE PEOPLE HAVE LOST FAITH
description: Following are excerpts from domestic Polish radio and television broadcasts as transcribed and translated from the Polish by the Foreign Broadcast Information Service, a United States Government agency:

title: FRIDAY, JANUARY 1, 1982; News Summary
description: International Many Poles believe that resistance to the martial law Government will take the form of a long struggle involving industrial sabotage, intermittent strikes and some sort of underground organization, according to reports reaching The New York Times from Poland. They said there were signs that such a struggle had begun. The authorities were reportedly formulating plans to head it off with reforms. (Page 1, Column 2.) An appeal to Polish soldiers and policemen not to oppress the people has been made by the senior Solidarity leader still at liberty, according to information arriving from Poland. In the handwritten plea, Zbigniew Bujak, the leader of the union's Warsaw branch, said that Solidarity, despite martial law, was still able to function because of acts of bravery and defiance by its members. (1:1.)

title: To Miss Bellamy From a Fellow Turtle Lover
description: A month ago, when Mayor Koch suddenly let loose with a barrage of public criticism of her, City Council President Carol Bellamy responded by giving the Mayor a copy of Dr. Seuss' ''Yertle the Turtle.'' In the book, Yertle, the king of the turtles, decides his kingdom is too small, so he makes the other turtles pile on top of each other to form a turtle throne, topped by Yertle himself.

title: MUSIC: FOUR MAKE BASSTET
description: Though the instruments at the Greenwich House Music School on Tuesday night were among the weightiest around, the new music they played was mostly airy and pleasurable. The Times Square Basstet, as the four bass players - Jaime Austria, Don Palma, Joseph Tamosaitis and Michael Willens - called themselves, didn't even permit terribly ''advanced'' works to become ballast.

title: FUND CUTS CITED
description: The New Jersey Department of Labor and Industry announced today that 468 employees were given layoff notices in their year-end paychecks this week. The layoffs take effect in 45 days.

title: Relations Are Resumed By Saudis and Libyans
description: Saudi Arabia and Libya announced today that they were resuming diplomatic relations after a 14-month break. A joint statement issued simultaneously in Riyadh and Tripoli emphasized the need to insure unity of Arab ranks to face ''the common enemy,'' which was taken as an allusion to Israel.

title: 'DALLAS' IS A LOSER IN JAPAN
description: Japan is one country where not even J.R. Ewing can throw his weight around. Television viewers here couldn't care less who shot him, and the ratings show they'd much rather watch teen-age singers and other variety-show performers. Shown on Thursday nights from 9 to 10 o'clock, ''Dallas'' began with 10 percent of the audience, and since then has regularly declined - hitting a low of just over 3 percent on Christmas Eve.

title: A Dash of Offstage Merriment in 'Nickleby'
description: He begins the play as a cad and ends it something of a hero, albeit a dead one. As ''Nicholas Nickleby'' gets under way, Lord Frederick Verisopht is a weak-willed young nobleman who develops a hankering for Nicholas Nickleby's sister Kate.

title: GEORGIA LOOKING TO ADVANCE
description: Georgia is a slight favorite to beat Pittsburgh at the Superdome Friday night in t he 48th Sugar Bowl game.This may be the first Sugar Bowl game in thre e years that fails to produce the season's No.1-ranked team.

title: No Headline
description: MICHIGAN TOPS U.C.L.A., 33-14

title: IN HAWAII, NEW SPARK IN DEBATE ON FIRECRACKERS
description: The Hawaiian custom of shooting off firecrackers to welcome the New Year is on trial this holiday season. The sale of firecrackers is a $4 million-a-year business in this c ity, and to allow or to prohibit virtually u nrestricted access to firecrackers is a controversy widely debated every year about this time.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Carter Hawley Hale Stores Inc., Los Angeles, has appointed Joseph Harlan as president and chief executive officer of its Broadway-Southwest unit.

title: WILL TRUE DIGITAL-SOUND RECORDS ARRIVE IN 1982?
description: Innovations in high-fidelity technology are first and properly the concern of audiophile experts - such as Hans Fantel of The New York Times. But just as hardware affects software, to borrow from computer lingo, the corporate and technical machinations (electrifications?) of the high-fidelity giants have ripple effects on the innocent consumer. And it is the consumer who is my concern here.

title: PRESIDENT SELECTED AT BUSHNELL OPTICAL
description: Harold O. Johnson, 47 years old, has been named president of Bushnell Optical, a manufacturer of binoculars, telescopes and other optical equipment based in Pasadena, Calif. He succeeds Myron G. Stolp, 66, who retired from the division of Bausch & Lomb Inc.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Company Briefs article in Business Day last Friday described a bank acquisition incorrectly. The Federal Reserve Board approved United Bank New York's aquisition of the Oneida National Bank and Trust Company of Central New York.

title: EX-OFFICER OUSTS GHANA'S GOVERNMENT AGAIN
description: Jerry J. Rawlings seized power in Ghana for a second time today, overthrowing the civilian Government that he had resigned in favor of two years ago.

title: Rain Predicted on Coast
description: The National Weather Service reported that light rain may be falling Sunday. That precipitation could turn Candlestick Park, home of the 49ers, into Candleswamp, as it has been referred to by visiting players during much of this season.

title: ERNEST M. WALKER JR.
description: Ernest M. Walker Jr, the publisher of Bon Appetit magazine, died Wednesday of a heart attack in his Manhattan apartment. He was 44 years old.

title: WALESA NEGOTIATING? U.S. DOES NOT KNOW
description: The United States has not been able to determine whether Lech Walesa has been negotiating with the Polish authorities.

title: Auto Sales Drive Set
description: The auto industry is planning a midwinter marketing campaign around new model introductions in hopes of cashing in on a major sales recovery forecast for 1982, a trade publication reported today.

title: NEXT: THE ST. PIERRE SYNDROME
description: -Those who say that our foreign policy is inconsistent and unpredictable have one thing solidly against them. That is our deep and reliable concern for adverse political developments in small countries, both nearby and around the world. The objects of our concern change radically with the passage of time. As surely as we grow weary of our occupation with one country, or as it comes to seem a bit unnecessary or foolish, or as it encounters the problem that your average American does not always know where the country is, then we can count on alarm shifting to another.

title: WHITE HOUSE EXPECTS ALLIED BACKING
description: The White House said yesterday that it was confident that the Eu ropean allies would eventually take steps to support President Re agan's sanctions against the Soviet Union for what he said was its ro le in the military crackdown in Poland.

title: SOLIDARITY AIDE BIDS TROOPS PUT CONSCIENCE FIRST
description: The following dispatch is based on information arriving from Poland.

title: Eagle Bid for Wien Delayed by C.A.B.
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board yesterday denied a request by the Eagle International Corporation for speedy approval of its plans to purchase Wien Air Alaska from Household International Inc. Instead, Eagle was told it must file a formal application for approval of the combination.

title: TO PROTECT OUR AGENTS
description: To the Editor:

title: PRICES PAID FOR FARM GOODS FALL
description: Prices paid to farmers for raw food products dropped 3.1 percent in December and for the fifth consecutive month averaged below levels a year earlier, the Agriculture Department reported today.

title: Around the Nation; 2 More Held in Slaying Of A rizona Ma il Carrier
description: Two of the three remaining suspects in the kidnapping and slaying of a mail carrier last weekend were apprehended tonight by Maricopa County sheriff's deputies.

title: PITT RALLY TOPS GEORGIA; MARINO'S PASS PROVIDES 24-20 VICTORY
description: Dan Marino stole the limelight from Herschel Walker and the victory from Georgia tonight when he threw a 33-yard touchdown pass to John Brown with 35 seconds left that gave Pittsburgh a 24-20 triumph over the Bulldogs in the 48th annual Sugar Bowl game.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Here it is not political oppression that threatens us, but the diminishing of human freedom in a larger, more elusive sense. Can we New Yorkers call ourselves free if we are not free from fear? Can we allow our people to barricade themselves behind police locks, afraid to walk the streets or travel the subways?'' - Carol Bellamy, President of the City Council.

title:
Patents;
Over 65,000 Inventions During '81
description: WASHINGTON THE more than 65,000 inventions patented in the year just ended were on mechanical, engineering and chemical products and processes. Unusual items among them were microorganisms; the Supreme Court had decided that forms of life were patentable.

title: Consumer Saturday; NEW TESTS FOR AUTO EMISSIONS
description: W ITH the beginning of the year, metropolitan area drivers face a new legal requirement before they can have a 1982 New York State Inspection sticker pasted to their windshields: If vehicles do not pass the state's automobile emissions test, they must be repaired and tested again.

title: Sports People; Saban Is Rejected
description: Lou Saban, the president of the Yankees, is seeking a coaching position in the Canadian Football League and was a rejected applicant for a job with the Toronto Argonauts, the Toronto Globe and Mail reported. Saban, who spent 30 years as a college and professional football coach before joining the Yankee front office last spring, lost out when the Argonauts named Bob O'Billivich as coach Wednesday, but Saban is also interested in the job Frank Kush left with the Hamilton Tiger-Cats.

title: CHINA ALTERS TAX ON IMPORTS
description: China, in a step aimed at encouraging imports of foreign products needed for its modernization campaign, today reduced customs duties on 149 categories of industrial equipment and raw materials.

title: SOCIAL SECURITY TAX RISES A NICKEL FOR EVERY $100
description: The Social Security payroll tax will take an extra nickel for every $100 earned by most Americans all through 1982.

title: GHANAIANS REPORT LOOTING BY TROOPS
description: The Accra radio reported tonight that armed so ldiers had rampaged through sections of Ghana's capital looting homes and shops in exuberance over the ouster of the civilian Gove rnment.

title: Haas Leads by 3 Shots In Pro-Am Tournament
description: Jay Haas shot a six-under-par 66 for 198 to day at the Del Monte Golf Course to take a three-stroke lead after 54 holes of the $150,000 Spalding invitational pro-am tournament.

title: Observer; ARMA VIRUMQUE CANO; Russell Baker
description: .6,0There was a woman on television the other night, an American woman of Polish ancestry, complaining because Americans of Polish extraction are not officially classified as a ''minority'' group.

title: WHAT GOOD ARE EXTRA TAXIS STUCK IN TRAFFIC?
description: T o the Editor: For some years now my fellow taxi-owner friends and I have been alternately laughing/crying at your somewhat less than informed editorials concerning this city's taxi industry.

title: Your Money; Withholding: Many Changes
description: FOURTEEN allowances of $1,000 each on a W-4 tax withholding form? From now on, it will be possible. Because of the new tax law, many people will be filling out newly revised W-4 forms and getting many more allowances.

title: Ski Jumping to Grahek
description: Jim Grahek, 24, of Ely, Minn., won the 17-meter New Year's Day Ski Jump event of the Eastern Ski Association with jumps of 83 and 81.5 meters and a judges' point total of 230.6. In second place was Zane Palmer, 20, of Steamboat Springs, Colo.

title: Gary Zebrun
description: Seventy-five Decembers ago, my Russian greatgrandfather, Alex, with one wooden leg, set foot on Canadian soil. He was an old man, happiest on his own black earth outside of Novgorod; but to escape poverty, he came to this continent with my grandparents Andrew and Sophia Zebrunoff. Forest people in Russia, they knew the cold.

title: Around the World; A Newspaper Strike Is Averted in Britain
description: Negotiators announced tonight that they had reached an agreement in a dispute over a new clocking device in delivery vans and averted a strike threatened against 13 of Britain's 16 national newspapers.

title:
Patents;
Invisible Sound Track Coats Movie Film
description: Two specialists in photography have patented a motion picture film coated with an invisible sound track that is activated by ultraviolet light. They hope their method of recording image and sound over the same area will become standard in the industry.

title: Shakespeare Theater Names Management
description: Richard Horner Associates has become executive director of the American Shakespeare Theater in Stratford, Conn. The theatricalmanagment company will replace Richard Bader, whose resignation became effective Thursday.

title: CONGRESS WIDENS ROLE IN ARMS SALES
description: President Reagan's impressive string of victories on Capitol Hill was capped last month by Congressional approval of his foreign aid bills, which contained several of his most urgent requests for greater flexibility in foreign affairs.

title: FRESHMAN LEADS HUSKIES PAST IOWA, 28-0
description: Before the Washington-Southern Cal game last Nov. 14, Jacque Robinson, a freshman, was put on the scrub team and assigned to play the role of Marcus Allen, the tailback who won the Heisman Trophy this season. He did such an impressive job that he won a promotion from the coaching staff and played a key role in upsetting the Trojans.

title: CONVICTS WHO DON'T BELONG BEHIND BARS
description: To the Editor:

title: LEGAL AID AGENCY LIMITS ITS SPENDING
description: The new majority appointed by President Reagan last week to the board of the Legal Services Corporation convened an unscheduled meeting Thursday to reduce the agency's spending for January, pending a regular meeting to consider policy for the rest of the year.

title: HOLIDAY SLOWS 2 IN HARTFORD VYING FOR COTTER'S SEAT
description: Getting voters interested in choosing a new Representative is so difficult at this time of year that the candidates in a special election here, dodging holiday shoppers and snowdrifts, are using unusual gimmicks.

title: De Gustibus; WHEN THE BILL DOES NOT FIT
description: In evaluating restaurants, the relationship of price to food and the total experience is among the more elusive criteria confronting anyone who attempts to make fair and consistent judgments. Just how a check presented at the end of a meal can alter one's opinion of food already eaten became very clear last week as I was having lunch with a friend in one of Paris's newer, highly touted nouvelle cuisine establishments, Guy Savoy, on the Rue Duret in the 16th Arrondissement.

title: MEETING DISCUSSES 'WOMEN'S WORLDS'
description: More than 400 female scholars and feminists representing 30 countries - most from the United States and Israel and some from India, Japan, Argentina and South Africa, among others - are attending what they describe as the first interdisciplinary congress on the theme of ''women's worlds'' here.

title: Marianne Gupta Is the Bride of Dr. Bry Benjamin
description: At the Park Avenue Methodist Church yesterday, Marianne V. Gupta, chief librarian at the American Telephone and Telegraph Company in New York, was married to Dr. Bry Benjamin, a New York internist. The Rev. Philip Clarke performed the ceremony.

title: POLISH OFFICIAL URGES REJECTION OF UNION'S PLEA
description: Poland's Interior Minister asked the country's security forces today to reject Solidarity's pleas for resistance to military rule.

title: Threat From Gas Fire Threat
description: A gas fire that burned out of control for about eight hours Thursday night was extinguished early today, allowing about 50 families to return home.

title: Around the World; Death Toll in Lebanon Said to Be 2,100 in 1981
description: More than 2,100 people died as a result of v iolence in Lebanon in 1981, about 700 more than in the previous year , security sources said today.

title: Around the Nation; Legal Problems Delay F amily's Island Rescue
description: A Canadian family shipwrecked on a remote South Pacific atoll must wait until Saturday for an airlift back to civilization so that legal problems with the island's owners can be settled, the rescue pilot said today.

title: Getting Practical About Crime
description: The figures are startling. Fully 46 percent of New York ers say crime is the city's most important problem, a concern that dwarfs allothers, inclu ding mass transit. And confidence in the police and in the courts ha s declined sharply, according to a poll conducted by TheTimes.

title: ON POLISH FLIGHT HOME, SOME NERVOUS LAUGHTER
description: The following dispatch is based on information reaching The New York Times from Poland.

title: Conceptions of Children
description: Almost everyone knows someone who wanted to conceive a child and could not. Literature is filled with sad stories of the sterile.

title: EXPLORING ALERNATIVES IN EAST HARLEM SCHOOLS
description: The Bridge School is in a 71-year-old building on 111th Street between Lexington and Park Avenues, one of the worst blocks in East Harlem. Across the street is an abandoned apartment house; a few doors down is a drug rehabilitation center, and around the corner is a halfway house. Junkies break into the school several nights a month and steal whatever is not locked up.

title: HEALTH FEARS GROW AS DEBATE CONTINUES ON TOXIC WASTES
description: Just up the hill from the isolated Hawkins Point community on this city's southwest side sits a small, fetid pond, sectioned off by a chain-link fence and surrounded by an expanse of barren, slag- like earth.

title: Alabama Viewers Miss Final Drive by Team
description: Six Southern states, including Alabama, were in the dark on the Crimson Tide's final possession in the Cotton Bowl today because of a telephone company technician's mistake, Jay Rosenstein of CBS-TV said. Viewers in Alabama, Florida, Arkansas, Mississippi, Georgia and South Carolina missed the drive in the final minute of a 14-12 loss to Texas.

title: CONSUMER REPORTS' HARD TEST
description: It gave thumbs down to STP oil additives. It blasted the nation's airlines for the way they treated pets. It took digs at Swanson frozen sausage patties, and it turned up its nose at hot dogs. It rattled the auto industry when it told consumers to steer clear of the Rambler Ambassador sedan.

title: PENN ST. TROUNCES U.S.C. BY 26-10
description: As Penn State was preparing to face the Heisman Trophy winner, Marcus Allen, and Southern Cal in the Fiesta Bowl, Curt Warner made a promise.

title: The Talk of Vail
description: The windows of the Sweet Basil restaurant are fogged, and the bar inside is packed with skiers, waiting out a midday flurry of new snow blowing across Vail Mountain. In a 24-hour period on the weekend, more than two feet of snow fell, and on Sunday there was so much on the mountain that lifts had to be shut down until ski patrols could blast away the threat of avalanche on the steeper slopes.

title: Elizabeth Coward Married in Jersey
description: The marriage of Elizabeth Lamborn Coward and Gregory Kent Miller, who are with the United States Geological Survey's Branch of Marine Geology at Woods Hole, Mass., took place yesterday at the home of Mr. and Mrs. John Mortimer Coward, parents of the bride, in Essex Fells, N.J. The Rev. David St. George performed the Episcopal ceremony.

title: TO ENHANCE A FIRE DEPARTMENT'S EFFECTIVENESS
description: To the Editor:

title: Chargers' Offense Threat to Dolphins
description: The Dolphins play the San Diego Chargers in an American Conference semifinal Saturday, and Miami's biggest task will be trying to contain Dan Fouts, San Diego's record-setting passer.

title: John Wang; While the boom in office-building construction in Manhattan may be cause for celebration among builders and developers, it suggests the need for a serious examination of current land-use and zoning policies.
description: This is not only because the office market's boom-and-bust cycle has an immediate impact on the whole city's economic health but also because too much office space will, in the long run, be detrimental to balanced growth of the city's economy.

title:
Patents;
Four New Patents On Space Equipment
description: Four patents on space equipment are being issued in the name of the late William B. McLean, inventor of the Sidewinder missile, widely used by the military. Patent 4,307,855, granted this week, entitled Target-Seeking Gyro, is assigned to Walter G. Finch, the Baltimore patent attorney handling the cases.

title: Index; International
description: In Shanghai, Oriental grace be- hind a Western facade 2 Around the World 3 Reagan sends message to kid- napped general's wife 3 The Polish airwaves: New rules on legislative work 4 Go vernment/Politics Social Security payroll taxes go up by five cents per $100 18 Rain shifts mayoral inauguration ceremonies indoors 20 Transcript of Mayor Koch's inau- gural speech 20 Holiday hinders two campaigning for House seat in Connecticut 21 Washington Talk Briefing 9 Congress widens role in arms sales 9 General Around the Nation 8 Cattle thefts increasing over the nation 8 In Vail, Colo., heavy snows bring good news 8 Parents upheld in suit over ''wrongful birth'' 8 Rain didn't damper spirits of New Year's revelers 19 Education/Welfare East Harlem school district ex- plores educational alternatives 19 Features/Notes Going Out Guide 14 About New York 21 Saturday News Quiz 22 Sports People 26 Notes on People 31 21 Arts/Entertainment Shakespeare Theater Names Management 10 Israeli Film Festival at two thea- ters 11 Elvis Costello at the Palladium 11 Miles Davis and quintet at Bea- con Theater 11 Starry New Year's Eve at Carne- gie with 19 musicians 11 Arthur Prysock sings with quintet at Marty's 13 Harold Blooms revisionist study of poetry, ''Agon'' is reviewed 36 Style Consumer Saturday: New tests for auto emissions 15 Bargains on children's winter sports equipment 15 De Gustibus: When the bill does not fit 15 Feminists and scholars of 30 na- tions meet in Israel 15 Obituaries Charles H. Dolan of elite World War I pilots' group 22 (20:6.) Sports Clemson clinches top rating with defeat of Nebraska 23 Pitt defeats Georgia, 24-20, in Sugar Bowl 23 Texas stuns A labama, 14-12, in Cotton Bowl 23 Warner outruns Allen in Penn State's Fiesta Bowl victory 23 Washington routs Iowa in Rose Bowl, 28-0 23 George Vecsey on the Giants' bad memories 25 Giants give Flowers a chance at free safety 25 Cowboys prepare for Bucs' sur- prise 25 Chargers' offense a threat to Dol- phins 25 Curran at Molloy: A success story 26 Pfister and Denton reach Austral- ian tennis semifinal 26 News Analysis John F. Burns on Soviet second thoughts about Poland 5 Editorials/Letters/Op-Ed Editorials 16

title: Technical Aids Project Set Up by Dance Group
description: The American Dance Festival has established a Technical Assistance Project to pr ovide technical services previously offered by the TAG Foundation. Headed by Mark Litvin, former director of T AG's program, and MaxineGlorsky, former TAG director, as adviser, the new program will offer a year-round job-referral service providing d ance, theater and opera companies with stage managers, designers and backstage personnel.

title: Rabbi Edward Schoenfeld, 79; Ex-leader of Actor's Temple
description: Rabbi Edward Schoenfeld, spiritual leader of the Actor's Temple on West 47th Street from 1967 to 1974, died Thursday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center.

title: CONTRIBUTIONS FROM GROUPS HELP NEEDIEST
description: Among major contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund year after year are community groups and professional, business and corporate establishments that, together with their staffs, recognize a responsibility to the community of which they are a part.

title: POPE MAKES PLEA FOR POLISH UNION
description: Pope John Paul II, in his strongest and most explicit call for the survival of Solidarity, said today that the union had become an integral part of the ''heritage of the workers of Poland and of other nations.''

title: JUDGE FINDS BLACK CONCERN VIOLATED LAWS ON SEX BIAS
description: A Federal district judge has ruled that the Johnson Products Company, a leading manufacturer of hair-care products for black women that is one of the nation's largest blackowned businesses, has violated Federal laws prohibiting discrimination against women.

title: TRANSCRIPT OF ADDRESS DELIVERED BY MAYOR KOCH AT INAUGURATION CEREMONY
description: Following is a transcript of Mayor Koch's inaugural address yesterday as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of WNYC radio:

title: THE POLANDS CLOSER TO HOME
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Memories to Block
description: THE young Giants, the Scott Brunners and the Lawrence Taylors, will never know what the last few weeks have meant to the older Giants. For the young Giants, reaching the playoffs was a textbook football success: come out of college, follow orders, work hard, wait for it to pay off. For some older Giants, wearing a red, white and blue uniform in a playoff game was an honor many of them had despaired of gaining.

title: Notes on People; Deanship for Schmertz
description: He had wanted, at one time, to become a diplomat, and he might have become an infielder with the Pittsburgh Pirates. But Eric J. Schmertz leaned instead toward the fields of labor relations and law.

title: Business Digest; SATURDAY, JANUARY 2, 1982; The Economy
description: Major airlines are planning to increase fares for coach and firstclass seats on many of their routes by as much as $10. Florida and California routes, the focus of rate wars, would be excluded from the increases. Even Delta, which has blocked several price rises during 1981, will join in the new round. (Page 1.)

title: SATURDAY, JANUARY 2, 1982
description: International The departure of Richard V. Allen, President Reagan's national security adviser, is planned, according to White House officials. They said his successor would be William P. Clark, now Deputy Secretary of State, and that the functions of the post would be upgraded. Mr. Allen has been on leave of absence pending the completion of a White House investigation of his activities. (Page 1, Column 1.) A warning against Solidarity's pleas for resistance to military rule was issued by Poland's Interior Minister, Czeslaw Kiszczak. In a New Year's message on the Warsaw radio, he cautioned the country's security forces not to be swayed by a ''campaign of calumny by internal enemies and their foreign sponsors.'' (1:2.)

title: Julia Vitullo-Martin
description: Despite som e triumphs, one ongoing defeat particularly rankles the Reagan Admini stration's economists: the loud vote of no-confidence that comes re curringly from the bond markets.

title: POP: ELVIS COSTELLO'S CELEBRATION
description: Elvis Costello proved to be a surprisingly affable host for New Year's Eve festivities at the Palladium. Before his concert, one wondered how an artist whose songs tend to be as personal, and as frequently bitter and scathing, as Mr. Costello's would deal with the nostalgia and sentiment that tend to adhere to the occasion, and his solution was rather ingenious.

title: DEATH OF 'ANGEL' WILL BE STUDIED BY A PROSECUTOR
description: The Newark police today turned over to the Essex County Prosecutor the direction of the investigation into the fatal shooting of a member of the Guardian Angels by a police officer on Wednesday night.

title: Around the World; Israelis Search Village In the Golan Heights
description: Israel's Chief of Staff said today that the largest Druse village in the Golan Heights was placed under curfew Thursday while Israeli troops searched the homes of pro-Syrian residents.

title: DOCTOR SAYS PAIN DRUG CAUSED JUSTICE REHNQUIST TO SLUR HIS SPEECH
description: Associate Justice William H. Rehnquist of the Supreme Court has been receiving treatment at George Washington University Hospital for side effects, including slurred speech, caused by drugs used to relieve severe back pain, Dr. Dennis S. O'Leary, the hospital's dean of clinical affa irs, said today.

title: THE POLANDS CLOSER TO HOME
description: To the Editor:

title: POLISH AIRWAVES: NEW RULES WILL 'SIMPLIFY' LEGISLATIVE WORK
description: Following are excerpts from domestic Polish radio and television broadcasts and, where noted, from Soviet broadcasts concerning Poland, as transcribed and translated from Polish and Russian by the Foreign Broadcast Information Service, a United States Government agency:

title: Going Out Guide
description: MILESTONES

title: RAIN DRIVES THE CEREMONIES INDOORS
description: ''All right,'' Linda Frankel Cahill said ominously as Mayor Koch arrived in his City Hall office yesterday. ''Here's the weather forecast.''

title: JAZZ: MILES DAVIS QUINTET
description: Miles Davis's comeback to the New York concert stage last summer after a five-year absence aroused a number of complaints, not the least of which had to do with the shortness of his sets and the paucity of his solos. But at the Beacon Theater, where he fronted his latest quintet Thursday, the great trumpeter performed two generous and engrossing 45-minute sets in which he was a more than equal soloist with the other musicians.

title: AMERICAN GREETINGS BOLSTERED BY ITS 'STRAWBERRY SHORTCAKE'
description: Henry Lowenthal, senior vice president and chief financial officer at the American Greetings Corporation, is nonchalant about the fact that his company's stock has gone up 70 percent in the past four months.

title: NICARAGUA POOR GET SIDEWALKS, BUSES AND DIALECTIC
description: New revolutionary governments like to go around renaming everything, but it usually makes no difference. In Ciudad Sandino, it did.

title: Sports People; Nater Outlook Dim
description: One of the National Basketball Association's leading rebounders, Swen Nater, will probably miss the rest of the season with a knee injury. Nater, the San Diego Clippers' center, underwent surgery at the end of last season t hat removed calcium deposits in the knee.

title: Ballesteros Leads by 3
description: Lee Trevino took a quick glance at Severiano Ballesteros of Spain and recalled a warning about what might happen in the $1 million Sun City Golf Challenge.

title: WHAT GOOD ARE EXTRA TAXIS STUCK IN TRAFFIC?
description: To the Editor:

title: Court Lets Electronic Mail Start
description: The United States Court of Appeals here cleared the way today for the Postal Service to begin a new electronic mail system on Monday that is designed to benefit businesses with large mailing lists.

title: Susan Cantor Is Bride Of Dr. Paul Bachner
description: Susan Cantor of Greenwich, Conn., an occupational-therapy consultant, was married yesterday to Dr. Paul Bachner, chairman of the department of pathology and laboratory medicine at United Hospital in Port Chester, N.Y. Cantor Mark Lipson performed the ceremony at the Silvermine Tavern in Norwalk, Conn.

title: Diana Ingram Romig Wed
description: Diana Ingram Romig, daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. David W. Romig of Rochester, and John O. Mellin Jr., son of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. Mellin of New York, were married yes terday at the First Presbyterian Church in Man hattan. The ceremony was performed by the fathers of thecouple. Mr. R omig is co-pastor of the Downtown Presbyterian Church in Rochester and Dr. Mellin is co-pastor of First Presbyterian. The bride is a gr aphic artist for the Thompson Printing Company in Orleans, Mass ., where Mr. Mellin, a building contractor, is head of John Mellin A ssociates.

title: SHANGHAI: ORIENTAL GRACE BEHIND A WESTERN FACADE
description: Just past daybreak, when there is enough light for the first river junks to hoist sail and start tacking patiently up the muddy currents of the Huangpu, an impromptu pageant unfolds along the riverfront that foreign residents once named the Bund.

title: 6 KILLINGS IN CITY MAR FIRST HOURS OF THE NEW YEAR
description: Six persons were killed yesterday in separa te incidents in Manhattan, Brooklyn and the Bronx, the police said, and a 77-yearold woman who was assaulted Monday die d at St. Vincent's Hospital in Manhattan.

title: A.M.C. Increases Prices of Le Car
description: The American Motors Corporation has announced that that it will increase the base prices of its imported Renault Le Car models an average of 5.4 percent, or $303.

title: Notes on People; Reunion for Twins
description: It was just after Thanksgiving when, Rachel Shelton said, she had the strangest experience on the telephone. ''It was like nothing I could ever explain,'' the 54-year-old Mrs. Shelton said this week from her home in Hammond, Ind.

title: CABARET: PRYSOCK SINGS
description: Arthur Prysock has become a perennial holiday attraction at Marty's.
