For the third year in a row, the casual, deep-voiced singer is in for both Christmas week and New Year's week at the restaurantcabaret on Third Avenue at 73d Street with a program that remains unchanged in its general outline from year to year.

title: COWBOYS PREPARE FOR BUC'S SURPRISE
description: The Dallas Cowboys and the Tampa Bay Buccaneers meet Saturday for what is only their third - but certainly most critical - matchup.

title: Czechs Said to Release A French Philosopher
description: A French philosopher held by Czechoslovak authorities on suspicion of drug dealing was released Thursday night, and he left for Paris by train today, French diplomatic sources said in Prague.

title: Copter Forced Down, Stranding 4 in Rockies
description: Four persons were stranded on a snowbound mountainside after a television news helicopter made a forced landing today in a heavy storm while flying over the Rockies to cover a fatal airplane crash, the officials said.

title: Yonkers, New Haven Swear In Mayors, Too
description: New York City was not the only place in the metropolitan area to see its mayor take the oath of office yesterday. At Yonkers City Hall, Angelo J. Martinelli, a Republican and former Mayor, was inaugurated at noon and returned to the office he had lost to a Democrat, Gerald E. Loehr, two years earlier.

title: IRISH LIQUEURS SCARCE
description: A shortage of Irish cream liqueurs is likely in the near future because of severe winter weather in Ireland that has prevented cattle from feeding normally.

title: CATTLE THEFTS INCREASING OVER NATION
description: A count that fell 10 short of Mike McKee's steers and a set of fresh tire tracks across his pasture were all the signs he needed to suspect that rustlers had called at his far m in northwest Missouri. A search of his 1 20-acre pasture proved his suspicion.

title: PITT RALLY TOPS GEORGIA; TIGERS DEFEAT NEBRASKA FOR 12-0 RECORD
description: With a defense that set up three scores, a punt return unit that positioned another, and an o ffense that scored oftenenough to win, the Clemson Tigers, unranked a t the start of the season, guaranteed themselves a No.1 ranking when they held off a Nebraska rally for a 22-15 victory in the 48t h Orange Bowl game tonight.

title: Sports People; Comings and Goings
description: Robin Gabriel, a senior at the University o f New Mexico and the sonof Roman, will be one of the quarterbacks on the North squad for the Senior Bowl game Jan. 16. Gabriel will share duties with Jim McMahon of Brigham Young.

title: MOLLOY COACH STUDIES SUCCESS
description: If St. Ann's Academy had not decided to move from East 76th Street in Manhattan to the Briarwood section of Queens in 1957, it is possible that Jack Curran might have been able to complete one of the strongest recruiting achievements in high school basketball.

title: Saturday News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 36. 1. A special prosecutor was named this week. Who is he and who is being investigated? 2. Suspension of Aeroflot flights from the Soviet Union to the United States was one of the measures taken by President Reagan in response to repression in Poland. True or false?

title: STAGNATION IS FORECAST FOR STEEL
description: The steel industry is facing an uphill struggle in the new year. Some analysts believe that steel shipments, already faltering, may decline in 1982 and provoke new layoffs, a sampling of industry opinion shows.

title: JACK DANIEL'S WINS FAVORED SALES SPOT
description: The black-and-white photographs of those good ol' boys down in Lynchburg, Tenn., are easy on the eyes, and the advertising copy is restful, too.

title: CHARLES DOLAN, AVIATOR, DIES; LAST OF LAFAYETTE ESCADRILLE
description: Charles H. Dolan, the last surviving member of the Lafayette Escadrille of World War I, died Thursday in Honolulu. He was 86 years old.

title: U.S. BUDGET CUTS STRAIN CHURCH AID PROGRAMS
description: Dozens of church-sponsored social service programs are scrambling to maintain their activities because of cuts in the Federal support on which they have come to rely. The cuts have come as the number of people asking for help has increased dramatically.

title: Bridge McKenney Trophy Is Won By Mel Skolnik in Nevada
description: The race for the McKenney trophy, awarded annually to the player scoring the most master points in a calendar year, reached a remarkable climax in Reno on New Year's Eve.

title: PFISTER AND DENTON REACH SEMIFINALS IN AUSTRALIA
description: Two hard-serving Americans, Hank Pfister and Steve Denton, moved into the semifinals of the $400,000 Aust ralian Open tennis championships today.

title: Y's 'The Price' Delayed
description: The opening of the American Jewish Theater's production of ''The Price'' by Arthur Miller, at the 92d Street Y has been postponed from next Saturday to Jan 16. The drama stars Joseph Buloff and Joan Copeland and is directed by Dan Held. It is scheduled to run through Feb. 14, although the engagement may be extended a week.

title: Sports People; If Price Is Right
description: Pat Ewing, the 7-foot freshman center at Georgetown University, said yesterday that he would consider leaving college early to play professional basketball ''if the price is right.''

title: Books of The Times
description: The Anxiety of Poetry By ANATOLE BROYARD AGON: Towards a Theory of Revisionism. By Harold Bloom. 336 pages. Oxford University Press. $19.95.

title: Filipino Sportsman Missing; Parents Blame Marcos Family
description: A popular Filipino sportsman who reportedly divorced his wife, a former beauty queen, to marry the daughter of President Ferdinand E. Marcos was missing today. His parents blamed the Marcos family for the disappearance.

title: The Bomb in Nuclear Trade
description: To prevent the military use of internationally traded nuclear facilities, the United States has relied for a generation on safeguards provided at bargain prices by the International Atomic Energy Agency. Diplomats never thought it gentlemanly to look this gift horse in the mouth; it did its work with only 150 inspectors and a budget of $25 million. But the Nuclear Regulatory Commission has finally looked and found some teeth missing.

title: Around the World; South Korean Chief Ends Curfew Restrictions
description: President Chun Doo-hwan today ordered the lifting of curfew restrictions in force since the end of World War II.

title: Hagop Missak Merjian
description: I left New York City 20 years ago filled with the relief of escape. I was born there of orphaned immigrant parents who fled to its shores, victi ms of war and famine. New York answered a need. They found jobs, h omes, and built families, though for these agrarian people from e astern Turkey, New York would always be a prolonged incarceration .

title: Sports People; Top Female Jockey
description: Patti Cooksey, a regular rider on the thoroughbred circuit in Ohio and Kentucky, won more races and more money than any female jockey in 1981, according to Daily Racing Form statistics. Miss Cooksey, 23, finished the year with 197 victories and more than $850,000 in purses earned by her mounts.

title: FLOWERS OF GIANTS TO START AT FREE SAFETY
description: Larry Flowers is 23 years old, 6 feet 1 inch, 190 pounds and easy-going. He is a tough football player with good range and good reactions, and Sunday he will probably be in the Giants starting lineup against the 49ers - as the free safety.

title: BARGAINS IN CHILDREN'S SKATES AND SKIS
description: With the prices of ski lift tickets, transportation and accommodations and the fees for ice-skating lessons soaring, introducing a child to a winter sport can seem like a costly investment indeed.

title: About New York; AT DEBS' BALL, ELEGANCE AND SWOOPING CURTSIES
description: The long pink candles in the silver candelabra had burned low, leaving puddles of pink wax on the pink tablecloths. The pink lights twinkled on the pink draperies on the upper boxes, and the pink stage stood empty. Society was spread all over the room, or at least that segment of it that had anted up $120 for a ticket, and there was a pleasant air of surfeit, and of expectation.

title: Answers to Quiz
description: Questions appear on page 22. 1. Leon Silverman, a New York City lawyer, was appointed to investigate reports of corruption against Raymond J. Donovan, the United States Secretary of Labor.

title: TEXAS TOPPLES ALABAMA BY 14-12
description: Who says wishbone teams don't pass? Texas stunned Alabama with two fourth-quarter touchdown drives today and registered a 14-12 Cotton Bowl victory that eliminated the Crimson Tide from any chance at being ranked No. 1.

title: Sports People; Malavasi to Stay
description: The owner of the Los Angeles Rams, Georgia Frontiere, has announced that Ray Malavasi will return as coach for 1982 despite the team's 5-11 record, its worst in 16 years. ''I give my complete support to Ray Malavasi as head coach of the Los Angeles Rams,'' Mrs. Frontiere said. ''I also have complete confidence in his 1982 plans for the team, which we believe will bring back winning football to all Rams fans.''

title: Frederic Nelson, 88, an Editor Of The Saturday Evening Post
description: Frederic C. Nelson, senior editor of The Saturday Evening Post in charge of the magazine's editorial page from 1942 until his retirement in 1962, died Wednesday at his home in Truro, Mass.

title: Briefing
description: F ORMER Attorney General Griffin B. Bell is the first of the Georgians from the Carter Administration to complete his memoirs. His book, ''Taking Care of the Law,'' is to be published this summer by the William Morrow Company.

title: REAGAN REPLACING SECURITY ADVISER, OFFICIALS REPORT
description: President Reagan plans to appoint Deputy Secretary of State William P. Clark to replace Richard V. Allen as national security adviser and to upgrade the job, White House officials said today.

title: KOCH CHALLENGES U.S. TO STAND BY URBAN AMERICANS
description: Edward Irving Koch took the oath of office yesterday for his secondterm as Mayor of New York, then challenged th e Federal Government andthe state to stand by the city and the rest o f urban America.

title: Shepard's 'Angel City' To Open Wednesday
description: ''Angel City,'' Sam Shepard's surrealistic satire about Hollywood moguls who create entertainment for mass-mark et consumption, will open Wednesday at the Wonderhorse Theater, 83 East Fourth Street, after a preview performance Tuesday. It will run through Jan. 30.

title: 'WRONGFUL BIRTH' SUIT UPHELD
description: The Pennsylvania Supreme Court has ruled that a couple may sue doctors over the birth of a crippled child that allegedly occurred despite the husband's vasectomy and the wife's abortion.

title: Notes on People; A Happy Newborn Year for Erin
description: Despite what doctors said, her timing was impeccable. Erin Lynn Fish weighed into the world one minute into 1982 at Fairfax Hospital in Falls Church, Va., giving her father, Kevin Fish, also a New Year's Day baby, ''the best birthday present in the world.''

title: Clarence Hoiles Dead at 76; Freedom Newspapers Chief
description: Clarence Harrison Hoiles, chairman of the board of Freedom Newspapers Inc., died Thursday after a brief illness. He was 76 years old.

title: Delta Air Loan
description: Delta Air Lines has reported the completion of a $50 million loan agreement with the Prudential Insurance Company of America to help offset a cash-flow squeeze caused by the need to pay out $75 million for the delivery of three jets. Robert Oppenlander, the senior vice president of finance for Delta, said that the borrowings ''will be used to supplement internally generated funds to meet peaks in cash requirements.'' Under the agreement, announced Thursday, Delta can borrow up to $50 million on a revolving basis through December 1984, when the outstanding balance will be converted to a term loan due December 1989.

title:
Patents;
Fluid to Help Treat Kidney Failure
description: A patent for a fluid to be used in treating kidney failure was granted this week to two Connecticut physicians who have served on college faculties.

title: News Analysis
description: After three weeks of martial law in Poland, whatever satisfaction the Kremlin might have felt over the triumph of force must be balanced by anxieties over what will happen in Poland over the longer term and by an accounting of the cost to Soviet-American relations.

title: REAGAN AND HAIG EXPRESS CONCERN IN MESSAGES TO WIFE OF GEN. DOZIER
description: President Reagan sent a message to the wife of Brig. Gen. James L. Dozier today amid unconfirmed reports that a group of the kidnapped general's friends have offered a $2 million reward for information leading to his release. The message from Mr. Reagan and another fro m Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. were delivered by Ambas sador Maxwell M. Rabb, who said they ''expressed great concern and s ympathy and hope that inthis new year the hopes of Mrs. Dozier about her husband are realized.''

title: SMALL STEEL MILLS FEEL PINCH IN ITALY
description: The small, mostly family-owned steel mills that surround this northern Italian city have for years been an integral part of the industry and a force in the European steel market.

title: DAY IS DAMP, BUT SPIRITS ARE NOT AS CITY WELCOMES NEW YEAR
description: The night before, 150,000 people had packed the area, drinking and yelling, jumping up and down, dancing and carrying on, heedless of rain and chill as they waited to welcome the New Year with general commotion.

title: AIRLINES PLAN AN INCREASE IN FARES ON MANY ROUTES AROUND COUNTRY
description: Many of the nation's major airlines will raise their fares next Friday by as much as $10 a ticket on many routes. The increases will come against a backdrop of heavily advertised fare cuts on flights between Northeastern and Middle Western citie s and Florida and California,

title: CONCERT: 19 STARS AT CARNEGIE BENEFIT
description: It was a starry New Year's Eve at Carnegie Hall. Nineteen prominent musicians donated their services, a large audience their financial support, and the beneficiaries were the Musicians Foundation and the hall.

title: ISRAELI FILM FESTIVAL AT 2 NEW YORK THEATERS
description: An Israeli Film Festival, expected to become an annual event in New York, will be held from Jan. 13 to 19 at the Manhattan I Theater on East 59th Street and from Jan. 17 to 21 at the Continental Theater in Forest Hills, Queens.

title: Notes on People
description: The Rev. Lucius Tyrasinski, prior of the Pauline Fathers of the National Shrine of Our Lady of Czestochowa, began the New Year yesterday with a special mass for Poland that will be offered every day until the crisis is over. The shrine, which shares 210 acres in Doylestown, Pa., with the Pauline Fathers' monastery, is considered the most famous Polish place of worship in the United States.

title: Letter: On Giving at the Office Keeping Politics Out of Charity
description: To the Editor:

title: ON THINKING MEN IN CHINA
description: INTELLECTUALS AND THE STATE IN MODERN CHINA A Narrative H istory. By Jerome B. Grieder. 395 pp. New Y ork: The Free Pres s. $22.50. CHINA'S INTELLECTUALS Advise and Dissent. By Merle Goldman. 276 pp. Cambridge, Mass: Harvard University Press. $22.

title: PENNSYLVANIA'S LIQUOR STORE BATTLE INTENSIFIES
description: An 11th-hour decision by clerks at 730 state-owned liquor stores allowed Pennsylvanians to celebrate Christmas with rum-spiked eggnog and New Year's Eve with champagne, but a dispute over the method of operating the stores lingers.

title: ESKIMO ART
description: To the Editor:

title: CHAPIN CENTER SHUTTING DOWN
description: THE father figure in Bill Thompson's adaptation of ''Hansel and Gretel'' is a performer who lives for art but can't eke out a living. He represents man's spiritual nature, which needs to be nourished against materialistic odds.

title: Sound; FORECASTING THE FUTURE OF HOME ELECTRONICS
description: The coming of a new year invariably stirs prophecy, with everyone gazing into assorted crystal balls. The prevalent mood of seasonal clairvoyance tempts me to predict the shape of home electronics, not just for '82 but for all the 80's. Even such far-flung projections need not be exercises in pure fantasy, for the future - as usual - is already here. Technology now incipient already delineates what is to be.

title: KNOWN FOR PORTRAYALS OF VILLIANS
description: Victor Buono, the character actor whose portrayal of a momma's boy in ''Whatever Happened to Baby Jane?'' won an Oscar nomination in 1962, was found dead Friday morning at his home in Apple Valley, Calif. He was 43 years old.

title: OFFICIAL IN MARYLAND TIGHTENS STANDARDS ON DOCTORS'S RATES
description: In an attempt to stop the ''upward spiral'' of health insurance costs, the Maryland Insurance Commissioner has frozen the fees paid doctors in the state by the Blue Shield plan. The rates will be held at 1981 levels for six months.

title: THE PROFITS OF POSITIVE THINKING
description: KANSAS CITY M AYBE it's because sales people need a little S.T.P. when sales are harder to make. Perhaps the positive-thinking movement grows best in tough times the way Weight Watchers pros pers after a holiday gorge. Maybe Art Lin kletter, still trying to light a fire under audiences atage 69, is ri ght - people just miss hearing inspirational speakers the way they performed on the old Chautauqua circuit.

title: Abdul-Jabbar Back
description: Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, who has missed the Lakers' last six games because of a strained tendon in his right ankle, will return to action Sunday night against the Seattle SuperSonics, a spokesman for the Lakers said today. Bruce Jolesch, the Lakers' public relations director, said that Abdul-Jabbar definitely will play, but that Coach Pat Riley would wait until pre-game warmups to decide if Abdul-Jabbar, six times the National Basketball Association's most valuable player, would start or play as a reserve. The Lakers have won the six games they have played without Abdul-Jabbar, improving their record to 24-7.

title: REAL RISKS IN THE U.S.-TAIWANESE ARMS DEALS
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW ANGRY PLAYWRIGHTS ARE TAKING CENTER STAGE
description: Turned up to a high pitch and filtered through a true writer's sensibility, anger is once again proving to be a powerful force in the theater. Just how powerful is being demonstrated by the proliferation of angry plays of all shapes and sizes on New York stages this season -from the eight-and-a-half-hour ''Nicholas Nickleby'' on Broadway to Shirley Lauro's 25-minute ''Open Admissions'' Off Off Broadway.

title: Mailbox; FOOTBALL SCORING PROPOSALS
description: To the Sports Editor: One of the football rule changes suggested by Cliff Montgomery could promote a lot of resentment.

title: REMEMBRANCE OF THINGS PASTRAMI
description: AM I glad to be home. During the last eight and a half years, I've searched - like a female Moses in a Southern desert - for a prune Danish, a corned beef on rye, a fresh bialy, a potato knish.

title: QUEENS OWNERS TO BUY LEASED LAND- FINALLY
description: It has taken special legislation and 42 years of negotiations, but for 1,200 residents of Broad Channel, Queens, the day appears finally to be coming when they will be able to call their homes their own.

title: Personal Finance; THE FUNDS THAT DON'T PAY DIVIDENDS
description: G IVEN the lackluster performance of the stock market this past year, another kind of equity mutual fund would seem to be the last thing anybody needs. Yet several funds, some new and some older, have an interesting twist: They are structured to minimize taxes by reinvesting income and by never paying dividends.

title: Around the Nation; Five in Family Die In Shootings and Suicide
description: A man shot his two children, wife and mother-in-law to death today in a shopping mall parking lot, then killed himself with a pistol, the police said.

title: EXCERPTS FROM SCHMIDT INTERVIEW ON KEY ISSUES
description: Following are excerpts from an interview with Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany as transcribed by The New York Times:

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Rippling Rhythms Join Reagan and Conservationists
description: They haven't exactly seen eye to eye, but last week President Reagan and environmentalist groups seemed to be seized by the holiday spirit. Mr. Reagan signed amendments to the Clean Water Act of 1970 which will provide $10 billion over the next four years to help clean up the nation's polluted waters.

title: MEANS TESTS AND SOCIAL SECURITY DON'T MIX
description: To the Editor:

title: Article 155906 -- No Title
description: To the Business Editor: We were surprised by the advice, not to mention the near unanimity of advice, expressed in ''Professional Eyes on $1 Million'' (Dec. 13). The five money managers suggested an average investment in common stocks of 45 percent (the range was 40 percent to 55 percent), despite the fact that, among financial assets, equities offer the only real hope of beating inflation.

title: Kathy Langeloh to Be Wed
description: The engagement of Kathy Ann Langeloh to S. Clay Risk Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Risk of Chevy Chase, Md., has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. John E. Langeloh of Rye, N.Y., parents of the future bride.

title: HOW PERGOLESI LOST TITLE TO SIX CONCERTOS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Allan Kozinn writes frequently about music and musicians. By ALLAN KOZINN

title: OWNERS VALUE HOUSES MODESTLY
description: HOMEOWNERS in Westchester County say their houses are worth a lot, compared with what people in most of the country say their houses are worth.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Helium Scare
description: Scientists said that in 30 years, 85 percent of America's helium reserves would be wiped out - and just when the gas would be critically needed as a refrigerant for a new energy technology called superconductivity.

title: IF INEQUALITY IS INEVITABLE, WHAT CAN BE DONE ABOUT IT?
description: ''E QUALITY'' has been an historic American ideal, but the means of its achievement are a matter of perennial debate. The Reagan Administration's attempts to reduce sharply various ''Great Society'' social programs and the role of the Federal Government, have provoked renewed debate on social justice and how to attain it. The Week in Review has asked Anthony Lewis, a New York Times columnist, to talk about the subject with three distinguished scholars -sociologist Daniel Bell and philosopher Robert Nozick of Harvard University and James Tobin of Yale University who received the 1981 Nobel Prize in Economics. Excerpts from their discussion follow.

title: Customs Service Tells of Rise In Its Activities for Last Year
description: The Customs Service collected a record $9 billion in duties and taxes in 1981, seized more than $4 billion worth of illegal drugs and checked international traffic that has now passed a rate of 323 million travelers a year, the agency has reported.

title: Brown Coach Favors Bengals
description: The Buffalo Bills will have more problems to solve than the Bengals in today's American Conference semifinal at Cincinnati, in the opinion of Coach Sam Rutigliano of Cleveland.

title: Bid to Revive Name Of Eisenhower Road
description: A State Senator is urging Maryland to erect signs proclaiming Interstate 270 by its rightful name: the ''Dwight D. Eisenhower Highway.''

title: Other Business; TIGER IN THE WHI TE HOUSE
description: Certainly, it wasn't Izod's famous alligator, and although the resemblance was there, it wasn't J.C. Penney's fox, either - a fact that Penney executives discerned after examining the fuzzy image with a magnifying glass.

title: No Headline
description: Paul Hofmann implies that Italians are not ''serious,'' that they survive in much the same way as the 1930's Dead-End Kids.

title: T he Nation in Summary; Robert Poli, Over and Out
description: Some would say that he hadn't much of a job to give up, since his employer has not only been decertified but is also bankrupt. Robert E. Poli nevertheless resigned last week as president of the Professional Air Traffic Controllers Organization.

title: THE FRENCHMAN IN NEW ORLEANS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- John Gruen writes frequently on music and dance, his most recent book being ''The World's Great Ballets,'' published by Harry N. Abrams, Inc. By JOHN GRUEN

title: PANEL TO QUERY WATT ON FUNDS
description: A House subcommittee will investigate Interior Secretary James G. Watt's use of privately donated funds to finance two unofficial holiday parties at the Lee mansion in Arlington, Va., the panel's chairman said Friday.

title: Beth Katzman Is a Bride
description: The marriage of Beth Katzman, an accountant at Dun & Bradstreet, to Brett Kreitman, a senior at the Fairleigh Dickinson Dental School, took place yesterday at the Tamcrest Country Club in Alpine, N.J. Rabbi Leonard Krantz performed the ceremony. The bride is a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Merle Katzman of Tenafly, N.J . Her father is an orthopedic surgeon. Mr. Kreitman is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Kreitman of Paramus, N.J. His father is a cli nical psychologist.

title: NEW STUDY OF ANCHOR STONES REBUTS CHINA ORIGIN THEORY
description: A California historian has challenged a theory that stone anchors found off the coast of California were dropped by ships carrying explorers from China years before Columbus discovered America. Instead, the historian says, the stones were lost by Chinese fishermen living in California less than 100 years ago.

title: Headliners; Bundle of History
description: ''In the future, I think she will be just one of a crowd,'' said Judith Car r o f Westminster, Mass., speaking of her newborn daughter. At the moment , however, the child born to Judith and Roger Carr last week at Norfo lk General Hospital in Virginia, is one of a select few - conceived i n laboratory dishes and carried by women who would otherwise be unable to conceive. Elizabeth, the infant, is America's first, but fi ve other women who underwent ''test tube'' fertilization at Norfolk are pregnant.

title: MATTHEW ARNOLD ENTERTAINS AND OTHER FUN
description: The seven parodies below have been taken from the newly published ''The Brand-X Anthology of Poetry,'' edited, with an amusing critical apparatus, by William Zaranka (Apple-wood Books. Cloth, $17.95. Paper, $9.95.) PERCY BYSSHE SHELLEY I met a traveller from an antique land Who said: Two vast and trunkless legs of stone Stand in the desert. Near them on the sand Half sunk, a shatter'd visage lies, whose frown And wrinkled lip and sneer of cold command Tell that its sculptor well those passions read Which still survive, stamp'd on these lifeless things, The hand that mocked them and the heart that fed; And on the pedestal these words appear: ''My name is Ozymandias, king of kings! Look on my works, ye Mighty, and despair!'' Also the names of Emory P. Gray, Mr. and Mr s. Dukes, and Oscar Baer, Of 17 West 4th Street Oyster Bay. - Morris Bishop

title: Elizabeth M. Holmes to Marry April 27
description: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Cleaves Holmes Jr. of Monroe, La., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Milburn Holmes, to Alonzo Bertram See 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. See 2d of Greenwich, Conn.

title: STUDENT VISITORS GO 'WHERE I T'S AT'
description: ''It was early when I got there, so I just sat down on one of the leather couches right near the clock in the lobby and watched the girls. A lot of schools were home for vacation already, and there there were about a million girls sitting and standing around waiting for their dates to show up.'' - J.D. Salinger, ''Catcher in the Rye.'' By RON ALEXANDER

title: Press Notes
description: The Philadelphia Bulletin had disappointingly small increases in circulation and advertising in November, the publisher of the financially troubled newspaper has told his staff.

title: EUROPE'S ICEMEN COMETH
description: Robin Herman, a former New York Times sports reporter, is now on the staff of the metropolitan desk. By Robin Herman

title: CAN ISADORA DUNCAN'S SOLOS BE DANCED BY A MAN?
description: More than half a century after her death, Isadora Duncan continues to fascinate and challenge dancers. But the restaging this week of her two Scriabin works by Satoru Shimazaki, the Tokyo-born modern dancer and choreographer, may cause the staunch feminist to roll over in her resting place and prompt her disciples to rise up in fury. Mr. Shimazaki's efforts would surely have been anathema to Miss Duncan, who restricted her creative works to women dancers. Nevertheless, Mr. Shimazaki will perform ''Mother'' (1921) and ''Revolutionary'' (1922), set to Scriabin etudes, at the Theater of St. Peter's Church Wednesday through next Sunday.

title: Dirty Air
description: To the Business Editor: Leonard Bruckman from Connecticut correctly condemns the Traxler-Hillis bill in ''The Dirty Air Bill'' (Dec. 13).

title: KNICKS BEAT PISTONS FOR FOURTH IN A ROW
description: The offense was on, then off and then on for the Knicks last night and, after losing several leads late in the game, they defeated the Detroit Pistons, 121-108, at Madison Square Garden.

title: ACCORD REPORTED IN SUIT OVER BABY
description: A janitor at the Hurley Medical Center found the newborn infant, abandoned as dead, gasping for breath in a doctors' scrubroom.

title: Grace Meade, Teacher, Is Married to David Diggs
description: Grace Louise Meade and David Diggs were married yesterday at the Brick Presbyterian Church in New York. The Rev. Dr. Herbert B. Anderson performed the ceremony.

title: CALIFORNIA'S ODDBALL HOTEL
description: ALJEAN HARMETZ is the Hollywood correspondent of The Times. By ALJEAN HARMETZ

title:
Gardening;
SOME GARDENING RESOLUTIONS FOR 1982
description: WITH the New Year comes the time to declare one's good intentions and make resolutions. May we suggest a few for the 1982 gardening season?

title: Ford to Pay 41 Owners Of Defective Vehicles
description: The Ford Motor Company has agreed to pay $15,000 to 41 Maine residents whose Ford vehicles developed engine problems.

title: Moscow Calls U.S. Sanctions In the Crisis an 'Obvious Flop'
description: The Kremlin today called President Reagan's sanctions against the Soviet Union and Poland an ''obvious flop.'' Pravda, the Communist Party paper, said that the sanctions showed that Washington was ''opposing the normalization of the situation.''

title: Doctors And Medicine
description: I write with pleasure to acknowledge Dr. Isadore Rosenfeld's article, ''A Doctor Defends His Calling'' (Nov. 15). My late husband was an internist, too. His dedication and love of his profession were well known to his patients and colleagues, as he practiced medicine each day and, yes, many, many nights. ANNA PATRICIA HORAN, R.N., Teaneck, N.J.

title: The Grandest Project
description: To the Editor:

title: PUZZLE OF THE PARTHENON
description: JOHN RUSSELL is art critic of The New York Times. By JOHN RUSSELL

title: Charity (Cont.)
description: To the Business Editor: In their answering letter on Dec. 27 to Barbara Bergman's ''Charity Needs Coercion,'' John J. Schwartz et al stated that ''contributions in 1980 totoaled $39.93 billion.''

title: THE YEAR OF THE ACCOUNTANT
description: SOME people on Wall Street have their own name for the new tax law. They call it the ''Accountants' Relief Act,'' and they're not far off. The radical changes that Congress enacted last year in the nation's tax system is translating into big business for accountants this year, when those provisions take effect. And 1982 shapes up as the year of the accountant, if there ever was one.

title:
Economic Affairs;
LEASING: A GOOD PILL FOR SICK COMPANIES
description: ''L EASING'' is becoming a bad word, especially when it refers to the provision of the Economic Recovery Tax Act of 1981 that removes all restraints on one corporation leasing equipment from another.

title: ON THE STREETS OF BROKEN DREAMS
description: NEWARK STANDING in breadlines and sleeping in public shelters with homeless women - the so-called ''shopping-bag ladies'' - are experiences that Charisse Coston, a self-described product of middleclass America, will never forget.

title: CRACKING CREATING
description: THE MIND'S BEST WORK By D.N. Perkins. Illustrated. 314 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $18.50. By MARTIN GARDNER

title: Business Conditions; THE BOND MARKET LIVES ON
description: The corporate bond market may be beleagured by high and volatile interest rates, but it is far from dead. In fact, it functioned well enough in 1981 to handle a record volume of notes and bonds, and some experts say it could easily surpass that volume in the coming year.

title:
Dining Out;
THE RESULTS OF UNIFORMITY
description: RESTAURANTS in nationwide hotel and motel chains tend to be predictable. Such is their strength, an executive working for a large hotel chain told me many years ago.According to research undertaken by that particular chain, people wh o travel, especially those on business, have no desire to wrestle wi th unusual menus. Therefore, the food offered in each location, be it Philadelphia or Los Angeles, is similar.

title: Dublin
description: To the Editor : William Borders's account ''What's Doing in Dublin'' (Travel, Nov. 1) brought to mind an amusing if inconvenient incident that occurred during a recent visit to that city.

title: Politics; COHALAN, CAPUTO SEEK ACCORD
description: SUFFOLK County Executive Peter F. Cohalan and County Comptroller Joseph Caputo are trying to patch up a rift that had reached the stage where some Cohalan supporters were talking about a primary challenge against Mr. Caputo when he seeks re-election this year.

title: HE NURTURES THE GIFTED PLAYWRIGHT
description: A former member of Playwrights Horizons recalls passing by Andre Bishop's office one day when he heard a voice booming through the door.

title: IS IT 'PARITY'?  'MEDIOCRITY'?  PETE ROZELLE SAYS NO
description: AFEW call it ''parity.'' Others cry of ''mediocrity.'' But in cities like San Francisco, Cincinnati, Tampa and New York this weekend, as well as in millions of television households across the country, football fans are using terms like ''excitement'' and ''entertainment'' as they watch one of the most interesting seasons in my 22 years as National Football League commissioner approach its conclusion.

title: Graffiti Doesn't Wait For Miami Metrorail
description: It will be at least two more years before trains roll along Dade County's Metrorail route, but the concrete guideway is already marked by graffiti.

title: Business Conditions; DRILLING DROP-OFF AHEAD
description: One of the bright spots in the economy last year - oil and gas drilling -is expected to grow more slowly in 1982. One reason is price. Last year, the decontrol of crude oil prices sparked the most frenetic drilling pace in history. This year industry analysts are prophesying stagnant, or even slightly falling, prices.

title: Two Grants of $25,000 Given to Dance Fund
description: Two grants of $25,000 each have been awarded by the Chase Manhattan Bank and International Business Machines to the National Corporate Fund for Dance Inc.

title: WHY SAVE?
description: To the Editor:

title: SCIENCE TAKES A HEALTHY INTEREST IN PETS
description: It's no secret to most pet fanciers. Not only a dog, but a cat, parakeet, monkey - even fish - can be a human being's best friend, and may be good for one's mental and physical health besides. Such notions are not strangers to scientific laboratories either. But there have been few studies - fewer still of appropriate scale and structure - that might prove or disprove the body of pet pet-ownership mythology.

title: About Westchester
description: PELHAM THE dancers in the large gym hall were wearing various contemporary combinations - blue jeans, T-shirts, business suits and an occasional floor-length cotton skirt. But when one listened to the music - old, lilting airs played on fiddle, accordion and piano - it was easy to picture them in voluminous satin dresses with panniers and pinchwaists, in breeches and waistcoats and white-powdered wigs.

title:
Other Business;
HOWARD RUFF'S NEW TUNE
description: When Howard Ruff sings does anyone listen? At $9.95 a shot, he hopes so. Mr. Ruff, better known for run-for-the-hills economic advice, has cut his first album. The adviser, who turns out to be a classical baritone, renders ''I Walked Today Where Jesus Walked'' and ''If I Were a Rich Man,'' among other numbers.

title: Sculpture of Mayan God Will Return to Mexico
description: Customs officials said today they would return to Mexico an ''irreplaceable'' pre-Columbian stone sculpture of a Mayan god and numerous ancient beads that were smuggled into the United States.

title: TOYNBEE'S HELLENES
description: THE GREEKS AND THEIR HERITAGES By Arnold Toynbee. 334 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $19.95.

title: SAM HUFF LOOKS BACK AT THAT CHAMPIONSHIP SEASON
description: IT was 25 years ago this season that I entered pro football. I was a country boy from West Virginia, and when I went to the New Yor k Giants' train ing camp at Burlington, Vt., I had no way of even suspecting th at as a rookie I would soon play a role in some NationalFootball Leag ue history: becoming a member of what I consider the first defensi ve unit to gain widespread recognition and helping the Giants to the last league championship they ever won. In fact, at thebeginning of camp I didn't even know that I would be a defensive player, much less a starter at middle linebacker, a position I had never filled. And I certainly hadn't anticipated the way I would react to the treatment that rookies received from the coaches, treatment tha t nearly caused me to drop my pro career before it had begun.

title: Miss Davies Is Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. William de Ath Davies Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sandra Dawn Davies, to John Sherman Barada, son of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Sylvester Barada 3d of New Canaan, Conn., and Nantucket, Mass.

title: BILL FOR CRIME VICTIMS URGED
description: HARTFORD AN organization formed to assist victims of crimes in Connecticut has proposed that the 1982 General Assembly adopt a crime victim's ''bill of rights'' intended to change radically the treatment of these persons in the courts.

title: CLEMSON SAVORS THE TASTE OF VINDICATION
description: For the first time, the football players from Clemson knew the feeling of being a national champion. After previously No.2-rated Georgia lost and No.3 Alabama lost and the Tigers beat No.4 Nebraska, 22-15, in the 48th Orange Bowl game Friday night, the wire-service polls became a formality: Clemson had won its first national championship of any kind.

title: Man Sets Himself Afire On a Street in Chelsea
description: A Brooklyn man in his late 20's or early 30's was critically burned when he set himself afire early yesterday afternoon on a s treet in the Chelsea s ection of Manhattan, the police reported.

title: Television Week
description: Local Anthropology ''Paradox on 72d Street,'' an hour-long documentary on individualism in American society as exemplified by one busy Manhattan street intersection, is derived in part from a book, Philip Slater's 1970 ''The Pursuit of Loneliness,'' which was subtitled ''American Cultureat the Breaki ng Point.'' In addition to Mr. Slater, another author, Dr. Lewis Tho mas, chancellor of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Research Cent er, who wrote ''The Lives of a Cell,'' appears on the program. It w ill be presented on C hannel 13 on Tuesday at 10 P.M. Theprogram is a pilot for a series called ''Film of Ideas.''

title: WALESA SAID TO SET TERMS FOR TALKS
description: The following dispatch is based on information arriving from Poland.

title: Art; A LACK OF SPACE BESETS MUSEUM
description: NEWARK MUSEUMS, especially those of encyclopedic rather than specialized persuasion, generally are desperate for space. And the Newark Museum, which John Cotton Dana founded in 1909, is no exception.

title: ALAN DAWES IS FIANCE OF KAREN A. TESHONY
description: Mrs. Nicholas W. Fenney of Hamden, Conn., has made known the engagement of her daughter, Karen Anne Teshony, to Alan Stuart Dawes, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Irving Dawes of Richmond.

title: REAGAN AND HAIG DISCUSS ALLIES' VIEW OF SANCTIONS
description: President Reagan spent the last day of his California trip today conferring with Secretary of State Alexande r M. Haig Jr. and others on foreign policy matters, includingthe American effort to win European approval of American economic sanctions aga inst the Soviet Union.

title: SOMERVILLE SALUTES A DANCING DAUGHTER
description: SOMERVILLE RUTH ST.DENIS, one of the founding figures of modern dance, will be honored next Saturday at a program sponsored by her hometown of Somerville, the New Jersey Center for the Per forming Arts and Somerset County College.

title: Dance View; 1982 MAY BE THE YEAR OF THE EUROPEAN IMPORT
description: Just when it seemed that the old year had been put safely away, a look into the crystal ball suggests that 1981 in European dance may well be part of 1982 in the United States. Last year's European premiere is shaping up increasingly as this year's European import. Consider some examples. There is Rudolf Nureyev's ''Don Quixote,'' in repertory in Paris-Vienna-Oslo-Zurich-Verona, which is about to be toured around the United States in the spring by the Boston Ballet. There is the Paris Opera Ballet's 1979 reconstruction of ''Sylvia'' - danced, incidentally, in the same version by the Peking Ballet - which is scheduled for an American premiere in March by the Washington Ballet.

title: Theater; 'KISS ME, KATE' AT THE COACHLIGHT
description: EAST WINDSOR ACCORDING to research, ''Kiss Me, Kate'' is 33 years old, a fact I find hard to believe because the show seems as fresh as ever. Revisiting this backstage musical, I can find hardly anything in danger of aging - certainly not the Cole Porter score, which doesn't have a weak number in it.

title: Paperback Talk
description: Coming attractions. When will it be out in paperback? The question is asked of booksellers more and more frequen tly as the prices of hardcover books rise.

title: FAST START IS PAYING OFF IN CAPUTO'S SENATE RACE
description: Bruce Caputo has introduced something new to New York State - the two-year Senate campaign. The former United States Representative and the Republican candidate for Lieutenant Governor in 1978 spent most of 1981 doggedly pursuing political leaders in search of support for his candidacy.

title: Susan Leon Sets Bridal in March
description: Susan Leon, a member of the editorial department of the Viking Press, will be married in March to Andrew David Fredman, a New York architect. Their engagement has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Sol Leon of Beverly Hills, Calif., parents of the future bride. Mr. Fredman's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Samuel G. Fredman, live in White Plains.

title: GHANA'S REGIME SUSPENDS CONSTITUTION
description: Ghana's new military regime announced tonight that it had suspended the country's constitution, banned all political parties and formally dismissed the civilian government of President Hilla Limann.

title: Cynthia Wright Wed to T. P. Hameline
description: Cynthia James Wright, an architect in San Francisco, was married yesterday to Thomas Peter Hameline, who is working for a doctorate in psychology at the University of California at Berkeley. Surrogate Bertram Gelfand of Bronx County performed the ceremony at the Bartow Pell Mansion in Pelham Bay Park, the Bronx, where the bride made her debut at the International Garden Club reception in 1971.

title: William E. Williams, 57, Dies; A Top Contract Bridge Player
description: William E. Williams, a leading contract bridge player, died in Harlem Hospital last Tuesday of complications from pneumonia.

title: Nonfiction in Brief
description: LIFE ON EARTH A Natural History. By David Attenborough. Illustrated. 319 pp. New York: Little, Brown & Co. $22.50.

title: Other Business; TECHNOLOGY'S MARTYRS: THE SLIDE RULE
description: In 1967, Keuffel & Esser, a scientific instrument manufacturer then located in Hoboken, N.J., was commissioned to make a study of the future.

title: Paterno Denies Interest In N.F.L. Job - Again
description: Coach Joe Paterno of Penn State repeated today that he was not interested in any coaching job in the National Football League and said ''I don't think I will be in the immediate future.''

title: PATERSON SPLIT ON SEWER FEES
description: PATERSON WHEN it comes to municipal sewer charges here, many residents say that they would rather attend their own funeral than pay the fees. Death is inevitable, some say, but taxes and the way they are levied can be challenged.

title: The Region in Summary; How to Gum Up The Water Works
description: Blessed with drinking water of almost unrivaled purity, New York City officials for the last year worried principally about having enough to go around. Last week, though, as 13,000 gallons of heating oil threatened to spill into the Croton Reservoir, their big concern was quality, not quantity.

title: Polish Official's Son To Move to Australia
description: The son of Mieczyslaw Rakowski, a Deputy Prime Minister of Poland, said today that he planned to emigrate to Australia from his home in West Germany.

title: Photography View; SPLIT PERSONALITIES: TICE, HORST AND AVEDON
description: At age 43, George Tice has had a career in photography spanning almost 30 years. Seven books of his photographs have been published; the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Museum of Modern Art have exhibited his work; he has received fellowships from the National Endowment for the Arts and the Guggenheim Foundation. Along the way he has acquired a national reputation as a master photographic printmaker and become a leading practitioner and teacher of platinum/palladium printing, a process which in the last five years has gone from cult status to fad.

title: PROTESTS BRING A REVIEW OF BOAT SEWAGE RULES
description: Government regulations designed to control the discharge of sewage from pleasure boats are being reexamined because of complaints about their cost and complexity.

title: Hilary V. Greene Affianced
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Jeffrey Alden Greene of Larchmont, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Hilary Virginia Greene, to Jonathan Stiehm, son of Mrs. Edward J. MacDermott of Tequesta, Fla., and the late Glen W. Stiehm.

title: The Coast Guard
description: To the Business Editor: The Coast Guard is not still part of the Treasury Department (''The Way It Was in the Year That Was,'' Dec. 27). It moved to the Department of Transportation when that depart ment was formed in 1967. DONALD A. NAPLES C aptain, U.S. Coast Guard Washington Dec. 28, 1981

title: Gallery View; THE DELICATE ART OF ENGLISH MINIATURES; NEW HAVEN, Conn.
description: It was in the Elizabethan miniature, around 400 years ago, that English painting reached a level of creativity that it was rarely to surpass. This is evident even in reproduction, but there is about the miniatures in question a confidentiality that does not reveal itself in ful l until we are nose to nose with the originals. Not to have seen those originals - all of them small, and many no larger than a passport photograph - is to have missed something as fundamental to the English achievement as the sonnets of Shakespeare and the polyphony of Thomas Tallis and William Byrd.

title: Top ics; TERMS AND TEAMS; Sporting Chance
description: Once it was known as Ping-Pong diplomacy; now the name of the game is soccer.

title: Around the World; Philippine Police Search For Missing Athlete
description: The Philippine police reported today that they were intensifying their search for a prominent athlete said by his family to have secretly married a daughter of President Ferdinand E. Marcos in the United States.

title:
Long Island Guide;
LOS REYES DE NAVIDAD
description: The holiday season is not yet over, at least not until after the ''Dia de Los Reyes Magos'' party, which the Great Neck Library is giving today at 2 P.M. A traditional Latin fiesta, the celebration will feature the Three Wise Men, a magician, balloons and a pinata. All is free; the library is on Bayview Avenue.SUNDAY AT THE MOVIES

title:
Dining Out;
ITALIAN DISHES IN UNUSUAL SETTING
description: BEFORE readers misunderstand this rating, it must be said that The Cafe Station serves unusual food in an unusual setting. The homemade pasta dishes are often luxurious, vigorous renditions of wellestablished combinations in the repertory of Italian cuisine found rarely in this county's restaurants. The restaurants prepares its entrees , however, according to a style it insouciantly calls ''lanuova cucina'' and there it falls flat.

title: Underground Oil Tank Leaks Into River on L.I.
description: A leak in an underground oil tank, apparently from a burned-out restaurant, spread a sheen of light oil on Long Island's Nissequogue River nearly to Long Island Sound yesterday morning.

title: HAWAII VOLCANOES
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORK GAINED JOBS DURING 1981
description: Employment in the New York metropolitan area continued to grow in 1981 but more slowly than in the three previous years, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday in a year-end review of labor market indicators.

title: Ellen Heath To Be Bride
description: The engagement of Ellen Louise Heath to Keith David Plapinger has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Richard Eddy Heath of Buffalo, parents of the future bride. mr. Plapinger is the son of Evelyn Adele Plapinger of Yardley, Pa., and Wallace Roland Plapinger of New York and Miami.

title: CAROL BELLAMY IS ON THE RUN, NEARING A FORK IN THE ROAD
description: The City Council presidency is not, by some standards, much of a job. Frank D. O'Connor, who held the position in the 1960's, said that all he did as President of the New York City Council was ''sit in an overstuffed chair,'' presiding over the Council's biweekly meetings.

title: MEDICAID REFINANCING SOUGHT
description: MINEOLA MAYOR KOCH of New York City, a Democrat who also had Republican endorsement when he ran for re-election last fall, spent several hours in a roomful of mostly Republicans here last week enlisting the support of the County Executives of Nassau and Suffolk, who are both Republicans.

title: LIVING IN THE LIMBO OF UNEMPLOYMENT
description: IREAD the headlines about the creeping unemployment rate, mergers, plant closings, layoffs, consolidations and corporate staff reductions with a strange feeling. It is not fear and it is not quite compassion. I am, rather, instantly assailed by a flood of images and memories of my own recent experience in t at twilightzone existence called unemployment.

title: Transactions
description: COLLEGE

title: Prospects
description: Autos Await Renewel

title: No Headline
description: Dr. Rosenfeld's article on health care was penetrating and timely. However, as a predoctoral fellow in cancer research at the Sloan-Kettering Institute, I take exception to Dr. Rosenfeld's assessment of high-scoring medical-school applicants as ''ideal candidates for careers in research.''

title: Maureen Miller, William Macier To Wed in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harold J. Miller of Mountain Lakes, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Maureen Lee Miller, to Willi am Charl es Macier, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Elden Macier of Saratoga Spri ngs, N.Y. A June wedding is planned.

title: Kathryn Tracy Bride Of Dr. William Wanck
description: Kathryn Bayard Tracy, a consultant in gerontology in Syracuse, and Dr. William Nicholas Wanck, a resident in psychiatry at the State University of New York in Syracuse, were married yesterday at the Erwin United Methodist Church in Syracuse. The Rev. Stephen T. Deckard performed the ceremony.

title: Anne Liegey Married To Martin J.  Nance
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More yesterday, Anne Lesley Liegey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jean R. Liegey of Stamford, Conn., was married to Martin John Nance, son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth J. Nance of Bromley, England. Msgr. Thomas Leonard performed the ceremony.

title: YOUNG DOCTORS AT YALE PRACTICE SKILLS IN HAITI
description: Patients do not go to Yale-New Haven Hospital with malaria or typhoid fever these days. Most of the surgeons who completed their residency there know, from firsthand experience, however, how to treat these diseases ''that don't exist any more in the civilized world,'' according to Dr. Michael Moses, a generalsurgery resident in his fifth year at Yale-New Haven.

title: Art; TWO PHOTOGRAPHERS AT BRIDGE GALLERY
description: WHITE PLAINS THE stretch of Martine Avenue that contains the County Building is no place for sauntering, winter or summer. Itself a not inelegant pile of 1930's vintage, the building is hard by a newer courthouse and public library - both genus Urban Renewal. Opposite, is the recently opened Galleria and a garage of several stories and, whether the buildings are made of concrete, stone or brick, the overall impression is one of soul-crushing, smog-colored modernity that nothing but giant slip-covers of ivy could possibly relieve.

title: THE STORY OF 'REDS' AND THE REED HOUSE
description: ABRAHAM VICTOR and his wife, Rose, enjoyed the movie ''Reds.'' They were just disappointed by the scenes depicting the Croton-on-Hudson home that was once the residence of the main subjects of the film, the journalists-activists John Reed and Louise Bryant. The recreation of the house, they say, was ''concocted.'' The Victors ought to know. They own it.

title: Washington; QUESTIONS FOR THE NEW YEAR
description: One of the few consolations about the old year is that the actions of the Reagan Administration were more moderate than its words. It reminds us for 1982 of the useful advice offe red by many public servants in the past: Pay attention to what g overnments do rather than what they say.

title: 'I'VE BEEN READY FOR THE MET SINCE 1974'
description: Tomorrow night, when Simon Estes makes his Metropolitan Opera debut as the Landgrave in ''Tannhauser,'' his American career finally will have caught up with his European reputation. Such lags are not unusual for a sing er, particularly an America n singer. Many have had to earn recognition on foreign stages before being given opportunities to sing at home. But the wait h as been an especially poignant one for Mr. Estes. He is black, the son of an Iowa coalminer who was himself the son of a slave.

title: Business Conditions; ENERGY PRICE EFFECT
description: Energy conservation has been a persistent theme of the past eight years, but a recent study by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development shows that the push to use energy more efficiently has taken years to develop and was strongest when real price increases were passed on to energy users.

title: New Jersey Guide; ISRAELI TO PERFORM
description: Yefim Bronfman, the young Israeli pianist who has created a stir in the five or so yea rs that he has been appearing in this country, will give a c oncert in Englewood Tuesday night.

title: Harold Steinbach, Lawyer, Fiance of Beryl Schwartz
description: Lillian Schwartz and Peter Schwartz of Bangor, Me., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Beryl Joy Schwartz, to Harold Ira Steinbach, son of Mr. and Mrs. Aaron Steinbach of the Bronx.

title: Writers
description: To the Editor:

title: Around the World; Iranian Ends Syrian Visit With No Gains on Iraq
description: Foreign Minister Ali Akbar Vellayati of Iran flew home today after three days of talks that produced no sign of progress toward ending the Iranian-Iraqi war.

title: Judge Joseph B. Williams
description: Joseph Banks Williams, who is 60 years old, was born in Annapolis, Md., and moved to New York in 1942. He served in the Navy in World War II and in the Korean War.

title: Cynthia Elliott Engaged
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Harry Barnwell Elliott of Milford, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Cynthia Sterling Elliott, to Michael Paul Sherman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Paul Sherman of White River Junction, Vt.

title: Best Sellers
description: Jx FICTION 1 1 11 AN INDECENT OBSESSION, by Colleen McCullough. (Harper & Row, $13.50.) A nurse and her charges in a special-care ward of a World War II hospital. 2 2 16 THE HOTEL NEW HAMPSHIRE, by John Irving. (Dutton/Henry Robbins, $15.50.) Life with an eccentric family. 3 3 35 NOBLE HOUSE, by James Clavell. (Delacorte, $19.95.) A British-Chinese struggle for control of one of Hong Kong's oldest trading houses. 4 4 21 CUJO, by Stephen King. (Viking, $13.95.) Monsters haunt a Ne w York family seeking peace in rural Maine. 5 5 8 NO TIME FOR TEARS, by Cynthia Freeman. (Arbor House, $14.95.) A dauntless woman leads her family from Czarist Russia to Palestine to New York's diamond center. 6 6 7 SPRING MOON, by Bette Bao Lord. (Harper & Row, $14.95.) Tradition and revolution in modern China seen through the life of an upper-class family. 7 7 9 REMEMBRANCE, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $14.95.) An Italian princess, in quest of romance, finds frustration, then fulfillment in America.

title: A HOBBY MAKES MILLIONS
description: ESSEX ''I'D always been busy cooking and sewing for the children,'' Jeanne Bouchever recalled recently. ''But with the girls married and my son away at school I felt lost. My oldest daughter said, 'You could make things to sell,' and she gave me a whole list.''

title: A LAKE SAFARI IN ZIMBABWE
description: ALAN COWELL, a correspondent for The Times, is based in Nairobi. By ALAN COWELL

title: ELIZABETH SEARLE ENGAGED
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Louis Searle of Lake Forest, Ill., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Searle, to James Dewar Reichert, son of Mr. and Mrs. Douglas A. Reichert of Pittsburgh. Miss Searle and her fiance, graduates of Ohio Wesleyan University, plan a spring wedding.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A picture caption in the Arts and Lei- sure section today gives an incorrect opening date for ''Waltz of the Stork.'' The comedy will open at the Century Theater on Tuesday.

title: St. Bart's With an Office Spire?
description: Saint Bartholomew's is a stately Byzantine church that stands alone, with its six-story Community House and gardens, on Park Avenue between 50th and 51st Streets. The site is such a relief from overpowering office towers that many New Yorkers consider the open space their own.

title: FOREIGN-AID STUDY FAVORS PRIVATE ENTERPRISE
description: A foreign-aid study by the Treasury Department calls for greater promotion of private enterprise in t hird worl d countries and recommends as a model the work of the Interna ti onal Financ e Corporation, an agency of the World Bank.

title: SAUDIS' CONDITIONS TO 'ACCEPT' ISRAEL LISTED BY PRINCE
description: The Saudi Foreign Minister said in an interview today that in return for Israeli recognition of Palestinian rights and the return of occupied Arab lands, his Government was prepared ''to accept'' Israel.

title: 'WHY GUATEMALA?' SOME ANSWERS TO THE QUESTION
description: The fall of Nicaragua's dictator, Gen. Anastasio Somoza Debayle, resounded around the world. El Salvador's civil war has dominated recent reporting from Central America. By comparison, Guatemala's leftist-led insurgency, which could have equally important consequences, is less well-known.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Garment Pillaging
description: For decades, New York's garment center - some 20 blocks in midtown Manhattan - had relied on primitive hand trucks to transport piece and finished goods from shop to shop. Such a vehicle, pushed by one or two men, might contain thousands of dollars worth of goods.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption and an Off Off Broadway listing in The Guide today give an incorrect opening date for a revival of Arthur Miller's play ''The Price.'' The 92d Street Y has postponed the opening to Saturday, Jan. 16.

title: Emilie Solotorovsky Wed
description: Emilie Solotorovsky, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Morris Solotorovsky of Skillman, N.J., was married yesterday to Peter Lapham, son of Mr. and Mrs. F. David Lapham of New Canaan, Conn. Municipal Court Judge Russell Annich of Princeton Borough performed the ceremony at the Friend's Meeting House in Princeton, N.J. The bride is a graphic designer in Philadelphia. Her father is professor of microbiology at Rutgers University. Mr. Lapham is a principal in Urban Partners, a development consulting concern in Philadelphia.

title: Headliners; Isn't It Enough?
description: Judge Alcee Hastings, appointed by President Carter in 1978 and the first black man on the Federal bench in Florida, said that he read the Federal grand jury indictment against him and thought of the song, ''Is That All There Is?'' Even then, it was a lot.

title: HEALTH ADVOCATES PLAY VITAL ROLE
description: TOO many of us have experienced the sense of disorientation and fear that accompanies a stay in the hospital. Too many of us believe that our doctors, nurses or hospital administrators do not display genuine concern about our well-being, either physical or emotional. And too many of us have felt confused when confronted with complex medical procedures and language, yet powerless to make our needs afd questions known.

title: Miss Cash Sets Bridal For Feb. 20
description: Courtney Elizabeth Cash, a technical consultant in data planning, research and development for the Reynolds Metals Company in Richmond, plans to be married on Feb. 20 to Lloyd Montague Mustin 2d, who is attending Naval Officer Candidate School in Newport, R.I.

title: France to Assist Ethiopia
description: Foreign Minister Claude Cheysson of France ended a four-day visit to Ethiopia today with a pledge for financial assistance in developing the Marxist country's economy. Mr. Cheysson mentioned no figures but said an Ethiopian team would visit Paris at the end of the month to discuss details of economic cooperation.

title: Dining Out; WHERE PEKING DUCK IS A SPECIALTY
description: THE unusua l name of a new Chinese restaurant in Woodbury Common, Mo-er of Home r's, refers to the black, ruffled fungus commonly calledtree ears or cloud ears, widely used in Chinese cooking. Mo-er of Homer's is al so more of Homer's.

title: WASHINGTON'S FIRST RECESSION
description: WASHINGTON IN the real estate offices, economists' suites and counting houses of the nation's capital, an uneasy consensus is forming: Washington, which long has considered itself immune to such things, is falling prey to recession.

title: Marcum of Kansas Gets Post at South Carolina
description: Robert Marcum, the University of Kansas athletic director for three years, was named today to the same post at South Carolina.

title: New Jersey Journal
description: THE search for the killer or killers of State Trooper Philip J. Lamonaco goes on. In the week after the highly decorated, 32-year-old trooper was mortally wounded in a shoot-out on Interstate 80, about 250 troopers and detectives roamed the back roads around Knowlton Township, looking for physical evidence from the murder and responding to scores of reports about strange or suspicious people lurking here and there in the countryside.

title: 2 Quakes Shake Mexico City; No Injuries or Damages Cited
description: Two earthquakes shook this capital of 15 million people early today, but there were no reports of damage or injuries, the authorities said.

title: STATES GROWING DISILLUSIONED ABOUT 'NEW FEDERALISM' CUTS
description: In state capitals across the nation, the once positive response to President Reagan's ''new federalism'' plan to return authority from the Federal Government to the states has turned sour as budget cuts and the recession squeeze many state treasuries.

title: INDONESIA GRANTS CLEMENCY TO SUKARNO AID
description: President Sukarno called him ''the best Foreign Minister Indonesia ever had.'' Anti-Communists denounced him as ''a little Pekingese dog.'' The prosecutor at his trial 15 years ago called him the architect of the country's old order.

title: JAZZ STATION'S LISTENERS ORGANIZE- JUST IN CASE
description: SECONDS after 6 P.M. on Sept. 2, 1980, the first chord of Herbie Hancock's ''Maiden Voyage'' was sent over the airwaves by WYRS-FM, the 3,000-watt radio station in Stamford. The selection was anything but random, for WYRS was prepared to supplant WRVR-FM as the only full-time, commercial jazz station in the New York metropolitan area Six days later, the final elegiaic strains of Charles Mingus' ''Goodbye Pork Pie Hat'' gave way on WRVR to Waylon Jennings' ''Are You Ready for the Country?'' -a rhetorical question since the shift to country music had just been made.

title: Theater in Review; 'LONDON SKETCHBOOK': A CURIOSITY
description: IN Off Off Broadway parlance, there are showcases and there are workshops - works in progress that need time and space to develop, evolve and attract the attention of producers.

title: Westchester Housing; HOW RESIDENTS APPRAISE HOUSES
description: WESTCHESTER home owners think their houses are worth a lot, compared with what people in most of the country think of their houses -but compared with sales figures, all of them are modest.

title: REAGAN'S POLICIES ASSAILED BY YOUNG
description: Andrew Young, the former chief American delegate to the United Nations, says that the foreign and domestic policies of the Reagan Administration are ''clear failures'' and that President Reagan will have to be ''turned around or turned out.''

title: NEWTONIA
description: To the Editor:

title:
Speaking Personally;
THE PREDICTABILITY OF MOTHER NATURE
description: WITH the start of every year, I begin a new list. Not a grocery list or a list of things to do but, rather, a list of all the natural events that occur throughout the year.

title: Design; ANYTHING GOES
description: atch out for that pendulum! These post-modernist times can be terribly treacherous. After decades of ''cutting edge'' design based on a strict modernist credo of form following function, we have entered a period so philosophically amorphous and liberal as to be dizzying. Bad enough keeping track of historicism, regionalism and pop symbolism, one must also keep a sharp eye out for the architectural kids.

title: Food; Rolling in Dough
description: The American fondness for pizza, the great Neapolitan specialty that invaded these shores after World War II, is one we share. More recently, we have become enthusiastic about a stuffed version of pizza, another Italian specialty called calzoni.

title: SUSSEX EXPANDS ITS FREE BUS SERVICE
description: NEWTON ON A recent morning, Katherine Hunce, a widow living alone in rural Sussex County, was among the few passengers on a small bus that traveled through rolling meadows and over steep mountain roads to Newton, the county seat.

title: The German Peace Movement
description: It is very heartwarming to see that hundreds of thousands of Western Europeans are concerned about the future of mankind (''The German Malaise,'' by John Vinocur, Nov. 15).

title: The Nation in Summary; Guess Where the MX Is Going
description: The MX intercontinental ballistic missile - still years away from lifting off the drawing boards - is already perhaps the most travelweary weapon never built. Last week, the Pentagon disclosed yet another interim basing plan, this one designed to give the MX's greater protection from attack by Soviet missiles and by skeptical American politicians.

title: A VOICE HEARD ROUND THE WORLD
description: To the Editor:

title: Connecticut Journal
description: THE average size of elementary school classes, which has been dropping for more than a decade, is beginning to stabilize, according to a study by the Connecticut Public Expenditure Council.

title: Juliette T. Curtiss, Student, Married In Massachusetts
description: Juliette Talpey Curtiss and Richard Nicholas John Carlton Rowlands were married yesterday in Christ Episcopal Church in Sheffield, Mass. The Rev. Donald O. Platt performed the ceremony.

title: Headliners; Disparaging Words
description: Abortion rights proponents sent a chastity belt to a noted abortion foe, California State Senator John G. Schmitz, but the exchange of hostilities didn't end there. In a press release, Mr. Schmitz called adversaries of his proposed legislation, defining life as beginning at conception, ''lesbians'' and ''murderous marauders'' who are ''hard, Jewish and arguably female.'' The state Senate Rules Committee moved fast and last week it stripped him of a committee chairmanship and fired him from a commission on women.

title: MAIL ORDER DISKS SING A SWEET SONG
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Paul Kresh is a contributing editor of Stereo Review, where he reviews both popular and classical records. By PAUL KRESH

title: Laura Heery Married to Seth Goldwin
description: Laura Marian Heery, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Thomas Heery of Atlanta, was married there yesterday to Seth Charles Goldwin, son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Allen Goldwin of Washington. The Rev. James L. Johnson, rector of St. George's Episcopal Church in Nashville and an uncle of the bride, performed the ceremony at the Piedmont Driving Club.

title: JERSEY CITY THEATER TO GET A NEW LIFE
description: JERSEY CITY ''IT WAS like going on an archeological dig in Pompeii,'' said the young, ebullient architect who is restoring the Majestic Theater here.

title: GIRAFFE FIRST ZOO BABY IN '82
description: It's a boy. He weighs 125 pounds, and he's already standing - 6 feet tall. He doesn't even have a name yet, but the Bronx Zoo's new giraffe calf has distinguished himself by being the zoo's first baby of 1982.

title: Travel Advisory; PHONES ALOFT, FUN AT SEA; Making Calls I n High Places
description: Help is on the way for two kinds of air tra velers: the executive who longs to continue barking out orders to h is staff even when he's in the air, and the passenger who just wants to reach out and touch someone at 35,000 feet. They will be able to dial direct when telephones are installed on 550 planes flying on long hauls within the United States. Tests are scheduled for th e spring, and the phonesshould be operational by the end of the year.

title: Nancy Louise Rabin Is Betrothed to Andrew Neff
description: Dr. and Mrs. Sidney C. Rabin of West Chester, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Louise Rabin, to Andrew J. Neff, son of Judge and Mrs. Alan M. Neff of Philadelphia.

title: THE FOOD WEAPON STILL WON'T WORK
description: To the Editor:

title: Field Condition Is 'Good'
description: The man in charge of the playing surface at Candlestick Park, the site of Sunday's playoff game between the Giants and 49ers, says he is pleased with its condition. That report came today from George Kerwin, the chief engineer at the stadium, as a work crew was removing the tarpaulin to allow the sun to absorb moisture.

title: THE DANCE: THE TOLLE COMPANY
description: Dancers have to be able to sing to dance with Roger Tolle, whose choreography has as much to do with the music the performers make as with movement. And the nine-member Roger Tolle Company, which performed Friday at the Dance Theater Workshop's Bessie Schonberg Theater, sings very well. Song was, in fact, the high point of the evening.

title: A FAMILIAR NAME STAGES A COMEBACK
description: WEST CALDWELL DUMONT, a familiar name in the early years of electronics manufacturing and a pioneering television company, is making a remarkable comeback, as evidenced by the fact that it recently bought the company that had absorbed the Dumont Laboratories in 1960.

title: STATE DEFICIT RAISED BY SPECIAL SESSION
description: HARTFORD WHEN the General Assembly convened Nov. 19 for a special session, the intention was to reduce an $83 million deficit. That could come about if the legislators can agree on a fiscal package. Meanwhile, the cost of the session itself is increasing the deficit.

title: Caldwell Wins Skiing
description: Tim Caldwell of Putney, Vt., won the 15-kilometer North American cross-country ski race at Mount Van Hoevenburg today in 41 minutes 41.2 seconds. Stan Dunklee of Brattleboro, Vt., was second at 42:46.4 and Todd Kempainen of Minnetonka, Minn., was third at 43:11.0.

title: GROWING IMBALANCE OF JOBS, HOUSING WORRIES PLANNERS IN LOWER FAIRFIELD
description: COUNTY By RICHARD L. MADDEN ROWAYTON IN the last decade, the eight munici palitie s in lower Fairfield County that comprise the South Western Region al Planning Agency reported a population decline of about 8,000. At the same time the number of jobs in the eight towns soared by a lmost 40,000, but only about 15,000 housing units were added.

title: THE UNIVERSE OF MONEY
description: THE MONEY LENDERS Bankers and a World in Turmoil. By Anthony Sampson. 336 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $16.95.

title: WHEN SINGLE PARENTS HAVE A DATE
description: ''I DON'T even want to get to know him - I don't want to be hurt again,'' a 14-year-old said, explaining her feelings about her divorced mother's new date.

title: Music; NEW CONCERT SERIES IN MIDSEASON DEBUT
description: MOST Connecticut orchestras are approaching midseason as the new year settles in, but not the Chamber Orchestra of New England. Having warmed up last month with two special Baroque concerts, in 18th-century costume, the orchestra is ready to begin its official subscription series a week from Saturday evening at Lyman Auditorium on the Southern Connecticut State College campus. ''We're having great music, great artists and great fun,'' says the music director, James Sinclair. ''Our popular tradition of postconcert wine-and-cheese receptions continues this year - open to all our subscribers - so join us and enjoy.''

title: IN SOUTH AFRICA, STERN LAWS FORGE A RARE ALLIANCE
description: At the end of a long meeting here Wednesday of families whose relatives have been jailed by the security police without charge, an Afrikaner professor raised his hand and quietly volunteered to call the Attorney General's office on behalf of a housewife from the black township of Soweto.

title: The Nation in Summary; Judge Upholds A Handgun Ban
description: After a man applied for a license to open the town's first gun shop, the village board of Morton Grove, Ill., population 24,000, in June enacted the toughest gun controls in the land, barring the sale of pistols and forbidding their possession outright. Last week, rejecting claims by opponents of the controls, Federal District Court Judge Bernard Decker said that Morton Grove, a northern suburb of Chicago, hadn't run afoul of either the state or Federal constitutions.

title: Food; HOW A GOURMET DINING CLUB CELEBRATED THE SEASON
description: OLD WESTBURY A GROUP of people on the Island have found an enjoyable alternative to dining in restaurants or entertaining at home. Actually, what they do is a combination of both.

title: HEATING COSTS, TRANSIT AND INCOME TROUBLE ELDERLY
description: THEY are often alone and sometimes lonely. They worry about paying their heating bills and balancing their small monthly budgets. Transportation is a tremendous problem, and seemingly small tasks like cutting toenails or carrying groceries up a flight of stairs are unsurmountable for some.

title: COWBOYS ROMP 38-0 VICTORY PUTS DALLAS IN FINAL
description: The Doomsday Defense, almost forgotten in the lore of the Dallas Cowboys, played with authority today in a 38-0 National Football Conference divisional semifinal playoff victory over the Tampa Bay Buccaneers.

title: Pilot Is Killed in Crash Of a Navy Cargo Plane
description: A Navy C-12 cargo plane lost power, dropped onto a compact car and hit a tree in a housing development today. The pilot was killed and three of the seven others on board were injured, the authorities said.

title: NEW ADMINISTRATOR OF CITY COURTS IS SELECTED BY CHIEF JUDGE OF STATE
description: New leaders for the New York City court system were announced yesterday as the state's Chief Judge renewed his call for improvements in efficiency and productivity.

title:
Gardening;
SOME GARDENING RESOLUTIONS FOR 1982
description: WITH the New Year comes the time to declare one's good intentions and make resolutions. May we suggest a few for the 1982 gardening season?

title: GERMANY'S REASONS FOR IMMOBILITY ON POLAND
description: When Helmut Schmidt talks about Poland with Ronald Reagan this week he will be watched very carefully at home by a constituency whose response to the Polish situation so far has basically been a low murmur, ''Do nothing.''

title: Mike Rossman Indicted On 2 Charges in Jersey
description: Mike Rossman, the former World Boxing Association light-heavyweight champion, has been indicted by an Atlantic County grand jury on charges of resisting arrest and possessing a dangerous weapon Dec. 15 at 2:45 A.M.

title: NEW FILM SERIES TO BEGIN IN COUNTY
description: ''IT'S like embarking on an adventure,'' Marilyn Ackerman was saying. ''It's like Columbus discove ring America; it's a very specialfeeling.''

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article in some editions yesterday gave incorrect information on an action by the board of the Legal Services Corporation. A corrective article appears on page 26.

title:
Business Forum;
U.S. INTEREST RATES AND ANGRY EUROPEANS
description: IN discussing monetary policy and the international impact of interest rates, two recent episodes come to mind. One is the discussion of the prospective United States budget deficit and its international repercussions. The other relates to the period of high interest rates earlier this year, when the United States was frequently accused of responsibility for high rates in the rest of the world.

title:
RED SMITH;
Tommy Henrich, Very Patient Man
description: ONE of the finest baseball players, one of the finest people and certainly one of the most patient not in the Hall of Fame is Tommy Henrich, whom they called ''the club pro'' through his 11 seasons as a Yankee outfielder and first baseman.

title:
Art;
POST-MODERNISM AT THE SQUIBB
description: LAWRENCE TOWNSHIP WHAT surely must be the latest word on what is happening in the international art world is on view at the Squibb Art Gallery through next Sunday.

title: AN EX-MARINE ASKS: WHAT'S GOING ON?
description: Ever since the end of the war, we - the most powerful nation -have been running around the earth lamenting our loss of manhood, while trying to prove we haven't. Everywhere, we have discovered alien forces that threaten us and our benign role as leader of a new, decent, disciplined, democratic world shaped into our mirror-image.

title: Houston Mayor Takes Oath
description: Kathryn J. Whitmire, a 35-year-old certified public accountant and former City Controller, took the oath of office today to become the first woman to be Mayor of Houston.

title: JAPAN'S CHALLENGE TO U.S. IS POLICIES, NOT PRODUCTS
description: Other industries in the United States may be falling by the wayside, but the American computer industry still reigns supreme. United States companies hold about four-fifths of the world market and the computer kingpin, the International Business Machines Corporation, alone claims half the global market.

title: FIRE SWEEPS TOWER'S LOWER FLOORS
