description: A three-alarm fire raged through the lower floors of a 15-story Park Avenue building in midtown Manhattan for more than three hours last night. The blaze threatened films, recordings and broadcasting facilities in a number of the offices occupied by companies in the entertainment field.

title: Art
description: 49 ARTISTS CAPTURE THE ILLUSIONS AND REALITIES OF WINTER By HELEN A. HARRISON EAST HAMPTON ''WINTERSCAPE,'' the current exhibition at Guild Hall, features many paintings that relate to the East End in winter, as well as works that refer to the season in abstract terms or deal with other locales. A quiet, contemplative mood permeates the galleries, induced by the cool tones and restrained compositions that predominate. The effect is far from somber, however, for the 49 invited artists offer much that is delightful and captivating, even in its understatement.

title: Leisure; THE CATALOGUES ARE COMING, THE CATALOGUES ARE COMING
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Frederick McGourty is editor of the Brooklyn Botanic Garden Handbooks. By FREDERICK McGOURTY

title: REALPOLITIK
description: Two dramas are taking place in Poland today. The first is the apparent denouement of Solidarity's struggle against an autocratic, incompetent, and corrupt Government. This romantic endeavor, tinged with syndicalism and anarchism, has touched the hearts of people everywhere.

title: Connecticut Guide; SLEIGHING RALLY
description: The Wimler Farm Sleigh Rally in Durham gets under way at 11 A.M. today. If there is no snow, the rally will be postponed to next Sunday. There is no charge for spectators or participants, and everyone gets at least a consolation prize. ''It's a friendly affair, and we don't like to see anyone go home without a ribbon,'' Mrs. Charles Wimler said.

title: Topics; Terms and Teams
description: The Parking

title: RICHARD KASKEL TO WED LESLIE ROBYN ALTMAN
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Earle S. Altman of the engagement of their daughter, Leslie Robyn Altman, to Richard Lewis Kaskel.

title: MILLER SHARES LEAD
description: Johnny Miller shot a sixunder-par 66 and went from three strokes back to a share of the lead today going into Sunday's final round of the world's richest golf tournament.

title: Investing; HOW TO GO WRONG IN STOCK OPTIONS
description: T HE boom in options trading has stirred the blood of speculators an d conservative investors alike since these contracts began changingha nds in 1973 on the Chicago Board Options Exchange. ''The C.B.O.E. be came the biggest success in the shortest time of any financial ex change that has ever existed in the United States,'' declared Max G. Ansbacher, a stockbroker at Bear, Stearns & Company.

title: Nancy Doerr To Be Bride Of a Student
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Edwin Doerr of Philadelphia have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Christine Doerr, to Thomas Francis O'Neil 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. O'Neil Jr. of Fairfield, Conn. The wedding is planned for August in New Haven.

title: Gordon Medenica Weds Ann Connolly
description: At Our Lady Queen of Martyrs Roman Catholic Church in Forest Hills, Queens, yesterday, Ann M. Connolly and Gordon Medenica, who received M.B.A. degrees in 1979 from Harvard University, were married by the Rev. Francis X. Mulhall.

title: Critics' Choices
description: CLASSICAL MUSICThere are performers who are content to play the existing literature, and then there are those who devote at least part of their time to making it grow. Among the most successful at this art of musical husbandry is the English-born clarinetist, Gervase De Peyer, who will perform with Christopher O'Riley, pianist, and Tsuyoshi Tsutsumi, cellist, Thursday at 8 P.M. in Alice Tully Hall.

title: PRESCRIPTION FOR AILING HOLLYWOOD: GLAMOUR
description: Stanley, my film producer friend from Hollywood, swept into Sardi's for our annual State of Stanley and the Arts session, 45 minutes late for our appointment at 6. ''This town is getting to be too much,'' he said by way of explanation. ''Every empty cab was full by the time it got to me.'' Stanley looked not only tan and trim but glamorous, wearing black tie, dinner jacket and at least $500 worth of cologne that evaporated during our talk. As he settled into our corner table, he ordered what became the first of a succession of Perriers with lime twists. Among other things, he's into health and off booze completely. Even white wine.

title: A.I.A. MEDAL GIVES A CLUE TO ARCHITECTURE'S OTHER AGENDAS
description: When the American Institute of Architects recently announced that the New York architect Romaldo Giurgola would receive its 1982 gold medal, it was not just naming a new honoree. By conferring its highest award on Mr. Giurgola, the institute - the official organization of the architectural profession in America - took a major step toward recognizing the importance of design innovation.

title: Venice
description: To the Editor:

title: Politics; A POLITICAL ALMANAC FOR 1982
description: WITH all the forecasts about what 1982 will bring, here is an Old Reporter's Almanac for Connecticut politics in the year ahead: January - The General Assembly, still meeting in special session, finally finds a solution to the state's fiscal problem. It adopts $10 license fees on parakeets, canaries, cats and goats kept as pets to yield $83 million. A blizzard strikes the Hartford area on Jan. 12, the date of the special election to fill the vacancy in the First Congressional District. Only the two candidates, Barbara B. Kennelly, the Democrat, and Ann Uccello, the Republican, are able to get to the polls. The vote is a tie, 1 to 1, and Governor O'Neill orders a new election for Feb. 9. Prescott Bush Jr., announcing his candidacy to challenge Lowell P. Weicker Jr. for the Republican nomination for the United States Senate, stresses his independence from the White House and his brother, Vice President George Bush. Prescott Bush says he will not accept phone calls from his brother during the campaign. The Vice President replies: ''Prescott who?''

title: Victorian Line Takes Calder Feature
description: Victorian Line, the 6-5 favorite, ran away with the $113,800 Tropical Park Derby at Calder today, winning by 10 lengths before a crowd of 12,372.

title: Wedding Planned By Miss Brainard
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frank Samuel Brainard of Princeton, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Annabelle Carpenter Bowditch Brainard, to Douglas Arthur Canning, son of Mr. and Mrs. William John Canning of Groton, Conn.

title: 'Potential Hijacker' Seized
description: Karachi airport security officials said today that they had arrested a Palestinian ''potential hijacker'' while he was trying to board a Gulf Air flight. When they searched the 30-year-old Yusuf Yusufi, the officials said, they found a pen pistol and 25 rounds of ammunition hidden in his shoes.

title: Bridge; 'ENRY VERSUS ELIZA
description: Last August, Rex Harrison made a triumphant Broadway return, after more than 20 years, as Professor Henry Higgins in the revival of Lerner and Loewe's ''My Fair Lady.''

title: No Headline
description: As a plaintiffs's malpractice attorney, I am always amazed by the repeated assertions of some physicians that the answer to the socalled malpractice crisis is to deprive those patients injured as a result of medical malpractice of their opportunity to seek restitution in our courts. If, as Dr. Rosenfeld asserts, there are thousands of malpractice cases before the courts each year in which doctors are sued for missing pathology that could have been diagnosed, I say, ''Bravo!''

title: STATE TO STRESS WILDLIFE PROTECTION
description: TRENTON ANTICIPATING a minimum of $250,000 a year from a new fund for endangered and non-game species, the state's Department of Environmental Protection will begin a publicity campaign this week to educate the public about the importance of preserving 600 wildlife species in New Jersey that are not hunted.

title:
The Week in Business;
U.S. STEEL CLOSES IN ON MARATHON
description: U.S. Steel is looking like a winner again in the bidding for Marathon Oil. Mobil's request that the Supreme Court block Big Steel's $6.3 billion takeover bid was denied on procedural grounds. Chief Justice Warren E. Burger said that Mobil must return to a lower court, which has already ruled that Mobil's purchase of Marathon would violate antitrust law. Chastened, Mobil lawyers did refile, but only a rapid reversal could prevent the nation's largest steelmaker from buying control of Marathon on Thursday. Meanwhile, U.S. Steel has its own troubles, laying off 1,000 workers at Edgar Thomson Works near Pittsburg, and idling another 350 at another plant.

title: HAS FAKERY BECOME REALITY?
description: IRECENTLY approached a salesperson in a department store to ask the price of a blouse whose tag had been torn off. After repeating the question twice, I discovered, to my embarrassment, that the ''salesperson'' was a stunningly life-like mannequin.

title: PROBLEM OF RUNAWAYS AND HOMELESS YOUTH INCREASES
description: CHILDREN who left home in the late 60's and early 70's appeared more adventurous than troubled, wandering the country in search of experience and a communal ideal of sharing and caring.

title: Medical Questions
description: To the Editor:

title: THE HIGH PRIEST OF A TROUBLED CHURCH
description: WASHINGTON M OST years, the president of the American Economics Association is largely a figurehead, albeit one of considerable prestige. But these are difficult times for economists, who have been struggling not only with the normal self-doubt generated by a troubled economy, but also with the Reagan Administration's assault on the funding of economic research.

title: Swede and Italian Reach Final in Junior Tennis
description: Henrik Sundstrom of Sweden and Francesco Cancellotti of Italy eliminated the last two Americans in the boys 18 division today and reached the final at the Rolex International junior tennis championships at the Port Washington Tennis Academy.

title: Alisa Levin Is a Bride
description: Alisa F. Levin and Charles M. Nathan, both lawyers, were married yesterday at the Carlyle Hotel.

title: WILLIAM M. BLACK, A RETIRED EXECUTIVE IN ACCOUNTING FIRM
description: William M. Black, retired senior partner of the accounting firm of Peat, Marwick, Mitchell & Company, died Thursday of cancer in the University of South Carolina Hospital in Charleston. Mr. Black, who was a resident of Marco Island, Fla., was 78 years old.

title: No Headline
description: Since most of the Inuit live in northern Quebec ("New Quebec"), the lowest prices and widest variety are to be found in that province. In Montreal the best and most reasonable source is the gift shop of the Montreal Museum of Fine Arts.

title: DENTON AND KRIEK GAIN AUSTRALIAN FINAL
description: Steve Denton of Driscoll, Tex., upset a fellow American, Hank Pfister, in five sets today and gained the final of the $400,000 Australian Open tennis tournament against South Africa's Johan Kriek.

title: NEW HARD TIMES FILL SOUP KITCHENS
description: For the first time in many years, Col. Clarence Kinnett has begun to remember the Depression. ''It's the kind of memory you tend to submerge, if you can,'' said Colonel Kinnett, who directs the Salvation Army's northeastern Ohio region. ''I had to pull my little red wagon down to the county welfare to pick up the dried beans and the prunes and the canned beef, right through the center of town. You know, I can stilll feel the sting of that experience.''

title: Fashion Beauty
description: Are Hats Taking Off? Back in the 1950's, a woman was not properly dressed without one. Then it became just a cover-up from the elements.

title: Miss Makepeace T o Be June Bride
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Russell Makepeace of Marion, Mass., of the engagement of their daughter, Mary Zelinda Makepeace, to the Rev. Dr. John Douhan Jr., son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Douhan of Cambridge, Mass.

title: HELEN WRIGHT AND MATTHEW HOBBS TO WED IN MAY
description: Announcement has been made by Helen M. Wright of New York of the engagement of her daughter, Helen Cecilia Wright, to Matthew Baird Hobbs, son of Mr. and Mrs. Franklin Warren Hobbs of Chestnut Hill and South Dartmouth, Mass.

title: Military Analysis
description: In 1981, the United States completed a major adjustment in military policy that began after the Soviet Union sent troops into Afghanistan in December

title: THE TWO SIDES OF DEREK WALCOTT
description: THE FORTUNATE TRAVELLER By Derek Walcott. 99 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $11.95 By DENIS DONOGHUE

title: Marie Ashton Is Married To Peter Henry Werner
description: The wedding of Marie Elizabeth Ashton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William P. Ashton of Glen Rock, N.J., to Peter Henry Werner took place in New York Dec. 26. The Rev. Dr. Frank Forrester Church, minister of the Unitarian Church of All Souls, performed the ceremony at the home of the bridegroom's parents, Mr. and Mrs. S. Henry Werner.

title: DELBELLO IS OPTIMISTIC AS 3D TERM BEGINS
description: THE past and the future will come together briefly for 47-year-old Alfred B. DelBello today when the Yonkers-born Democrat takes the oath of office for a third term as Westchester County Executive.

title: CHINA'S POLICY ON BIRTHS
description: Peking's rigid plan to control population growth conflicts sharply with the liberal economic policies it is pursuing in the countryside, where family planning has met renewed resistance from 800 million peasants now armed with greater economic rights.

title: FOOD STAMP PLAN COULD INCREASE RENTS FOR THE POOR
description: Federal housing officials want to count food stamps as part of the income of poor people, a step that would increase rents for most of the eight million people living in federally subsidized housing.

title: Virginia Regan To Become Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Nicholas Regan of New York, East Hampton, L.I., and Dublin have announced that their daughter, Virginia Regan, and John Bennett Coleman plan to marry at the end of this month.

title: The Tuberculosis Rate In Suffolk County
description: In the article on migrant workers on Dec. 20 (''For Migrant Workers, It's a Cycle of Grading and Waiting''), David Shapiro of the Eastern Farmworkers Association was reported to have asserted that Suffolk County had the highest rate of tuberculosis in the United States, largely because of its incidence among seasonal and migrant farm workers.

title: Elizabeth Crandall And James Barnes Engaged to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Wilson Crandall of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Alice Crandall, to James Douglas Barnes, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul McClung Barnes of Milwaukee.

title: Promoter to Consider Purchase of Rockies
description: Barry Fey, who promotes rock-music concerts, says he does not like hockey, but he will probably meet with the Colorado Rockies' owner, Peter Gilbert, next week to discuss entering a partners hip to buy the team.

title: HE GIVES CLUES TO THE 'REAL' HOLMES
description: ROSLYN HEIGHTS HE comes on stage wearing or carrying the props that foster the Sherlock Holmes myth: a deerstalker hat, an Inverness cape-coat, spats and a calabash pipe. Then, one by one, except for the spats, as his wife, Joyce Ann Liebman, plays suitable nickelodeon piano music, Dr. Arthur Liebman discards the symbols, moving through a kind of literary striptease that sets the tone for ''An Evening With Sherlock Holmes '' - wh ich, starting Wednesday in East Meadow, the team will per form at libraries throughout the Island this winter and next spring.

title: HOUSEHOLD SIZES CITED
description: HOW can there be more housing units in the eight Fairfield County towns covered by the South Western Regional Planning Agency when their total population declined by 8,000 in the last decade?

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We hate the news that comes out of Poland . I said, in front of Parliament at home, in a rather solemn declaration, that I am from the bottom of my heart on the side of the workers in Warsa w and in Silesia and in Gdansk.

title: SPECIAL CUISINE FOR SPECIAL TASTES
description: TO French, Italian, soul, fast and nouvelle has been added a category of cookery that might be called museum cuisine. A 184-page book with 500 recipes of dishes originally prepared for receptions at the William Benton Museum of Art at the University of Connecticut has just been published by the museum.

title: 3 ARTISANS CREATE ILLUSIONS AT FIN ISHING STUDIO
description: GREENWICH THREE artisans - Eileen Gillespie, Renee Wilson and Joan Kane - are producing furniture and objects of art that are not necessarily what they seem in the studio of their three-year-old business, The Painted Finish Ltd.

title: News Summary; SUNDAY, JANUARY 3, 1982
description: International Poland's military rulers dismissed 90 provincial administrative officials, according to a high-ranking member of the ruling military council, apparently because they were not effectively enforcing martial law. Provincial defense committees have been running the provinces since the imposition of military rule on Dec. 13. (Page 1, Column 6.)

title: THE LIFE OF MEYER LEVIN
description: THE ARCHITECT By Meyer Levin. 413 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $15.50. FOR Frank L loyd Wright, who is the subject of Meyer Levin's novel ''The Archite ct,'' the enemy was ''they,'' so designated as a matter of convenienc e; at one point in his autobiography, Wright drew up a partial list of the people afflicting him: reporters, cameramen, editors, immi gration officers, judges, federal officials, county officials, la wyers in Chicago, in Milwaukee, in Baraboo, Wis. Levin, who died this year, was similarly beset. He believed he was the victim of a c onspiracy of silence; that hostile, left-wing critics unfairly dism issed his work as ''too Jewish,'' as sentimental; that he was system atically persecuted and then ridiculed because he was persecuted, s ince his detractors, when he fought back, had a chance to make him o ut ''a complainer, a loser, a freak.'' He was caught in a maze.

title: De Soto in Tampa
description: To the Editor:

title: PERKINS GETS JOB DONE
description: W ITH the icy stare from his narrow blue eyes, he looks like a Marlboro Man or a gunslinger from a western movie. He is 40 years old, 6 feet tall, lean and tough, and television viewers go weeks without seeing him smile. But he is not always what he seems.

title: Ann Barkley Married To David P. Hickey
description: Ann Elyse Marie Barkley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Barkley of Yonkers, was married yesterday to David Patrick Hickey, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward F. Hickey of Boca Raton, Fla. Msgr. Daniel Flynn performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at Butl er Memorial Chapel at Marymount College in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: Music View; THE IMPACT OF THE AVANT-GARDE ON OPERA
description: Ever since World War I, avant-gardists have tended to dismiss opera with impatience. Opera seemed creatively extinct, appealing to a comfortably bourgeois audience that neither knew nor wanted to know of the radical innovations that were transforming the other arts. There were exceptions to this generalization, of course, both in the composition of an occasional important new opera and some strikingly original productions of the classics. But, for the most part, the avant-garde expressed itself in painting, theater, performance art, dance, even rock-and-roll more readily than in dear, dead old opera.

title: Marianne Christine Heilmann Bride Of David A. Wilkinson in Greenwich
description: Marianne Christine Heilmann, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John E. Heilmann of Greenwich, Conn., and Norwood, Va., was married in Greenwich yesterday to David Anthony Wilkinson, son of Mr. and Mrs. C.A. Wilkinson of London and Bodingham, Suffolk, England.

title: MORE AUTO THAN BIO
description: GEORGE MEANY AND HIS TIMES A Biography. By Archie Robinson. Illustrated. 445 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $18.75.

title: A NURSE CALLS FOR REVALUATION OF THE PROFESSION
description: LET US rejoice in the fact that nurses are finally standing up to be counted. They have remained the silent majority for too long a time.

title: Pauline Aberbach Married To Michael Marx, Lawyer
description: Pauline Aberbach, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Isidore Aberbach of Jamaica, Queens, was married at the Warwick Hotel yesterday to Michael Lee Marx, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jean-Paul Marx of Martinsville, N.J. Rabbi David Moseson performed the ceremony.

title: A VOICE HEARD ROUND THE WORLD
description: To the Editor:

title: Stage View; 'DREAMGIRLS': RICH DESSERT WITHOUT THE MAIN COURSE
description: Michael Bennett's ''Dreamgirls,'' the eagerly awaited new venture from the choreographer-director who fashioned ''A Chorus Line'' and ''Ballroom,'' may be the most restlessly impersonal musical I've ever come across. In charting the rise of a black singing group resembling The Supremes, Mr. Bennett has at his disposal a stageful of performers so technically accomplished that they can blast away on trumpets while twirling their knees counterclockwise until you're terrified they'll fly off. He has girls and to spare, each of them able not only to strip vocal gears somewhere between gospel and neopop but also to change costumes apparently by metamorphosis: you're looking at them in green and suddenly they're in dazzling white. He has 30 separate songs if I counted correctly, not including the dialogue in rhymed couplets that is sung in betweentimes. He has plexiglass towers that can ice-skate about the stage floor doing geometric arabesques, he can lower walkways from the heavens that look as though he'd inherited everything left over from the George Washington Bridge. And he doesn't trust any of it.

title: HONDURAS REPORTS 2 INCURSIONS BY NICARAGUA
description: Honduras said today that Nicaraguan troops crossed the border in the Mosquitia region on the Caribbean coast twice just after Christmas and killed more than 200 Nicaraguan refugees.

title: WESTFIELD GIRDS FOR THREE HOURS OF BACH
description: WESTFIELD A ''Nicholas Nickleby experience with Bach'' is the way Philip Dietterich, a choirmaster, characterizes the musical event he will be directing today at the First United Methodist Church in Westfield. The 80-voice Oratorio Choir, with soloists and a professional orchestra, will present Bach's ''Christmas Oratorio.''

title: Wendy Wood, Pro Golfer, Is Engaged
description: Announcement has been made by Landine Legendre Manigault of Stonington, Conn., and Peter Hodgson Wood of Cross River, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Wendy Legendre Wood, to Maurice W. Ver Brugge, son of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice A. Ver Brugge of San Francisco.

title: No Headline
description: Kentucky Tip-In Defeats Georgia, 68-66

title:
The Careful Shopper;
Fresh, Dried Flowers At Preserved Prices
description: Holiday decorations at Miss Plum's Particulars, ''The Old Fashioned Store,'' in Westport, Conn., are going fast now, at half-price until the shop closes Jan. 15 for two weeks. When it reopens Feb. 1, Miss Plum's will be ready for Valentine's Day. The constant weekend - and sometimes mid-week - bargain is the four fragrent, locally grown miniature roses for $2. Preservation of that $2 limit despite rising wholesale costs is a matter of principle for the owner, David Quigley.

title: CLEMSON HAS TOP RANKING IN FINAL POLLS
description: Clemson, which defeated Nebraska, 22-15, in the Orange Bowl Friday night to finish as the only undefeated and untied major team, was the unanimous No.1 selection yesterday in college football.

title: Leon Silverman Is On the Case
description: Leon Silverman, a New York City lawyer with a reputation as a tenacious investigator, will head an inquiry into the conduct of Raymond J. Donovan, the New Jersey contractor who became Secretary of Labor.

title: 49ers on Defense
description: No. 21, Eric Wright, rcb, 6 foot 1 inch, 180 pounds; Missouri; rookie; One of three rookies in secondary. No. 22, Dwight Hicks, fs, 6-1, 189; Michigan; 3d year; Pro Bowl selection, who has nine interceptions. No. 27, Carlton Williamson, ss, 6-0, 204; Pittsburgh; rookie; Fierce tackler and intense player with speed to spare. No. 42, Ronnie Lott, lcb, 6-0, 199; Southern California; rookie; Instinctive hitter who makes big plays. Pro Bowl choice. No. 58, Keena Turner, rolb, 6-2, 219; Purdue; 2d year; Quick and getting smarter all the time. Good at turnovers. No. 54, Craig Puki, rilb, 6-1, 231; Tennessee; 2d year; Superior athlete in his first year as a starter. No. 64, Jack Reynolds, lilb, 6-1, 232; Tennessee; 12th year; Hard work and thorough preparation set an example for the youngsters surrounding him.

title:
Comment;
WHY P.R. GETS FLAK
description: T IME magazine reported not long ago that Jorge Batista, the son of Cuba's late dictator who currently attends modeling school and works as a runway model at fashion shows, would like to rule the island one day. Failing that, he says, ''perhaps I can do public relations.'' And, if experience is any indicator, he probably will. Do public relations, that is.

title: Buffalo School Budget Given
description: The Superintendent of Schools announced a 1982-83 budget proposal yesterday that would raise spending by $19 million over the current school year.

title: JERSEY OFFICER HURT IN SHOOTOUT AT HOLLAND TUNNEL
description: A Jersey City police officer was shot yesterday in an exchange of gunfire with one of three occupants of a car the officer and his partner had stopped outside the Holland Tunnel, according to the Jersey City police. One of the men in the car was wounded.

title: f Around the Nation; Coal Mine Death Toll Is 20 Higher Than in '80
description: The death toll in coal mines increased in 1981, with 20 more miners killed in accidents than in the previous year, according to the Federal Mine Health and Safety Administration. Kentucky reported the most deaths.

title: 'SINCE I'M THE WORRYING TYPE...'
description: IDON'T know whether to be more upset about the haphazard industrial poisoning of our environment or about the steady, ominous nuclear-arms buildup in the world.

title: Reading and Writing; THE COST OF BEING FUNNY
description: How do they do it? I wondered, after reading Art Buchwald's new collection, ''Laid Back in Washington,'' and a reissue of Russell Baker's ''Poor Russell's Almanac.'' How can they be so consistently funny week after week, year after year? How had S.J. Perelman done it for 50 years?

title: Critics' Choices
description: ART Not much was made in New York City of the centenary of Fernand Leger, who was born in 1881 and died in 1955. In fact the centenary passed by quietly all over the country, and we have to wait till the 16th of this month for the major retrospective that is due at the Albright-Knox Art Gallery in Buffalo.

title: Around the Nation; Tanker Accident Halts Florida Keys Traffic
description: A gasoline tanker overturned and spilled its contents on the Overseas Highway today, halting traffic on the only link between the Florida mainland and Key West and creating a traffic jam six miles long, the Highway Patrol said.

title: SOME TIMELY COUNSEL FOR THE NEW MAYORS
description: THE recently elected mayors in Connecticut will face a host of problems. From my perspective as a re-elected council member, I offer the following for the purpose of analysis and resolution: The first issue facing municipal chief executives is the political context of the times. Citizens want services maintained and they want reduced taxes. As an article in this section noted last summer, the frustration of attempting to meet this contradiction in voter demand led many mayors and first selectmen not to seek re-election. This situation is compounded by another set of factors.

title: City Council Sessions To Be Held This Week
description: The following City Council meetings are scheduled for this week at City Hall: MONDAY and TUESDAY - Maps of the newly proposed Council districts will be on display for the public from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. in the Council chamber.

title: REBELS CUT POWER IN EL SALVADOR
description: Rebel bombings of electrical installations caused a two-hour blackout in El Salvador on New Year's Day. The coordinated rebel attacks began just after midnight Thursday and temporarily cut electricity to San Salvador and most major cities.

title: '82 CANDIDATES RUN ON EXPERT ADVICE
description: WHATEVER else it may hold for Connecticut residents, 1982 almost certainly will produce political advertising and candidate spending on levels unseen in the state's election history.

title: Hunter Killed by Own Rifle
description: A Greene County man accidentally shot himself to death with his own rifle while on a hunting trip, the state police reported. Troopers said the man, Robert McGuire, 31 years old, of Oak Hill, N.Y., had been climbing over a tall barbedwire fence on Friday and bracing himself with his .308-caliber semiautomatic rifle. Mr. McGuire apparently slipped on a rock, troopers said, and the gun fired a shot, which hit him in the chest.

title: WINTER STORMS MAY IMPERIL SANDY HOOK BATHING AREAS
description: WHETHER the 1.5 million people who usually visit the beaches at Sandy Hook during the summer can do so this year will depend on how rough the winter storms are. The Atlantic Ocean is slowly eating away at the peninsula's only link with the mainland, a tiny stretch of sand 100 yards wide and 400 yards long that motorists use to get to the beaches.

title: SHOOTING 'SIX WEEKS' IN SEVEN
description: Tantrums, ego trips and trauma would have made perfect sense. After all, ''Six Weeks'' is only the second feature that Tony Bill, the 41-year-old co-producer of ''The Sting'' and ''Taxi Driver,'' has ever directed. His leads are two of the most sought-after stars working today - Mary Tyler Moore and Dudley Moore. And the new film follows on the heels of what were for both actors personal screen triumphs - ''Ordinary People'' for Miss Moore and ''Arthur'' for Mister.

title: POLISH EX-ENVOY TO JAPAN TELLS WHY HE DEFECTED
description: Zdzislaw Rurarz, the Polish Ambassador to Japan who defected last week, says he and ''most of the people in Poland'' have grown disillusioned with Communism.

title: No Headline
description: Mrs. Moynihan's article might have mentioned one important group, employed by senators and representatives in sorting, screening a nd answering Congressional mail: college interns . Both houses of Congress maintain an active internship progra m, and college students who have worked on Capitol Hill will tell you that they have opened, sorted and answered many a letter. ANDREA ATKINS, Emerson, N.J.

title:
Gardening;
SOME GARDENING RESOLUTIONS FOR 1982
description: WITH the New Year comes the time to declare one's good intentions and make resolutions. May we suggest a few for the 1982 gardening season?

title: Long Island Journal
description: GOVERNOR CAREY has ordered state officials to proceed with the transfer to Suffolk County of 616 acres of state land around Edgewood State Hospital. The property is part of the Island's 1,400 remaining acres of ecologically unique oak brush plains, which once covered 60,000 acres extending eastward from the Hempstead plains.

title: Maryland Crabs
description: To the Editor:

title: Sports of The Times; Riding the Quarterback Seesaw
description: FOR about half an hour, Scott Brunner had been sitting at his locker, talking about his role in the Giants' ascent into today's game here against the 49ers in the Super Bowl playoffs. As the tall quarterback with the dark curly hair spoke, every so often the Giants' other quarterback, Phil Simms, hovered momentarily around his adjacent locker, but then Simms would walk off to the trainer's room or the equipment room. Anywhere but there.

title: Renton Sled Winner
description: Bill Renton piloted his United States Navy sled to the fastest first-heat time today, en route to a half-second lead in the national Amateur Athletic Union four-man bobsled championship. His times were 1 minute 01.45 seconds and 1:01.83, for a combined 2:03.28.

title: zf Bullets Defeat Pacers
description: Greg Ballard scored 21 of his 23 points in the second half to help the Washington Bullets defeat the Indiana Pacers, 107-103, tonight. The victory was the fourth in their last five games for the Bullets.

title: REAGANOMICS: THE REPORT CARD FOR 1981, AND THE PROSPECTS
description: As he outlined his economic program early last year, President Reagan declared that the United States could have it all, and with relatively little pain: fatter military budgets and big tax cuts; a tight monetary policy and strong growth in the economy, a balanced budget by 1984 and a rapid decline in inflation and a reduction in unemployment.

title: Westchester Guide; 'RAGTIME' EXHIBIT
description: While treading the brick streets of downtown New Rochelle, it is not too difficult to conjure up the ''Ragtime'' days, when the city was 45 minutes from George M. Cohan's Broadway, the seven little Foys cavorted in their Weyman Avenue backyard, and characters such as those invented by the novelist E.L. Doctorow were entirely possible.

title: OTHERS' BURDENS MOTIVATE DONORS TO NEEDIEST
description: ''These days, which are full of joy for many of us, are full of sadness and loneliness and burdens beyond bearing for many others,'' wrote Dr. Marjorie Lewisohn of Manhattan in a note accompanying a donation of $150 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title:
Numismatic;
COIN 'BURIAL GROUND'
description: From a coin's point of view, numismatics represents a kind of survival of the fittest: only the most desirable specimens are being saved as collector's items. The rest remain in use as circulating change until, at length, they have to be retired. At that point, many find their way to a fortress-like building in Lower Manhattan - the New York Assay Office. It serves, in a sense, as Uncle Sam's coin burial ground.

title: NEW LEGAL AID BOARD SETS CEILING ON SPENDING BY GRANT RECIPIENTS
description: The new majority appointed by President Reagan to the board of the Legal Services Corporation convened an unscheduled meeting Thursday to notify grant recipients of the effect of Congressionally mandated spending reductions for January. Another meeting is planned this month on policy for the rest of the year.

title: COWBOYS ROMP; BENIRSCHKE KICK GIVES SAN DIEGO 41-38 DECISION
description: At the end of the wildest, highest scoring playoff game in National Football League history, Kellen Winslow of the San Diego Chargers looked more like a boxer at the end of a fight.

title:
Stamps;
U.S. MAKES ANOTHER TRY AT SHOWING WILDLIFE
description: The United States, attempting again to put out a wildlife stamp booklet in which an animal looks like an animal and not a blob, is issuing a new booklet picturing the Bighorn Sheep this Friday.

title: Banker Engaged To C. V. Jackson
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Schwartzstein of Trenton have announced the engagement of their daughter, Frances Miriam Schwartzstein, to Charles Vivian Jackson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis C. Jackson of Cults, Aberdeenshire, Scotland.

title:
Camera;
PHOTOGRAPHY CLUBS OFFER MANY BENEFITS
REAGAN CUT TAXES, NOW HE PONDERS RAISING THEM
description: WASHINGTON W ITHIN the next fortnight or so, President Reagan must put the finishing touches to his budget for 1983. The spending decisions have been made. Still undecided is an issue that has been dividing the Administration and bedeviling the President - whether to ask Congress for tax increases and, if so, which ones.

title: RANGERS DEFEAT CANADIENS, 6-5, AT FORUM
description: Don Maloney scored early and late against the Mo ntreal Canadiens at the Forum tonight, and between his efforts, four other Rangers scored.

title: AN ENGLISH TOWN BUILT ON FEET
description: STANLEY CARR is assistant to the editor of the Travel section. By STANLEY CARR

title: Ellen L. Knobloch Is Married to Charles Steinmetz
description: Ellen Louise Knobloch, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William R. Knobloch of Stamford, Conn., was married there yesterday to Charles William Steinmetz, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Steinmetz of Rancho Palos Verdes, Calif. The ceremony was performed in the First Presbyterian Church by Rev. Ronald James.

title: PITT'S VICTORY A TRIBUTE TO MARINO'S POISE
description: ''I guess the first thing to talk about is the last thing, which was the only thing,'' said Coach Vince Dooley of Georgia today on the morning after his team's last-minute loss to Pittsburgh in the 48th annual Sugar Bowl game.

title: COUPLE ARE KILLED BY HIT-AND-RUN DRIVER IN BRONX
description: A 65-year-old Bronx man and his wife were struck and killed by a hit-and-run driver near dawn yesterday as they crossed Pelham Parkway at Williamsbridge Road in the Wakefield section of the borough.

title: MUSINGS ABOUT LIFE NEAR THE AGRICULTURAL SCHOOL
description: ''HOGS and cows are fine in the A.& P., but to have them actually grunting and mooing in the immediate neighborhood is too much,'' my friend said over the telephone. ''Return to Dartmouth immediately. You could be our displaced cultivated person in residence.''

title: Dining Out; CHINESE, WITH SOME SURPRISES
description: GREENWICH ESTHETICALLY pleasing decor and good food are not always synonymous in Chinese restaurants. In fact, attractive surroundings are often a secondary consideration at some of the very best.

title: OUTSIDE MEDICAID AND LOOKING IN
description: NOT long ago we were a fairly typical Westchester family. Two boys in high school, my wife starting a midlife career and I commuting to the city. Then one night the phone rang, and we learned that my mother had a year to live. Bone cancer, said the doctor's voice from Arizona.

title: CALIFORNIA'S POOR FACE UPHILL FIGHTS
description: Larry Garrett is black and newly unemployed, the breadwinner for a family that includes two small daughters. Elsie Marshall is white and on Social Security; she and her husband are too old now to earn an income.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Hypnotic Power
description: Many a college teacher has put students to sleep by lecturing. Arlie Lincks did it by hypnosis and almost lost his teaching job at Manatee Junior College in Bradenton, Fla.

title: Mercedes: Fun and Prestige
description: THE attendant was aghast. ''How much?'' he asked again, pouring gallon after gallon of unleaded regular into the newest Mercedes. I told him $49,827, and he shook his head. ''Man,'' he said, ''that's an awful lot of money.'' It is indeed. It would buy a small house. It would buy a Honda for each day of the week. It might even buy enough Big Macs to last a gaggle of teen-agers for life.

title: Chess; DELAY CAN BE DANGEROUS
description: To allow the opponent to set up a cramping pawn center and to be a step late in counterattacking it is likely to make you right on time for your funeral.

title: Woman, 33, and Daughter, 15, Found Slain in Meriden Home
description: A 33-year-old woman and her 15-yearold daughter were found fatally stabbed in their home here today, the police said.

title: Environews
description: THE Johns-Manville Company of Manville, the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company and several Canadian concerns have agreed to pay a total of $15.5 million to 683 former employees of the defunct Raybestos-Manhattan Company of Passaic for medical disabilities related to working with asbestos.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; A Hard Landing For Art Dealers
description: For those who transport art from country to country, things are getting tough all over. The United States Customs Service has tried to prosecute importers of artifacts claimed by other countries as part of their cultural heritage.

title: ALL 4 ARE SAFE
description: Rescue teams today reached a local television news helicopter that was forced down on New Year's Day in a blinding snowstorm near the Continental Divide.

title: REGIME IN POLAND OUSTS 90 OFFICIALS IN THE PROVINCES
description: Poland's military regime has removed 90 provincial and city officials, according to a senior staff member of the country's ruling military council.

title: Correction
description: Because of wrong information supplied by Arthur Anderson & Company, the value of a 10-year charitable lead trust that provides a charity with income of $8,000 a year from the securities funding the trust was incorrectly stated in ''A Way to Give a Lot, for Less'' (Dec. 20). The value of that gift today is $58,880, and would have reduced 1981 taxes for someone in the 70 percent bracket by $41,206.

title: Rev. Julia Fuller Wed To Rev. Eric K. Renz
description: The Rev. Julia Ann Fuller, pastor of the Church of the Eternal Hills in Granby, Colo., was married yesterday in the First Presbyterian Church in Englewood, N.J., to the Rev. Eric Kendall Renz, pastor of the First Presbyterian Church in Frankfort, Kan. The Rev. Harry E. Chase, of Tenafly, N.J., performed the ceremony.

title: Antonia Dupont, Editor, Married
description: Antonia Chafee Dupont, editor of the small-magazine section of Seventeen magazine, was married yesterday to Peter Nicholaas Roelof van der Meer, who is with the specia l loan de partment at the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company. The ceremony was perf ormed in Our Lady Chapel of St. Patrick's Cathedral by the Rev. Marcellus Liotta, associate pastor of St. John's Roman Catholic Church in Middletown, Conn.

title: Ohioan Sues Hospital Over Wife's Respirator
description: An Akron man has filed a $2.3 million lawsuit against a local hospital and doctor for refusing his terminally ill wife's wishes to be disconnected from life supports, it was disclosed Tuesday.

title: ATLANTA'S CALM AS MURDER TRIAL UNFOLDS REFLECTS CIVIL RIGHTS CHANGES IN SOUTH
description: Two and a half decades ago, in a small town in Mississippi, a black teen-ager from Chicago, who was visiting relatives, whistled at a white woman and was later abducted at gunpoint by two white men. Several days later the boy's body was found in a river, a bullet in his skull.

title: Carrots and Sticks in Warsaw And the West
description: The next few weeks could well decide whether Poland's martial law gamble will bring angry workers to heel and perhaps allow for some relaxation of controls - or lead to even harsher repression. For the West, the question last week was how to push the Polish regime toward relaxation. As often with East-West issues, there was little agreement.

title: Around the World; Friends of Dozier Offer Reward for His Release
description: Friends of Brig. Gen. James L. Dozier, who was kidnapped by the Red Brigades terrorist organization last month, have set up a reward fund of $1.6 million for information leading to the release of the American officer, a NATO spokesman said today.

title: The World in Summary; Assad, the Fixer-Upper
description: Syria's President Hafez al-Assad is trying to transform himself from a spoiler into a healer. Returning from a tour of Persian Gulf oil states during which he patched up relations with Saudi Arabia, the Syrian leader last week received a delegation from Teheran and offered to mediate Iran's 15-month war with Iraq.

title: Laurie Curran Is Married To Robert W. Hernandez
description: Laurie Ellen Curran, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond L. Curran of Whittier, Calif., was married there yesterday at the United Methodist Church to Robert Washburn Hernandez, son of Mr. and Mrs. Silvio E. Hernandez of Essex, Conn., formerly of Havana. The Rev. Dr. Lee Truman performed the ceremony.

title: BISHOP IN WASHINGTON NAMED BY POPE FOR A LOUISVILLE POST
description: Pope John Paul II has named Bishop Thomas Kelly, general secretary of the National Conference of Catholic Bishops and the United States Catholic Conference, to be the new Archbishop of Louisville, Ky.

title: DESIGNING AN EMPIRE
description: John Duka is a reporter for the Style section of The New York Times. By John Duka

title: The World in Summary; Rawlings Redux In Ghana
description: Ghana's military officers have been itching to get back into the presidential castle ever since international pressure cut short the 90-day rule of Flight Lieut. Jerry J. Rawlings in 1979.

title: THE PICTURES OF THE POET
description: THE PAINTINGS AND DRAWINGS OF WILLIAM BLAKE By Martin Butlin. Vol. I, Text. Vol. II, Plates. 1,408 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $300. By HAROLD BLOOM

title: Headliners; Family Affair
description: When the American public last heard of 14-year-old Walter Polovchak - the boy who ran away from his parents rather than return with them to the Ukraine - he had been granted asylum in the United States and was a ward of the Cook County Juvenile Court.

title: Texas Man Is Charged In Drugging of Coffee
description: A 24-year-old man has been charged with eight counts of aggravated assault in the drugging of 10 workers at a factory where he once worked.

title: A SON RECOLLECTS HOAGY CARMICHAEL
description: ''DAD'S life was a very long corridor, at the end of which was his music'' Hoagy Carmichael Jr. observed last week when he returned to his home in Bedford after the death of his father, the songwriter, in California. ''Along that corridor there were a number of doors andwe were in one of them. He looked in on us fr om time to time. But he was not so driven that he didn't treat us wit h a lot of kindness. He spent time with us,'' said the son. ''Dad was a very private person who loved center stage.''

title: DARWIN AND THE RABBI
description: To the Editor:

title: ASSESSMENTS MUDDLED DESPITE NEW LAW
description: IT wasn't the kind of reading matter that most people take on vacation, nothing like an engrossing mystery or an escapist romance. Henrietta Acampora, the new Supervisor of Brookhaven, recently lay on the beach in Florida and soaked up, along with the sunshine, the dry facts and figures of a report called ''Property Tax Inequity: A Study of Residential Property Tax Assessments in the Town of Brookhaven.''

title: 45 FOOD ESTABLISHMENTS CITED
description: The New York City Department of Health has released the names of 45 food establishments that it said were in violation of the Health Code.

title: GIANTS NEED EDGE ON FIRST DOWN
description: Instead of being home for the holidays, as almost everyone thought they would be, the Giants will play the 49ers at 2 P.M. (5 P.M., New York time) Sunday in the semifinals of the National Football Conference playoffs. What do they have to do to win this game from a team that beat them, 17-10, in a regular-season matchup here Nov. 29?

title: No Headline
description: Hawks Defeat Nets by 97-95

title: MOVIES INSPIRE TWO NEW ALBUMS
description: Pop and jazz musicians are not overly fond of the categories critics use to separate and label them. Categories are generalizations that often have little real content, and in some cases they do harm by creating cultural ghettos. Call a man a ''jazz'' musician, for example, and you may be saddling him with second-class citizenship (he is not ''classical'') while questioning his moneymaking potential (he is not ''pop'').

title: New York Times Magazine January 3, 1982
description: William Safire 6 On Language Double-A Rating Russell Baker 10 Sunday Observer Congress's Stepchild Jeremy Bernstein 14 Recreating the Power of the Sun Robin Herman 18 Europe's Icemen Cometh John Duka 20 The Designing of an Empire Craig Claiborne 37 Food with Pierre Franey Rolling in Dough Marilyn Bethany 38 Design Anything Goes Carrie Donovan 40 Fashion/Beauty Are Hats Taking Off? 44 Puzzles Answers, Page 45 54 Letters Cover:A color-enhanced Skylab photograph of the sun. Courtesy of NASA. Copyright 1980, The New York Times

title: Until Tanks Can Milk Cows
description: ''I lived through '56 and '68 and '70 and '76,'' said an unnamed Polish Communist in Warsaw last week, ''but this one was different. We had a year and a half to create something unique and beautiful. This time I thought there's really a chance to reform socialism, to change it, to make it just and make it work.

title: On Language
description: By William Safire Double-A Rating

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Muscle Therapy For Some MDs
description: If doctors and other health professionals think their medical degrees are licenses to default on student loans, they better think again, Richard S. Schweiker, Secretary of Health and Human Services, warned last week. ''We owe it to future health professions students to stop the widespread delinquency in loan payments,'' he said.

title: SHERIFF RUNS HIS JAIL ON HONOR SYSTEM
description: Sheriff Lloyd Boston spent a recent night catnapping at a hospital in nearby Parkersburg, keeping an eye on the grizzled old man who was his prisoner.

title: Antiques View; THE COLLECTIBLES MARKET IN DECLINE
description: Collectibles - objects acquired as if they were antiques but are not old enough to qualify as such - are no longer viewed as glamourous investments. Over the last year the recession and soaring interest rates have taken their toll on the collectibles market and its nostalgia-type objects - vintage tin toys, steam engines, dolls, buttons, baseball cards, postcards, Mickey Mouse objects, mechanical banks, coins, stamps, ephemera, music boxes, phonographs, typewriters, cash registers, jukeboxes, coin-operated machines - virtually anything produced in the 20th century that we identify with as the objects we cared about in childhood.

title: WHY THE SCHOOLS ARE FAILING
description: IT IS not my intent to defend American teachers. I am disappointed enough with my own classroom failures to have as many complaints as any parent, taxpayer, school superintendent or journalist. But recent articles on why public schools are flunking deserve one response that is pointed, shrill and full. This is it.

title: CONCERT: 'AMHAL' SUNG BY HARLEM BOYS CHOIR
description: Thirty years ago this Christmas Eve, Gian-Carlo Menotti's ''Amahl and the Night Visitors'' had its world premiere on American television, the first opera written expressly for the fledgling medium. In countless stage performances sin ce , it has become almost as much of a Christmas fixture as ''The Nutcr acker'' - hardly surprising for a piece that combines, in sure -fire fashion, a simple tale, a small cast and an easily performable vocal and instrumental score.

title: The World in Summary; A Timetable For Democracy
description: Even when military men seize power reluctantly, they seem to be equally reluctant to give it up. Last week, under pressure from European allies and internal critics, Turkey's junta promised to step down and restore democratic government - in two or three years.

title: Social Security Check Loses Its Green Back
description: The 36 million Social Security payments for January that were sent out this week are checks of a different color.

title: SPLIT AMONG ALLIES RUNS DEEPER THAN SANCTIONS
description: LONDON A British radio commentator, discussing President Reagan's announcement of sanctions against the Soviet Union because of repression in Poland, expressed some sympathy but added that, of course, ''we'' have a more subtle approach to the situation.

title: SCHMIDT VOICING GREATER CONCERN OVER ECONOMY THAN OVER POLAND
description: Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany is ap parently more concerned that the world could drift into an economic d epression than into war over Poland or the Middle East.

title: VISITORS TO PRISON SAY JEAN HARRIS HAS ADJUSTED WELL
description: WHEN Jean S. Harris entered the Bedfo rd Hills Correctional Facilityon March 20 s he was a terrified woman facing a minimum sentence of 15years for mur der. It had taken four female guards to hold her down for handcuffi ng the day before she was sentenced, and she was moving from the Coun ty Jail to the more severe incarceration of a state prison.

title: Topics; TERMS AND TEAMS; Resolve in Turkey
description: Turkey's ruling generals have at last named a time for a return to democracy. General elections are to be held no sooner than the fall of 1983, no later than the spring of 1984 - barring international complications, or failure to agree on a new constitution.

title: Allison Kezer Engaged To Leighton Lobdell
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard F. Kezer of Shrewsbury , N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Allison Tay lor Kezer, to Leighton Danforth Lobdell, son of Phyllis S. Lobdell o f Rumson, N.J., and Leighton M. Lobdell of Highlands, N.J.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; But They Know What They Like
description: Contrary to popular opinion, neither artistry nor the ability to appreciate it is usually inborn; they must be taught. That is precisely what the nation's elementary and secondary schools are not doing, according to art and music test results made public last week by the Na tion al Assessment of Educational Progress, a Federal programwhich monitor s schools.

title: The Region in Summary; No New Chance For Jean Harris
description: Though a trial be less than just perfect, it may still be perfectly just, the New York State Supreme Court suggested last week in rejecting Jean S. Harris's bid to be retried for the murder of her lover, Herman Tarnower.

title: January 3,1982
description: NONFICTION CHINA'S INTELLECTUALS: Advise and Dissent. By Merle Goldman. 7 EVERY SECRET THING. By Patricia Campbell Hearst, with Alvin Moscow. 3 GEORGE MEANY AND HIS TIMES: A Biography.

title: A MAJOR SOVIET GEOPHYSICIST
description: Yevgeny K. Fedorov, one of the Soviet Union's leading geophysicists, died Wednesday, Tass, the official press agency, reported today. He was 71 years old.

title: VACANT MANSION AWAITS NEW GOVERNOR ON COAST
description: After six years, California's $1.3 million Governor's mansion still has no official tenant and the grounds are host nightly to distinctly unofficial visitors: raccoons,foxes, skunks , even a possum.

title: Paperback Best Sellers; MASS MARKET
description: Mass-market paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States. 1THE SIMPLE SOLUTION TO RUBIK'S CUBE, by Ja mes G. Nourse. (Bantam, $1.95.) How-to. 2ANSWER AS A MAN, by Taylor Caldwell. (Fawc ett, $3.95.) A self-mademan struggles against the corruption engulfin g his life: fiction. 3NEVADA! by Dana Fuller Ross. (Bantam, $3.5 0.) Virginia City duringthe Civil War: fiction. 4FREE FALL IN CRIMSON, by John D. MacDonald . (Fawcett, $2.95.) Travis McGee on the trail of a murderer: fict ion. 5SHADOWLAND, by Peter Straub. (Berkley, $3. 50.) Two friends try to learn the secrets of a horror house in the Ve rmont woods: fiction. 6BUCKSKIN RUN, by Louis L'Amour. (Bantam, $ 2.25.) Eight short stories about the Old West. 7PASTORA, by Joanna Barnes. (Avon, $3.50.) A woman's progress to the heights of San Francisco society: histori cal romance. 8THE TRIBE, by Bari Wood. (NAL/Signet, $3.5 0.) Horror and mysticismin a Nazi concentration camp and present-day Brooklyn: fiction. 9THE LAST MAFIOSO, by Ovid Demaris. (Bantam , $3.95.) Secrets of theMafia. 10THE FRENCH LIEUTENANT'S WOMAN, by John Fo wles.

title: The Nation in Summary; Army Cleared In LSD Trial
description: Calvin Sweet, a former soldier, claimed that Washington owed him $3.9 million because in 1957 he had been required to participate unknowingly in Army LSD experiments that had left him mentally ill - afflicted with ''paranoia, schizophrenia and chronic depression'' - and unemployable.

title: No Headline
description: This Week:

title: The Region in Summary; Connecticut Frees Spirits
description: It may not be Connecticut's proudest distinction, but the state is nevertheless notable for having, in proportion to its population, twice as many liquor stores as neighboring New York and Massachusetts. That is expected to change as a result of a liquor decontrol law that went into effect last week.

title: THE JOYS OF A ONE-CAR LIFE
description: IT'S been nearly a year since our son, Jason, tied our brand new Buick 'round the old oak tree. Jason and the tree came out of it relatively unscathed. The Buick was totaled. The incident left us shaken. It also left us with just one car. One car for a family of five suburban activists. Our immediate impulse was to rush off to some distressed showroom and quickly buy a replacement car. And we almost did just that. But as we were considering our various vehicular options, ranging in Prestige Quotient from a Mercedes to a Moped, my wife and I experienced a moment of extraordinary lucidity.

title: Watford and Wrexham Gain in English Cup
description: Watford beat Manchester United, 1-0, and Wrexham downed Nottingham Forest, 3-1, today as Second Division teams scored upsets in the third round of the English Cup soccer competition.

title: Ceramco Paces Round-the-World Sail
description: Ceramco New Zealand holds a slight lead over Euromarche in the 6,030-mile third leg - from Auckland, New Zealand, to Mar del Plata, Argentina - of the Whitbread round-the-world race, according to the latest position reports.

title: CONSUMER RATES
description: * Rates restricted by state usury laws

title: Westchester Journal
description: THE industrial liquid waste removal company that was assigned the task of cleaning up the oil spill in the Croton watershed last week has been in the business since 1968. That was when laws were enacted to require the spillers to pay for the cleanups, according to John Brown, a partner of the company, Hitchcock Oil Pollution Systems of Bridgeport, Conn.

title: The Region in Summary; Governor Carey's Campaign Style For Hard Times
description: Though there will be an election next year, Governor Carey seems destined to face it withou t an ''election-year'' budget loaded with the usual goo dies. Instead, his aides worried last week about how to fill what cou ld be a deficit of hundreds of millions of dollars in the fiscal ye ar beginning in April.

title: U.S. AIDES SUSPECT ALBANIAN PREMIER WAS KILLED
description: United States Government officials believe that Albania's Prime Minister was killed last month and did not commit suicide, as the Albanian radio asserted at the time.

title: STUDY HAILS A YOUTH PROGRAM PERILED BY U.S. BUDGET CUTS
description: A job training program that is susceptible to Reagan Administration budget cuts has been highly successful in finding employment for teen-agers, according to the preliminary findings of a research study.

title: No Headline
description: Fire destroyed 170 coffins at a funeral home today in what the police said was part of a war between rival undertakers in this Sardinian capital. Investigators said it was the second fire attack in three days on the funeral home owned by Mario Ligas, who had been threatened by his rivals for cutting his prices.

title:
Antiques;
REMINDERS OF WHEN A WOMAN'S WORK WAS NEVER DONE
description: IN the average Colonial Connecticut home, the parlor was a room rarely used except when entertaining. Chambers or bedrooms were places in which to sleep and to store articles not in seasonal use. Few homes knew the luxury of a separate room for dining. Only the very wealthy could afford to build larger houses with additional rooms for other specific uses.

title: The Nation in Summary; Few Atlantans Ready to Sit In Judgment
description: For nearly two years, Atlantans wondered who was killing the city's young people and why. Last week, as Wayne B. Williams stood trial in two of the 28 murders, it seemed hard to find enough Atlantans willing or able to serve on a jury that might decide the answers.

title: Editors' Choice
description: Hill, $22.95.) The most complete study of Pearl Harbor, laying to rest the theory that we were railroaded into war.

title: NEW YORK TO MONTAUK, EH?
description: ''BUT who would want to go to Riverhead?'' asked Stanton. Lincoln grew impatient. The Secretary of War had raised one objection after another. To Lincoln, a railroad on Long Island was vital to recovery from the Civil War.

title:
Gardening;
SOME GARDENING RESOLUTIONS FOR 1982
description: WITH the New Year comes the time to declare one's good intentions and make resolutions. May we suggest a few for the 1982 gardening season?

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: BILL MOYERS- 'THE TRICK IS TO MAKE TV WORK FOR YOU'
description: In the six weeks since he moved - for the second time in his career - from public television to CBS News, Bill Moyers has delivered a dozen commentaries for the morning and evening news on subjects ranging from the situation in Poland to Christmas books; completed an hour-long documentary on Vietnam veterans and begun another, about the underclass in the Reagan era; reported a five-and-a-half-minute story for the evening news about political maneuvering on an Alaskan pipeline bill, which inspired several hundred letters of praise, and interviewed Saul Bellow for a lengthy profile that appeared on CBS's ''Sunday Morning.'' In his spare moments, he has found time to promote one of the most intellectually ambitious television projects in many years: a 17-part series titled ''Creativity With Bill Moyers,'' that begins this Friday on public television (WNET/Channel 13 at 9:00 P.M.) with a profile of the poet Maya Angelou.

title: Children's Books
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Susan Bolotin is an editor of The New York Times Book Review. By SUSAN BOLOTIN Parents use d to breathe easy when a child received a book as a gift; at leas t they would be spared the agony of missing or mislabeled pa rts and misleading instructions. But some books are now so complicate d that their title pages (if, in fact, they look enough like books to have title pages) read like announcements for Academy Award nominat ions in special effects.

title: IT'S TIME FOR IMMIGRATION LAW REFORM--OR IS IT?
description: Despite the sporadic, intense focus on specific groups of foreigners who seek the American dream - Hungarians, Mexicans, ''boat people,'' and now Haitians - the historical record suggests that only once in a generation does Congress deal comprehensively with the issue of immigration. The last sweeping revision, the McCarran-Walter Act, was passed in 1952 and many of its provisions are still on the books. The Reagan Administration thus had every reason to hope for the best when it proposed ''omnibus'' legislation designed to control the flow of aliens across the nation's borders.

title: The World in Summary; Begin Reaffirms Sinai Withdrawal Despite Protests
description: One reason Israel suddenly annexed the formerly Syrian Golan Heights last month may have been to blunt domestic opposition to returning the rest of Sinai to Egypt on April 26. But many Sinai settlers under orders to clear out by March 31 were not appeased.

title: FOR LIBRARY REFERENCE STAFF, IT'S A QUESTION OF ANSWERS
description: In a nearly silent office, surrounded by 1,500 volumes of almanacs, indexes and other reference materials, employees of the New York Public Library's telephone reference service spend their working hours answering obscure questions.

title: Cup Skiing Canceled
description: The World Cup women's giant slalom scheduled for Monday has been canceled because of lack of snow, organizers said today. Sunday's slalom for women will take place as scheduled.

title: WIDE APPEAL FOR 'ACCESSORY APARTMENTS'
description: Contrary to predictions by many professionals in the housing field, the homeowners who have created accessory apartments inside their single-family houses are not necessarily ''empty nesters,'' a planning consultant reports.

title: DR. WILLIAM STUBENBORD
description: Dr. William D. Stubenbord, who practiced internal medicine in New York City for nearly 50 years, died Friday at his home in Manhattan. He was 76 years old.

title: China
description: To the Editor:

title: A NEW OWNER TAKES THE REINS IN TIMES SQUARE
description: When Lawrence I. Linksman assembled a small group of investors last July to buy the former Times Tower, known as One Times Square, he did not anticipate the avalanche of publicity that seems to come with the building. He says that if he had known, ''I would have hired an agent instead of an architect.''

title: OCEAN LAB SALE IS TOPIC OF TALKS
description: NEGOTIATIONS for the sale of the New York Ocean Science Laboratory property in Montauk to a Southampton businessman are under way, according to John McGowan, lawyer for the laboratory.

title: Essay; THE KREMLIN PIPELINE
description: The United States has finally shown its willingness to step out in front of the Western alliance in reaction to the Sovietordered suppression of the glimmerings of freedom in Poland.

title: STUDY SHOWS DRUG MAY FIGHT ANGINA
description: A drug that is new to this country, verapamil, alleviated the symptoms of angina more often and effectively than propranolol, the drug most widely prescribed for this common form of heart disease, according to a report in the current issue of the medical journal Circulation.

title: JULENE RUPP AFFIANCED TO THOMAS T. DASHER
description: Mr. and Mrs. James M. Rupp of Minnetonka, Minn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Julene Adell Rupp, to Thomas Thomson Dasher, son of Dr. and Mrs. George F. Dasher of Inverness, Ill.

title: Mailbox; Football Scoring Proposals
description: To the Sports Editor: Cliff Montgomery is the latest to recommend that the number of points earned by a field goal be determined by the distance of the kick (''Recalling Columbia's Startling Trip to the Rose Bowl,'' The New York Times, Dec. 27, 1981). While this idea demonstrates a certain logic and concern for fair play, it would introduce the sillyspectacle of teams' deliberately losing yardage to qualify for a richer reward .

title: Lesley I. Brown Bride of Lawyer
description: Lesley I. Brown and Eric H. Schless were married yesterday at the Congregational Church in Middlebury, Vt., by the Rev. Donald Campbell.

title: I read with interest Dr. Rosenfeld's article defending his (and my) calling. I found the questions asked of him simplistic, if not selfish, and far from the real problems facing medicine today.
description: These problems include the rewriting of the entire judicial tort system, which Dr. Rosenfeld mentioned, in an effort to reduce not only malpractice premiums but also the malpractice problem. As it is currently constituted, this system demands the increased cost of medical care through higher malpractice premiums, ''gunshot diagnosis'' and other allied problems.

title: EVERYTHING BUT THE REASON
description: EVERY SECRET THING By Patricia Campbell Hearst, with Alvin Moscow. Illustrated. 466 pp. New York: Doubleday & Co. $17.95.

title: Food; FOR THE TWELFTH DAY OF CHRISMAS, TWO ROAST GEESE
description: ONCE New Year's Day has past most people think the holiday season is over. But they've forgotten Twelfth Night, a day that in many parts of Europe was - and still is - celebrated with all the vigor of Christmas Day itself. This is the Feast of the Epiphany and falls on Jan. 6, the 12th day of Christmas. During the Middle Ages, it was a celebration of the end of the winter solstice, marked by special entertainments, plays, music and, of course, a lavish banquet.

title: No Headline
description: MUBARAK DISMISSES EGYPTIAN CABINET

title: Mail Call on Capitol Hill
description: Elizabeth B. Moynihan's article on Senator Patrick Moynihan's mail room seemed to assume that all his correspondents are his constituents (''Mail Call on Capitol Hill,'' Nov. 15).

title: Coast Senator Defends Anti-Semitic Remarks
description: State Senator John Schmitz, who is runni ng for the Republican nomination for the United States Senateseat now held by S.I. Hayakawa, says he does not regret anti-Semitic remarks about abortion supporters that prompt ed his colleagues to strip him of three Senate jobs.

title: THE ISLAND'S WASHINGTON CONNECTION
description: THE differences among lobbying, selling and educating may be clear by definition, but in the high-stakes world of Washington defense appropriations, all three are critical to the successful promotion of weapons systems, and thus the distinctions among them are frequently blurred.

title: No Headline
description: As a German attorney, belonging to the postwar generation, who has lived in the United States for the last four years, I wonder what John Vinocur would have to say if instead of demonstrating for peace, the Germans in Bonn were demanding nuclear weapons and seriously talking about the prospects of winning a ''limited'' third world war. The rest of the world would be horrified. WALTER F. PETZINGER, New York City

title: NEW ENGLANDERS BEGIN THE DAY GENTLY TO THE MUSIC OF ROBERT J.
description: At certain houses in the snowy remoteness of Presque Isle in Maine this morning, a chorus of birds twittered sweetly at precisely 7 A.M. Eastern standard time. The same thing happened in Bangor, in Albany, in Burlington, Vt., in Brookings, S.D., Louisville, Ky., Salt Lake City, Point Lookout, Mo., Portland, Ore., Mount Pleasant, Mich., and here in Boston.

title: Nora J. Ambrose Wed to John P. Baker
description: Nora Jeanne Ambrose, daughter of Myles J. Ambrose of Washington and the late Elaine Miller Ambrose, was married yesterday at St. Thomas Apostle Roman Catholic Church in Washington to John Preston Baker, son of Dr. and Mrs. John W. Baker of Bethesda, Md.

title: CO-OPS SEEK LAWSUIT PROTECTION
description: For five years, a tenant shareholder whose Central Park West cooperative was extensively and repeatedly damaged by leaking water from an overhead roof garden battled to have her neighbor's greenhouse and planters removed. Although the building has spent thousands of dollars to repair the ceiling and walls, the shareholder is suing the cooperative board, the building, and the managing agent for $1.7 million.

title: About Books and Authors
description: For Emigre Audiences

title: Three Children Die in Fire
description: Fire and heavy smoke swept a town house today, killing three children, officials said.

title: No Headline
description: Sabres Are Beaten By Nordiques, 6 to 3

title: ACCESS TO FARM LABOR CAMPS STIRS FUROR IN JERSEY
description: Organizations that aid migrants and other farm workers are applauding a memorandum by New Jersey's Attorney General and expressing hope that it will end efforts by farmers to bar visits to farm labor camps.

title: Index; International
description: Ghana's new military regime sus- pends the Constitution 3 In South Africa, a harsh law creates an unusual alliance 3 U.S. foreign aid study backs promotion of private enterprise 5 Around the World 7 Reagan confers with Haig on sanctions and other issues 10 Polish Ambassador to Japan ex- plains why he defected 13 U.S. suspects Albanian Premier was killed 15 Government/Politics Calm of Atlanta trial reflects civil rights changes in South 16 Andrew Young says Reagan poli- cies are ''clear failures'' 16 Early start is paying off in Bruce Caputo's Senate race 42 General Pennsylvania dispute over liquor stores widens 18 Economic hard times are forcing more people into soup kitchens 20 New England awakes to sounds of 'Morning Pro Musica' 20 Around the Nation 20 California's poor are beset by housing, job and pay problems 21 Mayor of Berkeley, California is criticized on his travels 48 For library reference staff, ob- scure questions are the norm 49 West Virginia sheriff runs his jail on the honor system 50 Health/Science Study shows drug may aid angina victims 17 Young doctors at Yale practice their skills in Haiti 36 Industry/Labor Air controllers' union reportedly choses successor to Poli 22 Arts/Entertainment Roger Tolle Company dances at Schonberg Theater 51 Boys Choir of Harlem sings at Church of the Intercession 51 Style Visiting college students go 'where it's at' 52 Obituaries Dumont F. Kenny, ex- head of 2 colleges of City U. 28 Yevgeny K. Fedorov, a leading Soviet geophysicist 28 Victor Buono, character actor 28 William M. Black, retired partner in accounting firm 28 News Analysis Drew Middleton examines a change in U.S. military policy 6

title: Long Islanders; OLD ADVICE LED HER INTO WORLD OF BOOKS
description: WHEN Connie Epstein was 10-year-old Connie Carstens, attending the Plandome Road School in Manhasset, the school librarian, Phyllis Fenner, told her that she ''ought to go into publishing'' when she started to look for a job.''

title: TV View; LIVE TV SHOWS- MAY THEY REST IN PEACE
description: Nothing in the realm of television mythology has quite endured like the mystique of the live presentation. Admittedly, live coverage has become an essential element for nearly all sports and certain breaking news stories. But hardened veterans of the business tend to get misty eyed recalling the ''golden age'' of television drama, th ose early years when shows such as ' 'Playhouse 90'' and ''Philco Playhouse'' were done live out of Ne w York studios. They will reminisce warmly about the special tensi ons generated by workingin front of live cameras with no chance for c orrecting flubs. Storiesabout missed cues and missing props are endle ss. As it happens, though, records of a good many of those progr ams do exist to prove that the special tensions too often produced little more than obvious nervousness and stilted movements on the part of the actors crammed into tiny sets.

title: Theater; SHAW'S 'MILLIONAIRESS' IS A STAR VEHICLE FOR TAMMY GRIMES
description: STAMFORD ''THE MILLIONAIRESS'' is a play of George Bernard Shaw's old age, written when he was 79 years old. I don't feel completely comfortable going along with Brooks Atkinson, who referred to it as ''a senile play.'' Rather, I find myse lf more at ease wi th the comments of Kenneth Tynan, who referred to the play as '' a didactic farce'' in which ''the characters talk interminably, inf ectiously and almost interchangeably,'' a play in which Shaw is '' grinding an ax, but the sparks refuse to fly.''

title: THE 49ERS' SECONDARY IS NOW SECOND TO NONE
description: SAN FRANCISCO ONE day not long ago, the San Francisco 49ers' defensive backs were engaged in a classroom meeting when George Seifert, the assistant coach who supervises them, called on Dwight Hicks to answer a question. ''He caught me falling asleep,'' Hicks recalled. ''I really wasn't concentrating on what he was saying, obviously, but I heard it, and I came up with the right answer.''

title: INQUIRY ON CORRUPTION IN PAVING INDUSTRY WIDENING
description: A trail of corruption in the paving industry, which came to light two years ago at a Virginia airport, has led Federal investigators into 13 other states.

title: About Long Island
description: SEARINGTOWN MICHAEL brought his back-up sandwich to the fourth grade at Center Street School. ''And what is a back-up sandwich?'' his father asked. ''It's in case you don't like the food the other kids bring - you've got a back-up,'' Michael explained. This was the day before the long holiday began: each child brought something from home to share with Mrs. Shapiro's fourth-grade class. So Michael's mother packed along a potato pudding for 30. His mother never does anything simple. On Mexican holidays she sends pinadas to school; on Halloween Michael dresses like a bumblebee, even though stingers don't fit on school buses; on Orville Wright's birthday she probably will send in a biplane.

title: NEW CHARITY COALITIONS CHALLENGING LONGTIME DOMINANCE OF UNITED WAY
description: In a challenge to the United Way of Tri-State, which for years has maintained nearly exclusive access to companies in the metropolitan area, new coalitions of charities are beginning to solicit donations in the work place.

title: TAPS AND BURIAL MARKER END A WIDOW'S NINE-YEAR BATTLE
description: A bugler played taps and Beverly Brew Miranda tamped the earth around a memorial marker to her husband in a national cemetery this week in a tribute she achieved after nine years of fighting to change Federal law.

title:
Long Island Housing;
A COMMUNITY PITCHES IN TO CREATE A SPECIAL APARTMENT
description: NORTH BELLMORE AT first glance, the trim white split-level house on Lindale Street looks no different from neighboring homes on the block. The garage has been replaced by an apartment, but that is not unusual. The unforgettable thing about the house is the way the new apartment came to be built.

title: AN UPDATE FROM ATHENS: THE VIEW FROM THE ACROPOLIS
description: The pall that hangs over modern-day Athens has had its effect on the most prominent of its ancient monuments. The statues of the caryatid maidens on view at the Erechtheum Temple on the north side of the Acropolis are replicas. The originals are indoors, in the Acropolis Museum, disfigured almost beyond recognition by the exhaust fumes and industrial smog that, according to UNESCO, have caused more damage over the last 40 years than all the depredations - including bombardment and earthquakes - of the preceding four centuries.

title: THE PRIMARY CALLING OF KARL MARX
description: To the Editor:

title: DUMONT F. KENNY, RETIRED EDUCATOR
description: Dumont F. Kenny, who served as president of two colleges of the City University of New York in the 1960's, died of a heart attack Thursday night at the General Rose Hospital in Denver. He was 67 years old and lived in Denver and Cornwall, Conn.

title: Connecticut Housing; SOME OPTIMISM ABOUT 1982
description: PLANNERS, architects, appraisers, bankers, lawyers and public officials with expertise in the housing field are not as pessimistic as they were last January. In fact a majority of those who were questioned recently about the prospects they see for 1982 was surprisingly upbeat. Here are some of their predictions:

title: PATRICIA LEE CLOUGH, TV PRODUCER, TO WED
description: Mr. and Mrs. William R. Clough of Martinsville, N.J., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Patricia Lee Clough, to Girard Franklin Oberrender 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Oberrender Jr. of Ithaca, N.Y., and Bridgehampton, L.I. An April wedding is planned.

title: Robots
description: To the Business Editor: The robots are coming. The robots are coming. Your article, ''New in Japan: The Manless Factory'' (Dec. 13), reported the advances being made by major corporations toward the manless factories and even a recent accident in which a Japanese worker was killed by a robot.

title: A FIND THAT WOULD SHIVER ANYONE'S TIMBERS
description: After four summers of combing the Arctic depths, the scientists were frustrated but determined as they continued to monitor the instruments on their ship. Then, on August 13, 1980, dots began to appear on the sidescan sonar. As the instrument's needle slowly and silently registered its readings, the excited men watched the dots become lines and the lines take on the shape of a 19th-century sailing ship.

title: No Headline
description: School Says Coach Quit, But She Says She Didn't

title: IN SAME FAMILIES 3 CENTURIES
description: Four New York State farms that have been run by the same families for more than 300 years will be honored Thursday at the annual meeting here of the New York Agricultural Society.

title: THE NEW YEAR DEMANDS ITS OWN RESOLUTIONS
description: As he arrived in California for the holidays, President Reagan observed wryly that the only New Year's resolution he planned for 1982 was not to make any New Year' s resolutions.
