It was an apt comment considerin g the fate of some of the pledges his Administration made when it t ook office early last year.

title: ISLANDERS SET BACK BLACK HAWKS BY 5-3
description: In their first meeting the season with the Chicago Black Hawks, the Islanders stuck to fundamental hockey tonight and scored a 5-3 triumph at Nassau Coliseum.

title: U.S. ENVIRONMENTAL AGENCY MAKING DEEP STAFFING CUTS
description: The Environmental Protection Agency will announce a new reorganization plan next month involving deep staff reductions beyond those required by its budget, according to civil servants in the agency.

title: A LIFE OF THOMAS MANN
description: THOMAS MANN The Making of an Artist, 1875-1911. By Richard Winston. With an Afterword by Clara Winston. 325 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $17.95.

title: Q&A
description: Question:I would like to take a pony trek in the Lake District of England. When is the best time to do this, and where can I get information to make arrangements? - V.V., Ville Mont-Royal, Quebec Answer:The British Tourist Authority publishes a brochure called ''Pony Trekking and Riding'' that lists facilities for these activities by county. Under Cumbria, which e ncompasses the Lake District, are the Fox Inn Trekking Centre (Ousby, Penrith), Glenridding H otel (Glenridding, Penrith), Lakeland Adventure (Harecroft Ha ll, Gosforth, Seascale), Lakeland Trekking (Troutbeck Hotel, Troutb eck, Penrith), Robin Hood Riding Centre (Bassenthwaite, Keswick) and Tarns How Hotel (Hawkshead, Ambleside).

title: Critics' Choices
description: THEATER Spalding Gray is a sit-down monologist with the soul of a stand-up comedian. His new one-man show, ''47 Beds'' (at the Performing Garage), is a deliriously eccentric tour of the events in his life since last March.

title: Practical Traveler; CHECKING OUT THE CHARTERS
description: As usually happens in winter, newspaper ads are drawing attention to vacations by charter flights, and this may be a year to take them much more seriously than many travelers have in the past.

title: GRANGER FOLLOWS HIS OWN SCRIPT
description: ''LIFE'S a rerun,'' Farley Granger said with resigned amusement. The actor had been talking about his ''new fans'' who have seen him in ''Strangers on a Train'' and ''Rope,'' the Alfred Hitchcock classics, on the late show or the ''old movie theater circuit,'' and who are ''discovering'' him live - in yet another thriller, ''Deathtrap'' - and a comedic one at that. Now they're stopping him on the street and saying: ''You're funny. We've never seen y ou be funny.''

title: A MIGHTY OAK, A FRIEND
description: IN my dream I was in the safe darkness of my mother's womb, nestled snugly beneath her pulsating heart. When I woke, the dream persisted. I nudged my sleeping husband and he raised his head and listened, eyes shut. ''What is it?'' he asked. I said I didn't know, ''but it sounds like the pounding of a giant heart.'' Suddenly the thud, thud, thud stopped. I walked to my window and pulled up the shade.

title: Winter's Reward: A Full Larder
description: DURING the last several months, fish and game have been accumulating in home freezers, and, now that most Northeast hunting and angling is over, sportsmen will begin to savor seriously the final rewards of their endeavors.

title: MASTER 'SHIPWRIGHT' IN A VANISHING CRAFT
description: PORT CHESTER JOHN F. KENNEDY had an untold number. A doctor in Westchester has 130 in his private collection. And Franklin D. Roosevelt collected more than 160 model ships, many of which are displayed at Hyde Park.

title: Critics' Choices
description: JAZZ In 1957, Tal Farlow, the jazz guitarist, withdrew from the hurlyburly of constant travel, smokey nightclubs, and late hours that are the usual lot of the jazz musician, to settle in the little coastal New Jersey town of Sea Bright where he could jam in local bars when he felt like it and return to his avocational vocation of sign painting.

title: LAURA FINLEY BETROTHED TO GERALD SKONING, LAWYER
description: Mr. and Mrs. Sherwood H.K. Finley of Bolton Landing, N.Y.,have made known the engagement of their daughter, Laura Alexander Finley, to Gerald Dunlap Skoning, son of Mrs. Warren G. Skoning of St. Charles, Ill. and Sanibel Island, and the late Mr. Skoning. The wedding is planned for February.

title: Israel Five Wins
description: Maccabi Tel Aviv of Israel defeated Solent Stars of Britain, 109-94, today in the final of the Phillips world invitation club basketball tournament at Crystal Palace. Mickey Berkowitz led the Israelis with 33 points.

title: HOUSING-AID CUTS AFFECT POOR INDIVIDUALLY AND COLLECTIVELY
description: Rebuilding a neighborhood is usually easier if people are enthusiastic about living in it. Last October, though, when officials of the Manhattan Valley Development Corporation tried to hand out applications for 126 federally subsidized apartments on the Upper West Side, they were quickly confronted with too much of a good thing.

title: N.L.R.B. Finds Unions Losing Collective Bargaining Votes
description: Unions lost more than half the collective bargaining el ections supervised by the National Labor Relations Boardin the fiscal year 1980, the agency said this week.

title: Around the Nation; Middle West Storms Cause 2 Deaths on Highways
description: B y United Press International New storms arose yesterday in the Middle West and the West. A storm left 8 inches of snow and ice-slickened roadways in Iowa and Minnesota, and pounding rains in northern California caused mudslides.

title: Around the Nation; Justice Rehnquist May Leave Hospital
description: Supreme Court Justice William H. Rehnquist could leave a hospital Sunday after treatment for the ''disturbances in mental clarity'' he suffered when medication for back pain was sharply reduced, a hospital spokesman said today.

title: Shelagh Marie Markey Wed
description: Shelagh Marie Markey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard A. Markey Jr. of Summit, N.J., was married yesterday to William Robert Maass, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert H. Maass of Madison and North Beach, N.J. The Rev. Beatus T. Lucey performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at St. Mary's Abbey in Morristown, N.J.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN THE LAURENTIANS
description: ROBERT KARNIOL is a Montreal-based business journalist. By ROBERT KARNIOL

title: Politics; ASSEMBLY GETS LOBBYING BILL
description: THE State Assembly is scheduled to vote tomorrow on a bill that makes a one-word change in a law, but it is a change that speaks volumes.

title: BERKELEY MAYOR CRITICIZED ON TRAVELS
description: Mayor Eugene Newport took his first trip to Cuba by accident when he was aboard a hijacked airliner bound for Puerto Rico in 1971. His next two trips to Havana, made since he took office two years ago, have prompted a local controversy.

title: CONTROLLER UNION SAID TO PICK CHIEF
description: Gary Eads, the Kansas City regional vice president of the Professional Air Traffic Controllers Organization, will report edly be named Monday to succeed Ro bert E. Poli, who resigned Thursday as president of the decerti fied union.

title: St. John's Downs Columbia
description: Columbia played slow-down basketball against St. John's last night, a tactic that Lou Carnesecca, the St. John's coach, does not favor. But the strategy proved ineffective as the Redmen achieved their sixth straight victory, 58-51, before a near capacity crowd of 5,397 at Alumni Hall in Jamaica, Queens.

title: Around the World; Britain Said to Withhold Files on Two Defectors
description: Government files on two Britons who defected to the Soviet Union in 1951, Guy Burgess and Donald Maclean, are being withheld by the Foreign Office even though they are eligible for publication, British newspapers reported today.

title: Sunday Observer
description: By Russell Baker Congress's Stepchild Patrick McDonnell

title: Follow-Up on the News; Love Talk
description: How do you feel about love? Wendy Clarke began to ask people in 1977. She taped respondents and their replies with a video camera, and the project, ''Love Tapes,'' received more than $15,000 in grants from art benefactors.

title: Judge Betty W. Ellerin
description: Betty Weinberg Ellerin, the new administrator of the New York City courts, grew up in the Bronx, where she graduated from James Monroe High School in 1946. She graduated from New York University in 1950, and received a law degree there in 1952.

title: THE POLISH AIRWAVES: OFFICIAL'S VISIT TO BONN
description: Following are excerpts from domestic Polish radio and television broadcasts as transcribed and translated from the Polish by the Foreign Broadcast Information Service, a United States Government agency : Sentences for 5 in Solidarity 7:30 P.M. Saturday

title: Chicago Finds the Hispanic Outnumber Whites in Schools
description: Hispanic students outnumber whites in the Chicago public school system and are the only major racial group among whom enrollment is growing, according to Chicago school officials.

title: RECREATING THE POWER OF THE SUN
description: Jeremy Bernstein is a professor of physics at the Stevens Institute of Technology and a staff writer for The New Yorker. His forthcoming book is ''Science Observed.'' By Jeremy Bernstein

title: The Region in Summary; Have Robes, Must Travel
description: ''Musical benches'' has lost its charm for many New York State judges who have had to play it the last two years, but the game isn'tover yet. Last week, it was announced that th e system of rotating upstate and suburban judges to hear New York City civil cases would be continued through 1982.

title: Ann Jones, City Planner, Wed to Donald H. Koch
description: Ann Holmes Jones, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ridgely Jones of Sykesville, Md., was married yesterday to Donald Henry Koch, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Koch of Livingston, N.J. The Rev. Albert Burton of Martinsburg, W.Va., performed the ceremony at the St. James United Methodist Church in West Friendship, Md.

title: Home Clinic; CLEANING FIBERGLASS BATH FIXTURES NEEDN'T BE A PROBLEM
description: THE increasing popularity of fiberglass bathtubs and stall showers, in new construction as well as in remodeling projects, has led to problems for some people. To judge from letters received here, it seems that many are having trouble properly cleaning and maintaining the surfaces of these bath fixtures.

title: WAS TE HEAT: IN TRENTON, IT LOOMS AS A BIG SAVING
description: TRENTON COME next Christmas, Sant a Claus will have a 150-foot chimney to descend in downtown Trenton. It will stand on top of the Trenton ICES(Integrated Community Energy System) plant, o ne of the best gifts that the decaying state capital is likely to receive in this decade.

title: Pakistani Finds Old Gems
description: A Pakistani villager found a 4,500-year-old sapphire necklace in a pile of rubble that was left by visiting archeologists who reported finding no relics of ancient civilization. The necklace is on display in the museum of the Mohenjo-Daro ruins in Sind Province.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: side economics that has found much favor among supporters of President Reagan. Our reviewer Roger Starr said that it ''alternately astonishes the reader with new and rather daring insights into familiar problems and bores him with long, tract-like passages to support them.''

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE: SOME CAPITAL BRUNCHES
description: MIMI SHERATON is restaurant critic of The New York Times. By MIMI SHERATON

title: IN THE LAND OF 'LAUGHING WATERS'
description: Southeast of Phoenix and northeast of Tucson in the Pinal Mountains is a short, deep gorge called Aravaipa Canyon. It is among the few places in Arizona with a permanent stream of water and in popular estimation one of the most beautiful.

title: The Serious Italians
description: It was a delight to read Paul Hofmann's article ''The Italian Art of Survival'' (Nov. 22). The Italians have survived floods, earthquakes, foreign invasion and conquest, dictatorship. Mr. Hofmann notes that stable government is an illusory matter in Italy: ''The Government changes every year and is on the brink of collapse every two months.''

title: Sports World Specials; No O.T.
description: Its proponents like to say that one of the attractions of basketball - unlike its major sister fall and winter sports, football and hockey - is that there are always a winner and a loser. There is never a tie.

title: MUSIC: RETURN OF A ROMANTIC
description: THE surest way to understand what makes ''great'' compositions worth hearing is to listen to two hours of ''competent'' music. At Carnegie Recital Hall on Saturday night, Joseph Marx (1882-1964) was lauded with encomiums that made him seem like a neglected worldclass genius.

title: Papers Reveal Britain Balked In '51 at Halting China Trade
description: Britain agreed to restrict, but not to stop, exports of strategic supplies to China during the Korean War after a request from the United States, according to previously secret British Government documents for 1951.

title: Visitors in Las Vegas Flee From 16 Fires
description: Sixteen fires set in two hotels on the Las Vegas Strip and a nearby apartment complex forced the evacuation of scores of visitors but caused no major damage or injury, the police said today.

title: Commodities; Gold Bug Returns T o the Fold
description: IN August 1980, the international fraternity of gold bugs was stunned when one of its prophets, James E. Sinclair, warned his followers to abandon the metal, unless they were planning to leave their hoard to their heirs. Gold bullion was then selling at roughly $650 an ounce, and ended 1980 at about $500. It closed at $400 last Thursday, down $3.50 for the holiday-shortened week.

title: Greek Leader Announces Policy on Key Industries
description: Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou said tonight that his Socialist Government would place key industries that are not already state-controlled under the guidance of supervisory committees that would include elected representatives of their workers, local authorities, the state and their boards.

title: LAWYERS TIE TRIAL READINESS ILLS TO SCHEDULING
description: Trial lawyers acknowledge that lack of preparation is a major reason why some attorneys perform poorly in trials, according to an American Bar Foundation study.

title: Year Starting on Gloomy Note; Caution Being Emphasized
description: The optimism that usually greets the start of a new year in the bond market will be notably absent this morning. The gloomy mood will have little to do with the further rise of half a percentage point in Treasury bill yields last week or the loss of another full point in prices of long-term Treasury bonds during the holiday-shortened trading week.

title: 4 FEMALE GUERRILLAS FLEE IN ITALY AS COMRADES BOMB PRISON WALL
description: Four women suspected of b eing terrorists escaped from the Rovigo women's pr ison today after accomplices outside blasted a hole in the pri son wall, tossed them machine guns and kept guards at bay with auto matic fire, authorities said.

title: Miss Hess Takes 3d Slalom in Row
description: Erika Hess of Switzerland won her third consecutive women's World Ski Cup slalom race today and increased her lead in the overall cup standing to 34 points.

title: POLITICS KEY TO THE FATE OF CAMP'S LAST CUBANS
description: Orestes Carrera Bravo, who is 53 years old, saw his first snow last winter, a light dusting that did not cover the soles of his boots, but he and the other Cuban refugees who remain here are soon to go to Glasgow, Mont., where snow is often measured in feet.

title: JURY SELECTION STARTS TODAY IN THE ABBOTT MURDER TRIAL
description: Jack Henry Abbott, who became an overnight literary celebrity last summer for his nightmare rendition of prison life, goes on trial today in Manhattan for murder.

title: Rangers' 5-Game Streak Ends With a 4-3 Loss to the Capitals
description: The Rangers, having defeated the powerful Islanders and Montreal Canadiens in successive games, were stricken with acute lassitude last night at Madison Square Garden.

title: New Governor for Bank of Israel
description: Dr. Moshe Mandelbaum, deputy director of the Bank of Israel, was elected by the Cabinet today to succeed the controversial Arnon Gafny as governor.

title: Disney 'Cinderella' Back
description: Walt Disney's 1950 animated version of the Charles Perrault classic ''Cinderella'' has been rereleased to theaters. For the next week the 74-minute film, last shown in 1973, will be playing at the Embassy I, Broadway and 46th Street; Loews 83, Broadway and 83d Street; the Guild, 50th Street between Fifth Avenue and the Avenue of the Americas, and neighborhood theaters.

title: Wild Camels Found in China
description: Wild camels, which are considered on the verge of extinction, have been found in northwest China, the official New China News Agency reported today. The camels, a taller, thinner ancestor of the domesticated two-hump camel, were found in Dunhuang county in Gansu Province and in the northeastern part of the Xinjiang Uygur region during a survey last summer and fall, the agency said. It did not say how many were seen.

title: Sports World Specials; Watching From Afar
description: Quick, who were the Giants' starting running backs in the opening game of the season? If you answered with any combination of Rob Carpenter, Leon Perry, Doug Kotar, Leon Bright, Louis Jackson, Larry Heater, Alvin Garrett and Ike Forte, you were wrong -though you can probably be excused, inasmuch as the pre-Carpenter days now seem like eons ago.

title: THE CALENDAR
description: Monday

title: NUGGETS END WINNING STREAK BY BUCKS
description: The Denver Nuggets, led by 38 points by Alex English and 25 by Kiki Vandeweghe, held off a rally and defeated the Milwaukee Bucks, 128-122, tonight. The defeat broke a five-game winning streak for the Bucks.

title: Marcos Denies 'Interest' In Missing Athlete
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos denied tonight that he and his family had ''any interest whatsoever'' in the disappearance of a prominent Filipino athlete who is said to have secretly married Mr. Marcos's eldest daughter last month.

title: Market Place; Will OPEC's P rices Crack?
description: IN a report that is bound to be controversial, a leading petroleum comme ntator a rgues that the price of OPEC oil may crack as early as the middle of this year, and that the decline will help the economiesof the rest o f the world.

title: Furor Over Seats Splits Britain's New Alliance
description: A furor erupted in Britain's new centrist political alliance today between the Social Democratic Party and the Liberal Party over the division of seats in Parliament to be contested in the next general election.

title: Carol A. Miller Bride of William J. Lipton, Lawyer
description: Carol A. Miller, an accounting officer with the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, and William J. Lipton, a partner in Ernst & Whinney, accountants, were married yesterday. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Bonnie Steinberg of Hofstra University at the Murray Hill Townhouse.

title: Sonics 110, Lakers 90
description: LOS ANGELES (UPI) - Gus Williams scored 27 points and Jack Sikma took 20 rebounds for Seattle, whose victory ended a six-game winning streak for Los Angeles. The Laker center, Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, who was playing his first game after a recent ankle injury, scored 26 points and had 16 rebounds.

title: News Analysis
description: Environmental boll weevils? Antipollution gypsy moths? These exotic Congressional forms of life may play key roles in the fate of the Clean Air Act this year.

title: BENGALS DEFEAT BILLS, 28-21
description: The touchdown that won today's divisional playoff game for the Cincinnati Bengals was a 16-yard pass from a veteran quarterback, Ken Anderson, to a rookie wide receiver, Cris Collinsworth. It came in the fifth minute of the final period, and it gave the Bengals a 28-21 victory over the Buffalo Bills.

title: HELPING CHILDREN DEAL WITH LEGAL SYSTEM
description: A 7-year-old girl is taken to a New York City clinic for a physical checkup. A doctor discovers that she has gonorrhea, and the police are notified. Efforts to learn how the child contracted the disease are unavailing until a detective offers her a set of anatomically complete dolls used to interview sexually abused children.

title: Money Funds' Strength Continues
description: While inflation and volatile interest rates have sent most segments of the economy into a tailspin, they continue to be a boon for money market funds, attracting investors seeking hi gh yields and more than doubling the funds' assets.

title: Salvador Military Chief Is Reportedly Demoted
description: The Commander in Chief of the Armed Forces, Col. Jaime Abdul Gutierrez, regarded as a political moderate, has been demoted to third in command behind the country's conservative Defense Minister, Col. Guillermo Garcia, the Salvadoran newspaper El Mundo said today.

title: Tendler Turns Phibro Toward New Objectives
description: With the acquisition of Salomon Brothers, David Tendler, the 43-year-old chairman and chief executive of the Phibro Corporation, continues to lead his company rapidly into new avenues of diversification.

title: THE SHUTTLE, YES
description: The attack on the space shuttle has begun. After the shuttle's second, abbreviated, test flight, in November, a headline proclaimed: SHUTTLE'S CRITICS CALL FOR A BROAD REASSESSMENT, and a news story said that ''space agency officials...doubt that the shuttle will ever be able to be serviced and return to space as rapidly as originally hoped.''

title: SOME BEVERLY HILLS GLITTER IS PAWNED
description: -When Don Clark, a Los Angeles area insurance adjuster, needed "just a quickie loan," he brought his wife's fur coat to the Beverly Loan Company. In return for the full-length back mink for which he had paid $3,500 five years ago, Mr. Clark received $500 and a pawn ticket.

title: 100 Are Stranded by Airline
description: More than 100 passengers were stranded overnight because United Airlines overbooked flights to Portland and Seattle. A spokesman said that one-third of the passengers were accommodated by United or other lines Saturday night and early today. The others spent the night at the airport, The line offered $200 and a standby seat to each, but when it could not cash checks, many were unable to buy meals or hotel rooms.

title: JAPAN SEEMS TO TAKE ON BIGGER DEFENSE ROLE
description: Last week the Japanese Cabinet approved a budget for 1982 that includes a 7.7 percent increase in military spending. The rise, which will bring the amount of money spent on the nation's armed forces to $11.8 billion, was th e first increase in military expe nditures as a percentage of the national budget since 1956.

title: AS A CAMPAIGN FOR MAYOR HEATS UP, NEW ORLEANS PURSUES CIVIC REVIVAL
description: A glossy brochure, reflecting the sentiments of this city's political and business leaders, boasts of the ''unvarnished evidence of profound evolution'' it is said to contain. It is also filled with apologies for appearing ''unconcerned'' with changes that have taken place in such nearby centers as Houston, Dallas and Atlanta.

title: CONCERT: THE AMERICAN SYMPHONY
description: THE American Symphony Orchestra played three 20th-century pieces at Carnegie Hall Sunday afternoon - each with one of its feet planted firmly and unashamedly in the century before. David Ramadanoff, making his first appearance in Carnegie Hall, was the conductor here, while Gregory Fulkerson, who won first prize in the 1980 International American Music Competition for Violin, played the solo part in Samuel Barber's Concerto for Violin.

title: Minnesota Player R egains Eligibility
description: Mark Hall, who played guard on the University of Minnesota basketball team for three years, will rejoin the Gophers this week in accord with a court ruling.

title: Levine, Huntley
description: Levine, Huntley, Schmidt, Plapler & Beaver last week became the agency for the Entertainment Channel, a pay-cable entry that is due out this spring. The client is a joint venture of Rockefeller Center Cable and RCA Cable.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: With the bases loaded and one out, the home team is trailing by a run in the bottom of the ninth inning. The batter drives a ball that barely goes into the stands for a home run. As he rounds first, he passes the runner, who has been waiting to see if the ball would drop in safely. What is the ruling? What if two men are out? What if it happens in the middle of the game?

title: CHARGER VICTORY: CONTRAST IN KICKS
description: As the most unpredictable game in National Football League playoff history went on and on, as records fell, emotions drained and bodies pushed themselves to the limit, Rolf Benirschke, the San Diego Charger kicker who has lived through far more important moments than the winning or losing of a football game, thought about another kicker and another game.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: VILLAGE

title: KRIEK BEATS DENTON IN 4-SET AUSSIE FINAL
description: Johan Kriek became the first South African to win a Grand Slam tennis tournament when he defeated Steve Denton of the United States, 6-2, 7-6, 6-7, 6-4, in the final of the $400,000 Australian Open today.

title: NEBRASKA JOINING 26 STATES IN TRAFFIC TICKET AGREEMENT
description: -Nebraska motorists who have been ignoring Iowa traffic tickets could soon find themselves without driver's licenses under an interstate pact that took effect Friday.

title: WEST'S DIPLOMATS WILL MEET TODAY WITH POLISH CHIEF
description: The head of Poland's military Government will meet the ambassadors of the 10 European Common Market countries in Warsaw Monday, the West German Foreign Ministry in Bonn said today.

title: CALLAN'S TASK AT BANK FOR SAVINGS
description: Rescuing New York City's third-largest savings bank is proving an uphill battle for Eugene J. Callan.

title: WHEN 'MORAL CLAIMS' COLLIDE HEAD-ON
description: To the Editor:

title: WITH DUAL FARES, SOME RIDERS ARE AVOIDING MORE COSTLY CABS
description: A new regulation limiting the number of taxicabs that can impose a 50-cent night surcharge went into effect in New York City on New Year's Day, and by the end of the holiday weekend some people were already avoiding the higher-priced cabs.

title: LENDL: DOING THINGS HIS WAY
description: ONE year after he admittedly gave away a set and the match to Jimmy Connors in the Volvo Masters tennis tournament, Ivan Lendl says he has no regrets about the episode.

title: GARY JETER'S LOST TEMPER
description: SAN FRANCISCO IN their locker room, the other Giants were up and around. Some were shaking hands with each other. Some were in the shower. Some were in the trainer's room, slicing the tape off their ankles. And some were already getting dressed. But at his locker, Gary Jeter, still in his uniform, was sitting on a stool with his head down and his back to everybody else, almost as if he didn't want to face his teammates.

title: EXPORTS AND SMUGGLING FUEL LAREDO SALES BOOM
description: This is a boom town for some, a bust town for others and a paradise for smugglers. Despite a per capita income of only $5,109, the second lowest in Texas, Laredo has the nation's second highest retail sales per household, $20,149.

title: Advertising Teachers Needed by Colleges
description: Althoug h en rollments in college-level advertising courses around the country c ontinue to increase, there is an apparent shortage of instructors, according to the two professors who annually publish ''Where Shall I Go To College to Study Advertising.''

title: Susan Edelman and Jay Levin, Reporters, Married
description: Susan Bonnie Edelman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Marcus Edelman of Los Angeles, was married there yesterday to Jay Scott Levin, son of Ann Levin of Hollis Hills, Queens, and the late Howard Levin. Rabbi Charles Lipshultz performed the ceremony at the Odyssey, a restaurant.

title: Sports World Specials; Man on the Move
description: Now that the relief pitcher Jim Kern feels he has mostly recovered from the physical problems that bedeviled him for the last two seasons with the Texas Rangers, he is still having a difficulty: He finds it hard to believe in the recent trade that sent him to the Mets in exchange for Doug Flynn and Dan Boitano, a minor league pitcher.

title: 3-DAY HOLIDAY WEEKEND ENDS WITH TRAFFIC JAMS
description: The three-day holiday weekend of traditional New Year's festivities ended yesterday with another tradition: traffic jams. What had been only minor delays in the morning became a two-and-ahalf-hour clot of private cars, buses and taxis on the Grand Central Parkway in Queens as the access ramps to La Guardia Airport became backed up with traffic from Shea Stadium.

title: 8 Die as Small Plane Crashes I n Virginia in Drizzle and Fog
description: All eight persons aboard a twin-engine Cessna were killed when the airplane crashed tonight in fog and light rain within a mile of Hanover Airport, the authorities said.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article Saturday gave an incor- rect date for the announcement by At- torney General William French Smith that none of the evidence or allega- tions against Richard V. Allen, the na- tional securi ty adviser, merited the appointment o f a special prosecutor. The correct d ate is Dec. 23.

title: 'JESUS JEANS' MAKER EXPANDS INTO U.S.
description: In 1980, a cluttered little Italian apparel company became an official sponsor of America's Olympic track team and also signed a contract to build a factory outside Moscow to sew jeans for Russian youth. By any standard, Maglificio Calcificio Torinese, a little company that works out of a drab stucco factory in an industrial neighborhood of Turin, is extremely unusual.

title: TRADE-OFF ON INFLATION
description: Unemployment is at 8.4 percent - up almost a full point in the last two months - and rising. We are clearly moving into a typical recession, and all the forecasters seem to agree that it is going to get worse -possibly much worse - before it gets better. The recession may have one considerable virtue. This looks like a very good time to try to strike a better bargain: to exchange modestly expansionary monetary and fiscal policies for wage restraint.

title: Central Park Race To Ludwikowski
description: Marty Ludwikowski of the New York Athletic Club set meet and course records in winning the opener of the Manufacturers Hanover fiveborough, five-mile championship series yesterday morning at Central Park. Ludwikowski, 24 years old, registered a 30- yard victory over his New York Athletic Club teammate, Luis Ostoloz aga, for the Manhattan title of the series.

title: GIANTS, WITH COSTLY ERRORS, LOSE TO 49ERS, 38-24
description: The party's over. The Giants, a losing team that had suddenly became a winning team, lost today to the 49ers, 38-24, and their season was ended.

title: Australian Says Polish Crew S houldn't Be Urged to Desert
description: A spokesman for Perth's Polish community urged Australians today not to put pressure on the crew of the Polish cargo ship Artur Grottger to jump ship.

title: ROBINSON'S NEW TARGET FOR HIS SHEARSON UNIT
description: Wall Street expected fireworks when James D. Robinson 3d, the quietly dedicated chairman of American Express, and Sanford I. Weill, the hard-driving chairman of Shearson/American Express, faced each other across the boardroom table.

title: Red Smith; The Bowls Of Rhetoric
description: HEREWITH, fragments of wisdom gleaned from watching, and listening to, bowl game s: ''Missed opportunities sometimes come back to haunt you.'' Any fo rward pass a defender can see is ''almost intercepted.''

title: Kissinger Meets Dominican
description: Former Secretary of State Henry M. Kissinger met Saturday with President Antonio Guzman to discuss President Reagan's planned Caribbean basin development plan. Mr. Kissinger was accompanied by the United States Ambasador here, Robert L. Yost, and the designer Oscar de la Renta. Mr. Kissinger and his wife, Nancy, have been staying Mr. de la Renta's villa.

title: THE DAY THE HURDY-GURDIES DISAPPEARED
description: To the Editor:

title: TV: ANGLIM REPEATS ROLE IN 'THE ELEPHANT MAN'
description: ''THE ELEPHANT MAN,'' the play that had a long run and won several awards on Broadway, has been adapted for television with admirable skill and sensitivity, and it can be seen tonight on ABC-TV at 9 o'clock.

title: Investigators Seeking Cause Of 3-Alarm Park Avenue Fire
description: New York City fire marshals were seeking the cause of a three-alarm fire that swept the third floor of a Park Avenue office building Saturday night and damaged several offices extensively.

title: FIRST NATIONWIDE: A NEW ERA
description: West Side Federal Savings and Loan, a big New York thrift institution, was losing about $10 million a month when Citizens Savings of California came to the rescue last September.

title: ITS BORDER RAIDED, NICARAUGA TRAINS CIVILIANS
description: The bullet holes stitched into the sides of buildings at this border crossing into Honduras are not, like those in so many parts of Nicaragua, traces of an old war. The Sandinist leaders of the country say they fear that they could be the precursors of a new one.

title: WEBB INSTITUTE MOLDS BUILDERS OF BETTER SHIPS
description: Anthony Attanasio and Lori Reinhold are college senio rs whose major academic pursuit at the moment is a study of what happens when you load little gray weights into a model boat and laun ch it in a 95-foot-long indoor canal.

title: USE OF CITY POLICE ON SUBWAYS URGED
description: Citing reports of a surge in subway crime in New York, Council President Carol Bellamy urged yesterday that officers from the city's Police Department supplement the transit police force.

title: LEBANESE PIPELINE WRECKED BY BLAST
description: The pipeline that carries Iraqi crude oil to the Lebanese Mediterranean coast was blown up by an explosion today.

title: POLISH AIRWAVES: U.S. POLICY ASSAULTED
description: Following are exc erpts from domestic Polish radio and tel evision broadcasts as transcribed and translated from the Polish by the Foreign Broadcast Information Service, a United States Govern ment agency.

title: ROCK: CLUB SPOTLIGHTS KARLA DEVITO
description: A year on the road with Meat Loaf and six months in the Broadway production of ''The Pirates of Penzance'' have helped Karla DeVito evolve into a theatrical rock singer of exceptional promise. And at the Bottom Line, where she appeared over the weekend, supported by a five-piece band, Miss DeVito displayed a vivacious personality and a powerful rock soprano that was particularly effective on her original ballad, ''Just Like You.''

title: U.N. Soldier Is Killed In Ambush in Lebanon
description: A Ghanaian soldier serving with the United Nations peacekeeping force was killed and another was wounded in an attack by gunmen against their post in southern Lebanon Saturday night, a United Nations spokesman said today.

title: BUDGET CUTS AND ELECTION POLITICS TO DOMINATE ALBANY LEGISLATURE
description: A troubled national economy, Federal budget cuts and election year infighting will dominate the 205th session of the Legislature, which opens this week.

title: Advertising; Agencies Forecast Tough '82
description: THIS year could very well turn out better for ad agencies than clients, because the clients, despite the economic crunch, will be forced by competitive pressures to maintain or exceed 1981 advertising levels. Up to a point.

title: Lynne Weil, Ph.D. Student, Bride of Bruce E. Holman
description: Lynne Rose Weil, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Weil of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., was married yesterday to Bruce E. Holman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Holman of New York.

title: Bruins 8, Jets 5
description: A goal by Normand Leveille broke a 5-5 tie with 27 seconds left in the second period and put Boston ahead to stay.

title: The Premier-Designate Names Egyptian Cabinet
description: Egypt's Prime Minister-designate, Fuad Mohieddin, appointed a Cabinet today, naming a new Interior Minister and replacing a Deputy Prime Minister accus ed of corruption, officials sai d.

title: 49ER COACH'S TACTIC HELPS NULLIFY TAYLOR
description: Before Bill Walsh, the 49ers' tactician and head coach, came to Candlestick Park today, he had devised an offensive scheme designed to take advantage of the skill of the Giant defense.

title: Index; International
description: Shetland isles try to cope with the impact of oil A2 The coup in Ghana has alarmed other nations in West Africa A3 Italian prison wall is bombed, and four terrorist suspects escape A3 Around the World A7 George Kennan says U.S. sanctions were hasty A8 The Polish airwaves: Reagan's policy is assailed A8 Outcome of election increases bit- terness in Malta A9 Chun names new South Korean Premier and shuffles Cabinet A10 U.S. officials still dubious about Japan's military budget A11 Government/Politics Youngstown, Ohio, works to save public transit A18 New Orleans, seeking civic renewal, faces mayoral election A18 Work on the Watergate tapes delayed due to budget cuts A19 Progress is spotty on efforts to cut government regulations B11 Washington Talk Briefing A20 Lawrence K. Altman looks at secrecy and a Justice's health A20 Democrats discover lure of G.O.P. fund-raising tactics A20 General Around the Nation A18 Traffic jams around La Guardia mark end of holiday weekend B3 Questions raised on Congressional aide's work for media B8 Laredo, Tex., a haven for Mexican buyers and smugglers B9 Former headmaster has unusual cure for ''sophomore slump'' B13 Style Relationships B14 Helping children deal with the legal system B14 Retirement - Japanese-style B14 SportsMonday Basketball: The Knicks remain a team for Richard son to lead C12 Columns: Dave Anderson on Gary Jeter's lost temper C1

title: MISSISSIPPI TORNADO KILLS ONE
description: A tornado skipped through Newton County in eastern Mississippi yesterday, killing one person, injuring at least 17 and damaging houses, the authorities said.

title: Ad Writer To Be Honored
description: Bernice Fitz-Gibbon, retailing's legendary ad maker who starred at both Macy's and Gimbel's, is being installed in another hall of fame, this time by the American Advertising Federation.

title: The Region; 'Angels' Protest Inquiry in Killing
description: NEWARK (AP) - Dozens of Guardian Angels set off on a two-day, 50-mile march to Trenton, the state capital, to show their dissatisfaction with an investigation into the shooting death of a member of the group by a Newark police officer.

title: Washington Watch; Regan's Fight With the Fed
description: WASHINGTON THE Federal Reserve is still Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan's bete noir. And the former Merrill Lynch chairman still doesn't know whether he can get the nation's central bank off his back.

title: FURTHER DIP IN DOLLAR IS FORECAST
description: The dollar is likely to continue its recent slow decline against other major currencies during 1982, but will still remain high by historic standards, bankers and economists agree.

title: Attles Wins 500th
description: Al Attles of Golden State became the sixth coach to achieve 500 career coaching victories in the National Basketball Association Saturday night when the Warriors beat the Dallas Mavericks, 119-100. Attles, in his 13th season with the Warriors, the only team for which he has coached or played professionally, has a 500-541 record.

title: Poland's Population Is Up
description: Poland's population increased by 400,000 in 1981, according to the official Polish news agency P.A.P. It said the total population was estimated at 36,100,000, compared to 35,700,000 in 1980.

title: Term of Chief of Staff Is Extended by Israelis
description: The Israeli Government today extended Lieut. Gen. Rafael Eytan's term as military Chief of Staff to an unprecedented fifth year.

title: No Jumping Over Candlestick
description: The Dallas Cowboys are not enthusiastic about playing the National Football Conference championship game Sunday in Candlestick Park, and it has nothing to do with wearing blue jerseys.

title: Notes on People; Cake and Jellybeans
description: Air Force One was the scene of a party last night as the Presidential jet flew to Washington from California. President and Mrs. Reagan joined Secret Service agents in a rear compartment of the airplane for cake and jellybeans in celebration of the promotion of three agents in the White House detail.

title: WITH EARLY NEW YEAR, MALAYSIA SEEKS UNITY
description: The New Year arrived early on the Malay Peninsula this year. At 11:30 P.M. on New Year's Eve, all clocks were moved forward to mid night.

title: MILTON WATSON, 79, SANG LEADING ROLES IN BROADWAY SHOWS
description: Milton Watson, who succeeded Ray Middleton as Frank Butler in ''Annie Get Your Gun'' in 1948 and was a featured juvenile in other Broadway musicals, died Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 79 years old.

title: THE $110,000 BLUNDER, OR THE MAN WHO COULDN'T WORK MOVIE MIRACLES
description: HOLLYWOOD BARRY JAGODA arrived in Hollywood on Dec. 1, 1980, with the screen rights to a novel, $110,000 to spend and a jaunty confidence that by the end of a year he would be a movie producer.

title: CUT IN SOVIET STAFF IN U.S. DEBATED
description: The United States, concerned about what it considers a growing espionage threat from Soviet diplomats, has discussed forcing the Soviet Union to cut back the size of its representation in this country, the director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation said today.

title: Navy Team Takes B obsledding Title
description: Despite a track record by Bob Hickey of Keene, N.Y., Bill Renton and his United States Navy team held a lead they had established in the first run Saturday and won the national four-man bobsled championship today at Mount Van Hoevenberg.

title: HAIG AIDES SAY MIDEAST ENVOY MAY BE NAMED
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. was reported by a ides today to be seriously considering whether to name a high-level negotiator to the drawn-out Egyptian-Israeli negotiations on Palestinian self-rule. The aides said that Mr. Haig spent consider able time during the last five days while he was in California stu dying Middle East problems, and in particular the pros and cons of appointing a specialMiddle East envoy in order to dramatize the R eagan Administration's commitment to gaining an agreement by the end of April. One key StateDepartment official said, however, that Mr. H aig seems unconvinced, despite recommendations from within the Admin istration and from outside experts, that the time is right to ta ke that action. Talks With Envoys This Week

title: The Equitable Tax Gimmick
description: ''This is a sick piece of legislation. The sooner they kill it the better.'' That is one security analyst's view of new tax provisions that permit a company to sell unused tax benefits to the highest bidder. The sentiment is shared by many in Congress, who see repeal of this controversial reform as a good way to generate badly needed revenues.

title: CITY BALLET: LISA HESS DANCES SUGAR PLUM IN 'NUTC RACKER'
description: TRADITIONALISTS sometimes cluck over George Balanchine's ''Nutcracker'' for the New York City Ballet because Mr. Balanchine has taken the Sugar Plum Fairy's solo out of the climactic second-act pas de deux and has moved it to the very beginning of the act. Yet this arrangement can be defended because it permits the Sugar Plum Fairy to show right from the start in both demeanor and dancing exactly what sort of magical being she is.

title: Notes on People; California Couple Take Vows of Conscience
description: There wasn't a single ''I do'' or an ''I will'' at San Francisco's Glide Memorial Church during the weekend wedding of the pastor, the Rev. Cecil Williams, and Janice Mirikitani, a poet and choreographer.

title: Christmases of 1800's At Historical Society
description: An exhibition of Christmas in the 19th century, titled ''Tales of Christmas Past,'' is at the New-York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West, through Sunday.

title: HYPOCRISY WINS AGAIN
description: Last Oct. 2 Jeane Kirkpatrick, United States Ambassador to the United Nations, spoke in the U.N. General Assembly about what she called the ''savagery'' of the Marxist regime in Ethiopia. In graphic terms she denounced assaults on human rights that have occurred since Col. Mengistu Haile Mariam took over in the revolution of 1974.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We need the help of the city's police force to stop the intolerable crime wave now plaguing the subways.'' -Carol Bellamy, President of the New York City Council. (A1:1.)

title: TIRE DESIGNER'S CRAFT USED TO SOLVE MURDERS
description: -Most of the time, Peter McDonald makes his living designing the countless squiggles and grooves that help Firestone tires grip the road confidently and roll smoothly.

title: A Step Forward for Foster Care
description: There is nothing particularly uplifting about foster care, in New York or anywhere. It's a holding-tank system for children whose parents cannot or will not care for them. It does too little to prevent the collapse of families and too little, when families fail, to find permanent adoptive homes.

title: Regan's Quiet Role May Alter
description: One evening a year ago, Donald T. Regan, the Wall Street executive selected to be Secretary of the Treasury, and Representative David A. Stockman, who was about to become b udget director, emerged from a planning meeting and faced reporters.

title: Canada Captures Junior Hockey
description: Third-period goals by Mike Moller and Marc Habscheid gave Canada a 3-3 tie with Czechoslovakia and its first world junior hockey championship Saturday night.

title: ELISABETH MILLSPAUGH
description: Elisabeth Park Millspaugh, a Baltimore civic leader for almost half a century, died of heart failure yesterday at Union Memorial Hospital. She was 86 years old.

title: TURNER OPENS 2D NETWORK IN CABLE-NEWS WAR
description: Four months ago, ABC News and Westinghouse announced plans for the Satellite Newschannels, a venture to create a 24-hour cabletelevision network patterned on the all-news radio format of constantly updated 18-minute segments of news.

title: SABRES TURN BACK CANADIENS BY 3-2
description: Gil Perreault scored with 11 minutes to play to give the Buffalo Sabres a 3-2 victory over the Montreal Canadiens tonight.

title: REAGAN IS RATED HIGH ON CAMPAIGN PLEDGES
description: Most Americans either say that President Reagan has kept his campaign promises or that they do not blame him for not keeping them, according to the latest Associated Press-NBC News poll.

title: The Region; 3 Suspects Named I n Jersey Shooting
description: A policeman who was shot after stopping a car at the Jersey City entrance to the Holland Tunnel was reported in critical condition yesterday with a wound in his side. The man identified as his assailant was also listed as critically wounded.

title: OPERETTA: 'H.M.S. PINAFORE' AND 'TRIAL BY JURY' OFFERED
description: ''THINGS are seldom what they seem,'' Little Buttercup warned during a Gilbert and Sullivan double feature at Symphony Space yesterday afternoon. And, as if in answer to her words, the highly honored, tune-rich ''H.M.S. Pinafore'' and the less reknowned, more scrappily clothed, ''Trial by Jury'' proved t o be like the two babes switched by Buttercup at birth. For by the en d of the Gilbert and Sullivan Players productions - which are runn ing through Sunday - thelower-class ''Trial'' seemed to high honors b orn, and noble ''Pinafore'' seemed a bit poverty stricken.

title: Steven Peters Weds Nancy Freedman
description: Nancy Robin Freedman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Freedman of Riverside, Conn., was married yesterday to Steven Morris Peters, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest S. Peters of Longboat Key, Fla. Rabbi Bernard Cohn and Cantor Erwin Hirsch performed the ceremony in the Crystal Room of the Plaza Hotel.

title: REAGAN'S WAR ON OIL CHEATING
description: To the Editor:

title: RETIREMENT--JAPANESE-STYLE
description: ''I don't expect that my children will want to help me,'' said Isa Godai, 81 years old, as she helped her 89-year-old husband into a chair. ''I don't want to depend on anyone because I may feel betrayed. I believe in independence and freedom.''

title: EDUCATOR PROVIDES A CURE FOR 'SOPHO MORE SLUMP'
description: A former private school headmaster has a generally profitable cure for what was once known as ''sophomore slump,'' a condition that leads a student to question the value and purpose of traditional education and that is often treated by taking time off from school.

title: U.S., AID THE AFGHANS
description: Just two years ago, when Soviet forces rolled into Afghanistan to prevent the overthrow of the Communist regime installed in the bloody 1978 coup, most of the world thought that Afghanis tan was conquered. Few observers would have predicted then that Mos cow's new puppets would fail as badly as their predecessors, and that in 1982 the Afghan people would still be fighting for their freedom, and more strongly than ever.

title: Bridge: It's Hard to Play Seriously When Nothing Is at Stake
description: In bridge, as in many contests, play may continue when the result is a foregone conclusion. In such circumstances the customary grim concentration is likely to be replaced by a degree of levity.

title: IRT TRAIN DERAILS AT E. 125TH ST.
description: A subway tr ain derailed yesterday near the 125th Street station on the East Side IRT. No one was hurt, but southbound local service was disrupted for more than five hours, the Transit Authority said.

title: Texas Thief Apologizes And Returns 10 Snakes
description: A thief who lowered himself into the Fort Worth Zoo's reptile house through a skylight and stole 10 rare snakes returned the creatures with a note of apology, zoo officials said today.

title: AIRLINES EXTEND RECORD FOR NONFATAL SERVICE
description: Washington, Jan. 3 (AP)--The nation's major airlines have gone 26 months without a fatal accident, eight months longer than the previous record, the Federal Aviation Administration said Friday.

title: BRIEFING
description: I T'S uncanny to some Reagan watchers that Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. often appears in California when the President journeys back there. This time, Mr. Haig delivered a speech in San Francisico and played a round of golf in Palm Springs during Mr. Reagan's holiday visit.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: By Michiko Kakutani EDITH SITWELL. Fire of the Mind. An an- thology by Elizabeth Salter and Allanah Harper. 320 pages. Vanguard. $15.95.

title: MILITARY COUP IN GHANA ALARMS WEST AFRICAN GOVERNMENTS
description: The military coup in Ghana last week has alarmed governments, both civilian and military, in West Africa, according to African and Western diplomats.

title: THE CURSE OF NOT KNOWING
description: A private report from Warsaw, based on access to high-level information, said that Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski was on the verge of suicide about 10 days ago. According to this account, Poland's military leader was in a state of despair when he learned that miners were killed and workers were solemnly enraged at what he said was a regime of national salvation.

title: TV: 'KID FROM NOWHERE' ON NBC
description: ONE of the best things about ''The Kid From Nowhere,'' which will be seen tonight at 9 on NBC-TV, is its handicapped star. This television movie is about Down's syndrome, and it features a 12-year-old actor, Ricky Wittman, who is himself a Down's syndrome victim. As written by Judy Farrell and directed by Beau Bridges, the movie is affecting, interesting and not unduly sudsy. And the presence of Ricky Wittman brings the to story an authenticity that could not otherwise be achieved. He brings to it an unexpected warmth and humor, too.

title: MISSOURI GETS VOTE TO GAIN FINAL FOUR
description: Although his Notre Dame basketball team is floundering this season, Digger Phelps, the coach of the Irish, can spot talent in the opposition. Saturday night he found it in unbeaten Missouri, which beat the Irish, 92-70, in Kansas City, Mo.

title: A JUSTICE'S HEALTH: WHAT IS PRIVATE?
description: Associate Justice William H. Rehnquist of the Supreme Court went home yesterday from a Washington hospital after a one-week stay for a flare-up of a chronic low back problem and after reportedly experiencing a serious adverse reaction to a drug prescribed for his backache before his admission to the hospital.

title: JULIE BENELL
description: Julie Benell, a reporter and editor on food who worked 25 years at The Dallas Morning News, died Friday after a long illness. She was 76 years old. Mrs. Benell, a native of San Antonio, was a former concert pianist who switched to the stage and later to performances on radio and television. She was the author of a recipe book , "Let's Eat at Home."

title: People
description: * John M. Pope appointed to vice president of marketing for the consumer products division of the Western Publishing Company, a subsidiary of Mattel Inc.

title: Job Seekers in Oilfield Facing Police Checks
description: Starting Monday, employers seeking to weed out fugitives from justice among oilfield workers applying here may ask applicants to undergo checking by the police.

title: Bond List Unavailable
description: A schedule of bond offerings for this week was not available because of the New Year's holiday.

title: OPINIONS DIFFER ON REAGAN'S EFFORTS TO CUT AWAY RULES AND REGULATIONS
description: Until the Reagan Administration came to town last January, it looked like the bus fleet up in Fairbanks, Alaska, was going to have to be equipped with rear-door elevators for passengers in wheelchairs.

title: VOLCKER MAINTAINS A FIRM HAND AT FED
description: -Paul A. Volcker, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, was asked last summer what would get him to ease his tight grip on the nation's money supply. "Impeachment," he answered quickly.

title: SMALL CITY'S TRANSIT HANGS BY A THREAD
description: Against considerable odds, officials here are working to save a public transit system that has been fading along with the economic vitality of this once-prosperous steel city. The bus sys tem, operated by the Western Reserve Transit Authority, shut down for a month after the November election, when voters turned down a proposal to increase the property tax that helps finance it. A bout 6,000 daily riders had to scramble for other transportatio n. The local authorities, their system operating now on interim aid f rom the state, plan to put the money issue again before the voters Fe b. 2.

title: CULT LEAVING JERSEY CASTLE FOR OREGON
description: Followers of a guru from India who upset townspeople when they moved into a castle in Montclair, N.J., have decided to relocate in Oregon.

title: A DEMOCRATIC TURKEY MUST GO BEYOND THE 'LEGACY OF ATATURK'
description: To the Editor:

title: DEMOCRATS BORROW G.O.P. STRATEGIES
description: If imitation is the sincerest flattery, Republicans should be very flattered these days. For from the ashes of the Democratic debacle in the elections of 1980 has emerged a group of Democratic organizations that bear a striking resemblance to such conservative precursors as the National Conservative Po litical Action Committee and the policy-oriented Amer ican Enterprise Institute.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article Dec. 13 on a Philadelphia murder case contained an incorrect reference to the Association of Black Journalists. The association has not joined a defense committee formed in behalf of Mumia Abu-Jamal, who was arrested in the slaying of a police officer.

title: U.S. Offers Shipping Aid
description: The Reagan Administration supports Congressional efforts to ease antitrust regulations it believes have hurt the United States merchant shipping industry's ability to compete with foreign shippers, according to Transportation Secretary Drew Lewis.

title: Purchasing Agents Cite Deeper Slide
description: The deeper slide into the recession foreseen in November by purchasing agents at many of the nation's leading industrial companies materialized in December.

title: BITTERNESS GROWS AFTER MALTA VOTE
description: The businessman was visibly agitated. He said he had received death threats and had been legally harassed for his support o f th e opposition Nationalist Party, which finished a close second in the parliamentary elections Dec. 12.

title: Banking Free-for-All Ends in Turkey
description: Ismail Mertoglu worked hard as a laborer for eight years in West Germany and Libya and then invested all his savings with a local broker. When the broker failed to pay back either his capital or interest last month, Mr. Mertoglu killed himself.

title: SOUTH KOREAN CABINET SHUFFLED TO SPUR ECONOMY
description: President Chun Doo Hwan of South Korea appointed a new Prime Minister today and replaced five other ministers in his first major Cabinet shuffle since becoming head of state in September 1980.

title: Quake Hits in Mid-Atlantic
description: A sharp earthquake occurred today in the middle of the Atlantic Ocean between South America and Africa, a spokesman for the United States Geologic Survey said.

title: Black Hawks 4, Wings 3
description: CHICAGO (UPI) - Denis Savard scored with 3 seconds left to finish a four-goal third period for Chicago. The goal, on a slap shot after he crossed the blue line, was Savard's second of the game and 21st of the season.

title: COMMITTEE AIDE'S WORK FOR MEDIA IS CHALLENGED
description: ABC television's news program ''20/20'' paid a Congressional staff aide $5,000 in 1980 to help prepare an investigative report on insurance abuses involving the elderly.

title: Increases Planned In National Ad Budgets
description: Sixty percent of 800 ad managers of national advertiser companies responding to a survey in October said that they would be increasing their advertising budgets in 1982, according to an article in the January issue of Magazine Age magazine. And, the magazine reported, that increase will average 23 percent.

title: PLAN ON PRIOR APPROVAL FOR MEDICAID IS BEGUN
description: A program calling for prior approval of Medicaid claims took effect in Indiana on Friday in a money-saving effort prompted by the Federal Government's reduction in its share of medical payments.

title:
Relationships;
SIBLINGS TRY LIVING TOGETHER
description: U NTIL last spring, Patrick Dillon, a screenwriter, and his younger brother, Tom, a patrolman in the South Bronx, had little daily contact with each other.

title: YOUR I.R.A. MILLION MAY NOT BUY ALL THAT MUCH
description: To the Editor:

title: The Editorial Notebook The Endless Fifties
description: Q: When is a decade longer than a decade? A: When revived by a later generation, as may occur with the continuing re-run of the 1950's, and early 1960's.

title: Miss Gabler Wed To M. L. Cantor
description: Kathryn Gabler, director of the Law Associates Placement Service, and Melvyn L. Cantor, a member of the law firm of Simpson, Thacher & Bartlett, were married yesterday at the bride's Manhattan home. The Rev. Carl E. Flemister, executive minister of the American Baptist Churches of Metropolitan New York, performed the ceremony.

title: Notes on People; Shelley Bruce's Return
description: She didn't sing or dance, but the weekend appearance of Shelley Bruce on a WNEW-TV leukemia telethon was her first public performance since 1979, when she outgrew the Broadway role of ''Annie,'' Miss Bruce said yesterday from her Rutherford, N.J., home.

title: REAGAN AND ALLEN TO MEET TO DISCUSS POSSIBLE CHANGES
description: President Reagan will meet with Richard V. Allen, his national security adviser, in the next few days to discuss Mr. Allen's status in the Administration, White House officials said today.

title: ANNIVERSARIES ARE INSPIRATION FOR GIFTS TO THE NEEDIEST
description: Anniversaries of many kinds are the inspiration for contributions to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. However, few are as notable as that celebrated by Hannah Herz of Kew Gardens, Queens, who, with her parents and brother, arrived in the United States from Germany on Dec. 20, 1937.

title: Miller Wins in Playoff
description: Johnny Miller of the United States defeated Severiano Ballesteros of Spain on the ninth hole of a sudden-death playoff in the $1 million Sun City Classic today and won the richest prize ever offered in golf.

title: THE CRAZY SEASON
description: One year ago, the talk was of the ''subway slasher'' and of a man who killed sleeping derelicts. No late night TV news was complete without man-on-the-street interviews about the streets being unsafe; homicides were at a record high.

title: ERWIN CANHAM, LONGTIME EDITOR OF CHRISTIAN SCIENCE MONITOR, DIES
description: Erwin D. Canham, who guided The Christian Science Monitor as its chief news executive for nearly three decades, died yesterday in Agana, Guam. It was under Mr. Canham's leadership that the churchsponsored paper attained its reputation for thoughtful, analytical coverage. Mr. Canham was 77 years old.

title: Talafous Is Retiring With No Regrets After Trade
description: Dean Talafous, the tall, smiling forward who decided to retire on New Year's Day after the Rangers had traded him to the Quebec Nordiques, said yesterday that he was quitting hockey with no regret, no bitterness.

title: DELBELLO BEGINS HIS THIRD TERM IN WESTCHESTER
description: Alfred B. DelBello was sworn in today for his third term as Westchester County Executive. He pledged to reverse what he said were trends at the Federal and state levels that had all but eliminated the discretionary powers of local governments.

title: AIDES SAY PRESIDENT OPPOSES QUOTAS IN AFFIRMATIVE ACTION
description: White House aides, clarifying President Reagan's recent remarks about civil rights, say he believes the Supreme Court was wrong in upholding an affirmative action program that reserved a certain number of places for blacks.

title: Notes on People; Helping the Deaf 'Talk to Each Other' by Phone
description: It was during a shopping expedition for a pocket computer of his own that the proverbial light bulb went on above the head of Dr. Harry Levitt of the Graduate School of the City University of New York.

title: OUTDOORS: CAROLINA AS A HUNTER'S DELIGHT
description: FAIRFIELD, N.C. VISITING Bob Hester's Mattamuskeet Inn, a waterfowl hunting establishment on the north shore of the lake of the same name, one tends to react like a child in a toy shop. One can go after puddle ducks in specially created impoundments, and later hunt diving ducks on the lake itself or perhaps Canada geese or snow and blue geese, or sea ducks on Pamlico Sound.

title: Assailant Stabs Doctor In a Brooklyn Hospital
description: A resident physician who had just finished examining a patient at Cumberland Hospital in Brooklyn's Fort Greene section was stabbed on a stairway at 6:45 A.M. yesterday in an attempted robbery, according to the police.

title: FAMILIAR FACE TO GHANAIANS
description: Some months ago, in one of his reflective moods, Jerry John Rawlings acknowledged to a friend that one of the things he regretted about his 112 days in power two years ago was giving up the leadership of Ghana to the elected civilian Government of President Hilla Limann.

title: Notes on People; This Time, the Mayor Will Take a Real Vacation
description: Mayor Koch is not much for vacations. Right after his re-election, for instance, he went to Puerto Rico for a long weekend but spent most of his time making ceremonial appearances and speaking to a group of bond analysts.

title: 'Sugar' Key to Knicks
description: Red Holzman, the Knick coach, will often cry out from the bench: ''Sugar, bring it out front. Sugar, get something going for us.'' Similiar pleas are heard from the players.

title: POLAND SAID TO PRODUCE CASH TO AVOID A DEFAULT
description: The following dispatch is based on information arriving from Poland.

title: SPORTS OWNERS: THEY VARY AS MUCH AS THEIR TEAMS
description: IT is the day after the World Series and a group of truant office workers - all lifelong Yankee-lovers or Yankee-haters - are reviewing and debating the key moments of the baseball season in a Manhattan bar.

title: THE BIG BOARD'S BEST AND WORST OF 1981
description: The New York Stock Exchange's worst performers of 1981 were either victims of a changing economy that left them mired in unprofitability or of poor management decisions.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, JANUARY 4, 1982
description: International European Community ambassadors will m eet in W arsaw today with Poland's military leader, Gen. Wojciech Jaruz elski, according to the West German news agency. It said diplomatic s ources had reported thatGeneral Jaruzelski had requested the meeting. In the meantime, Poland's military Government promised to incr ease wages to offset some of the steep rises in the price of stapl e goods. It was also announced that the Polish currency had been d evalued. (Page A1, Col. 6.) Poland now has the money to pay the $350 million that it said it needed to pay Western banks and avoid technical default at the end of 1981, Western sources said. The sources said this information had been given by Deputy Prime Minister Mieczyslaw Rakowski during a visit last week to West Germany. It was assumed that the $350 million came from the Soviet bloc, probably from Moscow. (A8:1-2.)

title: BUDGET CUTS WILL SLOW WORK ON WATERGATE TAPES
description: The contents of 4,000 hours of Presiident Nixon's White House tapes that have never been disclosed will remain secret until 1987 because of budget cuts, Government officials say.

title: OIL BOOM BRINGS CASH, AND CRIME, TO SHETLAND ISLES
description: Mattie Jamieson, an elderly resident of picturesque Scalloway, has just received $185 to help with winter heating bills. Kenneth Pottinger, owner of the Ardent, a new fishing boat, was awarded a $835,000 loan. And Arthur Williamson's family fish-processing company received $22,000 to help promote new products.

title: NEW, 'SAFER' TYPES OF KEROSENE HEATER CALLED FIRE HAZARDS
description: A new type of kerosene heater on the market worries fire safety officials because, they say, carelessness or misuse could cause deaths and injuries.

title: YOUTHS VIE FOR ARTS AID
description: One hundred and fifty high-school-age finalists in a nationwide search for talent in the arts will gather today on the campus of the University of Miami for a two-week series of auditions, workshops and consultations. They will be competing for more than $400,000 in cash and scholarships from the National Foundation for Advancement in the Arts, which was founded last fall by business and civic leaders in the Miami area.

title: Sports World Specials; Sultan of a C League
description: How is that the man who holds the single-season record for the most home runs in organized baseball never even got close to a major league tryout?

title: SMOKE DETECTORS THAT MAY DO HARM
description: To the Editor:

title: GEORGE KENNAN SAYS SANCTIONS WERE HASTY
description: George F. Kennan, former Ambassador to the Soviet Union, suggested today that the Reagan Administration should have waited ''until more of the returns are in'' before passing judgment on the military regime in Poland.

title: Barge Catches Fire After Hitting Bridge
description: A barge loaded with a poisonous corrosive chemical ran into a Galveston Bay drawbridge and caught fire today, the authorities said.

title: IRAQ SAYS JET FIGHTERS FROM ISRAEL VIOLATED AIRSPACE A 2D TIME
description: Iraq, for the second time in five days, charged today that Israeli jet fighters had violated its a irspace.

title: Dow Up 7.52 in Slow Trading
description: Led by International Business Machines, the stock market posted a moderate adva nce yesterday amid slow trading in the first session of 1982.

title: REGAN TO FACE TEST AT G.O.P. MEETING
description: Failure to win a majority at tomorrow's State Republican Committee meeting would drive State Comptroller Edward V. Regan out of the race for the party's nomination for Governor, the party's state chairman said yesterday.

title: Business People; Inter-Regional Financial Appoints Executives
description: With its acquisition of Rauscher Pierce Refsnes Inc., a Texas securities firm, completed on Dec. 31, the Inter-Regional Financial Group has elected Richard D. McFarland, 51, as president. He succeeds Thomas E. Holloran, 52, who had been chairman and president and now formally assumes the title of chief executive officer along with the chairmanship.

title: About Education; THE IRREVERSIBLE EFFECTS OF THE 'CREATIONISM' FUROR
description: THE court challenge of an Arkansas law that defines creationism as a science has done more than focus on what most scientists consider a silly issue. It has exposed the vulnerability of the public schools to noneducational, political pressures.

title: LEGISLATIVE PRACTICES AND PAY ALSO D IFFER IN REGION
description: By law, Connecticut legislators convene to legislate less often than their counterparts in the New York area. In their two-year terms they are limited to one short session (in even-numbered years, starting in early February and ending in early May) and one long session (in odd-numbered years, from January to June).

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Comsat, Washington, has named Robert W. Kinzie vice president, satellite systems and technology of Comsat General; Edmund Bartlett 3d, vice president, finance and administration of Comsat General; Don R. Owen, vice president of earth station programs of Comsat General, and Stanley L. Shubilla, vice president of finance and administration of Comsat World Systems division.

title: PUPILS GET LESSON ON CARING BY CONTRIBUTING TO NEEDIEST
description: ''Now more than ever,'' the note read in part, ''giving is caring, giving is sharing, giving is helping, giving is living.'' The message accompanied a gift of $191.94 to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund from students of Miriam S. Gemson at Lawrence Junior High School in Lawrence, L.I.

title: BERNSTEIN PREPARING NEW OPERA FOR HOUSTON PREMIERE IN 1983
description: Leonard Bernstein, who for the last 30 years has been represented on the operatic stage by a single one-act work, ''Trouble in Tahiti,'' has composed a new, full-length opera as a sequel to that work. ''Tahiti Two'' - the tentative designation for the still untitled opera - will be given its premiere in Houston in the spring of 1983 and then taken to Washington and Milan.

title: WANNA FIX YOUR FIRM?
description: A quiet but potentially terminal disease has been creeping through the private sector of the economy. Its symptoms are subtle, afflicting only the most successful small businesses. The ''carriers'' are consultants.

title: DANKER LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-After a tax credit of $10,393...C-Net loss

title: Hearing Ordered On Prison Issue
description: A Federal judge asked the city's Department of Correction to show cause why he should not temporarily permit the state to keep its inmates in city jails for periods longer than 48 hours.

title: Sports People; Navy Names Coach
description: Gary Tranquill, the offensive coordinator and passing coach at West Virginia, has been appointed football coach at the Naval Academy.

title: G.O.P. APPARENTLY LOSER IN MISSOURI REDISTRICITNG
description: With the state Legislature deadlocked on the issue, three Federal judges have redrawn Missouri's Congressional boundaries in a manner that appears likely to preserve the three Democratic Congressional seats in the St. Louis area and cost the Republicans a seat.

title: U.S. AND BONN SAID TO AGREE TO AVOID 'CRISIS' IN WEST
description: Poland still owes $500 million to foreign banks in interest. Page D6. By BERNARD GWERTZMAN Spec ial to the Ne w York Times

title: ALLISON SEEKS TO REGAIN FORM
description: On his first shift on ice in the National Hockey League a season and a half ago, Mike Allison, at the age of 19, scored his first goalfor the Range rs, against the Boston Bruins.

title: ARTHUR P. IRVING
description: Arthur P. Irving, publisher emeritus of The Post-Star in Glens Falls, N.Y., died yesterday at Glens Falls Hospital.

title: AMERICAN PIONEER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MUBARAK, INSTALLING CABINET, STRESSES STABILITY
description: President Hosni Mubarak swore in a new Egyptian Cabinet today and ordered it to focus on internal calm and on national economic and social stability.

title: Virginia, Kentucky Get Mare-Import Approval
description: Virginia and Kentucky are the first states approved to handle breeding-age mares imported from countries affected by a highly contagious venereal disease of horses, Federal officials said today.

title: Right to Solicit in Mall For E.R.A. Is Upheld
description: A Superior Court judge ruled today that the management of a major shopping mall had violated the free-speech rights of supporters of the proposed Federal equal rights amendment when it barred them from collecting petition signatures in the mall.

title: COURT TEST FOR VOICE ANALYZER
description: ''The Truth Machine - simply turn it on and if anyone ever tells you less than the truth, you'll know!'' That's the claim Telestar Inc. used to make for its device that monitors voices for signs of stress.

title: SAUDIS DISAVOW PRINCE'S REMARKS ON EVENTUAL ACCEPTANCE OF ISRAEL
description: Saudi Arabia's offer to accept Israel's existence and the subsequent Saudi denial that the offer had been made produced no expressions of surprise or disappointment in Israel today.

title: CRISES AND CUTBACKS STIR FRESH CONCERNS ON NATION'S PRISONS
description: The problem of protecting Americans from criminals, while providing a corrections system that does more than ''warehouse'' felons, is arousing fresh concern and study among government officials around the nation.

title: Canada Paper Data
description: British Columbia is overtaking Quebec as Canada's leading producer of pulp and paper, according to industry statistics released today. According to the Canadian Pulp and Paper Association, total pulp and paper production in 1980 was 6.4 million tons for Quebec, up from 4 million tons in 1960, and 6.03 million tons in British Columbia, up from 1.9 million tons. Overall production in Canada as recorded by Statistics Canada was 21 million tons in 1980, almost double the 10.4 million tons produced two decades earlier.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article yesterday on George Ken- nan's views of the sanctions imposed against the Soviet Union incorrectly described the Institute for Advanced Study. It is in Princeton, N.J., but has no connection with the university.

title: COLLEGES FIGHT DROP IN NURSING ENROLLMENT
description: FOR a few weeks before graduation, seniors at the Nursing School of New York's City College take a credit course that has been dubbed ''What the Real World Is.''

title: Jartran Files For Chapter 11
description: Jartran Inc., a truck rental company started by the founder and former chairman of the Ryder System Inc., has sought court protection from creditors under Federal bankruptcy law, according to Frank B. Hall & Company, which has acquired 90 percent of Jartran's stock.

title: Steel Output Up 5.7%
description: Steel production rose to 1.68 million tons in the week ended last Saturday, up 5.7 percent from the previous week's 1.59 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

title: ISRAELIS PRESS U.S. TO SHUN U.N. DRAFT
description: Israel tried to dissuade the United States today from supporting a proposed Security Council resolution urging nations to ''take appropriate measures'' aimed at encouraging Israel to revoke its annexation of the Golan Heights.

title: U.S. Ships to Visit Singapore
description: Three 7th Fleet ships, the amphibious assault ship Tripoli, the transport ship Duluth and the tank landing ship Fresno, are scheduled to arrive Wednesday for a five-day visit, the American Embassy said today.

title: GOV. KING SUES BOSTON GLOB
description: Gov. Edward J. King filed a $3.6 million lawsuit against The Boston Globe today for what he termed ''false and defamatory'' columns and cartoons published about him.

title: BOND PRICES IN SHARP DECLINE
description: Prices of Government bonds fell sharply yesterday, with half the losses occurring after the Federal Reserve announced an unexpectedly large rise in the nation's money supply for the week ended Dec.23.

title: Business People; President Is Selected At Pioneer Corporation
description: C.David Culver, 45, has been appointed president of the Pioneer Corporation, an oil and gas company based in Amarillo, Tex. He succeeds K.Bert Watson, 57, who continues as chairman and chief executive officer.

title: Auto Output Off 1.5% in '81
description: Auto production in the United States fell about 1.5 percent in 1981, to the lowest level in 2 0 years, as a prolonged sales slump forced sharp production cutbacks late in the year, according to company reports released t oday.

title: REAGAN HAILS HIS 'INTEGRITY'; HAIG'S DEPUTY IS SUCCESSOR; News An alysis
description: As President Reagan's new national security adviser, William P. Clark Jr. is more likely, at first, to reduce friction and in-fighting at top levels of the Administration than to make an imprint on the Administration's foreign policy.

title: William Taylor, Chief Of A.I.D. Recruitment
description: William M. Taylor, chief of the recruitment branch of the United States Agency for International Development, died Thursday after open-heart surgery at George Washington University Hospital in Washington. He was 61 years old.

title: MISS SHRIVER WINS
description: Pam Shriver and Bettina Bunge scored opening-round victories tonight in the $200,000 Avon Washington tournament, the first stop on the winter tour. Leslie Allen of New York also won.

title: THE WRONGFULLY JAILED
description: To the Editor:

title: POLITICS AND ECONOMICS
description: ''The next twelve to eighteen months,'' Felix Rohatyn writes in the current New York Review of Books, ''are likely to be the most dangerous that I can remember in my thirty-odd years in the banking business. ... A national economic emergency, which has long been threatening, might soon be upon us, with its inevitable social implications.''

title: Another Kind of Broadcast Fairness
description: Ronald Reagan's deregulators are up to some mischief at the Federal Communications Commission. Radio and television broadcasters justifiably long for a freer hand in programming. But the commission, in league with the Office of Management and Budget, is also contemplating changes in the equal employment obligations imposed on stations. That kind of deregulation is decidedly not in the public interest.

title: 'ATLANTIC CITY' WINS CRITICS' PRIZES
description: ''Atlantic City,'' Louis Malle's film about an aging numbers runner and his changing fortunes, was voted the best film of 1981 by the National Society of Film Critics, a 40-member group of newspaper and magazine critics from Boston, Chicago, Los Angeles, New York and other cities.

title: NEW AIR CONTROLLERS' UNION CHIEF SAYS U.S. SHOULD REHIRE STRIKERS
description: The new head of the decertified air traffic controllers' union, Gary Eads, said yesterday t hat his main goal was to obtain the reinstatement of the 11,500 controllers who were dismissed by the Reagan Admini stration last August for participating in an illegal walkout.

title: Sports People; Whiz Kid Pursued
