description: Mark Cline, a West Virginia high school basketball player, is such a prospect for college coaches and recruiters that he has had to have his telephone number changed. Cline, 6 feet 7 inches and still growing, has averaged 34.2 points in the first four games this season for the Williamson team.

title: U.S. TO APPEAL RULING THAT UPSET LONGER DEADLINE ON EQUAL RIGHTS
description: The Justice Department said today it would appeal a Federal judge's ruling that Congress violated the Constitution when it extended the deadline for states to ratify the proposed equal rights amendment.

title: COMMON MARKET PROMISES NOT TO UNDERCUT U.S. MOVES
description: The European Common Market, while neither joining nor endorsing American sanctions against Poland, promised today to consult with the United States on steps to be taken and to avoid any action that would dilute the economic sanctions imposed by Washington.

title: TV: 'AMBUSH MURDERS,' BASED ON TRIAL
description: TONIGHT'S based-on-a-true-story movie is ''The Ambush Murders'' on CBS-TV at 9 o'clock. Based on a book by Ben Bradlee Jr., Tony Kayden's script traces the case of an outspoken black activist accused of murdering two white policemen in Lindero, Calif.

title: SOAP OPERA IN MEXICO DRAMATIZING BIRTH CONTROL
description: An early scene shows the dilapidated, noisy and overcrowded home of a poor Mexican family as a grown-up daughter reports tearfully that she is pregnant for the third time in three years. ''I don't want my child to grow up in a place like this,'' she screams.

title: WHITE MOTOR CITES HUGE LOSS
description: The White Motor Corporation, the ailing truck manufacturer that has been trying to reorganize after filing a bankruptcy petition last year, announced yesterday that it lost more than $300 million on operations and the sale of assets during the 15-month period ending March 31, 1981.

title: Xerox Makes Price Changes
description: The Xerox Corporation announced an average price reduction of 25 percent on three of its low- to mid-volume copying machines and increases in service contract rates for all its copiers and duplicators.

title: AGAIN, THE 'ETERNAL QUEST OF SCRATCH'
description: The 1982 pro golf tour begins this week in Tucson, Ariz., and the P.G. Wodehouse exhibit at the Pierpont Morgan Library here winds down; the two events have a connection.

title: President Is Named At Steelmet Inc.
description: Albert J. Wein, 57 years old, has been named president and chief operating officer of Steelmet Inc., a leading secondary metals company with headquarters in Pittsburgh. He succeeds Joseph F. Rooney, 53, who resigned to pursue personal interests.

title: WELFARE: PUBLIC, PRIVATE
description: A dramatic shift is transforming America's w elfare system. Public benefits are declining while the private w elfare system has grown rapidly. The shift is not a simple s ubstitution: Those losing public benefits will not gain from growth i n the private system. Those losing the most are likely to be the w orking poor. People who work and then lose or leave their jobs, and s ome who are regularly employed but in low-wage jobs, get minimal p rivate welfare benefits. Since many cuts in the public welfare s ystem are directed specifically at the working poor, they will o ften find that they qualify neither for public nor private benefits.

title: Transactions
description: COLLEGE NAVY - Named Gary F. Tranquill foot- ball coach. Tranquill, an assistant coach at West Virginia the last three seasons, succeeds George Welsh, who resigned to become coach at Virginia.

title: A Way to Remember Frank Melvin
description: Essex County Prosecutor George Schneider will event ually provide some insight into how Frank Melvin, a member of the Guardian Angels, died last wee k from shots apparently fired by a Newark police officer. In t he meantime the incident, which has generated bitter denunciations of the police by leaders of the paramilitary anti-crimegroup, points up the need for better relations between the police and community anti-crime efforts.

title: JAMES RIVER, AMERICAN CAN IN DEAL
description: The James River Corporation has tentatively agreed to buy certain paper-making operations of the American Can Company for about $420 million in cash and stock, American Can said yesterday.

title: MAREE OPTS TO RUN IN FIFTH AVE. MILE
description: The scheduling of the final event of the so-called triple crown of foot racing - a one-mile run in Eugene, Ore. - on the same day as the Fifth Avenue Mile has angered Fred Lebow, director of the New York event.

title: TUESDAY, JANUARY 5, 1982; Markets
description: A $1.4 billion increase in the nation's basic money supply was reported by the Federal Reserve. The unexpected rise startled the credit markets, where a slight decline had been expected. (Page D1.) Short-term and long-term interest rates rose sharply after the Fed's money supply announcement. (D12.)

title: RITE AID CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 28
Oil Price Cuts Are Reported
description: Mexico has cut the price of its lower-grade crude oil by $2 a barrel, to $26.50, and Venezuela has dropped prices on several lower grades by as much as 90 cents a barrel, an industry newsletter reported yesterday.

title: Market Place; The Attraction Of Filmways
description: TO seekers of buried treasure Filmways Inc. is not the disaster its persistent losses in recent years might suggest. The company has assets of substantial value and that helps explain why last month three separate groups expressed an interest in acquiring all or part of this self-proclaimed buyout candidate.

title: Accord on Talafous Deal
description: The Rangers said yesterday that they and the Quebec Nordiques had reaffirmed the validity of the trade that brought Robbie Ftorek, a center, to New York for two forwards, Jere Gilli s and Dean Talafous.

title: CSX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes $11.7 million gain on the sale of an interest in the Kentucky & Indiana Terminal Railroad Co

title: TEMPORARY TRANSIT PATROLS BY CITY POLICE ARE WEIGHED
description: Mayor Koch directed Police Commissioner Robert J. McGuire yesterday to develop a plan for temporarily reinforcing the Transit Authority's police force, possibly with city police officers who would work overtime.

title: The Department of Detention
description: ''People are losing their minds. Prison does that. It makes them think and say crazy things. It is so crazy you cannot remember.'' The speaker, a man named Lucian, is not in prison, but he's not exaggerating. For 10 months, the United States Department of Justice has kept him locked up, inside the wire at the Krome Avenue Detention Facility in Miami. Why? Because he, like more than 2,000 other detainees, is a Haitian who entered this country illegally -and because detention is regarded as a way to deter other migrants.

title: HOSPITALS IN CITY INCREASING SECURITY
description: Faced with increasing attacks on doctors and other employees, New York City hospitals have stepped up security measures in the last several months.

title: OXFORD INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 27
BARNWELL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Yr to Sept 30
description: B-After $3,633,285 loss from discontinued operations... C-Net loss aater $2,552,561 loss from discontinued operations

title: MOBIL LOSES APPEAL TO BLOCK U.S. STEEL
description: A Federal appeals court today rejected the Mobil Corporation's emergency application to delay the United States Steel Corporation's $6.3 billion purchase of the Marathon Oil Company.

title: Christmas Sales Plunge
description: The just completed Christmas shopping season was the worst for major department stores since 1974 because price cutting that was aimed at enticing customers into stores erased potential profits from a strong last-minute buying surge, according to several industry analysts.

title: Railroad Merger Is Completed
description: The Burlington Northern Railroad has completed its takeover of the Colorado & Southern Railway Company following approval by the Interstate Commerce Commission, officials of the two companies said.

title: SPACE TELESCOPE HOLDS NASA'S HOPES FOR GRAND DISCOVERIES IN UNIVERSE
description: THE large circular mirror stood on display in the fac

title: 9 WOMEN AND 3 MEN ARE CHOSEN FOR JURY IN ATLANTA MURDERS TRIAL
description: A jury of nine women and three men was selected today to hear the first-degree murder case against Wayne B. Williams, the 23-year-old self-styled music promoter accused of killing two of the 28 young blacks who were slain from July 1979 to May 1981.

title: TURKS TELL ITALY OF AGGA ASSOCIATE
description: A man standing next to Mehmet Ali Agca when he shot the Pope May 13 has been identified by Turkish investigators as Oemer Ay, a Turk who is known to have been an associate of Mr. Agca for many years.

title: POLISH AIRWAVES: MEAT MAY BE IN THIN SUPPLY
description: Following are excerpts from domestic Polish radio and television broadcasts as transcribed and translated from the Polish by the Foreign Broadcast Information Service, a United States Government agency.

title: Sports of the Times; BETTER TO COME FOR GIANTS, JETS
description: SAN FRANCISCO AS he went from player to player and from coach to coach, Wellington Mara, the president of the Giants, had a smile and the same consoling words.

title: No Headline
description: GHANA'S DEPOSED PRESIDENT IS ARRESTED

title: NOTES ON PEOPLE
description: A Theater Curse Works For more than 18 months, Mary Lou Rosato had participated in workshop productions of the play, which she loved, and not only because her role was the second most prominent in it.

title: LIFE-SAVING BENEFITS OF LOW-CHOLESTEROL DIET AFFIRMED IN RIGOROUS STUDY
description: designed study has shown more persuasively than any previous experiment that eating less fats and cholesterol can reduce the chances of suffering a heart attack or of dying suddenly from heart disease. The study also showed a smaller benefit from stopping smoking or reducing the number of cigarettes smoked.

title: The Doctor's World; 'CURE' FOR AN EYE AILMENT ILLUSTRATES THE PUBLIC'S VULNERABILITY TO CLAIMS
description: THE hereditary eye disorder called retinitis pigmentosa starts with night blindness. To imagine its effects, picture yourself awakening at 3 A.M. and, guided by the dim rays coming through a window from a street light, walking across your dark bedroom, only to stumble on an unseen chair.

title: U.S. Bankers Say Poles Did Not Pay
description: Poland made no significant repayments as of yesterday on about $500 million in past-due interest owed to foreign banks, according to several American bankers.

title: Washington-Chicago Trains Back With a New York Stop
description: The Cardinal passenger train, which runs between Washington and Chicago by way of Cincinnati, will resume three-times-a-week service Friday.

title: Chess: Anti-Mera n Leads the List Of the Ye ar's Top Gambits
description: Despite an overall tendency toward conservative, technical openings, 1981 was a good year for gambits, Even in the highly positional Queen's Indian and Slav Defenses, lively gambit play came to the fore.

title: Fed Backs Thrift Unit, Bank Ties
description: The Federal Reserve Board and the Government agencies that insure deposits in savings institutions have begun establishing the legal machinery needed to enable commercial banks to acquire troubled savings institutions, Frank O'Brien, a Federal Reserve public information officer, said yesterday.

title: Harvester Deal
description: The International Harvester Company said it had been awarded contracts valued at nearly $5 million to supply trucks and parts to Egypt. The Peoria-based company, which recently completed an agreement with 193 lenders to reschedule $3.5 billion in short-term loans, said it would build 105 dump trucks worth $3 million for the Egyptians. The company said it would also build 42 truck chassis for another $1.45 million and would earn $250,000 for subcontract work for the Elgin Sweeper Company of Elgin, Ill.

title: Q & A
description: Q. In digging for coal and minerals, what is the farthest depth at which some form of life has been discovered?

title: B.P. Sells Travel Unit
description: The British Petroleum Company agreed today to sell its wholly owned subsidiary, Rankin Kuhn Travel Ltd., a travel agency and tour operator, to Thomas Cook Ltd., a wholly owned subsidiary of Midland Bank. B.P. and Thomas Cook jointly announced the agreement. Terms were not disclosed.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Airco Inc., a subsidiary of BOC International Ltd., London, said its industrial gases division would build a 300-ton-a-day carbon dioxide facility in Pekin, Ill., for food processing, chilling and freezing applications, for $6 million.

title: 75 Harness Horses Sold For Record $12.4 Million
description: Anthony Pedone of New York, general partner of Boardwalk Farms Ltd., said yesterday that his group had sold its entire stock of 75 standardbreds for $12.4 million in the biggest single-asset sale in harness racing history.

title: Cornell 53, Colgate 38
description: Paul Arand of Cornell, who scored 10 points, was the only player in double figures.Arand scored all his points in the second half to help Cornell win its first game after eight losses.

title: Maine Judge Appointed Fo r Trial of Miami Judge
description: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger named a Federal judge from Maine today to preside over the trial of Alcee Hastings, a Miami Federal judge accused of involvement in a bribery plot.

title: Miners' Union in Britain Calls a Strike Vote
description: Leaders of Britain's 250,000 miners sought authorization today to call a strike. A showdown with miners over a big wage demand would test Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's resolve to hold down pat incr eases just when she feels she is starting to win her war on inflation .

title: HUNGRY TIGER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 20
TWO SLAIN AND ONE HURT IN A MOB-STYLE SHOOTING
description: Two people - one of them a woman storing laundry in a hallway closet in her home - were killed during a gangland attempt to assassinate a convicted pornographer and Mafia member last night on a quiet, residential side street in the Gravesend section of Brooklyn, the police said.

title: Topics Small Bangs, Big Bucks
description: Over a Barrel

title: CSX Profit Up 45.8% in Period
description: A 45.8 percent fourth-quarter earnings gain helped the CSX Corporation, a diversified transportation, leisure, publishing and minerals company, post record earnings for 1981.

title: Avco Embassy
description: Norman Lear, the producer, and his partner, Jerry Perenchio, have closed a deal to purchase Avco Embassy Pictures, their company, the privately held TAT Communications, announced. No price was disclosed, but reports in Daily Variety and other industry publications said the two partners paid between $25 million and $26 million for the motion picture production and distribution company. The name of the movi e c ompany will be changed to Embassy Pictures, a TAT spokesman said.

title: World Bank Sets Fee Vote
description: Directors of the World Bank will vote at a closed meeting Tuesday on increasing the fees it charges for loans to poor nations, officials said today.

title: TEXTS OF ALLEN RESIGNATION AND REAGAN REPLY
description: Following are the texts of the letter of resignation submitted to President Reagan today by Richard V. Allen, the national security adviser, and Mr. Reagan's reply: Richard Allen's Letter

title: PRINCETON, N.J. - The Soviet hegemony established in Eastern Europe in 1945 was from the start an unnatural - and, in the long run, untenable - arrangement.
description: This hegemony was bound to yield, with the passage of time, to a state of affairs more compatible with geopolitical realities, including the traditions and feelings of the affected peoples, and their capacities for lea ding a successful independent national existence. Th e question was only how, at what pace, and in what manner, the c hange would come about.

title: Adam Publications Buys Attenzione
description: Jeno F. Paulucci, the famous entrepreneur, has sold Attenzione magazine for Italian-Americans to Adam Publications. Alan Dambrosio, identified as the lawyer for Adam, said that he would not be able to identify any of the people involved except Ray G. Forenza, who will be general manager, until today. Mr. Forenza, when reached, said he had been ad director of I-AM, one of two shortlived magazines begun in 1976 that had the same target audience as Attenzione.

title: DECISION FILE
description: Every day Federal agencies and courts make decisions that affect the lives of America ns. Here are some recent cases: Nonprofit Groups Vs. Postal Service

title: APPLICATION ENGINEERING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Sports People; Too Rich for Reggie
description: Reggie Jackson made a big bid for a gray and black Corvette, a turbine-powered sports car built by Vince Granatelli, the son of motor racing's Andy Granatelli. Jackson bid $525,000.

title: Archivist to Press On With Watergate Tapes
description: The Archivist of the United States said today that ways would be found to prevent a delay in the release of Richard M. Nixon's still secret White House tape recordings and papers dealing with the Watergate scandals and other controversies of the Nixon Administration.

title: ONEOK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
SECURITY FORCES OF POLISH RULERS PUT AT 250,000
description: The Polish security forces are capable of mobilizing a force of 250,000 in an internal crisis such as the recent imposition of martial law, according to a consultant for the Rand Corporation.

title: NEW FACES REFLECT THE LESSONS OF '81
description: President Reagan is beginning his second year in office with some new faces in ke y positions, as well as some changes in th e White House organizational structure that reflect lessons learn ed in the last year.

title: SPECIALIZED IN CANCER SURGERY
description: Dr. Frank E. Adair, attending surgeon emeritus and former chief of breast service at the Memorial Hospital for Cancer and Allied Diseases, died Thursday at his home in Bedford, N.Y. He was 94 years old.

title: SOFTECH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 27
CRAZY-QUILT PAY PATTERN COVERS TRISTATE OFFICIALS
description: The Governor of New Jersey is going to get a raise. The Mayor of New York has finally accepted a raise. And a study commission says the Governor of Connecticut needs a raise. According to a spot check of public compensation for full-time jobs in the tristate region, the pattern involves an unusual mix of pay and perquisites.

title: No Headline
description: WASHINGTON DEFEATS U.C.L.A.

title: Italian Aid Sent to Poland
description: Nine tons of medicine and food for Poland donated by Italians left today on a special Polish Airlines flight.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Whatever we do is wrong. How can we say to children, 'You can't eat lunch because your parent didn't fill out a form'? On the other hand, if we feed them we're not in compliance with the law.''

title: POLAND'S LEADER WEIGHS DEPORTING SOME UNION CHIEFS
description: The following dispatch is based on information arriving from Poland.

title: ENZYME SYSTEM IN CELLS FOUND TO ACT AS A SWITCH IN GENETIC REPRODUCTION
description: SCIENTISTS in California have discovered a group of substances that can act together to recognize and activate the crucial, minute portion of a chromosome where the instructions for the reproduction of that chromosome are sited.

title: BUSINESS EXCHANGE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Science Library
description: PURE POLITICS AND IMPURE SCIENCE: THE SWINE FLU AFFAIR By Arthur M. Silverstein. 176 pages. The Johns Hopkins University Press. $12.50.

title: Union Assails Pan Am
description: Unionized employees of Pan American World Airways assailed the carrier's management yesterday, contending that it had used their wage concessions to give nonunionized personnel a ''Christmas present.'' Mel Brackett, president of Air Transport Local 504 of the Transport Workers Union, said unionized workers were infuriated at reports that the airline recently gave its 5,000 nonunion employees substantial improvements in their retirement, medical, dental and optical plans. A Pan Am spokesman, James Arey, said he thought that the principal improvement to which the union was objecting was ''an insurance company offering'' that raised the limit of benefits on a noncontributory medical plan.

title: British Ford Strike Off
description: A threatened strike by 54,000 bluecollar workers at 24 Ford Motor Company plants in Britain was postponed today, less than 12 hours before it was to begin. Ford, the biggest auto maker in Britain, avoided the strike by agreeing to bring forward a shorter workweek and improve pensions, although it stood firm in refusing to increase its offer of a 7.4 percent pay rise. Ron Todd, chief negotiator for the union, said that its bargaining committee would recommend that workers accept the new offer, which he said amounted to an effective increase of 18 percent to 20 percent.

title: MISS WEAVER QUITS 'MACBETH'
description: Sigourney Weaver, whose casting as Lady Macbeth was recently announced with fanfare by the Circle in the Square Theater, left the cast Thursday.

title: A LANDLORD'S CASE AGAINST THREE COLUMNS ON ABUSES OF TENANTS
description: To the Editor:

title: PIANIST: DUDLEY MOORE PLAYS
description: THERE was music by Bach, Mozart and Delius. Distinguished musicians such as Robert Mann, Joel Krosnick and Stanley Drucker joined in.

title: Fred Harman, Creator Of 'Red Ryder,' Dies
description: Fred Harman, the cartoonist and artist who created the cowboy comic strip ''Red Ryder,'' died Saturday of complications from a stroke suffered Dec. 27. He was 79 years old.

title: JERSEY RULES OUT SPECIAL INQUIRY IN 'ANGEL' DEATH
description: The New Jersey Attorney General rejected today a demand by the Guardian Angels that he appoint a special prosecutor to investigate the slaying last week by a Newark policeman of one of the volunteer group's members.

title: KOCH CALLS FISCAL PLAN A 'SUCCESS'
description: Mayor Koch took issue yesterda y with City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin's rece nt contention that New York City's capital construction program is fa lling behind schedule. The Mayor argued that his administratio n's record on capital spending ''is one of the city's real success stories.''

title: ALTAMIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: 1980 qr results restated to reflect investment tax credits related to that period and a reclassification of state taxes

title: YOUNG TAKES OATH AS ATLANTA MAYOR
description: Andrew Jackson Young became Atlanta's 55th Mayor tonight in inauguration ceremonies where he reminded several thousand cheering supporters of Atlanta's leading role in integration and the election of blacks and said tha t the city ''must point the way in theeconomic aren a as it has in social and political spheres.''

title: Japan Research Spending Rises
description: Japan spent $23.9 billion on research in the fiscal year 1980, making it second only to the United States in research outlays, the Prime Minister's office reported today.

title: COHALAN CHARGES SUFFOLK IS SHORTCHANGED ON AID
description: The Suffolk County Executive, Peter F. Cohalan, charged today that suburbia was being shortchanged on state aid for the benefit of New York City.

title: 33 Are Reported Slain In Guatemala Violence
description: At least 33 people, including 21 guerrillas, were killed in violence here over the weekend, the authorities said today. They also reported widespread injuries and property damage.

title: RICHERT'S 'AMERICAN SUCCESS'
description: BECAUSE William Richert's ''American Success'' never had the wide release originally intended for it - having already been shown on cable television, it is only now having its theatrical premiere at the Public Theater -it qualifies as a curiosity rather than a flop. And, as curiosities go, it's a nutty but appealing one.

title: 'NICKELBY' CLOSING IS AS SPECTACULAR AND STAR-STUDDED AS ITS OPENING
description: ''Nicholas Nickleby'' closed on Sunday night, very much the way it opened on Oct. 4. People cried; people applauded; the actors, meanwhile, just got on with it. ''You must understand,'' said Lila Kaye, the c heerful actress who played Mrs. Sq ueers, Mrs. Crummles and any number of walk-ons, ''we all had a lo ve-hate relationship with 'Nicholas Nickleby.' We loved it when we were on stage; we hatedthinking about having to get up on stage and do all that work. But our final performance - we handled it with ma jesty.''

title: Nurses in Oregon End Strike
description: Nurses at Holy Rosary Hospital called off their 23-day-old strike today, apparently giving up their fight with hospital officials over the terms of a new contract.

title: IMPACT OF SOVIET GOLD SALES
description: Beset by economic difficulties, including the troubles in Poland, the Soviet Union has been selling gold heavily in recent months.

title: PERKINS LIKES PROGRESS BUT IS 'NO WAY SATISFIED'
description: In one sense, it was depressing. The Giants, their season ended Sunday by the 38-24 playoff loss to the 49ers in San Francisco, cleaned out their lockers today and said goodbye to one another until minicamp in May. In another sense, there was exhiliration be cause the Giants, a 4-12team in 1980, had climbed to 9-7 and the play offs. And many players felt they had established a base for more win ning seasons and more playoffs.

title: New Heart Drug
description: The Food and Drug Administration today approved a new drug, nifedipine, for treating angina, the chest pains that occur when the heart muscle receives too little oxygen-bearing blood. Arthur Hull Hayes Jr., the F.D.A. Commissioner, said that the drug was ''a significant medical advance for patients who cannot tolerate or are not helped by other drugs.'' The drug, manufactured by Pfizer Inc., will be sold under the trade name Procardia.

title: TROUT SETS ITS AGENCY APART
description: WHEN an ad agency gets a new product assignment, one of the first things it does when preparing to write advertising is seek out the product difference, the quality that sets it apart.

title: DUMPING OF LETHAL WASTES AT 3 CITY LANDFILLS CHARGED
description: More than 150,000 gallons of highly toxic wastes were dumped at three city landfills in 1978 and 1979 by a New Jersey company, according to investigators for the New York State Senate Select Committee on Crime.

title: Ohio Nurses Reject Pact in 17-Month Strike
description: Striking nurses from Ashtabula General Hospital voted today to reject a contract proposal and to continue their 17-month strike.

title: Priest, 56, Mugged On Subway Train
description: A 56-year-old Roman Catholic priest dressed in clerical garb was held up at knifepoint by two boys about 16 years of age on a subway train he was taking to get to his church in the Williamsbridge section of the Bronx, the police said. It was the fourth attack in New York City since October on priests or nuns wearing clerical clothing.

title: Medical World News, Don Kirschner in Pact
description: Medical World News, a publication for physicians, has gone into partnership with Don Kirschner Cable Television to produce a series of 26 half-hour consumer-oriented programs for use as cable TV programming.

title: Bridge: An Expert Dummy Feels The Pressure on Occasion
description: It is popularly supposed, wrongly, that the player who finds himself dummy is always quite relaxed. It is true that he does not have an active role to play, and if he thinks he should have he becomes a nuisance. Those who persistently ask questions such as ''Having no hearts?'' without strong reason to suspect a revoke simply disrupt the play unnecessarily.

title: Pieces of Bullet Remain In Thigh of Viking Back
description: Ted Brown, the Minnesota Vikings running back, has bullet fragments in his right thigh from an accident Dec. 27 in the home of his parents, and it may be two weeks before physicians can evaluate his athletic future, doctors have said.

title: Elmer Homrighausen, Le d Seminary in Jersey
description: The Rev. Dr. Elmer G. Homrighausen, retired dean of Princeton (N.J.) Theological Seminary, died yesterday at his home in Princeton. He was 81 years old.

title: Emirates' Oil Output
description: The United Arab Emirates produced 1.4 million barrels of crude oil a day in 1981, down 15 percent from 1980, the petroleum ministry said today.

title: Air Florida Giving S.& H. Stamps
description: Air Florida, a Miami-based carrier that has won a reputation for its fare promotions, said it would begin offering S.& H. Gr een Stamps to its intrastat e passengers on flights between 11 Florida cities on Jan. 11.

title: ISLANDERS WIN WITH 3 IN FIRST
description: The Islanders, who have been unable lately to find the motivation that pleases coaches and wins games, had some thrust upon them tonight. They responded by scoring three goals in 2 minutes 37 seconds in the first period and went on to a 4-1 victory over the Vancouver Canucks at Nassau Coliseum.

title: FOR U.S. EDUCATION, A TEMPORARY BACKSEAT
description: To the Editor:

title: A Philosophical Split
description: Pam Parsons resigned today as coach of South Carolina's women's basketball team, but for a reason that differed from the one announced by the school last Friday. The school said then that she had resigned for health reasons. Miss Parsons said her health was fine, but she was quitting because ''it has become obvious that neither the administration nor the athletic department agree with me philosophically.''

title: Traffic Agent Critically Hurt By a Van on Lower East Side
description: A 23-year-old traffic-enforcement agent, Ismail Vega, was critically injured when he was hit by a van while on duty directing traffic at Delancey and Essex Streets on the Lower East Side during the evening rush hour yesterday.

title: Texaco Refinery
description: Texaco Inc. said it had advised its 400 employees at the West Tulsa refinery that it was considering closing the facility but that no decision had been reached. Texaco, which operates 11 refineries in the United States and has interests in 60 outside the country, said the Tulsa facility had been operating at 75 percent of its 50,000-barrel-a-day capacity. The company closed a refinery at Lockport, Ill., last March.

title: Sports People; Comings and Goings
description: Tony Dorsett, the Dallas Cowboys running back, was chosen National Football Conference player of the year in a poll of 56 sportswriters conducted by United Press International. Dorsett, with the benefit of an offseason conditioning program, was the N.F.L.'s second leading rusher, with 1,646 yards on 342 carries.

title: MONEY SUPPLY UP $1.4 BILLION
description: The Federal Reserve yesterday announced a larger-than-expected $1.4 billion increase in the nation's basic money supply, startling the credit markets, where a slight decline had been widely expected.

title: URS CORP reports earnings for Yr to Oct 31
Going Out Guide
description: PUPPET STATE

title: POLAND SAYS WORKERS RESUME FULL OPERATIONS
description: Poland's military rule rs said today that work on this first post-holiday workday began with out interruption at mines, shipyards and industries across the co untry.

title: THE BATTLE FOR AMERICA'S YOUTH
description: ''There is trouble in Centereach,'' said Ronnie Lamm somberly - and trouble starts with T, and that rhymes with E and V as well as G, and that stands for electronic video games.

title: No Headline
description: SYRACUSE DEFEATED

title: MONFORT OF COLORADO (CO) reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 28
description: B-After tax credits of $1,658,000 in latest qr and $993,000 in earlier period

title: Banking on Repression
description: ''Most bankers think authoritarian governments are good because they impose discipline,'' declares a banker charitably unnamed in a Wall Street Journal report. ''Every time there's a coup d'etat in Latin America, there's much rejoicing and knocking at the door offering credit.''

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, JANUARY 5, 1982
description: International Warsaw assailed President Reagan over his policy on Poland, according to information arriving from there. The report said that, in a meeting with representatives of Western European governments, Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Polish leader, also suggested that Poland would consider deporting interned Solidarity union leaders to Western countries. At the meeting, requested by General Jaruzelski, he appealed to the Western Europeans for patience while Poland resolved its crisis. (Page A1, Column 3.) Lech Walesa was persuaded to make an appeal to Solidarity members to give up open resistance on Dec. 13, the first day of the crackdown in Poland, according to a well-informed Communist Party source there. But the source said that the move was blocked by the Roman Catholic Church, which argued that such an appeal would undercut the union leader's credibility and make it difficult for him to play a useful role in the future. (A6:1-3.)

title: Horsemen Threaten A Boycott at Latonia
description: Latonia Race Course, a Cincinnati-area thoroughbred track, faces a boycott this week by members of the Kentucky division of the Horsemen's Benevolent and Protective Association.

title: U PDIKE'S 'RABBIT IS RICH' WINS CRITIC' PRIZE
description: John Updike's ''Rabbit Is Rich'' (Knopf) was named the outstanding work of fiction for 1981 by the National Book Critics Circle yesterday.

title: SUPERIOR PIPELINES GIVE COAL A DRY RUN
description: To the Editor:

title: Hunt Seeks a Pardon in Watergate Case
description: He served his time, he testified against his fellow conspirators, and now E. Howard Hunt Jr. wants a Presidential pardon for his part in the 1972 Watergate burglary and cover-up.

title: Science Watch; Dinosaurs Speed Up
description: Measurements of dinosaur tracks found in Texas have produced new estimates indicating that some of the great reptiles could run faster than sprinting humans, though not as fast as greyhounds or race horses. The finding lends support to the growing number of scientists who believe that dinosaurs were generally more active creatures than they had long been portra yed.

title: BUILDING OUTLAYS ROSE 0.2% IN NOVEMBER
description: Spending for new building construction rose a scant two-tenths of 1 percent in November. The rise was mainly attributable to increases in the building of offices, highways and schools, the Commerce Department said today.

title: A Perennial Tree Is Returned to the Earth
description: He would no t go so far as to say he felt like a latter-day Scrooge, but Anthony Ciufo did allow yesterday that he could not help''feeling a l ittle sad'' about the task he was performing.

title: ROSLYN SCHOMER
description: Roslyn Schomer, a retired art teacher whose paintings and drawings received gallery exhibitions, died yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital after a long illness.

title: AMERICAN EXPRESS TO ACQUIRE F.&M.
description: Shearson/American Express Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the F.& M. Corporation, the parent of a Seattle securities firm, in a cash and stock transaction valued at $76 million.

title: Marriott Offers To Buy Gino's
description: The Marriott Corporation said it had offered $48.6 million to acquire ''any and all'' of the common stock of Gino's Inc., a rival fast-food restaurant chain.

title: Rehnquist Due Back at Work
description: Associate Justice William H. Rehnquist is expected to return to work Tuesday after a weeklong hospital stay for treatment of a back problem. Barrett McGurn, the Supreme Court's spokesman, said today that Justice Rehnquist was expected to be in his chambers Tuesday. Justice Rehnquist returned home Sunday from George Washington University Hospital after undergoing a reevaluation of medication he was taking to relieve low back pain.

title: Key Rates
description: * Rates are before any surcharges on large loans to banks that are frequent borrowers.+ Maximum rate payable by savings institutions.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: FLOODS OF A RECORD RAIN SNARL ROADS AND TRANSIT
description: Skies wept at the outset of the New Year's first workday in the metropolitan area. A deluge starting Sunday night and extending into yesterday afternoon poured 2.72 inches of rain on New York City, washing out the record for the date set at 0.99 inches in 1971.

title: OPEC Output Seen Stable
description: The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries will find it difficult, if not impossible, to increase its oil output this year much above the 10-year low of around 23 million barrels daily produced in 1981, Petroleum Intelligence Weekly said today.

title: NEWCOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-After an extraordinary tax charge of $49,000... C-After a tax loss carryforward credit of $210,000

title: Books of the Times
description: THE HANGOVER HANDBOOK. By David E. Outerbridge. Illustrated by Gray Jol- life. 96 pages. Harmony. Paperback, $3.95.

title: SOCIAL WORKERS' PROFITLESS HAGGLES
description: To the Editor:

title: Campbell Creates A Camaro Commercial
description: Campbell-Ewald has created a 90-second commercial for use in movie theaters and on cable television to promote the Camaro, which the agency called ''an avant-garde campaign very different from any other ever run by Chevrolet.'' It said that ''it is part of Chevrolet's new youth program.''

title: BLASIUS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-Includes $119,000 tax credit...C-Net loss after losses from discontinued operations of $399,000 for the qr and $903,000 for the 6 mos

title: Arcata Agrees To Purchase
description: The Arcata Corporation, a leading printing and redwood lumber company, said it had agreed to be acquired by a new company to be formed by the New York merchant banking firm of Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, an expert in leveraged buy-outs, for $37 a share, or about $330 million,

title: BEARS DISMISS COACH
description: The Chicago Bears, who finished last in the National Conference's Central Division with a 6-10 record this season, dismissed Coach Neill Armstrong today.

title: APOGEE ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 28
NUCLEAR PHARMACY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-Includes tax credits of $77,944 for the qr and $134,944 for the 6 mos...C-Includes $212,741 tax credit

title: 20 DESIGNERS PRESCRIBE A TONIC FOR SPRING
description: It was easier in the old days to get ready for the new season. In midwinter gloom, the woman of fashion bought a cheerful new hat, with or without flowers, thereby lifting her spirits and getting a head start on spring.

title: Talking Business with Professor Domar of M.I.T. The Troubled Polish System
description: In decades past, advocates of capitalism criticized the inefficiencies of socialist economies, while Communists predicted the downfall of capitalist economies. More recently, comparisons of different countries' prosperity have been made, but little attention has been given to the relative merits of different economic systems.

title: Chile Inflation Slowed
description: Chile had an inflation rate of 9.5 percent in 1981, a sharp improvement over the 1980 rate of 31.2 percent, the National Statistics Institute reported today.

title: OFFICIAL IN POLISH CENTRAL COMMITTEE RECONSTRUCTS THE EVENTS OF DECEMBER
description: The following dispatch is based on information reaching The New York Times from Poland. Normal communications with The Times's Warsaw bureau chief, John Darnton, have been barred by the authorities there since Dec. 14.

title: NBC-TV to Salute Caruso
description: Placido Domingo and the New York Philharmonic under Zubin Mehta will pay homage to Enrico Caruso in a ''Live from Studio 8-H'' telecast Jan. 16 from 9:30 to 11 P.M. The music will be by Verdi, Bizet, Wagner, Halevy, Leoncavallo, Richard Strauss and Puccini. Portions of the 1918 American film ''My Cousin,'' which starred Caruso, will be shown, plus newsreels, photos and caricatures.

title: A Policeman Goes South, and Discovers New York
description: It was his first day on duty as chief of police in Birmingham, Ala., yesterday, and Arthur V. Deutcsh, a native of Brooklyn and former New York City police captain, said he saw no essential difference between policing New York and policing Birmingham.

title: BENGALS ACCEPT GREGG'S DISCIPLINE
description: Forrest Gregg, the coach of the Cincinnati Bengals, said today that he has fined some of his players this season for breaking his rules. He named no names and talked only generally about the infractions. But Gregg made it clear that the Bengals are his charges; he looks after them, and they do what he says.

title: BROOKLYN PUPILS FED OTHERS' LUNCH LEFTOVERS
description: Leftovers from other children's trays were fed yesterday to some of about 50 children in a Brooklyn elementary school who returned from winter vacation to find they were no longer e ligible for free hot lunches. Most of the se children had failed to return completed forms that are required under new Federal regulations to determine eligibility for federally subsidized hot lunches. The new regulations lowered the amount of money families can earn and still be eligible for free or reduced-pr ice lunches.

title: BRIEFING
description: T HE January-February issue of American Education, the magazine published by the Department of Education, may co me as a jolt to readers who have grown accustomed to the publication's plodding reports on poli cy changes and Federal education grants.

title: No Headline
description: COMMUNIQUE BY THE COMMON MARKET

title: U.S. JURY ON COAST GETS WELLS FARGO THEFT CASE
description: After a seven-week trial, a jury today began deliberating the fate of Harold Rossfields Smith and an associate, Sammie Marshall, who Federal prosecuters say stole $21.3 million from the Wells Fargo National Bank in a plot to dominate professional boxing in the United States.

title: The Nation's First 'Test Tube' Baby Heads Home
description: A week after her birth, the first baby in the United States to have been conceived outside the mother's body was taken home to Massachusetts yesterday.

title: UNITED CANSO OIL & GAS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-After $55,000 extraordinary charges...C-Net income... D-Includes $25,000 credit...E-Net loss; the company is traded on the Pacific Stock Exchange

title: STATE DEPA RTMENT'S ROOMS AT THE TOP
description: Few Americans ever see them, but they are some of the most sought-after rooms for entertaining in official Washington.

title: Science Library
description: NORTH AMERICAN GAME BIRDS AND MAMMALS By A. Starker Leopold, Ralph J. Gutierrez and Michael T. Bronson. 198 pages. Illustrated. Charles Scribner's Sons.

title: REAGAN HAILS HIS 'INTEGRITY'; HAIG'S DEPUTY IS SUCCESSOR
description: Richard V. Allen resigned today as the White House national security adviser, and President Reagan appointed William P. Clark Jr., Deputy Secretary of State, to succeed him.

title: MCDONNELL DOUGLAS SCHEDULES TALKS ON DC-10 DESIGN ISSUE
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation, maker of the troubled DC-10 wide-body jetliner, will hold a ''special meeting'' for all of the plane's 45 operators on Jan. 14 to discuss possible design changes to correct a problem in the aircraft's lift system, the company said today.

title: Company Name Changes Rise in '81
description: Anspach Grossman Portugal, a design firm and therefore interested in company name changes and new logotypes, keeps track of that sort of activity.

title: Pro Basketball Notebook; DISPARITY CONTINUES TO HAUNT LEAGUE
description: The question of parity for the National Basketball Association, which several league owners constantly talk about but have been unable to solve, has surfaced again. Another attempt will be made to place the issue on the agenda when the owners meet Jan. 30, the day before the All-Star Game at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: CALIFORNIA OPENS CAPITOL BUILDING
description: While a raging wind-and-rainstorm stripped oranges from the trees in Capital Park, the rebuilt California Capitol was formally opened in brief ceremonies at noon today.

title: Educators Seek Political Action
description: Creationism is a political movement and must be met with political action as well as scientific argument, science educators said today.

title: Renault Chief Is Named French Envoy to U.S.
description: Bernard Vernier-Palliez, chief executive officer of the Renault auto company, was appointed Ambassador to the United States today.

title: G.M. TO GET $500 MILLION FOR EDIFICE
description: The General Motors Corporation moved a step closer yesterday to selling its New York City office building, through a private financing deal that would garner the cash-short No.1 auto maker $500 million.

title: REQUIRED READING
description: Artistic Temperament

title: BOSTON MAYOR SUGGESTS SALE OF TWO PROPERTIES
description: Mayor Kevin H. White said today he may consider selling the municipally owned Boston City Hospital and a large convention center to raise new revenue for this fiscally pinched city.

title: The U.N. Today; Jan. 5, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Committee on Transnational Corpo- rations' Intergovernmental Working Groups on a Code of Conduct:

title: DELIVERY IS BEGUN OF ELECTRONIC MAIL DESPITE OBJECTIONS
description: The United States Postal Service, after years of delay, today began its electronic mail service for commercial users, in the face of criticism and court action.

title: Sports People; Information, Please
description: The Birmingham-Southern College basketball team was all set for its home game last night against Friendship College of Rock Hill, S.C. But when the Southern coach, Greg Walcavich, telephoned to arrange practice schedules, there was no answer. Walcavich learned from a telephone-company recording that Friendship's telephones had been disconnected - all of them.

title: NOTES ON FASHIONS
description: I T is not exactly the kind of face guaranteed to launch a thousand ships, or even two for that matter. But over the past year Joe Famolare's bearded visage has launched a stunningly successful campaign in the print media in a series of full-page, four-color advertisements for shoes. Now you are going to be seeing a lot more of it, for Mr. Famolare, the designer and originator of that funnylooking shoe with the thick, wavy sole, has completed a series of television commercials that, like the print campaign, were photographed by Richard Avedon.

title: PONTIAC REDUCES COMPACT PRICES
description: selling compact front-wheel-drive J-2000 model by an anverage of $320 because of poor market conditions.

title: Canadian Im port Study
description: A top trade official said today that the Reagan Ad ministration would become more responsive to the problems of d omestic industries hurt by subsidized imports from Canada.

title: BEETLE FIGHTS FOES WITH LAW OF PHYSICS
description: BOMBARDIER BEETLES are famous enough among entomologists for their power to repel enemies with a jet of scalding hot chemicals, produced in a way similar to the ignition of spacecraft rockets. Now, scientists have found that the bombardier has a second hightechnology trick in its weapons system: It aims its jets at the foe by a principle of physics never before known to be used by any animal but man.

title: WASHINGTON GAS LIGHT CO reports earnings for Yr to Nov 30
description: Revs reflects utility operating revs

title: Abbott Trial Judge Denies a Request
description: The State Supreme Court justice presiding in the murder trial of Jack Henry Abbott refused to grant a defense request to sequester the jury as selection of the panel began.

title: Around the World; China to Sell Writings Of a Former President
description: A volume of the selected writings of President Liu Shaoqi, who died in disgrace but was exonerated 11 years later, will go on sale Sunday, the official New China News Agency said today.

title: No Headline
description: DEFINITIONS OF TERMS AND EXCERPT FROM RULING OVERTURNING ARKANSAS LAW

title: NATIONAL MEDICAL ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: The 1980 periods were restated to reflect changes in accounting for vacation and sick leave benefits

title: Study Says Death Rate Is Higher in Small Cars
description: Motorists in small cars are twice as likely to be killed in accidents as those in full-size models, and Japanese automobiles are generally less safe than their American counterparts, according to an insurance industry study made public today.

title: Around the Nation; Massachusetts Modifies Limit on Property Taxes
description: Gov. Edward J. King of Massachusetts signed into law today a bill allowing communities to override the Proposition 2 1/2 property tax limit by a majority vote in local referendums.

title: Advertising; 'Jersey' Tag Confining For G.& M.
description: WHEN they first started their agency in New Jersey five years ago, Ron Gianettino and George D. Meredith just wanted it to be the best agency in the state. After a while that was no longer a sufficient goal, so it w as a changed to the ''biggest'' New Jersey agency. Now they feel tha t the New Jersey tag is too confining.

title: PORT UNIT PURCHASES JERSEY CITY RAILYARD IN COAL EXPORT PLAN
description: The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, pressing ahead with its quest for a coal-export terminal, announced yesterday that it had purchased a railyard in Jersey City and was shopping for other sites on the Jersey City-Bayonne waterfront.

title:
METROPOLITAN DIARY;
HUGO FLESCH'S PROVERBS FOR OUR TIME
description: He that sitteth on the subway shall immediately findeth himself dislodged.

title: PREPARATION OF FOOD IN AMERICA: A DECADE OF CHANGE
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Evan Jones is the author of ''American Food: The Gastronomic Story'' (Random House and Vintage Books), ''A Food Lover's Companion'' (Harper & Row), and ''The World of Cheese'' (Knopf). By EVAN JONES

title: KITCHEN EQUIPMENT
description: BECAUSE copper pots are so expensive, I am often reluctant to urge home cooks to buy them. These days, other materials - stainless steel with thick aluminum cladding on the bottom, for instance - are almost as good and sometimes better for many jobs. The heavy, deep, straight-sided skillet called a sautoir (because it is used in sauteing) is an exception.

title: BEEFALO: THERE ARE FEW ON THE RANGE
description: IN the early 1970's it was touted as the meat of the future - higher in protein than conventional beef while much lower in fat and calories. The animal that produced the meat was a hybrid, norm ally three-eighths buffalo and five-eighths a cattle breed such as Hereford or C harolais. These animals were described as 25 percent cheaper to ra ise than cattle; they were said to be more resistant to disease and h arsh weather. Proponents contended the meat was at leastas flavorful, if not more so, than top-grade beef.

title: Foreign Worker Ban
description: Canada today banned the hiring of foreign workers in mines, on construction sites, in some factories and for non-specialized occupations to protect Canadian jobs in a sluggish economy. The ban, announced by Lloyd Axworthy, Minister of Employment and Immigration, was part of a $50 million program begun last month to minimize the impact of Canada's growing unemployment.

title: U.S. OPPOSES NOW ON EQUAL RIGHTS APPEAL
description: The Justice Department said today that despite its decision to appeal a court ruling that struck down Congress's extended ratification deadline for the equal rights amendment, it opposed a request by the National Organization for Women for an expedited Supreme Court appeal ''since the entire matter may be rendered moot in the months ahead.''

title: MURDOCK'S RECORD: GO-GETTER INVESTOR IN VARIOUS FIELDS
description: David H. Murdock amassed a base for his fortune, now estimated at more than $400 million, through long days and nights in Phoenix real estate during the 25 years that followed World War II.

title: REAGAN IS NEUTRAL ON PRIMARY
description: The White House political director has informed the New York State Republican chairman that President Reagan will remain neutral in the party's gubernatorial primary.

title: U.S. IS PROPOSING LEANER BEEF GRADES
description: The Department of Agriculture, in response to a request from the National Cattlemen's Association, has proposed a change in Federal beef-grading standards that would reduce the amount of fat in the two most expensive grades of meat: prime and choice. The association requested the change, a spokesman said, in response to consumer demands for leaner beef.

title: MYSTERY OF THE MISSING FILIPINO ATHLETE TAKES ON A POLITICAL TINGE
description: The mystery over the disappearance of a prominent athlete after dining with a daughter of President Ferdinand E. Marcos went into a second week today, with the father of the missing man again accusing the Philippine leader of involvement.

title: CAREY WEIGHS CUT IN PAID WORKWEEK FOR CIVIL SERVANTS
description: New York State employees may be asked to shorten their paid workweek to forestall thousands of layoffs. That is one of the many budget proposals that stand behind the annual State of the State Message Governor Carey will deliver to the Legislature Wednesday.

title: SCHMIDT SUPPORTS REAGAN ON POLAND AND RUSSIAN ROLE
description: Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany, for the first time directly criticizing Soviet i n volvement in the Polish crisis, joined President Reagan today in expr essing concern about ''the serious pressure'' brought by Moscow ag ainst Polish efforts forchange.

title: Bridge: McKenney Trophy Winner Has Tested His Endurance
description: As the supreme test of endurance, most people would think of a 50-mile run, climbing Mount Everest or sailing round the world. But on a more sedentary plane, the McKenney Trophy race - concerning master points won in a calendar year - comes into consideration.

title: STAGE: 'WALTZ' OF VAN PEEBLES OPENS
description: WHEN a performer takes the stage to bare his soul in two solid hours of song and monologue, the result can be theater at its most personal and ecstatic. That's one (and only one) of the lessons that Lena Horne has taught us this year. But such evenings are not so easy to bring off as Miss Horne makes it seem. What if the monologues are opaque and at times nonsensical? What if the songs are poorly written and sung? What if the bared soul often seems petty and selfish?

title: REHNQUIST BACK AT HIGH COURT
description: Justice William H. Rehnquist returned to work at the Supreme Court today, apparently recovered from drug withdrawal complications that were said to have arisen while he was in the hospital for back pain.

title: EX-CHIEF OF POLAND'S TV IS PUT ON TRIAL
description: The following dispatch is based on information arriving from Poland. In an attempt to mitigate public anger over trials of Solidarity activists, Poland's military Government yesterday put on trial a former high party official who was close to Edward Gierek, the disgraced former Communist Party leader.

title: STUDY FINDS ANTI-SEMITIC ACTS ROSE AGAIN IN YEAR
description: For the third consecutive year, the number of reported anti-Semitic incidents in the United States more than doubled in 1981, according to a survey released yesterday by the Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith.

title: LIBYA WILL PAY EXXON FOR ASSETS
description: The Exxon Corporation said yesterday that Libya had agreed to compensate the huge oil company for the Libyan assets it abandoned in November.

title: Notes on People; Mr. Kennedy, You Remember Mrs. ... Uh ...
description: For at least one of the participants, a trip down memory lane yesterday proved just a bit too far back. Barbara B. Kennelly, daughter of the late John M. Bailey, the Democratic leader in Connecticut, is a candidate to fill the unexpired term of a deceased United States Representative, and she invited Senator Edward M. Kennedy, an old family friend, to a campaign rally in Hartford.

title: CLARK, J L, MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Yr to Nov 30
Man, 22, Slain on W. 114th St.  In Apparent Robbery Attempt
description: A 22-year-old man was shot to death early yesterday in an apparent robbery attempt after he had just walked a young woman home, the police said.

title: ENDS AT 865.30
description: The Dow Jones industrial average plunged 17.22 points, to 865.30, yesterday as investors reacted to a surprise increase in the nation's basic money supply and to forecasts of higher interest rates by a prominent economist.

title: NOT SO VITAL STATISTICS ON MR. HELMS
description: For people watchers and others interested in bits of Americana, here are some insights into Senator Jesse Helms. A leading conservative Republican from North Carolina, he is chairman of the Senate Agriculture Committee, an ardent advocate of school prayers and an archfoe of abortion:

title: NON-BIBLICAL AND UNSCIENTIFIC CREATIONISM
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. STEEL WAITS TO CLOSE MARATHON DEAL
description: By midnight tonight - unless the Supreme Court stops the clock in response to Mobil's emergency petition - the United States Steel Corporation will be free to buy a controlling interest in the Marathon Oil Company, thus ending the biggest takeover battle since Du Pont's $7.6 billion purchase of Conoco last summer.

title: Giants Preparing To Fill Cupboard
description: Now that the Giants have been eliminated from the playoffs, they have turned their attention to next s eason. Not the season that begins with training camp in July, exhibtion games in August and the real thing in September. The next season they are concerned with culminates in the draft of college players April 27 and 28.

title: Notes on People; NBC Sued by Father W ho Sought Pat ernity Leave
description: When his wife was about to give birth last August, Robert A. Batsche asked for a six-week unpaid leave from his job as an NBC engineer so he could help take care of the baby.

title: BRZEZINSKI, ON NATIONAL SECURITY ADVISERS
description: The followi ng is adapted from an interview with Zbigniew Brze zinski, President Jimmy Carter's national security adviser, that is to appear in the winter issue of The Washington Quarterly, pu blished by the Center for Strategic and International Studies, at G eorgetown University. (Dr. Brzezinski, a senior adviser at the Center , is professor of government at Columbia University.) The interview , by the executive editor, Allen Weinstein, and another historian, Mi chael Beschloss, was conducted before the resignation, on Monday, of Richard V. Allen as President Reagan's national security advi ser, the naming of William P. Clark Jr., Deputy Secretary of State, to replace him, and Mr. Reagan's decision to upgrade the a dviser's position so that Mr. Clark would have a ''direct repo rting relationship to the President.''

title: Observer; A GIFT OF GAB
description: In my long career as news analyst I have seldom had a patient as vexing as Vernon Spokes. In youth Spokes yearned for a career in public relations and dreamed of some day reaching the heights as press secretary for a gigantic corporation or a huge Government bureaucracy.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: Cozy Feet, Hands and Legs

title: BUT SERIOUSLY, FOLKS: ALLEN ON SMALL TALK
description: The writer, who interviewed himself for this article, holds the world's hyphen championship, inasmuch as he is a comedian-novelistpoet-composer-pianist-actor -producer-playwright. By STEVE ALLEN

title: People
description: * John G. Foerst Jr., president of the Community Counseling Service, has been elected chairman of the American Association of Fund-Raising Counsel. * James Rob inson has been appointed executive vice president and general manag er-agency operations at Sieber & McIntyre Inc., Chicago.

title: CORRECTION
description: Due to an editing error, an article in The Times on Sunday incorrectly iden- tified the winner of the 1979 Pulitzer Prize for local investigative reporting. The winner was The Pottsville (Pa.) Republican; The Chicago Sun-Times was a leading contender but was re- jected by the prize board because of its use of disputed reporting techniques.

title: A Brooklyn Prosecutor Is Assaulted in Court
description: An assistant district attorney in Brooklyn was assaulted in a courtroom after making post-trial arguments in a homicide case, a spokesman for the Brooklyn district attorney said last night.

title: THEATER: 'THE UNSEEN HAND,' SHEPARD REVIVAL AT LA MAMA
description: THE centerpiece of Sam Shepard's ''The Unseen Hand,'' in revival at La Mama, is a shell of a derelict 1951 Chevrolet convertible that appears to have taken root in the ground. Sitting in the car, and encrusted with age, is Beeson Carroll, recreating his original role as Blue Morphan, a 120-year-old relic of the Old West and a rambling wreck of a monologuist.

title: Article 159691 -- No Title
description: A Federal District judge has ordered the University of South Alabama to pay about $1 million in back wages to female faculty members and administrators to settle one of the largest sex discrimination lawsuits filed against a university.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: By Anatole Broyard MERMAID. By Margaret Millar. 215 pages. William Morrow. $11.50.

title: Robinson, R.S.V.P.
description: The New England Patriots have offered their coaching job to John Robinson, the football coach at Southern California, The Associated Press reported. The report said that Bucko Kilroy had conveyed an opening offer yesterday to Robinson and his attorney, Ed Hookstraten, and should know their response by today.

title: BYSTANDER KILLED IN MOB SHOOTING WAS A SOCIAL WORKER AND EX-NUN
description: The innocent bystander who was killed in what was apparently a gangland attack on two men in Brooklyn Monday night was described yesterday as a social worker who had devoted her life to helping others.

title: CANAL-RANDOLPH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Money, Money, Money
description: Jack Morris, the Detroit Tiger pitcher who posted a 14-7 record last season, said he wanted a multiyear contract that eventually would pay him $1 million a season. ''I think I'm as good as Ron Guidry,'' Morris said.

title: Around the World; South Korea Lifts Its 36-Year-Old Curfew
description: South Korea's nationwide curfew was lifted throughout most of the country today for the first time since it was originally imposed by American occupation troops 36 years ago at the end of World War II.

title: NICARAGUAN SCENE: FIERY SLOGANS, DESIGNER JEANS
description: No stranger to invasions in recent years, Managua today is being occupied by a fresh-faced army of backpacking youths in shorts and hiking boots. They are leftist students on holiday from Europe, here to see the revolution firsthand.

title: WRONG IMPRESSIONS ABOUT THE YALE LITERARY MAGAZINE
description: To the Editor:

title: FEDERAL CUTS HAMPER EAST ST. LOUIS REVIVAL PLAN
description: Nearly half of the 55,000 residents of East St. Louis receive public aid, and more than 50 percent of the city's budget is financed by the Federal Government. Now city officials fear that Reagan Administration budget cuts may end the city's hopes for revival.

title: TEXT OF THE STATEMENT BY REAGAN AND SCHMIDT
description: Following is the text of a joint statement by President Reagan and Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany on their White House meeting today:

title: OPERA: ESTES'S DEBUT IN MET'S 'TANNHAUSER'
description: THE Metropolitan Opera's production of ''Tannhauser,'' with its realistic but poetically haunting sets and its adherence to 19thcentury staging traditions, has gone back on display at Lincoln Center. If there is a better argument for restoring musical masterpieces in a style consonant with their own times rather than tricking them out in modish clothes, it has not been made hereabouts recently.

title: Topics; OMISSIONS; Taste Test
description: Ask people to name the prototypical junk food, and most would say the potato chip. What redeems it? It's too thin to offer much nourishment; its main purpose appears to be to deliver a heavy - and unhealthy - dose of salt.

title: KNICKS DEFEAT BUCKS
description: In speaking about Sly Williams's brilliant performance in the Knicks' 112-102 victory over his Milwaukee Bucks tonight, Marques Johnson, one of the standards by which basketball forwards are judged, said: ''Everybody in the world knows that he's going to go left, and we were told emphatically not to let him do that. Well, he did it a couple of times early on us, and folks stood there looking like they were shocked.

title: BLACKS IN NEW YORK'S SUBURBS FIND THEY'R E SOCIALLY ISOLATED
description: By her own account, Paula Redd, an attractive 23-year-old black, is a ''very social person.'' A native of Rye, N.Y., she left Westchester County five years ago to attend Indiana University, where she graduated last year with a degree in music. She returned home, found a job as an office manager at the YWCA here and is pursuing an operatic career.

title: S.& P. Lowers Ward Debt Rating
description: The Standard & Poor's Corporation lowered its rating on the senior long-term debt issues of Montgomery Ward & Company and the Montgomery Ward Credit Corporation to double B-plus from triple B.

title: Oliveira in Danger
description: Joao Carlos de Oliveiro, holder of the world triple-jump record, underwent two more operations to deal with injuries he suffered two weeks ago in a head-on auto accident in Brazil. Surgeons operated on his windpipe and set his jawbone to make his breathing easier, but they said the greatest risk came from infectio n in his lungs and legs that app arently has not been controlled.

title: SYRIA PUSHES HARD U.N. LINE OVER GOLAN
description: Syria insisted publicly today that, despite the prospect of a United States veto, it would press for a harsh Security Council resolution designed to isolate Israel for annexing the Golan Heights. But behind the scenes, and even in public, efforts were under way to negotiate a compromise that would avoid a veto.

title: AMERICAN HOIST & DERRICK CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Sears to Offer Levi's Clothes
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company announced that its merchandise group had reached an agreement with Levi Strauss & Company to sell Levi's clothes in its retail stores and mail-order catalogue.

title: APPLIED MATERIALS INC reports earnings for Yr to Oct 25
Q&A
description: Q. Our local supermarket occasionally has sea urchins. Years ago a man we knew in Barbados used to serve them on the half shell with cocktails. He would not say how they were prepared, but I believe he boiled them, cracked them open, mixed the inside with lime juice and hot sauce. Wh at do you recommend?

title: WRONG IMPRESSIONS ABOUT THE YALE LITERARY MAGAZINE
description: To the Editor:

title: Metromedia Tax Credits
description: Metromedia Inc. said that during December it had acquired for about $28 million the rights to claim investment tax credit and depreciation deductions on equipment valued at about $115 million.

title: Editor Assails Tiger Curb
description: The editor of The Grand Rapids Press charged today that the Detroit Tigers are trying to curb unbiased coverage by imposing sanctions on a sports reporter for the paper who revealed the team's internal player-rating system.

title: A FREED SOLIDARITY ACTIVIST DESCRIBES MOOD IN A POLISH PRISON AS
description: 'BUOYANT'

title: INQUIRY BY F.B.I. STARTS IN NEWARK IN 'ANGEL' DEATH
description: The F.B.I. has started a preliminary investigation into the shooting of a member of the Guardian Angels last week by a Newark police officer, a spokesman for the bureau said today.

title:
RED SMITH;
A Vote for Little Looie
description: AT this time of year, the Baseball Hall of Fame commands lively attention, partly because the reader has had so much pro football that his teeth hurt and partly because the annual complement of immortals will be minted soon. Jack Lang, secretary of the Baseball Writers' Association of America, will wait only for the Super Bowl to get out of the way before announcing the results of the authors' election, and a few days later the Veterans' Committee will meet to consider candidates passed up by the literary set.

title: CATHOLICS GET RECORD NUMBER OF ANNULMENTS
description: Divorced Roman Catholics in the United States are receiving annulments in record numbers, the result of streamlined procedures for dissolving a marriage by a church trying to end the estrangement of thousands of members.

title: Market Place; Mutual Funds And I.R.A.'s
description: TAXPAYERS picking among alternatives as they decide how to capitalize on the expanded Individual Retirement Accounts are in some cases turning to mutual funds that ignore tax considerations as irrelevant.

title: No Headline
description: Sherwood Stewart and Ferdi Taygan of the United States defeated John Lloyd and Buster Mottram of Britain, 7-5, 7-6, 7-5, tonight in the opening match of the $175,000 world doubles championship.

title: AS THE KREMLIN SEES IT
description: The sanctions imposed on the Soviet Union by the Reagan Administration are, unfortunately, marked by an extreme vagueness about what the Soviet regime would be expected to do to bring about their removal.

title: JAPAN TO LET DOW RAISE $100 MILLION
description: - The Dow Chemical Company has received permission from Japan to raise nearly $100 million in their capital markets, the largest such transaction by a foreign firm to date, a U.S. official said today.

title: Briefing
description: T HE National Rifle Association's ''open letter to all Polish Americans,'' a newspaper advertisement in which martial law in Poland was construed as a lesson in the American public's right and need to bear arms, has backfired with at least one leading Polish-American.

title: Simmons-Boardman Promotes Sclater
description: The Simmons-Boardman Publishing Corporation, whose titles include the ABA Banking Journal, has bestowed upon Ranald D. Sclater, publisher of that magazine, the additional titles of president and chief operating officer. Neither his promotion, nor any of the others announced with it, include a change of status for Arthur J. McGinnis Sr., 70, who remains owner, chairman of the executive committee and chief executive.

title: HOW TO TREAT THE ISRAELIS
description: To the Editor:

title: COUPLE ARE HELD IN ABDUCTION OF 5 ELDERLY WOMEN
description: A couple sought since last summer on suspicion of abducting five elderly women from a boarding house in Florida and abandoning them in Detroit were arrested here today.

title: Topics Omissions
description: Proof Negative

title: MISSES NAVRATILOVA AND AUSTIN SCORE
description: Tracy Austin and Martina Navratilova posted victories tonight in the opening round of the $200,000 Avon Washington tennis tournament, the first stop on the winter tour.

title: AT THE POLISH REGIME'S DISPOSAL
description: To the Editor:

title: WARSAW SAYS LEADERS OF SOLIDARITY WILL MEET WITH REGIME
description: The Warsaw radio said tonight that talks had begun between leaders of the Solidarity trade union movement and the Polish Government at the Ministry of Trade Union Affairs.

title: Cosmos Win, 8-6, End Losing Streak
description: The Cosmos broke a five-game losing streak with an 8-6 victory over the Tulsa Roughnecks tonight in a North American Soccer League indoor game at the Byrne Meadowlands Arena before a crowd of 7,287.

title: POLISH AIRWAVES: AIDE ASSERTS GOVERNMENT DEMANDS ONLY 'UNDERSTANDING'
description: Following are excerpts from domestic Polish radio and television broadcasts as transcribed and translated from the Polish by the Foreign Broadcast Information Service, a United States Government agency:

title: Around the World; 2 Refugees Begin a Fast At Embassy in Moscow
description: Two of seven Siberians who have lived as religious refugees in the United States Embassy since 1978 have begun a hunger strike to protest the failure to resolve their plight, a relative of the two Siberians said today.

title: SOME CITY PUPILS FED LEFTOVERS AGAIN
description: More eligibility forms for free and reduced-price lunches were returned yesterday to a Brooklyn elementary school where some children received leftover food Monday.

title: EX-GREEN BERET GETS 2-YEAR TERM
description: A former Green Beret convicted last month of two misdemeanor assault charges in the 1980 shooting of a Libyan student here was sentenced by a Federal district judge today to serve two years in the Larimer County Jail.

title: LATE RALLY CUTS BOND LOSSES
description: A late rally yesterday halted a precipitous drop in Government, corporate and tax-exempt bonds, but did not fully erase the losses recorded earlier in the day. Short-term interest rates closed very slightly higher after being up as much as one-quarter of a percentage point.

title: AUSTRALIAN DEPORTEES ARE NO BOAT PEOPLE
description: To the Editor:

title: Around the Nation;  g U.S. Ends Fraud Inquir y Into General Dynamics
description: The Justice Department announced today that it had dropped an investigation into charges that the General Dynamics Corporation of Groton, Conn., engaged in fraud in seeking to recover cost overruns for attack submarines that it produced for the Navy.

title: Chamber Music at St. Ann's
description: The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center, with Earl Wild as guest pianist, will play a concert at the Gothic Cathedral of St. Ann's on Jan. 20 at 8 P.M. The music, under the direction of Charles Wadsworth, will include pieces by Debussy, Chausson and Haydn, and Mr. Wild and Mr. Wadsworth will play the Brahms ''Seven Hungarian Dances for Piano Four-Hands.'' Tickets are $8. Call 834-8794.

title: BEST BUYS
description: THE year's end saw a sharp increase in food prices, according to the market basket survey of the New York City Department of Consumer Affairs. For the two weeks that ended Jan. 1 the average cost was $107.13 - $5.76 more than in the corresponding period a year ago.

title: News An alysis
description: Almost from the day two decades ago when he started publishing his weekly Comments on Credit, Henry Kaufman has had an attentive following. But to be an analyst on Wall Street and to have a following is not all that unusual.

title: WINE TALK
description: WINE lovers the world over will be delighted to le arn that poor vintages are a phenomenon of the past for most of the best chateaus of the Bordea ux district of France. This extraordinary message was brought here by a delegation of some of the region's most prestigiousgrowers, who recently visited five American cities.

title: GHANA'S NEW LEADER PLEDGES SWEEPING CHANGES IN SOCIETY
description: The leader of Ghana's new military Government today pledged sweeping changes in Ghanaian society that would include the establishment of ''people's committees'' to monitor the country's defense and economy and to ''re-educate'' the country on what an ''open democracy'' should be.

title: GENERAL CINEMA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-After $3.4 million loss from discontinued operations

title: Redmen's Task: Stop Ewing
description: Bill Wennington, the 7-foot center at St. John's, was a junior at Lutheran (L.I.) High School two Januarys ago, when his team was scheduled to play against Pat Ewing of Rindge and Latin High School in Cambridge, Mass. Ewing was already on his way to becoming a celebrity, and more significantly, a player believed capable of leading a college team to the Final Four. Wennington had never seen Ewing play. ''I just heard,'' he said.

title: U. S. Ban on Aeroflot Formally Takes Effect
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board today formally banned all flights into the United States by Aeroflot, the Soviet airline, on orders from President Reagan.

title: Miller Accuses Owners
description: Marvin Miller, executive director of the Major League Players Association, told The Atlanta Journal he was collecting evidence to show Congress that baseball team owners had conspired to stop competitive bidding for free agents. Preparing for a February hearing by a House subcommittee that is reconsidering baseball's exemption from Federal antitrust laws, Miller cited several circumstances that, he said, indicated the owners were conspiring in their dealings with free agents.

title: American Agronomics In Interim Shift
description: Last October, the American Agronomics Corporation - a Tampa, Fla., citrus company with operations from tree planting to marketing - hired 50-year-old Kenneth A. Barnebey, one of the best-known executives in the industry, as deputy chairman and chief corporate officer, with the understanding that he would soon become chief executive.

title: Ranger Report
description: Under an agreement with the Rangers, the Quebec Nordiques have until March 9 to persuade Dean Talafous to change his mind about retiring. If Talafous sticks to his decision on that day, the two clubs will resume negotiations on another player to complete the deal that sent Talafous and Jere Gillis to Quebec for Robbie Ftorek. ... John Davidson, the Ranger goaltender who has played only one game this season, visited an orthopedist in Toronto and has been put on anti-inflammatory medication for the next two weeks as treatment for the sciatic condition that has sidelined him since Oct. 17. '' If ths treatment wor ks,'' Davidson said, ''I'll be skating in two weeks, If it doesn't wo rk, I'll probably be operated on.''

title: MOBIL BIDS BURGER HALT U.S. STEEL
description: With time running out, the Mobil Corporation asked Chief Justice Warren E. Burger today to block the United States Steel Corporation's $6.2 billion takeover of the Marathon Oil Company.

title: Index; International
description: Nicaraguan scene: fiery slogans and designer jeans A2 The mystery of the missing Fili- pino athlete continues A3 Syria pressing for harsh U.N. sanctions against Israel A3 Ghana's new leader pledges sweeping changes in society A4 Around the World A5 Polish airwaves: Deputy Prime Minister's speech A6 Freed Solidarity activist de- scribes prison conditions A7 Text of Reagan-Schmidt state- ment A7 South Africa charges white mercenaries with hijacking A9 Government/Politics Yale Law School professor sworn in as U.S. Appeals Court judge B2 U.S. drops fr aud suit against Gen- eral Dynami cs B9 Democrat criticism varies on Reagan approach B12 Washington Talk Briefing A16 Congress: self-preservation in an election year A16 Washington Follow-Up A16 On this visit, Schmidt does not seem relaxed A16 General Around the Nation A12 Port Authority buys a Jersey City railyard B2 Shelter program for homeless found in general compliance B3 Author refusing to give up tapes in Penthouse trial B24 Education/Welfare Some Brooklyn pupils again get leftover food for lunch B3 Excerpts from ruling overturning Arkansas creation law B8 The Living Section Food Preparation of food in Amer- ica: a decade of change C1

title: Notes on People; For Manes, a Day of Joy and Discomfort
