description: An hour after Donald R. Manes was sworn in for his third full term as Queens Borough President yesterday, he was taken to Long Island Jewish Hospital, suffering from what turned out to be acute appendicitis.

title: THE STAGE: 'ZEKS,' BUREAUCRATIC IDIOCY
description: IN a way, ''Zeks: An Oratorio for Seven Voices and Madman's Solo,'' the new play at the Theater for the New City, is extraordinarily slight. Although the subject is important, not much happens. Zeks is Russian slang for Soviet political prisoners, incarcerated by a bureacracy whose cruelty is not so much calculated as it is mindless. All bureaucracies are mindless, of course; they exist for their own perpetuation. The mindlessness shown in ''Zeks,'' however, rests on ideological zeal. Therefore, it is more frightening.

title: RANSBURG CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-After gains from the sales of discontinued operations of $632,000 for the qr and $961,000 for the yr; the revs and net for 1981 and 1980 have been restated to include the financial results of the Globe Tool and Engineering Co and Acro Automation Systems Inc acquired in pooling of interest transactions, respectively, in May and August 1981

title: Article 159890 -- No Title
description: David H. Murdock, the Los Angeles real estate developer and investor who put together the deal earlier this year under which Occidental Petroleum bought Iowa Beef, has now made a $375 million offer for the Cannon Mills Company, the nation's seventh-largest publicly held textile manufacturer.

title: Bulls 134, Nuggets 128
description: CHICAGO (UPI) - Reggie Theus scored 20 points to lead seven Chicago players in double figures as the Bulls posted their highest point total this season.

title: A YALE PROFESSOR OF LAW SWORN IN AS U.S. JUDGE
description: In an unusual judicial ceremony at the Yale Law School, where he has taught for nearly 20 years, Ralph Karl Winter Jr. was sworn in today as a judge on the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.

title: Capitol Air To Lower Fares
description: Continuing a round of fare-cutting, Capitol Air said it would drop its round-trip fare between New York and San Francisco and Los Angeles to $318 from $348, effective tomorrow.

title: Blaze Destroys Art Gallery
description: A fire destroyed Bendann Art Galleries, one of the ci ty's leading art dealers, today. Fire officials said they were sti ll trying to determine the cause of the blaze at the five-story of fice building that housed the galleries. David P. Bendann, the owner of the building, said the property appeared to be ''a total los s.''

title: FARE WAR: TRAVEL AGENTS BURDENED
description: ''I can't believe this,'' said Estelle Lessack, president of Travel Trends Inc., as she threw her hands apart and tried to describe the confusion caused by Delta Air Lines when it initiated a fare war on routes between New York and Florida.

title: 'OPERA PRIMA,' PORTRAIT OF A MADRILENO
description: MATIAS, who lives in Madrid and is suspicious of anything beyond the city limits, is in his mid-20', tall, dark-haired, extraordinarily skinny and full of eccentric, off-the-top-of-the-head opinions on everything from Mozart to meat-eating. He's also ambitious but totally unfocused. He works without interest as a journalist and is in the process of writing what he describes as ''my best-selling book'' about an aging spy, though he can't get beyond chapter six.

title: SMALL-CAR EXTRAS TRIMMED BY G.M.
description: Last spring, the General Motors Corporation said that it would take an ''if you can't lick them, join them'' approach to the marketing of its new ''J''-body cars - the Chevrolet Cavalier and Pontiac J2000.

title: WASHINGTON FOLLOW-UP
description: It may be living on borrowed time, but Vista, which stands for Volunteers in Service to America, is still very much alive.

title: BUT POLITICS IS RULED OUT
description: An adviser to Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Polish leader, said today that there was ''a place'' for Solidarity as ''an independent self-governing trade union'' in Poland as long as it did not stray into opposition politics.

title: Economic Scene; The Sanctions A nd the Allies
description: THE Polish crisis - and the efforts of President Reagan and Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany to coordinate their political and economic positions on how to deal with it - needs to be seen as a critical element in a larger agony, which is the 1980's equivalent of the severe testing that the world faced in the 1930's. It failed that last test miserably.

title: Above and Beyond
description: 13Dan Ross, a tight end who has led the Cincinnati Bengals in receiving for the last two seasons, says he set a team record for receptions - 71 - this season while playing on a broken foot. Ross revealed that he suffered a hairline fracture in his right foot during training camp but did not have it put in a cast.

title: Heritage Foundation Urging A Voluntary Social Security
description: A voluntary Social Security system, supported in part by taxes on Social Security benefits, is being proposed by the Heritage Foundation.

title: Congress; SELF-PRESERVATION IN AN ELECTION YEAR
description: ''Self-preservation is the first law of politics,'' Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. noted today, musing about the impact of the forthcoming Congressional elections on the second session of the 97th Congress. ''Congress is going to be a different body, an entirely different body. They will center on the elections. They will follow the whims of their constituents more than the whims of their party.''

title: About Real Estate; OFF ICE CONDOMINIUMS CATCHING ON AS RENTS INCREASE
description: Office condominiums are gaining interest across the country as rents soar and new rent escalation clauses in leases make long-term costs for office space unpredictable.

title: CONCORD FABRICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 29
description: B-Includes $45,000 extraordinary gain

title: A TAXING PROBLEM IN ALBANY
description: Nearly half the 1981 New York State income tax forms mailed to individuals by the state's Taxation and Finance Department have the wrong Social Security number on the peel-off address labels.

title: REACHING FOR THE AMERICAN DREAM
description: The music from the movie ''Rocky'' blared on the tape recorder in the gymnasium, a signal ordering the 75 female gymnasts back from their luncheon break. Bela Karolyi watched the girls organize quickly on the mats in front of him for the daily lecture.

title: U.S. URGED TO KEEP DRAFT ENROLLMENT
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger and the Joint Chiefs of Staff have recommended that draft registration continue, Administration and Congressional officials said today.

title: From Allen To Clark To What?
description: President Reagan has not solved the problem of American foreign policy by replacing Richard Allen with Judge Clark as head of the National Security Council. He has merely made a bad situation more comfortable.

title: Consumers A Bit Gloomy
description: Consumers' confidence about the economy ebbed in December for the fourth consecutive month, but not as much as might have been expected in view of the dreary economic news, the Conference Board reported yesterday.

title: MOSCOW REJECTS SOME ASPECTS OF EUROPEANS' STAND
description: The Soviet press today rej ected the Common Market's criticism of martial law in Poland a nd supported the refusal of the Western European bloc to jo in in the United States sanctions.

title: The Faithless Fed
description: If they will not listen to liberal critics, will President Reagan and his coterie of monetarists at least heed the anguish of the experts they've sent to battle inflation? It's one thing to have faith in the wisdom and power of the Federal Reserve Board to reduce inflation by manipulating the nation's money supply. But surely it is foolhardy to have more faith than the Fed has in itself.

title: No Headline
description: Around the World; Rome Police Question 2 In General's Kidnapping

title: COOKING: A TREND TOWARD 'LESS WELL DONE'
description: THE tradition in this country of eating well-done or overcooked meat, fish, poultry, game and vegetables may finally be heading for extinction. Both Oriental and French nouvelle cuisines have influenced this trend. Food has become fresher tasting and more likely to ret ain its natural juices. Rosy slices of sauteed duck breast, delic ately pink calf's liver, vegetables that are brightly crisp-tender, and moist fillets of fish are setting the standards in restaurants a nd at dinner parties.

title: JUDGE APPROVES NEW YORK'S PLAN TO SHELTER MEN
description: A State Supreme Court justice yesterday found that New York City's shelter program for homeless men was in general compliance with a court-approved agreement. But he said the two armories the city recently opened to handle the winter crush of men were ''obviously inadequate and cannot be used permanently.''

title: RAYMOND B. DOWDEN
description: Raymond Baxter Dowden, former chairman of design at the Cooper Union School of Art, died Monday at St. Vincent's Hospital.

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 6, 1982
description: International Bonn criticized Soviet involvement in the Polish crisis. It was the first direct criticism expressed by Chancellor Helmut Schmidt as he joined President Reagan in expressing concern about ''the serious pressure'' brought by Moscow against Polish efforts for change. The West German leader's comments were milder than those expressed by American officials, who welcomed them. (Page A1, Column 6.) There is ''a place'' for Solidarity as ''an independent selfgoverning trade union'' as long as it does not stray into opposition politics, according to an aide to Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Polish leader. A dispatch passed through military censorship quoted the aide as saying that the authorities ''have no intention of dissolving Solidarity,'' and he explained the Government's position on how such a union wo uld function. (A1:4.)

title: Trident Holders Back Casino Bid
description: Shareholders of Trident Television Ltd. approved the company's $28 million purchase of Playboy Enterprise's casinos and clubs in Britain.

title: Canada Sells Gold
description: The Finance Department said today that it sold 190,000 ounces of gold from the Government's reserves last month, reducing official gold holdings to 20.5 million ounces.

title: INTERCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
HIGH GREEK OFFICIAL DISMISSED
description: Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou dismissed his Under Secretary of Foreign Affairs because he failed to block a Common Market communique criticizing Soviet involvement in Poland's crackdown, Government and diplomatic sources said today.

title: AUTHOR REFUSING TO YIELD TAPES IN LIBEL SUIT
description: Ovid Demaris, an author, said today he would not produce tapes of his interviews with a hired killer that have been subpoenaed in connection with a libel suit against Penthouse magazine.

title: HEADED HEARST CORPORATION
description: John R. Miller, the former president and chief executive officer of the Hearst Corporation, the nationwide publishing and broadcasting concern, died yesterday at New York Hospital in Manhattan. He was 67 years old and lived in Garden City, L.I.

title: No Headline
description: THE prenatal period is the most vulnerable time of a child's life. Though it was once thought that the fetus was well protected from external harm, in recent decades hundreds of substances, organisms and circumstances have been shown to have a malignant effect on fetal development and survival.

title: FREDERICK'S OF HOLLYWOOD reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 27
CALVIN EXPLORATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net income...C-Net loss

title: PACO PHARMACEUTICAL SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 21
ON THIS VISIT, SCHMIDT DOES NOT SEEM RELAXED
description: Chancellor Helmut Schmidt has been to the United States 40 or 50 times. He says himself he has lost count: The years blur now, Presidents change, and he feels sometimes that he embodies all there is of continuity in the relations between the Germans and the Americans.

title: SAN DIEGO GAS & ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Yr to Nov 30
60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: A FEW nights ago I was at a dinner when the guest sitting next to me asked if I would explain how a professional chef goes about ''inventing'' a dish.

title: SOUTH AFRICA TO TRY MERCENARIES IN HIJACKING
description: South Africa brought charges under its stiff antihijacking law today against 45 white mercenaries who fled the Seychelles in an Air India plane after a bungled coup at the end of November.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Babcock & Wilcox, a subsidiary of McDermott Inc., said it planned a $14.6 million expansion of its capacity to finish and treat oil industry tubular products by more than 40 percent.

title: Gracie Mansion Is Topic Of Lecture on Jan. 20
description: Gracie Mansion, the Mayor's official residence, will be the subject of an illustrated lecture at the New-York Historical Society on Jan. 20. Joan K. Davidson, head of the Gracie Mansion Conservancy, will discuss the conservancy's project - now under way - to renovate the 102-year-old white frame Colonial house, which is used for a number of city ceremonial functions, though Mayor Koch has chosen not to live there.

title: Woman, 65, Foils a Robbery; Two Brooklyn Men Charged
description: An attempt by two assailants to rob an elderly couple in Brooklyn was foiled yesterday when the woman, who was returning from a bank where one of the asssailants had forced her to make a withdrawal, lept from a taxi and screamed at a passing patrol car, the police said. The robber was arrested at the scene.

title: DEMOCRATS IN THE STATES TAKE MILD TONE ON REAGAN
description: The argument that President Reagan's budget cuts are unfair to the poor, a dominant theme among Democrats in Congress, finds only faint echoes from Democratic leaders in most state capitals, according to interviews around the country.

title: Cocoa Prices Rise Sharply
description: The price of coc oa rose to its highest point in almost three months on world commodi ty markets today as speculators showed continuing interest in acq uiring supplies following the military takeover in Ghana.

title: Fewer Rises In Dividends
description: The number of companies reporting increased dividends during December fell below the prior year's pace for the fifth consecutive month, the Standard & Poor's Corporation said yesterday.

title: No Headline
description: 55 JOURNALISTS ARE APPOINTED TO PULITZER NOMINATING JURIES

title: 'Hoofers' Is Scheduled For a Jan. 20 Opening
description: The rise of a song-and-dance duo resembling Fred and Adele Astaire is the basis for a new musical, ''Hoofers,'' which will open Jan. 20 at the Wooden O, 335 West 38th Street.

title: Notes on People; At Selma Jail, Fast Food Means Low Cost
description: The reason Jack Hughes, Chief of Police in Selma, Ala., allows prisoners in the city jail to order breakfast from McDonald's has nothing to do with coddling them, he e xplaine d yesterday.

title: FINANCIAL BRIEFS
description: * Callon Petroleum Company filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission an offering of $25 million of limited partnership interests in its oil and gas drilling program, Callon Drilling Fund 1982.

title: World Oil O utput Off 6 % in 1981
description: World oil production in 1981 declined by a record year-to-year amount - 6 percent - because a recession in Western consuming countries restricted economic growth and high oil prices spurred conservation, a leading oil journal said yesterday.

title: CONCERT: THE JUILLIARD STRING QUARTET
description: THE French are a nation of rational beings, as they are the first to explain, whose emotions are held in reserve and let out only on national holidays. They yearn to codify, categorize and organize knowledge, in the great tradition of their 18th century Encyclopedists. They even make love with a seriousness and determination that has an element of intellectual exploration to it. You would expect, then, that their best music would reflect a concern for clarity and logic.

title: A POSSIBLE RISK
description: Although medium-rare may be a more delicious way of eating certain cuts of beef and lamb, studies currently being made by the United States Department of Agriculture indicate that beef and lamb cooked to an internal temperature under 140 degrees may pose health risks.

title: WROTE 40 BOOKS AND 400 STORIES
description: Margaret Culkin Banning, author of 40 books and more than 400 short stories in a career that spanned six decades, died Monday night at her home in Tryon, N.C. She was 90 years old. ''She was working on another novel at the time of her death,'' said Tanner Banning, the author's son.

title: Accounts
description: * The Fidler Group has resigned the circulation marketing account of Business Week magazine, which is conducting an agency review.

title: LOYALTY TO NEW YORK INSPIRES NEEDIEST CASES FUND DONORS
description: New York City and its needs and problems remain in the thoughts of many former residents who have moved away, and thei r loyalties are often expressed in contributions to The New Y ork Times Neediest CasesFund.

title: Around the Nation; Justice Dept. May Block Return of Ukrainian Boy
description: The Justice Department is considering a request for an order to prevent the removal from the United States of Walter Polovchak, a 14-year-old Ukrainian who wants to remain in this country, a department spokesman said today.

title: FILM: WATER POLLUTION AND ROGER BALDWIN PROFILE
description: MEG SWITZGABLE'S fine forceful documentary ''In Our Water'' begins with the sound of a faucet dripping, a sound that becomes increasingly ominous as the film progresses and the special properties of this water are revealed. ''In Our Water'' is about the Kaler family of South Brunswick, N.J., who discovered that their tap water could rot holes in laundry, cause noodles to disintegrate and vegetables to turn black.

title: Forenza Appointed Director of Attenzione
description: Ray D. Forenza has been named executive director of Attenzione magazine by the newly formed Adam Publishing. Adam acquired the publication, which is aimed at an Italian-American audience, over the weekend.

title: JUDGE OVERTURNS ARKANSAS LAW ON CREATIONISM
description: A Federal district judge today overturned the Arkansas law requiring ''balanced'' classroom treatment for the theories of evolution and ''creation science.''

title: NEW GLOBE THEATER PLAYS IN TERRYTOWN
description: The New Globe Theater, a national touring company directed by Stuart Vaughan that specializes in the classics, has decided to settle in the New York area. This month it will play in Tarrytown, N.Y., offering a subsciption series of three plays at the Tarrytown Music Hall.

title: WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 6, 1982; Markets
description: Wall Street economist Henry Kaufman said interest rates will surge again, impairing the year's economic recovery. Mr. Kaufman, in his annual forecast of trends in the nation's financial markets, stressed that Federal borrowing would absorb so much of the money available for investment that other borrowers would be forced to do without, and the confrontation between the credit needs of the Treasury and corporations would produce a ''substantial rebound'' in rates. (Page A1.) Mr. Kaufman, who has a solid record as a forecaster, is noted for his pessimism. (D6.)

title: ABA INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Yr to Nov 1
description: Shr earnings adjusted for 5-for-4 stock split on Dec 17

title: FAIRFIELD COMMUNITIES LAND CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
'100 STARS' AND MORE TO BENEFIT ACTORS' FUND
description: There will be a ''chorus line'' doing a one-night stand at the Radio City Music Hall on Feb. 14 that Croesus could not assemble but Cohen (Alexander H.) has, because it will be for the benefit of the Actors' Fund of America. The fund is celebrating its 100th anniversary this year.

title: An R.J. Reynolds Unit T o Get a New President
description: Lester W. Pullen, 52, assumed his first international assignment at the age of 21, when he left his native England for the Netherlands as an employee of the Royal Dutch/Shell Group, and he has been on the move for much of the time since. On Friday, after serving in more than 12 different countries for several companies and after 14 years with R.J. Reynolds Industries, he will become president and chief executive of its R.J. Reynolds Tobacco International subsidiary.

title: U. of Wisconsin Placed On One-Year Probation
description: The N.C.A.A. today placed the University of Wisconsin on probation for one year for violations in the recruitment of Carlton Walker, an offensiv e lineman.

title: FOSSILS OFFERED TO REBUT THEORY THAT METEORITE KILLED THE DINOSAUR
description: The proposal that an asteroid's impact with the earth caused the extinction of the dinosaurs was challenged here today by the presentation of fossil findings tending to show prehistoric time sequences incompatible with that explanation.

title: LETTER TO YANKEES FROM STEINBRENNER URGES EARLY CAMP
description: George Steinbrenner, the Yankees' principal owner, has sent a three-page letter to his players urging each of them to report to spring training several weeks before they are required to under the terms of the collective bargaining agreement. The letter states Steinbrenner's desire for ''maximum dedication'' and offers to trade any player who ''would rather be a part of another organization.''

title: Around the Nation; Alabama Is Accused Of College Segregation
description: The Department of Education accused the State of Alabama today of failing to eliminate student and faculty segregation in its colleges and universities.

title: Casino Panel Names Leader
description: The State Casino Control Commission today unanimously elected Commissioner Don M. Thomas its new vice chairman, effectively elevating him to acting chairman.

title: About New York; FELINE AID AND COMFORT ON WEST 25TH STREET
description: It is tempting for dog lovers to think that some New Yorkers are enamored of cats only because they need not be picked up after on the street, but, of course, that is not true.

title: CLARK STARTS PERFORMING NEW TASKS
description: William P. Clark Jr. moved swiftly into his new job as President Reagan's national security assistant today, taking part in presidential talks with Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany and running the agenda of a National Security Council meeting this afternoon.

title: The U.N. Today; Jan. 6, 1982; SECURITY COUNCIL
description: Meets on Golan Heights issue at 3:30 P.M. GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Family Values for the Polovchaks
description: It's a common source of domestic aggravation: an adolescent child adopts alien habits and companions, defying his parents. And most parents know what to do: for the sake of the family, they insist on their authority and make clear the limits of their tolerance.

title: ALPHA MICROSYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Transactions
description: BASEBALL ATLANTA (NL) - Sig ned Glenn Hub- bard, second basema n.

title: Oldsmobile Plans To Lay Off 1,000
description: The Oldsmobile division of the General Motors Corporation, the principal employer in the Lansing area, said it would lay off 1,000 workers over the next month.

title: Reinventing the Diplomatic Wheel
description: It is high time that President Reagan got someone in his inner circle to coordinate foreign policy full time. William Clark comes to the job with only a year's experience in world affairs, as Deputy Secretary of State. He will not, therefore, have much independent knowledge or sensitivity about the advice flowing to the President. But unlike the hapless Richard Allen, he has a long association with Mr. Reagan and is promised regular access to the Oval Office. That means important conflicts can now come to Mr. Reagan in timely fashion. It also offers a new chance to impose the President's priorities on the capital's most powerful bureaucracies.

title: Article 159786 -- No Title
description: Neil Simon, the playwright, and Jack I. Levin, chairman of the executive committee of KCET-TV, the public-television station in Los Angeles, have each contributed $25,000 to create the Neil Simon Award. The award will go to the authors of the best scripts written for the first two seasons of the public-television series ''American Playhouse.'' The winners will each be given $25,000.

title: Chief Executive Joins Parker Pen
description: James R. Peterson, 54 years old, has joined the Parker Pen Company in Janesville, Wis., as president and chief executive officer. He succeeds George Parker, a 52-year-old grandson of the founder, who continues as chairman of the company, which had sales in its last fiscal year of almost three-quarters of a billion dollars. ''About the only thing I haven't done in bu siness is to be a chief executive officer of a company and this was a vailable here,'' Mr. Peterson said yesterday.

title: Perlman on PBS Feb. 10
description: Itzhak Perlman and the New York Philharmonic will appear on a ''Live from Lincoln Center'' telecast Feb. 10 on PBS. With David Zinman conducting, the violinist will play Vivaldi's ''Winter'' from ''The Four Seasons'' and concertos for violin and orchestra by Mendelssohn and Brahms. The performance, which starts at 8 P.M., will be part of the ''Great Performers at Avery Fisher Hall'' series.

title: New Man at Mike
description: Steve Lamar, who was the play-by-play announcer for the Durham Bulls of the Carolina League last season, has been hired by the Mets for their radio broadcasts. Lamar, a 35-year-old Californian, will team with Bob Murphy, the veteran Met announcer.

title: CHURCH IS SPLIT ON CRISIS
description: The following dispatch is based on information reaching The New York Times from Poland.

title: No Headline
description: FLOOD AND MUDSLIDES KILL AT LEAST 12 IN CALIFORNIA

title: G.M. AND CHRYSLER SALES DROP
description: The General Motors Corporation reported yesterday that its new-car sales in the United States fell 15.9 percent in the final 10 days of December while the Chrysler Corporation posted a 36.7 percent decline in the same period. The decline s, continuing months of depressed sales in the auto industry -cam e as the nation's auto makers began reporting the final figures of wh at is certain to be the industry's worst sales year since 1961.

title: No Headline
description: Princeton Tops Fairfield, 50-49

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Creation-science as defined not only fails to follow the canons defining scientific theory, it also fails to fit the more general descriptions of 'what scientists think' and 'what scientists do,''' - Judge William Ray Overton of the United States Court for the Eastern District of Arkansas.

title: Rockets 112, Warriors 111
description: A 20-foot jump shot by Elvin Hayes with 18 seconds to play gave Houston the victory. Hayes's field goal came after the Rockets called a time out. He took an inbounds pass and scored from the left side.

title: OIL CONCERNS FIGHTING U.S. TO BUY SHALE LANDS AT $2.50 AN ACRE
description: A Federal hearing that began here today will decide whether a handful of energy companies and private investors may obtain legal title to more than 30,000 acres of publicly owned oil shale land in northwestern Colorado at a fee of $2.50 an acre. The land has a potential market value of hundreds of millions of dollars.

title: DESIGN CHANGES PLANNED FOR DC-10 WING PROBLEM
description: The manufacturer of the DC-10 airliner said last night that it was proposing two design changes to guard against a crash if one of the jumbo jets lost an underwing engine and simultaneously suffered damage to high-lift wing devi ces. The builder, the McDonnell Douglas Corporat ion, announced in Long Beach, Calif., that the changes would be made in the mechanism that controls the movement of the airliner's wing slats. The wing slats are aerodynamic surfaces on the front of the wing that, when extended, provide extra lift on takeoff and l anding, when speeds are comparatively slow.

title: Algeria Cuts Price of Oil
description: Algeria has notified customers that it has cut its crude oil price by 50 cents a barrel, to $37, effective Jan. 1, industry sources said yesterday.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: THE BRONX IS UP

title: Careers; The Job Outlook F or 1982
description: AS the new year begins, so does the business of forecasting what it will bring. In the job market, the forecast for 1982 is mixed. There will be a lot more jobs this year, according to Theodore Barry & Associates, a management consulting firm with headquarters in Los Angeles and offices in New York, Atlanta, Chicago, Portland, Ore., and Washington. Its study, ''The 1990 Worker,'' estimates that there will be an average of 1.6 million new jobs created in business and industry each year through the decade. And in line with the trend toward service industries, the study says, many of the new openings will be for white-collar workers.

title: Senator Hawkins Injured
description: Senator Paula Hawkins, Republican of Florida, was hospitalized tonight for injuries when struck by a falling partition at the taping of an interview at Orlando television station WESH. The 6-foot, 40-pound backdrop hit the 54-year-old Senator on the head, shoulders and back and she blacked out briefly, according to station employees. She was described as ''conscious and lucid although in pain'' as she left the studio for the Orlando Regional Medical Center.

title: WHITHER HEMLINES? WELL, UP AND DOWN
description: AS spring clothes start coming into the stores this month, it will be immediately apparent that there is no rule about hemlines. Those who remember the miniskirt's passing with something approaching regret will find plenty of knee-baring hemlines. Those women who feel like story-book heroines when their skirts swish around their ankles will find a good choice of longer skirts, with which they can wear petticoats if they are so inclined.

title: GOODRICH IN PLASTICS PURCHASE
description: The B.F. Goodrich Company and the Diamond Shamrock Corporation announced late yesterday that Goodrich had purchased Diamond Shamrock's plastics subsidiary, effective Jan. 1.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rate payable by savings institutions.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: No Headline
description: NETS TOPPLE BULLETS

title: HANS CONRIED, 66, AN ACTOR ON STAGE, TV AND IN MOVIES
description: Hans Conried, a versatile character actor and comedian who entertained audiences on stage, radio and television and in films for more than 40 years, died of a heart attack yesterday in a hospital in Burbank, Calif. A resident of Hollywood, he was 66 years old.

title: DEFENSE LAWYER FOR 'GANG OF FOUR' RETAINS HIS FAITH IN CHINA
description: Like most of the lawyers in China, Ma Rongjie suffered grievously during the Cultural Revolution, a time when the legal profession was deemed degenerate and parasitic.

title: No Headline
description: Canadiens Snap Bruin Streak

title: Rams Wielding Broom
description: Five assistant coaches of the Los Angeles Rams were dismissed by Coach Ray Malavasi in what appears to be the teams' biggest housecleaning since 1979.

title: OMEGA OPTICAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
A WEEK'S STRATEGY FOR 30-MINUTE MEALS
description: JANUARY is the frugal month. The holiday season has reduced the bank account and increased the waistline; both trends must be reversed. This is not the season to be jolly and give parties; it's the time to retrench.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Anheuser-Busch Companies, St. Louis, has elected to its board Paul Thayer, chairman and chief executive officer of the LTV Corp.

title: U.S.F. 78, San Jose State 66
description: SAN FRANCISCO (AP) - Quintin Dailey scored 20 points and the University of San Francisco raised its season record to 12-1. The Spartans were never in the game, scoring just 4 points and committing seven turnovers in the first nine minutes to fall behind, 16-4.

title: Debt Payment By Poland
description: A Luxembourg subsidiary of a West German bank has been paid its share of an overdue $550 million interest payment that Poland owes to a consortium of Western banks, reliable banking sources said here today.

title: Around the Nation; 3 Marooned on Island Arrive in Honolulu
description: Three Canadian castaways arrived here tonight after being marooned for nearly a month on a remote mid-Pacific atoll.

title: World Bank Increases Its Charges on Loans
description: Directors of the World Bank today voted to increase char ges on loans to poor countries because of the squeeze onresources cau sed by austerity moves in the United States and other industrial co untries.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: THE worst concert tragedy in the history of rock-and-roll took place a little more than two years ago, on Dec. 3, 1979, outside Cincinnati's Riverfront Coliseum. Eleven young people died of asphyxiation in a crowd that was jammed together on an open plaza, waiting for the doors to open so that they could see a concert by the Who. Official inquiries have been conducted and the findings studied, and the policy of selling unreserved, or ''festival seating,'' tickets, a policy that may encourage enthusiastic fans to rush and shove for the most desirable seats, has been discontinued at Riverfront Coliseum and at many other rock venues.

title: New Business Tabloid
description: In May the Washington-Baltimore market will become the 11th market to have a weekly, local business tabloid published by Cordovan Business Journals of Houston. The Washington Business Journal is scheduled to begin publication on May 17 after an April 26 preview issue.

title: British Reserves Down
description: Britain's reserves of gold and foreign currency in the Bank of England fell by $116 million last month to $23.3 billion at the end of 1981, the Government announced today.

title: STOCKS FALL AFTER ECONOMIST PREDICTS INTEREST RATE SPURT
description: Stock prices fell sharply yesterday after Henry Kaufman, an influential Wall Street economist, said that an economic recovery this year will be marred by another spurt in interest rates to record or near-record levels in the second half of 1982. In his annual, broad-brushed forecast of tr ends in the financial markets of the United States, Mr. Kaufman str essed that the Federal Government's borrowing - which he expects to account for 30 percent of all borrowing - will absorb so much of the money available for investment that other borrowers will be force d to do without.

title: CITY STUDYING WAYS TO TEST FOR ILLEGAL WASTE IN DUMPS
description: The Sanitation Department, responding to reports that toxic wastes had been dumped illegally at three New York City landfills, said yesterday that it was trying to decide how to tes t for the chemicals and what steps to take if they are found.

title: Iran Reports Execution Of 8 Bahais for Spying
description: Eight Bahais have been executed in Teheran for ''spying for foreign powers,'' the official Iranian press agency reported today.

title: THE VALUE-ADDED TAX IS LESS THAN A CURE-ALL
description: To the Editor:

title: POLISH AIDE ACCUSES U.S. OF 'IMMORALITY'
description: A top adviser to Poland's military leader, Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, bitterly accused the United States today of ''attempting to recolonize Western Europe politically'' and of practicing ''the utmost immorality'' in withdrawing Poland's fishing rights in United States waters.

title: SYNTHETIC FUEL PLANS ADVANCE
description: The United States Synthetic Fuels Corporation, which expects to have $14.8 billion available by June to aid sponsors of development projects, today identified 27 applicants from among whom the first recipients of funds would be selected.

title: Nuclear Plant Plan Hindered
description: A plan to mothball two nuclear power plants being built in Washington State at a cost of almost $3 billion appears in danger of being rejected and the head of the committee representing the sponsoring utilities says the plants will probably be abandoned.

title: Women's Track Series Will Offer Cash Prizes
description: A Grand Prix series for women, involving four track meets this month and next and carrying a total purse of $57,000, was announced yesterday by its sponsor, Jean Nate, a manufacturer of fragrances. The series is sanctioned by The Athletics Congress, and the cash prizes will be paid not to the athletes, but to their clubs.

title: ON FLY FISHING: BY JIMMY CARTER
description: The January/February issue of Fly Fisherman, a glossy magazine devoted to the intricacies and pleasures of fishing with a fly rod, bears a new byline: Jimmy Carter.

title: Robert Johnson, 61, Broadway Tap Dancer
description: Robert (Bobby) Johnson, a tap dancer in vaudeville and on the musical-comedy stage, died of a cardiac arrest Sunday while on his way to St. Vincent's Hospital for dialysis treatment. He lived in Manhattan and would have been 61 years old on Jan. 21.

title: Sittler Boycott
description: The feud between the front office of the Toronto Maple Leafs and Darryl Sittler, the Leafs' captain and star center, had appeared somewhat defused after Sittler backed down last month on his threat to leave the team if he were not traded. But yesterday Sittler refused to accompany the Maple Leafs for their game against the North Stars in Bloomington, Minn., last night.

title: Philip Morris Net For 1981 to Be Cut
description: Philip Morris Inc. said that 1981 earnings will be reduced by about $16 million from an extension of the last-in, first-out, or LIFO, method of inventory accounting.

title: U.S. STEEL CLEARED TO BUY MARATHON
description: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger refused today to block the United States Steel Corporation's acquisition of the Marathon Oil Company. His ruling cleared the way for the $6.2 billion purchase to go forward.

title: LOS ANGELES JURY CONVICTS MAN ACCUSED IN 10 KILLINGS
description: William Bonin, a 34-year-old truck driver, was convicted today of murdering 10 boys and young men and abandoning their bodies near freeways in Los Angeles County in 1979 and 1980. He was acquitted of killing two other young men in the heavily publicized freeway killings case that haunted the homosexual community here for months.

title: TV Ratings
description: Following are the top 15 national television shows of the past week (Monday, Dec. 28, to Sunday, Jan. 3), listed according to their rank in the ratings compiled by the A.C. Nielsen Company. A rating is a percentage of the total number of United States households with television sets. Rating Program Network 1 33.3 60 Minutes CBS 2 29.3 Dallas CBS 3 27.6 Alice CBS 4 25.8 M*A*S*H CBS 5 25.5 The Jeffersons CBS 6 25.1 Dukes of Hazzard CBS 7 23.8 Falcon Crest CBS 8 23.3 House Calls CBS 9 21.9 Three's Company ABC 1 0 21.5 Trapper John, M.D. CBS 1 1 21.1 Love Boat ABC 1 2 20.9 Lou Grant CBS 1 3 20.3 Too Close for Comfort ABC 1 4 20.1 CBS Saturday Night Movie CBS 1 5 20.0 Magnum, P.I. CBS

title: TAINTED EGGNOG FATAL TO 4 RESIDENTS OF A COUNTY NURSING HOME IN JERSEY
description: Four residents of a nursing home died and 120 residents and staff members became ill as a result of food poisoning apparently caused by eggnog served Christmas Eve, state and Gloucester County health officials said today.

title: Political Snipers and a Good Judge
description: Until early November Judith Whittaker, a Kansas City lawyer, was the Justice Department's leading candidate for a seat on the 8th Circuit Court of Appeals. The American Bar Association found her well qualified. The F.B.I. had no objections. And Chief Judge Donald Lay was delighted that after nearly two years Washington was finally ready to appoint a judge whom he considered an excellent choice. But the nomination never happened. At the last minute, the White House decided to look for someone else. Why?

title: NEVADA POWER COMPANY CO reports earnings for Yr to Nov 30
LAZARE KAPLAN INTENRATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
2 SOLIDARITY LEADERS URGE POLES TO RESIST THE MILITARY REGIME
description: The following dispatch is based on information arriving from Poland.

title: Mortgage Rate Sl ides to 17.54%
description: The average interest rate charged on long-term, fixed-rate mortgages for new homes fell to 17.54 percent in December from 18.16 percent in November, the Government said today.

title: GHANAIAN RULERS SHAKE UP COURTS
description: Ghana's new military Government said today that it was setting up ''people's tribunals'' to dispense ''revolutionary justice'' to scores of Ghanaians arrested over the last few days for ''crimes against the people.''

title: PRUDENTIAL BUYS STAKE IN DENVER DEVELOPMENT
description: The Urban Investment and Development Company of Chicago and the Miller-Davis Company of Denver announced yesterday the sale of a major portion of their joint interests in the City Center, a multiblock commercial development in downtown Denver, to the Prudential Insurance Company of America.

title: UNIFORMS FOR SCHOOL GUARDS
description: Security guards in the nation's second largest school district will put on uniforms, the city school board decided Monday night. Supporters of the plan, which involves 83 guards, said the uniforms would help deter vandalism and reduce the chance that guards might be accidentally shot by police officers responding to reports of violence.

title: Around the Nation; Improvements Pledged For Haitian Refugee Site
description: The Justice Depa rtment told Miami community representatives today that conditions would be improved at the Krome detention center, the scene of recent disturbances by Haitian refugees.

title: No Headline
description: After his first year as chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, Mark S. Fowler remains unshaken in his faith in the marketplace.

title: Bridge: Two New Yorkers Missed A Rare Tit le Double in '81
description: Two New York experts came within a hairbreadth of achieving an unusual double in 1981. The experts, Bill William s and Fred Jones of Brooklyn, sco red 75 percent in the American Contract Bridge League's charity game, played at the Vanderbilt Club in Manhasset, L.I. This was the highe st score in the United States, in a field of 23,000 players, but they were beaten by a Canadian partnership.

title: 3 REPUBLICANS EYEING WILLIAMS SEAT
description: TRENTON Jan . 6 - Representative Millicent Fenwick, Republican of Bernardsville , said today that she had met with Governor-elect ThomasH. Kean to te ll him of her plans to run for the United State Senate seat held by Harrison A. Williams Jr.

title: U.S. STEEL MOVES TO BUY MARATHON
description: The United States Steel Corporation moved ahead today with its purchase of the Marathon Oil Company. The Bankers Trust Company, paying agent for U.S. Steel, said that it was making plans to put 50 people on overtime almost immediately so that it could begin issuing checks to stockholders in person and by mail on Monday morning. It became free to issue $3.7 billion in checks at 12:01 A.M. today, at the expiration of a deadline set by a Federal appeals court. The money will buy 51 percent of the Marathon shares.

title: WOMAN FEARFUL AFTER 2 ROBBERS KILL STUDENT, 22
description: Standing in the lobby of the apartment house where she has lived all of her 17 years, across the street from the southern edge of the Columbia University campus, Lucy Vanegas looked nervously yesterday at the glass-paneled front door. ''I don't want them to get me,'' she said.

title: EXCERPTS FROM GOVERNOR CAREY'S STATE OF THE STATE MESSAGE TO
description: LEGISLATURE Following are excerpts from Governor Carey's State of the State Message to the Legislature in Albany yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times

title: Fire Damages Jersey Inn
description: A fire today damaged the historic Princessville Inn, which had served as a way station for travelers in the 1700's, authorities said. A spokesman for the Lawrence Township Police Department said the fire in the two-story wooden building on the Princeton Pike was ''definitely suspicious.''

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an arti- cle last Sunday incorrectly described the production of The International Herald Tribune. It is edited in Paris and printed in Paris, London, Zurich and Hong Kong.

title: Around the World; Filipino Athlete's Family Gets New Ransom Note
description: The family of a missing athlete, Tommy Manotoc, who secretly married the daughter of President Ferdinand E. Marcos, recei ved a note today urging them to comply with ransom demands.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Ampco-Pittsburgh Corp. said it had increased its stake in Vulcan Inc. to 269,700 shares, or 12.7 percent, through the purchase of 23,600 shares on the New York Stock Exchange between Nov.17 and Dec.31 for an aggregate price of $426,604.

title: STAY IS GRANTED ON PLAN TO RAZE 2 CITY THEATERS
description: Plans to demolish two theaters to make way for construction of the Portman hotel in the Times Square area were temporarily blocked yesterday by a Federal appeals court. The court acted pending the outcome of accusations that improper political influence had been used to approve the demolition.

title: No Headline
description: Gretzky Gets 2 Goals as Oilers Win, 5-3

title: Advertising; B.B.D.O. Obtains A Quaker Oats Account
description: Quaker Oats has assigned its Quaker 100% Natural Cereal to Batten, Barton Durstine & Osborn, already one of its agencies.

title: GRIM TELEVISION NEWS WITH A PURPOSE
description: To the Editor:

title: News Analysis
description: Trying to walk a fine legal and political line in a court case filled with political significance, the Justice Department in turn infuriated the opponents and the supporters of the proposed equal rights amendment this week.

title: IN PRAISE OF PATTERNS--SUBTLE TO STRIKING
description: THE awful truth of interior design these days is that many people would prefer a subtly patterned carpet underfoot, a plump three-cushion damask sofa (with arms), and a restful pattern on the walls any day of the week, rather than a room that seems fixed forever in bare, minimalist whiteness.

title: A RENAISSANCE OF VICTORIAN-STYLE HOUSES
description: LOS ANGELES THE Victorian house is making a curious comeback in California, heartland of the low-slung three-bedroom, two-bath bungalow. Builders and real estate agents reported that they have discovered a surprising market recently for new houses featuring gables, turrets, gazebos, cupolas, leaded glass, parlors and yes, even front porches - houses built in 1981 with 1890 architectural touches.

title: Miller Heads Field In $300,000 Tucson Golf
description: The golf pros are heading back to work, beginning Thursday with the Tucson Open, the first of 44 events on the 1982 tour. A field of 144, vying for the top prize of $54,000 from a total purse of $300,000, includes Johnny Miller.

title: Around the World; Gunmen in Guatemala Kidnap Nun and Priests
description: Masked gunmen kidnapped a Guatemalan Roman Catholic nun in eastern Chiquimula Province today, then set fire to the convent, the authorities there reported.

title: Shortstopping Bowa
description: The Philadelphia Phillies said that Larry Bowa, their shortstop, would hear from them by the end of this week as to whether they will renegotiate his contract or trade him. Bowa, who is under contract until next fall, wants a three-year pact raising his salary from $250,000 a year to $400,000.

title: Advertising; Accounts
description: * Gurney's Ventures Inc. to the real estate division of Fairfax Inc., a subsidiary of Compton Advertising, for Gurney's Inn Resort/Spa.

title: CAREY OFFERS PLAN ON MEDICAID COSTS AND EDUCATION AID
description: Governor Carey opened the 205th session of the Legislature today with a call for drastic and potentially expensive changes in the way New York State finances education, health care for the poor and its crumbling system of roads and bridges.

title: POLAND: WHAT ARE OUR MOTIVES?
description: To the Editor:

title: Administration Delays Secrecy Order Briefing
description: The Reagan Administration today abruptly canceled plans to brief Congress on a proposed Presidential order that would let Government officialsinvoke national security more easily and more often in keeping information from the public.

title: CAMPBELL RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Net income including $5,287,000 gain from insurance of shares by majority-owned companies

title: DISCOUNT CORP OF NY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
KEROSENE HEATERS: ARE NEW ONES SAFE?
description: FOR some homeowners, portable kerosene space heaters may seem like a double blessing - a way to shrink fuel bills while warming one's toes. But in recent months, these devices, mainly imported from Japan, have been described by fire experts in far different terms. They say that such products can be dangerous, pointing to a history of home fires caused by kerosene heaters.

title: REAGAN OFFICIALS WEIGH EX-IM BANK FUND CUTS
description: President Reagan is being called on to arbitrate a sharp dispute between the Administration's trade officers and budget cutters over future funding levels for the Export-Import Bank, Administration sources reported today.

title: The U.N. Today; Jan. 7, 1982; SECURITY COUNCIL
description: Meets on Golan Heights issue at 3:30 P.M. GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Notes on People; Moynihan Voices Concern on Reagan Tax Plan
description: You are a United States Senator from New York. It is January. You need to do a little campaigning, test the political waters and make a Democratic issue out of the Reagan tax program.

title: Long-Term Prices Off Sharply; 7-Year Notes Bring 14.74%
description: The bond market moved erratically yesterday before closing with large losses in the longest maturities. Short-term Treasury bills, which have been favored by instituional buyers in recent weeks, ended with rates unchanged to modestly higher.

title: WARMING OF WORLD'S CLIMATE EXPECTED TO BEGIN IN THE 80'S
description: Mankind's activities in increasing the amount of carbon dioxide and other chemicals in the atmosphere can be expected to have a substantial warming effect on climate, with the first clear signs of the trend becoming evident within this decade, a scientist at the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said here today.

title: Pipe Order Sought
description: Mannesmann, the West German steel producer, has begun negotiations to supply the Soviet Union with one million tons of steel pipe for a gas pipeline from Siberia to Western Europe, a company spokesman said today.

title: CITY AND STATE REACH AGREEMENT TO END DISPUTE OVER USE OF JAILS
description: A long and sometimes acrimonious dispute ended yesterday when New York City agreed to continue housing state prisoners temporarily and the state agreed to pay for such housing when the inmates' stays exceeded 48 hours after processing.

title: GOLAN DEBATE AT U.N. IS FULL OF VENOM
description: Syria and Israel traded charges of aggression today as the Security Council reopened its debate on the Israeli annexation of the Golan Heights.

title: Business Digest; THURSDAY, JANUARY 7, 1982; The Economy
description: Increases in taxes on consumer items are being urged by President Reagan's economic advisers as part of a strategy to bring budget deficits well below $100 billion in the next few years, officials reported. The advisers' common position represents a shift by Treasury Secretary Regan. The Secretary, meanwhile, voiced disagreement with the prediction by Henry Kaufman, the Wall Street economist, that interest rates would climb in the second half of 1982. (Page A1.) The average interest rate charged for new home loans has fallen to 17.54 percent. (D9.)

title: Dolphins Beach Themselves
description: About 150 dolphins beached themselves today despite efforts by volunteers to force them back out to sea.

title: APPLICATION ENGINEERING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Running With Roosevelt
description: To judge by all the 1932 phrases from Gov. Franklin Roosevelt, Hugh Carey's State of New York State message suggests whom he would most like to run against for re-election: Herbert Hoover. By comparing the present to the Depression, and by equating President Reagan's policies with Hoover's, the Governor talks as though he were asking for a dramatic expansion of state spending.

title: Morris Brown Stripped of Title
description: For the second straight year, Morris Brown College has been stripped of the football title in the Southern Intercollegiate Athletic Conference for using academically ineligible players.

title: SUSPECT IN LIBYAN TERRORIST PROJECT SAYS TOP C.I.A. AIDES ENDORSED IT
description: The man identified by the Government as the supervisor of a terrorist training project in Libya has told Federal prosecutors that the operation was endorsed and put to use by two senior officials at the Central Intelligence Agency when it began in 1976.

title: NEW JERSEY CHARGES 3 JOCKEYS
description: Mr. Zazzali said the conspiracy was discovered by undercover State Police detectives working on a yearlong investigation into attempts to fix races at the Meadowlands and other thoroughbred tracks in New Jersey. He said that the races targeted fro fixing were run last October but that the comspiracy was uncoverd before the races were run, and no tampering occurred. He declined to say how the jockeys planned to fix the outcome of the races.

title: WHERE TO GO FOR TUTORING
description: Here is a list of facilities that offer tutoring services. Some require that children be tested first. Marymount Manhattan College Com- munication and Learning Center, 221 East 71st Street.

title: 3 Poles Jump Ship in Canada
description: Three Polish sailors jumped ship and sought asylum in Canada today while their vessel was loading grain in a St. Lawrence River port, immigration officials said. More than 80 Polish sailors, mostly from fishing vessels, have sought permission to stay in Canada since martial law was declared in Poland last month.

title: Around the World; Soviet Said to Add 10,000 To Units in Afghanistan
description: The Soviet Union has started to move more troops into Afghanistan, military analysts here said today.

title: Soviet Market For Robots
description: The Soviet Union plans to expand the use of industrial robots to increase output, according to Yoshitaka Kitao, research analyst at the Nomura Securities Compa ny, a large brokerage.

title: Stepien Resentful
description: Ted Stepien, owner of the Cleveland Cavaliers, agrees with a lot of other N.B.A. owners that, for the sake of maintaining fan interest, some way must be found to help the weaker of the league's 23 teams draw closer to parity with the stronger teams. But Stepien differs on what specific steps should be taken, and he expresses resentment over what he considers the singling-out of his club, whose 6-25 record is the worst in the N.B.A. Some owners have suggested extra draft choices for the most untalented teams; others have proposed limits on the trading of draft choices so as to save a profligate front office from itself.

title: Seven N.Y. All-Pros
description: The Jets and the Giants placed seven players on the first and second all-pro teams announced by The Associa ted Press after a national poll of sports reporters and broadca sters. On the first team are Marvin Powell, offensive tackle of t he Jets; Joe Klecko, defensive end of the Jets, and Lawrence Taylo r, outside linebacker ofthe Giants. On the second are Joe Fields, Je t center; Mark Gastineau, Jet defensive end; Mark Haynes, Gi ant cornerback, and DaveJennings, Giant punter . . . George Rogers of the New Orleans Saints,who led the league in rushing with 1,674 yard s, was named the A.P. rookie of the year on offense. . . . U.P.I. r eported that the ChicagoBears will announce the re-signing of Buddy R yan as defensive coordinator.

title: E.E.C. Hints Of Recovery
description: The European Economic Community appears to be emerging from the current worldwide recession, according to statistics and a survey released today by the E.E.C. Commission.

title: Israel Immigration Unit Curtails Vienna Efforts
description: The official Israeli agency that handles the immigration of Soviet Jews to Israel said today that it was curtailing its activities in Vienna because of a dispute with the Austrian authorities.

title: Business World; New President Named At Sonat Subsidiary
description: Sonat Inc., the renamed Southern Natural Resources Inc., has appointed N. Thomas Williams, 48, president of its Southern Forest Products subsidiary, based in Birmingham, Ala. At Southern Forest Products, which has more than 800,000 acres of timberland and operates paper mills, he succeeds Ronald L. Kuehn, 46, who, as previously announced, has become president and chief operating officer of the parent company.

title: KNICKS PROFITING BY A CHANGE
description: Maurice Lucas, at the age of 29, is not a tired, old man - at least, not yet. So he knows that age is not the reason that he, the man who was supposed to make the difference for the Knicks this season, has been spending a lot of time on the bench recently.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''In the winter of 1982, the elderly fear for their security, workers for their jobs, parents for their families, the young for their future.'' - Governor Carey. (A1:6.)

title: HOUSING PANEL URGES MORE LENDER LEEWAY
description: A Presidential commission today recommended a sweeping expansion in the powers of savings and loan associations, mutual savings banks and commercial banks so that all of these financial institutions could pump more money into the home mortgage market.

title: ARMIES OF JOBLESS YOUTHS MARKING TIME IN CHINA
description: If there is enough for her to do, Sun Fang goes each weekday to a small backroom workshop to sit with other young women around a cramped table assembling plastic toy automobiles under the harsh glare of a fluorescent light.

title: RECITAL: NANCY CIRILLO PLAYS BACH PARTITA NO.1 FOR VIOLIN
description: THE playing of Nancy Cirillo Tuesday at the Merkin Concert Hall sounded like the playing of two different vio linists. At its best, asin Bach's Partita No. 1 in B minor for solo v iolin, it was characterized by an admirable flexibility in the shaping of phrases and the treatment of rhythm.

title: A RUSSIAN VIEWS U.S. NEWS
description: When I came to the United States for the first time, in 1966, a neighbor in my apartment house told me that she had toured Russia the year before: ''Oh, Russians are so friendly, so hospitable!'' It was a pleasure to hear this, and I quoted her in a dispatch. In 1979, I returned here, moved into the same building, and met the same woman, and she spoke again of her visit. This time she said: ''I was in your country in the middle of the 1960's. I wonder why your people are so aggressive and secretive, so hostile toward everyone?''

title: India Seeking Loan for Mill
description: The Government of India is expected to raise a $1 billion, 10-year syndicated bank loan later this month, banking sources said here today.

title: Inco Cutbacks To Lessen Output
description: Inco Ltd., the world's biggest nickel producer, said it expects 1982 production at its Sudbury operation to fall to 195 million pounds from 220 million pounds in 1981.

title: SOVIET AND POLAND SIGN $11.8 BILLION TRADE PACT
description: Poland and the Soviet Union signed an $11.8 billion trade agreement today, the Warsaw radio reported. Under the accord, signed in Moscow by the Foreign Trade Ministers of the two nations, Poland will receive fuel, raw materials and $3.8 billion in credits, the radio said.

title: Low Supply of Blood Called an Emergency
description: A blood emergency was declared yesterday in the metropolitan New York area and outlying regions because the supply levels of all blood types are extremely low, officials of the Greater New York Blood Program said.

title: AN UNTRADITIONAL TIGHT END
description: SAN DIEGO UNDER the microscope of the Super Bowl playoffs, Kellen Winslow is in focus now as a tight end in a class by himself. Except that he is not a traditional tight end. In the San Diego Chargers' pass-oriented offense, he also lines up as a wide receiver, a halfback, a fullback and a slotback.

title: BIRDSONG SIDELINED
description: Quinn Buckner, the Milwaukee Bucks' playmaker, who describes himself as ''the least likely scorer on this team,'' scored 22 points tonight and his team scored a 101-95 victory over the New Jersey Nets at the Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: ACTED ON SGT. BILKO PROGRAM
description: Harvey Lembeck, a character actor who was featured on Broadway as Harry Shapiro in ''Stalag 17'' and on television as Cpl. Rocco Barbella on ''You'll Never Get Rich,'' the Phil Silvers comedy series, died Tuesday in Los Angeles.

title: Design Notebook
description: THREE rapid glimpses of architectural details in Manhattan: On the southeast corner of 72d Street and Madison Avenue, there is a store that has a marble floor, a stone balustrade and a stone doorway arch; on the northeast corner of the same intersection, an apartment building displays rusticated limestone on its facade, and a few blocks away at 80th Street and Fifth Avenue, the ornate ironwork of another apartment building surrounds the lower portion of the windows, creating tiny balconies. At first glance, there is nothing remarkabl e about these details. They could be any of the thousands of pieces of fine architectural work that fill both interiors and exteriors o f older buildings throughout the city.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Adams Express Co., Baltimore, has elected Joan L. Eichenberg vice president-research.

title: John Brown Owns Olofsson
description: John Brown & Company Ltd., the Scottish shipbuilding and engineering concern, said it had completed the acquisition of the Olofsson Corporation, a privately held machine tool manufacturer based in Lansing, Mich., in a move that the company said would probably be its last major acquisition in the United States for some time.

title: THE REGION
description: TRENTON (UPI) - The State Supreme Court has ruled that Governor-Byrne acted within the law when he ordered county jails to take state prisoners to ease overcrowding.

title: Notes on People; Warm Welcome for the Semyonovs
description: Lisa and Alexey Semyonov, the daughter-in-law and stepson of the dissident Soviet scientist Andrei Sakharov, began their honeymoon yesterday in Butte, Mont., where they were married by proxy last June.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, JANUARY 7, 1982
description: International American isolation on sanctions against the Soviet Union was acknowledged by the Reagan Administration. It said it would not press at next week's NATO meeting for a concerted program of sanctions but would be satisfied with a strong condemnation of Moscow's involvement in the crackdown in Poland. Washington's position was announced after a two-day visit by Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany, who opposes the sanctions. (Page A1, Column 1.) Major financial aid for Poland if Warsaw returns to the policies in effect before martial law is expected to be provided by Western Europe. Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher spoke of the aid plan soon after returning to Bonn from the two-day conference in Washington. (A12:2-4.)

title: THIRD OF CALIFORNIA CHEESE DISTRIBUTED
description: On a chilly day just before Christmas, the deliveries began: Trucks carrying thousands of pounds of surplus American cheese wended their way through California, dropping off their loads for the needy.

title: PARENTS' QUESTION ON DRUGS
description: Following are questions parents often ask about their children and drugs during drug prevention sessions with Phoenix House counselors: Q: How do I know if my child is involved with drugs? A: You will find real changes in standard patterns of behavior over and above those normally associated with adolescence. These include general apathy, sharp mood changes and an abrupt drop in school marks. Certain drugs have specific side effects, such as red eyes (marijuana), weight loss (cocaine), appetite increase (marijuana), general paranoia (angel dust).

title: Hers
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- The Hers column was designed as a forum for writing by women. For several weeks, it will be written by Gail Godwin, whose book, ''A Mother and Two Daughters,'' is being published this month by Viking Press.

title: NEEDIEST CASES FUND PASSES $1 MILLION 1 2th STRAIGHT YEAR
description: The 70th annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund has received a total of $1,031,591.73 in contributions, making it a million-dollar fund for the 12th year in a row.

title: TURKEY DEBATING A PRESIDENT'S ROLE
description: A consultative assembly that is working on a constitution for Turkey is reported to be debating how powerful the president should be.

title: QUEBEC'S CABINET LOSES STRATEGIST
description: The Quebec politician who devised the provincial Government's strategy of seeking to take gradual steps toward independence has resigned from both the Cabinet and the legislature.

title: 4.5 MILLION UNIONISTS FACE BID FOR CONCESSIONS
description: American labor unions are heading into negotiations on contracts estimated to cover 4.5 million workers against a backdrop of high unemployment, continuing recession and wide industry demands for labor cost concessions.

title: TV: 'FAME' BEGINS AS WEEKLY SERIES
description: ROLLING off the success of the movie, ''Fame'' comes to television tonight, at 8 on NBC, as a weekly series. The central setting is the New York High School for Performing Arts, w he re talented city youngsters prepare furiously for what they ho pe will be sparkling careers in the theater, movies, television, d ance or music. The typesof students and teachers are straight out of central casting.

title: Miss Reagan Denies Money Forced Her to Oust Advisers
description: Maureen Reagan, the President's elder daughter, denied today that fund-raisi ng prob lems forced her to dismiss her professional consultants and put her husband in charge ofher campaign for a seat in the United States Senate.

title: YONKERS MAYOR DROPPING SCORES OF CITY WORKERS
description: The Mayor of Yonkers, who was sworn into office on New Year's Day, is dismissing scores of temporary city workers and has requested resignations from all city department heads.

title: Earth Tremors in France
description: Five earth tremors today shook the area around this village in southwest France at the foot of the Pyrenees Mountains. No serious damage or injur y was reported.

title: BONN VOWS AID IF POLES LIFT MARTIAL LAW
description: Several hours after returning from talks between Chancellor Helmut Schmidt and American officials, Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher said today that Bonn and its Western allies were prepared to grant Poland considerable financial aid if Warsaw returned to the policies in effect before martial law.

title: News Analysis
description: During the nearly three months that he has been in office, President Hosni Mubarak has adhered to the foreign policy of Anwar el-Sadat, as he said he would, but he has put his own stamp on internal policies and issues. Since Mr. Sadat's assassination at a military parade on Oct. 6, Mr . Mubarak has repeatedly said he is committed to the Camp David pe ace treaty with Israel and the return to Egypt by Israel of the la st portion of Sinai by April 25.

title: COMMITTEE IN U.S. WORKING ON BEHALF OF LABOR IN POLAND
description: Since the declaration of martial law in Poland on Dec. 13, a small group of activists in New York, most of them college students or union members, has maintained an information and lobbying center devoted to publicizing the cause of Polish workers.

title: SANTA MONICA BANK (CALIF) reports earnings for Yr to Sept 30
Around the Nation; Cardinal Cody Moved To Coronary Care Unit
description: John Cardinal Cody was transferred tonight in serious condition to the coronary care unit of Northwestern Memorial Hospital, a hospital official said.

title: Alcoa to Close Second Potline
description: The Aluminum Company of America said it will temporarily shut down a second potline, with a rated capacity of 34,200 tons, at its Rockdale, Tex., smelter, effective Jan.17.

title: Technology; Monitoring Temperatures
description: THE ancient science of measuring temperatures is being swept up in the modern technological rush to impro ve moni toring systems of every sort.

title: News Analysis
description: A new year has dawned for City Hall with a chronic affliction: a surging crime rate on the streets and in the subways. Mayor Koch and his top law enforcement officials have responded to the latest crime problems with several proposals that had been tried before or discarded as impractical. These were the key ideas s uggested by the Mayor and his aides earlier this week:

title: U.S. IS RELENTING ON NATO SANCTIONS AGAINST RUSSIANS
description: The United States said today that it would not press at next week's NATO meeting for a concerted program of sanctions against the Russians but would be satisfied with a strong condemnation of their involvement in the Polish crackdown.

title: U.S. FAMILY ESCAPES FROM IRAN ON CAMEL, FOOT AND HORSEBACK
description: An Iranian-born American citizen who had been imprisoned in Teheran on espionage charges said today that he, his wife and their 5-year-old daughter had managed to flee from Iran on foot and by camel, horse and motorcycle. They flew from Pakistan to the United States last weekend.

title: CALLERS SAY DOZIER HAS BEEN KILLED
description: Anonymous callers who said they spoke for the Red Brigades told the newspaper La Repubblica tonight that Brig. Gen. James L. Dozier had been slain and that his body could be found in a secluded spot about 30 miles from Pescara on the Adriatic coast.

title: Ski Jump to E. German
description: Manfred Deckert of East Germany took first place in the annual four-hill ski-jumping tournament, finishing fifth today in the final event. Roger Ruud of Norway was second.

title: Critic's Notebook; EDWARD GOREY ACHIEVES STATUS OF A GRAND OLD MAN
description: IT used to be that you had to be a Grand Old Man before anyone thought of issuing your Collected Works. (Historians did best, with novelists a close second.) Those Collected Works didn't always do too well, though, and by the time an author's centenary came around, they often got sold by the yard to give someone's house the look of an instant library.

title: THE TRUCK-LEASING TRIANGLE
description: They are, to be sure, an unlikely threesome: two of the nation's largest truck-leasing companies and a giant insurance brokerage firm. Yet in the past five months they have managed to intertwine themselves in a tangle of illuminating legal and financial transactions.

title: OPEC'S LINGERING IMPACT ON AMERICA'S G.N.P.
description: To the Editor:

title: TANANA JOINS RANGERS, GLAD TO LEAVE BOSTON
description: Frank Tanana, the free-agent left-hander, signed a two-year contract with the Texas Rangers today, reportedly for $400,000 a year.

title: Ohio State Firings
description: Three defensive coaches of the Ohio State football team were dismissed by Coach Earle Bruce after a season in which the Buckeyes yielded 253 points, a school record, and a total of 2,220 yards in passing. Dismissed were Dennis Fryzel, defensive coordinator; Nick Saban, backfield coach, and Steve Szabo, line coach.

title: CHAMBER: ASPEN SOLOISTS
description: IN their recital in Alice Tully Hall on Tuesday night, the Aspen Soloists proved to be a proficient piano trio whose ensemble precision was matched by musical competence.

title: COSMETICS MAKERS ARE LURING MEN
description: There are mirrors, displays, lights and computers that will analyzehis skin in 3 0 seconds. A woman in a white smock leans over the counter, take s his chin in her hands and scrutinizes his pores. She will study hi s face, and then prescribe a regimen of products for thehealth, beaut y and manicured ruggedness of her client's skin.

title: CALENDAR OF EVENTS: ARCH ITECT URAL FETE
description: The Making of an Architect, 1881-1981, National Academy of Design, 1083 Fifth Avenue (89th Street).

title: Advertising; New Executives At David H. Mann
description: Two new arrivals from big agencies and one 10-year veteran have all been promoted to executive vice president and made stockholders of David H. Mann Advertising.

title: Key Rates
description: Previous Year In percent Yesterday Day Ago PRIME RATE 15.75 15.75 19.50 DISCOUNT RATE 12.00 12.00 13.00 FEDERAL FUNDS 11.85 12.90 18.90 3-MO. TREAS. BILLS 11.70 11.65 14.49 6-MO. TREAS. BILLS 12.50 12.31 13.90 7-YR. TREAS. NOTES 14.82 14.65 12.44 30-YR. TREAS. BONDS 14.29 14.09 11.84 BELL SYSTEM BONDS 16.15 15.96 12.76 MUNICIPAL BONDS 14.21 13.95 10.25 6-MONTH SAVINGS 12.532 CERTIFICATES * * Maximum rate payable by savings institutions. Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball

title: Rubik's Cube Trade Dispute
description: A company claiming exclusive United States sales rights to the popular Rubik's cube today accused 96 other companies around the world of violating its rights.

title: Britain Contends Soviet Jams BBC's Broadcasts to Poland
description: The British Government told Ambassador Viktor I. Popov of the Soviet Union today that it ''strongly deplores'' the Soviet jamming of Polish-language broadcasts of the British Broadcasting Corporation and asked that the jamming stop at once.

title: WILLIAM CLANCY, 59, JOURNALIST
description: The Rev. William Clancy, a Roman Catholic priest and journalist who founded Worldview magazine and wrote for other New York-based publications, died yesterday in Pittsburgh after a long illness. He was 59 years old.

title: HELPING YOUNG STUDENTS AVOID DRUGS
description: Counselors at Phoenix House, who conduct drug-abuse prevention courses for more than 5,000 students a month, say the level of drug use in New York State seems to be about the same in public, private, parochial and preparatory schools. In all of these schools, they say, some students begin using drugs in the seventh grade and, in some cases, even earlier.

title: RECITAL: KIHWA JIN, SOPRANO, S
description: THE New York recital debut of Kihwa Jin, a Korean-born soprano, Monday night at the Merkin Concert Hall asked a lot of the accompanist, Raymond Beegle, whose piano had to masquerade as the orchestra of Richard Strauss's ''Four Last Songs,'' Berlioz's ''Les nuits d'ete,'' Korngold's ''Die tote Stadt'' and Puccini's ''La Rondine.''

title: PROSECUTOR CALLS DATA CONSISTENT IN 'ANGEL' DEATH
description: The law enforcement official investigating the killing of a member of the Guardian Angels by a police officer here said today that autopsy reports and ballistics tests appeared to uphold the police version of the incident.

title: Around the World; Dublin Car Bomb Injures Irish Forensic Expert
description: Dr. James Donovan, Ireland's top police scientist and a witness against I.R.A. guerrillas, was seriously injured today when a booby-trap bomb exploded in his car, the police said.

title: MOVIE SYSTEMS (CO) reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
SOME ADVICE ON BUYING EGGS
description: A spokesman for the New York State Department of Health advised people yesterday to buy fresh eggs without cracks to avoid salmonellosis.

title: COPPOLA SETS UP PREVIEW, DOESN'T TELL PARAMOUNT
description: In an unprecedented and unexpected move, Francis Coppola will preview his new film, ''One From the Heart,'' on Friday, Jan. 15, at Radio City Music Hall, without having consulted or even notified Paramount Pictures, the film's distributor.

title: SCHOOLBOY PLAYER WINS $1.5 MILLION FOR INJURY
description: The Texas Supreme Court ordered the Rawlings Sportings Goods Company today to pay $1.5 million in damages to a former high school football player injured in a collision with another player.

title: Advertising; How 1981 Changed Ad World
description: FREQUENTLY a sign of stress in an industry is the number of companies that switch ad agencies. That was certainly the case with the airlines last year. Seven major carriers found new homes for their advertising accounts.

title: Books of the Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt ON LEARNING TO READ. The Child's Fascination With Meaning. By Bruno Bettelheim and Karen Zelan. 306 pages. Knopf. $13.95.

title: STUDIO GLASS ARTIST TO EXHIBIT IN SOHO
description: As early as 1957, Harvey K. Littleton became interested in the possibilities of glass as a medium for the artist who worked alone at a small furnace. But the birth of what is now called the studio glass movement probably did not occur until March 1962, at a glass seminarworkshop on the grounds of the Toledo (Ohio) Museum of Art.

title: Duke Defeats Rutgers, 80-61
description: Vince Taylor scored 26 points, and Chip Engelland added 13 to lead Duke to an 80-61 victory over Rutgers tonight. Taylor, a guard, had 16 points in the second half.

title: Escalera Heads Card
description: Alfredo Escalera, the former World Boxing Council junior lightweight champion, will headline the first boxing card of the year at the Felt Forum Jan. 22. He will meet Angel Cruz in a scheduled 10-rounder.

title: McDonnell Order
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation said that its Douglas Aircraft Company subsidiary had been awarded a $195.1 million contract by the Air Force for production of four KC-10 aircraft. The planes, the military version of the DC-10 jetliner, are used for aerial refueling.

title: Gardening; PLANTS THAT GIVE A BIT OF WINTER COLOR
description: IT is easy to ignore the winter garden since it is usually rather drab, largely, no doubt, because most planting takes place when gardeners are concentrating on spring and summer blooms. A hint of hue is especially appreciated in winter, so gather planting ideas now for a more cheerful scene next year.

title: Data Access Shifts Executives Again
description: The revolving door for top management at Data Access Systems Inc. spun again yesterday as Robert M. Franklin, president and chief executive officer since Oct. 9, resigned both positions. Frank J. Lockwood, an investment banker who had been a director and part-time vice chairman, was elected chief executive officer of the Blackwood, N.J., computer terminal system distribution company, and Howard B. Chrystal, the chief operating officer and executive vice president, was promoted from the latter post to the presidency.

title: Oil Find Off Yugoslavia
description: A consortium that includes two American companies has struck oil off Yugolavia's southern Adriatic coast, the Belgrade newspaper Politika reported today.

title: THE AGONY OF WRITING A MESSAGE
description: The State of the State Message Governor Carey delivered today was the result of a process that began last June and was not completed until a few hours before he spoke.

title: Home Improvement
description: MADE of tough, break-resistant plastic and rustproof aluminum, Multi-Tote is an all-purpose heavy-duty carryall that makes it easy for the handyman, gardener or hobbyist to carry tools or supplies inside or outside the house.
