title: STAGE: PUPPETEER AS 'FRANKIE AND JOHNNIE'
description: WINSTON TONG is an artist as illusionist, performing sleight-ofhand feats with his face, body, fingers and theatrical imagination. He is, first of all, a puppeteer, and that remains his primary talent even as he moves further into the use of film as a stage technique and, with less justification, into acting. Both of these aspects are prevalent, almost dominant, in his new show at La Mama Annex, ''Frankie and Johnnie.'' But the evening is at its most hypnotic in moments of puppetry.

title: Bill Crawford, 68, Dies; Led Cartoonists' Group
description: Bill Crawford, a newspaper editorial cartoonist and recipient in 1973 of the Silver T-Square Award of the National Cartoonists Society, died of pneumonia yesterday at the George Washington University Hospital in Washington.

title: A PRESIDENTIAL ADDRESS SPECIALLY FOR CHRISTIANS
description: To the Editor:

title: COAST TEAMS DIG FOR STORM VICTIMS
description: Work crews fought through tangled mud and trees south of San Francisco today to reach buried houses possibly containing more victims of a fierce storm that struck on Monday and Tuesday.

title: Advertising; Ad Workshop Pair Form an Agency
description: Phil Franznick and J. Kathleen Cusatis, who have been running the Advertising Workshop since 1971, have now established an ad agency called Franznick & Cusatis at 246 Fifth Avenue. They will continue running the Workshop.

title: Notes on People; Cadillacs and the Bronx
description: If Richard D. Gidron has his way, business in the Bronx will soon be so good that the market for Cadillacs will skyrocket. Mr. Gidron, the new president of the Bronx Chamber of Commerce, has a special motive. He is a local Cadillac dealer, and when business in the Bronx booms, so does his.

title: INSULATING WINDOWS ON THE INSIDE
description: This article was prepared by John Rothchild and Daniel Yergin, the authors of ''Stop Burning Your Money: The Intelligent Homeowner's Guide to Household Energy Savings'' (Random House), and was written by Mr. Rothchild. Mr. Rothchild has been a co nsultant to the Federal Department of Energy. Dr. Yergin is a lecture r at Harvard University's Energy and Environmental Policy Center.

title: Abroad at Home; WHO LOST POLAND?
description: If Jimmy Carter were President now, he would surely be under savage attack from the right on the Polish question. That would be so, in fact, if just about any Democrat were in the White House. The critics would be blaming him for failing to prevent the disaster in Poland.

title: British Oil Output Up
description: Britain's petroleum production in the three months ended Nov. 30, 1981, rose 14.6 percent from the comparable period of 1980, to 22.9 million tons, the Department of Energy said today. Cumulative petroleum production through November was 81.4 million tons, or 11.5 percent more than in the first 11 months of 1980, the department said.

title: AM International In Austerity Plan
description: AM International Inc. said today that it would reduce its worldwide work force by 5 percent and cut the wages of its employees in the United States by 8 percent as it attempts to cope with the recession and high interest rates.

title: BATON BROADCASTING INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-Includes $3,582,000 gain from the sale of Maclean-Hunter shares

title: ANDERSON 2000 INC reports earnings for Yr to Sept 30
TESTIMONY BEGINS IN ATLANTA TRIAL OF MAN ACCUSED OF TWO MURDERS
description: The prosecutor likened the cases to a ''jigsaw puzzle with a whole lot of little pieces fitting in,'' and the defense attor ney insisted, ''You don't get a killer from a boy who was raised li ke this boy was.''

title: Swiss Banks' Disclosure
description: Swiss banks, starting today, are required to give the public a clearer picture of their operations. The new rule follows controversy over a major bank's losses in silver trading.

title: Kean Will Open All Parkway Lanes
description: NEWARK (AP) - Governor-elect Thomas H. Kean will open the Garden State Parkway's restricted lanes to all motorists shortly after he takes office Jan. 19, a spokesman said.

title: SOUTH AFRICAN WOMAN 'BANNED' BUT UNBOWED
description: The police station on the main street of this small farming town in the Orange Free State has two entrances, one marked ''white'' and the other ''nonwhite.'' Winnie Mandela, wife of the imprisoned leader of the banned African National Conference, went through the one marked ''white'' today when she reported for the first time under a new order that banishes and confines her to Brandfort for another five years.

title: Phelps Dodge
description: Moody's Investors Service Inc. said it had cut the bond ra ting of the Phelps Do dge Corporation, a major copper producer, to Baa from A because the c ompany's profit margins, cash flow and fixed charge coverage were currently at cyclically depressed levels.

title: WICHITA QUIET ON INQUIRY
description: After Wichita State's 11th victory of the season was complete last night, Coach Gene Smithson walked down the long corridor from his team's dressing room to answer questions that had little to do with basketball, and everything to do with his team's future.

title: Required Reading
description: Big Government

title: THE FRONT STOOP MAKES A COMEBACK
description: ''YOU could see the grin on the corners of his mouth,'' said Mark Ahasic of Park Slope, Brooklyn, speaking of h ow John Markasie reactedwhen Mr. Ahasic hired him to replace the stoo p on his brownstone. Mr.Markasie, it seems, was the contractor who ha d torn down Mr. Ahasic'sstoop in the first place, several decades ago .

title: CABARET: BARBARA MCNAIR
description: BARBARA McNAIR, who is singing at Marty's, Third Avenue at 73d Street, through next week, has so much potential that one is constantly surprised that she does not come into focus as a performer.

title: DRUG REHNQUIST USED CARRIES STRICT WARNING
description: The drug taken by Associate Justice William H. Rehnquist to help him sleep while afflicted with back pain is Placidyl, a prescription hypnotic recommended by its manufacturer for short periods only.

title: Briefing
description: J OSEPH WALSH, the Democratic mayor of Warwick, R.I., says he doesn't mind the White House snub. ''I didn't know anybody in the White House had even heard of me,'' the Mayor said after hearing that President Reagan's aides had rejected him as a speaker at a February conference sponsored by the American Association of Retired Persons and the Office of Consumer Affairs, which answers to the White House.

title: THE WEATHER IS LIKE TAXES
description: While climatologists concentrate on variability in the weather, on unpredictable storms, on surprising frosts and scorching droughts and on the world trends that exacerbate these problems, there are places on the earth where sameness and predictability are the order of the day, almost every day.

title: A DAVID IN OFFICE MACHINES
description: In 1969, a group of engineers deserted I.B.M.'s manufacturing facility here to form the Storage Technology Corporation, now a leading manufacturer of computer tape storage systems.

title: SOURCES FOR WINDOW THERMAL PROTECTION
description: Be accurate where dimensions are called for in ordering. Prices are representative. R-values (resistance to heat loss) vary for each product; consult the manufacturers. Window Quilts WindowBlanket Company, 107 Kings- ton Street, Lenoir City, Tenn. 37771, 615-986-2115.

title: Advertising; Chevy Dealers Switch To Smith/Greenland
description: Smith/Greenland, a 23-year-old agency that has not had an automotive account since its Triumph ads in the 1960's, is breaking its streak with the help of Chevrolet.

title: REAGAN'S AIDES BACK INCREASES IN SOME TAXES
description: President Reagan's eco nomic advisers have reached a consensus that he seek increases in ''consumption taxes,'' including those on alcohol, tobacco and gasol ine, as part of a strategy to shrink budget deficits in the nex t few years well below $100 billion, Administration officials report ed today.

title: 'CONGRATULATING A TRAGEDY'
description: To the Editor:

title: HOYAS TROUNCE ST.
description: A basketball game that helped attract a capacity crowd to Madison Square Garden to see an interesting confrontation turned into a rare, stunning exhibition of power and skill last night.

title: Around the Nation; Lawyer Enters Plea On Bribery Charges
description: William A. Borders Jr., a Washington lawyer, pleaded not guilty today to bribery conspiracy charges in a case related to an indictment against a Federal district judge.

title: 2 CONVICTED IN '72 KIDNAPPING OF 7-YEAR-OLD CALIFORNIA BOY
description: Kenneth Parnell, accused of kidnapping 7-year-old Steven Stayner in 1972, was convicted today of abducting the youth who lived with him seven years.

title: No Headline
description: 1981 U.S. AUTO SALES FELL 5.3%

title: MASSACHUSETTS TO GET BIGGEST TRASH-TO-ELECTRICITY PLANT IN U.S.
description: The Commonwealth Electric Company announced plans today to build a $124 million plant that will convert garbage to electricity, the largest such facility in the country to be privately financed.

title: Market Place; The Restrictive Merger Option
description: IF you can't have the well - poison the water. Until two weeks ago, that philosophy repeatedly found expression in restrictive options offered by managements to merger partners of their choice.

title: Home Beat; 'NEW WAVE' PILLOWS
description: HE'S an actor, she's a painter; they both wanted to raise money for a play he was producing.

title: Helpful Hardware; COMPACT WORK SPACES
description: WE have found three work surfaces, each having an unusual feature that makes it particularly useful for smaller spaces. One work surface is a foldaway butcher-block table that is great for small kitchens.

title: F.C.C. SHIFTS VOTE ON RADIO SIGNALS
description: An unexpected decision by the Federal Communications Commission authorizes a top staff official to order the shutdown of electronic news cameras and other equipment if they cause radio i nterference that threatens ''the safety of life or protection of property.''

title: PATRICIA HEARST DROPS ATTEMPT TO WIN NEW TRIAL
description: Patricia Hearst, who was convicted of bank robbery in 1976, today dropped her attempt to win a new trial. Miss Hearst, 26 years old, had been seeking to show that her conviction resulted from an inadequate defens e by F. Lee Bailey and J. Albert Johnson, the Boston lawyers.

title: Q & A
description: Q. I have an antique oak chest that was originally finished with shellac. The shellac was stripped off years ago and the piece was refinished with Minwax oak stain. Over this we applied a finish of the same company's antique oil finish. Recently a white water stain has appeared and I am trying to figure out the best way to treat it. Can I just apply more of the same stain and then put on more of the same oil finish? - M.K., Chestnut Hill, Mass.

title: G.O.P. LEADERS DECLINE REGAN ENDORSEMENT NOW
description: The Republican Party declined today to follo w its state leader and give an early endorsement fo r Governor to State Comptroller Edward V. Regan.

title: MIDEAST POLICY
description: There is a clear line of policy to be pursued by the United S tates in the Middle East - a line that has been reaffirmed by P resident Reagan and the Congress, that is contained in the Camp D avid accords of 1978, in United Nations Resolutions 242 and 338, u pon which the accords are structured, and in the Egypt-Israel peace t reaty, by which the accords are being implemented.

title: DANCE: RIVERSIDE FESTIVAL HOLDS A 'FAMILY' GALA
description: THE Riverside Dance Festival gave itself a gala Tuesday night at the Theater of the Riverside Church and made it a family affair. The mix of premieres, classics and works-in-between were drawn primarily from modern dance but also included ballet and ethnic dance. The choreographers and dancers had all been represented in the festival since it began in 1975.

title: CITY IS TERMED YOUTH JOBLESS 'CAPITAL'
description: The job market for young people is ''substantially worse'' in New York City than in other sections of the country, according to a report released yesterday.

title: SOVIET ACCUSES SCHMIDT AND U.S. OF INTERFERENCE
description: The Soviet Union, reacting to the strongly critical wording of a communique issued in Washington Tuesday by Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany and President Reagan, said in a press commentary today that Mr. Schmidt had joined the President in a bid to dictate the Polish Government's domestic policies.

title: Business World; Primark Corporation Elects First Chairman
description: Robert W. Stewart, 57, has been elected chairman and chief executive officer of the Primark Corporation, a newly formed holding company in the gas distribution business in Michigan. Succeeding him as president and chief operating officer of the Michigan Consolidated Gas Company, Primark's only subsidiary, is Harold J. Mellen Jr., 47.

title: Judge Cited Again On Bribery Charge
description: TRENTON (UPI) - A Camden County Superior Court judge, Peter J. Coruzzi, who was suspended last year after being indicted on a bribery charge, was indicted Wednesday on new charges of taking a bribe in return for releasing an inmate from prison.

title: Market Off on Higher Volume
description: Stock prices continued to retreat yesterday amid renewed fears of higher interest rates, but the market recovered part of its lost ground late in the session. Meanwhile, trading volume accelerated.

title:
News Of Music;
CITIBANK SENDING PHILHARMONIC TO SOUTH AMERICA
description: FOR the first time in 24 years, the New York Philharmonic will make a major tour of South America, playing 15 concerts in seven cities between Aug. 21 and Sept. 9. The tour is being underwritten by Citibank, which yesterday announced its entry into a five-year agreement with the Philharmonic that will give it the option to underwrite the orchestra's international touring on a steady basis.

title: Gas Investment In U.S. Revised
description: The American Gas Association now expects the United States gas utility industry to require total capital investment of $482 billion between 1982 and 2000, an industry spokesman said in New York yesterday.

title: The Fluoridation Plot
description: One of the movies' most memorable madmen, the Communist-hating general in ''Dr. Strangelove,'' described fluoridating water as ''a Red conspiracy ... to pollute our precious body fluids.'' But for every five moviegoers who laughed, another nodded knowingly.

title: Going Out Guide
description: MAKING THE 'SCENE'

title: 2 LAWS CONCERNING THE NATIONAL SECURITY ADVISER
description: There are two iron laws that govern relations between the White House, on t he one hand, and the State Department and the Defen se Department, on the other.

title: KOCH SAYS CAREY 'SET HIS SIGHTS TOO LOW' ON MEDICAID
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that Governor Carey had ''retreated'' and ''set his sights too low'' by proposing less than a full state takeover of local Medicaid costs in his State of the State Message.

title: Essay; CHANGING OF THE GUARD
description: After being exonerated by the Justice Department and declared clean as a hound's tooth by the White House counsel, longtime Reagan loyalist Richard Allen was asked to step down as national security adviser. The reason given him was that he would continue to be a target for the press and the House Democrats.

title: WINNEBAGO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 28
description: B-Includes $1,064,000 tax credit

title: Rolls-Royce Exports
description: Rolls-Royce Motors Holdings, a subsidiary of Vickers Ltd., predicted today that exports of Rolls-Royce and Bentley cars would total $180 million this year, up from $146 million in 1981.

title: FILM GROUPS' PROTEST IGNORED
description: A protest by American film organizations against what they say is the detention in Poland of Andrzej Wajda, the film director, has gone unanswered by the Polish Governemnt. His latest film, ''Man of Iron,'' has been nominated for an Academy Award.

title: NANTUCKET INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 5
description: Results adjusted for 33% stock dividend paid Sept 1980 and 15% stock dividend paid May 1981

title: More Belgians Idle
description: Unemployment in Bel gium reached a record of424,000, or 10.2 percent of the labor force, on Dec. 31, the Government reported today. It has predicted a further rise to 450,000in January.

title: Shelter Resources Expects Big Loss
description: The Shelter Resources Corporation, an Ohio-based mobile home and consumer products concern, said that it is in violation of the net worth covenant of its revolving bank loan agreement and expects a ''larger than anticipated'' loss in the fourth quarter.

title: PARENTAL DECISION: HIRING A TUTOR
description: JOEY spends no discernible time on his studies, but he always gets the kind of high marks that inspire his teachers to say, ''What a shame he doesn't work up to his potential.''

title: GRIFFIN'S DAYS OF GLORY ARE FADING INTO MEMORIES
description: Nearing the end of a season that could be his last in pro football, and in the midst of personal bankruptcy proceedings, Archie Griffin remembered a bittersweet moment.

title: RESEARCH ON SEX DIFFERENCES SEEN AS A KEY TO LONGER LIFE
description: There has been ''shockingly little'' research on biological differences between men and women that might help both sexes lead longer and better lives, a medical scientist said here today. Dr. Estelle R. Ramey, a professor of physiology and biophysics at Ge orgetown University's medical school, said more study of hormonal an d other biochemical characteristics of men and women might make it po ssible to lengthen the lives of men by reducing the toll of heart at tacks.

title: GOVERNOR PROPOSES A STATE-FINANCED FORCE TO RID THE SUBWAYS OF HABITUAL CRIMINALS
description: An anticrime program that would include a statefinanced strike force to search out habitual criminals in New York City's subways was proposed today by Governor Carey.

title: Advertising; Barnum Opens New Unit
description: Barnum Communications, which some time ago started moving beyond its original health-care-agency status, has established a new subsidiary called Barnum/Secunda Associates, which will do corporate advertising and public relations.

title: U.S. CARDINAL SAYS WARSAW INCITES ANTI-SEMITISM
description: John Cardinal Krol, Archbishop of Philadelphia, and a high official of the American Jewish Committee accused the military Government of Poland today of attempts to foment anti-Semitism among the Polish people.

title: Advertising; People
description: * Jerry Sherman, Stuart Epstein and Murray Gaylord have been elected senior vice presidents at Scali, McCabe, Sloves Inc.

title: Around the Nation; Prison Searched for Clues On Gambling Operation
description: More than 200 state troopers swept through Framingham State Prison early today in a search for evidence of a gambling operation and narcotics ring.

title: Laughlin to Be Honored For Role as Publisher
description: James A. Laughlin, poet and publisher of New Directions, will be the guest of honor at a celebration of his role in bringing out works of literature and poetry. The event will be held at 8 P.M. on Jan. 13 at B. Dalton in Greenwich Village, 396 Avenue of the Americas.

title: A.T.&T. TO LAY OFF 1,200 AT PLANT IN INDIANAPOLIS
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company, which has a reputation for job security, announced yesterday that it was laying off 1,200 employees, or about 21 percent of the hourly work force, at an assembly plant in Indianapolis.

title: BARN-THEATER AT WOLF TRAP
description: A new theater made up of two pre-Revolutionary War barns from upstate New York, dismantled, carted several hundred miles south and reassembled in nearby Vienna, Va., was dedicated last night as part of the Wolf Trap performing arts complex.

title: No Headline
description: 10TH IN ROW FOR NORTH CAROLINA

title: Once More the Yalta Myth
description: West Germany's Chancellor Schmidt says he would find it difficult to apply sanctions over Poland because in 1945 the West agreed at Yalta to yield Eastern Europe to a Soviet sphere of influence. Did it really?

title: Anne Smith Conquers Tracy Austin
description: Anne Smith of the United States upset top-seeded Tracy Austin tonight, 6-3, 6-1, to advance to the quarterfinals of the $200,000 Avon tennis championships of Washington.

title: OWNER SAYS BULLETIN IN PHILADELPHIA IS UP FOR SALE
description: The Bulletin in Philadelphia is for sale, its owner announced yesterday, and the publisher said that recent financial results ''do not augur well for the future.''

title: G.& W. Stakes
description: Gulf and Western Industries said it had increased its stake in the Brunswick Corporation to 3,152,620 shares, or 15.43 percent, through the acquisition of 248,000 shares bought between Oct.7 and Dec.24 on the New York Stock Exchange. In a separate filing, the company said it had also increased its stake in the Libbey-Owens-Ford Company to 2,645,300 shares, or 23.84 percent. In its S.E.C. filings, G.& W. said that both purchases were for investment purposes.

title: DUTTON OF COWBOYS AILING
description: John Dutton, defensive tackle of the Dallas Cowboys, awoke shortly before dawn today with a sharp pain in his right thigh and could barely walk. Doctors diagnosed the injury as a contusion and a broken blood vessel but said Dutton would probably play in the National Conference championship game against San Francisco Sunday.

title: 8 Drown Near Aleutians
description: A Japanese fishing vessel capsized in the Bering Sea near the Aleutian Islands, leaving at least eight fishermen dead, company officials said today. Twenty-four crew members were still missing Wednesday after a daylong search, the Nichiro Gyogyo Company, a major Japanese fishery, reported.

title: GOV. RHODES OF OHIO RULES OUT CHALLENGE FOR U.S. SENATE SEAT
description: Saying he wanted to spend more time with hisfamily, Ohio' s 72-year-old Governor, James A. Rhodes, a Republican, today ruled o ut a race against Senator Howard M. Metzenbaum, a liberal Democ rat who is completing his first term.

title: Texasgulf Sale
description: The Canada Development Corporation said it had completed the $1.85 billion (United States) acquisition of Texasgulf Inc.'s Canadian mining and minerals operations. As previously reported, C.D.C. swapped its 35 percent interest in Texasgulf plus $521 million in cash to acquire the Canadian assets, which inclu de the huge Kidd Creek mine in northern Ontario. The agreement was part of an agreement under which Societe Nationale Elf A quitaine of France acquired the non-Canadian assets of Texasgulf in mid-1981.

title: WALGREEN CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
BROOKS FASHION STORES INC reports earnings for 13 weeks to Nov 28
SCM Assails Import Prices
description: Smith-Corona, the only maker of portable electric typewriters in the United States, today asked the Government for help against Japanese competitors' pricing practices.

title: Pay More to Pay Less for Health
description: Richard Schweiker's remedy for swollen medical costs may be unpleasant, but at least it is evenhanded and perhaps essential.

title: STATEX PETROLEUM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
BRIEFING
description: S OMEONE has cracked the Crayola Code at the Environmental Protection Agency. There has been a mysterious rating system by which E.P.A. administrators secret their talent evaluations by putting different colored dots on lists of names of members of the Senior Executive Service. This is the top level of managerial bureaucrats that each new administration inherits, sight unseen.

title: No Headline
description: The Dallas Cowboys said today that John Dutton's status for the National Conference championship game at San Francisco Sunday had been reduced from probable, meaning he had a 75 percent chance of playing, to questionable, meaning his chances were only 50-50.

title: THE WORLDS MOST PRODUCTIVE TEXTILE MILLS
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Children Killed
description: Two small children died when they panicked while an uncle was trying to rescue them from their burning apartment in a five-story brick building at 643 Wales Avenue in the South Bronx.

title: Bridge: New Book on Conventions Covers a V ariety of Topics
description: An enthusiast who wanted to build a small library of essential bridge books would need about a dozen works. One of them would be ''Modern Bridge Conventions'' by William Root and Richard Pavlicek, recently published by Crown. The list price is $15.95, but it can be obtained for $12.95 from Bridge World, at 39 West 94th Street, New York, N.Y. 10025.

title: REAGAN SPUR RED BY POLISH CRISIS , AGAIN CONSIDERS BREZHNEV TALKS
description: State Department officials said today that the Polish crisis had prompted new consideration within the Administration of a possible meeting between President Reagan and Leonid I. Brezhnev.

title: Restaurants; East Side Italian, Broadway seafood.
description: IF the food is Italian, it must be 58th Street. The block between Second and Third Avenues now has 10 Italian restaurants, including the newest, Anche Vivolo. ''Anche'' means ''also'' in Italian and Vivolo is the name of the parent restaurant, which has been a successful neighborhood hangout on East 74th Street for the last four years.

title: Pop Jazz; CECIL TAYLOR GROUP AT NEW VILLAGE CLUB
description: ''MUSIC is supposed to make people change,'' Cecil Taylor remarked this week at a rehearsal of his quartet for their appearance at the new Greenwich Village jazz club Lush Life tonight through Su nday. ''When you da nce, you change. When you sing, you change. The musicians I h ave most admired just kept developing, evolving, expanding, an d it seems to me that this is what makes the difference between music ians who are simply professional, musicians who are verygood and musi cians who are great. There aren't very many great musicians, or great anythings, but there are a few of those people around.''

title: PIANO: DIANE WALSH'S MOZART
description: MOZART'S piano music is so transparent and deceptively simple that it requires rare qualities of mind and finger to allow its profundity to emerge. Diane Walsh may not have honed her faculties to that rarefied state, but after the intermission of her all-Mozart program at the Merkin Concert Hall on Wednesday night, she was able to communicate something of that Mozartean grace that rests just on the edge of sorrow.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: T HE week after New Year's is considered by many social cognoscenti to be the deadliest time of the year to throw a party. Allegedly, people are at home resting, dieting and recovering from their hangovers. Allegedly.

title: News Analysis
description: For a year now, top executives of the two largest American automobile companies have been hammering away at the United Automobile Workers, arguing that high labor costs are pushing the price of cars made in this country too high to compete with those imported from Japan.

title: ENERGY METHODS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes a tax credit of $60,000...C-Net loss

title: UNITED STATES ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Yr to Sept 30
description: B-Net loss; the 1981 revs include $612,976 representation of recognition of deferred income as a result of its settlement of the Washtenaw Energy Corp litigation

title: U.S. LEGAL OFFICIALS DIVIDE ON EQUAL RIGHTS APPEAL
description: Disagreements have developed in the Reagan Administration over what position to take in appealing the politically sensitive case of the proposed Federal equal rights amendment to the Supreme Court, Justice Department sources said today.

title: Dr. Stuart H.Q. Quan Weds Victoria Adams
description: Victoria Adams, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lane W. Adams of New York and New Canaan, Conn., and Dr. Stuart H.Q. Quan of New York were married yesterday. The Rev. John Andrew, rector of the St. Thomas Episcopal Church, performed the ceremony at the Church Center for the United Nations.

title: CHEMPLAST INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Somali Leader Invited to U.S.
description: President Reagan has invited President Mohammed Siad Barre of Somalia to visit Washington on March 11, the White House announced today.

title: MR BAKER'S PHOTOGRAPHIC MIND
description: Several years ago, when President Ford was visiting Tennessee, Secret Service agents sighted a bantam-size man with cameras dangling around his neck following Mr. Ford into a Knoxville hotel. The agents, thinking a news photographer had strayed into the procession, took the man by the arm and escorted him to a roped-off press area.

title: WARDS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-Net is after nonrecurring tax benefit of $470,000

title: THE REGION
description: Governor Byrne signed a bill authorizing the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey to spend up to $100 million from its reserves on mass-transportation improvements in New Jersey. A similar bill making a like amount available for New York has already been passed and signed by Governor Carey.

title: Stocks Mixed; Trading Slow
description: The stock market finished mixed in slower trading yesterday as growing fears of higher interest rates kept many investors on the sidelines.

title: Mouths to Feed
description: Pregnant Women, Children ...

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: HOW TO PAY OUT $3.75 BILLION
description: At 12:01 A.M. yesterday, exactly one minute after the United States Steel Corporation was free to buy the Marathon Oil Company, a U.S. Steel executive in Pittsburgh phoned a Bankers Trust official in Manhattan and told him to proceed ''forthwith'' to pay out $3.75 billion to Marathon stockholders for 30 million shares.

title: Gas-Powered Ford Vehicle
description: The Ford Motor Company introduced a twopassenger car that burns natural gas and can be refueled at home. There are no plans to produce the car.

title: SCIENTISTS WARNED OF U.S. CURBS
description: The deputy director of the Central Intelligence Agency warned scientists today that they face legal restraints unless they agree voluntarily to measures to prevent the loss of militarily sensitive technology to the Soviet Union.

title: Wage Freeze At Eastern Air
description: Most of the 18,500 nonunion employees of Eastern Airlines have agreed to a one-year wage freeze to help the carrier through the year, according to Frank Borman, chairman and president of Eastern.

title: POLISH AIRWAVES: UNION'S PLAN ON 'CONFRONTATION'
description: Following are excerpts from domestic Polish radio and television broadcasts as transcribed and translated from the Polish and the Russian by the Foreign Broadcast Information Special to the New York Times Service, a United States Government agency:

title: Amex Loses Futures Suit
description: The American Stock Exchange Inc. yesterday lost a court bid to block enforcement of new regulations adopted by the Commodity Futures Trading Commission as part of a program for trading of options on commodity futures contracts.

title: SENSORMATIC ELECTRONICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: The 1980 revs figures were restated

title: HOW RICHARD ALLEN FINALLY WAS FORCED TO RESIGN
description: There was a time, early in the Reagan Administration, when Richard V. Allen almost prided himself on his anonymity. He toiled quietly behind the White House gates, seldom emerging for talks with the press or for public app earances. It was as if he were skirting the spotlight that seemed to follow previous national secu rity advisers.

title: RANGERS DEFEAT CANUCKS
description: The Rangers scored twice on their usually weak power play and once wh en they were a man short last night at Madison Square Garden, and th e result was a 4-1 victory over the Vancouver Canucks.

title: SOVIET JOINS CZECHOSLOVAKIA AND HUNGARY FOR WAR GAMES
description: Soviet, Czechoslovak and Hungarian troops plan joint maneuvers in western Czechoslovakia this month, the Czechoslovak press agency reported today.

title: KEY HOUSING PROGRAM REVIVED IN CITY
description: New York City housing officials and a consortium of 13 city banks have established a $6 .5 million rehabilitation loan program to aid housing renov ation in 33 city neighborhoods. The program will combine $1.5 million in Federal funds with $5 million from the banks to provide re habilitation funds to qualified applicants at below-market interest rates.

title: PIONEER HI-BRED INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
MORGADO SEEKS INQUIRY ON 11% LOAN
description: Governor Carey's top aide, Robert J. Morgado, called on the State Attorney General yesterday to investigate whether his borrowing of $100,000 from a person doing business with the state violated ethical standards.

title: Business People; ACT III APPOINTS HEAD
description: Howard Rosenberger, 43, has been named president of Act III, a leading producer of women's sportswear sold in department and specialty stores, with estimated sales in 1981 of $60 million. He succeeds Willard Stotter, 62, who will become a senior corporate sales executive at Jonathan Logan Inc., Act III's parent company.

title: WATER SHORTAGES AND MUD THWART CALIFORNIA'S STORM CLEANUP EFFORT
description: Critical water shortages and thick mud thwarted rescue workers today as they struggled to unearth landslide victims and repair destruction from a storm that killed 24 persons and caused damage estimated at $200 million.

title: COURT BARS START OF NUCLEAR PLANT
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia ruled today that the undamaged reactor at the Three Mile Island nuclear plant in Pennsylvania could not be restarted until the Government assessed the possible effects on people and communities nearby.

title: Reliance Holders Vote to Go Private
description: Shareholders of the Reliance Group Inc. voted overwhelmingly yesterday to approve the offer by Saul P. Steinberg and his family to take the major, New York-based insurance holding company private. Earlier, a similar offer was approved by shareholders of the Leasco Corporation, a computer leasing concern.

title: METRO-GOLDWYN-MAYER FILM CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
MILLER, HERMAN, INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 28
description: The shr earnings figures restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in Oct 1981

title: A.H.L. Board to Study Abuse of Fans, Officials
description: Abuse of referees and spectators by American Hockey League players has grown to such an extent that the league's board of governors plans a special meeting later this month to deal with the problem, an official of the Binghamton Whalers said today.

title: Washington Opera Says Its Season Is Sold Out
description: The Washington Opera said on Wednesday that it was sold out for the balance of its 57-performance season and that it will have grossed $1.35 million when the final receipts are in.

title: U.S. COURT EASES JAIL RESTRICTIONS ON MISS BOUDIN
description: A Federal judge sharply criticized prison officials yesterday and ordered them to provide less restrictive conditions for Katherine Boudin. She has been held in virtual solitary confinement since her arrest Oct. 20 as a suspect in the Rockland County armored-car robbery in which a guard and two police officers were killed.

title: Mexico to Cut Oil Shipments
description: Mexico's state oil monopoly, Petroleos Mexicanos, said today that it would provide o nly 50 percent of the oil exports contracted for in January in orde r to make up for exportslost last month because of loading difficulti es and bad weather.

title: Art People; Louvre v. Cleveland.
description: THE raised cultural consciousness of foreign governments makes acquiring a work of art without an export permit from its country of origin a very delicate business these days. In the March issue of the Burlington Magazine, Sherman Lee, director of the Cleveland Museum of Art, will answer charges by two curators of the Louvre that his museum had bought a painting shipped out of France without an export license.

title: Ninth Trident Contract Let
description: The Navy announced today that it was awarding a $523.7 million contract to the Electric Boat Division of the General Dynamics Corporation to build the ninth nuclear-powered, missile-firing Trident submarine. The cost of the new vessel is expected to total at least $1.2 billion. The contract was awarded after the Navy and the company resolved differences over construction problems.

title: CORRECTION
description: A movie review of ''Opera Prima'' on Wednesday gave an incorrect age for the director, Fernando Trueba. He is 25 years old.

title: British Car Production
description: Auto production by British manufacturers rose to a provisional 75,000 units in December from 66,000 in November and 57,000 in December 1980, the Departme nt of Industry saidtoday.

title: No Headline
description: U.S. PANEL CRITICAL OF BABY WALKERS

title: APPLIED POWER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
KOCH LOSES RULING ON SCREENING 'TOWN MEETINGS'
description: A Federal judge has ruled that Mayor Koch has no automatic right to decide who may attend the ''town hall'' meetings that he holds periodically in New York City neighborhoods.

title: NURSING HOME SERVICES FACING FEDERAL REPEAL
description: As part of its effort to reduce Federal regulation of nursing homes, the Reagan Administration has tentatively decided to repeal a rule requiring a wide range of social and psychological services for patients.

title: James Seiler, Pioneer In Audience Measuring
description: James W. Seiler, a pioneer in the measurement of broadcast audiences, died of cancer Saturday at Montgomery General Hospital in Olney, Md. He was 65 years old and lived in Silver Spring, Md.

title: Angola Accuses Pretoria Of Stepping Up Raids
description: Angola accused S outh Africa today of attacking Cuban troops deep inside the countr y and of stepping up the conflict with long-range air raids.

title: Going Out Guide; Friday; UPPER EAST SIDE MOLIERE
description: A rich young farmer marries into an impoverished noble family and has a terrible time, frustrated in his attempts to prove his wife's suspected infidelity to his in-laws or to society. It happens in ''George Dandin, or the Jealous Husband,'' Moliere's dark comedy, which is at the Theater of the Open Eye, 216 East 88th Street. Robert Wesley Martin plays the title role, and Mark Epstein is the director. Performances tonight, tomorrow and Sunday and Jan. 12 through Jan. 17 at 8:30 P.M., Sunday at 2:30 P.M. Tickets: $6 ($4 for students and the elderly). Information: 534-6909. JUILLIARDS IN BROOKLYN

title: Canada's Trade Surplus
description: Canada's trade surplus rose to $1.12 billion (Canadian) in November from a revised $758 million surplus in October.

title: Oil and Chemical Union Extends Strike Deadline
description: Union officials today extended indefinitely a deadline for reaching new contracts that could otherwise have put about 55,000 workers on a nationwide strike at 12:01 A.M. Friday in the refinery, petrochemical and pipeline industries.

title: SHCHARANSKY BACK IN A SOVIET PRISON
description: Anatoly B. Shcharansky, the convicted dissident, has been sent back from labor camp to prison for three years for refusing to acknowledge his guilt, his mother reported today after returning from her first visit with her son in 16 months.

title: MOODY SUSPENDS RATING ON 2 NUCLEAR PROJECTS
description: Moody's Investors Services Inc. suspended the credit rating yesterday on two controversial West Coast nuclear power projects, a move that effectively shuts them out of the credit markets and brings the projects one step closer to being terminated.

title: SOVIET PAPER ACCUSES THE U.S. OF 'SORDID' ESPIONAGE
description: The Soviet Communist Party daily Pravda said today that the ''top U.S. leadership'' was directing a ''sordid'' espionage campaign against the Soviet Union. The paper named a man, apparently a Russian, who it said had been sentenced to death by firing squad as a spy for the United States.

title: VOLT INFORMATION SCIENCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
description: The shr earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in June 198

title: Notes on People; A Fitting Tribute
description: When plans were being made for New Jersey's new criminal-justice complex in Trenton, Richard J. Hughes lobbied to have the $93 million building named for Woodrow Wilson, who was Governor of New Jersey before becoming President.

title: MARRIOTT GINO'S BID BACKED BY BOARDS
description: The boards of directors of the Marriott Corporation and Gino's Inc. have approved Marriott's $48.6 million cash tender offer for all of Gino's common stock, the companies announced.

title: TRUDEAU PLANS MEXICO VISIT
description: On a state visit to Mexico City next week, Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau hopes to reinforce the political ties and booming trade between Canada and Mexico, Government officials said today. Mr. Trudeau will meet twice with President Jose Lopez Portillo between Jan. 13 and 16 to discuss what both countries see as a blooming "special relationship," the officials said.

title: EVENING WITH A LIVELY COMPOSER FROM SOVIET
description: Alfred Schnittke is a contemporary Soviet composer who is hardly known outside of his homeland. But like Coleridge's Ancient Mariner, once his voice is heard, it cannot be ignored. He fixes a listener with a glittering eye and holds him fast until he has had his say. There is no easy way out of the world he weaves.

title: Ward Is Quarantined For Hepatitis Outbreak
description: A 40-bed neurology ward at City Hospital Center in Queen's Elmhurst section was placed under quarantine yesterday after two doctors, three nurses, one patient and the mother of a patient were found to have contracted infectious hepatitis, according to a spokesman for the New York City Department of Health.

title: AID SET FOR POLES STRANDED BY CRISIS
description: Visiting Polish scholars and artists who are unable to return home because of the political crisis in their country will receive financial aid under a new emergency program set up by the Rockefeller Brothers Fund and the Rockefeller and Ford Foundations.

title: At the Movies; Reynolds's leading lady gets the raves.
description: WHEN is the last time the woman in a Burt Reynolds movie got the notices? It's happened to Rachel Ward, English born, 24 years old and a smash hit with the press. A reviewer who liked ''Sharky's Machine'' described Miss Ward's ''smoky voice, distinctive personality and face worth sonnets.'' Another reviewer , who didn't like ''Sharky's Machine,'' said, ''The only interesting thing about this tedious, contrived picture is an actress named Rachel Ward.''

title: TV Tapes of Prison Rio t Go to Idaho Prosecutor
description: Two cartons of a television station's videotapes of the 1980 Idaho penitentiary riot were turned over to a prosecutor today after a judge ordered their release.

title: LOUD OPPOSITION GREETS NEW PLAN FOR REDRAWING CITY COUNCIL DISTRICT LINES
description: The latest version of proposed district lines for the City Council encountered loud and long opposition yesterday as residents and groups from around the city joined numerous Council members in attacking the plan.

title: REAGAN, IN A SHIFT, PLANS TO CONTINUE SIGN-UP FOR DRAFT
description: President Reagan announced today that he had decided to continue registration of young men for a possible military draft.

title: ISRAELI CABINET APPROVES PAYMENT TO THE DISPLACED SETTLERS IN SINAI
description: The Israeli Cabinet voted narrowly today for a large package of financial compensation to Jewish settlers who will have to vacate their homes, farms and businesses when the final strip of Sinai is returned to Egypt next April.

title: AFTER SIX YEARS AT CITY BALLET, ADAM LUDERS IS REALLY SOARING
description: He's tall, fair haired and Danish, so by rights Adam Luders ought to be dancing some princely role this weekend at the New York State Theater, where the New York City Ballet has just returned to repertory after its yearly slew of performances of ''The Nutcracker.'' Instead, Mr. Luders, who has become one of the City Ballet's leading - and most interesting -male dancers, will be dancing with Karin von Aroldingen around an imaginary campfire in ''Hungarian Gypsy Airs,'' a ballet choreographed by George Balanchine for last year's Tchaikovsky Festival and seen in New York City only once. Tha t Mr. Luders is at the City Ballet at all, and dancin g with authority and elegance, is the result of a long and diffic ult battle with himself and his surroundings. He began taking class i n his native Copenhagen, entering the school of the Royal Danish Ballet in 1962, at 12, and graduated into the company four years lat er as an apprentice. His parents had not been happy about his choic e of career, and once he was in the Royal Danish Ballet, Mr. Lu ders felt adistinct lack of interest among the company teachers and b allet masters.

title: THE POLISH DEBT
description: While Western governments have reacted to the imposition of martial law in Poland by cutting aid, and the United States has announced economic sanctions against both Poland and the Soviet Union, the private international banking community has greeted the Polish Government crackdown with a collective sigh of relief.

title: FINANCIAL BRIEFS
description: * Dow Chemical Co. announced plans to issue bonds valued at about $140 million in Japan and Brazil. A Dow spokesman said the $90 million offering i n Japan would be the first major bond issue made inJapan by a fo reign industrial corporation.

title: Business People; PAYMENTS DEFENDED BY RALSTON PURINA
description: Three outsi de directors of the Ralston Purina Company received $100,000 each for their efforts in helping to find a new chief executive off icer, the corporation's proxy statement discloses. Yesterday, th e diversified foods, agricultural products and restaurant co mpany issued a statement defending the work of the board members and the unusual special payments to them.

title: No Headline
description: Spurs 123, Warriors 112

title: AT CO-OP CITY HOME BY DARK
description: From the terrace of her 30th-floor apartment in Co-op City, Josephine Williams looks out on the marshes of Pelham Bay Park and beyond that to City Island. In the summer, she said, there are water skiers on Eastchester Bay.

title: Redistricted Lawmaker To Oppose Rep. Heckler
description: Representative Barney Frank, Democrat of Massachusetts, who said last month that he was undecided about seeking reelection for a redistricted Congressional seat, announced today that he would run to create a referendum on President Reagan's domestic policies.

title: CHATTEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-After a loss from discontinued operations of $49,000 for the qr and net from discontinued operations of $4,000 for the 6 mos

title: OWNERS OF DAILY NEWS REPORT 'SERIOUS INQUIRES' ON ITS SALE
description: The owners of The Daily News said yesterday that they had recieved a number of "serious inquiries" from potential buyers.

title: MOSLEM-LEFTIST CLASH KILLS FIVE IN LEBANON
description: Rival militia groups battled through the day here with grenades, mortars and heavy machine guns, and police sources said that five people were killed and several were wounded.

title: LAWYER TERMS SHELTERS FOR WOMEN INADEQUATE
description: Just days after a State Supreme Court justice f ound that New York City's shelte r program for homeless men was acceptable for this winter, a vol unteer lawyer is in a dispute with the city over its plans for hom eless women.

title: GOLDEN ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: The shr earnings reflect 3-for-2 stock split paid in Oct

title: Westinghouse Pact
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation said it had signed a contract with the Egyptian Electricity Authority to supply three 315-megawatt turbine-generators for what will be Egypt's largest steam-driven electric power station near Cairo. Although Westinghouse did not disclose the amount of the contract, the Middle East Electronics Digest, published in London, has put the value at $82 million.

title: No Headline
description: OHIO STATE, IN AN UPSET DEFEATS MINNESOTA, 49-47

title: BANCO POPULAR DE PUERTO RICO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
4 Are Indicted in Slaying Of Arizona Mail Carrier
description: A Federal grand jury has indicted four persons on charges of murder, robbery and kidnapping in the stabbing death of a postal carrier on an Indian reservation, according to the United States Attorney here.

title: Advertising; Industrial Ad Spending Prospects Stir Concern
description: Consumer products companies may be doggedly increasing their advertising spending to keep up with media inflation in order to protect market shares, but such is not the case with industrial advertisers, according to an industrial agency man.

title: KINGS WIN, 107-103, END KNICKS' STREAK
description: The Knicks, who had a five-game winning streak, came here tonight to play the Kansas City Kings, a struggling and injured team that had lost three straight games. Both streaks ended.

title: C hina Vows to Oppose Arms Sales to Taiwan
description: In a sharp new public declaration that seemed to rule out compromise, China vowed today to ''oppose to the end'' United States arms sales to Taiwan.

title: Winning in Law, but Not in Life
description: William French Smith is taking a strangely narrow view of the Attorney General's duty to protect the Federal Government's interests in court.

title: 'THE NICEST MAN' PACKS IN HIS FANS
description: Adolfo fans rallied round the designer they tend to call ''the nicest man in the world.'' As they always do in early January and mid-July, more than 600 packed two presentations of his new collection at the St. Regis Hotel yesterday afternoon.

title: Telefunken Fined
description: The European Commission levied a fine of $1.08 million today against AEG-Telefunken, charging that the West German electronics concern had violated fair trade rules with a distribution system it used between 1976 and 1980. The commission issued a statement saying that the company used a discriminatory system to select distributors for its equipment, mostly television sets, resulting in higher prices and profits. The commission said the company replaced the ''selective'' system in 1981.

title: LESS RED TAPE CAN BE A BOON TO NURSING HOME AND PATIENTS
description: To the Editor:

title: ART: SONIA GECHTOFF AT HER BEST AT GRUENEBAUM
description: FOR certain artists, the resonances and ambiguities of visual memory, with its metaphorical transformation of things seen into visionary images, have come to play a crucial role in the development of their work. This has certainly been the case with the recent work of the American painter Sonia Gechtoff. Increasingly important for this artist, too, are the elusive and affectionate memories of certain modes of 19th-century landscape painting. Yet Miss Gechtoff, who made her artistic debut in the 1950's as an Abstract Expressionist, still brings an abstractionist's sense of form and structure to the very conception of her work. It is thus in the way memory and form, recollected emotion and rigorous technique are now combined in her work that gives it its special magic.

title: Coach Dismissed
description: Lambert Reed, the football coach of Morris Brown College, reported that he had been discharged by Robert Threatt, the president of the college.

title: Funds' Assets Rising Again
description: Assets of the nation's money market funds rose $1.9 billion in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday. The rise followed two consecutive weeks of seasonal, endof-the-year declines.

title: 2 DIFFERENT VIEWS OF CITY AND WHAT IT HAS TO OFFER
description: Josephine Williams and Michael Davido have been New Yorkers most of their lives, she for 40 years and he for 45. They have never met, but both have raised children and worked hard, she as a nurse and he as a painter.

title: SOME POLAR ICE MELTING LINKED TO GLOBAL HEATING
description: Because of global heating attributed to an increase in atmospheric carbon dioxide from fuel burning, about 20,000 cubic miles of polar ice has melted in the past 40 years, apparently contributing to a rise in sea levels, according to calculations by two scientists of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration.

title: RECESSION'S START PLACED AT JULY 1981
description: The National Bureau of Economic Research, the arbiter of the nation's business cycles, declared yesterday that the current recession began last July. It was the eighth recession pronounced by the organization since the end of World War II.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The continuation of peacetime registration does not foreshadow a return to the draft.'' - President Reagan. (A1:6.)

title: Broadway; Event that haunted Jung inspires play by Morris West.
description: IT was late in 1980. Morris L. West had just finished his latest best-seller, ''The Clowns of God,'' and his spirit was in a tailspin.''I was very empty, and was casting about for something completely different to do,'' the popular Australian-born novelist was saying the other day . ''So I decided to have a go at another play.'' The play, Mr. Wes t's first since his ''Daughter of Silence,'' which played 36 per formances on Broadway in 1961, is ''The World Is Made ofGlass.'' It w ill be directed by Jose Quintero, produced by Lester Osterman in a ssociation with his wife, Marjorie, and open on Broadwayin the spring .

title: A Prokofiev Night
description: A Prokofiev program will be presented by the New Orleans Philharmonic tomorrow at 8 P.M. at Carnegie Hall, Seventh Avenue and 57th Street.

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, JANUARY 8, 1982
description: International The Polish Primate spoke out against Government demands for Polish workers to sign loyalty oaths and den ounce th eir membership in Solidarity. The Primate, Archbishop Jozef Gle mp, termed the demands ''unethical'' and said that any such declarat ions signed under coercion were ''invalid.'' He was addressing 3,000 people at a mass in Warsaw. (Page A1, Column 2.) Indictments against Polish ex-leaders were announced on Warsaw television. Officials of both the Communist Party and Government as well as industrial managers were charged with using their positions for personal gain. At the same time, the Warsaw radio announced many sentences against violators of martial law, most involving strike actions. (A9:1-4.)

title: Sale at St. Bart's Held Up by Court
description: The Appellate Division of State Supreme Court issued an order barring any sale of the community house of St. Bartholomew's Church on Park Avenue at 50th Street pending its decision on an appeal by opponents of the sale.

title: ODE TO MARTHA
description: To the Editor:

title: TV Weekend; BUSY '82 START FOR PBS
description: PUBLIC television seems determined this month to unveil every new series and program the system has in the can. As a result, WNET-13 is unusually busy with new progamming material this weekend.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Can Company said it had agreed to acquire a 25 percent stake, or 1,754,320 shares, in the Associated Madison Companies, and will buy 69.3 percent, or 490,000 shares, of convertible preferred stock, for an aggregate price of $38.7 million.

title: Ruth Vollmer, Sculptor, 80; Designed Window Displays
description: Ruth Vollmer, an abstract sculptor who used mathematics to arrive at geometrical forms, died Jan. 1 it her home at 25 Central Park West. She was about 80 years old.

title: U.S. Tennis Doubles Team Fi ne d $1,000
description: The American tennis players Hank Pfister and Victor Amaya were fined $500 each today for abusive language at the World Doubles Championship - Amaya for calling the umpire a ''cheat'' and Pfister for shouting an obscenity at him.

title: Morris-Jumel Mansion Offers a Play and a Tour
description: Eliza Jumel, 19th-century mistress of the house now called the Morris-Jumel Mansion, is the subject of a play that will be given a dramatic reading by Arts Interaction on Sunday at 2 P.M. at the mansion, Edgecombe Avenue and West 160th Street. The play, by H.G. Merz, tells the rags-to-riches story of Mrs. Jumel, who after the death of her first husband, Stephen Jumel, married Aaron Burr,

title: UNIVERSITY PATENTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
11 of 33 in Roundup Of Slug Users Work In Government Jobs
description: Thirty-three persons were arrested on Wednesday for feeding slugs into subway turnstiles at a station near City Hall, and yesterday the Transit Authority police disclosed that 11 of them were employees of the city, state or Federal governments.

title: ELIZABETH FISHER
description: Elizabeth Fisher, a writer and editor who in 1969 founded Aphra, a former feminist literary magazine, died last Friday at her studio in Sag Harbor, L.I. Miss Fisher, who also had a residence in Manhattan, was 57 years old.

title: John Siddeley Is Dead; An Interior Decorator
description: John Siddeley, an interior decorator and chairman of John Siddeley International Ltd. of London, died of a heart attack in the New Jersey Medical Center in Neptune on Dec. 26. He was 57 years old and had recently moved to Little Silver, N.J.

title: GERMANS SEE A SPLIT IN U.S. OVER HANDLING POLISH CRISIS
description: Chancellor Helmut Schmidt believes that there are divisions within the Reagan Administration about how to deal with the situation in Poland and questions whether the United States has thought out its strategy for dealing with a possible worsening of the Polish problems.

title: U.S. MEMOS INDICATE CASEY DIDN'T REPORT ALL LOBBYING
description: William J. Casey, the Director of Central Intelligence, failed to tell a Senate committee the full extent of his lobbying on behalf of Indonesia in 1976, Government documents show.

title: DEFENSE PLANNING GONE AWRY
description: To the Editor:

title: THE 'SPHERES' OF YALTA
description: Suppression of the Polish people's attempt to wrest reform from their rulers has revived the myth of Yalta. Even the West German Chancellor, Helmut Schmidt, said recently that the West had agreed to divide Europe into spheres of influence in 1945, and any attempt to change the balance of power would mean war. France's President Mitterrand said in his New Year's message that it was time to consider ''getting out of Yalta.''

title: ISLANDERS BEAT FLYERS, 5-4, ON A LATE GOAL BY GILLIES
description: A goal by Clark Gillies with 13 seconds left gave the Islanders a 5-4 victory tonight over the Philadelphia Flyers at the Spectrum that kept New York in sole possession of first place in the Patrick Division.

title: FRIEND OF STA TESMEN
description: Lady Hartwell, known for her political salon and one of Britain's museum leaders, died yesterday in Westminster Hospital in London. She was 67 years old.

title: PHILADELPHIA MOB FIGURE SLAIN
description: Frank Narducci, a reputed leader of organized crime who was about to go on trial on Federal charges of loansharking and racketeering, was found shot to death today, the police said.

title: F.B.I. Operative Held in Car Theft
description: A man identified as a Federal Bureau of Investigation operative in a bungled sting operation in Bridgeport was charged here Thursday with stealing a motor vehicle, a state police spokesman said in Hartford.

title: MUSIC: PAIR OF PROKOFIEV CONCERTOS BY STERN
description: PROKOFIEV'S violin concertos have been pillars of Isaac Stern's exhaustive repertory for many years, and his recordings of both works are well known to his admirers. But the Russian composer somehow found time to write only two such works, which showed a certain lack of consideration for violinists.

title: CITY STORES MAY SELL A CHAIN
description: Talks are under way for a sale of the Maison Blanche Company of New Orleans, one of the South's oldest and largest department store chains, to Goudchaux's Inc., a Baton Rouge, La., retailer.

title: OHIO-SEALY MATTRESS MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
SPORTS PEOPLE
description: A Tale of Two Taylors Billy Taylor, the 25-year-old running back who spent this season as a Giant, then as a Jet, and then unemployed, is heading for the Oakland Raiders, with whom he has signed a two-year contract. Taylor began his fourth year as a Giant as the starting halfback.

title: Tariffs Drop On Fasteners
description: Higher duties on most imported nuts, boltsand screws ex pired Wednesday night and the office of Bill Brock, the United States trade representative, said that the Reagan Administratio n had decided against renewing them.

title: Lewis Looks Beyond 49ers
description: Imagination has never been something closely associated with weakside linebackers, but after 13 quietly efficient seasons in the National Football League, D.D. Lewis of the Dallas Cowboys can close his eyes and see more than X's and O's.

title: AMERICAN PACIFIC CORP reports earnings for Yr to Sept 30
description: B-Net income included extraordinary gain of $710,000... The yr-ago net income was adjusted for a 1-for-4 reverse split effective Mar 27, 1981; the company stock is traded on the Pacific Stock Exchange

title: Western Air Wins Pay Concessions
description: Western Airlines, which has forecast a 1981 loss of as much as $77 million, has reached a tentative agreement on a 10 percent wage cut for pilots and flight attendants, union sources said.

title: Auctions; Masters and Americana.
description: THE second part of New York's long auction season, which begins in September and ends in July, is about to open, offering quite a few objects with impressive pedigrees. Among these are George Washington's armchair, locks of his and Martha Washington's hair, two pieces of Colonial silver that once belonged to Philip Livingston, a signer of the Declaration of Independence, Joseph Hirshhorn's 18thcentury American furniture, Arthur Fiedler's musical-instrument collection and jewelry belonging to Mrs. Rex Harrison.

title: HOTEL INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
PUBLISHING: HOW A BOOK IS TURNED OUT IN A HURRY
description: IT takes about a year from the time the average manuscript is accepted until it appears between covers. During the interval the manuscript must be edited, the book printed, galleys sent to book clubs, magazines and paperback houses, and orders taken by the sales force. But the time most of these procedures take can be shortened if necessary. A good recent example is ''Wodehouse at War'' by Iain Sproat, published by Ticknor & Fields.

title: BRITISH TAKE A NEW STEP ON ULSTER HOME RULE
description: The British Government is beginning a new initiative aimed at bringing a measure of home rule to Northern Ireland.

title: THE MATINEE IDYLLS OF A SUBURBAN CLUB
description: The first women to climb into the red, white and blue bus parked behind the Central Presbyterian Church in New Providence, N.J., were Marianne Draper and Louise Smith, and they were reading up on Katharine Hepburn.

title: Ransom Recovered in Italy
description: The authorities said today that they had recovered the $800,000 ransom paid to the kidnappers of a 39-year-old woman who was found chained in a cave Tuesday night. The woman, Donatella Tesi Mosca, was kidnapped on Nov. 12.

title: WALLY POST, OUTFIELDER FOR REDS AND PHILLIES
description: Walter Charles (Wally) Post, an outfielder who spent most of his career with the Cincinnati Reds, died Wednesday at his son's home in this western Ohio community. He was 52 years old and had been in and out of hospitals recently for treatment of cancer.

title: Paris to Limit Sales to Soviet Of Computers
description: French Defense Minister Charles Hernu and Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger agreed today that an unchecked flow of advanced technology to the Soviet Union would be a ''windfall'' for Moscow.

title: Bell Seeks to Curb Aid To Colleges in Defaults
description: The Education Department wants to bar colleges from getting any new Federal money to lend if default rates on student loans exceed 25 percent.

title: PRESIDENT STUDIES A $30 BILLION PLAN FOR TAX INCREASES
description: President Reagan today reviewed new proposals for tax increases worth $30 billion to $35 billion for 1984, a package that was designed by his advisers to bring the 1984 Federal deficit down to $55 billion.

title: TEXT OF STATEMENT BY REAGAN ON REGISTRATION
description: Following is the text of a statement by President Reagan today on continuing draft registration: Last July I established a Presidential Military Manpower Task Force chaired by Defense Secretary Weinberger. One of the mandates of the task force was to examine the cases for and against continued military registration, as well as to review other issues affecting military manpower.

title: Delivering Gas From Siberia
description: The pipeline that the Soviet Union plans to build to supply Western Europe with natural gas from Siberia would follow a 3,300-mile route from the Urengoy field, north of the Arctic Circle, passing south of Moscow to the Soviet border with Czechoslovakia.

title: Credit Markets; GOVERNMENT BONDS EDGE UP
description: Prices of long-term Government securities edged slightly higher yesterday, after severe price declines earlier this week. Over all, analysts said, it was a quiet day in the fixed-income markets: Price changes were small and retail activity extremely light.

title: SHORTAGE OF BLOOD IN THE NEW YORK AREA CUTS SUPPLIES TO HOSPITALS
description: When an aide from the Kingsbrook Jewish Medical Center in Brooklyn telephoned the New York Blood Services yesterday seeking B positive blood for an accident victim, she was told th e center was out of thattype of blood.

title: MILITARY SPENDING'S BOTTOM LINE
description: To the Editor:

title: POLAND'S SLUMP ENDANGERING ECONOMICS OF THE SOVIET BLOC
description: Poland's deteriorating economy, whic h has suffered a 25 percent drop in industrial production over the last two years, is threatenin g to cause severe damage to the economies of the Soviet Union and its European allies.

title: A Raise for Gretzky
description: Wayne Gretzky of the Edmonton Oilers is the best hockey player in the world and is going to be the highest paid in the game's history, says Peter Pocklington, owner of the team. Gretzky will earn ''a lot more'' than the previously reported $550,000 for this season when he finally signs his renegotiated contract, Pocklington said.

title: CONRIED SERVICE TOMORROW
description: Four close friends were chosen Wednesday to deliver eulogies at a memorial serivce for Hans Conried, the character actor who died of a heart attack Tuesday at the age of 66. A family spokesman said eulogies at the services, scheduled for 3 P.M. Saturday at Forest Lawn, Hollywood Hills, would be given by Frank Nelson, James Karen and Elliot Reid, all actors, and by Henri Temianka, a musician.

title: U.S. to Help Make Carrier a Museum
description: A Federal grant of $4.5 million to help build a floating naval museum in a mothballed aircraft carrier and dock the vessel in Manhattan has been approved, the Department of Housing and Urban Development announced yesterday.

title: BROWNING PIANO RECITAL DEDICATED TO BARBER
description: THE pianist John Browning will give his first New York recital in seven years tonight at 8 in Carnegie Hall. The program, which consists of Mozart's Sonata in F (K. 332), Samuel Barber's Sonata (Op. 26) and Mussorgsky's ''Pictures at an Exhibition,'' will be dedicated to the memory of Mr. Barber, who died a year ago this month.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rate payable by savings institutions.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues.

title: Want Ads Up In November
description: The volume of help-wanted advertisements in newspapers around the nation rose slightly in November, the same month that the nation's unemployment rate rose to a six-year high of 8.4 percent, the Conference Board reported yesterday.

title: ANOTHER CURTAIN, ANOTHER SHOW
description: TRADITIONALLY, first nights are the most dramatic event in the theater: reputations are made and memories begin. Closing nights, however, can be equally exciting, as artistry turns into legend. The closing night of ''My Fair Lady'' was one such occasion. After more than six years on Broadway, the production must have been on its fifth replacement cast, but the actors and the audience were fully prepared for a celebration. The evening was a homecoming for previous ''My Fair Lady'' companies and for the creators of the show. At the final curtain, the stage was awash with well-wishers and well-earned sentiment. Something similar occurred several years later with the closing night of ''Fiddler on the Roof,'' after a run of almost eight years. However, in that instance, along with the jubilation there was more than an undercurrent of backstage animosity.

title: ATLANTAN TELLS MURDER TRIAL OF A SPLASH
description: A rookie police officer who was on a bridge surveillance squad in the predawn hours of May 22, 1981, testified today that he saw a car driven by Wayne B. Williams ''appear to come from a parked position'' on a bridge over the Chattahoochee River and ''drive very slowly'' across immediately after a policeman under the bridge radioed that he had heard ''a big, loud splash.''

title: DOROTHY de BORCHGRAVE
description: Dorothy Solon de Borchgrave, executive assistant to Douglas Dillon, former Secretary of the Treasury and chairman of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, died Wednesday in Boston.

title: Birks to Acquire Six Jewelry Units
description: The Dayton-Hudson Corporation said it had agreed in principle to sell its jewelry operations to Henry Birks & Sons of Montreal for an undisclosed price.

title: Bowa Says He'll Be Sent To the Cubs for DeJesus
description: Larry Bowa, the Philadelphia shortstop, said tonight that a five-player deal involving himself and Ivan DeJesus, the Chicago Cub shortstop, was close to being completed.

title: HUNT TRUST PLANS SALE OF OIL SITES
description: The Placid Oil Company, which is owned in trust for members of the Hunt family of Dallas, has agreed to sell some of its oil and gas properties for $410 million in cash to the Petro-Lewis Corporation, it was announced yesterday. Petro-Lewis, a Denver company that acquires, develops and operates oi l and gas properties for itself and others, said it would pay Pl acid $347 million and Hunt family interests about $63 million. Pe tro-Lewis expects to complete the transaction this month.

title: C.A.B. ALLOWS CARRIERS TO RETURN TO FARE TALKS
description: The Civil Aeronautics Board today extended the authority of United States carriers to take part in conferences aimed at restoring a fare-setting mechanism for North Atlantic routes.

title: Transactions
description: AUTO RACING

title: SOME PEOPLE ARE ABLE TO AID NEEDIEST CASES FOR FIRST TIME
description: ''One needs to give to others in order to appreciate our own lives; to give is to enhance or help, in whatever small way, the life of another but it also enriches the life of the giver as well.''

title: OCILLA INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-After an extraordinary charge on $136,000 or 10 cents a shr

title: LANIER BUSINESS PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 27
GENERAL MICROWAVE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 28
A SHARP TURNAROUND AT FIAT
description: A little over a year ago, people in this Piedmontese city would have taken bets that Fiat, Italy's biggest auto maker and the country's largest private company, was on the verge of disaster.

title: Racing Inquiry Widens
description: Law-enforcement sources and racing officials say they expect that a New Jersey State Police investigation of thoroughbred race-fixing at Meadowlands Race Track will result in the indictments of jockeys and trainers in addition to the three riders who were named Wednesday in criminalcharges. A state grand jury is expected to hand up indictments as early as next week.

title: ART: FROM NED SMYTH, A MOSAIC TANTALIZER
description: ONE of the better-kept secrets of the new year is the ultimate location of a large environmental piece on which a young mosaicist called Ned Smyth is now engaged. The piece in question consists of an oval floor, 55 feet long and 44 feet wide, and an arcade of columns in the form of jeweled palm trees. The subject matter of the floor has to do with the relations between men, women and zebras. On one side is a scene of pastoral felicity, in which men and women serenade the zebras by playing on the flute. On the other, humankind takes on a less amiable aspect, and the men and women hunt the zebras with javelins. Over all, the palm trees rise, to a height of 18 feet, each one with a different jewel threaded in and out of its bright green leaves.

title: AUTO WORKERS DIVIDE ON DEMANDS FO R CONCESSIONS
description: James Faulkner has the feeling he is being squeezed. Laid off by the Ford Motor Company two months ago, he sees the certainty of getting his job back threatened by the slump in automobile sales. Now Ford and the General Motors Corporation are asking his union to give up some of the benefits he has taken for granted in his six years as an automobile worker. At a meeting Friday, union leaders will decide whether to meet with the companies and hear them out. If the union refuses the concessions, the companies are saying, more jobs may disappear. It is hard for auto workers, who are used to being the envy of industrial workers everywhere, to accept such a reversal of fortune.

title: Voice of America Stepping Up Polish-Language Broadcasts
description: The Voice of America announced today that it had increased its Polish-language broadcasts in Eastern Europe to seven hours a day. It had been broadcasting two and a half hours a day before the declaration of martial law last month.

title: NIKE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
ACTIVE IN CHILD CARE PROJECTS
description: Beatrice Sulzberger Trilling, long active in child care programs, died yesterday at her home in Chevy Chase, Md. She was 71 years old. Mrs. Trilling, who formerly lived in New York City, was associated for many years with the Louise Wise Adoption Service in New York.

title: Economic Scene; The Outlook For Volcker
description: WILL Paul A. Volcker serve out his term, which ends in August 1983, as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board? And will the Administration replace him as chairman thereafter?

title: AN IDEOLOGICAL RUSSIAN-GERMAN TANK
description: To the Editor:

title: Business Digest; FRIDAY, JANUARY 8, 1982; International
description: Poland's deteriorating economy may cause severe damage to the economies of the Soviet Union and its Eastern European allies, according to Western experts. Throughout the Eastern bloc, they say, the Polish crisis is aggravating shortages of food and industrial goods, weakening economic lin ks between count ries and undermining their creditworthiness in financial markets. (Page A1.) Events in Poland are causing deep economic concerns in Czechoslovakia. (A8.)

title: NEW FACES: A GUIDE TO FRESH TALENT NOW ON THE LOCAL SCENE
description: On this page, nine arts critics for The New York Times share their discoveries of some of the bright new talents now appearing on the New York scene: Stage

title: Eggnog Blamed In 5th Jersey Death
description: The death of a fifth elderly resident of the Shady Lane Rest Home in Clarksboro has been linked to contaminated eggnog served at a Christmas Eve party, a state health official said Thursday.

title: WASHINGTON POST SELLS INSIDE SPORTS MAGAZINE
description: The Washington Post Company said yesterday that it had reached an agreement in principle to sell its money-losing sports magazine, Inside Sports, to a small publishing concern that specializes in magazines for children and young athletes.

title: SONICS, SLOT MACHINE FIRM SEEK MERGER
description: An agreement in principle has been reached to merge the Seattle SuperSonics with a highly profitable worldwide supplier of casino gambling machines. But the proposed deal is subject to approval by the National Basketball Association, which prohibits its teams from having significant ties with the gambling industry.

title: Phillips Gas Plants
description: The Phillips Petroleum Company said it planned to more than double the capacity of its natural gas liquids facilities in central Texas.

title: REAGAN AND THE E.R.A.
description: Conservatives proclaim themselves respectful of constitutional powers, procedures and states' rights. And those who preach judicial restraint denounce unnecessary or premature judicial intervention.

title: PUBLICITY HELPS A STATE AGENCY TO STAY IN CITY
description: The chairman of the State Power Authority, who threatened several weeks ago to move most of his agency's operations out of New York City, said yest erday that it now appeared the authority would be staying.

title: LEVI STRAUSS & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 29
News Analysis
description: Just how the combination of United States Steel and Marathon Oil will work is subject to a substantial degree of uncertainty about the economic outlook and the strategy U.S. Steel has plotted for the new company.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article on the Washington Talk page Tuesday incorrectly reported the political affiliation of Lyndon H. La- Rouche as a Presidential candidate. He ran as a Labor Party candidate in 1976 and as a Democrat in the 1980 pri- maries.

title: IN MT. CARMEL, ENDURING LOVE
description: Michael Davido is 64 years old, and he has a heart problem that has slowed him down since middle age. He lives in a walk-up in an Italian enclave in the Bronx that is distant in more than just travel time from the New York of loft galleries, Hunanese restaurants and Broadway, which he still calls ''the Great White Way.''

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Airwick Industries, Carlstadt, N.J., has elected to its board Robert J. Tarr Jr., president and chief executive officer of GCC Beverages Inc., and John Phillips, on loan to CBS Inc. from the National Executive Services Corps, where he serves as executive vice president and chief operating officer.

title: COMMERCIAL METALS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: A change in inventory method increased the 1981 net by $98,000 or 7 cents a shr and decreased the 1980 net by $987,000 or 22 cents a shr

title: FOREST TRIBES OF SURINAME 'SETTLE IN' AT MUSEUM
description: IT may be winter here, but it's forever summer in Suriname. Or so it looks in ''Afro-American Arts of the Suriname Rain Forest'' at the American Museum of Natural History, an exhibition of everyday objects carved, stitched and woven by the Maroon tribes, escaped slaves in the South American country.

title: ENVIRONMENTAL AGENCY MOVES TO EASE TRUCK EXHAUST RULES
description: The Environmental Protection Agency has proposed easing the air pollution rules for heavy-duty trucks despite a recent signal from Congress that it wants the stricter rules to be retained.

title: The Jury Empaneled, Abbott Trial to Begin
