description: The Selection of a jury of nine men and three women for the murder trial of Jack Henry Abbott was completed yesterday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan. The trial is to begin at 11 A.M. today before Acting Justice Irving Lang.

title: VERTIPILE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
AAV COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Market Place
description: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS MACHINES, a disappointment for almost a decade, could produce good gains for its 737,000 owners over the next two to three years.

title: CZECH LEADERS ARE NERVOUS ABOUT CRISIS IN POLAND
description: The crisis in neighboring Poland is causing nervousness in Czechoslovakia. While there appears to be some concern about possible political consequences, the reasons for the nervousness are largely economic.

title: PRIVATE FOOD AID FROM U.S. TO POLES RESUMES
description: A private group announced today that it had begun the first American shipment of food to Poland since martial law was imposed last month.

title: Martina Navratilova Gains
description: Martina Navratilova and Andrea Jaeger moved into the quarterfinals of the $200,000 Avon tournament tonight. Miss Navratilova, seeded second, beat JoAnne Russell, 7-5, 6-2, and Miss Jaeger, seeded No. 3, beat Leslie Allen, 6-2, 6-2.

title: STUDY SAYS CRIMINAL TENDENCIES MAY BE INHERITED
description: A long-term study of nearly 15,000 adopted children in Denmark strongly suggests that a predisposition to chronic criminal behavior may be inherited, a California researcher reported today.

title: Bronx Battle Marked
description: More than 200 years ago this month, a Revolutionary War skirmish between Hessian and American soldiers at the Bronx home of Isaac Valentine end ed in triumph for the Revolutionary forces.

title: HIGHBROW PIANO COMES TO BRUNCH AT THE BALLROOM
description: SERGEI RACHMANINOFF will drop in at brunch in the New Ballroom this Sunday to play a Chopin Scherzo. George Gershwin will stop by to show off his ''Rhapsody in Blue.'' Josef Lhevinne will turn up to give a glimpse at his interpretation of Beethoven's ''Moonlight'' Sonata. These long-dead artists will not be heard on recordings. Instead, a Knabe concert grand piano will be played automatically, according to half-century-old instructions left by the artists.

title: U.N. Chief Vows Support For a Free Namibia
description: 0 UNITED NATI ONS, N.Y., Jan. 7 (AP) -Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar pl edged his personal support today for efforts to bring speedy indepe ndence to Namibia.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By John Leonard ALL THAT IS SOLID MELTS INTO AIR. The Experience of Modernity. By Mar- shall Berman. 384 pages. Simon & Schuster. $17.50. CONTEMPLATING a story by Gogol in which a w oman floats through the air on her own sleeves, Marshall Berman says, ''Gogol seems to be inventing the 20th century out of his own hea d.'' Mr. Berman, a professor of political science at the City Un iversity, improves on Gogol. In this brilliant and exasperating boo k, he invents the last 200 years of Western intellectual history. Th e women who float on hissleeves include Goethe, Marx, Baudelaire, Dos toyevsky and the ''spectral'' city of St. Petersburg. Accordin g to Mr. Berman, all that is modern, in literature and the arts, i n architecture and in politics, is sexy.

title: Levi Strauss Net Off
description: Levi Strauss & Company said today that its net income for the fourth quarter ended Dec. 31 dropped 26 percent, to $44.8 million, or $1.08 a share, from $60.3 million, or $1.46 a share, in the 1980 period. The apparel maker said sales declined 11 percent, to $721.3 million, from $810.7 million a year earlier. Levi's president, Robert T. Grohman, citing poor business conditions for the first half of 1982, said the company plans to cut production in North America, including temporary layoffs at several plants.

title: United Front Formed To Topple Ugandan
description: Two former Presidents of Uganda announced the formation today of a united front to oppose the year-old rule of President Milton Obote, whose rule they compared to the dictatorship of Idi Amin.

title: The U.N. Today; Jan. 8, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: International Oceanographic Commission's Working Committee for Global Investigations of Pollution in Marine Environment - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title:
RED SMITH;
George and the Calendar
description: NEITHER the laws of the land nor the rules of his lodge govern George M. Steinbrenner. The basic agreement between baseball players and their employers, with which the Yankees' chief owner is pledged to comply, declares that no player may be forced to report for spring training before March 1.So Steinbrenner wrote a letter to each of t he Yankees. It said in effect: Start reporting Feb. 9. If this makes you unhappy, I will do my best to place you anywhere you might be ha ppy.

title: Advertising; Avis Plans A Review Of B.B.D.O.
description: If Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn, which has been the Avis agency since mid-1980, is asked to compete with other agencies to keep the business, it will refuse, Bruce Crawford, president of BBDO International said yesterday.

title: Rockets Win Amid Changes
description: When the Rockets lost their fourth consecutive Major Indoor Soccer League game last Saturday at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, Ed Tepper, president of the club, decided to make immediate changes.

title: TYCO LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 28
description: All shr earnings adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split effective Nov 18, 1981...C-Includes a gain of $3.7 million or 40 cents per shr as a result of the exchange of Tyco's Investment in Fisher Scientific Company for convertible preferred stock of Allied Corp...D-Includes a foreign exchange loss after tax of $1.5 million for second fiscal 1982 qr and $1.1 million for the 6 mos of fiscal 1982...E-Includes a gain of $1.6 million from settlement of litigation

title: DECISION FILE
description: Every day Federal agencies make decisions that affect the lives of Americans. Here is a recent case: Freight Rate

title: Disappointin g Change
description: Ted Stepien, owner of the Cleveland Cavaliers, says that Chuck Daly cannot be considered a ''great'' basketball coach until he wins with the Cavaliers. Stepien was expressing disenchantment with Daly less than a month after hiring him to replace Don Delaney.

title: FORMER POLISH OFFICIALS ARE INDICTED FOR CORRUPTION
description: Polish television announced a series of indictments t onight against former party leaders, Government officials and industrial managers for using their positions for personal gain .

title: Boy, 17, Is Seized in Shooting Of Detective Lured Into Trap
description: A 17-year-old Brooklyn youth was arrested yesterday afternoon and charged with shooting an off-duty detective who was lured into a trap set for a good Samaritan in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn on Dec. 31, the police said.

title: Harvester Talks
description: The International Harvester Company said that the United Automobile Workers union has agreed to meet the company here next Wednesday to discuss Harvester's request for a $100 million reduction in its employment costs up to Oct. 1, the expiration date of the current union contract. About 20,000 of Harvester's employees are represented by the U.A.W. The union said it had agreed to meet International Harvester representatives next week but had not agreed to reopen the three-year contract.

title: No Headline
description: Track Closes in Dispute With Horsemen

title: WARSAW PRELATE DENOUNCES USE OF LOYALTY OATH
description: The following dispatch is based on information arriving from Poland.

title: Business People; MAY DEPART MENT STORES SELECTS VI CE CHAIRMAN
description: Thomas A. Hays, 49, has been elected a vice chairman of the May Department Stores Company, a leading national retailer, with overall responsibility for its 45 Venture discount stores and its more than 1,000 Volume shoe stores. David C. Farrell, 48, continues as president and chief executive officer of May, and John W. Boyle, 52, remains chairman.

title: WHY OPTIMISM ABOUT A NAMIBIAN SETTLEMENT
description: The Reagan Administration is optimistic about its d iplomatic efforts to reach a Namibian settlement with a two-track p olicy - an approach that depends on both South African and Angolan c ooperation. Yet while both tracks are considered equally necessary, t he Adminstration has until now essentially ignored the Angolan t rack. Why then is there so much optimism that an internationally r ecognized Namibian settlement is imminent?

title: Giants Increasing Prices For First Time Since '76
description: The Giants, who had the lowest scale for ticket prices of the National Football League's 28 teams, raised prices today for the first time since the team moved into Giants Stadium in 1976.

title: Foreign Reporters Ask An End to Censorship
description: The following dispatch was passed through Polish military censorship.

title: GERMANS CITE SOVIET LOAN BID
description: The Soviet Union has asked West German banks for an additional $137 million in credit to help finance a controversial natural gas pipeline from Siberia to Western Europe, German banking officials disclosed today.

title: Malaysia Cuts Oil Price
description: Malaysia's state oil agency, Petronas, has reduced crude oil prices by as much as $1 a barrel, the first price cut since last July, oil industry sources said here today.

title: Stadler Leads By Shot on 65
description: Craig Stadler birdied three holes in a row on the way to a five-under-par 65 and the first-round lead today in the $300,000 Tucson Open, the first event on the 10-month pro golf tour.

title: BALLET: CRACKLING 'HISTOIRE DU SOLDAT'
description: CAN improved dancing improve a ballet? The answer is no, but it can certainly give that impression - as it did Wednesday night in the New York City Ballet's first performance this season of Peter Martins's ''Suite from Histoire du Soldat.''

title: Still Talking
description: Negotiations for the position of head coach of the New England Patriots were at a standstill yesterday after two days of telephone conferences between Chuck Sullivan, vice president of the club, and Ed Hookstratten, the lawyer representing Coach John Robinson of Southern California.

title: Notes on People; Arms Control Talks
description: D. L. Walker, the Police Chief in Whitewright, Tex., concedes that there has been something of a crime wave in the little town near the Oklahoma border. Indeed, since he took over on Nov. 16, he said yesterday, there has already been a burglary and a theft.

title: Notes on People; Toast to 'Marco Polo'
description: ''I almost never give cocktail parties,'' Pat Buckley was saying, despite the fact that she is one of New York's best-known hostesses. ''So when I asked people to come from 6 to 8, I had no idea whether anyone would show up, at least till 7.

title: LAW GROUP VOTES $1.2 MILLION TO LURE MINORITIES
description: Expressing concern over the continuing low enrollment of minority students in law schools, the trustees o f the Law School Admission Council voted today to c ommit $1.2 million over the next four years to programs designed to a ttract more blacks, Hispanic Americans and members of other minor ities to the bar. ''We are pu tting our money where society's mouth has been for a long time,'' said Rennard Strickland, a professor of law at the University of Tulsa, chairman of the council's minority enrollment task force.

title: M-G-M Net Up 75% in Quarter
description: The Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Film Company reported today that first-quarter net income rose 75 percent, to $9.8 million, or 20 cents a share, on revenues of $208.4 million.

title: FARCE: TONY ROBERTS IN HOROVITZ'S 'GOOD PARTS'
description: ISRAEL HOROVITZ, one of our most eclectic as well as uneven playwrights, is in his silly mode in ''The Good Parts,'' his new comedy that opened at the Astor Place last night. And why not? If Mr. Horovitz wants to write ''The Odd Couple Goes to Greece'' - which seems to be his intention - heaven knows we're all ready to join him in some mindless mirth. But silly writing requires the same energy as any other kind of writing. It's because Mr. Horovitz has executed his farce so lazily that the good parts of ''The Good Parts'' are so few and far between.

title: FRIENDS OF MRS. GANDHI JOIN ANTICORRUPTION OUTCRY
description: Charges that India's governmental institutions have crumbled, that corruption is rampant and that public morality is in sharp decline have recently spread from anti-establishment journals into the mass-circulation press that is essentially middle class and middle of the road.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Metropolitan Report yesterday incorrectly cited figures on dr ug use among students in the 7th through 12th grades. According to the New York State study, 27 percent of such students use drugs reg ularly and 1.6 percent are ''extensive users.''

title: UNIVERSAL RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
'Angels' Marching To Washington
description: TRENTON (AP) - Members of the Guardian Angels started a march to Washington to seek Federal intervention in the case of a member who was shot to death by a Newark policeman.

title: Around the Nation; Fraternity Expels a Unit Over Religious Language
description: The fraternity Kappa Sigma has revoked the charter of its Stanford chapter in a dispute over omitting religious references in its initiation ritual, it was announced today.

title: Ninth Trident Contract Let
description: The Navy announced Thursday that it was awarding a $523.7 million contract to the Electric Boat Division of the General Dynamics Corporation to build the ninth nuclear-powered, missile-firing Trident submarine.

title: POLISH ARTISTS AND INTELLECTUALS URGE JARUZELSKI TO END MARTIAL LAW
description: The following dispatch is based on information arriving from Poland.

title: Carolina-Wilmington 52 St. Francis, N.Y. 43
description: Shawn Williams scored 12 points to lead North Carolina-Wilmington (6-5), which made 22 of 27 free throws in the second half of a first-round game in the Siena Invitational.

title:
Patents;
Bed Sheet Enhances Patients' Comfort
description: A top bed sheet that provides space underneath for comfortable accommodation of the user's feet was patented this week for the Sleep Knit Corporation, New York. According to Sidney M. Weiss, who was granted patent 4,308,626, an initial version, made of soft, stretchable cotton, is currently in use by more than 200 hospitals, including several in New York.

title: SUSPECT IN BRINK'S ROBBERY AND POLICE SLAYING IS SEIZED
description: A suspect in the $1.6 million Brink's holdup that left three persons dead in Rockland County in October and the ambush-slaying of a policeman in Queens last April was arrested in Philadelphia Thursday and turned over to New York authorities last night.

title: Sports People; Comings and Goings
description: Lawrence Taylor, the Giant linebacker, became the first rookie ever named The Associated Press's defensive player of the year. ... The African National Congress said Jack Nicklaus, Johnny Miller, Lee Trevino and Severiano Ballesteros were guilty of ''an unfriendly act'' against the black people of Africa for having played in a promotional golf tournament last week in Bophuthatswana. Alfred Nzo, secretary-general of the congress, told a news conference in the British House of Commons that t he golfers had collaborated with the apartheid pol icy of South Africa and said there were indications thatthe $1 millio n purse had come from South Africa. The only other competitor wa s Gary Player, a South African.

title: Going Out Guide
description: NORSE WINDS

title: The Region; Judge Upholds Margiotta Verdict
description: A Federal judge refused yesterday to overturn the indictment and conviction of Joseph M. Margiotta, the Republican chairman of Nassau County. Mr. Margiotta was convicted last December of extorting more than $500,000 in insurance kickbacks for his political supporters.

title: G.E. Cites U.S. Bar On Soviet Project
description: The General Electric Company said today that it had been informed by the Commerce Department that parts it was to have shipped to Europe for use on the Siberian gas pipeline would not be given export licenses.

title: Business Digest; SATURDAY, JANUARY 9, 1982; Antitrust
description: A.T.& T., in a landmark accord, agreed to give up its 22 localservice ope rating telephone companies and thus settle a seven-year an titrust suit. As part of the accord, which must be approved by a Federal court, A.T.& T. would sell $80 billion in assets, about twothirds of its worth, but retain its most profitable operations. ( Page 1.) Consumers could experience a rapid increase in local phone r ates, but a decline in long-distance rates. (1.)

title: 3 Alumni Will Perform At Benefit for Mannes
description: The mezzo-soprano Frederica von Stade, the pianist Eugene Istomin and the conductor Julius Rudel will take part in a benefit concert Jan. 17 for the Mannes College of Music at Avery Fisher Hall at 7:30 P.M. The concert will also feature the Lincoln Center debut of the Mannes Orchestra. The artists are alumni of the school.

title: Notes on People; Andre Previn Weds
description: In a quiet ceremony conducted by a judge, Andre Previn, music director of the Pittsburgh Symphony and guest conductor of the New York Philharmonic and other major orchestras, was married in Pittsburgh to Heather Hales, the Allegheny County Marriage License Bureau confirmed yesterday.

title: SPAIN TO REOPEN ITS GIBRALTER BORDER
description: Spain announced today that it would reopen the border with Gibraltar, which it closed 12 years ago, on April 20, the day on which Madrid and London begin talks on the future of the twoand-a-half-square-mile British territory at the mouth of the Mediterranean. The talks could lead ultimately to the end of the colonial status of the Rock, as the fortress has been called for years.

title: Sports People; Robinson Declines Offer
description: After a week of discussions between his lawyer and the New England Patriots, John Robinson, the football coach at Southern California, declined the Patriots' offer to replace Ron Erhardt as head coach. At a news conference in Los Angeles, Robinson said that for ''commitment to U.S.C.'' he had decided to stay at the college, where he has coached teams to three victories in the Rose Bowl and one in the Bluebonnet Bowl in his six years and where he has four years left on his current contract.

title: Traffic Agent Hit by Van Dies
description: A 23-year-old traffic enforcement agent died yesterday at St. Vincent's Hospital of head injuries he suffered last Monday when he was struck by a van while on duty in lower Manhattan. The victim, Ismael Vega, was at the corner of Delancey and Essex Streets when he was struck. No charges were filed against the driver.

title: Disarmed Guards
description: With more and more Americans purchasing handguns for self-defense, we are pleased to note a sensible countertrend: some private security companies are abandoning the use of firearms. Owners of the businesses have no political ax to grind.

title: Religious Zeal, Religious Tyranny
description: Why don't religious zealots understand that their own religious freedom depends on the tolerance and diversity that the First Amendment protects? Why do Americans, devout or doubting, permit the passage of laws that inject a particular religious doctrine into public school teaching? Fortunately, the courts are available to enforce the Bill of Rights, but why is it necessary to summon their power?

title: KEYSTONE FOODS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 28
Around the Nation; 'Traffic Jam' Reported As Waterway Reopens
description: Boats and barges, backed up for five days after a barge struck a railroad bridge, began moving again early today as the Intracoastal Waterway was reopened to one-way traffic.

title: Radioactive Freight Found in Derailment
description: Workers of the Southern Pacific Transportation Company searching the wreckage of a freight car for a container of low-level radioactive material.

title: A Need for Nuance in Nicaragua
description: As it looks to its second year, the Reagan Administration apparently plans to continue with its truculent policy toward Nicaragua: a suspension of aid and mutterings about possible reprisals if a hard-pressed Managua turns east - or even to France - for guns and sympathy. A second course is possible. Why not promis e resumed American help once the Sandinist regime acts on its democra tic pledges, starting with a broad amnesty for political prisoners? And why not welcome contacts that tie Nicaragua to other democracies, like the $16 million arms deal with France?

title: CORRECTION
description: An article Dec. 15 on minimum So- cial Security benefits incompletely stated one provision of a bill that is now the law. As of Jan. 1, and for the next 10 years, only nuns and other members of religious orders will be able to begin receiving the minimum benefit.

title: No Headline
description: Misses Shriver, Jaeger Upset

title: A.T.& T.  TO SPLIT UP, TRANSFORMING INDUSTRY
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company settled the Justice Department's antitrust lawsuit today by agreeing to give up the 22 Bell System companies that provide most of the nation's local telephone service.

title: Horovitz's 'Good Parts' Will Close Tomorrow
description: ''The Good Parts,'' a play by Israel Horovitz about two men going through a midlife crisis, will close after tomorrow evening's performance at the Astor Place Theater.

title: Dow Advances 4.75; Phone Accord Cited
description: Stock prices moved higher yesterday, with investor sentiment buoyed by news that the Justice Department had settled its antitrust case against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. The settlement calls for A.T.& T. to divest itself of its local telephone companies.

title: Around the World; Iran Executes 6 Bahais, Religious Leaders Say
description: Iranian firing squads have executed six more leaders of the Bahai religion, according to a Bahai statement made public here today.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Bethlehem Steel Corp. said it will eliminate about 160 salaried positions at its Burns Harbor, Ind., plant effective Feb. 1.

title: Pardee Assists Chargers' Title Drive
description: Jack Pardee, a two-time co ach of the year in the National Conference, says he never expected to be in Cincinnati today -especi ally as a football coach -preparing for the American Conference ch ampionship game.

title: IN A TROUBLES POLAND, JEWS AGAIN SEEM TO BE MADE SCAPEGOATS
description: The following dispatch is based on information reaching The New York Times from Poland. Normal communications with The Times's Warsaw bureau chief, John Darnton, have been barred by the authorities there since Dec. 14.

title: ANALYSTS ARE BULLISH ON FUTURE OF A.T.&T.
description: Some Wall Street analysts suggested yesterday that the settlement of the antitrust case against the American Telephone and Telegraph Co mpany could transform the company's stock from a classic conservative investment into a more speculative telecommunications play.

title: BALLET: STEPS IN THE RIGHT DIRECTION
description: A recent, disturbing aspect of the New York City Ballet's performances has been the tendency of the younger principals and soloists to treat nearly all ballets as if they were the same.

title: '81 Chicago Options Up
description: The Chicago Board Options Exchange said today that its volume last year rose to 57.6 million contracts from 52.9 million in 1980, with the average daily volume up to 227,605 from 209,158. Call-options trading slipped to 40.8 million contracts in 1981 from 42.9 million in the previous year, while put-options volume increa sed to 16.8 million from 10 million, the exchange said. It traded put and call options on 120 listed stocks at the year-end.

title: News An alysis
description: Through some tacit, behind-the-scenes trad eoffs, th e United States and its key European allies have so far avoided allow ing their persistent differences to overshadow the crackdown in Poland.

title: N.A.A.C.P. MAY PROTEST ON FILM INDUSTRY HIRING
description: The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People has threatened a nationwide protest if negotiations with a group representing movie studios next month fail to produce guidelines to get more blacks into the industry, the head of the organization said this week.

title: Sentencing Is Put Off In Point-Shaving Case
description: The sentencing of five men convicted in November of conspiring to shave points in Boston College basketball games three years ago was deferred yesterday to give lawyers time to prepare rebuttals of allegations contained in probation reports. Judge Henry Bramwell of United States District Court in Brooklyn granted the delay ''in order not to unduly prejudice any defendant.''

title: WEINBERGER EXPLAINS DRAFT REGISTRATION SHIFT
description: President Reagan reversed his campaign stand and continued draft registration mainly because new information showed it would save up to seven weeks if mobilization became necessary, Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger said today.

title: Rise Seen For Stock Of I.B.M.
description: When the New York Stock Exchange opens for trading on Monday, Stephen T. McClellan, the computer industry analyst for Salomon Brothers, expects the stock of the International Business Machines Corporation to go up a few points.

title: Boy, 11, Found Alive In Wreckage of Plane
description: An 11-year-old boy was found alive today after five days in the wreckage of a small plane that crashed in a snowstorm in the Sierra Nevada, the authorities said.

title: STAODYNAMICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
DOMINANCE ENDED, I.B.M. FIGHTS BACK
description: In agreeing to drop its antitrust suit against the International Business Machines Corporation, the Department of Justice has recognized what computer experts and securities analysts had long since concluded: I.B.M. no longer dominates the computer business.

title: THETFORD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-After loss of $919,000 in the qr and $1.1 million for the 9 mos from discontinued operations...C-After $302,000 loss from discontinued operations

title: JAZZ: GEORGE SHEARING$
description: It says something for the wells of creativity on which George Shearing can draw that the high point of one of his sets at Michael's Pub this week, as he began a two-month engagement there, was ''Lullaby of Birdland,'' a tune he w rote 30 years ago and which he has been play ing, literally ''by popular demand,'' almost every nightsince then.

title: Bertha Harris, a Civic Leader And a Minister in Harlem, 89
description: Bertha Nelms Harris, a longtime civic leader in Harlem and the founder and president emeritus of Key Women of America, a community service organization, died Tuesday in Harlem Hospital. She was 89 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: EXCERPTS FROM TEXT OF A DECREE SIGNED BY A.T.&T. AND U.S.
description: Following is the text of the consent decree filed by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and the Justice Department yesterday with the United States District Court in Newark:

title: HEINICKE INSTRUMENTS CO reports earnings for Yr to Oct 31
MURDER TRIAL OF JACK ABBOTT IS BEGUN
description: The prosecutor in the murder trial of Jack Henry Abbott told the jury yesterday that the prison writer had intentionally stabbed an East Village waiter last summer after attacking the victim from behind. Mr. Abbott's lawyer argued that the death was a ''tragic accident'' motivated by self-defense.

title: Seeker of Sonic Merger Wants Gaming Licenses
description: Harvey Siegel, the gambling-machine distributor seeking a merger with the Seattle SuperSonics, said Thursday that he had applied for a gaming license in New Jersey and planned to seek a Nevada gaming license if the merger is completed.

title: Harvester Trucks
description: The International Harvester Company said it had reached a long-term agreement with Fiat's Iveco truck subsidiary to sell light-duty trucks built by Iveco in the United States and Canada. International Harvester said initial deliveries of the trucks will start in March. The length or value of the contract was not disclosed.

title: Midas Almahurst Wins As Meadowlands Opens
description: Midas Almahurst, a 4-to-1 shot, scored a 1 3/4-length victory tonight in the $35,000 Inaugural Pace as the Meadowlands opened a 182-night harness racing season before a crowd of 25,854. Lew Williams drove the w inne r, who paced the mile in 1:56 and returned $10.80 for $2 to win.

title: De Gustibus; SOME CURMUDGE ONLY BUT BEGUILING VIEWS ON FOOD
description: Preferences in cookbooks vary with moods and humors. There is a time for large, encyclopedic ones that include professionally written recipes that are precise and depersonalized, and there is a time for small, whimsical ones that reflect the cantankerous views of enthusiastic amateurs. Among the more beguiling examples of the latter group are the tiny, decorative pamphlets that make up the Simple Cooking Series, distributed through the mail by a Boston publishing company.

title: I.B.M.'S PERSISTENT LEADER
description: In March 1980 John Roberts Opel was named chief executive officer of the International Business Machines Corporation in addition to his title of president. I.B.M.'s decision ended brief speculation that he might be passed over in favor of someone deemed more likely to help the giant, but troubled, company improve its less-than-customary performance. In the end, it seemed, loyalty, a plan of succession and his role as a sort of alter ego won out.

title: IT WOULD BE TRAGIC IF GINNIE MAE DIED
description: To the Editor:

title: NOEL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
JUSTICE DEPARTMENT'S WATCHDOG
description: William Francis Baxter, an assistant Attorney General in charge of the antitrust division of the Justice Department, was on a skiing vacation in Utah until late this week. But from out West, he followed the last-minute, secret negotiations for a settlement of the historic antitrust case against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. A Justice Department attorney served as a courier, delivering documents to him in Utah. He was in constant contact with his office by telephone to check on the status of the case against the International Business Machines Corporation, which the Justice Department dropped today.

title: WHEN CRIME BECOMES A REALITY...
description: For Martin E. Segal, chairman of the board of Lincoln Center, crime in New York became a reality the other day when he was robbed at gunpoint in an elevator in the Pan Am Building, at Park Avenue and 45th Street.

title: Sports People; Aaron's Confidence
description: Hank Aaron, who retired from baseball five years go after hitting 755 home runs, is assuming he will be elected next week to the Hall of Fame. More than that, the former star of the Milwaukee and Atlanta Braves says, ''I'll tell you point-blank: Yes, I think I deserve to be a unanimous choice.'' No one has ever been a unanimous choice of the sportswriters' committee.

title: Consumer Saturday; ADVOCACY UNITS SEEK NEW FUNDS
description: Struggling is a word that is invariably used to describe the financial health of consumer advocacy groups. So when a small lobbying group like the National Family Farm Coalition folds, as it did earlier this year, even the family farmers may not have been surprised.

title: CITY MOVES TO CUT RESPONSE TIME ON HEAT COMPLAINTS TO 24 HOURS
description: As a bitterly cold weekend approached, New York City housing officials said they would seek to have heat inspectors respond to telephoned complaints within 24 hours.

title: SOLOMON FORGETS QUARTERBACK DREAM
description: No one from the pros had made any promises to Freddie Solomon when he was a successful quarterback at the University of Tampa, but it was something that was always in the back of his mind. He wanted to play the position in the National Football League.

title: Mets Get Veryzer for Searage
description: The Mets yesterday made a trade for a shortstop when they acquired Tom Veryzer from the Cleveland Indians for Ray Searage, a relief pitcher.

title: Letter: On International Communication Objective Voice
description: To the Editor:

title: Show and Lecture On Washington Feb. 11
description: An exhibition and lecture at the New-York Historical Society will mark the 250th anniversary of the birth of George Washington on his actual birthdate, Feb 11.

title: U.S. and Nicaragua Are Close To Exchanging Ambassadors
description: The United States and Nicaragua were reported today to be close to announcing an exchange of ambassadors. The United States nominee is expected to be Anthony C.E. Quainton, according to Larry Birns, head of the Council on Hemispheric Affairs, a Washington-based policy lobbying group. Mr. Quainton is a career Foreign Service officer who has been director of the State Department's Working Group on Terrorism.

title: News Analysis
description: Governor Carey's Budget Director, C. Mark Lawton, was asked repeatedly after the Governor's State of the State Message this week to explain how much he would have to cut from state services - and raise in taxes

title:
Patents;
Tethered Airfoil Uses Wind as Energy Source
description: A Washington electronics engineer has patented a tethered airfoil as a source of energy from the wind.

title: Late Surge Helps Celtics Beat 76ers
description: Larry Bird and Gerald Henderson combined for 17 points in the fourth quarter to help the Boston Celtics to a 96-90 victory over the Philadelphia 76ers tonight.

title: Observer; THE BIG DIPPERS
description: Time once again, ladies and gentlemen, to play ''Soak the Poor,'' the game in which those glorious guy and gal millionaires from the sun-kissed Arcadia of the Supply-Side Belt match political clout with life's losers. Will our first player step up and identify himself?

title: AERO SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-Includes $58,000 loss from disontinued operations

title: COURT NARROWS GROUNDS FOR CUT IN ASSESSMENTS
description: New York State's highest court has narrowed the grounds on which owners of business property in New York City and Nassau County may challenge their tax assessments.

title: MASSEY-FERGUSON CITES BIG '81 LOSS
description: Massey-Ferguson Ltd., the financially troubled farm equipment company, today reported a loss of $194.8 million (in United States currency) for the year ended Oct. 31, exceeding expectations. The figure compares with a $225.2 million loss for the fiscal year 1980.

title: PARIS DEFENDS PLAN TO SELL ARMS TO MANAGUA
description: French officials today defended the decision to supply military equipment to Nicaragua despite expressions of concern by the United States.

title: U.S. TAX RULE SHIFT APPLAUDED AND ATTACKED
description: The Administration's decision permitting taxexempt status for institutions without regard to their racial policies was welcomed today by the schools involved and assailed by some civil libertarians and religious organizations as a blow to racial justice.

title: Briefing
description: T HE Navy has selected the first captains to be promoted to the timehonored but newly revived rank of commodore. In the American Revol ution, the Navy conferred the rank on outstanding s ea captains such as John Paul Jones. Later, Commodore Stephen Decat ur was a hero in the wars against the Barbary pirates, and Commodore Matthew Calbraith Perry led the naval squadron that opened Japan to the West in 1864.

title: N.B.A. FINES CLIPPERS' OWNER
description: Commissioner Larry O'Brien of the National Basketball Association yesterday fined Donald Sterling, owner of the San Diego Clippers, $10,000 for ''conduct prejudicial and detrimental to the N.B.A.''

title: QUIET FORCE AT A.T.&T.
description: Charles Lee Brown, chairman of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, is described as a quiet, determined man who, over the last three years, has moved a highly entrenched bureaucratic corporation -the largest in the world -from the protective umbrella of regulation to a new era of competition.

title: MEDICARE PATIENTS MAY BE FORCED TO PAY 10% OF HOSPITAL CHARGES
description: The Reagan Administration is considering a proposal that could force Medicare recipients to pay 10 percent of their hospital charges, up to $2,500, if they stay in the hospital longer than one day, Richard S. Schweiker, Secretary of Health and Human Services, said today.

title: MCLOUTH STEEL WINS PAY CUTS
description: Blue-collar employees of the struggling McLouth Steel Corporation have accepted pay concessions that will mean a $1.14 average hourly loss, a United Steelworkers of America official said.

title: North Carolina, Virginia in Clash of Top 2 Teams
description: The nation's top-two rated collegiate basketball teams are meeting for the second time this season Saturday, but this time only North Carolina is a repeat performer.

title: THE RACE IS NOT TO THE SWIFT. NOR IS THE LEASE
description: It was the second day of my search for a place to live in my new hometown, New York City. I was examining a one-bedroom apartment with ''loft'' (about three feet of airspace on stilts above the kitchen) that could be mine for only $1,350 a month, plus an agent's fee of about $2,500.

title: The City; 5th Man Sentenced In Officer's Killing
description: After being judge mentally competent, Leroy Williams was sentenced to 25 years t o life in prison for the murder of Police Officer RobertSorrentino.

title: THE POLISH AIRWAVES: PUBLIC ORDER DISCUSSED
description: Following are excerpts from domestic Polish radio and television broadcasts as transcribed and translated from the Polish and the Russian by the Foreign Broadcast Information Service, a United States Government agency:

title: Around the Nation; Maryland Lacks Funds To Give Out Free Cheese
description: Residents of Maryland, eager to receive more than 558,000 pounds of free cheese, were thwarted today because there was no money in the state budget to distribute the food, officials said.

title: Notes on People; Purcell Takes Office With a Public Works Vow
description: When he was sworn in yesterday for his second term as Nassau County Executive, Francis T. Purcell said that high among his priorities was a determination ''to make sure that Nassau County does not suffer the same decay that we see in New York City.''

title: FAKE JEWELRY: TRAPS TO AVOID
description: The woman given a watch marked Cartier for her birthday was delighted. But when it stopped running a couple of months later and she took it to the store she found that it was one of the 100,000 counterfeit Cartier watches that are being sold annually in the Western Hemisphere. Her husband had paid $100 for it and it seemed a great buy, since the real tank watches cost $650 to $2,300. Counterfeiters also fake the Cartier Santos watch, although it is more difficult to do. (A genuine one costs $1,050 to $6,000.) Sales in co unterfeit jewelry are booming, on the streets, in flyby-night s tores and even, said James Bikoff, vice president and general couns el for Cartier, at housewives' sales parties, similar tothe ones at w hich kitchen ware or cosmetics are sold.

title: U.S. DROPS RULE ON TAX PENALTY FOR RACIAL BIAS
description: The Reagan Administration, reversing an 11-year-old Federal policy, announced today that it would no longer deny tax-exempt status to private schools, colleges and certain other nonprofit institutions that practice racial discrimination.

title: THREE DECADES OF INDIAN APPROACHES TO PAKISTAN
description: To the Editor:

title: 3,000 FAMILIES IN CITY TO LOSE WELFARE FUNDS
description: About 3,000 New York City families have been told that they will lose their welfare benefits next Saturday because of cuts in Federal spending.

title: FOR THE RAILS, COAL AND PASSENGERS
description: To the Editor:

title: Your Money; I.R.A. Myths And Realities
description: WHO wouldn't like to become a millionaire? That's the fantasy being played on by banks and other financial institutions in the hope of luring customers into setting up tax-deferred retirement accounts, known as I.R.A's.

title: SUDAN CLOSES COLLEGES OVER RIOTS
description: The Sudan's four universities were ordered closed today because of recent student demonstrations and rioting over increases in the price of gasoline and sugar.

title: A UTILITY'S PROBLEM IN SELLING INSURANCE
description: Along with the Christmas mail this past season, 200,000 Maryland residents received a sales brochure for small amounts of life insurance - known in the trade as burial insurance, to cover one's final expenses.

title: Sports People; Bowa Trade in Works
description: The Philadelphia Phillies have decided to trade Larry Bowa, although a deal has not yet been completed, Bill Giles, the club president, said yesterday. According to Giles, the Phillies had three choices with the 12-year veteran: trade Bowa to a team of his choice; grant his request for a two-year extension at a substantial increase (in the $400,000-per-season area), or let him play the final year of his $250,000 contract and become a free agent.

title: LEGAL PANEL'S NEW YEAR RESOLUTION
description: Of all the Reagan Administration's efforts to bring to heel Federal agencies born in more liberal times, few have generated more confusion and conflict here than the lightning move on New Year's Eve to take control of the board of the Legal Services Corporation.

title: The City; Man, 63, Is Slain In Wife's Defense
description: A 63-year-old Queens man was shot and killed when he tried to stop two muggers from assaulting and robbing his wife and sister last night outside a Jackson Heights restaurant, the police said.

title: AN ACCORD ENDS DISPUTE ON WESTCHESTER SHERIFF
description: A yearlong political dispute ended today when County Executive Alfred B. DelBello withdrew charges of misconduct against the suspended Sheriff/Commissioner of Public Safety, Thomas J. Delaney. Under the agreement, Mr. Delaney is to resign.

title: Credit Markets; MONEY SUPPLY OFF $1.4 BILLION
description: The basic measure of the nation's money supply declined by a modest $1.4 billion in the week ended Dec. 30, the Federal Reserve System reported yesterday, reversing a similar upswing in the previous week.

title: Beverly Marshall Married
description: Beverly Marshall of Fort Lee, N.J., was married there yesterday to Roger C. Goring of Rye, N.Y. Mayor Nicholas Corbiscello performed the ceremony at the Fort Lee City Hall. Mr. Goring is a vice president of Saks Fifth Avenue and his bride is general manager of the store's Bergen County branch. Mrs. Goring is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Vincent Hudson of Grosse Pointe, Mich. Her previous marriage ended in divorce, as did the bridegroom's. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack F. Goring of New York.

title: OPTICAL COATING LABORATORY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Net loss...C-Net income is after $42,000 loss from discontinued operations

title: Notes on People; A New Chief of Staff for Mrs. Reagan
description: The appointment of James Rosebush as Nancy Reagan's chief of staff in charge of the First Lady's operations in the White House's East Wing was announced yesterday by the President.

title: Pincay Will Be Sidelined For Up to Three Weeks
description: The jockey Laffit Pincay Jr., who washurt in a spill at Santa Anita Wednesday, wil l be sidelined for up tothree weeks because of a back injury, it was announced today.

title: Ruth Vollmer, Sculptor, 80, Designed Window Displays
description: Ruth Vollmer, an abstract sculptor who used mathematics to arrive at geometrical forms, died Jan. 1 it her home at 25 Central Park West. She was about 80 years old.

title: The Region; A Casino Record
description: ATLANTIC CITY (AP) - A Staten Isl and woman won $150,000 at a slot machine at th e Claridge Hotel and Hi-Ho Casino Thursday night. The woman, Lorett a Calamela, a secretary in New York and the mother of four children , won at a $1 progressive slot machine. The sum is the largest amoun t the casino has paid out since opening last July, a casino spokes man said.

title: Around the Nation; Neighbors Say Officer Foiled Bid to Save Family
description: A white policeman at the scene of a fire that killed seven members of a black family kept neighbors from attempting to rescue them and made no effort to help them himself, some of the neighbors said.

title: Answers to Quiz
description: Questions appear on page 13. 1. It is a beefalo, a hybrid that is three-eighths buffalo and five-eighths a cattle breed such as Hereford or Charolais. Although it was touted as the meat of the future in the early 1970's, higher in protein and lower in fat and calories than conventional beef, demand for beefalo never caught on.

title: AMERICAN THRIFT SHOP CHIC IS SELLING WELL IN PARIS
description: In a shop on the Boulevard St.-Michel, Parisians root through a bin of secondhand Van Heusens going for 40 francs ($7). Down the street, gravy-stained ties with labels that say ''Bloomingdale's Men's Shop'' and ''Wittner's, Reading, Pa.'' are selling for 5 francs apiece.

title: Princeton 59, Yale 47
description: NEW HAVEN (AP) - Craig Robinson scored 24 points, and Rich Simkus added 20 for Princeton (5-6). Princeton went on a 10-1 spurt in the final minutes of the first half to take a 21-12 lead. Butch Graves scored 14 points and grabbed 5 rebounds for Yale (4-4).

title: REAGAN PROMOTES 2 AT STATE DEPT.
description: President Reagan named two career specialists in European affairs today to the second and third ranking positions in the State Department.

title: The Region; Bills Signed to Aid Atlantic City's Hall
description: ATLANTIC CITY (UPI) - Governor Byrne signed three bills Friday designed to pay for the renovation and expansion of Convention Hall. The signing came as officials in the casino-hotel industry threatened court action to block the measures, which will require casino-hotels and noncasino hotels to pay the aging structure's $3 million operating deficit.

title: JERSEY TROOPERS CIRCULATE PHOTO OF SUSPECT'S SON
description: The Superintendent of the New Jersey State Police, in a step that he conceded stretched the bounds of propriety, today released a photograph of the 9-year-old son of a man wanted in the killing of a state trooper on Dec. 21.

title: Truck Rule May Be Eased
description: The Reagan Administration, as part of its package of regulatory relief for the auto industry, proposed today that pollution rules for trucks be relaxed. The changes would save auto makers $450 million over five years, the Environmental Protection Agency said.

title: Sports People; Landmark of Longevity
description: Ray Meyer, the 68-year-old basketball coach at De Paul, has had enough experience with the news media to know that his 1,000th game as head basketball coach of the Blue Demons, to be played at home this afternoon against Dayton, will be ''a circus, and I guess I'll be the ringmaster.'' Only four men have coached more college basketball games than Meyer: Henry Iba, Adolph Rupp, Ed Diddle and Phog Allen. So what is the significance of his milestone? ''It really doesn't mean too much to me,'' Meyer said, ''except that I've had longevity.''

title: HARRY ROTHPEARL
description: Harry Rothpearl, a lumber merchant and champion of the Yiddish theater, died Thursday in a hospital in Miami.

title: CONTINUITY IS OBSERVED IN U.S. ANTITRUST POLICY
description: Perhaps the most extraordinary dimension to the Government's stunning disposition of its two biggest antitrust suits is that the actions represented no major departure from the policies of p revious administrations, several antitrust specialists said here tod ay.

title: MASSEY-FERGUSON-PERKINS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Qtr is after a $38.2 million exchange loss and $22 million of unusual costs and reorganization expense and the yr net loss is after $27.8 million exchange gain and $28.5 million expense...C-After $28.5 million exchange gain and $5.1 million of unusual costs and reorganization expenses in the qr; net los for the yr is after $76.8 million exchange loss and $28.5 milli expense

title: The U.N. Today; Jan. 9, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: International Oceanographic Com- mission's Working Committee for Global Investigations of Pollution in the Marine Environment - 10 A.M.

title: U.S. Order Bars Return Of Boy to Soviet Union
description: The Justice Department issued an order today to prevent the immediate removal from the United States of Walter Polovchak, a 14-year-old Ukrainian who wants to remain in this country.

title: News Analysis
description: The settlements by the Justice Department of two critical antitrust suits promise to accelerate the communications revolution in American and worldwide.

title: G.E., Mitsui Plan J oint Plastic Deal
description: The General Electric Company and two Mitsui Industrial Group companies have agreed to establish a joint venture in March to manufacture and market engineering plastic, the companies announced.

title: Brooks Happy With Rangers' Showing
description: Herb Brooks, the Rangers' rookie coach, in assessing the performance of his team at midseason, says, ''I'm happy, but I'm not satisfied.''

title: THEATER: D"URRENMATT'S 'PHYSICISTS' IS REVIVED
description: There have been political upheavals as well as scientific breakthroughs since Friedrich Durrenmatt's ''The Physicists'' was first produced on Broadway in 1964. However, the Swiss playwright's cynical view of mankind courting, and surrendering itself to, its own extinction remains no less valid or horrifying.

title: NEW LAYOFFS PUSH U.S. JOBLESS RATE TO 8.9% FROM 8.4%
description: Layoffs of 460,000 workers in December pushed the nation's unemployment rate from 8.4 percent of the labor force to 8.9 percent, the second highest monthly level since the beginning of World War II. The number of unemployed Americans climbed to a nearly 9.5 million.

title: Norwegian Train Fire Kills 4
description: Four people died early today in a fire aboard a sleeping car on an overnight train from Oslo to Stavanger. The police said a 60-year-old Norwegian, one of 17 passengers rescued from the burning car, admitted setting the blaze. All of the victims were Norwegians.

title: THE THWARTING OF DE-NAZIFICATION
description: Tens of thousands of Government documents, recently released in Washington and London, conclusively prove that, despite Presidential directives, Germany was not as de-Nazified after World War II as public opinion believed. Equally disconcerting, the documents also show that a disturbingly large number of German war criminals remained unprosecuted and unpunished by the Allies and settled down to comfortable lives in western Germany.

title: Panel Favors U.S. Gold Coin
description: A majority of the United States Gold Commission gave informal backing today to the minting of a gold coin but withheld its support for linking gold and the dollar.

title: AVANT: USING SOUND TO BE A BUFFER
description: No longer is an evening of electronic or computer-synthesized music likely to hound a listener out of his seat and into the subway hungering for a salutary blast of real, machine-made noise. These days the accent is on achieving stable and harmonious relationships in sound as a buffer, sometimes even as an alternative, to the sonic cataclysms and disintegration of bygone days.

title: SCHOOL VOLUNTEERS ARE BRIDGING A GAP
description: To the Editor:

title: EVANS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 28
FRASER MORTGAGE INVESTMENTS reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
2 Swim Marks Set By Miss Schneider
description: Petra Schneider of East Germany swam to world-best times in the 200-meter women's individual medley and the 800-meter freestyle events tonight in an international swimming meet.

title: Books of The Times; The Critic Reviewed
description: A MINGLED YARN: THE LIFE OF R.P. BLACKMUR. By Russell Fraser. Illustrated. 357 pages. Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $19.95.

title: State Loses an Appeal I n Case of Bull v. Auto
description: New York State is liable for injuries suffered by a man whose car collided with a bull on the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway in 1976, an appeals court ruled Thursday.

title: About New York; GRIM NOTES FROM UNDERGROUND, AT 42D AND 8TH
description: If there is any one thing that has become a metaphor for the degeneration of life in this city, it may be the subway system. And if there is any one part of that system that seems like the distillation of all of its menacing elements, it might be the stations around Times Square: the tunnels winding beneath the Port Authority Bus Terminal to the Seventh Avenue IRT lines, the bleak terminus of the Flushing line and the IND station that stretches from 40th to 44th Streets beneath Eighth Avenue -nearly a quarter mile of damp, dank, cold corridor, tiled like a bathroom, lit like a ghastly operating theater and peopled by eccentrics, psychotics, criminals and the average commuter.

title: Around the World; Two Kidnapped Priests Are Freed in Guatemala
description: Two priests kidnapped by armed men near here on Tuesday have been freed, the Vatican representative in Guatemala said today.

title: JOBLESSNESS RISES IN NEW YORK AREA
description: The job market in New York and New Jersey showed some weakness last month, as the unemployment rate rose in both states. New York City's rate, which dropped sharply in November, moved upward again in December, contrary to the pattern of recent years, when it has usually gone down in the final month of the year.

title: THE 7-YEAR CHRONOLOGY OF THE SUIT AGAINST BELL
description: Following is a chronology of the Federal Government's antitrust suit against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company:

title: News Summary; SATURDAY, JANUARY 9, 1982
description: International 17 Poles have been killed since martial law was declared Dec. 13, more than dou ble the number of deaths previously reported by the military rule rs. The new official total was included in a comprehensive report on the events in Poland in the last month that was presented to a parliamentary commission. The report said that eight deaths occurred at the Wujek coal mine and nine in Gdansk. (Page 1, Colu mn 1. ) Spain will reopen its Gibraltar border April 20, the same day Spain and Britain open talks on the peninsula, which Britain captured in 1704 in the War of the Spanish Succession. Franco closed the border in 1969. The announcement followed a meeting in London between Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and Prime Minister Leopoldo Calvo Sotelo. (3:4-6.)

title: Index; International
description: France sees sale to Nicaragua reducing dependency on Soviet 2 The Sudan closes its four universities because of student riots 2 Around the World 4 Three U.N. members offer compromise on Israeli sanctions 4 Once again, the Jews are a scapegoat in Poland 6 Polsih airwaves: public order discussed 7 Government/Politics Weinberger explains shift on draft registration 13 Court narrows grounds for challenging tax assessments 28 Washington Talk Briefing 10 New Year's resolution of the Legal Services board 10 General Around the Nation 8 Policeman says suspect car stopped on Atlanta bridge 8 Relatives of mud slide victims keep a hopeful vigil 8 Supreme Court asked to reverse ruling on rights amendment 13 Unemployment rate rises in New York and New Jersey 13 Murder trial of Jack Abbott opens in Manhattan 28 Photo issued of son of suspect in trooper's slaying 29 Infant mortality rate drops in the city 29 Transit performance was of mixed quality in October 29 Health/Science Medicare recipients may have to pay 10 percent of hospital costs 11 New tests produce evidence that early man ate a balanced diet 11 Scientists warned on research secrecy 11 Health officials predict increase in leprosy cases 26 Arts/Entertainment Satoru Shimazaki performs Isadora Duncan solo 13 Richard Salomon thanks library with $1.2 million 15 City Ballet takes steps in right direction 15 N.A.A.C.P. threatens protest over jobs in film industry 15 Durrenmatt's ''The Physicists'' is revived 16 ''A Mingled Yarn: The Life of R.P. Blackmur'' is reviewed 18 Energy Unfinished nuclear power plants face more obstacles 9 City prepares to respond to heat complaints within 24 hours 23 Style Consumer Saturday: Advocacy units seek new funds 12 Fake jewelry: Traps to avoid 12 American thrift shop chic is sell- ing well in Paris 12 Some curmudgeonly but beguil- ing views on food 12 Sports Nets defeat Cavs, 110-100 19 Sterling, Clippers' owner, fined $10,000 by N.B.A. 19 Mets Get Veryzer from Indians for Searage 19 Pardee is assisting Chargers' playoff drive 19 George Vecsey on Bobby Orr's children's crusade 19 Andrea Jaeger and Pam Shriver upset in Washington tennis 20 Petra Schneider sets world best in 800-meter swim event 21 Celtics beat 76ers, 96-90 21 Holy Cross tops Manhattan 21 Solomon, 49er receiver, puts his quarterback dream aside 21 Brooks happy, but not satisfied, with Rangers so far 22 Features/Notes Saturday News Quiz 13 Going Out Guide 17 Sports People 20 About New York 27 23 Man in the News: Charles L. Brown, chairman of A.T. & T. 34 Man in the News: John Opel, chief officer of I.B.M. 34 Man in the News: Williams Bax- ter of Justice Department 34 Notes on People 51 News Analysis Leonard Silk looks at the future of telecommunications 1 Bernard Gwertzman on the crackdown in Poland 6 John F. Burns assesses Soviet ties with Western Europe 6 E.J. Dionne Jr. on the difficult choices facing Albany 28 Editorials/Letters/Op-Ed Editorials 24

title: HEALTH OFFICIALS PREDEICT RISE IN LEPROSY CASES
description: The unexpectedly widespread resistance to the main drug used to treat leprosy will probably lead to an increase in the disease throughout the world, according to specialists in communicable diseases.

title: FLYERS' CLARKE LAMENTS 'NEW' GAME
description: If it weren't for hockey duels like the Islander-Philadelphia Flyer series, Bobby Clarke might have decided to hang up his skates seasons ago. Clarke, the Flyers' 32-year-old center and assistant coach, claims the game has changed, and he says the thinking player has been left behind.

title: Holy Cross Wins, 58-53
description: Chris Logan scored 15 points and grabbed 9 rebounds tonight as Holy Cross beat Manhattan, 58-53, in the first round of the Worcester County tournament.

title: RISE IN LOCAL RATES MAY COME RAPIDLY
description: Consumers could face a rapid increase in local telephone rates - possibly a doubling in certain parts of the country - and a decline in long-distance charges as a result of the Government's antitrust settlement with the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

title: NEW TESTING ON FOSSIL REMAINS INDICATES PREHISTORIC MAN ATE BALANCED DIET
description: A rich new understanding of the evolution of the human diet is beginning to emerge as a result of sophisticated chemical and microscopic tests on the fossil remains of prehistoric humans.

title: Dome Energy Gets $1.7 Billion Loan
description: Dome Energy Ltd., a wholly owned subsidiary of Dome Petroleum Ltd., said it had signed a $1.7 billion secured-loan agreement with 25 international banks led by a Citicorp subsidiary. It is the largest production loan ever granted to a Canadian borrower.

title: LIFE-SUSTAINING ETHICS STUDIED
description: A Presidential commission on ethical problems in m edicine today approved preliminary guidelines that say it is morally acceptable in rare cases to stop extraordinary treatment of permanently unconscious patients.

title: The City; More Buses Fitted For Wheelchairs
description: The Transit Authority announced that it would add its wheelchairlift service on 10 more routes served by the new General Motors buses in Manhattan and Brooklyn, beginning at 12:01 A.M. Monday.

title: WHY LA GUARDIA PUT AN END TO ORGAN GRINDING
description: To the Editor:

title: THE TRAUMA IN A TAKEOVER
description: As the United States Steel Corporation went about completing its acquisition of the Marathon Oil Company, Marathon's 16,000 employees today began receiving assurances that they need not fear any changes that the new order might bring.

title: 27 Die in Colombia Mudslide
description: The death toll from a mudslide in western Colombia Thursday rose to 27 today after rescue workers recovered 23 bodies and said four more were buried under mud caused by heavy rains.

title: The Region; Defense Rests In Purolator Case
description: Lawyers for the two defendants in the Purolator robbery-murder trial rested their cases after calling only five witnesses to rebut prosecution evidence the judge called ''overwhelming.''

title: THE 'DOOMSDAY PLANE'--NUCLEAR CHIC?
description: A couple of months ago, the newspapers carried stories about President Reagan's first flight in the ''doomsday plane,'' the airplane he would use aloft if there were a nuclear confrontation.

title: Hawks 90, Bucks 88
description: MILWAUKEE (AP) - Dan Roundfield was credited with the winning ba sket when Milwaukee's Harvey Catchings tipped an Atlanta inbounds pa ss into the Hawks' basket. The play occurred after Atlanta's Wayne (T ree) Rollins rebounded a missed shot by the Bucks' Sidney Moncrief,an d the Hawks called time out with two seconds to play and the score ti ed at 88-88.

title: The City; 300 at Hospital Get Hepatitis Shots
description: More than 300 people have been inoculated with gamma globulin to prevent the spread of infectious hepatitis at the City Hospital Center in Elmhurst, Queens, health officials said.

title: VAN BREDA KOLFF, WALKER STAR AS NETS DEFEAT CAVS
description: The New Jersey Nets rediscovered Clarence (Foots) Walker and Jan van Breda Kolff tonight in scoring a 110-100 victory over the Cleveland Cavaliers at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: FOR BELL, THE END OF A LEGACY: CONCEPT OF UNIVERSAL SERVICE
description: Ma Bell, if the mythical lady ever truly existed, wouldn't know what to make of it. For more than a century, Bell's basic mission has been to extend ''P.O.T.'' - plain old telephone service - to every American who wanted it, at a price almost every American could afford.

title: Fordham 100, Tufts 57
description: Fordham, playing at home, took a 25-0 lead and was ahead by as many as 51 points in the second half.

title: ATLANTA OFFICER SAYS SUSPECT CAR HALTED ON BRIDGE
description: A 27-year-old rookie policeman offered unexpectedly strong testimony today indicating that Wayne B. Williams's car was stopped on a bridge above the spot in the Chattahoochee River where a loud splash was heard about 60 hours before a body floated to the surface downstream.

title: DEALER IN ROTHKO CASE EXPECTED TO SURRENDER
description: Frank Lloyd, the art dealer and owner of the Marlborough Gallery who was indicted in 1977 for tampering with evidence in the Mark Rothko trial that ended in 1974, will give himself up Monday morning to the New York County District Attorney to answer the indictment.

title: BALLET: SATORU SHIMAZAKI
description: There was a full house Thursday at the Theater at St. Peter's Church, when Satoru Shimazaki performed a program of dances by himself, Michio Ito and Isadora Duncan. It's not that often that male dancers take on a Duncan solo. And Mr. Shimazaki's performances of Miss Duncan's ''Mother'' and ''Revolutionary,'' taught to him by Sylvia Gold and Gemze de Lappe, were never uninteresting, and often they were provocative. But they remained only that.

title: Saturday News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 51.

title: ATOMIC PLANT HURT BY COURT DECISION
description: Nuclear energy officials and opponents of nuclear power agreed today that a Federal court ruling would probably delay the startup of Three Mile Island Unit 1 for months and could have incalculable effects on the whole industry.

title: DEATH RATE FOR INFANTS CONTINUES TO DECLINE IN CITY
description: For the eighth consecutive year, the infant mortality rate in New York City has declined slightly, the city's Department of Health announced yesterday. There were 1,700 deaths of babies less than a year old in 1981, a rate of 15.7 deaths for each 1,000 live births.

title: News Analysis
description: After a number of propaganda at tacks in recent days on the a ttitude of Western European nations to events in Poland,the Soviet Un ion appears to have lost much of its earlier confidence that the Poli sh crackdown could be carried through without significant d amage to its ties with the European nations.

title: 15 PERSONS SURROUNDING BRINK'S CASE
description: Following are the 15 persons who have been identified by law enforcement authorities as suspects, or individuals linked to suspects, in the Brink's armored-car robbery in Rockland County and in related activities attributed to the Weather Underground and several black separatist organizations.

title: Bridge:; 'A Little Bit of Luck' Helps, Even at the Highest Levels
description: At crucial moments bridge players often ask, like Alfred Doolittle, who appeared recently on the Broadway stage, for ''a little bit of luck.'' But their prayers are not often answered in quite such a spectacular fashion as they were on the diagramed deal, from the recent Reisinger board-a-match team championship at the Fall Nationals in San Francisco.

title: 8.6% Jobless in Canada
description: Nearly one million people were out of work in Canada last month as the rising unemployment rate tied the record of 8.6 percent, the Government reported today.

title: TWO SETTLEMENTS MAY WIDEN THE PRESSURES ON COMPETITION
description: A settlement of the antitrust suit against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and the end of the Government's suit against the International Business Machines Corporation are likely to dramatically change the competitive situation in the rapidly merging industries of computers and telecommunications, according to industry officials and executives.

title: Louisiana Tech Women Win 47th Straight Game
description: Louisiana Tech, the nation's topranked women's basketball team, won its 47th straight game by topping No.2 South Carolina, 71-58, tonight.

title: OPPONENTS OF ATOM POWER PLANTS IN NORTHWEST SEEM TO BE WINNING
description: A plan to temporarily shelve two nuclear reactor projects in Washington State appears to be falling apart because of opposition in some of the public-power districts that took part in financing them, officials said today.

title: Dutch Joblessness Up
description: Provisional unadjusted unemployment in the Netherlands rose 6.8 percent in December, to a postwar record of 473,700, from 443,200 in November. The rat e was up 46.9 percent from 322,400 in December 1980, according to D eputy Prime Minister Joop M. den Uyl, the Minister of Social Affai rs. Mr. den Uyl repeated his earlier expectation that unemplo yment is likely to reach500,000 by the end of February.

title: WHY BAXTER DROPPED THE I.B.M. SUIT
description: William F. Baxter, the Assistant Attorney General in charge of the antitrust division, said today that the Government's decision to drop its 13-year-old antitrust suit against the International Business Machines Corporation was ''the only sensible thing to do'' and that the case against the computer giant was based on ''flimsy'' evidence.

title: LONG VIGIL FOR MUD SLIDES' SURVIVORS
description: For the relatives and friends gathered here, the main task now is to keep hope from sliding away like the cascading mud that brought death and destruction to this mountain village in northern California. The death toll in Santa Cruz County from th e mud slides that followed this week's torrrential rains has ri sen to 11, according to the county sheriff's department. The worst de struction occurred in this community of 5,000 people perched in the redwood forests of the Santa Cruz Mountains, south of San Francisco.

title: Sports of The Times; Orr's Children's Crusade
description: BOBBY ORR was never bashful about taking a shot. He would rampage up the ice and fire a slap shot as soon as he thought it was appropriate. He was a defender who loved to go on the offensive.

title: NOW ASKS HIGH COURT TO REVERSE IDAHO JUDGE'S EQUAL RIGHTS RULING
description: With the Reagan Administration's legal position still in doubt, the National Organization for Women filed its brief with the Supreme Court today requesting a speedy reversal of a lower court's decision on the ratification of the proposed Federal equal rights amendment.

title: Around the Nation; Recurrence of TB Linked To Inadequate Treatment
description: Inadequate drug treatment is the main cause of recurrence of tuberculosis, officials at the national Centers for Disease Contr ol reported today.

title: Robert A. Dreyer Dead at 65; Former Metromedia Counsel
description: Robert A. Dreyer, the general counsel, secretary and a vice president of Metromedia Inc. from 1955 to 1969, died yesterday at Overlook Hospital in Summit, N.J., after a heart attack. He was 65 years old and lived in Short Hills, N.J.

title: Around the World; U.S. Declines Comment On Accusation in Pravda
description: The United States Embassy declined to comment today on the Soviet press accusation that a large group of American spies had been working under the guise of diplomats in Moscow.

title: Teledyne Files Harvester Plan
description: Teledyne Inc. disclosed that it planned to raise its stake in the financially ailing International Harvester Company to more than 15 percent.

title: Around the World; Beirut Clashes Continue For a Third Day
description: Fighting between rival armed groups continued for a third day today in the Moslem section of Beirut despite the efforts of reinforced units of Syrian peacekeeping troops to end the clashes.

title: Notes on People; Singer to Assume a Past Role for Sons' Weddings
description: Back in the United States after four months of starring in ''Man of La Mancha'' in Vienna, the baritone Steven Kimbrough will return to work tomorrow, not as a singer, but in his former occupation. Mr. Kimbrou gh, a Princeton Theological Seminary graduate and an ordained mini ster, was pastor of St. Paul's United Methodist Church in Bay Head, N.J., from 1962 to 1966.

title: TO POLAND
description: Poland, Christ-statue struck by lightning, around your blackening wounds circles the J uly sunlight, your bones constantly kissed by flies.I suffe r for you as if I too were lying bludg eoned in some stinking shed gazing at a single carnation mirrored in watery soup.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rate payable by savings institutions.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues.

title:
Patents;
Vaccine Is Developed To Protect Fish
description: Researchers in microbiology at the University of Georgia in Athens have developed a vaccine for the protection of trout, salmon, catfish, carp and other fish against ''white spot disease.'' Patent 4,309,416, granted this week, says the vaccine can be readily produced on a big enough scale for commercial operations.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We are attempting to protect the independence of all private tax-exempt organizations - many of which may follow practices and adhere to principles with which we disagree.'' -Richard McNamar, Deputy Treasury Secretary, on ex emptions for racially discriminatory schools. (10: 6.)

title: Maine Senator to Run in '82
description: Senator George J. Mitchell, Democrat of Maine, formally announced his candidacy for election Thursday by criticizing President Reagan's economic policies and accusing the President of leading the nation into a recession.

title: The Region; Man Posts Reward Of $5,000 in Theft
description: ROCHESTER (AP) - The owner of a gas station is offering a $5,000 reward for the capture of three men who stole a 300-pound safe containing $300,000 in cash from his home.

title: A NEW YORK CITY LAW IGNORANT OF THE DEAF
description: To the Editor:

title:
Patents;
New Way Of Making Gold Films
description: WASHINGTON A PROCESS for producing gold films was patented this week for Bell Telephone Laboratories, Murray Hill, N.J. Gold films are used in various ways, in electronic circuitry, jewelry and optical devices, among others. Patent 4,309,460 was granted LeGrand G. Van Uitert, Shobha Singh and George J. Zydzik of the Bell staff.

title: Bulls 119, Lakers 113
description: CHICAGO (AP) - Artis Gilmore scored a season-high 31 points, and Ronnie Lester added 22 for Chicago, which won its third straight.

title: HAIG AND WEINBERGER EXPRESS CONCERN ON FRENCH AID TO NICARAGUA
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. and Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger expressed disappointment and concern today over a decision by France to sell some military equipment to Nicaragua.

title: AUTO UNION AGREES TO TALKS ON FORD AND G.M. DEMANDS
description: The United Automobile Workers agreed today to begin negotiations with the General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company next week in a move that could lead to reductions in wages and benefits, possibly in return for job guarantees.

title: UNICOA CORP reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-After gains on sale of investments of $1 million in the latest yr and $5.7 million for the earlier period

title: DONORS TO THE NEEDIEST VOICE GRATITUDE FOR FAMILIES' LOVE
description: In an expression of gratitude often voiced in messages explaining gifts to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, Kathy and Bob Mannis of Bronxville, N.Y., wrote in a note accompanying their check for

title: 3 U.N. MEMBERS PROPOSE PLAN ON ISRAELI SANCTIONS
description: Japan, Spa in and Ireland are draftinga compromise resolution that proposes voluntary sanctions against Israel for an nexing the Golan Heights, Western diplomats said today.

title: CARE Head, on Warsaw Trip, Gets Message for Reagan
description: The executive director of the CARE relief agency, returning from a visit to Poland, said here tonight that he was carrying a message from Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Polish leader, to President Reagan.

title: WARSAW RULERS PUT TOLL OF DEAD AT 17, DOUBLE EARLIER TOTAL
description: Poland's military Government announced today that 17 people have died since the imposition of martial law, according to the Warsaw radio. The figure is more than double the number of deaths previously disclosed by the Government.

title: MUSIC: DE PEYER RECITAL
description: We could have judged Gervase de Peyer Thursday night almost by the company he kept. This program of clarinet music at Alice Tully Hall was rich in both past and present, but it benefited most from the youthful enthusiasm of Christopher O'Riley at the piano and the elegant cello playing of Tsuyoshi Tsutsumi.

title: GARTH REEVES Jr.
description: Garth Reeves Jr., managing editor of The Miami Times, a black-oriente d newspaper, died of cancer Thursday in Cedars of Lebanon Ho spital.

title: 2 MEN AND MAID CHARGED WITH MURDER OF HER EMPLOYER, 82, ON L.I.
description: A maid and two men were arrested to day and charged with murdering the maid's 82-year-old employer herela st October, according to the Nassau County police.

title: 125th St. Parkway Exit Shut
description: W The southbound exit ramp of the Henry Hudson Parkway at 125th Street has been closed to traffic for reconstruction that is expec tedto take nine months. Southbound motorists who normally leave the parkway at 125th Street are advised by the State Department of Transportation to use the 158th Street exit and to follow detour signs to 125th Street.

title: Patents
description: A coin grader for use by collectors who are not expert numismatists was patented this week by Edmund J. Sobresky Sr. of Pottstown, Pa., himself an enthusiastic collector.

title: Walter J. Stoessel Jr.
description: Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs ... A 61-year-old diplomat who joined the Foreign Service after graduation from college in 1941 ... Served as Ambassador to Poland from 1968 to 1972 and to the Soviet Union from 1973 to 1976 ... Was named by the Carter Administration to be Ambassador to West Germany, where he remained until January 1981, when President Reagan named him to the No. 3 State Department post ... His career interest has been the Soviet Union, and he mastered the Russian language ... A former aide called him ''one of our top pros, deceptive in appearance - so gentle and polite - but with a pretty hard core.'' Lawrence S. Eagleburger

title: END OF ACTION ON I.B.M. FOLLOWS EROSION OF ITS DOMINANT POSITION
description: The Justice Department announced yesterday that it had decided to drop an antitrust suit that it started almost 13 years ago in an effort to dismember the International Business Machines Corporation.

title: Stadler, Carding 64-129, Opens a 4-Stroke Lead
description: Craig Stadler made four consecutive birdies on the way to a six-under-par 64 today to open a four-stroke lead after the second round of the $300,000 Tucson Open, the season's first event on the pro golf tour.

title: Robert Johnson, 61, Broadway Tap Dancer
description: Robert (Bobby) Johnson, a tap dancer in vaudeville and on the musical-comedy stage, died of a cardiac arrest Sunday while on his way to St. Vincent's Hospital for dialysis treatment. He lived in Manhattan and would have been 61 years old Jan. 21.

title: U.S. Studying M uir Practices
description: The Justice Department said yesterday that its New York office had started a criminal investigation into the way stocks were sold and traded at John Muir & Company, a Wall Street securities firm that went bankrupt last August.

title: M.T.A. REPORTS SERVICE IS BETTER ON CITY'S BUSES
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority yesterday gave itself a mixed grade for its performance in October as the agency released its second monthly progress report on subway, bus and railroad operations.

title: PAN AM PLANS TO SHIFT ACCOUNT TO WELLS, RICH
description: Pan American World Airways said yesterday that it would switch its $50 million worldwide advertising account to Wells, Rich, Greene Inc. The announcement raised a question about whether Wells, Rich would be able to retain Continental Air Lines' $14.9 million account, whichit won last S eptember.

title: EUROPEAN STEEL TALKS BREAK OFF
description: Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige said today that efforts to reach an agreement over steel imports with the European Common Market had broken down and that steel companies would shortly file sweeping complaints charging unfair trade practices by European and other foreign steelmakers.

title: France-Egypt Talks
description: Framatome of the Creusot-Loire Group is negotiating to sell Egypt two commercial nuclear power plants, Industry Ministry sources said here today. France's Minister in charge of industry, Edmond Herve, will visit Egypt between Jan. 17 and Jan. 21 and agreement on the sale could be reached soon, the sources said. Last year, Egypt signed a cooperation pact with France allowing for the supply of two French power plants worth some 5 billion francs, or about $870.5 million, each and with a total capacity of up to 2,000 megawatts.

title: Notes on People; Princess of Wales Returning to the Public Eye
