description: The Princess of Wales has apparently got over her bouts with morning sickness and intends to carry out her public engagements through March, which will be the sixth month of her pregnancy.

title: LIBRARY IS RICHER FOR IT
description: They gave Richard Salomon a 70th birthday party Thursday in the Astor Hall Rotunda at the New York Public Library, two days before his actual birthday, and the only surprise of the evening was pulled off by the birthday fellow himself.

title: China Consumer Goods
description: Prices of a wide range of Chinese consumer goods, including watches, televisions and transistor radios, are being reduced by up to 20 percent, the New China News Agency said today. The price of several brands of small black-andwhite televisions will drop to $220 from $240, and ''Shanghai'' brand watches will be cut to $50 from $70, it added. Theprice of Chinesemade polyester fabric will also be reduced by 10 percent to 15 percent on Jan. 15, the news agency said.

title: NO REVERSE RACISM
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW ART FOR STATE BUILDINGS
description: NEWARK ART commissioned by New Jersey for use in new state buildings is currently on view in the Robeson Gallery at Rutgers-Newark. Sponsored by the State Council on the Arts in cooperation with Rutgers-Newark, the display, which will continue through Jan. 29, represents 15 artists commissioned to produce work under the Public Buildings Arts Inclusion Act of 1978.

title: GRADUATE EDUCATION: A PLAGUE OF PROBLEMS
description: AFTER nine years as assistant professor of comparative literature at Columbia University, Sarah B. is seeking another position, having been turned down for tenure long ago. Of the 35 applications she had sent to schools that advertised openings, three had resulted in interviews. These, moreover, were for assistant professorships and not at the associate-professor level that she felt her experience and qualifications merited. ''At this level,'' said Sarah, who requested anonymity because of her situation, ''it is very hard to stay in the profession.''

title: PITFALLS SEEN IN CONSERVATION EASEMENTS
description: To the Editor:

title: DEMAND FOR HOME HEATING OIL OFF 30%
description: DELIVERIES of home heating oil in Nassau and Suffolk Counties have declined as much as 30 percent over the last two heating seasons, according to retail dealers and spokesmen for the industry. One result is that supplies of home heating oil are high as the 1982 heating season gets under way.

title: Work Bees
description: To the Editor:

title: HARRISON AIDES 'ACTORS CHURCH' BENEFIT
description: Ever since it was the scene of Rex Harrison's wedding three years ago this month - one of 100,000 marriages in its 131-year history - the Little Church Around the Corner, less well-known as the Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration, has had the 73-year-old British actor as a parishioner and lay reader.

title: CHICAGO'S EARLY FOCUS ON LEARNING PROBLEMS
description: CHICAGO LINDA PARK discovered that her 4-year-old daughter, Lori, had suffered a hearing loss that was affecting her ability to learn to speak. Diane Davis wanted her son, Antoine, in a school environment before he entered kindergarten.Debra Nolan wanted to learn activities she could do at home with her preschool er, Travis, to reinforce his language and motor skills. All three p arents enrolled their children in a free program for preschoolers -Project EARLY (Early Assessment and Remediation Laboratory) - sponsored by the Chicago Board of Education.

title: Laura Ann Smith Is Bride
description: Laura Ann Smith, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Smith of Commack, L.I., was married yesterday to Michael Basil Sisak 3d of Cold Spring Hills, L.I., son of the Very Rev. Michael B. Sisak of Ambler, Pa. The Rev. Daniel Bitsko performed the ceremony at the Byzantine Catholic Church of the Resurrection in Smithtown, L.I. The bride is a bookkeeper with Jaco Electronics in Hauppauge, L.I. Mr. Sisak is a copy editor in the sports department of The New York Times. His father is a retired priest in the Byzantine Catholic Diocese of Passaic, N.J.

title: Surviving The Recession; Surviving Th e Recession
description: THE steep recession, which battered the American economy in the final months of the old year, poses the greatest problem for business in the new. And the recession also poses the greatest domestic challenge to President Reagan who, having led the nation into this slump, to his Administration's proclaimed surprise, now hopes to lead it out without reviving inflation or sending interest rates skyward again.

title: PUTTING THE RAIL LINES BACK ON THE RIGHT TRACK
description: WHEN it comes to transportation, New Jersey is the ''California of the East.'' Having trouble getting from here to there? Build a road and, if you're a good New Jerseyan, paint the divider islands green.

title: Television Week
description: Streep as Alice When Elizabeth Swados set ''Alice in Wonderland'' and ''Through the Looking Glass'' to music in ''Alice in Concert,'' presented at the Public Theater a year ago, she was fortunate to have Meryl Streep singing the title role. Miss Streep won high praise for her performance, while the production received mixed to negative reviews. Now titled ''Alice at the Palace,'' it has been adapted for television and will be broadcast on NBC on Saturday at 8 P.M.

title: A WEDDING STIRS HOMETOWN MEMORIES
description: THE golden girl of Greenwich has married, and, but for the sighs of would-be suitors, local joy was just short of absolute. Residents in the hometown of the Olympic gold medalist Dorothy Hamill only wish she had chosen Greenwich rather than Beverly Hills, Calif., as the setting for her wedding two days ago to Dean Paul Martin, a union some here likened to the wedding of Prince Charles and Lady Diana.

title: CHANGED STYLE EVIDENT AS BROWN PLANS FOR LAST YEAR AS CALIFORNIA GOVERNOR
description: Subtle changes in mood and behavior were evident this week as Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. delivered his final State of the State message to the Legislature and disclosed his last budget proposals at the opening of his final year in office.

title: NATURE'S FACTS TURNED INTO FANTASIES
description: PORT WASHINGTON MUCH of the landscape photography we see these days is beautiful in subject matter, beautiful an composition and beautiful in mood. It is technically proficient and professional in approach. But it is boring. The principal reason for its tedium is that it all looks alike. It is without character and expressive individuality. It is, in effect, anonymous.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day yester- day incorrectly stated the number of shares the American Telephone and Telegraph Company has outstanding. The correct number is 755 million.

title: OPPOSITION IN INDIA TRYING TO REVIVE COALITION
description: The fragmented and bickering non-Communist opposition parties have taken the first tentative steps toward restoring a cohesive coalition such as the one they formed to drive Prime Minister Indira Gandhi out of office in 1977.

title:
Long Island Guide;
RUMANIAN SWANS
description: Rumania has a national classic ballet company - Ballet Fantasio - and has sent the troupe of young artists, aged 18 to 23, on its first tour of the United States. This week is the Island's chance to see the company, which, under the direction of Oleg Danovski, combines training in the classical Russian style with the dynamics of contemporary dance, in action.

title: By Sports of The Times; Bill Walsh's Quarterback
description: O F the four quarterbacks in today's conference championship games that will determine the Super Bowl XVI matchup, three have been developed by Bill Walsh, the coach of the San Francisco 49ers -his own Joe Montana as well as Ken Anderson of the Cincinnati Bengals and Dan Fouts of the San Diego Chargers.

title: THERE IS NOTHING TREASONOUS ABOUT SOLIDARITY
description: To the Editor:

title: Ballet School's Benefit Aided by Bank's Gift
description: The Bank of America has become the largest corporate benefactor of the New York City Ballet-affiliated School of American Ballet, with a contribution of $49,250 for the school's fourth benefit Jan. 21 at the New York State Theater.

title: ARTS GROUPS SEE NO FALLOUT IN CENTER'S DEMISE
description: THE Harry Chapin Center for the Performing Arts shut its doors last week, but the rest of the arts on Long Island are alive. If they are not exactly prosperous, they are well enough to survive, their leaders insist.Although reeling from the suddenness of the move to dissolve the ce nter, which for most of its life was known as the Performing Arts Fo undation, the heads of the other major cultural organizations on th e Island were quick to say that what happened to the pioneering pl ayhouse will have little or no impact on their activities.

title: Beth Bratches Is Married To David Farrar Conley
description: Beth Sharon Bratches, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Bratches of Rye, N.Y., was married at Christ's Episcopal Church there yesterday to David Farrar Conley, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Conley of Camillus, N.Y. The Rev. Edward Johnston performed the ceremony.

title: Volatile Rates Cause Basic Credit Shifts
description: AFTER two years of extraordinary fluctuations in interest rates, the 1982 credit markets are viewed as a treacherous arena where a revived economy will pull rates up as slower inflation pulls them down.

title: Other World Events; Dozier 'Trial' Begins
description: The Italian police dragnet for the Red Brigades kidnappers of Brig. Gen. James L. Dozier snared several more suspected members of the terrorist group last week, but still no sign of General Dozier. Anonymous telephone calls reporting variously that the senior NATO officer's body could be found in a secluded spot on Italy's Adriatic coast or in a small lake near Pisa turned out to be hoaxes.

title: Transactions
description: BASKETBALL

title: ...BEATEN BY COMPUTER CHESS
description: CHRISTMAS confirmed my worst fears. I had lost my husband to computer chess. For two years I had put off buying, ''the only game I really want.'' It wasn't the $90 for a game that I don't even understand. It wasn't the thought of playing second fiddle to a computer. It was having to watch my husband debilitated by that insidious contest: man versus machine.

title: U.S. WON'T LET PEKING DETER TAIWAN JET SALE
description: The Reagan Administration, in its planning for the sale of fighter planes to Taiwan, will not be deterred by Chinese protests against last month's United States arms sales to Taiwan, according to senior Administration officials.

title: Preppies From Abroad
description: I commend headmasters such as Dr. Joseph Curry of the Cushing Academy for making their schools available to foreign students (''Preppies from Abroad,'' by Andree Brooks, Nov. 22).

title: 'Poets at the Public' Will Begin Tomorrow
description: Language and noise will be featured during the first two ''Poets at the Public'' programs for this year. Tomorrow, writers who explore the limits of language and are called ''language'' writers will read from their recent works.

title: SPEAKING WITH..UH..CONFIDENCE
description: IT was the last session of ''Speaking With Confidence,'' an eightweek course offered by New York University's School of Continuing Education and Extension Services. Each student in Elayne Snyder's class delivered a three-minute talk.

title: PICKING A TOT'S 'HOME AWAY FROM HOME'
description: FOR Kaye Unger Pitman, a working mother, there were several concerns when she started looking for child care for Sam, her 21-monthold son: good instruction, individual care, being with other children and somewhere that would give him the feeling that he ''has his own place to go.'' Mrs. Pitman, a fashion designer, is among a growing group of working women who have young children in need of care outside the home. Nationwide, there are about seven million children under 6 whose mothers work.

title: Fashion
description: MAKING A SPLASH It's time for floating thoughts, time to think about the swim of things. The new bathing suits are sleek and simple, as designers continue to improve upon the maillots in their resort wear. Many are high-cut, giving the illusion of particularly long legs. Colors are sharp, bright, clean -w ith an emphasis on bla cks, reds and whites. And the suits are just as comfortable for swi mming laps as they are for lolling on the beach.

title: Food; A FLING WITH SCOTLAND'S SOUP
description: Of an array of impressive foods sampled during a recent visit, the soups - particularly one made with cheese - were the most memorable.

title: MISS HOLTZMAN MOVES TO INSURE FAIR TRIAL TACTICS
description: Elizabeth Holtzman, who took over last week as Brooklyn District Attorney, has moved to assure the public that her prosecutors will be fair in their trial tactics and to assure her prosecutors that she is concerned about their welfare.

title: The World in Summary; New Broom, Old Straw in Ghana
description: The last time Jerry J. Rawlings seized power in Ghana, in 1979, he slashed prices and plowed under profiteers' food stalls - enormously popular gestures for consumers but ones which gave farmers little incentive to produce more. The stalls and shelves were soon emptied but Mr. Rawlings was not around to take the blame, having surrendered power to the elected civilian Government of Hilla Limann after only 112 days.

title: N. CAROLINA TOPS VIRGINIA AND REMAINS UNDEFEATED
description: North Carolina's Tar Heels did not beat Ralph Sampson this afternoon. They outnumbered him. Sampson, Virginia's 7-foot-4-inch junior center, scored from inside and out, above the basket and below, with his injured right hand and his left. He played one of the greatest games of his career, scoring 30 points and getting 19 rebounds.

title: NEW JERSEY
description: TRENTON ECONOMIC planners and forecasters are stressing that hightechnology industries are the best infusion for New Jersey's eroding manufacturing sector. Pointing to the strong base in Bell Labs and companies in the Princeton area, they say that future growth is most promising in electronic and communications equipment, as well as in computers.

title: No Headline
description: Lucinda Franks's article was enlightening, but I was disturbed by her concluding comments. I am angered not because I am ''young,'' butbecause I treasure humanistic ideals - something mature individuals can strive to achieve.

title:
Art;
THE MANY LEGACIES OF JOSEF ALBERS
description: MONTCLAIR SOME painters make good artists and some make good teachers, but very few make both good artists and good teachers. An exception was Josef Albers, who was good not only at both painting and teaching but also of such an excellence that he won international acclaim. His experimentations with color in a square format have been widely celebrated for their inventive originality, and the lessons that Albers taught about color and form are seen today as invaluable touchstones in the pedagogy of art.

title: ANECDOTES WITH PUNCH
description: ONLY THE RING WAS SQUARE By Teddy Brenner as Told to Barney Nagler. 164 pp. Englewood Cliffs, N.J.: Prentice-Hall. $10.95. By PETER ANDREWS

title: STAGE: 'STREET SCENES' AT THE EQUITY LIBRARY
description: In the 35 years since Kurt Weill wrote his closest approach to an American operatic score for ''Street Scenes,'' this ''dramatic musical,'' as it was originally billed, has been performed occasionally as opera - by the New York City Opera - and has not had a musical-theater production until the one that opened Thursday at the Equity Library Theater.

title: A COMPOSER WHO BACKED INTO THE BUSINESS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Glenn Plaskin is the author of the forthcoming biography of Vladimir Horowitz to be published by William Morrow. By GLENN PLASKIN

title: TRADING THE BIG APPLE FOR BEET SUGAR
description: I N June 1963, a day after he graduated from Brown University with a degree in industrial psychology, Michael S. Buchsbaum went to work for the Chemical Bank. He soon discovered that working with money is far different from working for money.

title: PORTRAIT OF THE ARTIST AS A WHOLE MAN
description: LEONARDO DA VINCI The Marvellous Works of Nature and Man. By Martin Kemp. Illustrated. 384 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $30.

title: Wall Street Mergers Gather Momentum
description: MERGER mania has hit Wall Street again. Less than a decade ago, many brokerage firms were forced to seek the shelter of stronger houses to survive failing finances and a faltering stock market. Others simply closed their doors.

title: Barbara Gunther Is Married
description: Barbara Ann Gunther, first assistant corporation counsel for Mount Vernon, N.Y., was married yesterday to Andrew J. Zambelli Jr., assistant chairman of and an associate professor in the department of psychology at Mercy College in Dobbs Fer ry, N.Y.

title: Ann Stillman Is Married to William J. O'Leary Jr.
description: Ann Gregory Stillman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gregory Howard Stillman of Snyder, N.Y., was married there yesterday to William John O'Leary Jr., son of Mr. O'Leary and the late Joan O'Leary of Bethlehem, Pa. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Daniel Palace at Christ the King Roman Catholic Church.

title: RIVALS OF A.T.&T. ASSESS DIVESTITURE
description: Communication and data processing companies across the nation spent the day yesterday analyzing the agreement between the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and Justice Department under which the company agreed to give up control of the 22 Bell System companies that provide most of the country's local telephone service.

title: Conigliaro in Hospital After a Heart Attack
description: Tony Conigliaro, a former Boston Red Sox outfielder, suffered a heart attack this morning and was taken to Massachusetts General Hospital, where he was placed in the coronary care unit.

title: Literacy
description: To the Editor:

title: AT JUSTICE, I.B.M. POINTS A CLEARER PATH THAN A.T.&T.
description: I T was an ironic, revealing and, as Charles L. Brown, chairman of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, put it, a ''historic'' decision.

title: A TOP HOSTESS AND HER PARTY PRECEPTS
description: Every once in a while, a woman emerges in New York as the hostess whose parties everyone is talking about. Usually this woman comes from the social or fashion world, but this season's hostess-of-thehour is a successful real estate woman. Her name is Alice Mason.

title: GEORGE E. GULLEN Jr.
description: George E. Gullen Jr., former president of Wayne State University and a former vice president of the American Motors Corporation, died Friday at a hospital here after a long illness resulting from a brain tumor. He was 67 years old.

title: ISRAEL'S STRATEGY DEPENDS ON A FEW OBLIGING PALESTINIANS
description: Occupied West Bank - The driveway to Mustafa Doudin's office is blocked by an Israeli Army jeep; heavily armed troops guard the door. Every visitor is challenged, kept outside the two-story stone building until a soldier has made a phone call for authorization from the military government. Then the soldier escorts Mr. Doudin's guest into an anteroom and frisks him thoroughly. Thus, Israel's most important Arab on the occupied West Bank is kept alive, and with him and others like him, Israel's latest strategy of occupation.

title: HARNESS INQUIRY CENTERS ON 3
description: An investigation into race-fixing at the Meadowlands harness track in New Jersey has centered on a Delaware gambler, a New York lawyer and one of the nation's leading harness drivers, according to Federal law enforcement and harness-racing security officials.

title:
The Careful Shopper;
Inexpensive Beauty Aids
description: Beauty Barn on Central Avenue is the first New York retail branch of the New Jersey chain store known for health and beauty products and fragrances for men and women at discount prices. The Scarsdale store, opened Nov. 15, is the eighth retail outlet opened by the 45-year-old company and further expansion is planned in Connecticut and Massachussetts.

title: Race at 10 Kilometers W on by Salazar in 28:03
description: Alberto Salazar, the world-record holder in the marathon, won the 10-kilometer Race of the Americas today, beating a quality field with a time of 28 minutes 3 seconds.

title: No Headline
description: 2 West Teams Prevail

title: CITY'S INSTANT TEACHERS MEET SPECIAL PROBLEMS
description: IN the ''Methods of Teaching'' course Maxine Newman took as part of her training, she learned that a good way to gain the class's attention was to have an exercise ready for them on the blackboard as soon as they walked in. As a social studies instructor at Richmond Hill High School in Queens, she followed that advice until she walked into her freshman class one day and found the board already covered - with four-letter words, threats and a sketch of a nude woman with her name printed below.

title: About Westchester
description: GREENBURGH ''WHEN I was younger,'' an 18-year-old in jeans and a tight T-shirt was saying, ''when I was younger, a whole bunch of stuff was going down. I used to get in trouble a little bit. When somebody used to steal something, my name would come up, even though I didn't do it. Then I got to comin' over here, and well, things got different.''

title: No Headline
description: VIRGINIA TECH DEFEATS LOUISVILLE, 75-74

title: PADRES' SHORTSTOP IS CLOSE TO CARDS' DEAL
description: Ozzie Smith, the San Diego Padres' shortstop, seemed closer to accepting a trade to the St. Louis Cardinals late last week, and his willingness to waive the no-trade provision in his contract might have come after a review of the financial risks in retaining it.

title: WREN'S CHURCHES
description: To the Editor:I

title: FRED MORAN, OWNER OF THUNDERBOLT RIDE AT CONEY ISLAND PARK
description: Fred Moran, whose family owned and operated the Thunderbolt roller coaster at Coney Island for more than 50 years, died Friday at Veterans Hospital in Brooklyn. He was 64 years old.

title: NEW ANTIBIOTIC WEAPONS IN THE OLD BACTERIA WAR
description: In recent months, the Food and Drug Administration has approved the marketing of two new antibiotics to help fight the vast array of bacterial infections that remain a leading cause of death in this country. Many infectious disease experts have greeted this new group of antibiotics - the so-called third generation cephalosporins - with optimism about their increased effectiveness and safety.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: DEBACLE: The American Failure in Iran, by Michael Ledeen and William Lewis. (Vintage, $6.95.) This collaboration, of an editor of the Washington Quarterly and a former Foreign Service officer with considerable experience in the Middle East is a brief, well-written account of the relations between the United States and Iran in 1978-79, during and after the fall of the Shah. The authors attribute the political disaster to disarray in the Carter Administration and our foreign policy apparatus, especially our officials' inclination to give priority to ''an abstract human-rights doctrine'' over ''a geopolitical concept of the national interest.''

title: A LEADING LADY OF LANDMARKS ENDS SERVICE
description: Margaret Tuft caresses New York City with her eyes. No cornice, no lintel, no doorway escapes her gaze as she contemplates the architectural integrity of her domain.

title: CONGRESS TO WEIGH ACTIONS TO MODIFY A.T.&T. SETTLEMENT
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company agreed to dismantle its communications empire to settle an antitrust suit in part because it disliked the direction of legislation pending in Congress, the company's chairman and chief executive, Charles L. Brown, said yesterday.

title: DANCE THEATER OF HARLEM, FEELING ACCEPTED, SETS SIGHTS ON ARTISTRY
description: ''You may start something for social reasons, but after a certain point, what you're striving for as an artist will outweigh anything,'' Arthur Mitchell said. Mr. Mitchell is founder and director - with Karel Shook - of the Dance Theater of Harlem, the 12-year-old ballet company that will open a five-week season Tuesday at the City Center, on West 55th Street.

title: BOSTON
description: BOSTON IN 1970, a decade after completing a doctoral dissertation on the old mill town of Lawrence, Mass., James M. Howell started work as an economist for the First National Bank of Boston. His experience with Lawrence, which had lost 22,000 textile jobs in less than three years, and the disintegration of such old New England manufacturing industries as textiles, leather and shoes had darkened his view of the region's economy. Shortly after he joined the bank he wrote a jarring report on the state, which forms half of New England's economy. Now the financial community here likes to look back on it because what seemed so true then and for several years afterwards is so untrue now.

title: 'OLD-TIMER' OF 32 ENJOYS PLAYING COLLEGE BASKETBALL
description: DANBURY HE is older than most of the opposing teams' coaches, 15 years older than several of his teammates and only a year younger than his own coach, but Bob Ward does not feel out of place playing for the Western Connecticut State College varsity basketball team.

title: On the Treatment Of Aphasia
description: An article about Alzheimer's disease and the program at the Burke Rehabilitation Center (''New Center Fights Big Killer of the Aged,'' Dec. 6) was timely and informative.

title: Martin Wants to Make His Presence Felt
description: There was this Texas-sized headline recently, ''Has Martin-izing Lost Its Starch?'' And there were stories about Harvey Martin which implied that the Dallas Cowboys' defensive ends were nicknamed Too Tall and Too Old.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Second Place Is Nowhere
description: In the market for a big city daily newspaper? As of last week, you could take your pick - The New York Daily News, which went on the auction block last month, and now, The Philadelphia Bulletin.

title: About Long Island
description: BALDWIN THERE'S a storm up right now, and from this window the thick row of evergreens on the other side of our fence is responding to the wind as though on cue, like so many tall showgirls in ''A Chorus Line'' waving and fluttering their feathered limbs in perfect unison. Below them the cover on our pool bells up like a sail, goes slack and bells up again.

title: A WARRIOR FOR WILDLIFE
description: John Heminway, a film maker and freelance writer, is working on ''Whistling Thorns,'' a book profiling unsung heroes of Africa. By John Heminway Recently, a wildlife journal ran a short notice rejoicing that the elephant population in Uganda's Ruwenzori National Park had risen to 200. For those who knew this lovely sanctuary of savannas, rivers and lakes 10 years ago, when it was called Queen Elizabe th National Park,this news was hardly cause for celebration. Then, the park supported more than 3,0 00 elephants. Today, in the aftermath of war and nearly a decade of l awlessness under Idi Amin, not only have more than 90 percent of th e elephants been slaughtered, but all the rhinoceroses are gone, the plains game has been heavily poached, the lodge looted, the r oads mined and the whole system of game protection gutted.

title: Stage View; TWO ON THE STAGE- MUCH TOO OFTEN
description: Two on the aisle is perfectly all right, but two on the stage is starting to get worrisome. Not tiresome, worrisome. And by ''two on the stage'' I mean only two on the stage, plays that introduce us to no more than two characters, two actors, two psyches, two names on the Playbill.

title: Washington; NITZE AT 75
description: Forty years ago, Paul Henry Nitze began his service to the United States Government with the Board of Economic Warfare. He will celebrate his 75th birthday on Jan. 16 in Geneva where he heads the U. S. delegation that is negotiating with the Russians on the mutual limitation of medium-range nuclear weapons.

title: WHAT HAPPENS WHEN PARENTS TURN TEACHERS
description: THE Old Country Road School in rural Smithfield, R.I., is no longer the well-mannered, traditional place its name suggests, says Linda Rothwell, who studied there in the 1950's. Tired of watching her children's grades drop and upset by what she says were their daily reports of foul language and fighting, Mrs. Rothwell decided to remove her children from school and teach them at home.

title: County's Law On Conversions
description: The article ''Tenants Uniting to Fight Conversions'' (Westchester Housing, Dec. 23), to illustrate the problem created for tenants where landlords accumulate vacant apartments, gave the following example:

title: ON THE FARM, A PROBLEM OF ABUNDANCE
description: WASHINGTON AMONG the Agriculture Department's 85,000 employees, none are busier these days than the 112 agricultural attaches hustling this country's farm products in every part of the world where there is enough money or credit to pay for them.

title: No Headline
description: Although it would be wrong to eliminate psychological factors from any examination of human events, it is equally incorrect to make psychology solely determinative of those same events. It is necessary to include history, economics, the power of special interests in a complex of interacting factors in order to gain an understanding of the war on Vietnam and people's resistance to that war. Were there no children of relatively privileged and doting parents among those who ran the war? Although some of the members of the Weatherpeople came from wealthy backgrounds, did they all? How many? Did any more of them have such backgrounds than, say, the Young Americans for Freedom or the Young Republicans? BERTRAM GARSKOF, New Haven

title: No Headline
description: To the Business Editor:

title: BALTIMORE
description: JAMES W. ROUSE, the visionary founder of ''new towns'' like this one, likes to talk about creating cities. Having developed a parkfilled metropolis between Washington, D.C. and Baltimore that has grown from 100 cows 20 years ago to nearly 100,000 people today, he envisions a ''bi-metropolitan center,'' a coalescense of expanding Baltimore and Washington.

title: Bridge;  UNUSUAL STRATEGIES SPARK MCKENNEY CAMPAIGN
description: It is 3 A.M. and George Steinbrenner is pitching for the Yankees in the World Series. To make it harder for his opponents to run the bases, he has hired two more top teams to play on the same field simul taneously, at right angles.

title: ANSWERING THE NOT-SO-OBVIOUS QUESTION
description: ONE looks back over a lifetime of questions, questions. As a small boy he hears, ''My, you're growing taller, aren't you?'' In later years, on the sidewalks of New York, the panhandlers dominate: ''You got any change?'' Sports questions are stereotyped: ''Is wrestling on the level?'' ''Who was the best, Mickey, Willie or the Duke?'' ''Do you think Joe Louis coulda whipped Ali?'' ''What's with this Steinbrenner?'' ''What's with this McEnroe kid?''

title: 13 DIE IN COLD AND STORMS IN NORTHERN EUROPE
description: Snowstorms and frigid air gripped Britain again today with no warming trend in sight. The death toll from the unseasonal cold spreading across northern Europe rose to at least 13.

title: LAWYER DONATE AID TO ARTISTS
description: After two years, Bobby Bank, a New York photographer, had not been paid f or some publicity pictures he had taken , and he could not afford the legal fees to claim the payment. S usyn Berger, a printmaker, could not afford to take legal ac tion against a Boston gallery that returned her prints damaged afte r accepting them on consignment.

title: Critics' Choices
description: JAZZ/FOLK The Heath Brothers Band has always represented something more than the sum of its parts. For one thing, the saxophonist Jimmy Heath and the bassist Percy Heath are family, and they play together like family.

title: TEACHERS' UNION: VIEW FROM THE TOP
description: TRENTON EDITH FULTON, president of the New Jersey Education Association, loves it when people say that her union is the most powerful in the state.

title: Chargers Ready for a Cool Reception in Cincinnati
description: Disdainful of the outside temperatures that approached zero, Coach Don Coryell of the San Diego Chargers showed up in his hotel wearing a short-sleeve Ban-Lon shirt today and proclaimed, ''We're so happy to be here we'll play this game in a doggone iceberg and a blizzard.''

title: Personal Finance; YOU CAN GET SUED, EVEN AT HOME
description: C ASE 1: The house painter assembles his ladder outside your window and climbs up. Suddenly, somehow, the ladder slips and the painter breaks a hip.

title: I.B.M. SAYS 13-YEAR SUIT DIDN'T AFFEC T OPERATIONS
description: The International Business Machines Corporation spent millions of dollars and thousands of executive manhours preparing and giving testimony in the 13-year antitrust suit dropped Friday by the Federal Government. But the computer giant's investment and marketing decisions were unaffected, Thomas Barr, the company's lead counsel, said yesterday.

title: SAVING GRAND ESTATES: THE OPTIONS DWINDLE
description: AMAGANSETT WITH the presentation last November before the East Hampton Town Planning Board of a development proposal for the third and largest section of the former Bell estate in Amagansett, the long search for an alternative to subdivision for one of eastern Long Island's few remaining grand old estates has apparently ended.

title: 2 SHOT, ONE FATALLY OUTSIDE A NEWSSTAND ON BROOKLYN CORNER
description: A man was shot to death and the operator of an all-night newspaper stand was critically wounded early yesterday at a deserted intersection in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn, the police said.

title: Coast Town Honors Ford
description: The City Council voted Friday to name a street for former President Gerald R. Ford, one of the desert community's most prominent citizens. The street signs along Avenue 36 will be replaced by Gerald Ford Drive signs.

title: Nancy Leffler Is Wed To Dr. Evan Berman
description: Nancy Ellen Leffler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Leffler of New York, was married yesterday at the Fenway Golf Club in Scarsdale, N.Y., to Dr. Evan Neal Berman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Berman of New York. Rabbi Melvin N. Serner performed the ceremony.

title: Manchester City Plays Ti e With Stoke City, 1-1
description: Manchester City squandered a chance to take the lead in the English First Division soccer standings by playing a 1-1 tie at home against Stoke City today.

title:
Photography View;
STROBOSCOPIC LIGHTING IN THE REALM OF ART
description: To people over 50, the photographs of Harold E. Edgerton are like the movies of Fred Astaire and Ginger Rogers. They were happily imbibed in childhood or adolescence without any thought of their being art. But they made an indelible impression on the imagination, and now that they are being revived for a younger generation under such auspices as the Museum of Modern Art, the Public Broadcasting System and 57th Street galleries, the older generation feels faintly embarrassed.

title: LAFOLLETTE HAILED AS GOVERNOR
description: Robert M. LaFollette of Wisconsin leads a list of ''10 outstanding governors of the 20th century,'' published in the current newsletter of the National Governors Association.

title: Mailbox; Masks Could Help Hockey
description: To the Sports Editor: I may have the answer to the question that has perplexed man for years: How to curb violence in the National Hockey League without losing its fans?

title: Elizabeth Bloch and Michael Yefsky to Be Married
description: Mrs. Jack Bloom of Roslyn Estates, L.I., and Palm Beach, Fla., and Ralph Bloch of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Bloch, to Michael Yefsky, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sheldon A. Yefsky of Chicago.

title: MUCH BESIDES THE DECAMERON
description: BOCCACCIO By Thomas G. Bergin. 392 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $25.

title: Index; International
description: Nubian date palms grow again near the temples of Abu Simbel 3 Around the World 4 U.S. won't let Peking deter Tai- wan arms sales 6 Regional disparities between east and west growing in Canada 7 Text of Polish and Soviet broad- casts on crisis in Poland 12 Poland Government approves ex- pansion of private ownership 12 Austria finds Polish refugees a burden 12 Aides seek to stem flow of scien- tific data to Russians 21 Government/Politics Reagan to make a statement Tuesday on Puerto Rico 20 Reagan below Carter in Gallup Poll 20 California's Gov. Brown shows changed style in his last year 22 Fourth candidate enters G.O.P. Connecticut Governor's race 34 Brooklyn District Attorney moves to insure fair trial tactics 35 General Santa Cruz water emergency eases 22 Around the Nation 23 As landfills fill up, recycling gar- bage is encouraged 28 Woman, 76, named as driver in State judge approves razing two theaters to make way for hotel 36 Rex Harrison aids ''Actors Church'' benefit< 38 Health/Science Cousteau to lead 13-month study of Amazon 10 Industry/Labor Competitors assess impact of A.T.&T.s planned divestiture 15 I.B.M. says antitrust suit did not affect investment policy 16 A rts/Entertainment Kay Standifer, soprano, in debut recital 49 eg Ahrens offers avant-garde music 49 Richard Thompson sings folk bal- lads 49 Weill's ''Street Scenes'' staged at Equity Library Theaer 49 Dance Theater of Harlem, feeling accepted, looks to artistry 51 The Grover Mitchell Orchestra plays the Rainbow Room 49 John Browning, pianist, at Carne- gie Hall 51 The Lenore Latimer company dances at Riverside Church 51 Style A top hostess and her party pre- cepts 52 Dino De Laurentiis becomes a food mogul 52 Obituaries Antonio Mendez, 80, Democratic leader in East Harlem 32 Fred Moran, owner of Coney Is- land roller coaster 32 News Analysis Drew Middleton examines NATO stragegy for defending Europe 13

title: REAGAN'S ANTITRUST EXPLOSION
description: WITH last week's historic developments in suits against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and the International Business Machines Corporation, the attention of antitrust-policy watchers snapped back toward the Justice Department and its antitrust enforcer, William F. Baxter. Until the Friday announcements, however, it had been the Federal Trade Commission and its new chairman, William C. Miller 3d, in the spotlight with the Mobil and U.S. Steel bids for Marathon Oil.

title: Paul Samuelson Weds Miss Scarf
description: Martha Anne Scarf, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Scarf of New Haven, and Paul Reid Samuelson, son of Paul A. Samuelson and the late Marion Samuelson, were married yesterday at the New Haven Lawn Club. Rabbi Mark Panoff performed the ceremony.

title: Paisley, Barred in U.S., Plans to Visit Canada
description: The Rev. Ian Paisley, the militant Protestant leader in Northern Ireland, said today that he would visit Canada next weekend ''to combat pro-I.R.A. propaganda.''

title: Camera; A GUIDE FOR THE ASPIRING PHOTOJOURNALIST
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Jack Manning is a photographer on the staff of this newspaper, and the author of several books on photography.

title: LAST CHANCE FOR JERSEY'S DEMOCRATS
description: TRENTON WITH time running out in the New Jersey Legislature's lame duck session, the Democrats who control it will return to the State House tomorrow to wrestle with what has become a political Rubik's cube - how to redraw the state's Congressional districts in a way that will satisfy enough party factions to ensure legislative approval.

title: JAPAN'S LOVE AFFAIR WITH THE ROBOT
description: The white cone atop Fuji sparkles against a wintry blue sky. At the mountain's base, among stands of fir, rests a bright yellow factory. It has drawn 100,000 visitors in the year since it was built. The visitors stand behind windows looking down with awe upon a shop floor a bit smaller than a football field where some two dozen robots calmly, untiringly labor at work that once required human hands. This is one of the world's first unmanned plants - a symbol of Japanese technological and economic leadership, a vision of where the world is going. It is also more than a little incongruous.

title: Decontrolling Natural Gas
description: UTILITY executives, politicians and analysts are convinced that natural gas pricing is likely to be the hottest energy issue of the year. The stakes are billions of dollars in revenues for industry and hundreds of dollars in fuel bills for homeowners.

title: BOB BALABAN- HE'S MAKING A CAREER OF PROJECTING INTELLIGENCE
description: When Bob Balaban was 18 years old and just beginning his acting career, an actress in his native Chicago told him, ''As long as there are parts for people who look smart, you're going to get work.''

title: Best Sellers
description: Jx FICTION 1 1 12 AN INDECENT OBSESSION, by Colleen McCullough. (Harper & Row, $13.50.) A nurse and her charges in a special-care ward of a World War II hospital. 2 2 17 THE HOTEL NEW HAMPSHIRE, by John Irving. (Dutton/Henry Robbins, $15.50.) Life with an eccentric family. 3 3 36 NOBLE HOUSE, by James Clavell. (Delacorte, $19.95.) A British-Chinese struggle for control of one of Hong Kong's oldest trading houses. 4 4 22 CUJO, by Stephen King. (Viking, $13.95.) Monsters haunt a New York family seeking peace in rural Maine. 5 6 8 SPRING MOON, by Bette Bao Lord. (Harper & Row, $14.95.) Tradition and revolution in modern China seen through the life of an upper-class family. 6 8 40 GORKY PARK, by Martin Cruz Smith. (Random House, $13.95.) A triple murder in Moscow leads to a chase on two continents. 7 13 37 MASQUERADE, by Kit Williams. (Schocken Books, $10.95.) An illustrated fable about the sun, the moon and a hidden treasure.

title: TRANSFORMATION IN THE COMMODITIES
description: MARKET By H.J. MAIDENBERG

title: Around the Nation; Saturday Evening Post Sold to Franklin Society
description: The Saturday Evening Post, which is $2.5 million in debt, has been purchased by the Benjamin Franklin Literary Soci ety from the Curtis Publishing Company.

title: Ivy League Considers Adding 2 Schools
description: The Ivy League is considering an expansion from its traditional eight schools to a 10-team league, with Army, Northwestern and Navy the most likely candidates for membership. However, none of these institutions has been formally approached on the subject, according to league officials.

title: PRIVATE SCHOOLS GROUPS ASSAIL TAX RULE SHIFT
description: The Reagan Administration's decision to stop denying tax-exempt status to educational institutions that practice racial discrimination was deplored yesterday by spokesmen for two national organizations of private colleges and schools.

title: Around the World; Police in Rome Arrest 11 Red Brigades Suspects
description: Policemen investigating the kidnapping of Brig. Gen. James L. Dozier today arrested a fugitive suspected leader of the Red Brigades and 10 others believed to be members of the terrorist organization, the authorities said.

title:
Business Forum;
REAGAN SHOULD CURB BIG MAIL, TOO
description: T HE Reagan Administration's commitment to cutting down big government and improving government efficiency faces a rigorous test in the Postal Service.

title: THE PAPERBACK EVOLUTION
description: When Thomas H. Guinzburg, chairman of the 1982 American Book Awards ceremony, proposed that the board designate a prize for the best original softcover book of 1981, he was pleased by the response. "They said it was a fantastic idea; why didn't we think of it before?" recalled Mr. Guinzburg. "Then they proceeded to vote me down by something like 26 to 3."

title: INFANT DAY CARE: HOW WISE?
description: NEW HAVEN WORKING parents are increasingly placing infants and toddlers in some form of out-of-home child care, but not even researchers in child development can say whether day care is good or bad for infants.

title: 22 Food Outlets in City Fail Health Inspections
description: The New York City Department of Health released the names of 22 food outlets that it said had violated the city's Health Code. The department also released the names of three that had reopened after correcting earlier violations and one that had been closed for failing to do so.

title: Major News in Summary; Creationism Loses First Test
description: Proponents called it ''creation science,'' but in a sharply worded 38-page opinion, Federal District Court Judge William Ray Overton called it hogwash. Ruling last week in Little Rock, Judge Overton held that creationism is religious in its import and that the Arkansas law requiring its teaching in public schools violated the constitutional separation of church and state.

title: THE FED'S WORTHWHILE TARGET PRACTICE
description: To the Editor:

title: Headliners Rehnquist Recovering
description: A drug recommended for short term use only was identified last week as the substance taken by William H. Rehnquist to help him sleep while afflicted with back pain.

title: CONNECTICUT
description: HARTFORD FOR years the economic folklore has held that when a recession hits the national economy, Connecticut has a delayed reaction. The reasoning is that the state has been a major manufacturer of capital goods, such as transportation equipment and machine tools, which require a long time, both to wind down and to start up again.

title: Women of the Weather Movement
description: Lucinda Franks's absorbing article on the women of the Weather Underground shows how seductive (in every sense) that ideology was to the women of her generation (''The Seeds of Terror,'' Nov. 22). To write off these women as spoiled brats of the middle class having a temper tantrum, however, is to miss the essential tragedy of their lives.

title: More on China
description: To the Editor:

title: RESEARCH AGENCY TO GET NEW CHIEF
description: After only two presidents in 61 years, the Institute of Public Administration, the nation's oldest organization promoting scientific management in government, has come to a turning point.

title: CONSUMER RATES
description: * Rates restricted by state usury laws

title: TRANSIT POLICE AILMENTS: CHRONIC--OR ONLY SERIOUS?
description: New York's Transit Authority Police Force will mark its 35th anniversary this year but no one seems inclined to open any champagne. Law enforcement experts have long given the department poor marks for efficiency and statistics released last week, which showed felonies had increased by 13.7 percent in 1981, only seemed to reinforce their assessment. The end of the year was particlarly bleak, with serious crime soarin g 45 percent in November and 65 percent in De cember.

title: National Economic Survey January 10, 1982
description: OUTLOOK Surviving the Recession. By Leonard Silk Cover The Critical Off-year Elections.

title: Children's Books
description: THE FEATHERED SERPENT By Scott O'Dell. 211 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company. $10.95. (Ages 12 to 15) By GEORGESS McHARGUE

title: Nonaligned Lands to Meet
description: Representatives from the so-called movement of nonaligned nations will hold a tw o-day conference here April 16, the Kuwaiti F oreign Minister, Sheik Sabah al-Ahmed al-Sabah, said today. The 36 foreign ministers from the 94-member movement, members of the group' s executive board, will discuss the Palestinian question, he said.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary
description: Having progressed from pony to truck and train to plane, the United States Postal Service last week extended its delivery system to the computer chip. The 206-year-old agency unveiled ''E-COM,'' for electronic computer originated mail.

title: The Region in Summary; LaBorde Caught; Brink's Suspect
description: After a bloody struggle with two Philadelphia police officers, Anthony H. LaBorde, a suspect in last October's Weather Underground Brink's robbery in Rockland County, was arrested last week. Mr. LaBorde, who is also wanted in the April 1981 ambush shooting that killed one New York City police officer and wounded another, was held on $10 million bail.

title: Freighter Sinks Off Japan
description: An 11,400-ton Panamanian-registered freighter sank in rough seas off Japan today. The Maritime Safety Agency said all 33 crewmen, from Hong Kong, Taiwan and Indonesia, were rescued by a Japanese fishing boat.

title: New Jersey Guide; SLAPSTICK IN PRINCETON
description: The likes of Mack Sennett, Charlie Chaplin, Fatty Arbuckle, Mabel Normand and the Keystone Kops, not to mention all their slapstick antics, are coming to Princeton in ''Keystone,'' a new musical about the glory days of silent-screen comedy.

title: ST. JOHN'S DOWNS PROVIDENCE, 76-62
description: With 4 minutes 37 seconds remaining in the game, Lou Carnesecca sat down. That was a signal to the 4,412 fans at the Nassau Coliseum that he thought his St. John's basketball team was on its way to a victory over Providence.

title: Investing; HOW TO SPOT A TURNAROUND STOCK
description: S OMETIMES stocks go up, and sometimes they go down; and with so many stocks in the doldrums today, hundreds ought to rebound eventually. But how do you spot those that will? Professional money managers make a business of identifying such turnaround stocks, so managers from four firms were selected at random and asked how they make their picks.

title: THE FED VS. THE WHITE HOUSE: A COLLISION IS BREWING OVER THE COURSE OF RECOVERY
description: WASHINGTON PAUL A. VOLCKER and the Federal Reserve Board, if they maintain their present tight, anti-inflationary monetary policy, could easil y get in the wa y of President Reagan's economic program and the strong rebound he ne eds to help Republi- 0,2cans in the key off-year Congressional elections. Mr. Volcker has increased the chances of a clash by repeatedly telling the financial markets that high interest rates will result if nothing is done about the enormous budget deficits anticipated in 1983 and 1984 - deficits brought on by the recession and the Administration's supply-side tax cuts.

title: North Korea Accuses U.S.
description: North Korea accused the United States today of violating its airspace with a high-altitude SR-71 reconnaissance plane on Friday. The North Korean press agency, monitored here, said the plane committed ''an espionage act'' against the northern half of North Korea, the fifth this year.

title: PREMED DOORS OPEN TO ADULTS
description: THREE nights a week, 100 students gather at Columbia University for a lesson in chemistry. Among the students are musicians, journalists and lawyers. The age range is from the early 20's to the late 30's. Despite the group's diversity, all have the same goal: acceptance into a medical school.

title: CAROL ELSMAN AFFIANCED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas R. Elsman of Centreville, Del., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Carol Ruth Elsman, to Stephen Galloway Grove, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Styer Grove 3d of Wyndmoor, Pa. The couple, graduates of Bucknell University, plan to be married in September.

title: Deregulation Carried Out With Zeal
description: WASHINGTON IF one song was being belted out in perfect harmony by all the President's men as the Reagan Administration came to power, it was that overregulation was doing the nation in. Now, a year later the Administration contends it has achieved some remarkable results in slicing away Federal regulations.

title: Other World Events; A Hard Place and a Rock
description: The world proclaimed Juan Carlos the savior of Spanish democracy when he squelched a coup attempt last year. But diehard Francoists in the army refuse to give up and have been distributing leaflets hinting that the King really backed the coup but got cold feet.

title: SALVADOR WAR ALSO PUTS SQUEEZE ON MANAGUA
description: About the only thing that could make anyone mistake this dusty Central American capital for its granite counterpart in Washington is a common absorption in a third seat of government -San Salvador. Both the pin-striped diplomats of the Reagan Administration and the fatigue-clad Sandinist leadership of Nicaragua agree that El Salvador effectively blocks any understanding between their two countries.

title: Acoustical Pots and Skulls
description: In his article, ''Acoustics: Still Playing It by Ear'' (Nov. 22), Harold Schonberg laments the inferior quality of the sound in nearly all concert halls built in the 20th century. I would like to make several observations which might help put this subject in perspective.

title: Jane Enid Durkin
description: Mr. and Mrs. William M. Durkin of Glen Rock, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jane Enid Durkin, to Charles Norman Andreae 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Andreae Jr. of Baltimore.

title: WALKER LEADS NETS OVER 76ERS, 120-113
description: Clarence (Foots) Walker, the Nets' onceforgotten playmaker, continued his resurgence tonight. Walker, making his first start since Dec. 11, directed the Nets to a 120-113 victory over the Philadelphia 76ers at the Spectrum.

title: A NOVEL OF POLITICS, WIT AND SORROW
description: THE DEAN'S DECEMBER By Saul Bellow. 312 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $13.95.

title: BENGALS USE THEIR OPTIONS TO THE FULLEST
description: a little-known phenomenon in which orange stickers with black stripes suddenly appear in store-fronts, car windows and hotel lobbies - pervades the city.

title: R.O.T.C. BUTT OF THE 70'S, IS ON TARGET AGAIN
description: IN the early 1970's, when khaki wasn't such a popular shade, the Reserve Officer Training Corps was feeling the heat - especially after the Kent State tragedy in which four students demonstrating against the Vietnam war were slain by the National Guard in Ohio.

title: Art; A CURATORIAL COUP IN STAMFORD
description: STAMFORD THE coziness of its title notwithstanding, ''Greetings From the World of Art'' represents a curatorial coup for the Stamford Museum and Nature Center (through Feb. 22).

title: Allen Sperry Jr. to Wed Sarah Blodget
description: The engagement of Sarah Richards Blodget to Allen McBrier Sperry Jr. has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Alden S. Blodget Jr. of Princeton, N.J., and Annisquam, Mass., parents of the future bride. Mr. Sperry is the son of Mr. Sperry of Litchfield, Conn., and Robbie Oxnard of New York.

title: Art View; BENTON, THE RADICAL MODERNIST
description: It will probably come as something of a shock to admirers of the late Thomas Hart Benton (1889-1975) to discover that this pillar of the American Scene School, now mainly known for his populist murals on native themes and for his raucous anti-modernist views, was in his youth an enthusiastic and accomplished modernist. Not that it was ever exactly a secret, of course. Benton had been to Paris before World War I. There, like other aspiring artists of his generation, he had discovered Cezanne, Matisse and the Cubists, and willingly succumbed to their influence. He was especially drawn to the Synchromist innovations of Stanton Macdonald-Wright and Morgan Russell, and painted for a time in the Synchromist manner. His attachment to the abstractionist tendencies of the early American avant-garde was marked by his participation in the Forum Exhibition in New York in 1916.

title: LEARNING HOW CHILDREN LEARN FROM THE FRIST MOMENTS OF LIFE
description: MONTH-OLD Alana Arbe sits strapped into a baby chair and babbles happily at the pattern of dots flashed across the screen in the Roosevelt Hospital Infant Laboratory, oblivious to the electrodes attached to her chest. Suddenly a variation on the dot pattern appears on the screen and Alana becomes quiet as she gazes at the new picture. The screen dims and becomes blank.

title: BIOTECHNOLOGY PASSING MAJOR MILESTONES
description: THE biotechnology industry is so young that it still passes major milestones with noteworthy regularity. Experts say that the two highlights to expect this year will be the introduction of the first commercial products made by gene splicing and the first significant business failures.

title: THE REAGANITES BUSINESS IS WATCHING
description: THE Reagan Administration has put together a team of managers in the Cabinet departments and regulatory agencies to help shape its economic policy. Ernest Holsendolph, Phil Gailey and David Schribman of The New York Times's Washington Bureau look at 10 of the team members, who are expected to play increasingly significant roles. RAYMOND A. PECK Jr.

title:
Dance;
EXPANDING LEGACY OF A SPECIAL DANCER
description: MANY dance enthusiasts remember fondly the legacy left in Westchester by the modern dancer Steffi Nossen. Since her death in 1979, her commitment to dance education has been continued by a nonprofit organization, The Dance in Education Fund, which she helped formulate more than 20 years ago.

title: Radine Abramson Is Bride Of William Spier, Executive
description: Radine Abramson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Abramson of Teaneck, N.J., was married there yesterday in the Jewish Center to William Spier, son of Rosi Spier of New York and the late Joseph Klibansky. Rabbi Judah Washer performed the ceremony.

title: DR. BERNARD WEISL
description: Dr. Bernard Weisl, who had be en a professor of medicine at New York Universi ty Medical Center and a consultant in gynecology and obstetrics fo r the New Jersey Department of Health and the New York City Departme nt of Health, died Thursday at the Princeton (N.J.) Medical Cente r. He was 75 years old and lived in Monroe Township, N.J.

title: ON TAXES, THE PRESIDENT'S MEN VERSUS THE PRESIDENT
description: To those outside the wagon train, it looked last week as if the circle had closed around President Reagan. Finally, his top advisers were unanimous in recommending that he present for 1983 a budget containing significant proposals for tax increases. Even the last holdout, Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan - the only member of the inner circle who had been arguing in private what Mr. Reagan had been arguing in public, that new tax increases would drag the economy down - had switched. ''I think,'' announced Mr. Regan, ''there will be some new tax increases'' in 1983 and 1984 beyond the $22 billion package the President reluctantly accepted in September. There seemed to be no one left. On Capitol Hill, Representative Jack F. Kem p, the upstate New York Republican for whom tax increases are anathem a, assessed Mr. Regan's comment as a defection that did not mean that the battle was lost. Mr. Kemp said he had been promised one last c hance this week to make the opposition case, and he sounded hopeful. ''I have been assured that the decisions are not locked in,'' he sa id, adding defiantly: ''Douglas MacArthur once said that the counci ls of war breed timidity and defeatism. The forces of timidit y and defeatism are having their hour, but I have hope the Presid ent will decide the right thing in the end.''

title: Social Programs - 'A Chasm'
description: WASHINGTON AS the second year of the ''Reagan revolution'' begins, business leaders and Government officials find themselves in surprising agreement on one point: The private sector cannot fill the gap left by the withdrawal of Federal money from social welfare programs, education and scientific research.

title: THE GLOSS FADES FROM MAGAZINES
description: ''Nothing's going to save these magazines. Nothing. I can tell it by feel, by the heft of the magazine - lay a copy on the doorstep and the wind blows it away. Not that I'm against your trying to save it. Go ahead. It's like someone in your family dying, you have to try to save him...'' ''The View from the Fortieth Floor,'' Theodore H. White

title: A NEW WAY TO ACCOUNT FOR OVERSEAS PROFITS
description: THE role of foreign currency in determining how earnings are reported promises to continue to stir debate at corporations and in the accounting community. The single biggest cause of lower earnings reported last year by dozens of major multinational companies was the strengthening of the dollar against foreign currencies, especially in Europe. When the dollar stre ngthens, for instance against the French franc, more francs are required to equal a dollar. If sales volume remains stable, an American subsidiary selling goods in francs will experience a decline in gross dollar income when those francs are translated back to dollars.

title: Bengal Tickets Are Misprinted
description: Misprinted playoff tickets could present a crowd-control problem for Sunday's American Football Conference championship game between the Bengals and Chargers.

title: LAWYER TO WED NANCY KILKENNY
description: Mr. and Mrs. James T. Kilkenny of Forest Hills, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Kilkenny, to John C. Crabill, son of Lois Conway Crabill of Forest Hills, and Dr. Ralph E. Crabill of Washington.

title: KEEPING A NATION IN LINE
description: THE POLISH COMPLEX By Tadeusz Konwicki. Translated by Richard Lourie. 211 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $12.95.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The tougher the restrictions by the West, the longer will be the democratization process.

title: DANCE THERAPY CERTIFICATION OFFERED
description: PROMPTED by a growing interest on the Island in dance therapy, Adelphi University has begun offering a degree of master of professional studies in dance/movement therapy for graduate students.

title: Jeffrey Sklaroff, Lawyer, Marries Andrea S. Cohen
description: Andrea Sue Cohen, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Abert Cohen of Brooklyn, was married at the Seaview Jewish Center there last night to Jeffrey B. Sklaroff, son of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Sklaroff of Valley Stream, L.I. Rabbi Norman Strizower and Cantor Erno Grosz officiated.

title: U.S. FIRM ON PACT WITH ISRAEL
description: The United States remains unwilling to reopen a strategic cooperation agreement with Israel because of its annexation of the Golan Heights last month, the State Department said today.

title: MERYL GITTLEMAN IS FIANCEE
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edward Gittleman of Oceanside, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Meryl Gittleman, to Andrew Perry Kaplan, son of Shirley Kaplan of North Miami, Fla., and Sidney Kaplan of Hollywood, Fla. Miss Gittleman is a consultant in new-product development at Business Week, a magazine published by McGraw Hill. Mr. Kaplan is director of finance for Home Box Office, a subsidiary of Time Inc. in New York. An April 4 wedding is planned.

title: Topics; MATTERS OF LAW; Buyer's Market?
description: If you believe the anguished cries of Marvin Miller, the executive director of the Major League Baseball Players Association, baseball stars who have declared themselves free bargaining agents will soon be standing in line for unemployment checks.

title: SUPERMAN! SUPERSTAR! NOW IT'S SUPERLEARNING
description: THE first thing students do in Charles Schmid's French class is take off their shoes. Next, they take a whiff of the fresh daisies and marigolds placed on a table in the room, sit down in high-back canvas chairs and close their eyes. Baroque music begins to waft through the air, and a voice comes on over the music, reciting the lesson:

title: Long Islanders; FARM LIFE IDYLLIC? HE SAYS IT ISN'T SO
description: PEOPLE caught up in what is commonly known as the urban rat race have an idyllic vision of an alternate existence - peaceful life on a farm, up early to the crowing of roosters, a day of hard work in the outdoors and, at night, deep, restful, well-earned sleep.

title: Leisure; THE BEAUTIES OF GLORY BOWER
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Anna L. Wang is a writer and translator of Chinese books. BY ANNA L. WANG

title: ASSEMBLY TO HEAR STATE OF THE ECOLOGY
description: TRENTON INCLUDED in New Jersey's environmental agenda for 1982 is a proposed $200 million bond act to provide incentives to build modern resource-recovery plants, such as recycling facilities and incinerators, as well as what appears to be a different posture by the Legislature in working with Governor-elect Thomas H. Kean.

title: Ships' Names
description: To the Editor:

title:
RED SMITH;
Sweet Smell Of Inflation
description: WONDER what Gary Player thinks when he hears that somebody put the knock on inflation. Playing a golf course he designed, Gary finished last and took away $100,000 on the New Year weekend. If he ever won that much finishing first in a tournament, the occasion has eluded memory.

title: NEW-WAVE ADS: 'START AND WILD'
description: Mercury, especially the eerie commercials for the Lynx; Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn for Diet Pepsi, and the Chanel No.5 spot with the man who swims the length of a pool to a reclining woman only to disappear when he gets there.

title: La Vue, King Ranch Mare, Takes Interborough
description: King Ranch, the Texas-based stable, won its first stakes race in New York since 1976 when La Vue captured the $54,900 Interborough Handicap yesterday at Aqueduct.

title: Rich and Poor Nations Are Urged to Negotiate
description: The Brandt Commission called today for immediate global negotiations between rich and poor nations on ways to rescue the poorest countries from the effects of the worldwide recession.

title: IF YOU WANT TO TAKE A COURSE
description: Speech courses at continuing-education divisions of high schools, community and four-year colleges are listed in their publications, and many will be starting this month or next.

title: Patrick Higgins, Joanne P. Cushing Marry in Queens
description: Joanne Pike Cushing, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Prentice Cushing Jr. of Douglas Manor, Queens, was married at Zion Episcopal Church in Douglaston, Queens, yesterday to Patrick Joseph Higgins, son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis E. Higgins of Pomona, N.Y.

title: EXPERT WARNS ON TESTIMONY BY WITNESSES AFTER HYPNOSIS
description: Witnesses previously hypnotized by the police should not be allowed to testify in court because their memories may have been altered by the people who hypnotized them, a psychiatrist contends.

title: INVADED BY VIDEO WAR GAMES
description: I AM a parent who can remember just how traum atic it was to be a child. I can also fully understand the distre ss of peer pressure. However, despite my compassionate understandi ng, I managed to ignore my sons' constant pleas for a video game set.

title: Linda Ucko, K. L. Leiby Jr.  W ill Be Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Kurt J. Ucko of Packanack Lake, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Linda Evelyn Ucko, to Kenneth Llewellyn Leiby Jr., son of Colonel Leiby, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Leiby of Simsbury, Conn.

title: The Nation in Summary; Economy Slump Made Official
description: Since 1854, no recession has been official until certified by the independent National Bureau of Economic Research. Last week, the bureau entered the current slump on its records.

title: The Struggle To Win Control Of Congress In November; Republicans may keep the Senate, but economic travail favors House Democrats.; Perico Pastor
description: AS the year-end budget maneuvering moved toward a climax, the House Majority Leader, Jim Wright, protested one day to reporters that the Democrats were not the problem. ''The President's gotten everything he's asked for,'' he contended. ''From a complaisant and compliant Congress, he got what he wanted on budget cuts. He got what he wanted on tax cuts. And manifestly it isn't working.''

title:
Dining Out;
REVISIT TO A SWISS RESTAURANT
description: IN RESPONSE to complaints from readers over the last few months, we returned to Movenpick, the Swiss restaurant in East Hanover. Given two stars in this column soon after it opened two years ago, the restaurant had impressed this reviewer not only with its charming atmosphere and friendly, efficient service, but also with authentic, nicely prepared fare.

title: Mary Fraser Wed To R. W. Edixon
description: Mary James Fraser and Roger Walter Edixon were married yesterday in St. Michael's Roman Catholic Church in Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Thomas P. Guinan, the pastor, performed the ceremony.

title: SUPPORT OF EARLY SCHOOLING GROWS AS U.S. THREATENS RETRENCHMENT
description: WHEN the Ne w York State Board of Regents recently encouraged the creation of f ormal public-school programs for 4-year-olds, it acted in concert wi th a nationwide trend of almost two decades in which educators hav e tried to begin teaching children sooner.

title: CLARINETIST SCORES AS A SOLOIST
description: IN THE world of classical music, perhaps the most treacherous terrain of all is the solo field. At the top, there is room for about 150 big-name soloists, those box-office magnets who are heard regularly in the United States. Of the hundreds of other superbly equipped artists who may never achieve that kind of stardom, only a handful will eventually enjoy fruitful careers and command the type of fees to sustain a livelihood.

title: PIANO RECITAL: BROWNING'S 'PICTURES'
description: The first New York recital in seven seasons by the pianist John Browning, which was devoted to Mussorgsky's ''Pictures at an Exhibition'' and sonatas by Mozart and the late Samuel Barber, may not have been the most dazzling display ever offered at Carnegie Hall, but it none theless took hold of Friday night's audience the way performances of real depth sometimes do.

title: No Headline
description: Johnson Scores 40 as Lakers Win

title: Critics' Choices
description: DANCE The new season has just started at Theater of the Riverside Church, an ongoing festival of just about every kind of dance that's being done in New York. And one week into the season, Riverside has come up with some interesting dance.

title: Sharon J. Abbott Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Lee Abbott of Kinnelon, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sharon Jeanne Abbott, to Dirk F. Zuschlag, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest F. Zuschlag of Wexford, Pa. The wedding is planned for June. Miss Abbott and her fiance are seniors at Duke University.

title: Philosophy and Science
description: To the Editor:

title: ANTITRUST POLICIES AFFECT NOT JUST CORPORATE FUTURES
description: The disposition of the giant antitrust cases against the Bell System and I.B.M. marked the end of an era in antitrust law and very likely the beginning of an era in information and telecommunications t echnology. In the end, la st week's exercise in national policy could dramatically affect the mold of American life.

title: The Kennan Doctrine
description: George Kennan has the courage of Helmut Schmidt's convictions and makes what case there is for acquiescing in Poland's suppression. He says the Soviet Union will always risk more to keep Poland supine than the West should risk to make it freer. So why impose sanctions that can only damage the peace of Europe?

title: TEA MEN BEAT THE COSMOS, 7-4
description: The Cosmos continued to struggle in the indoor season, losing by 7-4 to the Jacksonville Tea Men at the Byrne Meadowlands Arena tonight.

title: Nonfiction in Brief
description: A FEARFUL INNOCENCE By Frances Davis. Illustrated. 253 pp. Kent, Ohio: Kent State University Press. $14.95.

title: THE LEGENDS OF SKUNK HOLLOW...
description: ALPINE USING a borrowed $100, Jack Earnest bought his freedom from slavery from a farmer in Bergen County. Then, by hard work, he earned $87.50 to acquire five acres and 30 square rods of woodlot in what was then Harrington Township atop the Palisades.

title: Deborah Harper Wed to a Lawyer
description: Deborah Moore Harper and Gary David Hailey were married yesterday in St. John's Episcopal Church, Lafayette Square, in Washington. The Rev. James C. Holmes performed the ceremony and was assisted by the Rev. Timothy D. Dobbins.

title: The Week in Business; A SPLIT UP FOR A.T.&T., BUT NOT FOR I.B.M.
description: A.T.&T. settled a seven-year-old suit with the Justice Department by agreeing to shed 22 fully owned local telephone companies. Under the decision, one of the most historic in antitrust annals, A.T.&T. would be allowed to keep its long-distance operations, Bell Laboratories and its Western Electric unit.

title: FOR RENT: A SEYCHELLE OF ONE'S OWN
description: LAILAN YOUNG, a writer and lecturer on travel, lives in London. By LAILAN YOUNG

title: Antiques View; ART DECO DOYENNE
description: Nobody who knows her believes Lillian Nassau is really retiring. The energetic 82-year-old doyenne of antiques dealers in New York - a tiny blue-eyed woman with a halo of silver framing her lively face - will continue to reign over a forest of Art Nouveau and Art Deco glass and wood-carved treasures in her establishment at 220 East 57th Street ''forever,'' said one collector.

title: HEATH LICKLIDER
description: Heath Licklider, a professor of architecture at Princeton University, died Friday of leukemia at his home in Princeton, N.J. He was 64 years old.

title: Children's Books
description: AS DEAD AS A DODO By Peter Mayle and Paul Rice. Illustrated by Shawn Rice. Unpaged. Boston: David R. Godine. $10.95. (Ages 9 to 12) By MARGUERITE FEITLO- WITZ

title: The Region in Summary; Creative Tension Grips Yonkers
description: Politicians frequently promise to clean house, but seldom do they approach the task with the alacrity displayed in Yonkers last week. City Hall hadn't opened for the first business day of Mayor Angelo R. Martinelli's term before he began booting out workers and department heads hired by the previous administration.

title: Jailed Felons to Help Recycle Islip's Trash
description: A resolution to enable convicted felons to work off their sentences at the Town of Islip's recycling plant, rather than serve time in the Suffolk County Jail, has been unanimously approved by the Town Board.

title: Fireman Dies of Injuries Received at a Hospital
description: A 38-year-old firefighter died last night of injuries that he received a month ago while checking a report of an electrical emergency at a hospital, Fire Department officials said.

title: GUATEMALAN CRITICIZES CLERICS
description: The Guatemalan Army's Chief of Staff said today that a nun who was kidnapped three days ago was ''linked to the guerrillas'' and suggested that other religious workers involved in similar activities should leave the country.

title: AND IF YOU LIKE SUSHI
description: HOBOKEN STANDING behind a gray-marble sandwich counter in a refurbished barroom here, a man starts to unwind a zucchini with a knife, paring a broad, thin strip of white calabash that comes off like paper towels from a roll.

title: DEFICITS D O MATTER
description: Even if the President accedes to the selective tax increases urged by his senior economic advisers, the Federal Government will incur huge deficits for the remainder of his Administration. The decision to accept unbalanced budgets betrays a principle that Ronald Reagan has espoused throughout his political career. Worse, it is wrong in theory and dangerous in practice. Whatever supply-side economists may say, deficits do matter.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Administration Split Over an E.R.A. Appeal
description: Backers of the Federal equal rights amendment were not sure last week whether the Justice Department was deciding the best strategy to push the proposal - or giving a demonstration in how to lose a case without really trying.

title: DETROIT'S LONG WAIT FOR PROSPERITY
description: DETROIT AMONG the c ity's automotive moguls, there are few better phrasemakers than the gruff, tough-talking chairman of the Chrysler Corporation, Lee A. Iacocca. His assessment of the current state of the American automobile industry clearly illustrates the bunker mentality pre valent here despite forecasts of banner sales years justover the hori zon.

title: WOMAN, 76, IS ACCUSED OF KILLING BRONX COUPLE IN A HIT-RUN WRECK
description: A 76-year-old Bronx woman was arrested and charged yesterday in a hit-and-run accident in which an elderly Bronx couple were killed as they crossed the Pelham Parkway at Williamsbridge Road last weekend.

title:
Antiques;
EXPLORING A HIDEAWAY IN MAHWAH
description: MAHWAH SHOPPERS might encounter a little trouble finding Robert G. Simpson's antiques store the first time - and little wonder. The antiques share space with automotive equipment in various stages of repair in the Traffic Safety and Equipment Company building at 437 Route 17 (northbound lane). Also, there is no antiques sign on the shop, which stands behind a Roy Rogers restaurant.

title: Westchester Journal
description: THE Democrats increased their strength on the Board of Legislators in the November elections, reducing the 11 to 6 Republican majority of the last session to a narrower 10 to 7 margin for the next two years, but they retained only token representation last week when it came to committee assignments.

title: VIETNAM AND THE MILITARY MIND
description: Sooner or later, the scar is bared. Late at night in an Army club or an aircraft carrier's wardroom, someone will say, ''My God, if they'd only thought it through in Washington,'' or, ''Brother, if we knew then what we know now about that kind of war,'' or, ''You damned reporters and the damned TV, you're as much to blame as anyone.''

title: Business Class
description: To the Editor:

title: JOURNEY TO MACHU PICCHU
description: EDWARD SCHUMACHER is chief of The New York Times bureau in Buenos Aires. By EDWARD SCHUMACHER

title: Miss Summerill T o Be June Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph John Summerill 3d of Toms River, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kristine Starr Summerill ,to Stuart Laurens Craig Jr., son of Mr. and M rs. Craig of Danville, Va.

title: UTILITY REGULATORS EXPECT IMPACT ON RATES TO VARY
description: Officials of several regulatory agencies around the country reacted with varying degrees of concern yesterday to the implications of the settlement under which the American Telephone and Telegraph Company will divest itself of 22 local Bell System companies.

title: CURBS BEING URGED ON DATA TO SOVIET
description: High Pentagon and intelligence officials are urging that action be taken to stem the flow of unclassified scientific communication that might be of military value to the Soviet Union.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Multiplication Theory, by Cell
description: A cell's reproductive machinery has an on-off switch, a minute segment of each chromosome where the instructions for that chromosome's replication are sited. Scientists can pinpoint a switch's location, but until now they have not been able to find the chemical impulse that turns it on.

title: A GLIMPSE OF THE YEAR 2000
description: WHITHER our world? Walk out the door in the year 2000 and what will be? Datsun spaceships flashing by? Robot chiropractors? Everyone packing a ray gun? No more inflation? No more tooth decay? Everyone parked before the shimmering tube, playing Hyperactive Pac-Man?

title: The Nation in Summary; Pinch and Pain In Massachusetts
description: With what was called at the time ''anger in their eyes,'' Massachusetts citizens marched to the polls two Novembers ago to liberate themselves from onerous property taxes, and in the process from many municipal services. Last year, $550 million to $600 million in revenues were lost, along with 40,000 state and local employees.

title: Does Labor Face a Year of Givebacks?
description: FOR unions, says Douglas A. Fraser, president of the United Automobile Wo rkers, these are the most dismal of times.
