Contracts covering some 4.5 million workers will be negotiated this year against a bac kdrop of demands by American business for major union concessions f ollowing almost a decade of troubled economic times. This year, am id the uncertainties of Reagan Administration labor policies, con tracts are scheduled to be negotiated for more than one million worke rs in the old bellwether industries -autos, rubber and trucking. In addition, major public employee contracts, including agreements co vering 225,000 workers in New York City, will expire. Other pacts c overing workers in teaching, construction, food processing, a griculture, clothing and electri-cal equipment must alsobe negotiated .

title: A CRISIS WITH CHINA MUST BE AVOIDED
description: The No. 1 task for the United States in Asia in 1982 is to repair our strained relations with China. Last year was not a good year for those relations; despite impressive efforts by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr., the seeds have been sown for a full-scale crisis in 1982.

title: THREE-FRONT GUBERNATORIAL FREE-FOR-ALL
description: The Republican State Chairman, George L. Clark Jr., and his choice for Governor, State Comptroller Edward V. Regan, had hoped to paint a rainbow of unity behind Mr. Regan's candidacy at a meeting of the state's 62 Republican county chairmen last week in Albany. Instead, they evidently encountered something more nearly approaching what State Senator Roy M. Goodman called ''an explosion in a paint factory.''

title: History
description: To the Editor:

title: Eden Lipson Is Bride of Neal Johnston
description: Eden Ross Lipson, an editor of The New York Times Book Review, was married yesterday to Neal W. Johnston, deputy chief of the litigation bureau of the New York State Department of Law. Judge Bernard S. Meyer of the State Court of Appeals performed the ceremony at the Manhattan home of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Simons.

title: U.N. CHIEF URGES REAGAN-BREZHNEV MEETING
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar says he believes that a meeting between President Reagan and Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader, would ease tensions in the world.

title: Wren's Churches
description: To the Editor:

title: Paperback Best Sellers; MASS MARKET
description: Mass-market paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: Valenzuela's Salad Night
description: Fernando Valenzuela, the Cy Young Award winner and top rookie in the National League last year, pitched a no-hitter Friday night as the Mayos of Navojoa scored a 1-0 victory in a Mexican Winter League game.

title: The Nation in Summary; Reagan Switches On Draft Sign-up
description: In politics as in philosphy, contradiction can often be resolved by redefinition. And so it was last week, when President Reagan announced he had decided to continue registration of young men for a possible military draft - a practice he had often denounced as an empty symbol from the moment former President Carter ordered its resumption after the Soviet invasion of Afganistan.

title: RANGERS WIN AND REACH .500
description: At 9:49 last night at Madison Square Garden, the Rangers left the ranks of losing hockey clubs, temporarily at least, for the first time since Oct. 11, 1980.

title: Music; GOOD MUSICAL NEWS FROM WHITE PLAINS
description: WHITE PLAINS has long been a political and commercial center in Westchester, but gradually it is becoming a nucleus of cultural activity, too, as the January arts calendar well attests. Two concerts by the White Plains Symphony, a cham ber program by the SaxonWoods Players, and no less than four recitals at the Westchester Conservatory add up to good musical news all around.

title:
Art;
NEW APPROACHES TO 'SOCIAL' ART
description: k PORT WASHINGT ON SO far, the second half of the 20th century has been a less than hospitable er a for the socially conscious artist. It seems that when the world int rudes on its domain, art flies out the window, or so the detractor s of ''social'' art would have us believe.The Courbets, Daumiers and Goyas of another age are judged by different standards, not only because their s ocieties are removed from our own, but also because they are part of the pre-modernist tradition, in which, we presume, all art had some social function, whether religious, political, educational or moral. Since Impressionism, art has been purified and is n ow to be pursued for itsown sake rather than in aid of didactic or id eological ends.

title:
ONE-YEAR PREP SCHOOL OPENS COLLEGE DOORS;
NORTH BRIDGTON, Me.
description: AS a high school student, Tom Viafora of Nashua, N.H., devoted much of his time to his social life, slept when he should have been studying and did just enough schoolwork to get by. When he applied to colleges last year, he wasn't accepted. So he came to this rural New England town to spend a postgraduate year at Bridgton Academy.

title: On 'Eating the Bricks'
description: To the Editor:

title: LOOKING BACKWARD
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Kenneth S. Lynn teaches American history at Johns Hopkins. NO PLACE OF GRACE Antimodernism and the Transformation of American Culture 1880-1920. By T.J. Jackson Lears. 375 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $18.50. By KENNETH S. LYNN

title: Westchester Guide; PERSPECTIVES ON AGE
description: Between 1790 and 1864 the aged in America were regarded as respected and useful members of society. From 1865 to 1935, in a period of rapidly expanding technology and the Great Depression, they came to be viewed as a social problem, and from 1935 to the present, the perception of the elderly has once again shifted, this time spurred by the fact that one out of every six Americans will soon be over 65.

title: Future Events Afloa t and Ashore
description: Tickets to the following may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated. Shipboard Fete Jan. 16 - More than 1,000 merry-makers will board the Qu een Elizabeth 2 at Pier 88 for ''Escape on the Queen,'' a lavish black-tie gala from 8 P.M. to 2 A.M. Georgiana Bronfman, c hairman, heads New York and Washington committees for the event, wh ich includes a champagne reception with raw seafood bar as well as a n international sit-down buffet offering everything from lamb curry to bratwurst and potato pancakes. There'll also be improvisations b y John Monteith and Suzanne Rand and songs by Sarah Dash, to say nothing of dancing in five band areas. Proceeds will be shared eq ually by the Upward Fund, an educational and sports foundation for East Harlem youth, and the Wolf Trap Foundation, the private n onprofit organization responsible for performances at Wolf Trap F arm Park in Vienna, Va. Tickets, $200, from 572-1168.

title: No Headline
description: One is left with the impression that the idealism that fed the civil-rights movement, the antiwar demonstrations and the campus uprisings in the 1960's led to either of two extremes: to the violence of the radical left as demonstrated by the Weather Underground or to assimilation into traditional middle-class strivings, as the enthusiasm of the dissidents faded. My experience is that there are a large number of people who emerged from those years to choose ''alter native life styles.''

title: Mailbox; Build Y ankees, Don't Buy Them
description: To the Sports Editor: What has happened to Yankee baseball? It se ems that every winter George Steinbrenner conducts a metamorphosis. Few would argue the fact that the Yankees h ave the most talented group of players in baseball. The Yankees sho uld win 140 games every year until Steinbrenner's charge card runs ou t. Yet last year, the Yankees collapsed in the World Series to a te am fielding just two players apparently capable of breaking into t he New York lineup.

title: I read with interest Dr. Nelson's article. To begin with, an Individualized Educational Plan (I.E.P.) is done for each child in special education every year, and each child is given a psychological evaluation every three years.
description: In a class of only five children this year, at least 300 sheets of paper were used to write their I.E.P's.

title: RACCOON; Procyon lotor
description: Size: 30 to 36 inches. Color: Grizzled gray, brown and black.

title: Military Analysis
description: For the first time in more than a decade, serious doubts are being expressed about the soundness of the North Atlantic alliance's strategy in defense of Western Europe.

title: zf Around the Nation; Mexican Strike Ends, Freeing Produce for U.S.
description: Mexican truck drivers have ended a six-day strike that had begun to affect the availability and prices of produce in American supermarkets.

title: DALLAS-FT. WORTH
description: FORT WORTH DALLAS and Houston have drawn more attention, but there is no better gauge of the economic mood of the Southwest than this city of 385,000 persons. Long known more for its cattle-town heritage than for entrepreneurial dynamism, Fort Worth is, nevertheless, the site of surging downtown office construction.

title: IN N.Y., REDRAWING LINES STRAINS BIPARTISAN SPIRIT
description: ALBANY WHEN it comes to distributing Congressional seats, small is never beautiful and scarcity always hurts. That, certainly, is the lesson being learned by the state legislators who are now in the process of reapportioning the state to reflect population shifts revealed by the 1980 Census. Because the state's population has grown smaller, five of New York's 39 members of Congress will find next year that seats in the House have grown very hard to find.

title: zf Porters in Tokyo
description: To the Editor:

title: Editors' Choice
description: Hill, $22.95.) The most complete study of Pearl Harbor, laying to rest the theory that we were railroaded into war.

title: THE FACE OF A JOKE ON THE BODY OF A TRUTH
OLDER MANAGERS FIGHTING DISMISSAL
description: AN uncertain economy and America's emphasis on youth are being blamed for a sudden surge in charges of age discrimination in business. The accusations of unfairness by older workers are creating unpleasant situations, a flurry of business for lawyers and occasionally sizable settlements. Within recent months, Abraham & Straus in Brooklyn, I. Magnin in San Francisco, and Marshall Field & Company of Chicago have been involved in lawsuits filed by former senior and middle-level executives, alleging age discrimination in dismissals.

title: On Language
description: By William Safire Vehement Objection KIMBLE MEAD

title: GAPS IN PROSPERITY TROUBLING CANADA
description: Mayor Ralph Klein of Calgary, one of Canada's biggest boom cities, has sent shock waves through the country's growing ranks of unemployed by denouncing the ''bums and creeps'' who come to his city looking for work and end up resorting to crime.

title: Cairo Aide Leaves for U.S.
description: The Egyptian Chief of Staff, Abd Rabel Nabi Hafez, left for the United States today for talks with officials on Egyptian arms purchases from Washington.

title: Charles K. Ortel, Clarissa Bushman Have Wedding
description: Clarissa Lucretia Bushman, a sales and trading associate with Salomon Brothers Inc., the investment bankers, and Charles Kampmann Ortel, a corporate finance associate with the investment banking firm of Dillon, Read & Company, were married yesterday in Grace Episcopal Church. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Paul F.M. Zahl.

title: Theater; A REPERTORY TROUPE COMING TO COUNTY
description: I FIRST saw The New Globe Theater at its very beginnings, in an engagement at the University of Bridgeport in 1979. The plays were ''The Contrast'' by Royall Tyler and ''Hedda Gabler'' by Henrik Ibsen. Although those performances were not overly impressive, a lot has happened since. The company is now fully professional and almost two years of travel and playing have garnered it excellent reviews from St. Louis to Richmond. Now this rare form of theater - a traveling repertory company devoted to the world's great plays - is beginning two engagements in Westchester.

title: Wes Chandler Fits Into the Chargers' Tradition
description: Until John Jefferson arrived in this city in 1978, all receivers had been measured against Lance Alworth. But then Jefferson made the city his with a joyous manner and a willingness to dive for a football as perhaps no one else ever had. After Jeffe rson got here, he became a community asset, like the zoo, the Paci fic Ocean and the United States Navy. He was ''J. J.'', a leaping, laughing young man who once expressed the ambition to be remembered as the greatest receiver ever in the National Foot ball League. His was the stuff of which legends are made.

title:
Speaking Personlly;
TEAMWORK, FROM A GOALIE'S PERSPECTIVE
description: THE wind comes in cold, moist gusts across the playing field at Byram Hills High. The field is neutral ground. Standing on the sidelines, about a hundred parents and high school coaches watch 20 pairs of girls' legs get redder by the minute, either from running or from the cold, probably both. The legs belong to the varsity field hockey teams of Mamaroneck and Centereach (L.I.) high schools, and the game will decide the regional championship.

title: TURKS DENY IDENTIFYING AGCA ASSOCIATE
description: High-ranking Turkish officials are convinced that Mehmet Ali Agca, the man who tried to kill Pope John Paul II, did not act alone, but they have not been able to identify any of his accomplices.

title: AS THE CASE FOR REGULATING BROADCAST JOURNALISM GETS WEAKER
description: To the Editor:

title: Headliners; Roll 'em, Pete!
description: Officials at the Framingham State Prison for Women last week accused former antiwar activist Susan Saxe of being the leader of a computerized narcotics and gambling operation at the Massachusetts facility. A raid by 260 State police and 60 corrections officials cracked the ring and produced ''strong evidence'' that Miss Saxe, a onetime honors student at Brandeis University, now serving time for the 1970 murder of a Boston police officer during a bank robbery, was its ringleader. Her attorney, Nancy Gertner, characterized Miss Saxe as ''a model prisoner,'' and called the charges against her client 'ridiculous.''

title: SOPRANO: KAY STANDIFER
description: Kay Standifer is a young soprano with an excellent ear and a determination to reach inside the songs she sings and make her voice reflect their content. Her program last Monday at Carnegie Recital Hall chose wisely from the songs of Schubert, Strauss and Debussy and added, for extra inter est, six unusual an d interesting ones by Szymanowski.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Village Windfall
description: When Grace Winings died in Argenta, Ill., in 1979, the farm village of 1,000 residents appeared to be the sole heir. Mrs. Winings, a frugal widow, stipulated in her will that the income from her properties, valued at $1.9 million, go for community projects.

title: HOW U.S. PUTS TOGETHER UNEMPLOYMENT STATISTICS
description: When the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced Friday that almost 9.5 million people were unemployed in December, it based this conclusion on a data-gathering procedure whose basic concepts have not changed for 40 years.

title: Critics' Choices
description: MUSIC As our century begins to draw to a close, the term ''20th-century music'' becomes ever more amorphous. One indication of this stylistic breadth can be seen in two programs being presented in New York this week. Sunday afternoon at 2 in the handsome new Lehman College Theater in the Bronx, the well-regarded Bronx Opera will present Ralph Vaughan Williams's nostalgic, bucolic, heartily tonal comic opera, ''Hugh the Drover.''

title: Health Is a Big Factor in Cowboy-49er Showdown
description: Neither chicken pox nor flu will be vital factors in Sunday's game here between the Dallas Cowboys and the San Francisco 49ers for the National Football Conference title. But a sprained ankle and a broken blood vessel may be. Most certainly the forward pass will be.

title: No Headline
description: With regard to Anna Quindlen's informative article, your readers may be interested to learn that, in the New York City area alone, more than 350 women's organizations - ranging from business and professional associations to legislative and political advocacy groups - are actively working to advance the social and economic status of the four million wome n who live and work here. The New York City Commission on the Status of Women has recently compiled information about these organizations into a directory. MARCELLA MAXWELL, New York City Commission on the Status of Women, New York City

title: Other Business; THE CRUNCH IS GONE IN PEANUT BUTTER
description: If you've been scared away from peanut butter, or rather by the price, there's good news in the offing. The 1981 harvest was about double 1980's drought-shrunken 2.3 billion pounds.

title: FOCUSING IN ON CHANNEL 13 OF OLD
description: IT IS now 20 years since WNTA-TV, Channel 13 in Newark, left the air. The station was sold to Educational Television for the Metropolitan Area.

title: LAW STUDENTS AIDING ELDERLY
description: THE Senior Citizen Law Project, which began in September as a joint program of the Pace University Law School and Westchester Legal Services, is providing a new resource for the county's senior citizens who are in need of free legal assistance and representation.

title: STARKER'S FIRST 50 YEARS
description: Since he was six years old, Janos Starker has been married to the cello. Even he, perfectionist that he is, admits it has worked out pretty well.

title: GENEVA'S GEM OF A TOBACCONIST
description: JOHN VINOCUR is chief of The Times bureau in Bonn. By JOHN VINOCUR

title: ...AND THE WOMAN WHO TRACED THEM
description: FOR five years, Dr. Joan Geismar was captivated by the notion of recreating a lost world. After having scoured archival documents in Hackensack, Bayo nne and Palisades, N.Y., and in a half-dozen libraries in the New York metropolitan area, and sifting through the remains of Skunk Hollow, she had become intim ately involved with the freed slaves of the community.

title: 3. CRUISING THE CANALS
description: The tinkle of the ice in my martini indicated that the Janine was under way, easing from her berth at Dijon and into the Burgundy Canal. It was a shakedown cruise of sorts; 14 of us had come down from Paris to participate in a two-day barge trip, the first of the season. The operators of the trip, Floating through Europe, have operated weeklong summer cruises, but the winter weekend trips are something new. Short though it was, the voyage did give us a taste of life aboard a luxury barge.

title: Topics; MATTERS OF LAW; Court Relief
description: A dispute resolution center is a place where trained mediators ventilate grievances between warring neighbors or a shopkeeper and his customers before the conflicts erupt into civil suits or even violence. Reformers have long believed that the centers ease the load on overworked courts.

title: ASSESSMENT OF OIL DAMAGE CONTINUES
description: ''WHO would have thought that the Amawalk would have an oil spill - on the Hudson, sure, but where are you going to find an oil tanker on the Amawalk,'' said a fly fisherman from Bedford Hills, referring to the recent oil spill that affected the Amawalk Outlet, one of the county's best trout streams, and a section of the Muscoot Reservoir in Somers. The spill occured not from a tanker but fro m an oil storage tank in Yorktown Heights when its lock was broken and the pump activated. Cleanup efforts came to an end Friday, but th e investigation and assessment of damages are continuing. Both th e trout stream and the reservoir are part of the Croton watershed an d reservoir system, which is one of the sources of drinking water for New York City and much of Westchester.

title: New York Legal Notes; DEPARTURES A KEY ISSUE FOR LAW FIRM; New York Legal Notes
description: In law as much as in telecommunications, computers and baseball, free enterprise is changing the shape of the marketplace. Seven corporate lawyers from the New York firm of Marshall, Bratter, Greene, Allison & Tucker recently decided to move elsewhere, and after some shopping around are joining the Chicago-based labor law firm of Seyfarth, Shaw, Fairweather & Geraldson. The move, which could ultimately involve as many as 30 lawyers and such key clients as the investment securities house of Drexel Burnham Lambert, is thought to be one of the largest ever in New York.

title: Dining Out; COUNTRY INN WITH EUROPEAN FLAIR
description: STAMFORD TUCKED along Route 104 in the woods of North Stamford near the New York State line, The Country Tavern appears almost a stereotype of a New England country inn. Flagstone and wide-planked flooring, dark rough-hewn wood and stucco walls, Shaker-style chairs and rustic wood tables, pewter service plates and an open hearth with a crackling fire combine to make this old restaurant an inviting winter retreat.

title: SURVIVING A WEEK IN A CARPOOL
description: AN article on a plan for ride-sharing in Westchester County brought to mind my own experience in the realm of car-pooling. It occurred a few years back, during the first gasoline crisis here, and immediately altered my Sybaritic life style as a commuter.

title: FOR ROSSIGNOL, IT'S STILL UPHILL
description: NO one has to sport ''Think Snow'' bumper stickers in this Alpine community in southeastern France. This is the home of Rossignol skis, the world's biggest manufacturer of skis, and a large portion of the 20,000 people who live and work here think of little else but snow. They think about it even more when there isn't any, which was pretty much the case in the last three years. What's more, the snow drought extended from the Alps to Vermont and the Rocky Mountains in the United States. Worldwide sales of skis decreased by 13 percent in the 1980-81 season, and the drop was centered in the United States and Canada.

title: ORLANDO
description: THE last orange tree on Orange Avenue here in the seat of Orange County went under six years ago as unbridled growth and development swept across central Florida like a tropical storm. The boom never lost intensity - rather, it gained in force to the point that the simile today would have to be a hurricane.

title: Home Clinic; HOW TO PREPARE FOR THE WORST THAT WINTER HAS TO OFFER
description: WINTER is a time of many things -some pleasant and some unpleasant - but one of the more unpleasant realities for those living in this area is that fierce storms are likely to strike at any time, leaving homeowners without heat, power and even transportation in some cases.

title: MAYOR'S PAY STIRS FREEPORT GRUMBLING
description: IT is budget time again in Freeport, and if the Board of Trustees adopts the village's proposed 1982-83 budget, Mayor William H. White, who earns $42,500 now and is the highest-paid village official on the Island, will receive a $2,500 pay increase and the four part-time board members earning $6,000 will get $500 raises.

title: Donna Green to Be Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Melvin W. Green of Clifton, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Donna Lynn Green, to Larry S. Gagliardi, son of Mr. and Mrs. Larry R. Gagliardi of Somers, N.Y. The wedding is planned for Aug. 28. Miss Green and her fiance are graduates of Ithaca College. The future bride is vice president of operations with the Government Guaranteed Funding Corporation in Houston, where Mr. Gagliardi is an oil b roker with PVM Oil Associates.

title: Coach Denies Pressure Forced Him to Resign
description: Fred Snowden, the Arizona basketball coach who said Friday night that he would resign after the season to become an assistant athletic director, insisted today that the decision had not been forced by outside pressure.

title: SCANNING AND PLANNING
description: IT was John F. Kennedy's impatience with what he sometimes patronizingly called the ''striped pants boys'' at the State Department that led to the development of the modern National Security Council staff. Under Dwight D. Eisenhower , it had been a small group that did little more than process paperwork for the President and the Council. Mr. Kennedy wanted an aggressive staff of foreign policy specialists, his own ''vest po cket'' State Department.

title:
Gardening;
EDIBLE AS WELL AS ORNAMENTAL PLANTINGS
description: AMONG the more familiar cultivated plants are many examples of closely related species having widely divergent uses. One may find in the same family or genus plants valued for ornamental characteristics and others for edible fruits. Some of the relationships are well known; others are not.

title: AS POLAND'S ECONOMY SLIDES, COMECON FEELS THE BACKLASH
description: Playing down Poland, West German Ch ancellor Helmut Schmidt warned Americ ans last week that world depression may be the biggest political dan ger facing the Western industrial democracies. He could have added th at that Politburo members from Moscow to East Berlin share similar fears. Like some of their capitalist rivals, the Soviet Union and its partners are caught in a severe recession. The virtual colla pse of normal economic life and accompanying political repercussions in Poland, Eastern Europe's second largest country, is the most extr eme example of economic decline throughout the Soviet bloc.

title: CENSUS DATA-VITAL STATISTICS FOR DOING BUSINESS
description: WASHINGTON DURING the last decade demographic information has become increasingly essential for doing business in the United States - to investors who want to know whether to put their money into baby food or wheelchairs; to corporations deciding in which region and locality to build their plants, to marketing companies that must know where to direct advertising and to many others.

title: Volunteer Activity Surveyed
description: About half the adults in the United States took p art in volunteer activities last year, according to a survey commis sioned by Independent Sector, a coalition of volunteer groups. The s urvey showed 52 percent of American adults volunteered in 1981. Elim inating those who simply helped neighbors or engaged in some other in formal activity, the total was still 47 percent of adults, the g roup said.

title: THE GAMES PEOPLE PLAY
description: THE BREAKS OF THE GAME By David Halberstam. 362 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $15.

title: BOB DISHY, STAGE COMIC WITH A FLAIR FOR DRAMA
description: The framed drawing hanging near the door in Bob Dishy's dressing room at the Lyceum is by Jules Feiffer. It portrays Mr. Dishy as an archetypal vaudeville hoofer, his straw hat tilted at a rakish angle, his cane a rapier at the ready, his feet effortlessly shuffling out the old soft-shoe. Mr. Feiffer, the cartoonist and playwright, has bestowed his fondest accolade on Mr. Dishy, the actor and star of his new play ''Grown Ups.'' Mr. Dishy, in turn, is giving the performance of his career in the savage Feiffer comedy about one man's family and how it blows sky high.

title: Film View; LITTLE-NOTICED ACTING GEMS LENT LUSTER TO 1981
description: The year-end orgy of award-giving and the compiling of 10-best lists is, I suppose, a kind of therapy. Something like a wake. It sets the horrors of the old yea r to rest whil e making a pretense at conferring immortality on what are supposed t o be the worthiest of the year's endeavors. Yet no year can be adeq uately recalled by awards given or by severely limited inventori es of excellence. Actors, especially, get short shrift in these various processes. Dustin Hoffman was right when, a couple of ye ars ago, he suggested that such awards are meaningless in that no t wo performances are comparable, and that actors act rather than c ompete. When a comparatively small number of good performanc es are thus recognized, a great many other memorable appearances auto matically become downgraded or lost, left out of the almanacs, remembered only by the trivia experts.

title: Wine
description: MEMORIES ARE MADE OF THIS ur first view of the stone chateau is from above as the three red and white helicopters bank across the beach under cloudy skies, seeking an open space for landing. We settle down on a sand spit jutting into the bay and trudge toward shore as the flying machines whirl upward and away, the beating of their blades vanishing in the distance.

title: Sled Races Canceled
description: The two-man and four-man World Cup bobsled events scheduled here next week have been canceled because of heavy snow, officials said today.

title: Major News in Summary; Western Capitals Seek Alignment On Polish Crisis
description: Americans and Europeans last week sought to prevent the Polish crisis from becoming a crisis for the West. Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. shifted an earlier insistence that the allies join in economic sanctions against the Soviet Union and prepared to settle for ''a confluence of assessment'' of Moscow's role in Poland when NATO foreign ministers meet in Brussels tomorrow.

title: FLOOD OF FOREIGN STUDENTS IS ONLY BEGINNING
description: WHEN Carlos Barron, a native of Mexico City now studying film at New York University, decided he wanted to be a film maker, he knew he had to come to the United States to study. ''If I could have stayed in Mexico, I would have,'' he said, ''but there is only one film school there, and it is not a good one.'' So he enrolled in the program at New York University.

title: FACULTY RESEARCH AND THE WHISTLE
description: BLOWERS By ALAN F. WESTIN

title: Critics' Choices
description: ART One of the most idiosyncratic of artists in the 1960's and early 70's was Oyvind Fahlstrom, who died of cancer at the age of 48 in 1976. Born in Brazil of Swedish and Norwegian parents, he studied art history and archaeology in Stockholm.

title: Essay; HELMUT'S DINNER PARTY
description: The lamb was overdone. That was not the fault of Leonardo Paras, chef at the Federal Republ ic of Germany's Embassy in Washington.

title: YEAR OF DISABLED UNDERMINED BY SETBACKS
description: THE handicapped have rights, but you would never know it from the following: - Connecticut's Attorney General recently filed a brief in the United States Supreme Court in which he stated that deferring expenditures for the Southbury Training School was warranted because mentally retarded people in institutions have a constitutional right for only minimal ''custodial care.'' Twenty other states have joined with Connecticut.

title: HAWKS DEFEAT KNICKS, 102-89
description: With barely more than seven minutes remaining in the Atlanta Hawks' 102-89 defeat of the Knicks tonight, John Drew, a Hawk forward, motioned to his coach, Kevin Loughery, asking to be taken out of the game. The player's face was coated with sweat, and his chest heaved from exhaustion. ''Me,'' he said to Loughery. ''I'm tired.''

title:
Stamps;
NEW 13-CENT ISSUE PAYS TRIBUTE TO CRAZY HORSE
description: The United States is issuing this Friday a stamp to honor an Indian chief who fought to keep his people free a century ago and not subjugated by a great power. The Indian is Crazy Horse, chief of the Oglalas and the military genius of the Sioux Confederacy.

title: HOSPITAL EXPANDED IN HACKENSACK
description: HACKENSACK LONGTIME residents still remember it as the place where they had their appendix or tonsils removed or where their children or grandchildren were born.

title: CHIEF OF FRAUDS UNIT WARNS OF RISING WHITE-COLLAR CRIME
description: WHITE PLAINS AWESTCHESTER County attorney with more than 21 years of law practice is accused of systematically overcharging more than 40 of his clients. A former bookkeeper and computer operator surrenders to investigators from the County District Attorney's office on larceny and forgery charges stemming from his job. A New Rochelle resident is arrested for possessing forged Conrail tickets.

title: Fare of the Country; THE ONE AND ONLY KEY LIME PIE
description: One major attraction of a trip to the Keys, that string of coral outcroppings trailing southwestward into the sea from the tip of Florida, is a wedge of Key lime pie. Better still is several portions, so the visitor can compare one pie with another - as well as enjoy a suitably regional ending to sunny lunches or lazy dinners.

title: NUBIANS SETTLE BY FLOODED HOMELAND
description: The man had last seen his Nubian village, Adendan, in 1963, just before it and two dozen other centuries-old settlements were submer ged by the vast artifi cal lake created by the construction of the Aswan High Dam.

title: AUSTRIA FINDS POLISH INFLOW A BURDEN
description: Austria, a country of 7 million people, prides itself as a haven for East Europeans fleeing Communist rule. In 1981, 34,457 East Europeans -29,059 of them Poles - applied for political asylum in Austria. That was three and a half times the number of refugees who came here in 1980.

title: Around the Nation; Maryland to Cut Off I nstant Lottery Game
description: An aide to Gov. Harry R. Hughes has said that the Governor has decided to end the instant lottery, criticized as a game that attracts the poor, because Maryland does not need such revenue to balance the budget.

title: Headliners; Hired Gun
description: Eugene Tafoya, a former Green Beret convicted last month of two misdemeanor assualt charges in the 1980 shooting of a Libyan student in Colorado, will spend the next two years of his life in Colorado's Larimer County Jail. The resident of Truth or Consequences, N.M. was sentenced to concurrent terms by Federal District Judge J. Robert Miller who imposed the maximum sentence for each of the two counts of assault. Faisal Zagallai, described as a critic of Libyan leader Col. Mummar el-Qaddafi, was shot twice in t he head by Mr. Tafoya. Mr.Zagallai survived but was left blind in his r ight eye. Prosecutors said Mr. Tafoya had been hired by a former Ce ntral Intelligence Agency employee on behalf of the Libyan Gover nment. Mr. Tofoya testified that he thought he was working for the C.I.A.

title: Out of Work First article of a series on the nation's unemployment problem.
description: Just as the burden of inflation has begun to ease, surging unemployment is posing a mounting threat to the security of many Americans.

title: MUSICAL DETECTIVE ARMED WITH A BATON
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- George Malko, a novelist and screenwriter, is the son of Nicolai Malko, the late conductor. By GEORGE MALKO

title: Headliners; Camel Express
description: For Mohi Sobhani an 18-hour camel ride through rugged terrain between Iran to Pakistan was rough on the rump, but worth the effort. The 45-year-old computer expert and naturalized American citizen had been forbidden by the Iranian government to leave the country since 1979 when the U.S. Embassy was seized.

title: Melinda Jill Blau Is the Bride of David Alan Page
description: Melinda Jill Blau, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. BenAmi Blau of Somers, N.Y., was married yesterday to David Alan Page, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Page of Bardonia, N.Y. Westchester County Supreme Court Judge Matthew F. Coppola performed the ceremo ny at the White Plains Hotel.

title: G.S.A. Advisory Unit Named For Efficiency and Operation
description: The administrator of the General Services Administration has named an advisory board composed mostly of business executives to help the agency improve its efficiency and operation.

title:
Comment;
TAX BREAKS: TRY RENT-A-KID
description: T HE Reagan Administration is trying to enlist the private sector in augmenting funds reduced by cutbacks in s ocia l programs such as food stamps and rent subsidies. They could encoura ge this by permitting the sale, for tax purposes only, of the natio n's poor children.

title: Around the World; Libyan Aides Reported In Ghanaian Capital
description: A large number of Libyan officials arrived in Accra, the Ghanaian capital, today, according to informed sources here.

title: Draft Heat
description: One of Washington's favorite sports is catching Presidents in postelection switches. Candidate John Kennedy repeatedly promised in 1960 to end discrimination in Federally assisted housing with ''the stroke of a pen.'' It took 21 months for President Kennedy to make good. Candidate Jimmy Carter resisted decontrol of oil and gas prices. President Carter, to his great credit, led the long and fierce battle to decontrol both.

title: China Wiping Out Plague
description: China said today that it had almost eradicated bu bonic plague, which killed more than a million people here in epide mics in the first half of the century.

title: DENVER
description: DENVER KENNETH J. Barr is still bullish on 1982 economic prospects for the Rockies, but even here -where oil, gas and mineral activity has turned sleepy mountain villages into boom towns - the slowdown in the national economy is having an impact. ''We're lay ing on our plans, and we're certain the boom in mineral activity is c oming,'' said Mr. Barr, president of Amoco Minerals, a unit of the S tandard Oil Company of Indiana. ''But it's been delayed.''

title: New York Times Magazine January 10, 1982
description: William Safire 10 On Language Vehement Objection Russell Baker 19 Sunday Observer Never Say Sorry Henry Scott Stokes 24 Japan's Love Affair With the Robot John Heminway 28 A Warrior for Wildlife Ugandan game warden Paul Ssali defended his embattled park against not only poachers but also the savagery of Idi Amin. Drew Middleton 34 Vietnam and the Military Mind Hedrick Smith 38 How Reagan Rode Out 1981 Terry Robards 66 Wine Memories Are Made of This 68 Fashion Making a Splash Craig Claiborne 74 Food with Pierre Franey A Fling With Scotland's Soups 92 Puzzles Answers, Page 56 94 Letters Cover:Photograph by Jack Mitchell Copyright 1980, The New York Times

title: 1. BRITTANY'S RUGGED NORTH COAST
description: RICHARD EDER is chief of The Times Paris bureau By RICHARD EDER

title:
AT SORBONNE, IT'S OUVRE LA PORTE;
PARIS
description: BEATRICE DOURTHE, who retired at age 60 this year from her job as a graphologist in a Paris department store, is studying myth and literature at the Sorbonne this semester. ''I love to read and I wanted to seek the sources of literature,'' she says.

title: The World in Summary; Arabs Agree on a Common Foe, but Only at the U.N.
description: Israel's annexation of the formerly Syrian Golan Heights last month has not made Arabs forget their bitter internal quarrels. But it did give Damascus the opening to reassert Arab leadership behind a hard, rejectionist line.

title: TO STOP THOSE HURTFUL MERGERS IN THEIR TRACKS
description: To the Editor:

title: 2. AT HOME IN A CHATEAU
description: IRVIN M. HOROWITZ is an assistant national news editor of The Times. By IRVIN M.HOROWITZ

title:
Gardening;
EDIBLE AS WELL AS ORNAMENTAL PLANTINGS
description: AMONG the more familiar cultivated plants are many examples of closely related species having widely divergent uses. One may find in the same family or genus plants valued for ornamental characteristics and others for edible fruits. Some of the relationships are well known; others are not.

title: THE BABY BOOM COMES OF AGE
description: THE first class of the baby-boom generation will turn 36 years old in 1982, the heart of the prime working years, when the limitless opportunities for promotion and career development promised by parents and teachers should be manifesting themselves aplenty.

title: A SIGN OF HOPE IN BRITAIN
description: LONDON A T first glance, the result of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's bold economic experiment seems a landscape of devastation. From an 11.5 percent unemployment rate, more than double what it was when she arrived, to a 15 percent drop in manufacturing output, the overwhelming impression is of a teetering economy dealt a near-fatal blow by her policies of austerity.

title: DANCE: LENORE LATIMER PRESENTS 2 NEW WORKS
description: Lenore Latimer came out before the curtain Friday night at the Theater of the Riverside Church, welcomed the audience and expressed the wish that they should have a good time. How can you miss with an opener like that?

title: Soviet Warns Europe on Trade
description: The Soviet Union cautioned Western European countries today against any moves to join the United States in sanctions imposed on Moscow after the military crackdown in Poland.

title: Miss Cosgrove Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Joseph Cosgrove of Darien, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Ann Cosgrove, to David George Chandler, son of Mr. and Mrs. George A. Chandler,also of Darien. The wedding is planned for late next July.

title: QUICK ACTION ON NO-HEAT CALLS SURPRISES TENANTS
description: After Arthur Avila and Frank Autunnale made their way through the ice-cold furnace room yesterday morning and up the splintered stairs piled with trash and reeking of cats, they came upon the only tenanted apartment in the three-story building in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn.

title: RENOVATED LIVES
description: A MOTHER AND TWO DAUGHTERS By Gail Godwin. 564 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $15.95.

title: PENTAGON STUDIES PHONE PACT'S SECURITY PROVISION
description: Defense Department law yers said today that they had not determined whether the proposed settlement of the antitrust case against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company adequately protected national security, inclu ding the need for a nationwide emergency communications network.

title: AVANT-GARDE: PEG AHRENS MIXE S MEDIA
description: Peg Ahrens is a young woman trying to juggle many artistic media at once - her evening at the Kitchen on Friday mixing mime, sign language, dancing, singing, flute playing, poetry, video tape, photography and lighting effects.

title: BROWNSTONE BUYERS GET A SHORT COURSE IN WISDOM
description: It was a familiar situation: The house-hunting young man and his wife took one look at a 130-year-old brownstone in the Boerum Hill section of Brooklyn and were snared.

title: Stadler, on 66-195, Leads By 7 Strokes
description: Craig Stadler shot a four-under-par 66 and took a seven-stroke lead today after the third round of the $300,000 Tucson Open, the first event on the pro golf tour.

title: HOSPICE PROJECTS: A DEBATE ON L.I.
description: MRS. SMITH, a woman in her 50's suffering from cancer of the kidneys and the intestines, was taken to the hospice unit for terminally ill patients at Mercy Hospital in Rockville Centre last year. A local resident, she had been discharged from a New York City hospital, where she was told that nothing further could be done to prevent the rapid spread of the disease. Unable to eat, she was resigned to a few more weeks of pain and discomfort before dying.

title: REALISM (TRUE AND FALSE) IS EVERYWHERE
description: Realism, like influenza, is always with us. So I infer, at any rate, from the fact that so many of the most talked-of things in the fall and winter season have come to us tagged with its name. Andrzej Wajda's movie, ''Man of Iron,'' is indispensable, for instance, to anyone who wants to understand what has lately happened in Poland. What better name than ''realist'' for the immediacy with which it spells out the facts about Solidarity? Among current one-man exhibitions in New York, the most distinguished is the show of paintings by Giorgio Morandi at the Guggenheim Museum. And you can't get much closer to most people's idea of realism than by spending your life painting jugs and vases, over and over.

title: Music View; OH, THE TALENT IT TAKES TO MAKE A BOW INTO A WOW
description: The young virtuosos who stampede out of our music schools and onto our concert stages each season are in most ways superior to the renowned performers of yesteryear. The pianists can play faster, the sopranos can trill longer, the conductors c an leap higher than ever. But in one area the training of the modern mu sician is woefully weak:hardly any of the new virtuosos enter profess ional life prepared to execute their post-performance bows with ecla t, let alone panache. For the most part they are ignorant of the gr eat traditions of this crucial maneuver and give little indication t hat they have studied its nuances. They actually relax when encore time comes, not realizing that the concert is but a prelude.

title: AVOCADO GLUT HAS GROWERS THINKING OF PET FOOD
description: California growers are awash in avocados this winter, and the surplus has touched off a feud in the avocado groves over how to get rid of the extra fruit.

title: WAYS IN WHICH PARENTS CAN HELP A PRESCHOOLER DEVELOP BASIC SKILLS
description: How can you help your preschooler develop basic skills? Dr. Nancy K. Naron, Director of Project EARLY in Chicago, suggests that you can have your child do the seemingly simple activities below to help improve language and motor skills and memory. Language Skills

title: REAGAN EXPECTED TO ACCEPT TAX RISE
description: President Reagan is expected to accept the consensus among his senior advisers that he must propose tax increases for the next two fiscal years, according to Administration officials involved in the budget deliberations.

title: No Headline
description: To the Business Editor:

title: Reading and Writing; THE NEW WOMAN
description: A new sort of woman has appeared in the fiction of the past decade: not the feminist's woman, with whom she has some qualities in common, but something more idiosyncratic, more a product of the literary than the political i magination. One might say that in the new woman'spolitics, she herself is the candidate. There is about her an air of nomination or election.

title: The Nation in Summary; Dirty Tricks, Dirty Hands?
description: From the start, the Central Intelligence Agency has denied any official connections with the former agents who have been accused of training and arming Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi's terror squads. Enter into this bloody labryinth Douglas M. Schlacter, who last week threw the C.I.A. denials into doubt.

title: KEY ISLE IN 1776 NAVAL BATTLE NOW MOSTLY IN STATE'S HANDS
description: New York State has acquired almost all of Valcour Island in Lake Champlain, the site of the first major naval battle of the Revolutionary War on Oct. 11, 1776.

title: BLACK THEATER: MUST IT APPEAL TO WHITES?
description: The Negro Ensemble Company, the oldest and best-known black theater group in New York City, has a hit on its hands. ''A Soldier's Play,'' Charles Fuller's skillfully crafted murder mystery, set in the 1940's, which is also a subtle exploration of racism, is packing the N.E.C.'s Theater Four at 424 West 55th Street.

title: WHY FORT LEE LURES JAPANESE
description: FORT LEE HIDEO and Misako Miyamoto are typical of the more than 4,000 Japanese who live in Fort Lee. The Miyamotos, who have been here for two years, rent a two-family brick house on 13th Street, in the middle of the mostly transient Japanese community.

title: ATLANTA
description: ATLANTA FOR most of the last decade, Crest Properties Inc. ranked among the most successful home builders in the Atlanta area. It constructed more than 900 single-family houses in the last seven years and never missed a payment to its lenders. Today, it is on the growing list of business casualties in the South with troubles traceable largely to an ailing national economy.

title: AID FOR DISABLED IS DEFENDED
description: A WISE old farmer in Alabama listened to my plans many years ago and summed up his views with the folk saying, ''If it ain't broke, don't fix it.'' The Education of the Handicapped Act, which finally assures handicapped children a free and appropriate public education, is working. As we pass the third anniversary of the full implementation of this law, 4.2 million children - blind, deaf, mentally, physically or emotionally disabled, speech- or language-impaired or with specific learning disabilities - are enrolled in special-education programs. Despite remarkable progress in the educating of the handicapped children of our nation, the Reagan Administration wants to ''fix'' this problem by returning national public policy to what it was before 1965. Congress, recalling all too well the pain and anger of parents of disabled children who are denied schooling, has refused to go along with the Administration, but the Administration threatens to keep trying.

title: ELDERLY AID IN STUDY OF BONE DISEASE
description: It was barely 9 A.M., and the walks of Leisure Village, a 2,000-member community of the elderly in Suffolk County, were quiet except for the sound of a gentle rain. But inside a converted model condominium unit, a few residents were already taking turns working out on a treadmill, rowing machine and other exercise apparatus.

title: Other World Events; Belated Charges in Pretoria
description: South Africa is among the first to condemn ''international terrorism'' when the alleged perpetrators happen to be nonwhite. But Pretoria reacted with marked leniency when 45 white mercenaries hijacked an Air India plane to South Africa in November after bungling a coup in the Seychelles.

title: WHERE TOWN HALL IS THE FAMILY ROOM
description: WARREN WHEN Patricia Tanner began her duties as Warren's new Town Clerk last week, there was plenty of family around to wish her well. But other members of the Tanner family didn't come down to Town Hall just to celebrate the occasion; they work there, serving in elected or appointed offices or as town employees.

title: The Region in Summary; Pursuing the Key Question
description: Everyone seemed to agree last week that the killing of Frank Melvin, a 26-year-old Guardian Angel, by a Newark policeman was a ''tragic error.'' That was about the only point of agreement.

title: Headliners; Back to Prison
description: Ida Milgron, mother of convicted Soviet dissident Anatoly B. Shcharansky, says her son has been transferred from a labor camp to a prison on the Volga River. Mrs. Milgron said last week she had visited her son at the Chistopol Prison where he has been sentenced to three years for refusing to acknowledge his guilt. Mr. Shcharansky, convicted in 1978 of anti-Soviet activities and spying for the United States, served two years of a three-year prison sentence before being transferred to a labor camp in April 1980. In a letter to The New York Times Boris Antonov of the Soviet Press agency said he visited Mr. Shchransky at Chistopol and found him to be in good condition. ''What a great joke,'' Shcharansky remarked to his mother.

title: FOLK: RICHARD THOMPSON
description: Richard Thompson, who is almost certainly the greatest English composer of contemporary folk music, made a rare solo appearance at the Bottom Line on Thursday. Accompanying himself on acoustic guitar and mandolin, he performed 27 songs, ranging in style from Highland jigs to Hank Williams tunes, at the first of two shows.

title: The Region in Summary; Carey Reviews The State, Its Needs and Wants
description: Like many a speech before it, Governor Carey's State of the State Message last week evoked more history than it is likely to make. His call for a partial state takeo ver of welfare and Medicaid payments and revamping public education financing were statements on significant i ssues, but for the most part, the Governor's proposals had either be en much heard of before or seemed likely to be little heard of late r.

title: Crime U pdate
description: The body of a 26-year-old taxi driver, Ben Zion Babahanov, was discovered at 4:30 A.M. on Oct. 16 in front of 20-30 127th Street in College Point, Queens. He had been shot to death. His taxi was later found in Manhattan. The following morning, a second New York City taxi driver, Stephen Myers, 38, was found shot to death in a driveway in Baldwin, L.I. His cab was later recovered in East Harlem.

title: 'FLING IT OUT WHEN IN DOUBT'
description: SOME people are savers. I go to the other extreme, throwing out items with abandon, hoping the other inhabitants of my home will not see them before pickup time. I am one of those people who throw out everything; I don't discriminate.

title: STENMARK'S 63D VICTORY SETS MARK
description: AVORIAZ, France, Jan. 9 (AP) - Ingemar Stenmark of Sweden set a career record today by posting his 63d World Cup skiing victory.

title: NEW FROM SILICON VALLEY: THE WINCHESTER DRIVE
description: SAN JOSE, Calif. W HILE the rest of the electronics industry is bracing to weather the recession, one young business has made an extraordinary debut, one that its partisans compare to the first months of the calculator and digital watch booms of the early 70's.

title: Chicago Firefighters Agree
description: Union firefighters and the city have tentatively agreed on a contract that covers at least 1982, Mayor Jane M. Byrne announced Friday. Details of the pact, only the second formal one between the parties, were being wi thheld pending its presentation to the Chicago Fire Fighters Uni on Local 2 executive board on Monday.

title: THE PRESIDENT AS CHAIRMAN OF THE BOARD
description: WASHINGTON HE meets with his Cabinet once a week. He takes off one afternoon a week, usually Wednesday, frequently to go riding. Typically he puts in a nine-hour day at the office and reads an hour or two in the evening. But most of his day is spent performing ceremonial functions or trying to persuade people to do the things he wants done.

title: CHEEVER SCRIPT OPENS 'AMERICAN PLAYHOUSE'
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Doug Hill is a freelance writer who frequently reports on the television sc ene. By DOUG HILL

title: Mailbox; Simms Deserves His Job Back
description: To the Sports Editor: It was fun while it lasted for Giants fans, but the thrill was shortlived and it's gone. And who can honestly say that football's final four don't deserve it? It is time for all diehard Giants fans to direct their thoughts to next season.

title: JAZZ: 'HEART' OF BASIE BAND
description: There are Basie sounds floating through the Rainbow Room these nights, but the Count is nowhere in sight. The sounds are coming from a 12-piece ensemble led by Grover Mitchell that includes seven members of the Basie band, inc luding Mr. Mitchell, a trombonist. Mr. Mitchell's gr oup, called the Heart of the Basie Band, will be in the Rainbow Room through next Sunday.

title: SOME PEOPLE LEARN DEGREE BY NIGHT
description: AT the end of World War II, Michael Luther came home wanting an education. And like so many other returning veterans, he was looking for work as well. At Columbia University he found both: a job with the Columbia Press during the day, and an education in the classroom at night. Now Professor Luther tells his own evening class students at Hunter College, ''I know how you feel.''

title: No Headline
description: This Week: To save fil e space, don't forget to discard old seed catalogues as new ones arri ve. . . . Stock bird feeders daily and scatter dried corn for grou nd feeding birds such as quail and pheasants. . . . Lightly water the amaryllis bulb, if the tip of a round flower stalk is starting t o emerge. Warm and Cozy

title: Thoreau's Journals
description: To the Editor:

title: INFLATION DECLINES AS THEORIES MULTIPLY
description: Along with the bad news in last week's Labor Department report on employment, there was a kernel of good news, for inflation watchers at least. While unemployment rose to 8.9 percent in December, the average hourly earnings of nonfarm workers were only 8.1 per cent higher than a year earlier.

title:
New Jersey Housing;
STATE IS LURING FOREIGN INVESTORS
description: WHEN we think of foreigners investing in real estate in this country, we generally conjure up images of posh Manhattan co-ops, Beverly Hills mansions, shopping centers in Texas or rambling Middle Western farms. We do not think of two-story office buildings and suburban garden-apartment complexes.

title: POLAND TO EXPAND ITS PRIVATE SECTOR
description: The Polish military Government, faced with severe food shortages, has decided to allow some rural factories and processing plants to be turned over to private ownership, according to the Warsaw radio.

title: Qand A
description: Question:Are there any bus tours of Europe that absolutely ban smoking? Our tour last year put smokers in the back, but the smoke still came up to the front, and a person with lung problems can't stand smoke. - E.R., Rochester, N.Y. Answer:Mildred A. Post, coordinator of the Nonsmokers Travel Club, says: ''Yes, tours offered by our organization will have exclusiveuse buses where there is absolutely no smoking.

title: NERVOUS BANKS START STRIKING BACK
description: BANKS are getting nervouser and nervouser. They see the financial world rapidly changing around them while they remain locked into a legal and regulatory structure developed decades before automation and low-cost, high-speed communications made geographic and productline boundaries obsolete.

title: No Headline
description: TENNESSEE OVERCOMES KENTUCKY, 70-66

title: STATE TO STUDY PUBLIC FINANCING IN FUTURE VOTING FOR GOVERNOR
description: TRENTON THE closest gubernatorial election in New Jersey - given the size of the vote - is history. However, a group of state officials are getting ready to review the 1981 primary and general elections, not to rehash who won and who lost, but to examine how they played the game.

title: Business Conditions; U.S. OFFSHORE BANKING
description: America's answer to offshore banking centers such as the Cayman Islands, Bermuda, and perhaps someday London, are International Banking Facilities, which encourage banks to do their foreign business in this country by insulating them from domestic taxes and some Federal Reserve regulations.

title: No Headline
description: Child custody determinations should be among the most difficult decisions a court must make because of their profound effect on all involved. If the court is serious in its task, we can expect such determinations to exemplify its best intelligent judgment and prudence. Indeed, the ideals of judicial procedure are abrogated in favor of some vaguely conceived higher knowledge with this abrogation couched in the ''best interest of the children'' doctrine. Elizabeth Greene's letter to the editor is important to the issue of child custody determinations because it represents the worst of a bad situation, i.e, thoughtlessness, presumption and fabrication.

title: Automated Offices to Give Managers a Competitive Edge
description: THE focus of office automation is shifting away from the secretary's desk to the boss's. Both office equipment vendors and their customers have ceased stressing word processors that electronically speed up typing and have started to stress putting computer terminals, or entire personal computers, on the desks of nearly every white-collar worker.

title: CLARK PICKS UP THE PIECES BUT CAN HE DO THE PUZZLE?
description: WASHINGTON LIKE generals preoccupied with the lessons of the last war, new Administrations are often so determined to avoid their predecessors' mistakes that they create new ones, often worse. A year ago, Mr. Reagan and his advisers, eager to avoid the internal foreign policy conflicts that marked the Carter Administration, downgraded the nation al secu rity operation under Richard V. Allen. But they wound up publicly d isplaying differences between Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. and Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger, friction betw een Mr. Haig and the White House, and confusion in the bureaucracy a nd among America's allies. By replacing Mr. Allen last week and upgr ading the authority of the new national security adviser, Will iam P. Clark Jr., the President tacitly acknowledged that the orig inal tinkering had not worked.

title: The World in Summary; Who Kidnapped The Groom?
description: Romeo and Juliet had only parental opposition to contend with. But Verona isn't Manila and Tommy Manotoc's father charged last week that the father of Imee Marcos, who happens to be Philippines President Ferdinand E. Marcos, was responsible for Tommy's disappearance in Manila on Dec. 29 shortly after he secretly married Miss Marcos in Arlington, Va.

title:
ETHNICITY ISSUE RISES IN ISRAEL;
JERUSALEM INTEGRATION, long a problem in the schools of the United States, has become a controversial issue in Israel. The major center of the controversy is this most ethnically diverse city in the nation, with courts, despite parental opposition, continuing to uphold the mingling of Sephardis a nd Ashkenazis.
description: Tensions have long been increasing between the Sephardis, Jews of mostly North African and Asian origin, and the Ashkenazis of primarily European and North American extraction. These strains have spilled over into the nation's classrooms, where parents of children of varied backgrounds oppose integrated attendance.

title: AS THE LANDFILLS FILL UP, RECYCLING IS ENCOURAGED
description: ''We're trying to reverse 300 years of an established pattern of burying our garbage,'' said Donald Middleton, director of the Long Island office of the State Department of Environmental Conservation.

title: No Headline
description: Miss Navratilova Gains Final

title: MANAGEMENT MEMORANDUM
description: TO: Male Ex ecutives SUBJECT: Combat Orders

title: SPECIAL ELECTION FOR CONGRESS IS FOSTERING ODD STRATEGIES
description: HARTFORD REPUBLICANS view Tuesday's special election in the First Congressional District as a chance to win a third House seat, which would give them possession of half of the state's Washington, D.C., delegation. Democrats, who held the seat from 1959 until the death of William R. Cotter on Sept. 8, see the race as an opportunity to extend their claim on a district that has been described as the Democratic heartland of the state.

title: COMPUTER ADDS EFFICIENCY TO POLITICAL CALCULATIONS
description: FARMINGTON IT is just a small computer, recently installed in a tiny Farmington office, but already it is regarded by supporters of United States Representative Toby Moffett as a significant asset in his effort to win the Democratic Party's nomination for United States Senate.

title: Paperback Talk
description: Author of the year. The midwinter gloom pervading Publishers Row was broken last week by a cheery publicist asking an arresting question: ''Who do you suppose was the author of 1981's best-selling book? Sidney Sheldon? Richard Simmons? V.C. Andrews? Stephen King?'' Stuart Applebaum of Bantam Books answered his own question. ''It was James G. Nourse. His 'The Simple Solution to Rubik's Cube' has had printings totaling 6,300,000 copies and helped make last November and December the best two months in Bantam's 36-year history.''

title: COMMERCIAL BUILDING PACE QUICKENS
description: THE construction of luxury office and industrial buildings in Nassau County is undergoing a sharp increase, as developers race to meet a growing demand for commercial space. ''The construction that's going on in our county now is just unprecedented,'' according to the Nassau County Executive, Francis T. Purcell, who said in a recent interview that both new office space and manufacturing space were ''on a tremendous rise here.''

title: Phone and Telex Link With Poland Still Cut
description: Although the Polish Government has lifted censorship restric tions on foreign co rrespondents, regular telephone and telex links between Poland and th e outside world remain cut.

title: The Women's Networks
description: Anna Quindlen's article, ''Women's Networks Come of Age'' (Nov. 22), which was centered around the Women's Media Group and the Women's Forum, here in New York, may prompt a few letters complaining about the ''elitism'' of such selective networks.

title: 'GREATEST HITS' HELP TO CLARIFY BRITISH ROCK
description: When the punks transformed British rock-and-roll after 1977, they did so with an ideology. That theoretical framework, paradoxically, stressed the intuitive, instinctual basis of their music, as opposed to the supposedly overfancified decadence of their immediate predecessors. But these supposedly anti-cultural diatribes were written with considerable passion and intelligence; indeed, they had a considerably greater intellectual depth than their more mindless, hedonistic precursors. And the unwillingness of the mass audience to abandon the old and to accept this brave new world merely proves that pop music is meant to be popular. A pop audience will generally resist elitist innovators, even when those innovators drape themselves in populist rhetoric.

title: DAVE JENNINGS ON A SEASON OF GIANT STEPS
description: AS I look back on this past season, it's tough to look beyond last weekend. I'm still so very disappointed in the way we played against San Francisco. Losing is bad enough but it's how we lost. I don't want to take anything away from the 49ers; they played well and deserve to play Dallas this afternoon. But after playing so well for six weeks, we played poorly and made a bunch of costly mistakes. And now the season is over.

title: Practical Traveler; THE OUTLOOK FOR 1982
description: Despite an uncertain economy and uneasiness in the travel industry, some excellent vacation opportunities are expected to be available in 1982 - both at home and abroad - for those who know where to look and how to shop among the choices.

title: BUDGET CUT COSTS RUTGERS CLERIC HIS JOB
description: NEW BRUNSWICK THE Rev. Robert J. Tanksley's 7 1/2-year tenure as Coordinator of Religious Affairs at Rutgers University ended with the close of fall semester on Dec. 22. Dr. Edward J. Bloustein, president of the university, said that the clergyman had to be let go for budgetary reasons.

title: SO, GIVE CREDIT WHERE CREDIT IS DUE (POLAND)
description: The political crisis in Poland cannot be separated from the financial crisis, and the mountain of foreign debt. But before the West becomes too moralistic and dogmatic about the need to shut off credit, we should recall how we first built up that mountain of debt.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Unwanted Fame
description: She was 17 years old, academically brilliant and a talented soprano and flutist when a youth pushed her in front of a subway train in mid-Manhattan on June 7, 1979, and her name, Renee Katz, became familiar to millions. Her right hand was severed, but in a 14-hour operation at Bellevue Hospital, surgeons reattached it.

title: Sound; A NEW TUNER EMBODIES SIGNIFICANT GAINS IN FM RECEPTION
description: One New Year's resolution I am definitely going to keep - right away, in fact - is to thank all the readers who have written to me. I can't always send personal replies, but fan mail is good for the ego, and even critical letters are valuable because they remind me that nobody is perfect.

title: Chess; THE ONE-TWO PUNCH
description: One of the most difficult types of combinations to envision is that in which the initial sally following the sacrifice does not subdue the opponent but demands a second theme to prevail. If one spots only the first segment, one is apt to get discouraged and drop the whole combinational idea.

title: RATING BELOW 50%
description: Public approval of President Reagan has slipped below 50 percent for the first time and he now stands lower than President Carter did four years ago, according to the latest Gallup Poll.

title: The World in Summary; Mubarak Weeds His Backyard
description: Three months on the job, Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak has lost no time in stepping out of the shadow of Anwar el-Sadat, his assassinated predecessor. Last week, he dropped some Sadat cronies from power and made a big weapons deal with France that may somewhat lessen Cairo's dependence on the United States.

title: THE DANCE: A NAHARIN SHOWCASE
description: Although Thursday night's program at the Theater of the Riverside Church was called ''Dances by Mari Kajiwara and Ohad Naharin,'' choreographically it was a showcase for Mr. Naharin, who devised six of the seven offerings.

title: Dance View; A REVEALING SOVIET DANCE ENCYCLOPEDIA
description: Did you know that the Mongolian Ballet staged ''Giselle'' in 1978 and that Siberia's Yakutsk Ballet did an original ballet version of ''The Hunchback of Notre Dame'' in 1980? Or that patriotic divertissements to Russian songs stemming from Napoleon's invasion of Russia in 1812 were created by Isaak Abletz, a 19th-century choreograper in Moscow? And although one knew that Leningrad's Kirov Ballet had a ballerina named Ninel Kurgapkina -whose firt name is Lenin spelled backwards -and a premier danseur named Vladilen Semyenov - whose first name is a contraction of Vladimir Lenin - one did not know that a leading Kirov-trained Soviet ballerina and choreographer in the Central Asian city of Dushanbe is named Stalina Azimovna Azamatova.

title: Miss Myers To Be Bride
description: Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Eugene N. Myers of Pittsburgh of the engagement of their daughter, Marjorie Rose Myers, to Cary Freeman Fulbright, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Freeman Fulbright of New York.

title: BLACK WOMEN: ON THEIR OWN
description: WOMEN, RACE & CLASS By Angela Y. Davis. 271 pp. New York: Random House. $13.50. By ANN JONES

title: PASTA PRODUCERS FEAR IMPORT IMPACT
description: WASHINGTON AMERICANS are getting stuffed with foreign pasta. According to the National Pasta Association, the average American eats nine pounds of macaroni, spaghetti and noodles a year, but perhaps as much as two pounds of that is produced by foreign (mostly Italian) manufacturers.

title: COLLEGES FOSTER TECHNICAL TR AINING
description: year-old manufacturing process engineer at Sperry Gyroscope in Lake Success, has been on the job only a year and a half. But he already considers himself a success because he is doing what he wants to do and expects to reach his goal of a manufacturing management position in the not-too-distant future.

title: VON BULOW TRIAL, TO OPEN TOMORROW, FOCUSES ON NEWPORT SUMMER COLONY
description: Uncharacteristically for him, Claus von Bulow is spending the winter season here in Newport, which is gray and blowing cold this time of year.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; When Weather Is Merciless
description: Wet and windy was the weather forecast for much of the United States when a violent shift in upper air masses greeted the New Year. By the end of last week, there was tragedy and disaster.

title: WESTCHESTER
description: WHITE PLAINS TUCKED into a corner of Westchester's commuter and corporate economy is Per Sorens en. Mr. Sorensen's Royal Copenhagen P orcelain Corporation, a $7 million Danish importing and distributin g company, trucked its delicate inventory of 350,000 plates and figur ines last August into a warehouse here and became one of a growing n umber of small businesses that the county helped to remain and expa nd here.

title: WASHINGTON
description: IT started with a question: Why aren't black youngsters going to Georgetown or Harvard? The answers were largely cultural. For Washington's schools, there was a solution: provide a school that offers things black children don't normally get - a little Shakespeare, a grounding in classical and modern languages, perhaps a trip to Europe, certainly a venture into community service.

title: Around the World; Arabs' Anti-U.S. Plan Is Endorsed by Assad
description: President Hafez al-Assad of Syria today endorsed resolutions by the Arab League's Labor Organization that call for unspecified actions against United States diplomatic missions and interests in the Middle East and the use of oil as a political weapon.

title: BIRTH-CONTROL SHOWCASE
description: To the Editor:

title: Connecticut Housing; REFINANCING PRIVATE HOME LOANS
description: WITH mortgage interest rates floating downward, this may be the ideal time for someone holding short-term seller financing to consider shopping around for refinancing from a bank.

title:
Antiques;
FURNITURE FEATURED AT WALLINGFORD
description: WALLINGFORD WITH its concentration on 18th- and early-19th-century heirlooms, the 19th annual Wallingford Antiques Show opens the winter show schedule for collectors of Early American furniture and decorative accessories. The show will be presented next weekend at the State Armory on Main Street, running Friday and Saturday from !1 A.M. to 9 P.M. and Sunday from noon until 6 P.M.

title: JUDGE SETS BAIL OF $10 MILLION IN QUEENS FOR BRINK'S SUSPECT
description: A suspect in the ambush-slaying of a police officer in Queens last April and the $1.6 million Brink's holdup in Rockland County in October that left three persons dead was arraigned in Queens yesterday and ordered held in $10 million bail.

title: A Sport y, Subtler Camar o
description: THE new car creates a sensation at gas stations. It draws a small crowd when you park it. And it's something of a menace on the highway, since other drivers are constantly taking their eyes off the road to weave alongside for a 60-mile-an-hour once-over.

title: The Region in Summary; Mrs. Fenwick Joins the Rush
description: In politics, adversity can sometimes be the mother of ambition. For Representative Millicent Fenwick last week, the adversity was the prospect of sharing a Congressional district with another Republican under a reapportionment plan approved by the Democratic-controlled State Legisla ture.

title: 'GYPSY SCHOLARS' ROAM ACADEMIC LANDSCAPE
description: PAUL PICCONE began teaching sociology at the Memorial University of Newfoundland this fall. He has barely finished grading his first set of final exams in St. John's and he and his family are already packing to head for Carbondale, Ill., where h e will teach this spring at the University of Southern Illinois .

title: A MOVIE EPICURE'S VENTURE
description: Dino De Laurentiis, who made a name for himself as the producer of the movie ''Bitter Rice,'' has set his sights on becoming equally famous as a purveyor of other kinds of rice: arborio, basmati, pecan, wild and perhaps even long grain. Mr. De Laurentiis has leased space for two food shops on the Upper West Side that are scheduled to open late this spring.

title: Hound & Horn
description: To the Editor:

title: Virginia L. Macomber Is Married to a Banker
description: Virginia Lee Macomber, program manager of the Department of Housing and Urban Development in New York, was married yesterday at the Plaza to Roger Williams Jr., a vice president of the Dime Savings Bank of New York. State Supreme Court Justice Leonard E. Yoswein performed the ceremony.

title: STATE TO ALLOT SURPLUS CHEESE AT 9 POINTS OUTSIDE THE CITY
description: New York State has chosen nine sites upstate and on Long Island for the distribution of surplus cheese for the poor under the Federal Government's nationwide program, and officials said yesterday that there would be no distribution site in New York City.

title: EXCEPTIONAL BRAVERY OF OTHERS MOTIVATES AID FOR THE NEEDIEST
description: People who have borne misfortune with exceptional spirit or bravery often awaken a sense of sacrifice in others grateful for their own comfort. One of those responding was Dr. John M. Graham of Manhattan, who contributed to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund for the first time.

title: Chamber Music at St. Ann's
description: The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center, with Earl Wild as guest pianist, will play a concert at the Gothic Cathedral of St. Ann's on Jan. 20 at 8 P.M. The music, under the direction of Charles Wadsworth, will include pieces by Debussy, Chausson and Haydn, and Mr. Wild and Mr. Wadsworth will play the Brahms ''Seven Hungarian Dances for Piano Four-Hands.'' Tickets are $8. Call 834-8794.

title: New Jersey Journal
description: THAT saucer-like object perched atop a 20-foot tower on the Burlington County College campus in Pemberton is a satellite receiver called an Earth Reception Station. It's called that because of its location (Earth) and where it gets information beamed from (Earth again). The information is reflected from one of the 11 satellites floating somewhere over Hawaii; the information then comes back down to Earth again, to a reception station.

title: TV View; IS THIS AUTOBIOGRAPHY REALLY NECESSARY?
description: Considered in a vacuum, moral or otherwise, ''Will, G. Gordon Liddy'' works quite well as an evening's entertainment. The madefor-television movie, which will be presented on NBC tonight at 9, has been made with care. Frank Abatemarco's script remains reasonably faithful to the published autobiography of the convicted Watergate conspirator, even though a prefatory note concedes that ''certain fictional characters have been introduced and a number of incidents modified for dramatic purposes.'' Robert Leiberman's direction avoids unnecessary frills. And Robert Conrad's performance in the title role is impressive and uncompromising. The A. Shane Company production offers still another smooth example of the ''based on a true story'' project that television has become so fond of these days.

title: NEW EFFORT BEGINS ON AIRPORT NOISE
description: A PLAN for solving the problems of airplane noise around Westchester County Airport moved into a new phase last week as users of the airport, many of them pilots for major corporations, were urged to cooperate in the efforts to reduce the noise.

title: EXTRACURRICULAR ACTIVITIES GET EXTRA EXPENSIVE
description: THIS year high school students in Bethel Park, Pa., are paying $26 to play baseball and $15 to play tennis for their school. If a student wants to participate in the marching band or school orchestra, the cost is $4, while working on the school paper or being in the Astronomy Club cost only $2. The charges represent a move on the part of an increasing number of school districts in such states as California, Utah, Michigan, Pennsylvania and Connecticut, to charge users' fees, sometimes for all extracurricular activities but most often for sports.

title: Children's Books
description: BILLY BUMBRY'S YEAR By Garry Puffer. Illustrated by Joe Servello. 180 pp. New York: Lothrop, Lee & Shepard Books. $9.95. (Ages 10 to 14) By JANE O'CONNOR

title: Food; THE LARGER THE CHILE, THE MILDER IT TASTES
description: CHILE, variously spelled chili, chilli and chilie, much to the consternation of people who speak Spanish, and the confusion of everyone else, is a member of the same family as the ordinary green (or bell) pepper.

title: MEMORABLE GIFT FOR GRADUATE
description: IT was not a run-of-the-mill graduation present, but then again neither was Ann Penney Ross's college career. Starting at Mary Washington College in Fredericksburg, Va., in 1948 and transferring two years later to Cornell University, Ann Penney married her highschool sweetheart from Elmira, N.Y., James B. Ross. He went on to become an insurance executive while she dropped out of college to become a mother for the first of 11 times.

title: Estimate on Presley Estate
description: The Tennessee Department of Revenue has valued the estate of the late entertainer Elvis Presley at $31 million.

title: DOESN'T A JUROR HAVE RIGHTS, TOO?
description: THE idea of trial by jury can be traced back to ancient Greece, where, in Athens, people were tried by their peers. Male citizens were chosen in large numbers to serve as jurors. This was the Golden Era, the Age of Pericles.

title: THE FOLLOW THROUGH ON HEAD START'S GAINS
