description: IT was time to study contractions in Lucille Santoro's third-grade language arts class at Public School 137 in Brooklyn. ''Is not,'' she began firmly. ''Isn't,'' a chorus of 23 strong, youthful voices responded immediately. ''I-s-n-apostrophe-t.''

title: Other World Events; No Tolerance for Bahais
description: The Bahai sect, founded in Iran a century ago, holds that all religions teach the same basic truth and that all religious and ethnic hatred is therefore absurd and abhorent.

title: ISLANDERS WIN, 3-1
description: A five-minute spearing penalty after an unusual call by a linesman against the Philadelphia Flyers tonight helped the Islanders to score two power-play goals in the last 2 minutes and gain a 3-1 victory at Nassau Coliseum.

title: WATER PROBLEMS EASING ON COAST
description: A water emergency in this stormdamaged city eased today, permitting restaurants to reopen and citizens to begin to bathe away a week's worth of mud.

title: Music; CANDLELIGHT SERIES
description: MOST concert organizat ions take three or four weeks to recover fromthe Christmas break. Not so the Wilton candlelight series, which willbe back in mu sical business as of 4 o'clock this afternoon.

title:
Other Business;
WHAT'S A NICE EXECUTIVE LIKE YOU...?
description: Silver-haired, serene, self-possessed, and distinguished of name, Warner Ackerman speaks in the measured cadences of a bank executive. But Warner Ackerman is not a real-life banker. He is a character in the movie ''Rollover.''

title: Around the Nation
description: By The Associated Press A sharp earthquake that ''sounded like thunder'' jolted residents of eastern Canada awake yesterday morning, rattling dishes and shaking furniture through New England as far south as Connecticut .

title: VISITS TO LYNDHURST MAY BE CURTAILED
description: CONCERNED about ''an uncertain Federal future,'' the National Trust for Historic Preservation has announced that it is considering closing the Lyndhurst mansion in Tarrytown to regular public visits.

title: Economic Affairs; AN AFFIRMATIVE LOOK AT HIRING QUOTAS
description: IS affirmative action a burden on American business? Bradford Reynolds, the head of the Justice Departmen t's Civil Rights Division, apparently thinks so. At a press conference recently Mr. Reynolds said that he hoped to get the Supreme Court to reverse the action it took in the Weber case, in which the Court upheld the voluntary use by companies of numerical goals in advancing minority candidates.

title: HOSPICE TEAMWORK
description: HOSPICE is not simply a place, its advocates say. It is a philosophy and an entire program. Hospice advocates fear that the public may not understand that the physical location is merely the center of a wide-ranging array of services.

title: Chloe Monzani and Geoffrey Berger Are Married in Edgartown, Mass.
description: At St. Andrew's Episcopal Church in Edgartown, Mass., yesterday, Caroline Viall Monzani was married to Geoffrey Leslie Berger by the Rev. John A. Greely.

title: Crime
description: POWDER BURN (Atheneum, $12.95) is the result of the collaboration of William D. Montalbano and Carl Hiaasen, both reporters for The Miami Herald. Mr. Montalbano is a Latin American specialist, and Mr. Hiaasen concentrates on the drug trade in Florida. What more natural, then, than that they should write about the Florida drug trade, a thriving business that has tentacles throughout Latin America?

title: IN BAY RIDGE, DEMAND SPURS BUILDING
description: Change comes slowly to Brooklyn's Bay Ridge section, a sleepy, old residential community along the shore facing Staten Island over the Narrows and New York Bay. Yet there are subtle signs of transformation in a neighborhood most noted for its panoramic views of the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge and one of the oldest military bases in the country, Fort Hamilton.

title: Environews
description: FOLLOWING are some of the events and disclosures that made environmental news in 1981, with their corresponding updates: JANUARY

title: Penn State's Munchak To Enter N.F.L. Draft
description: The Penn State offensive guard Mike Munchak, a senior with a year of eligibility remaining, has decided to end his collegiate career and enter this year's National Football League player draft.

title: MALLS FEAR LOSS OF 'PRIVATE' STATUS
description: HARTFORD A HARTFORD Superior Court judge's ruling last week that a shopping mall cannot bar the National Organization for Women from gathering signatures in support of the proposed equal rights amendment has several owners and managers of other large shopping malls reevaluating their policies of restricting political activity on their property.

title: East Africa
description: To the Editor:

title: The Nation in Summary; In Major Shift, I.R.S. Is Now Neutral on Bias
description: For 11 years, the Federal tax code had been an effective civil rights sword as Washington denied or revoked indirect tax subsidies in the form of exemptions to more than 100 private schools, colleges and certain other nonprofit institutions that practiced racial discrimination. Last week, the Reagan Administration returned the code to its scabbard.

title: SCHOOL TAX RULING FACES A CHALLENGE
description: The Reagan Administration's decision to stop denying tax e xemptions to private schools and colleges that practice racial discri mination will be challenged as a violation of other court orders and Supreme Court precedents, a civil rights law group said today.

title: A HISTORY OF THE NEW HISTORY
description: THE PAST AND THE PRESENT By Lawrence Stone. 274 pp. Boston: Routledge & Kegan Paul. $15.95.

title: Children's Books
description: MR.YOWDER AND THE TRAIN ROBBERS Written and Illustrated by Glen Rounds. Unpaged. New York: Holiday House. $7.95. (Ages 8 to 11) By KARLA KUSKIN

title: In Antitrust, a Surprisingly Tough Stand?
description: WASHINGTON THE current wave of mergers between big corporations, one rivaled only by the 1967-1969 wave, has thrust Federal antitrust policy back into the mainstream of economic and political debate. Perhaps not since the trust-busting days of Theodore Roosevelt have giant business pairings such as Du Pont and Conoco or United States Steel and Marathon Oil attracted such widespread public attention.

title: CATHOLIC PROGRAM DRAWS RYE YOUTHS
description: IT'S Thursday evening at the Cassetta household in Rye. But the 15-year-old twins, Stephen and Michael, are not settling down in front of the television. Instead, they grab their coats and - joined by their 16-year-old brother Paul - head out the door to play Ping-Ping, shoot pool and ''rap'' with some peers about the criteria for leading a Christian life.

title: No Headline
description: A.T.&T. IS FREE TO SET UP ELECTRONIC NEWS AND ADVERTISING SERVICE

title: Connecticut Guide; 'BLACK LANDMARKS'
description: The Scott-Fanton Museum and Historical Society in Danbury will open an exhibition honoring the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. at 2 P.M. today, with a reception from 7 to 9 P.M. on Friday. The display will continue through Jan. 2 4.

title: Westchester Housing; HELPING ELDERLY TO LIVE AT HOME
description: DOROTHEA W. turned 100 years old on Sept. 14, and she says she has to ''take it easy now.'' She lives alone in a two-story house in Yonkers, doing her own cleaning and cooking.

title: East German Swimmers Star
description: Caren Metschuck and Ute Geweniger achieved world-best performances in the 50-meter freestyle and 200-meter breast-stroke tonight as East Germany solidified its lead in the women's competition at the United States Swimming International meet.

title: A NONSMOKER DESCRIBES DAILY STRUGGLE FOR CLEAN AIR
description: WHILE Congress continues to subsidize the tobacco industry and drags its feet on raising the cigarette tax, which hasn't been increased in 50 years, we non-smokers are developing survival tactics to keep from choking to death on other people's sidestream smoke, more lethal than the smoke those puffers filter through their cigarettes and their lungs.

title: Sunday Observer
description: By Russell Baker Never Say Sorry PATRICK MCDONNELL

title: AMONG SMALL-BUSINESS MEN, A MEASURE OF OPTIMISM
description: THE core of private enterprise in the United States, many believe, is small business. Of late, however, volatile credit conditions and a troublesome economy have wreaked havoc in the small-business sector, bringing about an epidemic of business failures and shriveling the profits of those who have survived.

title: Business Conditions; CREDIT: THE SUPPLY IS THERE
description: Record demand for credit by the Federal Government and business is expected to push interest rates higher this year, according to many analysts, most notably Henry Kaufman, chief economist at Salomon Brothers.

title: COLLEGE STUDENTS TAKE TO QUICKIE INTERNSHIPS
description: WHILE many college students have settled in for the long and lazy four-week intersession between New Year's and the resumption of classes, Nancy Minnicks, a Connecticut College senior, is learning about publishing as an intern without pay at Harry N. Abrams Publishers in New York. A native of Darien, Conn., Miss Minnicks is one of many liberal-arts students around the country participating in a growing number of short-term internship programs. The programs are designed to help students explore career options, learn jobhunting skills and get a taste of working experience.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY 'MIX' IN MORRIS
description: MORRISTOWN GALLERY group shows in which several unknowns are combined with a few ''names'' are not uncommon and generally do little for either side. However, a judicious mix can work occasionally, especially when there are more knowns than unknowns, as is currently the case at the Woodman Gallery.

title: REAGAN TEAM IS BANKING ON NEW SAVINGS
description: exempt savings certificates and tax-deferred retirement accounts, known as I.R.A.'s and Keoghs.

title: New Fee Plan Irks Boatmen
description: The United States Coast Guard has devised a system of annual user fees for the nation's 12 million recreational boat owners that is designed to cover the costs of all Federal recreational boating services, including search and rescue.

title: Connecticut Journal
description: TO a layman, gatherings of Federal judges might not rank very high on the levity scale. But the ceremony at the Yale Law School last Tuesday at which Ralph K. Winter Jr. was sworn in as a judge on the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit demonstrated that there is bantering even on the bench.

title: Round 3 on the Roundtable
description: To the Business Editor: Although Milton Friedman remains a lively presence in our midst and in occasional television re-runs, he has apparently already been reincarnated in the person of the Yale economist, Paul W. MacAvoy. In his ''The Business Lobby's Wrong Business'' (Dec. 20), Professor MacAvoy echoes Professor Friedman's classic declaration that, ''The social responsibility of business is to increase its profits,'' and takes to task the members of the Business Roundtable for their recently published ''Statement on Corporate Responsibility.''

title: Major News in Summary; Allen Is 'Pushed Onto the Sword'
description: Being certifiably clean wasn't nearly enough, so Richard V. Allen, the President's national security adviser, was forced to resign last week.

title: TV STATIONS VOW BOLSTERED COVERAGE OF NEWS IN STATE
description: THE latest chapter in the saga of New Jersey's struggle for expanded news coverage by New York City and Philadelphia television stations has ended: There was a report that WABC-TV was planning to give up its Hackensack bureau, but the station issued a strong denial.

title: Study Finds More Amputees Suffer From 'Phantom Pain'
description: The Army says 90 percent of amputees responding to a recent survey said they suffered so-called phantom pain, a discomfort perceived to be coming from a missing limb.

title: Crafts
description: ''METAL LIFE ROUS BIFURCATIONS,'' an exhibition of sculptural forms in metal at t he Newark Museum, affirms that Charles Kumnick of Hopewell is n ot only a master technician but also an artist who extracts eloq uence from resistant substances.

title: A Test of Reagan's Fiscal Conservatism
description: WASHINGTON BETWEEN now and Election Day this November, the country will learn whether the conservative Administration headed by President Reagan is really going to pursue a conservative fiscal policy - and, if it does, whether it can persuade Congress to come along.

title: WHAT'S A COLLEGE PRESIDENT? NOT WHAT HE THOUGHT IT WAS
description: AFUNNY thing happened to me on the way to the presidency of the University of Hartford. I was put through a series of interviews so devastatingly protracted and thorough, involving so many of the university constituencies, that I began to feel the way a pebble must after its first 5,000 years at the bottom of Niagara Falls. Not that I was being consciously hypocritical. But one does try to respond to one's audience - if only to meet the standards of basic politeness - and the effort made me feel, in this case, as if I had bid farewell to anything as crudely individualized as a human personality.

title: Topics; Matters of Law; Stacked Deck
description: Stymied in its effort to eliminate the Legal Services Corporation, the White House has stacked the organization's 11-member board with seven recess appointees. The action seems innocent on its face; recess appointments are intended to insure continuity until the Senate can confirm permanent appointments.

title: EAST HARLEM POLITICAL LEADER
description: Antonio Mendez, who in 1954 became the first native-born Puerto Rican to become a district leader of a major political party in New York City, died Friday while on vacation in Puerto Rico. He was 80 years old and lived in East Harlem.

title: Patricia Ericksen Affianced
description: The engagement of Patricia M. Ericksen to William F. Branston has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. John H. Ericksen of Northport, L.I., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. William Branston of Centerport, L.I. A June wedding is planned.

title: COMPUTERS EXTEND LOCAL LIBRARY'S REACH
description: WHEN man first began to write, only the scribes knew how and the rest of the population was sometimes suspicious of such ''magic powers.'' Today almost everyone can read and write, but only a small portion of us are ''computer literate''; consequently, we may be somewhat skeptical about this new way of dealing with information. But computers have made it possible for a visitor to a local county library to obtain almost any kind of information, even if it isn't physically there in a specific library's collection.

title: POLISH AIRWAVES: PROVINCIAL PARTY LEADER RESIGNS
description: Following are excerpts from domestic Polish radio and television broadcasts and a Soviet broadcast to Poland as transcribed a nd translated from the Polish by the Foreign Broadcast Information S ervice, a United States Government agency:

title: Nancy A. Cenek Wed To David Brigstocke
description: The marriage of Nancy Ann Cenek, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Henry Cenek of Syracuse, to David Hugh Charles Brigstocke, son of Heather Renwick Brigstocke of London and the late Geoffrey R.W. Brigstocke, took place yesterday in Manhattan. The Rev. Gary Fertis performed the ceremony in St. Thomas Episcopal Church.

title: Fathers and Custody: Another View
description: Elizabeth Greene's recent letter to the letter in regard to fathers' winning custody cases is replete with error and misinformation.

title: DETROIT
description: DETROIT THE industrial Middle West's long slide into economic stagnation is now in its third year, and the optimism that once came easily to people used to the ups and down of a manufacturing economy is giving way. Midwesterners are beginning to recognize that basic changes will have to be made before lost jobs and business start coming back.

title: Miss Carroll Wed To William Farrell
description: Lindsay Carroll, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Willis Carroll of Newtown Square, Pa., was married at the Wayne (Pa.) Presbyterian Church yesterday to William J. Farrell, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Gaillard Farrell of Whitestone, Queens.

title: No Headline
description: In a nation which allows its young people the opportunity to feign social revolution, and then return to the fold of middle-class materialism, with not even the hint of personal sacrifice, it is quite evident why the Weather Underground could find no base of popular support, even among those they ''fought'' for. Despite the tragic and senseless killings of a security guard and two policemen, the Weather Underground faded, along with the student movements that spawned it, with a whimper. Had these upper-class malcontents realized the futility of their aspirations, more than one family might have been spared a lot of tears. HARRY M. AGNOSTAK, Dunellen, N.J.

title: BOARD TO SET DATE FOR REFERENDUMS
description: TWO of the county's most vexing issues - formation of a public utility agency and establishment of a garbage recycling plant and its taxing district -will come together tomorrow night when the Board of Legislators meets to set a single date for referendums on each.

title:
Gardening;
EDIBLE AS WELL AS ORNAMENTAL PLANTINGS
description: AMONG the more familiar cultivated plants are many examples of closely related species having widely divergent uses. One may find in the same family or genus plants valued for ornamental characteristics and others for edible fruits. Some of the relationships are well known; others are not.

title:
Gardening;
EDIBLE AS WELL AS ORNAMENTAL PLANTINGS
description: AMONG the more familiar cultivated plants are many examples of closely related species having widely divergent uses. One may find in the same family or genus plants valued for ornamental characteristics and others for edible fruits. Some of the relationships are well known; others are not.

title: Correspondent's Choice; BERLIN'S HAVEN FOR FEINSCHMECKERS
description: R.W.APPLE Jr. is chief of the London bureau of The New York Times. By R.W.APPLE Jr.

title: LEARNING FROM MAN'S VARIED MUSICS
description: Travel, goes the cliche, broadens the mind. Anyone who has seen tourists abroad may not actually believe that piece of wisdom. But travel does, at any rate, allow us to see more of our native land when we return home. The way advertising appears, the way clothes are worn, the way people walk in the street, the way television reports news, the way conversation is made - such details become quite peculiar after a journey to some other land - where robes are worn instead of suits, where advertisements are crudely sketched graphics, where pedestrians stride on the left instead of the right. Details we hardly see when embedded in daily life become quite remarkable after seeing other manners of drifting along. Ah yes, we realize, things can be quite different.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Braking at G.M.
description: With hard times shaking auto makers, General Motors was reported last August considering closing its engineering college, the General Motors Institute in Flint, Mich., sometimes called the West Point of the industry.

title: SHIPS' NAMES
description: To the Editor:

title: WARSAW PRELATE AND POLISH LEADER CONFER ON CRISIS
description: Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Polish leader, met today with Archbishop Jozef Glemp, the Roman Catholic Primate, apparently in a move to enlist the church's support under martial law.

title: Dining Out; WHERE PASTA STANDS OUT
description: AT Ciro's, which opened several months ago in Merrick, a table in the center of the dining room bears a pyramid of dried, golden homemade noodles. It is an attractive and appropriate centerpiece display. Not only is the list of pasta dishes on the menu longer than any other category, but also their preparation is consistently fine. Ciro's is a family-run restaurant that has strong two-star potential.

title: Long Island Journal
description: THE problem of vandalism on Long Island has been discussed at length by prosecutors, psychologists, social scientists and judges, but the Antivandalism Task Force of the Malverne School District will hear from a new source at a meeting Jan. 21: the vandals themselves.

title: Laura S. Friedland Married to Leonard Rosenblatt
description: Laura Susan Friedland, daughter of Mr. and Mr s. Abner M. Friedland of South Oran ge, N.J., and Boca Raton, Fla., was married yesterday to Leonard Re ed Rosenblatt, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Rosenblatt of Howard Beach, Queens. Rabbi Herbert Weiner performed the ceremony in the Pierre Ho tel.

title: Headliners; Queen for a Day
description: Betty Jean Meshey of Tallahasse, Fla. and her 12-year-old daughter, Jessica, were riding high after receiving more than $2,300 in cash and gifts, in response to a Dec. 23 story in the Clearwater (Fla.) Sun describing their plight. Their joy was short lived. Mrs. Meshy, who suffers from cervical cancer and receives $150 a month from the state of Florida was in tears last week when she showed up at the newspaper's office with a letter from the State Welfare Office expressing delight over the Meshey's good fortune but regrets at having to inform them that the windfall might cost them their monthly benefits. Mrs. Meshey has until Wednesday to report the amount of contributions she received or risk losing her monthly stipend.

title: COUSTEAU TO LEAD 13-MONTH STUDY OF AMAZON
description: Jacques Cousteau, the French oceanographer, says he will soon lead 40 scientists on a 13-month study by subm arine, helicopter and Hovercraft of Amazon animal and plant life.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: Business Conditions; POLITICAL RISK RISES
description: Political risk in the world economy increased during 1981, according to a recent report by Business Environment Risk Information, a consulting service that uses 60 political specialists around the world to assess the social stresses in 45 countries.

title:
Dining Out;
SEAFOOD AND A LIVELY ATMOSPHERE
description: THOSE diners seeking an atmosphere of gentle calm would do best to visit Corinthian in Scarsdale during the week. On weekends this ornate restaurant had the friendly air of carnival: guests were matched by lively staff fussing with much food preparation in the dining room. Corinthian at times appeared to be more a tourist attraction than a serious restaurant. And although Spyros Zouzias, the owner, keeps a strict eye on the quality of the ingredients, the kitchen could use some closer attention as well and might be encouraged to handle more delicately and with greater dependability the fresh ingredients at its disposal, so that the food, rather than the decor or staging, might fall under the brighter spotlight.

title: MORE THAN EVER, 'A WHITE-COLLAR TOWN'
description: SIDNEY KASTENBAUM, who has worked in the garment industry for 30 years, is beginning, just beginning, to wonder how much longer he will stay in business. His concern, S. Kastenbaum & Company, makes bridal and bridesmaids dresses, fluffy garments of white and brightly colored acetate that sell for modest prices and keep Mr. Kastenbaum and his 100 factory workers busy in a loft in Manhattan. This year, rent for that loft will double to $70,000, and the electric bill has also doubled in the last two years. Orders for his goods, however, are 10 to 15 percent lower than they were last year at this time.

title: A 'STRATEGY' CHANGE IN JERSEY
description: When the Galaxy, a 1,075-unit rental apartment development across the Hudson River from 69th Street, began its quest for tenants five years ago, its insistent advertising theme was "What Manhattan is coming to." But Manhattan didn't

title: The 'Average' Child: More Opinions
description: I would like to respond to the recent Long Island Opinion article by Dr. Bert Nelson, ''Is There Actually an Average Child?,'' which proposes a means for providing individualized programs of education for each and every child.

title: For Defense, Slow Gains
description: WASHINGTON WHEN Ronald Reagan took office and Caspar W. Weinberger became Secretary of Defense a year ago, they proclaimed the urgent need to ''rearm America.'' The nation's military contractors quickly snapped to attention, saluted smartly and did little to suppress their smiles.

title: Around the World; Salvador Election Panel Takes Turn to the Right
description: The membership of El Salvador's Electoral Commission moved sharply to the right today on orders of the ruling junta.

title: Prospects
description: A Spotty Recession

title: 4TH JOINS CONNECTICUT'S G.O.P. GOVERNOR RACE
description: Lewis B. Rome, a former leader of the State Senate, today joined a crowded field of candidates seeking the Republican nomination for Governor of Connecticut this year.

title: Elizabeth Bristol, Teacher, Betrothed
description: Elizabeth Wigton Bristol, a teacher at the Christ Church Day School in New York, and William Stockton Mellon Sayen, a computer programmer with the New Jersey Department of the Treasury in Trenton, plan to be married in June.

title: HOW REAGAN RODE OUT 1981
description: Hedrick Smith is The Times's chief Washington correspondent. By Hedrick Smith

title: LOS ANGELES
description: LOS ANGELES A CURIOUS thing has happened in California: Public officials and business leaders have discovered that for all of its vaunted glamour and ''high-tech'' industry, California is vulnerable to economic aches and pains during a recession just like Michigan or Indiana. And in a state where perpetual growth and a robust economy are regarded as a kind of birthright, the discovery is akin to a dreamy newcomer's realization that it occasionally rains here, too.

title: Open Skies Closing In
description: WHEN President Carter signed the Airline Deregulation Act in 1978, most airlines braced themselves for new competition. But as the major carriers were in the midst of adopting new strategies and the upstart airlines were creating new markets and muscling in on old ones, the air controllers' strike severely restricted the airlines' room to maneuver.

title: MUSIC: CARTER'S SONATA
description: The New York Philomusica, which is marking its 10th season, offered Elliott Carter's Sonata for Flute, Oboe, Cello and Harpsichord, a work that has been around for 30 seasons and still sound s fresh and fascinating, as the centerpi ece of its program Wednesday night at Alice Tully Hall.

title: Carolyn Rueckert Engaged to Teacher
description: Dr. and Mrs. Frederic Rueckert of Hanover, N.H., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Carolyn Rueckert, to C.J. Stouffer 3d, son of Mrs. Roger Saylor of Enola, Pa., and the late Brigadier General Stouffer Jr., U.S.A.

title: Travel Advisory; CREATIVITY TEST, ART QUEST IN ITALY; Great Minds At Work in Museum Show
description: Draw a square. Inside it place 25 dots spread out in five rows. Draw lines through the dots in such a way as to divide the square into four equal parts. How many ways do you suppose this can be done? The answer, according to the creators of an exhibition on creativity, is 104.

title: Theater in Review; COMEDY AT ARENA: FAMILIAR TERRAIN
description: EAST FARMINGDALE WITH ''December in New York,'' Joseph Lizardi, the prolific ''resident'' playwright of the Arena Players Repertory Theater, is having a field day - and an off night. Mr. Lizardi ascribes his play to autobiography. By his own accounting, about 60 percent of it is ''true,'' but to an objective observer, it's apt to appear like a retread of ''Barefoot in the Park'' without an assembly line of fresh jokes to redeem it, and with a lot of nasty bickering thrown in.

title: Ferries
description: To the Editor:

title: The Licensing Phenomenon
description: BILL BLASS chocolates. Sasson maternity jeans. M*A*S*H umbrellas. Playboy socks for women. Strawberry Shortcake everything. The list of licensed merchandise lengthens daily as licensing - the business of associating someone's name or identity with someone else's product or service, usually for a fee - establishes itself as an effective marketing tool.

title: STATE AND U.S. COURTS CONFLICT ON PORTMAN PROJECT
description: In the face of a conflicting Federal court ruling, a State Supreme Court judge has approved the demolition of two Broadway theate rs to make way for the construction of a hotel prop osed by John C. Portman Jr.

title: Politics; GRASSO I MPRINT STILL DOMINANT IN O'NEILL REGIME
description: THE death Dec. 28 of David H. Neiditz, the State Banking Commissioner, caused a sudden problem for Governor O'Neill. The Governor, who is recuperating from open-heart surgery, needed someone in a hurry to take charge of the agency that regulates the rapidly-changing banking industry in Connecticut.

title: About Books and Authors
description: Intensified Madness

title:
Food;
RESTAURANTEUR SHARES SOME SECRETS OF ITALIAN CUISINE
description: AS northern Italian restaurants, shops featuring freshly made pasta and Italian cooking classes proliferate on the Island, serving vermicelli pizzaiola for dinner has become not only fashionable but also feasible.

title: DIFFERENT INITIALS IN EASTERN EUROPE STILL SPELL K.G.B.
description: As the military crackdown in Poland has aga in made clear, Communistrule in Eastern Europe often depends more hea vily on ubiquitous internal security forces, patterned on Russia 's K.G.B., than on partycontrol or the regular army. Poland's Gen. Wo jciech Jaruzelski is relying on 150,000 security forces, capable o f mobilizing to a total of 250,000, to enforce military rule.

title: January 10, 1982
description: NONFICTION THE ART OF CARICATURE. By Edward Lucie-Smith. 30 BOCCACCIO. By Thomas G. Bergin. 11 THE BREAKS OF THE GAME. By David Halberstam. 6 DREAM TEAM. By Lewis Cole. 6 A FEARFUL INNOCENCE. By Frances Davis. 12 LADIES ON THE LOOSE. Edited by Leo Hamalian. 12 LEONARDO DA VINCI: The Marvellous Works of Nature and Man. By Martin Kemp. 11 THE MAN IN THE CROWD: Confessions of a Sports Addict. By Stanley Cohen. 6 MASTERS OF CARICATURE: From Hogarth and Gillray to Scarfe and Levine. Commentary by William Feaver. 30 NO PLACE OF GRACE: Antimodernism and the Transformation of American Culture 1880-1920. By T.J. Jackson Lears. 8 ONLY THE RING WAS SQUARE. By Teddy Brenner as Told to Barney Nagler. 6 THE PAST AND THE PRESENT. By Lawrence Stone. 9 THE POLITICS OF ARCHITECTURE: A Perspective on Nelson A. Rockefeller. By Samuel E. Bleecker. 10 RIGHTEOUS GENTILE: The Story of Raoul Wallenberg, Missing Hero of the Holocaust. By John Bierman. 12 WOMEN, RACE & CLASS. By Angela Y. Davis. 8 FICTION DARK BLUE AND DANGEROUS. By Jonathan Ross. 29 THE DEAN'S DECEMBER. By Saul Bellow. 1 A MOTHER AND TWO DAUGHTERS. y Gail Godwin. 3 PEL IS PU ZZLED. By Mark Hebden. 29 THE POLI SH COMPLEX. By Tadeusz Konwicki. 3 POWDER BU RN. By William D. Montalbano and Carl Hiaasen. 29 PROMISES TO KEEP.

title: Realty News
description: The law firm of Debevoise & Plimpton has leased about 250,000 square feet of new office space for approximately $30 million at 875 Third Avenue, a building in construction on the east side of the avenue between 52d Street and 53d Street. Madison Equities, in which Robert Gladstone is a principal, is the developer.

title: EXERCISING BY THE BOOK
description: REMEMBER the story about the man who read so much about cigarette smoking and cancer that he gave up reading? Well, I may have to give up reading too, and for a related reason. It's the libraries.

title: A TOURIST'S GUIDE TO THE MOON
description: ISAAC ASIMOV is a prolific author of works of science, fiction and science fiction. By ISAAC ASIMOV

title: News Summary; SUNDAY, JANUARY 10, 1982
description: International Enlisting church support for Poland's military Government was the apparent purpose of a meeting in Warsaw between Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Polish leader, and the Primate of the Roman Catholic Church, Archbishop Jozef Glemp. In the meantime, the Government announced that the reporting of foreign correspondents would no longer be subject to prior censorship. (Page 1, Column 6.)

title: LAWYERS DENY TALES OF PHONE BILLS RISING AFTER BELL SETTLEMENT
description: Justice Department lawyers, responding to news accounts that its antitrust settlement with the American Telephone and Telegraph Company could lead to higher bills for consumers, sought today to ''set the record straight.''

title: LONG ISLAND
description: MINEOLA L.I. WHILE the Grumman Corporation, Long Island's largest employer, was successful in keeping its independence last year when LTV, the Texas conglomerate, attempted to take it over, some economists warn that Grumman and smaller companies on Long Island remain attractive and ripe for tender offers.

title: KINDERGARTENS FINALLY BECOMING UNIVERSAL
description: BARELY five years ago there were no public kindergartens in Alabama; 15 years ago, the same was true in Idaho, Arkansas, Mississippi and the Carolinas. Today public kindergartens exist in every state, but they are still compulsory in none, despite a steadily incre asing enrollment of 5-year-olds .

title: BUILT WITH VISION, MONEY AND HUBRIS
description: THE POLITICS OF ARCHITECTURE A Perspective on Nelson A. Rockefeller. By Samuel E. Bleecker. Illustrated. 255 pp. New York: The Rutledge Press. $50.

title: What's Doing in; HONOLULU
description: ROBERT TRUMBULL, a retired Times correspondent, lives in Honolulu. By ROBERT TRUMBULL

title: 4. CHOICE COUNTRY INNS
description: PATRICIA WELLS is a writer who lives in Paris. By PATRICIA WELLS

title: Politics; G.O.P. PONDERS MARGIOTTA MOVES
description: TWO weeks before the sentencing of Joseph M. Margiotta following his conviction on mail fraud and extortion charges, Nassau Republicans are still unsure about his political future and about who will succeed him if he is forced to step down as Nassau Republican chairman.

title: FOR BUILDERS, A MATTER OF SURVIVAL
description: CHICAGO USUALLY after long periods of economic sluggishness businessmen and economists look to the housing industry to lead the nation out of recession: When housing picks up, it pulls other industries along with it. Lumber and metal perk up, as do sales of refrigerators, appliances and furniture.

title:
Numismatics;
GETTING READY FOR THE 1984 OLYMPIC COINS?
description: Athletes prepare for the Olympic Games with preliminary competitions at the regional level - and, apparently, so do the people who provide Olympic coins. While awaiting congressional action on a possible coinage program for the 1984 Summer Olympics in Los Angeles, one of the major sponsors of that proposal is honing its competitive edge by marketing coins for this year's 13th European Athletic Championships.

title: A Leaner Steel Industry Gets Tough
description: WEIRTON, PA. THE narrow road winds down to what looks like a string of gigantic green warehouses. Inside, iron ore is melted down in huge thimbleshaped pots, poured into slabs and then stretched and wound into fat coils of sheet steel that will eventually become small cans for soda, tomatoes or other goods.

title: Schmidt Urges Reagan To See Brezhnev Soon
description: Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany says an early meeting between President Reagan and Leonid I. Brezhnev is needed to avoid miscalculations by the Soviet leader.

title:
Speaking Personally;
THE DAY A GENDARME EARNED HIS STRIPES
description: LONG ago, when I was a child, my father told me a story about an extraordinary Rumanian gendarme. Then he adde d: ''Tell people about him. Such a deed should never be forgotten.''

title: REAGAN TO DISCUSS PUERTO RICO ISSUE
description: President Reagan plans to make a statement next Tuesday on the status of Puerto Rico, and there were indications tonight that he would repeat his 1980 campaign position of endorsing an islandwide referendum while personally favoring statehood.

title: 12-1 Clever Shot Wins at Aqueduct
description: Clever Shot, a 12-1 shot, closed powerfully in the stretch yesterday and won the $54,600 Rockaway Stakes by four lengths at Aqueduct.

title: ATLANTA MURDER TRIAL TURNS TOWARD SCIENTIFIC EVIDENCE
description: The two-week murder trial of Wayne B. Williams is about to leave the world of the sounds and sights as described by witnesses and enter the world of microscopic evidence, chemical tests and molecular configurations of fibers and hairs.

title: Connors Defeats M cEnroe in Final
description: Jimmy Connors displayed a brilliant array of passing shots today and outlasted John McEnroe, 6-7, 7-5, 6-7, 7-5, 6-4, in the final of the $310,000 Michelob Light Challenge tennis tournament.

title: 2 Youths' Honesty Nets $100 Reward
description: Two Levittown youths found a bank deposit sack containing $4,000 in a discarded shopping bag in a supermarket parking lot, turned it over to the police and got a $100 reward for their honesty.

title: Mrs. Thatcher Predicts Allies Will Back Actions on Poland
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain predicted today that the European allies would approve joint action to protest military rule in Poland, but she said it might take a ''slightly different'' form than the sanctions imposed by President Reagan.

title: Cold Shuts Track
description: Harness racing was canceled at Liberty Bell today because of the cold weather. Racing resumes Tuesday. The track is closed Mondays.

title: U.S. Aides Visit Peking For High-Level Talks
description: A high-ranking United States delegation arrived in Peking today for talks with Chinese officials, a State Department spokesman said.

title: NEW FOX OWNERS FILE REPORT ON VOTE LINEUP
description: Since the disclosure recently that half of the voting control of the 20th Century-Fox Film Corporation has been turned over by Marvin Davis, who purchased the company last June, to a little-known New York commodities trading concern, attention has focused on Marc Rich, the owner of that concern. But Mr. Rich is continuing to maintain his low profile, declining to respond to telephone calls.

title: Look Harder for Oil
description: Must Western countries keep relying so heavily on Arab oil? Not if they play it smarter. That is the surprising consensus of oil economists me eting this week at Israel's Bat-Sheva International Seminar on En ergy.

title: AN ELUSIVE CAREY GOAL: FISCAL REPORTS BY AIDES
description: Despite a series of executive orders designed to prevent conflicts of interest, Governor Carey's chief aides, commissioners and other ranking employees have not been required to file annual reports on their personal finances for at least three years.

title: MUSIC: CONTINUUM RECALLS SCHNITTKE
description: EXPERIENCING the retrospective concert of music by the littleknown Soviet avant-garde composer Alfred Schnittke that was offered on Saturday at Alice Tully Hall by Continuum, the performing ensemble of the Performers' Committee for 20th-Century Music, was a little like driving down a musical blind alley with a double-talking cabbie. The program notes by Joel Sachs, a co-director of Continuum, asked the reader to believe that Mr. Schnittke was ''one of the truly distinctive composers of our time.''

title: FEDERAL STUDY FINDS WOMEN MADE GAINS IN POLICE PATROL JOBS
description: Women have made major strides in the last 10 years in taking over police jobs traditionally handled by men, according to a study made public today by the Police Foundation.

title: NO GROWTH OF OIL NEED IS EXPECTED
description: The demand for oil is unlikely to grow at all this year, industry economists predict. But they also say that Saudi Arabia, by lowering its production, is both able and willing to prevent any substantial decline in the crude oil prices charged by members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.

title: HEAD OF OFFICE FOR CHILD CARE QUITS CITY POST
description: The head of New York City's Office of Special Services for Children, which has been criticized by city officials for its handling of foster care and child-abuse cases, has resigned.

title: Dr. Sheldon Calem, 48, Dead; Radiotherapist and Professor
description: Dr. Sheldon H. Calem, a radiotherapist at several New York hospitals and an assistant clinical professor of radiotherapy at Mount Sinai School of Medicine, died Thursday of a heart attack. He was 48 years old and lived in Teaneck, N.J.

title: Downes Captures S ix-Mile Park Run
description: Tom Downes of the Warren Street Social and Athletic Club, braving wind-chill temperatures of minus 30 degrees, won the New York Road Runners Club winter series six-mile run in 30 minutes 36.7 seconds yesterday morning in Central Park.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: JUST FOR LAUGHS

title: STAGE: 'CONFLUENCE,' 3 ONE-ACTERS, AT CIRCLE REP
description: THERE is nothing startling, in form or content, about the three one-act plays that opened under the collective title of ''Confluence'' at the Circle Repertory Company last night. However many characters the program may list, each play is essentially a standard two-handed work: a pair of lost souls come into conversational confluence, part with some cherished illusions and then arrive at an unsurprising epiphany about what it takes to ride out the harsh rapids of life.

title: Tank Car Explodes in Canada
description: Thirty-nine cars of a Canadian National Railroad freight train derailed four miles northwest of here today, and one of four propane tank cars exploded. Firefighters needed 10 hours in subzero temperatures to bring the ensuing fire under control. No injuries were reported.

title: DEBT CALENDAR IS LIGHT
description: This week's calendar of new fixed-income debt offerings will remain light and dominated by several large tax-exempt issues. But dealers said last week that a heavy flow of corporate bonds were being filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: REVIVAL OF THE DRAFT ISN'T IN AMERICA'S BEST INTEREST
description: The military draft will not be reinstated except in the most severe national emergency, President Reagan declared as he announced con tinuation of registration for a possible draft. Nonetheless, the idea of a draft seems to have some life in Washington, a las.

title: I.B.M. NOW FACES A.T.&T.
description: Until Friday, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and the International Business Machines Corporation faced a common opponent: the Justice Department. But with the ending of the suits against both companies, the biggest opponents of the two uncaged giants could be each other.

title: CITY PREPARING TO PAY CHARGES ON SURPLUS FOOD
description: New York City is preparing to reach into its own treasury to insure that surplus cheese, provided under a Federal plan, is made available to the poor, the city's Commissioner of General Services said yesterday.

title: WE CANNOT CREATE A 'MUNICIPAL ASSISTANCE CORPORATION' FOR POLAND. LET LET IT GO BANKRUPT
description: When New York City teetered on the brink of insolvency in 1975 - a s Poland has been doing for months - many conservatives advocated t hat the city declare bankruptcy to symbolize the bankruptcy of l iberalism carried to extremes. The symbolic lesson, however, would h ave been devastati ng to both the city and New York State.

title: A Producer's Past Echoed in Play
description: Nobody ever made a Woolworth milkshake the way Joseph Clapsaddle made a Woolworth milkshake, which and executives of the variety store chain are probably just as happy.

title: 12-Foot Snowdrifts Leave Wales Cut Off
description: Wales was virtually cut off from the rest of Britain today as two days of wind-whipped snow blockaded rural towns and villages behind 12-foot snowdrifts.

title: PLAYWRIGHT TRACES THE LONG ROAD TO A HIT
description: AFTER a matinee of ''A Soldier's Play'' recently, Cha rles Fuller sat in the fr ont row of the silent, half-darkened theater that had once been a c hurch, talking about his powerful drama, and his personal jour ney as a playwright - a playwright who happens to be black, rather than a black playwright.

title: TALKING BUSINESS
description: The Reagan Administration official who negotiated a settlement of the Government's antitrust suit against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company says that the turning point came in late December when the company ''suddenly decided'' to start talking seriously about divestiture of some subsidiaries.

title: SHOWING THE DIFFERENCE
description: A lot of people in Europe, but also in the U.S., have been asking how much difference there really i s between the Soviet supported military regime in Poland an d the American-backed junta in El Salvador.

title: MOHAMMED GHAZALI BIN SHAFIE, MALAYSIAN OFFICIAL, DIES IN CRASH
description: A small plane piloted by the Malaysian Foreign Minister, Mohammed Ghazali bin Shafie, crashed into a mountainous jungle today, killing all three people aboard, the police said.

title: No Headline
description: WIFE OF DYING PILOT TAKES OVER CONTROLS AND LANDS AIRPLANE

title: G.R. Scofield 3d Weds Dr. Meredith Gould
description: Dr. Meredith Gould and Giles Rolfe Scofield 3d were married yesterday at the Battleground Country Club in Freehold, N.J. The Rev. Dr. Cathy Stein Greenblat of the Universal Life Church in Princeton, N.J., performed the ceremony.

title: Marketing Man Makes a Move
description: This morning, Waring & LaRosa, 15 years old and billing $61 million, will welcome a new executive vice president -Charles Fredericks, former president and vice chairman of Wells, Rich, Greene.

title: Taroczy Wins
description: Heinz Guenthardt of Switzerland and Balazs Taroczy of Hungary won the $200,000 World Doubles Championship today, defeating Kevin Curren of South Africa and Steve Denton of the United States, 6-7, 6-3, 7-5, 6-4.

title: Rushlaw Team Bobsled Victor
description: Brent Rushlaw and Jim Tyler won the two-man North American bobsled championship today with a time of 4 minutes 9.25 seconds for four heats on the mile-long Mount Van Hoevenberg run.

title: Denmark's Already High Rate Of Suicides Rose Again in '81
description: Danish health authorities expressed alarm today at new statistics showing that Denmark's recorded suicide rate, traditionally one of the world's highest, is still rising.

title: CITY BALLET: BALANCHINE THE ROMANTIC
description: GEORGE BALANCHINE is so much an architect and celebrant of classical ballet - reflected in the playful ''Le Tombeau de Couperin'' and elegant ''Symphony in C,'' two Balanchine masterworks performed by New York City Ballet on Saturday afternoon at the New York State Theater - that it is easy to forget what a romantic he is. That romanticism takes over in ''Hungarian Gypsy Airs.''

title: Ilene Hamburger Married To Dr. Mark Jeffrey Rosen
description: Ilene Jane Hamburger, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lloyd Edward Hamburger of Kings Point, L.I., was married yesterday to Dr. Mark Jeffrey Rosen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sol Rosen of Great Neck, L.I. Rabbi Jerome K. Davidson performed the ceremony at the Helmsley Palace Hotel in Manhattan.

title: U.S. ASKS ITS ALLIES TO DENY TO SOVIET PARTS FOR PIPELINE
description: The Reagan Administration has asked European countries and Japan to stop supplying vital components for a new pipeline that would carry Soviet natural gas into Western Europe, according to diplomatic sources.

title: REBEL BAND SEIZES ISLAND OFF HAITI
description: AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Jan. 10 (UPI) - A band of Haitian exiles announced today that they overran the Haitian island of Tortuga just off the mainland in a bid to overthrow President Jean-Claude Duvalier. Later in the day, the Government said troops had recaptured the island.

title: OUTDOORS: NEW DRY-FLY HOOK MAKES THE FISHING FUN
description: THIRTY years ago, an angling buddy in New Hampshire weaned me away from nearly total addiction to the dry fly, and now three Californians who have devised a way of applying tough flotation material to a dry-fly hook may alter my attitude again.

title: NEW DRAFT BOARDS: DIVERSITY IS GREATER THAN IN 1960's
description: Standby draft boards established over the last few months have many more female, black and Hispanic members than the boards of the Vietnam era, according to the Selective Service System. And interviews with a score of the new members in the New York metropolitan area show that their views on war and military service vary widely.

title: VISA DISPUTE IMPERILS U.S. MEXICO TIES
description: A decision by the Reagan Administration to cancel the temporary immigrant visas of tens of thousands of Mexicans living in the United States has provoked loud protests in Mexico and is threatening the first storm in relations since President Reagan took office.

title: I. MAGNIN NAMES CHIEF
description: Steven H. Somers, 43, has been appointed chairman and chief executive officer of I. Magnin & Company, a chain of 25 specialty stores based in San Francisco, with units in Chicago and Washington, effective Feb. 1. He will be succeeded as president by Gerald Napier, 54, who is currently senior vice president for general operations at Abraham & Straus in Brooklyn. both A.& S. and Magnin are divisions of Federated Department Stores.

title: Political Notes
description: Reacting to the conviction of Joseph M. Margiotta, the Nassau Republican County chairman, on Federal mail fraud and extortion charges, two major county leaders have taken the unusual step of asking a district attorney to draw up guidelines in such areas as solicitation of contributions from businessmen, insurance and legal patronage, conflicts of interest and other potential legal and political minefields.

title: BALLET: PREMIERES BY THE JOFFREY II DANCERS
description: UNDER the direction of Sally Bliss and Maria Grandy, the Joffrey II Dancers offered premieres by four choreographers Saturday night at Brooklyn College.

title: HRT'S ZODYS CHAIN APPOINTS PRESIDENT
description: Frank Anslow, 43 years old, has been named president of the Zodys discount store division of HRT Industries, formerly known as Hartfield-Zodys. The division operates 48 stores in California, Nevada, Arizona and New Mexico, and expects sales of $365 million in the fiscal year ending Jan. 29.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Bear, Stearns Realty Co. named Gerald Kray senior vice president.

title: CALGARY CORRALS THE BANKERS
description: In the waning moments of daylight on a blustery February day in 1947, there was an unexpected rumbling beneath the frozen ground north of here. Within seconds, the future of Canada's poverty-stricken West came bursting out of a man-made hole. Vern Hunter's drilling crew had struck oil at Imperial Leduc No.1 well.

title: STADLER TRIUMPHS IN TUCSON OPEN BY 3 STROKES WITH 71-266
description: Craig Stadler, the leader from the first day, scored an easy three-stroke victory today in the Tucson Open, the opening event on the pro golf tour.

title: LEONARD-HAGLER OFF FOR NOW
description: The next ''fight of the year,'' after the Larry Holmes-Gerry Cooney heavyweight title bout March 15, apparently will not take place until 1983.

title: INQUIRY SOUGHT IN ARRESTS MADE BY TRANSIT FORCE
description: The Transit Authority Police Department has asked a Special State Prosecutor to investigate whether some of its officers filed fraudulent reports on arrests of chain snatchers last year, a spokeman for the department said last night.

title: 200 Are Seized in India In Anti-Immigrant Melee
description: About 200 peo ple were arrested and three bombs exploded in northeast India today during anti-immigrant demonstrations, the Press Trust of India repo rted.

title: New Instant Lottery Has $1 Million Prize
description: Tickets for a new ''Bowl for a Million'' instant lottery game go on sale Tuesday with a top prize of $1,000 a week for life, the New York State lottery director, John D. Quinn, announced toda y.

title: Search Is Suspended Fo r Mud Slides' Missing
description: Geologists surveyed devastated Santa Cruz County today to determine whether rescue crews could resume the search for at least five people still missing and feared killed in last week's mudslides.

title: Celtics 134, Pistons 124
description: HARTFORD (AP) - Larry Bird scored a season-high 40 points, and six other Boston players scored in double figures. The victory moved the Celtics (25-8) into sole possession of first place in the Atlantic Division.

title: Best Spaniel
description: A buff-colored cocker spaniel, Ch. Cottonwoods Colleen O'Brien, owned by Mrs. Charles Chase and Calvin Wa of Los Angeles, was gaited to best in show tonight by Don Johnston at the 65th American Spaniel Club specialty at the Rye Town Hilton Inn.

title: THAI PIRATES CONTINUING BRUTAL ATTACKS ON VIETNAMESE BOAT PEOPLE
description: Nguyen Tien Hoa says he escaped from Vietnam in mid-November aboard a 50-foot boat that carried about 75 refugees, more than half of them women and children.

title: FOOD PLANNING URGED FOR METROPOLITAN AREAS
description: Consumers could have access to fresher and and cheaper food if cities established metropolitan area food plans similar to existing plans for transportatin, housing, education and recreation, according to an energy and agriculture consultant's presentation before the American Association for the Advancement of Science.

title: LAZAR WEINER, 84, COMPOSERAND TEACHER OF JEWISH MUSIC
description: Lazar Weiner, a composer and a leading exponent of Jewish music in this country, died yesterday after a short illness. He was 84 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: BRIEFING
description: L ARRY SPEAKES, deputy press secretary at the White House, literally hid his face in embarrassment the other day. Facing his daily risky chore of briefing the press corps, he defended the Administration's economic record by quoting independent economic authorities as saying that the current recession began in July 1980, that is, in the Carter Administration.

title: UNIT OF N.A.A.C.P. SEEKS TO PROSECUTE BIAS CASE
description: The legal committee of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People voted in New York yesterday to ask the Supreme Court to allow it to replace the Justice Department in prosecuting the case against two schools accused of maintaining policies of segregation.

title: Gunmen Wound Brother Of Iranian President
description: The brother of President Ali Khamenei was wounded by gunmen today and two bodyguards were killed, the Teheran radio said. It identified the attackers as ''American mercenaries.''

title: Addendum
description: * Broder & Gazdag Inc. is a new agency located at 50 West 34th Street.

title: The U.N. Today; Jan. 11, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Special Committee Against Apart- heid - 10:30 A.M.

title: Polish Boxers Said to Defect
description: Three Polish boxers have defected to the West, a friend of the three said today. The friend, Christa Hamann, an official with the sports club in the north German town of Oldenburg, said the boxers -Kriztof Kania, 21 years old, Andrej Chabowski, 18, and Andrej Sliwinski, 21 - left their Gdansk teammates while on a tour of West Germany and Denmark at the beginning of December.

title: QUESTIONS UNANSWERED BY THE FREE TRADERS
description: To the Editor:

title: DRIVER FIND EXHAUST TEST IS NETTLESOME
description: The dark green letters filled the computer's bright green screen: STKR DENIED. Elizabeth Romeo's black Buick had just failed the test for a state inspection sticker because a machine that measures pollution indicated that it did not meet new state standards.

title: MASSACHUSETTS GOVERNOR'S LIBEL SUIT MAY HELP HIS AILING POLITICAL CAREER
description: On the night when Edward J. King upset Gov. Michael S. Dukakis in the 1978 Democratic gubernatorial primary in Massachusetts, Mr. King's jubiliant supporters broke into chants of ''Dump The Globe.''

title: RIPENESS IS ALL
description: A favorite conservative theme for years has been the danger of ''activist judges,'' the need for ''judicial restraint.'' Attorney General William French Smith charged recently, for example, that Federal courts have ''increasingly intruded upon the policy-making functions'' of Congress, the President and the states.

title: Mitsui May Seek Loan Delay
description: The Mitsui group, representing Japanese partners in a joint petrochemical project at Bandar Khomeini, Iran, will shortly ask for a one-year delay in repayment of more than 5 billion yen ($22.7 million) in loans from a Japanese bank syndicate, industry sources said today.

title: SPORTING NEWS ERA OVER
description: ST. LOUIS ''IALWAYS liked going to spring training - to soak up the atmosphere there, and to get out of the office,'' he was saying. ''I'd have two cameras around my neck because I'm a real photography bug. One day I asked Eddie Mathews, who was manager of the Braves then, if he'd pose for a picture when he had time. He said he had more important things to do than pose for pictures.

title: AFTER ENDURING NAZIS AND POVERTY, A POLISH WIDOW NOW FINDS DESPAIR
description: Pani Jadwiga Kowalska is a 62-year-old widow. Her life spans and illustrates the tragic history of this country over the last half century, and now, she says, she had had enough.

title: Article 168444 -- No Title
description: Forty oil, chemical and barge companies have agreed to pay $4.3 million to the families of four shipyard workers who said they contracted leukemia after being exposed to benzene. The settlement last Friday in a $20 million product liability suit was announced after three days of trial before FederalDistrict Judge Robert Parker. Two of the workers have died, one is reported near death and one testified at the trial.

title: JAPAN ORDERS A DC-10
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation said Japan Air Lines had ordered a DC-10 Series 40 jetliner for delivery this year. It said the aircraft, to be used in Japanese domestic service, would be equipped with three Pratt & Whitney JT9D-59A engines.

title: CHANGING VALUES IN MONEY AND LOVE
description: I T did not come up on the first date. Nor on the second. But at some point early in the romance between Roselle Rosenberg and Martin Hodes, mention was made of money. Money is no real problem for Mr. Hodes, who is president of an executive recruitment firm called Insurance-Risk Management. Still, when Mrs. Rosenberg, who is a special education teacher in the New York City school system, offered to share the cost of their dates, he was both pleased and surprised.

title: IF WALTER POLOVCHAK IS FORCED TO GO HOME
description: To the Editor:

title: BITTER ARCTIC WINDS BLOW IN AND STING NEW YORK AREA
description: Although some people swam in the icy waters off Coney Island yesterday or ran barelegged through Central Park in displays of disdain for the cold, most showed respect as Arctic air stung the New York metropolitan area over the weekend.

title: Collision in Turkey Kills 9
description: At least nine people were killed early today when a bus carrying workers to an industrial plant near the southern city of Adan rammed into an express train, the state-run radio reported.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It was kind of like kicking bricks.'' - George Roberts, San Diego punter, on playing in below-zero weather in Cincinnati. (C6:6.)

title: THE REGION
description: A 64-year-old Fl emi ngton woman remained in critical condition in a Hunterdon County hosp ital after being crushedin a trash compactor.

title: Out of Work Second article of a series on the nation's unemployment problem.
description: Joblessness in the United States wears many faces and assumes many patterns, and unfortunately for him, Cornelius Casey fits many of the patterns.

title: Rockwell Gets Japan Contract
description: The Rockwell International Corporation has b een named principal supplier of semiconducto rs for a $500, hand-heldcomputer to be introduced this year by the Ma tshusita Eletric Industrial Company, of Osaka, Japan.

title: Bell Ratings By Moody's
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company's agreement last Friday to divest 22 of its telephone operating subsidiaries may adversely affect the credit quality of those units, according to Moody's Investors Service.

title: Reputed Rackets Figure Denied Church Funeral
description: Frank (Chickie) Narducci, identified by the authorities as a top lieutenant in the Philadelphia underworld before he was killed last week, will not receive a Roman Catholic funeral because his marriage was invalid in the eyes of the church, the Archdiocese of Philadelphia said today.

title: Red Smith Write Less And Better?
description: UP to now, the pieces under my byline have run on Sunday, Monday, Wednesday and Friday. Starting this week, it will be Sunday, Monday and Thursday - three columns instead of four. We shall have to wait and see whether the quality improves.

title: cd3Miss Irwin Wed to Richard Kogan
description: Kathleen Lovell Irwin, daughter of Joseph Welsh Irwin of Tampa, Fla., and Martha Lovell Irwin of Birmingham, Mich., was married yesterday to Richard Kogan, son of Dr. and Mrs. Edgar Kogan of Elizabeth, N.J. The ceremony was performed at the Harvard University Faculty Club in Cambridge, Mass., by Judge Levin Hicks Campbell of the United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit.

title: Conigliaro Still On 'Serious' List
description: Tony Conigliaro, the former Boston Red Sox slugger who was stricken with a heart attack, was reported semiconscious, a hospital spokesman said today, but he remains in serious condition in a coronary care unit.

title: CITIBANK WILL RAISE FEE ON CHARGE CARDS TO $20
description: Citibank, New York's largest bank and the nation's second-largest, will increase the annual fee it charges on its Visa and MasterCard credit cards to $20 from $15, an official con firmed last Friday. The new rate will become effective March 2.

title: Incentives for Bulletin Sale
description: The city says it will offer incentives to anyone wishing to buy The Bulletin, put up for sale last week. ''We're dealing with a major institution with 2,000 jobs,'' Richard A. Doran, city director of commerce, said. Joseph M. Egan, incoming executive director of Philadelphia Industrial Development Corp., said the city could offer a buyer tax-exempt loans at 70 percent of prime interest rates and a sale-lease arrangement for the Bulletin building.

title: 49ERS AND BENGALS TRIUMPH, ADVANCE TO SUPER BOWL
description: With a force of will that overcame frostbite, numbed fingers and slashed hands, the Bengal s conquered the San DiegoChargers, 27- 7, today and moved on to their first Super Bowl.

title: PIANO: BOLET PLAYS SCHUBERT AS TRANSCRIBED BY LISZT
description: IN Liszt's transcriptions of Schubert's songs, the subtle textual evocations of Schubert's settings are overlaid with Liszt's elaborate pianistic filigree. Where Schubert varied the textures of ominous pulsing in ''Erlkonig,'' Liszt created symphonic contrasts; where Schubert let words speak for themselves, Liszt put grand operatic gestures in the virtuoso's hands.

title: NICARAGUAN WOMEN: EQUALS IN BATTLE, NOT IN HOME
description: Garrisons of Gen. Anastasio Somoza Debayle's National Guard were falling to the Sandinist insurgents all across Nicaragua in the closing days of the war, but the commander in the southwestern town of Diriamba still held out.

title: DONORS TO NEEDIEST CASES ASK TO AID VICTIMS OF MISFORTUNE
description: Many contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund ask that their gifts be used to help victims of personal afflictions or misfortunes - people who might otherwise be overlooked in the distribution of assistance to the needy.

title: Accord Is Reached In Latonia Dispute
description: A settlement was reached today in a contract dispute that closed Latonia Race Course last week, according to Pat Lang, a spokesman for the race track.

title: Washington Watch; Finding Where Buck Stops
description: WASHINGTON THE runaround. It's a practice of just about all Federal departments and agencies. You have a specific problem. One bureau can't handle it, suggests another, which suggests still another, and at the end of the line you still can't find the person with the answers.

title: ADVICE TO THOSE WHO DRINK: STAY INDOORS, OUT OF THE COLD
description: Alcohol can be a killer when it is mixed with extremely cold temperatures and high winds, according to Dr. Kent Schwitzer of Hennepin County Medical Center.

title: CONCERT: THE NEW ORLEANS IN RARE AND FAMILIAR PROKOFIEV
description: THE Russian-like winter that fell over New York last weekend had its musical accompaniment as well. First came the two Prokofiev violin concertos played at the New York Philharmonic subscription concerts and then more Prokofiev from the New Orleans Philharmonic at Carnegie Hall Saturday night.

title: ARMY IS SEEKING TO JOIN IVY BASKETBALL
description: Army's director of athletics, Carl Ullrich, said today that the Military Academy would like to join the Ivy League in basketball, but probably not in football.

title: Sabres Win Before 2,079
description: Dale McCourt and Gil Perreault each scored twice tonight, leading the Buffalo Sab res to a 6-4 victory over the Los Angeles Kings before 2,079 fans, the smallest crowd to attend a National Hockey League game in Memor ial Auditorium.

title: POLISH PRIMATE CRITICIZES REGIME'S LOYALTY OATHS
description: One day after his meeting with Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, Archbishop Jozef Glemp, Poland's Roman Catholic Primate, today criticized the martial law regime for extracting loyalty oaths from workers and likened the country's plight to the crucifixion of Jesus.

title: EL PASO SUING OVER BAR TO NEW MEXICO WATER
description: In a lawsuit that could have far-reaching consequences for water law in the West, attorneys for the city of El Paso, Tex., will argue in Federal court Monday that the city has the right to drill 326 wells in New Mexico and pump billions of gallons of water back across the state line into Texas.

title: ELLIS ISLAND IS A MOUNUMENT, NOT A MARKETPLACE
description: To the Editor:

title: READING TO CHILDREN: IT RUNS IN FAMILIES
description: Even as the celebrations marking the 100th anniversary of the birth of A.A.Milne proceed, parents in 60 countries are reading to their children in 25 languages from among the more than 30 million published copies of ''Winnie-the-Pooh'' about the adventures of Pooh, Piglet, Eeyore, Kanga and Roo.

title: U.S. FINDS WIDE SEGREGATION IN CHICAGO'S SUBURBAN AREAS
description: The Justice Department, in the course of a study of whether the desegregation of Chicago's schools should involve the suburban school system, last week reported that it had found widespread racial discrimination in suburban public employm ent and housing. This coincides with a shift of population and employment opportunities from the city to the suburbs, the department's report said.

title: POPE DENOUNCES POLISH CRACKDOWN
description: Pope John Paul II today issued a strong denunciation of the military crackdown in his native Poland, declaring tha t to violate a man's conscience is worse than killing him.

title: OILERS FIND THE WINNING EDGE
description: league clubhouse with table tennis right in the middle of the room. Rugged young men in shorts smack the little white ball and between points they wrestle and chortle and dispute the score.

title: F.D.R. Drive Repairs To Start in East 40's
description: Northbound traffic on the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive between 40th and 43d Streets will be disrupted for up to three months beginning today, as repair crews work on a 25-foot stretch of roadway that collapsed last June, according to the city's Department of Transportation.

title: MARTIN GERAGHTY, CITY OFFICIAL, DIES
description: Martin T. Geraghty, senior administrator of New York City's Bureau of Water Resource Development and a city employee for 56 years, died early Saturday of a heart attack in his home in Highland Lakes, N.J. He was 71 years old.

title: Nicaragua Answers U.S.  Over Arms From France
description: The Foreign Ministry has accused the United States of trying ''to deny Nicaragua its sovereign right to take the measures necessary to strengthen its capacity for defense.''

title: Hispanics and Blacks Clash in Florida Prison
description: Sixteen inmates of a prison for young criminals were injured today when about 30 blacks and Puerto Ricans clashed during free time in the open compound, officials said.

title: AN ARC TIC GRIP AT RIVERFRONT
description: By any barometer, it was cold. By unofficial records, it was the second coldest National Football League playoff game - the temperature was 9 below at kickoff and 4 below by the time the Cincinnati Bengals had warmed the hearts of the hometown fans with a 27-7 victory over the San Diego Chargers.

title: Raging Hormones
description: Twelve years ago, Dr. Edgar Berman, then a member of the Democratic Party's Committee on National Priorities, declared women unfit for executive office because of ''raging hormonal influences.'' By his reasoning, only the premenarcheal and postmenopausal could be depended upon not to be irrational severa l da ys a month.

title: Bridge: Institutions Seem to Need Both Skill and Luck to Last
description: Bridge clubs have a high mortality rate, but some of them, aided by good management and a little luck, go on forever. One of these is the Kissena Club, 41-25 Kissena Boulevard, Flushing, Queens, which was long owned and managed with quiet efficiency by Bob and Jeanette Adler. They retired recently, and the new manager is Bob Yellis, a player of considerable repute.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: A tight end in a National Football League game catches a short pass as an official spots holding by an offensive player. The flag is thrown and the tight end, trying to advance, slips on it and fumbles. A defensive player recovers the ball and runs for a touchdown. What is the ruling?

title: Perry Becomes C oach of Kings
description: Parker MacDonald will be removed as coach of the Los Angeles Kings and be succeeded by Don Perry, who has been coach of the team's minor league affiliate at New Haven, according to Jerry Buss, the hockey club's owner. MacDonald will become assistant general manager, a new position.

title: Judith Lea Friedman Is Bride of Christopher Yates
description: Judith Lea Friedman, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Eugene H. Friedman of New York, and Christopher Scott Yates, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold W. Yates of Alexandria, Va., were married in Manhattan yesterday.

title: U.S. ADVISERS SAW 'TORTURE CLASS,' SALVADORAN SAYS
description: A 21-year-old who asserts that he is a former Salvadoran soldier says that United States military advisers were present at two ''training sessions'' early last year when two suspected guerrillas were tortured by Salvadoran Army instructors.

title: RANGERS AND ISLANDERS BUOYED
description: Happiness comes in different forms in the National Hockey League, a fact emphasized by the Islander and Ranger victories Saturday night. By winning their second game in three nights from the Philadelphia Flyers, the Islanders stretched their Patrick Division lead over the Flyers to 6 points, their largest margin since early in the season.

title: Lynn Fruchter, Lawyer, Wed to Dr. Mark Stoopler
description: Lynn Sara Fruchter, an associate with the New York law firm of Kaye, Scholer, Fierman, Hays & Handler, and Dr. Mark Benjamin Stoopler, assistant professor of clinical medicine at the College of Physicians and Surgeons of Columbia University, were married yesterday. Rabbi Reuben Levine performed the ceremony at Temple Beth Ahm in Springfield, N.J.

title: A FIRST FIRST OF JANUARY BURIED IN HISTORY
description: To the Editor:

title: Keep Case Records Confidential
description: New York State's Preventive Child Care Program aims to avoid the need for foster care by offering help to troubled families. But the law that created the program requires the private agencies involved to turn over case records of the families to state or local welfare offices.

title: TV: DANCE TRIBUTE TO PAUL TAYLOR
description: PAUL TAYLOR hasn't been neglected by television. But ''Three Modern Classics,'' a ''Dance in America'' special that will be on the air tonight at 8 on WNET, Channel 13, is one of the best programs that has been devoted to him.

title: Advertising; Budweiser B olstering Needham
description: HAVING tested the advertising of D'Arcy-MacManus & Masius, of St. Louis, and Needham, Harper & Steers, of Chicago, Anheuser-Busch, the country's leading brewer, has decided to assign its Budweiser Light beer, a major entry now in test market, to Needham.

title: 50 KIDNAPPING VICTIMS FOUND DEAD IN GUATEMALA
description: The bodies of 50 people abducted from their homes by armed men 10 days ago have been found in western Guatemala, the police said today. They said all the bodies had bullet wounds and signs of torture.

title: SOME NOT-SO-VITAL STATISTICS
description: For weight-watchers and other observers of the American political scene, here are some little-known facts about the Speaker o f the House, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., a man who says he has lost more weight over a lifetime than anybody in America, only toput it right back on:

title: LEHRMAN SEEKING GOVERNORSHIP ARMED WITH A MARKETING PLAN
description: To Lewis E. Lehrman, running for Governor of New York State is not all that different from running a chain of drug stores. Having succeeded mightily at the latter, he is now preparing to tackle the former.

title: Market Place; Last Day of '81: Stock Action
description: WAS the clandestine practice of ''painting the tape'' in evidence in the waning hours of trading last year in connection with stocks owned by the American Financial Corporaton? The practice involves efforts to drive up the price of a stock - as shown on the ticker tape -through aggressive purchases over the course of one or more market sessions. It violates the rules that prohibit securities manipulation.

title: 8th Suspect Noted In Brink's Holdup
description: The Rockland County District Attorney said yesterday that he expected to obtain the indictment of an eighth suspect in the Brink's armored car holdup that left two police officers and a Brink's guard dead.

title: THE HYPOCRISY IN AMERICA'S ULSTER VISA POLICY
description: To the Editor:

title: CHINA EXONERATES A FORMER LEADER
description: A new book, jacketed in pale yellow, went on sale in China today. Its publication culminates the rehabilitation of Liu Shaoqi, the former Chief of State who died in disgrace after becoming a prime scapegoat in Mao Zedong's Cultural Revolution.

title: A Fonda Homecoming
description: The last ti me she visited her father's hometown was for an antiwar rally a decad e ago. This time Jane Fonda was in Omaha to attend the Middle West p remiere of the new movie ''On Golden Pond,'' in which she appears w ith her father, Henry Fonda.

title: AN UNLIKELY SETTING FOR UNUSUAL EVENTS: PACIFIC ATOLL (POPULATION 1)
description: A monthlong castaway drama that ended here last Tuesday with the arrest of one of those rescued was the latest in a series of off-beat happenings in the unlikely setting of Palmyra atoll, a cluster of coral islands 1,100 miles southwest of here.

title: KEMP SAYS FED FOSTERS JOBLESSNESS
description: Representative Jack Kemp today blamed the Federal Reserve Board's monetary policy for the nation's economic slowdown and high unemployment. The New York Republican said President Reagan should try to get the Fed to change its stance instead of asking Congress for higher taxes.

title: FOUTS COULD NOT GRIP FROZEN BALL, CHARGERS LAMENT
description: Kellen Winslow had a simple explanation why the best offense in National Football League history was colder than the weather today and could score only 7 points in frozen Riverfront Stadium.

title: HISTORIC A.T.&T. SETTLEMENT AS SEEN BY THE PARTICIPANTS
description: Seventeen directors assembled in the dark, wood-paneled board room of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company on Dec. 16. They listened quietly as Charles L. Brown, the chairman, presented a report that would lead to the dismemberment of the largest company in the world and to reshaping of the telecommunications industry.

title: Commodities; Options Hurdle Cleared
description: THE trading in commodity options on American exchanges, which the Government banned 49 years ago, came a step closer to reality last week when the Federal Commodity Futures Trading Commission invited public comment on the proposals by eight leading futures markets that want to list them. Another hur dle cleared last week came when a Federal court refused a request by the American Stock Exchange to delay the agency's move. Amex, which p lans to trade options on physical commodities rather than futures, feared that the commodity exchanges would get a head start.

title: GREECE CITES STAND ON POLAND
description: The Greek Government has officially notified its NATO partners of three key objections it has to the West's developing position on Poland. The notification makes it clear that Greece will obstruct the issuing of a joint communique at the NATO conference on the issue Monday.

title: TV: RAPE DRAMA AND FUGITIVE SPY
description: JUST when it might be supposed that television might have run out of scripts exploring rape, long a salable subject in television movieland, along comes ''The Victims'' on ABC this evening at 9. In this one, six women attacked at different time s over two years positively id entify the rapist in a police lineup. Because of a police foulup , however, the women had been placed together in the same room bef ore the identification procedure. In court, then, the judge is forc ed to throw the case out on the legal technicality of possible coll usion among the women. The smirking rapist goes free.

title: POLICY OFFICE IS SHORT ON CLOUT AND LONG ON CRITICS
description: In the Johnson, Kennedy, Nixon and Carter Administrations, the White House domestic policy shop was prominent and, oftentimes, feared. But President Reagan's Office of Policy Development is obscure and, sometimes, ridiculed.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt THE DEAN'S DECEMBER. By Saul Bel- low. 312 pages. Harper & Row. $13.95.

title: Kirk Gibson Signs
description: Kirk Gibson, the Detroit Tiger outfielder, said Saturday that he had signed a one-year contract with the team for 1982.

title: PLAYBOY CLOSES SALE TO TRIDENT
description: Playboy Enterprises has closed the sale of its British gambling interests to Trident Television Ltd. of London, three months after licenses for its two most profitable London casinos were revoked.

title: U NITY IS ELUSIVE FOR THE SRI LANKA OPPOSITION
description: An effort to unite the fractious Sri Lanka opposition got off to an inauspicious start last week. Former Prime Minister Sirimavo Bandaranaike and her Sri Lanka Freedom Party failed to appear at a meeting that had been advertised as a vital first step for the unity of the progressive forces.

title: THE CALENDAR
description: The following is the Washington calendar for this week. Monday

title: News Analysis
description: The relationship between West Germany and France, a central element in Western Europe's role in influencing international affairs, has been increasingly strained by the situation in Poland.

title: Other Account Shifts From a Busy Week
description: Although all of the talk this week in adland will be about Pan Am's latest switch, last Friday saw an unusually heavy flurry of account moves.

title: POLITICS HAS NO PLACE IN OUR EXTRADITION LAW
description: To the Editor:
