title: RECORD BREAKING COLD LEAVES 9 DEAD IN U.S.
description: One of the deepest winter chills on record numbed much of the nation today. It was the coldest day on record for Chicago, at 26 degrees below zero, Fahrenheit. In the most brutal cold spell of the season, records were broken in many other places in the Middle West, and swirling snowstorms and icy winds left scores stranded on highways or without heat in their homes.

title: Arrows Vanquish Rockets Again, 7-2
description: The bad news for the New Jersey Rockets is that their next game is against the New York Arrowss, but at leastthe Rockets w ill be home Wednesday night at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: SETTLEMENT REACHED WITH TITLE INSURERS ON FEES FOR SEARCHES
description: The Attorney General of New York State yesterday announced a $163,550 settlement with 104 title insurance companies and title examiners he had accused of conspiring to fix prices on title searches and reports.

title: OIL-DEAL MAKER LURES INSTITUTIONS INTO SEARCH
description: The age of the robber barons is long gone, and the world will rarely see again anything like the $1 billion personal fortune that John D. Rocke feller squeezed out of his hapless competitors. But big money is stil l being made in the United States, and by and large the new wealth, l ike Rockefeller's fortune, still flows out of the ground.

title: V.A. MAY ABANDON FREE CARE FOR VETERANS OVER 65
description: The Federal Government, concerned that millions of World War II servicemen will soon be eligible for free medical care, may have to stop offering no-strings-attached treatment to all veterans over 65 years of age, the head of the Veterans Administation says.

title: Ballesteros Wins
description: Severiano Ba llesteros of Spain won the two-round San Remo golf tournament by two strokes today with a 135.

title: WARSAW NOTEBOOK: 'END OF THE DREAM'
description: Five women were sitting in the treatment room of a cosmetics parlor Saturday, their faces piled with mud packs, wrinkle-erasing ointments and various creams. One remarked listlessly that tangerines were in the shops for the first time in a year.

title: Six Young Musicians Win New Competition
description: Three pianists and three violinists have won the Young Musicians Competition sponsored by the American Jewish Congress and Pepsico.

title: MAYOR IS PLANNING TO SEEK SURCHARGE FOR INCOME TAXES
description: The Koch administration is planning to seek a 5 to 10 percent surcharge on city and commuter income taxes to help close an expected budget gap of about $900 million, officials said yesterday.

title: DESAULNIERS WINS FINAL IN SQUASH
description: Michael Desaulniers retained his No.1 ranking on the World Professional Squash Association tour today with a fast-paced victory over Mario Sanchez in the final of the $10,000 Greenwich Open. The scores were 16-18, 15-11, 15-11, 15-5.

title: Burger on Ethics
description: Recent law school graduates may have higher ethical standards than the public gives them credit for, but they are not as high as they should be.

title: Books of The Times: 'The Dean's December'
description: There are two particularly striking passages in ''The Dean's December,'' Saul Bellow's ninth and latest novel, his first since he won the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1976. In one of these passages, which occurs near the opening of the story, Albert Corde, the novel's protagonist, sits with his wife in the office of a Bucharest hospital a dmi nistrator, who is officiously denying the couple the right to visi t Minna Corde's dying mother, and contemplates the dyinglight of a De cember evening. <TD WIDTH=2

title: TRADERS AWAIT MONEY DATA
description: Institutional buyers of fixed-income securities continued to avoid long-term bonds last week and this - more than any other factor - added to the downward pressure on prices.

title: HAIG BACKED IN OUSTER OF OFFICIAL
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. has won permission from President Reagan to replace a highranking S tate Department official after demanding White House support on th e matter, according to well-placed Administration sources.

title: POLE IS IN SOVIET FOR FIRST TALKS SINCE CRISIS
description: Foreign Minister Jozef Czyrek of Poland arrived here today on the first official visit by a high-ranking Polish leader since martial law was imposed by the Warsaw Government four weeks ago.

title: Telephones in Warsaw Are Switched On Again
description: Telephones were switched on in Warsaw today, 29 days after the declaration of martial law and the imposition of a communications blackout. But the restoration of service allowed Warsaw residents to call within the city only, and regular telephone and telex links between Poland and the outside world remain cut.

title: THE POLISH AIRWAVES: WESTERN SANCTIONS 'SEEM VERY STRANGE TO US'
description: Following is an excerpt from domestic Polish television, broadcast today, as transcribed and translated from the Polish by the Foreign Broadcast Information Service, a United States Special to the New York Times Government agency:

title: KNICKS TOPPLED IN OVERTIME
description: Greg Ballard's 3-point basket from the left of the key with a second remaining in overtime gave the Washington Bullets a 129-126 victory over the Knicks last night at Madison Square Garden.

title: A Nobel Shift
description: The Norwegian parliamentary committee that selects the winner of the Nobel Peace Prize has a new chairman.

title: HAIG, ON EVE OF NATO TALKS, SAYS HE WANTS UNITY ON SOVIET SANCTIONS
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. said today that the United States would press its allies at a special NATO meeting here Monday for agreement on a framework for imposing sanctions against Moscow if the situation in Poland is not ''remedied in the immediate future.''

title: MONDAY, JANUARY 11, 1982; Antitrust
description: The anatomy of the A.T.& T. divestiture involved not only the dismemberment of the world's largest private sector company but a multitude of major and minor decisions by its management and 17 directors. The quick resolution of the issues raised at a company meeting last month led to the settlement. (Page A1.)

title: PETRA SCHNEIDER WINS 4TH SWIM EVENT
description: Petra Schneider of East Germany, capturing her fourth gold medal, achieved a world-best mark in the women's 1,500-meter freestyle by a stunning 20 seconds tonight at the United States Swimming International meet.

title: Texas Is Riding High at 10-0
description: Even though Abe Lemons of Texas is a voter in the United Press International weekly poll of coaches, and his Longhorns are among the few remaining undefeated basketball teams in Division I, he has yet to cast a vote for them. Many other coaches may soon be naming them, though.

title: Georgetown Streak Is at 12
description: Eric Smith, Mike Hancock and Eric Floyd each scored 20 points tonight as Georgetown beat Boston College, 67-51, in the Big East.

title: Sports World Specials; Price Is Right
description: With the metropolitan area currently in the grip of its worst cold wave of the winter, the New York Racing Association is prepared to risk more than $200,000 in admission fares that temperatures at Aqueduct will stay above the freezing mark on 11 weekdays later this month.

title: New Zealand Gets World Cup Berth
description: New Zealand scored a 2-1 victory over China today to clinch the final berth in the World Cup soccer tournament, which will be played at sites throughout Spain from June 14 to July 11.

title: DISPUTE SETTLED OVER POWER USE IN NIAGARA FALLS
description: A four-year legal dispute over the distribution of power to industries in the Niagara Falls area has been settled, raising the hope that the accord will improv e the badly depress ed job market in western New York.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, JANUARY 11, 1982
description: International A cutoff of vital parts of a pipeline that will carry Soviet natural gas to Western Europe is being sought in West Europe and Japan by the Reagan Administration, diplomatic sources said. The request, which follows a United States decision to ban such shipments by the General Electric Company, is seen as the first major test of Western Europe's willingness to support the economic sanctions President Reagan imposed on the Soviet Union after the declaration of martial law in Poland. (Page A1, Column 4.) A warm welcome in Moscow was received by Foreign Minister Jozef Czyrek of Poland. It is the first visit by a high Polish official to the Soviet Union since martial law was declared in Poland nearly a month ago. So viet television showed Mr. Czyrek being embraced by the Soviet Foreig n Minister, Andrei A. Gromyko, perhaps to indicate that Soviet-Polish relations were continuing as usual. (A1:5.)

title: REVIEW OF BELL CASE ON RATES IS URGED
description: A Long Island consumer advocate asked the state Public Service Commission yesterday to reopen the New York Telephone Company's pending request for multimillion-dollar revenue increases so that the impact of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's reorganization on the request could be evaluated.

title: A 49ER PLAY FROM DAY 1
description: SAN FRANCISCO UP on the scoreboard the clock showed only 58 seconds remaining in the National Conference Championship game yesterday, but at the 49ers' sideline during their timeout, Coach Bill Walsh was talking to his quarterback, Joe Montana, as calmly as if it were the first day of training camp. And in a sense it was the first day of training camp.

title: Government's Duty in Recession
description: ''Almost two million Americans have lost their jobs t his year alone.... Individuals and families are being hurt and hurt badly. Factories are empty; unemployment lines are f ull.''

title: EXCERPTS FROM U.S. MESSAGE RECOUNTING A REFUGEE'S ORDEAL
description: Following are excerpts from a cablegram sent by the United States Embassy in Kuala Lumpur to the State Department relating the account of Nguyen Tien Hoa.

title: Rescue Efforts End in Beirut
description: Rescue teams ended their 27-day search of the rubble of the Iraqi Embassy today, and the police said 61 bodies had been recovered. The embassy was destroyed Dec. 15 when a car laden with explosives crashed into the building and blew up. A police spokesman said that the bodies of five other people were believed to be under the rubble.

title: White House; ON THE STATE OF THE STATE OF THE UNION
description: Is the state of the union good? Is it bad? If it is bad, would it be politically wise to describe it that way? These are the kinds of questions that keep Ronald Reagan poring over a sheaf of typewritten pages at his desk these days as he prepares his State of the Union Message, which he will deliver in a televised appearance before a joint session of Congress Jan. 26.

title: JOHNSON PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
By Sandra Salamans
description: Talking Businesswith Wolf of Trade Policy Center Textile Pact: The Outlook

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, JANUARY 12, 1982
description: International Soviet support of ''suppression'' in Poland was assailed by the Western alliance, which warned that Western Europe may join the United States in imposing economic sanctions against Moscow. The tough statement issued at the end of the first emergency meeting of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization was the first suggestion that Western Europe might join in sanctions. (Page A1, Column 6.) Poland's economy is still paralyzed, according to a Polish Government economist, who blamed American sanctions for the nation's continuing economic doldrums and implied that the sanctions would prolong military rule. Restoring the economy has been a key goal of the military regime, but according to the official, Wladyslaw Baka, the economic outlook is not good. (A9:1-3.)

title: SETTLERS PROTEST SINAI COMPENSATION PLAN
description: The Israeli Cabinet's decision last week on compensation for settlers evacuating Sinai has begun to encounter opposition, both from settlers who think the money is insufficient and from politicians who think it excessive.

title: SUPPORTING A NEIGHBOR
description: It appeared to be a typical church supper, with several hundred people digging into mountains of chicken, homemade salads, Jell-O molds and bundt cakes with plastic forks. Their children scurried noisily about, jostling the tables decorated with foil-covered peanut butter jars that served as flower vases.

title: 'THE SYRIANS HAVE BEEN THEIR OWN WORST ENEMIES'
description: To the Editor:

title: Higher Pay Approved For Kean and Cabinet
description: The State Legislature approved bills tonight to raise the pay of the incoming gubernatorial administration of Thomas H. Kean.

title: CELTICS DEFEAT NETS BY 112-94
description: As Kevin McHale walked out of the shower tonight, he was asked about the performance of the Boston front line in the Celtics' 112-94 victory over the New Jersey Nets at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: Rams' Hill Enters Plea In Misdemeanor Case
description: Drew Hill, a wide receiver for the Los Angeles Rams, pleaded not guilty through his attorney today of four misdemeanor charges involving a 16-year-old Buena Park girl.

title: Universe's Size Reappraised
description: From observing very distant galaxies a group of astronomers has found evidence implying that the universe is only half as large and half as old as generally believed. The basis for this supposition is their revised figure for the ''Hubble constant,'' a figure defining how fast the universe is expanding.

title: HER JOB: BUILDING STEEL MILLS
description: In the northeast corner of Italy, where most women concentrate more on polenta and chicken than cold-rolled steel, Cecilia Danieli has carved out an unusually successful career as the head of of Italy's leading builder of steel mills and steel-handling equipment.

title: New Genie, Old Duty
description: If you doubt the importance of the dramatic antitrust news from Washington, look at your teen-age son playing ''Asteroids'' on the color television set. Or turn on the cable TV news. Or look again at the sale prices for video cassette recorders. Or call up your tax records on your home computer. These are all different faces of the same genie - and by abandoning antitrust charges against I.B.M. and settling its suit against A.T.& T., the Department of Justice has let it all the way out of the bottle.

title: Around the World; Haiti Says It Captured 3 Exile Invaders of Island
description: AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Jan. 11 (UPI) - Government troops captured three exiles who invaded a small island off Haiti's north coast and were ''in total control'' despite claims of a second rebel landing, a Government minister said.

title: In the Nation; SUBSIDIZING RACISM
description: With its decision to grant a Federal tax exemption to segregated private schools, the Reagan Administration has moved from a lack of interest in fighting racial discrimination to active promotion of it.

title: Notes on Fashion
description: A FTER two weeks of almost no activity on or off Seventh Avenue, the fashion pace picked up last week. Designers of women's wear showed their summer collections. Perry Ellis returned from Leningrad, having eaten so much caviar, he said, that his teeth turned gray one morning in the Hermitage. And men's wear designers began showing their fall collections, but the total effect was enough to make one wonder if buying ''designed'' men's clothing is a particularly good idea, especially when one can just as easily go, say, to the area around 45th Street a nd Madison Avenue and be assured of quality and wearability a t reasonable prices.

title: Fear of Lisa H.  TO SCIENCE TIMES:
description: What is it in human nature that makes people react with fear and revulsion when confronted with something they do not understand and feel helpless in the face of? I am alluding to the extraordinary abuse accorded ''Lisa H.,'' whom you described so eloquently in your Science Times article of Dec. 8. The cruelty of her neighbors, not her disease, turned my stomach.

title: ABBOTT TRIAL WITNESS SAYS VICTIM WAS PEACEABLE
description: The 22-year-old waiter the author Jack Henry Abbott is accused of stabbing to death was portrayed in State Supreme Court in Manhattan yesterday as a peaceable person who did not carry a knife or fight.

title: Schmidt Plans to Meet Mitterrand Tomorrow
description: Chancellor Helmut Schmidt of West Germany will visit Paris on Wednesday for talks with President Francois Mitterrand.

title: Around the World; Salvadoran Troops Start Infantry Training in U.S.
description: The first of a group of about 1,000 Salvadoran soldiers began infantry training at Fort Bragg today as some 200 demonstrators delivered a letter for the base commander that opposed the program.

title: Texas Plea Blocked by N.C.A.A.
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association obtained relief today from a restraining order that would have prohibited its membership from voting Tuesday on three specific proposals aimed at giving the N.C.A.A. more control over network TV and future cablevision football rights.

title: OIL UNION SETTLES A KEY 2-YEAR PACT
description: The Oil, Chemical and Atomic Workers reached agreement today with the Gulf Oil Corporation on a new two-year contract, apparently averting a walkout by 55,000 oil workers at refineries from California to Pennsylvania, the union announced.

title: News Analysis
description: Now that the martial-law Government has quelled open resistance in Poland for the time being, it is faced with a more daunting task - trying to govern the country.

title: Chrysler Raises Some '82 Prices
description: The Chrysler Corporation, the only American auto maker to record a sales increase last year, said that it had raised prices on some 1982 subcompact and compact models that were frozen at 1981 levels last September.

title: Nigerian Oil Output Off
description: Nigerian crude oil production in 1981 totaled 522.29 million barrels, a decrease of 232.33 million barrels from 1980, the newspaper Business Times reported today. The country's average daily production rate in 1981 was 1.43 million barrels, compared with 2.07 million barrels in 1980, it reported.

title: FEW STATES SEEK TO EASE EFFECTS OF CUTS FOR POOR
description: Only a few of the 39 state legislatures convening this month are expected to alleviate the effects of reductions in Federal spending for social welfare programs.

title: JUSTICE REHNQUIST BACK AT WORK AFTER TREATMENT FOR DRUG REACTION
description: Associate Justice William H. Rehnquist of the Supreme C ourt returned to the bench today after being hospitalized for a back disorder and treated for a withdrawal reaction to a drug he was taking to help him sleep. His speech was nolonger haltin g and slurred, as it had been late last year.

title: Tax-Exempt Hate
description: The Reagan Administration is picking the pocket of every American taxpayer to subsidize racism in education.

title: DESIGNER OF ZERO FIGHTER AIRCRAFT
description: Jiro Horikoshi, designer of the Zero fighter plane used in the attack on Pearl Harbor at the outset of the Pacific phase of World War II, died of pneumonia today in a Tokyo hospital. He was 78 years old.

title: Sports People; Comings and Goings
description: Ernie DiGregorio, the former basketball player, has filed a $16 mil lion libel suit against Sports Illustrated magazine claiming that a 1981 articl e characterized him ''as a quitter, unwilling to compete, unre liable and undesireable in any employment capacity.'' ... Gordon Wo od, the football coach at Brownwood High School in San Angelo, Tex., has filed a $20,000 suit against ABC-TV, which wrongly identified hi m in film depicting a coach hitting his players. ... A spokesman for Massachusetts General Hospital said yesterday that the condition of Tony Conigliaro's heart has improved but that the formeroutfielder '' is not yet out of danger.''

title: Notes on People; A Mayor Turns Down 17% Pay Increase
description: When Kathy Whitmire was elected Mayor of Houston in November, the salary for the office was $81,880, the highest mayoral salary in the nation, and according to Mrs. Whitmire, quite enough for a newcomer to the office.

title: EX-TAX OFFICIALS ASSAIL SHIFT ON SCHOOL EXEMPTION STATUS
description: The new Reagan Administration policy of granting tax-exempt status to segregated private schools was criticized today by two former heads of the Internal Revenue Service, two Republican Senators and others.

title: IN QUEENS, UNPREDICTABLE RADIATORS
description: When Jerry Fisher lived in Leningrad a decade ago, he recalled, ''my job was an engineer for refrigerators; it's the same what I got here - a refrigerator.'' He was standing in the cold bedroom of his apartment in Rego Park, Queens, where the radiators have been dead since Saturday.

title: PARAMOUNT MAY DROP COPPOLA'S NEW MOVIE
description: Francis Coppola, the risk-taking director whose creativ ity always soars highest when he is on the verge of ruin, decided to preview his $27-million musical, ''One From the Heart,'' to a paying audience at the Radio City Music Hall in New York next Fri day night partly because of ongoing difficulties with the movie's d istributor, Paramount Pictures.

title: SUPREME COURT RETAINS SUIT ON ASBESTOS
description: In its latest action involving the flood of liability suits against manufacturers of asbestos products, the Supreme Court today kept a major category of those lawsuits alive by permitting them to remain in Federal court. Without comment, the Court turned down an appeal by the Johns-Manville Corporation and other manufacturers of asbestos products from a ruling by the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit in Richmond. That court allowed five former workers at the Newport News shipyards, who had been exposed to asbestos on the job as long as 42 years ago, to maintain their suit against the company in Federal court.

title: POP: PRETENDERS BEGIN CONCERT TOUR
description: THE Pretenders' triumphant performance at the Palladium on Saturday - the first of a series of local concerts - represented an impressive victory over recent misfortune and a bad press.

title: Chess: Two Cubans Get a Leg Up In 1984 Title Eliminations
description: More zonal tournaments - the first stage of trials to select a challenger for Anatoly Karpov, the world champion, in 1984, have recently been concluded.

title: TRUE 'LIONS OF THE BAR' INVISIBLE TO SOME
description: To the Editor:

title: DUO PERFORMS SHOSTAKOVICH
description: THE Clark-Schuldmann duo, a husband-wife cello-piano ensemble, presented a recital at the 92d Street Y on Sunday afternoon. Though the players coordinated their playing well, they didn't have much to say to each other.

title: CONSUMER DEBT RISE IS SLIGHT
description: Americans added just $342 million to their installment debt load last November, the smallest increase since the summer of 1980, the Federal Reserve Board reported today,

title: Disgruntled Cabby in Peking Said to Kill 3 in Crowd Crash
description: A taxi driver, unhappy over not receiving a bonus, drove her taxi into a crowd in front of Peking's Gate of Heavenly Peace, killing three people, Chinese sources said today.

title: REGAN HOLDS STATE SHOULDN'T PAY TO SUPPLY CAREY'S SUMMER HOME
description: State Comptroller Edward V. Regan said today thatstate funds s hould not be used to pay for food, supplies and other services at G overnor Carey's Long Island summer home on Shelter Island.

title: VILLANOVA FOUL SHOTS TOP ST. JOHN'S BY 2
description: At the end of an evening in the Villanova Field House, after St. John's reduced a 9-point deficit to 2 and was working for a shot to tie the score in the last 10 seconds, David Russell was right where he wanted to be, with the ball in his hands.

title: BERNADETTE PETERS
description: born actress who made her first hit in the Off Broadway musical spoof ''Dames at Sea'' in 1969, is coming back from Hollywood to star in another Off Broadway production. She begins rehearsals today for ''Sally and Marsha,'' a new two-character play by Sybille Pearson that will open Feb. 21 at the Manhattan Theater Club. If things go well, the production is likely to come to Broadway.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: By Susan Bolotin WHAT EVERY WOMAN SHOULD KNOW ABOUT MEN. By Dr. Joyce Brothers. 268 pages. Simon & Schuster. $14.50.

title: JUDGE OFFERS PRAISE FOR A.T.&T. ACCORD
description: A Federal judge with jurisdiction over a 1956 consent decree with A.T.& T. that the Justice Department is seeking to modify yesterday all but endorsed that modification.

title: Sports People; Hassle Over N.Y.R.A.
description: Bernard Rome, the former chairman of the New York Offtrack Betting Corporation, has proposed that a group of investors take over the operation of the New York Racing Association tracks - Saratoga, Belmont and Aqueduct - because of the N.Y.R.A.'s ''declining contribution to the New York State government and its inability to develop racing's potential benefit for itself and its fans.'' Mr. Rome's suggestion came in a letter to state legislative leaders and to Governor Carey, in which he said that he represented a group ''willing and able to invest $60 million in racing'' in the state. Ogden Mills Phipps, the chief operating officer for the N.Y.R.A., said Mr. Rome's contention ''is so permeated with inaccuracies that it is impossible to address.'' The N.Y.R.A. franchise to operate the tracks expires in 1985.

title: BIDDING IN THE PARTY SPIRIT
description: The bidding didn't start until 9 last night when Brendan Gill, the theater critic of The New Yorker, took the podium to exhort the black-tie crowd of 200 who had assembled to celebrate the 90th birthday of the Municipal Art Society at a benefi t auction at Christie's.

title: PAUL LYNDE, 55, STAGE-FILM ACTOR
description: Paul Lynde, who was a regular performer on the television game show ''The Hollywood Squares,'' died, possibly of a stroke, Saturday at his home in Los Angeles. The Beverly Hills police said an autopsy was to be performed to determine the cause of death. The actor was 55 years old.

title: ATLANTA SUSPECT IS DISPUTED ON HIS ACTIONS NEAR BRIDGE
description: Prosecution witnesses today disputed details of Wayne B. Williams's account of what he was doing in the early morning hours of May 22, when a police stake-out team heard a splash in the Chattahoochee River and saw Mr. Williams in a station wagon on the bridge above.

title: DECEMBER RETAIL SALES ROSE 7.8% IN NEW YORK
description: December sales at New York City's largest retailers wound up with a 7.8 percent gain over the same month a year earlier, according to a spot-check last weekend, but profits may suffer because of the substantial reductions in the prices of some merchandise.

title: Tapeworms Are Flat TO SCIENCE TIMES:
description: In a recent Q.&A. column (Dec. 22) tapeworms were incorrectly referred to as ''parasitic roundworms'' Tapeworms are flatworms and belong to the phylum Platyhelminthes. It is the phylum Nematodes which includes the roundworms such as hookworm, trichinella (which causes trichinosis), filaria (which causes elephantiasis), and many others. STEVE WOLFSON Syosset High School Syosset, N.Y.

title: CONTINENTAL INFORMATION SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company has restated revs and net earnings for the first qr of 1981 and the first and second qtrs of 1980 to conform to this report

title: The U.N. Today; Jan. 12, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Special Committee Against Aparthied - 10:30 A.M.

title: De Lorean Cuts Its Workweek
description: The De Lorean Motor Company said it had put 2,000 of the 2,600 employees at its Belfast plant on an indefinite three-day workweek because a ferry strike had caused a shortage of components made across the Irish Sea in Britain.

title: International Crane Check
description: The red-crowned crane, revered in Asia as a symbol of long life and good fortune, has dwindled in numbers to about 800, a population among cranes lower only than the Siberian and whooping cranes. The handsome white, black and red bird migrates across hostile nations that refuse to exchange scientific data.

title: WHAT YALIES COULD DO ABOUT THE LIT
description: To the Editor:

title: LEHRMAN STARTS HIS RUN IN G.O.P. GOVERNOR RACE
description: Lewis E. Lehrman, a wealthy businessman, announced his candidacy for the Republican gubernatorial nomination yesterday. He criticized Governor Carey and sharply attacked the state's highest court, the Court of Appeals.

title: NUCLEAR DATA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-Includes $1 million tax credit; 1980 net income including $100,000 tax credit

title: A Different Path To Top Management
description: Most top management people in magazines come up through advertising sales or circulation.

title: CAUCUS CHALLENGES DEFENSE CONCEPTS
description: About a year ago, Senator Gary Hart rose on the floor of a nearly empty Senate to deliver a lecture on inadequacies in the Navy's shipbuilding plans. He asserted that the Navy should construct several small, less expensive aircraft carriers rather than a few big, costly flattops. He contended that national security would be better served if the Navy acquired a fleet of less expensive diesel-electric submarines instead of a relative few, big, expensive nuclear-powered submarines. He went on to catalogue other mistakes in the nation's military posture and to outline what he thought should be done about them.

title: Diet and Colon Cancer
description: Israeli researchers have uncovered further evidence linking a diet high in fat and beef to an increased risk of developing cancer of the colon. The researchers, from Tel Aviv University's Sackler School of Medicine, compared dietary habits of two groups of Israelis who differed in cancer incidence but who were similar in age, sex, country of origin, socioeconomic status and length of residence in Israel.

title: EVOLUTION WINS AGAIN
description: Biblical literalists, this time masquerading under the nonsense phrase ''scientific creationism,'' have just lost the first skirmish of round three.

title: EVOLUTION, A 'CRIME'
description: In March 1925, the Tennessee Legislature outlawed the teaching of ''any theory that denies the story of the Divine Creation of man as taught in the Bible, and to teach instead that man has descended from the lower order of animals.'' That July, in a case that became known as the ''monkey trial,'' John T. Scopes was tried in Dayton for teaching the theory of evolution and fined $100 for the misdemeanor. Clarence Darrow was chief defense counsel. The prosecuting attorney was William Jennings Bryan. Following are excerpts from Mr. Darrow's remarks during the second day of the trial, in the circuit court of Rhea County. (In 1927, the Tennessee Supreme Court reversed the circuit court's decision.)

title: GHANA RESTORING ITS TIES TO LIBYA
description: Ghana's new military regime announced today that diplomatic relations with Libya were being resumed. It said in a statement that the Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, had sent a message to Ghana's leader, former Flight Lieut. Jerry J. Rawlings, in which he expressed ''solidarity'' with the revolution in which the civilian Government of President Hilla Limann was overthrown Dec. 31. The Limann administration broke off diplomatic relations with Libya in November 1980, charging Colonel Qaddafi with plotting subversive activities in Ghana.

title: Sports of The Times; Man Paul Brown Passed On
description: I N another of the quirks of fate that often govern sports, Bill Walsh, the 49er coach, now has an opportunity in Super Bowl XVI to remind Paul Brown that the Cincinnati Bengals' creator made a mistake six years ago in choosing his own successor.

title: Rolls-Royce U.S. Notes
description: State-owned Rolls-Royce Ltd. said to day that it would seek to raise up to $250 million by issuing commercial paper in the United States for the first time. The company said that its promissor y notes were guaranteed by the British Government and would be sold by Lehman Commercial Paper Inc. A Rolls-Royce spokesmansaid the issu e was to raise working capital for the company's aircraft engi ne program.

title: ROCKCOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Includes operating loss carryforwards of $306,000 for the qr and $1,009,000 for the yr

title: COAL UTILIZATION IS ANYTHING BUT BENIGN
description: To the Editor:

title: SCOTTY'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
Market Place;  High Liquidity Seen on Amex
description: CONTRARY to widespread belief, stocks traded on the American Stock Exchange can support considerably more trading at a given price than comparable stocks on the New York Stock Exchange, an Amex study has concluded.

title: CITY PLANS TO SUE G.M. FOR TAX
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that the city would sue the General Motors Corporation, charging that the company owed the city and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority $50 million in taxes related to a transaction involving its Fifth Avenue office building.

title: FIRST NATIONAL CINCINNATI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
POLISH OFFICIAL SAYS ECONOMIC OUTLOOK IS NOT GOOD
description: A Polish Government economist said today that the Government was having difficulty repairing Poland's paralyzed economy.

title: Steel Output Increases
description: Steel production rose to 1.78 million tons in the week ended last Saturday, an increase of 5.9 percent from the previous week's 1.68 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

title: Briefing
description: T HE wrenching plight of children of the Orient fathered by American servicemen is scheduled to reach Congress in the next few weeks, and Representative Stewart B. McKinney, who has been championing their cause, is faintly optimistic that the House will finally approve his bill.

title: Things Quieting Down For A.T.& T. Counsel
description: Now that th e big settlement announcement is behind him, Howard Trienens, the 58-year-old vice president and general counsel of the American Tele phone and Telegraph Company, said, ''It's very quiet compared with Friday.'' And well it might be, since last Friday was the day the J ustice Department and A.T.& T. announced that they had reached the a greement under which the antitrust suit against Bell would be sett led.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rate payable by savings institutions.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: BRIEFS
description: * Athlone Industries announced its purchase of 20,000 shares of its own common stock in a privately negotiated transaction for $562,500.

title: Venezuelan Oil Activity
description: Venezuela produced an average of 2.12 million barrels of oil a day in the week ended last Thursday, down from the previous week's 2.37 million, the Government said today. Average production in 1981 was 2.11 million barrels, up from 1980's 1.84 million.

title: Ex-Nazi Officer Convicted
description: A former SS captain, Gustav Richter, was sentenced today to four years but left the court a free man based on time already served in the Soviet Union. Mr. Richter, a police attache at the German mission in Bucharest in 1942, was found to have induced Rumania to treat Jews according to Nazi racial laws. As a result 1,600 Rumanian Jews were deported from France and most died at Auschwitz. Mr. Richter was a prisoner of war in the Soviet Union and served four years, from 1951 to 1955, as a war criminal.

title: Saudis Put Restrictions On Recognizing Israel
description: Saudi Arabia today ruled out recognition of Israel except with the agreement of all Ara b nations and the Palestinians.

title: Heavy Stock Trading In I.B.M. and A.T.&T.
description: Heavy volume marked trading in the shares of American Telephone and Telegraph Company and the International Business Machines Corporation yesterday. But their performances were below the expectations of many analysts who had predicted healthy advances.

title: Murjani Account W on by Doyle Dane
description: Doyle Dane Bernbach emerged victorious yesterday from a 35-agency competition for the account of Murjani International, maker of Gloria Vanderbilt jeans and sportswear. According to D.D.B., the new client spent more than $10 million on advertising last year.

title: SOUTH POLE DIARY: 'SOMETIMES YOU WANT TO GIVE UP HOPE'
description: Following are excerpts from the diary kept by Andrew Cameron at the South Pole during the winter of 1979: Paranoia

title: Advertising; Guides Set For Copy Testing
description: COPY testing, the fast-growing but still small facet of advertising research, has received a major form of industry recognition. In what has been described as an unprecedented move, 21 research directors from large competing ad agencies have after two years of work established guidelines for copy testing methodology and practices.

title: FIRST CONNECTICUT BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
UNUSUAL AUTO CONTRACT TALKS OPENED
description: Negotiations between the United Automobile Workers and the two major auto companies got under way today, with both sides di scussing conciliation rather than confrontation and expressing ho pe for a new contract in two weeks.

title: Mitsubishi Denies Report on Smelter
description: Mitsubishi Light Metals Industries, responding to a statement by a Philippines Government agency, said it had no intention of setting up an aluminum smelter there.

title: No Headline
description: TEXT OF DECLARATION ON POLAND BY THE FOREIGN MINISTERS OF NATO

title: ASK COMPUTER SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Cunningham Dancers Open Season March 16
description: The Merce Cunningham Dance Company will celebrate Mr. Cunningham's 40th year as a choreographer with a three-week season opening March 16 at the City Center-55th Street Theater.

title: 2 ALABAMA RIGHTS WORKERS ARE JAILED FOR VOTING FRAUD
description: Two of this county's leading civil rights workers, Julia Wilder and Maggie Bozeman, went to jail for vote fraud today after an Alabama circuit court judge rejected lastminute pleas for leniency.

title: Medcom Merger
description: Medcom Inc., a producer of information programs for medical personnel, and Medtrain Inc., a medical-care products concern, announced signing a letter of intent under which Medcom will be merged into a Medtrain subsidiary in a transaction valued at $35 a share. Medtrain, a unit of Baxter Travenol Laboratories Inc., said holders of about 490,000 Medcom shares, or about one-third of the total shares outstanding, had agreed to the acquisition at the stated price.

title: The Cold, Rediscovered
description: There is little good to say about the kind of weather that strands travelers, sneaks frigid air under doors and through window sashes, freezes gas lines, threatens citrus, fastens icicles to a quarterback's beard and even kills - by today, at least 40 people.

title: THE PROTECTION OF PAT EWING
description: Pat Ewing walked into the room on the second floor of Georgetown University's McDonough Arena and hesitated until his coach, John Thompson, directed him to sit in the chair closest to the window.

title: SUBARU OF AMERICA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
AFGHAN ARMS: FROM MISSILES TO RAMSHACKLE RIFLES
description: Mallem Abdul Shukor was, until one morning in October, a very important man in this hilltop headquarters of the major guerrilla organization fighting in Paktia Province on the Pakistan border, and now he said he did not know whether to laugh or cry in frustration.

title: SCM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After a charge of $2.4 milion or 25 cents a shr resulting from the decision to sell or close the company's Louisville, Ky edible oil refinery

title: NATO ALLIES ASSAIL SOVIET ON POLAND AND HINT REPRISAL
description: The Western alliance condemned the Soviet Union today for its active support of ''the systematic suppression'' in Poland and warned that Western Europe might join the United States in imposing economic sanctions against Moscow.

title: Martin Picked For Fed Post
description: President Reagan will nominate Preston Martin, a director of Sears, Roebuck & Company, as vice chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, the White House announced today.

title: Decision File
description: Every day Federal agencies and courts make decisions that affect the lives of Americans. Here are some rece nt cases: A Chardonnay May Not Be

title: TV: 2 PBS SERIES, NATURAL HISTORY AND DRAMA
description: TWO major series have premieres on public television this evening: At 8 o'clock ''Life on Earth,'' a 13-episode production from the BBC; and at 9 ''American Playhouse,'' a weekly drama showcase that is opening with ''The Shady Hill Kidnapping'' by John Cheever.

title: FORECASTS ARE GLUM AS RETAILERS GATHER
description: Speakers at a national retail convention yesterday predicted a gloomy first quarter, with earnings due to fall below those of a year earlier. The analyst s and economists also said that merchants would fare worse in the first half than they did in the 1981 period, which showed unexpe cted strength.

title: From Scotland Yard To Casino Director
description: Peter C. Neivens, a 59-year-old retired officer from London's Metropolitian Police, has been named an executive director of the new company that will run the British gambling casinos sold last week by Playboy Enterprises. In a transaction completed on Friday, Playboy's three London casinos and other gambling interests were purchased by Trident Television Ltd., which named Mr. Neivens to the post.

title: News Analysis
description: The proposed settlement of the Government's antitrust suit against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company lays the groundwork for the future of the telecommunications industry. But it also leaves complex issues unresolved and sets the stage for new and difficult disputes.

title: Grain Elevator Splits; 4 Hurt
description: A grain elevator containing 1.5 million bushels of wheat split open today. The rupture spilled meal and metal on nearby streets, injuring four people in this Mississippi River town 10 miles above New Orleans.

title: STRIFE AND DESPAIR AT SOUTH POLE ILLUMINATE PSYCHOLOGY OF ISOLATION
description: SOUTH POLE STATION, Antarctica THE events of Aug. 17, 1979, will not get into the official history books, but they were something of psychological milestone in the history of the South Pole. Outside, temperatures dipped to 71 degrees below zero in a blinding blizzard, but inside, emotional temperatures among the crew of 16 men and one woman, after nearly half a year of total darkness, were reaching the flash point.

title: WHERE JOBS ARE TO BE FOUND AND WHAT SKILLS ARE SOUGHT
description: Although almost 9.5 million people were unemployed last month, jobs are still available in many areas. What it takes to get them is the needed skill and swift action.

title: Wichita St.  On 3-Year Probation
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association today placed Wichita State's basketball program on probation for three years for what it termed numerous violations over the last six years.

title: AIC PHOTO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Yanks Pick Vernon As Batting Coach
description: Mickey Vernon, whose major league playing career spanned four decades and included two American League batting championships, has been named to succeed Charley Lau as the Yankees' batting coach. Vernon has spent the last three years as the Yankees' hitting instructor in the minor leagues. He will be replaced in that job by Joe Pepitone.

title: McCaffrey to Present Magazine Ad Award
description: James J. McCaffrey, retired co-founder of McCaffrey & McCall and a close personal friend of the late Stephen E. Kelly, who at his death was president of the Magazine Publishers Association, will come down from his Maine retreat on March 2 to present the first award for ''creative excellence in magazine advertising,'' named for Mr. Kelly.

title: ADVANCED MICRO DEVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
JUSTICES TO HEAR APPEAL OF FURLOUGHED NEW YORK POLICE IN BIAS SUIT
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether proof of intentional discrimination was needed to establish violations of two key Federal civil rights laws.

title: SOME IN POLAND WIN ACQUITTAL, BUT NO ONE CHEERS
description: Room 224 of the Warsaw courthouse was packed today with people sitting in the aisles and on the window sills when the defense lawyer began his summation.

title: The City; New Skyscraper Added to Midtown
description: The 44-story Grand Central Tower, a new office building in midtown Manhattan, was completed yesterday, and more than half of the $120 million structure has already been rented, according to the owners.

title: GAF Completes Graphics Unit Sale
description: The GAF Corporation, a producer of building materials, chemicals and other products, said it had completed the sale of its worldwide graphics business to Aarque Office Systems Inc., an affiliate of the Aarque Companies, a holding company, of Jamestown, N.Y.

title: CONNORS SEES TROUBLE IN ROW WITH MCENROE
description: After engaging in another verbal sparring match with John McEnroe, Jimmy Connors said yesterday that he thought it was only a matter of time before fists replaced words between them on the tennis court.

title: Israeli Injured by Bomb
description: A police demolitions expert was injured by a bomb in Petah Tiqva seven miles east of Tel Aviv today.

title: FUTURE OF BELL SYSTEM DEBT
description: ''It's a Bell System issue.'' For many years, that was all the salesmanship needed to find buyers for long-term bonds issued by any of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's 22 operating subsidiaries.

title: BILL SEEKS TO SAFEGUARD CABLE VIEWERS' PRIVACY
description: Attorney General Robert Abrams proposed legislation today to protect the privacy of cable-television subscribers.

title: Around the Nation; Paramilitary Training Reported in California
description: A group of Cubans and Nicaraguans dedicated to the overthrow of their nations' leftist governments is undergoing paramilitary training at a remote desert camp in southern California under close surveillance by the authorities.

title: The City; Hunts Point Fire Injures 9 Firemen
description: Nine firefighters were injured, one of them seriously, as they battled a three-alarm blaze at 925 Bruckner Boulevard in the Hunts Point section of the Bronx, the Fire Department said.

title: Dennis the Menace Stars in U.S. Booklet
description: Dennis the Menace is the star of a new national campaign against child abuse and neglect, a problem estimated to involve a million victims a year, the Government announced today.

title: The Region; Apartment Blaze Kills 3 in Newark
description: NEWARK (AP) - Three clients of a residential mental-health project were killed and four others were injured yesterday in a fire that started when a resident fell asleep while smoking in bed, fire officials said.

title: U.S. TO LET TAIWAN BUY SOME JETS BUT NOT MORE ADVANCED FIGHTERS
description: President Reagan has decided that the Government on Taiwan will be permitted to buy additional F-5E fighter planes but not more advanced aircraft, the State Department announced today.

title: 5 Harness Suspensions Upheld in New Jersey
description: The New Jersey State Racing Commission upheld tonight 30-day suspensions meted out to five drivers for ''carelessness'' in a harness race at Freeh old Raceway last Oct. 31. The suspensio n of a sixth driver, the winner of the race, was reducedfrom 30 to 10 days.

title: Miss Navratilova Wins Final From Ann Smith
description: Martina Navratilova snapped Anne Smith's weeklong string of upsets tonight with a 6-2, 6-3 victory in the final of the $200,000 Avon tennis tournament. Miss Navratilova, seeded second, lost only one set during the tournament.

title: Notes on People; Helicopter Rescues Mark Thatcher
description: Three days after he became stranded in the Sahara in southern Algeria, Mark Thatcher, the 28-year-old son of Margaret Thatcher, the British Prime Minister, was picked up yesterday by a rescue helicopter.

title: Notes on People; City Center Benefactors Are Remembered
description: Alton G. Marshall, chairman of the City Center of Music and Drama, presided over the dedication yesterday at the New York State Theater of plaques honoring two major benefactors of the City Center.

title: Philippines' Strongest Quake In Five Years Causes Injuries
description: The strongest earthquake in the Philippines in more than five years caused some damage and injuries today.

title: Books Grow Sweeter TO SCIENCE TIMES:
description: All lovers of books will be heartened by one major development in the paper manufacturing process that was not covered in your excellent article ''As Acid Devours Many Old Books, Chemists Race to Stop Decay'' (Dec. 1).

title: ROMEO R. BLANCHETTE
description: Bishop Romeo R. Blanchette, under whose direction the seven-county Roman Catholic Diocese of Joliet grew from 90,000 parishioners to more than 400,000, died Sunday at the age of 69.

title: EDUCATION
description: ALL the problems that Arlene Schoen wrote on the blackboard at the start of a mathematics class one day last week at John Bowne High School in Queens involved multiplying or dividing whole numbers and decimals by 100.

title: MALAYSIAN OFFICIAL, REPORTED KILLED, FOUND ALIVE
description: Malaysia's Foreign Minister was found alive in a mountainous jungle today a day after he was reported to have died in the crash of the light plane he was flying.

title: Teledyne Net Gains 14.6%
description: Teledyne Inc. reported yesterday that earnings in the fourth quarter of 1981 increased 14.6 percent, as sales edged up 1.3 percent.

title: 7TH AVE. GIVES NOD TO SUMMER
description: Spring slides almost imperceptibly into summer, marked only by the doffing of a raincoat, the dropping of a sweater. In a month or two, summer clothe s will begin supplementing the spring styles in the stores, the c olors a little brighter, some designs a little more openand freer.

title: Court Upholds Law O n Parental Consent
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit refused yesterday to overturn a New York State law requiring applicants for marriage lice nses to obtain parental consent if they are under the age of 18.

title: PLIGHT OF CITY'S HOMELESS INSPIRES DONATIONS FOR THE NEEDIEST
description: With reminders of the harsh winter weather all around them, many contributors to the The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund have asked that some way be found to use their donations for the homeless ''street poor.''

title: A.M.C. to Start Rebate Program
description: The American Motors Corporation said it would offer rebates of up to $500 to buyers who trade in their old cars for new 1981 or 1982 A.M.C. models.

title: MAYOR, IN A SHIFT, PLANS AN INCREASE OF 2,300 IN POLICE
description: Mayor Koch, who had insisted that New York City could not afford as many police officers as hoped for, reversed himself yesterday and announced he would increase the number of officers in uniform by 2,300, as originally planned for the present fiscal year.

title:
ONE WAY OR ANOTHER, NEW YORKERS FIND A WAY TO COPE WITH THE COLD;
IN BROOKLYN, TOUCH OF CHEER
description: The Fantauz zis have a big pot of water simmering on the stove, but there are sti ll lumps of ice growing on the living room walls. The Binas f amily has the oven on with the door open but Rosalina, who is 2 year s old, and her sister Carmen, 5, are getting sick anyway.

title: The City; Lloyd Enters Plea On Rothko Case
description: Frank Lloyd, the owner of the Marlborough Gallery, pleaded not guilty yesterday to three counts of tampering with evidence in a trial in 1977 over the assets of the late painter Mark Rothko.

title: U.S. IS SAID TO LOSE $650 MILLION OWED IN '81 ROYALTIES
description: The Government failed to receive $650 million in oil and gas royalties it was due last year, according to a special panel of investigators. It said that the loss was due to underreporting by companies operating on Federal lands and the inability of the Interior Department to police its ''honor system'' of collections.

title: ENGRAPH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
GROMYKI RECEIVES HIGH WARSAW AIDE
description: The Polish Foreign Minister held daylong talks today with his Soviet counterpart. Initial reports by the Soviet press agency Tass said the visiting official, Jozef Czyrek, and Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko had discussed Polish-Soviet relations and condemned American ''interference'' in Poland.

title: SCOPES: INFIDEL
description: The Baltimore Evening Sun sent H. L. Mencken to Dayton to cover the case of The State of Tennessee v. John Thomas Scopes, in 1925. Following are excerpts from various dispatches.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Alberto-Culver Co., Melrose Park, Ill., has named Thomas J. Sweeney president of its Phillippe of California Inc. subsidiary.

title: MEREDITH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The 1980 net restated to reflect increase in amortization of magazine subscription list

title: Barrie Bishop Wed to Wynant D. Vanderpool 3d
description: Barrie Osborn Bishop and Wynant Davis Vanderpool 3d were married yesterday at St. James Episcopal Church. Bishop John T. Walker of the Episcopal Diocese of Washington performed the ceremony.

title: TUESDAY, JANUARY 12, 1982; The Economy
description: Some $650 million in oil and gas royalties due the Federal Government last year was held back through underreporting by companies operating on Federal lands, a special panel of investigators has found. It said that up to 6 percent of all crude oil produced in the U.S. is being stolen from oil fields and tank farms. (Page A1.) Americans added just $342 million to their installment debt load inNovember, the smallest increase since the sum mer of 1980, the FederalReserve Board reported. It said that while co nsumers took on $27.5 billion in new debt for the month, they paid off $27.16 billion in outstanding debt, a record liquidation figure . (D1.)

title: REQUEST FOR RISE IN CARTING RATES DRAWS CRITICISM
description: A request by New York City's private carting industry for an increase in rates was assailed yesterday by some of the commercial establishments it serves.

title: Loan for Mexican Bank
description: Banco Nacional de Credito Rural, the stateowned Mexican agricultural bank, has arranged a $400 million eightyear loan with tougher terms than Mexican borrowers had negotiated late last year, bankers said today.

title: RATE OFFICIALS WARY ON PHONE REVENUES
description: State regulatory commissioners, who last year approved more than $3 billion in telephone rate increases, are resigned to the idea of the Bell System's divestiture of its regional phone companies, but the regulators look to Congress for help in offsetting potential losses in local phone revenues.

title: JAMES McLAUGHLIN, PAINTER AND CURATOR OF PHILLIPS GALLERY
description: James M. McLaughlin, chief curator of the Phillips Collection, died at his home in Arlington, Va., Saturday evening. He was 73 years old.

title: MRS. MARCOS ASSAILS ATHLETE AND FAMILY OVER TIE TO DAUGHTER
description: The Philippine athlete who secretly married the daughter of President Ferdinand E. Marcos on Dec. 4 and disappeared on Dec. 29 was denounced by Mrs. Marcos today as an inveigling ''man of the world.''

title: ELECTRO RENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
M-G-M, IN DEBT, HOPES FOR A WINNER
description: The Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer Film Company hopes to produce a blockbuster to wipe out its mounting pile of debt. Frank E. Rosenfelt, M-G-M's chairman, says he is not worried. ''Remember,'' he told a restless audience Saturday at the company's annual meeting here, ''it only takes one big success in this business to significantly change the debt structure.''

title: Around the Nation; Third Earthquake Hits Canada, New England
description: The third earthquake in three days rumbled throug h New England today, shaking fo undations and rattling nerves but bringing no reports of injuries, W eston Observatory scientists said.

title: A SINISTER PLOT AFOOT? NO, A MOVIE BEING SHOT
description: EVERY morning at dawn, the invasion begins. Caravans of yellow Ryder trucks and white Winnebego vans fan out across New York, rolling down sleepy, unsuspecting streets. Once they reach their destinations - sites determined with the utmost of strategic planning - platoons of beefy workmen and mountains of technologically sophisticated equipment are swiftly unloaded and put to work. And so, the city's chosen neighborhoods are secured for another day of movie making.

title: CASINO TELLS OF 60'S PAYOFF TO OFFICIALS
description: Playboy Enterprises acknowledged today that it had made payoffs 20 years ago to New York officials. but contended that the payoffs were extortion rather than bribery. The admissions came during a hearing on Playboy's application for a permanent license to operate a casino in Atlantic City.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: FRENCH FLAVOR

title: CHIEF TO REPAY COSTS CHARGED TO DRUG CENTER
description: The director of Odyssey House, the drug-rehabilitation agency, has agreed to repay $20,000 in ''excessive'' and ''unjustified'' personal expenses she charged to the agency, according to Robert Abrams, the State Attorney General.

title: Peking Criticizes U.S.  For 'Obstinate Stand'
description: The official New China News Agency today asserted that the Reagan Administration's ''obstinate stand'' on the Taiwan arms issue was responsible for the strain in relations between Peking and Washington.

title: MAYOR EXPECTED TO REJECT SWAP WITH TUDOR CITY
description: Mayor Koch is expected to reject the proposed Tudor City land exchange this week as a bad financial arrangement, according to a number of his advisers.

title: Phillips Petroleum Elects President
description: C.J. Silas, 49 years old, has been elected president and chief operating officer of the Phillips Petroleum Company, based in Bartlesville, Okla. As president, he succeeds William C. Douce, 62, who will become chairman and continue as chief executive officer. The management changes, effective April 1, will follow the retirement of William F. Martin, the chairman since 1974, at the age of 65.

title: BYRNE, IN A VALEDICTORY, SEEKS AGENCY REVIEWS
description: Governor Byrne, in his final State of the State Message, will urge a re-examination of the roles and spending policies of public authorities , including the Port Authority.

title: Disease Attacks Poultry Workers
description: An illness carried by turkeys infec ted about27 poultry plant workers in Ohio last July, c ausing aches, chills andcoughs, the Centers for Disease Control have reported.

title: Q&A
description: Q. How often does a full moon occur precisely on one's birthday?

title: HARVESTER TO MAKE $200 MILLION IN CUTS
description: The International Harvester Company said today that it would reduce its operating costs by $200 million in 1982 and raise another $100 million through the sale of additional assets. The struggling equipment manufacturer said that the actions would return the company to profitability despite declining demand for trucks and farm machinery.

title: TELEDYNE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Big Rise Seen In '81 Cotton
description: The 1981 cotton crop is expected to exceed 15.7 million bales, 41 percent larger than the drought-reduced 1980 harvest, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: A Settlement for Stuffed Prisons
description: An agreement between the New York state and city corrections departments ends a bitter feud over so-called ''state readies'' - the inmates who are sentenced to state prison but remain in city jails. But the dispute was a compelling reminder that, temporary relief notwithstanding, prison crowding grows worse each day. The need for a more basic remedy persists.

title: UNITED STATIONERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
FOODARAMA SUPERMARKETS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
ABOUT EDUCATION
description: ''THERE'S something badly wrong about the way science is being taught today,'' said Lewis Thomas, the microbiologist who is chancellor of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center.

title: WILL THE NEXT 20 YEARS BRING PROSPERITY OR DECLINE?
description: IS life on the earth getting better and better, with the promise of ample supplies of food, energy, income and health care for all? Or is the world headed for an ecological and social disaster, overcrowded, choked on pollution and running out of natural resources?

title: WALLACE TAPED IN ETHNIC REMARK
description: Mike Wallace, the correspondent for CBS News' ''60 Minutes'' who is best known for pointing a candid camera at the targets of his investigations, has himself been caught by a candid camera.

title: ARCTIC COLD SPREADS SOUTH, BRINGING MORE DEATHS
description: An invasion of arctic weather that has killed at least 65 people spread further yesterday, sending temperatures to record lows across the South.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Republic Steel C uts Some Prices
description: The Republic Steel Corporation, the fifth-largest United States steelmaker, said that it had reduced prices on hot-rolled and cold-finished carbon and alloy bar products.

title: Around the Nation; Von Bulow Denies Guilt In Wife's Illness
description: Claus von Bulow stood before 101 potential jurors today and pleaded not guilty to charges of trying to kill his wife with insulin injections.

title: RATE FEARS SEND DOW DOWN 16.07
description: Stock prices plunged yesterday in heavy trading, with most of the interest centered on American Telephone and Telegraph and I.B.M. because of the disposition of their antitrust cases with the Justice Department last Friday. Analysts attributed the decline to fears of higher interest rates.

title: VALLEY RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Suit on Yacht Handicap Is Dismissed by Judge
description: A Federal judge today dismissed Seymore Sinett's suit for damages against the United States Yacht Racing Union. In the suit, filed last October, Sinett contended that, in penalizing him for owning a boat with an inaccurate handicap rating, the union had caused him humiliation, embarrassment and ridicule through its mistakes.

title: RANGERS' RALLY BEATS STARS, 5-3
description: The Rangers are still not winners, in a larger sense, since they have not won the Stanley Cup since 1940 nor had a winning record since 1980.

title: BITING COLD DELAYS TRAVEL IN NEW YORK AREA
description: Numbing cold, made more frigid by winds that gusted to 34 miles an hour, froze subway equipment in New York City yesterday, causing delays in the morning rush that were described as ''horrendous.'' Commuter rail lines into the city also reported many delays, and record numbers of motorists were stranded.

title: No Headline
description: NAVY'S ANGUISH OVER PUEBLO CASE DESCRIBED IN A LONG-SECRET REPORT

title: FIRST BANKERS CORP OF FLORIDA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Mexico Silver Output
description: Mexico expe cts to increase its silver production to 70 million ounces a year by the end of 1983 fromthe current 50 million ounces, according to t he National Resources and Industrial Development Ministry. A minist ry announcement released last week said much of the increase would come from the Realde Los Angeles mine capable of producing abou t seven million ounces ayear when it becomes fully operational later this year. The announcement said the expansion would proceed despite the current lowworld price for silver.

title: Sports People; From Minor to Major
description: Don Perry was not initially sold on the idea of moving up from minor league to major league coaching, but after talking last night with George Maguire, the Los Angeles general manager, Perry accepted the job as the Kings' head coach. Perry, the coach of the Kings' minor league team in New Haven, earlier had hesitated to accept the offer to replace the dismissed Parker McDonald, saying: ''I have never made that much money in coaching and now I'm 51.

title: CHAMPION HOME BUILDERS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 27
description: B-Includes tax credits of $180,000 for the qr and $2.9 million for the 9 mos

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Realism would dictate that you won't make many advances in 1982.'' - Douglas A. Fraser, president, United Automobile Workers. (A12:4.)

title: Supreme Court Roundup; 40-YEAR DRUG TERM HELD 'LEGISLATIVE PREROGATIVE
description: The Supreme Court, declaring that the duration of prison sentences for felonies was ''purely a matter of legislative prerogative,'' today upheld the constitutionality of a 40-year prison sentence imposed on a Virginia man for possession and distribution of nine ounces of marijuana worth about $200.

title: ISRAELIS TO PRESS U.S. ON SHCHARANSKY
description: A Foreign Ministry official said today that the case of Anatoly B. Shcharansky, the imprisoned Soviet Jewish dissident, would be discussed this week when Prime Minister Menachem Begin meets Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. in Jerusalem.

title: THE ORIGINS OF BACKACHE: STUDIES BEGIN TO EXPLAIN THE CRIPPLING PAIN OF MILLIONS
description: Preventive and remedial approaches to back pain will be the focus of the Personal Health column in tomorrow's Living Section. By JANE E. BRODY

title: British Field's Reserves
description: The British Gas Corporation has doubled to 200 million barrels its estimate of proven reserves at the Wytch Farm oilfield in Dorset, southern England, a company spokesman said today. The Government has told British Gas to sell its 50 percent stake in the Wytch Farm oil license and the spokesman said that the sale could take place in four or five months. Analysts have speculated that the sale could raise nearly $800 million.

title: Sports People; Coach's Nose Broken
description: Wallace Robinson, the 6-foot-8-inch center who led the St. Louis University basketball team in rebounds, was dismissed from the team on Jan. 2 because of a fight in which he broke the nose and blackened the eyes of his coach, Ron Ekker, according to a published report. The fight, the report said, occurred in Ekker's hotel room in Indianapolis after Robinson and another player had missed the bus for a game at Butler, which the Billikens won.

title: APPLIED POWER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Notes on People; A New Citizen Marks 100th Birthday
description: A follow-up: Last July 22, Gabriel Isahar Isaharov, a 99-year-old immigrant from the Soviet Union who had been in this country only three years, was granted citizenship by a Federal judge even though Mr. Isaharov was unable to speak or write English.

title: CALIFORNI
description: Thirty-eight of California's 58 counties filed suit against the state today, charging that it had unconstitutionally refused to pay the cost of enforcing new laws.

title: 7 U.S. STEEL COMPANIES FILE FOR IMPORT RELIEF
description: Nearly 1,000 bo xes of legal documents were unloaded from trucks today at two Government agencies as seven steel companies filed for relief from low-priced im ports from 11 countries.It is the most sweeping cases for protection ever made by any domestic industry.

title: SUN BANKS OF FLORIDA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
REAGAN WEIGHS NEW TAX-RISE PLAN
description: The Reagan Administration is studying a proposal that would increase taxes and pass on the additional revenue to the states to offset reductions in Federal programs, such as those dealing with welfare, highways and education, top Administration officials said today.

title: U.S., Japan In Air Talks
description: Japanese and American rep resentatives today resumed discu ssing the thorny problem of airline rights. The negotiators a re ''far apart on basic issues,'' sources close to the talks said.

title: Ferronickel Mine Halting Output
description: Falconbridge Nickel Mines said it would temporarily shut down its ferronickel operations in the Dominican Republic in mid-January.

title: PRICES FALL IN CREDIT MARKETS
description: Bond prices plunged and yields of short-term debt issues rose sharply yesterday on fears that the nation's basic money supply might expand to the point at which the Federal Reserve would be forced to tighten credit.

title: Out of Work Third article of a series on the nation's unemployment problem.
description: The woman, a New Yorker in her late 20's, had degrees from two outstanding American universities. She was a specialist in advanced television technologies. She worked for Warner Communications Inc., the large, New York-based entertainment and recreation company that is the epitome of the modern, successful American business enterprise specializing in the newest kinds of technologies.

title: Sports People; Shaky at the Top
description: Merrily Dean Baker of Princeton assumed her duties as president of the Association for Intercollegiate Athletics for Women last weekend but she may be presiding over the disbanding of the 20-year-old organization.

title: Around the Nation; Plane Drops 20,000 Feet After Losing Pressure
description: A Capitol Air DC-10 with 215 passengers aboard lost cabin pressure and fell 20,000 feet over Nebraska today before making a safe landing at Stapleton International Airport in Denver.

title: IN HARLEM, STOVE'S WARMTH
description: Martha Tinoye says she has learned to cope with the cold. She said yesterday that, except for about an hour on Dec. 31, there had been no heat in the radiators of her third-floor Harlem apartment for three years.

title: Around the World; Wales Still Snowbound; Continent Buffeted Too
description: Wales was still virtually cut off from the rest of Britain by snow today in the worst winter weather for almost 20 years.

title: Landry's Strategy Pondered
description: ''We never really established a passing attack.'' So said Danny White, the Dallas Cowboys' quarterback, after his team lost the National Football Conference championship by a point to the San Francisco 49ers Sunday. And today his words were still bringing forth some questions:

title: ANKARA TAKES EMERGENCY STEPS AS POLLUTION REACHES 'DANGER LEVEL'
description: The authorities took emergency measures today as air pollution in Ankara reached ''the danger level.'' The Governor of Ankara, Mustafa Gonul, announced that primary and secondary schools would be closed until Thursday, central heating and coal stoves would be banned for the next 24 hours and the use of private cars would be limited to odd or even days based on license numbers. He said children and the elderly should stay home, and he advised people who did go outside to walk slowly and cover their mouths and noses.

title: JAN SCHILT, 87, FORMER HEAD OF ASTRONOMY AT COLUMBIA
description: Dr. Jan Schilt, chairman of the department of astronomy at Columbia University from 1936 until his retirement in 1962 and a pioneer in stellar statistics, died Saturday at Englewood Hospital in New Jersey. He was 87 years old and lived in Quonochontaug, R.I., and Leonia, N.J.

title: LOSS TO 49ERS HAUNTS BENGALS
description: This was a golden moment in Forrest Gregg's life, a day he wanted to savor. So he enjoyed talking about the cold weather and his Cincinnati Bengals, who are headed for the Super Bowl as American Conference champions.

title: Ecuador Oil Output Up
description: Ecuador's oil production in 1981 totaled 76.8 million barrels, up 27.1 percent from the year before, the state oil company, Cepe, said today.

title: Kaiser Closing 2 More Potlines
description: The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation said it would shut down another two aluminum potlines because of continued slow demand.

title: The Region; Mrs. Harris Given Appeal Permission
description: Jean S. Harris was granted permission to appeal her conviction of the murder of Dr. Herman Tarnower to the state's highest court, the Court of Appeals. Mrs. Harris's initial bid for a new trial was rejected two weeks ago by the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court.

title: REVIEW IS REFUSED OF CABLE TV RULING
description: The Supreme Court, without comment, refused yesterday to review a ruling of the Federal Communications Commission that has allowed cable television systems to broadcast several professional football games to a given city each Sunday. The National Football League has expressed fears that the F.C.C. ruling could lead to the televising of as many as a dozen games into one market every weekend.

title: Bridge: Some Imaginative Settings For Games in a New Book
description: Few bridge books have offered deals of high quality in an imaginative and original setting. One that did was ''Right Through the Pack,'' a classic by Robert Darvas and Norman de Vere Hart, published in 1947. Another is ''The Bridge Adventures of Androcles MacThick,'' published here recently by the author, Dr. Ernst Theimer of Rumson, N.J. ''MacThick'' has 247 pages, is pleasantly illustrated, and is obtainable from Bridge World, 39 West 94th Street, New York, N.Y. 10025, for $9.

title: TO NEW YORK STATE, NO ONE IS 'EXPENDABLE'
description: To the Editor:

title: Around the Nation; Court Rules J.P. Stevens Used Unfair Tactics
description: A Federal appeals court said today that J.P. Stevens and Company had engaged in unfair labor practices in trying to prevent unionization of its plants in Wallace, N.C.

title: MELLON NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
COUNCIL NAMED TO RULE GHANA
description: Former Flight Lieut. Jerry Rawlings has named a seven-man council, including a leftist Roman Catholic priest and a radical student leader, to exercise central Government authority in Ghana.

title: FIRST UNITED BANCORPORATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PAYMENTS REPORTED BY POLAND
description: Poland says it has paid about $200 million of the $500 million in overdue interest it owes Western banks, a West German bank reported today.

title: Real Estate; Upper-End R esidential Developer
description: AT one time or another, Charles Shaw has been an active bui lder in 13 cities. In no one place is he the biggest developer, or the most notable. But he is a major figure in commerci al real estate development, and he has several substantial p rojects in his portfolio, including the Museum Tower, the lu xury condominiums being built on top of the new wing of the Museum of Modern Art on West 53d Street. The Museum Tower is a joint venture w ith the Leon D. DeMatteis Construction Corporation.

title: SANCHEZ ACCEPTS AWARD WITH GUSTO
description: Salvador Sanchez, the World Boxing Council featherweight champion from Mexico, came to the luncheon wearing a bouquet of curly hair and a long scarf, black leather gloves and two winter coats - a woolen one over a leather one. The dark shaggy top was nature's protection against the elements, and the rest was Sanchez's attempt to keep warm in New York's stiffening cold.

title: HAIG SAYS POLAND IS A TESAT OF ALLIES
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. said today that the Polish crisis had produced ''a test case'' challenging the credibility of the West's previous warnings to the Soviet Union not to intervene in Poland's affairs.

title: BATTLE OVER THE 'BOTTLE BILL' BEGINS AGAIN IN ALBANY
description: Will legislators uneasy over a nickel deposit on bottles and cans in New York State ''get off the hook'' this year, as Victor F. Condello, an industry-labor lobbyist, expects, or will ''grass roots'' win the day, as Judy Enk, an environmental lobbyist, hopes?

title: PRESIDENT SHIFTS VIEW ON TAX RULE IN RACE BIAS CASES
description: President Reagan, in an abrupt policy change prompted by his advisers' warnings that he was being viewed as racist, called today for legislation to outlaw tax exemptions for organizations that discriminate racially.

title: BEGIN'S COMING TEST
description: In coming months, Prime Minister Menachem Begin will face the greatest test of his political career - one greater than the challenge posed by Anwar el-Sadat's visit to Jerusalem and by the agonizing days at Camp David when the peace treaty with Egypt was being drafted. He is confronted by a challenge from the ranks of longtime su pporters who broke with him over the treaty and who oppose the ev acuation of the Israeli settlements in the Sinai by April 25, when th e final strip of land is to be returned to Egypt. These dissidents,wh o openly threaten civil disobedience and violence, admit that theirai m is to subvert the last withdrawal by provoking the Government in to abrogating the Camp David agreement.

title: MOVIE STAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 28
2 Plead Guilty I n Attack on Nun
description: Two men pleaded guilty to the Oct. 10 attack on a nun in an East Harlem convent. In the attack, the police reported, 27 crosses were cut into the nun's body.

title: Best Buys; CITRUS STILL REASONABLE
description: THE current freeze in Florida may lead soon to a rise in prices of citrus fruits, but the extent of the damage is still unclear, according to the United States Department of Agriculture.

title: FOR TODAY'S KITCHEN: 50 ESSENTIALS
description: WHAT equipment is needed in setting up a basic modern kitchen? What dishes - and what techniques - are appropriate for the neophyte cook? Pierre Franey and I recently worked out a series of recipes for ambitious beginners, and in doing so compiled a list of utensils that we consider essential to those who want to cook wisely and well.

title: NEEDIEST CASES FUND AIDED BY DONATIONS OF NEW CONTRIBUTORS
description: For a variety of reasons - a twinge of conscience, an end to procrastination, a new job, a stroke of luck - many contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund are giving for the first time.

title: Perry Loses in Debut As Coach of Kings, 2-1
description: Mario Tremblay fired in a 30-foot slap shot at 1 minute 57 seconds of the final period tonight to lift the Montreal Canadiens to a 2-1 triumph over Los Angeles in the National Hockey League debut of the King's new head coach, Don Perry.

title: NEWTON MILLHAM
description: Newton Millham, a New York lawyer, died Sunday at Glen Cove (L.I.) Hospital. He was 73 years years old and lived in Locust Valley, L.I. He was senior partner of Remsen, Millham & Curran and remained with the firm as consulting attorney after his retirement in 1977.

title: FARAH MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Includes tax credits of $1,759,000 for the qr and $4,734,000 for the yr...C-Includes tax credits of $972,000 for the qr and $1,610,000 for the yr

title: NEVADA POWER CO reports earnings for Yr to Nov 30
DEMOCRATIC LEADERSHIP SEEKS ROLE IN REAGAN'S FORTHCOMING BUDGET
description: Representative Jim Wright, the House majority leader, called upon President Reagan today to invite Democratic Congressional leaders to help formulate his budget proposal for the fiscal year 1983, which begins Oct. 1.

title: BANK OF NEW YORK CHAIRMAN
description: Elliott Averett, chairman and chief executive officer of the Bank of New York Company, died yesterday at his home in New Vernon, N.J., after a brief illness. He was 64 years old.

title: MONTCLAIR ACTS TO BLOCK CLINIC FOR METHADONE
