description: A threat to the common weal here is usually met by an able and aggressive corps of citizen defenders. They form committees, pressure officials, circulate petitions and in general do whatever it takes to preserve the character of their community.

title: LYNDE HAD HEART ATTACK
description: A senior coroner's investigator, John Decker, said today that the preliminary results of an autopsy showed that the actor Paul Lynde had died of "a massive heart attack and as a result of natural causes" The actor, who was 55 years old, was found dead in his home here Sunday by friends.

title: BROADBENT ENDS HEUBLEIN TIES
description: Michael Broadbent, the most prominent wine auctioneer in the United States and Britain, has severed his ties with Heublein Inc. after 13 years and will not conduct the annual Heublein wine auction this year. The decision was announced by Christie's, the international auction house, of which Mr. Broadbent is wine director.

title: INVESTIGATOR CALLED STOUFFER'S INN FIRE ACCIDENTAL
description: A fire investigator for the state has termed ''accidental'' the 1980 fire that killed 26 people at Stouffer's Inn in Harrison, N.Y., and has said in court papers that an assistant district attorney told him not to write reports about it.

title: Philippine Raiders Slay 2
description: Communist rebels raided three southern Philippine villages on Monday, killed a woman and a boy and took two women hostage, military reports said today.

title: Razing to Begin For Portman Hotel
description: Legal barriers have been cleared to permit the demolition of all buildings, except for two theaters, on the site of the planned Portman Hotel on the west side of Broadway from 45th to 46th Street.

title: United Airlines Ordered To Rehire Stewardesses
description: A Federal district judge today ordered United Airlines to rehire 1,400 stewardesses who were forced to quit because they had married.

title: Advertising; Ruth Gordon To Sell Subarus
description: Subaru of America, the marketer of the Japanese automobile, has enlisted the whimsy of Ruth Gordon, the actress, in hopes of making the latest television commercial entry for its Brat model stand out from the pack. And since it will make its debut during the Super Bowl game coverage on Jan.24 before an audience of 100 million watching CBS-TV, it will need all the help it can get.

title: NATIONAL SECURITY TEXT
description: Following is the text of a statement by President Reagan on protection of classified National Security Council and intelligence information:

title: N.A.A.C.P. SEEKS KOCH'S AID IN BID TO STAY IN CITY
description: New York City and the N.A.A.C.P. will explore whether the city can help the association keep its headquarters in town. The executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People is scheduled to meet with Mayor Koch today to discuss the issue.

title: Yale Art Student Falls To Death on Campus
description: A Yale student fell to her death from the Arts and Architecture Building yesterday in what the police said was either an accident or suicide.

title: Careers; Luring Youth Into Energy
description: SOME 900 students from New York area high schools gathered last week for a day devoted to energy careers. The program was sponsored by the National Energy Foundation, whose members range from corporate giants like International Business Machines and the United States Steel Corporation to utilities like Brooklyn Union Gas and builders of power plants like Ebasco Services.

title: MACCHIAROLA FINDS JOB AS PRINCIPAL A REVELATION
description: One day recently, the acting principal of Jamaica High School in Queens got a letter from the Board of Education's testing division asking that he let his students participate in a pilot examination to help construct a new test.

title: REAGAN STATEMENT ON PRIVATE SCHOOLS
description: Following is the text of a statement today by President Reagan on the issue of tax exemptions for racially segregated private schools:

title: 3 Goals in 12 Seconds
description: Steve D'Innocenzo scored five goals in a hockey game, but that was not the most remarkable feat that he accomplished.

title: New N.Y.U. Chair To Honor Sadat
description: An Anwar el-Sadat chair in diplomacy will be established at New York University, its president, Dr. John Brademas, announced in Jerusalem. The chair will be occupied by scholars who will teach in this country and in Egypt and Israel.

title: Advertising; A Different Mission For M.L.A.
description: MARTIN H. LANDEY, 52 years old, resigned as deputy chairman of Geers, Gross, last week and this week opened Martin Landey Associates.

title: MOTORISTS FIND NOVEL WAYS TO START CARS IN BITTER COLD
description: New York-area motorists are engaged in a battle to keep their cars on the road during this bitter cold snap, and they are using all sorts of unusual products, practices and homemade remedies.

title: Required Reading; Judiciary Threatened
description: Lawrence Gene Sager, professor of law, New York University, in exerpts from ''Constitutional Limitations on Congress' Authority to Regulate the Jurisdiction of the Federal Courts,'' in the Harvard Law Review:

title: FREEZING SNOWSTORMS CHARGING ACROSS SOUTH
description: As the arctic temperatures that gripped the Middle West, the East and the South abated somewhat yesterday, snow and ice storms struck the Texas Gulf region moving rapidly into Alabama and Georgia and forcing the closing of schools, factories and businesses. Meanwhile city officials in the North were tallying up the costs of the record cold weather on their municipal budgets.

title: Judge Declines to Enter Plea in Bribery Plot Trial
description: Federal District Judge Alcee L. Hastings declined today to enter a plea at his arraignment in Federal District Court on an indictment charging him with bribery conspiracy and obstruction of justice.

title: Fiat Credit Venture
description: Fiat, the Italian car maker, said it would pull out of its jointventure credit company in the United States, the Illinois-based Fiat Credit Corporation, which finances sales of Fiat vehicles. Fiat said it would sell its 50 percent interest in the subsidiary to its partner, West Germany's Deutsche Bank, because of potential conflicts with the Federal Reserve Board over joint ventures between banking and industrial concern s. The unit has a loan portfolio of about $200 million, the auto maker said.

title: FEAR OF FOSSILS
description: S cientists examining ancient fossil evidence discovered recently that prehistoric man ate a well-balanced diet with plenty of vegetables. By one of those coincidences in which the daily news abounds, this report appeared simultaneously with news of an avocado glut in California. To reduce the surplus, some growers want to market avocados as pet food - dogs seem to be crazy about avocados - but other growers say that selling their crop as pet food would be disastrous for the avocado's image.

title: BATON IS PASSED IN TRENTON AMID CONFUSION AND ANGER
description: The 199th New Jersey Legislature gave way to the 200th today, and the transition was anything but smooth. The day began with the old Legislature continuing its Monday night session - it recessed last night for dinner ''and breakfast'' to keep the Monday session clock running into Tuesday - and progressed through a number of unusual developments, including these:

title: The Pop Life; 3 BANDS FIND NEW IN THE PAST
description: NEW YORK CITY'S artists tend to think of themselves as progressives or avant-gardists, creating works and trends that the rest of the country will learn to appreciate eventually but not right away. And the city's most celebrated rock bands, from the Velvet Underground in the mid-60's to the Talking Heads in the late 70's, have been an equall y adventurous lot.

title: Beatrice Must Sell Part of Fiberite
description: The Justice Department announced that it had reached a settlement to end an antitrust suit filed by the Carter Administration to block the merger of the Beatrice Foods Company and the Fiberite Corporation.

title: STATE NATIONAL BANCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Win e Talk
description: IN the Veneto region of northern Italy not far from the city of Verona, one of the world's most extraordinary wines is made, a red wine of great character and intensity called Recioto della Valpolicella Amarone, or often simply Amarone.

title: CANADA REORGANIZES ITS GOVERNMENT
description: With Canada in one of its worst recessions in 30 years, Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau reorganized his Government today in an attempt to step up exports and to take greater account of regional economic disparities.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Can Co. said it would make a cash tender offer at $33.50 a share for up to 2 million of its common shares outstanding.

title: BANK OF COMMERCE (NYC) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NEW SAFETY FOR REAGAN COPTER
description: District of Columbia fire officials moved today to upgrade the quality of protection offered while President Reagan's helicopter is in operation at the White House.

title: FINANCIAL BRIEFS
description: * Arizona Public Service Co. filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission to offer $100 million of 30-year first-mortgage bonds on Jan. 20, to be sold through a First Boston Corp. group.

title: THE SECRET OF THE SAUCE
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Robert Farrar Capon, an Episcopal priest and food writer, is the author of ''Supper of the Lamb'' (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich). By ROBERT FARRAR CAPON

title: Colorado Fines 3 Aides For Altering Expenses
description: The University of Colorado has imposed fines and other disciplinary action on three assistant football coaches for improper reporting of athletic department expenses.

title: FORD JOINING IN SALES PROMOTIONS
description: The Ford Motor Company followed three of its American competitors yesterday in offering new promotional incentives to reluctant car buyers. With the Ford announcement, Volkswagen of America became the only United States car maker without a current incentive program.

title: Books of the Times; Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt BAD DREAMS. By Anthony Haden-Guest. 420 pages. Macmillan. $14.95.

title: Advertising; Health-Chem Picks Smith/Greenland
description: The troops at Smith/Greenland have entered the unending war against the Japanese beetle and the gypsy moth.

title: 90 in House Urge President To Press Rights Issue Review
description: Ninety members of the House have asked President Reagan to seek an expedited Supreme Court review of a Federal district judge's decision striking down an extended ratification deadline for the proposed Federal equal rights amendment, the Congresswomen's Caucus announced Monday.

title: Business People; FOTOMAT'S BOARD NAMES REPLACEMENT IN TOP JOB
description: Ross E. Roeder, 43, has been named chairman and chief executive officer of the Fotomat Corporation, a photographic processing company with 3,700 stores and 10 photofinishing plants. The company announced from its Wilton, Conn., headquarters that Mr. Roeder was elected at a board meeting last Saturday to succeed Richard D. Irwin, 47, who resigned.

title: POOR IMAGE GRATES McENROE
description: Deep inside, buried beneath the countless scowls, groans and grimaces, John McEnroe hurts. He wants to let go, to loosen up and tell the world how he really feels, but he seems to sense that now is not the time.

title: U.S. Panel Reports On Harbor Crash
description: WASHINGTON (UPI) - Excessive speed and human error were to blame for a collision between a freighter and a Staten Island ferryboat carrying 2,400 people across fog-shrouded New York harbor, the National Transportation Safety Board said. The collision occurred May 6, 1981, when the Hoegh Orchid, a 600-foot Norwegian cargo vessel, collided with the American Legion.

title: BUSH URGES G.O.P. TO CITE THE ECONOMY IN COURTING VOTERS
description: Republicans should go to the voters this fall telling them of progress on the economy and credibility in foreign policy and criticizing the Democrats' lack of ''any reasonable, prudent alternatives,'' Vice President Bush said today.

title: BRANDT WARNS FRENCH POLITICIANS
description: Former Chancellor Willy Brandt was bitterly critical today of the French response to the Bonn Government's attitude toward the Polish crackdown.

title: TV: LUCIE ARNAZ APPEARS AS 'WASHINGTON MISTRESS'
description: IT takes the heroine of ''Washington Mistress'' an astonishing five years and two pregnancies to realize that her situation may be less than ideal. Maggie Parker (Lucie Arnaz), a perky young career girl, has become a kind of second wife to Michael, a dashing lawyer and lobbyist (Richard Jordan), who already has a first one.

title: Eckerd Halts Methaqualone
description: The Eckerd Drug Company, the nation's largest dispenser of prescriptions, announced that it would no longer sell methaqualone, a nervous system depressant, in its 1,209 pharmacies in 15 states.

title: Metropolitan Diary; ON THE ART OF DISCOVERY
description: 'Tis great to find the seren, true; But one must have the dipity, too.

title: Air Force Plane Order
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation said today that it had received a $196 million order from the Air Force for four KC-10A advanced tanker-cargo aircraft. It said the aircraft, which became operational in November 1981, can serve as either a refueling tanker or cargo carrier. The latest order raises to 16 the number of KC-10 aircraft purchased by the Air Force, the company said.

title: The U.N. Today; Jan. 13, 1982; SECURITY COUNCIL
description: Meets on the annexation of the Golan Heights at 3:30 P.M. GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: CONCERT: NEW WORLD QUARTET
description: IF there is anything wrong about New York's musical life, it is certainly not in the number of concerts being offered; on any given evening or any weekend afternoon, there may be as many as a dozen musical events of various sizes and shapes for the perusal of the curious. Yet the Merkin Concert Hall has taken a cue from its Broadway counterparts and has begun a weekday matinee series, adding, one might think, unnecessarily to our musical riches.

title: Business People; COTTON PETROLEUM PICKS CHIEF EXECUTIVE OFFICER
description: A. Ralph Reed, a 44-year-old oilman, has been named president and chief executive officer of the Cotton Petroleum Corporation, an independent oil and gas company based in Tulsa, Okla. He succeeds John G. Nikkel, 47, who resigned to establish his own energy exploration venture, Nike Exploration Inc. Cotton Petr oleum, with production now at the rate of 14,000 barrelsa day, was fo unded in 1966 and was sold to United Energy Resources Inc. 10 years later. Doyle W. Cotton Jr., the 50-year-old founder, remains its c hairman.

title: Royal Bank Deal
description: The Royal Bank of Canada said it had completed the previously announced acquisition of the Canadian Acceptance Corporation from the RCA Corporation and that it paid $127 million in securities and cash for the unit.

title: WACHOVIA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Air Jamaica Airbuses
description: Airbus Industrie, the European consortium that makes the A300 Airbus, said today that Air Jamaica had ordered two of the wide-body aircraft. The value of the deal was not disclosed. The planes, to be used on flights from Jamaica to Miami and New York, will have General Electric CF6-50C2 jet engines.

title: RATINGS PUT TWO COLTS IN DEAD HEAT
description: Timely Writer finished eight lengths ahead of Deputy Minister in the Champagne Stakes and far behind him in the Eclipse Award voting for the 2-year-old championship. But according to The Jockey Club's Experimental Free Handicap, there's not a nose of difference between them.

title: ON THE HILL, ADJOURNMENT OFFERS ITS OWN REWARDS
description: House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. sat in shirtsleeves behind a desk laden with Christmas cards and wrote responses in the margins to pass onto his secretary. His waiting room was empty, as were the corridor outside his office, the Rotunda, the House chamber and the entire Capitol.

title: CITRUS IS DAMAGED
description: Extreme cold continued to envelop the New York metropolitan area and much of the rest of the country yesterday. Across the nation, at least 100 fatalities have been attributed to the weather since Saturday.

title: PEKING PROTESTS SALE OF U.S. PLANES TO TAIWAN
description: The Chinese Government registered a strong protest today against President Reagan's decision to sell the Nationalist regime on Taiwan more F-5E fighters.

title: A JUDICIOUS DILIGENCE
description: When Judge Harold Herman Greene turned 57 two years ago in February, his law clerks gave him a cake. Inscribed on the dessert was one of Judge Greene's most frequently repeated expressions:

title: Citrus Crop Damage Is Substantial
description: Record-low temperatures severely damaged Florida's citrus crop today, raising the prospect that consumers will have to pay higher prices for orange juice. The state's winter vegetable crop was also hit hard.

title: UNION COMMERCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
AT THE MERCY OF OUR LAW ENFORCERS
description: To the Editor:

title: Q & A
description: Q. I am Southern born and recently dined over the holidays on the best sweet potatoes or yams I have ever eaten. They were so sweet I said that they must be yams. An argument ensued with half the family saying that yams and sweet potatoes are one and the same. Is this true?

title: Earnings;
description: AM International Inc., formerly the Addressograph-Multigraph Corporation, reported yesterday that it lost $19.3 million in the first fiscal quarter of 1982 ended Oct. 31 compared with a loss of $6.3 million in the similar 1981 quarter.

title: CAMBEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 28
description: B-Includes $74,000 tax credit...C-Includes $13,000 tax credit

title: Watt Raises Obstacle On Vietnam Memorial
description: Interior Secretary James G. Watt has raised a barrier to building a monument to America's Vietnam veterans after some Republicans complained that the memorial's design ''makes a statement of shame and dishonor.''

title: New Assignment for Dismissed General
description: Three months after he was dismissed from the staff of the National Security Council, Maj. Gen. Robert L. Schweitzer is getting a new assignment. He will become a special assistant to the Army's deputy chief of staff for operations and plans.

title: NARDA MICROWAVE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Pope Meets at Vatican W ith a Polish Official
description: Pope John Paul II met privately today with Kazimierz Szablewski, a Polish Government official who handles liaison with the Vatican.

title: N.C.A.A. TIGHTENS GRIP ON TV FOOTBALL
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association, which has been struggling with some of its strongest football colleges over the right to control football television contracts and policies, won a major concession today. N.C.A.A. members voted overwhelmingly to give the association the controls it wanted over all forms of football television during the regular season.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rate payable by savings institutions.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: COLLEGES TO REASSESS BACHELOR DEGREE
description: Proclaiming that undergraduate education in the nation had become fragmented and overspecialized and had lost its sense of civic purpose, the Association of American Colleges today announced a three-year program to reassess the bachelor's degree.

title: CENTRAL PENN NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Business Digest; WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 13, 1982; Companies
description: The agreement in the A.T.& T. antitrust case was called a ''good settlement'' by Federal Judge Harold H. Greene, who has been presiding over the yearlong trial of the suit brought by the Justice Department. However, the judge refused the request of both parties that he dismiss the case immediately. Instead he insisted on examining the merits of the divestiture agreement first. (Page A1.)

title: Advertising; CBS Sells Magazine
description: CBS Publications has sold its Pickup, Van and 4WD magazine with 230,000 circulation, to Petersen Publishing, which already has 4 Wheel & Off Road magazine, with 200,000. A Petersen spokesman said that the plan was to continue the two publications, with the newly acquired one concentrating on on-street trucks and the old one on off-road vehicles. The acquisition brings to 14 the number of specialty monthly magazines Petersen publishes.

title: POLAND SAYS IT 'WOULD LIKE TO END' GOVERNMENT BY MILITARY BY FEB. 1
description: The authorities have stepped up an attack in the press and at the universities against liberal writers, artists and scholars, arousing fears among intellectuals that they will suffer reprisals for speaking out under martial law.

title: HEADED BOOK HOUSE FOUNDED BY FATHER
description: Eva Schocken Glaser, president of Schocken Books, Inc., died at White Plains Hospital yesterday after a brief illness. She was 63 years old and lived in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A chart in Business Day yesterday incorrectly showed the November fig- ure for consumer installment debt out- standing. A corrected chart appears today on page D11.

title: A Sentimental Carew
description: Another first baseman who has been a league batting champion, Rod Carew of the California Angels, said in an interview with The Minneapolis Star that there was a possibility that he could finish his career where he started it - with the Minnesota Twins. After 12 years and seven American League batting titles with the Twins, Carew was traded to the Angels Feb. 3, 1979.

title: MEAD DEPRESSION DRUG IS APPROVED BY F.D.A.
description: The Mead Johnson & Company division of the Bristol-Myers Company announced yesterday that it had received permission from the Food and Drug Administration to sell a new antidepression drug, thus clearing the way for the company's entry into the mental health pharmaceuticals market.

title: SUBURBAN BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Catching Up With One China
description: President Reagan is trying hard to make amends for his foolish campaign promise to somehow upgrade relations with Taiwan. By finally refusing to sell the Nationalist Chinese a new line of jet fighters, he is doing that rare thin g, changing his mind in public. To appreciate his difficulty, one has only to listen to the spluttering a t the President's end of the political spectrum. To his conservative friends he now seems more faint-hearted than Jimmy Carter.

title: ARMS TALKS RESUME IN GENEVA
description: The United States and the Soviet Union resumed talks here today on the reduction of intermediate-range nuclear missiles in Europe, ending a month's recess for the holidays. It was their first session since the United States imposed economic sanctions against the Soviet Union because of the Polish crisis.

title: DATA GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 19
description: B-Includes $4.8 million extraordinary gain on the exchange of debentures...C-Includes $5.1 million extraordinary gain on the sale of securities

title: Defendant in Drug Case Dies
description: A defendant in a major marijuana smuggling case has died, apparently of a heart attack, his attorney said Monday. Talbot Trammel, the attorney, told Chief Federal District Judge C. Clyde Atkins that the defendant, Woody Adkinson, 38 years old, of Fort Pierce, Fla., died Sunday.

title: HILLENBRAND INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 28
Woman Is Shot On Canarsie Street
description: A woman was shot in the head on a street in the Canarsie section of Brooklyn yesterday evening by an armed robber who escaped with all the money she had on her - $10.

title: FINANCING TROUBLES CONFRONT DELOREAN
description: In an unsettled corner of this strifetorn ci ty, as many as 80 stainless-steel cars a day have rolledoff the assem bly line of DeLorean Motor Cars' modern plant, itself the occasiona l victim of the violence.

title: KING ASKS TAX CUT IN MASSACHUSETTS
description: Gov. Edward J. King proposed in his State of the State speech tonight to cut personal income taxes in Massachusetts by $160 million a year and called for a constitutional amendment that would put a ceiling on the growth of state and local taxes.

title: HAIG IN CAIRO TO PRESS MIDDLE EAST TALKS
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. flew here today to open a new round of American efforts to end the impasse in the Egyptian-Israeli negotiations on Palestinian self-rule.

title: ATI INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
description: B-Net income...C-Net loss

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: THE good cooks of Burgundy, where I was born, use a lot of wine in their cookery. The best-known wine dish in the world is probably boeuf Bourguignonne - beef Burgundy-style - and then there is coq au vin, both of which are well known in this country.

title: Christina Onassis' Fleet Weighs In
description: In Athens yesterday, Christina Onassis made a small footnote to history when she became the first woman to be elected to the board of the Greek Union of Shipowners, one of the world's richest of rich men's clubs.

title: KNICKS HALT LATE RALLY AND DEFEAT JAZZ, 129-121
description: This afternoon, hours before the Knicks played the Jazz here at the Salt Palace, Gene Littles, Utah's assistant coach, ran his team through some of the Knicks' plays. He diagrammed one that calls for Bill Cartwright, the Knick center, to get the ball on the baseline.

title: KOCH TO ASK COMMUTER TAX RISE
description: Mayor Koch will ask the Legislature to raise the basic income tax rate paid by suburban commuters but will not seek a similar increase for New York City residents.

title: SUIT DENIED IN U.S. LAND GIFT TO CHURCH SCHOOL
description: A narrowly divided Supreme Court today barred a lawsuit charging that the Federal Government's gift of property to a religious college violated the constitutional separation between church and state.

title: Buckner to Hold Out?
description: Bill Buckner, the Chicago Cubs' first baseman and the National League batting champion in 1980, has threatened to sit out the 1982 season unless his contract, which has three years to run, is extended or reopened. Buckner, who batted .311 during the strike-abbreviated 1981 season and .324 the previous year, said he wanted a better deal than the $310,000 salary he is earning.

title: Prosecutor in Harris Case Joining New York Firm
description: If Jean S. Harris ever gets the new trial she is seeking in the murder of Dr. Herman Tarnower, George Bolen will not be around to renew his prosecution. Mr. Bolen, the assistant district attorney who won the conviction, is leaving the Westchester County District Attorney's office to join the Manhattan law firm of Martin, Clearwater & Bell.

title: Kitchen Equipment; THE CAST-IRON SKILLET
description: SITTING quietly on the basic kitchen equipment list that appears on page C6 is the mention of a 10-inch cast-iron s killet. The fact that it is th ere should not surprise anyone. And yet, in these days of fancy pots and pans, one might wonder why cast iron seems so special, why this particular substance, which has been around for 4,000 years, still seems essential to cooking.

title: SOVIET AND POLAND ACCUSE NATO ALLIES OF 'INTERFERING'
description: A joint Soviet-Polish communique issued today at the conclusion of a visit by Poland's Foreign Minister combined a sharp criticism of Monday's statement by NATO with a strong appeal for maintenance of detente.

title: EXCHANGE BANCORPORATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Market Place; General Foods And Mergers
description: WHEN General Foods paid cash and securities for Oscar Mayer last May, it added exposure to wide swings in pork prices to its previous vulnerability to coffee and sugar price gyrations. Some Wall Street analysts questioned the wisdom of the move and speculated that the company might be trying to make itself less attractive to raiders.

title: Sports of The Times; Gaining Strength Through Losing
description: HE could hear the dismal clump of spikes as his teammates trudged up the runway. The World Series was over, and George Frazier had lost three games.

title: Red Sox Drop Bidding For Waits and Monge
description: The Boston Red Sox today dropped out of the bidding for the free agent pitchers Rick Waits and Sid Monge, who played last season for the Cleveland Indians. Boston officials said they informed the pitchers' agents that they ha ve decided to terminate negotiations.

title: BRIEFING
description: S TOMPING their feet and looking doubtful, poor people in the capital's northwest quarter lined up for more than three hours in the cold yesterday, waiting for the Government to finally yield some of its vast storehouse of cheese that has accumulated over the years as the result of Washington's subsidy of dairy fa rmers.

title: Advertising; Addendum
description: * Rolling Stone magazine increasing its advertising rates 10 percent, effective with the April 1 issue.

title: DOW OFF 2.76
description: Stock price s continued to retreat yesterday in active trading. The size of the d ecline, however, was much less than on Monday, when the Dow Jones ind ustrial average tumbled 16.07 points in reaction to fears of high er interest rates.

title: Palestinian Killed in Rome
description: A Palestinian has died of wounds he received in a shooting Sunday at the Rome office of the Palestine Liberation Organization, the police said today. They identified the dead man as Imad Osman, 22 years old. A security man at the office has been arrested and faces charges of homicide and possession of an unregistered weapon.

title: STAGE: 'WHEN WE DEAD AWAKEN,' LAST IBSEN PLAY
description: FOR Ibsen, ''When We Dead Awaken'' - his last and shortest play - was an epilogue that completed the cycle of dramas that began with ''A Doll's House.'' Seeing the seldom-performed work in a rare production, staged by Stephen Zuckerman at the Open Space Theater, one realizes that it is also an epiphany. ''When We Dead Awaken'' draws from Ibsen's early poetic excursions (''Brand'' and ''Peer Gynt'') and his naturalistic efforts. It is the snow-capped peak of his last trilogy about lofty, loveless genius, men who have forsaken their ideals and who look back with cynicism at the compromises of their youth.

title: Arab Extradited by U.S.  Denies Charge in Israel
description: A Palestinian extradited from the United States last month to stand trial has pleaded not guilty to setting a bomb that killed two Israeli boys and wounded 36 people.

title: PRESIDENT MOVES TO CURB UNAUTHORIZED DISCLOSURES
description: President Reagan, asserting that unauthorized disclosures of classified material had hampered the conduct of foreign policy, today ordered a series of measures to protect national security information.

title: BALLET: HARLEM DANCE THEATER PRESENTS 'FIREBIRD'
description: THE Dance Theater of Harlem opened last night at the City Center for a season through Feb. l4 and it wound up its first evening with an instant hit - ''Firebird'' by John Taras.

title: MET ACQUIRES EARLY POLLOCK
description: ''Pasiphae,'' a large early work (1943) by Jackson Pollock, has been sold to the Metropolitan Museum of Art for $1 million by Lee Krasner Pollock, the painter and widow of the artist. The price is the highest yet for an early work by Pollock that precedes the ''classic'' period beginning in 1947, when he began his ''spontaneous'' method of pouring paint onto the canvas in all-over webs of color.

title: COLONIAL BANCORP INC (WATERBURY, CONN) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Sudan and Chad Agree T o Normalize Relations
description: The Sudan and Chad agreed today to normalize relations and set up a ministerial committee to insure Chadian rebels do not use the Sudan as a base.

title: U.S. JUDGE REFUSES TO CLOSE BELL CASE
description: Federal Judge Harold H. Greene refused today to dismiss out-of-hand the antitrust lawsuit against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, but he said that he was ''delighted that a settlement has been reached.''

title: HILLER AVIATION reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
WITNESS TELLS COURT ABBOTT SAID HE HAD 'KILLED A MAN'
description: A Barnard College student who was having breakfast with Jack Henry Abbott in the East Village last summer testified yesterday that the prison author had an angry argument with a waiter and later returned to the restaurant, saying, ''Let's get out of here, I just killed a man.'' The student, Susan Roxas, also told the jur y in State Supreme Court in Manhattan at Mr. Abbott's murder tri al that she had seen a spatula-like knife stuck in his belt earlier that evening and that Mr. Abbott had had a dispute in the lobby of a friend's apartment building.

title: REPUBLIC OF TEXAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
HACKENSACK WATER CO reports earnings for Yr to Nov 30
description: B-Includes a gain of $891,000 on the sale of property

title: No Headline
description: VIRGINIA RALLIES TO WIN IN OVERTIME, 45-40

title: DON'T OVERTURN THE MIDEAST PEACE TABLE YET
description: To the Editor:

title: Going Out Guide
description: TIME FOR SHELTER

title: CITY TO PROVIDE 200 HEATED APARTMENTS
description: Two hundred apartments in city-owned residential buildings will be leased on a first-come, first-served basis to tenants who have no heat in their own apartments, New York City housing officials said yesterday..

title: DON'T OVERTURN THE MIDEAST PEACE TABLE YET
description: To the Editor:

title: MET OPERA: 'LUISA MILLER' RETURNS TO REPERTORY
description: JUST about the only surprise in Monday evening's performance of ''Luisa Miller'' at th e Metropolitan Opera ca me before the first curtain went up. A company functionary appear ed onstage and announcedthat Luciano Pavarotti would not be singing. The Italian tenor, it seems, developed a cold earlier in the day an d had to drop out.

title: PAYLESS CASHWAYS (CO) reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 28
description: 1980 results have been restated

title: New Seabrook Owners Sought
description: The builder of the Seabrook nuclear power plant has been ordered by the New Hampshire Public Utilities Commission to sell some of the project or face pressure to delay or cancel one or both Seabrook reactors.

title: 'Johnny' Closes at Opening
description: ''Oh, Johnny,'' a musical by Gary Cherpakov and Paul Streitz, opened and closed Sunday evening after one performance and 12 previews at the Players Theater. The play, about romance and adventure in the South Pacific during World War II, was directed and choreographed by Alan Weeks. Produced by Mr. Streitz, the show featured Michael Crouch, Christine Toy and Nazig Edwards.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: F.T.C. to Get Mobil Data

title: PULTE HOME CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes $1.3 million gain from the reversal of income taxes in prior yrs

title: Higher Gold Output Seen
description: World mine production of gold this year will total 43.83 million ounces, a drop of 2.69 million ounces from the forecast made a year ago, but up from 42.55 million ounces produced in 1981, the gold institute predicted here today.

title: No Headline
description: 76ers 95, Bullets 92

title: Haiti Reports Death of 3 Seized During Invasion
description: DE-PAIX, Haiti, Jan. 12 (AP) - Three men who were captured when a small invasion force landed on Haiti's Tortuga Island have ''succumbed to their wounds and died,'' the national television reported tonight.

title: UMET TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-Includes $9.6 million gain on restructuring of debt and $808,000 tax credit...C-Includes gains from accured interest forgiven of $140,000 for the qr and $302,000 for the yr and $814,00 tax credit for both periods

title: M.V.P. TO ANDERSON
description: Ken Anderson, the quarterback who led the Cincinnati Bengals to a 12-4 record and their first Super Bowl berth, was named the most valuable player in the National Football League in a vote by the Professional Football Writers of America. Anderson, 32, in his 11th pro season, completed 300 of 479 pass attempts for 3,754 yards and 29 touchdowns in the regular season and was intercepted only 10 times. His 300 yards rushing were the best in the league by a quarterback.

title: Discoveries; AN EARLY START ON A SPRING HAT; 1. Colorful Straw Hats
description: If you're heading for a sunny climate or want to buy your spring hat early, check the becoming brimmed straw hats that Lord & Taylor is selling for $8. They come in a range of delightful colors: red, turquoise, royal blue and toast beige as well as black and navy. Theycan be worn a s they are or banded with a silk scarf. The hat bar on the main floo r has them.

title: GREECE IS SAID TO TIE STAND ON POLAND TO OTHER ISSUES
description: Greece's decision to withhold full support for NATO's declaration on Poland was interpreted by officials and Western diplomats here today as another step to strengthen its hand in its disputes with Turkey and in negotiations on American bases.

title: Designing a Wedding Gown, but Not for Herself
description: When Jennifer von Mayrhauser, the Broadway costume designer, was married at City Hall the other day, she was unable to wear a wedding dress of her own design because she had been too busy whipping up such a creation for someone else.

title: MUNOZ MOST FEROCIOUS BENGAL
description: Anthony Munoz, one of the most massive offensive linemen in pro football, did no tinkering yesterday with his delicate model airplanes or his toy cars.

title: MEXICO'S MIDDLE CLASS TURNS TO DISCO AND BURGERS
description: Long before its official opening this month, crowds began flocking from all over this sprawling, overcrowded metropolis to a new amusement park on the wooded outskirts of Mexico City to enjoy a form of leisure until now available only north of the border.

title: JARUZELSKI & CO.
description: To the Editor:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''This will be a dollar-for-dollar pass-through. If we shave a benefit X dollars, then X dollars will be passed on to consumers.''

title: Cosmos Edge Manic, 5-4
description: Chico Borja scored two goals, including the winner 52 seconds into sudden-death overtime, and lifted the Cosmos to a 5-4 victory over the Montreal Manic in a North American Soccer League game tonight at the Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: Oil Price Cut By Venezuela
description: Venezuela has lowered its residual fuel prices by as much as $1 a barrel, a leading newspaper said today.

title: ABOUT NEW YORK
description: On the corner of Hester Street and the Bowery, just across from the Half Moon Tavern, the small fire leapt to the sky, orange and brilliant, makeshift and warm. It was started in a battered tin bucket, fueled with odd pieces of lumber and broken odds and ends of plywood, and four men held out their hands to it, as though to stroke its flames.

title: 'LISA H.' ENDS HOSPITAL STAY
description: Lisa H., the 21-year-old college student who underwent radical surgery on Dec. 9 to rid herself of disfiguring facial tumors caused by a rare genetic disease, was discharged yesterday from the Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania in Philadelphia.

title: Most Ankara Businesses Shut Because of Pollution
description: The Governor of Ankara ordered all industries and businesses to close down until further notice today as pollution rose alarmingly. Only hospitals and bakeries were excluded from the ban.

title: INTEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
TV RATINGS

title: RADIO CITY TO CELEBRATE GOLDEN JUBILEE
description: Radio City Music Hall, approaching its 50th birthday, will celebrate with a dinner and dance on its huge stage next Tuesday and then open a gala anniversary show, ''Encore,'' on March 26.

title: WITNESS LINKS DEFENDANT TO SLAIN ATALNTA YOUTH
description: An Atlanta woman testified today that she saw Wayne B. Williams with one of the two men he is accused of killing a week before the man's body was found floating in the Chattahoochee River.

title: Guatemala Amok
description: A diplomat recently called Guatemala ''a bloodbath waiting to happen.'' It's happening.

title: Weinberger to Visit Mideast
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger will visit Saudi Arabia next month and expects to visit Israel later this year, his office announced today.

title: TOWN & COUNTRY MOBILE HOMES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Net income; 1981 results restated to include Brigadier Industries Corp acquired in Sept on a pooling of interest basis

title: ECHOES ON THE CONFERENCE ON AGING STILL REVERBERATING IN THE CAPITAL
description: Political reverberations from the White House Conference on Aging are echoing through the capital a month after the delegates went home.

title: GETTING EASIER STARTS FOR CARS IN THE COLD
description: In cold weather, the Automobile Club of New York advises that motorists try this routine for easier starts:

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 13, 1982
description: International An end to martial law in Poland was discussed by a senior official at a news conference in Warsaw. Deputy Prime Minister Jerzy Ozdowski said that he would like to end martial law by Feb. 1. But Mr. Ozdowski said that there was no timetable for ending the state of emergency that was declared on Dec. 13, and he added that a decision to lift martial rule ''depends on the situation.'' (Page A1, Columns 1-2.) Attacks on intellectuals in Poland have increased in the press and at the universities, prompting fears among liberal writers, artists and scholars that they will suffer reprisals for speaking out. (A1:2.)

title: BOND YIELDS AT RECORD LEVELS
description: Yields on long-term tax-exempt bonds were at record levels yesterday, but dealers said that investor demand remained modest despite the widespread availablity of revenue bonds yielding more than 14 percent and high-grade general-obligation issues yielding more than 12 percent.

title: Election Day for Baseball
description: When the Baseball Writers Association of America announces the results of its voting today, Henry Aaron and Frank Robinson could become the 12th and 13th players elected to the Hall of Fame in their first year of eligibility. Aaron, who broke Babe Ruth's home run record of 714 in 1974 and ended his career two years later with 755, is considered a certain selection by the members of the association and might even be the first player to be elected unanimously.

title: CACI INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
A Top Official in India I s Convicted of Extortion
description: The Bombay High Court convicted the chief minister of Maharashtra state of extortion today.

title: French Steel Output Off
description: French output of crude steel in 1981 fell 8.2 percent from 1980, to 21.27 million tons, the steel producers' association said today.

title: Business People; BANK OF NEW YORK AND PARENT FILL POST
description: Shortly after Elliott Averett died yesterday at the age of 64, J. Carter Bacot was elected to succeed him as chairman and chief executive officer of the Bank of New York Company and chairman of its principal subsidiary, the Bank of New York. Mr. Bacot, 48, will continue to hold his other posts of president of the holding company and president and chief executive officer of the bank.

title: INTERFIRST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results for all periods reflect the 1980 mergers of Guaranty Bond State Bank and Nederland State Bank and the 1981 mergers of Greenspoint Bank, San Felipe Bank, First National Bank of San Antonio, Lake Air National Bank, First Bancorp Inc and the Paris Bank of Texas; results restated for 2-for-1 stock split

title: HIGH COURT BACKS CALIFORNIA ON CITIZENSHIP RULE FOR 'PEACE OFFICERS'
description: In a decision that appeared to give states new latitude to make citizenship a requirement for public employment, t he Supreme Court, on a 5-to-4 vote today, upheld a California la w requiring ''peace officers'' to be United States citizens.

title: Shift in Retail Shopping Seen
description: Department stores were warned yesterday at a national retailing convention in New York that increasing numbers of women are turning to speciality stores as a preferred place to shop for clothing.

title: Economic Scene; Looser Money, Less Inflation?
description: THE prospects for the American economy in 1982 are growing increasingly dismal. The securities markets have weakened, reflecting anxieties over rising interest rates. The Administration's policy makers have insisted that interest rates would come down with inflation, but the markets do not believe it. They foresee pressures on rates intensifying as the Government plans for growing budget deficits three years ahead - deficits that were supposed not to happen, as faster growth threw off enough additional revenue to pay for the big tax cuts.

title: Bridge: World Title Site to Feature Play of a Different Cali ber
description: It will be quantity rather than quality at the Rye Town Hilton, Port Chester, N.Y., during the next five days. Instead of 66 players fighting for two world team titles, as happened there in October, 2,000 players of widely ranging skills will compete in the Tristate Regional Championships, with the following schedule: Today - Men's and women's pairs, 1:30 P.M.; men's and women's Swiss teams, 8 P.M. Thursday - Men's and women's pairs, 1:30 P.M.; men's and women's Swiss teams, 8 P.M. Friday - Mixed pairs and individual, 1:30 P.M. and 8 P.M.; novice pairs, 8 P.M.; speedball Swiss teams, midnight. Saturday - Super flighted open pairs, 1:30 P.M. and 8 P.M. Sunday - Flighted Swiss teams (two sessions), noon; charity pairs, 6 P.M.

title: POLL AFTER POLL AFTER POLL AFTER POLL WARNS PRESIDENT ON PROGRAM
description: Accumulating evidence from several polls indicates that the public, in this year of Congressional midterm elections, is again in a mood to change the direction of public policy. Disillusionment with Ronald Reagan's performance has grown faster and is more widespread than for any other newly elected President. Most Americans remain committed to basic assumptions of the welfare state, although they initially supported Mr. Reagan's overall efforts to cut taxes and spending.

title: PNEUMATIC SCALE CORP reports earnings for Yr to Nov 30
description: B-Includes gain of $136,448 cumulative effect of accounting change; the 1980 shr earnings include 23 cent gain on cumulativ effect of accounting change

title: Mock Eggs Benedict
description: 3 cups sauce Mornay (see recipe) 8 cups water 1/4 cup white vinegar 4 tablespoons butter 8 thin slices cooked ham or prosciutto, about a quarter pound 8 eggs 4 English muffins, split in half 1/2 teaspoon paprika Parsley sprigs for garnish.

title: YANKS, METS EACH GET 3 PITCHERS IN DRAFT
description: The Mets and Yankees each selected three pitchers and one outfielder yesterday in the lesser of two free-agent amateur drafts conducted each year. Among the Mets' picks wa s Tim McMannon, a 6-foot-5-inch right-hander who was drafted as a pitcher although he played first base last year for the College o f Southern Idaho. Among the Yankee choices was Oddibe McDowell, an ou tfielder from Miami-DadeCommunity College North who hit .329 last yea r and stole 16 bases in 19 attempts.

title: CASH-FLOW SQUEEZE AT INVSCO
description: On Christmas Eve, lawyers for American Invsco took the New York State Attorney General, Robert Abrams, to court in Albany, challenging his blanket rejection of Invsco's efforts to evict scores of elderly tenants from a newly converted cooperative on New York's East Side.

title: NEW CABLE SIGNS STAGE SHOWS
description: Executives of the Entertainment Channel, a pay-television service scheduled to start June 4, announced an agreement yesterday with RKO Nederlander Productions to broadcast Broadway shows to cable subscribers.

title: TRUST CO OF GEORGIA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
TV: 'SHARKS' AND 'ALL THINGS' ON PBS
description: PBS has two documentaries on tap this evening. The National Geographic series returns, at 8 o'clock on WNET-TV, with an essay on ''The Sharks.'' And at 9:30, ''All Things Considered,'' long an award-winning beacon of National Public Radio, will attempt to transfer something of its special style to the television screen.

title: Article 169560 -- No Title
description: The National Park Service has announced a 10-year, $25 million development plan for Floyd Bennett Field in Brooklyn that would be partially financed by private funds.

title: Kuwait's Scottish Stake
description: The Bank of Scotland said today that the Kuwaiti Government now holds 9 percent of its stock, following the recent purchase of 35,000 shares. Barclays Bank, the largest shareholder, owns 34.8 percent.

title: BUDGET'S IMPACT REACHES LYNDHURST
description: The National Trust for Histor ic Preservation announced today that Lyndhurst, a Gothic Revi val mansion set on 67 acres at Tarrytown, N.Y., would restrict acce ss to the public as part of a nationwide budget-cutting effort.

title: PAKISTAN ACCUSED OF RIGHTS ABUSES
description: As Pakistan's new Consultative Assembly began the first public debate of Government policy in four years of military rule, and as President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq withdrew formal press censorship, Amnesty International today issued a 54-page report charging that torture, imprisonment and violation of human rights in this country had increased steadily in the last year.

title: DEMOCRAT WINS SPECIAL ELECTION IN CONNECTICUT
description: Barbara B. Kennelly, the Democratic candidate, defeated her Republican opponent, Antonina P. Uccello, tonight in a special election to fill a vacant seat in the United States House of Representatives.

title: No Headline
description: POLAND SAYS IT 'WOULD LIKE TO END' GOVERNMENT BY MILITARY BY FEB. 1

title: U.S. SETS GATT PLEA ON CANADA
description: The United States, which has had a series of sharp exchanges in the past year over Canada's nationalistic trade, energy and investment policies, plans to take its quarrels with Ottawa through the settlement procedures of an international forum.

title: WRONG-HEADED WISTFULNESS ABOUT THE 1960's
description: To the Editor:

title: SUNAIR ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CORRECTIONS
description: An article about Bulgaria on Dec. 11 gave incorrect nationalities for the developers of the Cyrillic alphabet. St. Cyril and his brother, St. Methodius, were Greek missionaries who developed an alphabet while serving in what is now Bulgaria. That alphabet, known as Glagolithic, was refined by their followers into Cyrillic.

title: A 'NUCLEAR ADVANTAGE' SWIFTLY GIVING WAY TO COAL
description: To the Editor:

title: JOHN ALBOK, TAILOR-PHOTOGRAPHER
description: John Albok, a tailor and photographer noted for his pictures of New York during the Depression, died of cancer Sunday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 87 years old and lived above the East Side tailor shop he had operated for 60 years.

title: HAITIANS AS HOSTAGES
description: One returns from a recent visit to Fort Allen, the former Army camp in Puerto Rico where 800 of the 2,500 Haitian refugees who have reached our shores are confined, with the distinct impression that they have become hostages to deter future arrivals. Perhaps our Government hopes that those who return to Haiti will spread the word of how bad things are in the United States so that others will not come.

title: DON'T OVERTURN THE MIDEAST PEACE TABLE YET
description: To the Editor:

title: Keeping the Bonds of Progress
description: To the Editor:

title: Von Bulow Defense Cites An Affair With Woman
description: Claus C. von Bulow, charged with twice trying to kill his heiress wife, was having an affair with another woman, his attorney said today.

title: MOB IN PHILADELPHIA IS CALLED 'FRAGMENTED' BY 11TH KILLING
description: A series of 11 gangland slayings in two years, carried out in what is believed to be a battle for control of Atlantic City's casino business, has ''badly fragmented and weakened'' the Philadelphia mob, according to the police.

title: Nebraska's Rimington To Play in Senior Year
description: Dave Rimington , Nebraska's center. announced today that he would return for his senior season with the Cornhuskers.

title: Haig's Verbal Success
description: At the end of the first emergency meeting in the history of the NATO alliance, Secretary of State Haig got the communique he wanted, condemning Moscow for its part in the suppression of freedom in Poland.

title: Model, 30 Years Young, Just Starting Out
description: Why was Lisa Taylor calling such attention to her 30th birthday Monday night? ''I don't feel old,'' said Miss Taylor, a model and actress, whose birthday celebration at Xenon drew a disparate group of admirers ranging from Rusty Staub to Andy Warhol.

title: News An alysis
description: Isaac Newton's first law of motion states that an object in motion tends to remain in motion unless acted upon by an outside force. But as the apparent legitimacy of New York's unelected, holdover City Council attests, the so-called

title: AM INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-AM International made no comparison between the 1982 first qr and the same period a yr ago because it has been unable to determine the extent to which its recently completed special accounting adjustments affect the 1980's qr results

title: Tony C. Unconscious
description: Tony Conigliaro, the former Boston Red Sox slugger, remained listed as unconscious yesterday in Massachusetts General Hospital, three days after he suffered a heart attack.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: GENE SHALIT works at a desk but he laughs maniacally when the word is mentioned. ''I haven't seen that desk in six months,'' he boomed between guffaws. ''It's piled high with debris.''

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: G.M. AND AUTO WORKERS TO LINK CUT IN WAGES TO LOWER CAR PRICES
description: The General Motors Corporation and the United Automobile Workers agreed today to link lower wages and benefits to lower prices for automobiles sold in this country.

title: New Oratorio Honoring Dr. King Set for Friday
description: The Collegiate Chorale will present the New York premiere of Undine Smith Moore's oratorio ''Scenes From the Life of a Martyr'' in Carnegie Hall on Friday at 8 P.M. The work, dedicated to the memory of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., will be performed on his birthday by the 160-voice chorus conducted by Robert Bass.

title: REAGAN PLEDGES HIS SUPPORT FOR PUERTO RICAN STATEHOOD
description: President Reagan today pledged to support statehood for Puerto Rico ''should the people of that island choose it in a free and democratic election.'' His statement was immediately welcomed by the Governor of Puerto Rico, who said it would help the chances of statehood in a future referendum on the issue.

title: Advertising; Ferber, Janklow Joins Chimbel & Bender
description: Ferber, Janklow & Associates has merged with Chimbel & Bender, a creative boutique, to form Ferber, Janklow, Chimbel, Bender, wit h billings of a bout $5.5 million.

title: Kitchen Library; AMERICAN CUISINE: IT'S A MELTING POT TOO
description: JUDGING from a number of new cookbooks and food books, it is becoming more difficult than ever to define American cuisine. The melting pot runneth over with French, Oriental, Middle Eastern and Italian influences. Add corn kernels to the stir-fry, deglaze a green peppercorn sauce with bourbon or turn pasta into a salad and it qualifies as American.

title: Out of Work Fourth article of a series on the nation's unemployment problem.
description: When Walter L. Barnes was discharged from the Navy last summer after a three-year hitch as a machinist's mate, he returned to his hometown expecting to find a job. But like many of the old industrial cities in the Middle West, St. Louis had fallen on hard times, and the 26-year-old veteran soon learned that jobs for which his Navy training had equipped him were ''not to be found in this city.''

title: AGAIN, PRESIDENT IS DRAWING CONSERVATIVES' IRE
description: As Ronald Reagan nears his first anniversary as President, some of the most ardent conservative partisans who celebrated his inauguration a year ago with almost parental pride are now so disgruntled that they are getting ready to give him a poor report card at a special anniversary critique later this month.

title: HIGH COURT BACKS MINERAL FORFEITURE
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that rights to oil, coal and other minerals that have not been exercised for many years can be declared forfeited under state law.

title: 'Creditwatch' On A.T.& T.
description: The Standard & Poor's Corporation said that it had put the debt of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and 20 of its 22 operating subsidiaries on its ''Creditwatch'' listing because of last week's antitrust action.

title: Article 169753 -- No Title
description: The $25,000 DeLorean, although introduced during the worst auto market in many years, has been selling briskly, dealers in the United States say. Of course, many of them add, it is a very limited, very exclusive market and the numbers are still small in absolute terms.

title: Lower Hudson Valley To Get New FM Station
description: An FM station that will serve Putnam, southern Dutchess and northern Westchester Counties will begin broadcasting next Sunday, the station's owners have announced.

title: HIGH JAPANESE OFFICIAL BIDS U.S. FOSTER CHINA TIES
description: A month after he took office as Foreign Minister, Yoshio Sakurauchi feels that Japanese foreign policies in 1982 will be different from those favored under his predecessor, Sunao Sonoda.

title: Mortgage Rates Rise
description: The average interest rate on 30-year home mortgages rose to 17.30 percent for the week ending Jan.8, up from 17.04 percent in the previous week, the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation reported today in its weekly primary mortgage market survey. The rate applies to single-family home mortgages with a 20 percent down payment. David Andrukonis, an economist for the mortgage corporation, said that the mortgage rate average rose steadily through 1981, to a peak of 18.63 percent on Oct.9.

title: Veterans Vow to Fight Medical Care Cutbacks
description: Veterans' organizations, responding to reports that the Reagan Administration is considering halting free medical care for veterans over 65 years old, said Monday they would fight any reductions.

title: Paterno Rejects Patriots
description: Penn State's football coach, Joe Paterno, officially rejected an offer to become the New England Patriots' coach.

title: Personal Health; CARE AND TREATMENT OF YOUR ACHING BACK
description: YOU lunge for a tennis ball, stoop to pick up a child, lean over to make the bed, reach for something on the back seat, push the car out of a snowdrift and, ow! you can't get up. Something has snapped in your lower back. Or, you awake in the morning, stand after a long plane ride, or come to the end of a car trip and find your back stiffened with pain.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Bausch & Lomb, Rochester, has named W. Terry Smith president of the new Soflens Professional Products division and William J. Godfrey president of the new Personal Products division.

title: British Railway Union Begins Two-Day Strike
description: Britain was hit today by a two-day national rail strike as road and rail transport was just recovering from some of the worst blizzards of this century.

title: FLORAFAX INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-Includes $299,000 tax credit...C-Includes $201,000 tax credit

title: New York Needs a New Council
description: The objections raised so far against the New York City Council's revised redistricting plan do not appear to justify much more tinkering or delay. The present Council is a flight of lame ducks that will be sitting at least until June. The legality of its actions has already been challenged and will be indefensible if the members do not move toward election at a decent pace. There can be no election until the Justice Department approves the districts and it cannot rule until a plan is formally adopted and submitted.

title: UNIFI INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
FRISCH'S RESTAURANTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 13
Wichita State Officials Call Probation Harsh
description: Wichita State University officials said Monday that they believed the three-year probation and sanctions imposed on their basketball program by the National Collegiate Athletic Association were ''unduly harsh.'' They also said any appeal would be futile.

title: YAMANI SAYS OIL OUTPUT COULD BE SHARPLY CUT
description: Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, Saudi Arabia's oil minister, said today that the current world oil glut ''will not continue,'' in large part because of his country's willingness to substantially cut oil output.

title: No Headline
description: Public Radio Chief Confirms Report on Talks to Buy U.P.I.

title: THURSDAY, JANUARY 14, 1982; The Economy
description: Retail sales in December rose only 0.4 percent after seasonal adjustment, the Commerce Department reported. Sales for the year were 9.3 percent higher, indicating little or no gain after allowing for inflation. The gain in December, when the recession apparently deepened, was less than November's 0.7 percent rise. (D1.)

title: VAN WYCK INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 28
description: B-Includes tax credits of $58,400 for the qr and $64,000 for the yr...C-Net loss

title: BRITONS TANGLED IN COMMUTER RAIL STRIKE
description: Britain struggled to work and back again today as the country's rail system ground to a halt in the largest railway work stoppage here in 27 years.

title: SECRET OVAL OFFICE RECORDINGS BY ROOSEVE LT IN '40 DISCLOSED
description: President Franklin D. Roosevelt used a secret device to record news conferences in the Oval Office of the White House for 11 weeks during his 1940 re-election campaign, according to a history professor who has spent the last three years studying the recordings. Some private conversations were also recorded, apparently inadvertently.

title: Larry C. Morris Snow yesterday and last night in New York made the going tough for cars, carts and commuters. Slippery roads caused buses to be delayed going into and out of Port Authority terminal in midtown, and at
description: least one line extended onto an escalator that had to be shut off.

title: The City; Berserk Man Dies After Injuring 7
description: A 29-year-old Queens man who was on the list for appointment to the Police Department died, apparently of cardiac arrest, after he went berserk and assaulted 10 persons, injuring seven - including six officers who had tried to subdue him, the police said.

title: FAMILY DOLLAR STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
DO WE EXPECT ACTORS TO TALK LIKE MERE MORTALS?
description: IT'S strange how willing we are to accept rhetoric from someone playing an actor, and a ham actor at that, while we're terribly reluctant to believe that a performer playing a real person would ever touch the stuff at all.

title: JUSTICES BACK POLICE SEARCHES IN ARRESTED SUSPECTS' HOMES
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that the police do not need a search warrant to accompany an arrested person into his home or to seize any incriminating evidence that is plainly visible there.

title: CITY HEALTH CARE FOR POOR IS PLEDGED DESPITE CUTS
description: Deputy Mayor Robert F. Wagner Jr. said yesterday that New York City would continue to provide free health care to the city's poor, including any family that loses its Medicaid benefits because of cuts in Federal health-care funds for the poor.

title: Sports People; Umpire Disputes Call
description: Steve Fields, hired in 1979 by the National League to work during the major league umpires' strike, said at his home in Alexandria, Va., that he planned to sue major league baseball in an attempt to get his job back. The National League confirmed yesterday that Fields had been dismissed.

title: Around the Nation; Toxic Leak Kills Two, Injures 15 in Michigan
description: A toxic substance, believed to be hydrogen sulfide, leaked from a tanker truck, instantly killing two people today and injuring at least 15 others, officials said.

title: FRENCH-I.T.T. RIFT IS SEEN ON ASSETS
description: The International Telephone an d Telegraph Corporation has asked France for $3 75 million as compensation for the proposed nationalization of its assets, Government sources said here today. The Gover nment sources described the request as ''clearly too high.''

title: HELENE CURTIS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
VINTAGE RADIOS AND TV's CATCHING ON
description: THE idea of ''antique electronics'' seems like a contradiction in terms. For most people, the best in electronic hardware implies the newest or the most technologically sophisticated.

title: DRAFT AGENCY PLANS DRIVE TO GET YOUTHS TO REGISTER
description: The Selective Service System, following President Reagan's decision last week to continue draft registration, has begun a nationwide campaign to persuade the one million young men who have failed to register to do so.

title: PALMETTO FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN (PALM reports earnings for Qtr to Dec
CORRECTION
description: A picture accompanying an article Dec. 14, describing the final session of China's legislature, was incorrectly described as that of the army chief. It showed Peng Chong, a party secretary and member of the Politburo.

title: HIGH COURT SAYS CITIES RISK ANTITRUST LIABILITY
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that cities and towns risk liability under the Federal antitrust laws when they regulate economic activity in the absence of explicit direction from the state government. While the decision involved cable television, its implications extend to state-local relations in a much wider regulatory context.

title: Rate Fears Depress Stocks
description: The stock market retreated again yesterday under the pressure of interest-rate worries, deteriorating technical indicators and a complete lack of group leadership.

title: NONESSENTIAL WORKERS IN CAPITAL STAY HOME
description: President Reagan and Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. of the District of Columbia tonight asked nonessential government employees in the Washington area not to report to work Thursday.

title: NAPLES FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN (FLA) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 3
description: B-Includes $932,309 gain from the sale of securities... C-Includes $294,584 gain from the sale of real estate and accounting changes

title: CORRECTION
description: An article about a Harlem family in Metropolitan Report Monday incorrectly i dentified the law school that has a program to help tenants witho ut heat. It is the New York Law School, at 47 Worth Street in Man hattan.

title: REPAIRING SPLITS IN OLDER FURNITURE
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Michael Varese restores antique furniture for dealers and collectors. By MICHAEL VARESE

title: COLT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Shr earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in Dec 1981

title: FLIGHT TRANSPORTATION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
EX-BOXING PROMOTER GUILTY OF EMBEZZLING $21 MILLION
description: Harold Rossfields Smith, who emerged from obscurity four years ago to become one of America's most powerful boxing promoters, was convicted today of stealing $21.3 million from Wells Fargo National Bank in one of the largest bank embezzlements in the nation's history.

title: Sports People; Comings and Goings
description: CBS has gone to court to try to block ABC from televising a fiveround exhibition bout between Gerr y Coone y and Joe Bugner scheduled for the Westbury (L.I.) Music Fair Jan. 22. Also named as adefendant is Tiffany Productions, the exhibit ion's promoter.

title: INTERNATIONAL MINERALS & CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
WHEN A CHILD IS ILL AWAY AT SCHOOL
description: ONE question that arises when a student becomes ill at college or boarding school centers on whether the campus health services should automatically contact the family.

title: FLOWERS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 12
NEEDIEST CASES FUND DRAWS DONATIONS FROM YOUNGSTERS
description: Children and young people are among the most faithful contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, often donating sums they might otherwise spend on themselves.

title: CITY'S FIRST BIG SNOW CAUSES MASSIVE TIE-UPS
description: The winter's first major snowstorm blew into the New York metropolitan area yesterday, paralyzing traffic, icing streets and causing accidents on the highways.

title: THE MAJOR TV NETWORKS' DWINDLING AUDIENCES
description: THE new year brings with it little cause for celebration at the three major commercial television networks. News Analysis

title: Boeing Refuses Lockheed Offer
description: The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation asked the Boeing Company to take over production of its L-1011 Tristar program, but Boeing declined, a Boeing spokesman said.

title: ALGER'S 150TH YEAR MARKED
description: Horatio Alger Jr., who became an unhappy millionaire by writing more than a hundred books about poor lads miraculously going from rags to riches through pluck and plot luck, was honored yesterday.

title: CONROY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Florida Citrus Embargo Set
description: The Florida Citrus Commission voted unanimously today to impose a 10-day sales and shipment embargo on fresh oranges and grapefruit, hit hard by a devastating freeze earlier in the week.

title: Interim License Is Authorized To Load Reactor in California
description: A Federal panel has authorized an interim license for loading fuel and testing the new San Onofre 2 nuclear power plant near San Clemente.

title: ONE MAN'S TIME IN THE WATER
description: As the plane struck the bridge and cracked open, Joseph Stiley was thrown from his seat and out through a gash in the fuselage, plunging down into the river, he said. Surfacing amid the ice in the freezing water, he found himself conscious and saw Patricia Felch, his co-worker at General Telephone and Electronics in Washington, bobbing nearby.

title: HART SCHAFFNER & MARX reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
No Headline
description: SIR KENNETH STRONG; ADVISED EISENHOWSER ON WAR INTELLIGENCE

title: Europe Keeps I.B.M. Case
description: The European Economic Community's investigation into the competitive practices of the International Business Machines Corporation in Europe will continue, despite the decision by the United States Justice Departm ent to drop its antitrust suit against I.B.M., an official sa id today.

title: INTEREST RATES RISE SHARPLY
description: Short- and long-term interest rates increased sharply yesterday as securities dealers worried that the Federal Reserve was in the midst of a tightening move to make credit less available to the banking system at the same time as dealers were preparing for new, large issues of Treasury notes and bonds.

title: Hortense Hilbert Dead at 85; Former Public Health Official
description: Hortense Hilbert Cikovsky, a former public health administrator, died Friday at her home in Southampton, L.I. She was 85 years old.

title: Orange Juice Up Again; Gold and Silver Lower
description: Prices for precious metals and financial instruments fell sharply yesterday amid signs of continued economic instability, and orange juice prices rose the daily allowable limit for the third consecutive day.

title: HOME FOR 2 GRAND PIANOS AND 2 CAREERS
description: THEY are in the same business but their orbits rarely cross. He has jobs in Paris, Cleveland and Vienna. She is resuming an international career after six years devoted to motherhood. Their two children are in elementary school. Where to live?

title: Around the Nation; Court Rules Spouse Can Share in Earnings
description: Divorced men and women who put their spouses through medical school or other professional training are entitled to a share of their future earnings, a California appeals court has runed.

title: Technology; A.T.T.'s New Computer Net
description: WHEN the American Telephone and Telegraph Company expands into new unregulated businesses - by dint of the proposed settlement of the Federal antitrust suit or by legislation or by an order of the Federal Communications Commission - its first offering is likely to be the Advanced Communications Service, a computer-to-computer communications network.

title: Potlatch Layoffs
description: The Potlatch Corporation, a major producer of lumber and paper products, said it would shut three Idaho plants and lay off 600 workers because of a continuing severe downturn in the housing market. The latest cutback, effective next Monday, raises to nearly 1,200 the number of Potlatch employees on indefinite layoff in the state, the company said. Its total payroll in Idaho is normally about 5,000, Potlatch said.

title: Plane Hits Bridge Over Potomac, 12 Dead, 50 Missing
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 13 — An Air Florida jetliner taking off from National Airport in a snowstorm crashed into a crowded bridge this afternoon and broke as it plunged into the Potomac River, leaving at least 12 people dead and more than 50 missing, according to unofficial police estimates.

title: 'ALLEN'S PLACE' OPENS JAN. 20
description: ''The Allen's Place,'' described as a meditative documentary about the personal and political implications of being Jewish will have its New York premiere next Wednesday at the Film Forum 1, 57 Watts Street. It will run through Feb.2.

title: U.S. WILL PRESS FOR MORE CURBS ON SOVIET TRADE
description: The United States signaled today that it was preparing to ask its Western allies and Japan for increased curbs on the shipment of high-technology products and oil and gas equipme nt tothe Soviet Un ion.

title: JEFF RULAND: SURPRISING ROOKIE
description: Jeff Ruland does not look graceful on the court. He lacks the agility of a Kareem Abdul-Jabbar or an Artis Gilmore. But in recent weeks the Washington Bullets' rookie has performed far better than the scouting reports that questioned his ability to succeed in pro basketball.

title: TEXAS OIL & GAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
FOR SOVIET MASS CONSUMPTION
description: To the Editor:

title: The Guns of Morton Grove
description: It was gratifying to learn recently that a Federal District Court upheld a village ordinance in Morton Grove, Ill., banning the possession of handguns. Now that we've read Judge Bernard Decker's opinion, we are even more encouraged. The case marks an important advance for the cause of handgun control.

title: Required Reading
description: Mr. Reagan's Job Remarks by President Reagan and Secretary of Transportation Drew Lewis at the Department of Transportation. Jan. 12, l982: Secretary Lewis: Mr. President, we're delighted to have you with us today to meet with our department managers. And as you know, in the Department of Transportation we have an executive mobility program wherein we interchange jobs within the department. Therefore, I'm doubly delighted you're here today so you can learn firsthand about our department in case you'd like to change jobs with me.

title: AUTO SALES BY BIG 3 FALL 20.3%
description: The nation's Big Three auto manufacturers reported today that domestic sales of new cars fell 20.3 percent in the first 10 days of January, continuing a downward trend that has prevailed since last September.

title: GROUP SAID TO SEEK CHANGES IN TURKEY
description: A 21-member delegation from the Council of Europe, which came here last week to inquire into the kind of democracy planned by Turkey's military rulers, is reported to be critical of the current restrictions on democratic liberties.

title: Australia's Wheat Up
description: The Australian wheat harvest will be the third biggest on record at 16.1 million tons, the Bureau of Agricultural Economics said today . The harvest, now nearly complete, is almost 50 percent bigger than last year's drought-affected crop and slightly less than the 1979 crop of 16.2 million tons.

title: PANTRY PRIDE SUPERMARKETS reports earnings for 16 weeks to Nov 21
description: B-Includes $1.1 million tax credit...C-Includes $1 million tax credit and $1.8 million charge representing the cumulative effect of an accounting change; the 1980 results have been restated to reflect an accounting change; the company is listed on the Pacific, Boston and the Philadelphia stock exchanges

title: STRIPPED PINE COUNTRY FURNITURE: WHEN BARE BECOMES BEAUTIFUL
description: WHEN Woody Allen was planning his movie ''Interiors'' he wanted to create th e ambience of an interior designer's ultr@achic Southampton mansion.

title: SCHMIDT IN PARIS IN BID TO HEAL RIFT ON POLAND
description: Chancellor Helmut Schmidt arrived in Paris this evening to attempt to ease the tensions that have arisen between France and West Germany over a policy toward Poland.

title: Weather Cools in Australia
description: Australians who have been broiling under record summer temperatures got a bit of relief today. Summer temperatures in Sydney, Melbourne and Adelaide soared past 100 degrees Monday and Tuesday, but today the mercury plummeted to the cool 60's and 70's.

title: Just a Little More Tax-Exempt Hate
description: Having ordered a tax exemption for schools that discriminate racially in admissions, President Reagan now proposes to undo the offense by asking Congress to prohibit such rewards. But that only adds confusion to what has been an extraordinary display of contempt for morality and law.

title: HOME BEAT
description: IT is a group that is known for its parties, its preview parties and its pre-preview parties, although this year Mario Buatta, the chairman of the 28th Annual Antiques Show, was a little disappointed with the turnout last Tuesday night. Never mind. The tumbling waterfall acted as a backdrop in La Cascade restaurant in the Olympic Tower, and there was still a good crowd by nearly any standard. The show, which will run from Jan. 22 to Jan. 31 at the Seventh Regiment Armory on Park Avenue and 67th Street, benefits the East Side House Settlement, a social-service agency in the South Bronx.

title: HUFFY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 25
POLE SAYS HE CANNOT PREDICT WHEN MARTIAL LAW WILL END
description: A senior official of the Polish Government said today that pressure from the West to relax military rule was interference in Poland's internal affairs and asserted that it could not be predicted when martial law would be lifted or political detainees released.

title: Around the World; Salvador Rebels Proclaim Capture of Key Town
description: Guerrillas said today that they had captured Jocaitique, a town 100 miles northeast of the capital, after a long battle with Government troops. The assertion was denied by a military spokesman.

title: RECAPTURED SPY AND FRIENDS CHARGED WITH BANK ROBBERY
description: Christo? pher J. Boyce, the convicted Soviet spy, and two associates were indicted today by a Federal grand jury in Boise, Idaho, on bank robbery and conspiracy charges.

title: KODAK INTRODUCES AN IMPROVED LINE OF INSTANT CAMERAS
