description: The Eastman Kodak Company yesterday introduced an improved instant camera line and faster instant film to replace the Colorburst line that has fared poorly in competition with the Polaroid Corporation.

title: Ozaki and Caldwell Lead by 1 With 64's
description: The Bob Hope Desert Classic got off to a lively start in sunny mid-60's weather today with two unheralded players sharing the lead at 64.

title: AUTO WORKERS' JOBS TO DECLINE
description: The Reagan Administration said Tuesday that about half the 214,000 automobile workers now on indefinite layoff would probably never be rehired.

title: THE 'REAL HERO OF THIS'
description: There was a hero, name unknown, in today's plane crash into the iced-over water of the Potomac River.

title: No Headline
description: CELTICS' LATE SURGE ROUTS HAWKS, 116-95

title: REAGAN NEWS CURB TERMED EXTENSIVE
description: A move by President Reagan to restrict reporters' access to national security information turned out today to be far more extensive. Even officials of the Department of Agriculture were told to clear major news interviews with the White House.

title: DENIS THATCHER JOINS SEARCH FOR SON
description: Denis Thatcher, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's husband, flew to Algeria today to help press the search for their 28-year-old son, Mark, who disappeared five days ago during an auto race through the Sahara.

title: CITY CHANGES TAX PLANS FOR DEVELOPERS OF 42D ST.
description: The Koch administration, bowing to criticism from a number of city officials, has abandoned its plan to seek automatic real-estate tax abatements for a swath of the Times Square area.

title: Around the Nation; Author Yields on Order In Penthouse Libel Case
description: A new confrontation between a judge and a journalist has been avoided by a com-promise in the libel suit by the resort La Costa against Penthouse magazine.

title: G.O.P. CHIEF'S DELINQUENT LOANS TERMED PERSONAL BY WHITE HOUSE
description: A White House spokesman today shrugged off a disclosure that Richard Richards, chairman of the Republican National Committee, had been repeatedly delinquent in paying off two business loans guaranteed by the Small Business Administration.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: MOST wood glues, as well as many other adhesives, require that pressure be applied to the joint while the glue hardens or cures. Pressure can be applied by wrapping with rubber bands, placing weights on top, or even tying tightly with strong string. But the most versatile and practical method is to use some type of clamp.

title: FORD HESITATING ON G.M.-UNION PACT
description: The Ford Motor Company is balking at accepting the precedent-shattering agreement reached between the General Motors Corporation and the United Automobile Workers yesterday to tie workers' wage and benefit concessions to lower car prices for consumers.

title: 'FRIENDS' HELP BALTIMORE SYMPHONY
description: A LABOR dispute between the Baltimore Symphony Orchestra and its board has been settled with an unorthodox agreement. After nearly three months of negotiations, the difference between the offers of the orchestra's board and the demands by the players had remained at more than $650,000. But an independent group, the Friends of the Symphony, resolved the dispute by committing itself to raise that sum for the orchestra o ver the next three years.

title: A 3-RING PARTY FOR LYN NOFZIGER
description: It appeared that almost all of official Washington was preparing for a dinner-dance tonight to help bid farewell to Lyn Nofziger, the rumpled, cigar-smoking political adviser to President Reagan. He is scheduled to leave the White House Jan. 22 when he will return to private political consulting, with an office in Washington.

title: CLARA STEURERMANN
description: Clara Steurermann, archivist of the Arnold Schoenberg Institute in Los Angeles and the widow of the pianist Eduard Steuermann, died of cancer Saturday in Norwalk, Calif. She was 59 years old.

title: CONCERT: FROM YUGOSLAVIA, BRANKO KRSMANOVICH CHORUS
description: THE Branko Krsmanovich Chorus of Yugoslavia, which has won a variety of prizes around the world and is in its seventh American tour, gave a concert in Carnegie Hall Tuesday night. The chorus was founded in 1945 as a continuation of the Obilich Choir that dates back to 1884 - said to be one of Europe's old est singing groups.

title: A DEAFENING ROAR AND THEN ICY SILENCE
description: It hit the bridge with a deafening roar and then, suddenly, there was silence. There was no sound at all, those who watched said later, as the Air Florida 737 jetliner glided onto the river, skidded across the gray ice and sank slowly into the icy waters.

title: GORDON JEWELRY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: The 1980 results restated to reflect additional LIFO inventory valuations and 1980 shr earnings restated to reflect 3-for-2 stock split

title: Fiat-Allis Plans Recall of Workers
description: Fiat-Allis Construction Machinery Inc., a joint venture of the Italian auto company, Fiat, and the Allis-Chalmer s Company, said it would recall 470 workers next week towork on filli ng a $25 million order from the Soviet Union for tractors and parts.

title: DEMOLITION OF BIJOU STARTS FOR PORTMAN HOTEL
description: A bulldozer began demolishing the interior of the Bijou Theater on 45th Street west of Times Square yesterday as work started to prepare the site for a 2,020-room hotel to be built by John Portman, the Atlanta developer.

title: POLAND CRISIS APPEARS TO SLOW ANTIMISSILE PROTESTS
description: An organization called the World Peace Council held three days of meetings in Copenhagen last week focusing on NATO's plan for deploying intermediate-range nuclear missiles in Western Europe. According to reports received here, attendance and press coverage were slim.

title: RIGHTS AMENDMENT ENCOUNTERS TROUBLE IN TWO LEGISLATURES
description: By The Associated Press

title: De Beers Sales Off 46%
description: De Beers Consolidated Mines, the South African group that dominates the world market in uncut diamonds, said today that sales in 1981 fell by 46 percent, to $1.47 billion from $2.72 billion in the year before.

title: Essay; STATE OF THE MESSAGE
description: This draft is a nice try, fellas, but it's not right yet. First, I don't want to begin by twisting around and saying ''Mr. Speaker, Mr. President.'' I know the correct way to address the Vice President, when he's acting as President pro tem of the Senate, is ''Mr. President,'' but the people watching on TV are going to say ''He means Mr. Vice President -that was a boo-boo, Reagan must be nervous.'' At the same time, I don't want to say ''Mr. Vice President'' and go down in history as starting my first State of the Union with a mistake, the way Carter did. Couldn't I just say ''Mr. Speaker, George''?

title: REP. CONABLE'S DANDY DOODLES
description: The average voter often starts yawning at the first whiff of political rhetoric. Imagine what it is like for a member of Congress, who has to sit through hours and hours of meetings and hearings every week.

title: ALICO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
PRESCOTT BUSH OPENS DRIVE TO WIN WEICKER'S SEAT
description: Prescott S. Bush Jr., the brother of Vice President Bush, began his campaign tonight for the Republican nomination for the United States Senate seat held by Lowell P. Weicker Jr.

title: Around the World; Guatemala Gunmen Kill 12 Members of a Family
description: Gunmen entered a village south of here and killed 12 members of a family ranging in age from 6 to 65, military authorities reported today.

title: Scholars of the Blues T o Meet Their Subjects
description: Scholars of blues lyrics and music will meet with the artists they write about - blues performers and writers - at the Smithsonian Institution in Washington Feb. 5 to 7.

title: EQUITY LETS CROSS APPEAR OFF BROADWAY
description: In a reversal of its ruling earlier this month, Actors Equity decided yesterday to allow Ben Cross, the British actor who is starring in the film ''Chariots of Fire,'' to play a leading role in a new Off Broadway production. The play is John Guare's ''Lydie Breeze,'' and it will begin a six-week run Feb. 4 at the American Place Theater. If all goes well there, ''Lydie Breeze'' is expected to move to Broadway.

title: STATE BILL ASKS PAYLESS LEAVES TO CUT LAYOFFS
description: The State Budget Director, C. Mark Lawton, submitted legislation today that would allow the state to shorten its employees' paid work weeks in an attempt to ''minimize layoffs.''

title: INTERMAGNETICS GENERAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
CORRECTIONS
description: An article in The Living Section yes- terday about a food book sale gave an incorrect address for the Corner Book Shop. It is at 102 Fourth Avenue, near 11th Street.

title: CALENDAR OF EVENTS: ARCHITECT'S WORKS
description: City Dwellings and Country Houses: Robert Adam and His Style, the Cooper-Hewitt Museum, 2 East 91st Street.

title: GEORGETOWN BEATS SETON HALL, 62-60, FOR 13TH IN ROW
description: Dan Callandrillo, the senior guard whose last-second shots have won three games for Seton Hall this season, had the ball tonight when Seton Hall needed a basket to tie Georgetown and the scoreboard clock above reached one second.

title: Sports of The Times; Nine Votes From Unanimous
description: NINE has always been an important number in baseball. Nine players. Nine innings. And now another nine has emerged, the nine members of the Baseball Writers Associati on who did not vote for Henry Aaron on this year's Hall of Fame ballot. Henry Aaron was elected, of course, along with Frank Robinson, but somehow the ni ne votes that Henry Aaron did not receive seem more significant t han the 406 he did receive. To think that nine presumably respon sible voters would deem Henry Aaron unworthy of the Hall of Fame is, in a word, preposterous.Almost scandalous.

title: Pornographer Loses Appeal
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit on Monday upheld the 1979 racketeering conviction of Michael Thevis, an Atlanta pornographer, and two co-defendants, Jeannette Evans and Bart Hood. They were convicted of conspiring to murder Roger Dean Underhill, a former Thevis associate, to prevent his testimony on racketeering charges against Mr. Thevis. All three were sentenced to life in prison.

title: BONN TO HONOR CONTRACTS FOR SIBERIAN GAS PIPELINE
description: The West German Government indicated today that it would do nothing to hinder West German companies from sidestepping the effects of American sanctions on the construction of a natural gas pipeline from Siberia to Western Europe.

title: HERS
description: ''DO you have any children?'' ''No,'' I say, ''but I have some I am interested in.'' There are people in this world who are neither emotional freaks nor physical failures, but who, for reasons of temperament and circumstance, choose not to become parents. I am one of these. Yet I seem to be collecting, through a process of elective affinities, a little family of children I hope to know all my life.

title: Parker Pen Net Down
description: The Parker Pen Company reported yesterday that net income in the third quarter dropped by 66.7 percent, to $5.2 million, or 30 cents a share, from $15.6 million, or 93 cents a share, in the corresponding quarter a year earlier. Sales of the Janesville, Wis., company slipped by 9.1 percent, to $184.5 million from $202.9 million in the period, which ended Nov. 30.

title: Notes on People; 18 Connecticut Authors Join in Nonfiction Effort
description: A bit of literature composed especially for the Speaker of the Connecticut House of Representatives and two other members of the state's General Assembly bore the names of an unusual collection of celebrated authors.

title: Around the World
description: An Algerian diplomat was found slain today after he was reportedly abducted last night from his home here.

title: South Korea's Currency
description: The South Korean won is expected to fall 6 percent in relation to the American dollar during 1982, Korea's central bank said today. The won depreciated 6 percent last year.

title: HORIZON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Quotation of the Day
description: ''It was so loud, I couldn't hear myself scream. And then, there was no sound.

title: Germans to Try 3-D TV In Two-Program Test
description: Three-dimensional television will be available to West Germans for the first time next month when a trial 3-D program is begun by a Hamburg station.

title: North Sea Oil
description: Texaco Inc. said that 1982 oil production from the Tartan Field in the British North Sea would be lower than it had anticipated. It said average production in 1982, which had been expected to reach 49,000 barrels a day, is now expected to be only 15,000 to 20,000 barrels a day, depending on the effectiveness of water injection. The company attributed the anticipated production decline to ''geologic complexities'' of the reservoir.

title: U.S. AIDES BELIEVE PERIL OF LIBYAN ATTACK ON THE PRESIDENT EASES
description: Senior Administration officials say the threat of a terrorist attack against President Reagan by a Libyan assassination team has apparently receded.

title: ADVERTISING
description: Y.& R. Handles Kodamatic Ads

title: A SOLIDARITY LEADER RECANTS STATEMENT SUPPORTING MILITARY
description: The regional chief of Solidarity in Poznan today publicly recanted a statement supporting martial law, and said it had been written under duress.

title: HAIG ASSERTS CAIRO AGREES TO HASTEN PALESTINE TALKS
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. said today that he had obtained President Hosni Mubarak's agreement for an intensified effort in coming months to achieve a breakthrough in the negotiations with Israel on Palestinian self-rule in the West Bank and the Gaza Strip.

title: Polish Grain Crop Up
description: Poland's 1981 grain crop of 20 million tons was up 11 percent from 1980 but still fell well short of demand, an agriculture newsletter, Agra Europe, reported today. The newsletter said that Poland would have to import 7 million tons of grain to meet demand. It added that meat shortages last year were ''only partly offset'' by imports, which in the first nine months of the year ''reached the unprecedented level of 101,000 tons, 19 times more than during the same period in 1980.''

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, JANUARY 14, 1982
description: International Talks on Palestinian self-rule are to be intensified, according to Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. After a 90-minute meeting with President Hosni Mubarak in Cairo, Mr. Haig said that the Egyptian leader had agreed to accelerate the negotiations to try to resolve the 20-month stalemate over autonomy for the Arabs in the Israeli-occupied territories. (Page A1, Col. 1.) More curbs on Soviet trade, especially on the shipment of hightechnology products and oil and gas equipment, are to be sought by the Reagan Administration in talks with Washington's allies. The Administration has apparently concluded that trade yields few benefits to the West and has helped the Soviet Union improve its military capacity to a point where it is a rising threat to Western security. (A1:2.)

title: WITNESS IN ABBOTT TRIAL TELLS OF NIGHT OF MURDER
description: The prosecution at the murder trial of Jack Henry Abbott concluded its case yesterday with seemingly unshakable testimony from an eyewitness who said that he had seen the prison author stab a retreating East Village waiter from behind last summer and then shout ''very sadistically'' at the victim.

title: WHERE TO FIND PINE FURNITURE
description: Following are some dealers who carry a selection of stripped pine furniture: Balasses House, Main Street and Hedges Lane, Amagan- sett, L.I. (516-267-3032).

title: EARLY MORNING RATINGS RACE
description: As NBC's ''Today'' program marks its 30th birthday this week, it has entered a new phase in its competition with two early-morning television rivals -ABC's ''Good Morning America'' and CBS's ''Morning.'' A new team of ''Today'' co-anchors is in the saddle, and the advertising salesmen are in full cry.

title: REDMAN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1
description: B-Net income; 1980 results have been restated

title: NOTED SURGEON TREATED SHAH
description: Dr. Frank Glenn, an internationally known authority on surgery who retired in 1967 as chairman of the department of surgery and surgeon in chief at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, died Tuesday at the center after a short illness. He was 80 years old and a resident of Manhattan.

title: Improved Method Is Reported On the Use of Fertility Drugs
description: Australian researchers say they have developed an improved method of using fertility drugs that should make it easier for some women to conceive children despite problems with ovulation.

title: THE TRIAL OF SPAIN'S FUTURE
description: Spa in's impending entry into the North Atlantic Treaty Organization will end its military and political isolation from postwar Europe. When it obtains its next goal, admission to the Common Market, its ties to the rest of the Continent will be further strengthened. But Spain's principle contribution to the stabilization of Europe will lie in preserving equilibrium in its own internal affairs.

title: DEAF BOY DIAGNOSED AS RETARDED IN ERROR IS GIVEN $2.5 MILLION
description: New York State was ordered yesterday to pay $2.5 million to a 19-year-old man who spent nearly nine years in facilities for the mentally retarded when in fact he was only deaf.

title: Notes on People; Oklahoman's Goal: Sunset for Rising-Sun Licenses
description: In Oklahoma City, a state representative has i ntroduced a bill in the legislatu re that would outlaw the further use of a symbolic representatio n of the rising sun on Oklahoma license plates. ''The people who designed and approved this tag obviously did not re member Pearl Harbor,'' the Republican legislator, Frank W. Davis, sa id yesterday.

title: Consolidated Capital Appoints President
description: John Lie-Nielsen has been named president of the Consolidated Capital Equities Corporation, a leading sponsor of real estate investment trusts and limited partnerships that is based in Emeryville, Calif. He succeeds Marvin T. Levin, who resigned, according to a spokesman, ''to free up some time for his personal interests.''

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: GREAT HALLS

title: GARDENING
description: AJADE plant is easy to grow. Give it full sun, water it now and then, and maybe add a dash of water-soluble house plant fertilizer upon occasion. The plant will grow for years of pleasure. And if all goes well, the jade may even offer a special reward, late fall bloom.

title: CONRAIL: WALL ST. GETS ABROAD
description: With its troubled history, Conrail has hardly been a name to bring a glint to the eyes of Wall Street's deal makers. Even so, investment bankers are beating a path to Conrail's door, vying for a piece of business - the Government's sale of Conrail - that could bring some of the highest fees in the history of Wall Street.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Letter: On Deregulation Congress Wants Trucking Limits
description: To the Editor: It is an incredible experience to read an editorial concerning a subject with which one is intimately involved and to wonder if the editorial writer was motivated by some political belief or information from an uninformed source (''Trucking Along - Against Deregulation'' Dec. 24).

title: BENGALS' WILLIAMS AN IVY LINEBACKER WHO HAS WON RESPECT
description: You don't have to earn a bachelor's degree in psychology from Dartmouth in three and a half years to play in the Super Bowl. But, as Reggie Williams will testify, it helps.

title: GANDHI ALLY QUITS AFTER CONVICTION
description: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi accepted the resignation of a close political supporter Tuesday night after he was found guilty of extortion.

title: VIRGINIA VILLAGERS USE PRAYER IN BID TO STOP POWER PROJECT
description: A delegation of 70 residents of Brumley Gap in western Virginia tried the power of prayer today in an effort to persuade the Federal Government to block a hydroelectric project that would drown the village and their valley.

title: Msgr. Francis W. Kelly Dies; Was 'Father Foxhole' in War
description: Msgr. Francis W. Kelly, the ''Father Foxhole'' of World War II who insisted on frontline duty with the Marines, died in Tri-City Hospital here Saturday of a heart attack.

title: BRIEFS
description: * A.G. Edwards & Sons Inc. said it had agreed in principle to acquire Burbank & Co., a closely held brokerage firm in Boston. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Israeli Will Head United Merchants
description: Uzi Ruskin, leader of an investment group that owns 22.4 percent of United Merchants and Manufacturers Inc., a major textile company, has been elected president and chief operating officer.

title: JAIL TERMS ORDERED FOR 2 FOUND GUILTY OF BRIBERY CHARGES
description: Carlos Marcello, who the Federal authorities assert is a major organized crime figure, and a former top state official were sentenced today for conspiring to use bribery to gain millions of dollars in state insurance contracts.

title: MANILA CURBS FOREIGN PRESS IN DISAPPEARANCE CASE
description: The Philippine Government blocked the distribution this week of foreign newspapers and magazines that carried accounts of the disappearance of a divorced athlete who secretly married a daughter of President Ferdinand E. Marcos on Dec. 4.

title: DESIGN NOTEBOOK
description: ARCHITECTURE in a dense, built-up place like Manhattan is essentially a matter of facades. By that I mean we do not tend to see most buildings in the city as complete shapes - the profiles of the Empire State Building or the Woolworth Building stand out, of course, but the typical apartment house or office block or brownstone house presents itself to us in a much less complete manner.

title: LEUKEMIA ADVANCE REPORTED
description: Bone marrow transplants can be used to delay and perhaps prevent the deaths of patients with slow-moving, chronic leukemia, which until now has always been considered fatal, a recent study suggests.

title: RIEGEL TEXTILE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 2
description: B-Includes $6,232,000 gain from an accounting change

title: INTERNATIONAL MINERALS' NET UP
description: The International Minerals and Chemical Corporation yesterday reported a 66.6 profit rise for its second fiscal quarter, ended Dec. 31, although sales dropped 17 percent.

title: Sports People; Foyt Revving Up
description: A.J. Foyt, still nursing a sore right arm incurred during a serious accident six months ago in an Indy-car race in Michigan, has decided to make a comeback in the Daytona 500 on Feb. 14 - against the advice of his physicians. ''I guess I decided to make Daytona my first race because if you can run here, you can run anywhere,'' said Foyt, 46 and the winner of four Indianapolis 500 races.

title: MCI NET INCREASES SHARPLY
description: The MCI Communications Corporation, the leading long-distance telephone competitor of the Bell System, yesterday reported that net income and revenues rose sharply in its most recent quarter.

title: 20-Year Congressman Shuns Race for a Redistricted Seat
description: Redistricting of Congressional s eats required by the 1980 census took its first prominent victi m when Representative Robert McClory, Republican of Illinois, ann ounced today that he would retire to avoid running against agains t another incumbent 28 years younger.

title: Price Cutting By Retailers
description: Edward F. Gibbons, chairman and chief executive officer of the F.W. Woolworth Company, yesterday told a news conference in New York that the current price promotions in retailing would continue indefinitely until ''there is a prolonged period of confidence on the part of the consumer.''

title: WASHINGTON FOLLOW-UP
description: Washington Follow-Up 'Wasteland' Revisited

title: CHINA WARNS U.S. TIES FACE 'RIGOROUS TEST'
description: China, reiterating its angry objection to the proposed sale of United States jet fighters to Taiwan, today accused the Reagan Administration of ''going too far'' by announcing its decision while the American and Chinese Governments were still consulting on the matter.

title: Northern Foods To Buy Keystone
description: The Keystone Foods Corporation said it had reached an agreement in principle to be acquired by Northern Foods Ltd. of Great Britain in a cash transaction valued at $69.1 million.

title: 2,500 IN LOS ANGELES MOURN 15 IRANIAN BAHAIS
description: More than 2,500 people, including many exiled Iranians, joined in a solemn afternoon of prayer, song and remembrance this week for 15 members of the Bahai faith who have been slain in recent weeks by firing squads in Iran.

title: BLACK POET, AN EXILE FOR 10 YEARS, BATTLES U.S. DEPORTATION TO AFRICA
description: For the last 10 years, since arriving in the United States as an exile after being shot by the secret police and imprisoned in South Africa, the black poet Dennis Brutus has been a professor of English at Northwestern University in Evanston, Ill.

title: Anheuser-Busch Has Record Sales
description: The Anheuser-Busch Companies reported selling a record 54.5 million barrels of beer last year, up 8.6 percent from the 50.2 million barrels sold in 1980.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By John Leonard THE AGE OF DESIRE. Case Histories of a Radical Psychoanalyst. By Joel Kovel. 282 pages. Pantheon. $16.50.

title: HOCKEY PLAYERS COMPETE IN 40'S AND RECALL 20'S
description: Hours past sunset on the coldest day in a year, the gentlemen commuters of this affluent village metamorphosed into a championship hockey team beside an empty skating rink beneath the full moon.

title: Marathon Oil Meeting Set
description: A special meeting to allow shareholders of the Marathon Oil Company to vote on the merger with the United States Steel Corporation will be held here March 11, Marathon officials said. Shareholders of record as of Jan. 25 will be eligible to vote.

title: MCI COMMUNICATIONS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After a tax credit of $1,196,000

title: Sports People; Borg Takes to Ice
description: Bjorn Borg has returned to one of his former loves - hockey - as a means of adding to his physical strength for the 1982 tennis season.

title: WAUGH'S 'BRIDESHEAD' COMING TO TV
description: WITH ''Brideshead Revisited,'' Evelyn Waugh, the masterful satirist who had chronicled the frivolities of the Bright Young People in such novels as ''Decline and Fall,'' became a romantic moralist. For all its detailing of the glittering aristocratic life, ''Brideshead'' was actually a study in the workings of memory and the operation of divine grace - the first work in which Waugh, a new convert to Catholicism, defined the dimensions of his faith. It would also prove to be his most popular book, establishing his reputation in England and abroad as one of the pre-eminent writers of his generation.

title: PLANE HITS BRIDGE OVER THE POTOMAC, 12 DEAD, 50 MISSING
description: An Air Florida jetliner taking off from National Airport in a snowstorm crashed into a crowded bridge this afternoon and broke as it plunged into the Potomac River, leaving at least 12 people dead and more than 50 missing, according to unofficial police estimates.

title: France to Cut Work Week
description: The Government today approved legislation to reduce the official length of the work week to 39 hours from 40, a presidential spokesman said.

title: Bridge: A Stretch to Win 10 Tricks Is Possible if 8 Are Certain
description: A bridge adage states that ''where there are eight there are nine.'' This means that an expert who can count eight sure tricks can generally find a maneuver that will produce one more to make his contract. There are plenty of deals, however, on which a declarer who goes in with eight comes out with the same number.

title: President O f Schering A dds a Post
description: At the Schering-Plough Corporation, Robert P. Luciano, the 48-yearold president, has been named to the added position of chief executive officer, effective Feb. 1. H e will succeed Richard J. Bennett, who will reach 65 on Jan. 20 and who will remain as chairman.

title: U.S. REPORTS POLISH CURBS AT EMBASSIES
description: The State Department said today that the Polish Government tightened access to diplomatic offices in Warsaw over the weekend, barring foreigners from entering Western embassies other than that of their own nation.

title: Notes on People; B elafonte to Get King Nonviolent Peace Prize
description: The 10th annual Martin Luther King King Jr. Non violent Peace Prize will be presented today to Harry Belafonte, t he singer and actor who has been a longtime civil rights activist.

title: Briefing
description: D URING the prolonged Congressional recess, groups favoring abortion rights have launched an unusual grass-roots campaign to head off a major effort expected in the next few months to restrict a woman's right to terminate a pregnancy.

title: Advertising; Pan Am Switch Disquieting
description: BY yesterday, the weekend's news of Pan American's second agency switch in eight months had sunken into the consciousnesses of the movers and shakers on Madison Avenue. They are appalled.

title: THRIFTY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
CIVIL RIGHTS GROUPS ACT TO BALK NEW TAX POLICY
description: A civil rights group asked a Federal district judge here today to bar the Reagan Administration from carrying out a policy of granting tax exemptions to private schools that discriminate on racial grounds.

title: Kayser-Roth Deal
description: Gulf and Western Industries said that its Kayser-Roth Corporation unit signed an exclusive licensing agreement with Jonathan Logan Inc. Under the agreement, Kayser-Roth becomes the sole licensee of women's clothing sold under the Jonathan Logan label. Terms of the agreement were not disclosed. Gulf and Western said the primary customer for the merchandise will be t he K Mart Corporatio n

title: Demonstrators in Amsterdam Protest Eviction of Squatters
description: About 150 protesters set up barricades on one of Amsterdam's main thoroughfares today after the police evicted a dozen squatters from a row of condemned houses.

title: PIANIST: SYLVIA ZAREMBA
description: WHEN she was young, Sylvia Zaremba built up a rock-solid piano technique in 13 years of study with the late Isabella Vengerova, and at Alice Tully Hall on Tuesday night, that technique stood Miss Zaremba in particularly good stead. Faced with a formidable program to play at the end of a day of illness, she tackled it forthrightly and was able to make her way through it - or most of it, anyway - remarkably well.

title: Events Put Off by Storm
description: Several harness racing programs, college basketball games and an indoor soccer match in the metropolitan area were called off last night because of the snowstorm.

title: Illinois Utility Sales Outlook
description: The Commonwealth Edison Company, the electric utility serving Chicago and northern Illinois, expects revenues to rise 2 percent in 1982 above the approximately $3.5 billion generated in 1981, company officials said in New York.

title: RANGERS BEAT NORTH STARS, 2-0
description: Avenging a 7-0 rout they endured here in October, the Rangers defeated the North Stars, 2-0, tonight on goals by Pat Hickey and Ron Duguay.

title:
PICK OUT A HOUSE AND TAKE IT HOME;
STOCKTON, Calif.
description: IN a housi n g market as tight as designer jeans, Tony Lozano fancieshimself a mod ern day Robin Hood. Mr. Lozano, a mustachioed contractorraised in the Los Angeles area, saves homes from the wrecker's ball only to sell them for a fraction of the price of a new home to what he calls ''th e hard-working little folks like you and me.''

title: Rumania Reviews Debt
description: Rumania is unlikely to seek new credits or ask that its debts to Western banks be rescheduled during current talks in Bucharest with representatives of nine Western banks, French banking sources said today. Rumania's economic and financial situation is being reviewed at the talks, the sources said. Rumania, whose debt is estimated at $10 billion, is in a stronger position than Poland because of its membership in the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank, the sources said.

title: LYMAN WALBRIDGE
description: Lyman Walbridge, a center and guard on the original New York Giants, died Monday in California.

title: AN EMINENT YUGOSLAV HISTORIAN UNDER FIRE
description: To the Editor:

title: A GOOD HEALTH-CARE DEAL FOR EAST HARLEM
description: To the Editor:

title: A SLIM 0.4% SALES GAIN AT RETAIL
description: Retail sales rose only four-tenths of one percent in December, with a late Christmas surge failing to offset sluggish sales earlier in the month, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Around the Nation; Illinois Repeals Law On Machine-Gun Use
description: The Illinois House and Senate voted in rapid succession today to repeal a new state law that allowed private citizens to own machine guns.

title: SHELDAHL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov
People
description: * Jerry Harmon has joined Greenstone & Rabasca Advertising as executive vice president and director of creative services.

title: STATES FIGHT EXCISE TAX RISE
description: Gov. Richard A. Snelling of Vermont, speaking on behalf of the nation's governors, urged President Reagan today to reject proposals for an increase in Federal excise taxes.

title: AGING, CROWDED FIELD HAS HAD GOOD RECORD
description: Although long denounced by airline pilots and local residents as dangerous, Washington's aging and overcrowded but exceptionally convenient National Airport has had an excellent safety record.

title: CHARLES GILMAN OF PAPER CONCERN
description: Charles Gilman Jr., president of the Gilman Paper Company, the largest privately owned concern in the industry, died yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital at the age of 51. He maintained homes in Manhattan, Yulee, Fla., and Gilman, Vt.

title: Notes on People; Applying Technology in the Desert
description: For the last 30 years, he has been a key figure in transforming Israeli desert into Israeli farmland, and that, Menahem Perlmutter noted the other day, is no job for a farmer.

title: Pakistani-Indian Talks
description: Foreign Minister Agha Shahi of Pakistan will hold talks in New Delh i Jan. 29 with his Indian counterpart, P.V. Narasimha Rao, on a security pact between the two neighboring countries.

title: PITTSBURGH BREWING CO reports earnings for Yr to Oct 31
description: B-Includes $400,700 tax credit...C-Includes $565,300 tax credit and $157,115 cummulative effect on prior yrs accounting change

title: JAZZ SEXTET: CHICO FREEMAN
description: THE sextet that Chico Freeman is leading at Lush Life, the jazz club at Bleecker and Thompson Streets through Sunday, is made up of strong musical personalities who play with great exuberance but has not yet discovered the merits of brevity. At their opening on Tuesday, when all their selections ran on for more than half an hour, they diluted their potential effectiveness by spreading their ideas too thin.

title: PARKER PEN CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: The 1980 results have been restated to reflect an accounting change

title: THE RECORD HIGHS AT 1981 AUCTIONS
description: THE Duke of Windsor's 18th-century English desk, which sold at auction in 1957 for $4,760, brought $860,000 in October at Christie's, establishing an auction record for English furniture. The Duke's desk was only one of a score or more of antiques and decorative objects that toppled records last year in public sales throughout the world, proof that quality offerings continue to command stunning prices in spite of the recession.

title: Market Place; Concentrating
description: WHAT would happen if a mutual fund defied tradition and concentrated assets in a few holdings? For one thing, the managers of the fund would open themselves to criticism for failing to limit risk.

title: Miss Soerensen Takes Downhill in Switzerland
description: Gerry Soerensen of Canada edged Marie-Cecile Gros of France by slightly more than three-tenths of a second today in a World Cup downhill ski race.

title: Around the Nation; 38 Persons Indicted In Philadel phia Inquiry
description: Thirty-eight persons, including an associate of Angelo Bruno, the slain crime chief, were indicted today on charges of supplying chemicals used to make an estimated $500 million worth of illegal drugs.

title: The U.N. Today; Jan 14, 1982; SECURITY COUNCIL
description: Meets on the annexation of the Golan Heights at 3:30 P.M. GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: CALIFORNIA JUDGES GET DISTRICTS CASE
description: The California Supreme Court, its image already heavily politicized, now faces a complicated case arising from a Republican attempt to upset the Democrats' plan to reapportion the Legislature and the state's 45 Congressional seats.

title: F-15'S ARE FLOWN TO SAUDI ARABIA
description: The first six F-15 fi ghters involved in a politically sensitive sale to Saudi Arabia le ft today for Riyadh. Spokesmen for the McDonnnell Douglas Corpor ation and the Air Force said the six planes were flown from St. Louis , where they were made, by United States Air Force pilots.

title: Q & A
description: Q. Our bathroom is covered with blue ceramic tile, and the white grout between these tiles in the shower is very dirty looking. I have scrubbed it several times and have used mildew-removing solutions sold for use on tile, but none of this has solved the problem. I am now convinced it is not mildew but some other reason for the discoloration. Interestingly enough, the grout in the area directly under the soap dish is not discolored. Do you have any suggestions as to what I can do? - L.R.B., Manhattan.

title: News An alysis
description: Everything from auto license plates to government stationery proclaims this country to be ''free Nicaragua,'' but the reality is that its fortunes are dependent upon other countries, particularly the United States.

title: Reagan Names Career Officer As Ambassador to Nicaragua
description: President Reagan today named Anthony Cecil Eden Quainton, a 48-year-old career Foreign Service officer, to be Ambassador to Nicaragua. He was previously director of the State Department's Working Group on Terrorism,

title: UNBENDING BOB JONES U. IS AGAIN FOCUS OF FUROR
description: There is nothing new from Bob Jones University. The students are still not allowed to dance, drink, smoke, be together male and female of an afternoon - be together on a date ever if their complexions do not match - grow hair on their jowls or, if they be women, wear slacks unless the occasion makes trousers more modest than dresses down to the shins.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rate payable by savings institutions.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: HEAD OF L.I. TEAMSTER LOCAL INDICTED IN RACKETS INQUIRY
description: The president of a Long Island-based teamster union local was indicted yesterday on Federal racketeering, extortion and tax-evasion charges after a four-year investigation of his affairs and those of his 5,000-member local.

title: DON'T HOLD RELIGION AGAINST A JUDGE
description: To the Editor:

title: WOMAN SHOT AND ROBBED OF 50
description: A 17-year-old youth was charged yesterday with shooting a woman in the head and stealing her purse, which contained only 50 c ents. The woman, who is 31 and has an 8-year-old son, was in critical conditionat Kings Coun ty Hospital.

title: A.T.&T.'s FINANCING CUT FROM 1981 LEVEL
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company announced yesterday that its external financing needs for this year would drop by nearly $2 billion, partly because more liberal depreciation allowances were making more cash available to the company.

title: Accounts
description: * Changing Times magazine to Bradley, Dimmock & Hungerford. * The Detroit News to N.W. Ayer, Detroit.

title: STAGE: 'THE ROVER,' OF 17th CENTURY
description: WASHINGTON APHRA BEHN (1640-89) was, as the history books characterize her, the first Englishwoman to earn her living by the pen. In the Dark Ages of female repression, it was as if she were fighting with a sword. A contemporary of Moliere and Wycherley, Mrs. Behn wrote many novels and at least 15 plays, the most famous of which is ''The Rover; or, the Banished Cavaliers.'' She became a popular and successful dramatist. However, in more recent times, her work has been considered historical rather than playable.

title: BUSINESS PLAN CUTS IN OUTLAYS
description: Executives of American companies plan to spend less this year than last on building expansion and new equipment, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: MALONE & HYDE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 21
description: B-Includes $994,000 gain from the sale of a subsidiary

title: CONSERVATIVES' TARGETS BATTLE BACK
description: If you are a group of ardent conservative activists and have just helped defeat four of the most prominent liberal Democrats in the Senate, what do you do for an encore?

title: ORIOLES INTRIGUE JACKSON
description: Reggie Jackson said yesterday that he considered the Baltimore Orioles an attractive team to play for next year because the Orioles would give him the opportunity to be an outfielder as well as a designated hitter and because they would be a contending team in the same division as the Yankees.

title: VERY REAL DANGERS IN THE WORKING PLACE
description: To the Editor:

title: TARGET: U.S. GUN LAW
description: The gun lobby, its finger on the trigger, is training its sights on public safety.

title: 'Delmore,' One Acters, To Bow at Jewish Rep
description: The Jewish Repertory Theater will present the premieres of two oneact plays Feb. 5 in a program entitled ''Delmore.''

title: MICHIGAN'S TROUBLES HIT HIGH SCHOOLS IN PONTIAC
description: Homecoming came and went at Pontiac's two high schools last October, with no football, no parades and no bands.

title: CONNORS, MCENROE AND LENDL TRIUMPH
description: Can one shot in the middle of a tennis match dramatically affect the performances of the players? Ivan Lendl's 4-6, 7-5, 6-2 victory over Vitas Gerulaitis in the $400,000 Volvo Masters tournament at Madison Square Garden last night appeared to answer that question.

title: Derailment in Subway In Washington Kills 3
description: About half an hour after an Air Florida plane crashed into the traffic-jammed 14th Street Bridge, and about half a mile away, Washington's Metro subway system had the first fatal accident in its six years of operation.

title: Japan's Shipbuilding Off
description: Foreign orders received by Japanese shipbuilders in 1981 declined 18 percent from 1980, to 5.3 million gross tons, the Japan Ship Exports Association said today. Foreign orders received in December fell 67 percent, to 204,000 gross tons, from the previous December and were down 38 percent from the previous month, the association said.

title: French Railway in Red
description: SNCF, the French state railway, will report a loss of $380 million for 1981, Andre Chadeau, its president, said today at a news conference. The company will have to rely on the capital markets, he said, to finance all of this year's $1.5 billion of outlays, despite an increase in subsidies from the Government.

title: Abroad at Home; REAGAN GETS IT RIGHT
description: It is a month since the nightmare descended on Poland. If anyone in the West thought there was an easy way for us to help the Polish people, that illusion must be long gone. The choices are difficult, our influence less than decisive, the interests of Western countries diverse.

title: The City; Unions Ask News N ot to Sell Paper
description: The unions at The Daily News asked that the owners of the newspaper reconsider their decision to sell the daily, which the unions said made money in the last four months of 1981.

title: Morgan's Earnings Up 35.4% in Quarter
description: J.P. Morgan & Company, the corporate parent of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, reported yesterday that its fourth-quarter operating earnings soared by 35.4 percent, to $124.7 million, from $92.1 million in the comparable period of 1980, largely because of a jump in net interest income.

title: The City; Koch Discusses N. A.A.C.P. Offices
description: Mayor Koch met with Benjamin L. Hooks, executive director of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, and discussed helping the association keep its headquarters in the city.

title: Qaddafi Reported Hurt In Attack Last Month
description: An officer in the Libyan Army wounded Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi last month in an attempt to assassinate the Libyan leader, the Sudanese press agency reported today.

title: Around the World; U.S. and South Africa Open Talks on Namibia
description: United States and South African officials opened two days of talks here today aimed at pushing forward delicate plans for independence of South-West Africa, which is also known as Namibia.

title: AUTOCLAVE ENGINEERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Japan Obtains Oil Discount
description: A group of Japanese oil companies signed a contract with Iraq for crude oil at an effective discount of about 90 cents a barrel, a trade publication based in New York said yesterday.

title: AARON, ROBINSON IN HALL OF FAME
description: Henry Aaron, baseball's career home run leader, and Frank Robinson, the only player to be voted Most Valuable Player in both leagues, were voted into the Hall of Fame yesterday in their first year of eligibility.

title: MERGER TO MAKE HARVARD GIFT WORTH $77 MILLION
description: Harvard University disclosed today that, as a result of a merger agreement, a bequest by an alumnus 15 years ago had become what is believed to be the largest single gift in the history of American education.

title: Pratt & Whitney Jet To Be in Use in Mid-1984
description: The Pratt & Whitney Aircraft Group said today that its new, fuel-efficient jet engine, the PW-2037, should be ready for commercial flights by mid-1984.

title: Caterpillar Sets Illinois Layoffs
description: The Caterpillar Tractor Company will lay off 11,200 workers for one week beginning Feb. 1 at its Peoria and Joliet plants to balance inventory, officials said.

title: THE BEST INVESTMENT TO AID THE HOMELESS
description: To the Editor:

title: Hepburn Illness Cancels A 'Waltz' Performance
description: Because Katharine Hepburn was suffering fro m a ''very bad sore throat,'' last night's performance of ''The W est Side Waltz'' was canceled at the Ethel Barrymore Theater.

title: BROKERS' RESERVES
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday approved a rule change that will free an estimated $500 million in ''customer protection'' funds held in reserve by Wall Street brokerage and investment houses -capital that may be used to expand greatly the scope of the industry's underwriting and marketing activities.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Diagnostics Corp., Newport Beach, Calif., has named Ronald H. Coelyn president and chief operating officer. * Bristol-Myers Co. has elected Giulio Vita a vice president.

title: 'Grown Ups' Will Close Unless Sales Pick Up
description: ''Grown Ups,'' the comedy by Jules Feiffer about the generation clash within a family, will close after Saturday evening's performance at the Lyceum Theater unless business improves.

title: HELPFUL HARDWARE
description: STORES specializing in decorative hardware report an increasing demand for Oriental-style furniture and door accessories during the last few years. While the purpose of such items in Oriental decor is obvious, people seem to have found other imaginative applications.

title: CANADA'S STRATFORD TO MOUNT 10 PLAYS
description: TORONTO FOR its 30th anniversary season next summer, Canada's Stratford Festival has announced a 20-week program of 10 productions in three theaters. The list of performers and directors includes Brian Bedford, Douglas Campbell, Len Cariou, Tammy Grimes and Carole Shelley.

title: FAST EXPANSION BROUGHT PROFITS AT AIR FLORIDA
description: Air Florida System Inc., which was a small regional airline until the last few years, expanded rapidly after the airline industry was deregulated. Its spectacular growth was a factor last summer in Pan American World Airways' decision to name as its new chairman and chief executive officer C. Edward Acker, Air Florida's chairman.

title: A Dose of Self-Help in Detroit
description: A union deal that reduces wage demands in exchange for price cuts should be good for General Motors - and for the country. The United Auto Workers and the auto companies collaborated for years in policies that drove up wages and prices together. Now that they recognize the damage done, in inflation and loss of sales to the Japanese, they at least deserve credit for innovative cooperation that points in the other direction.

title: Meadowlands Boycott By Drivers Is Averted
description: Meadowlands Race Track reached a tentative agreement with the Standardbred Breeders and Owners Association of New Jersey late today, averting a boycott by trainers and drivers.

title: Index; International
description: Denis Thatcher joins search for son A3 Philippines blocks foreign reports on athlete's disappearance A3 Commuter rail strike snarls Brit- ain A3 The first 6 of 60 F-15's are flown from U.S. to Saudi Arabia A4 Supporter of Mrs. Gandhi resigns after extortion conviction A5 Polish aide says he can't predict when martial law will end A6 Government/Politics President's curb on news ''leaks'' seen as widespread A17 Supreme Court backs police search rights A18 Bill would let state shorten its em- ployees' paid work week B2 Washington Talk Briefing A16 Problems of the conservative political action committee A16 Barber Conable's doodles A16 Required Reading A16 Washington Follow-Up A16 General Around the Nation A10 Furor over tax status of Bob Jones University A10 Youth accused of shooting woman and robbing her of 50 cents B2 Education/Welfare Merger makes Harvard bequest the largest ever giv en to school A11 Public schools in Pontiac, Mich., learn to get by on much less A20 Wagner says city's poor will get health care despite cuts B3 PARKING REGULATIONS Because of snow, alternate-side parking is suspended in New York City today. All other rules remain in effect. Home Section Home Stripped-pine country furni- ture: bare becomes beautiful C1

title: HAEMONETICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
A LAW TO AUGMENT PHONE DEAL SOUGHT
description: The proposed settlement of the antitrust suit against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company has increased, not lessened, the need for legislation, a key member of the House said today.

title: SOUTH SUFFERING
description: The second blanket of snow in 24 hours covered the New York metropolitan area last night, and back-to-back storms in the South and Northeast sent the death toll nationwide to at least 65 persons.

title: Funds' Assets Up $2.4 Billion
description: Assets of the nation's money market funds rose $2.4 billion in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday. The funds' total assets now stand at $186.8 billion, after two weeks of gains that have followed the seasonal decline in fund assets at the end of last year.

title: NORSTAR BANCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PHILHARMONIC: FOR MEZZO AND CELLIST
description: THE New York Philharmonic's program last night had a haphazard look to it, but peculiarly built concerts can sometimes turn out to be thoroughly wonderful. Who, after all, wants his expectations fulfilled every time exactly on schedule? Still, Zubin Mehta began rather inauspiciously with a rough and inelegant performance of Mozart's Symphony No. 25 (K. 16 3), the so-cal led ''Little G Minor.'' The conductor ran through the score with a st rong emphasis on its stormy vigor and unusual directness of expres sion, a perfectly valid approach to this potent work. But Mozart's ex citement is always more beneath the surface of his music, churning aw ay, and to blunt his phrases and overlook his concern for finespun tone is to distort him to no good purpose.

title: NEW HEAD OF ARTS FUND ASKS STRONGER FEDERAL-PRIVATE TIES
description: Francis S.M. Hodsoll, the new chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts, came to town yesterday from Washington with a call for stronger collaboration between government and the private sector in financing the arts. Addressing corporate executives and leaders in the arts at a luncheon at the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, 522 Fifth Avenue, Mr. Hodsoll said: ''We have a common objective.

title: POLISH WORKER TELLS OF STREET BATTLES IN GDANSK AT TIME OF THE CRACKDOWN
description: A 20-year-old worker from Gdansk arrived in Warsaw today and provided an account of the street fighting there in the days after the imposition of martial law Dec. 13. The authorites have said that more than 300 people were injured in the fighting and have admitted one death.

title: NO CHARGES IN GRID STAR'S DEATH, PROSECUTOR SAYS
description: District Attorney John K. Van de Kamp of Los Anaeles County said today that no criminal charges would be brought in the death of a college football star, Ron Settles, in a southern California jail. The announcement followed an eight-month investigation of the case.

title: Lord Grade Quits Troubled Company
description: Four months ago, Lord Grade, chairman of Britain's Associated Communications Corporation, told an interviewer that he had no intention of retiring before the year 2001. Last night, he stepped down as chairman and chief executive of the troubled company as he sold his interest to Robert Holmes a Court, an Australian newspaper and television millionaire who is expected to take operating control of the company.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Officials at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston reported that the heart condition of the former Red Sox outfielder Tony Conigliaro improved yesterday. Conigliaro had suffered a massive heart attack last weekend. ... Bobby Ross, who spent the last four seasons as an assistant coach with the Kansas City Chiefs, is returning to the University of Maryland as the Terrapins' football coach, succeeding Jerry Claiborne, who moved to Kentucky.

title: Credit Markets; RATES SHOW SLIGHT DECLINE
description: Interest rates declined slightly yesterday. Securities dealers said the market's recent sawtooth trading pattern demonstrated the uncertain outlook for interest rates.

title: HUNT MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 29
KAISER ALUMINUM & CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes foreign currency transactions of $2.2 million loss for the qr and $16.3 million gain for the yr...C-Net income including foreign currency transactions of $500,000 gain for the qr and $3.9 million loss for the yr; 1980 results have been restated for the consolidation of Kaiser Aluminum Europe Inc as of Jan 1, 1981

title: LAW REVIEW PLAN IS APPROVED
description: After nearly a year of controversy that has rippled through the nation's legal community, the editors of The Harvard Law Review have approved a plan that would take a student's race, but not sex, into account in filling some editorial positions.

title: COUNCIL URGES DECISION ON AT-LARGE ELECTIONS
description: The city's chief lawyer has asked a Federal appeals court to speed an appeal of a ruling that invalidated the City Council's practice of electing two at-large members from each borough.

title: CITY NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
RPM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
NEWTON DIEHL BAKER 3d
description: Newton Diehl Baker 3d, a business executive and son of a World War I Cabinet member, died here Saturday after a long illness.

title: Meadowlands Off Again
description: Harness racing was called off last night at Meadowlands Race Track because of poor conditions and a forecast of more snow. It was the second straight night that the Meadowlands card had been called off.

title: DAVIS RALIIES SUNS PAST KNICKS BY 90-89
description: Walter Davis, the Phoenix Suns' amiable all-star who was moved from forward to guard last season, did not start tonight. After receiving a fractured left elbow during his last preseason game, Davis has been slow working himself into shape as a reserve.

title: TOLL ON EAST RIVER CROSSINGS EXPECTED TO RISE 25, TO $1.25
description: The board of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority is expected to vote today to raise the $1 toll on the Triborough Bridge and four other East River crossings by 25 cents, sources close to the agency said yesterday.

title: No Headline
description: Western Union Inquiry

title: For Scrabble Fans
description: Scrabble enthusiasts at least 16 years old can try their hand in the first round of games toward the North American championship Sunday at noon at the Brooklyn War Memorial Building, Cadman Plaza (two blocks from the Brooklyn Bridge).

title: NEW RACE UPDATES FENEICK STYLE
description: Millicent Fenwick, the elegant yet combative Republican grande dame of the House of Representatives, nestled her two youngest grandchildren on the sofa in her living room overlooking the snowy hills of New Jersey's fox-hunting country. An old-fashioned box radio sat nearby, a telephone was within arm's reach and logs burned briskly in the fireplace.

title: ON KING'S ANNIVERSARY, REFLECTIONS OF HIS DREAM
description: Robert Ross sat in a welfare office in Harlem the other day and recalled another man's dream that was shared with this nation from the base of the Lincoln Memorial in Washington nearly two decades ago.

title: CERTRON CORP reports earnings for Yr to Oct 31
description: B-Includes $296,000 tax credit less $57,000 for preferred stock divd...C-Includes $265,000 tax credit less $88,000 for preferred stock divd

title: Merger Initiatives For Supron Energy
description: The Supron Energy Corporation of Dallas has received takeover initiatives from the Allied Corporation but ''nothing definite was going on'' and ''no offer had been made,'' A.M. Weiderkehr, the company's chairman, said.

title: Pop Jazz; BEAT GENERATION LIVES IN A NIGHT OF ROCK AND POETRY
description: ''I SAW the best minds of my generation destroyed by madness,'' Allen Ginsberg wailed in his poem ''Howl,'' published in 1956. Along with Jack Kerouac's ''On The Road''(1957) and William Burroughs's ''Naked Lunch''(1959), ''Howl'' announced the coming of age of an angry new generation, a ''beat'' generation.'' For many young people, the beat generation is history, but not for Tav Falco, leader of the rock band Panther Burns.

title: WE CANNOT AFFORD TO USE VIOLENCE'
description: Following are excerpts from a speech delivered by the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. on Dec. 1, 1957, to the National Committee for the Rural Schools, in New York City.. Dr. King, who was slain in 1968, would have been 55 years old today.

title: Critic's Notebook; THE CASE FOR KEEPING FEIFFER'S 'GROWN UPS' OPEN
description: IT'S sad news that Jules Feiffer's ''Grown Ups'' may close tomorrow night, a scant five weeks after its premiere. Or so it is if you you feel, as I do, that this is an exceptionally rewarding play in a top-flight production. Why is it closing? Maybe it's because the reviews were mixed. Maybe it's because of the snow. Maybe it's because ''Grown Ups'' is one of the few Broadway productions this sea son that has not blitzed us day and night with radio and television jingles.

title: Coghlan to Miss Season
description: Eamonn Coghlan, the world indoor record-holder in the mile (3 minutes 50.6 seconds), will miss the indoor track season because of a stress fracture of the right shin.

title: EXCERPTS FROM ADDRESS BY REAGAN ON ROLE OF PRIVATE GROUPS
description: Following are excerpts from a transcript of President Reagan's address to New York Partnership Inc. at the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of ABC News:

title: SOVIET FOOD SHORTAGES: GRUMBLING AND EXCUSES
description: State Food Store 42, two miles from the Kremlin, is a dingy, ill-lighted place with floors sli ck from the slush of Krasnoprudnaya Street. In the chilling blizza rds of the last week thewindows have been masked by a thick rime of f rost.

title: The U.N. Today; Jan. 15, 1982; SECURITY COUNCIL
description: Meets on the annexation of the Golan Heights at 3 P.M. GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Swiss Favor 'Insider' Laws
description: The Finance Ministry supports a demand by the federal banking commission that ''insider'' trading should be made a criminal offense in Switzerland, a spokesman for the ministry said today.

title: Sallie Mae Plans Sale Of Notes
description: The Student Loan Marketing Association, the Federal agency that buys federally guaranteed student loans from banks and others, announced a major step yesterday toward ending its dependence on financing from the United States Treasury.

title: IPCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes tax credits of $443,000 for the qr and $809,000 for the 6 mos...C-Includes $260,000 gain for both periods from the sale of land and tax credits of $468,000 for the qr and $783,000 for the 6 mos

title: Advertising; Changing From Meat To Media
description: THE Mickelberry Corporation, with roots that go back to 1893, appears to be doing something that other companies have tried and failed. A noncommunications company, Mickelberry has been successfully acquiring ad agencies for almost 10 years. That is a singular achievement, according to the American Association of Advertising Agencies.

title: Midwinter Powwow At New City Theater
description: American Indians and those interested in the culture and cuisine of the Seneca, Hopi and Mohawk people will gather for the annual midwinter dance concert and powwow over the next two weekends at the Theater for the New City, 162 Second Avenue, between 10th and 11th Streets.

title: Auctions; Old masters up for bids.
description: MASTER paintings and drawings will be in the spotlight next week at both Christie's and Sotheby Parke Bernet. At Christie's, Park Avenue at 59th Street, next Tuesday at 10 A.M. and 2 P.M., ''Southwark Fair,'' an engraving by William Hogarth from 1733, showing flags and banners flying in the air above street musicians, carries the higest estimate, as much as $300,000. Another important offering is a 1622 oil sketch by Rubens, one of a series of 12 designs for tapestries depicting the life of Constantine the Great, which is expected to sell for up to $200,000. A reliquary with a painted panel by Francesco di Vannuccio, depicting the Madonna and Child and saints against a gold ground, may bring as much as $150,000. Among still lifes in this sale is a signed painting on panel of fruit and flowers by Jan van Os (up to $100,000). The two most important old-master drawings up for bidding are Giovanni Battista Tiepolo's ''An Oriental,'' a 1750's pen-and-ink study, with brown wash, of an old man, and Thomas Rowlandson's ''Liberty Hall,'' a watercolor caricature of fox hunters relaxing (up to $8,000 each).

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, JANUARY 15, 1982
description: International Instructions for opposing martial law in Poland were issued by three leaders of the suspended union Solidarity who are in hiding. The typewriten leaflet called for 12 actions, including ''passive resistance'' in the workplace. (Page A6, Columns 4-6.) An account of the fighting in Gdansk in the days following the imposition of martial law Dec. 13 was given by a young worker just arrived in Warsaw. The worker is now a courier for a resistance movement. (A6:1-3.)

title: Restaurants; Village steakhouse, East Side glitter.
description: ONE of the more encouraging restaurant trends recently has been the break with cliche settings. The stuffy, traditional upholstered dining ''salon'' is no longer considered the only appropriate setting for fine French food and somewhere along the way everyone realized that you can have a good seafood dinner without a roomful of corkfloats and fish nets.

title: Airco Expansion
description: Airco Inc., a wholly owned subsidiary of the London-based BOC International, announced it had begun a $247 million program to expand its graphite manufacturing operations by the fall of 1983. Airco said it would soon start construction on a $128 million plant in Ridgeville, S.C., to make graphite electrodes used in electric arc furnaces by the steelmaking industry, and on a $119 million facility in Seadrift, Tex., to produce premium needle coke, a key raw material used in graphite electrode manufacturing.

title: AT LABOR NO. 2's IMPORTANCE WAXES
description: Early this week a group of top Labor Department officials gathered to address a question from Craig Fuller, President Reagan's assistant for Cabinet affairs: With unemployment now at 8.9 percent, what should the Government do?

title: SOVIET REPORTS LETHAL CENTURIES-OLD ANTHRAX
description: A Soviet newspaper reported today that a strain of anthrax bacteria that had lain dormant for 1,300 years until it was unearthed during an archeological dig had killed a cow on a collective farm near the Urals city of Perm.

title: Weekender Guide; Friday; RHYTHM-AND-BLUES PLAY ON GRAND ST.
description: Cleavon Little stars in ''Keyboard,'' a new play by Matt Robinson, which opens tonight at 7:30 at the Henry Street Settlement's New Federal Theater, 466 Grand Street. Mr. Little was seen this season as the saxophonist Lester Young in ''The Resurrection of Lady Lester'' at the Manhattan Theater Club. In ''Keyboard,'' he plays a fictional musician - a once-great rhythm-and-blues singer who ignores the problems of his family as he dreams of his past. Tickets are $2.50 and $5. Information: 598-0400. HIGH-HEELED WOMEN AT 54TH ST . CLUB

title: U.S. SAID TO WEIGH NERVE GAS OUTPUT
description: The Reagan Administration has laid the groundwork for a Presidential decision to begin producing a new nerve gas for chemical warfare, according to Administration and Congressional officials. The plan includes a request for a substantial increase in the 1983 budget for s uch weapons.

title: Dip in Business Optimism Seen
description: Business leaders' confidence in the American economy is slipping, but remains above the record low set during the depth of the previous recession, the Conference Board said in a report to be released today.

title: A JANUARY GUIDE TO GALLERY HOPPING 57TH STREET: A DOUBLE BIRTHDAY PARTY
description: BIRTHDAYS should be fun, and double birthdays doubly so. It so happens that both the Grace Borgenicht Gallery, now at 724 Fifth Avenue, at 57th Street, and the Terry Dintenfass Gallery, now at 50 West 57th Street, this year celebrate their 20th anniversaries. What better plan, they thought, than to mark the occasion jointly, by showing work by artists who had been with them throughout the 20 years of their existence?

title: NOTES ON PEOPLE
description: 'Judge' Excused 13The professional home of the baritone James Billings is chiefly the New York City Opera, but during its hiatus he has been appearing as the judge in Gilbert and Sullivan's ''Trial by Jury'' with the Washington National Opera at the Kennedy Center.

title: FIRST & MERCHANTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The per shr figures adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split Dec 29

title: Canada's Bank Rate Up
description: Canada's bank rate, the semiofficial benchmark lending rate, was set today at 14.81 percent, up from 14.74 percent last week. It was the second consecutive rise since the rate began falling last September, the Bank of Canada said. Canada's commercial banks typically set their prime lending rates about two and a quarter percentage points above the bank rate.

title: A LUXURY CONDOMINIUM ALONG BROOKLYN WATERFRONT
description: At first glance, Brooklyn's south-western shore would seem an unlikely place for residential development. It has suffered from years of decline and neglect and is cut off from Bensonhurst and Bay Ridge, two of its closest neighborhoods, by the Belt Parkway.

title: PORT AUTHORITY SEES NO TOLL OR FARE RISE DESPITE BUDGET GAP
description: Despite a projected 1982 deficit in the operation of the trains, tunnels and the bridge that connect Manhattan and New Jersey, officials of the Port Authority said yesterday that they did not expect toll or fare increases this year.

title: DANCE THEATER OF HARLEM A MAGNET FOR YOUTH
description: IT always seems busiest backstage just before a season. The City Center was no exception the other day, when Dance Theater of Harlem prepared for its opening this week. Stagehands hurtled through the cramped backstage quarters, muttering to people to watch their feet. Arthur Mitchell, who, with Karel Shook, founded and directs the company, enveloped a visitor in a quick bear hug as he rushed by. Dancers were everywhere, among them four of the company's brightest young talents - Stephanie Dabney, Lorraine Graves, Donald Williams and Lowell Smith. All of them will be performing in major roles this weekend.

title: LEARONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-Includes $739,000 gain from reversal of United Kingdom income taxes on inventory stock relief and foreign currency gains of $124,000

title: No Headline
description: SALVADORAN LETTERS DISPUTED

title: Economic Scene; Productivity: Why It's Off
description: A TOP priority of President Reagan's supply-side revolution in economic policy, with huge tax cuts to provide incentives for savings and business investment, has been to speed up the nation's sagging rate of productivity growth.

title: NO SETS, NO PROPS, JUST KATIA RICCIARELLI IN SONG
description: Backstage at the Metropolitan Opera, Katia Ricciarelli turned in her dressing room chair and greeted a young, admiring student - an operatic score hugged closely to her bosom. ''Any advice for me?'' the question came. ''Yes,'' said Miss Ricciarelli, ''find a good teacher and keep her.''

title: Cuban Offer to Nicaraguans
description: Cuba is offering 400 scholarships to Nicaraguan children to study on Havana's Isle of Youth in the next school year, according to a Managua radio broadcast monitored here Wednesday. The children, who must be no more than 15 years old, will join 1,200 other Nicaraguan students in Cuba, the radio said. More than 26,000 children from Africa and Central America have been educated by Cuba in the last four years on the Isle of Youth.

title: DALCO PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-Includes $4,563,000 pretax gain from the sale of stock

title: SHUHSI HSU, 89, EX-DIPLOMAT WITH THE CHINESE NATIONALISTS
description: Dr. Shuhsi Hsu, a specialist in international law and former Chinese Nationalist diplomat, died Thursday at his home in Westfield, N.J. He was 89 years old.

title: BALLET: CITY'S 'LA VALSE' AND 'GOLDBERG VARIATIONS'
description: IT is only a step from the Romantic to the Gothic and that detour was taken most surprisingly and effectively Wednesday night in the New York City Ballet's revival of ''La Valse'' at the State Theater.

title: INTERMEDICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 1
description: B-Includes $420,000 extraordinary credit from life insurance proceeds

title: BRIEFS
description: * Afga-Gevaert Graphics Inc. said it held about 2.2 million common shares of Compugraphic Corp. pursuant to its earlier tender offer.

title: PUBLISHING: CANADIAN GETS HOUGHTON MIFFLIN PRIZE
description: WHAT do the following writers have in common: Robert Penn Warren, Elizabeth Bishop, Eugene Burdick, Philip Roth, Robert Stone, Carson McCullers, Willie Morris and Helen Yglesias? Each was a recipient of the Houghton Mifflin Literary Fellowship, which has been given to 30 authors of fiction and nonfiction since its founding in 1935.

title: U.S. IS OPENING TALKS ON TAX HAVEN TREATY
description: The Treasury Department, in an effort to eliminate abuses in tax treaties with other countries, has reopened little-publicized but acrimonious negotiations over such a treaty with the British Virgin Islands, a Caribbean tax haven.

title: Angels in Bid for Jackson
description: The California Angels are now convinced that the Yankees do not intend to sign Reggie Jackson, and they will make a final bid this morning at a meeting in Palm Springs.

title: CARIBBEAN AID PLAN ADVANCES BUT FACE HURDLES
description: The Reagan Administration's development program for the Caribbean and Central America is almost certain to lead to requests for more foreign aid funds from Congress, business and Government officials say.

title: GREAT WESTERN FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
WHEN THE BULK OF 'WELFARE' IS NOTHING LIKE IT
description: To the Editor:

title: FORD OMITS QUARTERLY DIVIDEND
description: Reflecting hard times in the auto industry, the Ford Motor Company said today that it would not pay a dividend for this year's first quarter, the first time the company has not made such a payment since it went public in 1956. k Ford had been paying 30 cents a share since mid-1980, when it had cut the dividend from $1 a quarter. Philip Caldwell, Ford's chairman, said, ''T he board's action reflected not only continuation of the long s lump in the U.S. automotive market, but uncertainty in the gen eral economy with respect to the timing of the recovery.'' As a result, Mr. Caldwell said, ''It is essential that prudent steps be taken to conserve cash resources so that the company can continue th e development and introduction of its new products.''

title: Pakistani Regime Seizes 480 Suspected Foes
description: The authorities have arrested about 480 suspected members of an organization that wants to overthrow the military Government of President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq, Interior Minister Mahmoud Abdullah Haroon said today.

title: Ozaki Takes Lead by 1 on 68
description: Tateo (Jet) Ozaki, reacting to the pressure of being the co-leader, struggled today in the early stages of his second round but settled down to finish with a 68 and sole possession of the lead in the Bob Hope Desert Classic.

title: NETS TAKE ADVANTAGE OF BULLS' INJURIES AND TRIUMPH, 130-104
description: The New Jersey Nets took full advantage of the Bulls' lack of a seasoned playmaker tonight and overwhelmed Chicago, 130-104, at the Byrne Meadowlands Arena. The victory, which brought the Nets' record to 15-21, was their most one-sided of the season.

title: SOLON AUTOMATED SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
AM International
description: AM International Inc. said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had almost no net worth at the end of its fiscal year July 31, 1981. The graphics equipment and information processing systems manufacturer, formerly the Addressograph-Multigraph Corporation, said that it was almost $250 million in debt and that a recapitalization of the company was likely to be required if long-term stability was to be restored.

title: REGARDLESS OF THE HOUR A FIRE IS STILL A FIRE
description: To the Editor:

title: Two Boston Drama Critics Honored
description: Sylviane Gold, the New York-based theater critic for The Boston Phoenix, and that weekly's theater editor and critic, Carolyn Clay, were named yesterday co-winners of the $5,000 George Jean Nathan Award for dramatic criticism, one of the richest in the American theater.

title: CAMERON IRON WORKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt STORIES UP TO A POINT. By Bette Peset- sky. 113 pages. Knopf. $9.50.

title: DORCHESTER GAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
INTERSTATE BAKERIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-Includes tax credits of $9,000 for the qr and $132,000 for the 6 mos and gains from discontinued operations of $53,000 for qr and $290,000 for the 6 mos

title: HAIG IS HOPEFUL ON A PALESTINIAN ACCORD
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. said tonight that, as a result of talks with Egyptian and Israeli leaders, he was ''not pessimistic'' over the chances for an agreement in the next few months on Palestinian self-rule in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip.

title: Advertising; 7 Advertisers Change Claims or Drop Ads
description: Seven of th e 13 cases investigated by the National Advertising division of t he Council of Better Business Bureaus were resolved in December when the advertisers either changed the claims or dropped the advertisi ng.

title: JUSTICES ASKED TO VOID EQUAL RIGHTS DECISION
description: The Justice Department told the Supreme Court today that it should consider simply overturning a lower court's ruling on the proposed Federal equal rights amendment, without deciding any legal issues, on the ground that the case was decided prematurely.

title: TV Weekend; A MENTAL CHAMPIONSHIP, 'ALICE AT PALACE,' CARUSO
description: TONIGHT'S installment of ''Creativity with Bill Moyers,'' on WNET-TV at 9, stretches the borders of the series questionably with ''Olympics of the Mind.'' The ''Olympics'' are an extracurricular school program devised by two New Jersey educators, Ted Gouley and Sam Micklus. They concoct mental games that are then played with the same rah-rah spirit as physical games - cheerleaders, and all that sort of thing.

title: Out of Work Last of five articles on the; nation's unemployment problem.
description: The rising unemployment rate menaces thousands of Republican candidates in the 1982 elections, leaders of both parties agree. With 9.4 million Americans now out of work, incumbents and challengers alike are in jeopardy, they say. But Republicans say that if unemployment does not get too much higher than December's 8.9 percent, and if economic recovery is visible by Election Day, as most economists expect, voters will not punish them severely. They argue that just how particular economic factors affect votes is uncertain, and they count on other factors to help them.

title: Julie Bender Is Dead; Basketball Star in 30's
description: Jules (Julie) Bender, an all-America basketball star at Long Island University in the mid-1930's, died of cancer Wednesday night at the Boca Raton Hospital in Florida. He was 67 years old.

title: Embassy Row
description: It has been almost a year since the Institute for the Study of Diplomacy at Georgetown University held a symposium on the diplomatic wife and her problems. But reverberations are still being felt as the publication resulting from the ideas explored at that gathering makes the rou nds of Embassy Ro w.

title: REAGAN APPEALS TO CIVIC GROUPS TO AID THE POOR
description: Invoking the heroic efforts of volunteer rescuers in Wednesday's airplane crash in Washington, President Reagan yesterday exhorted business and civic leaders to display the same ''spirit of shared sacrifice'' in finding private substitutes for Government welfare programs.

title: Students to Aid Crime Fight
description: Station KETV, drama students at the University of Nebraska and the police have joined in a campaign called Crimestoppers to re-enact unsolved crimes. They are to be broadcast beginning in March, in the hope of attracting anonymous tips to lead the police to arrests and convictions, officials said.

title: NEW CITY GROUP TO BUILD MIDDLE-INCOME HOUSING
