description: The formation of a private nonprofit corporation to build or renovate 30,000 units of middle-income housing in New York City within a five-year period was announced yesterday by city housing officials and David Rockefeller.

title: CHARLES T. DOUDS, FORMER DIRECTOR OF REGIONAL N.L.R.B., DEAD AT 83
description: Charles T. Douds, who served as New York regional director for the National Labor Relations Board from 1942 to 1957, died Sunday at Holy Spirit Hospital in Camp Hill, Pa., where he lived. He was 83 years old.

title: Business People; Vendo Picks Outsider To Take Top Positions
description: Richard O. Donegan has been chosen by the financially troubled Vendo Company, a major vending machine manufacturer, to fill the vacant position of president and take over for Spencer Childers as chief executive officer, effective March 1.

title: AMERICAN WELDING MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Applied Molecular Genetics Inc., Thousand Oaks, Calif., has appointed Nowell Stebbing vice president-scientific affairs.

title: SOCIAL SECURITY SUGGESTIONS
description: In the endless halls of Government, there are fashions in issues, just as there are elsewhere in clothing and language. Within a few weeks, unnoticed outside events can somehow spin an aura of political chic around a previously ordinary subject, and consequential people begin talking about it.

title: JOY MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 25
description: 1980 results adjusted to reflect an accounting change and a $3-for-2 stock split paid in May 1981

title: MRS.
description: Mark Thatcher, the son of the British Prime Minister, was found alive and well today in the Sahara, along with his French co-driver and mechanic. The three disappeared six days ago while taking part in the punishing Paris-to-Dakar motor rally.

title: Savin in Discussion On Selling Control
description: The Savin Corporation announced yesterday that it was negotiating to sell control of the company to a multinational corporation with interests in office equipment. The company did not identify the prospective buyer.

title: RAID INFORMATION SYSTEMS reports earnings for 16 weeks to Nov 29
description: B-Includes $258,843 gain from the sale of subsidiary

title: Law on Closed Hearing Is Upheld in California
description: The California Supreme Court today unanimously upheld a 110-year-old state law that permits defendants to exclude the news media and the public from preliminary hearings in criminal cases.

title: U.S. Arrests Leader Of Haitian Invasion
description: Bernard Sansaricq, the leader of a group of exiles who apparently invaded the Haitian island of Tortuga, has been arrested and charged with violating United States neutrality laws, a Coast Guard spokesman said today.

title: NOTES ON PEOPLE
description: Time for Shalom His past policy uabbles with American officials took a back seat to personal diplomacy when it came time for some of his admirers to say goodbye to Ephraim Evron, the departing Israeli Ambassador to the United States.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: N O one could call Wednesday an ideal night. It was snowing an d sleeting, traffic was a mess and most people were thankful to get home and stay there. But if one stays home, one isn't seen , and to a small group of New Yorkers, not being seen is a fate worse than any storm.

title: Bridge: The Princess Made Good When Going Was Tough
description: Since French Revolutionary times, many have held the view that titled aristocrats contribute nothing of value to society. It is easy to destroy this generalization by cataloguing noble exceptions, especially in politics.

title: DEKALB AGRESEARCH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-After $300,000 loss from discontinued operations

title: Casting Helplessness Into the Past
description: Cradling a dying woman in his arms, helpless to save her, is not something Jeffrey Dorman is likely to forget. ''It was a terribly emotional experience,'' he said the other day, recalling the night last July when he and some friends were on a Fire Island water taxi that collided with a clam boat, fatally injuring a young woman aboard the other craft.

title: USES OF ANTI-SEMITISM
description: The sinister Christmas issue of a Communist Party paper blaming Poland's troubles on Jews provides a glimpse of the power struggle under military rule.

title: 3 STUDIES OF CAPITAL SUBWAY CRASH BEGIN
description: Crews with blowtorches and a crane dismantled the wreckage of a subway train today while three investigations were begun to seek to determine what caused a rushhour crash Wednesday that killed three persons and injured at least 25.

title: KOCH SEEKING FARE RISE ON S.I. FERRY
description: Mayor Koch has decided to recommend doubling the fare on the Staten Island ferry - to 50 cents for a round trip - in the preliminary budget plan that he will announce today for the 1983 fiscal year.

title: SOUTHWEST FLORIDA BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The 1980 results have been restated for a pooling acquisition; Southwest Florida has corrected its latest fourth-qr earnings report

title: JIM MILLER: BAREFOOT BOY OF THE 49ers
description: The San Francisco 49ers were practicing kickoff returns Wednesday, and Jim Miller, filling in on the kicking team, ran downfield. Miller slipped. Ronnie Lott tried to catch him and stepped on Miller's right foot. For a moment, Lott was horrified. He might have put Miller, the 49ers' barefoot punter, out of the Super Bowl.

title: CLARION CONCERT: STEFFANI'S 'L'AMOR VIEN DAL DESTINO'
description: IF Alexander Haig, the statesman, were also a bishop, an adviser to the Pope and one of the most important composers of his day, his career might roughly parallel that of Agostino Steffani. Granted, that is a large if. In our time, important people tend to specialize.

title: REAGAN TALKS TO CITY YOUTHS ABOUT JOBS
description: Seven New York City teen-agers who symbolized President Reagan's call for ''private-sector initiatives'' met with the President yesterday in a suite at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

title: Market Place; Savin Gamble On Process
description: THE Savin Corporation, whose shares have been surprisingly strong this week, continued to gain ground yesterday following an announcement that Savin was negotiating to sell control to a multinational company. The shares closed the day at 10 1/4 for a twoday gain of 2 1/8.

title: FULLER, H B, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Nicaragua Shuts Paper After Guards Shoot 3
description: The offices of the independent newspaper La Prensa were seized by the police last night after a violent public protest against the paper's editorial policies in which three people were shot and wounded, apparently by office guards.

title: UPTOWN: NEW RICHARD DIEBENKORN WORK
description: AN exhibition of new work by Richard Diebenkorn is always something of an event. An exhibition that marks a striking new development in his work is therefore likely to be a special event, and this is what we have in Mr. Diebenkorn's latest exhibition at M. Knoedler & Company, 19 East 70th Street (through Jan. 28). This is a show consisting of some 25 untitled ''drawings'' - actually they are small paintings on paper - executed in the last two years. In these bright, deft, inventive pictures, Mr. Diebenkorn can be seen bidding farewell, as it were, to his much-admired ''Ocean Park'' series and inaugurating a distinctly new phase of his work.

title: Dow Up 3.33 in Slow Trading
description: Stock price s moved ahead modestly in slow trading yesterday to register thei r first advance of this week. The Dow Jon es industrial average gained 3.33 points, to 842.28. In the first eig ht sessions of this year, the Dow fell 36 points, mainlyreflecting in vestor worries about rising interest rates.

title: PHILADELPHIA NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Five Die in Baltimore Blaze
description: Five children, ranging in age from 2 to 8, died today in an early morning row-house fire that the authorities said was the work of an arsonist. A quarrel was believed to have led to the arson, the police said, adding th at one of the 17 persons who lived in the three-story dwelling was suspected of setting the fire. The victims w ere identified as Victoria Marshall, 6; Theresa Morris, 4; Emanuel Bu rley, 8; Victor Burley, 5, and Shanti Burley, 2.

title: PIER 1 IMPORTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-Includes $978,000 tax credit...C-Net loss including $28,000 tax credit

title: RECOVERY EFFORT STARTS IN POTOMAC
description: With the death toll from Wednesday's crash of an Air Florida jetliner put at 78, emergency crews today began the slow process of removing the plane and its dead passengers from the ice-crusted Potomac River.

title: Puerto Rico Can't Eat Statehood
description: There's nothing wrong with President Reagan's endorsing statehood for Puerto Rico if the islanders freely choose to join the Union. But no such vote is likely before 1985, and even a statehood landslide would leave it to Congress to set the terms. Until they truly know the risks and benefits, Puerto Ricans cannot really be expected to choose wisely among statehood, the present commonwealth status or independence. Meanwhile, they still have to eat.

title: DEMOCRATS ACT TO IMPROVE CONVENTION ROLES
description: The Democratic Party moved on two fronts today to make its thinned ranks of elected officials more important in party deliberations.

title: BIG BANKS ADVANCE IN QUARTER
description: Several of the nation's leading banking companies, helped by gains in interest income, yesterday reported moderate to strong advances in earnings for both the fourth quarter of 1981 and the whole year.

title: SOVIET STEPS UP EFFORTS TO SPLIT THE WEST ON POLAND
description: Faced with a stiffening posture by the Atlantic alliance on Poland, the Kremlin has stepped up a propaganda campaign aimed at persuading Western Europeans that the United States is using the Polish crackdown as a pretext for destroying detente and restoring the ''obedience'' of European nations to America's commands.

title: Canada's Miss Sorensen Lowers Downhill Mark
description: Gerry Sorensen of Canada today bettered the record time she set a day earlier by scoring a second downhill victory on the most difficult and longest course of the women's World Cup ski circuit.

title: Hearing On Bell
description: The California Public Utilities Commission, charging that its rate-setting authority would be undermined, said today that it would seek to block at least temporarily the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's plan to divest 22 local operating companies.

title: DAYCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
EKKER WILL LEAVE POST AS ST. LOUIS U. COACH
description: Ron Ekker submitted his resignation today as basketball coach at St. Louis University, effective at the end of the season.

title: CITY AGENCY REPLACES 2 HIGH LEVEL OFFICIALS
description: The city's Department of Transportation announced replacements yesterday for two high-level positions.

title: Sprint Disrupted
description: Two American sprinters, Mel Lattany and Mark Kent, were injured slightly in Melbourne, Australia, when banner-waving demonstrators interrupted the 200-meter final of the Alcoa Challenge track and field meet.

title: More on Cornelius
description: James Anthony Cornelius, the promoter of the bout last month between Muhammad Ali and Trevor Berbick in the Bahamas, is a convicted felon who is being investigated by the F.B.I. in connection with a bank-fraud case in Atlanta, The Los Angeles Times reported. Cornelius, 35, it was reported, moved his family and belongings out of a rented $500,000 house near Ali's mansion in Hancock Park, which is near Los Angeles, several weeks ago and took up residence in the Bahamas.

title: Business Digest; FRIDAY, JANUARY 15, 1982; International
description: Two banks downgraded their loans to Poland to ''nonperforming assets.'' The two, Marine Midland of New York and Fidelity of Philadelphia, were the first Western banks to announce such an action. They still expect the loans, which were well below $100 million, to be paid, however. Many American bankers believe that Poland's large debt does not constitute a threat to the soundness of the international banking structure. (Page D1.)

title: Taxes And El ections
description: Senate Republican leaders, some House Republicans and President Reagan's ranking aides are urging him to propose higher taxes to hold down the horrendous budget deficits predicted for 1983 and 1984. But he probably won't, save for the $22 billion in ''tax enhancements'' he's already accepted. That foreca st is not based on one of those leaks to the press that have so exerc ised Mr. Reagan - as they have all Presidents back to George Washin gton. It derives, instead, from an enduring belief that political pre ssures usually prevail over economic.

title: Business People; CBI Aide Adds 2 Posts
description: William A. Pogue, president of CBI Industries for the past year, has been elected chairman and chief executive officer as well. He succeeds Marvin G. Mitchell, who has retired. Mr. Pogue, a West Point graduate, heads a fast-growing company based in Oak Brook, Ill., that builds refinery tanks and reactor vessels for the energy business.

title: COMPUTER TRANSCEIVER SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
CRUCIAL POWER PLANT DECISION
description: In a Seattle board room today, two troubled nuclear power projects that have consumed billions of dollars in borrowed funds may be ordered terminated. If so, that action will reverberate through the nation's municipal bond market.

title: SPENCER COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 28
CBT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The pes shr figures reflect a 3-for-2 stock split in June 1981

title: SOUTHEAST BANKING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
TO WHITE EXILES, THERE'LL ALWAYS BE A RHODESIA
description: Technically, there are no Rhodesians left in the world, since there is no Rhodesia. But white immigrants who are streaming into South Africa from Zimbabwe cling to the name and to racial attitudes that sometimes seem to put them to the right of most local whites.

title: Northwest Sets Stock Purchase
description: Northwest Industries said that its directors have authorized a cash tender offer to buy back five million of its common shares at $75 a share, or a total of $375 million. The company's stock closed yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange at 73 3/8, up 1 1/2 points.

title: TRACY WYNN FIGHTING TO GET TV-SERIES CREDIT
description: Tracy Keenan Wynn, two-time Emmy-winning television writer, has been denied writing credit on ''The Executioner's Song,'' a four-hour NBC series taken from Norman Mailer's Pulitzer Prize-winning book about the condemned murderer Gary Gilmore. He has demanded an arbitration by the Writers Guild of America.

title: Albanian Said to Name A New Prime Minister
description: Enver Hoxha, head of the Albanian Communist Party, was reported today to have nominated First Deputy Prime Minister Adil Carcani to succeed Prime Minister Mehmet Shehu, who reportedly committed suicide last month.

title: ABBOTT TELLS TRIAL OF HIS LIFE IN FOSTER HOMES AND PRISONS
description: Jack Henry Abbott, defending himself against a charge of murder, told a jury in State Supreme Court in Manhattan yesterday of his life since childhood in a succession of foster homes, reform schools and state and Federal prisons.

title: WESTERN BEEF INC reports earnings for Yr to Oct 31
G.E. Plans Layoffs In Kentucky Plant
description: The General Electric Company said that it would lay off up to 1,700 production workers at its Appliance Park manufacturing complex here on Feb. 8.

title: SUSPECT IS HELD IN SLAYINGS OF 6 IN LAST 6 WEEKS
description: A 21-year-old Manhattan man was arrested yesterday and charged early today with committing six murders since Dec. 4. The victims included a performer in a light opera company who was shot to death in Central Park and an investment adviser who was killed in his apartment-office in the financial district.

title: Why Let Pride Diminish the Police?
description: How many police officers does New York City need? To most New Yorkers the answer is obvious: more. And Mayor Koch, after a period of waffling, has bent to that political pressure by pledging again to expand the force by 2,300 officers.

title: COA LITION SEEKS TO CURB RISING HEALTH CARE COSTS
description: Leaders of six business, labor and medical organizations announced today that they would cooperate in a major voluntary effort to control the cost of health care.

title: Chemical Reported Shuffling Officers
description: Chemical Bank, the country's seventh largest, has quietly reshuffled its top management and established a three-way race for its No.2 position, according to sources within the bank.

title: Coach Is an Apparent Suicide
description: Willie Williams, the University of Arizona track coach, was found shot to death today in what the police termed an apparent suicide.

title: Learning About National Parks Very Early On
description: Forty-six years ago she was born in Grand Canyon National Park, and now she has become the first woman to be put in charge of a national park.

title: AIR TALKS IN JAPAN BROKEN OFF
description: American and Japanese officials today broke off four days of negotiations aimed at resolving their longstanding differences over trans-Pacific airline service.

title: At the Movies; Finding roots in Hitler's Germany.
description: ''DAVID,'' based on Joel Konig's novel about a Jewish boy who lives in - and escapes from - Nazi Germany, opens next Wednesday at the Lincoln Plaza 2. Peter Lilienthal, the 52-year-old director of ''David'' and himself a German-born Jew, has already lived several lives. When he was 10, he fled with his widowed mother to Uruguay. ''My mother had a special mother intuition,'' he says. ''My grandfather was rich. He had a house. He always thought, 'There's some way of staying.' But my mother said, 'We have to leave. Tomorrow. For whatever country. My child has to be safe.' ''

title: VIRGINIA'S FIRST LADY: A FAMILIAR FACE
description: McLEAN, Va., Jan. 12 - A generation of Americans has grown up with Lynda Bird Johnson Robb, the daughter of Lyndon B. Johnson, over the last quarter of a century.

title: Rolls-Royce Sales
description: Rolls-Royce Motors Inc. said that sales of Rolls-Royce cars in the United States rose 23 percent last year, to 1,158 units, from 912 in 1980. George W. Lewis, president, said he foresees another good year for the company this year and is hoping that the United States will be allocated most of the increased production that is planned at the Rolls-Royce factory in Britain. Last year the United States and other overseas markets took 62 percent of the luxury auto maker's output.

title: 5 Concerns Asked To Bid on Satellite
description: The Satellite Television Corporation has invited five American manufacturers to submit bids for construction of a new type of high-powered satellite to transmit television programs directly to home roof-top antennas.

title: Schoolboy Had $3 Exam
description: Joseph Prezioso, the athletic director of DeWitt Clinton High School, said yesterday that James Cousar, 17, who died of a heart attack during a basketball game Monday, had undergone a required $3 medical examination before the season.

title: Gunmen in Guatemala Murder Family of Five
description: Unidentified gunmen killed a family of five, the police here said today.

title: THEATER DIRECTOR IN HOUSTON IS SLAIN IN APPARENT BURGLARY
description: The director of the Alley Theater has been found slain in her office, and the police say that an automobile found burning in a poor neighborhood belonged to her.

title: Pennsylvania Ballet Suspends Performances
description: The Pennsylvania Ballet Company, facing a deficit of more than $1 million, today announced the suspension of its operations for 90 to 120 days.

title: SNOW
description: After eight years of exile from Chile, all I have to do to feel at home is look out the window. To a Latin American living in the States, this winter has turned the scenery into something sadly familiar.

title: EXILED SOUTH AFRICAN ALLOWED TO SEEK ASYLUM
description: Dennis Brutus, the exiled South African poet and scholar who has been ruled ''deportable'' because of an expired visa, received a temporary reprieve today.

title: N.Y.R.A. and Clerks Reach an Agreement
description: The New York Racing Association and the parimutuel clerks' union reached a contract agreement yesterday, subject to ratification by union membership.

title: BAYBANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NORTHWESTERN MUTUAL LIFE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes $186,000 gain from the sale of real estate... C-Includes $984,000 gain from the sale of real estate for the qr and $130,000 loss from the sale of real estate for the 6 mos

title: BRIEFING
description: T HE declaration that ''nonessential'' Government workers could take the day off because of the crippling effects of a snowstorm was instantly turned into a straight line all about the city.

title: NBD BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BANK OF NY CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After net securities losses of $475,423 and $1,750,685 for qr and yr, respectively, and an extraordinary charge of $6.2 milli for qr and yr

title: BREUER HELPS MINNESOTA TOP IOWA, 61-56
description: Randy Breuer, a 7-foot-3-inch center, scored 22 points to lead Minnesota to a 61-56 victory over Iowa tonight in a Big Ten game.

title: PIANO RECITAL: ZITTA FINKELSTEIN
description: ZITTA FINKELSTEIN'S technical achievements were not negligible in her recital at the 92d Street Y on Wednesday night; but they also were not transcendent enough to distract from the Israeli pianist's routine musical conceptions.

title: News Analysis
description: It may sound like a matter of semantics, but it makes a lot of difference whether the historic agreement between the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and the Justice Department is considered a ''settlement'' of the Government's antitrust case against the company or a ''modification'' of a 26-year-old consent decree. The two parties decided to frame their agreement as a modification of the consent decree that was signed in 1956 by A.T.&T. and the Justice Department and lodged in the Federal District Court in Newark. Therefore the parties submitted their proposal to the New Jersey court, along with a request to transfer jurisdiction over the consent decree to the Federal District Court in Washington, where Judge Harold H. Greene has been hearing the antitrust case.

title: MEGO INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-Includes $2,198,000 tax credit

title: Kaiser Unit Posts a Loss
description: The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation, hard hit by the worldwide decline in demand for aluminum, reported that it had a fourth-quarter loss of $16 million, compared with earnings of $43 million, or $1 a share, in the fourth quarter of 1980. Revenue slipped 11 percent, to $769.5 million from $864.2 million.

title: MORTON-NORWICH PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NATIONAL CONVENIENCE STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Shr earnings reflect a 20 percent stock divd paid in Oct

title: Paula Robison On L.I.
description: Paula Robison, the flutist, will perform with the Long Island Philharmonic tonight at 7:30 at Huntington High School, Oakwood and McKay Roads, in Huntington, L.I. The orchestra, directed by Christopher Keene, will play Handel's ''Water Music,'' Nielsen's Concerto for Flute and Brahms's Symphony No. 1 in C minor. Tickets are $8.50 to $13.75 (students and the elderly , half-price). Information: (516) 293-2222.

title: WEATHERING THE STORM IN QUIET DEPARTMENT STORES
description: ''I knew it would be a great morning to come over to Bloomie's,'' said Robert Rufino. ''I knew it would be dead. It's just a big playground for me, a big playground.''

title: GARY BURTON PLAYING RARE CLUB DATE
description: GARY BURTON, the jazz vibraharpist, is playing in a New York jazz club for the first time in five years this weekend. His engagement with his quartet at Seventh Avenue South tonight, tomorrow and Sunday is the result of a combination of convenience and timing that has drawn him away from his preference for playing concerts.

title: No Headline
description: CAREY REPORTED SET TO ANNOUNCE HE WILL NOT RUN

title: PITTSBURGH NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The per shr amounts have been adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in Oct 1981

title: TRANSAMERICA REALTY INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: B-Includes gains from the sale of investments of $818,000 for the qr and $849,000 for the yr and $1,100,000 tax credits for the yr...C-Includes tax credits of $521,000 for the qr and $1,219,000 for the yr and $139,000 gain for the yr from the sale of investments

title: Boat Show Opens Tomorrow
description: With miles of red-carpeted aisles and a record fleet of 550 boats, ranging from dinghies and canoes to a sleek 54-foot racing yacht, the 72d National Boat Show opens a nine-day run to the public tomorrow at 10 A.M. at the Coliseum.

title: MORGENTHAU SUING TO BAR STATE PLAN TO ROTATE JUSTICES
description: District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau of Manhatten filed suit yesterday to prevent the state's Chief Judge, Lawrence H. Cooke, from rotating acting judges in State Supreme Court.

title: USE OF CAMERAS IN COURT CLEARED FOR CONNECTICUT
description: The Connecticut Supreme Court will admit television cameras, tape recorders and still cameras for the first time beginning on April 12 for a one-year trial period, Chief Justice John A. Speziale announced today.

title: CHINESE 3-D MAYHEM
description: ''REVENGE of the Shogun Women,'' which opens today at the Embassy 3 and 4, is an English-dubbed kung-fu movie made in Taiwan. It would not deserve mention except for the fact that it's in a 3-D process to be avoided unless one is out to risk eye strain.

title: WHAT COMPETITION CAN DO TO HEALTH CARE
description: To the Editor:

title: McENROE TOPS CONNORS; LENDL BEATS VILAS EASILY
description: The match was not close, at least not compared with some of their previous ones. But John McEnroe's 6-2, 7-5 victory over Jimmy Connors in the Volvo Masters before a crowd of 18,753 at Madison Square Garden last night provided a sample of how tennis has changed as a spectator sport and why McEnroe now dictates the show.

title: Respite for Coach
description: Glen Sonmor, whose Minnesota North Stars have won only three of their last 16 games, will step down as coach for team's weekend games and sit in the press box.

title: EXPERTS VIEW ICE BUILDUP ON JETLINER AS LIKELY CAUSE OF CRASH IN
description: POTOMAC By RICHARD WITKIN

title: BARNETT BANKS OF FLORIDA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The 1980 per shr figures adjusted for 3-for-2 stock split paid in July 1981

title: SOLIDARITY CHIEFS LIST WAYS TO RESIST
description: As the Polish Government was saying again today that the country was gradually returning to normal, three leaders of the suspended Solidarity union who are in hiding issued a leaflet listing ways in which the population should oppose martial law. The methods included ''passive resistance'' and a variety of socialand psycholog ical pressures. The leaflet called for Communist Party members to re sign and urged a ''social boycott'' of all ''collaborato rs, sycophants and zealous supporters of the junta.''

title: LOYALTY TO NEW YORK EXPRESSED BY MANY WHO HELP NEDDIEST
description: New York City stirs devotion, loyalty and gratitude from residents past and present, and many contributors attest to that in their gifts to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Farah Wins Judgment
description: The Farah Manufacturing Company, a producer of slacks, jeans and shorts based in El Paso, Tex., said yesterday that a state court jury in El Paso had awarded it a $19 million judgment against the State National Bank of El Paso and other lenders, which Farah charged had unlawfully taken control of the company in the late 1970's. In the suit, filed three years ago, Farah had asked $86 million in actual damages and twice that much in exemplary damages.

title: Union Pacific Plan
description: The Union Pacific Corporation said it plans a record capital investment program of $1.3 billion this year, an increase of 36 percent, or $339 million, over 1981. James H. Evans, chairman, said that the the budget includes $1 billion for the Champlin Petroleum Company, $163 million for the Union Pacific Railroad and $63 million for the Rocky Mountain Energy Company. Of Champlin's total investment, $628 million will be allocated for oil and gas exploration, the company said.

title: NINE INMATES ESCAPE BY DISARMING GUARD AT COURT IN BROOKLYN
description: Nine prisoners charged with crimes ranging from assault to attempted murder - eight of them manacled in pairs by the hands and legs - overpowered three corrections officers and escaped from a downtown Brooklyn courthouse yesterday evening, city correction officials said.

title: Insurance Savings On G.M. 'A' Cars
description: The General Motors Corporation's wholly owned car insurance company, the Motors Insurance Corporation, announced that it will offer rate reductions of up to 28 percent on G.M.'s new ''A'' body cars. Premium savings will range from 17 percent on collision coverage to 28 percent on comprehensive, said John Andrews, a spokesman for the subsidiary.

title: AN AMAZON BUY OUT BY BRAZIL
description: Daniel K. Ludwig, the American shipping executive and financier, is abandoning his epic billion-dollar development project in the Brazilian Amazon.

title: The Family Is Crucial Indeed
description: Reflect a moment upon the uproar that never was when Richard Lyman, President of the Rockefeller Foundation, said the growth of households headed by minority women was now ''the most conspicuous and urgent single poverty problem in the country.''

title: SCHMIDT, IN PARLIAMENT, DEFENDS STANCE ON POLAND
description: Chancellor Helmut Schmidt told Parliament today that the nations of the Atlantic alliance would react with appropriate political and economic steps ''according to the development of the situation in Poland.''

title: LIST OF PLANE CRASH CASUALTIES
description: Following is an unofficial list of passengers and crew members on Air Florida's Flight 90, which crashed Wednesday after taking off from National Airport outside Washington, and of those reported killed on the 14th Street Bridge, which was hit by the jetliner. It is based on information from airline officials in Washington and Miami, hospital spokesmen and information provided by friends and relatives who were notified. In some cases the hometowns differ. In such cases, the first hometown is that provided by Air Florida, and one supplied by relatives follows.

title: A TOUR THROUGH CENTRAL PARK IN WINTER WOOLLIES
description: The majestic turkey oak trees in the northern part of Central Park have lost their leaves, but not their majesty - at least not in the eyes of an Urban Park Ranger named Bruce Reynolds. ''They're j ust as beautiful in the winter as they are in the summer,'' sai d Mr. Reynolds. ''The turkey oak has a dark, deeply furrowed bark , and against a white background it's very stately.''

title: Coach Is Optimistic
description: Gene Smithson, the coach of Wichita State's basketball team, said he was not expecting a defection by his players and recruits following an announcement by the National Collegiate Athletic Association that the university had been placed on probation for three years.

title: Treatment for Best
description: George Best, the San Jose Earthquakes' leading scorer, has entered an alcoholic rehabilitation program, according to John Carbay, the team's general manager. The 35-year-old remains suspended indefinitely for his failure to report to two of the Earthquakes' weekend matches in Seattle and Portland. The suspension will stand until he ''is mentally and physically prepared to rejoin the 'Quakes,'' Carbray said.

title: MARINE MIDLAND BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After securities losses of $146,000 and $2.5 million in qr and yr, respectively, and extraordinary gain of $6.8 million for qr and yr

title: BRUIN RALLY FOILS ISLANDERS, 5-4
description: With four goals in the last two periods, the Bruins rallied to defeat the Islanders, 5-4, tonight. Boston ended the Islanders' winning streak at four games and extended its winning streak to four.

title: CHEMICAL NEW YORK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After securities losses of $12.8 million and $10.1 million in qr and yr, respectively, and extraordinary gain of $9.9 million on exchange of equity for debt in qr and yr

title: CHARLES GILMAN OF PAPER CONCERN
description: Charles Gilman Jr., president of the Gilman Paper Company, the largest privately owned concern in the industry, died Wednesday at Lenox Hill Hospital at the age of 51. He maintained homes in Manhattan, Yulee, Fla., and Gilman, Vt.

title: France Reaffirms Plan To Rebuild Iraqi Reactor
description: Foreign Minister Claude Cheysson reiterated today that France would rebuild the Iraqi nuclear reactor destroyed by Israel last year. He added that Paris was taking steps ''to insure an exclusively peaceful utilization of the reactor.''

title: IRVING BANK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Death of Paratrooper, 18, Under Inquiry by Army
description: Spurred by complaints from enlisted men, military officials are investigating charges that a commander ignored wind restrictions in ordering a jump that resulted in the death of an 18-year-old paratrooper.

title: THOMAS R. WILLIAMS
description: Thomas Resolved Williams, a senior partner in the importing concern of Ichabod T. Williams & Sons of New York City, died Saturday at his home in Lawrence, L.I. He was 100 years old. The importi ng concern, which specialized in rare woods and veneers,was founded b y Mr. Williams's great-grandfather in 1838 and closed in1973.

title: HENRY AARON AND DEDICATION
description: ON the afternoon of April 4, 1974, a sports talk show was being taped in a television studio in Manhattan. Suddenly it was interrupted. A note had been passed to the host by a producer, and the guest, a sports reporter, waited.

title: Frost Lifts Wholesale J uice Prices
description: Wholesale prices for Florida orange concentrate have been raised 11.8 percent because of this week's freeze, and consumers soon will see higher juice prices at the supermarket, industry leaders said today.

title: DOWNTOWN: TRENDS IN AMERICAN DRAWING
description: IN the five years of its existence, the Drawing Center at 137 Greene Street in SoHo, founded by Martha Beck as a nonprofit showcase for unique works on paper, has proved itself a survivor. It has given exposure to young and untried artists, mounted a brilliant show or two (such as last year's ''Sculptors' Drawings over Six Centuries: 1400-1950,'' whose curator was Colin Eisler), and managed to attract the needed support money to stay alive. If its exhibitions, by and large, are too broadly inclusive, lacking the ''eye'' and standard of taste that could be expected from a privately run gallery, one might blame the center's policy of presenting group shows ''as diverse and unstructured as possible'' to illustrate its definition of drawing: any unique work on paper. And there is also the fact that the center is a public facility, getting funds from government, foundation and other sources that tend to emphasize coverage rather than selectivity.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL BALTIMORE (AL) - N amed Lance Nichols as manager of Rochester of the In- ternational League.

title: AGENCY MAY ALTER ATOM WASTE POLICY
description: The Environmental Protection Agency is preparing rules that would permit the dumping of low-level radioactive wastes in the ocean, officials said. Although su ch dumping is not prohibited by the Marine Protection Act of 1972, it has been considered contrary to Federal policy.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rate payable by savings institutions.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Manes Leaves Hospital
description: Borough President Donald R. Manes of Queens was released from a hospital yesterday and said he was ''feeling fine'' after undergoing an emergency appendectomy last week.

title: Children's Art Show
description: Until snow covers the city, children of all ages can get a preview of winter activity in the city's parks at ''A Children's View of Christmas,'' an exhibition that runs through Jan. 29 at the Department of Parks and Recreation's Arsenal Gallery, inside Central Park at 64th Street off Fifth Avenue. The paintings, drawings, banners and three-dimensional pieces on display are by students from kindergarten to ninth grade. Gallery hours are Monday to Friday, 9:30 A.M. to 4:30 P.M. Admission is free.

title: REAGAN'S SWIFT AND UNFAIR REFUGEE SOLUTION
description: To the Editor:

ATI INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
PENNSYLVANIA REAL ESTATE INVESTMENT TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Nov
COURAGE OF THE FOURTH IS KNOWN, BUT NOT THE NAME
description: There were brave men among the living and the dead in the crash of an Air Florida jetliner yesterday into the frozen Potomac River.

title: 1,056 Are Released, Polish Authorities Say
description: Poland's military regime announced today that 1,056 people arrested under martial law had been released. The Government spokesman, Jerzy Urban, also said that new arrests have dropped off sharply - from over 350 from Dec. 13 to 22, to about 210 for the entire period since then.

title: Books:
description: Kafka at Home By Michiko Kakutani KAFKA. A Biography. By Ronald Hayman. 349 pages. Oxford University Press.$19.95. LETTERS TO OTTLA & FAMILY. By Franz Kafka. Translated by Richard and Clara Winston. Edited by N.N. Glatzer. 130 pages. Schocken Books. $15.95.

title: WHAT COMPETITION CAN DO FOR HEALTH CARE
description: To the Editor:

title: Broadway; Most tickets for 'Dreamgirls' are now $40.
description: ''DREAMGIRLS,'' the single hit so far of the current Broadway season, is capitalizing on its position as the show of the moment. Tickets for nearly all seats for all evening performances, plus the Saturday matinee, have gone up to $40. ''Evita'' and ''42d Street,'' the only other shows with $40 tickets, are charging this top price only for Friday and Saturday night performances.

title: Images
description: There is a kind of story that television has told many times during the last 18 years. It lacks dialogue, although one sometimes hears the murmur of a crowd or a sudden shout, but it never lacks noise.

title: Marchi Supports Regan In Gubernatorial Race
description: High political office, State Senator John J. Marchi said yesterday, ''is rapidly becoming the sport of subsidized paupers or privileged princes who can launch their careers without experience and with a penchant for power.''

title: ITT INSURER UNIT DROPS WHOLE LIFE
description: Seldom does a company president acknowledge that his old products are obsolete and expensive, but that is what Robert W. MacDonald, president of the ITT Life Insurance Corporation, did today in discussing whole-life insurance.

title: TWO BANKS DOWNGRADE POLISH DEBT
description: The Marine Midland Bank of New York and the Fidelity Bank of Philadelphia reported yesterday that they had placed their loans to Poland in the category of ''nonperforming assets.''

title: MAYOR FIGHTS SAN DIEGO MEDIA VACUUM
description: By ROBERT LINDSEY SAN DIEGO, Jan. 10 - Pete Wilson, this city 's politically ambitiousMayor, says he believes that he may finally b e escaping from the clutches of what some analysts have called th e ''San Diego curse'': the difficulty in achieving credibility as a candidate for statewide office faced by a politician in California's second largest city.

title: Quincy Market Blackout Causes Toxic Fume Leak
description: A power blackout and fumes leaking from a transformer that contained PCB's today forced evacuation of 300 people from Quincy Market, the keystone of Boston's waterfront renewal.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''You are that tough little tug that can pull our ship of state off the shoals and out into open water.'' - President Reagan, to New York industrialists. (A14:1.)

title: Rockies a Step Closer On Moving to Ottawa
description: A special National Hockey League committee studying the Colorado Rockies gave tentative approval today for the Rockies to move their franchise to the Ottawa area.

title: Sigurd Olson, a Writer And Environmentalist
description: Sigurd F. Olson, nature writer and environmentalist, died of a heart attack Wednesday while snowshoeing near his home. He was 82 years old.

title: 2 Rules Eased on Thrift Units
description: Federal regulators today reduced the net worth that federally insured savings and loan associations must have, and thereby removed about 80 institutions from close scrutiny by the Government.

title: A WRONG LABEL FOR VIETNAMESE MOTHERS
description: To the Editor:

title: A.M.C. SHAKE-UP FIRST BY RENAULT
description: Gerald C. Meyers, chairman and chief executive of the American Motors Corporation, stepped down today, in the first real shake-up of the company since it came under French control.

title: Around the World; Carter Calls Protesters At Embassy in Moscow
description: Former President Jimmy Carter telephoned the United States Embassy in Moscow today in an effort to persuade two Russian Pentecostalists taking refuge there to give up a three-week protest fast. He failed.

title: City Sues Reds for Rent Lost During the Strike
description: City officials filed a long-threatened lawsuit today, asking $1.1 million from the Cincinnati Reds for breach of contract concerning Riverfront Stadium. The city is trying to recover stadium rent and fees it contends it lost during the 50-day baseball strike last summer.

title: No Headline
description: Sixers' Slump Worsens

title: Around the World; Chile's Supreme Court Reopens Letelier Inquiry
description: The Chilean supreme court today reopened an investigation of three secret police officials accused in the 1976 assassination of former Foreign Minister Orlando Letelier, saying their innocence had not been fully established.

title: CITY'S HOMELESS: STORY OF BOBBY CRUZ
description: When Bobby Cruz, by his own account a chronic alcoholic, landed homeless on the streets of Manhattan a year ago - at the age of 26 - he believed that his life was over.

title: Soviet Grain Output
description: The United States Agriculture Department today estimated Soviet 1981 grain production at 175 million metric tons, unchanged from its December estimate. In its monthly report, the department put Soviet wheat production at 88 million tons, coarse grain production at 77 million and miscellaneous grain production at 10 million tons, all unchanged from last month. The department said this compares with the Soviet target of 236 million tons and is the smallest crop since 1975.

title: Around the Nation; U.S. Deports First Cuban Since Castro Took Over
description: A man believed to be the first Cuban refugee ever to be deported from the United States to Havana under the Castro regime was flown to Havana today, the Immigration and Naturalization Service said.

title: RED SMITH, SPORTS COLUMNIST WHO WON PULITZER, DIES AT 76
description: Red Smith, a Pulitzer Prize-winning sports columnist for The New York Times and one of the nation's most admired sports commentators, died at Stamford (Conn.) Hospital yesterday of heart failure after a brief illness. He was 76 years old and lived in New Canaan.

title: Sports People; Hearns-Geraldo Bout
description: Thomas Hearns, the former World Boxing Association welterweight champion, yesterday signed to meet Marcos Geraldo, a veteran of 60 bouts, in a 10-round fight in Las Vegas on Feb 27.

title: EXCERPTS FROM TEXT OF MAYOR'S PLAN TO BALANC E BUDGET FOR FISCAL '83
description: Following are excerpts from Mayor Koch's letter to the Board of Estimate, the City Council and the Financial Control Board that accompanied his financial plan:

title: N.A.A.C.P. MOVES IN HIGH COURT TO BAR SCHOOL TAX-EXEMPT STATUS
description: The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People filed papers in the Supreme Court today seeking to block tax-exempt status for more than 100 private schools that discriminate on the basis of race.

title: 'FOSTER CARE IS NOT A HOLDING-TANK SYSTEM'
description: To the Editor:

title: BIDDER RAISES OFFER FOR CANNON MILLS
description: David Murdock, the West Coast multimillionaire, sweetened his offer to buy the Cannon Mills Company yesterday, but Wall Street analysts close to Cannon said privately that they expected the new proposal to get a cold reception.

title: THE 'MANSION CAP'
description: .6,2,570.4,0PRINCETON, N.J. - With estimates of future Federal budget deficits spiraling, and the Reagan Administration scrambling for new sources of revenue that will not thwart economic recovery, the time is ripe to go after one of the sacred cows of American tax policy: homeowners' unlimited tax deduction on the interest paid on a mortage.

title: HARMLESS RADIATION OF SMOKE DETECTORS
description: To the Editor:

title: Naval Order for Litton
description: The Ingall Shipbuilding division of Litton Industries was awarded a $664.2 million contract by the Navy for construction of Aegis guided missile cruisers, the Defense Department said today.

title: MRS. GANDHI MAKES SHIFTS IN CABINET
description: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi announced major changes in her Cabinet today to carry out an economic program, apparently in an attempt to soften growing public criticism of her rule.

title: HALT URGED AT NUCLEAR PROJECT
description: The managing director of the Washington Public Power Supply System yesterday recommended the termination of two controversial West Coast nuclear power projects, an action analysts felt would enable the troubled Supply System, which still has three other nuclear plants under construction, to continue its billion-dollar borrowings.

title: Turkish Ex-Chief to Be Freed
description: Former Prime Minister Bulent Ecevit, who is serving a three-month jail term for defying a military ban on public statements, will be released Feb. 1, his lawyer said today. Mr. Ecevit was jailed Dec. 3 after a martial-law court found him guilty of violating a decree aimed at gagging former politicians.

title: Clippers 117, Cavaliers 108
description: SAN DIEGO (UPI) - Michael Brooks scored 21 points and had 14 rebounds to help San Diego deal Cleveland its ninth consecutive loss and its 15th straight on the road. A field goal by Brooks with 3:24 left broke a 100-100 tie. San Diego (11-25) outscored Cleveland, 17-8, in the final three minutes as the Cavaliers fell to 6-30 - the worst record in the league.

title: A PRIVATE INDUSTRY COUNCIL THAT WORKS
description: To the Editor:

title: Panel Holds Hearing On Dispute in Indy 500
description: Members of a special three-man panel heard arguments yesterday from lawyers representing Bobby Unser and Mario Andretti, the two men contesting for an official victory in the 1981 Indianapolis 500 auto race.

description: Almost Tall Stories By ANATOLE BROYARD Ballads, Blues and Swansongs. By William Wiser. 182 pages. Atheneum. $10.95.

title: FOR THE YOUNG IN CITY, SNOW IS A JOY
description: ''I like to eat it,'' said Camille Kubie, who is 5 years old. ''I hate to walk on it,'' said Evelyn Porter, who was struggling down Fifth Avenue on her way to a doctor's appointment. ''Shoveling it is a drag,'' said Clinton Smith, who was trying to make a path through the snowbank in front of a drugstore on Madison Avenue.

title: G.O.P. SENATORS BID REAGAN LIFT TAXES
description: Republican leaders of the Senate pressed President Reagan today to accept a $45 billion package of tax increases to bring the Federal deficit down in the next two years. They said a decision by Mr. Reagan on the matter was ''imminent.''

title: GLOSSARY OF COMMONLY USED TERMS
description: Term Insurance Revertible term insurance is generally the cheapest policy for healthy people who gamble on continuing to stay healthy. However, it is not au- tomatically renewable. In later years a person who becomes sick would not be able to renew at the cheap rate and might have to pay a higher rate, sometimes much higher. Before buying compare the higher rates. Renewable term insurance offers a guaranteed option to renew without a health examination up to retirement age and sometimes beyond. In shopping for renewable term policies, buyers should keep an eye on re- newal costs for all ages. Since there is tremendous competition among companies selling one-year renewable term, it usually is the cheapest. Convertible term insuran ce can be converted t o a cash-value policy at any time, generally up to age 60 or 65, without another medi cal examination. Almost all renewable policies are convertible. When comparisionshop- ping, look for policies that have the oldest age for con version. Joint-life term insurance covers two persons but pays one death benefit. It may not be cheaper than two individual term policies. Decreasing term insurance, often used to cover the outstan ding balance of a home mortgage, has a fixed annual cost. Initially it o ffers largecover- age for a small premium, but since its benefits decline over time it should not be used as a primary insurance policy, accord ing to Consum- ers Union. Credit life or credit disability insurance is bought to pa y off a loan if the borrower dies or to pay monthly loan payments if the bor rower becomes disabled.

title: Federal Judge Is Selected
description: President Reagan plans to nominate Federal District Judge Leroy J. Contie Jr. to the appeals court bench, the White House announced today. If confirmed by the Senate, Judge Contie, 61 years old, of Canton, Ohio, would move up to the United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit, in Cincinnati.

title: MORGENTHAU AND OPPONENTS TRADE CHARGES ON COURT SUIT
description: District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau of Manhattan went to State Supreme Court himself yesterday to press his case against the state's Chief Judge, Lawrence H. Cooke. But a hearing on his lawsuit to block a new system of assigning judges to the court was postponed until Tuesday.

title: ABBOTT, ON WITNESS STAND, ADMITS FATAL STABBING
description: Jack Henry Abbott, weeping on the witness stand, admitted yesterday that he had stabbed a waiter to death with a kitchen knife last summer, but he pleaded that it was a ''tragic misunderstanding'' born of his lifetime of exposure to prison violence.

description: A dental patient can be supplied with analgesic gas and music at the same time with equipment patented this week by Nolan Bellisario of Cardiff, Calif.

description: The General Motors Corporation announced plant closings and production cutbacks for various periods over the next four months that will put 60,400 employees out of work, 5,400 of them indefinitely.

title: Cancer Group Accused Of Wasting $159,000
description: A critic of the National Cancer Institute has accused the agency of wasting $159,000 on a magazine ''entirely devoted to self-glorification and self-promotion.'' Irwin D.J. Bross, director of biostatistics at Roswell Park Memorial Inst itute for cancer treatment in Buffalo, said Wednesday that the mone y should have been spent on cancer research.

title: INVENTORIES UP 0.7% IN NOVEMBER
description: The value of inventories held by American business rose seven-tenths of 1 percent in November as manufacturers, wholesalers and retailers continued to have trouble selling off stockpiles, new Government figures indicated today.

title: Around the Nation; Jury Tentatively Seated For Trial of von Bulow
description: A jury of housewives, blue-collar workers and professionals was tentatively seated today to try Claus von Bulow in the attempted murder of his socialite wife.

title: MCI SEES BELL SHIFTING COSTS
description: William G. McGowan, chairman of the MCI Communications Corporation and one of the Bell System's most vocal competitors, warned today that the American Tele phone and Telegraph Company might attempt to shift its costs to c ustomers of local phone companies before a planned divestiture occurr ed over the next 18 months.

title: TEAMSTERS AGREE TO TENTATIVE PACT WITH CONCESSIONS
description: Negotiators for the International Brotherhood of Teamsters and trucking concerns reached a tentative agreement today on a contract reported to include major concessions made by theunion in the hope of protecting the 300,000 j obs in the troubled industry.

title: EX-TIMES EXECUTIVE IN ADVERTISING FIELD
description: Roger W. Atwood, a former assistant advertising manager of The New York Times who was with the newspaper for more than 20 years, died of cancer Thursday at New York Hospital. He was 56 years old and a resident of East Hampton, L.I.

title: Saturday News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 44.

title: JETS TIE RANGERS ON LATE GOAL, 4-4
description: The Rangers' unbeaten streak reached five games tonight in a 4-4 tie with the Winnipeg Jets. Morris Lukowich's power-play goal with 1 minute 34 seconds to play tied the game for Winnipeg.

title: PROVISIONAL APPROVAL GIVEN TO PARTIAL MERGER OF SEATTLE NEWSPAPERS
description: A Federal administrative law judge gave an unqualified endorsement yesterday to a plan for Seattle's two daily newspapers to merge their production, business, circulation and advertising functions. His opinion was submitted to William French Smith, the United States Attorney General, who will make the final decision on the joint operating agreement.

title: Consumer Saturday; ANSWERING ESSENTIAL QUESTIONS ABOUT LIFE INSURANCE
description: Americans spent $43 billion on life insurancepremiums last year, and, if consumer research is valid, a great number may no t have known what they were buying.

title: Council Turns Down Borg
description: Bjorn Borg may have to play in the qualifying round for the French, Wimbledon and United States Open tennis championships unless he upgrades his tournament commitments for the year, the Men's International Professional Tennis Council announced yesterday.

title: Czechoslovak Author Loses Citizenship While in the West
description: Jiri Grusa, the Czechoslovak author, has been stripped of his citizenship while on an extended stay in the West, a Czechoslovak Embassy spokesman confirmed today.

title: Paul Jacobs, Authority On Marketing of Food
description: Paul M. Jacobs, a well-known authority on food marketing and former chairman and chief executive officer of the Gorton Corporation of Gloucester, Mass., died Sunday at his home in Belmont, Mass. Mr. Jacobs, who also had a residence in Gloucester, was 65 years old.

title: FLYING FIRST CLASS FOR $5 MORE
description: Wes Williams, an engineer with the Magnavox Company who travels often on business, settled his 6-foot 2-inch frame into the wide seat on Trans World Airlines' flight 803, bound for Los Angeles from New York. Smiling, he stretched out his legs and said, ''Look at this seating.''

title: WARRIORS BEAT KNICKS, 104-102
description: As they did in Phoenix the night before, the Knicks seemed to be in control against the Warriors tonight when some last-second heroics by Golden State - and failures by New York - cost them the game.

title: FOR MRS. REAGAN, GIFTS MEAN HIGH FASHION AT NO COST
description: President Reagan's wife, Nancy, is accepting clothing valued at thousands of dollars as loans and gifts from American designers.

title: Dow Up 5.32, to 847.60; Energy Issues Advance
description: Strength in energy, technology and railroad issues - sectors hit by recent selling - helped to send the stock market higher yesterday. The Dow Jones industrial average rose by 5.32 points, to 847.60. But volume remained modest on the New York Stock Exchange. Many analysts have maintained that any prolonged market advance must be accompanied by a daily turnover exceeding 50 million shares. Yesterday, 43.3 million shares changed hands, compared with Thursday's 42.9 million.

title: Letter: On Dental Care; The Fluoridation Battle Isn't Over
description: To the Editor: Your editorial ''The Fluoridation Plot'' (Jan. 7) makes it clear that The Times has been out of touch with the fluoridation controversy. Proponents of fluoridation certainly don't make it easy for a newspaper to learn the truth about the health hazards and failure of fluoridation, so we can understand why you don't know what's been happening.

title: The City; 3 Hiding in Bank Rob It of $63,000
description: Three gunmen apparently hid overnight in the basement of a bank branch in Flushing, Queens, then robbed it of $63,000 when it opened, the police said.

description: To Dr. Steve Hotze, the basic question is strictly one of public morality: Should homosexuals be denied official support so that they will find it more difficult to expand their influence over the young people of the capital of Texas? He and his allies emphatically say yes.

title: German Bankruptcies
description: West German bankruptcies during November totaled 1,063, up 50.4 percent from a year earlier, the federal statistics office said today. Company bankruptcies climbed 67.9 percent, to 816; insolvencies of private individuals totaled 247. Bankruptcies in the first 11 months totaled 10,460, the agency said, up 25.7 percent from the similar 1980 period.

description: The Deep South, chopping its way out of a deep freeze virtually unparalled by other winter storms in this century, has been told to brace for another icy blast of freezing drizzle and record-low temperatures this weekend.

title: Reporter to Receive Award
description: Sarah McClendon, a Washington reporter since 1944, will receive the American Legion's National Commander's Public Relations Award for outstanding public service in communications. The award will be presented at a luncheon Feb. 17. Mrs. McClendon founded the McClendon News Service. She writes a column for the Intercontinental Press Syndicate and reports for daily newspapers in Texas, Wisconsin and California.

description: The British Government today turned down two $950 million bids to purchase the Royal Bank of Scotland, the largest bank in Scotland and the fifth largest in Britain.

description: In the two weeks since he seized power for the second time in two years, Jerry J. Rawlings has dismantled or suppressed most democratic institutions in Ghana.

description: ''Grown Ups,'' the comedy by Jules Feiffer that was to close tonight, won a reprieve when business improved in the last few days. The play will continue indefinitely at the Lyceum Theater.

description: The State Department said that Senator Larry Pressler, Republican of South Dakota, was detained by the Polish police for 30 minutes today in a dispute over the taking of photographs at a Warsaw market.

description: The highest-ranking Solidarity leader who is still at large has declared in an interview that the union is continuing its activities underground and is prepared for a long struggle to fight for democrac y and to overcome what he called military ''di ctatorship.''

title: 2D STUDY PLANNED ON TALKS ON AGING
description: The White House Conference on Aging, where acrimonious political conflict arose in its four-day session last month, will be the subject of a second assessment, independent of the one being conducted by the Reagan Administration.

title: 2 HORROR MOVIES
description: ''Saturday the 14th'' is not the worst horror film that opened here yesterday. That is ''The Boogens.'' However, ''Saturday the 14th'' is the most aggressively wasteful. It's an unfunny horror-filmparody with a cast headed by Richard Benjamin, Paula Prentiss and Severn Darden , directed and written by Howard R. Cohen, who shouldn't be trusted to park the cars of such people, much less make a movie with them.

title: Bridge: A Contract May Be Made When Hope Is Unjustified
description: Conventional wisdom advises that a game should be attempted if it has about a 50 percent chance of success. But this varies with the vulnerability and the type of scoring. In noncompetitive auctions, a player who is vulnerable should be aggressive, and one who is not should be cautious.

title: DEMOCRATS REDUCE CAMPAIGN SEASON
description: Even while preserving the New Hampshire primary and the Iowa caucuses as the opening battlefields of the Presidential race, the Democratic Party's latest commission on Presidential nomination rules voted today to shrink the 1984 campaign season from 20 weeks to 15.

title: MILNES ILL, CANCELS MET DATES
description: Sherrill Milnes has canceled the remainder of his scheduled appearances at the Metropolitan Opera for the 1981-82 season. Mr. Milnes's press representative, Cynthia Robbins, reports that the internationally known American baritone is suffering severe muscular strain in his throat. It was brought on, Miss Robbins said, by singing while suffering from an intestinal virus.

title: Briefing
description: S OMETIME over Christmas, former Vice President Walter F. Mondale phoned Eleanor Smeal, head of the National Organization for Women, to ask if there was anything he could do to spur passage of the proposed Federal equal rights amendment.

It wasn't that long ago that Edwin Viruet was one of the best lightweights in the world, a dancing, taunting boxer who could laugh at opponents because no one could hurt him. And then he virtually disappeared in his native Puerto Rico.

''His heart is continuing to show progress, but essentially, there has been no change in his level of consciousness,'' said a spokesman for Massachusetts General Hospital.

description: Mayor Koch and four of his friends are headed for a nine-day vacation in Spain, with stops planned in Madrid, Seville, Granada and Barcelona.

title: City Stores Sale
description: The City Stores Company, a major retail concern, announced signing of a previously reported agreement to sell three of its Maison Blanche suburban department stores in the New Orleans area to Goudchaux's Inc., a retail company based in Baton Rouge, La. Terms of the transaction, expected to be completed in February, were not disclosed. The stores will continue to operate under the Maison Blanche name.

title: DR. SEYMOUR HESS, MARS RESEARCHER
description: Seymour Lester Hess, the meteorologist who issued mankind's first weather report from Mars, died yesterday at the Tallahassee (Fla.) Memorial Medical Center. He was 61 years old and lived in Tallahassee, where he taught and conducted research at Florida State University.

title: Brazilian Law May Let Unionist Enter Election
description: Brazil's Congress approved a law today that could allow the country's best-known labor leader, Luis Inacio da Silva, to run in elections next November despite his conviction for violating national security laws.

title: HARDWICKE COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Yr to Sept 27
U.S. DROPS 10-YEAR ANTITRUST SUIT AGAINST 3 LARGEST CEREAL MAKERS
description: The Federal Trade Commission, in a 3-to-1 vote, decided today to dismiss the 1 0-year-old antitrust case againstthe nation's three biggest breakfast cereal makers, Kellogg, General Mills and Gen eral Foods.

title: Your Money; Tax Write-Offs Quietly Eased
description: IF you're not a coal miner, you may not have much interest in the Black Lung Benefits Revenue Act of 1981, which President Reagan signed on Dec. 29. But look again, for a rider to that bill goes far afield into the totally unrelated area of income-tax deduction. Specifically, it liberalizes, among other things, the requirements for claiming deductions for an office in your home.

title: Internorth Stake In Bucyrus-Erie
description: Internorth Inc., an energy company, disclosed that it had acquired an 8.8 percent interest in the Bucyrus-Erie Company, a manufacturer based in Milwaukee.

title: COPPOLA ENDS 'HEART' PACT
description: Francis Coppola has still not reached an agreement with Paramount Pictures concerning distribution of his new film, ''One From the Heart,'' he announced last night. At a news conference at Radio City Music Hall after the first of two preview screenings of ''One From the Heart'' at Radio City, he remained vague about when his film would be released and by whom.
To the Editor:

title: MANOR CARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
VIENNA CHOIR BOYS TAKE 483 YEARS INTO CARNEGIE
description: Tradition, especially if it's musical, has a special meaning in Vienna, where people showing a visitor through their home are quick to point out that Brahms once gave a recital in the drawing room, and where the waiters at the Cafe Mozart arch their eyebrows in disbelief if asked what music is inscribed on the papers in which the sugar cubes come wrapped. ''Die Zauberflote!'' they will bark, with ill-concealed irritation that their questioner either can't read music or doesn't recognize the tune.

title: M.T.A. TOLL HEARINGS PLANNED
description: The Board of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority voted yesterday to hold public hearings next month on its plan for toll increases of 25 percent or more on seven bridges and two tunnels in New York City. The board would then have to meet again and approve the toll increase proposal before it could go into effect.

title: GREAT AMERICAN BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Transit Strike in Montreal
description: Transit maintenance workers went on strike here early today, shutting down Montreal's bus and subway system and forcing half a million commuters to find other ways of getting to and from work in 15-degree weather.

title: FILM: 'VERNON, FLORIDA'
description: ''Vernon, Florida'' was shown in last year' s New York Film Festivalat Lincoln Center. Following are excerpts fro m a review by Janet Maslin in The New York Times of Oct. 8, 1981. The film is at the FilmForum 2, 57 Watts Street

title: FILMWAYS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-Net loss after losses of $1.1 million from discontinued operations...C-After income of $26.2 million from discontinued operations and extraordinary income of $17.1 million...D-Net lo is after $1.1 million net from discontinued operations

title: BELL PACT IS SENT TO TRIAL COURT
description: Federal Judge Vincent P. Biunno yesterday transferred supervision of the Justice Department's settlement of its antitrust suit against A.T.& T. to the Federal District Court in Washington from the Federal District Court in Newark.

title: Kite Is 1-Shot Leader With 200
description: Tom Kite, who bided his time the first two days, took the lead today in the third round of the Bob Hope Desert Classic. His round was graced by an eagle 2 on the 396-yard 18th hole, where he holed out with a 9-iron from 142 yards.

title: Seabrook Unit Ratings Cut
description: The Standard & Poor's Corporation yesterday reduced the credit ratings of bonds issued by the Public Service Company of New Hampshire, a move that could force the utility to stop building the second of two nuclear reactors at Seabrook, N.H.

title: Around the World; Bomb Explosion Wounds 15 in West Berlin
description: A bomb exploded in a restaurant frequented by Jews in West Berlin late today, wounding 15 people, including a 6-month-old baby, the police said.

title: FED RETURNS TO M-1 AS ITS KEY MEASURE
description: Monetary economists and others who follow the Federal Reserve's weekly money supply reports for clues about future interest rates said goodbye this week to M-1A, M-1B and shift-adjusted M-1B and greeted the return of the old familiar M-1 measure.

title: UNITED STATES TRUST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
GIRARD CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CULLEN-FROST BANKERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Notes on People; A Chastening Return Home for Mark Thatcher
description: With what sounded like a family row brewing over his future as a race-car driver, Mark Thatcher, the 28-year-old son of the British Prime Minister, Margaret Thatcher, returned to London yesterday.

title: AMERICAN CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Dr. Simon N. Whitney; Economist and Author
description: Dr. Simon Newcomb Whitney, an economist, author and professor emeritus of economics at New York University, died Thursday at his home in Scarsdale, N.Y. He was 78 years old.

title: ISC SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 24
Weirather of Austria Takes Cup Downhill
description: Harti Weirather of Austria bettered by more than six seconds the record for the Streif course and captured the men's World Cup downhill race today.

title: BENIGN FOREIGN AGENTS
description: To the Editor:

title: Hugh Carey's Choice
description: Hugh Carey has always known his priorities. That accounts for his most heroic acts as Governor, for his skill at looking beyond the moment, and also for his periodic aloofness. He weighed his priorities again in rejecting an arduous bid for re-election. As always, his decisions command respect.

title: SORG PRINTING CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
TRANSCRIPT OF GOVERNOR'S ANNOUNCEMENT THAT HE WON'T SEEK RE-ELECTION
description: Following is the text of Governor Carey's announcement that he would not seek a third term in office, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Match Lasts 100 Games
description: Harry Fritz of Canada needed a grueling 100 games and six hours to defeat Jorge Andrew of Venezuela today in the first singles match of an opening-round Davis Cup competition. The first set went 30 games before Fritz won, 16-14.

title: ALLRIGHT AUTO PARKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After gain from sale of land and leaseholds of $565,000 in the qr and $2.7 million for the 6 mos...C-After gain from sale of land and leaseholds of $863,000 in the qr and $145,000 for the 6 mos

title: G.O.P. Officials Differ
description: On Election Prospects

title: 40 FILM PROJEC TS AT CBS
description: CBS Theatrical Films has announced that it will be going into the movie business in a big way this year, with 40 films in various stages of development. Two of the movies will star Jon Voight and one will be directed by Michael Cimino, who won an Academy Award for ''The Deer Hunter'' in 1978 and then directed the $40 million failure ''Heaven's Gate.''

title: Volvo Robot Plan
description: Volvo, the Swedish auto maker, intends to begin producing industrial robots in a leased plant near Detroit, state officials said. The plant will manufacture ''guided driverless vehicles'' to carry parts between robots in automobile plants, Robert Berg, an aide to Gov. William G. Milliken, said. Mr. Berg said that the Swedish auto maker hopes to employ 200 to 300 workers and have annual sales of $100 million at full production.

title: SEVERAL ASSESS CHANCE TO WIN PARTY PRIMARY
description: Governor Carey's decision against seeking re-election set the stage yesterday for an unusually crowded gubernatorial primary in a party noted for its primary battles.

title: RAIN OF TERROR
description: .4,2,156.4,0,496.8,2We now enter the phase in which President Reagan fights leaks. It happens to them all. Maddened by leaks, President Nixon created the Watergate plumbers. It was like stopping a faucet drip by putting dynamite down the sink drain.

title: MRS. REAGAN SEES VICTIMS
description: Nancy Reagan visited a Virginia hospital today for private visits with five survivors of the Air Florida jet crash into the Potomac River, including a talk with a tearful passenger whose husband and baby were killed.

title: RENEWED OFFENSIVE ON TRADE POLICY
description: This is a tale of political survival in the nation's capital, the saga of a civil servant who was once called incompetent and was ousted, but who now has returned as one of the key policymakers of the Reagan Administration.

title: SADAT'S DEATH GIVES TOURISTS PAUSE ABOUT EGYPT
description: The horse and buggy, its brass fittings gleaming in the sunlight, sits with a forlorn driver for hours near the Happi Hotel waiting for a passenger.

title: A Red Smith Sampler
description: On a morning at the race track: ''Through the fragrance of wood fires burning under the elms in the stable area behind Saratoga's main track, wreaths of morning mist curled up to be burned away by slanting rays of sunshine. Hot-walkers led horses in lazy circles between the barns, while other horses stood relishing the flow of cool water from garden hoses trained on their forelegs. Grooms swathed horses with soapy sponges and rubbed them dry. The rhythmic throbbing of hooves could be heard from the track itself, where horses were working.''

title: TIGHTER SECURITY PLANNED AT LAKE IN PROSPECT PARK
description: The Police and Parks Departments plan to increase security precautions around Prospect Park Lake in Brooklyn as a result of the drowning of two teen-agers who fell through the ice Thursday night.

title: I.B.M. NET OFF 12.2% IN QUARTER
description: The International Business Machines Corporation reported yesterday that net income in the fourth quarter of 1981 had declined 12.2 percent, despite a 15.1 percent gain in revenues, in large part because the strength of the dollar had depressed earnings abroad.

title: Around the World; Iran Confirms Executing An Opposition Leader
description: Shokrollah Paknejad, an Iranian opposition leader from a party condemned by Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, has been executed, an official at Teheran's Evin Prison said today.

title: NORTHWESTERN FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes income from discontinued operations of $1.2 million and a gain of $519,000 on the sale of a bank building.. C-Includes income from discontinued operations of $1.4 million

title: REYNOLDS METALS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Industrial Output Fell By 2.1% in December
description: Industrial production tumbled 2.1 percent in December, the fifth straight monthly decline and the biggest since May 1980, the Federal Reserve Board said today.

title: COMPUTER DATA SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After net from discontinued operations of $10,100 in the qr and $19,700 for the 6 mos...C-After net from discontinued operations of $7,400 in the qr and $17,800 for the 6 mos

title: DANCE: HARLEM TROUPE PERFORMS 'STREETCAR'
description: He is Stanley Kowalski. He ambles in. Struts in, is more like it. When he sees a woman in pink chiffon before him, he sniffs with contempt at her obvious genteel veneer.

title: DREW NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-After an extraordinary credit of $525,000...C-After a $355,000 extraordinary credit

title: POLISH, AND PROUD OF IT
description: Whe n people asked me what I am, one word always rolls out: ''Irishenglishandpolish.''

title: ALTERED BEHAVIOR CITED IN HEART ATTACK DROP
description: Halfway through a five-year study, a Stanford University psychologist has found that heart attack victims who change some of their behavior characteristics apparently reduce by half their chances of suffering a second heart attack.

title: Mets Pursue Foster; B id for Abbott Fails
description: The Mets lost out in their bid to sign Glenn Abbott yesterday when the free-agent right-hander decided to remain with the Seattle Mariners, but they are still contenders for George Foster, the slugging Cincinnati outfielder.

title: No Headline
description: Jack V. Fox, 63, Dead; Retired U.P.I. Reporter

title: Sports People; Waits Disappointed
description: Rick Waits, a left-handed pitcher for the Cleveland Indians since 1975, signed a three-year contract with the club yesterday. He said he was far from enchanted with the highly publicized ''strike it rich'' qualities of the major leagues' free agency format.

title: BARTON VALVE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
The City; Commuter Plane Skids at Kennedy
description: A Pocono Airways commuter plane slammed into the runway and skidded to a stop during takeoff from Kennedy International Airport at 9:09 A.M. yesterday, damaging the plane's landing gear and injuring one passenger.

title: Around the Nation; Oil Workers in Texas Approve New Contract
description: More than 1,800 Amoco employees represented by the Oil, Chemical and Atomic Workers Union overwhelmingly approved a tentative labor contract today.

title: NATIONAL CITY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Average Mortgage Rate
description: The average mortgage interest rate at savings and loan associations rose to 17.44 percent for the week ending Jan. 15, from 17.30 percent in the previous week, the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation said today. The 17.44 percent average is the highest since 17.70 percent on Nov. 20, 1981, a spokesman for the corporation said. The rate applies to conventional 30-year mortgages on single-family homes where buyers have made down payments of 20 percent.

title: SUSPECT IN 6 SLAYINGS SAID TO HAVE SHOT AT OTHERS
description: A 2l-year-old man who was charged early yesterday with committing six murders in the last six weeks has told detectives that he also shot at people on four other occasions and may have killed some of them, according to police sources.

title: Business Digest; SATURDAY, JANUARY 16, 1982; The Economy
description: The Producer Price Index for finished goods rose 0.3 percent in December. For all of 1981 the index, a rough measure of the inflation consumers will face in the future, rose just 7 percent, the smallest increase since 1977. The figures were welcomed by economists as a sign that inflation was subsiding. (Page 1.)

title: SPAIN NAMES NEW MILITARY CHIEFS AFTER REMOVING FOUR TOP LEADERS
description: The Spanish Government announced the appointment today of new armed forces chiefs after suddenly relieving the nation's four top military men of their commands only hours before.

title: Bobbie Brooks In Chapter 11
description: Bobbie Brooks Inc., a major women's sportswear maker plagued in recent years by weak earnings and nearing its credit limit, filed here today for reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

title: WYNN LOSES 'SONG' TV CREDIT CASE
description: An arbitration panel of the Writers Guild of America has awarded Norman Mailer sole writing credit on the fourhour NBC-TV series based on his Pulitzer Prize-winning book about a condemned murderer, ''The Executioner's Song.''

title: Haig Dodges Question On Bible and Politics
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. faced a tricky question on the Bible and politics at a news conference today as he was leaving Israel. He dodged it artfully.

title: Meditations in Manila
description: Well, I'm not the first father who had to struggle to make his daughter listen to reason. The most eligible belle in the Philippines, she was throwing herself away, for Heaven's sake, on a divorced golfer.

title: ROAD SALT, USED SENSIBLY, IS A BOON TO THE PUBLIC, NOT A CURSE
description: To the Editor:

title: About New York; WHERE JUSTICE DEFIES A SINGLE DEFINITION
description: They came through the crowded basement room chained together in a long line, like a quarrelsome family or some modern theater representation of the seven deadly sins.

title:
Patents;
