A Method of Controlling Parasitic Cattle Ticks
description: A method of controlling the parasitic ticks that attack cattle was patented this week for the Department of Agriculture.

title: An Appreciation
description: Red Smith was, quite simply, the best sportswriter. Put the emphasis on writer. Of all those who have written sports for a living, nobody else ever had the command of the language, turn of the phrase, the subtlety of the skewer as he did. And perhaps nobody else ever enjoyed it more. All he ever wanted to be was a ''newspaper stiff,'' as he often identified himself.

title: WIDE FIELD LIKELY
description: Governor Carey announced today that he would not seek re-election to a third term and would devote himself instead to a yearlong battle to make New York ''at once compassionate and competitive.''

title: HAIG, OPTIMISTIC, TO RETURN TO MIDDLE EAST
description: After four days of talks in Cairo and Jerusalem, Se cretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. left for Washington to day expressing guarded optimism about the prospects for an accord on Palestinian self-administration. He said he planned to return to Egy pt and Israel at the end of January for further discussions.

title: News Analysis
description: After deliberately avoiding the problem for the last year, Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. has thrust himself into the intricate negotiations on Palestinian autonomy in the hope of achieving a diplomatic breakthrough between Egypt and Israel in the next three months.

title: 2 UPSTATE THRIFT UNITS ARE MERGED
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation yesterday merged the troubled Western New York Savings Bank into the Buffalo Savings Bank, creating the state's third-largest thrift institution, with assets of $5.5 billion. The merger became effective at 11:59 last night.

title: Kings Set Back Nets, 114-104
description: Mike Woodson, traded by tne Nets to the Kings early in the season, scored 26 poin ts tonight to lead Kansas City to a 114-104 victory over New Jer sey. Woodson, a guard who had been sent to the Kings for the center Sam Lacey, equale d his career-high scoring mark.

title: Putting the Bite on Medicare
description: Medicare costs for elderly Americans have ballooned in a decade from $7.8 billion to $42.5 billion; some expect them to reach $100 billion in 10 years more. Hospital charges alone rose by about 19 percent in 1981. These are figures to make anyone sympathetic to drastic economy measures.

title: CRAIG CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
News Summary; SATURDAY, JANUARY 16, 1982
description: International The objectives of Solidarity were discussed by the highest-ranking leader of the suppressed Polish union who is still at large. Answering questions carried by intermediaries, the union official, Zbigniew Bujak, said that Solidarity was continuin g its activities underground and was prepared for a long, nonv iolent struggle for democracy. (Page 1, Columns 4-6.) Syria put off a United Nations vote when Damascus discovered it lacked the minimum support needed for passage of a Security Council resolution to punish Israel for its annexation of the Golan Heights. Western diplomats said that the situation arose when the United States persuaded Zaire and Panama to drop their support for a resolution to halt arms shipments and economic aid to the Israelis. (6:3-6.)

title: SHAWMUT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FIDELCOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After a tax loss carryforward of $1,097,000...C-After a tax credit of $2,120,000...D-After securities losses of $1,023,000 and $2,580,000 for latest yr and 1980, respectively, and tax credits of $4,497,000 and $5,800,000 for 1981 and 1980 respectively

title: Answers to Quiz
description: Questions appear on page 14. 1. According to recent disclosures, President Roosevelt secretly recorded news conferences and, apparently inadvertently, recorded some private conversations in the Oval Office of the White House for 11 wee ks in his 1940 re-election campaign.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Boatman's Bancshares Inc. said it had reached an agreement in principle to acquire Farmers and Merchants Bank in Cape Girardeau, Mo.

title: U.S. Lets Home Savings Acquire Six Small Units
description: The nation's largest savings and loan association was given permission today to broaden its base and acquire five small savings and loan institutions in Texas and one in Illinois.

title: MATRIX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Oklahoma Deacon Accused Of Shooting Pastor at Church
description: A first-degree murder charge has been filed against a rural church deacon who the authorities said sat through a prayer service, then shot the pastor and seriously wounded the man's son.

title: SPECIALIST IN HARBOR DEFENSES
description: Brig. Gen. Philip S. Gage of the Army, who was commander of New York City Harbor Defenses in World War II, died Wednesday at his home in Atlanta. He was 96 years old.

title: FRANCIS J. AND CATHERINE QUILLINAN DIE IN ACCIDENT AT THEIR RYE HOME
description: Francis J. Quillinan, a lawyer who was once a Deputy Attorney General of New York State, and his wife, Catherine, a daughter of Alfred E. Smith, the former Governor of New York who was the Democratic Presidential candidate in 1928, were found dead on Thursday at their home in Rye, N.Y. Death was apparently due to accidental poisoning by carbon monoxide from their automobile, the police said.

title: Notes on People; Of Satin and Slush
description: The splendid long limousines pulled up to the curb of the New York Public Library at 42d Street and Fifth Avenue Thursday night to disgorge their cargoes of splendidly dressed people -New York's most powerful fashion designers, retailers and personalities.

title: PRODUCERS' PRICES UP ONLY 7% IN '81
description: The Producer Price Index for finished goods, a rough measure of the inflation consumers will face in the future, rose three-tenths of 1 percent in December and for all of 1981 was up only 7 percent, the lowest annual increase since 1977, the Labor Department reported today.

title: SALAZAR BECOMES A CELEBRITY
description: Life has changed for Alberto Salazar, the winner of the last two New York City Marathons. The Vitalis/United States Olympic Invitational indoor track meet will be run Saturday night at the Byrne Meadowlands Arena, and the main attraction may be the 23-year-old Salazar. He usually is now.

title: CANADIAN KILLER LEADS POLICE TO GRAVES, FOR A PRICE
description: Clifford Robert Olson, a 42-year-old construction worker who pleaded guilty Thursday to the murder of 11 children in the Vancouver area, was paid $100,000 by the Royal Canadian Mounted Police for revealing the graves of some of his victims.

title: CORRECTION
description: A brief article in Weekend yesterday gave an incorrect date for a performance by the Long Island Philharmonic with the flutist Paula Robison. The concert is tomorrow at 7:30 P.M. at Huntington High School.

title: JAZZ-LATIN: TITO PUENTE
description: Tito Puente, who established his musical ambivalence more than 30 years ago, when he was just as apt to be found leading a Latin band at the Paladium as he was to be playing jazz at Birdland, has boiled the mixture down to a music that is as much jazz as it is Latin. At Fat Tuesday's, a jazz room where his septet has been playing, he makes no conecessions to either aspect of his playing, with energizing results for both.

title: DECISION FILE
description: Every day Federal agencies and courts make decisions that affect the lives of Americans. Here is a recent case: Oily Problem Don't believe everything you read, especially not the directions onho w to replace an oil filter in the owner's manual furnished with 19 77-81 Volkswagens and Audis, the Federal Trade Commission warns.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day on Thursday incorrectly reported the percentage decline in domestic auto sales for the Big Three manufacturers in the first 10 days of the month. Sales declined 8.9 percent based on a daily selling rate of 14,006 in this year's period and 15,369 between Jan. 1 and 10, 1980.

title: WHITAKER CABLE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-After an extraordinary loss of $525,000 from partial reversal of a tax benefit taken in the first qr...C-net income D-After a tax credit of $251,000...E-Net loss

title: De Gustibus; FOR FROZEN DAYS, A MELTING CUP OF HOT CHOCOLATE
description: As restorative and warming as hot toddies, coffee and tea may be, the beverage I think of most in icy weather is steaming and frothy hot chocolate, or, more precisely perhaps, hot cocoa. The combination of creamy milk and bitter chocolate gentled with just the right amount of sugar and perhaps a hint of vanilla or cinnamon seems deeply warming and sustaining.

title: NEW BUDGET DIRECTOR IN DEBUT PERFORMANCE
description: Alair A. Townsend and her husband, Robert Harris, had looked forward to last Wednesday, the day they were scheduled to move into their new cooperative apartment in lower Manhattan. The move went ahead as scheduled, but with a slight hitch - Miss Townsend could not make it.

title: Sitting Down To Half a Loaf
description: With an increasing number of assembly lines and showrooms becoming quiet dark places, General Motors and the United Auto Workers cut an unprecedented deal last week. As their contract talks got under way, the corporation and the union agreed to pass along to G.M. customers, dollar for dollar, any savings that result from U.A.W. wage and fringe concessions. Ford, caught by surprise in its separate negotiations, didn't immediately say whether it would go along with the passalong.

title: BUSINESS TAX BREAKS THAT WON'T TRICKLE
description: To the Editor:

title: CAN GANNETT MAKE IT PAY?
description: floor offices in an unfinished commercial building here, staff members of USA Today can look for inspiration across the Potomac River to all of the major structures that symbolize the national Government. It is an appropriate view for a newspaper-to-be that hopes to find readers all over the country by offering, among other things, a substantial dose of national governmental coverage.

title: What to See at Show
description: Here is the general layout in the New York Coliseum: First floor: Outboard and stern-drive boats, outboard motors, boat trailers and fishing boats.

title: FollowUp on the News; One of the 'Finest'
description: Michael Buchanan, 17 years old and homeless, arrived in New York City in August 1981, hoping for a change in fortune. Since he was 9, he had been shunted from foster home to foster home in Tennessee, abandoned by his mother, forgotten by his father.

title: Stage View; SELECTED THOUGHTS ON FEET AND SYMPATHY
description: Ihave been dipping into a fairish number of stage and film books recently, and I don't see why you shouldn't catch up on my reading. In particular, I'd like to quote a couple of people on the subjects of feet and sympathy. The two themes aren't exactly relate d, but theymay be of equal importance.

title: WHEN MACHINES BECOME BOORISH
description: LAST week, I had a serious disagreement with a bank employee that could have led to violence, except that punching a hole in an automatic teller is less than satisfying and is also likely to arouse the local police.

title: Atlanta
description: To the Editor : I enjoyed ''What's Doing in Atlanta'' (Travel, Nov. 15). However, I must take exception to one observation made by Reginald Stua rt: The ''best way to see the city'' is not by car, as he suggests, but by bicycle.

title: REDISTRICTING LIKELY TO HAVE MAJOR IMPACT ON THE ISLAND
description: ALBANY FOR the next several months here, cartography - the art of drawing maps - will be power. The State Legislature is in the midst of redrawing the boundaries of every district in the State Senate and the Assembly, as well as the lines for the state's Congressional districts.

title: READERS REPLY TO 'A TALE OF TWO POWER PLANTS'
description: FAIRY tales about nuclear power abound among nuclear advocates - witness the recent Opinion Page article ''A Tale of Two Power Plants.'' The authors would have us believe that the opposition of public-interest groups to a future source of radioactive contamination of the environment was in itself responsible for the long delay in completion of Shoreham and, therefore, a matter for condemnation.

title: POLICE BLAME ALOOFNESS IN ANGEL'S DEATH
description: NEWARK THE one thing that has been made clear in the murky circumstances surrounding the death of a Guardian Angels patrol leader here last month is that the police and the Angels had not been talking to each other. Each group had been operating in the city streets in the dark, alone.

title: Margaret Hirsch Married
description: Margaret Rachel Hirsch, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ira J. Hirsch of Red Bank, N.J., was married yesterday to Marc Douglas Greenfield, son of Mr. and Mrs. Julius Greenfield of Matawan, N.J. Rabbis Jack Rosoff and Murray Ezring performed the ceremony at Temple Beth El in Oakhurst, N.J. The bride is vice president in charge of marketing for the National Sporting Goods Corporation, of which her father is president. Mr. Greenfield is president of Susan Green Inc., a chain of handbag and luggage stores in New Jersey.

title: HOW TO UPGRADE RAIL SERVICE IN NEW JERSEY
description: This is the second of two articles proposin g ways in which the transportation needs of New Jersey can be met . In the first article, the author, Douglas John Bowen, suggested lin king the Erie LackawannaMorristown Line with the Northeast Corridor ( Amtrak and NJ Transit), providing alternative transportation to the M eadowlands Sports Complex and looping passenger trains to conne ct the Bergen Main and Pascack Valley Lines on what was once the Eri e Railroad. The rest of Mr. Bowen's proposals are as follows: (1) - Terminate PATH trains at Newark International Airport.

title: Realty News; Staten Island Lease
description: U.S. Navigation, Inc., a subsidiary of Hapag Lloyd America, Inc., the shipping concern, will relocate its offices into the office building known as One Edgewater Plaza in Clinton, S.I., owned by the Pouch interests. They have leased 82,500 square feet of space at a rent of about $15 a per square foot.

title: LOS ANGELES COUNCIL TO VOTE ON FIVE-SQUARE-BLOCK, $1.2 BILLION DOWNTOWN COMPLEX
description: The City Council next week is expected to approve the biggest redevelopment project in Los Angeles history, a five-square-block, $1.2 billion complex of office buildings, condominium homes, theaters, stores and other facilities, including an art museum, in the heart of the city.

title: CHOLERA IS RIFE IN SOUTH AFRICA'S BLACK 'HOMELANDS'
description: Cholera, an infectious disease that thrives where there is an absence of clean drinking water and decent sanitation, has become endemic in South Africa's rural black ''homelands'' in the last two years.

title: Leonora Cohen Rosenfield, Professor at U. of Maryland
description: Leonora Cohen Rosenfield, an author and professor emeritus of French literature, civilization and culture at the University of Maryland, died Friday at George Washington Hospital in Washington, D.C. She was 72 years old and lived in Washington.

title: Winifred Zubin Engaged to Wed
description: The engagement of Winifred Anne Zubin to Laurence Reilly has been announced by Dr. and Mrs. Joseph Zubin of Leonia, N.J., parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Porter Reilly of New York.

title: Corrections
description: In the Economic Affairs graphic last week, ''The Changing Work Force,'' the figures for the white women in the work force actually represented all women in the work force.

title: COURT RULES THAT ACCEPTING GIRLS IS NO BAR TO A PREP SCHOOL BEQUEST
description: A state appeals court has decided that a New England preparatory school should not be stripped of a major bequest simply because it began accepting girls.

title: The Elgin Marbles
description: To the Editor:

title: The Jersey Corridor
description: To the Editor:

title: Inuit Art
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: Lester Trimble's article paints a very dark picture of a situation that has existed all the 51 years that I have been a composer. His despair is well justified, but I would like to project a positive ray of hope.

title: CLOSE-UP OF A LEGEND
description: Franklin Delano Roosevelt was born Jan. 30, 1882, and was elected President of the United States for the first time in November 1932. In the introduction to his new book, ''FDR: A Centenary Remembrance'' (The Viking Press, $25), columnist Joseph Alsop remarks that Roosevelt is ''already a remote and half-legendary figure.''

title:
Speaking Personally;
FOR A SICK CHILD, THE RX INCLUDES TLC
description: MY LITTLE boy is sick. He lies in bed perspiring, chilled and scared. He wants me to stay with him. He feels that, as long as I'm with him, he can't die.

title: Essay; F.D.R.'S DIRTY TRICKS
description: The archivists at Hyde Park have finally decided that enough time has elapsed since Watergate to share with their taxpayer employers the news that Franklin D. Roosevelt pioneered in the sleazy business of secretly recording conversations in the President's office. F.D.R. apologist Arthur Schlesinger Jr., ha stily assures us that the eavesdropping device installed by his ido l was merely ''to p rotect F.D.R. from being misquoted during the 1940 campai gn,'' presumably by his lapdog press corps, and that hours of co nversationswith political leaders were recorded ''through accident or inadvertence.''

title: IN THE FOOTSTEPS OF JAMES JOYCE
description: ''Weary? He rests. He has travelled.'' Thus Bloom comes home at the end of the day memorialized in James Joyce's ''Ulysses'' - June 16, 1904 -which has been celebrated by Joyceans ever since. This year, however, marks the centennial of Joyce's birth, and dedicated Joyceans as well as the more casual tourist are looking at the places where the author spent his life.

title:
Gardening;
PAPER BIRCH, THE EPITOME OF ORNAMENTALS
description: FEW trees are more striking than the paper birch. A multi stemmed, white-bark birch is considered to be the epitome of all ornamental trees, and it is often given the most prominent location.

title: TV View; THE BBC'S 'LIFE ON EARTH'- A BRILL IANT ACHIEVEMENT
description: Television does some things better than others. It can still be argued, for example, that the home screen frequently seems inhospitable to a dance performance or an art exhibit. At the other end of the programming spectrum, though, the medium has proved unquestionably suited to certain areas of material. One is sports. Another is nature documentaries, affording the armchair explorer fascinating close-ups of everything from undulating bacteria to ominously gliding sharks. Advances in photography have enabled camera crews to record aspects of wildlife in astonishing intimacy and detail. The result has been a fairly steady stream of splendid nature essays. Now, along comes ''Life on Earth,'' and, wi thout hestitation, the stops can justifiably be pulled out on the so unding of superlatives. This 13-part series, produced by the BBC's Na tural History Unit in Bristol, England, in association with Warner Brothers Television and a German company, is quite simply a brilliant and thoroughly awesome achievement. It is being broadcast on public television Tuesdays at 8P.M. (last week's first installment will be r epeated on WNET/Channel 13 tonight at 7).

title: Critics' Choices
description: DANCE Peter Shaffer's ''Equus'' seems an unlikely subject for a ballet. The story of a psychiatrist and his patient, a tormented boy with a passion for horses, ''Equus'' is a play of ideas.

title: Jury Acquits Ethiopian Charged With Assault
description: An Ethiopian student who waived diplomatic immunity in an effort to clear his name of assault charges has been acquitted by a jury in Criminal Court in Manhattan.

title: Westchester Housing; PORTABLE SUBSIDIES ARE SOUGHT
description: A FAMILY that receives a Federal housing subsidy in the county may have a hard time using it, because there are so few inexpensive apartments, according to Eli Kimels of Westchester Residential Opportunities.

title: OLD STAT E HOUSE IS BUSY LAUN CH PAD
description: SINCE its rededication in 1979, Hartford's 186-year-old Old State House increasingly has become the ''in'' place to begin Connecticut political campaigns, and the building's new executive director - a former campaign organizer -thinks he knows why.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Krenek Piano Sonata Played by Todd Crow
description: Todd Crow, a pianist from California teaching at Vassar College, gave an unusually serious, intelligent and thought-provoking recital last Sunday night at Alice Tully Hall. The program was chosen with care, and Mr. Crow's playing was at all times equal to his taste in music.

title:
Gardening;
PAPER BIRCH, THE EPITOME OF ORNAMENTALS
description: FEW trees are more striking than the paper birch. A multi stemmed, white-bark birch is considered to be the epitome of all ornamental trees, and it is often given the most prominent location.

title: Around the World
description: Libya's official press agency said today that President Gaafar al-Nimeiry of the Sudan had been shot during a military uprising.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Good Water and Bad Feelings
description: The Ten Commandments don't specifically address the issue, but angry farmers in Southwest New Mexico do. Bumper stickers in that part of the country read, ''Thou shalt not covet thy neighbor's water,'' and they are directed against a plan by the city of El Paso, Texas, to tap New Mexico's underground reserves.

title: Cup Soccer Draw Favors 3
description: Brazil, West Germany and Argentina became the three favorites to win the World Cup soccer tournament in Spain in July, after yesterday's draw in Madrid for the formation of the six groups among the 24 qualified nations. The United States was eliminated in the preliminary rounds of the quadrennial event.

title: UNIONS TEST THE METTLE OF THE 'IRON LADY'
description: Britain's Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher is a conservative of the old school who believes inflation can only be brought down when workers become willing to accept more modest wage increases. For 32 months, the Iron Lady and the unions have been sparring, with growing mutual hatred the only obvious result. But now both sides appear ready for a head-on clash. Last week, railroad engineers walked out for two days, demanding a 3 percent productivity raise. And coal miners, who recently elected a left-wing militant, Arthur Scargill, as president, voted on a call to authorize a strike unless the Government takes the lid off its proposed 9.3 percent pay increase.

title: AMY GROSSMAN TO BE JUNE BRIDE
description: Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Robert G. Grossman of Houston of the engagement of their daughter, Amy Esther Grossman, to Michael Coburn, son of Dr. and Mrs. Louis Coburn of Flushing, Queens.

title: CHANGES IN JOBS, CHANGE S IN LIFE
description: FOR some, the first morning might be the hardest - the waking up and remembering that the familiar routine is gone. For others, that initial sensation of freedom is to be savored, a living testiment to those posters that read, ''Today is the first day of the rest of your life.''

title: A Question For Brzezinski
description: Zbigniew Brzezinski's critical essay ''What's Wrong With Reagan's Foreign Policy?'' (Dec. 6) was precise, clear, accurate, erudite and sometimes brilliant, none of which qualities were ever apparent in Mr. Brzezinski's policy formulation in the Carter Administration, which took ''waffling,'' weakness and obscurity in foreign relations to its highest level in recent memory. Could it be the result of the incumbent's disease, which affects all Administrations, where constituency pressures really determine policy, even though the good of the country may be subordinated or subverted? WILLIAM BALLIN Geneva

title: AFTER ALEXANDER, NO ONE
description: FUNERAL GAMES By Mary Renault. 335 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $14.50.

title:
Economic Affairs;
A.T.&T.;: THE JUSTICE DEPARTMENT BLEW IT
description: A NTITRUST under the Sherman Act is marked by a half-dozen landmark decisions, particularly in the cases breaking up Standard Oil in 1911 and Alcoa in 1945. The A.T.&T.; case of 1982 was expected to join the m in framing the law of competition.

title: Help for Employees With Problems
description: You don't have to be as big as Xerox to have a program for helping employees with job-affecting personal problems. (''Alcoholics Get Help at Work,'' Dec. 13.)

title: Feminist Group Hails Y ale's Women's Studies
description: Hurray for Nancy Cott and Yale's approval of a major in women's studies (''Adding Women to the Story of Man,'' Dec. 13). The student editorialist complaining about one of the main purposes of women's studies (to get women's input and outlook about all matters into our cultural brew) as if it would be a pesky, unavoidable and unforeseen concomitant of the subject's new standing, exemplifies another reason why we all need the feminist movement.

title: Film View; FATHOMS DEEP IN THE MYSTERIES OF TASTE
description: Anyone who thinks that audiences are sheep -docile creatures to be pushed by critics and other self-appointed shepherds toward movies they otherwise would never see - should take a minute to look over the recent box office figures in Variety. To optimists who have faith in the independence of the American consumer, these reports support their wildest dreams. To the rest of us, they are a little scary and, even after the fact, more than a little baffling. The season's biggest hits are not only the films that have been critically acclaimed or that have prompted serious controversy, like ''Reds'' or ''Pennies From Heaven,'' but also movies of such fecklessness that even their success can't teach us any special lessons.

title: STATE TEST SHARPENS FOCUS ON BASICS
description: FOR three h ours last October, 40,120 ninth-grade students in Connecticut p ondered fractions and percentages, punctuation and the meanings of w ords in the state's third annual proficiency test.

title: Around the Nation; San Jose Nurses Strike At Two More Hospitals
description: Nurses demanding sexual equality in wages walked off their jobs at two more San Jose hospitals today, bringing to four the number of hospitals struck.

title: THE MANDATED CRUNCH ON COUNTY FUNDS
description: A decade ago, Westchester County spent $15.2 million a year on local Medicaid costs and $14,000 on its Education and Transportation of Handicapped Children program. This year, those figures will be $57.8 million and $4 million, respectively. These and other ''mandated services'' - those that the Federal or state governments require localities to provide - consume almost all of the county's property tax revenues.

title: Playing Indoor Game Bewilders Cosmos
description: Halfway through their first indoor season in the North American Soccer League, the Cosmos have the second-worst record. They are 3-6 and in last place in the Eastern Division, a position that would be unfamiliar to the Cosmos who play outdoors.

title: RUSSIAN ATTITUDE TOWARD POLAND HAS CHANGED LITTLE SINCE DAYS OF THE
description: CZARS By DREW MIDDLETON Military Analysis

title: NEW FINGERPRINTS TEST IS USED TO SOLVE ARSONS
description: A fingerprint on a soot-covered gasoline can retrieved after an apartment fire here last March led to the arrest and conviction of a 30-year-old man.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: WILL 'THE LITTLE PRINCE' COME ALIVE ON STAGE?
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Arthur Holmberg, who teaches literature and theater at Harvard, writes frequently about the arts. By ARTHUR HOLMBERG

title: CITY'S ASSESSORS DIG IN AS DEADLINE NEARS
description: A new team has taken charge of preparing the assessment role for New York City with a new law in hand and new ideas on how to modernize the department. They are using advanced computerized techniques to determine the value of properties and threatening tough penalties on commercial property owners for falsifying information about a building's expenses and income.

title: A FIGHT TO BE COUNTED AMONG THE ELECTED
description: GREENWICH MEMBERS of the Representative Town Meeting will convene here tomorrow knowing that the town's charter, at least as it is now written, prohibits one of their number, Leonard LaLuna, from being recognized.

title: EUROPEANS' PENSIONS RELY ON GENERAL FUNDS
description: The Social Security systems of European countries routinely rely on general fund revenue to supplement payroll taxes and keep their retirement programs solvent, a Senate staff report has found.

title: READERS REPLY TO 'A TALE OF TWO POWER PLANTS'
description: ''A Tale of Two Power Plants'' requires a response. Contrary to the authors' assertion, the decision to build the Shoreham nuclear plant was not the product of an exhaustive, no-holds-barred search for energy sources for Long Island. By November 1972, when Shoreham received its construction permit, numerous cheaper and safer energy sources - hydropower, solar, wind, cogeneration and others - were available.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Budget Balancing
description: Faced with a budget squeeze, Mayor Helen Boosalis of Lincoln, Neb., issued last November a catalogue of gifts that the city would like toreceive. Among them: a fire engine, four ligh ted ball fields and an infrared prober to locate bodies in disasters .

title: NEW DISTRICTING FACES CHALLENGES
description: TRENTON GOVERNOR BYRNE signed into law last week a bill redrawing the map of the state's Congressional districts, bu t his fellow Democrats are expected to t ry to change the map. And whether they succeed or not, Republicans a re certain to challenge the districting plan in court.

title: Mailbox; List of Honorees Omits Koufax
description: To the Sports Editor: The Jan. 10 Times lists ballplayers voted into the Baseball Hall of Fame the first time they were eligible. The list fails to mention Sanford Koufax.

title: BLACKS LEAD SNUB OF KING EVENT
description: In a show of support for black police officers who are protesting the city's hiring policies, many black leaders boycotted Mayor William J. Green's prayer breakfast Friday commemorating the birthday of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

title: CONNECTICUT SEEKS TO END DEADLOCK ON BUDGET
description: After a two-month stalemate on how to eliminate an $83 million deficit in the current state budget, the Connecticut House of Representatives has approved a $36 million package that will create some new taxes and increase others.

title: IN DEFENSE OF ILLNESS AS METAPHOR
description: MARS By Fritz Zorn. Afterword by Adolf Muschg. Translated by Robert and Rita Kimber. 241 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $12.95.

title: WARRIORS' FREE PROVES VERSATILITY IN HELPING TO BEAT KNICKS
description: The collar holding Al Attles's tie in place was coated with sweat from the workout he had sustained while choreographing the Golden State Warriors to a 104-102 victory over the Knicks Friday night. Yet, afterward, the gruff-voiced coach jumped up from behind his desk in the locker room and began a series of gyrations.

title: Q/ and A
description: QUESTIONS: What is the most efficient way of getting from New York City to Israel by ship or by a combination of surface transportation? - D.G., Bayside, N.Y. ANSWER: Geoffrey Weill, with the Israel Ministry of Tourism, says: "Unfortunately there is no longer any passenger steamship service from New York to anywhere in the Mediterranean. The most efficient combination of surface transportation is to take the Queen Elizabeth 2 from New York to Cherbourg, the boat train to Paris, the train to a Mediterranean port such as Genoa, Venice or Ancona where you can board ship for Haifa.

title: CITY MAY EASE RULES HOSPITALS CAN'T FOLLOW
description: More than a third of the 42 hospitals in New York City seeking official designation to receive emergency ambulance patients have failed to meet qualifying standards. As a result, city officials said yesterday that they would modify or waive the standards rather than exclude any hospitals.

title: Whodunit
description: To the Editor:

title: About Long Island
description: GREAT NECK abuts the New York City border, but that city line divides a world of differences. This discovery has been made recently by two friends of mine and their staff, who not long ago forsook Manhattan to set up shop in that special North Shore purlieu of Nassau.

title: The Week in Business; GAINS IN PRICES EASE; INDUSTRIAL OUTPUT SLUMPS
description: Producer prices rose only three-tenths of a percent in December, the Labor Department reported. That put the increase for all of 1981 at 7 percent, the lowest annual rise since 1977. Producer prices reflect changes at the wholesale level.

title:
Music: Debuts in Review;
Joseph Penrod Offers Program for a Baritone
description: Many a vocalist's hopes of being heard in Carnegie Recital Hall have been dashed by the Scylla and Charybdis of a loud piano and the hall's small size. In much of last Sunday's program by Joseph Penrod, a baritone, the situation was compounded by the absence of size in the singer's voice, not necessarily a drawback in the repertory that he chose to perform, and by his lack of resonance in the lower part of the range, which can be a disadvantage even without competition from the accompaniment.

title: Environews
description: AMONMOUTH COUNTY developer has received preliminary approval from the state's Department of Environmental Protection to build a 200-unit condominium and marina complex on Shark River Island in Neptune Township.

title: BENEFIT CUTOFF SPURS RUSH TO COLLEGES
description: With millions of dollars at stake, hundreds of high school seniors are seeking an early start on their college educations to avoid a cutoff of their Social Security benefits on May 1.

title: Miss Bigham, J.S. Hutchins Will Be Wed
description: Announcement has been made by the Rev. Dr. Thomas J. Bigham of New Marlborough, Mass., of the engagement of his daughter, Anne Scribner Bigham, to John Storm Hutchins, son of Waldo Hutchins 3d of Brookville, L.I., and the late Joan Adams Hutchins. A May wedding is planned at St. James Episc opal Church in Great Barrington, Mass.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: PEKING NEEDS MAO BUT IT WANTS HIM LESS AND LESS
description: The little red-bound quotations of Mao Zedong have long vanished from sight, but thousands of new, pale yellow books filled bookstore shelves in China last week. They held the selected works of Liu Shaoqi, once villified as China's ''biggest capitalist roader,'' more recently resurrected as ''a great Marxist-Leninist and proletarian revolutionary.''

title: STEVE TESICH TURNS MEMORIES INTO MOVIES
description: Barney Cohen is a freelance writer. By Barney Cohen

title: Eunice Campbell Is Wed
description: Eunice Coit Johnson Campbell and Dr. Thomas Scudder Winslow were married yesterday at St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church in Locust Valley, L.I. The Rev. Charles G. Newberry performed the ceremony. Mrs. Winslow, whose previous marriage ended in divorce, is a daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Stuart Holmes Johnson of Locust Valley.

title:
Other Business;
HARVARD'S STUDENT ENTREPRENEURS
description: style cap emblazoned with the trademark of the U.S. Tobacco Company covers Brett Johnson's well-creased brow. A crumpled United States Army Reserve hat protrudes from his bulging book bag. Ass orted other hats with the insignias of Southern collegesare stuffed i n his back pockets. Perhaps it is not the standard operating pro cedure for a million-dollar-a-year business, but this senior at Har vard college is not running his company, Crowd Caps, outof the seat o f his pants. He's running it out of his college dormatory.

title: Tesa Van Munching, Wheaton '82, Fiancee of Robert Hargadon, Planner
description: Mr. and Mrs. Leo Van Munching Jr. of Darien, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Maria Patricia Van Munching, to Robert Bernard Hargadon, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard J. Hargadon Jr. of Walnut Creek, Calif. Miss Van Mu nching, who is known as Tesa, is a senior at Wheaton College in No rton, Mass.

title: FOR VIETNAM VETERANS, WHAT HONORS?
description: In the colonnaded chamber of New York City's Board of Estimate, far from the mean rumblings of their war, a band of Vietnam veterans reflected aloud on how the city could best honor and help them.

title: HARRIET MANN, A TEACHER, FIANCEE OF JAMES FOGARTY
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph G. Mann of Wantagh, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Harriet Lois Mann, to James Michael Fogarty, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Fogarty of Schenectady, N.Y.

title: HEATHER HAYMAN FIANCEE OF TIMOTHY PAUL COHAN
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert W. Hayman of Chappaqua, N.Y., and Edgartown, Mass., have annonced the engagement of their daughter, Heather Marie Hayman, to Timothy Paul Cohan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walter E. Mohan of Weston, Conn.

title: Anne Marie Miles Is Bride of Dr. Emil Coccaro Jr.
description: Anne Marie Miles and Dr. Emil Frank Coccaro Jr. were married yesterday in St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church. The Revs.

title: Children's Books
description: SCARY STORIES TO TELL IN THE DARK Collected From American Folklore by Alvin Schwartz. Illustrated by Stephen Gammell. 111 pp. New York: J. B. Lippincott. Cloth, $8.25. Paper, $4.95. (Ages 9 to 12)

title: CHICAGO'S GLASSED-IN SEA
description: NATHANIEL SHEPPARD Jr. is a correspondent in the Chicago bureau of The New York Times. By NATHANIEL SHEPPARD Jr.

title: The Poles to Resume Broadcasting of Mass
description: The Warsaw radio said today that its broadcasts of the Roman Catholic mass, suspended during martial law, would resume Sunday.

title: Gallery View; REDISCOVERING GEORGES BRAQUE IN HIS CENTENARY YEAR
description: This is the centenary year of Georges Braque, one of the great French painters of all time. He was born in Argenteuil-sur-Seine on May 13, 1882, and he died in Paris on Aug. 31, 1963. He had a state funeral in the courtyard of the Louvre, at which Andre Malraux delivered an inspired harangue by torchlight, and in May of this year his centenary will be marked by a large official retrospective exhibition in Paris.

title: Moffett Urges Limit On Campaign Spending
description: Thanks for an informative and insightful article on the 1982 political scene ('' '82 Candidates Run on Expert Advice,'' Jan. 3). There is, however, an inaccuracy in your comments about my call for a spending limit in the Senate race.

title: Paperback Best Sellers; MASS MARKET
description: Mass-market paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: Long Island Guide; MUSICAL PREVIEW
description: John Anderson, the principal oboist of the BBC Symphony Orchestra, has got his act together for his American concert debut, and, taking it on the road for practice before appearing at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday, will play the Long Beach Public Library today at 2:30 P.M. Accompanied by Richard Nunn on piano (he's played for Maria Callas and Jessye Norman), Mr. Anderson will perform Schumann, Donizetti, Handel and Britten, among others, as he shows American audiences how he won the Geneva International Oboe Competition. The library is at 111 West Park Avenue, and the concert - the same he will play at Carnegie Hall - is free. JEWISH HISTORY

title: News Summary; SUNDAY, JANUARY 17, 1981
description: International The major Western trading powers and Japan have agreed not to take unilateral actions to curb imports from other countries. The agreement is an effort to check protectionism, which is growing because of the world economic slump. The chief trade officers from the United States, the European Common Market, Japan and Canada who met in Miami, said that reducing barriers to world trade would increase employment, reduce inflation and improve productivity. (1:6.)

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Boulder, Colo. Goes Too Far
description: The Federal Government occasionally bows to the sovereignty of states, but that's as far as it goes. There is ''no place for sovereign cities,'' Associate Supreme Court Justice William J. Brennan Jr. observed last week.

title: UNEMPLOYMENT AND INFLATION SPUR GIFTS TO NEEDIEST CASES
description: ''Caring and sharing is a must this year,'' wrote Robert S. Herzog of Larchmont, N.Y. ''Families have been devas tated by unemployment and general economic conditions. Many must be desperate and those that have must help their fellow men. We are our brothers' keepers and must help.''

title: WHY A TRADE WAR MAY BE LOOMING WITH JAPAN
description: TOKYO W ITH most major Western nations suffering the twin burdens of no growth and high unemployment, the world's trading system is said to be threatened today more than at any time in the past decade with a flight to protectionism -setting up barriers to imports from abroad to protect jobs and faltering industries at home.

title: CONGRESS TO WEIGH CURB ON 'ACID RAIN'
description: WASHINGTON, D.C. LAST fall, a National Wildlife Federation study found that Connecticut and the other New England states were ''extremely vulnerable'' to the effects of ''acid rain,'' the polluting fallout blamed for destroying lakes and vegetation in the Northeast and Canada.

title: FEASTING ON CRAYF ISH NEW ORLEANS STYLE
description: FRED FERRETTI is a reporter for The New York Times. By FRED FERRETTI

title: AS HOUSING GOES, SO GO BRICKS
description: day supply will do. The same goes for the rest of Lee's brickmaking operations here. No longer does the company stock ''two of everything,'' says Frank Perry, the company's president.

title: New Jersey Guide; TORME IN HACKENSACK
description: Mel Torme, the 56-year-old jazz and pop singer who just seems to get better each year, will give three concerts in Hackensack later this month with Phil Woods, the jazz saxophonist.

title: Scot Wins Darts Title
description: Jocky Wilson of Scotland beat England's John Lowe, 5-3, in the final of the world professional darts championship tonight and won a first prize of $12,350.

title: The Nation in Summary; A Winter's Week Of Freezing Cold And Icy Death
description: Even before the plane crash, it was a week in which nature's ferocity and human fallibility conspired to create victims - more than 150 people dead on icy highways, in frozen lakes, in snowdrifts, in homes without heat from Canad a to the Deep South.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: Leslie Alters Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Alters of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Leslie Ann Alters, to Sanford Dekovnick, son of Mrs. Claire Dekovnick of Miami Beach and Louis Dekovnick of New York. The wedding is planned for June.

title: Politics; DISSENT OVER DATE FOR GARBAGE PLAN AND UTILITY REFERENDUMS
description: THE tone of last Monday's meeting of the Bo ard of Legislators was evident even before it was gaveled to order. The legislators were meeting at night, which they dislike doing, a nd only at the earlier insistence of Carl J. Calvi, a two-term Repub lican from Yonkers. He was in the Bahamas, however.

title: Lisa M. Hawkins To Become Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Donald Hawkins of Scarsdale, N.Y., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Lisa Marie Hawkins, to Edmund H. Carroll Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Carroll of Davenport, Iowa. An August wedding is planned.

title: Connecticut Journal
description: THE Department of Transportation has begun a $3 million program to clean up the 10 service plazas on the Connecticut Turnpike. The buildings have been painted, and new booths have been installed for the gasoline attendants at Darien, Fairfield, Milford, Branford and Madison. More than $50,000 will be spent on landscaping, replacement of roofs and repair of heating and cooling systems. Access for the handicapped will be improved and restrooms renovated.

title: Connecticut Guide; BENEFIT FOR POLAND
description: Zbigniew Brzezinski, former national security adviser and now honorary chairman of Arts Against Hunger, will speak at a reception from 5 to 7 P.M. on Jan. 26 in the Old State House, 800 Main Street, Hartford. His talk will coincide with a special exhibition and sale of art, on display until Jan. 29, to raise money to send CARE food packages to Poland.

title: SOLIDARITY DID NOT GO FAR ENOUGH
description: To the Editor:

title: JOSEPH F. CLUNAN
description: Joseph F. Clunan, a Queens lawyer, died Friday of cancer at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. Mr. Clunan, who was a resident of Forest Hills, Queens, was 58 years old.

title: DEMOTION BY N.C.A.A. IRKS IVY LEAGUE
description: The Ivy League, which was dropped from Division I-A to Division I-AA l ast month by a vote of other m ajor football colleges, has refused to appeal that move. Jim Litvack, the executive director of the Ivy League, said, ''I guess the Ivy pr esidents just won't go with hat in hand begging.''

title: TRAVEL PLANS FOR CANADA GEESE
description: EVERY schoolchild knows that birds fly south for the winter. It is true that most summertime birds leave the Northeast, but from farther north come flocks of majestic visitors: the gentle, honking Canada geese.

title: The Steak Is on Knight
description: Bobby Knight, Indiana's basketball coach, is upset over Big Ten officiating, and the result could be a steak dinner for some sportswriters.

title: Colleen Moffett Is Married To Henry Noe Jr. on L. I.
description: Colleen Moffett, manager of the pro shop at the Fox Run Country Club in Muttontown, L.I., and Henry M. Noe Jr., a videotape news editor for CBS-TV's ''Morning'' program, were married yesterday at the Milleridge Inn in Jericho, L.I. Village Justice William Spane of Old Brookville, L.I., performed the ceremony.

title: SPIRIT OF SPORT INSPIRES NEW FAITH
description: AS the professional football season progresses toward its culmination in Super Bowl XVI and the Celtics continue on another frantic pursuit of the National Basketball Association championship, we find signs everywhere that sport has increasingly become one of the most integral elements in modern American culture.

title: Children's Books
description: MACMILLAN ILLUSTRATED ALMANAC FOR KIDS By Ann Elwood, Carol Orsag, & Sidney Solomon. Illustrated. 429 pp. New York: Macmillan Publishing Co. $12.95. (Ages 10 to 14) By Barbara Karlin

title: Deborah Yaeger Wed to John Emshwiller, Reporter
description: Deborah Sue Yaeger, a second-year student at the New York University School of Medicine, was married yesterday evening at the Harmonie Club to John Robert Emshwiller, a reporter for The Wall Street Journal. Rabbi Balfour Brickner performed the ceremony.

title: Press Notes; GROUND RULES ON INTERVIEWS VS. CONFUSION
description: When David R. Gergen, the White House communications director, talked with reporters last week about an effort to control unauthorized disclosures of information, he said the briefing was ''on background.'' But some news articles identified him as the source of the report, underlining again the potential for misunderstanding between reporters and officials over the ground rules for interviews.

title: SOVIET AND SYRIA PLAN RESPONSE ON GOLAN
description: The Soviet Union and Syria said today in a joint statement that they deemed it necessary to counter Israel's annexation of the Golan Heights. They also pledged to strengthen military cooperation.

title: CUBAN BROADCASTS CAUSING CONCERN
description: On a recent night in Stamford, Conn., a radio listener fiddled withhis AM dial a nd found himself hearing news, pop music and propaganda in English fr om the Soviet Union. It was the Moscow radio, broadcast by the Havana radio on 1160 AM.

title: LARGEST FLEET IS ON VIEW AT COLISEUM
description: ARCTIC winds blast down Manhattan streets. Snow swirls overhead and crunches under foot. No matter. On a bleak winter's day, it's not hard to conjure up visions of summer. Just stop by the 72d National Boat Show, which opened yesterday at the New York Coliseum for a nine-day run.

title: Michener's America
description: Mickey Mouse and Donald Duck at Disney World, the Spirit of St. Louis at the National Air and Space Museum - these are among the American symbols and institutions pictured in JAMES A. MICHENER'S USA (Crown, $25), an abundantly illustrated region-by-region survey based on the author's television series. With the help of Peter Chaitin, who edited the book and contributed additional narrative material, Mr. Michener explores the country's past, present and future in historical sketches, personal recollections and reflections, and interviews with the famous and the unknown, from a steelworker in Steubenville, Ohio, to a fisherman in Harris Neck, Ga. ''America is a nation with many flaws that only the stupid would deny,'' Mr. Michener writes, ''but with hopes so vast that only the cowardly would refuse to acknowledge them.'' -R.A.

title: Bridge; ORIENTAL CLIFF-HANGER
description: The crisis was at hand. In a smoke-filled room, a group of Chinese intellectuals focused grimly on the screen in front of them. They waited nervously for the next development, fearing the worst, and trying desperately to remember the intricacies of the Zirinsky formula.

title: Unsung American Composers
description: As a young, aspiring American composer, I applaud Lester Trimble's articulate and uncompromising condemnation of the situation currently facing us (''The Unsung American Composer,'' Nov. 29).

title: SAILING THE 'WINE-DARK SEAS'
description: JOAN GOULD, a contributor to the Hers column, is working on a book called ''Spirals,'' a personal account of a woman looking at her life. By JOAN GOULD

title: PLAN SOUGHT TO MAKE UTILITIES ABSORB COST OVERRUNS AT 9 MILE POINT 2 POINT
description: The State Public Service Commission is seeking a way to force utilities to absorb major cost overruns at the Nine Mile Point 2 nuclear plant, while at the same time allowing the plant to be completed.

title: WARSAW HAS LITTLE CHOICE BUT TO KEEP ON DANCING
description: WARSAW IN a month in which the army and the security forces have ''pacified'' the country and the Solidarity union, the Polish Government ha s found itself back dancing a familiar two-step polonaise - a step to the left for Moscow and a step to the right forWashington.

title: STUDY FINDS PUBLIC KNOWS LITTLE OF WILDLIFE
description: A majority of Americans think that spiders have 10 legs, that an iguana is an insect and that a koala is a bear. Americans' favorite creatures are dogs, horses, swans, robins, butterflies and trout, in that order. Their least favorite are cockroaches, mosquitos, rats, wasps, rattlesnakes and bats.

title: A DANCE MASTER INVADES PRINCETON
description: PRINCETON DESCRIBED by some as the most ''classic'' modern dancer of the century and by others as the most shocking, disconnected and difficult to watch, Merce Cunningham will offer New Jersey audiences an opportunity to judge for themselves Tuesday and Wednesday, when he and his dance company present two different programs at the McCarter Theater.

title: SALARIES: FISCAL REALITIES
description: HARTFORD ALREADY on the plate for action by the General Assembly when it convenes next month for its regular session is an item that is never very palatable for politicians in an election year -proposed salary increases starting in 1983 for the legislators themselves, plus the Governor and five other top state officials who are elected statewide.

title: Antiques View; A BOOM IN ROBERT ADAM DESIGNS
description: Most of Robert Adam's architectural ideas were embodied in his furniture and interior appointments, concepts that are rich in historicism and distinguished by their variety and refinement. Just how he achieved the translation of ancient elements into the shaping and decoration of chairs, tables, mantels, mirrors and pedestals is shown in ''City Dwellings and Country Houses: Robert Adam and His Style,'' opening Tuesday and remaining through April 11 at Cooper-Hewitt, the Smithsonian Institution's National Museum of Design, 2 East 91st Street.

title: Food; SQUID IS AN INEXPENSIVE TREAT
description: SQUID is one of the least alluring of mollusks. Even though it is inexpensive and readily available, Americans are put off by its peculiar shape and its resemblance - in miniature - to a Hollywood monster of the deep. But they are missing a treat. Squid is much beloved in the Mediterranean, where it goes under the prettier names of calamaro, kalmari or calmar. It can be made into the most fragrant of stews and has the most perfect shape for stuffing of any food. It is also a great delicacy fried in crisp golden rings and served with pepper and slices of lemon.

title:
Antiques;
DECORATIVE AND FUNCTIONAL
description: HARTFORD THE Wallace Nutting collection of early Colonial American furniture, the largest assemblage of its kind in the world, is owned, fittingly enough, by America's oldest art museum, the Wadsworth Atheneum. Unfortunately, for want of adequate exhibit space and, in some instances, the need for refurbishing, the collection for years has been stored away.

title: Paul Montalto to Wed Audrey Tansill
description: Mr. and Mrs. Donald B. Tansill Jr. of Brookville, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Audrey Usher Tansill, to Paul Joseph Montalto, son of Rose Mantalto of Bayville, L.I., and Paul Montalto of Franklin Square, L.I.

title: EDITORS' CHOICE
description: THE AGE OF WONDERS, By Aharon Appelfeld. (David R. Godine, $12.95.) A novel about Austrian Jews before World War II, the air full of ominous signs.

title: Alcohol and Body Warmth
description: The notion that alcoholic beverages warm the body is potentially dangerous (''Body-Warming Drinks,'' by Terry Robards, Dec. 13). While alcohol does provide caloric energy, this does not adequately explain the drinker's perception that it has a warming effect.

title: AMERICAN SETTINGS
description: IN A HIGH PLACE By Joanne Mes chery. 366 pp. New Y ork: Simon & Schuster. $14.95. AVERY'S KNOT By Mary Cable. 238 pp. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. $12.95. By VALERIE MINER

title: CAREY WEIGHS HIS GAINS AND MISTAKES OF 7 YEARS
description: Governor Carey's announcement Friday that he would not seek a third term stunned the political community, yet was consistent with a career built on defying political wisdom to satisfy the priorities he saw.

title: A LIFE AS STRANGE AS THE WORK
description: KAFKA A Biography. By Ronald Hayman. Illustrated. 349 pp. New York: Oxford Univer sity Press. $19.95.

title: Mailbox; A Postscript On Healey's Skill
description: To the Sports Editor: Some addenda to the obituary (The New York Times, Dec. 18) of James C. Healey, onetime track star at the University of Pennsylvania (Class of '33) and United States Representative from the Bronx.

title: BEHIND THE YORKTOWN MALL CONTROVERSY
description: YORKTOWN HEIGHTS MEN and bulldozers are clearing the gray trees of winter from a 50-acre site five miles north of here as the town of Yorktown prepares to greet the Jefferson Valley Mall. It will encounter both hope and fear.

title: POTTER FINDS FULFILLMENT IN FORMING 'LIFE' ON WHEEL
description: CORNWALL BRIDGE WHEN Todd Piker arrived in Cornwall, England, at the age of 18 to begin working as a potter's apprentice, he had almost no training in ceramics and had never heard of Cornwall, Conn.

title: Miss Spath, A Paralegal, To Be Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Walter F. Spath of Pelham Manor, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Margaret Mary Spath, to Charles Anderson McLeod Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. McLeod, also of Pelham Manor.

title: No Headline
description: Ipswich Town Tops Coventry City, 4-2

title: No Headline
description: Koch Captures Cup Ski Race

title: P. John Mare Fiance Of Jane H. Schlenger
description: Mr. and Mrs. Bennett M. Schlenger of Lambertville, N.J., and New York have made known the engagement of their daughter, Jane Helen Schlenger, to P. John Mare of Flemington, N.J., son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Mare of Tenafly, N.J.

title: IN THE FOOTSTEPS OF JAMES JOYCE PARIS
description: RICHARD EDER is chief of The Times Paris bureau. By RICHARD EDER

title: Art View; SHEDDING FRESH LIGHT ON THE ART OF KANDINSKY
description: The two decades or so that came to a violent end with the start of World War I in August 1914 are now seen to constitute the single greatest period in the history of the modernist movement in art. To these fateful years belong not only the emergence of Expressionism, Cubism and other key movements of the modern era, but the very beginnings of abstract art and the esthetic innovations that followed in its wake. From Moscow and St. Petersburg in the East to New York and Chicago in the West, enclaves of buoyant and embattled avantgarde artists and visionaries trans forme d virtually every aspectof the visual culture of the modern age.

title: The Nation in Summary; So Will He, Or Won't He?
description: President Reagan met with Congressional Republicans last week to hear their side of the great tax debate of 1982. As predicted, the consensus was that no matter how ideologically onerous, some substantial tax increases are necessary to bring down Federal deficits projected to balloon over $100 billion even after some $30 billion in new spending cuts are counted in. Though the $45 billion in new excise levies that was first floated in December was on the agenda, the White House offered only reiterations that the Presidential decision would be closely held until the State of the Union message Jan. 26 -and intimations that a pro-tax stand will be taken, however reluctantly.

title: Capital Dining
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss Robinson Will Be the Bride Of Austrian Count
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Patrick W. Robinson of Castle Ca ry, Somerset, England, and New York of the engagement of their daughter, Georgina Helen Drummond Robin son, to Count Konradin Khuen-Lutzow, son of Count and Countess Hans Jacob Khuen-Lutzow of Appiano, South Tyrol, Italy.

title: Joanna Broeckl Married To Everett B. Miller 3d
description: Joanna Pearl Broeckl, a business planner with Pepsico Inc. in Purchase, N.Y., was married yesterday to Everett B. Miller 3d, area manager of re al estate investment in White Plains for the Travelers Insurance Com pany.

title:
Business Forum;
WHY THE AIR CONTROLLERS' STRIKE FAILED
description: O N Aug. 3, 1981, over 10 years of neglect, frustration and bitterness with the Federal Aviation Administration exploded into an air traffic controllers' strike.

title: The Nation in Summary; Atlanta Jurors Begin to Listen
description: The murder trial of Wayne B. Williams was suspended last week because of Atlanta's crippling snowstorm, but not before a prosecution witness had tied the defendant to one of the men he is accused of killing.

title: Good Old Days
description: To the Editor:

title: 'I COULDN'T WAIT TO SAY THE WORD'
description: From time to time The Book Review has invited both new and established writers to comment on various aspects of their craft: their imaginative and autobiographical sources, their practices of composition, the origin of their sense of vocation. These essays are intended to provide a forum for writers to consider the rewards and perils of their craft.

title: THE 'STARTER' HOUSE FOR CAREER COUPLES NOW A CONDOMINIUM
description: Most people approach the decision to buy their first house with a mixture of hope and anxiety. The commitment usually seems staggering, and even more so with current interest rates.

title: IN THE FOOTSTEPS OF JAMES JOYCE TRIESTE
description: ANTHONY BURGESS, the novelist, has written a musical, ''The Blooms of Dublin,'' based on ''Ulysses.'' By ANTHONY BURGESS

title: FOR FRERE JACQUES, PROFITS COME FIRST
description: PARIS P RESIDENT Fr an,cois Mitterrand of France, as everyone knows, is in the business of nationalizing industry. His brother, Gen. Jacques Mitterrand, w ho looks like him and shares his precision of language, is in the bus iness of running a nationalized industry. It isn't at all the same thing.

title: Sports of the Times; PAYING RESPECTS TO EDDIE COUSAR
description: ANTONIO COUSAR was a year older th an his br other, Eddie, yet they were both in the 12th grade; Antonio attends a vocational school and works in a gasoline station, and Eddie was a basketball star at DeWitt Clinton High School in the Bronx.

title: Critics' Choices
description: ART The comic strip called ''Krazy Kat'' -the creation of the cartoonist George Herriman, who drew it from 1914 to 1944, the year of his death - has long been regarded as one of the legendary accomplishments of American popular culture. The public adored it, intellectuals pondered it, and analysts of popular culture made a cult of it, and other cartoonists envied its success. Many people tended to cherish ''Krazy Kat'' with the same kind of affection and fanaticism that they lavished on the early Marx Brothers movies. Yet the strip's combination of zany high spirits, innocent comedy, clever moralism and good clean fun was never really repeated. And unlike some other famous strips of Herriman's day, ''Krazy Kat'' - though often republished since his death - was never handed over to another carto onist to carry on.

title: AFTER A.T.&T., WHAT LAW FOR COMMUNICATIONS?
description: For years, Congress has been struggling with legislation that would restructure the booming telecommunications industry and, in particular, the operations of the giant American Telephone and Telegraph Company. Now, with the proposed settlement of the Government's antitrust lawsuit against A.T.&T., announced earlier this month, the plug has been pulled on much of that work.

title: EARLIER BOEING 737 INCIDENTS LED TO SAFETY ORDERS
description: Boeing 737 airliners like the one that crashed in a snowstorm here last Wednesday have been involved in several nonfatal incidents in similar circumstances that have prompted advisories to pilots to take special flight precautions, officials disclosed today.

title: No Headline
description: CELTICS RALLY TO TOP PISTONS BY 128-120

title: How to Get There
description: Here are the hours, admission fees and a description of public transportation to the 72d National Boat Show, which opened yesterday at the New York Coliseum on Columbus Circle between West 58th and West 60th Streets.

title: Travel Advisory; LANDMARKS, POSH TOURING AND A MUSEUM; Protecting Monuments For All Time
description: What do Mammoth Cave in Kentucky and Olympic National Park in Washington have in common with the ruins of Tikal in Guatemala and the ancient stone churches of Lalibela in Ethiopia? They are all on the World Heritage List, a selection of manmade and natural attractions judged by the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization to be of such universal value that they ''should be preserved for all time.''

title: Television Week
description: True Dignity Dezso Magyar, a film director who migrated to this country from Hungary less than 10 years ago, has directed ''King of America'' - his fourth television film - a drama that recounts a young Greek immigrant's arrival and assimilation into early 20th-century America. ''King of America,'' written by B.J. Merholz, will be broadcast as the second offering in public television's new ''American Playhouse'' series, Tuesday at 9 P.M. on Channel 13. The drama stars Michael Welden and Larry Atlas. Elizabeth Swados composed the music.

title: New York Times Magazine January 17, 1982
description: William Safire 8 On Language From Podunk to the Boonies Russell Baker 15 Sunday Observer Lost Genius Harold C. Schonberg 24 A Bravo for Opera's Black Voices Eva Hoffman 28 The Poet Of the Polish Diaspora Peter G. Peterson 40 No More Free Lunch for the Middle Class America's future prosperity requires that we vastly increase investment in industrial productivity. Where will we get the money? The author would cut into the massive Federal programs for housing and for the retired that primarily benefit the middle class. Barney Cohen 42 Steve Tesich Turns Memories Into Movies Deborah Blumenthal 67 Beauty Splitting the Difference In Hairbrushes Charles Churchward 68 Men's Fashion Preview Tampering With the Traditional Craig Claiborne 72 Food with Pierre Franey Rising to the Occasion Rita Reif 74 Design What Price Antiques? 77 Puzzles Answers, Page 82 94 Letters Cover:Photograph by Annie Leibovitz/Contact Copyright 1980, The New York Times

title: YACHTSMEN PREPARE FOR MALLORY RACES
description: GREENWICH ''POSH,'' a term that may be second only to ''affluent'' as the commonly held perception of this community, was derived from one of Greenwich's favorite pastimes - sailing. And even now, preparations are under way for the Mallory Cup finals, to be held here for the first time Sept. 12-15 at the Indian Harbor Yacht Club. There the late Clifford D. Mallory, seventh-generation owner of the Clyde and Mallory Steamship Companies, was commodore from 1930 to 1936.

title: Salvador's Rebels Say Planes Strafed Refugees in Honduras
description: Guerrillas say that Salvadoran Air Force planes bombed and strafed refugee camps in Honduras this week. The rebels' Radio Venceremos said Friday that ''planes from the Salvadoran Air Force bombed and strafed refugee camps in Honduran territory'' on Wednesday across the border Chalatenango Province of El Salvador.

title: FOR MEN, A FRESH APPROACH TO CLASSICS
description: The designers of men's clothing have always been faced with a challenging limitation. Most men simply do not want to wear clothing that is the least bit noticeable. With the exception of the revolution in dress in the late 60's, and the minor rebellion of the late 70's, men have been content, at least since World War II, to wear navy or gray suits, sport coats, trousers, white or blue shirts, rep ties, and leave it at that. It is a uniform that is distinctly, and satisfyingly, male, and one that is supremely successful in both professional and private contexts.

title: HOSTAGES, FAME FADING, RESUMING A NORMAL LIFE
description: The Hostage Crisis: One Year Later First of three articles. By ROBERT D. McFADDEN

title: 'Something Special' In Freeport
description: Hooray for Joan Colgan's recent article about Freeport (''I Love Freeport and Here's Why,'' Opinion Page). We've lived here almost 20 years and agree wholeheartedly that ours is a fine town.

title:
Speaking Personally;
IT'S SKI-TOURING TIME ON NEW JERSEY'S TRAILS
description: AS A backwoods snow fanatic ceremoniously deposited, via marriage, into the New York metropolitan area, I have spent my winters of exile trying to continue a lifelong love affair with snow.

title: No Headline
description: Lester Trimble's article inadvertently leads the public to believe that the Carnegie Hall Corporation ignores as a matter of policy the essential contribution of American composers to our culture. In fact, Carnegie Hall, while maintaining its international character, has a strong commitment to the performance of American music.

title: ADAPTING WAUGH'S 'BRIDESHEAD'- NOSTALGIA REVISITED
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- John Mortimer, who wrote the television adaptation of ''Brideshead Revisited,'' is a British playwright, author and barrister. His ''Rumpole of the Bailey'' series was shown on American public television last year. By JOHN MORTIMER LONDON Evelyn Waugh wrote ''Brideshead Revisited'' during a five-month leave from military service in 1944. It was a bleak period of our history, a time, as he said, ''of soya beans and Basic English,'' and so he produced a book that saw the past in a roseate glow. The splendors of country-house life took on a glamour, and Oxford in the 1920's appeared to have a succulent decadence, which may never have been apparent at the time. The book, as he said, tells us more about the England of the 1940's than it does of the 20's and 30's: Our dreams of the days that are gone throw less light on our past than on our present situation.

title: FLIGHT PATHS MOVED TO QUIET AIRPORT
description: IN his ground-floor office, Richard Smith, tower chief at Westchester County Airport, moved his hand over a map on the wall as he described the new departure procedure that will go into effect tomorrow for planes taking off from Runway 16, a planes taking off from Runway 16, a procedure intended to reduce noise in communities near the airport. ''We're try ing to get them to turn closer, over the less-populated areas, after takeoff,'' he said. Runway 16, the airport's main runway, points directly toward Rye and Port Ches ter, N.Y., and leads planes over Greenwich, where protest group s have been campaigning for more than a year for a new procedure wou ld require planes to observe a speed limit and to turn sooner after their takeoff to avoid the populated communities.

title: Jenny Gelber Is Married
description: Jenny Gelber, director of communications for the Massachusetts Department of Social Services, and Gerald Chervinsky, news assignment editor at WBZ-TV in Boston, plan to be married on May 23. Their engegament has been announced by Mrs. Isaac Gelber of St. Petersburg Beach, Fla., mother of the future bride, who is a daughter also of the late Dr. Gelber. Mr. Chervinsky's pa rents , Dr. and Mrs. Paul Chervinsky, live in New Bedford, Mass. His fa ther teaches at the Tufts University School of Medicine.

title: PREVIEW OF 'ONE FROM THE HEART'
description: In previewing his new film, ''One From the Heart,'' twice Friday night at Radio City Music Hall, Francis Coppola fulfilled his desire to present his new work directly to the public and let the public decide on its merits.

title: Prospects
description: A Sluggish Recovery

title:
The Careful Shopper;
Store's Winter Sale Has Some Fall Bargains
description: A winter sale of sportswear and casual clothes is on at Jeri's, near the Hartsdale train station, but a few summer and fall items in the backroom are marked down 50 percent. At the front of the store, prices vary from 20 percent - on gloves, bags, belts, scarves, jewelry and accessories - to 30 percent - on skirts, shirts, sweaters, pants and robes - and to 40 percent off on blazers, jackets and dresses. All prices are adjusted at the register. Early spring merchandise is 30 percent off, and the shop carries sizes 4 to 16.

title: MAN OF MANY HATS PUTS ON A NEW ONE FOR THE PINELANDS
description: MEDFORD RIC DAVIDGE, the new Federal appointee to the state's Pinelands Commission, asks people to judge him by his performance, not his past.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Law Review's New Criteria
description: After a year's debate full of sound and fury, the Harvard Law Review last week approved an affirmative action plan that may signify little since it mandates nothing.

title: WILLING VICTIM
description: HEADING WEST By Doris Betts. 359 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $13.50.

title: WITH CAREY OUT, IT'S ONE WILD POKER GAME
description: ''It's kind of sad to see the champ step aside,'' reflected Lieut. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, ''even if you've been in the ring with him.'' But hours after Hugh L. Care said he would step down, Mr. Cuomo confessed ''a sense of anticipation'' about running for Governor himself.

title: ENERGY RESOURCES NOTED IN NEW BOOK
description: CAROL WILSON and the students in her high-school science class probably did not expect to be singled out for exemplary behavior when they banded together with the maintenance crews at Sheehan High School in Wallingford to conduct an energy audit of their own and other school buildings in town. But that is what happened.

title: ST. JOHN'S SETS BACK CONNECTICUT, 77-71
description: At the end of a game that had 13 more fouls than field goals, that had seven St. John's and Connecticut players foul out and tha t had both coaches running out of both patience and players, Kevin Williams took advantage of a second chance.

title: THE POET OF THE POLISH DIASPORA
description: Eva Hoffman is an editor on The Week in Review. A native of Poland, she has taught literature in several American universities. By Eva Hoffman

title: JACOBSON REFLECTS ON ROLE IN ENERGY
description: NEWARK WITH a vase of decaying maroon roses as a backdrop and a pile of broken squash racquets at his feet, Joel R. Jacobson, the state's former Commissioner of Energy, spent the last minutes in his old office castigating critics and complimenting colleagues.

title: BRITAIN'S ALLIANCE DIVIDING DISTRICTS
description: Stephen Mennell, secretary of the local branch of Britain's new Social Democratic Party, thinks his party can easily win the Exeter seat in the next parliamentary election - but only if the local Liberal Party will stand aside in its favor.

title: RESTFUL CARE AT CLINIC
description: SLEEP certainly does not knit up ''the ravell'd sleave of care'' for the patients at the Sleep Disorders Center at the State University at Stony Brook.

title: Theater in Review; 'ARTICHOKE': DAFT, DROLL, PREDICTABLE
description: LINDENHURST WITH characteristically adventuresome spirit, Studio Theater is presenting a play that few people hereabouts are likely to have heard about: ''Artichoke,'' a daft, droll and engaging dramatic comedy by Joanna McClel land Glass, wh o just last season made her Bro adway playwriting debut with ''To Grandmother's House We Go,'' a contrived work that was attention-getting only as a vehicle for the ineffable Eva Le Gallienne.

title: SENATOR CRANSTON PONDERS BID FOR PRESIDENCY
description: Alan Cranston said that when he went to the United St ates Senate in 1969 he held the Presidency in such awe that it was ' 'hard to imagine one's self in it.''

title: Cancer Care Inc.: What It Does
description: We are writing in response to an article written by Bernard Sloan that appeared in the Jan. 3, 1982, Westchester Weekly section (''Outside Medicaid and Looking In''). While we share Mr. Sloan's displeasure with the fact that only the very poor are eligible for Medicaid services, we are deeply concerned by the aspersions cast upon our agency by the following statement in the article: ''I called Cancer Care, who I heard offered a skilled homemaker service. Is she on Medicaid?'' they asked. ''Sorry.''

title: G.M. SEEKING TO SLASH COSTS BY $1,000 TO $1,200 PER AUTO
description: Negotiators for the General Motors Corporation are seeking labor concessions and other cost reductions totaling from $1,000 to $1,200 a car as part of the company's plan to increase sales by cutting prices.

title: Sean McCooey to Wed Ja ne A. Franks in April
description: Mr. and Mrs. Alfred E. Franks of Convent Station, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jane Angela Franks, to Sean McCarthy McCooey, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert J. McCooey of Manhasset and Westhampton, L.I.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Inventor Struggle
description: Gordon Gould was 37 years old and a graduate student in physics at Columbia University in 1957 when he conceived of a device he called a laser. When he went to patent it in 1959, he learned to his chagrin that others had come up with the same principle.

title: QUEEN OF THE SHOW IS SLIM AND SPEEDY
description: THE queen of this year's National Boat Show is no dowager. At 54-feet and a mere 21,000 pounds, the slim and speedy Hunter 54 is a pedigreed stripling compared with the typical 50,000-pound motor yacht or cruising ketch that usually earns top billing when the show comes each January to the New York Coliseum.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: A LILTING TRIBUTE TO KURT WEILL
description: MONTCLAIR THE Whole Theater Company's production of ''A Kurt Weill Cabaret'' persuades us all that ''basic black'' is the best way to dress - to dress up certain shows, that is.

title: 28-FOOTER BY LEWIS
description: Big- time i ndoor track came to New Jersey tonight with a record binge in the Vit alis/United States Olympic Invitational meet. But the biggest ch eers of all went to Alberto Salazar, who did not set a record but came back from last place after a fall and won going away on the new board track.

title: Hugh W. Donaldson, 85, Dies; Ex-Official of Chicago Tribune
description: Hugh W. Donaldson, former manager of public services for The Chicago Tribune, died in New York Friday night.

title: HOWARD TOPAZ TO WED TERRI SOLOMON
description: Mr. and Mrs. Sol Solomon of Clifton, N.J., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Terri Solomon, to Howard M. Topaz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Topaz of the Bronx.

title: Kremer to Play at the Y
description: Gidon Kremer, the violinist, will make his first New York appearance as a chamber player at the 92d Street Y on Jan. 31 at 8 P.M. The concert, which includes music by Schubert and Haydn, also features Katherine Rabus, violinist; Kim Kashkashian, violist; Ko Iwasaki, cellist, and Elena Kramer, pianist. Tickets at $15 may be obtained through Chargit, 944-9300. There will be reduced rates for students and the elderly on the day of the concert.

title: VOLUNTEERS TO HELP WITH TAX RETURNS
description: A VOLUNTEER force of approximately 750 individuals, a majority of whom are either college students enrolled in accounting or business management courses or retired people with some accounting and business background, will be setting up temporary advisory centers in the next few weeks to provide free assistance to anyone needing help filling out a tax return.

title: No Headline
description: North Carolina Remains Unbeaten, 73-63

title: Briton Wins Marathon On His First Attempt
description: David Long, a British citizen who lives in Louisville, Ky., entered his first marathon today, won it and set a record for the course.

title: READERS REPLY TO 'A TALE OF TWO POWER PLANTS'
description: ''A Tale of Two Power Plants'' makes an int eresting comparison between Shoreham and Connecticut's Millstone II nuclear plant. Unfortunately, it left out several major poin ts.

title: THE EVOLVING THEORY OF EVOLUTION
description: THE NEW EVOLUTIONARY TIMETABLE Fossils, Genes, and the Origin of Species. By Steven M. Stanley. Illustrated. 222 pp. New York: Basic Books. $16.75.

title: A WORLD OF THINGS IN A WORLD OF WORDS
description: SCENES OF CHILDHOOD By Sylvia Townsend Warner. 177 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $10.95.

title: Demarche Polonaise
description: Having devoured their soc iety to satisfy th e Russians, the Polish putschists keep throwing one lean bone to the West. His name is Mieczyslaw Rakowski, a Deputy Prime Minister who has mastered the dialects of liberalism as well as Communism. The military junta has given him the Ministry of the Heavy Heart and made him its ambassadorto the dollar democracies to beg sympathy and credits.

title: No Headline
description: FLYERS DEFEAT CANADIENS, 4-2

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: DANCE: QUINLAN-KRICHELS IN SOKOLOW PROGRAM
description: Anna Sokolow won heads down Friday night over Isadora Duncan. Not that there was a contest.
