The program of works by the two women and other choreographers, presented by the Quinlan-Krichels Ensemble at the Washington Square Methodist Church, was an evening of tastefully conceived dance.

title: Dining Out; A NO-NONSENSE STEAKHOUSE
description: THE North Shore Steakhouse in Great Neck has been under new management for about a year. Its full name is now Grace Fives' North Shore Steakhouse. The change is evident in the decorations, not dramatically revised but fresher and done in a warmly tailored manner, mostly in beige with burgundy accents. The atmosphere is one of tasteful comfort. The restaurant also accepts a credit card now. It remains a serious, no-nonsense steakhous e providing massive portions of mainly grilled dishes that rely o n first-rate ingredients. The servings can be overgenerous . Faced with a pair of large loin veal chops, one settles in for som e hearty eating. Sharingis an obvious option, but it incurs a $3.50 s urcharge.

title: LIFE IN AN INGROWN HOUSEHOLD
description: AGAINST THE STREAM By James Hanley. 256 pp. New York: Horizon Press. $12.95.

title: ROBB VOWS EXCELLENCE AT VIRGINIA OATH-TAKING
description: Charles S. Robb was sworn in as Governor of Virginia today, his left hand resting on the Bible on which Lyndon B. Johnson, his late father-in-law, took the Presidential oath in 1965.

title: Laura deBuys Engaged To John H. Hastings
description: The engagement of Laura Rathbone deBuys to John Hamilton Hastings, son of Mr. and Mrs. David B. Hastings of Haverford, Pa., has been made known by Mr. and Mrs. William Eno deBuys of Ruxton, Mass., parents of the future bride. The wedding is planned for September.

title: LENDL TOPPLES MCENROE, FACES GERULAITIS IN FINAL
description: The gap is closing quickly between John McEnroe and Ivan Lendl at the top of international tennis. Lendl, No.2 in the ranking since Jan. 4, leveled his strongest challenge to McEnroe's top spot with a decisive 6-4, 6-2 victory yesterday in the semifinals of the $400,000 Volvo Masters tournament at Madison Square Garden. It was Lendl's 35th consecutive triumph in a Grand Prix event, and by far his most impressive performance against McEnroe.

title: INAUGURAL EVENTS GET EARLY START
description: TRENTON ALTHOUGH the inauguration of Thomas H. Kean as New Jersey's next Governor will not take place until noon on Tuesday, the round of cultural and social events ma rking the occasion already have begun.

title: No Headline
description: Around the World; Berlin Police Question 6 Palestinians on Blast

title: Two-Acre Zoning And Water Quality
description: In the recent article ''Three Years After Water Study, Cleanup Efforts Yield Mixed Results,'' the impression is given that the twoacre zoning ordinance which was unsuccessfully challenged in Federal Court was enacted by the Brookhaven Town Board solely to protect the high quality of water found in the eastern portion of the town where the pine barrens are located. To be sure, preservation of the high quality of water was a significant factor in the enactment of the two-acre zoning ordinance, but it was not the only one.

title: DEALING WITH CRIME AND CRIMINALS
description: ON DEC. 27, Prof. Jackson Toby of Rutgers University used this space to argue against the anticrime proposals offered by Governorelect Thomas H. Kean during the gubernatorial campaign.

title: Refugee Total in Asia Drops
description: The number of Indochinese refugees at camps throughout Asia dropped from 311,000 a year ago to 232,000 at the beginning of 1982, the office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees said today.

title: Restraint Toward East Is Affirmed by Schmidt
description: Chancellor Helmut Schmidt said today that West Germany would hold to its policy of restraint and cooperation with the Soviet bloc despite criticism from some Western countries.

title: Susan Golding Married
description: Susan Kirshnit Golding, widow of Stephen L. Golding, was married yesterday to Jerry M. Woodall. Village Justice Ralph Bettman of Tarrytown, N.Y., performed the ceremony at the couple's home in Bedford Hills, N.Y. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Max Kirshnit of Farmington, Conn. Mr. Woodall, whose previous marriage ended in divorce, is an inventor and research scientist with International Business Machines in Yorktown Heights, N.Y. He is a son of Mae Woodall of Takoma Park, Md., and the late Thornton Woodall.

title:
Antiques;
THE RESTORATION OF DRUMTHWACKET
description: PRINCETON ON A mild day less than three weeks ago, a cluster of architects and designers stood in the yard of Drumthwacket, the successor to Morven as the Governor's mansion. They were discussing the problem of completing restoration of the historic house - or, at least, making it presentable - for a party that was held last night to celebrate the election of the new Governor, Thomas H. Kean.

title: No Headline
description: South Wins, 27-10, In the Senior Bowl

title: Poland, Moscow And NATO Allies Ponder Strategy
description: After relentlessly cultivating the impression that Poland's Dec. 13 military crackdown was strictly a homegrown product, the Kremlin last week dropped the veil slightly and welcomed Polish Foreign Minister Jozef Czyrek to Moscow. His Soviet counterpart, Andrei A. Gromyko, embraced him and offered the nearest thing yet to a Soviet endorsement of martial law - confidence that Poland ''will, with the help of its friends and allies, cope successfully with its difficulties.'' The Czyrek-Gromyko talks, said Tass, ''passed in a heartfelt, comradely atmosphere.''

title: MANY GHANAIANS INTERPRET COUP AS TRIBAL PLOT
description: The coup in which Jerry J. Rawli ngs overthrew the Government of President Hilla Limann is being viewed bymany Ghanaian s as the result of a conspiracy by the minority Ewe tribal group to which Mr. Rawlings and most of his associates belong.

title: EMPLOYMENT PLAN IS AIDING ALCOHOLICS
description: FOR the first time in his 40 years, Dugan B. says he feels he is worth something to somebody. An alcoholic who has been on welfare most of his life, Mr. B. has never held a real job and has been in and out of jail throughout his drinking years from age 15 to 35. Except for one major relapse, he has been sober for four and a half years, but for him and many other recovered alcoholics with no employment background, finding out about the world of work and how to enter that world has constituted a major problem.

title: NATO'S NEW FLAP, OVER POLAND, IS DIFFERENT
description: SECRETARY of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. last week hailed NATO's togetherness on Poland as ''a solid success.'' Treaty members (except Greece) agreed they might emulate Washington by invoking sanctions against Moscow, if conditions in Warsaw don't improve. But they made no promises, dancing around some basic disagr eements. The differencesover Poland have revived debate about NATO's role. One prominent conservative, Irving Kristol, has even conten ded that ''NATO ceased to be a living reality some years ago.''

title:
Dining Out;
A CHOICE OF SPANISH OR PORTUGUESE
description: EL PESCADOR in Roselle Park is not for diners with timid palates. Neither is it recommended for those who blanch at the idea of primary colors used with abandon, or fishing nets, hawsers and fishing trophies used to decorate a dining room. However, for those who delight in brightly colored, noisy restaurants, and decent Portuguese and Spanish food, El Pescador is worth a visit.

title: NO MORE FREE LUNCH FOR THE MIDDLE CLASS
description: Peter G. Peterson, a former Secretary of Commerce, is the chairman of the board of Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb Inc. By Peter G. Peterson

title: ANN ENNIS TO BE A BRIDE
description: The engagement of Ann Maureen Ennis to Robert Griffin Wallace Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Wallace of Wayne, N.J., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. William H. Ennis, also of Wayne.

title: John Eric Stiner And a Designer To Wed in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. John B. Breckenridge of Bethesda, Md., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Robin Wilson Breckenridge, to John Eric Stiner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard M. Stiner of Hamden, Conn. A June wedding is planned.

title:
Food;
TO CUT THE MUSTARD, HE'S NOW MAKING HIS OWN
description: ROCKVILLE CENTRE WHEN he isn't trading bonds on Wall Street, Frank Henkel can often be found stirring a 10-gallon vat of his creamy herb-studded mustard. Appearing quite at ease with a white apron wrapped around his frame, Mr. Henkel thinks nothing of whipping up fettuccine for friends, souffles for supper or a three-course breakfast for his wife, Gail, and his three children.

title: Connecticut Housing; CONDO OWNERS LEARNING POLITICS
description: CONDOMINIUM owners have for years complained that they have been denied municipal services and forced to pay unfairly high tax rates. And now some say that the number of condominium owners has risen to the point whe re they can persuade political leaders to their point ofview.

title: UDALL IS DECIDING BETWEEN TWO DISTRICTS
description: Representative Morris K. Udall, Democrat of Arizona, has unofficially begun his re-election campaign, meeting with labor and community leaders, Democratic Party workers, farmers and other groups.

title: Keith Haurie Fiance Of Maura C. Deegan
description: New Jersey Superior Court Judge Joseph F. Deegan Jr. and Mrs. Deegan of Perth Amboy, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Maura Catherine Deegan, to Keith A. Haurie, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick C. Haurie of Scotch Plains, N.J.

title: AGE STUDY TO LOOK AT QUALITY OF LIFE
description: W HILE aging itself is inevitable, the compa ny you keep, your social networks and mental attitude could pla y as important a role asdiet, exercise and smoking in determining a h ealthy, long life.

title: Around the Nation; Backer of Arkansas Law On Creationism Resigns
description: State Senator Jim Holsted, who sponsored the creation science bill in Arkansas, has resigned as part of a negotiated agreement in a theft case.

title: Headliners; POETIC JUSTICE
description: Supporters were relieved last week when a Federal judge ruled that a South African poet and scholar, Dennis Brutus, had 20 days in which to apply for political asylum in this country. His friends had feared that Mr. Brutus, a professor of African literature at Northwestern University, might be deported. Described at one time as one of South Africa's most dangerous enemies, he came to the United States in exile 10 years ago after being shot and imprisoned by South African police.

title: Miss Fisher P lans Bridal
description: Dr. Mary Stuart Fisher and Dr. George Ross Fisher 3d of Haddonfield, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Margaret Fisher, to Jonathan Rosenthal, son of Mr. and Mrs. A.M. Rosenthal of New York.

title:
Stamps;
U.S. PAYS TRIBUTE TO A GREAT AMERICAN SCIENTIST
description: Dr. Robert A. Millikan, who became a scientist in spite of himself, went on to become a winner of the Nobel Prize in physics and a vital contributor to man's knowledge of electrons, cosmic rays and the quantum theory. He joins a growing roster of other Americans of distinction who have been appearing in the new Great Americans Series of regular issues.

title: Internist to Wed Jeryl E. Longfield
description: Dr. and Mrs. James E. Longfield of Basking Ridge, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jeryl Elizabeth Longfield, to Dr. John E. Erickson, son of Dr. and Mrs. Alan E. Erickson of Needham, Mass.

title: A GLIMMER OF HOPE FOR POLAND, HUNGARIAN STYLE
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWT'S EYE, LACE, ARSENIC FOR DINNER
description: foot invisible rabbit, is coming to dinner. But entertaining Harvey, the star of Mary Chase's 1944 Broadway hit and of the subsequent movie, is all in a night's work - or should I say play? - for us.

title: No Headline
description: When American composers have something to say, the world listens, applauds and adopts.

title: Dietary Trial Held Warranted To Treat Child Hyperactivity
description: A National Institutes of Health committee, trying to sort out the controversy over food additives andhyperactivity in children, said Friday that a n initial trial of dietary restrictions might be warranted to tr eat behavioral problems.

title: Leisure; IT'S TIME TO ORDER SEEDS FOR PERENNIALS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Joanna May Thach is a writer who gardens on Long Island. By JOANNA MAY THACH

title: WHEN ONE'S CHILD IS HANDICAPPED
description: BEING the mother of a handicapped child in 1982 is to sometimes feel slightly out of sync with society. In a time when women of all ages and middle-aged women in particular are encouraged to selfactualize, it's having one's own needs and desires come second to those of the child. At the same time, it's being careful to avoid, as one would the plague, donning the crown of martyrdom.

title: The Region in Summary; Koch Prepares More Turns Of the Screw
description: ''The worst pain is behind us,'' Mayor Koch said when he delivered his budget last year. But as he unveiled his 1983 spending plan last week, there seemed to be more of it ahead.

title: The World in Summary; Autonomy Talks Make Haig's 'Urgent' List
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. got out and pushed last week, restarting the long-stalled Israeli-Egyptian talks on Palestinian automony. After a year of standing aloof from the Camp David negotiations, Mr. Haig dropped by Cairo and Jerusalem where President Hosni Mubarak and Prime Minister Menachem Begin respectively agreed, he said, ''to achieve greater momentum'' toward a ''breakthrough'' on self-rule for 1.3 million Palestinians in the West Bank and Gaza Strip.

title: Headliners; Newport's Trial
description: Newport. R.I. has known its share of society scandals but nothing quite like the trial for attempted murder of Claus von Bulow that began last week. The ingredients include a doctor's black bag, a statement from a prostitute and letters from a maid. Mr. von Bulow is charged with twice trying to kill his heiress wife, the former Martha Sharp Crawford, by injecting her with insulin and barbiturates in 1979 and 1980. Mrs. von Bulow, whose estate is estimated as high as $35 million, has been in a coma since December 1980 and physicians say she will not recover.

title: IF SELLER GIVES AID TO BUYER, METHOD MATTERS
description: Some time late last year the people at the Suburban Savings and Loan Association of New Jersey tired of telling customers looking for a special kind of a ssistance that they could not help them.

title: DANCE: ROBIN FELD TROUPE
description: The company was called Robin Feld and Cohorts. And Miss Feld's two theater-dance pieces, performed Thursday at the American Theater Laboratory's Bessie Schonberg Theater, were on the cute side, too, but not unwitty.

title: An Easter Bonnet Lawsuit
description: Marcia Rodstein, an employment agency placement officer who is Jewish, has filed a $25,000 lawsuit contending th at her refusal to wear an Easter bonnet at a company luncheon resu lted in her unlawful dismissal. The concern, M. David Lowe Personne l Services, says her dimissal was not related to her religion.

title: Remembering Pearl Harbor
description: I read William Zinsser's article ''Pearl Harbor: The Way It Was at Princeton'' (Dec. 6) with an insatiable curiosity, bred as a war baby raised on a steady diet at home, in school and at the movies of the great American experience, World War II.

title: HEALTH DEPT. CITES 25 OUTLETS
description: The New York City Department of Health has released the names of 25 restaurants that it said had violated the Health Code. The department also released the names of four restaurants that had reopened after correcting earlier violations, and two that had been closed for f ailing to do so.

title: Brazil
description: To the Editor:

title:
Gardening;
PAPER BIRCH, THE EPITOME OF ORNAMENTALS
description: FEW trees are more striking than the paper birch. A multi stemmed, white-bark birch is considered to be the epitome of all ornamental trees, and it is often given the most prominent location.

title: The World in Summary; Ghana Restores Libyan Ties
description: The announcement last week by Ghana's military regime that it would restore diplomatic ties with Libya confirmed suspicions among some in the West that Libya's Col. Muammar el-Qadaffi played a direct role in the New Year's Eve coup that overthrew President Hilla Liman n.

title: LONDON'S LORDLY BARBER
description: WILLIAM BORDERS is a correspondent in the London bureau of The Times. By WILLIAM BORDERS

title: Art; ATHENEUM UNVEILS CLOTH TREASURES
description: HARTFORD LIKE Scheherazade, the Wadsworth Atheneum reveals its treasures gradually. The latest disclosure is ''Rites and Rituals,'' a group of 60 ceremonial costumes and textiles drawn from the museum's collection by its curator, Marianne Carlano, and sponsored by United Technologies.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Life Beyond the Core Curriculums
description: Time was when colleges and universities agreed on their goal - to turn out an educated person - and also agreed, more or less, on the academic production process. No longer.

title: HEFNER TESTIFIES AT HEARING ON CASINO
description: Hugh M. Hefner, founder, chairman and 70 percent owner of Playboy Enterprise s, spen t three days on the witness stand this week in quest of a casino license.

title: THE PERILS OF SLEEP
description: STONY BROOK FOR many of the patients at the State University at Stony Brook's Sleep Disorders Center, sleep is ''an unavoidable interval'' - and it could be hazardous to their health. In three small bedrooms here, patients spending the night slip under blue coverlets and drift off, with electrodes monitoring their heartbeat, eye movement, breathing patterns, brain waves and muscle twitches. The information is recorded on polygraph machines just outside the bedrooms.

title: FOR WILDLIFE PHOTOGRAPHER, HER 'LIFE BEGAN AT 40'
description: APEACOCK has pressed its beak against the camera while she was taking its picture and a herd of female elephants once protectively surrounded the baby she was attempting to photograph. Margot Conte of White Plains is a well-known wildlife photographer, but for the first four decades of her life she wasn't even interested in photography.

title: Charity
description: To the Business Editor: Stephen L. Slavin's Jan. 3 response, ''Charity (Cont.),'' to our Dec. 27 letter, ''Bergmann's Coercion,'' fell victim to a typographical error.

title: Pearl Harbor
description: To the Editor:$

title: Favorite Wins With Cordero
description: Angel Cordero, who rode a record 30 stakes winners in New York last year, won his first stakes of 1982 yesterday when he rode Polite Rebuff to victory in the $55,500 Busanda Stakes at Aqueduct.

title: The World in Summary; Huge Nest Egg But for Whom?
description: Wealthy political allies being no less prized in India than elsewhere, Prime Minister Indira Gandhi stonewalled weeks of criticism over her refusal to oust the Chief Minister of Maharashtra State, Abdur Rahman Antulay, who was accused of corruption. Upon his conviction for extortion last week, Mr. Antulay solved the problem the hard way, by resigning.

title: Westchester Guide; COUNTY SKI TRIPS OFFERED
description: Because Westchester County owns no downhill ski areas, the Parks and Recreation Department hosts ski sessions for county residents at nearby slopes each winter. A ''Learn to Ski Day'' has been arranged from 9 A.M. to 4 P.M. today at Bobcat Ski Center in Andes, N.Y., a two-and-a-half-hour drive from White Plains.

title: Sunday Observer
description: By Russell Baker Lost Genius PATRICK MCDONNELL

title: The Nation in Summary; A Gallon Here, A Dollar There
description: You may have to get up pretty early to outsmart some Federal Agencies, buy when it comes to cheating Uncle Sam on oil and gas leases it's apparently safe to sleep till noon.

title: KAMAKURA: ANCIENT CITY OF THE SHOGUNS
description: RICHARD HALLORAN is a reporter in the Washington bureau of The New York Times and a former Tokyo correspondent. By RICHARD HALLORAN

title: CONFESSIONS OF THE ULTIMATE SPORTS FAN
description: DO you know me? The name probably isn't familiar, but my face probably is. You see, I'm the world's greatest pro football fan. No, I don't have a million bubble gum football trading cards, or chinstraps from various National Football League helmets, or even Joe Namath's autograph. I don't even have season tickets. That's all kid stuff, and I grew out of those stages years ago.

title: No Headline
description: Tulsa Upsets Wichita State by 99-88

title: STILL SKIING AT 70
description: DINAH B. WITCHEL is executive editor of Skiing magazine and the author of ''Ski Woman's Way.'' By DINAH B.WITCHEL

title: The People on the Edge
description: Christina Nelson, a young mother from Mineral Point, Mo., had a job and wanted to keep it. Then why, asked John Hart of NBC News, did she quit? Because her baby daughter was sick. Working made her ineligible for medical coverage. By going onto welfare, she ''got my Medicaid card back on he r.... I had to take h er into consideration over myself. Myself, I'd rather work than be on welfare.''

title: Rape 'Victim' Recants
description: A man who has served nearly two years of a 12-year prison sentence for rape may get a new trial because the victim now says she lied, according to court records. The man, Joseph W. Hickman Jr., will get a new hearing Feb. 18 to determine whether his case should be retried. A brief court order issued by the Delaware Supreme Court last week said the woman, who was not identified, wanted to retract false statements implicating Mr. Hickman.

title: Nonfiction in Brief
description: AGAINST THE GRAIN Southern Radicals and Prophets, 1929-59. By Anthony P. Dunbar. Illustrated. 306 pp. Charlottesville, Va.: The University Press of Virginia. $16.95.

title: Sports of The Times; 'LIVING IS THE TRICK,' BUT WITHOUT THE LIME, THANK YOU
description: SEVERAL years ago, Red Smith agreed to deliver the eulogy at the funeral of his longtime friend Fred Corcoran, the golf impresario. When the mass ended, Red Smith walked up near the sanctuary and turned to face those assembled in the pews.

title: Endurance Racing Undergoes Change
description: For 15 years the 24-hour road race at Daytona Beach has marked the start of the international long-distance road racing season. The race will be different this time, though. Disagreements over rules for a new class of endurance racing cars has led to a split between Europe and North America, and none of the big European teams is scheduled to participate in the 24-Hour Pepsi Challenge at the end of this month.

title: No Headline
description: This Week:

title: Long Island Journal
description: AS the impact of the Reagan Administration's budget cuts begins to take effect, Hofstra University, which was founded in 1935 during the first Administration of Franklin D. Roosevelt, will celebrate from March 4 to 7 the centennial of the birth of the man who gave leadership to the United States during the Great Depression and who remains a symbol to many of a massive Federal aid program that gave help to those who could not help themselves.

title: Saving Face, Losing Ground
description: Reaction to President Reagan's decision on jet planes for Taiwan last week demonstrated the difficulty of finding a middle ground between the official reality of a one-China policy and the Administration's nostalgia for a two-China policy. By rejecting Taiwan's request for advanced fighters, Mr. Reagan angered Taiwan and its supporters in America.

title: ONE-ON-ONE PLAN AIDS CANCER PATIENTS
description: YEAR-OLD Beth wasn't worried about the tiny lump on the left side of her neck when it appeared last summer. She thought it was a swollen gland, a complication from an appendectomy performed in June.

title: WIDE VARIETY OF FISHING BOATS OFFERED
description: THIS year's National Boat Show offers a large selection of boats designed for fishing - whether for flounder or blues in Long Island Sound or game fish offshore. The Coliseum not being the easiest place in which to inser t a large boat, the really big sport fishing machines like the Bertram 58 Convertible and the Hatteras 60 Convertible a re not in evidence, but their slightly smaller sisters, the Bertram 4 2 and the Hatteras 46, are.

title: FORMER ARMY NEWSMEN RELIVE WORLD WAR II S TORIES
description: When Jack Raymond, a former Army sergeant, got together on Friday with some of his old Army buddies, the evening took its natural course: drinks, dinner and the swapping of war stories.

title: York Players to Revive Giraudoux 'Enchanted'
description: The York Players Company will present a revival of Jean Giraudoux's ''The Enchanted'' as its second production of the season.

title: Critics' Choices
description: PHOTOGRAPHYIn 1974, Robert D'Alessandro published a book of photographs, ''Glory,'' that was a masterpiece in the tradition of Robert Frank's ''The Americans'' and Lee Friedlander's ''Self Portrait.'' With its juxtaposition of American flags, guns and working-class Americans of various ages, it was apparently intended as an indictment of the kind of patriotism that led the American people to support the Vietnam War for so long.

title: CHANGE IN MAGIC'S ACT
description: For two months now, the joke has been that Earvin (Magic) Johnson made a coach disappear. But, in a sense, he's also made himself disappear.

title: REAGAN--NOT THE LAW--SHIFTED ON BIAS AND TAXES
description: President Reagan last week justified the new Administration policy of granting tax exemptions to private segregationist schools by calling the old policy of denying them a lawless invention of faceless bureaucrats. In the next breath, he promised to ask Congress to make the new policy illegal.

title: Transactions
description: FOOTBALL

title: THE FUN IS BACK FOR PAVELICH
description: Mark Pavelich, one of the smallest and easily the quietest Ranger, is having fun playing hockey again. He is one of the leaders of the team's recent resurgence and, as the Rangers' third-highest scorer, Pavelich knows he is needed, probably as much as he was as a member of the United States Olympic team that won a gold medal in 1980.

title: A LOCAL PROPOSAL FOR CARE OF AGED
description: HOW fast our image changes as the years fly by. When one becomes a certain age, most of the time is spent reminiscing. My interest a quarter of a century ago was, as it is now, the life style of the so-called aging, although I now prefer being called an oldster. My dream was, and is, to build the retirement period of our lives in a place we wanted, not feared, to go to.

title: JOB TRAINING BILLS TO REPLACE CETA PREPARED
description: Members of Congress are preparing legislation for a job training program th at would replace the Comprehensive Employment an d Training Act program.

title: Photography View; JILL FREEDMAN: A PHOTOJOURNALIST OF PASSION AND EMPATHY
description: Who, or what, makes a photograph? Of the three terms in the photographic act - subject, camera and photographer - which has the greatest claim to the picture? Ideally, we would agree that our understanding of a photograph is inescapably shaped by all three; however, in the realm of art (at least as it is presently constituted) it seems important that the third term be emphasized: the photographer, not the camera or the subject, has dominion over the pleasure we take in photographs. If it were otherwise, according to this view, photography's status as an art would be suspect.

title: Music; FORTNIGHT IS FULL OF CONCERT DOINGS
description: THERE are at least a dozen concerts scheduled over the next fortnight at various high schools, colleges and conservatories in the county. Sometimes, of course, school auditoriums are simply the handiest spots to hold such programs, but frequently there is important creative input from the institutions themselves.

title: OPERA: LEONTYNE PRICE IN 'TROVATORE'
description: Enrico Caruso's memorable dictum to the effect that all ''Il Trovatore'' needs is the four greatest singers in the world was scarcely put to the test Friday night, when the Metropolitan Opera presented Verdi's not-quite-masterpiece, in Nathaniel Merrill's drab 1969 production, for the first time this season.

title: SANDINISTS COURT INDIANS BUT EFFORT IS STRAINED
description: Nicaragua's Sandinist leaders have started a campaign to regain the support of the Miskito Indians on the country's Caribbean coast, an area potentially rich in minerals and agricultural land.

title: Personal Finance; EASING THE TOIL OF TRANSFERRING STOCK
description: T O circumvent some of the shoals of settling estates, married couples often register their holdings of securities under an arrangement known as ''joint tenancy with rights of survivorship.'' When one dies, the other becomes the sole owner and avoids the cost of probate.

title: Crime
description: As Heywood Gould's previous ''One Dead Debutante'' (1975) indicated, plotting is not the man's strong point. But he can write, and in GLITTERBURN (St. Martin's, $12.95) he is in turn sharp, wacky, earthy and full of felicitous phrases. Above all, in this new book he celebrates one particular version of New York - the New York that is full of frustrations, competition, ethnic tensions, bigots and militants.

title: Kathleen Oldford Engaged to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert Oldford of Stamford, Conn., and Southampton, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kathleen Oldford, to Robert Russell Sullivan Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Sullivan of Stamford and Harwichport, Mass.

title: Banana Pickers End Strike
description: About 4,000 banana pickers were expected to go back to work today after reaching an agreement to end a 37-day strike that cost the Standard Fruit Company about $3 million, a company spokesman said.

title: Travel by Train
description: To the Editor:

title: 4 CHILDREN KILLED IN BROOKLYN FIRE
description: Three brothers and their 5-year-old sister died yesterday when clothing caught fire above a gas stove and flames raced through the second floor of their Brooklyn home, the Fire Department said.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Ten years from now, I hope the people forget the misery and remember the good times.

title: Meredyth Armitage Married
description: Meredyth Sloan Armitage, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur L. Armitage of Rumson, N.J., was married there yesterday to Dexter Freeman, son of Mr. and Mrs. William R. Freeman of Osterville, Mass. The Rev. George Willis performed the ceremony at St. George's by-the-River Episcopal Church.

title: Chess; POWER OF PASSED PAWNS
description: Advanced connected passed pawns are such a potent weapon that they can decide a game even with an overall material disadvantage - and even when the opponent marshalls his entire force, including the king, to prevent them from producing a queen.

title: Mailbox; Tanner, Connors: Unforced Errors
description: To the Sports Editor: It seems to me that Jimmy Connors (The New York Times, Jan. 12) and Roscoe Tanner (Jan. 13) have committed unforced errors in making backhanded remarks about John McEnroe's court behavior. Don't they know that his game is based on piques and volleys? ROBERT E. HALL

title: MANY ARE THE WAYS TO MEASURE ALLIED TRADE WITH EAST BLOC
description: BONN IT depends a little on who the audience is. When it's foreign reporters asking if crass commercial considerations might have something to do with the way Bonn and other European governments have been tiptoeing around the Polish sanctions question, then the West German reaction is studied indignation. En route to the United States a fortnight ago, an a ide to Chancellor Helmut Schmidt stood in the aisle of Luft waffe Number One, fixed a few non-German guests with a how-dare-you gaze, and said that West German-Soviet trade was actually a tr ifle, half the yearly business West Germay does with Belgium and L uxembourg.

title: The Region in Summary; Rotating Judges: Fair to Whom?
description: Justice may be blind, but those who dispense it ought not be blindly chosen. So said Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan District Attorney, last week in challenging a move to rotate acting judges on the State Supreme Court in New York City.

title: Accountants
description: To the Business Editor: You were quite right in predicting a booming business for accounting firms (''The Year of the Accountants,'' Jan. 3). But it was unfortunate that the article was written only from the perspective of the Big 8, without any mention of accounting firms outside that group.

title: NEWS 'SHIELD' BEFORE TOP JERSEY COURT
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court has agreed to decide how far the Federal and State Constitutions and a state law go in protecting confidential sources of the news media in civil libel cases.

title: REAGAN'S STAFF IS LIKE-MINDED BUT NOT ALWAYS OF ONE MIND
description: LIKE most Presidents, Ronald Reagan took office with a new White House structure as well as new Federal programs in mind. Mr. Reagan's frame was to be Cabinet government; the supporting beams, a strong White House team of three top aides - James A. Baker 3d, the chief of staff, Michael K. Deaver, the deputy chief of staff, and Edwin Meese 3d, the counselor.

title: Beauty
description: By Deborah Blumenthal Splitting the Difference In Hairbrushes What does one look for in a hairbrush? Bristles that are natural, or synthetic? Handles of satinwood, ebony, or plastic? A round, narrow ''professional'' model, or one shaped in an oval? Black bristles, or white? And, most importantly, how much brushing is too much? he most savvy of shoppers is often stumped when it comes to choosing a hairbrush. And no wonder. Even the experts don't agree on how to make the selection. While brush manufacturers tout the benefits of brushing, particularly with natural boar bristles, some dermatologists say that it's best to brush as little as possible - regardless of which brush is purchased. Everyone does seem convinced, however, that excessive brushing is harmful.

title: Spain Fines Rightist Parties
description: Two right-wing parties must each pay a $51,500 fine for disrupting public order and using paramilitary uniforms last year to commemorate the sixth anniversary of the death of Francisco Franco. The Government approved the fines against the New Force Party and the Falange after a Cabinet meeting Friday.

title: MISS BISCHEL FIANCEE OF DR. STEPHEN TRUHON
description: The Rev. Dr. and Mrs. M. Alfred Bischel of Rochester have announced the engagement of their daughter, Yvonne Helene Bischel, to Dr. Stephen A Truhon, son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony Truhon of Freeport, L.I.

title: STAGE: TOURNEUR'S JACOBEAN T RAGEDY
description: Cyril Tourneur's ''The Revenger's Tragedy'' is an evening of ''villainous music,'' five acts jammed with dark thoughts and even darker deeds. This Jacobean tragedy is, at its black heart, a moral tale, demonstrating that all revenge is evil, even when it is struck in the name of justice.

title: NOTHING HERE BUT HILLS
description: THE WORLD RUSHED IN The California Gold Rush Experience.By J.S. Holliday. Illustrated. 559 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $16.95.

title: TAKEOFF ROUTES AT THE AIRPORT SHIFT TOMORROW
description: PURCHASE IN his ground-floor office, Richard Smith, the tower chief at the Westchester County Airport, moved his hand over a map on the wall as he described a new departure procedure that is to go into effect tomorrow for planes taking off from Runway 16, in a procedure intended to relieve community noise problems.

title: Headliners; The $21 Million Try
description: He wanted to run boxing but he broke a few rules. In one of the largest bank embezzlements in the nation's hi story, Harold Rossfields Smith and two accomplices were con victed last week of stealing $21.3 million from the Wells Fargo B ank in a scheme to make Mr. Smith boxing's most powerful promoter. L. Ben Lewis, a former officer of a Wells Fargo brank in Beverly Hil ls who pleaded guilty totwo counts of conspiracy and misappropriation of funds, testified that on orders from Mr. Smith he manipulated an interbank accounting system that monitored the flow of funds betwe en Wells Fargo branches.

title: Dance View; HAS THE TIME COME AGAIN TO 'SAVE' BALLET?
description: In his biographical study, ''Balanchine,'' Bernard Taper tells of how the great choreographer happened to meet the dance critic Edwin Denby in the street one day. ''We must save ballet,'' Mr. Balanchine declared. And when the startled Mr. Denby objected, ''But it's immortal,'' Mr. Balanchine explained, ''I don't mean the dance. I mean ballet.''

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Government Sees A Way Out On Equal Rights
description: The Justice Department last week hit a compromise on the equal rights amendment that could satisfy everyone - for the time being. In a closely watched brief, the department told the Supreme Court that it should vacate a lower court ruling on the proposed amendment not on the merits of the case, but because it had been decided prematurely - that is, before the amendment had been ratified.

title:
Comment;
PROFESSOR DIRECTOR
description: O VER the past several years, criticism has been directed at college professors for serving on corporate boards. At the recent American Writers Congress, for example, a panel discussion concluded that such service threatens to compromise academicians' objectivity as social critics and impairs their ability to speak out on public policy issues.

title: REAGAN AIDES ' SLIP BLAMED FOR DISPUTE ON TAX EXEMPTIONS
description: The Reagan Administration's political embarrassment over the restoration of tax exemptions to segregated schools stemmed from a breakdown in communications on the President's staff, according to White House officials. They say this lapse caused new personal tensions within his triumvirate of senior advisers.

title: Long Islanders; RETURNING A FAVOR ON CHINESE PRINTING
description: LEAVE it to someone who spoke no Chinese and knew nothing about computers to come up with a solution to a problem that has been a vexation for a millenium - finding a rapid method of printing Chinesecharacters.

title: Around the Nation; Stowaway's Deportation Is Protested in Miami
description: The police broke up a rowdy demonstration at the federal immigration offices today as about 1,000 chanting Cuban exiles protested the deportation of a 20-year-old Cuban stowaway. At least six people were arrested.

title: DEMOCRATIC RULES CHANGES PRODUCE FEW CONFLICTS
description: The Democrats scheduled a meeting for three days and finished it in two, finding themselves in an unusual degree of agreement about tilting the 1984 Presidential nomination process toward better-known candidates and professional politicians.

title: No Headline
description: The Personal Finance column last week incorrectly reported an aspect of homeowners' insurance liability coverage. The minimum liability of $25,000 is an industry standard, not a state law.

title: PORTMAN HOTEL'S PLAN SEEMS TO ASSURE MALL ON BROADWAY
description: Construction is likely to begin soon on the proposed Portman Hotel on Broadway between 45th and 46th Streets, and the plan appears to insure the adoption of the city's long-debated proposal to close Broadway to motor traffic between 45th and 47th Streets.

title: NETWORKING: GOALS AND DOUBTS
description: LONG ISLAND women are heeding a message preached by other women who have made careers out of giving suburban homemakers a special kind of boost, motivating them to select goals and believe in themselves. The message proclaims: You are liberated. Join with us in a network to exchange resources and to help one another achieve individual goals.

title: Music View; 'GIGANTISM' IS DISTORTING OPERA NOW AS IN THE PAST
description: It's one of Parkinson's laws, or should be: opera directors and designers will inflate any production as much as the budget allows - and more. More and bigger pillars, more and grander stairways, more soldiers marching out of step, more unnecessary avenues with deeper perspectives, more crenellated towers, more live animals, more children, more ladies cavorting on table tops, more stage levels, more flags and banners, more furniture, more snow, more fog. More everything. The result is the operatic gigantism that we now see on every hand.

title: INDIA STEPPING UP MONEY FOR SCIENCE
description: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's Government, in an attempt to stimulate India's often sluggish bureaucracies of science and technology, has increased direct investment in scientific research from $576 million to $888 million a year.

title: Musical on Alec Wilder Will Star Miss Andreas
description: Christine Andreas will star in ''Alec Wilder: Clues to a Life,'' a musical program about the late composer and arranger, in a four-week run starting Feb. 3 at the Vineyard Theater, 309 East 26th Street. Miss Andreas was nominated for a Tony award for her performance in ''Oklahoma!'' two years ago and was in a 1976 revival, with Ian Richardson, of ''My Fair Lady.''

title: On Qualifying For Medicaid
description: A young person can drink, drive, vote and marry at the age of 18 in New York State, but he/she cannot qualify for Medicaid or other forms of public assistance on the basis of his own income and assets until the age of 21. This is despite the erroneous statement made by a ''sympathetic person in the health-care field '' to Bernard Sloan and quoted in his moving article ''Outside Medica id and Looking In.''

title: STALIN'S TACTICS AT HOME AND ABROAD
description: THE TIME OF STALIN Portrait of a Tyranny. By Anton Antonov-Ovseyenko. Translated by George Saunders. With an Introduction by Stephen F. Cohen. Illustrated. 374 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $19.95.

title: About Westchester
description: BEDFORD HILLS SOME folks hate winter for its cold, some loathe the early darkness, others despise the icy roads. There are also those for whom these constitute minor annoyances, compared with one inescapable fact - in winter, there is no golf.

title: EUROPE DELEGATES TO PICK PRESIDENT
description: The 434-member European Parliament is scheduled to elect a President to succeed Simone Veil, a former French Health Minister, in voting that begins Tuesday and that could run to four rounds.

title: SHOULD L.I.R.R. BE SPLIT FROM M.T.A.?
description: SHOULD the Long Island Rail Road be separated from the Metropolitan Transportation Authority? Or is that idea, which recently gained the support of the Suffolk County Executive, Peter F. Cohalan, only a popular parochial issue that wouldn't make financial sense?

title: Dialogue With Mongolia
description: As one of only a handful of Americans in the United States who can claim Mongol descent, I would like to thank you for publishing ''The Hidden Mongolia,'' by Seymour Topping (Dec.13).

title: About Books and Authors
description: Historical Accuracy

title: DON'T READ TOO MUCH INTO A CHILD'S MISREADING
description: To the Editor:

title: Headliners; Problems, Problems
description: Even prominent Republicans don't always pay their bills on time. Last week, G.O.P. national chairman Richard Richards confirmed that he often had been late with installments on $300,000 in federally guaranteed loans on a health spa in Utah. The Small Business Administration, which approved the loans, had to pay $96,203 to the Bank of Utah, which declared the loan in default. Mr. Richards said, ''I'm a perfectly honest guy,'' adding ''I don't have any money.''

title: A CHILDLIKE SPIRIT BUOYS 'TOY MUSIC'
description: While it's commonly assumed that mainstream pop albums are designed for teen-agers and young adults, there is a strain of pure, childish escapism that runs through a broad segment of contemporary pop. Novelty tunes that appeal to all generations have long been a regular phenomenon on the pop charts. And rock and roll, from Little Richard's ''Tutti Frutti'' on, has embraced gibberish and nonsense. More recently, the crazes for disco and electronic toys have coincided with pop styles that are technologically sophisticated but childlike in spirit.

title: Around the Nation; Reporter's Killer Found Guilty in 1975 Beating
description: John Harvey Adamson, facing the death sentence for the 1976 murder of Don Bolles, a reporter, has been convicted of assault, conspiracy and forgery in the 1975 beating of a talent agent in a Scottsdale motel room.

title: Hook Removal (O uch!) Made Easy
description: ARECENT issue of the Pennsylvania Angler, a magazine of the state's Fish Commmission, offers a technique for removing hooks from humans that titilates me.

title: HOW A COMPANY DOES ITS SHOPPING
description: ANYONE flustered about the kind of money it takes these days to navigate a grocery cart through the checkout line can take a certain degree of solace from the buying experiences of Philip Korn. He deals in amounts that approach the Gross National Product of Tanzania. Last year, among a potpourri of other things, Mr. Korn bought about $170 million worth of sugar. He bought some $18 million worth of raisins. He picked up $4.4 million of Vitamin C, $8 million of plastic bottles, $35 million of corn sweeteners and something like $23 million of rice.

title: Around the World; Red Brigades Issue A Statement on Dozier
description: The Red Brigades today issued their fourth communique on the kidnapping of Brig. Gen. James L. Dozier. Journalists who found the statement said it did not set any conditions for his release or give any information about his fate.

title: Art Sampler
description: ONE can easily imagine the dumbfounded wonderment of a 19th-century American child if he were placed before computerized video games like those produced by, say, Atari.

title: zf Margaret Moorhead Is We d
description: Margaret Fahnestock Moorhead, an activities director at the Alaska Psychiatric Institute in Anchorage, and Ogden Williams, who is with Hope Cottages, a social service agency there, plan to be married in the spring. Clare F. Moorhead of Stratton Mountain, Vt., and Thomas C. Moorhead of Washington have announced their daughter's engagement to the son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Williams of Berkeley, Calif. Miss Moorhead was graduated from St. Lawrence University and her fiance from the University of California at Berkeley.

title: Topics Artful; Poetic Asylum
description: Another poet can be proudly added to this nation's population. He is Dennis Brutus, a Zimbabwean and tenured professor of English at Northwestern University, who has just been granted 20 days to apply for political asylum.

title: THE QUANDARY OF THE WRITING PIANIST
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Charles Rosen, author of ''The Classical Style'' and other works, will play two recitals at Carnegie Hall this week - Beethoven sonatas tomorrow night, a Schumann program on Thursday. By CHARLES ROSEN Ioriginally began to write about music quite simply to keep other people's nons ense off my record jackets. One of the rare times when Idid not write my own record notes, I found that someone had printed about Chopin' s Nocturne in F-sharp major that ''the tiny coda staggers drun ken with the odor of flowers.'' About the great contrapuntal B-major Nocturne (Op. 62, No. 1), there was a quotation from James Hu neker, who had said that it was ''faint with a rich, sick odor.'' My own approach to Chopin was less olfactory.

title: TURKISH ARMY TIGHTENS HOLD OVER COLLEGES
description: Despite continued resistance in universities, Turkey has begun to carry out a new Higher Education Law aimed at bringing profound changes to academic life.

title: WEST AND JAPAN PROMISE TO AVOID TRADE RESTRAINT
description: American and Japanese officials assess the long-term danger of a trade war. Business, Section 3. By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH Special to the New York Times

title: Follow-Up on the News; Reporter's Rights
description: ''Why don't you check the mess in the hospital?'' the anonymous postcard asked. Gerald Kelly, editor of The Grapevine on Martha's Vineyard, checked.

title: IN STUDENT SURVEY, MANY FAVOR LAW
description: THE county's schools are educating a nation of lawyers, if measured by the career interests of its 10th-grade students. In a survey of county sophomores, conducted in preparation for the fourth annual Regional Career Conference last Wednesday, the law was the overwhelming career choice, followed by computer programming and secretarial training. Other popular choices were accounting, medicine and cosmotology.

title: The Region in Summary; Yesterday, Today And Redistricting
description: Despite the fact that he is a lame-duck Governor, or because of it, Brendan Byrne pulled off a political maneuver last week that infuriated Republicans and even upset some fellow Democrats. He preserved, at least for now, a Democrat-favored redistricting plan by signing into life an amendment to a dead bill.

title: 2 Men Slain on W. 10th St.; 3 Suspects Arrested Nearby
description: Two men were stabbed and shotgunned to death early yesterday morning in a Greenwich Village apartment in what the police described as a drug dispute. Two men and a 15-year-old youth were arrested near the address and charged with the murders.

title: Sound; IN A BOLD NEW SPEAKER, ENDS JUSTIFY THE MEANS
description: When an audio company hits the market with something radically offbeat and blatantly expensive, it ought to have good reasons for going that particular route. In fact, the whole thing had better be good. Both conditions are happily met by a boldly unconventional loudspeaker now sounding off to the delight of well-heeled audio fans. The new Quad ESL-63 differs from other speakers in almost every aspect, including its basic operating principle.

title: The World in Summary; Zia Charged In Rights Report
description: Amnesty International last week turned its unflattering spotlight on human rights abuses in Pakistan, just as President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq was staging a show of civilian participation in his four-yearold military regime.

title: CORRECTION
description: A sports article last Sunday about off-season baseball activity incor- rectly described the function of Ray- mond Goetz, a University of Kansas law professor. Mr. Goetz is the arbitra- tor for cases involving interpretation and application of the collective bar- gaining agreement between baseball owners and players. Salary arbitra- tion cases are heard by a group of arbi- trators selected annually.

title: Miss Curtin Breaks State Mark for Mile
description: Chris Curtin, a sophomore at Mepham High School in Bellmore, L.I., was a surprise winner of the one-mile run, and West Hempstead, L.I., won the team title in the boys' competition yesterday at the 33d Cardinal Hayes Games.

title: 9TH INDICTED IN BRINK'S HOLDUP
description: A ninth person, apparently a longtime suspect, has been indicted in last October's attempted Brink's robbery in Nanuet, N.Y. District Attorney Kenneth Gribetz of Rockland County said Friday that a grand jury had handed up a sealed indictment, and he declined to identify the suspect. He acknowledged, however, that a warrant had been issued for Donald Weems, 37 years old, a former member of the Black Panthers, who has been involved in terrorist acts since 1969.

title: Navarrete Retains Title By Knockout in the 11th
description: Rolando Navarrete of the Philippines, the World Boxing Council superfeatherweight champion, got up from a fifth-round knockdown and retained the title by knocking out Choi Chung Il of South Korea in the 11th round tonight.

title: John Whipple Fiance of Mary Gibbons
description: Judge and Mrs. John J. Gibbons of Short Hills, N.J., and Hyannis, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Gibbons, to John C. Whipple, son of Judge Lawrence A. Whipple and Mrs. Whipple of Sea Girt, N.J.

title: Paul Wilkes, Author.  Weds Tracy Gochberg
description: Tracy Gochberg, an account executive with the advertising agency of Ash/LeDonne in New York, was married yesterday to Paul Wilkes, an author. The Rev. Robert V. Lott performed the ceremony at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church.

title: Alternative Suggested For Hempstead Plant
description: I, for one, would like to see County Executive Francis Purcell's prediction ''and nobody will get hurt'' come true (''Decision Nears on Reopening Hempstead Plant'').

title: Food
description: Rising to the Occasion Pita - the round, puffed bread from the Middle East that can be split open to form a pocket for filling - cooks quickly and is easily prepared with flour, water and yeast.

title: STOLID MONTANANS SHAKE OFF BLIZZARD
description: Outside, the snow was falling as fast as the temperature, which had dropped from 30 degrees to minus 7 in barely two hours. Inside, at City Hall, Gail Brandon was working the police switchboard as if it were a concert Wurlitzer.

title: JAMES LEVINE'S UPBEAT LIBRETTO FOR THE MET
description: There were times last season when things at the Metropolitan Opera began to look hopeless, says James Levine, the house's music director and a helpless bystander in the labor dispute which cost the Met almost half its 1980-81 season. ''I loved the company so much that I felt like someone with a mate who had been in a terrible accident, someone who needed nursing back to health,'' he says. ''But a music director can't take part in a labor dispute, and I saw all that incredibly complex planning for the years ahead just unraveling.

title: Fashion; TAMPERING WITH THE TRADITIONAL
description: esigners in Italy are taking a step beyond their traditional use of muted colors and handsome tailoring, showing mostly separates -rather than suits - and lines that are leaner in the 1982 spring and summer collections. A sport jacket, after all, can be a lot more versatile in hot weather than a suit, and it does give the wearer a chance to mix items for a more individual appearance.

title: BOARDSAILING LURES OLDER SAILORS, TOO
description: ONE day last summer at the American Yacht Club in Rye, a woman was explaining boardsailing to her aging and slightly deaf mother. ''It's the latest sport among the kids,'' she said. ''There's a kid out there now.''

title: New Tax Rules Provide A Bonus for Congress
description: While Americans are getting their annual tax forms, members of Congress are getting new rules that will allow them to avoid most income tax on their salaries.

title: Topics; ARTFUL; Masterpiece
description: Most of New York's scenic wonders are a permanent part of the cityscape.

title: Westchester Journal
description: THOUGH he is no longer a diplomat, Moorhead @Kennedy has enduring recollections of his 1980 captivity by Iranians in the United States Embassy in Teheran. ''When a wrong is committed,'' the former hostage told a Bronxville church group last week, ''then in accordance with established agreed principles, there should be some legal retribution for what happened.''

title: New Jersey Journal
description: NEW JERSEY is making progress in its efforts to use the stockade at Fort Dix to house prisoners crowded out of conventional state facilities, such as Trenton and Rahway, and now house d for the most part in count y jails.

title: Home Clinic; A SEQUENCE OF STEPS TO TAKE WHEN A LAMP DOESN'T LIGHT
description: IF a floor or table lamp fails to light up when you turn it on, the first thing to check is obviously the bulb and then the fuse or circuit breaker in that circuit. But if the fuse is all right and replacing the bulb with a new one still doesn't solve the problem, what do you check next?

title: Red Smith
description: Red Smith was not only a great sportswriter; he was a fine writer who wrote about sports. He mastered the stabbing thrust, the pithy scene, the precisely weighted accolade, all the hardest tests of his craft.

title: Future Events A Troika of Benefits
description: Tickets to the following may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated.. Another Opening Jan. 22 - The cognoscenti regard $90 as a small price to pay for a patron's ticket and the privilege of first chance at the wares of the 72 prestigious antiques dealers participating in the 28th annual Winter Antiques Show at the Seventh Regiment Armory. Patrons' preview party starting at 5 P.M., gives them an hour and a half's jump on holders of $60 preview tickets. They'll also be first to view a loan exhibition of antiques from the Winterthur Museum collection in Wilmington, Del., and copies in miniature of two rooms at Winterthur executed by Eugene J. Kupjak. Festivities lasting until 9 P.M. include cocktails and buffet in the main hall and the Tiffany Room with decorations by Paloma Picasso. Preview benefits the East Side House Settlement, a social-service agency in the South Bronx, as does $5 daily admission to the show Jan. 23 through Jan. 31.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: THE LEAN YEARS, by Richard J. Barnet. (Simon & Schuster/Touchstone, $7.25.) Richard J. Barnet, a founder of the Institute for Policy Studies, argues that during the lean decades he sees lying ahead, global politics will revolve about a struggle to control the vital but limited available quantities of energy, water, food and minerals. Our reviewer Robert Lekachman found the book useful for its appraisal of these resources, as well as for its critical look at the multinational corporations that control them and the governments that support the corporations.

title: 'BEAST OF TRURO' MYSTIFYING CAPE COD
description: Who or what is the ''Beast of Truro?'' Is it a mountain lion preying on local pets and livestock, a dog or pack of dogs, an ocelot, a lynx, a wild cat or some yet unidentified creature?

title: LINDSAY ANDERSON BREWS SOME CHAOS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Michael Billington frequently reports on the cultural scene in London. MICHAEL BILLINGTON LONDON Anew film from Lindsay Anderson is always an event. He has achieved much as documentary-maker, critical polemicist and stage director, but his international cimematic reputation rests on dismayingly few feature films: ''This Sporting Life,'' ''The White Bus,'' ''If,'' ''O Lucky Man,'' ''In Celebration.'' Now, however, he is in the cutting room with ''Britannia Hospital,'' a $4 million satirical comedy which covers one day in the hilariously traumatic life of an antiquated British hospital. It deals with science, the media, trade unions, royalty, strikes and protest. ''I'm not illustrating a thesis,'' says Mr. Anderson crisply. ''I'm telling a story.''

title: COIN AUCTION MAY BRING $10 MILLION
description: The remains of the Virgil M. Brand coin collection, one of the most important ever formed, will be auctioned in a series of sales beginning next summer. The 20,000 coins assembled and stored in cigar boxes over a 50-year period by the late Chicago brewer are expected to bring in excess of $10 million, according to Sotheby Parke Bernet. The first dispersal takes place July 1 at the Hotel Baur-au-Lac in Zurich. The rest of the sales will be held in New York, Zurich, London and Amsterdam, probably over a two-year period.

title: Jackson De cision Is 'Imminent'
description: A decision on Reggie Jackson's future is ''imminent,'' his agent said yesterday after a second meeting with Gene Autry of the California Angels and telephone conversations with Baltimore Oriole officials.

title: WALLY AND ANDRE DISSECT THE THEATER
description: The current Louis Malle film, ''My Dinner With Andre,'' consists entirely of a wide-ranging discussion between the playwright Wallace Shawn (''Marie and Bruce,'' ''The Hotel Play'') and the director Andre Gregory (''Alice in Wonderland'' by the Manhattan Project). In the following conversation, recorded especially for the Arts and Leisure section, Messrs. Shawn and Gregory talk about the state of the theater, on and Off Broadway.

title: CONFIDENT REPUBLICANS PREPARE FINANCES AND STAFF FOR FALL ELECTION
description: The National Republican Party intends to spend more than $63 million this year to increase Republican strength in an already Republican-controlled Senate and to retain, or improve, its present level of 192 members in the House of Representatives, party campaign strategists said here today.

title: Around the Nation; New Fears on Mine Fire Arise in Pennsylvania
description: Clouds of steam spewing from a hole outside Centralia have renewed fears that a 20-year-old underground mine fire is spreading and could be nearly twice as large as previously believed.

title: Business Conditions; JAPANESE AUTO STRENGTH
description: Sticker-price shock, high interest rates and a weak economy wreaked havoc among domestic automobile manufacturers last year, and helped send sales down 5.3 percent to their lowest levels since 1961. However, those conditions had less of an impact on imports, as sales fell 4.8 percent from 1980 levels, to 2.3 million units.

title: ACCLAIMED NOVEL BORN ON L.I.R.R.
description: THE Long Island Rail Road is many things to many people. But rarely has it been accused of encouraging, let alone, allowing, the creative urge. Robert Olen Butler, though, has written a critically acclaimed novel, ''The Alleys of Eden,'' while riding the diesel spur between Sea Cliff and Pennsylvania Station.

title: The Region in Summary; Defectors Fell O'Neill's Tax
description: With Connecticut $83 million in the red, it may not have been the most fiscally propitious time for lawmakers to repeal a tax. But with legislative elections just months away, it certainly seemed to be a politically advantageous one.

title: STAGE: ONE-ACTERS ON HUMAN GAMES
description: Games that people play are the subject of two new one-acts, performed in one evening by the New York Stageworks in its current festival of short plays. Marc Berman's ''The Bridge to Latonia'' deals with two kinds of ho rseplay - betting at the race track and theput-ons of co ntemporary youth. John Bishop's ''The Skirmishers'' alters the sc ene to war-gaming, with a mordant comedy about voyeurism.

title: * To the Editor:$
description: You close your editorial with, ''One might well ask business to shoulder part of the burden'' (of the tax increase necessary in 1982). Just before that, you say consumers are the beneficiaries of the tax break to business: ''Competition makes it likely that most of the tax break will be passed through ... in lower prices.''

title: HOW MARTINS MADE A NEW STORY BALLET
description: Peter Martins's ''The Magic Flute'' is, on the face of it, a typical story-ballet. The new ballet, which will be the centerpiece of a gala benefit for the New York City Ballet-affiliated School of American Ballet on Thursday at the New York State Theater before moving into the repertory, is about Luc, a handsome but impoverished boy, and Lise, the pretty girl he loves. Intractable parents are an element in the tale, as well an aging suitor and a flute that saves the day. But this ''Magic Flute,'' which has no relation to the Mozart opera, is about tradition, too. It has to do with the passing down of the classical heritage through George Balanchine, master choreographer of the City Ballet, to the new generation that Mr. Martins represents, and through Mr. Martins to yet another generation.

title: QUESTIONS OVER ALBANIAN'S DEATH STILL UNRESOLVED
description: While speculation continues over the death of Prime Minister Mehmet Shehu of Albania, no hard evidence has emerged to challenge the official version that he committed suicide.

title: No Headline
description: As a novelist, and the son of the concert violinist Julius Schulman, I have had the opportunity to compare the logical forms of both mediums, and I assure you that if Mr. Trimble - who writes very well - were to attempt to apply the same theories to writing sentences and paragraphs that the atonalists apply to musical phrases, his article would have been just as unintelligible - and just as unworthy of finding an audience. J. NEIL SCHULMAN, San Antonio

title: Paperback Talk
description: For the fans. In the world of books, as in the worlds of sports and entertainment, there are numerous cults whose members are avidly devoted to stellar performers and their works. They collect and study the writings of their favorite authors, attend conventions to exchange information about them, and subscribe to periodicals of the sort often referred to as ''fanzines.'' Herewith some notes on two currently flourishing literary cults.

title:
Art;
'SOLD AMERICAN,' ADVERTISING OF ANOTHER AGE
description: STONY BROOK THE slogan ''It takes art to make a company great'' is a classic example of the effective double entendre that earns bonuses for copywriters and a reminder that there is a considerable artistic dimension to advertising.

title: POLAND'S LESSONS FOR MR. REAGAN
description: Every Administration enters office determined to change the world. Sooner or later - sooner if it is fortunate - it is forced to reconsider its assumptions and procedures. It is the making of the Administration if it is prepared to examine itself seriously and to draw the necessary conclusions. If that test is failed, if energy is expended on rationalizing the status quo, mounting crises and disarray are inevitable.

title: CHARTER CRUISING IN WARM CARIBBEAN
description: WE are on our way by dinghy to Necker Island. Our chartered sloop is safely anchored behind Saba Rock in Gorda Sound, British Virgin Islands, and we are taking advantage of a wind-down day to power the mile or so over to the necklace of white sand inside the reef almost surrounding Necker.

title: Insurance for Co-ops
description: To the Editor:

title: FARMERS IN INDIA CHALLENGING RULING FAMILIES
description: Led by India's foremost advocate of producer cooperatives, hundreds of owners of small farms in this western state of Gujarat have been banding together to challenge the economic power of 13 families that have traditionally controlled a multibillion dollar trade in vegetable oils.

title: THE FALL AND RISE OF THE 10TH AMENDMENT
description: The Tenth Amendment has taken something of a roller coaster ride at the Supreme Court during the last few years. The Justices have seemed alternately enchanted and unmoved by this once overlooked amendment, which provides that ''the powers not delegated to the United States by the Constitution, nor prohibited by it to the States, are reserved to the States respectively, or to the people.''

title: Washington; REAGAN'S FIRST YEAR
description: a1WASHINGTON, Jan. 16 - When he was sworn in as the 40th President of the United States a year ago, Ronald Reagan merely promised a ''new beginning,'' and he has kept his promise.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Court Unbending On Stiff Sentence
description: Ruling in a case involv ing an unusually harsh sentence, the SupremeCourt last we ek implied that consistency with its own precedents sometimes ove rrides the notion of making punishments consistent with crimes. The C ourt upheld a 40-year prison sentence imposed on Roger T. Davis, a V irginian convicted for possession and distribution of nine ounces o f marijuana worth about $200, saying that the duration of sentences for felonies was ''purely a matter of legislative prerogative.'

title: DESIGN IDEAS: FROM RACERS TO CRUISERS
description: IS today's ocean racer tomorrow's production cruiser? Probably not, for many of the features on today's top-level ocean racers are too sophisticated and require too much fine-tuning for the average cruising sailor to want. The extra tenth of a knot of speed to be gained is not that important to him.

title: BALLET: 'MIDSUMMER NIGHT'S DREAM' IN MIDWINTER
description: Outside the New York State Theater Thursday night the snow fell steadily. But inside it was June in January. The New York City Ballet offered George Balanchine's ''A Midsummer Night's Dream'' and dancers tripped the light fantastic in sylvan settings without coming down with frostbite or chilblains.

title: The Nation in Summary; A 51st State Is Fine by Reagan
description: President Reagan, who is mightily concerned about his Administration's image in the Caribbean these days, went out of his way last week to reaffirm a stand he had taken as a candidate: that he would support statehood for Puerto Rico ''should the people of that island choose it in a free and democratic election.'' After meeting with visiting Puerto Rican officials, Mr. Reagan said he was ''still confident in my belief that statehood would benefit both the people of Puerto Rico and their fellow American citizens.''

title: Katharine Manning Is Married to Walter Weis 3d
description: Katharine Burton Manning, an actress, and Walter Robert Christian Weis 3d, associate creative director and vice president of S S C & B Advertising Inc., were married yesterday at the Unitarian Church of All Souls. The Rev. F. Forrester Church performed the ceremony.

title: U.S. ACTION ON A.T.&T. DEFIES COMMON SENSE
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction
description: To the Editor:

title: BIG YACHTS ARE GETTING BIGGER
description: THE Big Boys are getting bigger. And lighter. And faster. And, presumably, better. You might also add ''fancier.'' If there is one clear trend among top motor yachts produced in the United States - and those from abroad - it is that.

title: NO BUILDING FOUND TO MERIT CITY CLUB AWARD
description: For the second consecutive year the City Club of New York has been unable to find a building meriting its noted Albert S. Bard Award for excellence in urban design. Instead, it has made four awards of commendation.

title: PLAYING IT COOL IN THE WINTER
description: ''YOU couldn't possibly burn 4,000 gallons of oil a year, could you?'' asked the heating surveyor, after measuring the square footage of the house, counting the number of windows, sitting down on the living-room sofa and making some calculations in his black book.

title: FARM STUDY WARNS OF LOSS OF NEEDED WATER
description: A study prepared for the Department of Agriculture says that declines in the level of ground water beneath 15 million acres in 11 states will hamper American farming by the next century.

title: A NEW ISRAELI LAW PROHIBITS SEX BIAS IN JOBS
description: Israel's first law on equal employment opportunity, in effect since New Year's Day, prohibits discrimination in hiring and advertising for jobs on the basis of sex or marital or parental status.

title: Practical Traveler; AIRLINE COST-CUTTING
description: Air travel in the United States is likely to pose more problems for passengers this year as changes are made in consumer regulations and airline services. The wise passenger will learn where the pitfalls lie and how to deal with them effectively.

title:
Long Island Housing;
TOWN SERVICES FOR CONDOS DEBATED
description: AFTER a recent storm caused roads to flood inside the 111-unit Woodbury Village condominium in Woodbury, residents had to pay $1,500 to a private maintenance crew to pump out the water. Over the course of a year, street flooding adds about $5,000 to the condominium's maintenance bill and must be included in the budget.

title: Maria L. Heyssel To Marry April 3
description: Dr. and Mrs. Robert Morris Heyssel of Roland Park, Baltimore, have made known the engagement of their daughter, Maria Lisa Heyssel, to Charles Williams Flexner, son of Dr. and Mrs. John Morris Flexner of Nashville. An April 3 wedding is planned.

title: No Headline
description: POLE DASHES HOPES ON MILITARY RULE

title: CZECH TIES TO U.S. STILL COOL DESPITE AGREEMENT ON GOLD
description: Despite a recent hopeful development in relations between Czechoslovakia and the United States, Czechoslovak and American officials remain pessimistic about the possibility of a thaw in the frigid atmosphere.

title: More Flak
description: To the Business Editor: I suspect that in his commentary, ''Why P.R. Gets Flak'' (Jan. 3), it was Jack Bernstein's intent to expose some of the misperceptions of the profession as well as define public relation's role for the years ahead. Yet in his effort, Mr. Bernstein manages to ignore many of the more obvious and pertinent issues relating to this topic while presenting a narrow, if not inaccurate, view of corporate public relations.

title:
Music: Debuts in Review;
Bass Clarinet Solos Given by Dennis Smylie
description: Not the first instrument that comes to mind when the word ''solo'' is proposed, the bass clarinet shares the misfortune of its lowregister colleagues, the tuba and contrabassoon, of having been passed over for soloistic uses by generations of composers interested in their more agile relatives.

title:
Camera;
SIMPLIFYING EQUIPMENT
The World in Summary; Spain Pulls Off Military Shakeup
description: The Spanish Government, long beset by coup jitters, last week pulled off a small coup of its own. With little warning, it replaced the entire high military command.

title: Shaping Area's Change Vs. Adapting to It
description: I found Lyman B. Coddington's commentary on the Growth Management Conference (''Coping With a Changing Fairfield,'' Dec. 27) an intriguing example of the many interpretations that can come out of an event like this. A complex subject like gr owth management can be covered from many angles and I think the one he stressed - i.e., comparing the facts to our assumptions, is mo st timely and appropriate. Those who are trying to cope wit h growth must recognize the true direction of change and be prepared to accept that it may becompletely at variance with a planner's ideal ized pattern of development.

title: Mailbox; TANNER, CONNORS: UNFORCED ERRORS
description: To the Sports Editor: I am happy to read that John McEnroe wants to win respect, and change the image he feels people have of him (The New York Times, Jan. 13). I have long felt that he was a privileged young man who should know better than to have frequent outbursts on the courts.

title:
Dining Out;
A CERTAIN REGALITY IN MOUNT KISCO
description: PERCHED precariously on a steep hill overlooking Bedford Road in Mount Kisco, Chateaubriand seems to command a princely vantage over the grease and sugar purveyors in the street below. In fact, everything about the restaurant's physical situation promises distinction. The growing seasons bring pots of colorful annuals or white mums to outline the canopied walkway; fireplaces, quilted draperies, and tiered chandeliers adorn the dining rooms. Yet for all its regal beauty, Chateaubriand is at present a pretender, betrayed by a wellmeaning but disorganized staff in the dining room and a heavy hand and villainous salamander oven in the kitchen.

title:
Gardening;
PAPER BIRCH, THE EPITOME OF ORNAMENTALS
description: FEW trees are more striking than the paper birch. A multi stemmed, white-bark birch is considered to be the epitome of all ornamental trees, and it is often given the most prominent location.

title: Orchestre de Paris Sets 5 Concerts at Carnegie
description: The Orchestre de Paris, conducted by Daniel Barenboim, will begin a five-concert series of Beethoven's orchestral repertory at Carnegie Hall on Feb. 8 at 8 P.M. The program consists of the Second and Third Symphonies.

title: Business Conditions; PLEASURE BOAT TROUBLES
description: Last year was another rocky one for the pleasure boat industry, which is currently displaying its 1982 models at the New York Coliseum.

title: Leningrad Hit by Gale
description: Gale-force winds hit Leningrad Friday, disrupting communications and electricity and stopping the unloading of ships, the Soviet press agency Tass said. Winds reached 50 miles an hour, Tass said, and the Neva River burst its ice covering and rose by three feet.

title: IN CELEBRATION OF SHOSTAKOVICH
description: The career of Dmitri Shostakovich as a symphonist was one of the most remarkable in the history of music, both for the length of time it spanned and the amount of musical and political history it survived. Between Shostakovich's First Symphony, a stunning work completed in 1925, with which the 19-year-old composer graduated from Maximilian Steinberg's composition class at the Leningrad Conservatory, and his 15th, which was finished in 1971, four years before his death, there is a span of 46 years. That is a decade more than the total separating Haydn's and Prokofiev's first and last symphonies, and more than 20 years longer than the period separating the first and last symphonic essays of Beethoven, Sibelius and Mahler.

title: LAWYER IS THE FIANCE OF MARY MCL. LUMMIS
description: Mrs. Sheila W. Lummis of Greenwich, Conn., and John M. Lummis of New York City have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary McLean Lummis, to James Sedgwick Kernan 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. James S. Kernan Jr., of Whitesboro, N.Y. Mis Lummis graduated from Cornell University and is studying veterinary me dicine at the New York State College of Veterinary Medicine at C ornell University in Ithaca. Her mother is director of corporate rel ations at WNET, Channel 13, in New York.

title: SUGAR AND SLAVERY
description: 1905. By Walter Rodney. Illustrated. 282 pp. Baltimore: Johns Hopkins University Press. Cloth, $26.50. Paper, $6.95.

title: ISLIP HOSPITAL PLAN MEETING OPPOSITION
description: ISLIP ASTATE proposal to convert much of the Central Islip Psychiatric Center into a Suffolk campus for the New York Institute of Technology, which would like to develop part of the area into a hightechnology industrial park. is embroiled in a dispute over land values.

title: Heidi E. Brieger Sets '83 Wedding
description: Dr. and Mrs. Gert H. Brieger of Berkeley, Calif., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Heidi Elisabeth Brieger, to David Stephen Mackey, son of Mr. and Mrs. Willard C. Mackey of New Canaan, Conn.

title: Hatsy Tuttle Sets Bridal to an Artist
description: Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence E. Tuttle of North Andover, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Harriot Houghteling Tuttle, to Thomas Arthur McGraw Jr., son of Mrs. Eleanor B. Jenkins of Essex, Conn., and the late Dr. McGraw. An April wedding is planned.

title: LINES FROM L.A. AND N.Y.
description: DANGLING IN THE TOURNEFORTIA By Charles Bukowski. 281 pp. Santa Barbara: Black Sparrow Press. Cloth, $14. Paper, $6.50.

title: AS SECOND TERM BEGINS, PURCELL OFFERS HIS VIEWS
description: MINEOLA SURROUNDED by photographs of his family and friends and memorabilia from 34 years of running for political office without a loss, County Executive Francis T. Purcell spoke on a wide range of topics on the occasion of his inauguration to a second four-year term.

title: DON'T ELIMINATE INDUSTRIAL BONDS
description: Congress is seriously considering the elimination of industrial revenue bonds on a nationwide basis. A bill currently before the House of Representatives would phase out the bonds by 1984. Another piece of legislation, already passed by the Senate, would do away with their commercial, but not industrial, applications.

title: Dining Out; ITALIAN CUISINE AND A RIVER VIEW
description: STAMFORD IF restaurant ratings were based on service, Rugantino's, an Italian restaurant on the Post Road between Stamford and Darien, would be at the head of the class. The service, based on three recent visits (two lunches and one dinner) was consistently professional, accommodating and friendly.

title: Children's Books
description: SECOND STAR TO THE NIGHT By Deborah Hautzig. 151 pp. New York: Greenwillow Books. $7.95. (Ages 11 to 15) By Patricia Lee Gauch

title: Index; International
