description: The European Parliament is electing a president 4 Around the World 5 Nicaragua has trouble winning its independent Miskito Indians 6 New Israeli law bans sex dis- crimination in jobs 7 Social Democrats and Liberals haggle over elections in Britain 8 London's Billingsgate closes its doors 9 Cooperative movement in India is rapidly growing 10 India steps up spending on sci - ence, but d oubts are raised 11 U.S. and Czechoslovak officials doubt a thaw in relations 12 No evidence emerges on Alba- nian's purported suicide 13 Many in Ghana view the Rawl- ings coup a tribal plot 15 Cuban braodcasts to U.S. stir con- cern 16 Turkey's military tightens con- trol over universities 17 Government/Politics European and U.S. Social Se- curity compared 21 Los Angeles plans big redevelop- ment project 22 Senator Cranston weighs Presi- dential campaign 28 Morris Udall pondering which of two Arizona districts to run in 29 Changes in Democratic conven- tion rules produce few conflicts 30 Legislation to replace CETA pro- gram planned 32 Connecticut's House approves $36 million tax package 39 General Around the Nation 22 Clothespin makers worry about import quotas 33 Seek to force utilities to absorb cost overruns at nuclear plant 34 Hefner testifies at hearing on casino 46 Atlantic City's casinos won $1.1 billion in '81 47 Blacks snub King event to protest Philadelphia hiring practices 49 ''Beast of Truro'' mystifying to Cape Cod 54 New fingerprint test is used to solve arson 55 Education/Welfare Court rules that accepting girls is no bar to a prep school bequest 45 Benefit cutoff spurs rush to col- leges 51 Arts/Entertainment Robin Feld and Cohorts perform at Dance Theater 56 Quinlan-Kirchels in Sokolow dance program 56 ''Midsummer's Night Dream'' at City Ballet 56 ''One From the Heart'' previewed at Radio City 56 ''Dreams Deferred,'' drama set in Harlem ''Y'' cafeteria 57 ''Trovatore'' at the Met 57 Coin auction expected to bring $10 million 58 Music debuts in review 58 News Analysis Drew Middleton looks at the his- tory of Polish-Russian relations 12

title: Design; WHAT PRICE ANTIQUES?
description: ollectors and dealers consider the Winter Antiques Show, a fair that sets style trends and serves as a barometer for prices throughout the market, the most prestigious event of the year.

title: 9 Are Felled by Fumes Traced to Heating Unit
description: Nine persons were overcome by noxious fumes in a beauty parlor on Columbus Avenue shortly before noon yesterday. The police reported that the fumes apparently came from a malfunctioning heating unit on the roof of the one-story building, at 762 Columbus Avenue, at 96th Street in the Park West Village housing complex.

title: No Headline
description: MISSOURI BEATS NEBRASKA AT BUZZER, 44-42

title: LEGISLATURES AND GOVERNORS BATTLE FOR CONTROL OF U.S. BLOCK GRANTS
description: The legislatures in a number of states are struggling to seize from the governors control over block grants and other Federal assistance that the Reagan Administration has turned back to the states.

title: Suzanne Remy Bride Of Scott Robert Colton
description: Suzanne Elizabeth Remy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce Talbot Remy of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., and Scott Robert Colton, son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene J. Colton of Halesite, L.I., were married yesterday.

title: Children's Books
description: THE SILENT VOICE By Julia Cunningham. 145 pp. New York: Dutton/Unicorn. $10.75. (Ages 10 to 14) By Colby Rodowsky

title: NICA SANDINISTA VS. GRINGO KID
description: Everybody knows that Cubans and Latin Americans d ominate the world lightweight boxing scene, and that every now and t hen one of these windmill sluggers gets a romantic notion in his h ead and goes so far as to challenge the reigning super-heavyweight, t he Gringo Kid, the hard-nosed nuclear mauler currently managed by R onald Reagan, who has made it clear he believes such matches make g ood box-office preliminaries for the big fight with the Moscow Mule,t he other super-heavy who also packs a nuclear wallop and who trains o n vodka and caviar in Moscow, U.S.S.R.

title: WIFE OF ABSCAM WITNESS REPORTEDLY SAYS HE LIED
description: The Justice Department said today that it had passed along to the trial judge allegations that the Government's chief witness in the Abscam case, Melvin Weinberg, lied in some portions of h is testimony.

title: Vatican and Britain Upgrad e Their Links
description: Pope John Paul II announced today that the Vaican and Britain had upgraded their diplomatic relations to the ambassadorial level, just four months before the Pope's planned trip to Britain.

title: Amy Altman Will Be Bride Of Lester Mallet on May 29
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harold Altman of Bayside, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Amy Jean Altman, to Lester Mallet, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ronny Mallet of Boca Raton, Fla.

title: CONSUMER RATES
description: In percent Passbook Savings 5.50 At savings institutions ''All Savers'' Certificates 10.16 Tax-Exempt Bonds 13.44 Bond Buyer 20-Bond Index 6-Month Savings Certificates 13.06 Maximum rate at savings institutions Money Market Funds 11.80 Donoghue's Money Fund 7-Day Average Home Mortgage 17.54 Federal Home Loan Bank, national average Unsecured Personal Loans Minimum rate, 3-year maturity Chase Manhattan, New York 19.50 Continental Illinois, Chicago 21.00 Bank of America, San Francisco 22.00

title: ISLANDERS' CARROLL IN KEY ROLE
description: Until Thursday night, Billy Carroll had been a quiet and polite addition to the Islanders since he joined the club just under a year ago.

title: Dog Saves Blind Man
description: A 22-year-old blind, retarded man was found by a Suffolk County police dog in sub-freezing cold early this morning in a wooded area a half mile from his home here. The man, Gregory Race, was found wedged between a tree and a stone wall 16 hours after he apparently became lost and disoriented.

title: The Region in Summary; Funless Election, Even for Winner
description: The campaign to fill the Congressional seat of the late William R. Cotter of Connecticut, which didn't attract much interest in Washington, drew a similar response from the voters last week. With only 33 percent of those registered casting ballots (instead of the usual 80 percent), Democrat Barbara B. Kennelly, Connecticut's Secretary of the State, defeated Antonina P. Uccello, a Republican, by a vote of 51,631 to 36,085.

title: Investing; THIS YEAR'S WORST INVESTMENTS
description: O.K. You've talked to your stockbroker, your lawyer and your cousin the accountant about where to put your money in 1982. But for every Park Avenue triplex there exists many an acre of quicksand.

title: New Play on Hiroshima Set to Open on Feb. 28
description: ''Hibakusha: Stories From Hiroshima,'' a new play by Steve Friedman, resident playwright of the Modern Times Theater, will open at St. Peter's Hall, 336 West 20th Street, on Feb. 28, with previews starting Feb. 17.

title: Reading and Writing; DANCE STEPS
description: WATCHING people dance at a party on New Year's Eve, I found myself wondering about the uses of tradition in art. It seemed to me that many of the people in the room danced awkwardly, even sheepishly, Their dancing vacillated, in a rather clumsy pastiche, between folk, jazz and musical comedy idioms.

title: ATLANTIC CITY'S NINE CASINOS WON $1.1 BILLION IN '81
description: Atlantic City's casino hotels won $1 .1 billion from gamblers in 1981, including about $2.1 million fr om three unidentified Hong Kong high-rollers in one sitting just be fore Christmas.

title: FINNS VOTING IN PRESIDENTIAL CONTEST
description: Finns vote Sunday and Monday for the electoral college that will choose their next President amid assurances the country will stick to its official policy of neutrality and friendship with the neighboring Soviet Union.

title: R. Parker Sullivan, 67, Coast Phone Executive
description: R. Parker Sullivan, a former chairman of the board and chief executive officer of General Telephone Company of California, died Thursday at the age of 67.

title: SEMINARS BOLSTER 'NATURAL HELPERS'
description: THEY are considered natural helpers - the homemakers, storekeepers and real-estate agents in every community who habitually reach out to others. And in an effort to reduce emotional stress by promoting prevention, the Westchester County Department of Community Mental Health has initiated an unusual program to strengthen the community network of such natural helpers in the county.

title:
Numismatics;
THIS COULD BE A BIG YEAR FOR THE LITTLE CENT
description: Predicting what lies ahead can be risky in the coin market, just as in any other business. Many would-be seers got a rude awakening two years ago, for example, when the boom turned to gloom amid optimistic long-range forecasts. Still, some market analysts feel safe in predicting that after more than a decade in the wings, cents will reclaim center stage this year in numismatics.

title: On Language
description: By William Safire From Podunk to the Boonies Kimble Mead

title: SUPER BOWL WEEK: THE HOOPLA BEGINS
description: IT begins today, the endless talk show, the swirl of parties, hoopla and hype. Another Super Bowl Week. Fred Dryer, the irreverent defensive end who had experienced one with the Los Angeles Rams two years ago, wondered, ''Who cuts the ribbon and proclaims, 'We are now officially in Super Bowl Week?' '' According to several players who suffered the long, almostsurrealistic countdown to kickoff, the ribbon-cutter must be the National Football League, the television networks, Hollywood, Madison Avenue - all rolled into a caricature of the all-American capitalist. The Super Bowl may be just a football game, but there's nothing like Super Bowl Week to the players who endure and, in some cases, overcome them.

title: IN THE FOOTSTEPS ON JAMES JOYCE DUBLIN
description: DESMOND RUSHE is a critic and columnist for The Irish Independent in Dublin. By DESMOND RUSHE

title: WHY WESTERN ELECTRIC HAS TO HUSTLE
description: T HE restructuring of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company will require certain dramatic changes in the direction, style and business philosophy of all of A.T.& T.'s subsidiaries. But of all Ma Bell's children, probably none faces more of a transformation - and risks and opportunities - than Western Electric.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: Art; AN HOMAGE IS GIVEN TO AN HOMAGE
description: BRIARCLIFF IN 1979, an exhibition paying homage to David Smith was held in the upstate Prospect Mountain State Park near Lake George, where the late sculptor lived. It featured works by the master and 17 other protagonists of various ages, all of them living and working in upstate New York or in Vermont. Organized by the Lake George Arts Project, it was apparently a great success.

title: Around the World; St. Lucia Premier Quits Over a Series of Strikes
description: Prime Minister Winston Cenac announced his resignation today as this Caribbean island of 120,000 people remained paralyzed by a series of strikes that began Monday.

title: Business Conditions; INDICATOR OF WEAKNESS
description: Although recent strengthening in certain sectors of the economy has prompted talk among some analysts that the recession may have ended in December, a little-known forecasting indicator is giving off different signals.

title: 'YOU DON'T HAVE TO TELL THEM YOU'RE A WAITRESS'
description: NOT long ago, I was invited to a party wher e the only people I knewwere the host and hostess. As I arrived, the hostess pulled me aside and said, ''If someone asks you what you do f or a living, you don't have to tell them you're a waitress. You can tell them you're a writer.''

title: Best Sellers; FICTION
description: 1 1 13 AN INDECENT OBSESSION, by Colleen McCullough. (Harper & Row, $13.50.) A nurse and her charges in a special-care ward of a World War II hospital. 2 2 18 THE HOTEL NEW HAMPSHIRE, by John Irving. (Dutton/Henry Robbins, $15.50.) Life with an eccentric family. 3 3 37 NOBLE HOUSE, by James Clavell. (Delacorte, $19.95.) A British-Chinese struggle for control of one of Hong Kong's oldest trading houses. 4 4 23 CUJO, by Stephen King. (Viking, $13.95.) Monsters haunt a New York family seeking peace in rural Maine. 5 6 41 GORKY PARK, by Martin Cruz Smith. (Random House, $13.95.) A triple murder in Moscow leads to a chase on two continents. 6 8 10 NO TIME FOR TEARS, by Cynthia Freeman. (Arbor House, $14.95.) A dauntless woman leads her family from Czarist Russia to Palestine to New York's diamond center. 7 7 38 MASQUERADE, by Kit Williams. (Schocken Books, $10.95.) An illustrated fable about the sun, the moon and a hidden treasure.

title: A GERMAN CAUTIONARY TALE
description: BISMARCK By Edward Crankshaw. Illustrated. 451 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $19.95.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN COPENHAGEN
description: FRANK J. PRIAL is a Times correspondent based in Paris. By FRANK J.PRIAL

title: A BRAVO FOR OPERA'S BLACK VOICES
description: Harold C. Schonberg, cultural correspondent of The New York Times, is the author of the recently published book ''Facing the Music.'' By Harold C. Schonberg

title: NEW ISSUES RISE AS TENANTS' POWER TO SUBLET GROWS
description: Last June the State Supreme Court handed down a decision on tenants' subletting rights that lawyers predicted would have farreaching effects on the Manhattan rental market.

title: LANGUAGE IS WORK AND PLAY FOR EDITOR
description: CENTERBROOK WHERE is a blackjack a life preserver, a salesman a counter-jumper? Where is a bureaucrat a bumble, a shrink a trick cyclist? In Merrie Olde England, of course, and in ''English English,'' a book written for American readers by a Weston resident, Norman W. Shur, and published here by Verbatim Press.

title: No Headline
description: With reference to William Zinsser's article about the experience of being at Princeton when World War II broke out, and his confrontation with Dean Root: The ''Faculty Song,'' then, but no longer, sung by members of the senior class nightly, on the steps of Nassau Hall, included this verse: A playful lad is Robert Root, He'd like to give us all the boot. He raised the standards up so high, He graduated just one guy. WALTER GUZZARDI JR., (Princeton 1942) New York City

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: Nicaraguan Aides Let Staff of Paper Return
description: Government security officers allowed the owners and employees of the independent daily newspaper La Prensa to return to their offices today after a two-day shutdown.

title: STAGE: 'DREAMS' IN HARLEM 'Y' CAFETERIA
description: The dreamers in Laurence Holder's new play, ''Dreams Deferred,'' are dreaming the same dreams as the principal players in two vastly different works on New York stages right now - Charles Fuller's ''A Soldier's Play'' and Michael Bennett's ''Dreamgirls.''

title: LONDON LOSES BIT OF HISTORY IN BILLINGSGATE
description: They sold the last fish at Billingsgate market today, and London will never be quite the same. Billingsgate is one of the few markets whose name entered the language. Its fishmongers and porters in dirty white aprons were so famous for gutter language that ''billingsgate,'' says Webster, means ''foul, vulgar, abusive talk.''

title: PANEL CONSIDERS BROADER INS URANCE
description: HARTFORD IN a quiet corner of the State Capi tol, away from the tax and budget battle s, members of the General Assembly's Insurance and Real Estate Commit tee are considering a new series of mandates that, if passed, could put Connecticut - home of major insurers - in the forefront of auxiliary health-care coverage.

title: L.I.'s Oldest Theater: Another View
description: Responding to a recent letter to the editor concerning the longevity of the 100-year-old Vail-Leavitt Music Hall, expected to reopen on a limited basis this coming season, the challenge to the 1922 Hempstead Theater as not being the ''oldest surviving theater on L.I.'' may well be valid. However, as the owner of the 1,440-seat stadium-type theater built in 1922 by my father, it is to my belief the oldest proscenium-arch theater in Long Island east of Jamaica.

title: A SPIRITED STRAY AND ITS LEGACY
description: IN death, her neck was no longer crooked. As we buried her out by the garden, I hailed her valiant spirit and forgave the inconveniences she had caused. A motley ''tortoise shell'' stray, she had survived not only the injuries that had left her neck twisted and one eye blind, but also countless winters with only partial shelter, living on moles, mice and bits of pet food scavanged from the wellfed chosen. Too wily to be caught and spayed, she had consorted with wandering Toms who had serenaded us with their yowls and hisses. Those days were now over for Crooked Neck, but four kittens waited anxiously for her behind the wood pile.

title: OFFSTAGE, A ROLE AS ONE OF A FAMILY
description: WHEN her son was 19 years old, friends wondered how she could let him go to Hollywood alone. She replied that she gave him lots of advice. ''About women?'' they woul d ask.

title: Fiori's 67-268 Leads Desert Golf by Shot
description: The fifth and final round of the Bob Hope Desert Classic Sunday will be a good one, according to Ed Fiori, who will be in the thick of it. Fiori heads a group of five players - the others are Tom Kite, Rex Caldwell, Forrest Fezler and Mark O'Meara - who are within two strokes of one another.

title: Laura Dalley Affianced to James Tobin
description: Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Cutting Dalley Jr. of Washington and Vineyard Haven, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Agnes Laura Dalley, to James Emmett Tobin, son of Mrs. Emmett James Tobin of Waterloo, Iowa, and the late Mr. Tobin.

title: BIDS START FOR STATE'S NO. 3 JOB
description: HARTFORD THE job pays just $25,000 a year, and the contract is for less than a year anyway; much of the work is seasonal, and there is no provision for overtime; actual power is extremely limited; the public often gets the job title wrong, and the biggest ''perk'' is a parking spot convenient to the Capitol. But a small crowd of candidates wants to be the Secretary of the State, a position that will be vacated a week from tomorrow, when Barbara B. Kennelly is sworn in and takes her seat in the United States House of Representatives. Under the law, Mrs. Kennelly's successor will be chosen by the Ge neral Assembly, if it is in still in session, or by the Governor, if it is not. Either way, the position, which is considered the No. 3po st in the state government, is likely to go to a Democrat because th at party controls both the executive and legislative branches.

title: Critics' Choices
description: JAZZ An unusual confluence of jazz singers will take place this week. Three singers who have taken jazz singing beyond the initial scat sounds popularized by Louis Armstrong and Ella Fitzgerald will be performing in three different locations.

title: SAN FRANCISCO
description: Joe Montana, the quarterback, is by far the most important player for the 49ers. The offense was built around his quickness and his rollout ability. But what if he is hurt?

title: Canadian U nit to Buy Savin
description: The Canadian Development Corporation has agreed to purchase a controlling interest in the Savin Corporation, which markets copiers, word-and data-processing machines and other office equipment.

title: Mardi Gras Policing Planned
description: Louisiana will send 150 members of the state police here for the Mardi Gras celebration Feb. 23 and the preceding four days. The added forces should enable city police to concentrate on keeping order in the parades, the police superintendent, Henry M. Morris, said.

title: Treacher's Wins Suit
description: A Federal judge here has ordered several former franchisees of the Arthur Treacher's Fish & Chips restaurant chain to pay franchise fees and trademark infringement penalties of $3.97 million.

title: Lau rie Levitt, a TV Aide, Bride of Bruce Goodman
description: Laurie Levitt, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Levitt of Clifton, N.J., was married at Temple Emanuel in Passaic, N.J., yesterday to Bruce D. Goodman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Goodman of North Caldwell, N.J. Rabbi Joseph Herman officiated.

title: LINE
description: The color line drawn at the front door of the Goldsboro Christian Schools is by most definitions rather uneven. Blacks are barred on religious grounds, but Oriental children are regularly admitted to the private, fundamentalist institution.

title: Rorem to Give Recital
description: Ned Rorem will give a lecture-recital at the Bloomingdale House of Music, 323 West 108th Street, on Sunday at 3 P.M. The composer will be assisted by Rosalind Rees, the soprano, who will sing Mr. Rorem's settings of poems by Tennyson, Whitman, Stein, Sitwell, Roethke, Paul Goodman, Glaze Koch and Elizabeth Bishop.

title: A QUEST FOR QUAIL IN TOMS RIVER, N.J.
description: TOMS RIVER, N.J. IT is probable that our two guides for the quail hunt upon which Ed Zern of Scarsdale, N.Y., and I were embarking had never encountered two more methodical fellows, but they handled the assig nment with disarming gra ce.

title: The Talk of Jo hannesburg
description: Just off a highway that runs through the heart of the most affluent white suburbs here, there is a fastidiously maintained park and public garden called the Wilds, in which many species of South African flora are planted on craggy hillsides overlooking the greenest of lawns.

title: CINCINNATI BENGALS
description: In a comparison of personnel, which does not always determine who will win, the Bengals have an edge on the 49ers at wide receiver, offensive line, running back, linebackers and special teams.

title: ONCE-IMPERILED OSPREY MAKES NEW YORK COMEBACK
description: After what wildlife experts call ''a tremendous comeback'' spurred by a ban on the pesticide DDT, the once-rare osprey has re-appeared in modest numbers on the lakes and waterways of New York and has been taken off the state's endangered species list. ''The statu s of the osprey has changed significantly in the last few years for the better,'' said Eugene McCaffrey, an official of theState Departm ent of Environmental Conservation. ''We now consider it out of danger .''

title: DAWKINS IS INJURED
description: The struggling Philadelphia 76ers lost more than another game to the Nets, 105-97, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena today. In the early minutes of the their third consecutive loss and their sixth loss in the last eight games, Darryl Dawkins received a fractured right shin bone. He is expected to be sidelined six to eight weeks.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: TOTAL RECALL

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, an arti- cle on Saturday incorrectly described a ''loophole primary,'' which Demo- crats are seeking to reinstitute. In such a primary, the names of candi- dates for delegate to the Presidential nominating convention would be per- mitted to appear on the ballot, so long as the name o f the Presidential candi- dates the del egates favored also ap- peared.

title: Skate Sprint Title To Sarah Docter
description: Sarah Docter finished behind her sister, Mary, and Dorie Boyce in the 1,000-meter event today but still had enough points to win the overall title at the United States Sprint Championships in State Fair Park.

title: MODERN TIMES; Panda Debut
description: During last year's panda debacle at Washington's National Zoo (Chia-Chia, the new fiance to Ling-Ling turned out to be a brute; Hsing-Hsing, her old fiance, a wimp), Mexico City's Pe-Pe and Ying-Ying quietly got together.

title: AROUND THE NATION;
description: An estimated $250,000 worth of stolen books have been seized at a warehouse here, the Federal Bureau of Investigat ion said.

title: SCHOLAR'S PEERS CRITICIZE HIS THEORIES ON EXODUS
description: Archeologists and biblical scholars are disputing, often in uncommonly st rong language, the hypothesis that the Exodus of the Israelites fr om Egypt occurred about 200 years earlier than previously as sumed and that the pursuing Egyptian army drowned in a volcano-produ ced tidal wave.

title: Sharp Rise Is Found In Lung Cancer Deaths
description: By United Press International Lung cancer will account for more than 25 percent of all cancer deaths this year, a startling rise from a generation ago, the American Cancer Society said yesterday.

title: Colgate Unit Sale
description: The boards of United Biscuits (Holdings) Ltd. and the Colgate-Palmolive Company said that they had agreed for United Biscuits to acquire Joseph Terry & Sons Ltd., a Colgate subsidiary, for $46 million. Terry is a chocolate maker that Colgate acquired from Trust House Forte Ltd. in April 1977. United Biscuits said it expected to ''significantly increase'' Terry's sales, $78 million last year, through the distrubution outlets that it currently serves, including its networks in North America and Europe.

title: Market Place; Subaru Gains Equity Return
description: WHILE American automobile manufacturers have been laboring in low gear, Subaru of America has been burning up the track. Subaru automobiles are manufactered for the company to American specifications by Fuji Heavy Industries of Japan. Thus, Subaru has avoided the heavy capital commitment of a manufacturer, but has enjoyed the fruits of being the marketer of a popular car.

title: Yamani View Of Oil Pricing
description: There can be no substantial increase in the price of crude oil until demand picks up and coal ceases to be competitive, possibly not until the 1990's, Saudi Arabia's oil minister said in an interview to appear Monday.

title: LAWMAKER'S FUNDS CLOUDED BY FLAWS
description: A pattern of discrepancies in the reporting of campaign contributions made to Representative Frederick W. Richmond of Brooklyn has emerged in an examination of official records and in interviews with listed givers and aides.

title: 40 TOURISTS DROWNED IN BRAZIL
description: A footbridge over a spectacular waterfall on the Paraguay-Brazil border collapsed today and dozens of people tumbled into the churning water below. At least 40 people drowned and 10 were injured, local authorities said.

title: Stanley H. Lawrence, Expert In Makeup Art, Dies in Florida
description: Stanley H. Lawrence, a makeup expert who in 1960 was called in to work on Vice President Nixon after his first televised debate with John F. Kennedy, died Tuesday in Mount Sinai Hospital in Miami Beach. Mr. Lawrence, who lived in Miami Beach, was 59 years old.

title: COUNSELING MALE RAPE VICTIMS
description: O FTEN there is a presumption that phrases like ''rape victims'' and ''victims of sexual abuse'' are used to describe women, but in many cases the victims are boys and men. According to physicians, psychiatrists and counselors who have treated them, males suffer the same aftermath of trauma and humiliation as women, but they are more reluctant to admit that they've been assaulted and to seek help. And adolescent boys are more likely to commit suicide in a postrape despondency than girls are.

title: Ian Hunter Plays Two-Night Rock Stand
description: Ian Hunter, the frizzy-haired English singer and keyboardist who now lives in New York, is a towering intellectual by rock-music standards. His literary songs, composed when he was the leader of the critically esteemed group Mott the Hoople, and in the solo career that has followed the group's breakup, have looked to Bob Dylan, Lou Reed, and David Bowie as alienated heroes whose style was worth emulating.

title: CHAMBER: LINCOLN SOCIETY
description: FACED with the repertory's tiresome stagnancy, a frequent concertgoer is tempted to plead tirelessly for more variety. The Lincoln Chamber Music Society helps alleviate the situation with its unusual offerings.

title: OF GERMANS, RUSSIANS AND AN UNLIKELY LINK
description: To the Editor:

title: PRESIDENT OF RCA UNIT SAVORS SATELLITE LAUNCH
description: Andrew F. Inglis, president of RCA American Communications Inc., spent a busy last week at Cape Canaveral, Fla. It is there that the National Aeronautics and Space Administration launched Friday - after a 24-ho ur delay because of adverse high-altitude winds - his company's lat est communications satellite, the 2,000-pound Satcom IV,into orbit 22 ,300 miles overhead.

title: MERCURY SINKS TO 0, SEASON'S LOW IN NEW YORK CITY
description: Just when temperatures seemed to be on an upswing, the temperature plummeted yesterday, bringing New Yorkers their coldest day yet this winter.

title: IDAHO IS ROLLING ON, WITH NEW YORKER KEY PLAYER
description: Idaho's first appearance in a National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball championship tournament resulted in a quick round trip when Pittsburgh, itself a rare entry, edged the Vandals, 70-69, in overtime in the first round last March. Idaho has not lost a game since.

title: THE MEMORY OF MISTAKES
description: Not long ago, former Secretary of State Dean Rusk gave a rare interview. Standing back from the political fray, he mused about the reasons for the Western alliance and reminded Americans about the importance of keeping friends.

title: Miss Talavera, Vidmar Get Titles
description: Peter Vidmar of U.C.L.A. took the all-round men's title and Tracee Talavera won the all-round women's title Saturday night in The Albuquerque Journal International Invitational gymnastics meet.

title: CONGRESS VOTES LINKED TO BUSINESS DONATIONS
description: The organization said its finding was based on a study of 30 House votes and 40 Senate votes on which consumer groups lobbied, "votes which clearly divide consumer friends from foes," according to the report. The votes were in the areas of consumer protection, Government reform, tax reform, energy and the environment and efforts to "eliminate Government handouts to politically powerful special interests."

title: Reta Shaw, Was Mabel In 'The Pajama Game'
description: Reta Shaw, the chubby actress who pleased Broadway audiences in her comic role as Mabel in ''The Pajama Game'' in 1952, died in Encino Calif., on Jan. 8. She was 69 years old.

title: FOOTBALL, PAUL BROWN'S WAY
description: CINCINNATI PAUL BROWN'S players used to call it The Speech. They would get it the first day of training camp every year. Two hours of Paul Brown on what to wear. How to talk. When to smoke. Whom to associate with. The talk was so long, Paul Brown took two breaks. But when it was over they knew what it took to play football for Paul Brown, perhaps the most successful coach in the history of football. They knew that he had standards that went beyond blocking and tackling and running.

title: Top Parties in Zimbabwe To Discuss a Merger
description: Prime Minister Robert Mugabe said today th at the country's two main political parties would meet soon to discu ss a possible merger as a prelude to declaring Zimbabwe a one-party s tate.

title: ECONOMIC RELEVANCE OF MILIARY SPENDING
description: To the Editor:

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Bancoklahoma Corp. said its directors had authorized it to pursue a public offering of $15 million to $20 million in securities.

title: SHIFT IN BUDGET PROCESS BY CONGRESS IS UNLIKELY
description: Proposals intended to strengthen the Congressional budget act are considered unlikely to succeed this year because many Congressmen think their budget committees are already too powerful.

title: Mayor Koch's $171 Million Umbrella
description: Mayor Koch proposes to balance the city's budget for the year beginning July 1 by asking New Yorkers for $171 million in new taxes. The increases promise no improved city services, but given the gathering fiscal storm clouds, they may well be necessary for survival. They should be voted on a standby basis.

title: Rangers Acquire Confidence
description: After a clumsy start, the Rangers are playing like winners and have begun the push they quietly hope will bring the Stanley Cup to Madison Square Garden for the first time since 1940.

title: Phillips Petroleum To Cut Spending
description: The Phillips Petroleum Company, whose stock rose $350 Friday, to $38.75, on the New York Stock Exchange on the strength of takeover rumors, said it would cut spending for capital projects this year to about $2.2 billion from approximately $2.5 billion spent last year.

title: Inflation Rate 12% in Britain
description: The annual rate of inflation in Britain was 12 percent at the end of 1981, unchanged from November, according to Government figures released Friday.

title: FOR TURKS, COFFEE BREAK RETURNS
description: Turkish teahouses can become coffeehouses again with the ending of a four-year ban on coffee imports. The decision to allow imports of coffee and 12 other banned items was announced several days ago by Minister of Trade Kemal Canturk as a sign that some economic gains have been made in Turkey. The import ban was imposed at a time when Turkey was forced to spend its hardcurrency earnings on oil products.

title: JOE MONTANA, THE UNLIKELY HERO OF THE 49ers
description: SAN FRANCISCO THE San Francisco 49ers have just defeated the Dallas Cowboys, 28-27. Joe Montana, the quarterback, is sitting in front of his locker calmly explaining to an army of reporters how he took the 49ers on a la st-ditch 89-yard scoring drive that gave San Francisco its first Nat ional Football Conference championship.

title: Sherrill Is Sought For Aggies Posts
description: Coach Jackie Sherrill of Pittsburgh said today that he had been contacted about a job at Texas A & M. ''I have heard from them, not directly,'' he said, declining to talk further about being approached.

title: Score One for the Gipper at the Touchdown Club
description: It was a laugh a minute Saturday night when some of Washington's leading comedians gathered for the annual awards of the Washington Touchdown Club.

title: BONN'S 'VALIANT EFFORT' AGAINST WAR CRIMINALS
description: To the Editor:

title: HAVE NAMES, WILL OPEN RIGHT DOORS
description: Craig J. Spence finds much to admire in Oriental society. He likes to tell the story of a Japanese food service manager who, after some of his customers suffe red food poisoning, co mmitted suicide as a way of apologizing.

title: Singer's Father Rescued From Abductors in Spain
description: Spanish antiterrorist forces rescued the kidnapped father of a popular Spanish singer today, storming a house in a remote village where he was being held by suspected Basque guerrillas.

title: PLAN TO INCREASE FUEL TAXES COULD HELP TRANSIT SYSTEMS
description: The Reagan Administration is considering a plan that could more than double the Federal highway fuel tax to funnel new billions into the Highway Trust Fund, which was once bloated but has been dwindling for two years.

title: Debt Issues Still Lig- ht
description: The supply of new corporate note and bond issues continues to be scanty, with many potential issuers discouraged by high interest rates.

title: THE PATTERN OF PICKING THE 'WRONG' PARTNER
description: She searched for years for a man she could talk to, really talk to, about feelings. Instead, she found only men who had nothing to say about such things and this confirmed her theory that when it comes to the language of human emotions all men have had their tongues cut out.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Metropolitan Report Saturday incorrectly named two boys who fell through the ice and drowned in Prospect Park Lake in Brooklyn. Norman Cox and Michael Cook drowned; Robert Cox and Ronald McCloud were hospitalized.

title: Article 176311 -- No Title
description: An art dealer has won $938,000 in a long court dispute over a Matisse painting that was purchased from a former Metropolitan Opera singer.

title: ISLANDERS AND CAPITALS TIE, 2-2
description: The Islanders, hoping for a big victory over the last-place Washington Capitals, had to settle for a 2-2 tie tonight and fell from first place in the Patrick Division.

title: Erving Gets a Record Vote
description: Julius Erving of Philadelphia received a record number of votes and led for the second consecutive year in fan balloting for the National Basketball Association All-Star Game, the league announced yesterday.

title: A NEEDIEST CASES FUND RECORD
description: Contributions to the 70th annual New York Times Neediest Cases Fund have set a record, exceeding the one established two years ago. Donations over the weekend have brought the total received to $1,276,829.27, with about six weeks remaining before the drive formally ends. The previous high was $1,271,250.07, received during the 1979-80 campaign. This year is the 12th in a row that contributions have exceeded $1 million.

title: MONDAY, JANUARY 18, 1982; International
description: Japan and Western industrial nations agreed on topics to be discussed at a new round of trade talks that are to begin in Geneva next November. The talks, under the auspices of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, are to focus on broader trade in service industries and on reducing restrictions on foreign investment. (D1.)

title: Mother of the Bride and Various Other Roles
description: In a way, what Joel Flynn and Sandra Wessels were saying when they got married in Prophetstown, Ill., was something like ''What God and our mothers put together, let no man put asunder.''

title: Swedish Ski Team Wins Relay Race
description: Benny Kohlberg, Thomas Wassberg and Thomas Eriksson won the 30-kilometer relay ski race today, edging the United States team of Denis Simoneau, Jim Galanes and Bill Koch by 38 seconds.

title: If Iran Is Really Listening
description: So they aren't deaf, after all. One of Iran's mullahs - Ayatollah Musavi Ardebeli - recently called a news conference to deny Western reports about the slaughter of adherents of the Bahai religion.

title: FORMER NEWSPAPER PUBLISHER
description: William J. Conners 3d, retired president and publisher of The Buffalo Courier-Express, suffered a fatal heart attack Friday at the Good Samaritan Hospital here.

title: Advertising; Continental Stays Put
description: IT seems that Wells, Rich, Greene is always good for a surprise. Today's surprise is that the $16 million Continental Air Lines account will remain on the agency's client list, something that was thrown into doubt when Pan American World Airways also became a client Jan. 8. To keep Continental, however, the agency has had to reorganize its West Coast shop.

title: TRYINNG TO RESOLVE THE PRODUCTIVITY ISSUE
description: Stipulating that more investment is necessary - but perhaps not sufficient - to put the nation's economic productivity back on a growth path, Representative David R. Obey, a liberal Democrat from Wisconsin, held hearings last week to survey what else should be done.

title: Bullets 96, Hawks 78
description: Rick Mahorn and Don Collins scored 6 points each in a 14-0 streak that broke open a close game.

title: Crowd Control
description: More than 80,000 people are expected to be at the Silverdome in Pontiac, Mich., for Super Bowl XVI on Sunday. There will also be security forces estimated at between 700 and 1,000 to deal with parking, tickets, seating and crowd control.

title: HAITIAN EXILE LEADER IN CUSTODY
description: Bernard Sansaricq, right, and an associate leaving the U.S. Coast Guard station in Miami after being questioned by the Federal Bureau of Investigation. Mr. Sansaricq led a small group in an unsuccessful plan to invade Haiti to overthrow President Jean-Claude Duvalier. The Coast Guard rescued 25 persons, including Mr. Sansaricq, from a leaking 40-foot boat returning to the U.S. An F.B.I. agent said Mr. Sansaricq would be charged with violating U.S. neutrality laws.

title: Pacers 116, Bulls 103
description: INDIANAPOLIS (UPI) - Indiana, led by Johnny Davis's 20 points, broke a five-game losing streak and extended Chicago's losing streak to four games.

title: RECITAL: JAN DEGAETANI, GILBERT KALISH
description: WHAT Jan DeGaetani and Gilbert Kalish gave to a snow-laden audience Thursday at the Metropolitan Museum of Art was more an evening of music than just a vocal recital. Miss Gaetani's soprano is not the most beautiful instrument in the world; indeed, her voice takes on a rough, often metallic character as it rises and expands.

title: Colombia Hit by Quake
description: An earthquake shook northeastern Colombia early today, the Andes Geophysical Institute said. The police said there were no casualties or damages. The institute said the epicenter of the tremor, which registered IV on the XII-grade Mercalli scale, was 180 miles east of Bogota.

title: Peru's Oil Reserves Rise
description: Peru's proven oil reserves have risen to 900 million barrels following the discovery of new deposits, according to Petroperu, the state oil company. Further finds are expected this year because of intensifed exploration. It said 610 million barrels of reserves were located in the northern and central jungle, 200 million on the continental shelf and 90 million in old fields on the northern coast.

title: THOMAS H. BEMBRY
description: Dr. Thomas H. Bembry, a former professor of organic chemistry at City College, died yesterday at Overlook Hospital in Summit, N.J. He was 74 years old and lived in Summit.

title: CYZ POUNDS OUT VICTORY OVER SIMS
description: Bobby Czyz remained unbeaten with a 10-round unanimous decision over Robbie Sims today in a middleweight bout at the Tropicana Hotel and Casino.

title: WINDS OF UP TO 140 M.P.H. DAMAGE HOUSES IN COLORADO
description: Hurricane-force winds, gusting to almost 140 miles an hour, slammed off the Rocky Mountains onto the high plains of eastern Colorado early this morning, tearing roofs from houses, shattering windows and snapping utility poles like toothpicks.

title: TROUBLED YOUNG WOMAN TURNS TO THE CITY
description: Clearly, she was in trouble. She appeared to be in her 20's, a woman in a neat beige blouse and a long skirt of subdued plaid. When she walked into the Mayor's Action Center at 61 Chambers Street, she was in tears. Before long, the tears had turned to sobs.

title: RET IREMENT ACCOUNT OFFERINGS BRING CHOIC ES - AND CONFUSION
description: A barrage of advertisements is stirring public interest in the new program of tax-deferred retirement plans, known as individual retirement accounts, or I.R.A.'s.

title: EMIL DENANEBERG, EDUCATOR, IS DEAD
description: Emil Charles Danenberg, a musician who had been president of Oberlin College since 1975, died Saturday at Allen Memorial Hospital in Oberlin, Ohio, after several months of treatment for liver cancer. He was 64 years old.

title: Ulster Bishops Denounce College Merger Plan
description: Roman Catholic bishops in Northern Ireland circulated a letter to be read in all churches today protesting Britain's plans to merge two Roman Catholic teaching colleges with a Protestant facility.

title: REQUIRED READING
description: The Energy Myth Senator Bill Bradley, Democrat of New Jerse y, writing in SIPIscope,published by the Scientists' Institute for Pu blic Information: Why is our dependence on imported oil so tr oubling? It is a problem because, unlike most internationally traded goods, the flow of oil from the Mideast can be disrupted inte ntionally or by accidentin a variety of ways.

title: THE CALENDAR
description: Monday

title: TV: FIRST PART OF 'BRIDESHEAD R EVISITED'
description: LIKE the novel, the television version of ''Brideshead Revisited'' gets off to a smashing start in the special two-hour premiere tonight at 8 on WNET-TV, Channel 13.

title: CITY UNIVERSITY REPORT EMPHASIZES INADEQUATE SECURITY EQUIPMENT
description: Most of the 18 campuses of the City University of New York lack proper security equipment, and the university's guards are seriously overextended, according to a report on security at the institution. The report stresses the difficulty of making the vast institution secure at a time when crime has become an overriding concern to New Yorkers.

title: 49er OWNER IS A 35er
description: FOR most club owners in the National Football League, the Super Bowl is more of a party than anything else. Other teams are always in the game itself, not their team. And even for those two club owners whose teams are involved, it's usually been a long wait. Super Bowl XVI, for example, will be the first for 73-year-old Paul Brown, who created the Cincinnati Bengals long after he had assembled the Cleveland Browns. But little Eddie DeBartolo Jr., the 35-year-old owner of the San Francisco 49ers, has his team in the Super Bowl after only five seasons.

title: FOR CRAVATH, LIFE AFTER I.B.M.
description: Sixty years ago Paul D. Cravath, the patriarch of one of Wall Street's most prestigious law firms, described the qualities he looked for in the young men he hired.

title: Is There Life After the Energy Department?
description: He's been busy dismantling the Department of Energy and hopes to complete the job next summer, which raises the question of how the Secretary of Energy, James B. Edwards, will earn a living after putting himself out of a job.

title: A FANTASY QE2 CRUISE FOR CHARITY
description: Fantasizing about a cruise is the next best thing to taking one, and about a thousand formally clad revelers lived their fantasy, at least for one night, when they boarded the Queen Elizabeth 2 for an evening of nonstop dancing, dining and dreaming of sailings, past and future.

title: MISS POTTER WINS FINAL BY 6-4, 7-6
description: Barbara Potter, utilizing a strong serve-and-volley game, defeated Bettina Bunge, 6-4, 7-6, today to win a $150,000 Avon tennis tournament.

title: No Headline
description: RECORD 20,628 SEE OILERS, RED WINGS TIE

title: Peerce to Give Benefit
description: Jan Peerce will give a recital at Carnegie Hall on Sunday at 7:30 P.M. to benefit the Friends of Refugees of Eastern Europe. The program will include arias by Gluck, Mozart and Verdi, cantorial music and folk songs. Tickets, at $6, $8, $10, $12 and $15, are available through CarnegieCharge, 247-7459, or Ticketron, 977-9020.

title: cd3Burton Quartet Back in Jazz Club
description: Gary Burton, whose quartet has usually been booked into the generalized, expansive music hall surroundings of the Bottom Line in recent years, reverted to its origins over the weekend. For the first time in five years, it played in a New York jazz club, Seventh Avenue South, where the snug, intimate atmosphere set up a close response between musicians and audience that is dissipated in larger rooms.

title: STUDY FINDS U.N. ENVOYS ARE GENERALLY DISILLUSIONED
description: Diplomats serving here are a largely disillusioned lot, a United Nations study has disclosed. They regard peace in the Middle East as the world's most pressing problem, but do not think the United Nations will help much in achie ving it. They have a low opinion of the General Assembly, and aneven lower on e of the Security Council. They complain of spending toomuch time in too many meetings, wrestling with too much paper and overloaded ag endas.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Bi-Modal Corp. announced the appointment of James C. Louney to the position of vice president, administration and finance.

title: F OES OF NICARAGUA REGIME TRAIN IN CALIFORNIA
description: Small groups of Nicaraguans are undergoing military training under the guidance of Cuban exiles in the southern California desert for what the Nicaraguans say will be an invasion to liberate their country from the Sandinist Government.

title: A.M.C. RESTORES FAMILY CONNECTION
description: Once, the automobile industry was noted for its family dynasties. The cars they built bore their names: Ford, Chrysler, Dodge. Few members of those founding families remain in the industry, but a management shakeup at the American Motors Corporation last week will bring back one of the few remaining executives with family ties to the early days.

title: Continued Recession Is Seen
description: The economist Alan Greenspan, differing with the Reagan Administration's economic forecasts, predicted today that the recession would last several more months and unemployment would reach nearly 10 percent.

title: FORD SAYS G.M. DID NOT TELL OF PACT WITH UNION ON PRICES
description: Executives of the General Motors Corporation, at a meeting with their opposite numbers at the Ford Motor Company held to coordinate bargaining strategy, did not tell Ford that they were secretly negotiating with the United Auto Workers, Philip Caldwell, chairman of Ford, said today.

title: Wichita State Aide Calls School Guilty
description: A member of an internal committee that investigated Wichita State University's basketball program said today his findings clashed with those of two other members whose conclusions indicated the school was not guilty of violations.

title: WINIFRED P. ARMSTRONG
description: Winifred Pritchard Armstrong, former professional-services supervisor for Family Service of Yonkers, died of cancer on Jan. 7 at Bridgeport (Conn.) Hospital.

title: ONCE-UNFLAPPABLE AUTO EXECUTIVES SHOW STRESS SYMPTOMS
description: Automobile executives and their spouses are demonstrating intense anxiety, stress and depression about their future and the future of the industry in which they have invested so much of their lives, according to two psychiatrists with an extensive practice in the Detroit area.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, JANUARY 18, 1982
description: International Poland's Primate said that new arrests were being made under martial law. At a crowded mass in Warsaw, the Primate, Archbishop Jozef Glemp, again criticized the military regime for its campaign to extract loyalty oaths from Poles. (Page A1, Col. 4.) A response to the military buildup being pressed by the Reagan Administraton was issued by the Soviet Defense Ministry. It published an elaborate, 79-page booklet on American military strengthin which it a sserts that Washington's strategy is to develop its nuclear weapo ns to a point that ''a pre-emptive strike'' against the Soviet Union becomes possible in this decade. (A3:1-3.)

title: 2 BODIES FOUND, RAISING TOLL TO 30 IN CALIFORNIA MUD SLIDE
description: The bodies of John and Lynda McCluskey have been recovered from the mud-ravaged wreckage of their home north of Santa Cruz, bringing to 30 the number known dead after the devastating storm early this month, the officials said Saturday.

title: A Footnote to the Death of a Hero
description: For decades Swedish officials and Jewish leaders have been seeking to learn the fate of Raoul Wallenberg, the former Swedish diplomat who saved thousands of Jewish lives in World War II and was then presumably interred in Soviet prisons.

title: MUSIC: 'FOOLS' OFFICE,' WAVERLY CONSORT STYLE
description: IN 12th-century Europe, there were church celebrations just after Christmas in which a live donkey would be led into the sanctuary. Ecclesiastical authority would be overturned, and one member of the inferior clergy would be named ''lord of the asses.'' The liturgy of the mass would be punctuated with donkey brayings by the celebrants. Dice games might be played on the altar, and reigning subdeacons might turn their clothes inside out, wear masks or speak gibberish.

title: No Headline
description: POLAND'S PRIMATE CITES NEW ARRESTS UNDER ARMY RULE

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Mary Cantwell STRANGE GODS. The Great American Cult Scare. By David G. Bromley and Anson D. Sh upe Jr. Introduction by Har- vey Cox. 24 9 pages. Beacon Press. $13.50.

title: Article 176409 -- No Title
description: The Edmonton Oilers will hold a news conference before their game Wednesday night against the St. Louis Blues, at which they are expected to announce a deal making Wayne Gretzky the h ighest-paid player in hockey history.

title: AUSTIN VOTERS REJECT AMENDMENT ALLOWING HOUSING DISCRIMINATION
description: The voters of Austin Saturday overwhelmingly rejected a proposal that would have made the Texas capital the first city in the nation to legalize housing discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation.

title: DR. VERA MAE GREEN
description: Dr. Vera Mae Green, an associate professor of anthropology at Rutgers University, died Saturday at the Princeton (N.J.) Medical Center after a long illness.

title: Argerich Recital Now Feb. 5
description: Martha Argerich's piano recital at Avery Fisher Hall, scheduled for next Sunday, has been rescheduled on Feb. 5, at 8 P.M. The concert, part of Lincoln Center's ''Great Performers'' series will include music by Liszt, Bach and Chopin. Tickets purchased for Sunday will be honored on Feb. 5. For remaining seats, call 874-2424 or Center Charge, 874-6770.

title: CHALRES DIKRAN KELEKIAN, 82, MAJOR DEALER IN ANCIENT ART
description: Charles Dikran Kelekian, the dean of antiquities dealers in the United States, died Saturday morning of heart failure at his New York apartment. He was 82 years old.

title: MICRONESIANS ARE TROUBLED BY THE LACK OF DEVELOPMENT
description: After nearly four decades of United States rule, the paved road is coming to Ponape. Electricity and water supplies are still precarious, though, and the dock can take only one ship at a time. Ponape is part of the Caroline Islands, which in turn form part of Micronesia, some 2,000 islands - most of them small, only about 100 inhabited - that stretch 2,400 miles from east to west across the Pacific Ocean and 1,000 miles north from the Equator.

title: CITY BALLET: WEEKEND CAST CHANGES
description: GEORGE BALANCHINE'S ''A Midsummer Night's Dream'' allows stars to shine, but it is by no means merely a star vehicle. Rather, it is an ensemble piece with good parts for lots of dancers. And this was made clear at the New York City Ballet's yesterday afternoon performance at the New York State Theater when a new cast took over several principal roles.

title: FRANCE'S NATIONALIZATION PROGRAM IS DELAYED BY RULING ON PAYMENT
description: France's nationalization program, the political and economic centerpiece of its new Socialist Government, has been dealt a painful but temporary setback by a decision of the Constitutional Council.

title: STENMARK'S MARGIN IS SLALOM RECORD
description: Ingemar Stenmark of Sweden won a World Cup slalom race today by 3.16 seconds, the largest time margin ever in that event during Cup competition.

title: IRAN PURSUES GRIM REPRESSION TO MEET GUERRILLAS' CHALLENGE
description: The Hostage Crisis: One Year Later Second of three articles. By JOHN KIFNER

title: WEAKER ECONOMY FAILS TO LIFT PRICES
description: News of a weak economy - which normally leads to lower interest rates, weaker borrower demands and moderating inflation - has not been much help to the credit markets recently.

title: Sport World Specials; Viva Lazorko
description: It wasn't the hurricane that broke windows and turned over light towers, the 18-hour bus rides, the players hit by bottles thrown from the stands or the long, breath-takingly scenic train ride through the Sierra Madres that Jack Lazorko remembers best about his recently completed season in the Mexican League.

title: The 1984 Window
description: Remember the 1980 Presidential campaign? It's hard to forget considering how long it went on. But two years from now, with any sense of decency, we will all look back to what the Democrats did this past weekend with gratitude. The Hunt Commission, their reform panel chaired by Gov. James Hunt of North Carolina, took some serious steps toward taming the Endless Campaign.

title: TRADE TALKS TOPICS ARE DETERMINED
description: Western industrial nations and Japan have moved a step closer to a new round of multilateral negotiations aimed at reducing barriers to trade in services and easing investment restrictions.

title: Walsh and 49ers Arrive in Michigan
description: Bill Walsh, the San Francisco 49ers' coach, arrived in the Detroit suburb of Southfield today a few hours ahead of his club to begin preparations for the Super Bowl game Sunday.

title: ANN TUROBINER' LEGAL AIDE, BRIDE OF JONATHAN A. DACHS
description: At the Sephardic Temple in Cedarhurst, L.I., yesterday Ann Helaine Turobiner, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold L. Turobiner of New York, was married to Jonathan A. Dachs. son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman H. Dachs of Woodmere, L.I. Rabbis Sidney Lebor and Mendel Kaufman officiated.

title: CAREY IS EXPECTED TO SEEK DEEP CUTS IN HIS NEXT BUDGET
description: Governor Carey will call for an increase in the gasoline tax and a freeze on both education aid and state revenuesharing with localities in his budget proposal Tuesday, top aides to the Governor said today.

title: FREEZE IN FLORIDA TESTS STATE'S CITRUS AGENCY
description: When a damaging freeze strikes Florida's billion-dollar citrus industry, W. Bernard Lester, executive director of the Florida Department of Citrus, has his work cut out for him.

title: Unsung Hero Of the Masters
description: THE real hero was never introduced yesterday at the final of the Volvo Masters tennis tournament. Roscoe Tanner, a mild-mannered lefthander with a wicked serve, might have kept this midwinter creation from going further in the direction of the Literary Digest, the Edsel and the woolly mammoth, yet Tanner's name was never mentioned as Vitas Gerulaitis and Ivan Lendl slashed at each other on the court for five exhaustive sets.

title: Al Grey, Trombonist, Leads a 'Jazz Revue'
description: In one sense, Al Grey, the longtime trombone star of Count Basie's Orchestra, was lucky when the accumulation of snow prevented the delivery of an organ from Philadelphia for his concert Friday night at the Village Gate. The organ was replaced by Gloria Coleman on piano and Jamil Nasser on bass, who gave Mr. Grey's group a more varied yet cohesive support than an organ might have.

title: ONE KILLED IN TRAIN COLLISION
description: Two trains collided head on Saturday on the single-track Bessemer & Lake Erie Railroad near here. Paul McMillan, a 50-year-old trainman of Springboro, Pa., was killed and five crew members were injured, the authorities said.

title: MILAN KUNDERA: A MAN WHO CANNOT FORGET
description: IT was during the Stalinist era of the late 40's, when he was a student in Czechoslovakia, that Milan Kundera says he first learned the value of humor. He learned he could recognize a person who was not a Stalinist by his laughter - the ability to laugh was a sign that someone could be trusted, for it signified irreverence, a refusal to take history and its policemen seriously. Ever since then, he says, he has been ''terrified by a world that is losing its sense of humor.''

title: GOLDIN ASSERTS A CITY TAX RISE IS UNNECESSARY
description: The City Comptroller yesterday termed unnecessary Mayor Koch's call for a surcharge on city and commuter income taxes, saying that New York would have more money in the next fiscal year than the Mayor has predicted.

title: Republic Air's New Campaign
description: The ad campaign with which Campbell-Mithun, Minneapolis, won the $20 million Republic Airlines account will start running in a limited number of markets today. And then it will build itself into a crescendo of network advertising, all heralding this patriotic line: ''Nobody serves our republic like Republic.''

title: OPERA: 'TANNHAUSER' RECAST
description: THE Metropolitan Opera virtually repopulated its production of Wagner's ''Tannhauser'' Saturday night. Gwynn Cornell and Gerd Brenneis became the new Venus and Tannhauser; John Macurdy sang the Landgrave and Timothy Jenkins and Richard Vernon were Walther and Reinmar.

title: WEATHER DELAYS SEARCH IN CRASH
description: Because of subzero temperatures today, Government diving teams postponed until Monday the difficult task of recovering the two ''black box'' recorders that could provide solid clues to the cause of the crash of an Air Florida Boeing 737 jetliner Wednesday.

title: MEET EXEMPLIFIED FORTITUDE
description: One key to success in any sport is the ability to overcome adversity. Carl Lewis, Mary Decker and Alberto Salazar demonstrated that Saturday night as they achieved notable victories in the Vitalis/United States Olympic Invitational, the first major indoor track meet of the winter in the East.

title: SOVIET BOOKLET ATTACKS U.S. ARMS POLICY
description: The Soviet Defense Ministry has printed an elaborate booklet on United States military strength in which it argues that the Reagan Administration's strategy is to develop the country's nuclear forces to the point that ''a pre-emptive strike'' against the Soviet Union becomes possible in this decade.

title: JAZZ AT SAVOY: JACO PASTORIUS
description: bass player from the influential jazz-fusion band Weather Report, is the master of a quiveringly sensual style that is instantly recognizable. With its silky chromaticism and melancholy hornlike sighs, his playing suggests the sensibility of a true romantic.

title: RETAIL MERCHANTS TRY NEW METHODS TO BOLSTER PROFITS
description: Facing an uncertain first fiscal quarter, merchants in cities throughout the country are hoping that some new ideas they are trying this year will brighten their prospects.

title: JERSEY IS TOLD TO HASTEN ITS SPENDING ON TRANSIT
description: A Federal transportation official has charged that New Jersey is moving too slowly to spend some of the $608 million in Federal funds allocated for commuter-rail improvements and has warned that inflation is eroding the purchasing power of the money.

title: LENDL TAKES 5-SET FINAL
description: No one could question Ivan Lendl's courage yesterday at Madison Square Garden. Trailing by two sets to love and facing match point in a third-set tiebreaker, he rebounded for a five-set victory over Vitas Gerulaitis and took the $100,000 top prize in the Volvo Masters tennis tournament.

title: Victim of Drowning In Crash Is Identified
description: Dr. James L. Luke, the city's Chief Medical Examiner, said that the one drowning victim among those who died in the crash of the Air Florida jet Wednesday had been identified as Arland D. Williams, 46 years old, an employee of the Federal Reserve Board in Miami. Mr. Williams was described as a balding man with a beard.

title: Women's League Left With 2 Teams
description: The Women's Basketbal l League has apparently folded, according to a spokesman for the Nebr aska Wranglers, last season's champion.

title: Index; International
description: Blacks find a niche in South Afri- can suburban life A2 Many in Philippines doubt value of ending martial law A3 Micronesians are troubled by is- lands' lack of development A3 Around the World A4 Czechoslovak culture aide de- fends conditions for artists A6 Greek Socialists seek to end prison terms for adultery A6 Turkey ending its four-year ban on coffee imports A7 Study finds U.N. diplomats are largely disillusioned A8 France's nationalization pro- gram delayed A10 Government/Politics Jersey is warned about the slow pace of transit spending B2 State panel to study effects of A.T.&T. agreement B3 Efforts to strengthen budget act given slim chance B6 Washington Talk Briefing A14 Businessmen find Craig Spence a useful guide to the capital A14 Q&A: Samuel R. Pierce Jr., H.U.D. Secretary A14 General Around the Nation A12 Troubled young woman seeks aid at city office B3 Theories are many but cold is cold whatever the meteorology B5 Industry/Labor Ford says G.M. did not tell it of plans on cutting car prices A13 PARKING REGULATIONS Because of snow, alternate-side parking is suspended in New York City today. All other rules remain in effect. SportsMonday Basketball: 76ers' Dawkins breaks shin in loss to Nets C1

title: FIRST, COHERENT POLICY
description: A year ago, it was being said that it was dangerous to isolate one topic as the sole object of negotiation; linkage was the watchword. Arms control, in that concept, had to follow a military buildup and proceed on a broad front. High-level meetings were to reflect careful preparation and reward restrained Soviet conduct. All these premises are being cast overboard as negotiations at the highest levels continue while the vestiges of freedom in Poland are being snuffed out. Every Administration learns from experience, of course, but drastic reversals, especially midway in a crisis, run the risk of appearing panicky, of undermining credibil ity abroad and demoralizing well-wishers at home.

title: West Beats East In Japan, 28-17
description: Sam King, a quarterback from Nevada-Las Vegas, ran for a touchdown and passed for another today to lead the West team of American senior all-stars to a 28-17 victory over the East in the Japan Bowl.

title: Berbick Expecting To Fight Weaver
description: Trevor Berbick, the Canadian and Commonwealth heavyweight boxing champion, said Saturday that he was close to a deal to fight Mike Weaver in Z imbabwe in March.

title: New Trident Submarine Test-Fires First Missile
description: The $1.2 billion Ohio, the first of a new type of Trident submarines, fired its first Trident missile today about 50 miles off the Florida coast, the officials said.

title: Races Called Off
description: Officials canceled yesterday's thoroughbred racing program at Aqueduct when jockeys voted not to ride because of the cold weather. The stakes race, the Affectionately, will be rescheduled. Racing will be held today, weather permitting.

title: U.S. Oil Output F ell 6.2% in '81
description: The American Petroleum Institute, a private trade association, estimated that 1981 domestic oil production averaged 15.9 million barrels a day, a 6.2 percent drop from 1980.

title: Nordiques 7, Jets 5
description: The Nordiques' Stastny brothers - Peter, Anton and Marian - combined to score 11 points.

title: 'DEBT-EQUITY SWAPS' HELP PARE BOND DEBT
description: With a telephone call earlier this month, Ralph W. Babb Jr. wrapped up a deal that earned a quick, tax-free, $3 million for his company, the Mercantile Bancorporation of St. Louis.

title: Knight's Decorum Irks the Buckeyes
description: Troy Tayl or, a freshman guard forOhio State, experienced the wrath of Bobby Kn ight Saturday and described the Indiana coach as ''very impolit e, win or lose.''

title: GREEK SOCIALISTS WILL TRY TO ABOLISH JAIL TERMS FOR ADULTERY
description: The Greek Socialist Government is extending its drive for social change by seeking the abolition of adultery as a crime punishable by jail.

title: CITY ACTION CENTER REPORTS PLEAS FOR AID ARE INCREASING
description: A New York City office that handles citizens' complaints has found that in recent months more and more New Yorkers have been telephoning or coming to it because of economic hardship or because they are no longer a ble to deal with the problems of ever yday life.

title: No Headline
description: Lakers, Paced by Johnson, Defeat Kings by 109-97

title: It's the One Wins At Santa Anita
description: It's the One scored an upset victoryin the $140,900 San Fernando Stakes at Santa Anita today, with the even-money favorite, Island Whirl, finishing last in the mile-and-aneighth event.

title: Advice to Parents
description: Dr. Jack Llewellyn, a psychologist who specializes in sports, conducted a clinic yesterday in Detroit for parents of young athletes. He is director of the National Football League Alumni's Youth Program, which is attempting to advise parents about the proper way to handle their upcoming stars.

title: No Headline
description: SYRACUSE BREAKS GEORGETOWN STREAK

title: Demographic Battle Continues to Rage
description: In the hard-fought battle for corporate advertising dollars, C. John Kirby is pressing his efforts to undermine advertiser confidence in his major competition, the demographic editions of the newsweeklies.

title: Rutgers Is First
description: Rutgers got impressive performances in the 55-meter dash, the triple jump and the relays to overcome an early lead by Princeton and capture the 13th annual New Jersey college indoor track and field championships today at Jadwin Gymnasium.

title: CIVILIAN RULE FAILS TO UNITE FILIPINOS
description: A year ago today, President Ferdinand E. Marcos ended 8 years, 3 months and 26 days of martial law and proclaimed a ''new republi c'' in the Philippines.

title: Wallace B. BISHOP, CARTOONIST OF 'MUGGS AND SKEETER' STRIP
description: Wallace B. (Wally) Bishop, who drew the syndicated comic strip "Muggs and Skeeter" from 1927 to 1974, died Fr iday after a long illness.

title: 3 NURSING HOMES ARE STRUCK
description: A strike by 250 workers at three nursing homes in South Jersey entered its second day today, with the management of the homes asserting that their operations had not been significantly affected.

title: J I Case Layoffs
description: The J I Case Company, hurt by prolonged sluggish demand for its farm equipment products, said it had laid off 65 salaried corporate staff e mployees at its headquarters in Racine , Wis. Jerome K. Green, president of Case, said that the decision to reduce the executive staff was due entirely ''to the poor conditio n of the markets served by the company and a need to streamline the o perations of the corporate headquarters.'' Case is a subsidiar y of Tenneco Inc.

title: Cowboy Assistant Rejects S.M.U. Bid
description: Southern Methodist University's top three prospects to be its new football coach have decided to remain where they are.

title: A RAGE TO JUDGE
description: For possession and sale of nine ounces of marijuana, Roger Trenton Davis was sentenced by a Virginia jury and judge in 1974 to 40 years in prison. He was from the little town of Wytheville, and some people thought the sentence had something to do with the fact, not popular in Wytheville - that Mr. Davis was a black man married to a white woman.

title: Flames 5, Rockies 3
description: DENVER (AP) - Lanny McDonald scored the decisive goal with just under five minutes to play and Ken Houston got 3 goals to lead Calgary.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Brothers of the broken nation, get together, for we have to defend ourselves by ourselves, because no one is going to help us!'' - Archbishop Jozef Glemp, Primate of Poland. (A1:4.)

title: URANIUM, PLUTONIUM AND RESEARCH REACTORS
description: To the Editor:

title: Moscow Issues Works Of a Popular Satirist
description: The Soviet authorities have for the first time allowed publication of a collection of songs by Vladimir Vysotsky, a singer and actor whose death touched off an unruly gathering of thouands of mourners in Moscow 18 months ago.

title: PIRACY IN THE SOUTH CHINA SEA
description: On Sept. 25 Burton T. Kyle, director of the Office of Ship Operations of the Maritime Administration in Washington, sent out this advisory to international fleet managers:

title: News An alysis
description: The Reagan Administration has clearly taken a gamble in the bitter dispute between Washington and Peking over the sale of fighter planes to Taiwan, a gamble that rests on the assumption that China needs the United States more than the other way around.

title: Wanted: New Space for Oil
description: WASHINGTON MANAGERS of the nation's Strategic Petroleum Reserve, housed in underground salt caverns at five sites in Louisiana and Texas, seem never to get a respite. First there was the embarrassing problem of failing to install the equipment needed to draw the oil out. Then in April 1979, after the revolution in Iran, the Government stopped buying oil fo r fear of driving world prices still higher.

title: Manila Officials Investigat ing Reported Strafing of Tan ker
description: Philippine authorities are investigating the reported strafing of a Japanese chemical tanker by two unidentified fighter planes, a military source said today. The Japanes e Foreign Ministry in Tokyo said it had asked the Philippine Go vernment for more information. The Philipp ine military source said the office of the armed forces chief, Gen. F abian C. Ver, was informed of the incident, which reportedly oc curred Friday while the 5,307-ton tanker Hegg was cruising off Mindanao en route to Pusan, South Korea from Singapore.

title: THEORIES ABOUND, BUT COLD IS COLD NO MATTER WHY
description: There are elaborate scientific theories, crackpot notions, informed speculations, suggestions out of folklore and just plain wild guesses. But no one is sure why much of the United States has been plunged this month into what some experts call the coldest weather of the century.

title: AVANT-GARDE: JEFFREY LOHN'S NEW YORK
description: ''THEORETICAL MUSIC'' is not a title Jeffrey Lohn wants taken lightly, even though his new work heard at the Dance Theater Workshop on Saturday night was scored for five electric guitars, two electric keyboards and percussion. The work's first parts are ''Hypothesis'' and ''Refutation.''

title: Labor Executive, 70, Granted Order on Life Supports, Dies
description: Andrew C. McLellan, who obtained a court ruling last week permitting disconnection of his hospital lifesupport systems, died today.

title: MODERN TIMES; Beeps
description: In the last several years, sitting in a movie theater, one would sometimes hear the beep of a doctor's paging device. In the last several months, there's a new and invariable electronic phenomenon.

title: Wilkison Wins
description: Tim Wilkison of the United States won an international men's Grand Prix open tennis title today, defeating Russell Simpson of New Zealand, 6-4, 6-4, 6-4.

title: By S. Lee Kanner
description: Question Box QUESTION: In a professional basketball game, say between the Knicks and the Nets, a Knick player attempts to pass the ball to a teammate. A Net player, however, bats the ball toward the sideline. The Knick player, attempting to recover the ball, lunges for it and catches it just as he steps out of bounds. Whose ball is it?

title: NEW FILM ON HOLOCAUST HAS PREMIERE IN CAPITAL
description: The Simon Wiesenthal Center of Los Angeles tonight presented the premiere of ''Genocide,'' a film on the Holocaust narrated by Elizabeth Taylor and Orson Welles, at the Kennedy Center. The coast group plans to distribute the film to commercial theaters across the nation.

title: MUSIC: DAVIS LEADS TIPPETT'S TRIPLE CONCERTO
description: MICHAEL TIPPETT'S Triple Concerto for Violin, Viola, Cello and Orchestra, which was given its premiere in London less than 18 months ago, has already racked up two New York performances. The first was given in November by the Pittsburgh Symphony, the second by the Boston Symphony Orchestra under the direction of Colin Davis at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday night.

title: Angels Continue Talks on Jackson
description: Gary Walker, the agent for Reggie Jackson, and the California Angels continued discussions of a contract offer today, The Los Angeles Herald Examiner reported.

title: NORTH CAROLINA SCHOOL'S RACIAL POLICY FOLLOWS A RATHER UNEVEN COLOR LINE
description: Several years ago a Hindu girl also attended without incident, according to Margaret Tic e, the yearbook and journalism adviser at the schools, which offer classes from kinderg arten through 12th grade.

title: STAGE: SERBAN DIRECTS 'ZASTROZZI' AT THE PUBLIC
description: ''AN idea is the product of an ordinary mind,'' says the title character of ''Zastrozzi,'' George F. Walker's new play at the Public Theater. By this line of reasoning, Mr. Walker must want us to conclude that he has an extraordinary mind, because he surely hasn't produced any new ideas in ''Zastrozzi.'' This trying 90-minute fable is a precious repackaging of other writers' thoughts - starting with those in Moliere's ''Don Juan'' and plodding onward through Camus and 1950's absurdist theater.

title: Economic Analysis
description: In its new economic scenario for the fiscal 1983 budget, the Reagan Administration is finally acknowledging that its commitment to a restrictive monetary policy imposes limits on its goals for economic growth.

title: LABOR IS READY FOR A JUST RECOVERY PROGRAM
description: To the Editor:

title: BRIEFING
description: W HEN martial law was declared in Poland, a number of Polish tourists and professionals visiting in this country became, in effect, frozen in their tracks, not seeking refugee status but not wanting to return home until they had a clearer idea of the crisis.

title: Churchman in Salvador Expresses Doubt on Vote
description: A leading church figure said today that elections for a constituent assembly scheduled for March could be used as an excuse for more violence and repression in El Salvador, where 30,000 people have been slain in two years. The Reagan Adminstration is backing the elections as a way to settle the civil war.

title: ON THE CUTBACKS IN H.U.D. PROGRAMS
description: Like many Federal officials, Samuel R. Pierce Jr., the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, has spent much of the past month resisting specific cuts in the budget of his agency.

title: NEW YORK PANEL WILL STUDY IMPACT OF A.T.& T. ACCORD
description: The chairman of the State Public Service Commission, concerned that the pending a ntitrust settlement between the Federal Government and the American Telephone and Telegraph Company ''could increase costs and affect the quality'' of local service, ha s ordered an inquiry into the agreement's potential effect on New York State customers.

title: Proxmire Seeks Repeal Of Congress Tax Break
description: Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, pl ans to introduce legislation to repeal what he calls an ''outrageous' ' tax break that members of Congress have voted themselves.

title: Article 176367 -- No Title
description: A patron at Sunland Park won the largest Big Q payoff in the history of the race track Saturday - $38,840 for a $2 bet, track officials said. The ticket-holder correctly predicted the first two horses in the 10th and 11th races.

title: Joyce A. Brauer, Lawyer, Married to Jon Weston
description: Joyce Ann Brauer, a lawyer in the Office of Legal Services of the New York City Board of Education, was married in New York yesterday to Jon Steven Weston, an assistant to the chancellor of the New York City Board of Education. Rabbi Samuel Berman performed the ceremony at the Harmonie Club.

title: PAINO: ARRAU PAIRS LISZET, BEETHOVEN
description: JUST as Mozart heard the young Beethoven and warned the world to watch out, so Beethoven, four years before his death, bestowed his blessing upon the 11-year-old Franz Liszt. Of course, Beethoven could no more have known where the young pianist's gifts would lead him than Mozart had known where Beethoven's would; still, it was illuminating to find two works by Romanticism's prophet paired with two by the prodigy he so clearly recognized in Saturday evening's Carnegie Hall offering by the noted Chilean-born pianist Claudio Arrau.

title: OKLAHOMA REPUBLICAN
description: John Jarman, who served 26 years as a Representative from Oklahoma, died Friday of cancer at Presbyterian Hospital here. He was 66 years old.

title: People
description: Eugene Lawler, Tom Lom and Neve Savage have been elected to the board of Compton Advertising.

title: Augustana Passer
description: When Ken Anderson leads the Bengals against the 49ers in the Super Bowl Sunday, he will have a man rooting for him whom he does not know. But he should. Eighty-one-year-old Carl Erbe was the quarterback in 1919 at Augustana College in Rock Island, Ill.

title: Commodities; Recovery In Copper Forecast
description: AS if copper futures traders had any doubt that the market in this key industrial metal was sagging, New York's Commodity Exchange provided confirmation last Wednesday when it cut speculative margins to $700 for each contract of 25,000 pounds from $900.

title: LET STOCKHOLDERS PAY THEIR CORPORATIONS' TAXES
description: To the Editor:

title: Coach's Achievement
