description: Except for a three-year hitch in the Air Force in World War II, Dominic Rosselli has spent most of his 66 years in his native city, Youngstown, on the northeastern border of Ohio. Even when he went to college, he did not wander too far, attending close-by Geneva, on the other side of the state line in Beaver Falls, Pa. But since his graduation, Youngstown State University had been virtually his only employer.

title: Cuban Marchers Accuse Miami Police of Brutality
description: Meeting in an emergency session, the Miami City Commission today passed a resolution calling on the Justice Department to investigate charges of police brutality at a demonstration by Cubans Saturday.

title: An Indoors Best
description: Evelyn Ashford was clocked in an indoors best of 5.64 seconds in the 50-yard dash and Renaldo Nehemiah held off Greg Foster in the 50-yard high hurdles today in the first Chicago Goodwill Indoor Games. Miss Ashford achieved her feat in a preliminary heat and then barely defeated Chandra Cheeseborough in the final. Her preliminary time erased the standard of 5.80 set in 1978 by Andrea Lynch of Britain.

title: FIORI DEFEATS KITE IN PLAYOFF
description: ''What can I say? Truthfully, I thought the tournament was over, and he had it won.'' The speaker was Ed Fiori, and he was talking about his 30-foot putt that he did not think would drop, a putt that won the 23d annual Bob Hope Desert Classic on the second hole of a sudden-death playoff with Tom Kite.

title: The U.N. Today; Jan. 18, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Scientific and Technical Subcom- mittee of the Committee on the Peace- ful Uses of Outer Space - 10:30 A.M.

title: NATIONAL PUBLIC RADIO DELAYS ACTION ON TAKEOVER OF U.P.I.
description: The board of directors of National Public Radio Friday postponed action on a proposal to take over the financially troubled United Press International.

title: GUITAR: FOLK MEETS BLUES
description: and-take program of eclectic roots music that is informative and witty as well as musically polished. This weekend, the duo played Folk City, where each presented what amounted to a personal history of his respective tradition, before they teamed up for some delightful duets of American folk and jazz tunes.

title: Miss Kaplan Wed To a Physician
description: At the Sutton Place Synagogue yesterday, Janice Kaplan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Kaplan of Newton Centre, Mass., was married to Dr. Ronald Dennett, son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Dennett of Great Neck, L.I. Rabbi David B. Kahane performed the ceremony.

title: CZECH CULTURE AIDE DEFENDS CONDITIONS FOR ARTISTS
description: ''The conditions for creative freedom,'' a high official of the Czechoslovak Culture Ministry said, ''are guaranteed to all artists who want to contribute to the develop ment of culture.''

title: 1,400 WORKERS AT YALE RATIFY A NEW CONTRACT
description: The 1,400 maintenance and dining-hall workers at Yale University last night ratified a new three-year contract with the university, which has been struck by the workers four times in the last 14 years.

title: JEFFRY GALLET WEDS DR. GAIL WASSERMAN
description: The marriage of Dr. Gail A. Wasserman, assistant professor of psychology in the department of psychiatry at the Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons, to Jeffry H. Gallet, a partner in the New York law firm of Gallet & Dreyer, took place in New York yesterday. Family Court Judge Leon Deutsch performed the ceremony at Columbia's Gould Boat House.

title: North Stars 7 Black Hawks 5
description: Steve Payne and Bobby Smith combined for seven points to lead Minnesota to its second consecutive victory for the first time Nov.11.

title: DANCE: 'ALLURE' BY MATTHEW NASH
description: MATTHEW NASH is drawn to issues of style, whether in writing, theater or fashion. He has an eye for line and sleek visual effect. And his wit can be wickedly telling. But Mr. Nash's new ''Allure,'' performed Saturday night at the Theater of the Riverside Church, goes beyond all that in a feat of theatrical juggling that has resulted in a piece that is surprisingly touching.

title: Bridge: Weather Pays a Dividend For Two in Regional Test
description: Hundreds of bridge players heading for the Tristate Regional Championships at the Rye Town Hilton, Port Chester, N.Y. had reason to curse the snow that blanketed the New York metropolitan area last week, but for two players the storm became an unexpected blessing.

title: 'Magic Flute' Ballet Recast
description: Helgi Tomasson and Katrina Killian will head the cast for the New York City Ballet premiere of Peter Martins's ''The Magic Flute'' on Thursday at the New York State Theater.

title: Topics Modern Times The Room at the Top
description: The formula is familiar: as an executive rises, the girth of his briefcase diminishes. A case overflowing with work marks the midechelon drone.

title: POLITICIANS SEE CAREY DECISION AS SETBACK FOR KOCH
description: Mayor Koch lost an ally in government - and some political leverage -at a critical period in city-state relations when Governor Carey announced that he would not seek a third term, according to state political leaders.

title: Prints Are on Display At the Queens Museum
description: Prints by such artists as Daumier, Delacroix, Gericault and Goya can be seen at the Queens Museum in Flushing through Sunday, Jan. 24, in ''Circa 1800,'' an exhibition tracing the history of European printmaking from 1775 to 1835.

title: CONCERT: COLLEGIATE CHORALE OFFERS PREMIERE AND REVI VAL
description: THe Collegiate Chorale brought two unusual works to Carnegie Hall Friday evening - each different in its own way. Undine Smith Moore's ''Scenes from the Life of a Martyr'' had its New York premiere.

title: MISS FLANDERS WINS DOWNHILL
description: Holly Flanders of Deerfield, N.H., scored an upset in a downhill race today for her first World Cup triumph and the first cup downhill victory by an American in three years.

title: SUPPLY SIDE ADVOCATE LEAVES THE TREASURY
description: Paul Craig Roberts, the Administration's most fervent advocate of supply-side economics, has resigned as an Assistant Secretary of the Treasury to accept appointment to the newly endowed William E. Simon chair in political economy at Georgetown University, it was announced today.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt THE VILLA GOLITSYN. By Piers Paul Read. 193 pages. Harper & Row. $13.95.

title: KENTUCKY UTILITIES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MATSUSHITA ELECTRIC INDUSTRIAL CO LTD reports earnings for Yr to Nov 30
description: Results are translated from Japanese yen at the rate of $1 equals 221 yen

title: TV: 'KING OF AMERICA,' STORY OF GREEK IMMIGRAN
description: T By JOHN J. O'CONNOR

title: Governor Says Oregon Is in Economic Crisis
description: Gov. Vic Atiyeh asked Oregon lawmakers today to declare a statewide economic emergency and to change what he called the state's anti-business image.

title: Alfa Layoffs
description: Alfa Romeo, the second-largest Italian auto maker, laid off 30,000 workers and closed its factories for three weeks to reduce a growing inventory.

title: News Analysis
description: Naim Chatta, one of the 288 people named to Pakistan's new Federal Advisory Council, has not yet taken his seat because his father, Mohammad Hussein Chatta, a onceprominent politician, has threatened to go on a hunger strike if he does.

title: PROPERTY TAX CUT PROPOSED BY ESSEX COUNTY EXECUTIVE
description: The Essex County Executive, Peter Shapiro, proposed today a cut of about 10 percent in the property tax rate for the county, which is New Jersey's most populous and includes the city of Newark.

title: MANY DELAYED
description: Thousands of commuters were delayed yesterday as record low temperatures delayed and stalled subways and commuter trains. As it had the day before, the temperature dropped to zero in the morning in Central Park. The reading, at 3:30, broke the previous record for the date, 1 degree, set in 1975. Elsewhere in the metropolitan area there were record lows of 5 below in Bridgeport, Conn., and 6 below at Newark International Airport.

title: COCA-COLA BOTTLING OF MIAMI INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
H&H OIL TOOL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Corrected from Saturday's editions

title: UNESCO PARLEY ON THE PRESS OPENS WITH U.S. OPPOSING MANY PLANS
description: An internationa l conference aimed at finding practical ways to strengthen journali sm and communications indeveloping countries began here today, with t he United States strongly opposed to a series of proposals tha t would increase government control of news.

title: ROWAN COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
THE DOCTOR'S WORLD
description: LEGIONNAIRE'S disease is only one of the ''new'' diseases that have seemed to crop up continually in the last 20 years or so. There were Lassa fever and Marburg virus disease - both contagious and potentially lethal. There were the Norwalk agent and the whole family of rotaviruses that are a principal cause of diarrheal disease or ''intestinal flu'' among infants throughout the world.

title: News Summary; News Summary; TUESDAY, JANUARY 19, 1982
description: International A U.S. military attache was slain outside his home in Paris by a solitary gunman who escaped. The murder of Lieut. Col. Charles Robert Ray came two months after the attempted shooting of Christian A. Chapman, charge d'affaires at the American Embassy. The police called the two attacks very similar. (Page A1, Column 3.) Thousands of Indians were arrested in advance of a one-day national strike called for today to protest the economic policies of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi. Most of those seized are union activists. (A1:1.)

title: COMMERCIAL INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-Including $281,787, or 6 cents a share, gain for the quarter and 6 months from discontinued operations

title: GREECE WILL RESUME SERVICING OF VESSELS FOR THE SOVIET UNION
description: The Government confirmed tonight that it had reached an agreement with the Soviet Union to resume repairing its commercial and naval supply ships, a practice that the United States has criticized.

title: XIDEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
News Analysis
description: Mayor Koch's preliminary plans to balance his budget for the next fiscal year rest in good part on dozens of proposed efficiencies and changes in the way certain segments of local government go about their daily business.

title: Index; International

All other rules remain in effect. title: French Stock Trading Halt
description: France's economics minister, Jacques Delors, has told officials of the Paris Stock Exchange to suspend trading in the stocks of banks and companies due to be nationalized, a spokesman at the ministry said today.

title: Harvester Plants
description: Production has resumed at 16 United States manufacturing plants of the International Harvester Company, officials said.

title: It's Still Tax-Exempt Hate
description: White House post-mortems notwithstanding, the decision to give tax breaks to segregated private schools cannot be blamed on bad staffing or inept politics. The excuses fail for a simple reason: the President clings to the new racist policy. Even after being fully informed, he wants to start granting those exemptions and keep on going until Congress passes a new law forbidding them.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Chase Manhattan Bank has appointed Leslie N. Fineman, Gary S. Hett, Gail E. Horowitz, Charles J. McGlynn, Daniel W. McLaughlin, M. Beth Miller, Patricia H. Nelson, Judy A. Neville, Thomas P. Hurley, Won-Hyuck, Shital P. Jain, Susan L. Pearson, Paul H. Quinn, and Robert W. Mansour as vice presidents.

title: Staten Island 75, Wagner 69
description: Tom Johnson led the way with 26 points and Nat Harris added 25 as the second-ranked Division III team in the nation won at home. The Dolphins (13-1) took a 1-point lead with 15 minutes to play and were never headed, though Wagner cut the deficit to 73-69 with 13 seconds left. Wagner (3-11) was paced Bob Mahala's 15 points.

title: Manila Acknowledges Strafing Japanese Ship
description: The Government said today its warplanes strafed a Japanese tanker but claimed self-defense, saying the boat ignored warning shots to stop and was suspected of ferrying insurgents and weapons.

title: MISS LIEBERMAN FIGHTS FOR LEAGUE
description: A few years ago, a fund-raising event for women's athletics was held at the Stock Exchange here, and that is where Nancy Lieberman met Muhammad Ali.

title: DRAFT REGISTRATION'S SLIGHT DEFENSE CONTRIBUTION
description: T o the Editor: The arguments offered in favor of the continuation of Selective Service registration point to the amount of time that would be saved upon mobilization. Estimates range from seven days to six weeks.

title: Continental Illinois And Chase Surge
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation, the nation's third-largest bank holding company, reported yesterday that its earnings soared 99.2 percent in the fourth quarter of 1981, to $153.6 million, from $77.1 million earned in the comparable period of 1980. Chase's earnings per share rose to $4.40, from $2.12.

title: BEEHIVE INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago share earnings and shares outstanding have been adjusted for a 2-for-1stock split in January 1981

title: Bond Gains Help Dow Rise 7.52, to 855.12
description: The stock market, buoyed by a sharp rise in bond prices, rebounded in late trading and ended moderately higher. The strongest performers were some of the technology, blue-chip and energy issues.

title: Masters Format Faces Change
description: Changes in the format for next year's Volvo Masters tennis tournament now seem likely following the erratic performances of some of the players last week and the confusion over scheduling.

title: FIDDLING WITH THE THERMOSTAT
description: Barbara O'Connor said she and her husband were ''about to strangle each other'' in a struggle for control of the thermostat.

title: New York; FAIRNESS IN HARD TIMES
description: The forecast is cold and biting. And it has nothing to do with the weather. Governor Carey's state budget is a grim one, which portends an equally grim austerity for Mayor Koch's budget for the next fiscal year.

title: Articles on Detroit Man Are Ruled Not Libelous
description: A Federal appeals court said today that articles in Newsweek magazine and The Detroit News that described Leonard Schultz as a ''Detroit underworld figure'' and a ''key figure'' in the investigation of the disappearance of Jimmy Hoffa, the former president of the Teamsters Union, were not libelous.

title: WHEN EXTRADITION LAWS ARE TAINTED BY A COUNTRY'S POLITICS
description: To the Editor:

title: Brown Capitalizes on Pinter's U.S. Visit
description: When Arthur Cantor obtained the North American rights to Harold Pinter's latest play, ''The Hothouse,'' he persuaded the Trinity Square Repertory Company in Providence, R.I., to stage the American premiere, then asked Mr. Pinter to help with rehearsals, which begin next week.

title: 7 Drug Arrests in Tennessee
description: Narcotics agents arrested seven people and confiscated marijuana and cash late Sunday and early today after they caught a drug-laden airplane being unloaded at an airport near here, officials said. The plane's pilot managed to fly away in a hail of gunfire when the police began to move in at Everett-Stewart Airport, Obion County Sheriff Danny Cunningham said.

title: SOCIETY FORMED TO BRING THEM BACK ALIVE
description: EVERY seeker after lost, legendary or otherwise mysterious creatures on the earth finds encouragement in the story of the okapi, and these are the people who have formed a new scientific group, the International Society of Cryptozoology, and adopted the giraffelike animal as its symbol.

title: CHAMPION INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After a loss of $18,277,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter and year and a tax credit of $6,062,000 for the quarter; C-After a loss of $18,375,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter and year, a tax credit of $683,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary charge of $16,977,000 for the year for the settlement and related expenses of certain antitrust litigation

title: Internorth Chief Calls Bucyrus an Investment
description: Internorth Inc., an Omaha-based natural gas and liquid fuels company, and the Bucyrus-Erie Company, a manufacturer of mining and construction equipment with headquarters in South Milwaukee, Wis., have been communicating in recent days by press release. And Sam F. Segnar, president and chief executive officer of Internorth - which recently bought 8.8 percent of Bucyrus-Erie - does not want to say much more on the telephone.

title: Fordham 80, UMass 65
description: David Maxwell, a junior guard, scored 20 points to lead Fordham at home. The Rams (9-6) took an 11-2 lead over Massachusetts, which committed 17 turnovers in the first half, after three minutes and led by 40-29 at the half. Donald Russell led Massachusetts (6-8) with 26 points.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE;
description: Ray Knight, who joined the Houston Astros from Cincinnati last month in a trade for Cesar Cedeno, has signed a five-year contract for $2.6 million. The announcement was made by General Manager Al Rosen, who also reported that Knight would remain at his regular position, third base, and that Art Howe would move back to first.

title: REP. RICHMOND PAYROLL RAISES ETHICS QUESTIONS
description: Congressional aides of Representative Frederick W. Richmond of Brooklyn received pay and expenses from several private and corporate accounts, according to some of Mr. Richmond's former aides and others familiar with some of the arrangements.

title: JONES INTERCABLE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
ASEPTIC PACKAGING IS TESTED IN U.S. AS AN ENERGY SAVER
description: One company is calling it the Paper Bottle. It looks like a cereal box but you need a straw rather than a spoon to remove the contents. To Americans who have traveled outside this country, a flexible carton of fruit juice or milk that requires n o refrigeration is not unusual. The aseptic packaging system, introd uced more than 20 years ago, is used extensively in countries where r efrigeration, transportation and storage facilities are lim ited. In 1980, about 50 billiion units were sold worldwide.

title: Savin Unit Sets An Acquisition
description: The Savin Corporation said that a subsidiary would purchase the assets of Savin Associates, a limited partnership, recently organized for the marketing of word and data processing products under development by Savin.

title: Algae Kill Competitors
description: Much like humans, many biological organisms have evolved weapons of one sort or another to enable them to fight off competitors. Certain molds, for example, produce penicillin, which attacks bacteria.

title: RAMTEK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
APPLIED MAGNETICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including net income from discontinued operations of $462,000, or 9 cents a share

title: BECKMAN INSTRUMENTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
THE DANCE: NEW AND RECENT CHOREOGRAPHY BY BILL CRATTY
description: PEOPLE sat up and took notice when a work by a relatively unfamiliar choreographer named Bill Cratty was presented last January by the Jose Limon Dance Company, with which he performs. It stood out in a program of dances by such august types as Mr. Limon, Doris Humphrey and Charles Weidman.

title: Brock Views S teel Impasse
description: Bill Brock, the United States trade representative, said today that he saw little hope for a negotiated settlement of the dispute between American steel companies and European producers.

title: BUSINESS-BACKED PANEL CRITICIZES COOKE'S PROPOSAL TO ROTATE JUDGES
description: The Citizens Crime Commission criticized yesterday a plan to rotate assignments for acting justices of the State Supreme Court in New York City.

title: BOSTON'S TRANSIT CHIEF GOES ON TRIAL IN KICKBACK CASE
description: At the start of a major corruption trial today that could affect Gov. Edward J. King's re-election campaign this year, the suspended State Secretary of Transportation was accused of receiving $60,000 in illegal kickbacks.

title: MUSIC: 3 MANNES ALUMNI REUNITED AT BENEFIT
description: THREE alumni of the Mannes College of Music joined forces with the Mannes Orchestra on Sunday at Avery Fisher Hall in a program of works from the 19th-century's concert and operatic stage. The event was the school's annual benefit concert, but in some ways the real beneficiary was Beethoven, whose Piano Concerto No. 4 in G (Op. 58) elicited a classic performance from the pianist Eugene Istomin, one of the three former students who volunteered their services.

title: 2 EXILE COMMUNITIES PROTEST IN MIAMI
description: Protest has at times seemed the lifeblood of Miami's Latin community, which now makes up 58 percent of the city's population, but until this weekend no protest had been marked by violence, nor, according to participants in a Saturday night demonstration, had there been such a sense of personal loss.

title: Exxon U.S.A Sets '82 Capital Budget
description: The Exxon Company U.S.A. announced that its 1982 capital and exploration spending is expected to rise 25 percent to a record total of $6 billion. Oil and gas exploration and production will account for about $5 billion, up 20 percent compared with 1981, the company said.

title: By Jack Rosenthal
description: The Editorial Notebook Political Lib

title: Fannie Mae Loses $70 Million
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association, the nation's largest purchaser of home loans, yesterday reported from Washington a fourth-quarter loss of $70.7 million, or $1.20 a share, in contrast to net income of $700,000, or 1 cent a share, in the fourth quarter of 1980. The loss was attributed to the high cost of funds.

title: In the Nation; WHERE THE BUCK STOPS
description: All right, Ronald Reagan is not a racist. The White House tells us that, instead, he's an uninformed and uninvolved President who on an important question of domestic policy didn't know what he was doing.

title: TOMLINSON OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-Net income including $537,000 tax credit

title: U.S. ARMY AIDE IS SLAIN IN PARIS NEAR HIS HOME
description: An American military attache was shot dead outside his home this morning by a solitary gunman. The killing of the attache, Lieut. Col. Charles Robert Ray, came two months after the attempted shooting of Christian A. Chapman, the charge d'affaires at the United States Embassy here. The police said the two attacks, which they assumed were the work of a terrorist group, had ''a great similarity,'' but they were not able to identify the group involved. Mitterrand Calls It 'Dastardly'

title: TUESDAY, JANUARY 19, 1982; Companies
description: An agreement for Coca-Cola to acquire Columbia Pictures in a $750 million transaction is expected to be announced today. The proposal is said to call for an offer of $74 a share in cash and stock for the profitable film company's 10.7 million shares outstanding. The acquisition would be the first major one under Roberto O. Goizueta, who took over Coca-Cola last March. (Page A1.)

title: DAMASCUS REPORTS MOSCOW ARMS PACT
description: The Soviet Union has agreed to provide the Syrian armed forces with more arms, a Government-controlled Damascus newspaper reported today.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Citicorp said the proposed sale of two Hong Kong subsidiaries of its Grindlays Bank affiliate, of which it owns 49 percent, should result in an aftertax profit for Citicorp of between $15 million and $20 million, probably in the first quarter of 1982.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: WRITERS

title: Platt Leaving Tiffany's March 1
description: Henry B. Platt, a great-great-grandson of the founder of Tiffany & Company who g ave up the titles of chairman and chief executive officer last June, announced yesterday that he would retire on March 1 at the age of 58. Mr. Platt had been succeeded as head of the jewelry and s ilverware retailer and producer after five months in thepost by David W. Mitchell, chairman of Avon Products Inc., the cosmetics and fragrance producer that acquired Tiffany in 1979 for $104 million in stock.

title: Mexican Bus Strike Ends
description: Bus service in Mexico City returned to normal today after a wildcat strike by bus drivers caused weekend disruptions. Negotiators ratified an agreement to end the strike in the Department of Labor Sunday. The main points of contention remain to be resolved after a referendum to determine which union will represent the drivers.

title: TV: 'MARIAN ROSE WHITE,' IN A MENTAL INSTITUTION
description: MARIAN ROSE WHITE is a California woman who as a 9-year-old was committed to a state mental institution and spent much of her life confined there. Though her ordeal lasted 30 years, it has been condensed, by the magic of television, to span only four. But it's an ordeal all the same, and it's been very ably presented. ''Marian Rose White,'' which will be shown tonight at 9 o'clock on CBS-TV, is an involving, well-executed movie that is at least as harrowing as it is inspiring.

title: ATI INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 27
description: B-Including tax credit of $33,531 for quarter and year; C-Net loss; D-Net income; corrected from Wednesday's editions

title: EASING OF MILK CURBS SOUGHT
description: Restrictions on milk sales should be relaxed, a New York State agency said yesterday. The State Office of Business Permits recommended that milk marketing licenses not be restricted by territory or be denied merely because they might ''tend to a destructive competition.''

title: LABOR DEPT. PROPOSES VOLUNTARY WORKER SAFETY PLANS
description: Voluntary worker protection plans that could eliminate many functions of the Occupational Safety and Health Administration were proposed today by the Department of Labor.

title: POLE DOUBTS SPEEDY END OF MARTIAL LAW OR EARLY FREEING OF WALESA
description: The Government tried to dampen speculation today that Lech Walesa would be released from house arrest soon and that martial law would be lifted in the near future.

title: Marriott Filing
description: The Marriott Corporation said that it had filed with the Securities and Exchange Commissio n a registration statement for a proposed offe ring of limited partnership interests to develop and operate 11 ho tels. Marriott said the hotels would be operated as partof the Marrio tt system. A group of commercial banks has agreed to lend the part nership, of which Marriott will act as general partner, up to $456.3 million to finance the acquisition, construction and operation of the hotels.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Why can only one side of the moon be viewed from Earth?

title: PIANO: ROSEN PLAYS ALL-BEETHOVEN
description: THE pianist who plays an all-Beethoven program has a universe of music to choose from, so ordinarily it does not make sense to confine the recital within the bounds of any of the so-called three periods of the composer's career. Even the mighty last sonatas, though often lumped together on philosophical grounds, can add up to total exhaustion for both performer and audience - in fact, must do so, if the player and the listener absorb themselves properly in the music. So, Charles Rosen set himself a challenge last night at Carnegie Hall when he offered a program that consisted of four sonatas from Beethoven's stormy middle period: Op. 31 (No. l, No. 2 and No. 3) and Op. 57, the ''Appassionata.''

title: HARTFORD SENATE SENDS A TAX BILL TO GOV. O'NEILL
description: The State Senate approved and sent to the Governor tonight a package of tax and fee increases designed to raise $36 million by July 1.

title: MCCORMICK & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
POLAND AND THE WESTERN 'PIPE DREAM'
description: To the Editor:

title: Trudging Tarantulas
description: In a laboratory on the Gainesville campus of the University of Florida, five big fuzzy tarantulas walk on a treadmill almost every day as their oxygen intake and energy output are recorded.

title: Tire Makers Increase Prices
description: The nation's top five tire makers are raising prices from 1.5 to 5.5 percent. The nation's largest tire producer, the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, said today it had raised prices an average 3.5 percent on passenger car, truck and heavy equipment tires on Jan. 1.

title: Howton Regretful
description: Billy Howton, the former all-pro end for the Green Bay Packers and an all-American at Rice, was sentenced in Houston last year to five years in prison in a fraud case involving $8 million. In a series of articles in The Houston Post, Howton, in Federal prison at Seagoville, Tex., says now that he is remorseful. ''You never fully appreciate things until you don't have them,'' he said.

title: AMERICAN HOME INDUSTRIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-Including $391,307 extraordinary tax credit; C-Net loss

title: SPARTAN MANUFACTURING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $783,000 for the quarter and $1,776,000 for the year; C-Net income after losses from discontinued operations of $199,000 for the quarter and $466,000 for the year

title: WELLS FARGO MORTGAGE & EQUITY TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
LOMAS & NETTLETON MORTGAGE INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
American Academy Honors Indian Author
description: R. K. Narayan, the 75-year-old Indian author of more than two dozen novels and collections of short stories woven around everyday life in his country, was inducted yesterday into the American Academy and Institute of Arts and Letters as an honorary member.

title: OOPS! REFEREE SAYS HE ERRED
description: Officials rarely admit they have made a mistake. But that is what Paul Mihalak has done. Unsolicited, he admitted that he missed a call that likely cost the Knicks a victory over the Suns last Thursday night in Phoenix.

title: COURIER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
OIL RICHES OFF CHINA'S SH ORES
description: China and Japan, joined by dozens of American and European oil companies with offshore technology and capital to offer, are preparing to pour billions of dollars into exploring the almost untouched offshore oil resources of China and the continental shelf between China and Japan.

title: Matsushita Net Increases 14%
description: The Matsushita Electric Industrial Company reported yesterday that net income rose 14 percent, to $378.3 million, or $2.65 a share, and sales increased 16 percent, to $10.62 billion, in the fiscal year ended Nov. 20, 1981.

title: Sports of The Times; Galoping Ghost is Heard From
description: THE Galloping Ghost never even breaks into a trot anymore. At 78, and perhaps still the most famous football player ever, Harold (Red) Grange looks in wonderment at joggers who go past his home in Indian Lake, Fla. ''I think they're crazy,'' he said by telephone recently. ''If you have a car, why run?''

title: Business Loans by Banks Rise
description: The Federal Reserve announced yesterday that business loans outstanding at large banks across the country rose $594 million in the week ended Jan. 6. Data on business loans extended by large banks are normally reported Friday, but were delayed last week because bad weather interferred with the gathering of statistics.

title: 4 Cooking Oil Deaths
description: The Health Ministry said today that four women died over the weekend from eating tainted cooking oil, raising the death toll to 249.

title: A SENSE OF ADVENTURE RETURNS TO MEN'S FASHION
description: The peacock revolution of the 1960's, which injected a volatile style element into the slow movement of men's fashions, is buried. The social upheavals of that decade have simmered down and so have the clothing styles they inspired. The Nehru jacket, wide ties, turtleneck shirts with dinner clothes, love beads and tie-dyed Tshirts are some of the innovations that lie, largely unmourned, in the graveyard of fashion history.

title: AN ACTING JUSTICE OFFERS TO JOIN MORGENTHAU SUIT
description: A Criminal Court judge has offered to join the Manhattan District Attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau, in his lawsuit against the state's Chief Judge, Lawrence H. Cooke. A hearing in the suit has been scheduled for noon today before Justice Andrew R. Tyler of State Supreme Court in Manhatta n.

title: Newspaper Boycott Begun
description: Editorial employees and photographers at The Pittsburgh Post-Gazette today started a byline and picture credit boycott to protest the slow pace of contract talks and the reported dismissal of a reporter. Em ployees h ave been working withouta contract since their old pact expired Dec 3 1.

title: London Panel Supports Charter for Canada
description: The British Parliament should approve a request by the Government of Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau of Canada to give his country complete control over its own Constitution, an all-party parliamentary committee said today.

title: Seiko and China In Watch Pact
description: The Seiko Group, Japan's largest watchmaker, announced it had reached agreement with China to establish a joint venture company in Hong Kong to assemble watches for worldwide export.

title: THE FALL AND RISE OF LEONARD HAYFLICK, BIOLOGIST WHOSE FIGHT WITH U.S.
description: SEEMS OVER By PHILIP M. BOFFEY

title: Reagan's First Year First of six articles.
description: Americans generally feel that President Reagan's program has hurt the economy so far, and this opinion is costing him support, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

title: ABBOTT REJECTS ACCOUNT OF HIM AS VIOLENT MAN
description: In a day of cross-examination at his murder trial yesterday, Jack Henry Abbott angrily denied the numerous charges of possession of weapons, stabbing and threatening inmates and guards that had been made against him in 24 years in Federal and state prisons.

title: TEAMSTER CONCESSIONS HAILED
description: The concessions announced by leaders of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters and the trucking industry last week indicate that the powerful union has decided that to save jobs, the industry must remain competitive with nonunion truckers, analysts and industry executives said yesterday.

title: JOSTENS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
KNOGO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
John Mills, Who Ran London Clubs, Is Dead
description: John Mills, who founded and operated some of London's favorite clubs for the rich and famous, died yesterday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York. A resident of Monaco, he was 68 years old.

title: SCIENCE WATCH
description: Supernovas Ever since it became evident that the explosions of massive stars produce extremely intense bursts of radiation, scientists have wondered how life on the earth might be affected if such an event occurred close by.

title: Phil Greenwald, Held Talent Post at Concord
description: Phil Greenwald, director of entertainment at the Concord Hotel for 35 years, died yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 63 years old and lived in Hewlett Harbor, L.I.

title: I.R.A. Disrupts Rail Traffic
description: Irish Republican Army guerrillas stopped rail traffic between Belfast and Dublin today by ditching a hijacked gasoline truck under a railroad bridge near the border with the Irish Republic. Policemen sealed off the area, evacuated several houses and called in bomb disposal experts after a warning from the I.R.A. that the truck was booby-trapped.

title: BEVERAGE MANAGEMENT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
description: B-Including a gain of $669,000 from a change in the method of accounting for soft drink returnable containers

title: Market Place; Analysts Differ Over E.D.S.
description: THE Electronic Data Systems Corporation is doing well at a time when some other computer service companies are suffering in the recession.

title: 'DOOR OPEN' TO FURTHER MEETINGS
description: The United States said today after discussions in Paris with a high-level Angolan delegation that the ''door remains open'' to further talks.

title: NEW DONOR TO NEEDIEST CASES HOPES TO ESTABLISH TRADITION
description: ''For years we have procrastinated in sending a contribution even though we are aware of the direct assistance given to the needy in our area by your Fund,'' Louise and Gilbert Hodges of Manhattan said in a letter accompanying a $50 donation to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. ''This year, we decided to make the Fund our first outlay for the new year and hope to do the same in succeeding years.''

title: SCIENCE WATCH
description: Toxic Shock Though most cases are still associated with menstruation and tampon use, toxic shock syndrome has occurred following surgery and childbirth, in patients with abscesses, boils and skin infections, and in burn patients.

title: Weaver Trying to Block Holmes-Cooney Fight
description: A Superior Court judge issued a temporary restraining order today to halt the promotion and ticket sales for the World Boxing Council heavyweight title fight between champion Larry Holmes and Gerry Cooney.

title: DRECO ENERGY SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Javits Bids Allies Hold More Top-Level Talks
description: Terming the ''disharmony'' among the NATO countries ''our greatest weakness,'' former Senator Jacob K. Javits urged yesterday that meetings among the top leaders of Western nations become a regular and institutionalized element of diplomacy.

title: CORRECTION
description: A brief news article by Reuters in Business Day yesterday mislabeled an oil industry statistic. The American Petroleum Institute said that the supply of petroleum products last year, a measure of domestic demand, averaged 15.9 million barrels daily, down 6.2 percent from 1980.

title: 'BERSERK' FATHER KILLS DAUGHTER, TAKES OWN LIFE
description: A 37-year-old man who had been having marital probl ems apparently went berserk this morning, firing at least 12 shot s with an automatic pistol and killing his young daughter, wou nding his wife and two sons and taking his own life, thepolice said.

title: CREDIT MARKETS
description: Interest Rates Move Lower By MICHAEL QUINT

title: MASS EXTINCTIONS INCREASINGLY BLAMED ON CASTROPHES FROM THE SKY
description: THE catastrophes have come repeatedly. Since life first appeared on earth, large percentages of the world's plants and animals have been wiped out in mass extinctions. Few scientific puzzles are more tantalizing than these calamities. Recently, at more than two dozen sites around the world, scientists have found geological evidence of a catastrophe 65 million years ago that apparently eliminated a large part of oceanic life.

title: FINANCIAL BRIEFS
description: * Esmark Inc. has entered into an agreement with Salomon Brothers Inc. that allows Salomon Brothers to exchange between $20 million and $30 million aggregate principal amount of Esmark's outstanding 9 1/4 percent sinking fund debentures due Feb. 1, 2000, for shares of Esmark common stock held in the company's treasury.

title: BONN PAYS THE PIPER
description: The unity displayed last week in Brussels when the North Atlantic Treaty Organization warned that it might comply with Washington's demands to impose economic sanctions against the Soviet Union was more symbolic than real.

title: F.B.I. Says Williams Altered His Story
description: Wayne B. Williams changed several details in two accounts he gave the authorities regarding his movements the night he was stopped near the Chattahoochee River, a Federal agent testified today at Mr. Williams's murder trial.

title: Moody's Reduces Pacific Gas Rating
description: Moody's Investors Service said it had reduced its ratings to A from AA on the 44 publicly held first and refunding bond issues on the Pacific Gas and Electric Company. In addition, the company's three secured pollution control revenue bond issues were lowered to A. The company's preferred stock will continue to be rated A and its prime-1 commercial paper rating is unchanged.

title: BOSTON OPERA TO OPEN LATE
description: The Opera Company of Boston's opening has been canceled because of a dispute with the company's orchestra. Sarah Caldwell, the company's artistic director, notified orchestra members by telegram on Saturday that the American premiere performances of Bernd Alois Zimmermann's ''Die Soldaten'' on Jan. 31 and Feb. 4, 6 and 7 had been canceled.

title: TRANSAMERICA INCOME SHARES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BOUTIQUES: NOTABLE NEWCOMERS
description: Every few months, it seems, a whole new crop of boutiques offers a whole new crop of wares for dedicated shoppers. Some of the best new ones to open in New York this winter have very definite points of view and their own special brand of fashions.

title: TEXAS PACIFIC LAND TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings figures represent sub-shares

title: New Car Inventories
description: Manufacturers' inventories of unsold new cars made in North America was a record 107-day supply on Jan. 1, the trade journal Automotive News said today.

title: Reagan News Session
description: Scheduled for Today

title: A 'CHARADE' FOR EL SALVADOR, WITH U.S. BLESSINGS
description: To the Editor:

title: TIGER INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes $7 million gain from sale of tax and appreciation benefits for the quarter and $17.7 million gain from the sale of aircraft for the year and $2.9 million gain for the year from the sale of mortgage insurance subsidiary and $12.5million writedown relating to certain aircraft and leasing assets for both the quarter and the year; C-Net income including $10 million gain from the sale of areal estate partnership

title: Dior-New York Hires A J.W.T. Subsidiary
description: Christian Dior-New York, maker of men's and women's clothing, thinks that its advertising needs have outgrown its in-house capability.

title: REPORTERS' SHIELD LAW OVERRULED
description: A law permitting reporters to withhold their sources, adopted by California voters in 1980, was declared unconstitutional today by a Superior Court judge on the ground that it created unsupportable conflict with the constitutional right to a fair trial.

title: Bridge: An Unknown Partnership Accomplishes a Rare Feat
description: Winning major titles in the New York metropolitan area is more difficult than anywhere else in North America. For two unknown players to win a regional title in the area is rare; for them to win two titles is almost unheard of.

title: the Hostage Crisis: One Year Later Last of three articles
description: The storming of the United States Embassy in Teheran in November 1979 was the first of three incidents that changed State Department thinking on how to protect American lives and property abroad.

title: HONEYWELL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including extraordinary credits of $600,000, or 3 cents a share, for the quarter, and $3 million, or 13 cents share, for the year; C-Including extraordinary credits of $11 million, or 49 cents a share, for the quarter and $12.6 million, or 56 cents a share, for the year

title: DATA RECORDERS MISSING FROM JET'S TAIL
description: The two ''black box'' flight recorders, deemed the most valuable tools for air-crash investigations, were missing today when salvage crews recovered the tail section of the Air Florida Boeing 737 that crashed in the Potomac River just north of Washington National Airport last Wednesday.

title: DIAMOND SHAMROCK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $7,342,000 for the quarter and $4,860,000 for the year; C-After 108,891 loss from discontinued operations

title: AMERICAN WELDING & MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Pabst Sues Biggest Holder
description: The Pabst Brewing Company said it had filed suit in the United States District Court against Irwin Jacobs, the Minneapolis businessman who has become the brewery's largest individual stockholder, and his associates.

title: Legislation on Bell Case
description: Congress is not likely to pass telecommunications industry legislation this session, despite the need to clarify the Federal antitrust settlement of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company case, a Senate official predicted yesterday.

title: Citrus Emergency Set
description: Gov. Bob Graham declared an emergency in the citrus industry in central and southern Florida today to speed processing of fruit damaged by last week's freezing temperatures. The order authorizes the Department of Transportation to set higher emergency weight allowances for trucks hauling citrus fruit.

title: MDS HEALTH GROUP LTD reports earnings for Yr to Oct 31
Jackson Talks Intensified
description: Reggie Jackson's agent, Gary Walker, continued negotiations with the California Angels and Baltimore Orioles yesterday, saying: ''It's getting a little more intense and a little more toward the finish. Both contracts are in the refining stages.''

title: WEATHER: 30 MORE DAYS OF COLD FORECAST
description: Thousands of commuters trying to get to work yesterday after snowor cold-bound weekends found that subways a nd trains in the New York City are a were disabled by switches that stuck and diesel engines that froze. Automobile batteries balked, too, in the near-zero tem peratures.

title: MICOM SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
WORKER'S SUIT OVER ASBESTOS AT GROTON SHIPYARD TO OPEN
description: A Federal court hearing is to begin Wednesday in the first of more than 300 suits brought by present and former employees of the Electric Boat plant here who say that their health has been harmed by asbestos insulation used in the plant's manufacturing operations.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL YANKEES (AL) - Named Jeff Torborg and Jerry Walker to share duties as pitch- ing coach. They replace Clyde King, who was reassigned to his former post as major league advance scout.

title: PLAQUE HONORS MELVILLE, NEW YORK'S OWN
description: A TROOP of intrepid scholars braved the cold the other afternoon to put up a bronze plaque on the side of a nondescript Manhattan office building just east of Park Avenue South. It reads: HERMAN MELVILLE The American Author Resided from 1863-1891 at This Site 104 East 26th Street Where He Wrote BILLY BUDD Among Other Works

title: DESIGNCRAFT JEWEL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-Including tax credits of $207,000 for the quarter and $804,000 for the 9 months and gains of $286,000 for the 9 months from the extinguishment of debt; C-Including tax credits of $202,000 for the quarter and $331,000 for the 9 months

title: CRASH HERO MAY BE IDENTIFIED
description: There was some evidence today that a 46-year-old Federal employee from Atlanta might have been the unidentified man who passed a helicopter rescue line to five other survivors, one by one, dying in the effort.

title: Addenda
description: * Ruder & Finn Fine Arts has changed its name to Arts and Communications Counselors.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption in the Arts and Lei- sure section on Sunday gave an incor- rect date for a performance by the vio- linist Dylana Jenson with the Balti- more Symphony at Carnegie Hall. She will appear Saturday at 8 P.M.

title: MICRODYNE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
ESQUIRE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split which becomes effective Feb 28

title: YANKEES RESHUFFLE COACHES
description: The Yankees announced yesterday a realignment of their coaching staff, with Clyde King resuming his duties as advance scout and Jeff Torborg and Jerry Walker sharing the job of pitching coach.

title: SOUTH CAROLINA ELECTRIC & GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ALASKA CALLS FOR A CONSTITUTIONAL CONVENTION
description: Alaska today became the 3lst state to call for a constitutional convention to devise an amendment requiring the Federal budget to be balanced.

title: ROSENTHAL RE-ELECTED IN CHICAGO
description: Members of the Chicago Board of Trade tonight narrowly re-elected Leslie Rosenthal to be chairman of the nation's largest commodities exchange in one of the biggest and most heated exchange elections in recent memory.

title: CONGRESS GIVES ITSELF A TAX BREAK
description: ''We've got the world by the tail,'' said Representative Benjamin S. Rosenthal, Democrat of Queens, referring to the perks enjoyed by members of Congress. ''We've got the gym, we've got the travel, we've got the office accounts with which we occasionally buy a typewriter.''

title: POLL INVOLVED QUERIES TO 1,540
description: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone intervie ws co nducted from Jan. 11 through Jan. 15 with 1,540 adults around the Un ited States.

title: BRIEFING
description: W HAT began as an embarrassing discovery by a private citizen, that there was no official plan for celebrating the 100th birthday of Franklin Delano Roosevelt, is about to blossom into a year of memories, festivities and history lessons across the nation in honor of F.D.R.

title: RANGERS LOSE TO MAPLE LEAFS, 6-2
description: The Rangers had the weekend off from the National Hockey League schedule, and skated onto the ice at Maple Leaf Gardens tonight a presumably rested, refreshed team, ready to prolong two unbeaten streaks.

title: Advertising; How to Get A Product Known
description: AS irritating as it may be, Wisk's long-lived ''Ring around the collar'' campaign is still terribly effective advertising. But James J. Jordan, the man who created it at Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn some years ago, is convinced now that it could be improved.

title: Thief in San Francisco Hotels Robs Couples of Over $8,000
description: A polite, well-dressed, man armed with a gun has robbed hotel guests here at least eight times in the last two mont hs, the police say.

title: Men Behind the Women Behind Rights Drive
description: Two former Presidents issued a joint statement yesterday supporting a constitutional amendment dear to their hearts and to the hearts of their wives - the equal rights amendment.

title: Talking Business with Hauser of Warner Amex Cable; What's Ahead For Cable TV
description: The proliferation of cable television services in major cities across the nation, along with the medium's numerous emerging applications beyond entertainment, promises to result in hot corporate competition both among companies already established in the field and among those in the process of entering it.

title: LAW, CUT ON A BIAS
description: Having brought down a legal pillar of tax and racial justice, President Reagan now delivers the debris to Congress and piously tells it: You pick up the pieces.

title: Baltimore Canyon Plans
description: A division of the Zapata Corporation has acquired interests in five adjacent nine-square-mile tracts about 70 miles southeast of Atlantic City in the Baltimore Canyon Trough, Barney White, a spokesman for the company, said today.

title: FINLAND'S PREMIER TRIUMPHS IN FIRST ROUND OF PRESIDENTIAL ELECTIONS
description: Prime Minister Mauno Koivisto, a Social Democrat, won a stunning triumph today in the first round of Finland's presidential elections, all but assuring himself of victory in the electoral college a week from Tuesday. He appears due to become Finland's first leftist President.

title: Pope Picks Congress Site
description: Pope John Paul II has decided that the next International Eucharistic Congress will be held in Nairobi, Kenya, the Vatican announced today.

title: NEDERLANDER BUYS THE ALDWYCH IN LONDON
description: James Nederlander, the Broadway producer, has purchased the Aldwych Theater, home of the Royal Shakespeare Company in London for 21 years, for a reported $2.3 million. The Royal Shakespeare Company will move to the new Barbican Arts Centre next June.

title: MICRO Z CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-Includes extraordinary gains of $3,233 for the quarter and $106,600 for the 9months; C-After an extraordinary gain of $288,994

title: China Output Up, but Short Of Demand
description: China has increased production of television sets ninefold, refrigerators by 233 percent and bicycles by 100 percent in the last three years, but is still far from keeping up with demand, the New China News Agency reported today.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: T HE fashion world presented no fewer than 80 citations and awards to its peers and best customers last week, inadvertently creating a vacuum: No one may be left to receive anything next year.

title: MARK IV INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-Net income; C-Net loss

title: YETTA ZWERLING
description: Yetta Zwerling, an actress and comedian of the Yiddish theater, died Sunday in Cedar-Sinai Hospital in Los Angeles.

title: Seton Hall Bows, 82-71
description: John Bagley scored 28 points and led a second-half comeback tonight as Boston College rallied for an 82-71 Big East Conference victory over Seton Hall.

title: Energy Agency Studying Gas Prices
description: The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission has begun a study of whether the agency itself should raise the price of certain categories of natural gas, including ''old'' gas, from wells drilled before 1977, and whether it has the authority to do so.

title: REAGAN ACTS TO BAR TAX BREAK TO SCHOOLS IN RACIAL BIAS CASES
description: President Reagan, in another modification of his position on Federal tax exemptions for racially discriminatory private schools, said today that the Internal Revenue Service would withhold exemptions from such schools until Congress acted on the issue.

title: DEATH OF A THOROUGHBRED AT AQUEDUCT
description: It was long after the last bettor had gone home from Aqueduct yesterday, and all but one of the horses that had raced had been cooled out and returned to their stalls. In the fading light of a frigid afternoon, only one sign remained of the gruesome moment a few hours earlier: the white edge of a metal railing on the clubhouse turn, now spattered with frozen blood, that had caused the death of a horse.

title: BURLINGTON NORTHERN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Reagan Actions Called C ivil Rights 'Betrayal'
description: President Reagan's first year in office was a year of ''betrayal of basic civil rights protections,'' the National Urban League said today.

title: THE CHURCH THAT DIED FOR AN OFFICE BUILDING
description: To the Editor:

title: TIMES AND REPORTER GRANTED BYRNE PARDON IN 'DR. X' CASE
description: Governor Byrne of New Jersey yesterday pardoned The New York Times and one of its reporters, M. A. Farber, for criminal contempt in their refusal to surrender the reporter's notes in the widely publicized 1978 ''Dr. X'' murder trial.

title: Laker Discharges 21 of 200 Pilots
description: Sir Freddie Laker has discharged 21 of his 200 pilots and demoted 10 of his captains in an attempt to keep his financially troubled airline flying, officials said.

title: HONEYWELL PROFIT DOWN 26.9%
description: Honeywell Inc. reported yesterday that earnings in the fourth quarter, depressed by a loss at a French subsidiary, fell 26.9 percent from the year before while revenues increased 9 percent.

title: FACET ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including a tax credit of $107,000; C-Net loss

title: PORTRAYED STALIN'S PRISON CAMPS
description: Varlam Shalamov, a Russian poet and writer best known for the ''Kolyma Tales'' based on 17 years' detention in Stalin's labo r camps, died on Sunday at the age of 74, his friends reported.

title: COKE EXPECTED TO ACQUIRE COLUMBIA PICTURES
description: The Coca-Cola Company, seeking greater diversification, is expected to announce Tuesday that it has reached an agreement to acquire Columbia Pictures Industries in a $750 million transaction, industry sources said today.

title: FASTER TRACK FOR JAMES RI VER
description: The growth of the James River Corporation, a corporate neophyte only 13 years ago, has relied on ferreting out salvageable paper mills.

title: CLARK IS STAKING OUT HIS TURF AS SECURITY ADVISER
description: For months, President Reagan had been complaining about unauthorized ''leaks.'' But his abrupt decision last week to limit reporters' access to national security information came so fast that it was said to have created some tension around the role of William P. Clark, the new national security adviser.

title: 'STILL MISSING': A CALL FOR CHILDREN
description: The waiting room was narrow, stuffy and crammed with wriggling boys and girls - a mass of yellow curls, black pigtails, bangs, barrettes, hairbows, ruffles, jeans, velveteen, long lashes, cowlicks, newly gap-toothed smiles and freckles.

title: REAGAN REPORTED READY TO TRANSFER FEDERAL PROGRAMS
description: President Reagan has decided to go ahead with a proposal to turn over control of major Federal programs to state and local governments, Administration officials and Congressional sources said today.

title: STUDY OF GERMAN IN U.S. FALLS UPON HARD TIMES
description: FIFTEEN years ago, Columbia University's German department was thriving. It had more than 50 graduate students and turned out at least half a dozen Ph.D.'s a year, and faculty members such as Ludwig Kahn were regularly making significant scholarly contributions to the study of 19th-century German literature.

title: SPECTRO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 2
description: B-After $529,000 loss from discontinued operations

title: RAMON JOSE SENDER
description: Ramon Jose Sender, a writer and educator who won the Spanish National Prize in literature in 1935, died at his home here last Friday.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The Siberian express is just temporarily derailed.'' - Harold Gibson of the National Weather Service.

title: NO INJURIES REPORTED
description: An earthquake centered in central New Hampshire shook wide sections of the Northeast last night. The temblor toppled telephone poles, shook homes and rattled windows and dishes, but there were no reports of injuries or major damage.

title: REYNOLDS IS 49ers' FILM BUFF
description: Jack Reynolds of the San Francisco 49ers has been described as too old, too short and too slow to be a starting insi de linebacker in the Super Bowl. He has also been described as too compulsive and too weird to play disciplined football at s uch a level.

title: A Not-So-Neutral Neutrality Act
description: Since 1794, United States law has forbidden American territory to be used to ''serve a foreign prince or state in war by land or sea.'' Violation is a high misdemeanor, punishable by three years in prison.

title: OPEC NATIONS REDUCE DEPOSITS IN U.S. BANKS
description: Oil-exporting countries have significantly reduced their deposits in American banks at a time when their overall foreign holdings have risen sharply.

title: UNITEL VIDEO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
A Revolution In Noncolas?
description: Did you know about the quiet, noncola, soft drink revolution? Of course you didn't, because it's quiet. You've already got the long-time national brands such as 7-Up and Canada Dry Ginger Ale, as well as the regionals.

title: Buffalo Bank Elects A Chief Executive
description: Andrew B. Craig 3d, the 50-year-old president of the Manufacturers and Traders Trust Company of Buffalo, has been elected to the additional post of chief executive officer, effective March 4. He will succeed Claude F. Shuchter, 58, who continues as chairman of the bank and president and chief executive officer of its parent corporation, the First Empire State Corporation.

title: SYSCON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
SOCIALISTS IN FRANCE SHRUG OFF TWO SETBACKS
description: Socialist Party leaders responded today to two major setbacks by saying that their losses in four by-elections were minor and that they would have a new nationalization plan to replace the one overturned Saturday by the Constitutional Council, France's highest judicial body.

title: SIOUX LOSE FIGHT FOR LAND IN DAKOTA
description: The decades-long effo rt in Federal courts by a tribe of Sioux seeking to regain ownership of the Black Hills of South Dakota ended today when the Supreme Cou rt refused to hear an appeal.

title: FACTORY USE FELL IN DECEM BER
description: The recession cut back utilization of the nation's factories to 72.9 percent of capacity in December - the lowest level since July 1975, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: 45 Men to Stand Trial For Seychelles Hijacking
description: Forty-five men charged with hijacking an Air India Boeing 707 after an attempted coup in the Seychelles last November were ordered today to stand trial in South Africa on March 10.

title: TRIAL HEARS OF GAMING AT SPA
description: A San Diego sheriff's lieutenant today revised earlier testimony and said he had witnessed illegal gambling at La Costa, the Southern California resort and health spa.

title: A JAPANESE REPORT PREDICTS DOMINANCE IN G.N.P. BY 2000
description: By the year 2000, the value of goods and services produced by each person in Japan will have surpassed that of the United States by more than 20 percent, according to the forecast of an advisory council to the Japanese Government.

title: Oil Prices I n Arab Lands
description: The Kuwait-based Organization of Arab Petroleum Exporting Countries has urged oil-producing Arab countries to raise their domestic oil prices to the level of world market prices.

title: Chess: Sax Victor by Half a Point In Yugoslav Memorial Play
description: Gyula Sax, a 30-year-old Hungarian grandmaster, captured the seventh Bora Kostic Memorial Tournament in Vrsac, Yugoslavia, winning eight games and drawing seven for an 11 1/2-3 1/2 score.

title: 4 PILOTS KILLED AS STUNT PLANES CRASH IN DESERT
description: Four jets fr om an Air Force stunt team crashed today, one after another, into t he rugged Nevada desert and exploded in flames, killing all four pilo ts.

title: SOFTWARE AG SYSTEMS GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Fire Forces The News To Print in Brooklyn
description: A smoky fire yesterday forced the removal of 7,000 people from the 38-story Daily News Building, at 220 East 42d Street, for half an hour.

title: Stock Groups Mostly Lower
description: More industries had lower stock prices in 1981 than recorded gains from the previous year, the Standard & Poor's Corporation said yesterday.

title: Texas 105, T.C.U. 89
description: The front line of LaSalle Thompson, Virdell Howland and Mike Wacker combined for 81 points to lead unbeaten Texas.

title: BSD MEDICAL (CO) reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Key Rates
description: * Maximum rate payable by savings institutions.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: 'Creationism' Furor TO SCIENCE TIMES:
description: In the article by Fred Hechinger ''The Irreversible Effects of the 'Creationism' Furor'' (Jan. 5), I am quoted erroneously and my views on creationism in science textbooks are misrepresented.

title: TRITON ENERGY CORPD reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-Includes tax credits of $20,000 for the quarter and $145,000 for the year

title: CHICAGO STOCKPILES SUPPLIES FOR BLIZZARD THAT HASN'T ARRIVED
description: A sudden snowfall recently caused wide absenteeism at a museum charity party, but the guests tactfully avoided discussing the weather when Michael Bilandic, the former Mayor, arrived.

title: Isabelle Byman, Pianist And an Educator, 75
description: Isabelle Yalkovsky Byman, a concert pianist and head of piano pedagogy at the Manhattan School of Music, died of a heart attack Dec. 27 while vacationing in Bakersfield, Calif. She was 75 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: CROSS & TRECKER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PRODUCTS RESEARCH & CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
EQUINOX SOLAR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
6,000 ARE ARRESTED AS NEW DELHI TRIES TO CRUSH A STRIKE
description: After the arrest of 6,000 labor activists throughout the country in the last two days, a one-day national strike called to protest Government economic policies began this morning with spotty compliance.

title: Paterno to Shed a Job
description: Joe Paterno, Penn State's head foot ball coa ch for the last 15 years, will have a lighter load to carry next season.

title: Supreme Folly in New York's Courts
description: To call New York's legal situation bizarre would not do it justice. The District Attorney for Manhattan, Robert Morgenthau, is suing the Chief Judge of the State, Lawrence Cooke. He asks the courts that are supervised by Judge Cooke to hold him in violation of the state Constitution, which all the parties are sworn to uphold. Can there be a starker symbol of a system's breakdown?

title: ABOUT EDUCATION
description: IN 1974, the Doublespeak Award, t hen a virtually unknown citation, was given to a United States Air Force press officer in Cambodia for having told r eporters after an American bombing raid: ''You always write it's bo mbing, bombing, bombing. It's not bombing. It's air support.''

title: FIELD BOSSES ON TRIAL IN CAROLINA SLAVERY CASE
description: A jury of 11 whites and one black was chosen today to hear Federal charges of enslavement against three crew chiefs, all black, who are accused of mistreating migrant workers in sweet-potato fields. One worker died.

title: Bengals Are Thriving on a No-Frills Diet
description: Call them Middle America's team. They are the Cincinnati Bengals and, typically, they arrived here today for the Super Bowl via Piedmont Airlines. They are staying in the Troy Hilton, betwee n Detroit and Pontiac, which is 30 miles to the north. But that's all right. For Middle America's team is accustomed to small-town amenities. They practiced this morning at their home f ield. It is a desolate place called Spinney Field in a virtually des erted warehouse section of Cincinnati. It is under the shadow of a hi ghway spur.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Bob Hickey piloted his crew to the North American four-man bobsled championship on Lake Placid's mile-long Mount Van Hoevenberg run with a total four-run time of 4 minutes 6.93 seconds. The victory was registered in temperature that hovered at 17 degrees below zero. ... Larry Coffey, West Virginia Wesleyan's leading career rusher, signed a one-year contract with the Giants.

title: ISRAELIS ASK EGYPTIANS TO REDRAW BORDER A BIT
description: Israel asked Egypt today for a slight alteration in their border to avoid splitting the Palestinian town of Rafah when the rest of Sinai goes back to Egyptian control in April.

title: Ethiopia Says It Crushed Eritrean Secessionists
description: The official Ethiopian press agency said today Government forces had ''effectively smashed'' the Eritrean secessionist movement, which has been fighting the central Government for more than 20 years.

title: JUDGE REBUFFS INTERIOR SECRETARY ON BRYCE CANYON MINING REQUEST
description: A Federal judge in Salt Lake City today denied a request by Interior Secretary James G. Watt seeking the authority to review a Carter Administration decision that banned strip mining of coal near Bryce Canyon National Park in southern Utah.

title: CITY'S WATER SHORTAGE NO LONGER EMERGENCY
description: Spurred by more than adequate levels of rain and snow - and an inadequate level of money - New York City officials declared yesterday that the city's water shortage was no longer an emergency.

title: A Separated Miss Taylor Still Loves New York
description: After Elizabeth Taylor announced her ''friendly separation'' from Senator John Warner of Virginia last month, the New York State Department of Commerce was faced with a minor crisis.

title: Hofstra 59, Rider 52
description: David Taylor scored 33 points and grabbed 19 rebounds to spark Hofstra, which trailed, 28-27, at halftime and had to rally from an 8-point deficit with 13:12 remaining.

title: JAPAN-U.S. TRADE GAP $13.4 BILLION
description: Japan reported today that it had achieved a record trade surplus with the United States in 1981 of $13.4 billion, nearly twice as high as in 1980. American trade officials said they saw little likelihood that the surplus would recede significantly this year.

title: November Newspaper Ad Revenue Rose 10.6%
description: The Newspaper Advertising Bureau and the Publishers Information Bureau, which deals with magazines, have issued information on November advertising in their particular spheres compared with a year ago.

title: LEGIONNAIRE'S DISEASE: 5 YEARS LATER THE MYSTERY IS ALL BUT
description: GONE By HAROLD M. SCHMECK Jr.

title: S.M.U. Picks Collins
description: Bobby Collins resigned as head football coach at Southern Mississippi yesterday to accept the vacant coaching post at Southern Methodist University. Collins signed a five-year contract, the terms of which were not disclosed but which is believed to be worth more than $100,000 a season.

title: CORRECTION
description: Henry A. Kissinger's article Sunday, ''Poland's Lessons for Mr. Reagan,'' spoke of Poland's ''need for $1.5 million of new capital from the West every quarter in 1982 just to stay afloat.'' The figure is $1.5 billion.

title: No Headline
description: Berkow, Johnson, Halls Win 4 Writing Awards

title: FIRST CHICAGO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago results have been restated to reflect an accounting change for accrualof vacation benefits

title: HARVARD PAPER SETTLES SUIT IN PHOTO DISPUTE
description: The Harvard Crimson, the student newspaper, has reached an out-of-court settlement with two Harvard graduates whose picture was used to illustrate an article about prison reform.

title: THE AU GRATIN PAN
description: DESIGNATING a dish as au gratin means that it is supposed to have a crusty top, usually consisting of a sauce of cheese and eggs and sometimes bread crumbs.

title: MIDWESTERN RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
NEWS OF THE THEATER
description: 'THE LITTLE PRINCE' GIVEN A NEW LIFE AFTER CLOSING By CAROL LAWSON

title: UTAH BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The 1980 figures restated to reflect merger of the Silver King State Bank

title: Doner Settles Case With Ex-employees
description: W.B. Doner & Company, Baltimore, has settled out of court a suit it filed last November in which it sought to prevent employees who formed another agency from serving former clients. In the settlement with members of the new firm, Smith, Burke & Azzam, Doner received an undisclosed amount of cash.

title: FIRST PENNSYLVANIA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After a loss from discontinued operations of $1.2 million plus a prior year tax recovery of $6.7 million; C-Net loss after securities losses of $71,800 plus a loss from discontinued operations of $18.7 million

title: Careers; Learning From the Japanese
description: ''J APAN, as successful as it is economically, is not a model but a reference point where we all must go,'' David T. Kearns, president of the Xerox Corporation, told Columbia Business School students some time ago.

title: Harper's Tries Program With Travel Agents
description: Those intellectual subscribers to Harper's magazine, especially those who like to travel, are going to feel so lucky when their favorite magazine includes a postage-paid card that will allow them to request additional information from any travel advertiser.

title: ENVIRONMENTAL HEALTH EXPERT
description: Dr. Cornelius W. Kruse, an environmental health consultant to Federal agencies and foreign nations and co-founder of the Johns Hopkins Department of Environmental Health, died Sunday. He was 68 years old.

title: Dutch Socialist to Head Parliament of Europe
description: Pieter Dankert, a Dutch Socialist, was elected president of the European Parliament tonight to succeed Simone Veil of France.

title: NATIONAL CENTRAL FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MESTA MACHINE NAMES NEW CHIEF EXECUTIVE
description: Putnam B. McDowell, 57, has been named chairman, president and chief executive officer of the Mesta Machine Company. As chairman, he succeeds John D. Iversen, 69, who retired.

title: MOTOWN AREA ADDS SOCIAL LIFE TO I TS BEAT
description: As usual, the social program of Super Bowl Week is threatening to overshadow the football game that inspires it. The Chamber of Commerce groups in the Detroit-Pontiac area, tourist bureaus and former pro football players, among others, are giving parties or dinners or receptions. There will be a Super Kite-Flying Exhibition, a Super Flea Market ( many functions are referred to as super), an ice-sculpture compe tition, an ice-fishing derby, a tea dance and a bonfire of thousands of Christmas trees.

title: 10th Meeting Is Held In Geneva Missile Talks
description: United States and Soviet negotiators met today for two and a half hours at the Geneva talks on limiting nuclear weapons in Europe.

title: No Headline
description: VILLANOVA DOWNS IRISH, 48-46

title: Machine Gun Bill Signed
description: Legislation repealing a shortlived law allowing private ownership of machine guns was signed Monday by Gov. James R. Thompson. The repeal was rammed through last week's one-day legislative session as lawmakers worked to recover from what many conceded was a mistake made last year when they approved the original measure.

title: AMERON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
SMITH, A O, CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net income; C-Net loss

title: RATES MOVE SLIGHTLY HIGHER
description: Short- and long-term rates rose slightly yesterday as dealers said they remained uncertain about the near-term future of interest rates. Demand of large institutional investors for United States Government and corporate notes was weak, and dealers said the day's price declines resulted largely from speculative activity.

title: Export Unit Considered NATO Economic Arm
description: The Coordinating Committee on Export Controls consists of representatives from 15 non-Communist industrial nations and tries to harmonize national policies controlling shipments of goods with military potential to the Communist world.

title: TOLEDO EDISON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes $10.8 million extraordinary gain from exchange of shares for bonds

title: CENTRAL BANCSHARES OF THE SOUTH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BRIEFING
description: I F there is one neighborhood in the nation that ought to have pull in Congress, it's Georgetown. It has such Senators as Mark O. Hatfield, Charles H. Percy and Claiborne Pell residing along its cobbled streets of affluence, along with a vocal chorus of ranking representatives, and a spear-carrying throng of informed sources, aides, journalists and other self-defined movers and shakers in the capital power game.

title: BENDIX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including $2,803,000 income from discontinued operations

title: VIDEO GAMES OFFER A LOT MORE THAN FUN
description: To the Editor:

title: United Brands Stake
description: The American Financial Corporation, an insurance holding company based in Cincinnati, said yesterday that it had increased its stake in the United Brands Company to 32.8 percent of the common stock outstanding, or 3,616,697 shares. The stake includes $20,600,000 principal amount convertible debentures due Feb. 1, 1994, which were purchased for $10.3 million.

title: FOR THE BUDGET CHIEF, IT'S A 'GRITTY , GRINDING' TASK
description: In the best of times, New York State's Budget Director is about as popular in the South Mall government complex as a bill collector on payday. But as the current director, C. Mark Lawton, went about preparing next year's 900-page, $26.7 billion austerity budget, he found himself unpopular even in Governor Carey's office.

title: Labor Union Man Slain
description: A 49-year-old man who resigned last week as recording secretary of Laborers Local 332 to run for higher office has been found beaten to death, the police said. Five masked men are believed to be responsible for the death of Bienvenido Medina of Philadelphia, whose body was discovered Sunday in his bed and covered by a sheet.

title: Neal Boenzi Blaze Snarls Traffic; Injures Firemen
description: Firemen in aerial buckets battling a three-alarm blaze in a commercial building at 16 West 45th Street. A man was rescued from the roof of the building as rush-hour traffic backed up on Fifth Avenue. Several firemen were injured in the fire, described by officials as suspicious.

title: New St. Paul's Rector; Yale Dean Named to Head St. Paul's; St. Paul's Appoints a Rector
description: The headmaster of St. Paul's School in Concord, N.H., is known as the rector, and when it came time to get a new one, the school turned to a man of the cloth.

title: CROCKER NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Ditka Bears' Coach?
description: Mike Ditka, an assistant coach with the Dallas Cowboys, appears closer to a head coaching job with the Chicago Bears. A Chicago newspaper reported that George Halas, the owner, had offered Ditka the job; Ditka's wife, in a telephone interview with United Press International, said her hus band had accepted the job; and a Chicago television st ation said Ditka would be formally named to the job today.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: IT is doubtful that anyone will ever trace the entire history of words and terms that are used in international cookery, and some of them are fascinating. One that appeals to me in particular is jocularly known in French as oiseaux sans tete, which translates freely as birds without head.

title: COUNTRY CABLE TO BEGIN IN '83
description: Group W Satellite Communications and the NL T Corporation of Nashville have announced the creation of the country's first cabletelevision network devoted solely to cou ntry music.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rate payable by savings institutions.

title: Turkey S ets Iran Tr ade Deal
description: Iran's Minister of Industry has proposed a reinforcement of trade relations with Turkey, offering more than 29,000,000 barrels of oil yearly in a barter deal for Turkish foodstuffs and industrial goods.

title: NEVADA SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes $1,773,000 gain from the sale of land held for investment

title: f PA, HURRY! THE PARLOR
description: During the centennial fuss, we must brace ourselves for renewed debate on Franklin Delano Roosevelt's life and legend. Much of it will be rerun material, but on one score there should be little controversy: Of all the Presidents, it was F.D.R. who was the ''Great Communicator.''

title: ROUNDUP OF AFGHANS IN A SUPRISE DRAFT FOR ARMY REPORTED
description: In a new drive to increase the strength of the Afghan Army, Afghan and Soviet troops last week seized hundreds of male residents of Kabul as they traveled in cars and buses and sent them to be processed for the military draft, a Western diplomat here reported today.

title: A GALA FOR RADIO CITY MUSIC HALL'S 50TH
description: AGLITTERING group of New Yorkers - including four former Mayors and such performers as Ginger Rogers, Peter Allen and Robert Merrill - turned out last night for a sentimental party in honor of Radio City Music Hall's 50th birthday.
