title: ALLIES DISCUSS MORE CURBS ON SALES TO SOVIET BLOC
description: The Reagan Administration began two days of talks with its NATO allies and Japan today on tightening curbs on the sale of strategically valuable goods to the Soviet Union and its Communist allies.

title: DESIGNER FOOD FOR WELL-TAILOED TASTES
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Elizabeth J. Block, a financial writer, is working on a book about women and credit. By ELIZABETH J. BLOCK

title: VICON INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
AMERICAN METALS SERVICE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
MARGIOTTA ACTS TO KEEP POWER DURING APPEALS
description: Joseph M. Margiotta plans to have party rules amended tomorrow so that he can remain the Nassau County Republican chairman despite his conviction on extortion and mail fraud charges.

title: COFFEE DRINKING IN PREGNANCY IS FOUND TO HARM FETUS
description: Coffee drinking in pregnancy had no detectable ill effects on the unborn babies of more than 12,000 women whose cases were studied by scientists at Harvard University, according to a report made public yesterday.

title: UNLIMI TED INDEPENDENT SPENDING IN POLITICS PASSES HIGH COURT TEST
description: A Supreme Court ruling today left political action committees and other ''independent'' political groups free to continue spending unlimited amounts in support of Presidential candidates, at least for the time being. Such groups spent $13.7 million in the 1980 campaign, almost all in behalf of Ronald Reagan.

title: KNICKS RALLY FAILS, CELTICS WIN, 11-107
description: The Boston Cel tics all but buried the Knicks in the first half lastnig ht at Madison Square Garden, then all but blew a 23-poi nt lead in the second half before winning, 111-107. Larry Bird scored 39 points,including a basket and two free throws in the final minute that kept New York at bay.

title: LEAR PLANS 8 TO 10 FILMS A YEAR FROM HIS NEW EMBASSY STUDIO
description: Embassy is the smallest of the four movie studios that have been sold during the last 10 months. In that time, Marvin Davis, the Denver oil magnate, paid nearly $800 million for 20th Century-Fox; Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer bought United Artists for $380 million; Coca-Cola offered $75 a share for Columbia on Monday, and A. Jerrold Perenchio and Norman Lear purchased Embassy from Avco late last November for $25 million cash on the barrelhead.

title: CHILDREN'S RIGHTS, INCLUDING WALTER POLOVCHAK'S
description: To the Editor:

title: KISSINGER VS. REAGAN
description: Former Secretary of State Henry Kissinger has published in the pages of The New York Times and other major newspapers of the world a really tough criticism of United States and NATO foreign policy.

title: OHIO EDISON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes $14,042,000 extraordinary gain on the repurchase of debt

title: CON ED WILL US E POWER PROVIDED BY TRASH BURNER
description: The Consolidated Edison Company signed an agreement today for the purchase of electricity from a $180 million garbage recycling plant being built in Peekskill. The pact could be a factor in the replacement of 600,000 barrels of oil and produce savings for Westchester County taxpayers.

title: News Analysis
description: Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski appears to be firmly in control of th e military council, the Government and the demoralized Communist Par ty, Western diplomats and knowledgeable Poles believe.

title: EXCERPTS FROM CAREY'S MESSAGE TO LEGISLATURE ON THE 1982-83 STATE BUDGET
description: Following are excerpts from Governor Carey's budget message to the Legislature: The budget I present today is a nonpolitical and nonpartisan program to finance the agenda I have set out for New York State for this year and the remainder of the 1980's.

title: Pennwalt to Sell S.S. White Unit
description: The Pennwalt Corporation said it had reached a formal agreement to sell its S.S. White dental retail business operations in the United States and France to a group of unidentified private investors for an undisclosed sum.

title: CAREY SEEKS RISES IN FEES AND TAXES FOR STATE BUDGET
description: Governor Carey proposed a new state budget today that includes more than $200 million in increased state fees, a rise in taxes on gasoline and alcohol and major cuts in a variety of state programs.

title: 22INJURED IN JERSEY BUS CRASH
description: Twenty-two persons were hurt this morning and traffic was snarled for almost an hour when a commuter bus bound for the Port Authority Bus Terminal in Manhattan was struck from behind by another bus.

title: Foster Counters Reds' Offer
description: George Foster has made a counterproposal to the Cincinnati Reds in negotiations that could lead to a long-term contract or a blockbuster trade.

title: Excerpts from address, page B8
description: Thomas Howard Kean, the 46-year-old Republican who won New Jersey's closest race for governor, took the oath of office today, promising to lead a bipartisan effort to solve state problems with sharply reduced resources.

title: LABOR MARKET 'DROPOUTS' STUGGLING TO STAY ALIVE
description: After a while, Randy Reagan said, there hardly seems to be any point in looking for a new job. ''I've been to every down-river pizza parlor and fast-food place there is,'' he said. ''Nothing! I mean, after you've stooped your pride down to where you're willing to put on a stupid Taco Bell hat and wash floors, and then even they don't want you, you don't feel much like trying.''

title: TANDY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CHILDREN'S RIGHTS, INCLUDING WALTER POLOVCHAK'S
description: To the Editor:

title: ZURN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SECURITY NEW YORK STATE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Accounting Rule Masking Future Profits
description: A little-understood accounting rule, once mostly an annoyance, is today masking millions of dollars in future profits at prospering motion picture companies.

title: Disney Net Off 33%
description: Walt Disney Productions has reported that its first-quarter profits for the fiscal year 1982 dropped 33 percent, to $17.4 million, or 53 cents a share, from $25.9 million, or 80 cents a share, for the similar period in the fiscal year 1981.

title: REAGAN HINTS U.S. WEIGHS NEW STEPS IN POLAND'S CRISIS
description: President Reagan, declaring that conditions in Poland had continued to worsen as a result of the imposition of martial law, warned today that ''we're not going to wait forever for improvement in the situation there'' before taking additional measures against the Soviet Union and the Polish military Government.

title: Juan O'Gorman, 76; Painter and Architect
description: Juan O'Gorman, one of Mexico's bestknown painters and architects, has committed suicide, apparently despondent because a heart ailment had curtailed his work, the authorities said today. Mr. O'Gorman, who was 76 years old, was found dead at his home on Monday.

title: AVANT-GARDE: LANGUAGE AND NOISE
description: MEDIUMS have merged more and more in recent years on the lower Manhattan avant-garde arts scene, and one of the most commonly blurred categorical lines is that between words and speech. To celebrate such confusion, the Public Theater's Poets at the Public series opened its 1982 offerings with two evenings of a Language/ Noise Festival. The second of the two programs took place Monday night, and although the grander semiotic pretensions of the merger remained a bit foggy, there was some lively art on display.

title: FIRST MARYLAND BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Central Poland Floodwaters Are Reported to Be Subsiding
description: Polish newspapers reported today that floo dwaters t hreatening the Plock region of central Poland were subsiding slo wly but that attempts to break up an ice jam on the Vistula River were proving unexpectedly difficult.

title: COMPUTER HORIZONS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $69.700 for the quarter and $188,300 for the 9 months; C-Including income of $82,500, or 6 cents a share, from the cumulative effect of an accounting change; year-ago results have been reclassified to segregate the discontinued operations of Custom Terminals Corp

title: Market Place; Skepticism On Coke Deal
description: COLA'S decision to buy Columbia Pictures is viewed by many in Wall Street a s a mistake, making a conglomerate of a company that hassucceeded bec ause it has stuck to its speciality in beverages.

title: ROYAL BUSINESS FORMS (CO) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net income including $549,000 pretax gain from the sale of Dataroyal Inc stock

title: KEY BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Canada Price Rise in '81
description: Consumer prices in Canada rose by 12.5 percent in 1981, the sharpest increase in 33 years, the Government announced today. The increase in the Canadian rate was 2.4 percentage points above the 10.1 percent rate recorded in 1980, but below the 14.2 percent figure in 1948, the highest since World War II. The record Canadian rate was 18.2 percent in 1917.

title: COLUMBIA' STOCK SOARS ON COKE DEAL
description: Columbia Pictures Industries' stock shot up more than $20 a share in hectic trading yesterday, reaching $62.50 in the wake of the announcement that the Coca-Cola Company had rea ched tentative agreement to buy the motion picture giant for some $760 million.

title: HUNTINGTON HEALTH SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Year-ago results have been restated to comply with the retroactive application of FASB Statement No 43 covering compensated absences

title: FINANCIAL BRIEFS
description: * Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce said it was offering six million cumulative redeemable class A preferred shares Series 2 at $25 a share, yielding 14.25 percent a year. * Citicorp said an average rate of 13.387 percent was set at the weekly auctio n of 91-day commercial paper, down from a 13.426 percentaverage rate last week.

title: INTERIOR DEPARTMENT PLANS TO LEASE SITES FOR OFFSHORE MINING
description: Interior Secretary James G. Watt announced plans today to lease Federal offshore waters for the undersea extraction of strategic minerals.

title: A RELUCTANT POLITICIAN; THOMAS HOWARD KEAN
description: He pined to be a scholar but became a public servant. He's a patrician who was taught to love the opera. He's a boxing fan who learned to be a trench fighter. As a man of wealth, he could spend his way to luxury, but he says, simply, ''I'm cheap.''

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article in Metropolitan Report on Jan. 12 incorrectly reported Lewis E. Lehrman's former position with the Rite Aid Corporation. Mr. Lehrman, a candidate for the Republican nomination for Governor, resigned on Jan. 5 as chairman of the executive committee of Rite Aid and from its board.

title: Birdsong Gets Chips Removed
description: Two bone chips were removed today from the right knee of Otis Birdsong, the Nets' high-scoring guard, to correct damage caused by a condition known as osteochrondritis, a chronic bone deterioration.

title: Japanese To Support Sanctions
description: Shintaro Abe, Japan's Minister of International Trade and Industry, reaffirmed yesterday his country's endorsement of economic sanctions against the Soviet Union for its support of martial law in Pol and.

title: U.S. Aide Visits Saudi Arabia
description: Nicholas A. Veliotes, Assistant Secretary of State for Near Eastern Affairs, conferred separately today with Crown Prince Fahd and the Saudi Foreign Minister, Prince Saud al-Faisal, the state-run Saudi press agency said. The agency said the talks dealt with relations between the two countries and topics of mutual interest. It gave no other details.

title: SAVIN'S HEAD SEEKS A BENEFICIAL MERGER
description: With negotiations under way for the Savin Corporation, a manufacturer and marketer of copying machines, to sell up to 58 percent of its stock to the Canada Development Corporation for $9 a share, E. Paul Charlap, Savin's chairman and chief executive officer, yesterday disclosed some of the background behind the proposed deal.

title: Advertising; Chemical Bank Sets Campaign
description: CHEMICAL BANK will break a new worldwide corporate advertising campaign tomorrow with the theme ''Chemical Takes You Beyond Tradition.''

title: Real Estate; The G.M.  Building: A Rare Deal
description: NINE months ago, some of the finest minds in business, law and realestate starte d working on a plan to sell the General Motors Building,a 50-story ma rble tower next to the Plaza and Pierre hotels on Fifth Avenue. What evolved is a rare and unconventional $500 million deal that has intr igued real estate experts, stirred endless questions about tax imp lications and prompted Mayor Koch to announce that the city would ta ke General Motors to court.

title: 1. Light on Predicaments
description: With cars acting up in bad weather, it's a good idea to equip oneself with a really strong flashlight that can be used for signaling and repairs on the road. The ''trucker's light'' made by Stud-Lite of California is an oversized (18-inch) flashlight made of heavy-duty metal and is adjustable to both flood and spot lighting. Batteries are not included, but an extra bulb is. The flashlight is $39.50 at Jenny B. Goode, 1194 Lexington Avenue (between 81st and 82d Streets). 2. A Handbag for a Lift At this time of year, when everything in one's closet looks a bit tired, a cheerfully colored handbag might provide a lift to a wardrobe in the January doldrums. Barbara Bolan has an attractive style in her spring collection that should do the trick. It's made of linen striped in peacock blue, mustard and beige, with a drawstring top and a bottom made of peacock leather. The strap is long enough to go over a shoulder and the body is leather lined. Bergdorf's has it on the main floor for $130.

title: JOSEPHSON INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including an approximate gain of $440,000, or 11 cents a share, for the quarter and 6 months from the sale of the company's holdings in First Artists Production Co; share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in December

title: DIGITAL EQUIPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
No Headline
description: Flyers Gain 2-2 Tie With Nordiques

title: 11 SYNTHETIC FUEL PROJECTS CHOSEN FO R POSSIBLE AID
description: The Government-sponsored corporation set up to encourage creation of an American synthetic fuels industry has picked 11 projects for possible financial aid. These are the first decisions it has made about specific proposals since it went into operation in October 1980.

description: 1980 share earnings restated for a 50% stock dividend issued in November 1981

16, IN SLAYING OF TROOPER
description: The Supreme Court today overturned a sentence of death imposed by the state courts in Oklahoma on a boy who was 16 years old when he murdered a state trooper.

description: To the Editor:

title: EXCERPTS FROM ADDRESS BY KEAN AT INAUGURATION
description: Following are excerpts from the inaugural address Governor Kean delivered before a joint session of the New Jersey Legislature at the War Memorial Building here:

title: Ensign in Coast Spy Case Pleads Guilty at Hearing
description: Ens. Stephen A. Baba, in a surprise at his Navy court-martial, pleaded guilty today to sending secret electronics d ocuments to a foreign power.

title: UNITED FOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After $27,000 loss from discontinued operations for both periods and $1,870,000 gain from recognition of LIFO liquidation

title: THE POP LIFE
description: CLEVELAND and Akron, Ohio, and the towns nearby, are the heartland of American rock-and-roll. Hard rock and heavy-metal bands thrive there, but during the mid-1970's the area also spawned Pere Ubu, Devo, Tin Huey and other bands that offered an antidote to the tedium and slickness of so much of the period's mainstream rock.

title: GENERAL ELECTRIC CO INC reports earnings for Qtr ot Dec 31
U.S. ASSAILED AT UNESCO CONFERENCE ON PRESS
description: The United States was criticized at a Unesco-sponso red conference here today for refusing to help finance an internatio nal program intended to improve journalism and communication s in third world countries.

title: WOODBINE PETROLEUM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes $7,470 tax credit

title: THE TASTING RITUAL: 4 BASIC ELEMENTS
description: To evaluate a wine thoroughly experts have evolved a tasting ritual that examines four basic elements: appearance, bouquet, taste and aftertaste.

title: Olds Dealers Choose S.& K.
description: The Oldsmobile Dealers Group of New York, New Jersey and Southern Connecticut has assigned its $1.5 million advertising account to Shaw & Kourlermos.

title: PENNWALT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After $5,072,000 loss from discontinued operations; C-Net income including $242,000 gain from discontinued operations

title: Article 179330 -- No Title
description: The Walter E. Heller International Corporation, the Chicago c ommercial finance and bank holding company, said today that it will take a one-time, pretax, $79 million write-off for 1981 as a result o f ''irregularities'' discovered in its Phoenix office. The write-off will cut Heller's 1981 net income 46.5 percent, to $23 million, from $43 million in 1980, the company said.

title: DOW LOSES 7.71
description: Stock prices generally lost ground yesterday, but Columbia Pictures Industries soared 20 3/4 points, to 62 1/2, the beneficiary of the first big takeover bid of 1982.

title: Austria Adopts Nureyev as One of Its Own
description: After more than 20 years as a stateless person, Rudolf Nureyev has been granted Austrian citizenship. The 42-year-old dancer, who defected from the Soviet Union while appearing in Paris with the Kirov Ballet of Leningrad in 1961, applied for Austrian citizenship last year, and it was granted last week, the Vienna Opera announced yesterday.

title: BALDWIN SECURITIES CORP reports earnings for As of Dec 31
description: Assets figures represent net assets

title: WHY $16 BILLION GREW TO $26 BILLION
description: How did New York State's budget go from $16.7 billion to $26.7 billion in one year? That is the question many New Yorkers may be asking themselves now that Governor Carey has presented the proposed 1982-83 state budget. The answer is that for the first time in 50 years, the state has changed its accounting and bookkeeping practices.

title: Chrysler Requests Pension Delay
description: The Chrysler Corporation, trying to conserve cash, has asked the United Autom obile Workers union for a second time t o permit the auto maker to defer payments to a pension fund for hour ly workers.

title: Pakistani Denies He Will Hold Talks in Paris on Atom Plant
description: President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq of Pakistan denied today that his visit to France next week would include negotiations for the purchase of a French-made nuclear fuel reprocessing plant.

title: HOUSEWARES SHOW IN CHICAGO, WITH GADGETS GALORE
description: For the thorough homemaker the National Housewares Exposition here this week has exhibited a $99.50 electric meter for measuring the salt content of foods and drinks.

title: Product Introductions Increased in December
description: New product introductions rose to 121 in December from 116 during the same month in 1980.

title: ALLIED SECURITIES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
G.E.'s NET UP 10% WESTINGHOUSE DIPS
description: The General Electric Company, the nation's largest supplier of electrical equipment, yesterday reported a modest gain in earnings and sales for the fourth quarter of 1981.

title: Q&A
description: Q. I cannot understand your use of foreign names for various recipes. In recent columns, for example, you have referred to a potage Esau, which is a lentil soup, and to a gateau de viande, which is a meat loaf. Why don't you simply call a dish by its English name?

title: DAUPHIN DEPOSIT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The 1981 per share figures have been adjusted to reflect a 10% stock dividend paid in September 1981

title: DREXLER TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 25
Phone Network Offers Entertainment News
description: Don H. Miller, once an ad salesman for Penthouse who later failed to get financing for a magazine of his own, a sports magazine called Play, now operates Hotel Entertainment Phone Network, which is part of One Minute Productions.

title: Lockheed Said to Get Cargo Plane Contract
description: Senator Thomas F. Eagleton, a Democrat, and Senator John C. Danforth, a Republican, said today that the Defense Department had decided on the Lockheed C-5, rather than the McDonnell Douglas C-17, as the new Air Force cargo plane.

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 20, 1982
description: International President Reagan warned Moscow and Warsaw that his Administration would not ''wait forever for improvement in the situation'' before taking additional measures in reaction to the ''deteriorating'' conditions in Poland. (Page A1, Column 3.) Curbs on sales to the Soviet bloc were discussed by the NATO allies and Japan in Paris. The allies maintain a list of sensitive items that members are pledged not to export to Communist countries and updates it every three years. Officials say the Reagan Administration is seeking major new restrictions this year. (A8:1-4.)

title: Pizza Parlor for Bo
description: Bo Schembechler, the football coach at Michigan who turned down a $2.5 million offer from Texas A & M last week, is about to go into the pizza parlor business in Columbus, Ohio, near the Ohio State campus. Schembechler, according to a report yesterday in the Columbus Citizen-Journal, is about to take over a Domino's Pizza franchise for a reported price of $150,000. ''Bo resisted but I insisted,'' said Tom Monaghan, a Michigan booster who is president of the pizza chain, which has its home office in Ann Arbor, Mich.

title: FREE RIDERS
description: To the Edit or: Crime in th e subways has again increased dramatically. One of the most easily p reventable subway crimes -and in the long run perhaps one of the mo st destructive - is failure to pay the fare.

title: Kuwait Rejects Proposal To Let Women Vote
description: The Kuwaiti Parliament rejected a proposal today to allow women to vote after opponents said it would break the customs and Islamic rules of the Persian Gulf nation.

title: La. Tech Ties Mark
description: Louisiana Tech tied the national women's collegiate record for consecutive basketball victories with a 74-46 triumph tonight over Long Beach State.

title: Harasser Ordered To Mental Facility
description: Kevin King, convicted of harassing Caroline Kennedy in his attempts to meet and marry her, was found mentally unfit to be sentenced and was ordered confined to a psychiatric institution in his native California.

title: CHAMBER: ENGLISH GROUP PLAYS HANDEL AND MOZART
description: NOW and then the constant concertgoer is brought up short by a performance so unusual that it justifies all those dark nights spent listening to conscientious people grinding out their carefully studied readings of works that long ago ceased to interest, let alone astonish, them. Last night's concert by the English Chamber Orchestra, during which Gidon Kremer and Kim Kashkashian took the solo roles in Mozart's Sinfonia Concertante for Violin and Viola, was one of those arresting occasions.

title: GENERAL FOODS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
description: B-After a provision of $12,350,000 for the quarter and 9 months for loss on discontinued operations

title: TIMES FIBER COMMUNICATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PERSONAL HEALTH
description: THOUGH it was not realized at the time, vitamin C was the subject of the first controlled clinical experiment on record. In the 1750's, a British physician named James Lind showed that by including limes in sea rations, the debilitating symptoms of scurvy - the vitamin C deficiency disease - could be prevented.

title: BAPTISM OF FIRE AT GOLD PANEL
description: Like children at a party they don't want to attend, a small group of men and one woman has been meeting about once a month since last September at the Treasury Department. Seated around a huge table in its high-ceilinged, marble-walled Cash Room, the appointed few have been debating the role of gold in the American monetary system.

title: Help Wanted
description: These times, the President suggests, demand The Washington Post. At his news conference yesterday he was asked what he had to say to blacks suffering exceptionally high unemployment. His answer: look at the want ads.

title: No Headline
description: Sylvia Eder Gains First Cup Victory

title: Governor Kean Takes Charge
description: New Jersey's new Governor, Thomas Kean, built his inaugural address yesterday on the theme of self-reliance. ''Let New Jersey show the nation,'' he said, ''that the Northeast can grow and prosper, not by what one takes from Washington, but by what it makes on its own.''

title: STUDENT LOAN MARKETING ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
'81 Shortfall In Soviet Oil
description: Soviet oil production last year grew by less than 1 percent and fell short of the modest output figure the nation had set for itself in the first year of the current five-year plan.

title: DIGITAL, BENDIX, OLIN INCREASE
description: The General Foods Corporation reported yesterday that the pending sale of one of its subsidiaries caused earnings in the third quarter of the fiscal year 1982, ended Dec. 26, 1981, to drop 31.7 percent, while revenues rose 32.9 percent.

title: MUSIC: MET'S KATHA RICCIARELLI GIVES RECITAL OF ITALIAN SONGS
description: KATIA RICCIARELLI, the soprano, took time from her stint at the Metropolitan Opera to sing a recital at Carnegie Hall on Sunday evening. Even in the concert hall, Miss Ricciarelli did not stray too far from her Italian origins.

title: CITIZENS & SOUTHERN GEORGIA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
RAINIER BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
COURT TO RULE ON INJUNCTION THIS WEEK IN SUIT ON JUDGES
description: Justice Andrew R. Tyler heard arguments yesterday from both sides in a suit by the Manhattan District Attorney to block Chief Judge Lawrence H. Cooke from instituting a new system for awarding 97 temporary judgeships in State Supreme Court in New York City.

title: 'COULDN'T BACK OFF,' ABBOTT SAYS IN COURT ABOUT FATAL DISPUTE
description: Jack Henry Abbott, ending the testimony at his murder trial, said yesterday that he ''couldn't back off'' from the East Village waiter he is accused of stabbing to death, even though he said he now realized the waiter meant him no harm.

title: SYRIA IS REPORTED TO FIRE MISSILES AT ISRAELI JETS OVER EAST LEBANON
description: Israeli jet fighters flew over Syrian positions in the Bekaa Valley of eastern Lebanon today, and the Beirut radio said that the Syrians fired three antiaircraft missiles at them.

title: SPECTRUM CONTROL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
DENNY'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 25
'Benefit for Nothing,' Arts Event, on Monday
description: What is billed as ''A Benefit for Nothing,'' performances and readings, will be given Monday at the Symphony Space, Broadway and West 95th Street.

title: PUBLIC SERVICE ELECTRIC & GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including extraordinary gains of $19,535,000 for the quarter and $6,316,000 for the year

title: MICRO MASK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 3
Nixon's Plans; Nixon Working on a New Book
description: Although he has been out of office since 1974, Richard M. Nixon is anything but forgotten.

title: POLICY MANAGEMENT SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes losses of $121,000 for the quarter and $394,000 loss from discontinued operations for the year and $13,042,000 special gain for the year

title: TEXAS AMERICAN BANKSHARES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Per share figures have been restated to reflect a 5-for-4 stock split paid in August and for the acquisitions of Collin County National Bank and Fondren Southwest Bank as pooling of interests

title: Turkey and Soviet Sign A Major Trade Pact
description: The Turkish Government signed a major trade agreement with the Soviet Union today, ignoring United States calls to curb economic ties with Moscow.

title: BIG BANKS' EARNINGS ARE MIXED
description: Eight major American banking companies yesterday reported fourthquarter net operating income that ranged from spectacular to disappointing.

title: The Paper Hotel in Times Sauare
description: By the time it is finished, the massive Portman Hotel in New York's Times Square could be filled entirely with the court papers that waves of opponents have generated to stop the project. For the last three years of the hotel's nine-year history, they have tried repeatedly to save two unused and probably unusable theaters on the site. They have now won a further delay from a Federal Appeals Court by charging that the White House used ''undue pressure'' to make the Federal landmarks agency permit the demolition.

title: TV Ratings
description: Following are the 15 most popular television shows of the last week (Monday, Jan. 11 to Sunday, Jan. 17), according to their rank in the ratings compiled by the A.C. Nielsen Company. A rating is a percentage of the number of households with television sets. Rating Program Network 1 31.1 DALLAS CBS 2 29.2 60 MINUTES CBS 3 28.8 "HELP WANTED: MALE" CBS 4 27.2 "VICTIMS" ABC 5 26.7 MAGNUM, P.I. CBS 6 25.5 DUKES OF HAZZARD CBS 7 25.3 THREE'S COMPANY ABC 8 24.2 TOO CLOSE FOR COMFORT ABC 9 24.2 M*A*S*H CBS 10 23.6 WALT DISNEY CBS 11 23. 3 ONE DAY AT A TIME CBS 12 23. 2 ALICE CBS 13 23. 0 THE JEFFERSONS CBS 14 23. 0 FACTS OF LIFE NBC 15 23. 0 REAL PEOPLE NBC

title: NOW, THE STAR OF THE SHOW: POLAND
description: The Reagan Administration, which has already demonstrated a penchant for injecting theatrics into its global diplomacy, now plans to dramatize Western opposition to the crackdown in Poland by putting on what on e key official boasts will be ''the bigg est show in the history of the world.''

title: Koch Outraces Luszcek
description: LES-BAINS, France, Jan. 19 (AP) - Bill Koch of Guilford, Vt., won the Alpine Cup cross-country ski race today by finishing 19 seconds ahead of the world champion, Josef Luszcek of Poland.

title: UNITED STATES HOME & DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
Woodside Oil Find
description: The Woodside Petroleum Company said it had made a major new oil discovery in the Northwest Shelf exploration area in western Australia. The company said its Goodwyn No.6 appraisal well is producing oil at the rate of 3,100 barels a day and 3.4 million cubic feet of gas a day over intervals of 3,022 to 3,032 meters.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: the Bob of Bob and Ray -is a connoisseur of uncommon Gotham signs, and he has identified two impor tant new finds. Imagine the confusion of any driver who hunts for a p arking space, says Mr. Elliott, and sees the sign on the building at 38 Bowery Street, near Chinatown: RICKSHAW GARAGE NO VANS

title: Catholic Peace Group Reports 2,000 Killings in El Salvador
description: An international Roman Catholic peace organization said today that more than 2,000 people had been murdered in El Salvador since October 1979, more than 85 per cent of them by the armed forces and right-wing death squads.

title: FIRST OHIO BANCSHARES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec31
Four Years for Temple Fire
description: A self-proclaimed American Nazi Party lieutenant was sentenced Monday to four years in state prison for setting fire to the Temple Beth David synagogue in Temple City at Hanukkah 1980. David Neilson, 25 years old, was convicted of felony arson last Dec. 10 before Judge Julius Leetham of the Los Angeles Superior Court.

title: CONTINENTAL BANK (PHILADELPHIA) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
WILLARD E. DODD
description: Willard E. Dodd, president of the Knott Hotels Corporation from 1947 until 1968, died Sunday in Albany, where he had lived in retirement.

title: ANTI-NAZI MASTER SPY
description: Leopold Trepper, organizer and leader of the ''Red Orchestra'' spy network in Nazi Europe during World War II, died in Jerusalem tonight at the age of 77.

title: The U.N. Today; Jan. 20, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Advisory Committee for the 1982 Outer Space Conference - 3 P.M.

title: Chemical Case Dropped
description: The European Community Commission dropped an antidumping case against American chemical exports.

title: VENERABLE TV SERIES RETAIN THEIR POPULARITY
description: The overwhelming popularity of veteran CBS-TV series, the continued weakness of NBC's overall prime-time schedule and the poor popularity-ratings of all three networks' new series have become the major motifs of the 1981-82 television season.

title: THE GAME IS NOT THE SAME AT TOURNAMENTS IN EUROPE
description: There are two obvious differences between tournaments in and around Europe and those on this side of the Atlantic. The Europeans offer substantial cash prizes, which are anathema to the American Contract Bridge League. Also, they have commercial sponsors.

title: MICHIGAN SUGAR CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MANUFACTURERS HANOVER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
KITCHEN CALISTHENICS: A MOVEABLE FEAST
description: SUZY PRUDDEN sported a turquoise Lycra stretch suit, and her 10 visitors, who arrived in business clothes, did a quick-change into gym shorts, sweat pants and running shoes before joining her around a circle of salad spinners.

title: INSILCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
INTELLIGENT SYSTEMS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Letter: On Human Rights Who Kept the Lid on Guatemala Aid?
description: To the Editor: Your Jan. 13 editorial (''Guatemala Amok'') implies that the Reagan Administration has not consistently tried to renew military ties with the Government of Guatemala. It further states that after Guatemala failed to respond to the suggestion that it moderate ''the slaughter of its opponents,'' the Reagan Admi nistration ''wisely'' decided ''to let Guatemala fend for itself.''

title: Borg Joins Qualifiers
description: Bjorn Borg sprang a surprise here last night by saying he had decided to play the qualifying round of every Grand Prix tennis tournament he entered this year, rather than play a minimum of 10.

title: CHOCLATES WITH A MASTER'STOUCH
description: Jacques Bernachon sees it, making chocolate is a lot like making wine. Success depends on the blend of quality ingredients, artistry and, most of all, patience.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Broadcasting Cos. said it had acquired for cash the assets of Watermark Inc., an independent syndicator of radio programs based in North Hollywood, Calif.

title: BALLET: YOUNG RUMANIANS DANCE FULL 'SWAN LAKE'
description: THE unexpec ted still can turn up on New York's dance scene: the latest entry is the full-length ''Swan Lake'' performed Sunday night by a company called Ballet Fantasio from Rumania at the Lehman College Cente r for the Performing Arts.

title: OF EAGLES AND SPARROWS
description: The Eagles are landing today, swooping down in private jets and commercial airliners, renting limousines and roosting in hotel penthouses and suites in numbers not seen here since last Jan. 20, when Ronald Reagan was inaugurated President.

title: No Headline
description: POLISH PANNEL SIGNALS INTENTION TO RESTORE CONTROL OVER UNIONS

title: Cooney Hurt; L.I.  Bout Off
description: Gerry Cooney injured himself again in training, it was announced yesterday, and he has withdrawn from his scheduled four-round exhibition Friday night at the Westbury Music Fair against Joe Bugner.

title: Allies Said to Urge U.S. to Lift Taxes
description: The major allies of the United States urged the Reagan Administration at an unpublicized meeting to raise taxes as a means of reducing the United States budget deficit and thus the pressure on interest rates, authoritative sources said today.

title: 6 KILLED IN OKLAHOMA SCHOOL EXPLOSION
description: An explosion tore through the kitchen of an elementary school today, raining bricks, glass and metal on children eating lunch in the cafeteria. The police said that five children and one teacher were killed and 35 children were injured.

title: Tea Men Beat Cosmos
description: The Jacksonville Tea Men defeated the Cosmos, 9-7, tonight for their fourth consecutive triumph over the Cosmos in the indoor season of the North American Soccer League. For the Cosmos, who trailed, 7-2, at halftime, Steve Moyers scored four goals and Giorgio Chinaglia three. It was the seventh loss in 10 games for the Cosmos, who will play in Tulsa Thursday and in Chicago Saturday.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Anatole Broyard REVERSE ANGLE: A DECADE OF AMERICAN FILMS. By John Simon. 466 pages. Clarkson N. Potter. $17.95.

title: Lufkin Profit Increases 55%
description: Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc. reported that its earnings for the fourth quarter ended Dec. 31 increased 55 percent, to $4.2 million, or 36 cents a share, from $2.7 million, or 29 cents a share, in the comparable period a year earlier.

title: DECEMBER INCOME UP ONLY 0.2%
description: The personal income of Americans rose just two-tenths of 1 percent in December, the smallest gain in near lytwo years, th e Commerce Department reported today.

title: 2 CONVICTED IN SLAYINGS OF 3 WATERBURY GUARDS
description: Two men described by state prosecutors as ''utterly reprehensible killers'' were found guilty today of the murders of three Purolator armored-car guards. They were slain during a $1.8 million robbery in this city before dawn on April 16, 1979.

title: SONOCO PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
6 in General's Kidnapping Known to Italian Police
description: Police investigators said today that they believed they knew the names of six of the Red Brigades terrorists who kidnapped Brig. Gen. James L. Dozier from his Verona apartment last month.

title: People
description: * John L. Dauer and Arthur E. Wilen, executive vice presidents at the Marschalk Company, have been elected to the executive committee, and Peter Detels, Donald C. Richards and Cynthia Woodward were appointed senior vice presidents.

title: SOME ANSWERS ON CAREY'S TAX PLAN
description: Residents of New York State may have to pay more to register their cars, fill their gas tanks, get hunting and fishing licenses and to obtain many other services under a plan Governor Carey outlined today in his 1982-83 budget.

title: THE ROLE OF THE GLASS
description: Large, clear glasses are a prerequisite in the evaluation of wine. A glass of adequate size should have a capacity of at least 10 ounces and preferably 12 or more.

title: Reagan's First Year Second of six articles.
description: President Reagan enters his second year in office presiding over a domestic Government reduced in size, scope and influence from what it was a year ago.

title: SECURITY PACIFIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
EQUAL RIGHTS REJECTED AGAIN
description: The State Senate today rejected the proposed Federal equal rights amendment on a vote of 27 to 21. Supporters of the amendment had lobbied intensely in Oklahoma in an effort to make it the 36th of the 38 states required for ratification of the measure, which would ban discrimination on the basis of sex. The ratification deadline is June 30.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL DETROIT (AL) - Asked waivers on Stan Papi, veteran utility infielder.

title: STAGE: IMITATION OF A COWARD COMEDY OF MANNERS
description: NO one expects a writer's first play to be a perfectly polished or fully realized work. What one does expect is the sound of a new and intriguing voice: if a novice playwright has something to say, and a fresh way to say it, it's easy to forgive lapses of form. The niceties of craft can come later, with experience - and often do.

title: PRESIDENT'S NEWS CONFERENCE ON FOREIGN AND DOMESTIC MATTERS
description: Following is a transcript of President Reagan's news conference in Washington yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: PIPER JAFFRAY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec31
description: Piper Jaffray is traded on the Midwest Stock Exchange

title: HOW ONE SHELTER FOR THE HOMELESS MANAGES
description: To the Editor:

title: ALASKA PANEL SAYS SECESSION IS UNWISE MOVE
description: A voter-mandated commission that studied the possibility of Alaska's secession said today that such a move would be unwise.

title: COCKPIT BUT NOT RECORDERS SALVAGED IN CRASH
description: Salvage teams today brought up parts of the cockpit of the Air Florida Boeing 737 jetliner that crashed in the Potomac River last Wednesday less than a mile north of Washington National Airport after taking off in a severe snowstorm.

title: COLUMBIA: BUSINESSLIKE STUDIO
description: For nearly 60 years, Columbia Pictures has created the stars and made the movies that have entertained generations of filmgoers. Columbia's studios have produced such hits as ''Lawrence of Arabia,'' ''Bridge on the River Kwai'' and ''From Here to Eternity.'' And, in darkened movie theaters, Columbia stars like Clark Gable, Marlon Brando, Jean Harlow and John Wayne captivated audiences worldwide.

title: RARE BEEF LINKED TO ILLNESSES
description: The penchant of Northeasterners for eating their beef rare may be why that part of the country recorded seven outbreaks of food poisoning traced to commercially prepared roast beef last year. At least that is the theory of a New York State health official, who said there had been no reported outbreaks in the rest of the country where people prefer to buy cooked cold roast beef medium or well done.

title: ON A TRAIN ACROSS CANADA, HOMEMADE CHICKEN POT PIES
description: Johnny Bryk was in pretty fair shape for groceries, so his shopping list included only 30 dozen eggs, 22 loaves of bread, 60 pounds of beef, 65 pounds of chicken, 50 pounds of potatoes, 18 heads of lettuce, 20 pounds of tomatoes and a dozen boxes of a dozen different breakfast foods.

title: 'Made in New York' Art Coming to City Gallery
description: The work of New York artists will be mounted in an exhibition titled ''Made in New York,'' Henry Geldzahler, the City Commissioner of Cultural Affairs, is the curator of the display, which will be displayed at the City Gallery, in the Department of Cultural Affairs headquarters, 2 Columbus Circle, starting Feb. 1.

title: 3 Children Get House In Unusual Divorce Pact
description: A judge in northern Michigan has taken an unusual approach in a divorce case, giving three boys custody of their parents' house while the mother and father alternate month-long visits.

title: Ludwig to Buy Financial Units
description: The United Financial Group Inc. said its board of directors had approved the sale of three of its subsidiaries to Daniel K. Ludwig, the financier who is one of the nation's wealthiest men, for a cash payment of $47 million.

title: New Studies Stress the Importance of Smell
description: TODAY a distorted sense of taste or smell is often an important diagnostic clue to doctors, who know that such aberrations can be clues to disease. Largely because of that medical interest, scientists have devoted much effort to understanding the biology of taste as a natural human phenomenon, and some of their findings can be useful to the wine taster.

title: 2d-Largest Publisher In Emmaus, Pa.
description: ''We are now the second-largest publishing company in Emmaus, Pa.,'' writes Jerome Goldstein, who used to work for Rodale Press, the largest in that location.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article on the Style Page last Saturday gave incorrect information on ordering the Consumers Union Re- port on Life Insurance. The book is $7.50, plus $1.75 for postage and han- dling, from Consumer Reports Books, Box C-719, Brooklyn, N.Y. 11205.

title: 2ND CHARGED IN TROOPER SLAYING
description: The state police today charged a second man in the Dec. 21 murder of a state trooper, Philip Lamonaco, but the police provided only scant details about the suspect's connection with the crime.

title: OFFICIAL SHAKE-UP REPORTED IN CHINA
description: The solicited resignations of over a dozen aging deputy ministers have produced the first tremors in a long awaited shake-up of China's bureaucracy.

title: TIMEPLEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $30,000 for quarter and $45,000 for 6 months and $382,000 loss for both periods on disposal of discontinued operations; C-After losses from discontinued operations of $103,000 for quarter and $213,000 for 6 months

title: EXPERT ON FIBERS TESTIFIES IN ATLANTA MURDER TRIAL
description: Jurors in the murder trial of Wayne B. Williams today heard hours of testimony by textile experts on the manufacture and identification of fibers and carpets.

title: COUNCIL VOTES ON TAX ABATEMENT BILL
description: By a vote of 35 to 8, the City Council approved the Koch administration's bill on real-estate tax abatements yesterday. The bill continues until 1986 - the Industrial and Commercial Incentive Board. a panel of mayoral appointees that grants abatements to developers.

title: A Tribute to Poe; Under Cover of Darkness, a Tribute to Poe
description: The night was cold, the graveyard dark, a figure lurked and two eyes watched. Deep into that darkness peering, long he stood there, wondering, fearing, but then Jeff Jerome knocked off for an hour, and when he returned the deed was done.

title: INDIAN STRIKE SLOWS BUT DOES NOT STOP, ECONOMIC ACTIVITIES
description: A one-day national strike called for todayto protest Government policies substantially slowed but did not stop economic activity throughout the country.

title: CATERPILLAR TRACTOR CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PIONEER STANDARD ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
GOING OUT GUIDE
description: CHURCHGOING

title: PRESIDENT ACCEPTS BLAME IN DISPUTE ON TAX EXEMPTION
description: President Reagan said today that he was the ''originator'' of the move to grant tax-exempt status to private schools that discriminate on the basis of race. He accepted blame for his Administration's failure to anticipate the outcry caused by the decision.

title: Turkey Lifts Two Curfews
description: Turkey's military authorities lifted a curfew in two towns today, the first time curfews have been removed since they were imposed throughout the country after a military coup in September 1980. A military statement said the curfew, from 2 A.M. to 5 A.M., would be immediately lifted in Cankiri and Kastamonu, both north of Ankara.

title: CITICORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Comings and Goings
description: The Milwaukee Bucks reactivated their swingman, Junior Bridgeman, who had missed five games with tendinitis of his left foot, and placed the guard Mike Evans on the injured list. ... Paul Holmgren, the Philadelphia Flyers' wing, will be out a minimum of three weeks with stretched ligaments in his left knee. ... Joe Paterno, Penn State's football coach, who has been doubling as the Nittany Lions' athletic director, confirmed yesterday that he is giving up the latter job so that he can devote more time to football. His successor is Jim Tarman, who has been filling the role of assistant athletic director. ... Grant Jackson, 39-year-old veteran left-handed relief pitcher, was acquired by the Kansas City Royals from the Montreal Expos in exchange for Ken Phelps, a minor league first baseman.

title: DONALDSON LUFKIN & JENRETTE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
British Oil Sale
description: The British Government plans to sell a majority inte rest in the oil producing business of the British National Oil Corporation before the end of the year, Energy SecretaryNigel Lawson told Parliament today.

title: 49ers ARE HAVING FUN AFTER LEAN YEARS
description: Keith Fahnhorst, the right tackle and offensive captain of the San Francisco 49ers, was talking about the obnoxious bellman at the team's hotel in nearby Southfield.

title: BANKERS TRUST NY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Results exclude a gain of $16.6 million, or 67 cents per share, from the saleof 39 branches; C-Results exclude gains of $33.1 million, or $1.44 per share, on the sales of 80 branch offices; D-Reflects a higher number of shares outstanding during 1981

title: Kreider Knows His Priorities
description: Neither the cavernous Silverdome, nor the Super Bowl game that will be played in it Sunday seemed to awe Steve Kreider today.

title: UNION NATIONAL BANK (PITTSBURGH, PA) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
KEMPER REINSURANCE FILLS VACANT TOP POST
description: David B. Mathis, a 43-year-old insurance executive, has been elected president and chief executive officer of the Kemper Reinsurance Company, a subsidiary of the Kemper Corporation, based in Long Grove, Ill. As head of the company - a leader in the reinsurance field, which involves the assumption of risk undertaken by primary insurers - he succeeds C. Frank Aldrich, who died this month at the age of 56.

title: NORTHEAST BANCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ANTITANK ROCKETS ARE FIRED AT FRENCH NUCLEAR REACTOR
description: Five antitank rockets were fired Monday night at a French nuclear power plant that is under construction, causing minor damage.

title: KANSAS CITY SOUTHERN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago share earnings have been restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in October 1981

title: GAP OF $900 BILLION IS SEEN FOR PENSIONS OF U.S. EMPLOYEES
description: The pension systems on which 5.7 million Federal employees are relying for retirement income have more than $900 billion in future obligations that are not backed by current assets, an amount nearly equal to the national debt, a Republican Congressman reported today.

title: Diamond Sells U.S. Playing Card
description: The Diamond International Corporation has sold its United States Playing Card Company division, which it has owned since 1969, to the Jesup & Lamont Holding Company of New York. The two companies did not disclose the terms of the deal.

title: Turkey Says It Has Arrested 51 Leftists in Ankara Raids
description: Military authorities today annnounced the arrest of 51 leftists and said that about 7,660 suspected terrorists were at large, some in self-exile in Europe.

title: STUDY IN CHEESE
description: I was surprised to hear that the Reagan Administration was giving free cheese to the poor. The credo of the Reagan people, if I've heard them right, is ''There is no free lunch.'' I always assumed this included the cheese course.

title: Developing a 'Memory,' One Wine at a Time
description: ADRAMATIC shift in American tastes is occurring as consumers of alcoholic beverages turn to wine as their first choice. Last year, for the second year in a row, more wine than spirits was consumed in this country as sales of bourbon, Scotch, gin and vodka declined, and the trend seems to be accelerating.

title: An Update on Pinky Pearl, Violinist
description: Although he celebrated his 50th anniversary as a singer last year, the tenor Jan Peerce is still listed by Local 802 of the Musicians Union as a violinist.

title: Control Data Deal
description: The Control Data Corporation said that it had agreed to acquire a ''significant interest'' in the Centronics Data Computer Corporation, a Hudson, N.H., maker of computer printers. Control Data said that the deal would be made in conjunction with the NCR Corporation and International Computers Ltd., Control Data's partners in the joint venture, Computer Peripherals Inc. Under terms of the agreement, Centronics would issue stock to Control Data, NCR and International Computers in return for a cash investment by Control Data and the printer business of Computer Peripherals. Centronics reported revenues of $124 million for the fiscal year ended June 28, 1981.

title: HI S FOES SAW RED
description: The F.D.R. centenary reaches into odd corners of memory.

title: Turco Chooses Grey
description: Grey Advertising has been named the new agency for the Japanesemade kerosene heaters that the Turco Manufacturing Company of DuQuoin, Ill., is marketing in this country. Bozell & Jacobs, Chicago, was the previous agency. The ad budget will be $1 million to $2 million.

title: TOPAZ INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
A.T&T. Review Urged
description: Attorneys general from 24 states told a Federal judge today that they believe he has no choice but to solicit public comment on the Government's landmark antitrust settlement with the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. Their court filing suggested that District Judge Harold H. Greene must adhere to the Tunney Act in reviewing the proposed settlement. That 1974 law sets out strict procedures, including a 60-day public comment period, for judges to follow in reviewing major antitrust settlements.

title: REAGAN SAYS HE CONTRIBUTES 10% OF HIS INCOME TO NEEDY
description: President Reagan, who has made voluntary contributions to the needy and to the arts one of the cornerstones of his efforts to reduce the size of the Federal budget, said today that he gave a tenth of his income to ''help people.''

title: ISRAELIS VISIT U.S. TO LOBBY ON SINAI
description: Three Israelis from a group called the Movement to Stop the Withdrawal from the Sinai began a three-week tour of the United States yesterday to seek the support of the American public for their cause.

title: D'Amato's First Year; Students Learn About D'Amato's Freshman Year
description: It has been 20 years since Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato graduated from college and law school, but Monday night he was back in a classroom, this time as an instructor.

title: BYRNE RETURNS $101,000 FINE TO TIMES
description: Acting on his last day as Governor of New Jersey, Brendan T. Byrne yesterday returned to The New York Times a $101,000 fine imposed on the newspaper and one of its reporters for criminal contempt in refusing to turn over notes during the ''Dr. X'' murder trial in 1978.

title: GEORGE VECSEYSports of The Times Bugner Loves His Manager
description: JOE BUGNER's manager never goes to the gymnasium to watch him train. Joe Bugner's manager has seen only one boxing match, lifetime. But every evening when Joe Bugner trudges back from a hard day in the ring, his manager is waiting in the hotel room.

title: Lucas of Bullets Tells Of His Drug Problems
description: John Lucas, a Washington Bullet guard and an all-American in 1976 after his senior season at Maryland, says his use of cocaine has caused him problems the last two seasons in the National Basketball Association.

title: SAGA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
TEXAS A&M SIGNS SHERRILL TO RICHEST COLLEGE PACT
description: Jackie Sherrill, head football coach at the University of Pittsburgh since 1977, yesterday was named coach and athletic director at Texas A & M and signed a six-year contract whose worth was put by knowledgeable sources at the College Station, Tex., campus at $1.7 million.

title: TRITON ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes $145,000 tax credit; share earnings corrected from yesterday's editions

title: ROADWAY EXPRESS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes $12.3 million extraordinary tax credit received for writeoff of motor carrier operating rights; C-After $26,802,000 charge for writeoff of motor carrier operation rights

title: A BELATED DISCOVERY: THE VERSITILE VEGETABLE CHAYOTE
description: OVER the years I'd heard of the vegetable chayote, a member of the squash family. And I knew that it is to be found almost all year long in the markets along Ninth Avenue in Manhattan. But through some curious circumstance, I never sampled it until a recent visit to the Caribbean island of St.-Barthelemy.

title: KITE FINDS VICTORY IS ELUSIVE
description: Tom Kite is the Mr. Consistency of the TPA Tour, but he has had his share of frustrat ion. Sunday was yet another one of those days: He came in second. He hadcome here det ermined to make up for some of last season's frustrations.

title: WESTINGHOUSE ELECTRIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The acquisition of Teleprompter Corp completed last Aug 18 was accounted for inthe 1981 fourth quarter and reduced earnings by 13 cents a share for the quarter and 32 cents a share for the year

title: WELLS FARGO & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
QUAKES IN EAST BIGGER PUZZLE THAN THOSE ON WEST COAST
description: A moderately severe earthquake struck central New Hampshire on Monday, a far stronger one centered in New Brunswick shook New England Jan. 9, and several small quakes hit southern New England more recently. While they all felt just like a quake on the West Coast, their origin is significantly different and these quakes perplex scientists far more than Western ones do.

title: THE RITES OF 'PASSAGE': A GUIDE FOR OUTSIDERS
description: This is a city of symbols of status and emblems of power, with the rituals surrounding them extending even to the seemingly prosaic pass that brings entry to the White House or the Department of Agriculture. It says ''access,'' a magic word here.

title: CENTRAL & SOUTH WEST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FOR THUNDERBIRDS, SHOCK AND DOUBT
description: To master jet jockeys like the Air Force Thunderbirds, it is not considered a particularly difficult maneuver: Four T-38 Talon jets whistle along at 400 miles an hour and 100 feet above the ground, wingtip to wingtip in a formation called ''line abreast.''

title: BOSTON OPERA'S TROUBLES ARE TRACED TO CALDWELL-UNION CONFLICT
description: The formal cancellation Saturday by the Opera Company of Boston of its eagerly anticipated American premiere of Bernd Alois Zimmermann's ''Die Soldaten'' was the result of a long-simmering conflict between Sarah Caldwell's impetuous, sometimes erratic managerial style and an increasingly militant desire for higher wages, job security and improved working conditions on the part of Boston's orchestral musicians.

title: BANCO DE PONCE (NYC) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
LOCAL OFFICIALS BOTH PLEASED AND PUZZLED BY BUDGET PLANS
description: Officials in the New York City metropolitan area praised Governor Carey's proposed state assumption of most local Medicaid costs, but expressed confusion and indignation over other aspects of the $26.7 billion state budget.

title: IN GHANA, LITTLE ZEAL FOR NEW REGIME
description: When Jerry J. Rawlings seized power in a military coup in 1979, one of his first moves was to seize the ubiquitous trading women who sell everything from soap to sandals in the markets.

title: Carey Legislation Offers Limited N.Y.R.A. Help
description: As part of his proposed 1982 budget, Governor Carey submitted legislation today to give the New York Racing Association limited financial relief.

title: WARNER ELECTRIC BRAKE & CLUTCH CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
EX-MANHATTAN AIDE CALLED FOR NEWPORT TRIAL
description: A former Manhattan District Attorney, Richard H. Kuh, has been subpoenaed in the trial of Claus von Bulow to testify about his efforts as a private lawyer to investigate the case of attempted murder against Mr. von Bulow.

title: Inquiry on Drug Use
description: Charges by James Bozeman, a senior guard who quit Florida State University's basketball team Dec.17, claiming that he was receiving drugs so that he could play while injured, will be investigated by a special panel according to Bernie Sliger, the president of the university. The accusations, printed in a campus newspaper, quoted Bozeman as having said that he was being given shots of Novocain and cortisone so that he could play with ankle injuries.

title: REAGAN CRITICIZES FED'S MOVE
description: President Reagan today criticized the Federal Reserve Board because of the recent spurt in the nation's money supply, and, going further, took a neutral stand when asked if Paul A. Volcker, the board's chairman, should resign.

title: California Indicts 25 As Prison Crime Ring
description: Twenty-five members of what the State Attorney General describes as the Nuestra Familia prison gang have been indicted on charges of conspiracy and racketeering involving murder, robbery, extortion and narcotics trafficking.

title: Smart Money on MacBeth
description: On a frosty night in the Canadian winter of 1964, a Pee Wee League hockey coach and a horse trainer were talking over a few beers at the Elks Lodge in Red Deer, Alberta.

title: MERRILL BANKSHARES CO (BANGOR, MA) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
'ALIEN'S PLACE,' ON 'JEWISHNESS'
description: EVEN in its new, comparatively classy home on Watts Street, the Film Forum continues to be one of Manhattan's most consistently rewarding showcases for those films, domestic and foreign, which would probably not be able to make the grade in conventional film release. Comfortable seats and good projection need not announce a sellout to Philistine film tastes.

title: NUCLEAR FACILITY FACING FINE
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission's staff notified the Boston Edison Company today that it proposed to fine the utility $550,000, the highest civil penalty it has sought to date, for safety violations at the Pilgrim atomic plant.

title: On Trial in Five Deaths, He Hangs Himself in Cell
description: A former high school math teacher accused of killing five people and wounding 10 in a church hanged himself in his jail cell today.

title: NEW ENGLAND MERCHANTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
YOUTH HELD IN PAN AM THEFTS
description: A 15-year-old Brooklyn youth was arrested yesterday and charged with participating in two recent robberies of passengers while they rode elevators in the Pan Am Building, at Park Avenue and 45th Street.

title: Don Adams Gets Smart For Savemart Spots
description: Shapiro/Budrow & Associates has enlisted the comic talents of Don Adams, star of the ''Get Smart'' series on television, to do his thing for Savemart, a 23-store retailer of video and audio equipment.

title: BEST BUYS
description: THE average cost of feeding a family of four in New York City rose 20 cents to a high of $107.33 during the two-week period ending Jan. 15. According to th e city's Department of Consumer Affairs, shoppers paid $6.06 mo re for food than during the corresponding period last year when the average price of the weekly market basket was $101.27.

title: REAGAN DEFENDS POLICIES TO CURB NEWS DISCLOSURES
description: President Reagan, saying he was only continuing th e policies of previous administrations, today defended the use of po lygraph tests for Government officials and restrictions on interviews to cut off the flow of news on sensitive subjects.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Adams Resources and Energy, Houston, has named to its board G. Clyde Buck, vice president and Houston corporate finance manager of Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company. * Atari Inc ., Sunnyvale, Calif., announces that Alan Kay has joinedthe company a s a vice president and chief scientist, a new post.

title: STANDARD PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings reflect 3% stock dividend in July 1981

title: OLIN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes nonrecurring $40 million charge; C-Net loss; year-ago sales have been restated to reclassify certain credits previously reported in interest and other income

title: Airline Traffic Down
description: Scheduled airline traffic, affected by the recession and the air controllers' strike, declined by 3.9 percent in 1981 from the previous year, an industry group reported today.

title: HORIZON BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Appellate Court Backs Jockey's Reinstatement
description: The New York Racing Association lost another round yesterday in its court fight to have the jockey Larry Saumell barred from its grounds. The four-judge Appellate Division of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn unanimously upheld a lower court decision last July 31 that reinstated Saumell.

title: For Florio, a Hearing As Kean Takes Office
description: Far from the pomp and pageantry of Gov. Thomas H. Kean's inaugural celebrations, Representative James J. Florio sat in a chilly meeting room today and listened to people discuss what it was like to die from asbestos poisoning.

title: TV: TARGET OF OVERZEALOUS NEWSMEN
description: PERHAPS it's just a case of action and reaction. After the revelations of Watergate, the press was riding high in the public's esteem. Going to journalism school became fashionable among the young. Now, rather suddenly, the press is being cast as a villain in popular entertainments. Audiences are flocking to see ''Absence of Malice,'' cheering for Paul Newman as he gets even with the reporter, Sally Field. Fair enough. An institution that claims to worship no sacred cows can hardly claim that status for itself.

title: Tandy Net Grows 28.8%
description: The Tandy Corporation, which runs the Radio Shack stores, reported today that earnings in its fiscal second quarter, ended Dec. 31, rose 28.8 percent to $70.26 million, or 68 cents a share, from $54.56 million, or 53 cents a share, a year before. Sales climbed 19 percent to $638.3 million from $534.3 million.

title: WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 20, 1982; The Economy
description: President Reagan criticized the Federal Reserve Board because of a recent surge in the nation's money supply. Speaking at a news conference, he took a neutral stand when asked if the chairman of the Fed, Paul A. Volcker, should resign. Later, aides insisted Mr. Reagan hadn't meant to avoid endorsing Mr. Volcker. (D1.)

title: TRANS TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PUREX INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr ot Dec 31
description: B-Includes gains from discontinued operations of $477,000 for the quarter and $372,000 for the 6 months

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''If the future is not bright for our state, then it is indeed dim for the United States; and so I say that the only thing New Jersey has to fear is the economic failure of the nation itself.'' - Gov. Thomas H. Kean. (A1:5.)

title: AT LIFEGFUARD TRYOUTS, MANY DO SWIMMINGLY
description: Summer is coming on West 59th Street. Across the lumps of gray snow it steps, over the ripples of frozen slush, armed with gym bags. Summer is coming on West 59th Street, in the person of hundreds of high school and college students, pursuing what remains, despite changing mores and manners, the ultimate summer job.

title: FGI INVESTORS reports earnings for Yr to Nov 30
description: B-Including $10,000 tax credit; C-Including an extraordinary credit of $5,469,000 related to certain asset exchanges

title: Tenants Sue City On Rent Increases
description: An organization of tenants sued New York City to challenge ''arbitrary'' rent increases in city-owned buildings, which are not covered by rent control.

title: Frenchman Sets Mark
description: Alain Prost of France loweredhi s lap time to 1 minute 5.74 seconds, the fastest ever on the Ky alami track, in practice today for Saturday's South African Grand Pr ix auto race.

title: RKO to Appeal
description: Denied an appeals court rehearing on Monday, RKO General Inc. yesterday said it will go to the United States Supreme Court to protect its threatened Boston TV station. The General Tire and Rubber Company unit was denied a rehearing request by the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia, which last month upheld a 1980 decision by the Federal Communications Commision denying RKO General renewal of the broadcasting license of its WNAC-TV station in Boston. The FCC had refused to renew the license because RKO's filing ''lacked candor'' in failing to report certain information about General Tire to the F.C.C. RKO, in its petition for a rehearing, said the Dec. 4 appeals court decision ''is strikingly inconsistent with the court's holdings on other phases of the case'' and conflicts with a number of prior decisions by that court and the United States Supreme Court.

title: Business Failures Rise
description: Business failures for the week ended Jan. 14 rose to 456 from 314 in the previous week, Dun & Bradstreet said yesterday.

title: Economic Scene; Reagan Shifts To Defensive
description: AT his news conference yesterday, President Reagan was on the defensive about the state of the economy. Well he might be, given the evidence of the latest New York Times/ CBS News Poll that nearly two-thirds of Americans feel that the economy is the nation's most important problem and that 51 percent believe Mr. Reagan's program has hurt the economy so far.

title: FIRST AMERICAN BANK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Man Killed as Vehicle Plunges From Bridge
description: A Chevrolet station wagon being pulled from the Raritan River in Perth Amboy, N.J., by the Army Corps of Engineers. The car had crashed through an iron gate on the Victory Bridge early yesterday morning and fell 50 feet to the frozen river. The car's lone occupant, identified as Angelo B. Cutrone Jr. of East Brunswick, died in the accident.

title: CHURCHES AND THEIR LEADERS AID FUND FOR NEEDIEST CASES
description: In addition to performing charitable duties within their parishes and neighborhoods, many church leaders in the city make donations to the The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Percy Meets Syria's Chief
description: Senator Charles H. Percy, the Illinois Republican who is chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, met President Hafez al-Assad of Syria and other Syrian leaders today, according to an official announcement.

title: HOUSING STARTS UP IN DECEMBER
description: Apartment construction pushed up new housing starts 13.3 percent in December, to an adjusted annual rate of 978,000, the highest it has been since last summer, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: TEMTEX INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including $14,000 gain from discontinued operation; C-Included $4,000 gain from discontinued operations and $180,000 extraordinary credit

title: Accounts
description: * Hellenic Lines Ltd., to Staley, Falcone and Gaynor.

title: EGYPT AND ISRAEL ON MOST SINAI ISSUES
description: Egyptian and Israeli negotiators announced today that they had reached agreement on most of the issues involved in Israel's return of the last occupied portion of the Sinai Peninsula to Egypt by April 25.

title: DESIGNATRONICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Byrne Is Kept at Desk Up to the Last Minute
description: TRENTON Jan. 19 - Governor Byrne was kept busy virtually up to the time he relinquished the reins to Thomas H. Kean at noon today. Mr. Byrne signed a new Congressional redistricting bill this morning that rescinds a bill he signed last week and establishes 14 new districts to replace the 15 current districts.

title: Two Savings Units To Merge on Coast
description: Great Western Savings and Northern California Savings and Loan have agreed in principle to merge through an exchange of stock valued at $61.2 million, officials of both savings institutions said today. The new uni t would have $12.6 billion in assets and thus solidify its position as the nation's second-largest savings and loan association.

title: Sales Decline At 2 Japanese Auto Makers
description: The Toyota Motor Company and the Nissan Motor Company, Japan's leading auto makers, said today that their 1981 exports, domestic sales and production all fell from the previous year.

title: A FLAWED ATTACK ON CREATIONISM
description: To the Editor:

title: BankAmerica Biggest Again
description: The BankAmerica Corporation overtook Citicorp in 1981 as the biggest bank holding company in the United States.

title: Radio Marti Head Named
description: President Reagan today named F. Clifton White, a longtime Republican Party official, to head Radio Marti, the United States broadcasting initiative designed to counter anti-American broadcasts from Cuba. The initiative, named for Jose Marti, leader of the Cuban drive for independence, is expected to get under way some time later this year.

title: Police Seek Ex-Pitchers
description: Two former pitchers, Mark Lemongello and Manny Seoane, both of whom had short careers in the major leagues, were being sought yesterday in Florida on kidnapping and robbery charges. The police in St. Petersburg said the two men had been accused of abducting Mike Lemongello, 37, and Peter Lemongello, 34, both cousins of Mark Lemongello, at gunpoint, and forcing them to make a withdrawal of more than $10,000 from a safety deposit box.

title: GLOSSARY OF TERMS IN WINE TASTING
description: SCIENTISTS who study taste have been able to agree on only four primary taste elements -sweet, sour, bitter and salty. As a result, much of the language of wine is metaphorical. Following is a glossary of terms commonly used by wine tasters.

title: UTL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes tax credits of $39,000 for quarter and $73,000 for 6 months; C-Includes tax credits of $109,000 for the quarter and $245,000 for the 6 months

title: BRAE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FIDELITY UNION BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results for the latest and previous year reflect losses applicable to discontinued operations

title: Virginia Fox Hartley, Ex-State Dept. Aide
description: Virginia Fox Hartley, a retired State Department official, died at Georgetown University Hospital Monday of a heart attack. She was 74 years old.

title: LIBYANS ARE GONE FROM CHAD, BUT RANCOR IS NOT
description: The Libyans have gone from this town, as they ha ve from the rest of Chad, and all that remains of their 11-month pr esence is an Arabic slogan or two daubed on a mud wall and a da maged airplane, discarded in the scrub by a desert runway. After in tervening in December 1980 to halt civil strife in Chad, Col. Mu ammar el-Qaddafi's 10,000 men pulled out last November. In th eir place have come a variety of forces.

title: CITY IS USING RIKERS PRISONERS TO CLEAN PARKS
description: For four months, New York City corrections officials have released prisoners from the Rikers Island jail complex for part of each workday to serve on crews that clean and rehabilitate parks.

title: S.E.C. IS INVESTIGATING SEARS-DEAN WITTER PACT
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating possible insider trading in the stock of Dean Witter Reynolds Organization Inc. before its takeover last October by Sears, Roebuck & Company, according to sources familiar with the investigation.

title: DOVER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PREVENTING THE PERIL OF FREEZING PIPES
description: THE severe cold spell has created a problem for many homeowners and apartment dwellers: frozen water pipes. At best the flow is halted; at worst the pipes burst, perhaps causing a great deal of damage when the water runs again.

title: American Air H ad '81 Profit
description: American Airlines, recovering from a substantial operating loss in 1980, said today that it earned $47.4 million in 1981. But company officials pointed to a dismal fourth quarter, just announced, which they said could portend trouble in 1982.

title: Ensign Given 8-Year Term
description: A United States naval officer was sentenced today to eight years of hard labor on his plea of guilty to sending secret information to the South African Embassy in Washington.

title: EQUILINK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-Including an extraordinary tax credit of $10,003; C-Net loss

title: 7 KILLED IN KENTUCKY MINE, SECOND DISASTER IN 2 MONTHS
description: Seven miners were killed today when a violent explosion ripped through a coal mine in southeastern Kentucky, state officials said.

title: REDPATH INDUSTRIES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net income including $900,000 tax credit and $4.7 million gain from the sale of base stock and portfolio investments; Redpath is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges

title: TOKHEIM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Business People; New President Chosen At Waste Company
description: Charles J. McMullin, 32, has been appointed president of Scientific Inc., a solid- and liquid-waste collection and disposal company based in Scotch Plains, N.J. He succeeds Marvin H. Mahan, 61, who continues as chairman and chief executive officer.

title: GRACE PERIOD IS ANNOUNCED FOR DRAFT REGISTRATION
description: Thomas K. Turnage, the director of Selective Service, announced today that young men who failed to register on time for a possible draft had a grace period until Feb. 28 to sign up without fear of prosecution.

title: DANCE: HARLEM TROUPE IN TWO HOLDER PREMIERES
description: YOU never know the direction a season will take. As it turns out, the Dance Theater of Harlem is offering what turns out to be a very exciting and enjoyable engagement at the City Center.

title: CURTICE-BURNS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 25
FIRS BANK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
EX-CELL-O CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
WOMEN IN VOTE FRAUD CASE MOVING TO COUNTY JAIL
description: Two black civil rights workers who were imprisoned last week in Alabama after their conviction on vote fraud charges will be transferred from a prison for women to the Macon County jail and placed in a work-release program, Alabama officials said today.

title: Georgia House Rejects Rights Amendment
description: The Georgia House rejected the proposed Federal equal rights amendment by a 2-to-1 ratio today, rebuffing appeals by two former Presidents and pleas by feminists and black lawmakers for ''a vote of courage.'' The vote was 116 to 57.

title: DOMINION BANKSHARES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: All per share figures for 1980 are restated for a 5% stock dividend declared inSeptember 1981

title: SHELDON V. EKMAN, JUDGE IN TAX COURT AND LAW INSTRUCTOR
description: Judge Sheldon V. Ekman of the United States Tax Court died of a heart attack Monday in Philadelphia, where he had been assigned to conduct a trial session. Judge Ekman, who lived in Washington and had been a longtime resident of Westport, Conn., was 61 years old.

title: areas SHAPING SPACE: NEW WAYS WITH WALLS AND DOORS
description: LOFT and apartment residents often find themselves in a similar predicament: They want to alter their space, by opening up one area to another, by putting up a wall to get privacy or by creating dualpurpose areas. The designers and architects who apply them selves to these problems, in both flexible loft areas and apa rtments divided more rigidly into partitioned rooms, appear to be most successful when their strategies revolve around innovative us e of doors, partitions and walls.

title: SELF-MADE FINNISH CHIEF
description: A month or so ago, one of the eight candidates in this week's Finnish presidential election told a friend that he felt as if he was running against an opponent with a charmed life.

title: PACIFIC LIGHTING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Georgia-Pacific Fights Court Rule
