description: The Georgia-Pacif ic Corporation of Portland, Ore., a major forest products comp any, said it would petition the United States Supreme Court for a r eview of an unfavorable United States Court of Appeals decision in a civil class-action antitrust suit involving the sale and distribut ion of softwood plywood.

title: Q&A
description: Q. The tenant in our house installed a dryer in the kitchen and vented the moist air from it into an adjoining closet that also contains our oil-fired hot-air furnace. We are concerned about this and feel it should be corrected. This closet is not vented, and since there is no basement, we would have to ven t the dryer through the ceiling into the attic or through the floor into the crawl space. Thecrawl space i s not vented, so it would accumulate moist air from the dryer if we v ented it there. The attic has louvers at each end, so weplan to send the moist air up there instead. Do you recommend this? -Mrs. D.P.S., Forest Heights, Md.

title: Simplify, Simplify
description: Mr. Thoreau is a rather odd bachelor who simply cannot be pried out of his funny little Massachusetts cabin (''I went to the woods ...''). And it seems to us that the man who said ''Simplify, simplify'' is just the guy to talk Mrs. Reagan into abandoning her announced plan of accepting loans and gifts of clothes from American designers. ''Mrs. R,'' we can hear him saying, ''do you need this aggravation?''

title: RITES FOR RED SMITH ARE HELD 'WITH TEARS, WITH LAUGHTER'
description: The solemnity of a memorial mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral for Red Smith was tempered yesterday by happy recollections of the Pulitzer Prize-winning sports columnist of The New York Times, who died last Friday at the age of 76.

title: Faulty Valves Blamed In Explosion at School
description: Investigators said today that two faulty valves, one of which had just been replaced, caused a water heater explosion that killed five children and a teacher and injured 34 in a school cafeteria on Tuesday.

title: WHAT GEO. WASHINGTON CALLED HIS WIFE
description: To the Editor:

title: Advertising; People
description: * Dick Hanley has joined Ted Bates as a senior vice president, creative director.

title: No Headline
description: LAKERS VANQUISH NETS, 132-11 3

title: NEEDIEST ARE AIDED BY RETIRED PERSONS WITH FIXED INCOME
description: For many contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, a compassionate impulse to give can mean a real sacrifice, especially by retired persons whose donations come out of fixed incomes pinched by inflation.

title: Pursuit Heats Up
description: The pursuit of Reggie Jackson heated up yesterday when the freeagent player and his agent met with Buzzie Bavasi, vice president of the California Angels in Phoenix. The agent, Gary Walker, also talked by telephone with the Atlanta Braves and Baltimore Orioles.

title: A HAIG CONFIDANT GETS POST AT WHITE HOUSE
description: William P. Clark, the new national security adviser, appointed a confidant of Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. as his deputy today, and made other personnel changes aimed at strengthening foreign policy operations at the White House.

title: GREATER JERSEY BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After extraordinary gains of $266,143 for the quarter and $450,177 for the year on extinguishment of debt

title: REINING IN THE SAUDI ECONOMY
description: If this country's political leaders had to run for office, they could easily point to their record in fighting inflation.

title: Texaco Is Said By Honduras To Curb Fuel
description: A Honduran official has accused Texaco Inc. of causing a gasoline shortage in an attempt to force the Government to approve a tripling of gasoline prices.

title: PARKER-HANNIFIN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Economic Analysis
description: The United States economy is in steep recession, with the gross national product falling at a 5.2 percent rate in the latest quarter. Inflation has declined steadily for nearly two years, and unemployment seems to have replaced rising prices as the nation's biggest economic worry.

title: Jets 3, Capitals 0
description: The Winnipeg goaltender, Doug Soetaert, turned aside 21 shots to post his first shutout of the season. The victory was the first for the Jets in 10 games against Washington since entering the National Hockey League in 1979.

title: WHIRLPOOL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Pacific Holding Bid for Cannon
description: The Cannon Mills Company said it would remain neutral concerning an offer by the Pacific Holding Corporation to purchase all outstanding shares of the company's stock for $44 each.

title: BURROUGHS UP A BIT
description: Two more large manufacturers of computers yesterday reported generally weak earnings for the fourth quarter of 1981 and for the year. The NCR Corporation said its net income dropped 23.6 percent for the fourth quarter and 18.3 percent for the year. The Burroughs Corporation reported an improvement in earnings for the quarter and the year, but last year's earnings were severely affected by a writeoff and other factors.

title: HOW TO DEAL LIVELY DINNER COMPANIONS
description: NOT too long ago, a number of people who invariably used place cards for their dinner parties decided that the idea was silly, unnecessary and smacked of too much formality. It would be much better, they reasoned, to let guests choose their own dinner partners and sit where they pleased. That way, the hosts couldn't be accused of playing favorites, and friends would be happy communing with kindred souls.

title: BRIEFING
description: S OME of the intellectuals who most vocally supported President Reagan's candidacy are beginning to express uneasiness, even opposition, to his foreign policy.

title: S.E.C. Studies Sales Role of 4
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday ordered a hearing into staff charges that four former employees of Ross Stebbins Inc., a New York securities concern, misled customers who bought common stock of the Revest Resources Corporation in 1979.

title: VIKING GIVING WRITERS FREE LIABILITY INSURANCE
description: In a major break with publishing industry tradition, Viking Penguin will provide its authors with free comprehensive liability insurance coverage. The coverage, thought to be first in the industry, will protect authors of all Viking and Penguin original books published in 1982, as well as authors of all original books contracted for this year for later publication.

title: U.S. VETOS U.N. RESOLUTION ON GOLAN ANNEXATION
description: The United States vetoed a compromise Security Council resolution today that called for the punishment of Israel for annexing the Golan Heights.

title: Books of the Times; Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt WITNESS TO POWER. The Nixon Years. By John Ehrlichman. 432 pages. Illus- trated. Simon & Schuster. $17.50.

title: LAIDLAW TRANSPORTATION LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
AMFAC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including net income from discontinued operations of $2.3 million

title: HARTMAN THEATER SEEKS MORE MONEY AND PEOPLE
description: The Hartman Theater will mount a fundraising drive and seek a wider regional audience in attempting to retire a $850,000 debt, its artistic and financial directors said today.

title: FIRST TENNESSEE NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
A DEATH CAMP SURVIVOR, SLAIN BY MUGGERS, BURIED
description: Sol David, who survived Nazi concentration camps in World War II only to be murdered in Brooklyn by a robber who killed him with a single bullet, was buried yesterday.

title: MODINE MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
description: The company is listed on the Midwest Stock Exchange

title: CITIZENS FIDELITY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Dow Off 1.52 as Rates Climb
description: Rising short-term interest rates sent the stock market down moderately yesterday in accelerated trading. A few of the specialsituation and transportation issues registered the largest declines.

title: CRACKDOWN ON SLUGS IN SUBWAY TURNSTILES RESULTS IN 17 ARRESTS
description: Transit Authority detectives arrested 17 persons yesterday on charges of illegally entering a Rockefeller Center subway station by using slugs, jumping the turnstile or attempting to use an invalid pass. It was the third such series of arrests in recent weeks.

title: The U.N. Today; Jan. 19, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Scientific and Technical Subcom- mittee of the Committee on the Peaceful Uses of Outer Space - 10:30 A.M.

title: Gardening; GROWING ORCHIDS UNDER INDOOR LIGHTING
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Jane Rosen, a member of the American Orchid Society, has been growing orchids for five years. By JANE ROSEN

title: PAN AMERICAN BANKS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Trust Houses Net Off
description: Trust Houses Forte Ltd., an international lodging and recreation conglomerate with substantial interests in the United States, reported that earnings fell 10.7 percent in the year ended Oct. 31 as interest expenses soared and tourism declined.

title: DINNER BELL FOODS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
TAKEOVER PRICE LIFTED BY FRANCE
description: France's Socialist Government said today that it would pay roughly 8 billion francs, or $1.5 billion, in additional compensation to shareholders in the leading industrial companies and banks that it plans to nationalize. The amount represents approximately a 25 percent increase over the compensation originally planned.

title: 'DAVID,' JEWISH LAD IN GERMANY
description: AT the beginning of Peter Lilienthal's ''David,'' the Jewish title character is seen as a small boy, being kicked and beaten by some of his anti-Semitic German countrymen. When David is seen next, he has grown into a quiet, observant young man with extraordinarily good instincts for staying out of trouble.

title: MARINE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
JERRICO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After charges of $56,000 for the quarter and $113,000 for the 6 months from achange in accounting

title: NORTHWEST BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Belfast Man Admits Devlin Murder Attempt
description: Andrew Watson, a 25-yearold Belfast electrician, pleaded guilty today to the attempted murder a year ago of Bernadette Devlin McAliskey, the Roman Catholic nationalist leader.

title: CENTRAL PACIFIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
VIETNAM POST-MORTEM: DID ARMY ALTER FACTS?
description: In a 90-minute television program, CBS News asserts that there was an effort by American intelligence officers to ''suppress and alter'' estimates of the size and strength of Communist forces in Vietnam before the 1968 Tet offensive.

title: Governor Carey's Bad News
description: Never mind the grim satisfaction in Governor Carey's budget message that New York's unemployment rate, 8.2 percent, is somewhat less than the national average. What he really paints is a dour picture of a government striving to do too much with too little.

title: MULTIBANK FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CROMPTON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 3
description: B-Including a gain of $861,000 from an accounting change

title: Transactions; BASEBALL CLEVELAND (AL) - Signed Sid Monge, a pitcher, to a three-year contract.  Signed Bill Nahorodny, a free-agent catch- er, and assigned him to Charleston of the International League.  PHILADELPHIA (NL) - Signed Ron Reed, a pitcher, to a three-year contract.  MILWAUKEE (AL) - Signed Mark Brouhard, an outfielder; Ned Yost, a catcher; Marshall Edwards, an outfield- er; and Frank DiPino and Rich Oldsen, both pitchers.; BASKETBALL INDIANA (NBA) - Sent Mike Bantom, a forward, to Philade
description: ATLANTA (NBA) - Traded Al Wood, a forward, and Charlie Criss, a guard, to San Diego for Freeman Williams, a guard.

title: ATLANTIC BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including an extraordinary gain of $1,178,000 for the quarter and the year

title: Comings and Goings
description: Buck Williams of the Nets and Michael Ray Richardson of the Knicks were among seven players added to the Eastern Conference team for the All-Star Game, to be played at Byrne Meadowlands Arena on Jan. 31. The others named, in a vote of Eastern Conference coaches, were: Robert Parish, Boston; Bob Lanier and Sidney Moncrief, Milwaukee; Bobby Jones, Philadelphia; and Dan Roundfield, Atlanta. ... Manuel Seoane, one of the two former baseball pitchers sought in the kidnapping and robbery of two men, surrendered to the police in Largo, Fla.

title: AFRICAN FORCES IN CHAD SEEN SHIFTING ROLE
description: The Organization of African Unity's peacekeeping force in Chad is trying to redeploy forces and is seeking reinforcements to meet a potential new threat from a rebellious former Defense Minister, according to Western and Nigerian military sources here.

title: Business Digest; THURSDAY, JANUARY 21, 1982; The Economy
description: President Reagan will seek temporary increases in excise taxes on gasoline, cigarettes, whisky and wine, officials said. Beer was excluded. Mr. Reagan is expected to seek to allot part or all of the additional revenues for distribution among the states. (Page A1.)

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The Business Dige st in Business Day yesterday incorrectly identified a company whose earnings declined 3.6 percent in the fourth quarter last year. It was the Westinghouse Electric Cor- poration.

title: TANDON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ARMCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
REAL G.N.P. DECLINES AT 5.2% RATE
description: The nation's gross national product, after adjustment for inflation, fell at an annual rate of 5.2 percent in the fourth quarter of 1981, confirming that a widespread recession has overtaken the economy.

title: STONE & WEBSTER INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
THE INCREDIBLE SHRINKING TV SETS
description: AMERICA'S dual passions, automobiles and televisions, have undergone similar design changes in recent years. Ten years ago, when families were tooling around in their stretch Oldsmobile Delta 88's, the chances were that they spent Sunday night s watching ''Bonanza'' in front of a massive wooden television unit that resembled a truncated coffin. The Mediterranean-style con sole was the center of the middle-class living room.

title: AKZONA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net income; results for the latest year reflect a gain of $912,000 from the adoption of an accounting standard relating to foreign currency translations

title: GEORGIA-PACIFIC NET FELL 65.6% IN PERIOD
description: The Georgia-Pacific Corporation, hard hit by the nationwide decline in home building, reported yesterday that earnings in the fourth quarter of 1981 plunged 65.6 percent as sales declined 7.6 percent.

title: Joseph Ternbach Dies; Restorer of Sculptures
description: Joseph Ternbach, a restorer of three-dimensional art works, died of a heart attack Monday on his way to his studio in Forest Hills, Queens.

title: PILLERS RELISHES 49ers' WINNING SPIRIT
description: Lawrence Pillers spent a little more than four years playing on the defensive line for the Jets, always troubled by what he considered a tense atmosphere.

title: SOVIET PIPELINE CALLED VULN ERABLE
description: A senior American Defense Department official said today that the Reagan Administration could delay a West European plan to import Soviet natural gas ''for many years'' by banning the export of all goods and technology needed to build the pipeline that is to carry the gas from Siberia.

title: 'ABSURD SPECULATIONS' ABOUT A VANQUISHED FILIPINO
description: To the Editor:

title: One State, Fiscal '82 Second article of a series appearing periodically on the Reagan budget's impact on Pennsylvania
description: Grim economic statistics are bringing increasing problems to the brick Executive Mansion overlooking the broad Susquehanna River, Gov. Dick Thornburgh conceded, relaxing in his living room after another day of what he calls his annual midwinter hibernation.

title: AT STAKE IN DETROIT
description: This month marks the 68th anniversary of the $5 day - Henry Ford's legendary doubling of wages, an innovation that galvanized productivity and increased car sales. In a turnaround, Ford and General Motors now seek survival through wage and benefit concessions by their workers. This strategy might spur sales now, but will it create jobs in the long run?

title: A TAX PACKAGE FOR TRANSIT FARE IS FALLING SHORT
description: A tax package enacted last year to subsidize mass transit and to help protect the 75-cent fare may produce up to $100 million dollars less than originally projected, state officials said today.

title: LAWRENCE J. DELANEY
description: Lawrence J. Delaney, a former Suffolk County Democratic leader in the 1960's and Huntington town leader, died Monday in Palestine, Tex.

title: The U.N. Today; Jan. 21, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Advisory Committee for the 1982 Outer Space Conference - 3 P.M.

title: STAGE: 'CHERRY ORCHARD' PRESENTED BY THE C.S.C.
description: IN recent seasons, especially with its cycle of ''Oedipus'' plays and its epic two-part version of ''Peer Gynt,'' the Classic Stage Company has become one of New York's primary classical resources. With its new production of ''The Cherry Orchard,'' as staged by Rene Buch, the C.S.C. takes a step backwards. This is a tiresome, superficial version of a great classic that undermines both Chekhov and Alex Szogyi's articulate translation.

title: NATIONAL CITY BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
President's Steel Remark Is Disputed
description: The steel industry, praised by President Reagan for embarking on a ''multibillion-dollar expansion plan,'' in fact seems to be embarking on a much smaller spending program, analysts said today.

title: ETHYL TO BUY INSURER
description: The Ethyl Corporation has agreed to buy the First Colony Life Insurance Company of Lynchburg, Va., for about $270 million in cash and stock, the two companies announced yesterday. The takeover would be another move in Ethyl's series of diversifications out of the declining business of making antiknock chemicals for gasoline.

title: Spanish Police Seize Terrorist Arms Cache
description: Antiterrorist police seized five tons of weapons and explosives belonging to the Basque E.T.A terrorist organization today and arrested two presumed members of the group.

title: Advertising; Life Sets Campaign To Spread Good Word
description: Unlike the old Life, which died going head to head with television, the new Life is thriving in a world of its own as the only consumer magazine with the large format.

title: Advertising; Shearson Campaign Charted
description: ''I F you want to out-image Merrill Lynch, you have to beat the bull,'' said Bill Giles, a vice president and the creative director at Grey Advertising for Shearson/ American Express. It was his way of getting into the story of a new campaign, a story that he would tell with Edward H. Meyer, president and chairman of the agency, and Robert H. Hussey, vice president and account supervisor.

title: RALSTON PURINA CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes gains equal to 3 cents a share from an accounting gain; C-After $2.5million loss from discontinued operations

title: News Analysis
description: Governor Carey's proposed budget is an effort to deal with a s eeming ambiguity in public attitudes toward government: the desire fo r both less government and more government services.

title: Steel Units' Results Mixed
description: Armco Inc. said yesterday that its earnings for the fourth quarter rose 10.5 percent, to $70.1 million, or $1.04 a share, compared with $63.4 million, or $1.13 a share, during the last quarter of 1980.

title: North Stars 3, Rockies 1
description: DENVER (UPI) - Tom McCarthy and Neal Broten each had a goal and an assist to pace Minnesota. Broten rifled in a 10-footer at 17:54 of the first period and set up McCarthy on a 15-foot backhand shot through the pads of the Colorado goalie, Glenn Resch, at 14:24 of the middle period.

title: RAYTHEON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FIRST INTERSTATE BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Article 181221 -- No Title
description: A $1 million fund voted to Representative Frederick W. Richmond as a pension by the corporation he controlled was voided yesterday by a State Supreme Court justice in Manhattan. The justice , Martin B. Stecher, ruled that the sum, payable over 10years beginni ng in 1978, constituted ''an illegal gift of corporate assets.'' He enjoined further payments and ordered Mr. Richmond, a Democrat of B rooklyn, to repay the portion already received, about $300,000.

title: The Life and Death of Black Colleges
description: Private black colleges have a unique and remarkable history. Created initially for freed slaves, they provided what was once the only opportunity for blacks to obtain a higher education.

title: OREGON METALLURGICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MARION LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes gains from discontinued operations

title: MOSCOW: IT TAKES 2 TO TANGLE
description: There are clues to the mysteries of the Soviet Union's foreign policy in the behavior of its people.

title: PARIS WARNED ON ARMENIANS
description: Turkey has warned France that Armenian militants might stage violent protests to exert pressure on a French court where a French Armenian is to go on trial Friday on charges of trying to kill the Turkish ambassador to Switzerland in 1980.

title: Ghanian Is Held in Dutchess On Illegal-Weapons Charges
description: A former resident of Ghana was arrested early today at a rest stop on Interstate 84 and charged with illegal possession of weapons after the police said they had found 24 pistols in his car.

title: Keeping Up Appearances; Chairman Felon
description: Convicted of selling his office, Joseph Margiotta, the Nassau County Republican chairman, wants to keep his post while he tries to have his conviction set aside. He has called an executive committee meeting for today - after a Federal judge's sentence renders him a fully certified felon - to seek a change in the party rule that bars convicted felons from office.

title: HARVARD DEFINES SOUTH AFRICA POLICY
description: Harvard University is apparently considering altering its policy of automatically divesting itself of bonds and certificates of deposit in banks that issue direct loans to the Government of South Africa.

title: RANGERS DEFEAT ISLANDERS FOR 2D STRAIGHT TIME, 3-2
description: The scoring came in three quick bursts at Madison Square Garden last night, and when it was over the Rangers had defeated the Islanders for the second straight time.

title: ABRUPT AND DISASTEROUS TRUCKING DEREGULATION
description: To the Editor:

title: MIDLANTIC BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The per share figures reflect a 3-for-2 stock split distributed in October 1981

title: REPUBLIC NEW YORK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
THRIFT UNITS JOIN FORCES IN AID PLEA
description: Two trade groups representing 7,000 savings and loan associations and 450 mutual savings banks have joined forces to ask for what could be vast Federal assistance to deal with the impact of low-yielding mortgages on the depressed earnings of their members.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Allied Corp. said it had received several proposals to purchase the Converse division of its Eltra Corp. subsidiary, including a management buyout offer from a number of Converse executives.

title: Bridge: Sweden Defies a Tradition By Failures in Title Events
description: If one lists the countries that have won world open titles, there is one surprising omission: Sweden has never won, in spite of a powerful bridge tradition stretching back half a century. Two key figures in that tradition are Eric Jannersten, a great writer and teacher, and Jan Wohlin, a great player.

title: NEW STRAIN ON AN OVERTRAINED COURT
description: To the Editor:

title: EVANS PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including a $2.5 million gain from a change in accounting; year-ago results have been restated to reflect a change in accounting for vacation pay as requiredby FASB Statement No 43

title: LUKENS STEEL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Microsystems Inc., Santa Clara, Calif., has named Richard C. Joy a vice president-research and development.

title: Home Beat; FURNITURE BY ROHDE
description: ALTHOUGH he was not the most influential designer, Gilbert Rohde did pioneer t he manufacturer-owned furniture showroom, to which designers and architects have special access. He also sought to simplify furn iture design, use new materials and develop modular furniture.

title: Hispanic Judge Accepted F or California Top Court
description: The appointment of Cruz Reynoso to the California Supreme Court was confirmed tonight on a 2-to-1 vote by the Commission on Judicial Appointments. He will be the first person of Hispanic ancestry to serve on the state's highest court.

title: FLORIDA STEEL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including $1,942,690 tax credit; C-Net income; year-ago results reflect a reduction equal to 1 cent a share as required by FASB Statement No 43 regarding accounting for compensated absences; shares outstanding have been adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split, effective March 12, 1981

title: REPUBLIC STEEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After $3,156,000 pretax charge from writeoffs of certain plant facilities andraw material properties and $20,600,000 tax credit; C-Includes $79,148,000 pretax gain from the sale of interest in coal reserves less pretax charges of $35,964,000 from writeoffs on plant facilities and raw material properties; D-Includes$21,100,000 tax credit

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The 20th century is beginning to wind down, and people want to know how we got where we are.'' - Byron Dobell, new editor of American Heritage magazine. (A17:2.)

title: MUSIC: BRASS OF OUR TIMES
description: MONDAY evening's program by the New York City Brass at the Good Shepherd-Faith Church offered a welcome look at several less wellknown works by major 20th-century American composers.

title: Critic's Notebook;  INEVITABLE: DE ZAYES IS BEING REDISCOVERED
description: THERE are careers in the arts that are virtually impossible to classify, and Marius de Zayas's is obviously one of them. De Zayas, who was born in Veracruz, Mexico, in 1880 and died in Greenwich, Conn., in 1961, was once a prodigious and versatile figure on the American art scene - an artist, a writer, an editor, a cartoonist and caricaturist, a film maker, an art dealer and public-relations agent, and even in one period of his life (in the early 1930's, when he occupied a chateau in the French countryside outside Grenoble), a chicken farmer. Was it Cyril Connolly who said that every young writer had to satisfy three illusions - falling in love, starting a magazine and having a chicken farm? Well, de Zayas seems to have managed all of this and a lot more in a very crowded life.

title: Sittler Traded to Flyers
description: Darryl Sittler, the Toronto Maple Leafs' career-scoring leader, was traded to the Philadelphia Flyers today for Rich Costello, the Flyers' 1981 second-round draft pick who plays center for Providence College; a second-round pick in the 1982 draft, and unspecified ''considerations.''

title: Coach Denies Charge
description: When Pam Parsons resigned as women's basketball coach at the University of South Carolina two weeks ago, both she and the university cited ''personal reasons'' and ''philosophical differences.''

title: CENVILL INVESTORS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Earnings for the fourth quarter do not include business operations of Cenvill Development Corp, a former subsidiary

title: 28 Die in Bangladesh Crash
description: An overcrowded bus swerved to avoid a speeding truck and plunged 30 feet off a bridge today, killing 28 people and injuring 40, witnesses said. Seventeen passengers were said to have died instantly in the accident 19 miles east of Dacca.

title: INDICTMENT LAYS 6 CITY MURDERS TO PROBATIONER
description: An indictment yesterday charged David Bullock, a 21-year-old on probation, with six shooting murders in Manhattan between last Dec. 5 and Jan. 4.

title: 2 'ANNIE' PRODUCERS GET 6-MONTH TERMS IN A TAX FRAUD CASE
description: Two producers of the Broadway musical ''Annie'' were sentenced today to six months in prison for their role in a tax scheme that bilked celebrities of millions of dollars.

title: GOLD COINS TO TRADE ON AMEX TODAY
description: The nation's first organized market in gold bullion coins will open today on the floor of the American Stock Exchange, when members of a new Amex unit begin trading the one-ounce gold ''maple leafs'' minted by the Canadian Government.

title: PENTAGON URGES 50 CARGO PLANES FOR RAPID FORCE
description: The Defense Department has recommended to President Reagan that 50 of the world's largest cargo planes be purchased to provide aerial transport for the Rapid Deployment Force, Congressional officials said today.

title: News of Music; COAST-TO-COAST, OPERA BASKS IN NEW POPULARITY
description: THOUGH contemporary operas have had a hard time proving themselves or finding a public, the traditional operatic repertory is in an era of wide popularity, expanding far beyond the bounds of the major houses. Festivals present operas during the once-silent summer months; smaller companies have grown; lost or neglected operas are enthusiastically revived.

title: U.S. APPROVES MEN'S USE OF DRUG TO HELP FERTILITY
description: A hormonal drug used for 10 years to help infertile women was approved yesterday by the Food and Drug Administration for use by men with fertility problems.

title: BEGIN IS REPORTED TO ASSURE THE U.S. ON LEBANON MOVES
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin, in a letter toPresident Rea gan, has reassured the United States that Israel will not make atta cks in Lebanon unless there is a ''clear provocation'' from Palestin ian or Syrian forces, Israeli and Administration sourcessaid today.

title: Black Sea Natural Gas
description: The Soviet Union this year will produce natural gas from the Black Sea for the first time, the press agency Tass said today.

title: LIBYA USING U.S. TRUCKS TO HAUL SOVIET TANKS
description: Four years ago, the United States approved the sale to Libya of 400 heavy-duty trucks manufactured in Wisconsin. The Libyan Government, which was barred from receiving military equipment made in the United States, provided written guarantees that the vehicles would be used only for agricultural purposes.

title: MARYA ZATURENSKA, LYRIC POET RECEIVED PULITZER PRIZE IN '38
description: Marya Zaturenska, an American lyric poet who received the Pulitzer Prize in 1938, died of heart failure Tuesday in Shelburne Falls, Mass., where she lived. She was 80 years old.

title: IRAN, A YEAR LATER, ACCUSES U.S. OF NOT HONORING HOSTAGE ACCORD
description: Iran said yesterday, on the first anniversary of the release of the American hostages, that the United States had not lived up to the accord that brought their 14-month captivity to an end. The charge was denied in Washington.

title: SEMYON K. TSVIGUN, OF THE K.G.B., DIES
description: Gen. Semyon Kuzmich Tsvigun, the deputy head of the K.G.B., the Soviet intelligence and internal security agency, died Tuesday at the age of 64, it was announced today.

title: ACETO CHEMICAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ALBERTO-CULVER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Player Quits in Protest Over Drugging Charges
description: Pernell Tookes, a senior forward, has quit the Florida State basketball team, saying James Bozeman's accusations of improper medical treatment and drug use ''opened my eyes,'' a school newspaper reported today.

title: McGovern to Teach in Santa Barbara
description: George McGovern, the 1972 Democratic Presidential candidate who was defeated in 1980 for re-election as a Senator from South Dakota, has a new job. On Monday, Mr. McGovern, who has spent the last year on the lecture circuit, began teaching a course on religion and politics in America at the University of California, Santa Barbara.

title: Show of Shows
description: It must have sounded like a great idea when Charles Wick tried it out on Ronald Reagan in the Oval Office:

title: PNEUMO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
X-RATED MOVIES STILL MAJOR FACTOR IN THE VIDEO MARKET
description: The rapid introduction of new movies, rock shows and family feature films is creating a boom in video cassette sales and rentals. But within this market, dealers say, the adult X-rated tapes remain a major factor.

title: 2 Massachusetts Towns To Decide on Tax Issue
description: Vote rs in the t owns of Stow and Weston will vote in March on overriding a tax-limiti ng proposition. Selectmen in both towns voted unanimously T uesday to hold a special referendum on the issue, a move made possible when Gov. Edward J. King signed legislation Jan. 5 allo wing some communities tovote on overriding the 1980 measure that limi ted property taxes.

title: FIRST JERSEY NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
TALKS SUSPENDED AT G.M. AND FORD
description: Negotiations on an early contract between the United Automobile Workers and General Motors and Ford, the nation's two largest car manufacturers, were suspended today because of disagreements on job security, the size of wage and benefit concessions by union workers and the duration of a new contract.

title: ELECTRONIC SLEUTHS SEEK CRASH DATA
description: Minutes after the ''black boxes'' were recovered from the Air Florida jet's crash site in the Potomac River this morning, Paul Turner was already working in a laboratory no bigger than a small bedroom. The moment he had been awaiting for nearly a week had arrived.

title: MUSIC: FILLED WITH SPIRIT IN MIDMORNING
description: ANYONE wondering what spirit is missing from our concert life would have done well to have stopped by Carnegie Hall the other morning. One heard the treble whir of chatter, the running in the aisles, the voluble enthusiasm; the audience was full of the expectation that precedes a major concert event, with none of the traditional solemn stuffiness.

title: BENGALS' CURTIS: MORE THAN A SPRINTER
description: Ten years after he left the University of California at a time when the school was being put on probation for a violation involving him, Isaac Curtis still finds it difficult talking about why he transferred to San Diego State.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption on Monday incorrectly characterized the Finnish Presidential election. The election was the first contested one since 1956.

title: Market Place; The Rising Toll On Dividends
description: THOSE cash dividends so dear to stockholders are feeling the effects of a bumpy economy. The Ford Motor Company served notice last week that it would not pay a dividend for this year's opening quarter - marking the first such omission since the company went public in 1956.

title: IN ICE LOCKED HARBOR, A CHILLY JOB
description: The Coast Guard cutter Wire plowed steadily through the ice-laden waters of New York Harbor yesterday, clearing the way for essential traffic such as fuel-laden barges.

title: Potash Mine to Close
description: The National Potash Company will suspend production Feb. 3, putting about 275 employees out of work, the president of the company, Rene L. Latiolais, said today.

title: Hers; HOW SEPARATE FROM THE REST OF SOCIETY SHOULD AN ARTIST BE?
description: ILIVE in a village where the artists are buried separately from other people. On one side of the road is the main cemetery with its neat rows of headstones. On the other side, across the brook behind the framer's shop and up the grassy knoll, is what has come to be known as the Artists' Cemetery.

title: Ships Collide in Baltic Sea
description: A Swedish trawler sank today after colliding with a Soviet tanker in the Baltic Sea, coast guard officials said. One Swedish fisherman was missing and four were saved.

title: UNITED BANCORP OF ARIZONA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FIRST NATIONAL BANK OF NEW JERSEY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Erika Hess Captures 4t h Straight Cup Slalom
description: Erika Hess of Switzerland won her fourth consecutive World Cup slalom today and regained the lead in the overall cup standing from Irene Epple of West Germany.

title: One-Foot Record Snow Fa lls on the Twin Cities
description: By The Associated Press A record snowfall of more than a foot in eight hours buried Minneapolis and St. Paul, as new storms began across the nation yesterday.

title: Technology; Catching Up With Down
description: AS the nation muddles through what could turn out to be a record cold winter, synthetic fiber manufacturers surveying the shivering masses might be moved to work a little harder on developing textiles that insulate as well as goose and duck down.

title: Aminoil-China
description: Aminoil USA Inc. of Houston, a subsidiary of R.J. Reynolds Inc., announced its signing of an agreement to buy refined gasoline from the China. Under the agreement, Aminoil will import the Chinese gasoline into its Vancouver, Wash., facilities, beginning with a shipment of about 180,000 barrels scheduled early in February. An Aminoil spokesman said the company has options on further shipments, but noted that they would depend on market and demand conditions.

title: INSULATION GROUP CRITICIZES AGENCY
description: Less than three weeks before the Consumer Product Safety Commission is to decide whether to ban urea-formaldehyde insulation as a health hazard, an industry trade association charged today that the commission's decision-making process is being sabotaged by its own staff.

title: BUNKER HILL MINING TO END OPERATIONS
description: COEUR D'ALENE, Idaho, Jan. 20 (AP) - The Bunker Hill Company, a mining complex, will close ''as quickly as possible,'' its owner said today after efforts to find a buyer failed. Bunker Hill had produced 20 percent of the nation's lead, zinc and silver.

title: CITYTRUST BANCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
New Yorker Wins BBC Conducting Prize
description: Andrew Litton, 22 years old, of New York, won the top prize tonight in the BBC's sixth International Young Conductors contest.

title: BEARINGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FARMERS IN POLAND PRESSED ON GRAIN
description: The Polish Government, conceding the existence of a drastic shortage of bread and flour, announced measures today that are designed to force farmers to sell grain to the state.

title: Business People; Chief of Nashville Bank Rises from Presidency
description: At the Commerce Union Bank of Nashville, with $1.5 billion in assets, Edward G. Nelson, 50, has been elected chairman and chief executive officer. Dennis C. Bottorff, 37, will succeed him as president and chief operating officer.

title: Why Make More Poison Gas?
description: President Reagan stands at the brink of a reckless decision to break a 12-year moratorium and produce a new poison gas weapon. He does not need it or the trouble it will bring.

title: Distillate Supply Down
description: Inventories of distillate, used mainly for home heating and diesel fuel, fell sharply in mid-January as the cold wave swept across much of the nation, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday.

title: DEBATE OVER BLAME FOR RECESSION BLURS REAGAN'S ECONOMIC RECORD
description: In his first year in office, President Reagan has been remarkably successful in persuading Congress to embrace his economic policy but less successful with the economy itself. This winter the economy is decidedly weaker, and unemployment higher, than the White House forecast a year ago, and the question is whether the strong expansion the Administration predicts for 1982 and beyond will occur despite a continuing tight-money policy.

title: AMERICAN FLETCHER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FOR MRS. KIRKPATRICK, FRUSTRATION IS A PART OF THE JOB
description: After a year on the job, Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the American delegate to the United Nations, acknowledges that she is frequently frustrated but says she has no plans to resign ''for the foreseeable future.''

title: REAGAN HOME SALE FAILS AT KEY POINT
description: Like many other homeowners these days, President and Mrs. Reagan have experienced the disappointment of seeing the anticipated sale of their home collapse at the last minute because of a dispute over mortgage money.

title: STAUFFER CHEMICAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes $14,832,000, or 34 cents a share, after tax gain on facility disposal

title: SOVIET PREMIER CALLS FOR DIALOGUE NOT CONFRONTATION, WITH THE U.S.
description: Prime Minister Nikolai A. Tikhonov said today that the Soviet Union ''does not seek confrontation'' with the United States and was doing all it could ''to direct the course of events into constructive dialogue.''

title: Sahl Updates His Well-Honed Humor
description: He has been writing Hollywood scripts with no more than prospective success, and he has a television project in the works that he cannot talk about yet. So what is a fellow to do?

title: British Railways Shut For 4th Day in a Week
description: Britain's state-run railways were shut down today for the fourth day in just over a week as 20,000 engineers began a 48-hour strike for a pay raise that they say they were promised.

title: TAPE RECORDERS RECOVERED AT AIR FLORIDA CRASH SITE
description: Navy divers retrieved the two electronic flight recorders today from the wreckage of the Air Florida plane that crashed here a week ago, killing 78 persons. Hopes for learning the causes of the accident rest chiefly on these devices.

title: SHUCKS, IT'S ONLY THE LAW
description: A three-judge Federal court, in an opinion by a distinguished judge, decides an important question of Federal law. The Supreme Court affirms the decision. Other courts follow it. The Federal Government incorporates it in rules, and three Presidents enforce them over a 10-year period.

title: SUSPECT IN KILLING OF WOMEN, 82
description: An unemployed 27-year-old man was arrested yesterday and charged with the beating death last week of an 82-year-old woman who lived in the apartment beneath his on 18th Avenue in the Bath Beach section of Brooklyn.

title: SUPREME COURT WEIGHS RIGHT TO STRIKE L.I.R.R.
description: The United States Supreme Court heard arguments today on whether the Long Island Rail Road is subject to the Federal Railway Labor Act, which permits strikes, or to New York's Taylor Law, which forbids strikes by public employees.

title: SANTA FE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FIRST CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Laker Air Aid
description: The General Electric Company said ithad agreed to participate with the McDonnell Douglas Corporation and European financial institutions in the financ ial restructuring of Laker Airways. G.E. said details of its parti cipation ar e still beingworked out. G.E. said it does not anticipate making a dire ct injection of cash to laker or assuming an equity position in the company. No other details were immediately available.

title: The Police Blotter
description: The owner of a Met Food Store at 1199 East 233d Street in the Wakefield section of the Bronx fatally shot 35-year-old Kenneth Ford as he attempted to rob the store at 1:09 P.M., the police said. The store owner, John Ireli, 44, had a pistol permit. Another man, still unidentified, was arrested as a possible accomplice. ... An unidentified man was found dead of multiple stab wounds of the head and chest at 1:50 P.M. in front of 808 MacDon ough Street in Brooklyn's Bedford-Stuyvesant section. ... Th e badly burned body of an unidentified man believed to be in his ear ly 30's was found at 5:30 A.M. in the stairwell of an IND subway s tation at 48th Street and the Avenue of the Americas.

title: REAGAN AIDES SEE RISK IN THE NEWS CONFERENCE
description: For a President who has a reputation as one of the nation's most effective political communicators, Ronald Reagan seems curiously shy about his televised news conferences, a political forum normally exploited by Presidents and their political strategists to project strength, put down criticism or convey some policy message.

title: ASTROSYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
UNIVERSAL FOODS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes $1,475,000 gain from sale of Wisconsin cheese plant

title: UNIMAX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-Includes $193,400 tax credit; C-Includes $14,500 gain from discontinued operations

title: ONE YALTA 'COMPROMISE' ON POLAND THAT REALLY NEVER WAS
description: To the Editor:

title: JANE KESSLER
description: Jane Kessler, a film editor for WCBS-TV and CBS News, died Monday in New York Hospital after a long illness. She was 31 years old. Miss Kessler worked on numerous documentaries for ''CBS Reports,'' among them ''Gay Power/Gay Politics'' and ''Nurse, Where Are You?'' She is survived by her husband, Joel Siegel, a critic for WABC-TV's ''Eyewitness News'' and ABC-TV's ''Good Morning America''; her mother, Belle; two brothers, Richard and Steven, and a sister, Rosalie.

title: NCR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
2 Are Arraigned In Officer's Ki lling
description: A State Supreme Court justice yesterday revoked the record $10 million bail set for Anthony N. LaBorde, a reputed Black Liberation Army member, and held him without bail on charges that he had killed a police officer and wounded his partner.

title: BURROUGHS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net loss; C-After a special charge of $125.1 for the quarter and the year; results for the latest periods include operations of System Development Corp, acquired in January 1981 and Memorex Corp for the month of December on the equity basis of accounting

title: Freeway Killer's Death Urged
description: A Superior Court jury today recommended the death penalty for William Bonin, who was convicted last week of the murders of 10 youths whose bodies were found dumped near freeways. The jury deliberated for two days.

title: Gretzky Gets Richest Pact
description: Wayne Gretzky, the Edmonton Oilers' high- scoring center, and the club's owner, Peter Pocklington,have agreed t o a renegotiated 21-year contract that will make Gretzky the h ighest-paid player in National Hockey League history.

title: ROLM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1
FOUR FOR THE PRICE OF ONE
description: ANY league that dares to stretch from Bangor, Me., to Anchorage, Alaska - with a change of dog sleds in Lethbridge, Alberta - deserves attention for sheer courage. But the Continental Basketball Association is creative as well as daring.

title: Date Is Set for Hearing On Ouster of Williams
description: The Senate will be asked to begin considering on Feb. 2 whether to expel Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. for his conduct in the Abscam case, a spokesman for the New Jersey Democrat said today.

title: INDIA SAID TO DROP MOST STRIKE CASES
description: Most of the nearly 25,000 people arrested in connection with Tuesday's general strike were reported to have been released this morning as labor officials and Government supporters made conflicting statements on the strike's impact.

title: U.N. RESOLUTION ON GOLAN
description: Following is the text of a resolution on the Israeli annexation of the Golan Heights that was vetoed by the United States today in the Security Council:

title: BROAD NATIONAL BANK OF NEWARK (NJ) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
First Interstate Has Fall in Net
description: The First Interstate Bancorporation reported yesterday that fourth-quarter net operating earnings declined 6.8 percent, to $63.3 million, from $67.9 million in the comparable period of 1980. On a per-share basis, earnings dropped to $1.55 from $1.70.

title: FOR SOME OF CITY'S BRIGHTEST, MAJORS AND MINORS DON'T MIX
description: Are such subjects as music, art and drafting as important as English, mathematics and science? Officials at the Board of Education think so, and they have directed two of New York City's special academic high schools - Stuyvesant and Bronx Science - to give added importance to minor subjects, which the schools have not counted in students' grade averages.

title: ST. JOHN'S SETS BACK SYRACUSE
description: For the St. John's basketball team, the 73-62 victory over Syracuse at Alumni Hall last night could be looked back upon as a night of progress.

title: A.C.L.U. Files Suit to Regain 11 Books Seized by the F.B.I.
description: The American Civil Liberties Union filed suit in Federal District Court for the District of Columbia today seeking the return of 11 books confiscated by the Federal Bureau of Investigation from a free-lance writer and two technicians when they returned to the United States from Iran last month.

title: Home Improvement; MOLDINGS OF PLASTIC LOOK LIKE WOOD BUT ARE EASIER TO WORK WITH
description: PLASTIC moldings that look like wood but are much lighter and easier to work with - and in most cases less expensive than comparable wood moldings - are widely available.

title: Finn Gains in Rally
description: Walter Rohrl and Christian Geistdorfer of West Germany maintained their lead in the Monte Carlo automobile rally tonight, but Hannu Mikkola of Finland was the star of the second stage. In the two-day run, including 13 speed tests, Mikkola and his navigator, Arne Hertz of Sweden, pulled their Audi Quattro up from fourth place, 3 minutes 14 seconds behind the Rohrl team, to second, only 1:45 behind.

title: FIRST RAILROAD & BANKING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
JURY STARTS DELIBERATING IN THE ABBOTT MURDER CASE
description: A jury of seven men and five women in the murder trial of Jack Henry Abbott was sent to sleep in a hotel last night after nearly eight hours of deliberations without a decision. The jury spent yesterday afternoon rehearing eyewitness testimony in the case.

title: AMERICAN NUCLEAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
6 INDICTED IN COAL FRAUD CASE
description: Six men were arrested and indicted yesterday on charges of defrauding as many as 400 people in various states of $40 million in investments in nonoperational coal mines in Kentucky.

title: DETROIT BANK CORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
COMMONWEALTH EDISON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
HOSTILITY MARKS VIEW ON JUDICIAL PRECEDENTS
description: In asserting Tuesday that there was ''no basis in law'' for denying tax exemptions to segregationist private schools, President Reagan displayed a lack of deference to judicial precedent that has antecedents throughout American history but seems to be a particular hallmark of his Administration.

title: Gov. Thone Seeks New Term
description: Gov. Charles Thone of Nebraska announced today that he would seek a second term, pledging to continue the economic programs he said had saved taxpayers more than $100 million.

title: LITCO BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
LAKEWOOD BANK & TRUST CO (DALLAS, TEX) reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
INDIANA NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
REEVES BROS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 2
AIDES SAY REAGAN WILL ASK CONGRESS FOR EXCISE TAX RISE
description: Administration officials reported tonight t hat Presiden t Reagan, wrapping up the final decisions on his proposed 1983 budget, had decided to ask Congress for temporary increases in Federal excise taxes on gasoline, cigarettes, whisky andwine, but not on beer.

title: KRUEGER, W A, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
LIFTOFF ON MARCH 22 SET FOR A THIRD TEST OF THE SPACE SHUTTLE
description: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration announced today that March 22 was the official launching date for the space shuttle Columbia's third test flight, a weeklong orbital mission around the earth.

title: STAMFORD NEED FOR PARAMEDICS CALLED PRESSING
description: One afternoon last fall, a 45-year-old executive her e collapsed with cardiac arrest as he walked toward a friend's desk to complain of indigestion. The friend did not know anyfirst aid, an d the ambulance crew that arrived four minutes later hadno advanced t raining in administering drugs or in electric stimulation o f the heart.

title: Advertising; Ex-Scali Partner Moves To Firehouse Magazine
description: As one of the five founding partners of Scali, McCabe, Sloves, J. Leonard Hultgren picked up a nice bundle when the agency was acquired by Ogilvy & Mather. Some of it went to start the Hultgren and Samperton Winery in Sonoma, Calif., and some went into buying out some of the f ormer investors in Firehouse Magazine.

title: FINANCIAL BRIEFS
description: * Anacomp Inc. is offering $50 million in 13 7/8 percent convertible subordinated debentures due January 2002 at a price of 85to yield 16.45 percent, to be sold through a Shearson/American Express Inc. group.

title: LINCOLN NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
OWENS-CORNING FIBERGLAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MISSOURI RALLIES TO DEFEAT KANSAS, 41-35
description: Ricky Frazier made six free throws in the final minute to help unbeaten Missouri turn back an upset bid by Kansas, 41-35, in a Big Eight Conference game tonight.

title: HARVARD MAY SELL ART TO PAY FOR WING
description: Harvard University is considering a plan that would allow its Fogg Art Museum to deaccession some of its less valuable works to help pay for the operation of a new wing of the museum, it was learned today.

title: TRANS-CANADA PIPELINES LTD reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: Revenue for 1980 has been restated

title: PHONE COMPANY OF THE FUTURE
description: Until a few years ago, the Evans Telephone Company was a sleepy, rural utility like most of the nation's 1,430 independent telephone companies.

title: WILLAMETTE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes $4,494,000 gain from a accounting change

title: Salvadoran Police Seek Rebel Hide-Outs
description: A thousand members of the National Police moved into northern San Salvador Tuesday, blocking streets with light tanks and searching houses for rebel hide-outs.

title: KENNAMETAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results for the latest 6 months reflect the restatement of first quarter results to comply with FASB Statement No 52 regarding foreign currency translations which increased net income by $1.5 million, or 12 cents a share; year-ago quarter and 6 month results include a tax credit of approximately $960,000, or 8 cents ashare

title: LONDON EXHIBITION OF INDUSTRIAL DESIGN
description: LONDON Two of the most influential names in British design - Terence Conran, the owner of the Habitat stores in Europe and Conran's in America, and the Victoria and Albert Museum here, a 130-year-old institution devoted to design and the decorative arts - have officially joined forces. They have opened the Boilerhouse Project, a new exhibition hall, created by renovating the old boiler room of the museum as a showcase for industrial design.

title: Home Away From Home
description: The U.S.O.'s new center at Kennedy International Airport joins the Gen. Douglas MacArthur Memorial Center at Times Square and the U.S.O. Shows program at veterans hospitals and military bases as a sign Americans have not forgotten their fellow citizens in uniform.

title: SHIFT IN FEDERAL-STATE ROLES SEEN AS CURBING MEDICAID AND WELFARE
description: Administration officials said today that President Reagan's proposal for the Federal Government to pay state Medicaid costs while shifting welfare responsibilities to the states was part of a long-term strategy for controlling the cost of both programs.

title: Libbey Unit Seeks Union Givebacks
description: The Libbey-Owens-Ford Company's LOF Glass division management is seeking a 10 percent reduction in labor costs from union employees, a union leader involved in negotiations in Toledo said today.

title: Ford Steel Unit Drawing Offers
description: The Ford Motor Company has been approached by companies wanting to buy its newly reorganized steel division, but officials at the No.2 United States auto maker, behind the General Motors Corporation, are not saying whether Ford has put the operation up for sale.

title: 49.6% Decline At Whirlpool
description: The Whirlpool Corporation's earnings for the final quarter of 1981 declined 49.6 percent from the fourth quarter of 1980, the appliance manufacturer said today.

title: REVOLT OF THE HAWKS
description: When Super Bowl XVI reaches its halftime, the teams will switch sides and proceed to march on the goals they previously defended. The same switch is taking place in Washington in the game between detenteniks and hard-liners.

title: PARAMOUNT DROPS NEW COPPOLA FILM
description: Paramount Pictures will not be distributing Francis Coppola's film ''One From the Heart.'' A spokesman for the company said it had reached this decision last Thursday but had declined to make the information public at that time.

title: UTAH POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes $11,850,000 gain from the sale of interest in power plants

title: AEROFLEX LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Key Rates
description: * Maximum rate payable by savings institutions.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Columbia Official Played Matchmaker
description: Karl Eller, the 53-year-old entrepreneur, communications executive and matchmaker of the planned Coca-Cola Company-Columbia Pictures Industries merger from the Columbia side, recalled yesterday his first conversation about the possibility of a deal with Ira C. Herbert, an executive vice president of Coke. Mr. Eller is currently president of the Columbia Pictures communications division.

title: No Headline
description: Penguins Win, 5-4, On Kehoe's 3 Goals

title: Argentine Junta Jails A Former Member
description: Argentina's ruling military junta jailed one of its former members for 10 days today after he joined a growing tide of public criticism of the junta's policies.

title: ZIONS UTAH BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NBI INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CESSNA AIRCRAFT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Kean Extends Order On Prison Crowding
description: Governor Kean, on his first day in office, today extended for four months an emergency order that allows the state to lodge its prisoners in county jails with empty cells.

title: RUSSELL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Latest results are for 13 and 52-week periods and year-ago results are for 14 and 53-week periods

title: GERULAITIS IS FINED $15,000 FOR CONDUCT
description: Vitas Gerulaitis, suspended several months ago for a series of minor conduct violations on the tennis court, has now been fined a total of $15,000 for two major offenses. It is the largest levied against a player by the Men's International Professional Tennis Council.

title: COST OF SHERRILL PACT DISMAYS EDUCATORS
description: Chief executive officers of universities across the country reacted strongly yesterday to Texas A & M's decision to pay Jackie Sherrill, its new football coach, $287,000 a year, calling this highest salary at a United States college or university ''wild'' and ''beyond reason,'' among other things. Some members of the A & M faculty even expressed mild surprise.

title: Judge Hears Case On Nuclear Waste
description: A judge heard arguments on whether Federal regulations could overrule a New York City regulation that prevents nuclear waste from being transported on highways through the city.

title: Tourney Shift Seen
description: The Sammy Davis Jr.-Greater Hartford Open golf tournament will probably be moved from the Wethersfield Country Club to another, more difficult course in 1984 in hopes of getting more name players, according to Jim Senk, head of the Greater Hartford Jaycees, the sponsor.

title: Helpful Hardware
description: ALINE of very attractive and well-designed bathroom fittings and accessories, heretofore inaccessible to the general public, is now available at retail. The Vola line was designed by Prof. Arne Jacobsen and many of the component parts have been selected for the Design Collection at the Museum of Modern Art.

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, JANUARY 21, 1982
description: International Israel has reassured the United States that it will not make attacks in Lebanon unless there is a ''clear provocation'' from Palestinian or Syrian forces, according to Israeli and Reagan Administration sources. The pledge was made, they said, by Prime Minister Begin in a letter to President Reagan. (Page A1, Column 1.) Washington vetoed a resolution in the United Nations Security Council that called for punishing Israel for annexing the Golan Heights. (A13:1-3.)

title: Treasury Notes Yield 15.08%; Up 2 Points In a Month
description: The Treasury sold a record amount of two-year notes yesterday at an average yield of 15.08 percent. The yield on this maturity has jumped by two percentage points since the December auction.

title: It's Official for Ditka
description: The Chicago Bears announced the appointment of a new coach yesterday, and, as had been expected virtually from the moment Neill Armstrong was dismissed two weeks ago, the appointee turned out to be Mike Ditka, the former all-pro tight end and most recently a n assistant coa ch with Dallas. Ditka, 42 years old, played 12 seasons in the Nation al Football League, the first six with the Bears.

title: New Editor at American Heritage Magazine
description: In his 25 years in publishing, Byron Dobell has been senior editor of Life, editor in chief of Bookworld, managing editor of New York, assistant director of planning for Time-Life Books and, in three separate tours, managing editor, executive editor and editor in chief of Esquire.

title: Advertising; Warner/Amex Satellite Switches Assignments
description: The Warner/Amex Satellite Entertainment Company, the cable TV programming suppliers, has moved advertising responsibility for two of its units from Ogilvy & Mather to its subsidiary, Scali, McCabe, Sloves, and for a third to LPG/Pons, a recently created, broadcastpromotion subsidiary of Lois, Pitts, Gershon.

title: MERCANTILE BANCORPORATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The 1981 net before securities gains for both periods includes an after-tax gain of $5,911,000 from sale of substantially all loan servicing rights and relatedassets of its Mercantile Mortgage co unit

title: DUKE PROFESSOR TO LEAD NATIOINAL HEALTH INSTITUTES
description: The Reagan Administration has selected Dr. James B. Wyngaarden, a professor of medicine at Duke University, to be director of the N ational Institutes of Hea lth, the world's leadingsponsor of biomedical research.

title: HARTFORD NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
President Marks His First Year
description: President Reagan gathered the hierarchy of his Administration today to toast his first anniversary in office and to remind them that ''you're here to drain the swamp'' of big Government.

title: THE AMERICAN EDGE
description: To the Editor:

title: CALENDAR OF EVENTS: ANTIQUES AT ARMORY
description: Winter Antiques Show and Preview Party, Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue at 67th Street.

title: U.N. PANEL APPROVES $1.5 MILLION FOR AFRICA NEWS AGENCY OPERATION
description: A United Nations panel today approved a $1.5 million grant to help a regional news service begin operations in Africa.

title: GEORGIA-PACIFIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Net income figures for the year-ago fourth quarter and year reflect a decrease of $1 million from an accounting change for vacation pay

title: NOTES ON PEOPLE;
description: A follow-up: After four years of legal wrangling, Frania Ty Lee can now collect the $9.2 million she won in a case in which she maintained she was once secretly married to the billionaire H.L. Hunt.

title: ARCHER-DANIELS-MIDLAND CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Lucas Will Play
description: John Lucas will be permitted to play with the Washington Bullets while undergoing a rehabilitation program for using cocaine, the National Basketball Commissioner, Larry O'Brien, has announced. However, during a meeting which lasted several hours, O'Brien told the 28-year-old Lucas that any recurrence of his involvement with drugs would result in an immediate suspension.

title: Design Notebook; ROBERT ADAM'S ZESTFUL CONTROL OF CLASSICISN
description: THE exhibition that has just opened at the Cooper-Hewitt Museum commemorating the work of Robert Adam, the great 18th-century architect of English neo-classicism, begins with an unexpected touch: a set of 10 drawings for buildings that are not in that vein at all. They are Gothic, and they range from a study for a Gothic folly, a half-serious pavilionlike structure, to plans for a Gothic tower, a Gothic church and an altogether exquisite and zestful Gothic bridge that spans a tiny river in charming indifference to the nature of its site.

title: COMPUTER NETWORK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FIRST NATIONAL BOSTON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Going Out Guide
description: FROM THE GERMAN

title: Ravitch Keeps His Son Off Subways at Night
description: The chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, Richard Ravitch, said yesterday that he did not permit his 14-year-old son to ride the subway at night because of what Mr. Ravitch termed his ''anxiety'' over crime in the system.

title: A CHANGE IN STYLE FOR A FUND-RAISER
description: For 17 year s, Alix Gres, the legendary French couturier, showed her collectio n in New York each year to benefit the Musicians' Emergency Fun d. Because the Mitterrand Government withdrew some tax benefits, Mme . Gres canceled her trip this year.

title: Art People; A French invasion.
description: WE'VE had an Italian art invasion and a German wave, and there'll soon be an onslaught from France. On Feb. 6, at 17 New York galleries, the work of 26 more or less established French artists will simultaneously be unveiled, thanks to a first-time collaboration between the French Government and commercial art dealers in Paris and New York.

title: POTOMAC ELECTRIC POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
REAGAN SAID TO ASK STATES TO ASSUME FOOD STAMP COSTS
description: President Reagan wants to transfer the Federal food stamp program to the states as part of a sweeping proposal to redefine Federal and state responsibilities for social welfare, Administration officials said today.

title: TEXT OF PETITION SIGNED BY POLISH INTELLECTUALS
description: Following is the text of a petition sent today to Poland's Parliament and Archbishop Jozef Glemp. The petition, signed by a group of leading Polish intellectuals and artists, was translated by The New York Times from the Polish.

title: RLC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
EASTERN GAS & FUEL ASSOCIATES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ELEMENTS THAT A JURY WEIGHS
description: In both murder in the second degree and manslaughter in the first degree, the defendant intends to kill his victim, but the jury can exercise ''leniency'' where the defendant demonstrates that he killed the victim while suffering from ''an extreme emotional disturbance.''

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on Wednesday about El Salvador gave an incorrect figure for the number of deaths that a Roman Catholic organization, Pax Christi In- ternational, says have occurred there. The correct figure is 20,000.

title: Economic Scene; Will the Slump Be Over Soon?
description: THE latest estimate by the Commerce Department, showing a 5.2 percent decline in real gross national product for the fourth quarter of 1981, was no surprise. Indeed, some economists had expected it to be worse.

title: AID LOSS SPURS EARLY RUSH TO COLLEGE
description: Next Monday Theresa White, a 16-year-old student at John Dewey High School in Brooklyn, will be starting as a freshman at Wagner College on Staten Island instead of finishing her junior year of high school.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY: PORTRAIT OF GERMANY IN 1800'S
description: RESEARCH into the history of photography is getting m ore and more to resemble the field of archeology, as one a fter another the layers of buried photographic treasures are unearthe d from the dust of unexamined archives and the neglect of years. The latest ''dig'' intothis rich photographic past, focusing our att ention on the history ofphotography in Germany, can be found at the I nternational Center of Photography, 1130 Fifth Avenue, at 94th Stree t.

title: U.S. Regrets Greek Decision On Servicing of Soviet Ships
description: The United States expressed regret today about a Greek decision to permit the repair of Soviet ships in a state-controlled shipyard.

title: 'ZOOT SUIT,' FILMED FROM THE STAGE
description: ''ZOOT SUIT,'' which opens today at the Criterion 2 and other theaters, is a holy mess of a movie, full of earnest, serious intentions and virtually no achievements. Its source material, like that of the 1979 Brodway and Los Angeles stage productions on which it is based, is the 1942 Los Angeles trial of a group of young Mexican-Americans, or Chicanos, for the murder of a rival gang member.

title: The Region; Roadblocks Check Oil Shortchanging
description: NEWARK (AP) - A 100-inspector task force from New Jersey's Division of Consumer Affairs set up surprise roadblocks for heating-oil delivery trucks yesterday in a search for faulty or rigged devices that could shortchange customers.

title: BIG BOARD SHORT INTEREST DOWN 4.6 MILLION SHARES
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that short interest was down by 4.6 million shares, to 85 million, in the month ended Jan. 15.

title: DEALER IN BOATS DESCRIBES SALES THAT AVOID TAX
description: A dealer of luxury sailboats testified yesterday that, because of competition, he sold boats to corporations in Delaware that were incorporated by New York residents so they could avoid paying New York State sales tax on the vessels.

title: AMERICAN MOTOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
GLENMORE DISTILLERIES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net loss; share earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 4% stock dividend declared in October 1981

title: Pop Jazz; URBANIAK HAS AN IDEA WHOSE TIME HAS RETURNED
description: MICHAL URBANIAK, the jazz violinist from Poland, who settled in the United States eight years ago playing electronic fusion music with a group called, appropriately, Fusion, is once again on what he calls his ''circular road.''

title: GENERAL BANCSHARES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
The Region; Man Found Guilty In Attack at Jail
description: A man convicted of murdering his ex-wife while he was on a one-day pass from a mental hospital was found guilty in Nassau County Court of assaulting a jail guard.

title: OUR PROPER ATTITUDE TOWARD THE ANGOLANS
description: To the Editor:

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American International Group Inc. has named James T. Howe to the newly created position of vice president-bank relations, and Frank Filipps as treasurer.

title: NATIONAL BANCSHARES OF TEXAS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago results have been restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in May

title: AND NOW, PRIVATE, PROFIT-MAKING PRISONS
description: To the Editor:

title: STAGE: CLEAVON LITTLE PLAYS POP SINGER IN 'KEYBOARD'
description: KEYBOARD HIGGINS is a famous fictional rhythm-and-blues singer of the 1940's who has found himself superseded by rock-and-roll. He has fallen on emotionally hard times, and his memories have dulled his appetite for living in the present. However, ''Keyboard,'' a new play by Matt Robinson at the Henry Street Settlement's New Federal Theater, only rarely conveys the wistfulness of the title character. One's disappointment is deepened by the fact that Cleavon Little is certainly capable of being a touching Keyboard.

title: AT GROLIER, A VIEW OF BALLET TAKING ITS FIRST STEPS
description: FIRST kings and their courts danced, then itinerant carnival performers and their horses, and finally stars. ''Ballet Before 1800,'' a free exhibition of prints, books and documents now at the Grolier Club, chronicles this progression in absorbing detail, giving a sense of how ballet began and grew, and the colorful characters who practiced it along the way.

title: TULTEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 27
description: B-Includes $473,000 gain from the sale of a unit

title: ALCAN ALUMINIUM LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Notes on People; Borges Visits South, Fulfilling a Dream
description: '' 'Huckleberry Finn' was the first novel I ever read through,'' said Jorge Luis Borges, the Argentine author, who is in New Orleans for 10 days to lecture and accept honors from two universities.

title: ALAGASCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NELSON, THOMAS, & SONS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
No Headline
description: President and Mrs. Reagan will spend their Easter vacation in Barbados in early April at the winter resort home of Claudette Colbert, Larry Speakes, the deputy White House press secretary, said today.

title: THREE LUTHERAN BODIES HOPE TO MERGE BY '87
description: Leaders of three North American Lu@theran denominations said yesterday that they hoped to complete the formation of a new Lutheran church by 1987.

title: Rockwell Net Climbs 11.7%
description: The Rockwell International Corporation, which was awarded two Air Force contracts yesterday for $2.2 billion for the development of the B-1B bomber, reported today that net income for its first fiscal quarter of 1982, which ended Dec. 31, was $61.9 million, or 81 cents a share, an increase of 11.7 percent from last year's comparable period, when net income was $55.4 million, or 73 cents a share.

title: Surgeon General Is Sworn In
description: Dr. C. Everett Koop, a pediatric surgeon from Philadelphia, was sworn in today as Surgeon General of the United States in a quiet ceremony that contrasted with the loud battle over his nomination. The Senate confirmed Dr. Koop as head of the Public Health Service on Nov. 16. The opposition centered on his views against abortion.

title: PRODUCERS OF PAPER LIST INCOME
description: The International Paper Company, the world's largest paper producer, said yesterday that its fourth-quarter profits more than tripled, primarily because of the sale of its Canadian subsidiary.

title: Dispute Over Licensing Threatens Grand Prix
description: The South African Grand Prix, the first race of the Formula One season, was near collapse today in a dispute over drivers' licenses.

title: U.S. OFFERS TO AID JOURNALISM IN THIRD WORLD
description: The United States offered today to support selected communications projects in developing countries as part of a ''cooperative association'' with a Unesco-sponsored program to promote third world journalism.

title: PUBLISHING: BEST SELLERS, YES, BUT QUALITY, TOO
description: THE catalogues heralding the spring publishing season are chock full of annou ncements for novels with commercial potential, self-helpbooks and boo ks that the publishers hope will be as successful this year as books about cats and cubes were in 1981. In short, they are offering the kind of fare that, depending on one's point of view, is (1) necessary to help pay the rent or (2) symptomatic of what ails the publishin g industry.

title: Sports People; Mariners Absolve Kuhn
description: Public pressure, and not Commissioner Bowie Kuhn, forced the Seattle Mariners to cancel exhibition games this spring against a Cuban baseball team, said Dan O'Brien, the Mariners' president.

title: Index; International
description: Saudi car craze is both a blessing and a blight A2 U.S. offers some aid to the press in the third world A2 Montreal transit strike ends after six days A3 Seoul proposing to exchange en- voys with North Korea A4 Around the World A6 Japanese ship captain denies car- rying arms to Filipino rebels A6 Soviet warns Angola on U.S. moves A8 Go vernment/Politics Legislature in Hartford votes to repeal a business tax B3 Williams seeks stay of sentence on bribery charges B4 Washington Talk Briefing A16 The President ponders increasing taxes A16 The workings of the Joint Eco- nomic Committee A16 Four Presidents and their chari- table contributions A16 General Around the Nation A12 Control of prisons at issue in Framingham raid A14 Report identifies sites of nuclear weapons A14 Rikers prisoners discover pride in work at parks B3 Two pistols found in apartment of Brink's suspect B4 Boat dealer describes how buyers avoided state sales tax B4 Franklin Ave. subway shuttle in Brooklyn shut for repairs B5 PARKING REGULATIONS Because of snow, alternate-side parking is suspended in New York City today. All other rules remain in effect. Weekend Weekender Guide C1 Where to celebrate Chinese Year of the Dog C1 Walking tour of Alley Pond Park and environs C26 Theater: Broadway C2

title: 'Annie' Co. Disavows 2 Convicted in Tax Fraud
description: Roger L. Stevens, general partner with James Nederlander of the ''Annie'' Company, producers of the musical ''Annie,'' issued a statement yesterday disassociating the company from Irwin Meyer and Stephen Friedman. Mr. Meyer and Mr. Friedman were sentenced Wednesday to six-month prison terms for their r ole in a bogus taxshelter scheme.

title: Alcoa and Alcan in Sharp Fall
description: The Aluminum Company of America, the nation's largest aluminum producer, and Alcan, Canada's primary aluminum concern, reported sharply lower earnings yesterday for the fourth quarter of 1981. Alcoa

title: FIRST ALABAMA BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
WILMINGTON TRUST CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
COLOR TILE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Around the World; White House Is Happy With Salvador Inquiry
description: The Reagan Administration is happy with the recent pace of El Salvador's 13-month-old investigation into the murders of three American nuns and a missionary, Alan D. Romberg, the deputy State Department spokesman, said today.

title: DR. JAMES COLSTON, EX-HEAD OF BRONX COMMUNITY COLLEGE
description: Dr. James A. Colston, president of Bronx Community College from 1966 to 1976, died of a heart attack yesterday in Greensboro, N.C., where he had lived. He was 72 years old.

title: RIP TORN IN 'STRANGER IS WATCHING'
description: ''A STRANGER Is Watching'' is the handiwork of Sean S. Cunningham, who also directed ''Friday the 13th.'' Mr. Cunningham's new film is a lot better. It's also less bloody and, though an opening rape-andvicious-murder sequence hints otherwise, more of a thriller than an exercise in viciousness and gore. ''A Stranger Is Watching'' opens today at the Cinerama I and other theaters.

title: SHAW INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
Broadway; 'Preppy Handbook' is turning into 'Preppy Musical.'
description: ''THE OFFICIAL PREPPY HANDBOOK,'' a fixture of the trade-paperback best-seller list for more than a year, has spawned something of a cottage industry, with T-shirts, date books, mugs, teddy bears and other preppy paraphernalia coming off the assembly line.
