title: ARKANSAS BEST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net loss after extraordinary charges of $17,286,352 for the quarter and $17,126,352 for the year from the writeoff of operating rights; C-Including $9,960,000 extraordinary tax credit

title: CONTRASTS IN HOST CITY FOR SUPER BOWL
description: As is usually the case when the well-to-do drop in on a poor cousin, this is a week of contrasts in Detroit. The municipal airport is preparing to receive more than 1,000 private airplanes in the next few days bearing jolly people with precious tickets to the Super Bowl game Sunday in the Pontiac Silverdome, 28 miles north of here.

title: Lockheed Gain by 1985 Seen in C-5 Deal
description: If the Lockheed Corporation ends up with a contract to produce 50 more C-5 Galaxy transport planes as recommended by the Defense Department, it would help the company eventually build up employment at its division in Georgia and contribute to profits by about 1985.

title: ALUMINUM CO OF AMERICA (ALCOA) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CORRECTION
description: A recipe for marjolaine in The Living Section on Wednesday omitted an ingredient for the pastry cream. The recipe should have included two and two-thirds cups of milk.

title: MUSIC: BARENBOIM PLAYS BARTOK'S C ONCERTO NO.1
description: IT is easy to make Bartok's Piano Concerto No. 1 sound savagely ugly. There is some testimony to support the claim that the composer himself played it that way, having recently decided to rejoice in the fact that the piano is a percussion instrument incapable, at least in theory, of producing a true legato or a vocal line.

title: HARRIS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Sports People; Olympic Post to Carlos
description: John Carlos, who was expelled from the 1968 United States Olympic team for giving the black-power salute during the playing of the national anthem at Mexico City, has been hired by the Los Angeles Organizing Committee for the 1984 Summer Games. Carlos, a sprinter who won a bronze medal in the 200-meter dash at Mexico City, will work with community and youth groups in the downtown Los Angeles area. ... Because of a stress fracture of the right shinbone, Eamonn Coghlan needed 40 minutes to run four miles in training last week. Coghlan, the best indoor miler in the world last year, said that he should be able to resume competition late next month but that his hope of breaking 3 minutes 50 seconds for the mile this year ''are down the drain.''

title: Weekender Guide; Friday; FREE JUILLIARD FESTIVAL
description: The Juilliard School is presenting a free six-concert festival of contemporary music, including 14 world, American or New York premieres. But the first concert, tonight at 8 at Alice Tully Hall, will offer previously heard major works: Elliott Carter's Variations for Orchestra, George Crumb's ''Echoes of Time and the River'' and the Eighth Symphony of Peter Mennin, the president of Juilliard. The Juilliard Orchestra under the direction of Stanislaw Skrowaczewski will perform. On Sunday at 3 P.M., a chamber music concert in the Juilliard Theater will include works by Lawrence Widdoes, Leslie Bassett, Milton Babbitt and Roy Harris. The festival runs through Jan. 29. Information: 874-7515 or 874-0465.

title: EQUIMARK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Operating earnings; C-Net income

title: United Technologies In Telefunken Talks
description: The United Technologies Corporation and AEG-Telefunken, the West German electrical company, said today that they are negotiating a major semiconductor venture.

title: SOCIETY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Big Board Officer Quits
description: Donald D. Kittell, 44 years old, one of the two executive vice pr esidents of the New York Stock Exchange, ha s resigned to join Dean Witter Reynolds, the big brokerage firm, the exchange confirmed yesterday.

title: AT PHILOSOPHY MUSEUM, PLEASE FEED THE MIND
description: Does the Museum of Philosophy actually exist? ''Yes,'' says Prof. Spencer Schein, curator of the museum, ''because everything hangs together consistently.'' Though the question may seem facetious, it really isn't. The elucidation of such questions is what Pace University's Institute and Museum of Philosophy specializes in.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Aegis Corp. said it had agreed to a settlement with a dissident stockholder, Sol Goldman, under which Aegis purchased 979,600 shares of its stock owned by Mr. Goldman and his brother for the aggregate price of $3.4 million.

title: BOISE CASCADE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including extraordinary gains of $5.7 million for quarter and $12.5 million for year

title: BOB ADDIE
description: Bob Addie, a retired sports columnist and former president of the Baseball Writers Asso ciation of America, died Monday n ight.

title: Notes on People; Birthday Bonus; An Extra Reason to Celebrate
description: He celebrated his 26th birthday in Los Angeles and turned 27 in Paris, so it was time that Ken Page had a birthday in New York. On Wednesday he did.

title: 8 Hurt as Car Brushes Crowd in Monte Carlo Rally
description: A car competing in the final stages of the Monte Carlo Rally hit a crowd and injured eight people, one seriously, before dawn today on an Alpine road in southern France.

title: CHARITABLY SPEAKING...
description: A glance at the income tax records of the last four Presidents suggests that Richard M. Nixon was the most charitable of the lot. A closer reading, however, shows that the Government eventually disallowed most of Mr. Nixon's giving, which involved little cash, after illegalities came to light.

title: ROCKWELL INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MARSHALL & ILSLEY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
UNITED ARTISTS COMMUNICATIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net loss; revenues include losses of $17,000 in the latest quarter and gains of $722,000 in the year-ago quarter from disposal of properties; year-ago results adjusted for 200% stock dividend paid in July 1981

title: THATCHER CABINET HAS UNION VICTORY
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher won a major victory today in her effort to tame British unions when the coal miners rejected a call by their leadership for authority to call a strike.

title: Notes on People; Turning a Reagan Home in Illinois Into a Shrine
description: The President's older brother, Neil Reagan, has changed his mind and decided it might not be a bad idea after all to turn the Reagan home in Dixon, Ill., into a Presidential shrine.

title: FIRST NATIONAL BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
F OUR STUDIOS DISCUSS RELEASE OF COPPOLA FILM
description: Representatives of Columbia, Universal, Warner Bros. and Embassy will be meeting today with executives of Zoetrope Pictures to discuss releasing Zoetrope's $26-million impressionistic musical love story, ''One From the Heart.''

title: SCIENTIFIC-ATLANTA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FULL STUDY ORDERED ON PHONE PACT
description: Judge Harold H. Greene today ordered a fulldress public review of the Federal antitrust settlement that frees the American Telephone and Telegraph Company to enter new businesses after divesting itself of its 22 local operating companies.

title: FIRST VIRGINIA BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
B.B. King's in Town
description: The blues guitarist B.B. King and his band are making two appearances in the metropolitan area this weekend.

title: GEOSOURCE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Sports People; Cooney Told to Rest
description: He has fought a total of only 5 rounds 43 seconds since Dec. 14, 1979, and now it could be two or three weeks before the oft-injured Gerry Cooney will be allowed to even spar again in preparation for his March 15 title fight against Larry Holmes, the World Boxing Council's heavyweight champion, according to Dr. Edwin Campbell. Dr. Campbell, physician for the New York State Athletic Commission, examined the top-ranked contender yesterday and found a ''tear, or partial rupture, of some fibers'' in a posterior left shoulder muscle. He agreed with the prescription of rest given by Cooney's physician, Dr. Barry Fischer.

title: BANCORP OF PENNSYLVANIA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Around the World; The Sandinists Silence Radio News Program
description: A popular radio news program has been ordered off the air by the Government ''for broadcasting news harmful to the armed forces,'' Nicaragua's General Administration of News Media said today.

title: Restaurants; Stylized Japanese, bustling pub-cafe.
description: NISHI is a small, dark and polished little stage-set of a restaurant on Amsterdam Avenue between 75th and 76th Streets. Stylized versions of Japanese dishes are featured in a modern dining room, where spotlights reflect on glassy black walls. A white brocade bridal kimono mounted on the wall and a tiny, decorative sushi bar add dramatic Japanese accents to the setting and the staff is friendly and accommodating. Although the food lacks consistent excellence at Nishi, a number of delicious and satisfying options are available at fairly moderate prices.

title: No Headline
description: EXCERPTS FROM MESSAGE BY POLAND'S BISHOPS

title: More Tankers Use Suez
description: The Suez Canal Authority said 21,577 tankers sailed through the international waterway in 1981, an increase of 784 tankers from the previous year, the newspaper Al Gomhuria reported today.

title: INTERNATIONAL PAPER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including a $215 million, or $4.24 a share, net gain from the sale of Canadian International Paper Co and a $12.5 million net charge associated with the phasing out of certain wood product facilities; C-Including a $65 million, or $1.32 share, net gain from major land transactions, $8 million net charge associated with phasing out of unprofitable product lines and $215 million, or $4.34 share, net gain from sale of Canadian International Paper; D-Including $10.4 million, or 22 cents share, net gain from major transactions

title: News Analysis
description: Despite mon ths of dispute about the way the Koch administration grants tax ab atements and exemptions to real estate developers, the City Council finally passed a bill this week that keeps things very much the way they were.

title: MISSISSIPPI VALLEY GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
RECIPROCITY IN TRADE
description: The international trade system is suffering from a deep, prolonged crisis, and there is a growing danger of protectionism among the chief economic powers. To avoid that peril, the United States must press for far greater reciprocity in the trade and investment policies of other countries.

title: SECURITY BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ROHM & HAAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes provisions for closedown and disposal of assets of $7.2 million for the quarter and $11 million for the year

title: The City; A $180,000 Theft R eported at Hilton
description: A guest at the New York Hilton reported that his room was broken into during the day and $180,000 in American and French currency was taken, the police said.

title: N.F.L. Players' Union Warns of Strike
description: Ed Garvey, executive director of the National Football League Players Association, said today that, if substantial progress were not made by May 1 in negotiations between his association and the N.F.L. Management Council, the chances of a players' strike before next season would be ''significantly increased.''

title: A CETA STORY
description: Representative Paul Simon, Democrat of Illinois, writing in his weekly Congressional newsletter on ''Last Year's CETA Workers: Where Are They Now?''

title: FRIDAY, JANUARY 22, 1982; The Economy
description: President Reagan appeared to be reconsidering increases in excise taxes on gasoline, liquor and tobacco. His uncertainty touched off a battle among advisers for and against the plan. Representative Jack Kemp took the lead in a last-ditch campaign against any tax increases in fiscal year 1983. But Reagan aides are convinced that the President will ask about $15 billion in new taxes. (Page A1.) An increase in the royalty rate for oil and gas leases on Federal land will be sought by the Administration, according to Interior Secretary Jam es G. Watt. (D1.)

title: WITH KOCH AWAY, CITY HALL LIFE AMBLES ALONG
description: The Mayor went out of town, and one of the first things they did was to take down the oil portrait of his favorite predecessor. There was Fiorello H. La Guardia in his gilt-edged frame, on the floor, his face to the wall in a back corridor at Ci ty Hall.

title: PREREQUISITES FOR TEEN-AGE BIRTH CONTROL
description: To the Editor:

title: WASHINGTON ENERGY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MCLEAN TRUCKING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes gains from discontinued operations of $2.9 million for the quarter and $2.2 million for the 6 months and $4.5 million extraordinary charge for the quarter and 6 months

title: MIDCON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Midcon corp was established as an independent company in the reorganization of People Energy Corp, effective Dec 1, 1981

title: Islanders Beat Penguins by 6-1
description: Everything came together for the faltering Islanders tonight as they beat the Pittsburgh Penguins, 6-1, at Nassau Coliseum.

title: HAIG SAID TO DROP PLANS FOR SETTING ATOMIC TALKS
description: Administration officials said today that because of the Polish crisis Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. would probably not agree, as initially planned, to set a starting date for talks on strategic arms reductions when he meets with his Soviet counterpart next week.

title: MUSIC: TARACKS PLAY HANDEL
description: ONE wonders whether Handel himself would have cared to hear a half dozen of his concerti grossi played back-to-back like games in a set of tennis, which is the way the Tarack Chamber Ensemble did three each from his two major collections (Op. 3 and 6) on Wednesday evening at Carnegie Recital Hall. Su rely ther e are more appealing approaches to programming this music, and mor e diversity in Handel's chamber oeuvre than met the ear on this occas ion.

title: The Region; Tax Computer Errs in Jersey
description: TRENTON (AP) - The State Tax Division has sent letters of apology to 36,000 businesses in New Jersey after discovering that a computer had sent out an unknown number of incorrect corporate income-tax bills.

title: SOUTHEAST NATIONAL BANCSHARES OF PA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Grey Obtains Account Of Holly Farms Poultry
description: Holly Farms Poultry Industries of Wilkesboro, N.C., i s bringing its advertisi ng business to the big city and depositing it at Grey Advertising.

title: Bengals' Pete Johnson Has Leading Role
description: Pete Johnson, aspiring actor and full-time fullback, put on his best expression of shock today. The Cincinn ati Bengals' 248-pounder - the heaviest runner in pro football -had just learned that Coach Bill Walsh of the San Francisco 49ers was calling him the Bengals' ''primary weapon'' for Sunday's Super Bowl game. Walsh said that Johnson ''might carry the ball 30 times.''

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: T WO men on horseback playing polo are not a common sight on Fifth Avenue at 52d Street, but they didn't actually stop traffic Wednesday night. They just slowed it a bit. A few passersby stopped to watch briefly. Others were more blase, like the two middle-age women who were hurrying along the street. One tugged at the other's sleeve when she saw the horses, but the other said impatiently, ''I don't have time for this.''

title: Japan Trade Plan
description: In an attempt to smooth trade relations with Western countries, Japan will review its import restrictions on 27 products and try to lower nontariff barriers, Shintaro Abe, Minister of International Trade and Industry, said today. At a news conference after returning from the United States, Mr. Abe said he would propose that a trade ombudsman's office reporting directly to the Prime Minister be created.

title: BRIDGE: When a Lack of Discipline Goes With Talent, It Helps
description: A somewhat old feature of international bridge politics is that Australia and New Zealand compete, and always have competed, in the Far East Championships, which is a separate zone in the structure of the World Bridge Federation. This permits those two remote countries to encounter serious competition when they get tired of playing each other.

title: SHORT TERM RATES RISE AS FED DRAINS RESERVES
description: Short-term interest rates rose yesterday, with all of the increase coming in the afternoon after the Federal Reserve Bank drained credit from the banking system.

title: SOUTHWEST AIRLINES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
APPLE COMPUTER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 25
Credit Card Holders W in a Billing Battle
description: Citibank has agreed to pay $50 to any of its Visa or Mastercard customers who can show that the ''improper handling of billing errors'' subjected them to ''needless inconvenience, embarrassment and suspension of credit card privileges,'' the State Attorney General, Robert Abrams, announced yesterday.

title: The U.N. Today; Jan. 22, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Scientific and Technical Subcom- mittee of the Committee on the Peace- ful Uses of Outer Space - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: ROCK: RONNIE SPECTOR IS BACK
description: IT'S doubtful whether another rock-and-roll singer evokes the days before and during Beatlemania more poignantly than Ronnie Spector, who app eared at the Bottom Line last night and Wednesday night. As the lead sing er of the Ronettes, Miss Spector projected a throbbing teen-age emot ionality with a confidence that was perfectly attuned tothe grand pro duction style of her husband-to-be, Phil Spector.

title: MARGIOTTA SENTENCED TO 2 YEARS FOR EXTORTION
description: Joseph M. Margiotta, the chairman of the Nassau County Republican Party, was sentenced today to two years in Federal prison for extorting more than $500,000 in insurance kickbacks for his supporters.

title: At the Movies; Director with a whole world to explore.
description: ''SHOOT THE MOON,'' the story of a marriage, opens in New York today. (For a review, see page C13). It was directed by a 38-yearold Englishman named Alan Parker, who can't be accused of making the same picture over and over again.

title: Around the World; Palestinians Get Life In Austrian Slayings
description: A Vienna court sentenced two Palestinians to life imprisonment today for a machine-gun and grenade attack that killed two people and wounded 30 at a downtown synagogue on Aug. 29. The attack was directed at a crowd leaving a bar mitzvah ceremony.

title: PACIFIC LIGHTING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
The Search for the True B.A.
description: They take their S.A.T.'s over and over again, hoping for a 20-point boost with each try. They know by the thickness of the envelope if they're in or out: thin is a letter saying no, fat is a batch of forms to be returned with a deposit.

title: PENN CENTRAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings adjusted for 3-for-2 stock split payable Jan 22 to stockholders of record Jan 4

title: Reagan's First Year Fourth of six articles.
description: In his first year in office, President Reagan has found it hard to translate the tough anti-Soviet oratory of his campaign into a consistent foreign policy and has had to moderate, reshape or even defer some early objectives because of frustrating realities abroad. Except for his one major initiative, on reducing nuclear arms in Europe, the President has not displayed the personal involvement, enthusiasm, conviction or sure sense of command in foreign affairs that has characterized his economic program or his legislative disputes with Congress.

title: VALLEY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes $239,000 gain for the quarter from discontinued operations and $1,030,000 loss for the year from discontinued operations; C-Includes $95,000 gain from discontinued operations

title: RATING U.S. BANKS BY ASSETS
description: With a dramatic $9.5 billion gain in total assets in 1981, the BankAmerica Corporation regained its position as the nation's largest bank holding company, nudging Citicorp into second place.

title: RISE IN PHONE RATES EXPECTED
description: The Federal Communications Commission, putting into effect a policy change approved more than a year ago, gave final approval today to a plan that would increase telephone rates across the country by as much as $1 billion.

title: SEOUL PROPOSING AN EXCHANGE OF ENVOYS WITH NORTH KOREA
description: President Chun Doo Hwan of South Korea is proposing that his nation and North Korea exchange ambassadors as a first step toward eventual reunification.

title: AMERICAN BANCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PRISON CONTROLS AT ISSUE IN MASSACHUSETTS RAID
description: Nine women who are inmates at the Massachusetts Correctional Institution at Framingham filed a suit in Federal District Court here Wednesday charging that strip searches in a raid at the prison two weeks ago violated their right of privacy.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rate payable by savings institutions.

title: TO INCREASE TAXES OR NOT TO INCREASE TAXES
description: The now-you-see-them, now-you-don't tax increases for next year's Federal budget illustrate what White House aides say is a peculiarity of President Reagan's management style: a heavy reliance on h is senior staff combined with a sometimes stubbornindependence in making decisions.

title: ACME-CLEVELAND CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
AMATEURS WON'T DO IN ARTS EDUCATION
description: To the Editor:

title: Cuban Stowayay Is Back With Family in Havana
description: A young Cuban stowaway whose swift deportation led to an outbreak of violence in Miami last weekend was reported safely back with his family in Havana today.

title: KEY SUSPECT IS ARRESTED IN BRINK'S CAR ROBBERY
description: A 35-year-old man was arrested in a Bronx apartment Wednesday night as a key suspect in the Oct. 20 armored-car robbery in Rockland County that left a Brink's guard and two police officers dead.

title: Japan Steel Exports Off
description: In the face of stiff competition from South Korea, the volume of Japan's steel exports in 1981 fell 4.4 percent from the previous year to about 29 million metric tons, the lowest in recent years, the Japan Iron and Steel Federation said today in a preliminary report. A metric ton equals about 2,205 pounds.

title: L.I. MOTHER AND 3 CHILDREN KILLED IN FIRE THAT BEGAN IN WOOD STOVE
description: A fast-spreading fire that apparently st arted in a wood stove killed a woman and her three children toda y as neighbors tried to rescue them, fire officials said.

title: HEUBLEIN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including $2.5 million from the acquisition of debentures

title: FINANCIAL BRIEFS
description: * Cincinnati Gas and Electric Company said its directors had approved a proposed offering of 3 million common shares.

title: CITY ACTS TO ATTRACT DOCTORS TO WORK IN HOSPITAL CLINICS
description: A new progr am aimed at getting more physicians to practice in municipal hos pital clinics was approved yesterday by the New York City Health a nd Hospitals Corporation.

title: ORANGE & ROCKLAND UTILITIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SOUTHERN PACIFIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes $12 million, or 44 cents a share, gain on the sale of Federal incometax benefits and $6.2 million, or 23 cents a share, gain on exchange of common stock debentures; C-Includes $10.8 million, or 40 cents a share, third quarter gain on the sale of securities

title: UNITED CENTRAL BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Money Fund Assets Rise
description: Assets of the nation's money market funds rose $1.4 billion in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday, the third consecutive weekly increase. A week earlier, the funds posted a $2.4 billion gain in assets.

description: B-After $7.4 million loss from discontinued operations and $45 million provision for loss on disposal of discontinued operations

INTER-TEL INC reports earnings for Yr to Nov 30

title: SWEDISH SOPRANO WITH A SPECIAL SENSE
description: ''I'VE had a fantastic career, because I never wanted one,'' said Elisabeth Soederstroem, the Swedish soprano, at her Fifth Avenue hotel the other day. ''If you aren't anxious to have a lot of money and to be famous, there is so much fun to be had.''

title: PRINTRONIX (ORGN) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 25
OPERA: RETURN OF PAVAROTTI
description: LUCIANO PAVAROTTI was unable to sing in the first two Metropolitan Opera performances of ''Luisa Miller'' because of illness. There may have been remnants of that weakness on Wednesday night, when the tenor appeared as Rodolfo.
