SIMON, NORTON, INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including $5.5 million gain from the repurchase of debebtures for sinking fund requirements; shares outstanding are fully diluted

title: Canada Fund Faces Inquiry
description: Canada's largest single investment fund has been asked to testify before the regulatory body of the Ontario securities industry here next Monday in a hearing that could result in the fund's expulsion from the Toronto Stock Exchange, the nation's biggest.

title: FIRST NATIONAL STATE BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA EDISON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
COMPUTER MARKERS LIST EARNINGS
description: Large gains were reported yesterday in the quarterly earnings of makers of small computer systems, many of them used in homes. But companies making larger computers did not perform as well because the recession and high interest rates dampened business orders.

title: PBA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Notes on People; High Marks for Haig
description: Since he became Secretary of State, Alexander M. Haig Jr. has not lacked for critics among officials of the previous Administration. Now, it turns out, he has an admirer of sorts in Malcolm Toon, who served as Ambassador to the Soviet Union under President Jimmy Carter.

title: NASHVILLE CITY BANK & TRUST CO (TENN) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Dow Gains 2.38; C omputers Strong
description: Earnings developments affected numerous issues yesterday, as the stock market over all showed a slight advance. The Dow Jones industrial average, which has traded within a narrow range for nearly two weeks, gained 2.38 points, to 848.27. It finished last year at 875. Trading volume slipped to 48.6 million shares from Wednesday's 48.9 million.

title: ABBOTT LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SCAN-OPTICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes extraordinary credits of $185,000 for the quarter and $365,000 for the year; C-Includes extraordinary credits of $256,000 for the quarter and $533,000 for the year

title: AMERICAN ELECTRIC POWER CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Chrysler Gets Pension Delay
description: The United Automobile Workers union has agreed to give the Chrysler Corporation until September 1984 to pay its $187 million pension contribution for 1980, the two sides said today.

title: A TAX REPEAL IS VOTED IN HARTFORD
description: The State House of Representatives gave final legislative approval today to a measure canceling Connecticut's tax on unincorporated businesses, which was adopted only last year.

title: AMSTAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
'Fifth of July' Will Close Sunday After Long Run
description: ''Fifth of July,'' the hit play by Lanford Wilson, will end its run at the New Apollo Theater, 234 West 43d Street, after this Sunday's matinee. The play, which opened on Nov. 5, 1980, will have given 511 performances and nine previews.

title: People
description: * Howard S. Plisstner named director of advertising for Omni magazine.

title: SHOWBOAT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
COAL MINE SAFETY COMES UNDER FIRE
description: As workers in the nation's coal fields mourned the deaths of seven Kentucky miners in an underground explosion, demands grew today for Congressional intervention to overcome the Reagan Administration's staff reductions in the Federal coal mine safety program.

title: NORTH CAROLINA IS UPSET
description: Wake Forest scored a 55-48 victory tonight over top-ranked and previously unbeaten North Carolina on the Tar Heels' home cour t.

title: Sports People; Surgery for Davidson
description: Another often-injured athlete, the Ranger goaltender John Davidson, is to undergo an exploratory operation on his long-ailing back next Monday.

title: PENN CENTRAL, AIR PRODUCTS AND MONSANTO POST BIG GAINS
description: The Penn Central Company reported yesterday that net income in the fourth quarter more than doubled, while sales increased 52.6 percent. The sharp gain in profits was caused by the inclusion of the results of GK Technologies Inc., which Penn Central acquired last year, and increased income from an oil rig-building subsidiary, the company said.

title: Market Place; Orange Groves And the Future
description: LAST week's frigid weather didn't much change the prospects of the Florida orange juice companies. Even before the temperature plunged, neither of the two companies offering investors a pure play was doing well.

title: CIPHER DATA PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net loss after losses from discontinued operations of $20,000 for the quarterand $5,000 for the 6 months

title: SYRIA ASSAILS U.S. STAND ON GOLAN
description: Syria charged the United States today with encouraging Israel to destroy chances of peace in the Middle East by vetoing a United Nations Security Council resolution on sanctions.

title: Abbott Labs Up 12.6%
description: Abbott Laboratories, an international health-care products concern, reported today that earnings rose 12.6 percent in the final quarter of 1981, to $72.3 million, or 61 cents a share, from $64.2 million, or 52 cents, in 1980.

title: 2 I.R.A. LEADERS ARRESTED WHILE TRYING TO ENTER U.S. ILLEGALLY
description: Two leaders of the Irish Republican Army - in what appeared to be a coordinated effort to reach New York City in time for a fundraising dinner tonight - were arrested in separate incidents last night as each was trying to cross into the United States illegally from Canada, the Immigration and Naturalization Service said.

title: MONTREAL TRANSIT STRIKE IS ENDED AFTER 6 DAYS OF FROZEN COMMUTING
description: Subway trains and buses were back in service today after a six-day strike, and for hundreds of thousands of freezing Montrealers the resumption came not a minute too soon.

title: NEW YORK STATE ELECTRIC & GAS CORP reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
Lois, Pitts, Wins Simac Appliances
description: The maker of a home pasta-making machine has left Della Femina, Travisano & Partners and has taken up with Lois, Pitts, Gershon. The company is the Simac Appliances Corporation, whose products include the Pastamatic line and the Il Gelataio ice cream machine. The new agency says that the billings will be more than $1 million.

title: ZENITH LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes utilization of tax credits

title: Inquiry Seen O n Arbitragers
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating options trading irregularities last Christmas Eve that resulted in the dismissal of two high-level employees of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, Wall Street sources said yesterday.

title: UNION CAMP CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes gain equal to 16 cents a share from the sale of a minority interest in a French packaging firm

title: BOSTON OPERA REACHES INTERIM ORCHESTRA PACT
description: The Opera Company of Boston announced yesterday an interim settlement with its orchestra that will allow it to present the American premiere of Bernd Alois Zimmermann's ''Die Soldaten'' after all.

title: BRIEFING
description: T HE Reagan Administration called a pep rally for its political appointees the other day and, perhaps out of sheer enthusiasm, but then again maybe from lack of civil service job protection, everyone showed up.

title: I.L.O. Workweek Study
description: South Koreans have the longest workweek while Norwegians put in the fewest hours on the job, according to statistics compiled by the International Labor Organization.

title:
ADVERTISING;
Rado Watch Selects Creamer as Agency
description: Creamer Inc. is the new agency for the Rado Watch Company U.S.A., which was for merly handled by Harvard & Edrick/WMD. Rado, impor ter of Swiss watches, will spend $1 million for promotion, ac cording to the agency. At first, t he advertising will be all in color in national magazines and some city magazines.

title: News Summary; FRIDAY, JANUARY 22, 1982
description: International A delay in arms reductions talks is likely. Reagan Administration officials said that because of the Polish crisis Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. would probably not agree, as initially planned, to set a date for the start of the negotiations when he meets with Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko in Geneva next Tuesday. (Page A1, Column 1.) A petition against martial law and its repressions signed by more than a hundred intellectuals and artists was sent to the Polish Parliament and the Roman Catholic Primate, Archbishop Jozef Glemp. The petition, which includes an appeal to the United Nations' Human Rights Commission, is the strongest written protest to date against the Dec. 13 military takeover in Poland. (A1:2.)

title: FRANKLIN AVENUE SUBWAY SHUTTLE IN BROOKLYN IS CLOSED FOR REPAIRS
description: The troubled Franklin Avenue Shuttle, once the gateway to Brooklyn's Ebbets Field, was shut down yesterday for emergency repairs after the Transit Authority said a street-level concrete retaining wall holding up a an elevated section of the subway line was in danger of collapse.

title: ENTANGLING ECONOMICS
description: The Soviet bloc's debt to the West has now reached the staggering sum of $90 billion, according to the U.N.'s Economic Commission for Europe. Recently it has been growing at a slower rate than during the last few years, primarily because of higher Soviet gold sales.

title: LENNAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
THE JOINT COMMITTEE SOMETIMES ISN'T
description: The Joint Economic Committee of Congress issued a press release the other day denouncing a study on the effect of the Reagan Administration's budget cuts on large cities. Oddly, the study itself had been published by the Joint Economic Committee.

title: Florida Crop Loss Set
description: A new report says about 25 percent of the citrus crop, half of the winter vegetable crop and 10 percent of the sugar cane crop were lost in Florida during last week's freeze.

title: Notes on People; Bette Davis on Children and Aging Parents
description: ''I brought my own children up to be independent of me, and I of them,'' Bette Davis was saying yesterday, ''so I'll never have to worry about being one of those people whose children shabbily warehouse them because they don't want to bother with them anymore.''

title: Kellwood Picks Head
description: William J. McKenna, 55, will join the Kellwood Company, a manufacturer of clothing, recreation equipment and home furnishings, as president and chief operating officer on March 1. Fred W. Wenzel, 65, continues as chairman and chief executive officer of the St. Louis-based corporation that is 22.6 percent owned by Sears Roebuck & Company, of which it is a major supplier.

title: Jan Peerce at Carnegie
description: The operatic tenor Jan Peerce will appear in a benefit recital on Sunday at 7:30 P.M. in Carnegie Hall, Seventh Avenue and 57th Street.

title: SKIPPER WHO WAS ATTACKED DENIES AIDING FILIPINO REBELS
description: The captain of a Japanese tanker attacked by Philippine fighters at sea on Jan. 15 said here today that Philippine Government suspicions that his ship carried ''terrorists'' and $10 million worth of arms and explosives for anti-Government guerrilla forces in the Philippines were unfounded.

title: Sports of The Times; The Super-Rookie Matchup
description: WHEN the Cincinnati Bengals started growling early in the season and people asked Cris Collinsworth about their Super Bowl chances, the rookie wide receiver didn't hide behind the standard answers.

title: Volkswagen Names Financial Officer
description: Rolf Selowsky, 51 years old, has been named chief financial officer of Volkswagen, West Germany's biggest auto maker, whose sales and profits slipped sharply last year. Mr. Selowsky will succeed Friedrich Thomee, who stepped down last October.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: No Headline
description: REAGAN'S STAND ON EXCISE TAXES AGAIN IN DOUBT

title: FIRST WISCONSIN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After an extraordinary credit of $609,000, or 15 cents a share; C-After an extraordinary charge of $10,991,000

title: Rhodes to Leave Congress
description: Representative John J. Rhodes, Republican of Arizona, the former House minority leader, announced today that he would not seek election to a 16th term in November. Mr. Rhodes is 65 years old.

title: PRESIDENT WARNED BY CONSERVATIVES
description: Forty-five conservative activists and organization leaders warned President Reagan today that he was allowing ''the abandonment, reversal or blunting'' of the policies that got him elected, such as opposition to abortion, lower taxes and a tough line with the Soviet Union.

title: SEAFIRST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
The City; Drag Racer Guilty
description: An unemployed mechanic was convicted yesterday in the deaths of two persons who were killed when his car went out of control at an illegal drag race in August 1980.

title: Dr. Stella Schaeffer-Epstein, Injured in Park in 1975, Dies
description: Dr. Stella Schaeffer-Epstein, who had practiced medicine for more than 60 years when she was attacked and severely injured by nine teen-agers in Central Park on Feb. 28, 1975, died Tuesday at her home in Manhattan. She was 91 years old.

title: The Region; Transit Report
description: Of 134 trains operating in the morning rush period, 57 were late and one was canceled. The 6:55 A.M. train from Hicksville, with 2,200 pa ssengers and due at Pennsylvania Station at 7:44, stalled benea th the river and was pulled to Manhattan by an Amtrak locomotive.

title: 2 MORE 9-MM. PISTOLS ARE FOUND
description: Another arrest in the Brink's robbery in Rockland County led yesterday to the discovery of two more Browning 9-millimeter semiautomatic handguns.

title: DATAPRODUCTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
Quotation of the Day
description: ''I'm very happy he wasn't convicted of murder. I guess the jury felt they made scrambled eggs out of his soul in prison.

title: ABBOTT CONVICTED OF MANSLAUGHTER IN STABBING OF EAST VILLAGE WAITER
description: Jack Henry Abbott was convicted of first-degree manslaughter yesterday after a jury debated for more than 24 hours and rejected the original murder charge against him.

title: AFFILIATED BANKSHARES OF COLORADO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
TANDYCRAFTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
AIR PRODUCTS & CHEMICAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including $61,937,000 from the cumulative effect of a change in accounting for investment tax credits; results for the latest first quarter also include a foreign currency translation gain, equal to 14 cents a share, from the transitional impact of the adoption of FASB Statement No 52 and a gain from the sale of minor business equal to 14 cents a share

title: Dr. Richard Coumbis, Jersey Forensic Expert
description: Dr. Richard J. Coumbis, director of forensi c laboratories in the New Jersey Department of Law and Public Safet y, died of cancer Tuesday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Ce nter. He was 55 years old and a resident of Long Valley, N.J.

title: KNICKS SET BACK HAWKS, 104-101
description: With Dan Roundfield sidelined and only nine players available, the Atlanta Hawks provided the Knicks with the ingredients for an easy victory last night. Instead, the Knicks had a difficult time before they finally won, 104-101, at Madison Square Garden and ended a three-game losing streak.

title: REAGAN'S 'GREAT HINGE'
description: No wonder President Reagan is reported to have left beer off his list of possible excise tax increases. That's the ''working man's drink'' - and Ronald Reagan, though a conservative Republican, is heavily dependent on support from the ''sons of toil.''

title: THEATER: COCO IN SIMON'S 'LITTLE ME'
description: MAYBE ''Little Me'' wasn't in the class of the great comic musicals of the early 1960's - ''How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying'' and ''A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum'' - but it was, in its way, a wonderful show. For one all-too-brief moment, a sassy group of young Broadway talents came into glittering conjunction: the writer Neil Simon, the choreographer Bob Fosse, the composer Cy Coleman and the lyricist Carolyn Leigh.

title: MUSIC: YEFIM BRONFMAN PIANO RECITAL AT Y
description: YEFIM BRONFMAN revealed both his promise and his limitations in his piano recital Tuesday at the 92d Street Y -while also proving that much else can be taken for granted about his playing.

title: STANDARD-COOSA-THATCHER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 2
JAZZ: BUD SHANK TRIO
description: AFTER more than two decades of being locked into studio work in California, Bud Shank, the saxophonist who was one of the early stars of Stan Kenton's band, is on the road again. He first came out as a member of the L A Four, which was in New York last June.

title: COURT IS ASKED TO DEFER SENTENCING OF WILLIAMS
description: An attorney for Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. of New Jersey, scheduled to be sentenced Tuesday on bribery charges, asked yesterday that the sentencing be postponed. He cited new accusations that a key undercover operative in the Abscam investigation had committed perjury ''with the knowledge of the F.B.I.''

title: CHINATOWN CELEBRATING YEAR OF THE DOG
description: OBSERVANCES of the Chinese New Year are beginning this weekend, although the first day of lunar year 4680, the Year of the Dog in the Chinese zodiac, does not officially arrive until Monday. The Chinese, who love a good celebration, are already marking the ''Little New Year,'' as the days preceding the holiday are often called, with food, firecrackers and feasts.

title: UNITED VIRGINIA BANKSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
3 Jockeys Indicted in Jersey
description: Three jockeys were indicted yesterday on charges of arranging or receiving bribes from New Jersey state police detectives who posed as crooked gamblers in an undercover operation at the Meadowlands last fall.

title: FINNEY AND MISS KEATON IN 'SHOOT THE MOON'
description: ''SHOOT THE MOON,'' written by the Oscar-winning Bo Goldman (''Melvin and Howard'' and ''One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest'') and directed by Alan Parker (''Fame'' and ''Midnight Express''), is a bittersweet comedy about a marriage that has gone smash before the film opens.

title: THREE *'S IN LONDON
description: The myth of England as a gastronomic wasteland was officially buried today as Le Gavroche became the first restaurant in the country to win the coveted three-star status in the Michelin guide, published annually.

title: Moral Majority Official Attacks Council Head
description: The Rev. Greg Dixon, national secretary of Moral Majority, says James Armstrong, president of the National Council of Churches, is a socialist whose organization has goals parallel to those of the Communist Party.

title: FIBERS ON TWO BODIES LINKED TO DEFENDANT AT ATLANTA TRIAL
description: A microanalyst for the Georgia State Crime Laboratory, t estified today that fibers found on the bodies of Nathaniel Cat er and Jimmy Ray Payne had the same ''microscopic characteristi cs'' as fibers found in the house and car of Wayne B. Williams.

title: U.S. MAY RAISE GAS AND OIL ROYALTY
description: The Reagan Administration will seek an increase in the Government's royalty rate for oil and gas leases on Federal lands to 162/3 percent from 12 1/2 percent, Interior Secretary James G. Watt said today.

title: MEAL CHIEF SAYS REAGAN HAD FIGURES WRONG
description: The director of a meal program in Pima County, Ariz., says President Reagan was wrong when he told a news conference this week that the program had saved thousands of dollars by using volunteers to cut administrative overhead.

title: MIDNIGHT BOWLING IN FURS AND LEATHER, TO MUSIC
description: At the Bowlmor Lanes, life in the fast lane has taken on new meaning. By day, the Bowlmor, at University Place and 12th Street, is like any other 40-year-old bowling alley. The lanes are a little bumpy, the lighting mercilessly fluorescent, the beer very cold. But Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday nights from midnight to 5 A.M., the slightly overweight world of league bowling stays home.

title: HERMAN N. SCHWARTZ
description: Herman N. Schwartz, who practiced law in New York for 56 years, died Wednesday in his Manhattan home at the age of 78. Mr. Schwartz, who graduated from the Brooklyn Law School, was twice president of the Greenwich Village Association. He is survived by his wife, Justice Hilda G. Schwartz of State Supreme Court; a son, John of Manhattan; a sister, Beatrice Levine of Hollywood, Fla., and a brother, Sidney, of Winmoor Village, Fla.

title: Books of the Times
description: By John Leonard MEMOIRS OF A SPACE TRAVELER. Further Reminiscences of Ijon Tichy. By Stanislaw Lem. Translated from the Polish by Joel Stern and Maria Swiecicka-Ziemianek. 153 pages. Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $9.95.

title: ART: BY ROBERT GRAHAM, FOUR NUDES AND A MARE
description: ROBERT GRAHAM first attracted notice in the mid-60's with tiny wax effigies of nude women sequestered in Plexiglas boxes. Often tanned and with hair artfully tousled, these perfect little nymphs were pinups more than they were traditional artists' nudes and they disported themselves in spaces that implied the beaches, patios and bedrooms of Southern California.

title: SAVING SALVADOR
description: There are two different approaches to finding a political solution to the conflict in El Salvador. The first was proposed by the Salvadoran Government and is supported by the Reagan Administration. The other has been proposed by the Salvadoran opposition - the broad alliance of progressive political parties, peasants' and labor unions, professional associations, and popular mass organizations that form the Democratic Revolutionary Front and by the five political military organizations now united in the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front - and is supported by the Roman Catholic Church as well as several European and Latin-American countries.

title: FIRST OKLAHOMA BANCORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Aim Again With a Realty Tax
description: Perfectly legal tax dodging is not a pretty sight but it is an established American sport, encouraged by the structure of law. So when a tax is easily evaded, the blame falls not on the dodgers but on the drafters. And that is why the sales tax on real estate profits in New York City needs urgent revision.

title: COAST GUARD DISCLOSES PLAN TO CUT 17 STATIONS AND RETIRE 11 VESSELS
description: The Coast Guard announced plans tonight to close 17 offices and stations and to decommission 11 of its 75 cutters. Some Congressmen, forewarned of the decisions, registered objections. John B. Hay es, the Coast Guard Commandant, said the service would close distric t offices in St. Louis and Long Beach, Calif., and 15 search and re scue stations in 11 states. He also announced plans to decomission t he cutters, which are based in eight states, and to makebudget cuts a ffecting 16 other stations. In addition, the Coast Guardband is to be moved to Washington from the Coast Guard Academy in New London, C onn.

title: ALPHA INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Grumman's 'Flxible' To Become a 'Metro'
description: The Grumman Corporation said yesterday that new models of its Flxible buses, which have gained notoriety because of mechanical and structural defects, would now be known as Grumman Metro buses.

title: IN QUEENS, A BRISK TOUR OF COAST AND WETLANDS
description: If it's not too cold for the rabbits, sparrows and rosebushes, it's not too cold for people to go outside and take a good look at them. Such is the philosophy of the Outdoors Club, a group that is leading a winter nature walk in northeastern Queens on Sunday afternoon.

title: Dispute Arises Over Jackson
description: The California Angels said yesterday that if they signed Reggie Jackson, a free agent, they would ''compensate'' the Yankees by sending them a player. The statement drew strong criticism from Marvin Miller, who said that the Players Association would consider any such transaction collusion and a violation of baseball's strict new rules on free agents.

title: OF POVERTY, NUTRITION AND SOCIAL DARWINISM
description: To the Editor:

title: Around the World; Greek Orthodox Church B alks at Civil Marriage
description: The Greek Orthodox Church refused today to accept a Government plan to permit civil marriage as a legal alternative to marriage through the church.

title: SOVIET WARNS ANGOLANS ON U.S.
description: The Soviet leadership has warned a visiting Angolan delegation of an American ''plot'' to return the African nation to the American sphere of influence.

title: Austrian Post for Waldheim
description: Kurt Waldheim, the former United Nations Secretary General, will become a special envoy at international conferences for his native Austria, Chancellor Bruno Kreisky said on the Austrian radio tonight. Mr. Waldheim ran for an unprecedented third term as Secretary General, but stepped down after his nomination was repeatedly vetoed by China. He was succeeded by Javier Perez de Cuellar of Peru.

title: Grand Union Sets Closings in South
description: The Grand Union Company of Elmwood Park, N.J., said it would close nine Big Star supermarkets and a warehouse in South Carolina, putting 300 employees out of work.

title: The City; The Police Blotter
description: A 35-year-old nun in civilian clothes was assaulted and robbed at 10:30 A.M. yesterday as she entered a church building adjoining Our Lady of Mercy Roman Catholic Church, at 680 Stone Avenue in Brooklyn's Brownsville section. The nun, Sister Joan McCorkell of the Sisters of St. Joseph of Brentwood, N.Y., was not seriously injured.

title: A DOWN AND UP DAY IN FIGHT ON SCHOOL TAX STATUS
description: The expanding legal dispute over the tax status of racially discriminatory private schools took another odd and, for the Reagan Administration, potentially embarrassing turn in the Supreme Court today.

title: F.B.I. DIRECTOR TO TAKE OVER KEY ROLE IN NARCOTICS CASES
description: Declaring that narcotics trafficking was the nation's ''most serious crime problem,'' Attorney General William French Smith announced today that the Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation would take over efforts to combat it.

title: FIRST ARKANSAS BANKSTOCK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The per share figures for all periods restated for 10% stock dividend paid in January 1982

title: DANCE: CITY BALLET'S 'BALLADE,' 'MOZARTIANA,' 'PIANO PIECES'
description: RECENT programs by the New York City Ballet have featured some gracious works by George Balanchine. For instance, on Wednesday night at the New York State Theater, Robert Irving conducted a revival of Mr. Balanchine's pretty little ''Ballade.''

title: BURLINGTON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 2
FIRST EMPIRE STATE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
HILTON HOTELS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Best Products To Acquire Basco
description: The Best Products Company of Richmond said it had agreed to buy Basco Inc. of Cherry Hill, N.J., Both companies are catalogue showroom merchandisers.

title: 38% Like 49ers; 40% Don't Care
description: Despite the hours of television promotion and the gallons of printing ink, more people do not care who wins the Super Bowl than prefer either team, according to The New York Times/CBS News Poll.

title: EDWARD S. (NED) IRISH, FOUNDER OF THE KNICKS, DIES
description: Edward S. (Ned) Irish, the founder and former president of the New York Knickerbockers and one of the leaders in the development of college and professional basketball in the United States, died at Venice (Fla.) Hospital yesterday after suffering a heart attack. Mr. Irish, who had been hospitalized recently with heart trouble, was 76 years old.

title: THE ROCKEFELLER PROPOSAL FOR MIDDLE-CLASS HOMES
description: Last week, David Rockefeller announced the formation of a private, nonprofit corporation, the New York City Housing Partnership, to build or renovate 30,000 units of middle-income housing in the city within a five-year period. The announcement came after President Reagan addressed a luncheon of the New York City Partnership, a private civic group whose membership includes the city's leading business executives, and renewed his call for the private sector to become more involved in charitable and social causes.

title: CALIFORNIA FIRST BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Text of petition, page A10.
description: A sharply worded petition against martial law and its repressions, signed by more than a hundred intellectuals and artists, was sent today to Parliament and to Archbishop Jozef Glemp, the Roman Catholic Primate.

title: Divers Seek Last Victim Of Air Florida Jet Crash
description: Technicians tried today to decipher unintelligible portions of the tape from the cockpit voice recorder retrieved Wednesday from the wreckage of the Air Florida jetliner that crashed here, and divers searched the Po tomac River for the lastof the 78 victims.

title: Texaco Fuel F or Honduras
description: Texaco Inc. said that it expects to have gasoline available in Honduras early today, with ''all shortages cleared up over the weekend.''

title: Special Aid For Farmers
description: The Farmers Home Administration is ready to extend special assistance to those relatively few farmers who are in danger of going bankrupt, the Agriculture Secretary, John R. Block, said today.

title: ALEXANDER & ALEXANDER SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ARMATRON INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including $49,000 extraordinary tax credit; C-Including $5,000 extraordinary tax credit and $1,449,000 gain from the settlement of litigation

title: DIVESTITURE PLAN NEXT AT A.T.&T.
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company yesterday announced changes in upper management intended to help prepare the company for the gigantic divestiture required by its recent antitrust settlement with the Justice Department.

title: RIKERS PRISONERS FIND PRIDE IN WORK AT PARKS
description: Stepping gingerly to the center of a makeshift scaffold seven feet hi gh, and easing a roller soaked with white paint across a dingy br own area, Jesse Walls, a Rikers Island inmate, spoke yesterday ab out the work.

title: THE CHALLENGE AT BELL LABS
description: At Bell Laboratories Inc., the world's largest research institution by some measures and a giant by any, big challenges tend to be taken in stride.

title: TV Weekend; SUPER BOWL, DRUG WAR, MICKEY ROONEY SERIES
description: THIS is the weekend, in case you hadn't heard, of football's Super Bowl, always one of the most watched television attractions of the year. The 16th annual confrontation will have the San Francisco 49ers facing the Cincinnati Bengals at the Pontiac Silverdome in Michigan. Sunday's presentation on CBS-TV will begin at 2:30 P.M. with assorted reports and commentaries. The game itself gets under way at about 4.

title: OUTBOARD MARINE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
AMERICANA AND FOLK ART IN ANTIQUES SHOW AT ARMORY
description: THE Winter Antiques Show, the nation's most important fair for second-hand objects, opens tomorrow for a nine-day run at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue at 67th Street. Collectors and dealers from throughout the United States and from Europe will be on hand in the baronial hall to inspect vintage prizes - some with royal pedigrees - in the booths of 73 dealers, many of whom save the plums from their stocks all year to present at this prestigious show.

title: Researchers Say Dialysis May Damage the Liver
description: Some people who undergo kidney dialysis may suffer liver damage because tiny bits of silicone flake off tubes in the machinery and collect inside the body, according to Australian researchers.

title: Sports People; Comings and Goings
description: After meeting with Gov. Harry Hughes of Maryland and Mayor William Donald Schaefer of Baltimore, Robert Irsay, onwer of the Colts, said the team would remain in Baltimore and play in a refurbished Memorial Stadium. A $22 million bond authorization for stadium improvements passed by the state's General Assembly expires July 1 unless Irsay signs a 15-year lease on the stadium. ... The Los Angeles Lakers' backcourt pair of Earvin (Magic) Johnson and Norm Nixon were among the seven players named by the Western Conference coaches to the roster for the National Basketball Association's All-Star Game Jan. 31 at the Byrne Meadowlands Arena. Also picked were Moses Malone of the Houston Rockets, Jack Sikma of the Seattle SuperSonics, Bernard King of the Golden State Warriors, Alex English of the Denver Nuggets and Dennis Johnson of the Phoenix Suns. ... Emile Francis, president and general manager of the St. Louis Blues, has been named the winner of the Lester Patrick Trophy for his contributions to American hockey, the National Hockey League announced.

title: Judging the Reagan Mistakes
description: President Reagan has offered a fair test for his performance on the issue of tax exemptions for segregated schools. ''Don't judge us by our mistakes,'' he said at his news conference this week; the real question is ''how well we recover.'' At the current rate, the President is failing his own test.

title: WANG LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
LEAR SIEGLER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
RSI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Year-ago results reflect change to LIFO method of accounting

title: MOSELEY HALLGARTEN & ESTABROOK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Autonomy, American Style
description: The Camp David clock is running out of sand. When Israel delivers the last of the Sinai Desert to Egypt on April 25 and thus gains its first recognized border, Part One of a historic deal will be accomplished. Both nations, however, will then be eager to forget the importance they once attached to Part Two: that ''for peace to endure,'' the Palestinians must be brought into the bargaining process.

title: South Florida Is Given Probation by N.C.A.A.
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association today imposed a one-year probationary period on the University of South Florida for recruiting violations involving two high school basketball prospects.

title: ART: YOUNG KANDINSKY AND LIVELY MUNICH ERA
description: KANDINSKY is not a neglected artist. To a quite exceptional degree, his work is in the public domain. Books on him abound. He has been in major exhibitions in public places almost continually since the 1950's. He is fundamental to the history of Russian art, to the history of German art and (to a lesser degree) to the history of art in Paris in the second quarter of this century. He stood out in the Blue Rider Group before 1914. He stood out in postrevolutionary Russia, where from 1918 to 1921 he had a considerable hand in official cultural policy. He stood out at the Bauhaus in the 1920's. There's just no escaping him in Europe.

title: SAUDI CRAZE FOR CARS IS BOTH A BLESSING AND A BLIGHT
description: Gasoline costs 24 cents a gallon, Cadillacs are selling like Toyotas, and everywhere there is the rumble of heavy machinery building more freeways.

title: PACIFIC GAS & ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PHOENIX GOLF HIT BY RAIN
description: Sun Belt and the Chamber of Commerce's Valley of the Sun became reverse characterizations of this desert city today when the first round of the Phoenix Open was suspended because of rain. The weather was also cold and windy.

title: Canadian Output Off
description: The Canadian gross domestic product fell one-half of a percentage point in November following October's 1.3 percent decline, Statistics Canada reported today.

title: WAVETEK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 2
PRIME COMPUTER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CHINA IS AT PRESENT 'NOT IMPORTANT' TO THE U.S.
description: To the Editor:

title: PREREQUISITES FOR TEEN-AGE BIRTH CONTROL
description: To the Editor:

title: KEYSTONE CONSOLIDATED INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including $1,342,000 extraordinary tax credit

title: CNA INCOME SHARES INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: Net income figures represent net investment income

title: MONSANTO CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net loss; C-After a net charge of $107.7 million associated with the company's withdrawal from the polyester filament business and a majority-owned Spanish subsidiary; D-Includes gain from third quarter sales of Monsanto's portion of theMonsanto-Conoco Inc joint venture

title: PORTEC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FIRST FLORIDA BANKS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NUCLEAR WEAPONS SITES IDENTIFIED IN RESEARCH GROUP'S REPORT
description: The Center for Defense Information, a liberal-oriented military research organization, said today that most of the Army's nuclear weapons stored on United States soil were at two large depots in New York and California.

title: BECTON DICKINSON & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CHAIRMAN OF UNIROYAL TO RESIGN
description: Uniroyal Inc., the nation's fourth-largest tire and rubber company, announced yesterday that David Beretta, its 53-year-old chairman and an employee for almost 30 years, would resign on Feb. 28 ''to pursue business interests.'' Joseph P. Flannery, 49, president and chief executive officer, will become chairman as well.

title: Advertising; Bendix's Super Bowl Showcase
description: THE Super Bowl is getting to be more than just the battle of the best of the professional football teams and the final test of patience of Sunday's football widows. It has also become a showcase for television advertising campaigns to make their debut. With an audience of 100 million people, largely male and often upscale, why not?

title: Amherst, as Stipulated, Hires a Black Professor
description: Amherst College has hired a black professor for a new faculty position, complying with a condition on a $1 million gift from a white benefactor.

title: Auctions; Bonanza of Americana.
description: A BONANZA of Americana goes on view this weekend and will be up for bidding next week at three of New York's art-auction houses. Sotheby Parke Bernet will hold four sales. Among them, a giant six-session ''American Heritage'' auction of more than 1,000 lots takes place at Sotheby's York Avenue galleries, at 72d Street, Wednesday at 2 P.M., Thursday at 10:15 A.M., Friday at 10:15 A.M. and 2 P.M. and Saturday at 10:15 A.M. and 2 P.M.

title: Sports People; Carter Agreement Near
description: In Montreal, an agent for Gary Carter, said that only final details remained to be worked out in an agreement that would bring the Expos' all-star catcher about $2 million a year for the next eight years. The agent, Jerry Petrie, said the remaining details are concentrated in a complicated six-page set of clauses dealing with guarantees that would alter the final dollar amount.

title: PRIME MOTOR INNS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CITY REVISES METHOD OF ASSESSING CO-OPS, RAISING THEIR TAXES
description: New York City has changed its method of computing the value of cooperative a partment buildings in a way that would sharply increase property taxe s for residents of those buildings.

title: TRIPS TO CITY INSPIRE SOME OF THE DONORS TO FUND FOR NEEDIEST
description: Often a trip to New York City will inspire a contribution to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, but visitors cite different reasons for giving.

title: VERSA TECHNOLOGIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
REAGANS GET MIXED RATING ON LIFE STYLE
description: ''The times demand that we all cut down, and I think that means all of us, the Reagans included,'' said Rose Novell of Antioch, Ill. ''I think the President and First Lady of the United States should be as well represented as kings and queens,'' said Ella Winn of Darien, Conn.

title: PFIZER INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-After $7.4 million loss from discontinued operations and $45 million provision for loss on discontinued operations; corrected from yesterday's editions

title: ROCHESTER GAS & ELECTRIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MERCHANTS NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Books of The Times; Resistance at the Ritz
description: THE MAN WHO LIVED AT THE RITZ. By A.E. Hotchner. 286 pages. G.P. Put- nam's Sons. $13.95.

title: COLUMBIA PLANS TO TAKE WOMEN BEGINNING IN '83
description: Columbia College, the last all-male college in the Ivy League, announced yesterday that it would begin accepting women as freshmen in the fall of 1983.

title: CABARET: LIZ CORRIGAN SINGS
description: Liz Corrigan, a singer whose instincts are toward country and urban folk music with a bit of blues and comedy thrown in, was one of the performers who appeared from time to time at the Ballroom when it was on West Broadway, in Soho.

title: JUDGE RICHARD EDSTROM
description: Judge Richard Edstrom of Nassau County District Court died Wednesday at Mercy Hospital in Rockville Centre, L.I., after heart surgery.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day last Tues- day about Coca-Cola's proposed pur- chase of Columbia Pictures Industries Inc. incorrectly identified the largest shareholder of General Cinema. Rich- ard A. Smith, chairman and president, and his family own 25.2 percent of the common stock.

title: Team of West Germans Wins Monte Carlo Rally
description: Walter Rohrl and his codriver, Christian Geistdorfer, won the Monte Carlo automobile rally today for the second time in three years, after six days and some 2,000 miles of virtually faultless driving around the mountains of central and southern France.

title: Thais Jail a Jersey Woman
description: Candice Lee Carpenter of Oakland, N.J., was sentenced to 25 years in jail today for her attempt to smuggle seven pounds of heroin out of Thailand last September.

title: Backhanded Aid for Public Schools
description: Public school administrators face taxpayer resistance at home and aid cuts in Washington; to whom can they turn to keep struggling school systems afloat? Why, to corporations, of course, say supporters of Reaganomics. And indeed, ''corporate support'' has become the new buzzword in the education community.

title: Northrop Names Chief In a Management Shift
description: The Northrop Corporation, a major builder of military aircraft and beneficiary of accelerated defense spending, named a new president today as part of a management realignment.

title: No Headline
description: FLOYD AND MISS DECKER SET WORLD INDOOR MARKS

title: Arnoux Captures Pole For South African Race
description: Rene Arnoux of France won the pole today as turbocharged cars took the front six places on the grid in practice for Saturday's South African Grand Prix, the season's first Formula One event that had been threatened with cancellation.

title: The Region; Judge Dismisses Housing Bias Suit
description: A Federal judge has dismissed a suit in whi ch the National Association for the Advancement of Colored Pe ople charged that the town of Huntington, L.I., was pursuing racial ly discriminatory housing and zoning practices.

title: HONDA MOTOR CO reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Share earnings figures are per American shares each of which represents 10 shars of common stock

title: SCRIPPS-HOWARD BROADCASTING reports earnings for Qtr to dec 31
AIR FARES TO FLORIDA TUMBLE TO $77
description: A pell-mell round of cuts yesterday in air fares between New York and Florida brought the price of a one-way, economy-class ticket to $77. Air Florida set off the fare cutting. Then Air Florida's fare was undercut by P an American World Airways, with other major carriers matching Pan Am's new level. Air Florida in turn decided to match thePan Am prices , though with certain restrictions.

title:
Patents;
A Way to Add Strength To Porous Plastic
description: A pioneer inventor of porous plastic sheets used in clothing, shoes and automobile upholstery offers an improvement by adding needed strength to certain sections where porosity is not required.

title: Iran Reports an Earthquake
description: The Teheran radio said an earthquake measuring 4.5 on the Richter scale struck the central province of Kerman today. No injuries or serious d amage were reported, according to the Tehera n radio.

title: 4 AMERICANS FREED BY HAVANNA
description: The State Department announced today that three New York Congressmen had arranged the release of four Americans who were being held in Cuba on drug charges.

title: THE BIG LOSERS IN HEALTH-CARE COST SHARING
description: To the Editor:

title: CONIFER GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
TRAVEL PUBLISHER'S WANDERLUST OPENS WAY TO NEW MARKETS
description: Hans Johannes Hoefer's passion for travel took him to places many people only dream of going to. He has seen the sunset from the summit of one of the world's highest passes in the Hindu Kush mountains, visited hill tribes in Malaysia a nd lived in a village in Bali, Indonesia.

title: Sports People; Money Man
description: Bill Rodgers says he is too busy making money to win marathons. ''My schedule is the main reason I doubt I'll get to be No.1 again,'' he said from Houston, where he is training for the Houston Marathon tomorrow.

title: U.S WEIGHS SECURITIES SALE LIMITS
description: The Treasury Department is considering changes in the way it sells its securities through Federal Reserve banks, weighing the possibilities of raising minimum purchases sharply, imposing fees or even stopping direct sales to the public.

title: MUSIC: 'RAVINIA' SERIES
description: ''James Levine's Music From Ravinia,'' a three-concert series that opened Wednesday night at Alice Tully Hall, might suggest music that came from the Chicago Symphony Orchestra's summer Ravinia Festival, of which Mr. Levine has been music director s ince 1973. But Mr. Levine is also music director o f the Metropolitan Opera, a nd naturally his interests and collaborating artists tend to overlap.

title: HEIRS OF PASTERNAK FIGHTING EVICTION FROM DACHA
description: After tacitly allowing Boris Pasternak's country house to serve as an unofficial museum and memorial for the 22 years since his death, the Soviet literary establishment is demanding that the dacha be vacated for a ''productive'' writer.

title: STAGE: IN VIETNAM WAR
description: Late in ''Dustoff,'' Bruce King's Vietnam play at the Westside Mainstage, a lethally drunk young G.I., drafted out of an Indian reservation, tells his buddies of the worst atrocities he's seen in a grueling war. The atrocities involve rape, castration and throatslitting, and, once they've been described, what can anyone say? A dead silence hangs in the air, and the actor, Tino Juarez, takes a pause. Then he stares out at the audience and, in an affectless voice, says, ''I just stood there and watched it happen.''

title: POLICE AIDE ON COAST SAYS SPIES MAY POSE AS JEWISH EMIGR ES
description: Daryl Gates, the Los Angeles police chief, said today that intelligence reports indicated the Soviet Union was sending ''dangerous criminals'' to this country, posing as Jewish emigres and that they might attempt to disrupt the 1984 Summer Olympic Games here.

title: TWO KILLED IN KENTUCKY MINE
description: Two men were killed today when the roof of a mine collapsed on them in the fifth fatal Appalachian coal mine accident in less than two months. Thirty-three miners have died in the incidents.

title: Jobless Rate 9% in E.E.C.
description: The symptoms of the continuing European recession worsened today with unemployment in the 10-nation European Economic Community hitting the 10 million mark for the first time since World War II.

title: Margaret Fossi Rites Today
description: A funeral service will be held today at 2 P.M. in Christ Church in Bronxville, N.Y., for Margaret Everson Fossi, whose body was found in Houston in the trunk for her car.

title: News Analysis
description: Questioning the tax-exempt status of church-related schools wh ose theology mand ates racial discrimination raises serious church-state issues, churc h leaders and lawyers say.

title: OMARK INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Yankees Have Mixed Feelings on Jackson's Leaving
description: For five years Lou Piniella watched Reggie Jackson's heroic performances and his crises, and last night Piniella, a 38-year-old outfielder, had mixed feelings about Jackson's decision yesterday to sign with the California Angels.

title: DANCE: CHARLES MOULTON COMPANY
description: There's a good deal of new-generation modern dance these days that leaves one exhilarated with its sheer physicality. Very seldom, however, does that go along with wit, a developed choreographic perspective, elegance, humanity and just plain good dancing. But it happened on Wednesday at the American Theater Laboratory's Bessie Schonberg Theater, where the Charles Moulton Dance Company performs through Jan. 31. If you see only one dance concert this year, as the saying goes, see this.

title: MONOGRAM INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Quarter is after $695,000 gain from sale of obsolete manufacturing facility, and 6 months is after gain of $832,000 from sale of obsolete manufacturing facility and gain of $439,000 from adoption of FASB rule on foreign currency trans-lations

title:
Patents;
Vaporization Process In Crude Refining
description: Two patents received this week by the Engelhard Corporation, Edison, N.J., are part of a series that the company believes can cut crude oil imports in half by increasing the proportion of gasoline and other valuable products recovered from the crude during the refining process.

title: SYRIA ACCUSES JORDAN OF KILLING SOLDIER IN RAID
description: Syria said today that armed men infiltrated into its territory from Jordan on Thursday and ambushed an army patrol, killing a sergeant and wounding another soldier.

title: OLD NATIONAL BANKCORP (SPOKANE, WASH) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The 1980 per shre amounts have been restated to reflect the 10% stock dividend paid March 6 1981

title: FOREMOST-MCKESSON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Bendix Won't Buy Burroughs
description: The Bendix Corporation, a diversified manufacturer of automotive and aerospace products, held merger talks with the Burroughs Corporation but is no longer interested in such a combination, the Bendix chairman, William M. Agee, disclosed at a meeting of New York financial writers.

title: Notes on People; Another Job for Richard Allen
description: Richard V. Allen, who was forced out as President Reagan's national security adviser two weeks ago, has found another job in Washington.

title: NEW YORK PLANS OFFICE COMPLEX IN NORTH BRONX
description: New York City plans to apply for an $18.9 million Federal grant to help build a complex of office buildings in the northeast Bronx - the largest request ever made for a commercial enterprise outside Manhattan.

title: CUBANS IN ARKANSAS WILL BE TRANSFERRED TO 2 FEDERAL PRISONS
description: The 392 Cuban refugees still being held at Fort Chaffee, Ark., will be transferred this weekend to prisons in Georgia and Missouri ''because it's cheaper to keep them there,'' Justice Department officials said today.

title: CETUS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including extraordinary tax credits of $115,000 for the quarter and $490,000 for the 6 months; C-Net loss

title: NOFZIGER LEAVES REAGAN: TAKE THREE
description: For the third time in three years, Lyn Nofziger has quit for good as an aide to President Reagan. No one, except possibly Mr. Nofziger, is sure that the White House political director and former campaign press secretary will stay gone. But just in case, he went through the farewell motions today that he uses every time he leaves Mr. Reagan's employ.

title: Around the Nation; Ten Avalanches Strike Utah Ski Resort Area
description: Ten avalanches surged into Little Cottonwood Canyon in Utah's ski country today, blocking a highway, burying a dormitory and stranding 3,000 people at two major resorts.

title: FROM THE 'TRULY NEEDY,' A CRY FOR THAT ELUSIVE 'SAFETY NET'
description: More than 2,000 elderly, poor and disabled people, some in organized bus groups and others managing alone on one of the coldest days of the year, crowded a Manhattan auditorium yesterday to talk about the devastating effects of the Reagan budget cuts on their lives.

title: AMERICAN HOME PRODUCTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Observer; RIGHT SMART O' WIND
description: Watching television weather reporters rave about the wind chill factor this winter has started me thinking about my Uncle Bruce and what a loss his passing was to the art of cold-weather reporting.

title: Sports People; Indiana St. Coach Quits
description: Bill Hodges, who was named college basketball's coach of the year when he guided Indiana State to a 33-1 record and second place in the national collegiate tournament in 1978-79, said yest erday that hewas resigning , effective at the end of this season. Hodges, 38 years old, was an a ssistant to Coach Bob King for three year s be fore takingover the job in 1977.

title: Your Money; Is 'Whole Life' Worthwhile?
description: THE whole-life policy, which provides insurance benefits along with a forced savings plan, has for years been the bread and butter of the insurance industry. But whole life is under pressure these days because in times of inflation and high interest rates it seems a poor investment even though interest earned accumulates tax-free. Its savings component provides a skimpy return compared with, say, a money-market mutual fund.

title: NEEDIEST CASES APPEAL REACHES DISTANT PLACES
description: Distance appears to make little difference to contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund who once lived in New York City or have memories of visits. Annually, they make their donations from faraway places.

title: 2 Northwest Nuclear Plants to Be Ended
description: The Washington Public Power Supply System, acting on the recommendation of its managing director, voted yesterday to terminate two controversial West Coast nuclear power projects that have already raised some $2.25 billion in the nation's municipal bond market.

title: No Headline
description: Red Smith Honored

title: INSTRUMENTATION LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including a pretax gain of $241,000 for the quarter and a pretax loss of $144,000 for 9 months from foreign currency translations; C-Net income after a foreign currency translation loss of $299,000 and credit of $483,000, or 16 cents a share, realized in connection with the closing of foreign operation; D-After foriegn currency translation loss of $227,000; results have been restated to conformwith FASB Statement No 52

title: AN UNPERSUASIVE DEFENSE OF THE CAUSE OF SCIENCE
description: To the Editor:

title: SmithKline Tie Gets Approval
description: The boards of the SmithKline Corporation and Beckman Instruments Inc. approved a definitive merger agreement providing for the latter company to become a subsidiar y of a new company named SmithKline Beckman Corpo ration.

title: INJURED SOLOMON IS BETTER
description: The availability of Freddie Solomon, a starting wide receiver for the San Francisco 49ers, was upgraded today from ''questionable'' to ''probable'' for Super Bowl XVI.

title:
Patents;
TV Show on Inventors
description: Inventors can watch their segment of Bill Moyers's ''Creativity'' series next Friday evening on Public Broadcasting System stations. The guests include Harold Blac k, member of th e National Inventors Hall of Fame; Jacob Rabinow, who has 217 pate nts, and Chris Fatis, inventor of a computer to aid shepherds.

title: BOATMEN'S BANCSHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The per share net reflects a 10% stock dividend declared December 1981

title: GIBRALTAR SAVINGS ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including a tax credit of $5,485,000; C-Net income including a tax credit of $2,021,000; Gibraltar Savings was spun of its parent company, Imperial Corp of America, and year-ago results were prepared in conformity with applicable regulations on an unaudited basis

title: Around the World; Haiti Says 8 Exiles Died In Bungled Invasion
description: AU-PRINCE, Haiti, Jan. 22 (UPI) - The Government said Thursday night that its troops killed eight exiles and forced 10 others to flee in repulsing an invasion attempt this month.

title: POLISH CHIEF PLANS MAJOR ADDRESS TO OUTLINE CHANGES IN ECONOMY
description: In a major address to Parliament on Monday, Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski is expected to present programs for economic and eventual political changes, but the Polish leader is not likely to end martial law, well-informed Polish sources said today.

title: CONSUMER PRICES ROSE 8.9% IN 1981,LEAST IN 4 YEARS
description: Consumer prices rose four-tenths of 1 percent in December, the Labor Department reported today, bringing the rise for 1981 to only 8.9 percent, the lowest annual increase since 1977.

title: Canada Unit to Get 58% Stake in Savin
description: The Canada Development Corporation will acquire a 58 percent stake in the Savin Corporation, a marketer and manufacturer of copiers, under an agreement signed yesterday by directors of both companies, Savin said.

title: RARE BOOK THEFTS: THE WINDING TRAIL
description: James Richard Shinn, an ''extraordinarily gentle man,'' according to law enforcement officials and others, is a book lover. He also likes money and good living. He is a large man, about 6 foot 2 inches tall, weighing about 225 pounds.

title: Around the World; Rebels Say U.S. Advisers Aided Salvador Attack
description: A clandestine rebel radio station said today that two United States military advisers took part in a Salvadoran Army attack this month in which 70 civilians were slain.

title: BETHLEHEM MAYOR CALLS ON P.L.O. TO RECOGNIZE ISRAELI RIGHT TO EXIST
description: Mayor Elias Frej of Bethlehem, considered a relative moderate among prominent Palestinians in the Israelioccupied West Bank, called on the Palestine Liberation Organization today to recognize Israel so that political efforts can proceed toward establishing a Palestinian state.state.

title: FARMER BROS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
No Headline
description: NETS END SUNS' STREAK, 99-97

title: PEOPLES ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
