title: Credit Market; MONEY SUPPLY UP $700 MILLION
description: The Federal Reserve Board yesterday announced a $700 million increase in the nation's basic money supply for the week ended Jan. 13 - a surprising development to analysts who had expected a decline of about $4 billion to offset some of the previous week's large, $10.2 billion increase.

title: Around the Nation; Klansman Surrenders In Newspaper Shooting
description: Kenneth Painter, a Ku Klux Klansman, has surrendered to the Jackson police on charges that he fired a gun into the office of a black weekly newspaper.

title: Briefing
description: T HE odd saga of Myer Rashish at the State Department is about to end, or is it? For the past few months there have been numerous reports that Mr. Rashish, the No. 4 official and senior economic expert at the department, is on his way out because Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. is unhappy with him. The stories have never been denied, although no one seems quite sure why Mr. Haig might want to get rid of him. Speculation has centered less on policy differences than on a lack of ''personal chemistry.''

title: INLAND STEEL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net income; C-After $4.1 million nonrecurring expenses

title: AGENCY IS SPLIT ON PRODUCT RECALL IN CHILD'S DEATH
description: The Consumer Product Safety Commission, in a closed session, has decided to close a two-year-old recall case involving a slide that has been associated with one child's death and serious brain injury for another.

title: IMPERIAL CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Notes on People; Outlaw No More
description: A follow-up: The man who feared that his real name, Archie Outlaw, would prejudice a jury against him yesterday settled on Archie Simmons as the name under which he will be tried next week on charges of possession and sale of heroin.

title: The Recidivist Mrs. Gandhi
description: Gerald Ford has boasted that in his Presidency, the United States became the world's largest democracy. But that was only because Indira Gandhi subverted India's democracy in 1975.

title: Foremost Net Up 4.7%
description: Foremost-McKesson Inc., a diversified home building, health care and food company, announced yesterday that its net income rose 4.7 percent in the third fiscal quarter of 1982 e nded Dec. 31, to $22.2 million, or $1.29 a share, from $21.2 million , or $1.33 a share, in the comparable period of 1980. Revenues of th e San Francisco-based concern increased 7.2 percent, to $1.19 billi on, from $1.11 billion.

title: U.N. Group Chooses Rome
description: The 136-member governing council of the International Fund for Agricultural Development has chosen Rome as its permanent headquarters, the United Nations agency announced today.

title: William Kelly Jr., 74; Ex-Chairman of Abex
description: William Tolson Kelly Jr., who started as a molder's helper and stepped down 42 years later as chairman and chief executive officer of the company, the Abex Corporation, died Monday in Naples, Fla., at the age of 74. He had moved to Naples from Darien, Conn., upon his retirement in 1970.

title: BRANIFF DEBT DEADLINE IS POSTPONED
description: The Braniff International Corporation announced last night that its creditors had postponed for eight months a deadline for collecting overdue debt payments while the money-losing trunk carrier tries to reorganize as a smaller airline.

title: By David C. Anderson
description: The Editorial Notebook Why Was Jack Abbott Released?

title: Notes on People; Landlord Group Gets a New Chief
description: The Rent Stabilization Association, New York City's largest organization of rental-property owners, has a new executive director.

title: A HUNTER'S FAMILY: A WAY OF LIFE AND DEATH
description: The snow lies deep and fresh in the gentle valleys and hollows between the shadowed ridgelines here, so that when game animals move in the woods, they leave clear tracks for the hunter's eye.

title: News Analysis; DECLINE IN INFLATION: PRESIDENT IS MODEST
description: The Reagan Administration is being rather modest about the slowdown of inflation in 1981, although it is the only good economic news on the President's slate after one year in office.

title: ARMS CONTROL CHIEF ASSERTS REAGAN IS UNCERTAIN HOW TO USE POWER
description: Eugene V. Rostow, Director of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, said today that, while President Reagan had turned American foreign policy in the proper direction, the Administration still lacked a consensus on how its military and diplomatic power should be used.

title: Sports People; Comings and Goings
description: Lawrence O'Brien, commisioner of the National Basketball Association, announced that a league inquiry had found that the New Jersey Nets did not make an unauthorized approach to Marvin Webster, the Knick center. ... Earl Anthony has been voted the male Bowler of the Year for 1981 by the Bowling Writers Association of America. The group also gave him that honor in 1974, 1975 and 1976.

title: CAROLINA POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
GREEK ARCHBISHOP IN A SCUFFLE WITH A BISHOP
description: A senior Greek bishop sai d today that he had been assaulted by his archbishop during a sto rmy session of the GreekOrthodox Church hierarchy.

title: Ban on Vietnam Book Lifted
description: Federal District Judge Conrad Cyr today lifted the Baileyville School Board's ban on ''365 Days,'' ordering that the book by Ronald Glasser about Americans wounded in Vietnam go back on the Woodland High School library's shelves.

title: Around the World; Bonn's Budget Passes; Gives Military 'Problems'
description: The West German Parliament approved an austere 1982 federal budget today that Bonn's Defense Minister, Dr. Hans Apel, said would confront the armed forces with ''serious problems.''

title: GOING TO ORLANDO--OR, REUNION AT TET
description: On the eve of last Tet - the Vietnamese New Year, Feb. 4, 1981 - an old friend of mine with whom I had lost contact since the fall of Saigon in 1975 paid me an unexpected visit.

title: Germans Agree to Sell Fiber Plant to Russians
description: A West German manufacturer has agreed to supply the Soviet Union with a $260 million polyester filament plant. It was the first such agreement since the United States imposed economic sanctions on the Russians because of the military crackdown in Poland and called on its allies to do so, too.

title: NUCLEAR TALKS MUST GO ON
description: Despite the current climate of hostility, the United States and Soviet Union continue to share common interests that cannot be neglected. Nuclear nonproliferation is a prime example.

title:
Patents;
Microphones on Wand For Phone Conferences
description: An array of microphones, patented this week for Bell Telephone Laboratories, Murray Hill, N.J., is regarded as valuable for telephone conferences.

title: FOUR-PHASE SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including a $1,398,000 pretax gain for the quarter and year from the sale of investment tax credits and depreciation benefits

title: PAN AM EXECUTIVE
description: John C. Leslie, a prominent figure in the aviation industry for more than four decades, died Tuesday on the island of Antigua, in the West Indies. He was 76 years old and had lived in Scarsdale, N.Y., for several years before his retirement.

title: Business Digest; SATURDAY, JANUARY 23, 1982; The Economy
description: Consumer prices rose just 0.4 percent in December and only 8.9 percent for the year as a whole, the lowest annual increase since 1977, the Labor Department reported. Price increases, held back by the recession, slowed across the board, except in medical care. The inflation rate for the last three months of 1 981, if it were to continue for a year, would be 5.3 percent, wh ile the December rate, computed annually, would be 5.2 percent. But the key to continued improvement on inflation, many economists say , is lower wage settlements this year. (Page 1.) In the New Y ork area, the 0.7 percent inflation rate for the last quarter w as the lowest in 15 years. (32.) President Reagan can't applaud t he slowing of inflation without seeming to endorse the recession. (32 .)

title: U.S. Lifts Cap On Mortgages
description: In a discouraging signal for the nation's depressed housing industry, Government officials said today that they are raising the ceilings for federally insured home loan rates.

title: Going Out Guide
description: HOUSE GUESTS

title: GALILEO SPACE MISSION EXTENDED
description: The space agency announced today that it would continue development of the Galileo space mission to explore Jupiter and its moons but that the new plan would lengthen the voyage by 30 months and add $170 million to the project's cost.

title: NEW HAMPSHIRE BALL BEARINGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Koch Wins for 2d Time In Cup Cross-Country
description: Bill Koch, who last Saturday in Switzerland became the first American to win a World Cup crosscountry ski race, scored another victory today and moved into second place in the standing, a point behind the leader.

title: Around the Nation; Miami Seeking Killer Who Called Crisis Center
description: The police are seeking a man who phoned a crisis center to say, ''I'm going to kill myself or somebody else,'' then killed a man.

title: LARCHMONT ELBOWS CONRAIL FOR SEATS
description: Larchmont is talking back to Conrail, and in no uncertain terms. If Conrail refuses to put more cars on its New Haven commuter trains, the village says it will close its metered parking lot to nonvillagers to cut down on the number of passengers. The Village Board put all this in writing today in a letter to Conrail.

title: Sports People; Rautins Sidelined
description: Leo Rautins, the 6-foot-8-inch standout with the Syracuse University basketball team, has undergone arthroscopic surgery at Upstate Medical Center in Syracuse for the removal of three bone chips from his right knee.

title: JACOBS ENGINEERING GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
DANCE: CITY BALLET'S NEW 'MAGIC FLUTE'
description: ''The Magic Flute,'' a sweet but silly little ballet, was given for the first time Thursday night at the State Theater as the New York City Ballet's first new production of the season.

title: 3 FARM BOSSES FOUND GUILTY OF MIGRANT WORKER SLAVERY
description: Three field bosses who Federal prosecutors said ''ran a reign of terror'' on a North Carolina sweet potato farm were convicted tonight on 9 of 12 counts of conspiracy to kidnap, intimidate and enslave migrant farm workers.

title: GUIDO IS NAMED TO HEAD THE WESTCHESTER POLICE
description: Daniel P. Guido, former Police Commissioner of Nassau County and of Yonkers, was named Westchester County's top law enforcement officer today. He replaces Thomas J. Delaney, whose resignation as Commissioner of Public Safety also became effective today.

title: Around the World; Ghana's New Ruler Names a Civilian Cabinet
description: Jerry J. Rawlings, Ghana's new leader, named a Cabinet of 16 civilians today, but made clear that he was not handing over power.

title: CENVILL DEVELOPMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: B-There are no comparable year-ago figures since the three months ended Oct 31,1981 was the first quarter of business operations for the company; October 31 is the company's fiscal year-end

title: FIRST OF MICHIGAN CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for 14 wks to Dec 31
De Gustibus; FINDING A GOOD CROISSANT
description: Given the newly won popularity of the croissant in New York, it is disappointing to realize how few good representations of it can be found. That, unfortunately, is the conclusion after a recent sampling of croissants from 20 sources.

title: Answers to Quiz
description: Questions appear on page 14. 1. Antitank rockets were fired at a French plant under construction. 2. The Pentagon is said to have recommended the building of 50 additional C-5 cargo planes, produced in Georgia, instead of a new plane, the C-17, which would have been manufactured in St. Louis.

title: GIBRALTAR FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net income; C-Including a gain of $6,246,000 on the repurchase of mortgage backed bonds; D-After a charge of $2,660,000 from penalties on prepayments of Federal Home Loan Bank borrowings

title: MUSIC: 'FOR THE LOVE'
description: Artistic affiliations go by all manner of catchy names, but few have titles as to-the-point as ''For the Love of Music,'' which neatly summarizes the reasons why most musicians play concerts and most members of the audience listen to them. Of course, it takes morethan love to make a concert come to life; it takes skills and interpretive insights that the musicians of ' 'For the Love of Music''sometimes made evident and sometimes did not in their Tuesday night program at the Merkin Concert Hall.The group's offering of chamber works by Mozart, Hindemith and Dvorak was bo th interesting and well-balanced, but the quality of the performan ces varied with the performers who took part in each piece. At one end of the spectrum was the account of Hindemith's Sonata for Vi ola and Piano (Op. 11, No. 4) that closed the first halfof the progra m, in which the playing of Robert Vernon, violist, and Pamela Mia Pa ul, pianist, showed extraordinary depth and finish.

title: 3 Sentenced for Point-Shaving
description: Three of the five men convicted last November of having conspired to manipulate the scores of Boston College basketball games were sentenced to prison yesterday. Judge Henry Bramwell of United States District Court in Brooklyn imposed the heaviest punishment - a 20-year term and a $30 ,000 fine -on James Burke, 50 years old, a previously convicted extor tionist and reputed organized-crime figure from Howard Beach, Quee ns.

title: Pillsbury Seeks Wickes Division
description: The Wickes Companies Inc., a diversified commodities, manufacturing and retail concern, said that the Pillsbury Company had agreed in principle to acquire its agriculture division.

title:
Patents;
New Tube Brightens TV Colors
description: WASHINGTON A TELEVISION picture tube invented by scientists at RCA Laboratories in Princeton, N.J., is expected to display much brighter colors and requi re less electric power.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I don't think we got all the bad guys out of Government we should have gotten and all the good guys into Government we should have gotten.'' - Lyn Nofziger, former White House political director. (9:5.)

title: BALTIMORE GAS & ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
LANDMARK BANKING CORP OF FLORIDA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The per share figure reflect a 5% stock dividend paid in January 1982

title: The Region; Bill to Cancel Tax Vetoed by O'Neill
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill, as expected, vetoed legislation that would have canceled Connecticut's tax on unincorporated businesses.

title: U.S. FORMALLY LINKS ARMS TALKS WITH THE 'REPRESSION' IN POLAND
description: The Reagan Administration today formally linked progress in arms control negotiations with the Soviet Union to Moscow's involvement in what it called ''the continuing repression of the Polish people.''

title: MARSH SUPERMARKETS reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 2
description: The results of the latest periods include a gain of $492,000 from the sale of 12 drug stores in Indiana and Ohio

title: Nelson's 63 Leads at Phoenix by 2 Shots
description: Seventy-two players, one-half the field in the rain-delayed Phoenix Open, spent today trying futilely to catch Thursday's leaders.

title: COMMERCIAL TRUST CO OF NJ reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Around the Nation; Blacks in Vote Fraud Given Work Releases
description: Two black women from Pickens County, convicted of voting fraud, left prison today on a workrelease program.

title: AT A HEARING ON INDIAN POINT, FEAR HAS A DOUBLE EDGE
description: Neighbors of Indian Point have strong fears about its two nuclear power plants. Some are frightened that the plants will continue to operate; others are worried that they will not.

title: Saturday News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 47. 1. France's nuclear power industry, which appeared to be supported by most Frenchmen, came under attack this week. Explain. 2. Because of a reported Pentagon decision, members of Congress from Georgia are delighted and those from Missouri are glum. Why? 3. ''That's $20 million not being sent to Arab states. We're helping the balance of trade,''said County executive Alfred B. DelBello. About what?

title: DIAMOND CRYSTAL SALT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CALIFORNIA MICROWAVE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Whose Gravy Train of Coal?
description: Should railroads be regulated where shippers have no other practical means of moving freight to market? Last year's rail deregulation act requires the Interstate Commerce Commission to set rates in such cases, lest the railroads overcharge. But the industry now seeks an exemption for one important commodity: coal destined for export. And it has found important allies in the Government.

title:
Patents;
Solar Engine Functions Without a Bright Sun
description: Charles J. Wurmfeld of New York, former president of the New York State Professional Engineers Society, has invented an engine that draws solar energy from the ''ambient,'' or ordinary, atmosphere, not requiring bright sunshine.

title: Gregg Is Trying to Stay Loose
description: Laughing, Forrest Gregg said, ''I'm intense.'' But is intensity the same as tightness or nervousness? In the Super Bowl, the rule is that the nervous team loses. ''That's been the history of the game,'' Don Weiss, the executive director of the National Football League, said.

title: WHEN WORLD LAW SHOULD PREVAIL IN EXTRADITION PROCEEDINGS
description: To the Editor:

title: STATE IS CENSURED ON CAR INSPECTION
description: Federal District Judge Louis Bechtle today held the State of Pennsylvania in civil contempt of court for not putting an automobile emissions inspection program into effect.

title: FIRST MISSISSIPPI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: CINEMA VERITE OF ABBOTT TRIAL
description: In the nearly three weeks that Jack Henry Abbott stood trial in Manhattan for murder, the grimy corridor outside the courtroom was filled with photographers and television apparatus. Lines of the curious milled behind police sawhorses, waiting for empty seats on the court's oak benches.

title: News Analysis
description: If there were any lingering doubts, developments at the now-suspended talks between the two largest automobile companies and the United Automobile Workers union make it clear that some of the automobile industry's cherished traditions and prejudices have fallen victim to the losses of the past two years.

title: URBAN SPACE WAR WITH MULTIPLE WINNERS
description: To the Editor:

title: ATWOOD OCEANICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
INTERMOUNTAIN GAS INDUSTRIES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Consumer Saturday; OF WINTER, SHOES AND AUTOS
description: T HEY may seem like the ghosts of snowstorms past, the faint white stains that haunt shoes and boots long after the drifts outside have melted. Salt, used to melt ice on streets and sidewalks, appears on footwear as it dries, and if not removed may split, crack and destroy leather. But the untimely death of a good sole can be avoided, shoe repairers say, with a bit of careful maintainance.

title: U.S. EXPECTS PROGRESS IN NAMIBIA TALKS
description: State Department officials said today that the United States and four other Western nations expected to make progress next week in their efforts to bring about the independence of South-West Africa from South Africa.

title: RYLAND GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
INFLATION COOLED IN NEW YORK
description: Cost-of-living data for the last three months in the New Yorknortheastern New Jersey area indicate that inflation is cooling off, the Regional Commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics said yesterday.

title: British Banks Cut Rates
description: Britain's four major banks cut their base lending rates to 14 percent from 14 1/2 percent today, a day after the Dutch and West German central banks cut the rates on loans they make to commercial banks. The four British banks, National Westminster, Barclays, Lloyds and Midland, cut their rates after the Bank of England made funds available to them at lower interest rates. The West German central bank cut its rate to 10 percent from 10 1/2 percent, and the Dutch central bank cut its rate to 8 1/2 percent from 9 percent.

title: 'FRONT LINE,' WAR CAMERAMAN
description: Neil Davis is an unusual kind of war hero: he's one of the intrepid cameramen who helped bring the Vietnam War into America's living rooms, at enormous personal risk. Mr. Davis spent 11 years in Indochina, intimately involved in the events that he recorded on film.

title: MARATHON DOWN 27.5% ON 9.1% REVENUES GAIN
description: The Marathon Oil Company reported yesterday that high inventories and the costs incurred in fighting a takeover attempt by the Mobil Corporation caused net earnings to drop 27.5 percent in the fourth quarter of 1981, while revenues rose 9.1 percent.

title: Sports People; Ken Boyer Ailing
description: Ken Boyer, the former standout third baseman of the St. Louis Cardinals who now manages the team's Louisville Redbirds Triple-A farm club, is receiving treatment for lung cancer. A. Ray Smith, the Redbirds' owner, in reporting Boyer's illness, said: ''The doctor says that with medical science he could whip it. As far as I'm concerned, he's going to manage.'' Boyer, 50 years old, hit .287 for 15 major league seasons, most of them with the Cardinals, whom he managed from 1978 through mid-1980.

title: MORGENTHAU'S SUIT ON SHIFT OF JUDGES DISMISSED IN COURT
description: A State Supreme Court justice yesterday ruled against District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau of Manhattan in his lawsuit against the state's Chief Judge, Lawrence H. Cooke. But the District Attorney's office said he would appeal.

title: FALSE HONDURAN CLAIM AGAINST NICARAGUA
description: To the Editor:

title: ARKLA INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results have been adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split on Nov 23, 1981

title: STOCK PRICES DOWN IN LIGHT TRADING
description: Stock prices eased yesterday in light trading, following signs that the Federal Reserve had embarked upon a more restrictive monetary policy. As a result, rising short-term interest rates kept many equity investors on the defensive.

title: HERCULES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FOOD VENDORS, IN A PROTEST, ASSAIL TIGHTER HEALTH RULES
description: About 200 angry food vendors gave away pretzels and leaflets yesterday as they marched to City Hall to protest Health Department regulations they said were driving them out of business.

title: New York; SOMEBODY CALL THE COPS
description: A month and a half ago, on a rainy Dec. 8, more than 20 policemen, in squad cars and vans, pulled up to 126 La Salle Street in Harlem to evict the occupants of the six-story building. It's not often that the police are used to summarily evict people. The law says landlords are supposed to go through the courts and get proper papers and use marshals.

title: KOPPERS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Sakharov Issues a Plea For Dissident's Release
description: Andrei D. Sakharov, the Soviet physicist, is appealing for international pressure to bring about the release of a fellow dissident from prison, two members of Congress who recently returned from the Soviet Union said today.

title: PAUL VAN ANDA, 82, A LAWYER
description: Paul Van Anda, an estate and corporation lawyer, died Thursday in Salt Lake City while preparing for a skiing trip in nearby Snowbird, Utah. Mr. Van Anda, who lived in Upper Nyack, N.Y., was 82 years old.

title: SOVIET HAILS FINNISH VOTE AS 'SHIFT TO THE LEFT'
description: The result of the Finnish presidential election of last Sunday and Monday was acclaimed in a commentary by the Moscow radio today as a ''clear shift to the left.''

title: WIDER EVIDENCE URGED FOR ATLANTA TRIAL
description: Prosecutors in the trial of Wayne B. Williams, who is charged with murdering two black youths, said today that they wanted to introduce evidence linking him with the deaths of 10 other young blacks.

title: LEXIDATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

description: To the Edit or: Your Op-Ed page of Jan. 12 dealt with creationism and showed a caricature of Michelangelo's famous fresco in which God and Adam had the faces of apes. I take strong issue with this kind of ''fun.''

title: STALEY, A E, MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CINCINNATI GAS & ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Presumed Hero of Jet Crash Eulogized in Hometown Rites
description: Family and friends in his hometown paid final tribute today to Arland D. Williams Jr., who most likely was the hero who drowned after helping save other victims of the Air Florida crash in Washington on Jan. 13.

title: Chrysler Talks On Unit's Sale
description: The Chrysler Corporation is reported near an agreement to sell its tank-building unit, but one of the three companies said to be bidding said yesterday it had dropped out.

title: FOES OF ABORTION MEET WITH REAGAN
description: On the ninth anniversary of the Supreme Court decision that legalized abortion, demonstrators marched here today to support a legislative campaign to reverse that ruling.

title: 'Little Prince' Closes Before Formal Opening
description: ''The Little Prince and the Aviator,'' which was supposed to have opened tomorrow at the Alvin Theater, closed yesterday. The musical, starring Michael York, has been plagued by financial problems and has not given a performance since last Sunday. Mr. York is scheduled to leave for California today.

title: JACKSON LEAVES THE YANKEES, AGREEING TO ANGELS CONTRACT
description: Reggie Jackson ended five years as one of the most colorful and controversial players on the Yankees yesterday when he agreed to a four-year contract with the California Angels for close to $1 million a season.

title: Norway's Bankruptcies
description: Norway had 810 bankruptcies in 1981 - the highest annual number since World War II. A report today from the Central Bureau of Statistics said the comparative figure in 1980 was 765.

title: VIRGINIA ELECTRIC & POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Bridge: Beginner's Natural Move Can Be the Expert's, Too
description: Suppose that the contract is three no-trump and there are eight fast tricks available. If the declarer runs his tricks and then looks round for salvation, he is probably a foolish beginner who has thereby established tricks for the defense.

title: YOUNG OF THE 49ERS EXUDES CONFIDENCE
description: Charle Young finds a reason for everything. The San Francisco 49ers' tight end, who will finish his ninth pro football season by playing in Super Bowl XVI Sunday in nearby Pontiac, can explain why his physical condition is better than ever at the age of 30. He can tell why he gained something while sitting on the Los Angeles Rams' bench during his potentially most productive years; why he is playing so well now; why he will play well for years to come, and why the 49ers are here. He can disc ourse on why faith is so important to him, a task that comes easily because he is an ordained minister. He can even detail how the Charl es in Charles Edward Young became Charle.

title: Transit Report
description: Delays of up to 56 minutes were reported in the morning rush hour, with 95 of the 134 scheduled trains late and nine canceled. The 5:55 from Greenport, due at Hunts Point Avenue at 9, did not arrive until 9:56.

title: Greek Official Will Visit U.S.  For Talks on Military Bases
description: Carolos Papoulias, Greece's Undersecretary of Foreign Affairs, will pay a semiofficial visit to the United States next month, during which he will assess American intentions over the forthcoming negotiations on its military bases here, Government sources said today.

title: UNION PLANTERS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After a tax charge of $122,000 for the quarter and a tax credit of $1,806,000for the year; C-Including a tax credit of $1,638,000

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rate payable by savings institutions.

title: FIRST INTERSTATE BANK OF CALIFORNIA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec31
PNB MORTGAGE & REALTY INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
A Censor Confesses
description: Following are excerpts from an interview with a former Polish censor, identified as K-62, that appeared in May 1981 in a Solidarity weekly. Radio Free Europe published an English version. It appeared in the December 1981 issue of ''Index on Cens orship,'' which is distributed by the Fund for Free Expression, in New York.

title: SCA SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
L.I.U. Streak Ends at 7
description: Tom Caraher scored 25 points and Maurice Hicks added 20 to pace Loyola College of Baltimore to a 96-87 victory over Long Island University tonight in an Eastern College Athletic Conference Metro-South game.

title: MESQUITE, TEX., VS. 'EVIL EMPIRE'
description: Like their peers in other parts of the country, the youths of Mesquite have survived killer piranhas, berserk gorillas, an almost infinite variety of alien missiles and the depredations of the Evil Gorfian Robot Empire. Now they are facing a forc e far more implacable and dangerous than the assorted terrors that rocket across the screens of video games all over town.

title: WALCO: A HISTORY OF DISPUTES
description: Only three months ago, the Walco National Corporation was just another of the thousands of anonymous manufacturers supplying industry with products ranging from steel forgings to electric motors. It was not even followed on Wall Street by a full-time stock analyst.

title: Sports of The Times; Pro Football's Labor Scene
description: DEARBORN,Mi ch. ED GARVEY, his glasses glittering in the television lights, stood behind the po dium and appeared not much taller than the three huge men seated on either side of him. ''We,'' he said, ''are up against apowerful, soc ialistic, monopolistic industry called the National Football Leag ue.''

title: News Summary; SATURDAY, JANUARY 23, 1982
description: International Arms talks and the Polish crisis were formally linked by the Reagan Administration. The State Department spokesman said that no progress could be made in efforts to limit strategic nuclear weapons while the Soviet Union was involved in the ''continuing repression'' of the Polish people under martial law. (Page 1, Columns 2-3.) A key address to Poland's Parliament will be delivered Monday by Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski. Knowledgeable sources said that the leader was expected to present programs for economic reform and eventual political changes but that he is not likely to end martial law. (5:1-2.)

title: NEW ENGLAND ELECTRIC SYSTEM reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MARATHON OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SOUTHERN BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Saudi Bond Report
description: The Saudi Arabian Monetary Authority, the banking and investment arm of the Saudi Government, plans to buy yen-denominated convertible bonds issued by the Sony Corporation and the Honda Motor Company, a Japanese financial newspaper reported today.

title: DUKE POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Reagan's First Year Fifth of six articles.
description: In the belief that the biggest problem of consumers is too much government, the Reagan Administration has spentan active yea r giving ''regulatory relief'' to business.

title: U.S. FROST AND BRAZIL ORANGES
description: Carlos Quintella can be forgiven if he expresses something less than understanding for the plight of the Northern Hemisphere this frigid winter.

title: HEUBLEIN INC reports earnings for 6 mos to Dec 31
description: B-Including $2.5 million from the acquisition of debentures; corrected from yesterday's editions

title: MODERN LIBRARY GIANT, 80 TODAY, STILL ACTIVE
description: Donald S. Klopfer is 80 years old today, and if Klopfer isn't exactly a household name it can safely be said that millions of Americans have in their homes books that he helped to popularize: the 600 titles brought out over the years by the Modern Library.

title: 2 I.R.A. SUPPORTERS RRMAIN IN CUSTODY
description: Two prominent Irish republican activists remained in c ustody here today after trying to enter the United States illega lly from Canada in separate cars.

title: NEW ENGLAND BUSINESS SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 25
LOMAS & NETTLETON FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Daimler to Buy Fr eightliner Credit
description: Daimler-Benz, the West German auto maker, said that the Federal Reserve Board had approved its purchase of the Freightliner Credit Corporation, a financing unit for its major American operations.

title: Notes on People; Ex-Nixon Aide Keeps On Truckin'
description: The man in the cowboy hat, T-shirt and jeans at Perlis's truck stop in Cordele, Ga., was Ron Ziegler, who was the White House press secretary in the 1970's under President Richard M. Nixon.

title: SHAKLEE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Record 52d Victory in Row
description: The Louisiana Tech basketball team tonight set a national collegiate women's record with its 52d consecutive victory, beating Oral Roberts, 94-53.

title: Cruz Defeats Escalera With a Split Decision
description: Angel Cruz won a split decision from Alfredo Escalera, the former Wor ld Boxing Council junior lightweight champion, in the feature 10-round figh t before a crowd of 2,275 at the Felt Forum last night.

title: MAHON'S GOAL: FULL-TIME SETON HALL JOB
description: Hoddy Mahon, the acting basketball coach at Seton Hall University, says he does not know the status of the university's search for a permanent coach. He does not know the guidelines that will determine his future, or when a decision will be made, or what he should say to high school recruits and their coaches.

title: SOLARZ PLANS FOR A RACE TO KEEP BROOKLYN SEAT
description: Representative Stephen J. Solarz was in Cleveland the other day delivering a fervent address on the security and survival of Israel. As he drew to a close, Mr. Solarz, who speaks in a manner that is both confident and affable, came to the matter closest to his heart and the real reason he had flown more than 1,000 miles for a two-hour visit.

title: WILLIAM LUNEBURG, A FORMER PRESIDENT OF A.M.C., IS DEAD
description: William V. Luneburg, a retired president of the American Motors Corporation, died of a heart attack Thursday night at the Detroit Science Center, whlie attending a meeting of the center's executive committee. He was 69 years old and lived in Ann Arbor, Mich.

title: EDUARDO FREI, EX-PRESIDENT OF CHILE, IS DEAD AT 71
description: Former President Eduardo Frei Montalva, the Western Hemisphere's first Christian Democratic President, died here today after a two-month illness. He was 71 years old.

title: Ursula Konzett Prevails In a World Cup Slalom
description: Ursula Konzett of Liechtenstein and Anni Kronbichler of Austria were separated by the blink of an eye - one-hundredth of a second - finishing first and second today in a women's World Cup slalom ski race.

title: SEAGATE TECHNOLOGY reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes $89,000 extraordinary credit

title: Sports People; Valuable Property
description: Deputy Minister, last year's champion 2-year-old colt and the early favorite for the Kentucky Derby, seems to keep splitting like a valuable stock. Last summer, Morton and Marjoh Levy, who bred him and raced him in the colors of their Centurion Farm near Toronto, sold a half interest in the colt to Kinghaven Farm, which is owned by a fellow Canadian, Donald G. Wilmot.

title: NOT JUST ANOTHER OPENING OF THE ANTIQUES SHOW
description: It was, more than one observer remarked, a ''killer party.'' A wall-to wall crowd of over 2,500 people, including the top names in society, antiques collecting, show business, the arts and decorating, crammed themselves into the Seventh Regiment Armory, at Park Avenue at 67th Street, as the 28th Annual Winter Antiques Show got under away last night. The show be nefits the East Side House Settlement, a socialservice s organization in the South Bronx. Two parties - one the Patrons Preview, the other a Guests Preview (tickets were $90 and $60, respectively) -marked the opening of the prestigious s how and sale, open to the public today through Jan. 31.

title: Lemongello Surrenders On Kidnapping Charges
description: Mark Lemongello, a 26-year-old former major league pitcher, surrendered at the Pinellas County sheriff's office today and was booked on charges of kidnapping and armed robbery. He was released on $10,000 bond.

title: About New York; FOR SLAIN WAITER'S FAMILY, ANGER AND PAIN REMAIN
description: On the morning after judgment was rendered, Luisa and Henry Howard were back where it all began, at a table in the Binibon restaurant on the corner of Fifth Street. The restaurant is one of those unassuming Lower East Side places with a hand-painted sign, part ethnic-exotic, part perfectly ordinary, on a beat-up stretch of Second Avenue.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Lucette Dunlop Married
description: The marriage of Lucette Colvin Dunlop, daughter of Mrs. Whitney Trowbridge Kelsey of Madison, Conn., and the late Capt. Robert H. Dunlop, U.S.A., to Dale Frank Favreau took place yesterday. The Rev. Rebecca Spencer performed the ceremony in the Waterman Chapel of the Second Congregational Church in Greenwich, Conn. The bride is manager and acting director of security, property management, at the Connecticut General Life Insurance Company in Hartford. Mr. Favreau, son of the late George L. Favreau and the late Mrs. M. Staffor d Favreau of Ch arlton, Mass., is senior experimental aircraftequip ment engineer at the Wilgoos Laboratory of Pratt & Whitney in Ea st Hartford, Conn.

title: Judaism and the Liberal Tradition
description: In his article on Irving Kristol, Walter Goodman made the error of implying that ''liberal Jewish attitudes on economic matters'' are a relatively recent phenomenon (''Irving Kristol: Patron Saint of the New Right,'' Dec. 6). He describes ''a Jewish conservatism, centered on family and on law'' as being more ancient and therefore more authentic.

title: No Headline
description: Referring to ''Assessments Muddled Despite New Law'' - some statements require correction: The Hellerstein decision in Islip, which brought revaluation at full value, was not a constitutional matter, but merely a literal reading of a law dating back to Revolutionary times, and the decision intimated ''enforce the law or repeal it.'' The Grumman rebate of property taxes was $8.4 million, rather than $4 million. Experience always being the best teacher, might I suggest that driving to Islip and viewing the areas of prevalent foreclosures (noting also that they appear like mushrooms here and there) would allow one to feel the tragedy of people who lost their homes. Had those who remained and whose taxes doubled and tripled under full value been interviewed, the article might have dealt with the actual human problems involved; had that elusive ''equity'' been looked for, one would have found no more equity under full value than under the prior system.

title: Dance View; THE JOFFREY II GETS OUT OF THE STUDIO
description: The question of how dancers become dancers is always a tantalizing one to laymen and outsiders -many of whom do not realize the decade it does indeed take to form a dancer from childhood. This is especially true in ballet - modern dancers can begin their study of technique at a later age. On the other hand, changing times may now be altering the insider's traditional image of the very young dancer who remains the perpetual student. Memoirs such as those by the Russian ballerina Tamara Karsavina have always suggested the passage from the classroom to professional dancing to be only one of degree. As full members of a state company, dancers like Karsavina continued to rehearse and take class day in and day out in the very studios in which they had grown up and been hermetically enclosed since childhood. The formative and early professional years of young dancers no wadays tend to be quite, even brutally, different. These thoughts ca me to mind the other day after two recent and contrasting viewing ex periences. One involved the appearance of the Joffrey II Dancers at Brooklyn College's Whitman Hall. The other was the first American br oadcast on WNET/Channel 13 of ''Dancing Bournonville,'' a Danish fi lm about the legacy of August Bournonville - his ballets and his tr aining - as handed down to young dancers at the Royal Danish Balletin Copenhagen.

title: Investing; THE PERILS IN TENDERING YOUR STOCK
description: S OME 30 years ago, when he was 51 years old, Bert Luckenbach, now a retired real estate broker from Allentown, Pa., bought 25 shares of Conoco. By last year, after other purchases, stock splits and the reinvestment of his dividends, Mr. Luckenbach and his wife, Clara, had 412 shares.

title:
The Lively Arts;
SOCIAL CHANGE SET TO MUSIC
description: USING songs and dramatic narrative, an actress, a folk singer and a college history professor have fashioned ''Good Times ... Bad Times,'' an entertainment that will play the East Meadow Public Library on Friday evening. But there are entertainments and there are entertainments; and this one, devised by Shirley Blanc Romaine, David Sear and Michael D'Innocenzo, is after more than just a smile and a tear. It is a social-historical tract that demands some thought.

title: The Nation; Reagan Takes the Blame, and Heat As Well
description: If the Reagan Administration is to be graded the way the President himself last week proposed - ''not by our mistakes but how well we recover and solve the situation'' - then on the matter of tax exemptions for private schools that discriminate on the basis of race the White House may need to hit the books a little harder.

title: UNION'S FORD AND G.M. COUNCILS VOTE TO RENEW TALKS ON PAY CONCESSIONS
description: Negotiators for the United Automobile Workers voted today to resume emergency contract talks with the General Motors Corporation and Ford Motor Company on wage and benefit concessions sought by the companies.

title: Gallery View; CELEBRATING THE AGE OF ORNAMENT
description: The most provocative show now to be seen at the Metropolitan Museum, though not the one most heavily attended, is ''Renaissance Ornament: Prints and Drawings.'' It is provocative because it suggests that, in just about every department of design, the world has been going downhill since the middle of the 16th century. Its title might suggest that it is an affair for specialists. The prints, drawings and books in question have almost no color - one or two German fashion designs alone contradict this - and they call for close and careful looking of a kind that leaves the conscientious visitor dazed and exhausted. (There are close to 200 of them, by the way.)

title: CANADA IN WINTER
description: To the Editor:

title: Albert Dishner, Engineer, Fiance of Linda Rosenberg
description: Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Rosenberg of Jericho, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Linda Rosenberg, to Albert Dishner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Julius Dishner of South Fallsburgh, N.Y.

title: HOW TO SAVE AN AGING PRODUCT
description: ''P ROMISE her anything,'' the ads used to say, ''but give her Arpege.'' It was a memorable message, but it had lost some of its appeal, especially to younger women. So a few months ago, Lanvin's Arpege introduced a new two-page ad.

title: Suspect Held in Miami In Stabbing After Call
description: The police today arrested a man who they said fatally stabbed a stranger 30 minutes after phoning a crisis center Friday and saying he was going to kill himself or someone else.

title: Children's Books
description: THE UGLY PRINCESS By Nancy Luenn. Illustrated by David Wiesner. 28 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Co. $6.95. (Ages 8 to 10) By MARJORIE N.ALLEN

title: Children's Books
description: SARA CREWE Or What Happened at Miss Minchin's. By Frances Hodgson Burnett. Illustrated by Margot Tomes. 79 pp. New York: G.P. Putnam's Sons. $9.95. (Ages 8 to 11) By ARLENE M.PILLAR

title: The Week in Business; CONSUMER PRICES RISE, BUT NOT BY MUCH
description: Consumer prices rose just four-tenths of a percent in December, the Labor Department reported. For the year, they were up only 8.9 percent, the lowest annual increase since 1977. The December increase translates to a compound annual rate of 5.2 percent.

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER: IN CASE OF ACCIDENT
description: S kiing is supposed to provide thrills and pleasure, and it usually does. It also involves risks, however, and when skiing far from home, it is wise to have insurance and other protection to cover them.

title: REMEMBERING RED SMITH
description: To the Editor:

title: IN MARTINIQUE: CREOLE CUISINE WITH FLAIR
description: CRAIG CLAIBORNE is the food editor of The New York Times. By CRAIG CLAIBORNE

title: Art; 'INNER VISION: ABSTRACT IMAGES' IN PLAINFIELD
description: PLAINFIELD IN THE words of one resident, Plainfield ''was once a haven for millionaires'' and, until a riot in the late 60's ''was very much the place to come from.''

title: Topics; EFFICIENCIES; All in a Day's Robot
description: The word ''robot'' was coined by a Czechoslovak writer, Karel Capek, in a 1921 play called ''R.U.R.,'' short for ''Rossum's Universal Robots.'' The catchy word was derived from ''robota,'' meaning labor or servitude.

title: KANDINSKY'S LINK TO CRAFTS
description: At the turn of the century Munich's art world was in ferment. Artists, designers and architects, inspired by the ideals of the Arts and Crafts Movement as put forth a half century earlier by William Morris, embraced the applied arts with messianic fervor. And, over the next few decades, the outpouring of graphics, posters, objects, furniture, embroideries and accessories in Jugendstil, Germany's version of Art Nouveau, or the ''style of youth,'' was astounding.

title: To Mrs. Kirkpatrick, The Crisis in Poland Is Not a NATO Issue
description: Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the United States delegate to the United Nations, said today that Western European nations did not have an obligation to coordinate their responses to the events in Poland.

title: Ideas and Trends; Let Us Reason Together on Workers' Safety
description: The Reagan Administration, which is big on voluntarism to patch up the social ''safety net,'' last week brought its philosophy to the workplace. The Labor Department proposed that many functions of the Occupational Safety and Health Administration be replaced by voluntary worker-management arrangements.

title: January 24, 1982
description: NONFICTION THE AUSCHWITZ ALBUM: A Book Based Upon an Album Discovered by a Concentration Camp Survivor, Lili Meier. Text by Peter Hellman. 8 DEATH MARCH: The Survivors of Bataan. By Donald Knox. 14 GUERILLA: Colonel Von Lettow-Vorbeck and Germany's East African Empire. By Edwin P. Hoyt. 16 HERO OF BATAAN: The Story of General Jonathan M. Wainwright. By Duane Schultz. 14 THE HOLOCAUST AND THE HISTORIANS. By Lucy S. Dawidowicz. 8 OUTCAST CAPE TOWN. By John Western. 9 THE PLACE OF POETRY: Two Centuries of an Art in Crisis. By Christopher Clausen. 10 THE REALISTIC IMAGINATION: English Fiction From Frankenstein to Lady Chatterley. By George Levine. 10 SLAVERY AND FREEDOM. By Willie Lee Rose. 8 WITNESS TO POWER: The Nixon Years. By Joh n Ehrlichman. 1 FICTION THE APOCALYPSE BRIGADE. By Alfred Coppel. 12 BIG BEAR, LITTLE BEAR. By David Brierley. 12 DOUBLE CROSS. By Michael Barak. 34 THE KGB DIRECTIVE. By Richard Cox. 12 MARCO POLO, IF YOU CAN. By William F. Buckley Jr. 12 MEMORY BOY. By Victor Canning. 12 THE OTHER SIDE OF SILENCE. By Ted Allbeury. 34 THE ROYAL GAME & OTHER STORIES. By Stefan Zweig. 7 SITUATION TRAGEDY. By Simon Brett. 34 THE VOICES OF THE DEAD. By Autran Dourado. 13 THE WEDDING GUEST.

title: Realty News; EAST 54TH STREET BUILDING SOLD FOR $42 MILLION TO CONVERTER
description: The Brevard, a 30-story apartment building that just six years ago stood unfinished and unrented, has been sold for $42.1 million to a group headed by a Chicago condominium converter.

title: Essay; POLY WANTS A LEAKER
description: The muffled voice on the phone told me to be in a bar near the White House in a half hour, if I wanted a message from ''the halls of Montezuma.'' Since I know no family by the name of Hall in Mexico, I took that to be a veiled reference to ''the shores of Tripoli,'' suggesting a leak from intelligence sources about Libya. I grabbed the latest clippings about dictator Qaddafi, put on my galoshes (which really leak) and mushed across Farragut Square to my rendezvous.

title: 49ERS ON OFFENSE
description: Receivers No. 86 Charle Young TE 6 feet 4 inches 234 pounds 9th season, U.S.C. A possession-type receiver seldom used as a deep threat. 88 Freddie Solomon WR 5-11 185 7 Tampa. Despite knee injury, he can run deep patterns skillfully and requires double coverage. On occasion, he will take the snap from center and run or pass. 87 Dwight Clark WR 6-4 210 3 Clemson. Perfect target for Montana's short passing game. His catch in the last minute beat the Cowboys. Others: 80 Eason Ramson; 84 Mike Shumann; 85 Mike Wilson. Offensive Line 61 Dan Audick LT 6-3 253 4 Hawaii. A former guard who filled a gap. 68 John Ayers LG 6-5 260 5 West Texas State. An effective pass blocker, who has played every position on the line. 56 Fred Quillan C 6-5 260 4 Oregon. Because Quillan is so big, so smart and Montana so quick, defenses seldom dare to blitz the 49ers. He has started 57 consecutive games. 51 Randy Cross RG 6-3 250 6 U.C.L.A. A Pro Bowl starter and the club's best offensive lineman. 71 Keith Fahnhorst RT 6-6 263 8 Minnesota. Tenacious, determined; offensive captain. He was a tight end in college and moved to tackle as a rookie. Others: 60 John Choma; 62 Walt Downing; 66 Allan Kennedy. Offensive Backfield 16 Joe Montana QB 6-2 200 3 Notre Dame. Chosen as a Pro Bowl starter in his second season as a regular. 32 Ricky Patton HB 5-11 192 4 Jackson State.

title:
Stamps;
 UNITED STATES LISTS ITS 1982 COMMEMORATIVES
description: Two of the nation's greatest Presidents are being honored in the vanguard of this year's commemorative issues, which are beginning to move along now that the rush to provide adequate supplies of stamps for the new higher rates has subsided.

title: Jill Beth Weiss Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Martin L. Weiss of West Orange, N.J., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Jill Beth Weiss, to Paul Scott Jacobs, son of Mrs. Jean Jacobs of Brooklyn and the late Mr. Jacobs.

title: Miss Broadus Is Betrothed; June Bridal
description: The engagement of Anne Elizabeth Broadus to Hunter Holding Jr. has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Carlisle Broadus of New York, parents of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Mrs. Holding of Larchmont, N.Y., and the late Mr. Holding.

title: SECRET F.D.R. RECORDINGS ADD UP TO LESS THAN 'DIRTY TRICKS'
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: Despite the dedicated and persistent efforts of my mother, grandmother, aunts and even a couple of uncles, I never quite mastered the intricacies of ethnic needlework and cookery which would have earned me the coveted Greek appellative ikokira (''keeper of the house''). The fact that I flunked long ago convinced me that skilled homemakers, not unlike artists and athletes, are born, not made. MARY MICHAELIDES, Keene, N.H.

title: 30-YEAR POLISH PARTY VETERAN JOINS THOUSANDS IN QUITTING
description: The letter began ''Comrade Secretary'' and it got right to the point. ''I hereby return my party card,'' wrote Tadeusz Lomnicki, one of Poland's foremost actors, who for 30 years had been a member of the Polish Communist Party, rising in 1975 to membership in the Central Committee. ''This must be a shock to it - I cannot deny that - but I cannot do anything else. ''

title: 2 Magic Words ('I Do') End Curse on a Justice
description: Nineteen years ago, Burton B. Roberts, then an assistant district attorney in Manhattan, was placed under a curse by a self-styled gypsy whom he had prosecuted in a swindle: No woman would ever fall in love with him.

title: Follow-Up on the News; On Child Abuse
description: The news item was dated Dec. 25, 1980, and it said the Federal Department of Health and Human Services had granted $1.4 million for projects to combat the sexual abuse of children by family members and others. The National Center on Child Abuse and Neglect was to distribute the money.

title:
Antiques;
FAMILY OF CLOCKMAKERS
description: ''LIKE father, like son'' - the old saying is seldom better exemplified than in the careers of 18th-century Connecticut craftsmen such as the Averys, a family of clockmakers who worked in the Norwich area in the generations preceding and following the American Revolutionary War.

title: Radio More Efficient Than TV in Campaigns
description: I am writing in response to an article written by Dick Davies ('' '82 Candidates Run on Expert Advice,'' Jan. 3). Mr. Davies mentions the dollars expected to be spent on television by Connecticut political hopefuls during 1982. While I agree that television stations will have their wallets fattened by political spending, Mr. Davies was remiss when he failed to mention radio and newspapers.

title: SAVORING NAPLES: AN INSIDERS GUIDE
description: V isitors to Naples may seek practical assi stance at either of two central information offices: Ente Provinciale del Turismo, Via Partenope 10A (telephone: 418988); and C.I.T. , Piazza Municipio (tel:325426). Bus, train and funicular routes, and timetables of steamers and hydrofoils to the nearby islands, are ava ilable from major hotelsas well as the tourist bureaus. Security

title: Environews
description: THE Somerset County Environmental Education Center in Basking Ridge will open the state's first environmental nursery school next month, using Montessori techniques to teach environmental subjects.

title: Critics' Choices
description: ROCK/BLUES Judging a band on the basis of one single record isn't always wise, but the first single by R.E.M., a pop-rock quartet from Georgi a, has knocked the socks off of just about everyone who's heard it. The two songs on the record, ''Radio Free Europe'' an d ''Sitting Still,'' combine the chiming guitar lyricism of mid-60 's bands like The Byrds and the fondly remembered Beau Brummels with a contemporary intensity. Listeners who have heard the band in person report that it's even better than the single (which is on the supremely obscure Hib-Tone label). On Saturday night, R.E.M. wi ll be at Maxwell's, the comfortably informal rock club at 1039 Washin gton Street in Hoboken, N.J.

title: Long Island Journal
description: THE trustees of the Museums at Stony Brook and the Stony Brook Community Fund, a charitable trust, will be hosts of a gala on Feb. 6 to celebrate the 88th birthday of Dorothy Melville, president of the two institutions. Through the endeavors of Mrs. Melville and those of her late husband, Ward Melville, an industrialist, most of the bucolic and historic character of the Three Village area - Stony Brook, Setauket and Old Field - is preserved today.

title: DISCOVERIES IN THE MIDDLE OF IT ALL
description: PERHAPS it's the season, with all its physical characteristics: the bare, stark trees, the last few wind-driven leaves still skittering across the now empty streets; the early nightfall, the icy inevitably of winter. Flights of literary fancy aside, and whatever else the cause may be, one thing is certain: the arrival of my 45th year is a disquieting and somewhat melancholy event.

title: CORRECTION
description: All performances of ''Shalom '82,'' a musical event scheduled at the Felt Forum and included in the Spectacles listing in The Guide today, have been canceled.

title: Critics' Choices
description: ART One of the more interesting things about other people's works of art is how much they paid for them. It is rude to ask, of course, and quite possibly they would say that it was none of our business, but it's fascinating all the same.

title: WASHINGTON HAS COME FULL CIRCLE ON DETENTE
description: WASHINGTON EXACTLY one year after Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. launched the Reagan Administration's contacts with the Soviet Union by sending a note to Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko warning the Russians to stay out of Poland, American policy toward Moscow seems to have returned to where it started. As Mr. Haig flies to Geneva to meet with Mr. Gromyko on Tuesday, Poland's own crackdown has punctured recent expectations that, after two years of chill in Soviet-American relations, some warming trends were on the h orizon. ''We have got a decent dialogue going, which offers some b asis for optimism that perhaps, in the months ahead, we'll make pr ogress, but we have to be prepared for the opposite,'' Mr. Haig had confided on Nov. 20, emphasizing the positive. The Secretary had had two days of talks with Mr. Gromyko at the United Nations in Se ptember that he found free of polemics. And President Reagan, at Mr . Haig's urging, had delivered a major speech on arms control that was free of such anti-Soviet invective as his remark, inhis first new s conference, that Moscow was prepared ''to commit any crime'' to sp read communism.

title: 268.8 Million in Soviet
description: The Central Statistical Administration said today that the population of the Soviet Union on Jan. 1 was 268.8 million, an increase of 2.2 million from the beginning of last year.

title: LENNIE TRISTANO- A NEGLECTED JAZZMAN
description: Historians of modern jazz have been curiously and almost unanimously parsimonious in their appraisals of Lennie Tristano, the pianist, composer, bandleader, theoretician, teacher, and recluse. When Mr. Tristano died of a heart attack at his home in Queens on Nov. 18, 1978, only one album of his work was in print, and it was on a Japanese label. Most critical accounts of the development of modern jazz in the 1940's and 1950's treated him as an interesting but minor footnote, more impressive as the mentor of first-rate improvisers l ike Lee Konitz and Warne Marsh than as a musician in hisown right. The reasons for Mr. Tristano's exclusion fr om so many jazz critics' pantheons are almost as interesting as the pianist's longneglected music. He has been taken to tas k for emphasizing melodic counterpoint and difficult, altered h armonies while bullying his drummers into functioning as self-effacin g human metronomes. The Dutch critic Martin Schouten has called the s ound of the pianist's bands ''pale'' and ''characterless'' and conc luded that Mr. Tristano's recordings betrayed a ''lack of fe eling for the role of 'sound' in jazz.''

title: SECURITY AND SCIENCE COLLIDE ON DATA FLOW
description: The exchange of ideas between nations is not easily controlled through export fees and licenses. So, while the Reagan Administration is raising the alarm over the flow of America's advanced scientific information to the Soviet Union, it is not clear how the Administration can stop it, or that it merits stopping. Indeed, many American scientists consider attempts to curb scientific interchange unpardonable, and dangerous, censorship.

title: Exception Taken To ' Glassworks' Review
description: It is indeed a privilege for me to be one of the exhibiting artists of ''Glassworks,'' the first major showing of contemporary art glass on Long Island at the St. James Mills Pond House. But the review, ''What One Can and Can't Do With Glass'' (Dec. 20), is both incomplete and misleading.

title: SUCCESS IS IN SWING FOR YOUTH HOCKEY
description: year-old Kyle Tucker, a third-grade student at the Midland School here, had a twofold reason for writing to his grandmother the other day.

title: Too Few Democrats On Budget Committee
description: The Jan. 10 Westchester Journal item about the unbalanced representation Democrats were given on the committees in the County Board of Legislators indicates that there is a strong need to reform the committee appointment processes in the Legislature.

title: RAIN MAKES NEW YORK SLUSH CITY
description: Under skies of oyster gray that wept snow, sleet and rain on the whole of a dull and dreary January day, the New York metropolitan area was the scene yesterday of swirling mists and solitary strollers, of churning slush and curbside lakes and of icy roads and flooded, nearly deserted streets.

title: 25 TAKE LIE TESTS AS PENTAGON SEEKS DISCLOSURE SOURCE
description: The Defense Department has given lie-detector tests to about 25 senior officials in an unsuccessful effort to find the source of an unauthorized disclosure of confidential information, according to Pentagon officials.

title: Other Business; TRADE: IT'S THE SAME OLD TUNE...
description: Over the years, as the United States and Japan have talked about Tokyo's burgeoning trade surplus, their comments have taken on a pattern as predictable as that of the ritual tea ceremony.

title: Business Conditions; MERGER FEVER UNABATED
description: As Marathon Oil recently discovered, high interest rates, weak demand and sagging stock prices can make even the strongest company ripe for takeover. Last year, those conditions helped send corporate mergers up 27 percent from 1980 levels.

title:
Dining Out;
SHARING SLAVIC CUISINE AND CULTURE
description: THE rather sober name of the restaurant, Wallington Exchange, gives no indication of the smashing entertainment and convivial brio throbbing within its unpretentious walls. Converted from a pizza parlor about 18 months ago, the Wallington Exchange has a large, comfortable interior in which customers, many of them first- or second-generation Mittel Europeans, relax into the spirit of the old country.

title: No Headline
description: This Week:

title:
Gardening;
BIRCH SPECIES THAT OFFER DIVERSITY
description: LAST week we discussed birches in the landscape and enumerated their problems and weaknesses. Although attractive and useful, their inability to adapt to hot, dry summers and their susceptibility to leaf miner and bronze-headed birch borer shorten their lifespan and limit their value.

title: MORAL MAJORITY GAINS IN POLL ON RECOGNITION
description: According to a Gallup poll, public awareness of Moral Majority has risen in the last year from 40 percent to 55 percent, but the public still holds an unfavorable view of the fundamentalist movement by a ratio of more than 2 to 1.

title: Wasting Time
description: All day long, in game arcades and in front of the living room TV, millions of children fire off laser cannon till their trigger thumbs grow numb. Some play Defenders, Spa ce Fury, Pac-Man and similar electronic ga mes for hours on end. Time magazine estimates that in 1981, arcade players alone used up 75,000 man-years and 20 billion quarters. But their intensity is nothing compared with the mounting opposition. M oralists are on the march.

title: Sportmen's Equipment On Display at L.I. Show
description: The latest fishing, hunting, boating and camping equipment will be on view at the New York National Sportsmen's Expo Wednesday through next Sunday at Nassau Coliseum.

title: Mancini Stops Valdez In 10th and Keeps Title
description: Ray (Boom Boom) Mancini used two right hooks to stop Julio (Diablito) Valdez at 59 seconds of the 10th round in their scheduled 12-round lightweight bout today and retained his North American Boxing Federation title.

title: Around the World; Pope's February Trip Sets 5 Days in Nigeria
description: Pope John Paul II will spend five days in Nigeria during his weeklong four-nation tour of Africa starting Feb. 12, the Vatican announced today.

title: A CASE FOR BACKING CINCINNATI- AND FOR ICE FISHING
description: ON a flight from Syracuse to Los Angeles, the pilot came on the air and said that if we looked off to our left we could see Cincinnati. One guy actually stood up in the aisle, leaned over my lap and looked down on Cincinnati, which is not at all hard to do. His face, it is my solemn duty to report, registered dismay. Invited to do so, some folks will of course look at anything, in the same way that some folks, uninvited, will look through other folks' bedroom windows.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN HOUSTON
description: There is one spot on the west side of Houston where the sheer sweep and energy of the country's fastest growing metropolis hits the eye as a breathtaking vista in which at least three major, identifiable clusters of glistening new skyscrapers boldly jut up out of a thick carpet of green. It's the overpass where the West Loop, part of the circumferential freeway that encloses the central sections of town, crosses the Southwest Freeway.

title: KNICKS LOSE ON OVERTIME SHOT AT BUZZER
description: Reggie Theus made a 20-foot bank shot at the buzzer in overtime last night to give the Chicago Bulls a 140-139 victory over the Knicks at Madison Square Garden. The basket by Theus hit the glass, bounced to the rim and spun around before going through the hoop for his season-high 35th and 36th points of the game.

title: U.  S . SAYS PAKISTAN'S NUCLEAR POTENTIAL IS GROWING
description: An intelligence report has concluded that Pakistan will be able to detonate a nuclear device within the next three years, but is not likely to do so, according to Administration and Congressional officials.

title: OUTCAST CAPE TOWN By John Western.  Illustrated. 372 pp. Minneapolis: University of Minnesota Press. $22.50.
description: TO those who believe that apartheid is a fixed system of outmoded practices and beliefs, South Africa's policies appear not only unjust but irrational, for they seem to be hastening a racial catastrophe that is already two or three decades overdue by the world's reckoning. If there is a reform movement slowly gathering momentum, as optimists maintain, and if that catastrope is not inevitable, it is natural to wonder why the South African authorities squander the little time left for change. For example, Kenneth Adelman, a member of the United States Mission to the United Nations, recently told the General Assembly that it ''remains a mystery'' why the governing party of South Africa clings to the cruel and discredited ideology and practices that have kept it in power for 33 years.

title: No Headline
description: Illinois Stops Minnesota, 64-57

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: Connecticut Housing; HUDDLING CONCEPT OF PAST REVIVED
description: WHEN central heating first came along toward the end of the 19th century, it seemed that living patterns would never be quite the same. Instead of huddling around an open hearth, keeping doors tightly shut between rooms or even going to bed with a nightcap (the knitted kind, of course), people reveled in a newfound freedom.

title: SATURN STUDY INDICATES RINGS HAVE FEW GAPS
description: When Voyager 1 flew by Saturn in November 1980, the spacecraft discovered what appeared to be hundreds of gaps in the planet's major rings, which seemed to be composed of countless ringlets. Voyager 2, in August 1981, detected the same phenomenon, but scientists who have analyzed the data now report that nearly all of Saturn's ringlets are more apparent than real.

title: Martha Willoughby Is Wed
description: Martha Willoughby, daughter of Lieut. Col. Charles Willoughby, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Willoughby of Greenville, S.C., was married in the chapel at the Church Center for the United Nations yesterday to the Rev. Dr. Melvin A. Hawthorne, director of chapel activities at the center and the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Hawthorne of Alexandria, La.

title: W. R. Evans 3d to Wed Ashton Applewhite
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Edgar J. Applewhite of Washington of the engagement of their daughter, Ashton Applewhite, to William R. Evans 3d, son of Eliot Yehle Marshall of Haddonfield, N.J., and Mr. Evans Jr. of New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: No Headline
description: NORTH CAROLINA BEATS GEORGIA TECH BY 66-54

title: LOCAL PARTY REBUFFS SCHMIDT OVER ARMS
description: Chancellor Helmut Schmidt and Defense Minister Hans Apel received a symbolic political slap today when their local Social Democratic Party organization, against the leaders' objections, voted for a motion favoring establishment of a nuclear weapons-free zone in Europe.

title: Ideas and Trends; New Ribbons for Food Packaging
description: In more ways than one, food packaging for American consumers is currently a fluid market; new sterilization technologies are replacing the old bottles, cans and cartons. The latest technique, called asceptic packaging, confers a long refrigeration-free shelf life on perishable foods.

title: Television Week
description: All-Star Cast Several programs this week will salute the 100th anniversary of Franklin @D. Roosevelt's birth, and one of them will offer a television first: four living American Presidents interviewed on a single program. On ABC's ''F.D.R.,'' to be broadcast Friday from 8 to 11 P.M., President Ronald Reagan and former Presidents Jimmy Carter, Gerald Ford and Richard Nixon will express opinions of their White House predecessor.

title: Chess; YUGOSLAVS TRIUMPH IN ZONAL TOURNAMENT
description: That the Mediterranean is a Yugoslav lake was once again proved by the results of the International Chess Federation's Zone 11 Tournament in Becici, Yugoslavia, one sector of the worldwide first stage of qualifications to determine a challenger for the world championship in 1984.

title: The Region; What Work? What Pension?
description: Still waters run deep, but in the case of Representative Frederick W. Richmond, the water is rising and beginning to make waves, even though Mr. Richmond kept his silence. Amid mounting questions about the Brooklyn Democrat's public and corporate activities, State Supreme Court Judge Martin B. Stecher ruled last week that a $1 million ''pension'' voted to Mr. Richmond by the Walco National Corporation constituted an illegal gift of corporate assets.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Clement Janequin, French Vocal Group
description: Groups specializing in old music have been the province of the English, Dutch, Germans and Americans in recent years. But the Clement Janequin Vocal Ensemble, presented in its New York debut Thursday night at Carnegie Recital Hall as part of a French Government series, deserves consideration along with the best such groups from other countries.

title: A VISIT TO THE REAL 'BRIDESHEAD'
description: STEVEN RATTNER is a New York Times correspondent in London. By STEVEN RATTNER ''B rideshead Revisited,'' the television a daptation of the Evelyn Waugh novel now running on more than 250 Publ ic Broadcasting Service stations, is fiction, but the setting for the bulk of the 11-part series is no stage set. For television purpos es, Brideshead is an early 18th-century English stately home calle d Castle Howard, which sits majestically above a 10,000-acre estate near Coneysthorpe 15 miles northeast of York.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Ties to Kiribati
description: Perhaps you have heard of Kiribati? On Aug. 11, 1980, the State Department announced that the United States had established diplomatic relations with this new nation, part of the Gilbert Islands in the South Pacific. The announcement said that ambassadors would be exch anged.

title: Nonfiction in Brief
description: HERO OF BATAAN The Story of General Jonathan M. Wainwright. By Duane Schultz. Illustrated. 479 pp. New York: St. Martin's Press. $19.95.

title: Sally A. Haas Fiancee Of Jonathan R. Colbert
description: Mr. and Mrs. George Charles Haas Jr. of Lake Worth, Fla., and New York, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sally Anne Haas, to Jonathan Ross Colbert, son of Mr. and Mrs. Roger Edward Colbert of Woodstock, Vt.

title: UConn U psets Vi llanova
description: Karl Hobbs, a 5-foot-8-inch guard, ran around all the big men to tip in a rebound with one second to go and give Connecticut a 53-51 victory over Villanova in a Big East Conference game tonight.

title: SECRET F.D.R. RECORDINGS ADD UP TO LESS THAN 'DIRTY TRICKS'
description: To the Editor:

title: STUDENTS TO CHECK BLOOD PRESSURE AND EFFICIENCY
description: NEXT fall, about 1,000 sixth-grade students from central Connecticut will begin monitoring their blood pressure and how well they perform at different times in the school day in a research project of the Talcott Mountain Science Center in Avon.

title: Denise Kearns to Be Bride Of Frederick C. Witsell 3d
description: Mr. and Mrs. Leo J. Kearns of South Weymouth and Manomet, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Denise Lee Kearns, to Frederick C. Witsell 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Witsell Jr. of Locust Valley, L.I.

title: Foreigners' Art Barred From U.S. Campaigns
description: The Federal Election Commission voted 5-1 Thursday to ban artists who are foreign nationals from giving their works to political campaigns for Federal office.

title: Canadian Aide Visits Kuwait
description: The Canadian Minister of Energy, Marc Lalonde, arrived here today for talks with Government officials on energy issues and ways to promote relations, the Kuwaiti press agency said.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; John Anderson, Oboist With BBC Symphony
description: Oboe playing of high quality was heard Tuesday at Carnegie Recital Hall when John Anderson made his New York debut in a Concert Artists Guild Award Concert. Mr. Anderson, who is from England, has been principal oboist of the BBC Symphony Orchestra since 1979. His piano accompanist, Richard Nunn, is also English and teaches at the Royal College of Music.

title: 'JINGLE BELLS'
description: To the Editor:

title: Susan Jaffe Is Fiancee Of H.B. Scho enberger
description: Mr. and Mrs. Rudolph M. Jaffe of West Orange, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Carol Jaffe, to Howard Barton Schoenberger, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur M. Schoenberger of East Hills, L.I. A summer wedding is planned.

title: ON ENTERPRISE ZONES,
description: INITIATIVE By RICHARD L. MADDEN

title:
Economic Affairs;
THE PRESIDENT GETS A GENTLEMAN'S C
description: W E have now had one year to assess the economics of the Reagan Administration, and it is time for its first report card. The new Administration a year ago faced an economy that had undergone a severe series of shocks and was performing very poorly. The period from 1973 to 1981 had seen a deterioration in all of the major indexes of economic performance from the period 1960-73.

title: UCONN OPENS BETWEEN ROUNDS OF BUDGET BATTLE
description: SECOND semester will dawn tomorrow at the University of Connecticut in Storrs with some budget cuts just completed and further financial wrangling with the General Assembly looming next month.

title: The Nation; Austin Would Rather Not
description: Rejecting what they evidently regarded as a dubious distinction, voters in Austin, Tex. last week defeated a p roposal that would have made the university town the first city in th e country to legalize housing discrimination based on sexual orient ation. In a high turnoutfollowing a nasty campaign, the vote was 36,2 39 to 20,997.

title: JAMAICA GETAWAY, SHORT AND
description: SWEET DENA KLEIMAN is a reporter for The Times. By DENA KLEIMAN

title: SURGE BY ISLANDERS BEATS RANGERS, 6-1
description: Who owns New York? There was little doubt among the hockey fans at Nassau Coliseum tonight as the Islanders routed the Rangers, 6-1, with a four-goal second period and took sole posession of first place in the Patrick Division. The Islanders moved a point ahead of the Ph iladelphia Flyers, who tied tonight with the Pittsburgh Penguins, an d 12 ahead of the Rangers. The Rangers and the Penguins are tie d for third place in thestanding.

title: BENGALS ON OFFENCS
description: Receivers No. 89 Dan Ro ss TE 6 feet 4 inches 235 pounds 3d season Northeastern.Team's leadin g receiver with 86 receptions in 18 games. 49ers cannot overlook him. 85 Isaac Curt is WR 6-1 192 9 San Diego State. Has all the m oves; knows all the tricks. Benefitted by addition of Collinsworth and was injury free. 80 Cris Colli nsworth WR 6-5 192 R Florida. Has caught 71 passes, nine for touchdowns, in 18 games and chosen forPro Bowl in r ookie season. Others: 81 Da vid Verser; 83 M.L. Harris; 84 Don Bass; 86 Steve Kreider; 87 P at McInally. He was voted N.F.L. offensive lin eman of the year. 62 Dave Lapha m LG 6-4 262 8 Syracuse. Seventh seaso n as a starter, fine run blocker. 58 Blair Bush C 6-3 252 4 Washington.
