Strongest offensive lineman; 3d season as starter; he swit ched from left side when Munoz joined the team. Others: 60 Blake Moore; 68 Mike Obrovac.

title: LAYOFFS ARE JUST ONE U.A.W. PROBLEM
description: Earlier this month, the United Auto Workers and the nation's two largest automobile manufacturers began an extraordinary round of contract talks. Before negotiations were suspended last week, the union demonstrated that even on the defensive, it could muster some of its old originality.

title: THE WINTER SHORE: ANOTHER WORLD
description: SURF CITY THE traffic lights on Ocean Boulevard, the main thoroughfare of this Long Beach Island resort community, have been turned off. Most of the shops are closed and, near the beach, only the sound of the wind blowing against empty bungalows competes with the rhythmic pounding of the surf.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: A RUN-ON SESSION
description: HARTFORD THE House a nd Senate had met late into the night, hoping to finish the business of a special session. But instead, they got into a disagreement over budget cuts that made it all but certain that they would be in H artford at least another week.

title: Paperback Talk
description: Belles-lettres. ''Our most endangered species.'' Such is the anxious way in which many bookpeople now refer to serious fiction. With production and distribution costs making it necessary to charge from $13 to $15 for a ''blockbuster'' hardcover novel, it has become very difficult to make ends meet when publishing a quiet, stylish work.

title: The Nation; Breathtaking - And Tragic
description: They were practicing a familiar maneuver that rarely fails to thrill a crowd. But something went wrong last week, and four experienced Air Force stunt-fliers soared sky high, dived rapidly toward earth, and then, maintaining their tight wingtip-to-wingtip formation, flew their jets straight into the Nevada desert.

title: No Headline
description: Mavericks Win Third Straight, Set Mark

title: 'Jingle Bells'
description: To the Editor:

title: Connecticut Guide; LECTURES ON ISLAM
description: A series of eight weekly lectures dealing with specific aspects of Moslem culture will begin at 7:30 P.M. Thursday at the Hartford Seminary, 77 Sherman Street. Supported by a grant from the Connecticut Humanities Council, the talks are open free to the public. They represent an effort ''to create better understanding of the Moslem world,'' according to Dr. Byron L. Haines, chairman of a study group on Chr istian-Moslem Relations of the National Council of Churches.

title: Politics; CANDIDATES DIVIDED ON SPENDING LIMITS
description: HARTFORD IT may not get very far, but an effort to try to set voluntary limits on the high cost of campaigning has emerged as one of the first issues in the race for the United States Senate in Connecticut this year.

title: GARBAGE CONVERSION MOVES STEP CLOSER
description: PIECE by piece and week by week, the county assembles its ambitious plan to convert the household garbage of 35 communities into energy, even as the Board of Legislators continues to argue over the date for a referendum that would establish a major fiscal component of that plan.

title: A Booklist On Fly Fishing
description: MANY of us who have been hunting and fishing for 40 or 50 years aren't quite used to the recent spate of books devoted to our endeavors.

title: On Language; BEEFING UP PHRASES
description: KIMBLE MEAD

title: Topics; Efficiencies; Many Mansions
description: A friend of ours, bent on making a mountain out of the molehill in which she lives, always refers to the straw mat at her door as the ''mud room.'' A studio couch signals the ''bedroom,'' a tableful of books constitutes the ''library'' and the closet in which she keeps her tiny television set is the ''media center.''

title: POETRIES AND THEIR AUDIENCES
description: THE PLACE OF POETRY Two Centuries of an Art in Crisis. By Christopher Clausen. 145 pp. Lexington: The University Press of Kentucky. $12.50. By DENIS DONOGHUE

title: A NEW NUCLEAR STRATEGY
description: Laurence W. Beilenson is a historian and former adviser to President Reagan. Samuel T. Cohen is a nuclear scientist, known as the father of the neutron bomb. They collaborated on the writing of this article. By Laurence W. Beilenson and Samuel T. Cohen

title: Games, Races Are Called Off
description: Last night's scheduled Major Indoor Soccer League game between the Buffalo Stallions and the New York Arrows at Buffalo's Memorial Auditorium was postponed when neither team could reach the city because of the snow and rain that hit the Northeast. The Arrows were stranded in New York and the Stallions in Baltimore.

title: REGARDING WILDLIFE AND RIFLE ORGANIZATIONS
description: The National Wildlife Federation, which is the nation's largest citizens conservation organization, is not now and has never been affiliated with the National Rifle Association. It is one thing to give Miss Herrington space in The Times; it is something else to let her make a statement which she knows is factually inaccurate.

title: Susan E. Martin Is Engaged to Floyd M. Fishleigh
description: Dr. and Mrs. Anthony W. Martin of New Canaan, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Elizabeth Martin, to Floyd Mark Fishleigh of Denver, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry G. Fishleigh Jr. of Mentor, Ohio. An April wedding is planned.

title: About Books and Authors
description: A Composer of Symphonies THIRTY year s ago Ralph Ellison's ''Invisible Man,'' a novel about the struggles of a young black in contemporary America, was publishedto almost una nimous acclaim. It took only one ballot for jurors Saul Bellow, Marth a Foley, Irving Howe, Howard Mumford Jones and Alfred Kazin to vote it the 1953 National Book Award for the best novel of the previous year. On March 20 Random House will publish a special anniversary e dition of the book, which will include a lengthy new introduction by the author.

title: Martin Birnbaum Fiance Of Barbara A. Rosenthal
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jack Rosenthal of Searingtown, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Barbara Ann Rosenthal, to Martin Birnbaum, son of Mr. and Mrs. Oscar Birnbaum of Manhasset Hills, L.I.

title: By David Diamond
description: SURVIVOR:IU INTERNATIONAL

description: PATRICK MCDONNELL

title: Patco React
description: To the Business Editor: As a Captain with major airline I take exception to the uncomplimentary picture that Robert E. Poli painted of me and my fellow pilots in ''Why the Controllers' Strike Failed'' (Jan. 17).

title: SPIES AND MOLES AND OTHER ENTERTAINERS
description: THE KGB DIRECTIVE By Richard Cox. 336 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $13.95. BIG BEAR, LITTLE BEAR By David Brierley. 223 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $11.95. MEMORY BOY By Victor Canning. 177 pp. New York: William Morrow & Co. $10.95.

title: THE ASSISTANT'S REVENGE
description: WITNESS TO POWER The Nixon Years. By John Ehrlichman. Illustrated. 432 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $17.50.By ROBERT SHERRILL

title: Music View; THE COMPOSER AS MUSKETEER
description: Composers nowadays are a generally sane and domesticated lot. With few exceptions, the faces they present to the public are interchangeable with those of middle-level insurance executives or computer software salesmen. Why so? It cannot be only that composers have allied themselves so intimately with the business and academic worlds, through foundation commissions and faculty employment, that they think it wise to dress their minds and bodies in institutional gray. Something deeper is involved, something that separates the respected composer of our time from the more raffish and more colorful types who preceded him in history: our composers for the most part have never shown any desire to become celebrated public performers and do not have the virtuoso's volatile temperament.

title: COURT FAULTS SMITHVILLE PERMIT
description: THE crisply lettered Biblical quotation inscribed on the side of a barn in Galloway Township reads like a deed: ''The earth is the Lord's and the fullness thereof and they that dwell therein.''

title: Jobless Benefits Up in Week
description: The Labor Department reported Thursday that 4.7 million Americans were receiving unemployment insurance benefits and that 1 million more had filed new claims for such assistance. The department's Bureau of Labor Statistics said 4,688,000 people received benefits for the week ending Jan. 2, an increase of 613,200 over the previous week but 271,800 fewer than a year ago. In the week ending Jan. 9, there were 1,081,000 first claims for unemployment insurance, 382,000 more than the previous week and 230,400 more than a year ago.

title: FRANCE IS BUYING MORE RUSSIAN GAS DESPITE U.S. FEARS
description: France signed a major natural gas contract with the Soviet Union today despite objections by the Reagan Administration.

title: Lindsey Stansfield Betrothed
description: The engagement of Lindsey Mary Stansfield to Samuel Frazier Pryor 4th, son of Mr. and Mrs. Pryor 3d of Bedford Hills, N.Y., has been announced by her parents, Dr. and Mrs. John B. Stansfield of New York.

title: Around the Nation; Two Small Planes Collide And One Falls Into Town
description: Two small planes collided in midair today, and one pilot was killed when his aircraft crashed into this city's business district, officials said.

title: No Headline
description: LOUISVILLE'S HOME WINNING STREAK ENDS

title: SPEAK-EASIES FLOURISHING IN SOWETO
description: No neon signs blink outside Rowena's, which might be termed the 21 Club of Soweto, South Africa's largest black settlement.

title: Husband and Wife Business Partners
description: Arthur Levitt's article, ''In Praise of Small Business'' (Dec. 6), mentioned a number of husband-and-wife-operated businesses. This is an interesting side development of the growth of entrepreneurship.

title: Jane A. McKeever Will Be Married
description: Mr. and Mrs. Paul B. McKeever of New Canaan, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jane A. McKeever, to Kenneth Drury Toumey, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hugh J. Toumey, also of New Canaan. An August wedding is planned.

title: News Summary; News Summary; SUNDAY, JANUARY 24, 1982
description: Intern ational A French-Soviet natural gas contract was signed by France despite strong objections by the Reagan Administration, which fears that the agreement will make Western Europe too dependent on Soviet energy. The gas is to be carried in a 2,800-mile pipeline from western Siberia and extending into France, West Germany, Italy and several other Western European countries. (Page 1, Column 6.) A Soviet economic report for 1981 confirmed previous predictions of a generally poor year economically. Breaking with precedent, it omitted the size of last year's grain harvest, suggesting a figure so low as to be politically embarrassing. (1:5.)

title: Seton Hall and Iona Defeated At Garden
description: Seton Hall's immediate problem yesterday was how to deal with the Running Rebels of Nevada-Las Vegas without the use of three starters who had been ruled academically ineligible for the spring semester.

title: No Headline
description: MISS NAVRATILOVA MOVES UP

title: No Headline
description: Nordiques' Streak Stopped by Sabres

title: PADDING THE TIP
description: To the Editor:

title: 'FROM GLAMOUR TO GRIT'
description: WASHINGTON HOW thin is the ice President Reagan is skating on? That is the question being asked as he begins a second year in office anxious to continue cutting the influence of the Federal Government but to manage politics and economics in a way that avoids major manage politics and economics in a way that avoids major Republican losses in the 1982 elections.

title: Headliners; Sharing the Guilt
description: In a verdict decided on his 38th birthday, Jack Henry Abbott, who wrote a critically acclaimed book, ''In the Belly of the Beast,'' while serving time for robbery and the murder of a fellow inmate, was convicted again last week. He will be sentenced for first degree manslaughter in the July 18 stabbing death of Richard Adan, a waiter in an East Village restaurant. Mr. Abbott's book was published last year with the help and endorsement of author Norman Mailer, who also supported his protege's successful bid for parole.

title: A MAN WHO WANTS TO MAKE MOVIES
description: ''I told our officers there's nothing new in this world. Euripides was banished from Athens because he wrote a play that was deemed to be offensive. Columbia Pictures has a history of high-quality films done in extremely good taste. If we got into the business of reproducing Michela ngelo statues, we would be criticized.''

title: TELEVISION'S HIGH-ANTE EXTRAVAGANZA
description: SOME 80,000 fans will squeeze into the Silverdome in Pontiac, Mich., for the Super Bowl today, but for most Americans - a projected 100 million of them anyway, in addition to viewers in countries ranging from South Korea to Belgium - the game will come alive only on the 18-inch boxes in their living rooms.

title: MINERS, MR. PRESIDENT, ARE NOT SLAG
description: ''The only thing keeping the rock off your back when you're two miles underground is Government regulations,'' says Willie Anderson. Like most West Virginia coal miners, he is incensed by President Reagan's drive to reduce the Mine Safety and Health Administration's budget. Mr. Reagan cut Jimmy Carter's fiscal 1981 budget from $157.7 million to $153.6 million; the current, fiscal 1982 budget is only $148 million. These cutbacks involve an industry where there have 121,000 deaths since 1870 and there have been 1.7 million lost-time injuries since 1930.

title: CAMINO REAL
description: To the Editor:

title: OTB PROFITS DOWN
description: ADOZEN men in winter jackets lined the tables at the Hauppauge Offtrack Betting parlor, marking their programs, glancing up at the television screen showing the current racing information and sharing whispered tips with their neighbors.

title: Antiques View; A COLLECTION FOR THE YOUNG AT HEART
description: One of the most famous and generally beloved children's books will be exhibited starting Thursday at the estimable Morgan Library - the original manuscript of Lewis Carroll's ''Alice's Adventures Under Ground,'' that is to say, the handwritten and hand-illustrated article that Carroll presented to Alice Liddell on Christmas Day in 1864. It is the centerpiece of the show commemorating the 150th anniversary of the birth of Carroll. The exhibition marks the first time since 1948 that ''Alice'' has left England, where it has resided at the British Library.

title: Steven C. Weisfeld to Wed Violet Vigovich o n April 25
description: Mr. and Mrs. George Vigovich of Philadelphia have made known the engagement of their daughter, Violet Helene Vigovich, to Steven Craig Weisfeld, son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Weisfeld of New York.

title: CHURCH'S LIBRARY STORES FAMILY DATA
description: THE time may be close at hand when anyone who wants to trace his family's history will be able to do so because of a project undertaken by the Mormon Church 44 years ago.

title: ASBESTOS REMAINS A PROBLEM
description: LAST Monday, workmen set up scaffolding so that they could start removing asbestos insulation in the basement of the huge annex building at the headquarters of the state's Department of Transportation in Ewing Township. The basement houses the department's computer operations.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Cocktail Lessons
description: To fight alcoholism, the Johnson Count y Mental Health Center in Shawnee, Kan. , said it would teach people how to drink. It began in 1979 to arrange cocktail parties that combined instruction i n ''sensible'' drinking with serious discussion of the consequences of overconsumption.

title: Follow-Up on the News; The Army Way
description: The Army wanted an alternative to its shiny black boot. It began adopting standards as far back as 1970. What emerged was a prototype no-shine boot with a suede-like finish that resisted detection by heat-sensing devices.

title: ON CHOOSING A GYNECOLOGIST
description: HOW should a woman select a gynecologist? And is choosing a female doctor the answer to the complaints that women have voiced for years about unsympathetic or patronizing male doctors?

title: The Region; The D.A. Loses To the Judge
description: In accusing the state's Chief Judge of overstepping his powers, Manhattan District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau overstepped some of his own. So ruled a judge last week in rejecting Mr. Morgenthau's attempt to block a new system of selecting temporary judges for the State Supreme Court in New York City.

title: ELIOT AND FRIENDS
description: The following selection has been adapted from Eileen Simpson's ''Poets in Their Youth,'' a memoir of her many literary associations, particularly of Delmore Schwartz, Randall Jarrell and Robert Lowell. Miss Simpson, who was married to John Berryman, is the author of ''The Maze,'' a novel, and ''Reversals: A Personal Account of Victory Over Dyslexia.'' ''Poets in Their Youth'' will be published by Random House in the spring.

title: Personal Finance; HOW TO DEDUCT A NIGHT ON THE TOWN
description: A S tax time approaches, so does deduction da y, and with it the question of handling the entertainment expens es that are major items for professionals and for business executives with entertainment bills that are not reimbursed by their compan ies. The watchwords, taxexperts stress, are ''be sure you can prove i t.''

title: WORLD AIRWAYS JETLINER SKIDS INTO BOSTON HARBOR
description: A World Airways DC-10 jetliner nosed part way into the shallow water of Boston Harbor this evening after landing and skidding off an ice-slick runway at Logan International Airport, the authorities said. The airline said that all aboard had been accounted for , but the Massachusetts Port Authority said it still haddivers lookin g around in the water about four hours after the landing.

title: Constance Wallace Fiancee
description: Mr. and Mrs. Hugh C. Wallace of Greenville, Del., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Constance Vauclain Wallace, to Timothy Hudson Manahan, son of Jesse Manahan of Paterson, N.J., and Patricia F. Manahan of Franklin Lakes, N.J. A spring wedding is planned.

title: CONSUMER RATES
A CONTEST OF QUARTERBACKS
description: Up to now, this Super Bowl scene has been different. Snow instead of palm trees. Auto workers on unemployment lines instead of revelers on Bourbon Street or Sunset Boulevard. But today Super Bowl XVI will be the same as all the others - a game decided by the better of two quarterbacks, either Joe Montana of the San Francisco 49ers or Ken Anderson of the Cincinnati Bengals.

title: Mary Dorsey, Senator's Aide, Fiance e of Brian Lee
description: Dr. and Mrs. James B. Dorsey of Saratoga Springs, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Lee Dorsey, to Brian Donald Lee, son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald I. Lee, also of Saratoga Springs. An October wedding is planned.

title: Around the Nation; Last Plane Crash Victim Recovered From River
description: Divers recovered the body of a 2-month-old infant from the Potomac River today, the last of 78 persons killed in the Jan. 13 crash of an Air Florida jet.

title: The Nation; Building Dams To Stop Leaks
description: President Reagan began last week's press confererence with a smile and a quip about leaks. But hHis Administration doesn't seem to be fooling around in its campaign against unauthorized - some might read that ''embarrassing'' - disclosures.

title: NEW SHOWCASE FOR SCULPTURE
description: GREAT NECK DESPITE a growing sense of democracy in the visual arts, painting is still seen as its aristocrat - the most refined, the most elegant and the most significant of all artistic disciplines. Graphics and photography have been climbing in the hierarchy, but their status is still far behind that of painting.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD SECURITY PATROLS DOUBLE
description: Driving down a street in the homeowner community of Kew Gardens in Queens one recent evening, volunteers on a security patrol noticed two men sitting in a parked car. They jotted down the number of the license plates and called the police.

title: REGIME'S 'LOYAL BLOCKHEADS' LAID WASTE POLAND'S ECONOMY
description: POLAND prepared last week for a stiff increase in food prices (increases of the sort that toppled previous regimes) as the country braced for its fourth straight year of economic slump. For an insider's view of what went wrong, three members of The New York Times Washington bureau spoke with Zdzislaw Rurarz, who resigned last month as Poland's Ambassador to Japan and defected to the United States. Mr. Rurarz was personal economic adviser to party chief Edward Gierek for 16 months until December 1972 and chief economic adviser to the Foreign Minister from 1976 to 1980. Excerpts follow from the interview conducted by Edward Cowan, Barbara Crossette and David Binder.

title: Politics; SENATE RACE PICKS UP STEAM; MRS. FENWICK IN, BELL DUE NEXT
description: TRENTON REPRESENTATIVE Millicent Fenwick of Bernardsville got the Republican primary election campaign for United States Senator off in high style last week.

title: RONNIE LOTT, 49ER-CORNERBACK: AGGRESSIVE, EMOTIONAL TALENT
description: PONTIAC, Mich. WHEN the San Francisco 49ers made Ronnie Lott their first choice in last April's National Football League draft, they knew they were getting a future star. But a star so soon?

title: The Region; Margiotta Gets Jail Term but Still Keeps Job
description: A Federal judge gave Nassau County Republican leader Joseph Margiotta two years in prison for political corruption last week, but his party allies gave him a suspended sentence.

title: SUSPENSIONS MAR PROST'S VICTORY IN SOUTH AFRICAN GRAND PRIX
description: Alain Prost of France drove his turbocharged Renault to victory by 15 seconds today in the South African Formu la One Grand Prix, but immediately afterward his international license was suspended.

title: DANCE: 'FROM THE SAVOY' RECALLS THE 30'S AND 40'S
description: Two old-time Savoy Ballroom dancers stole the show on Thursday at the Theater of the Riverside Church. Al Minns and Sugar Sullivan danced rings around the Dance in New York Repertory Company, though that company, making its debut here, includes some of the best modern-dance ''gypsies'' in the city.

title: Sherrill Adds Aide
description: Charles J. Thornton of the University of Alabama will join the Texas A & M athletic staff, Jackie Sherrill, the new athletic dir ector an d football coach, announced today. Thornton, who had been assis tant athletic director at Alabama for 18 years, will be associate at hletic director for all sports except football, Sherill said.

title: A FLOOD OF MISLEADING LURES INTO I.R.A. PLANS
description: To the Editor:

title: Prospects
description: A Not-So-Stable Union

title: PEOPLE AS PROPERTY
ON NOT BLAMING PRESIDENTS FOR UNBALANCED BUDGETS
description: Of Ronald Reagan's early goals for his Administration, balancing the Federal budget by 1984 seemed to win the widest approval. One year ago, seven out of ten persons interviewed by the New York Times/CBS News Poll said that if they had to choose between a balanced budget and a large tax cut they would prefer a balanced budget; 52 percent to 41 percent of those same people said that they would prefer a balanced budget to an increase in military spending.

title: The World; Namibia Progress Worries Moscow
description: Good news in South-West Africa can be bad news in Moscow, as Soviet Prime Minister Nikolai A. Tikhonov make clear to high-level visitors from Angola last week. A few days earlier, Angola's Foreign Minister, Paulo Jorge, had met in Paris with Chester A. Crocker, the Assistant Secretary of State working on independence for the territory, also known as Namibia.

title: FAYE DUN AWAY- ON STAGE IN A LAB OR OF LOVE
description: That first moment was magical and transforming. It happened one hot September afternoon in 1965. Wiliam Alfred, a popular professor of English literature at Harvard, was in despair because he could not find an actress to play the role of Kathleen, the wife of an up-andcoming ward boss in Brooklyn, in his play ''Hogan's Goat.'' He was nearing the end of yet another long day of auditions in a studio behind Carnegie Hall.

title: SKI JUMPING FACES LONG DECLINE
description: ''MEN jumping off of mountains in their long underwear,'' is how one middle-aged woman, sipping hot chocolate in the Bear Mountain Inn, described them.

title:
WORDS OF THE TORAH ARE RENEWED IN TWO PROJECTS;
Great Neck TWO copies of Torahs - texts of the Penta teuch, the Five Books of Moses comprising the Old Testament - are no w being hand-lettered by men associated with Temple Israel here.  Th e two works present a study in contrasts, although each is the pr oduct of extraordinary dedication and talent - plus a lifetime of experience.
description: The men are Dr. Eric F.L. Ray, an official sofer (Torah scribe), and Samuel Fink, a retired advertising agency art director.

title: Mary Keepnews Fiancee of Eric Luskin
description: Mrs. Lawrence William Keepnews of Pelham Manor, N.Y., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Mary Theresa Keepnews, to Eric Stephen Luskin, son of Dr. and Mrs. Arthur J. Luskin of Wellesley Hills, Mass.

title: Teacher Association Challenged on Figures
description: The Jan. 10 article, ''View From the Top,'' regarding the New Jersey Education Association, was similar to one of those selfserving press releases tha t the N.J.E.A. cranks out periodically.Unfortunately, much of it does not add up whe n viewed from a different perspective.

title: PLOWING THOSE PETRODOLLARS INTO
description: FARMING By DOUGLAS MARTIN

title: THE BLUE-RIBBON BATTLE FOR PABST
description: MILWAUKEE ''S HOW me a good loser and I'll show you a loser.'' The motto adorns a wall in the new and somewhat spartan office of William F. Smith Jr., who signed on last October as p resident and chief executive officer of the strugg ling Pabst Brewing Company here.

title: Major News in Summ ary; Free Speech For Big Bucks
description: During the 1980 campaign, three ''independent'' political committees bet an $11 million bundle on Ronald Reagan. Thanks to a United States Supreme Court ruling last week, more from the same cornucopia is likely in 1984.

title: To B. or Not a Winner
description: To B. or Not beat Bold Ego by a neck today to win the $66,550 Sierra Madre Handicap before a crowd of 56,072 at Santa Anita. To B. or Not, carrying 120 pounds including Laffit Pincay, covered the six and a half furlongs in 1:14 4/5 and paid $8.40 for $2 to win.

title: JUDITH STURTZ FIANCEE OF PHILIP E. KARP
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Sturtz of Livingston, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Judith Carole Sturtz, to Philip Eugene Karp, son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Karp, also of Livingston.

title: Slide Rules
description: To the Business Editor: Regarding ''Technology's Martyrs: The Slide Rule'' (Jan. 3), in the 1940's, one of the status symbols among the engineering students at City College was a log-log duplex decitrig slide rule from Keuffel & Esser. I got mine as part of the G.I. Bill course requirements for physical chemistry and used it until 1975 when I broke down and bought a small calculator.

title: Ideas and Trends; Authors Get a Leg to Stand On
description: Caught between authors' demands for fairness and the costs of authorial irresponsibility, most publishers have chosen to do nothing. But last week, in what writer Gay Talese called a ''historic act of faith in defense of the written word,'' Viking Penguin announced that it will provide free liability insurance to the writers it publishes.

title: IS SILENT ON CROP
description: The Soviet Government issued its annual economic report for 1981 today and it confirmed previous indications of a gloomy year on most fronts.

title: The Region; Supply Side Comes to N.J.
description: Politicians frequently promise bipartisan administrations, but how often do they deliver? Thomas H. Kean, who took the oath as New Jersey's 48th Governor with that promise last week, may not have a choice.

title: Reagan's First Year Last of six articles.
description: President Reagan is beginning his second year in office under a mounting barrage of assertions that he is undermining the civil rights and civil liberties of Americans in a broad range of areas.

title: LARK-OWL MARRIAGES
description: He is a lark and she is an owl. That means he rises before dawn, jogs a few miles and is at work in his office by 6:30 A.M. If left on her own she would remain in bed till noon and does not really feel vibrant until evening, when she is ready to write a book or dance all night. But by then he is asleep - or wishing he was.

title: FOR EAST AND WEST, AVENUES, NOT RUTS
description: The latest phase of the tragedy of Poland has raised but not resolved fundamental q uestions in the West about policy toward Eastern Europe and the Soviet Unio n's role in that region. What is now required is a vision - a farsighted plan to en d the confrontation in Central Europe that, for 35 years, has pa ssed for normality. Like President Reagan's ''zero option'' for red uction of theater nuclear forces in Europe, such a plan would transc end current conflicts and practical obstacles but provide a go al that would both unify the West and guide short-term decisions a nd negotiations.

title: 2 Women Found Dead In Home Without Heat
description: A 76-year-old woman and her bedridden daughter were found dead yesterday in their unheated house in Elmont, L.I., the Nassau County police said.

title: A SYSTEM THAT REWARDS INEFFICIENCY
description: WHEN you wait months to receive a check from your health insurance company, you probably assume that the delay results from inefficiency. You're right; it does.

title: Illegal Fishing Arrests Made
description: Federal and state wildlife officials have made arrests involving buyers and sellers of chinook and coho salmon and steelhead trout iillegally taken from California's Klamath River. The Fish and Wildlife Service of the Department of the Interior said that an undercover investigation of sales of contraband fish had been going on for six months.

title: MINERS MOURNED WITH MOUNTAIN RITUAL
description: A refrain from a doleful coal-field folk song by Hazel Dickens - ''the mines was his first love, but never his friend'' - is being acted out here this weekend for the 100 ,000th-oddtime in this century.

title: Paperback Best Sellers; MASS MARKET
description: Mass-market paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: Fashion
description: WHERE DO YOU DRAW THE LINE? he lines are drawn. Stripes are streaming into stores for spring and summer: broad and narrow; horizontal and vertical; broken and continuous.

title: PERSIAN GULF GROUP SEEKING COMMON POLICIES
description: The six-nation Persian Gulf Cooperation Council is scheduled to meet next week to try to coordinate regional policies as joint security takes on growing importance.

title: Other Business; THE MILLION-DOLLAR SURE THING
description: Through much of this year, the figures for top executives' 1981 salaries will come drifting in on corporate proxy statements, setting off another round of counting the rich. The 1980 tabulations, meanwhile, indicate that the million-dollar club is growing.

title: HUMANITY'S SOLIDARITY UNDER FIRE
description: To the Editor:

title: BUYING IS ONE WAY TO LEARN ABOUT ART
description: NEW HAVEN CHRIS CARDONE talks casually about art collecting, tossing off the jargon of dealers, artists and the market with practiced familiarity. ''If you are going to collect, appreciating the art is only the first step,'' he says.

title:
Other Business;
THE RISE AND FALL AND FUTURE OF BROOKS SHOE
description: It sounded like a classic success story. In 1977, Runner's World, bible of the fast-growing sport, gave the Brooks Vantage its No. 1 rating. At its peak, just nine years after the Brooks Shoe Manufacturing Company had started in performance shoes, it ran second in the sports-shoe business, by most counts, outdistancing all but Nike with its high-quality, $20 to $50 sneakers. Sales in the fiscal year ended May 1981 were $53 million.

title: Wedding in May For Helena Sias
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Barnes Sias of Westport, Conn., and San Rafael, Calif., have announced the engagement of t hei r daughter, Helena Thorpe Sias, to Jeffrey Thomas Webber of Palo Alto, Calif. He is the son of Robert Brodus Webber of Medford, Mass. , and the late Shirley Anderson Webber of Medford, Ore.

title: Plane Skids to Safe Landing
description: A giant C-5A Air Force cargo plane skidded on its nose to a safe landing Friday at McChord Air Force Base after the front landing gear failed to extend, an Air Force spokesman said.

title: War, Intelligence and Truth
description: A CBS documentary on Vietnam last night has surprising present pertinence. ''The Uncounted Enemy: A Vietnam Deception'' showed that Lyndon Johnson himself was victimized by mendacious intelligence.

title: Dining Out; EATING SIMPLY, CHEAPLY AND WELL
description: EVERY now and then we come across unpretentious eateries that serve the needs of a specific local clientele, featuring respectable food decently prepared, for the most part, and served in a modest setting. The following are our latest finds.

title: CONSERVATIVES AT PRINCETON GET NEW, TABLOID VOICE
description: PRINCETON IT IS nearly a decade since campus liberals ended their outcry over the Vietnam War, but the voice of political activism at Princeton University goes on. This time, the voice is that of a new student newspaper with a decidedly conservative tone.

title: PORTMAN HOTEL: BROADWAY IS A HOUSE DIVIDED
description: Several weeks ago, a confrontation occurred at the Plymouth Theater - a confrontation over an issue that has polarized the theater community. It was shortly before a performance of ''Nicholas Nickleby,'' when the playwright David Mamet approached Gerald Schoenfeld, chairman of the Shubert Organization. ''You call yourself a producer,'' Mr. Mamet recalls saying, ''but you don't know how to create anything; all you know how to do is destroy.'' Mr. Schoenfeld quickly snapped back that Mr. Mamet did not know how to write plays, and the two men stalked off in opposite directions.

title: AVIATION COMPANY CAUGHT IN NOISE BATTLE
description: OUTWARDLY, Panorama Flight Service seemed to have become fortune's child. The small aviation company moved on Nov. 1 from its cramped quarters at the Westchester County Airport into new hangar and office facilities there. It offered private flyers a home base, a counterpart to what has long been available to pilots of the socalled ''Big Iron'' or large corporate jet.

title: Q&A
description: Question:My husband and I are interested in visiting Oaxaca, Mexico, during February. Could you tell me what the temperature is likely to be during the day and whether there is a change at night, and what kinds of clothes to take? - H.D., Derby, Conn. Answer:The month of February offers delightful weather in Mexico; you can expect sunny days and cool nights with hardly a drop of rain. In central Mexico temperatures average 70 degrees Fahrenheit during the day and 55 degrees at night. Rarely will you find central heating throughout the country - but rarely does the temperature fall near freezing at any time during the year.

title: LYNN ROBBINS
description: REMEMBER when you couldn't wait for your children to learn to talk? You'd spend hours over the crib wondering what lay behind a contented smile and gurgle or trying desperately to figure out what caused the terrible screaming. If she could only tell us, my husband and I used to say. If we only knew what she was thinking. If she could only express herself, we thought, then life with her would be so simple, so rewarding - in a word, perfect.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: Lawyer Is Fiance Of Lisa Chrystal
description: Mr. and Mrs. Herman Chrystal of Union, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lisa Fran Chrystal, to Peter J. Herzberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arno Herzberg, also of Union.

title: Westchester Housing; HOMEOWNERS FIND FUEL-OIL SUBSTITUTES
description: STUART TIEKERT and his wife, Mary Edwards, close off most of the 10 rooms in their Victorian house in Port Chester and cart a kerosene heater back and forth from the kitchen to the study to keep warm.

title:
Gardening;
BIRCH SPECIES THAT OFFER DIVERSITY
description: LAST week we discussed birches in the landscape and enumerated their problems and weaknesses. Although attractive and useful, their inability to adapt to hot, dry summers and their susceptibility to leaf miner and bronze-headed birch borer shorten their lifespan and limit their value.

title: BROKERS PRESS BUTTONS TO FIND CO-OPS
description: Stalking the perfect co-op has become a matter of pressing buttons at one real-estate concern in the city, and others are warily considering a similar approach.

title: Health-Care System Needs to Be Understood
description: Bernard Sloan's article ''Outside Medicaid and Looking In'' on the opinion page of Jan. 3 was of particular interest to me as a ''medical'' social worker employed in Westchester County.

title: Critics' Choices
description: CLASSICAL MUSIC Musica Sacra will celebrate the sacred side of Stravinsky's music when it performs his Mass at Avery Fisher Hall this Wednesday evening at 7:30. The music world is currently observing the 100th anniversary of the composer's birth.

title: FILMING 'LIFE ON EARTH'- FROM PRIMEVAL OOZE TO INTELLECT
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Pearce Wright is science editor of The London Times. By PEARCE WRIGHT LONDON ''You must belch quietly and keep your head down as you lope along or he'll put his fist in your mouth like that!'' Shambling across the floor in an ape-like gait, David Attenborough raised his hand menacingly to show how gorillas, like men, can become aggressive if approached the wrong way.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It was worse than the worst nightmare. There was a moment there when it seemed as if we'd lose the whole thing.'' - Dixon Freeland, superintendent of the Roosevelt home in Hyde Park, N.Y., after a fire there.

title: THE HOOVER WAY TO HELP SICK COMPANIES
description: F IFTY years ago this month, Republican President Herbert Hoover signed a bill setting up the Reconstruction Finance Corporation. Conceived as a modest and temporary anti-Depression measure, with initial capital of $500 million, the R.F.C. lasted 21 years, through the Depression, two wars, and a postwar boom. It was finally killed off in 1953, having dispersed $40.6 billion.

title: BAR GROUP TO DEBATE LAW SCHOOL ISSUE AGAIN
description: As 2,000 lawyers convening at the American Bar Association's midyear meeting here debate a potpourri of issues, ranging from proposals to narrow the Freedom of Information Act to ''preventive detention'' of some criminal suspects awaiting trial, the hottest center of controversy again appears to be a small, Christian fundamentalist law school in Oklahoma.

title: Around the World; Canada Denies That U.S.  May Have Broken Code
description: The Toronto Star reported today that Canadian officials were checking the possibility that the United States had cracked Canada's diplomatic code and had been intercepting dispatches from Ottawa to the Canadian Embassy in Washington. Canadian officials denied the report.

title: MEN AND WOMEN POSSESSED
description: THE ROYAL GAME & OTHER STORIES By Stefan Zweig. Translated by Jill Sutcliffe. With an Introduction by John Fowles. 250 pp. New York: Harmony Books. $12.95. By SALMAN RUSHDIE

title: PICTURING THE HOLOCAUST
description: THE AUSCHWITZ ALBUM A Book Based Upon an Album Discovered by a Concentration Camp Survivor, Lili Meier. Text by Peter Hellman. Illustrated. 167 pp. New York: Random House. $23.50. THE HOLOCAUST AND THE HISTORIANS By Lucy S. Dawidowicz. 187 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $15.

title: Robyn W. Gill to be Married April 24
description: Mr. and Mrs. William R. Goss of Chicago have announced the engagement of Mrs. Goss's daughter, Robyn Wor th Gill, to LeRoy Banks Attaway Jr. Both are of New York.

title: IMMIGRATION AGENCY CURBED IN SEARCH ES FOR ALIENS
description: A Federal district judge here has permanently enjoined the Immigration and Naturalization Service from surrounding or invading factories and homes and then forcibly interrogating Hispanic Americans on the status of their citizenship.

title: CITY OF SECRETS AND SURPRISES
description: T hose who love Naples are continually challenged to defend the city by visitors who have spent a harrowing day or two there, on their way to Sorrento or Positano, Amalfi or Ravello, or to the islands of the Neapolitan gulf. Travelers who have lost wallet and temper in the Naples crush, been cheated by taxi drivers, felled by an aberrant clam and bedeviled by chaotic traffic, have stood in that great scene of anarchy and poverty and wondered at the city's fame.

title: No Headline
description: It was gratifying to see that there are at least some women who are fulfilled in the role of running and managing a home.

title: EDWARD R. FARBER, INVENTOR OF FLASH
description: Edward Rolke Farber, a pioneer in electronic lighting who is considered to be the inventor of the portable strobe light for still cameras, died of a heart attack Friday at his home in Delafield, Wis. He was 67 years old.

title: G.O.P. 1% CASE LINGERS IN NASSAU
description: WHILE the controversy over insurance patronage in the Nassau County Republican organization reached a climax with the conviction last month of Joseph M. Margiotta, the Republican chairman, on Federal extortion and mail-fraud charges, the final chapter in another political controversy - 1 percent contributions to the party by public employees - was being written.

title: TEACHING PROBLEMS, IN AND OUT OF THE CLASSROOM
description: IDON'T know if it is the kind of parties I go to, or if this is the red flag generally waved in front of a teacher no matter where. I am hearing this remark more and more. I used to respond, ''You are absolutely right, and I couldn't agree with you more.'' End of a never-begun argument.

title: About Long Island
description: WITHOUT even poking my nose outside, I could tell it was a cartrouble morning. The view from the kitchen window was tidy: the street was sanded, the driveways shoveled, the sun shining on snow. But the central figure in the glossy landscape was my neighbor, wrapped up against the cold, laboriously pushing his car out to the hill so he could start it with the clutch.

title: Diary of a Glad Housewife
description: Joyce Colony's ''Diary of a Glad Housewife'' (Dec. 6) is the article I have always wanted to write. Oh, the pleasures of longsimmering chicken soup and the satisfaction of being there when a child calls home sick from school.

title: Liza Minnelli Wins Award
description: The 1982 Martha Graham Award has been given to Liza Minnelli.

title: Film View; DOES A DECENT MOVIE HAVE TO BE DULL?
description: What's gone wrong with the movies this season? Is there one, even one, that you can recommend wholeheartedly to your friends? A mention of ''Reds'' is bound to produce a respectful hush in some circles, since this is a certifiably long, serious and award-winning effort. But has it generated much real enthusiasm? Does anyone really care to dispute the merits of ''Chariots of Fire,'' ''Atlantic City,'' ''Absence of Malice,'' or any other of last year's honorable, admirable, largely unexciting screen successes?

title: DOWNTOWN SPACES FOR DANCERS
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Barry Laine writes frequently about dance and dancers. By BARRY LAINE

title: U.S. PLANS PROTEST ON POLAND AT MADRID TALKS
description: The United States is planning several measures, including a prolonged recess of the Madrid talks on East-West cooperatio n, to demonstrate its opposition to the crackdown in Poland, Administration officials disclosed today.

title: SPIES AND MOLES AND OTHER ENTERTAINERS
description: THE WEDDING GUEST By David Wiltse. 312 pp. New York: Delacorte Press. $15.95.

title: FATAL SUBWAY CRASH TIED TO WORKERS' ERRORS
description: Errors by a supervisor and a motorman caused the Jan. 13 subway crash that killed three persons and injured 27, according to preliminary findings of an investigation.

title:
Art;
3 PRIZE-WINN ERS SHOW THEIR STYLE
description: RIVERHEAD THE East End Arts Center's current exhibition (through Feb. 3) is a three-person show by the top prize-winners of last year's juried exhibition. Paintings by Jacqueline Penney, ink drawings by Gwen Cole and screen prints of George Wybenga are featured, and brief statements by each artist give the viewer insights into the techniques used and the motivations behind the works.

title: About Westchester
description: THE members of the class are drawing oranges, but they are not supposed to think of them as such. Instead, they have been encouraged by the instructor to regard the fruit in purely visual terms, to eliminate any narrative, verbal associations of oranges per se, and to see them merely as manifestations of mass and line and light. In order to do this, they have been told, they should try to experience a shift in perception - a subtle change that will indicate they are relying on a different part of the brain.

title: ALBERTA MACLEOD TO BE JULY BRIDE
description: The Rev. Dr. Donald Macleod of Princeton, N.J., has announced the engagement of his daughter, Alberta Anne Mac leod, to James Otis Weeks, son of Frederick V. Weeks of Villanova, Pa., and the late MaryFinck Weeks.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: Trading in Poverty
description: It sounds as though President Reagan is ready to toss out some big bait to the nation's governors and mayors. He would have Washington take over health care that costs them billions. In exchange, state and local governments would pay the full cost of other programs, notably welfare and food stamps.

title: Around the World; Black Leaders in Accord At Meeting on Namibia
description: Representatives of eight black African nations and the guerrilla leader Sam Nujoma agreed tonight on a common response to a Western plan for a peaceful independence settlement for South-West Africa.

title: WESTWAY IS ON TRIAL OVER ISSUE OF STRIPED BASS
description: A trial has opened on a complaint seeking to block the Westway project on the ground that it could seriously harm striped bass in the Hudson River.

title: Robert Bruder, Vice President For Planning of G.T.E., Is Dead
description: Robert I. Bruder, executive vice president for corporate planning and development for the General Telephone and Electronics Corporation, died Friday in Stamford Hospital in Connecticut after suffering a heart attack Jan. 12. He was 51 years old and a resident of Stamford.

title: 'JINGLE BELLS'
description: To the Editor:

title: Critics' Choices
description: THEATER One of the most promising young talents to pop up in the New York theater in recent seasons is James Lapine. He's a true double-threat man.

title:
Numismatics;
FOR F.D.R.- THE DIME STILL MARCHES ON
description: With a new commemorative coin on the way to serve as a glowing reminder, it is being widely publicized that this year marks the 250th anniversary of George Washington's birth. Less well known is the fact that it is also a milestone year for another outstanding United States president: Saturday, Jan. 30, is the 100th anniversary of the birth of our 32d president, Franklin Delano Roosevelt.

title: ORAL-HISTORY PROJECT TO RECALL SCARSDALE
description: BY the end of next month, 14 potential historians trained by the Scarsdale Historical Society will be qualified to interview hundreds of people for an oral history of the village.

title: Clarkson Dominating Again
description: Most of the Eastern college hockey teams that were looking for a little revenge against Clarkson this season will have to wait at least another year.

title: UTILITY OFFERS INSULATION PROGRAM
description: BERLIN AFTER you install the storm windows, after you buy a fancy clockthermostat that automatically turns down the heat at night while you sleep and during the day after you go to work, and after you put glass doors on the fireplace to make the fires more efficient and stop the heat in the room from flying up the chimney at night, what's left?

title:
Business Forum;
THE REAL LOSERS WERE STOCKHOLDERS
description: I N recent we eks, much has been made of Mobil's inability to acquire the Marathon Oil Company. This was the second time in six months thata Mobil bid f or an oil company failed. The first attempt was for Conoco, which went to Du Pont.

title: CONCERT: SKROWACZEWSKI OPENS JUILLIARD'S MODERNS
description: Festivals of contemporary music generally run one of two risks: either they gamble on a lot of experimental pieces by comparatively unknown composers, which virtually insures that not much music of real quality will be presented, or they play safe with lots of wellknown composers and/or well-known works.

title: ABORTION FOES AND DIOCESE SPLIT ON TACTICS
description: THE Roman Catholic Diocese of Rockville Centre has begun a new antiabortion campaign, but some of the movement's most dedicated Long Island activists are denouncing it as divisive and unprincipled.

title: Stage View; TWO PARTS GIMMICKRY, ONE PART DISCRETION
description: Sometimes I think discretion is the better part of playwriting. In the first play on the new triple bill at the Circle Rep in Sheridan Square, an overweight frump tries to hide behind a refrigerator door that does not conceal her while her daughter rips off a platinum wig, strides to the edge of the stage apron, and orders the house electrician to hit her with an amber spotlight. In the third of the evening's adventures, a waif who looks like a gnome and talks like a refugee from an animated cartoon becomes so frustrated by her failed attempts to seduce a shy boy that she leaps into a steamer trunk and pulls the lid down after her.

title: Sound; LISTENING FOR MUSICALITY IN SPEAKERS
description: Someone signing himself ''A Faithful Reader'' quarrels with my locution: ''You often speak of the 'musicality' of audio components,'' he complains. ''This is nonsense! Components have no talent.'' It all depends, I suppose, on what you mean by ''musical.'' I certainly don't mean to suggest that electric gadgets are possessed of the creative urge and that the further course of technical development would culminate in a solid-state Mozart. By saying that a stereo component is musical I mean that the sound closely resembles that of musical instruments and voices. Or, putting it another way, musicality in sound equipment means that the components do not draw attention to themselves and leave the listener unaware of their role in bringing home the music.

title: 'AUTHOR! AUTHOR!' SHOOTS IN N.Y., N.Y.
description: Inside Sardi's it is cozy and dim, the lamplight casting warm shadows on the men in black tie and the women in their sequins and feathers. Fresh flowers bloom on every table, brandy snifters are placed within reach of every hand; a stunning and very young blonde in plunging decolletage stifles a yawn as she smiles prettily at her attentive white-haired escort. A knot of elegantly attired people cluster around a television set, listening to the late news and anxiously awaiting the theater review. Another opening, another show; the playwright chain-smokes at his table, looking tense.

title: Mary L. Cohoe Is Bride Of Leigh Randall Smith
description: Mary Leen Cohoe, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. A. Wilson Cohoe of Lake Orion, Mich., was married yesterday to Leigh Randall Smith, son of Virginia G. Smith of Memphis and R. Leigh Smith Jr. of New York. S tate Supreme Court Justice Harold Rothwax pe rformed the ceremony at the Georgian Suite in Manhattan.

title: MISSING WRITER'S FAMILY PRESSES SEARCH
description: BOGOTA LORRAINE SULLIVAN'S monthly bills are much like anyone else's, but she also spends nearly $200 a week advertising in Spanish-language newspapers in El Salvador for information about her 26-year-old son, John Jr., a freelance journalist missing since Dec. 28, 1980.

title: New Jersey Guide; STATE OPERA OPENER
description: Political intrigue, furtive love, witchcraft and assassination are only a few of the intricately woven elements of Verdi's ''Un Ballo in Maschera,'' which opens the New Jersey State Opera's season next Sunday night.

title: New Jersey Journal
description: OFFICIALS of the Hackensack Meadowlands Development Commission, which oversees planning and construction in the 32-square-mile marshland, expect to pass the $1 billion mark in development this year. This optimistic forecast is based on trends in the district since the commission was set up by the Legislature a decade ago.

title: No Headline
description: Joyce Colony's article makes a point which scholarly accounts have often missed: namely, that in its traditional form, housewifery is not only ''work'' but also an ''occupation,'' with a certain structure and particular processes which demand more skill and provide more flexibility and autonomy than many of the labor-force occupations. While lauding increased options for women, we must emphasize that the growing labor-force participation of women is, in itself, no cause for celebration, since the vast majority of employed women continue to be concentrated in low-paying, low-status and low-power positions. MARY FRANK FOX, Lecturer in Sociology, The University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, Mich.

title: REMEMBERING RED SMITH
description: To the Editor:

title: SOVIET WANTS U.S. TO PLAY BY THE RULES OF REALPOLITIK
description: MOSCOW Aquarter of a century ago, Geneva became synonymous with hopes for a thaw in the cold war. When President Eisenhower, British Prime Minister Anthony Eden and Soviet Prime Minister Nikita S. Khrushchev met there for five days in July 1955, they accomplished little of substance. But the mere fact of the meeting, after a decade of hostility, gave birth to the phrase, ''the spirit of Geneva.''

title: Critics' Choices
description: FILM It's a good week for glamorous Oscar-winners at the Regency, in ''The Leading Ladies'' series. This week, Elizabeth Taylor, Julie Christie, Katharine Hepburn and Audrey Hepburn are represented, while a French program spotlights Isabelle Adjani in ''The Story of Adele H'' and Anna Karine in ''My Life to Live.''

title: The World; Koivisto Pleases The Right People
description: Some facts of Finnish political life do not change, such as the country's 788-mile border with the Soviet Union. But for the first time in 25 years, someone other than Urho Kekkonen is about to manage Finland's delicate relationship with its superpowerful neighbor.

title: ANTI-GAMBLING SITE TO BE IN BRIDGEPORT
description: WHAT is being termed the country's first community-based center for the treatment of chronic gambling will open this spring at the Greater Bridgeport Mental Health Center, selected earlier this month by State Mental Health Department officials to conduct the pilot program.

title: National Consumers' Week
description: President Reagan has designated April 25 to May 1 as National Consumers' Week, saying that the Government must protect consumer health and safety but ''too much government regulation'' was counterproductive.

title: 'INVESTING' IN HUSBAND'S M.D. DEGREE MAY EARN WOMAN SHARE IN EARNINGS
description: The plots in the movie 27 years ago and in the court case here earlier this month were the same: Ambitious young man marries ambitious young woman. Both sacrifice while he completes medical school and she holds a job. And, just when a promising medical career is about to become a reality, the marriage breaks up.

title: Editors' Choice
description: Paul Sartre. (The University of Chicago Press, $25.) The first volume of Sartre's immense study of Flaubert.

title: ETHICS PANEL TO CONSIDER ISSUE OF $100,000 LOAN TO MORGADO
description: The committee that will soon begin reviewing the circumstances of a $100,000 low-interest loan to Governor Carey's chief aide, Robert J. Morgado, is the only state body authorized by the Legislature to advise on potential conflicts of interest in state government, state officials said.

title: Around the Nation
description: Two armed robbers held up a Brink's Inc. armored truck today and fatally shot one of its two guards, the police said.

title: A FAMILY'S FRUITLESS QUEST
description: BOGOTA ON THE collar of Lorraine Sullivan's light-green blouse, partly hidden by a gray and white sweater, is a stamped button that says: Find John Sullivan.

title: Cup Sail Group Withdraws
description: The Independent Syndicate has withdrawn its campaign to represent the United States in a defense of the America's Cup in 1983. Russell Long, the owner of the 12-Meter yacht Clipper and the syndicate's helmsman, said the withdrawal was brought about by the inability of his group ''to make satisfactory arrangements for a trial horse yacht in 1982.''

title: THE HIGH ART OF PRIMITIVISM
description: Hilton Kramer is the chief art critic of The New York Times. By Hilton Kramer

title:
Antiques;
DRUMTHWACKET'S FURNISHINGS
description: PRINCETON ANTIQUE furnishings selected for the public rooms of Drumthwacket, the successor to Morven as the Governor's Mansion, will be in the American classical style of Greek Revival. The furniture was made mostly in New York and Philadelphia, the chief production centers for this formal mode, which held sway from 1815 to 1840.

title: WINTER THOUGHTS
description: Here in Maine it is a cold start to the new year as a tempestuous ocean throws up fountains of spray at the end of my field and its ice on the dirt roads where I walk Tamas, my dog. But the cold is not only in the weather - after all, we expect that, and we are bundled up; the cold is in the heart. I cannot remember a year when I was more aware of suffering and need, more aware of the botch governments make of human lives, more aware of my own helplessness as though the fire in me had frozen at the center.

title: Tows Collide in Kentucky
description: A towboat pushing 30 barges struck another towboat near the junction of the Mississippi and Ohio Rivers today, clogging traffic for several hours, the Coast Guard said. No injuries were reported.

title: 100 FOR DINNER? WHO'S COUNTING?
description: ISTARTED to feed the birds that cold winter's morning through pure selfishness, so I deserved just what I got. I might have fancied that it was all sheer humane motivation that prompted buying the new bird feeder and the sack of wild birdseed, but even as I hung the device high out of cat and brat reach, I knew deep down it was plain selfishness.

title: IN 'VILLAGE' CONVERSIONS, BEWARE THE ZONING
description: The strong demand for housing in and around Greenwich Village in recent years has resulted in the reincarnation of a number of cityowned properties as apartment buildings.

title: SHADES OF THE SENNNETT AT THE MCCARTER
description: PRINCETON AT THE beginning of ''Keystone,'' at the McCarter Theater now through next Sunday, we face a ramshackle movie lot, circa 1912. Desmond Heeley's setting is not built for strict realism. It overflows with the rigging of a latter-day plan to impose a kind of cinematic illusion on its period. We see a camera on a tripod, weather-stained flats, a piano, a mass of ropes and arc lights and an upstage network of rectangular wired dividers.

title: SILVER HAKE; Merluccius bilinearis
description: Size: 12 to 20 inches; averages 1/2 to 1 1/2 pounds.

title: FEINT, THRUST AND PARRY IS PAPANDREOU'S STYLE SO FAR
description: A political consensus (relatively unusual in Greece) seems to have emerged about the first 100 days of Prime Minister Andreas Papandreou's Government: It has abandoned many radical plans and retreated to Western European-style Social Democratic government behind a screen of Socialist rhetoric.

title: UTILITIES OFFERING ENERGY 'BARGAIN'
description: IT ISN'T often that a utility company offers a bargain. And it is rarer still when it offers not only a bargain, but a long-term investment in energy savings to boot.

title: Food; CORNMEAL: HOME AWAY FROM HOME
description: Polenta is foreign to most American palates, though it is made with one of the nation's major foodstuffs. In Italy, however, this form of cornmeal mush is a versatile dish prepared by the best cooks.

title: THE UNHOLY ALLIANCE OF BROWN AND WALSH
description: FOR me the Super Bowl is a mirror that reflects another time, another place, a moment when it was not as it is now for either Paul Brown or Bill Walsh.

title: In Honor Of F.D.R.
description: Franklin D. Roosevelt reportedly said that if there was to be a memorial in Washington honoring his Presidency, it should be no larger than his desk. But the celebration this year of the centennial of his birth will be substantial. Outside the capital the largest celebrations will be in Hyde Park, N.Y., Mr. Roosevelt's hometown, and Warm Springs, Ga., where his vacation home was often called the Little White House.

title: WHAT PRICE PROGRESS ON THE RAILS?
description: IRODE one of those newfangled commuter trains to work the other day. It was one of those shiny silver models that NJ Transit is putting on the Morristown and Gladstone lines of the former Erie Lackawanna to ''upgrade passenger service.''

title: CITY POLICE LEARNING ICE-RESCUE TECHNIQUES
description: For police officers watching a mock drowning and rescue the other day at the Lake in Central Park, the routine exercise had acquired a sense of urgency. The drownin gs of two teen-agers in Prospect Park Lake in Brooklyn aweek earlier and the deaths of 78 people in a plane crash on the Potomac River were on the minds of many of the officers who gathered to watch the Police Department's scuba team demonstrate ice-rescue techniques.

title: SILVERMAN PROCEEDS ON DONOVAN INQUIRY
description: Leon Silverman, the recently appointed special prosecutor in the investigation of Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan, is conducting his inquiry from his own law firm, from which he has also hired two assistants.

title: Home Clinic;          A TOP-QUALITY PAINTBRUSH MAY BE CHEAPER IN THE LONG RUN
description: ALTHOUGH rollers and flat painting pads have almost replaced brushes as tools for applying paint to interior walls, ceilings and other large flat surfaces, a brush is still the most versatile and useful applicator for painting woodwork and trim, as well as furniture, cabinets and other objects where a really fine finish is desired. However, paintbrushes vary widely in grade, and it is essential that a top-quality brush be selected for those fine-finish jobs. Even the best of craftsmen cannot get a smooth, professional-looking finish with an inexpensive, poor-quality brush. It will not have enough bristles to spread the paint on uniformly, and the bristles it does contain will leave streaks and brush marks that will be almost impossible to smooth out. In addition, ''bargain'' brushes often shed bristles continuously, so that picking them off the wet finish becomes an almost impossible problem. Top-quality brushes will, of course, cost more, but for fine work and for maximum ease of application, they are well worth the difference. Their better grade of bristle will spread the finish on more uniformly, and the brush will have more bristles so that the finish is applied smoothly without brush marks or streaks showing up after the paint dries. In addition , a brush of good quality will, if properly taken care of, also last much longer than a cheap one, so in the long run it will often ac tually cost less than an inexpensive so-called ''throwaway'' brush. The latter are really not good for anything other than ap plying a wood stain or penetrating sealer, or perhaps slapping on a paint remover so you can strip off an old finish. The bristles in a top-quality brush may be either of natural origin or of a synthetic filament made for the purpose. The most widely used and best-quality natural bristle is hog bristle, which is imported from China. But for really fine work with varnish and lacquer, there are also badger-hair and ox-hair brushes that many serious craftmen prefer - especially for furniture finishing. However, these are very expensive and also hard to find in most local paint stores. They can be obtained through mail order houses that cater to craftsmen. Good-quality Chinese hog bristle is naturally tapered, which gives it resiliency, and the bristles have naturally ''flagged'' tips (split ends) that greatly contribute to their ability to spread paint on smoothly. However, like most natural bristles, hog bristle is porous and tends to absorb water, so while it is excellent for use with alkyd enamels, varnishes and oil paints, it doesn't work well with latex paints (the bristles tend to swell and lose their springiness). Synthetic bristles are either nylon or poly ester filaments, and thebetter grades are made so that the individual bristles are tapered and ''flagged'' at the ends to duplicate the excellent working qualities of good hog bristle. Neither of the se synthetic bristles isaffected by water, and they can be used in la tex (water-thinned) finishes without swelling or getting floppy ( losing their springiness). In addition, both synthetic bri stles will withstand wear better than natural bristle, and thus la st longer than natural bristle (nylon will outwear polyester when us ed on rough surfaces). One drawback to nylon bristles is that they tend to soften and lose their springiness when used in shellac or lacquer, as well as in some of the newer synthetic finishes that use powerful solvents. Polyester, on the other hand, is not affected by shellac or lacquer, or by any of the other common solvents found in most paints and finishes used around the home. Regardless of the type of bristle used, a good-quality brush should have a very high percentage of bristle with flagged tips, especially around the outside of the brush. The bristles should also be of different lengths so the brush will spread paint on smoothly from all positions, and will continue to do this as the longest bristles start to wear off. To check for this, hold the brush upside down at eye level, then spread the bristles between your fingers and look for the flagged ends. Next, separate the bristles in the center, as shown in the illustration, to see how wide the block is in the center. All brushes have a filler block to create a hollow in the center, but if this block is much thicker than in other brushes of the same size, it probably means that there is less bristle in that brush than there should be. Cheap brushes often have thick blocks to make them look as though they have more bristle in them than they actually do. Answering the Mail Q. We recently had new shingles installed on the roof of our house, on top of the old shingles. When the original shingles were installed, none of the nails used penetrated through where you could see them sticking out on the inside. However, our new roof has longer nails that now stick down inside the attic by approximately threequarters of an inch (the attic is unfinished). When I asked the contractor about this, he said there was nothing wrong. Another roofer has told me, however, that under certain winter conditions condensation would form on these exposed nails and drip down onto the attic floor, so he advises cutting all the nails off. This would be quite a job. Is it really necessary? -M.B., Oradell, N.J. A. If the attic is not properly ventilated, condensation could form - on roof rafters or sheathing, as well as on the nails. Since the nails are metal and would get colder than the wood, condensation would be more likely to form on them first. But cutting off the nails would not necessarily eliminate the problem. If this does become a problem, it means your attic needs more ventilation above the insulation because with proper venting condensation should not form anywhere in the attic.

title: No Headline
description: Miss Cooper Posts Ski Victory

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: WALT WHITMAN: A Life, by Justin Kaplan. (Bantam, $8.95.) A richly detailed biography of America's greatest poet that makes use of his verse chiefly to illuminate his life. In naming it one of their Choices of 1980, the editors of The Book Review declared that in its pages ''Whitman sometimes seems like 19th-century America itself, condensed int o one allegorical embodiment exhibiting all its embryonic int erests and potential identities.''

title:
Gardening;
BIRCH SPECIES THAT OFFER DIVERSITY
description: LAST week we discussed birches in the landscape and enumerated their problems and weaknesses. Although attractive and useful, their inability to adapt to hot, dry summers and their susceptibility to leaf miner and bronze-headed birch borer shorten their lifespan and limit their value.

title: New York Times Magazine January 24, 1982
description: William Safire 9 On Language Beefing Up Phrases Russell Baker 14 Sunday Observer Southern Comfort 16 THE MET'S PRIMITIVE-ART TREASURES Hilton Kramer18 The High Art of Primitivism Grace Glueck20 A Spectacular New Wing Morton Hunt 30 How the Mind Works Hailed as a revolutionary new field of inquiry, cognitive science is offering intriguing theories about the complex nature of human thought. Laurence W. Beilenson 34 A New Nuclear Strategy and Samuel T. Cohen A military scholar and a weapons analyst propose that we stop trying to match the Russians in conventional weapons and base our security on overwhelming power in nuclear arms.

title: TREATMENT URGED FOR HYPERTENSION
description: The usefulness of treating the mildest form of high blood pressure has been confirmed in four studies in the United States, Australia and Norway, according to a report by a joint committee of the World Health Organization and International Society of Hypertension.

title: The World; Reagan, Begin, Have Reasonably Polite Exchange
description: American-Israeli relations warmed a bit last week. President Reagan exchanged messages and metaphors with Prime Minister Menachem Begin and the United States vetoed an anti-Israel resolution in the United Nations Security Council.

title: J.A. Brady Fiance Of Julie P. Nassau
description: Mr. and Mrs. Paul David Nassau of New York and Stockbridge, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Julie Pamela Nassau, to James Alan Brady, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry William Brady of Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, and Lavallette, N.J.

title: Bridge; TRICKSTER CULBERTSON
description: In hindsight, the celebrated Culbertson-Lenz match that ended 50 years ago in New York City might be regarded as a gigantic confidence trick. The trickster was Ely Culbertson, and his reward was enormous. He persuaded the American bridge public that his victory by 8,980 points ''proved'' that his system was superior to the Official System recommended by Lenz and his associates. And as a result, Culbertson became the dominant authority for two decades, selling so many books and bridge products that he became a millionaire many times over.

title: Anthony Beats Soutar
description: Earl Anthony offset two splits with seven strikes in the final match today and defeated Dave Soutar, 218-199, to capture the $100,000 Alameda Open Professional Bowlers Association tournament.

title: ALTERNATIVE TO UNIONS SUGGESTED
description: AT a presentation last week sponsored by the Personnel Council of the County Chamber of Commerce, Martin R. Payson, a labor lawyer, warned that white-collar workers were the future targets for union organizing and urged personnel managers to engage in preventive labor relations.

title: No Headline
description: Joyce Colony has put her finger on what is frightening about being a full-time housewife today, and why so many of us want to run away from it: solitary confinement.

title: LOW-INCOME TENANTS FACE HIGHER RENTS
description: SPURRED by rising energy costs, monthly rents for low-income housing are rising sharply in Suffolk County. According to one private agency that seeks housing for low-income people, the higher rents are resulting in a growing number of evictions and a further reduction in the limited supply of rental housing that low-income people can afford.

title: NELSON KEEPS LEAD AT PHOENIX BY SHOT
description: Larry Nelson, pressed by two lesser known players, struggled today to retain his lead in the second round of the Phoenix Open. Nelson, the first-round leader with a 63, said he felt fortunate to shoot 70, one under par for the Phoenix Country Club. His aggregate of 133 was nine under par for 36 holes and gave him a one-stroke lead.

title: EGYPTIAN STUDENTS VISIT ISRAEL IN FIRST EXCHANGE PROGRAM
description: Sixty Egyptian high school students arrived in Israel this week for a 10-day visit as part of the first cultural exchange project between Egypt and Israel under an agreement signed last March.

title: MOVING NUCLEAR WASTE: DEBATE REVIVES
description: SIX years after the matter first came before a Federal judge, the question of how to ship nuclear wastes from Brookhaven to So uth Carolina stil l has not been answered. And the clash of Federal and Long Island o fficials, who disagree on how such shipments should be regulated and how their various regulatory powers should be exercised, re mains as sharp as ever.

title: REMEMBERING RED SMITH
description: To the Editor:

title: THE ROCKY ROAD FOR TRUCKERS
description: I T happened to the airlines and now it is happening to the truckers. Deregulation, coupled with a downturn in the economy, has thrown the once-utility-like American trucking industry skidding into a wholly new world and has touched off a price war that makes the competition between airlines seem like light-hearted jousting among friends.

title: A SPECTACULAR NEW WING
description: Grace Glueck is an arts reporter and critic for The Times. By Grace Glueck When the Metropolitan Museum of Art, prodded by the late Nelson Rockefeller, decided in 1969 to commit itself to the ''primitive'' arts of Africa, the Pacific Islands and the Americas that it had long eschewed, it went all out to create for them what is probably the world's most spectacular showcase. The result, more than a decade in the making, is the new $18.3 million Michael C. Rockefeller wing. Of great architectural drama, the installation in which this fragile art is displayed is also a conservator's dream. ''Never,'' as one Met official bemusedly puts it, ''has so much expensive high technology been lavished on a display of 'primitive' art.''

title: TO THE PARTHENON
description: To the Editor:

title: SOVIET CONCEDES POLISH LEADERS FACE BIG PROBLEMS
description: In a departure from its previously optimistic coverage of developments in Poland, the Soviet Communist Party daily Pravda acknowledged today that the Polish auth orities faced ''big difficulties.''

title: NOTED FOR HIS 'NEW FACES' REVUES
description: Leonard Sillman, producer of the ''New Faces'' revues that gave such stars as Henry Fonda, Imogene Coca, Eve Arden, Alice Ghostley, Van Johnson, Eartha Kitt and the late Paul Lynde their first roles on Broadway, died yesterday at Mount Sinai Medical Center after a long illness. He was 72 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: ARE BIG DEFENSE DOLLARS HEALTHY FOR THE ECONOMY?
description: The military buildup started by President Carter and accelerated by President Reagan is said by its supporters to be good for national security and the ailing economy as well. An 18 percent jump in military spending, to $215 billion, is one reason White House economists daringly predict a strong expansion in the summer and autumn that will run right through 1983.

title: IT'S SUPER SUNDAY AND THE PASSING IS FANCY
description: PONTIAC, Mich. U NDER a quilted roof that must keep out the Michigan winter while holding in flying footballs, Super Bowl XVI will be staged today between the San Francisco 49ers and the Cincinnati Bengals.

title: No Headline
description: How much time has Joyce Colony spent talking to her working neighbors? Has she heard them talk about the complementary, not ''confusing,'' roles they share with their husbands, and the mutual empathy which comes from sharing an understanding of the marketplace? Has she heard how much fun it is, at the end of the day, to emerge from the office into the kitchen, and to exchange the high-heeled pumps for an apron? Does she know that one of the highest forms of relaxation can be in transferring one's creative energies from writing a business report to baking a fresh apple pie for dinner? KATE B. WOOD, Summit, N.J.

title:
The Careful Shopper;
Shop Doubles in Size, Some Prices Cut in Half
description: Josh n Abby in Hartsdale tickets all merchandise with two prices: list price and its own. This month, prices on first-quality winter merchandise are reduced as much as 50 percent off list until the end of the month. Spring items are discounted by 10 percent or more.

title: HONG KONG'S ANTIQUES TREASURE TROVE
description: RITA REIF reports on antiques for The New York Times. By RITA REIF

title: Rabbi Dennis N. Math M arries Ellen Stettner
description: Ellen Stettner and Rabbi Dennis Neal Math were married yesterday at the Stephen Wise Free Synagogue, where the bride is the cantor. Rabbis Norman Cohen, Balfour Brickner, Helene Ferris and Mark Golub performed the ceremony.

title: KIRI TE KANAWA IS BACK AT THE MET
description: When Kiri Te Kanawa steps onto the stage this Friday as Fiordiligi in Mozart's ''Cosi fan Tutte,'' it will be five years to the month since she last sang at the Metropolitan Opera. In the interim, she has become a full-fledged star.

title: HUMORIST, AS SEEN IN LETTERS
description: JAMES THURBER never wrote a letter to his wife and she never wrote one to him. ''Why should I?'' said Helen Thurber. ''He was in the next room.''

title: Book Banning
description: To the Editor:

title: The Region; Rate Rise Granted Atlantic Electric
description: NEWARK (UPI) - The Atlantic City Electric Company was allowed to raise its rates by $11.3 million to cover operations and investment costs for its share of the Salem II nuclear power plant.

title: TROUPE GIVING 'NUTS' ANOTHER CHANCE
description: GREAT NECK ''EVERYBODY does Neil Simon and we don't want to be run-of-themill,'' said A.J. Orville, producer of the reorganized, renamed and relocated Great Neck Theater Guild.

title: Connecticut Journal
description: THERE are 2,596 fire and burglary alarms in homes and businesses in Greenwich and because of a lot of malfunctions or accidental activations, the protective devices have been driving the police and fire departments to distraction instead of sounding alarms over burglaries or fires.

title: Headliners Big Score
description: Professors who couldn't tell a fast ball from a forward pass have taken angry note of Jackie Sherrill, head football coach at the University of Pittsburgh, who last week became the nation's highest paid university employee. Mr. Sherrill signed a six-year contract worth $1.7 million to coach and serve as athletic director at Texas A & M University.
