With perks such as a new car and insurance policies, his annual salary is estimated at $280,000. But considering that the job was first offered to Michigan's Bo Schembechler for a reported $2.5 million, the Aggies got off cheaply.

title: First of Two Articles
description: The amount of arms in the Middle East has more than doubled since the 1973 war, and there is no end in sight. Israel and its potential Arab adversaries have almost as many conventional weapons as those that the Soviet Union and its allies have in Northern and Central Europe, and exceed the Atlantic alliance in tanks and combat aircraft.

title: TRAINS CARRY HOPES OF THE FUTURE
description: WITH the winds of change blowing hard in the transportation industry, one wonders why Connecticut continues to dream only of highway expansion and airport improvement, to the exclusion of an inevitable railroad renaissance in our state.

title: PLAINFIELD'S VICTORIANS AND THEIR STATELY HOMES
description: PLAINFIELD ALTHOUGH Cape May springs to the minds of many when ''New Jersey'' and ''Victorian homes'' are coupled, other cities - such as this ''Queen City of Central New Jersey'' - are not without their examples of elaborate houses.

title: RECALLING THE HEYDAY OF THE GREAT WHITE WAY
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Allen Churchill is the author of ''The Great White Way'' and ''The Theatrical 20's.'' By ALLEN CHURCHILL

title: Patriots Keep No.1 Choice
description: The New England Patriots, who have the first choice this spring in the draft of college players, have turned down an offer to sell the choice, reportedly for $2.5 million from Jack Kent Cooke, owner of the Washington Redskins.

title: DR. E.S. LENGER FIANCE OF SANDY B. BERNSTEIN
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Milton Bernstein of Jericho, L.I. of the engagement of their daughter, Sandy Barber Bernstein, to Dr. E. Steven Lenger, son of Mrs. Paul Lenger of Englewood, N.J., and the late Mr. Lenger. A March wedding is planned in Manhasset, L.I.

title: Reading and Writing; THE TALKING AGE
description: While reading Robert Stone's ''A Flag for Sunrise,'' which one reviewer called the best novel of ideas since Dostoyevsky, I was pleasantly surprised by the way the characters talked to one another. Unlike the speech of characters in some modern fiction, theirs was full of inquiry, meaning and desire. They were always pushing and pulling at ideas, and these ideas generated a tension, even passion, between them.

title: Fashion Exhibit At the Met
description: ''The 18th-Century Woman'' exhibition, newly installed in the Costume Institute of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, deserves comment (''Vreeland's Show,'' by Andre Leon Talley, Dec. 6). It is a very beautiful show to look at.

title: Reassessments And Realities
description: I am responding to some of the points in the article ''Assessment Muddled Despite New Law'' (Jan. 3). Forced reassessment of all homes in the state at full market value, such as the New York Public Interest Research Group and Governor Carey suggest, is a futile attempt at ''instant equity'' lacking any insight into the harsh realities of homeownership in the 80's.

title: Around the World; Honduran Group Says It Bombed a Coke Plant
description: A Honduran guerrilla group has said it was responsible for bombing a subsidiary of the Coca-Cola Company, and it threatened to conduct a campaign of sabotage in the Central American nation.

title: MIDWINTER GUIDE TO THE ISLANDS OF THE CARIBBEAN
description: T his roundup of accommodations in the Caribbean, an update of ''A Beachcomber's Baedeker,'' which appeared in these pages on Nov. 22, 1981, outlines the availability of rooms on the islands for the remainder of the winter season. It is meant to give an indication of the range of accommodations available, not to be a definitive selection of hotels and housekeeping units.

title: 'NEW INFORMATION ORDER': DEBATING PRAGMATICS
description: In recent years, the mere mention of UNESCO has set off alarms in newrooms throughout the United States and Western Europe where the organization is suspected of attempting to curb freedom of information by implementing ''codes of journalistic conduct'' and issuing licenses to reporters.

title: PATCO REACT
description: To the Business Editor: Mr. Poli's article is most valuable to students and experts in the industrial relations. The miscalculations and errors recounted by Mr. Poli are most frank, considering the cheap shots he has been subjected to by many alleged experts with very little background in the Federal sector, and even less background in the ''cat and dog'' type relationship that existed for too many years between the Federal Aviation Administration and the Professional Air Traffic Controllers Organization.

title: Kristin O'Brien Married
description: The marriage of Kristin Marie O'Brien, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Francis O'Brien of Baltimore, to William Henry Spencer-Strong 3d, son of Dr. and Mrs. Spencer-Strong 2d, also of Baltimore, took place there yesterday.

title: WEEKEND PACKAGES: MINI TO MAXI
description: A long weekend is all you need to enjoy much of the Caribbean this year. You might prefer, of course, to stay longer, but an increasing number of three-night packages are available for busy Northeasterners who simply cannot put together more winter vacation time.

title: zf The Nation; Restructuring The Drug War
description: Officials and agents of the Drug Enforcement Administration must be wondering if their agency is destined, or doomed, to become part the ''new F.B.I.''

title: TEMPEST IN A TEACUP
description: To the Editor:

title: A SUPERB 'TRISTAN' BY WAY OF WALES
description: The first thing that should be said about London Records' superb new recording of Wagner's ''Tristan und Isolde'' (LDR 75001, five disks) is that it is not in English. It's not in Welsh, either, even though the recording is by the Welsh National Opera under the baton of Reginald Goodall. Mr. Goodall is the reclusive British Wagnerian who is best known for his English-language ''Ring of the Nibelung'' with the English National Opera, which was recorded complete. Mr. Goodall also led performances of ''Tristan'' in English this past summer with the English National with some of the same singers who appear on the London set. But the recording is in German.

title: RHODODENDRONS MAY BE THE GARDENERS'S BEST THERMOMETER
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Margery Daughtrey is an associate pathologist with Cornell University's Horticultural Research Laboratory. By MARGERY DAUGHTREY

title: Children's Books
description: JULIE'S SUMMER By Crystal Thrasher. 263 pp. New York: Atheneum/McElderry. $11.95. (Ages 12 to 15) By PATRICIA LEE GAUCH

title: HOW THE MIND WORKS
description: COPYRIGHT c 1982 BY MORTON HUNT This article is adapted from ''The Universe Within: A New Science Explores the Human Mind,'' to be published next month by Simon and Schuster. By Morton Hunt No scientific endeavor of recent years has been more dramatic or commanded greater public attention than our exploration of outer space. In these same years, with no drama whatever and almost no public notice, a small band of researchers, now numbering perhaps a thousand, has been exploring inner space - the universe within our minds, where, in words and images, we make a working model of what lies outside.

title:
New Jersey Housing;
A LOOK AT HHE FUTURE OF HOUSING
description: NEW BRUNSWICK FIRST, the good news: ''The Future of Rental Housing,'' a book just published by Rutgers University's Center for Urban Policy Research, concludes that ''the housing history of the last three decades has been one of enormous progress of conversion of the bulk of America's households from renters to owners, and of a vast upgrading of the physical nature of the housing stock in all forms of tenure.''

title: No Headline
description: Joyce Colony can stay at home and be ''glad.'' I can go to the office and be happy.

title: H AYAKAWA RESISTS IDEA OF DROPPING OUT OF RACE
description: For a moment, the scene had the sharp edges of the confrontations of the late 1960's. At a lectern, brandishing his rainbow tam o'shanter, was Samuel Ichiye Hayakawa, the scrappy Japanese-American semantics professor who came to national prominence when, as president of San Francisco State College in 1968, he climbed up on a sound truck manned by campus radicals and jerked out the wires of the public address system.

title: Theater; BIG APPLE BECKONS MORTON DA COSTA
description: HE lives in a large split-level ranch home in Redding. It is handsomely furnished with mementos of an illustrious career in the theater. He is Morton Da Costa, the stage and film director.

title: June Bridal Is Set By Andrea Henk
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edmund F. Henk of Stamford, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Andrea Henk, to David Randolph Corbin, son of Mrs. Natalie Corbin of Westport, Conn., and Howard J. Corbin of Oyster Bay, L. I.

title: Boxers Don't Favor Thumbless Gloves
description: The first boxers to use them have said they dislike the thumbless gloves now made mandatory for some bouts by the New York State Athletic Commission.

title: THEY WORK BY NIGHT
description: ''I LIKE working these hours - people are relaxed and the pay differential adds up to about $3,000 a year more,'' said Harold Oster of New Hyde Park, an assistant head nurse at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset. ''The way the economy is going now, that would be a big chunk to give up. Besides, I work with a good bunch.''

title: COVENTRY AND THE MALL IN YORKTOWN
description: AFTER the Germans had finished their punitive saturation bombing of Coventry in World War II, there was very little left of the English city's center but rubble. But Coventry, deeply wounded, was far from dead. Out of the ashes, once the war was over, rose not only a soaring cathedral but also a phoenix of commerce, a strikingly attractive two-level shopping mall, complete with landscaping and parking.

title: IN PARK SLOPE, LESS-AFFLUENT FEAR FOR HOMES
description: The revitalization of Brooklyn's Park Slope section in the last 10 years has sharply raised the cost of neighborhood housing and has led to increasing fears of displacement among renters with low or moderate incomes.

title: Business Conditions; RELIEF FOR CEREAL STOCKS
description: After two consecutive years of declining world cereal stocks, this year's expected record crop should go far to swell inventories, economsts at the International Monetary Fund say. They anticipate a 1981-82 world cereal crop of 1.5 billion tons.

title: ELIZABETH FAUVER BETROTHED
description: Mr. and Mrs. John K. Fauver of Perrysburg, Ohio, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Lamb Fauver, to Frederick George Stueber 2d, son of Dr. and Mrs. Stueber Jr. of Shaker Heights, Ohio.

title: BUY A CONDOMINIUM, TAKE ON A PARTNER
description: In the beginning, sales were brisk when a Westchester-based real estate company started converting a rental apartment project called Fountain Terrace to condominiums here.

title: SKI TOURS THRIVE ON L.I.
description: DESPITE a slow start, group tour companies that take thousands of skiers off the Island each weekend to upstate New York and New England are reporting an increase in riders on luxury buses that leave during predawn hours to make their way to places like Whiteface near Lake Placid or Mount Snow in Vermont.

title: REHABILITATION OFFICIAL NAMED
description: Dr. Joseph Goodgold, a scientist associated with the New York University Sch ool of Medicine for 19 years, has been appointed chairman of t he school's department of rehabilitation medicine. He succeeds Dr. Howard A. Rusk, who retired from the chairmanship in 1980.

title: AN ART BLACKOUT IN POLAND
description: Apart from all the other hardships it has wrought, the Polish military crackdown in early December has cut off communication between American and Polish artists whose friendship began last fall with a big international art show in Lodz. The Solidarity-backed show, a rough-and-ready affair entitled ''Construction and Process'' and housed in a factory building, was organized by Polish artists under the leade rship of Ryszard and Maria Was ko, filmmakers.

title: Gretchen G. Teichgraeber Is Bride of John S. Neff
description: Gretchen Gehring Teichgraeber, daughter of Bernard E. Teichgraeber of Greenwich, Conn., was married there yesterday to John Stanley Neff, son of Dr. and Mrs. Stanley D. Neff of Salt Lake City. The Rev. Walter D. Wagoner performed the ceremony at the Round Hill Community Church.

title: The Distant Courts of Men's Pro Tennis
description: For the players, it will mean more money. For the officials, there will be more headaches. For the public, the 1982 men's professional tennis circuit will be more confusing than ever, with conflicting tournaments and even conflicting computers.

title: Ford's New Baby Has an Old Appeal
description: THE old man came into the garage muttering and shaking rain from his coat. He was there to pick up a new car, and he was furious. The thing he was mad about, he said with no little heat, was that his car, his shiny new baby, was out there getting wet. He was tempted, he said, to cancel the order right then and there. To buy a car from somebody who knew how to do things properly.

title: JUVENILE JUSTICE STIRS NEW DEBATE
description: About 10 years ago, Massachusetts began an experiment in juvenile justice by abolishing its overcrowded, understaffed reform schools for delinquents and replacing them with communitybased work and educational programs, specialized foster care and group homes.

title: Chicago May Delay Busing
description: By a 6-to-3 vote, the Chicago Board of Education on Friday approved a desegregation plan that will postpone any mandatory busing of public school students at least until the fall of 1983. The plan will be sent to Federal District Judge Milton I. Shadur, who is to decide on it next month after the Justice Department responds to it.

title: BIOLOGISTS BEGIN DRIVE TO SAVE A CONDOR FROM EXTINCTION
description: A team of biologists has hurried into the coastal mountains in search of California condors after a program to save the big birds from extinction cleared a final administrative hurdle.

title: NETS SUBDUE CLIPPERS, 113,109
description: Ray Williams connected on a 15-foot jump shot with six seconds remaining and made a pair of free throws with two seconds to go tonight, giving the New Jersey Nets a 113-109 victory over the San Diego Clippers.

title: Woman Held in Son's Slaying
description: A 20-year-old woman was charged yesterday with slaying her 3-yearold son, whose body was found in Riverside Park at 159th Street. According to the police, the woman, Susan Davis of 596 West 152d Street near Broadway, had led detectives to the body of the boy, Kenny. The police said Miss Davis told them she had strangled her son with a scarf Friday night after becoming upset over an argument with a male friend.

title: MINNESOTA PARALYZED BY RECORD 37-INCH SNOWFALL
description: Snowstorms brought activities throughout Minnesota to a virtual halt today. Strong winds following the 37 inches of snow that has fallen since Wednesday severely reduced visibility, hampered road-plowing efforts and kept most Minnesotans in their homes.

title: FOR TOMMY AT 13, NO NEW FREEDOMS
description: TWELVE ... going on 13 ... becoming a teen-ager. We can all probably recall the inner excitement and ambivalent feelings that we experienced at the prospect: Physical changes, anticipation of new freedoms, going to high school, more-difficult studies, sports, dating, driving.

title: Around the Nation; First Group of Cubans Leaves Arkansas Center
description: A bus carrying 60 Cubans left the refugee relocation center here at daybreak today in the first of a series of transfers to prison facilities in Atlanta and Springfield, Mo.

title: JERSEYAN RECANTS STORY IN MURDER CONVICTIONS OF 3
description: A Bridgeton man whose testimony was crucial in co nvicting three persons of murdering a gas-station attendant has recanted his story, saying that his only link to the scene of the crime may have been in a drug-induced ''vision.''

title: Pamela and Anne Stern Will Be Brides
description: Mr. and Mrs. Marvin A. Stern of Passaic, N.J., have announced the engagements of their daughters, Pamela Wynne Stern and Anne Carole Stern, to Lance Stuart Rozsa and Harmon Greenblatt.

title: Sports of the Times; GRACIOUS WASTELAND
description: PONTIAC, Mich. A FTER 15 years, a note of sanity has been heard in the endless, yawning week before the Super Bowl. In past years, a myth was allowed to grow, like some festering monster in a science fiction movie (The Pigskin That Held America Hostage), that the Super Bowl game was a test of character of the two teams.

title: Music: Debuts in Review
description: Karyl Louwenaar's harpsichord recital Wednesday at the Abraham Goodman House pursued a conventional course for most of its duration before erupting in a welcome flash of excitement at the end. A pair of Scarlatti sonatas, Bach's Partita No. 4 and four pieces by Rameau made up the bulk of the program, and these were performed fluently and sensibly by Miss Louwenaar, who teaches at Florida State University in Tallahassee.

title: THOMAS HOLLAND, UNION CHIEF
description: Thomas Holland, executive director of the union that represents corrections officers in New York State, was killed Wednesday night when his car struck a tree on the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway near Kingston. He was 53 years old and lived in Hopewell Junction, N.Y.

title: Margaret Ford Bride of E. L. Cosgrove
description: Margaret Catherine Ford, assistant city editor of The Day in New London, Conn., was married there yesterday to Emmet Lawrence Cosgrove, a New York lawyer. The nondenominational ceremony was performed in the Harkness Chapel at Connecticut College by the Rev. David Robb, the college chaplain.

title: A LOOK AT THE MORAL MAJORITY
description: WHEN first setting eyes on the Thomas Road Baptist Church, the Lynchburg, Va., home of the controversial Rev. Jerry Falwell and headquarters of the Moral Majority, an out-of-towner cannot help but be impressed.

title:
Gardening;
BIRCH SPECIES THAT OFFER DIVERSITY
description: LAST week we discussed birches in the landscape and enumerated their problems and weaknesses. Although attractive and useful, their inability to adapt to hot, dry summers and their susceptibility to leaf miner and bronze-headed birch borer shorten their lifespan and limit their value.

title: Joan Murtagh To Be Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Martin J. Murtagh of Rye, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Joan Patricia Murtagh, to Joseph Hugh Marren, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard D. Marren of White Plains.

title: Major News in Summary; Some Static as Reagan Readies For Big Speech
description: As the struggle between Ronald Reagan's instincts and his advisers' calculations wore on last week, tw o things be came almost perfectly clear. First, to an extraordinary degree for an Administration that swore by ''Cabinet government,'' planning tak es place in a tight inner circle. Second, in looking for an escap e hatch from one ideological trap - how to make tax increases palatable to a supplyside President - the Administration may be digging another - a new ''new federalism'' involving a Federal-st ate swap of dollars and programs that could punch more holes in Mr. R eagan's frayed safety net.

title: Choice Films on TV
description: 'Ruggles of Red Gap' For something disarming and different in the field of gentle satire, catch Leo McCarey's ''Ruggles of Red Gap'' (1935), showing Tuesday at midnight on Channel 13. In this fond, funny serving of Americana, an imported British butler reluctantly, then proudly adjusts to the crude but hearty spirit of a turn-of-the-century frontier town. A sporting cast headed by Charles Laughton in the title role, Charles Ruggles (no connection with the title), Mary Boland, Leila Hyams, ZaSu Pitts and the leathery Maude Eburne, perform winningly under McCarey's flavorsome direction.

title:
Dining Out;
THE SEASONS- ON THE WATERFRONT
description: MR. B's is a most attractive addition to county dining places. Open since early last month, the restaurant occupies the site of the old Washington Arms and the more recent Lil's. We have always thought it odd that restaurants bordering Mamaroneck Harbor and Park have not taken full advantage of that interesting and beautiful prospect. But from almost anywhere in Mr. B's (for Mr. Walter Bodenstein's) bilevel dining room - reminiscent of a luxury liner - diners can enjoy the changing seasons through the curving wall of windows that wrap around almost half the restaurant - snow drifting under street lamps, famous pink cherry blossoms blooming in the lush park, bustling harbor, dazzling autumn foliage.

title: BENGALS ON DEFENSE
description: Defensive Line 73 Eddie Edwards LE 6-5 253 5 Miami (Fla.). A starter since rookie season and effective pass rusher who had 10 sacks; he missed last three games of the regular season. 75 Wilson Whitley NT 6-3 265 5 Houston. Once the team began winning he became a more interested participant. He won Lombardi Award as top college lineman. He is sometimes replaced by Gary Burley on passing downs. 79 Ross Browner RE 6-3 261 4 Notre Dame. Like Edwards and Whitley a first-round draft choice realizing his potential; he had six tackles, three assists and a fumble recovery against the Chargers. Others: 72 Mike St. Clair; 67 Gary Burley; 71 Rod Horn. Linebackers 53 Bo Harris LOLB 6-3 226 7 Louisiana State. Like so many other Bengals he has experienced his best season; had a sack against Chargers. 55 Jim LeClair LILB 6-3 234 10 North Dakota. For the seventh straight season, he had highest team total of solo tackles and assists. 50 Glenn Cameron RILB 6-2 228 7 Florida. A steady veteran, who may have trouble against 49ers' intricate passing schemes. 57 Reggie Williams ROLB 6-0 228 6 Dartmouth. Led team in sacks with 11. When Bengals choose to blitz, which isn't often, he is the choice. Others: 49 Guy Frazier; 51 Rick Razzano; 59 Jeff Schuh; 52 Tom Dinkel. Defensive Bac kfield 34 Louis Bree den LCB 5-11 195 4 N. Carolina Central. Well-respecte d corner in his second season as a starter; he returned a pass interc eption 102 yards for a touchdown during the season. 13 Ken Riley RCB 6-0 183 13 Florida A.& M. Opponent pass ers prefer to stay away from Riley; he had five interceptions in the regular season. 26 Bobby Kemp SS 6-0 186 R California-Fullerton.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Quartet Montage Gives 'Quartet' by Messiaen
description: Quartet Montage, four young musicians operating out of New York and Philadelphia, mixed music for violin, cello, clarinet and piano Friday night at Carnegie Recital Hall. Nancy Bean, Jonathan Spitz and Christopher Sanborn played a Haydn Trio in F for violin, cello and piano; Cheryl Hill's clarinet joined Mr. Spitz and Mr. Sanborn in Brahms's A minor Trio; and all were together in Messiaen's ''Quartet for the End of Time.''

title: Ideas and Trends; More on Coffee And Pregnancy
description: Of that favorite morning wake-me-up - a cup of coffee and a cigarette -it's mother's smoking, not coffee drinking, that can endanger an unborn baby's health, scientists at Harvard University reported last week.

title: Westchester Guide; REMBRANDT RECALLED
description: Nanette Salomon, lecturer at the Metropolitan Museum of Art and at the State University of New York College at Purchase, will speak on ''Rembrandt's Contribution in His Time and After,'' from 9:30 to noon Saturday in the Humanities Building on the college's campus. Her talk will relate to the exhibition opening next Sunday in the college's Neuberger Museum, tracing the impact of Rembrandt's graphics from the 17th century to the present. Ten works by Rembrandt will be accompanied by graphics of those artists whom he influenced, including Goya, Millet, Whistler, Degas, Matisse and Picasso.

title: LONDON
description: To the Editor:

title: PROTESTS ARE PLANNED ON OCEAN DUMPING
description: LONG BRANCH AN AD HOC committee of environmentalists and commercial fishermen, led by Greenpeace, the Boston-based marine-conservation organization, began laying plans last week for what it said would be a major protest against the Federal Government's approval of renewed waste dumping in the Atlantic Ocean.

title: The World; British Miners Settle for Less
description: Britain's coal miners last week pulled the rug out from under their militant president-elect, Arthur Scargill, and handed a crucial victory to Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. By a vote of 113,144 to 91,477, they accepted a Government offer of a 9.3 percent raise, rejecting their leaders' call for a strike authorization.

title: 'SOAPS' UPDATED BY PHONE
description: NOT all advertising innovations come from Madison Avenue. The latest in telephone marketing is being pioneered by a Danbury advertising studio.

title: 3 Parties in India Uniting
description: Three centrist groups have decided to merge and form a new party to challenge Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, former Industry Minister George Fernandes said Friday. The three groups are the Janata Party, Lok Dal and the Rump Congress.

title: Ideas and Trends; Columbia Goes Its Coed Way
description: Columbia College, the last male bastion of the Ivy League, has been waiting impatiently to be stormed. ''The school will become a coeducational institution,'' Michael I. Sovern, Columbia University's president, said several months ago.

title: U.S. COOL TO GIVING MORE POLES VISAS
description: The Reagan Administration has chosen not to encourage the 50,000 Poles who have flooded Austrian refugee centers to come to the United States, according to a high American official.

title: Rachel Helfand To Be April Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Helfand of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Rachel Helfand, to William Balter Frankel, son of Ethel Rankel of New York and the late Bennett Frankel.

title: INFLUENCE AND NUMBERS SWELL NEW WAVE IN HISPANIC POLITICS
description: Driving home from Albany one day, Assemblymen William F. Passannante of Manhattan and Jose E. Serrano of the Bronx made a wrong turn and found themselves on a Bronx side street.

title: BAVASI STILL TALKING OF YANK TRADE
description: Buzzie Bavasi, executive vice president of the California Angels, said yesterday that ''we are going to make a trade with the Yankees.'' But he denied that the trade would involve collusion to compensate the Yankees because they had lost Reggie Jackson to the Angels in the free-agent market.

title: THE ENVELOPE THAT DIDN'T SAY 'OCCUPANT'
description: THERE must be a law saying that you can't fit 500 cubic inches of tightly packed material into 400 square inches of space. If so, I wish someone would tell my mail carrier.

title: Business Conditions; LITTLE MIRTH FOR STEEL
description: Although fourth-quarter earnings of major domestic steelmakers are just beginning to trickle in, and are showing mixed results, continued weak demand in the key auto and nonresidential constructionmarkets gives little room for optimism.

title: Headliners; Preventive Medicine
description: Asked about his selection by the Reagan Administration last week to serve as director of the National Institutes of Health, Dr. James B. Wyngaarden took his pulse. ''Sometimes I wake up feeling very excited about the new job,'' he said, ''other times I wake up feeling very melancholy about having to leave Duke.'' Dr. Wyngaarden, chairman of Duke University's department of medicine and a faculty member since 1956, succeeds Dr. Donald S. Fredrickson as head of the N.I.H., which funds most of the nation's research in life sciences. A specialist in metabolic disease, especially gout, and co-author of a medical classic, ''The Metabolic Basis of Inherited Diseases,'' Dr. Wyngaarden must protect the agency from unnecessary surgery on its $3.5 billion budget.

title: MR. REAGAN'S PENCHANT FOR DEFECTIVE SOLUTIONS
description: To the Editor:

title: Speaking Personally; GARAGE SALE: IS IT WORTH THE TRAUMA?
description: IF SIGMUND FREUD had ever been to a garage sale, he undoubtedly would have had a field day, even though someone probably would have bought his couch right out from under him. Human nature at its best - and worst - is on display in these suburban rituals.

title:
Camera;
PRESERVING VALUED BLACK-AND-WHITE PRINTS
NATO SEES DECLINE IN POLAND
description: The NATO allies said here today that the situation in Poland had worsened and that sanctions against Poland and the Soviet Union might be imposed ''in the immediate future.''

title: Long Islanders; The 'Dear Abby' Of Medical Students
description: TO understand why Dr. Naomi Bluestone of Great Neck is newly in print as the author of ''So You Want to Be a Doctor?'' it helps to have a quick genealogical and biographical sketch.

title: Major News in Summary; 'Linkage' Revived Over Poland
description: The Reagan Administration last week turned a new cold shoulder to Moscow. Geneva talks scheduled for Tuesday and Wednesday between Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. and Soviet Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko were cut back to just Tuesday. More importantly, Mr. Haig, instead of setting a date to resume strategic arms limitation negotiations, will focus on Moscow's role in Poland's military crackdown. Arms talks, the State Department said, ''cannot be insulated from other events.''

title: THE TEXT AND THE TRUTH
description: THE REALISTIC IMAGINATION English Fiction from Frankenstein to Lady Chatterley. By George Levine. 357 pp. Chicago: The University of Chicago Press. $25.EVEN the title of this rich and provocative book says a good deal about the range and authority of its claims: Realism and Frankenstein? Lady Chatterley? Inside we find other surprises: discussions of Sir Walter Scott, Charles Dickens, Joseph Conrad, Thomas Hardy, Emily Bronte as realists. Of course George Levine is fully aware of the conventional lineup of realists in English fiction - Jane Austen, William Makepeace Thackeray, Anthony Trollope, George Eliot - and he gives them full attention. But, alert to the slipperiness of the term and the tradition (''All writers believe they are realists,'' says Alain Robbe-Grillet), he is less interested in rehearsing the cliched characteristics of a school of writing than in investigating the urgent, ingenious, often heroic attempts by writers to overcome artificial conventions and make some connection between the text and what is ''out there.'' Mr. Levine argues that the great Victorian realists were fully aware that conventions could be replaced only by other conventions, and that they were struggling to get at the ''true'' by means of structures and plots demonstrably unreal and by means of a language dangerously distanced from the ''real.''

title: The World; The Elephant That Roared
description: India's democracy stepped on a thorn last week as the Government resorted to mass arrests and police shootings to curb a 24-hour strike by millions of union members. At least 10 people were killed in clashes with Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's Congress Party supporters and the police.

title: ROOSEVELT'S HOME DAMAGED BY FIRE
description: A fire raced through the birthplace of Franklin D. Roosevelt this morning, destroying much of a 75-foot section of the roof and damaging several bedrooms in the oldest part of the historic 35-room mansion.

title: Crafts
description: LAWRENCEVILLE FOR an exhibit entitled ''Valley Reflections,'' Chris Craig has transformed fragments of nature into handmade box-like sculptures of paper. These are among the 22 works by this artist that will be on view through Friday at the Rider College Student Center Art Gallery.

title: DARK FORCES, TAINTED BLOOD AND A GRIM FAMILY FATE
description: THE VOICES OF THE DEAD By Autran Dourado. Translated by John M. Parker. 248 pp. New York: Taplinger Publishing Co. $10.95.

title:
Comment;
MA BELL'S MYTHS
description: D URING the past two weeks we have seen how a powerful corporate public relations campaign prepares consumers to have their pockets picked. It may cost consumers dearly, if they are forced, unjustifiably, to pay for the proposed breakup of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, in the form of high local telephone bills.

title: Best Sellers
description: Jx FICTION 1 1 14 AN INDECENT OBSESSION, by Colleen McCullough. (Harper & Row, $13.50.) A nurse and her charges in a special-care ward of a World War II hospital. 2 2 19 THE HOTEL NEW HAMPSHIRE, by John Irving. (Dutton/Henry Robbins, $15.50.) Life with an eccentric family. 3 3 38 NOBLE HOUSE, by James Clavell. (Delacorte, $19.95.) A British-Chinese struggle for control of one of Hong Kong's oldest trading houses. 4 6 11 NO TIME FOR TEARS, by Cynthia Freeman. (Arbor House, $14.95.) A dauntless woman leads her family from Czarist Russia to Palestine to New York's diamond center. 5 8 10 SPRING MOON, by Bette Bao Lord. (Harper & Row, $14.95.) Tradition and revolution in modern China seen through the life of an upper-class family. 6 10 14 RABBIT IS RICH, by John Updike. (Knopf, $13.95.) Harry Angstrom of ''Rabbit, Run'' returns in the chips but unfulfilled. 7 11 12 REMEMBRANCE, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $14.95.) An Italian princess, in quest of romance, finds frustration, then fulfillment in America.

title: TV View; TWO SPECIALS LOOK BACK ON THE ROOSEVELT YEARS
description: The 100th anniversary of Franklin Delano Roosevelt's birth is next Saturday, and television is getting an opportunity to flex its retrospective history muscles. Dipping into just about every available film and newsreel archive, several broadcasters will be offering extensive re-creations and contemporary reviews of the Roosevelt years that began when he first entered the White House in 1933 and ended, in the midst of an unprecedented fourth Presidential term, when he died in 1945.

title: Matthew Hogan Weds Kristine Louise Kehoe
description: Kristine Louise Kehoe and Matthew Paul Hogan were married yesterday in a Quaker ceremony at the Friends Meeting House in Syracuse. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph N. Kehoe of West Winfield, N.Y. Her father is owner of the Remtico Business Machine Company in Utica and Mrs. Kehoe is a retired school nurse.

title: TOWNS, VILLAGES POINT TO MONEY AS MAJOR NEED
description: THE other day, Lowell J. Tooley, Village Manager of Scarsdale, was asked to describe the main concerns of local government. ''Money,'' he replied, with a little smile. It was a succinct answer and one repeated in many ways by other town and village officials in Westchester, many of whom are working on new budgets for the fiscal year that starts June 1. Money-related issues are expected to figure in the village elections on March 16 and, with Federal and state governments continuing to freeze or propose cutbacks in revenues to local governments, the officials have intensified their search for new sources of funds.

title: BRITONS OUTRAGED OVER 3 RAPE CASES
description: Several unrelated cases of rape have aroused a growing controversy in Britain in the past two weeks, fueling a debate among women's organizations, legal groups and Parliament.

title: THE DARK SIDE OF WALL ST. WEST
description: DENVER A S oil, gas and mineral development throughout the Rocky Mountain states has boomed, so has Denver, and the forest of sleek new skyscrapers that rise against the jagged mountains to the West are a symbol not only of the city's prosperity, but its growing role as a bustling financial center.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Jaime Bolipata Gives Romantic Piano Bill
description: Jaime Bolipata, a pianist from the Philippines studying at Juilliard, played Brahms, Debussy and Chopin last Sunday afternoon at Carnegie Recital Hall. Mr. Bolipata handles the Romantic style of pianism very well -with articulate fingers, a booming sound and genuinely musical instincts. At the beginning of Brahms's early F minor Sonata, his fortissimos fairly battered the piano to its knees, but the Andante espressivo that followed was simply and gracefully played.

title: SECRET F.D.R. RECORDINGS ADD UP TO LESS THAN 'DIRTY TRICKS'
description: To the Editor:

title: 'SHIELD LAWS' PROTECT PRESS SOURCES- IN MOST CASES
description: On Aug. 4, 1978, M.A. Farber, a reporter for The New York Times, was jailed in Hackensack, N.J., for contempt of court. He and his newspaper had refused court orders to turn over documents detailing what they knew about the case of a surgeon, Doctor X, charged with murdering patients at a small osteopathic hospital 13 years earlier. As the jail doors slammed shut on Mr. Farber, many lawyers and journalists shuddered at what it meant for the press. They feared that the Farber decision would encourage others to demand reporters' unpublished notes and records, scaring away sources who would reveal wrong-doing only if their identities could be kept secret. Last week, in one of his last acts as Governor of New Jersey, Brendan T. Byrne pardoned Mr. Farber and The Times and remitted $101,000 of the $286,000 in fines the newspaper had paid. The journalists' purpose, Mr. Byrne explained, ''was not to insult or frustrate the judicial process, but to stand on a noble, if sometimes imperfect, principle.'' Those who had supported the reporter and the newspaper, however, were already breathing more easily. A review of cases over the last three years shows no sharp increase in the number of reported incidents in which journalists were forced to disclose their sources or were jailed for not doing so. Twenty-six states now have statutory protections for newsmen, and some, New York among them, have strengthened their ''shield laws.'' Among states without shield laws, several courts have ruled in favor of reporters. This turn of events, say legal experts, rests in part on the specific circumstances of the Farber case, where the issues of press freedom were colored by the fact that the reporter's investigation of the unsolved deaths of patients at the Riverdell Hospital in Oradell, N.J., had prodded the county prosecutor to reopen the matter. Accusations of collaboration between journalists and law enforcement officers have not figured prominently in other courtroom battles between the Sixth Amendment rights of defendants to a fair trial and the First Amendment rights of the press. The courts, themselves, have helped shift the legal climate in favor of the press, generally insisting that defense attorneys must vigorously seek alternative sources of information before they can demand the notes of newsmen. In a major ruling in 1980, for example, a Federal Appeals Court in Philadelphia affirmed a reporter's ''qualified privilege'' not to disclose unpublished information, although it allowed that defendants in a fraud case involving fast-food franchises might be entitled to some ''outtakes'' - footage not broadcast - from a CBS ''60 Minutes'' program on the subject. In a more explicit commentary last year, the appellate court instructed the trial judge to release only footage that was material to defense efforts to impeach the testimony of prosecution witnesses. In the years since the Farber case, New Jersey has rewritten its shield law and the State Supreme Court has upheld it in a decision widely read as an acknowledgement that its 1978 decision, affirming the contempt finding, went too far. ''To all confidential sources,'' the court said, ''the promise of silence is absolute, and any breach is a total one.'' To compel a reporter's testimony would destroy the ''free flow o f information,'' the court concluded. Not all such cases have ended with as clearcut a judgment in favor of press protections. In September 1980, Ellen Marks, a reporter for the Idaho Statesman in Boise, was ja iled for a day and her paper was fined $36,000 when they refused tote ll a magistrate how Miss Marks had found a woman whose former hu sband had charged her with kidnapping their child. The case againstth e reporter became meaningless when the parents reconciled. But it is not meaningless for Miss Marks, who in a recent article for the So ciety of Professional Journalists wrote: ''We all pay in a co mmunity where the line between law enforcement and the media is bl urred, and where reporters are punished for being reporters.'' Lastwe ek, a Superior Court judge in California ruled the state's tw oyear-old shield law unconstitutional. The judge said the rights ofa criminal defendant are simply stronger than those of the press. Libel Cases as Pressure Points While the criminal cases involving journalists tend to grab the headlines, the issue of compelling a reporter's testimony may be developing more rapidly on the civil side, particularly in libel cases, where press defenses are weakest. The Supreme Court opened wide the civil suit door in 1978, in the case of a Green Beret colonel, Anthony Herbert, versus ''60 Minutes.'' The Court said that because libel plaintiffs who are public figures must prove malicious intent, they must be given access to the information reporters and editors had gathered for the article or broadcast in question. In 1980, the New Hampshire Supreme Court took the High Court's reasoning one step further, striking down the libel defense of The Concord Monitor by ruling that if the paper would not reveal its sources, it should be presumed not to have any. Libel litigation has raised other seemingly quirky issues, such as who constitutes a confidential source. A nightclub owner in Babylon, L.I., for example, is suing The Babylon Beacon, a local weekly, over an anonymous letter to the editor criticizing the bar. The nightclub owner has demanded the name of the letter writer. The newspaper owners, citing shield law protections, have lost the first round of court action, Still, several observers see Governor Byrne's pardon last week as the ultimate vindication of press principles. In a letter to the Governor, Floyd Abrams, the lawyer who began seeking pardon more than a year ago, observed: ''Journalists generally believe, and in this case firmly believed, that only by protecting their sources could they serve their country as well as their profession. That they do not always prevail, that they did not prevail in the Farber case itself, should not lessen the recognition that the 'crime' committed here was one committed with regret, in good faith and out of a sense of honor.''

title: RILEY, THE GRAND OLD BENGAL
description: This time Ken Riley's mother is going to keep an eye on him. Ken Riley's mother? Why, he's 34 years old, the oldest player in the Super Bowl, in his 13th year as a Bengal cornerback. He has been around so long that he played in Crosley Field. That was the Bengals' home in 1969, when he joined them. They were a year old and he was a quarterback out of Florida A.& M.

title: STAGE: DENIS CANNAN'S 'DEAR DADDY'
description: Bernard, the title character in Denis Cannan's ''Dear Daddy,'' presented by the Philadelphia Drama Guild at the Annenberg Center, is an angry old man, a bitterly abusive critic of art, life, marriage and family. Joseph Maher, the excellent American acto r, assumes the very British role as if it were his birthright. M erging with the character, he becomes a man you hate to love. If ther e is any real flaw in Mr. Cannan's malicious and mirthful play , it is that, against all instinct and authorial guidance, we enjoy Bernard tremendously.

title: Design; NEW POMP AMID OLD CIRCUMSTANCES
description: he early decades of this century marked a high point in the design of American country houses . The times were afflu ent. Burgeoning automobile ownership made commuting practical . Prosperous families, many of whom once would have taken up annual residence in grand summer hotels, now sought their country pleas ures year round. And a coterie of notable American architects respon ded with their own classical styles. Their houses offered suffic ient ''European'' grandeur to satisfy the client's aristocratic yearning, yet were small enough to accommodate his essentially d own-to-earth American life style.

title:
Long Island Guide;
FAMILY TOGETHERNESS
description: Getting into subjects ranging from penguins to winter weeds, nature-loving families can engage in some invigorating togetherness this week at both the Theodore Roosevelt Sanctuary in Oyster Bay and the Garvies Point Museum and Preserve in Glen Cove.

title: Westchester Journal
description: DURING preluncheon chit-chat at a recent meeting in White Plains of municipal administrators, County Executive Alfred B. DelBello was delving into his store of historical tidbits. ''There are more trees now in Westchester than there were 100 years ago,'' he told others athis table.

title: Music; BRAZIL CELLO CONTEST WITH A DASH OF YALE
description: IT'S a long, long way to Campos do Jordao, a little resort town about two hours' drive up the mountain and through the fog from Sao Paulo, Brazil, but when I arrived there on Jan. 2 to serve as a judge in the third annual Parisot International Cello Competition, it seemed like New Haven South.

title: VISTA HOTEL BRINGING NEW LIFE TO DOWNTOWN AREA
description: Tucked between the World Trade Center's twin towers, the Vista International Hotel looks like a 23-story tot come to town with a pair of 110-story parents. The 825-room hotel is more than three miles south of the midtown ho tel heartland and almost in a world, or at least a city, of its ow n.

title: Darcy J. Rudder, Teacher, Fiancee
description: Mr. and Mrs. Donald Rudder of Hobe Sound, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Darcy Joy Rudder, to Bradford Bartram Griswold, son of Mr. and Mrs. H. Bridgeman Griswold of Jupiter Island, Fla.

title: U.S. DISAPPOINTED BY PARIS DECISION
description: The French decision not to cut back on the planned purchase of Siberian natural gas was viewed by Reagan Administration officials today with disappointment.

title:
Photography View;
THE SONNEMAN ENIGMA
description: Fortunately, Eve Sonneman's new color photographs have titles written on their mats, because otherwise the viewer might not know what some of them represent. (They may be seen at Castelli Photographs, 4 East 77th Street, through Jan. 30.) There is, for instance, a large photograph of a pink rose whose leaves are covered with something that looks like dried insect spray - or is it glittering drops of dew that are slightly out of focus? It is neither, says the title, it is volcanic ash, presumably deposited by the Mount St. Helens eruption. The juxtaposition of ash and rose is a chilling one, once the viewer knows what he is seeing.

title: Food; SOUPS: THE HEARTY MEALS IN A BOWL
description: IF you want to get vegetables into a child; stretch a pound of stew to serve eight; warm the cockles of your heart for less money than it costs to heat your home, serve soup.

title: Mailbox; The Hero Red Smith
description: To the Sports Editor: When we wer e kids and the inevitable roll call of personal heroes would come up , the one girl who would place Red Smith among such luminaries as the Beatles and Spiderman was regarded as somewhat an odd bird. She never could see why. She was a horse racing enthusiast and the entir e world from rub rag to blanket of roses was intensely alive to her.

title: SWIFT-MOVING 'VICE SQUAD'
description: Because of the pious, precredit note to the effect that all the events we are about to witness are based on fact, and because of the title, which is so lurid that it seems to be recycled for a new picture every few years, you might think that ''Vice Squad'' was going to be just another piece of cheese. It isn't, though the people who produced it might not want that information spread around.

title: ELIZABETH LEYDA BETROTHED
description: Mrs. Paul Leighton Leyda Jr. of Denver, Colo., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Elizabeth Ann Leyda, to O. Waring Mellick Jr., so n of M r. and Mrs. O. Waring Mellick of Greenwich, Conn., and Watch Hill, R . I. An April wedding is planned. The future bride, daughter also of the late Dr. Ledya, graduated in 1979 from the University of Denver, as did her fiance.

title: AMERICANS IN EGYPT RECORD PAST FOR THE FUTURE
description: In this sleepy town on the Nile River, which is surrounded by an astounding wealth of ancient temples and tombs, there is a 51-year-old compound called Chicago House.

title: Washington; REAGAN AND HIS CRITICS
description: Between the first anniversary of his Presidency and his 71st birthday (Feb. 6), Ronald Reagan has been condemned by the Russians as a warmonger, criticized by his allies as a wassailer and battered by the radical conservatives of his own party as a traitor to his own campaign promises.

title: BATTLING OIL PRICES WITH FUEL CO-OPS
description: In a time of strained budgets and freezing weather, local governments need all the ingenuity they can muster to try to outwit upward lurches in oil prices. In the latest innovation, several states - led by Massachusetts - are looking at the advantages of fuel oil cooperatives.

title: HOW TO SUCCEED IN BASKETBALL BY REALLY TRYING
description: RICK MAHORN could not have been blamed if he had decided to forget about basketball and concentrate instead on football after his experiences at Weaver High School in Hartford in the early 1970's.

title: THE WINNING PHILOSOPHY OF BILL WALSH
description: In 1957, Bill Walsh became football coach at Washington Union High School in Fremont, Calif., where the team had lost 26 of 27 games over the previous three seasons. In his second season, the team won a conference championship with a 9-1 record.

title: RECITAL: A BEETHOVEN CANON
description: Beethoven's complete works for piano and cello - five sonatas and three sets of variations - fit very nicely on two programs. For the pieces to succeed individually or as a complete offering, however, the cellist and the pianist who play them must establish a sensitive and balanced partnership and maintain parity on the interpretive front.

title: CAN CAREY BE MORE EFFECTIVE AS A LAME DUCK GOVERNOR?
description: Politicians spend so much time seeking new jobs or trying to hang onto old ones that it is almost always surprising when one of them decides to do neither. Thus Hugh Leo Carey startled New York State just over a week ago with his announcement that he would not seek re-election.

title:
Art;
STILL-LIFE PAINTINGS ARE MAKING A VITAL COMEBACK
description: THE Gallery at Hastings-on-Hudson recently opened the first segment of an innovative three-part exhibition of contemporary realism. This show is devoted to still life in paintings, works on paper and sculpture, and it is really quite wonderful. Succeeding segments of the exhibition are at the Museum Gallery at the White Plains Library, where a show of realist landscapes opened last Sunday, and at the Castle Gallery at the College of New Rochelle, where an exhibition of contemporary figure painting will open today.

title: Eglevsky Will Present Villella's New 'Suite'
description: The Eglevsky Ballet will present the premiere of ''Harlequin Suite'' by Edward Villella, the company's director, in a program Feb. 5, 6 and 7 at the Hofstra Playhouse in Hempstead, L.I.

title: LILCO-BACKED PLANT NEARS P.S.C. RULING
description: THE State Public Service Commission will begin final deliberations this week on whether to permit continued construction of the N ine Mile Point Un it 2 nuclear plant in upstate Oswego County. It will cost Long Isl and Lighting Company customers nearly $1 billion to complete the project, or half a billion to abandon it.

title: WINTER REVELS IN VERMONT
description: W inter carnivals are reappearing in nearly every corner of Vermont after a lapse of several decades, with activities ranging from icecutting festivals and black-tie balls to snow golf, snow volleyball and inner-tube races.

title: CONTRIBUTORS GIVE TO NEEDIEST AS AN EXPRESSION OF GRATITUDE
description: ''So that others may hope, and to thank God for His abundance to my family and friends, I e nclose a check for $5,000 to your fund,'' Robert Brooks of Port Washington, L.I., said in note accompanying a gift to The N ew York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: 49ERS ON DEFENSE
description: Defensive Line 79 Jim Stuckey LE 6-4 251 2 Clemson. A second-year starter and one of six linemen 49ers rotate in three and four-man fronts. 78 Archie Reese NT 6-3 262 4 Clemson. In the three-man front he is a trouble maker playing over the center's head. Captain of the defense; starter for two seasons at defensive end. 76 Dwaine Board RE 6-5 250 3 North Carolina A&T. Moves to tackle on passing downs with Fred Dean at end for the pass rush. Had seven sacks. Dean, who was acquired during the season from the Chargers, has had 13 sacks. Others: 65 Lawrence Pillers; 74 Fred Dean; 75 John Harty. Linebackers 59 Willie Harper LOLB 6-2 215 8 Nebraska. Enthusiastic and experienced, he had 43 tackles, a sack and a fumble recovery. 64 Jack Reynolds LILB 6-1 232 12 Tennessee. This former Ram has keyed the defense. Led the team in solo tackles and assists. 54 Craig Puki RILB 6-1 231 2 Tennessee. Superior athlete in his first year as starter; he may share time with the more experienced Dan Bunz. 58 Keena Turner ROLB 6-2 219 2 Purdue. When the 49ers wish to risk a blitz they will send Turner; he recovered three fumbles. Others: 52 Bobby Leopold; 53 Milt McColl; 57 Dan Bunz. Defensive Backfield 42 Ronnie Lott LCB 6-0 199 R Southern California. Pro Bowl starter as a rookie. Moves to safety, his college position, in nickel defense. 21 Eric Wright RCB 6-1 180 R Missouri.

title: Joann V. Bonanno Becomes the Bride Of T.B. Walker 3d
description: Joann Virginia Bonanno, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Anthony J. Bonanno of Garden City, L.I., and Thomas Bidwell Walker 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Walker of Dallas, were married yesterday in Manhattan. Msgr. Joseph J. Quinn performed the ceremony in Our Lady of Peace Roman Catholic Church.

title: The Region; Budget Pinch Squeezes Carey
description: It may not have been his parting shot, but the budget Governor Carey proposed last week - his tightest since 1976 - left many in the Legislature feeling wounded.

title: Miss Hawes, Gallery Aide, Darien Bride
description: Barbara Lynn Hawes and Samuel Allen Darlington Vincent were married yesterday at the Noroton Presbyterian Church in Darien, Conn. The Rev. Dr. Lawrence M. Horton, pastor emeritus, performed the ceremony.

title: No Headline
description: To the Editor:

title: WAYNE CLINCH TO WED CAROLYN PATRICIA GAY
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert A. Gay of Roslyn, L.I. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Carolyn Patricia Gay, to Wayne Michael Clinch, son of Mr. and Mr.s James J. Clinch of Westbury, L.I.

title: Regarding Wildlife An d Rifle Organizations
description: We are greatly beholden to you for publishing Alice Herrington's essay, ''Is Hunting Mourning Doves Justified?'' (Dec. 27). For a number of years, we contributed to the National Wildlife Federation, affixing its stamps to our correspondence.

title: No Headline
description: All Joyce Colony has done is to convince me of my own desire to have a wife. But as I am one myself, I find myself resenting her image of the homemaker only in wifely terms. Isn't it really a maid that we all want? A devoted servant to cook that spaghetti sauce while we fulfill ourselves elsewhere - either in the garden, at the typewriter or in the marketplace? BARBARA H. PIERCE, Salt Point, N.Y.

title: Crime
description: Ted Allbeury's THE OTHER SIDE OF SILENCE (Scribner's, $11.95) is a spy story with a difference. Seizing upon the imaginative idea that the British defector Kim Philby might have requested to live out his last few years in England, Mr. Allbeury has probed into the available facts about Philby's career as a spy, his youth, his motivations, his philosophy, his psychological problems.

title: THE BOOKS OF SPRING '82
description: IN book publishing, spring magically starts at the end of January and runs past the summer solstice, and decisions about what will be published in that time have usually been made several years in advance. Therefore, I asked some top editors and publishers who are already deciding what we will be reading a few years hence how the future of publishing is shaping up for that eventual judge of all the writers' efforts and publishers' editorial meetings: the American reader.

title: Dining Out; A MENU THAT PROMISED TOO MUCH
description: KWONG MING in Wantagh is for nostalgia buffs. It serves the kind of Chinese food you may remember from 25 years ago. The restaurant is rooted in the pre-Sichuan-Hunan era of Chinese dining, when Levittown was young and no one owned a wok. This is not to imply that Chinese cooking must be spicy to be good, but that Chinese food has become more s ophisti cated and authentic in recent years.

title: Figures Reversed On Regional Plan Chart
description: I want to thank you for the excellent article on the Second Regional Plan (''Growing Imbalance of Jobs, Housing Worries Planners in Lower Fairfield County,'' Jan. 3). It has engendered a great deal of interest and we are very grateful for your help in publicizing the plan.

title: Wadkins Shoots 63-198 and Leads by 4
description: Under flawless conditions, Lanny Wadkins wrung an eight-under-par 63 from the golf course of the Phoenix Country Club today and took a four-stroke lead after the third round of the Phoenix Open XLVII. His card included a hole-in-one eagle, eight birdies - four of them consecutively - and two bogeys.

title: Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt LIFE AFTER MARRIAGE. Love in an Age of Divorce. By A. Alvarez. 269 pages. Simon & Schuster. $14.50.

title: Cozza to Receive Sheehan Award
description: Carmen Cozza, whose Yale football team won nine games and lost one and tied Dartmouth for the Ivy League title last season, has been named winner of the 14th annual Joseph M. Sheehan Award, presented by the New York Football Writers Association to the major college coach of the year in the East.

title: Thai Police Said to Rout Forces of a Smuggler
description: A battle that began Thursday between Thai border police and forces of Khun Sa, a man described by the authorities as an opium smuggler, continued today with the police asserting that they had routed several hundred of his troops with attacks by helicopter gunships and light bombers. Skirmishes were said to be continuing near the border in Chiangrai Province.

title: India Loan Package To Be Cut
description: The World Bank intends to reduce the amount of low-interest loans that India receives from the agency because of cutbacks in contributions from donor nations.

title: SHELTON SOARING WITH SONICS
description: The Lonnie Shelton Knick fans knew used to foul excessively and often picked up technical fouls when he objected to the calls. That player is gone.

title: Victory Stirs S an Franciscans
description: Within a half-hour after the Super Bowl ended, thousands of exuberant San Franciscans choked the streets, blaring horns, waving pennants and raising their index fingers as a symbol that they, at last, were No.1.

title: Robert Higginbotham, Singer Of Blues and Jazz, Dead at 48
description: Robert Higginbotham, a blues and jazz singer who performed under the name Tommy Tucker, died Friday at College Hospital in Newark. Mr. Higginbotham, who lived in East Orange, N.J., was 48 years old.

title: Carolina County Sets Up Fund to Assist Its Poor
description: Community leaders in heavily Democratic Montgomery County took the suggestion of President Reagan and organized a nonprofit corporation to raise money for neighbors in difficulty because of cuts in Federal aid.

title: WHEN TV SETS BECOME TD SETS
description: At 4:21 P.M., this Westchester County suburb looked as if it had been hit by a neutron bomb. There were no signs of outdoor life on block after block, perhaps the only waking hour of the year when this will be so.

title: WORKERS AT ROOSEVELT HOME FIND FIRE SPARED MOST ITEMS
description: Amid charred and soaked debris and an omnipresent smell of smoke, preservationists and museum specialists gathered today at the birthplace of Franklin D. Roosevelt to assess the damage and salvage the remains of the fire that ruined a large section of the 35-room house Saturday.

title: Europe, Japan May Cut Rate
description: Leading West European countries and Japan, apparently abandoning hopes for American action, have agreed to stimulate their economies by reducing interest rates, European monetary sources report.

title: SOVIET PUBLISHERS SCATHING ATTACK ON ITALIAN PARTY
description: After years of mounting tension that was brought to a head by events in Poland, the Soviet Union today delivered a scathing attack on the leadership of the Italian Communist Party, the largest in the West.

title: SKEPTIC WITH SCRUPLES
description: When President Reagan spoke last w eek of his ''determination to have an open Administration'' - as hisp eople frant ically tried to close everything d own - I thought of a man whose life has been a challenge to such of ficial pieties. He is Louis M. Lyons, who made the Nieman Foundation at Harvard a force for understanding and seriousness in American journalism.

title: U.S. TO LOOK INTO CONTROLLER TESTS
description: Federal officials have opened an inquiry into charges of grade-rigging at the Federal Aviation Administration's air controller academy here, according to a report published in a newspaper today.

title: Nystrom Does Job on Rangers
description: It happened in the catacombs of Nassau Coliseum. Coa ch Herb Brooks was holding forth in a corridor Saturday night on why the Rangers had just dropped a 6-1 decision, when the general manag er of the victorious Islanders, Bill Torrey, walked by.

title: CAR-GLASS SHOP OWNER SEIZED IN SHOOTING OUT OF WINDOWS
description: Night after night, on street after street in a neighborhood of neat two-family homes in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn, car windows have been shot out - more than a thousand in the last few months.

title: Letter: On Vietnam No Time for 'Amateur Diplomats'
description: To the Editor:

title: News Analysis
description: French politics, generally, is the art of the expected, and it takes only a small dose of the unexpected to convulse it.

title: Center on Trauma Resources For U.S. Planned in Phoenix
description: Doctors at a Phoenix hospital have announced plans for a national trauma resource center as a computer-based clearinghouse for information on emergency care.

title: ARCHBISHOP SAYS POLES HAVE RIGHT TO GET THE TRUTH
description: The Roman Catholic Primate of Poland, Archbishop Jozef Glemp, said in a sermon broadcast over national radio today that Poles had the right to honest information in the Government-controlled press and the right to know why they were being deprived of civil liberties.

title: 23 EX-HOSTAGES GATHER ONE YEAR AFTER RELEASE
description: Trees and traffic signs sprouted a fresh crop of yellow ribbons this weekend as 23 of the Americans who were held hostage in Iran gathered for a reunion on the eve of the first anniversary of their return home.

title: CHIEF JUSTICE PROPOSES ARBITRATION TO STEM 'AVALANCHE' OF LAWSUITS
description: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger today urged lawyers to look beyond courtroom litigation as a means of solving disputes and to turn instead to mediation, conciliation and arbitration.

title: THEATER: 'THANKSGIVING'
description: LORETTA LOTMAN'S ''Thanksgiving,'' at the Stonewall Repertory Theater, is a captious, quarrelsome play about a lesbian's homecoming to a traditional Middle Western family.

title: FREEDOM CRUSADES ARE FUTILE
description: As the Administration prepares a worldwide TV s pectacular, ''Let Poland Be Poland,'' to express solidarity with theP oles, some may recall that 25 years ago this winter the E isenhower-Dulles ''Crusade for Freedom'' was sponsoring similar r allies at Madison Square Garden and elsewhere to protest Soviet i ntervention in Hungary.

title: A NEW MEMBER OF THE CONGRESS VS. MR. REAGAN
description: A 33-year-old freshman Congressman from Connecticut cast more votes last year against President Reagan than did any other member of the House.

title: FAILED CREATIONISM
description: To the Editor:

title: JOHNSTONE SCORES TWO IN 4-4 RANGER TIE
description: Washington is last in the Patrick Division, but first in its ability to frustrate the third-place Rangers. Last night at Madison Square Garden, the Capitals seemed to be toying again with the Rangers' self-im age, as they led twice by two goals, relaxe d and let the Rangers move ahead, then gained a 4-4 tie on a goal wit h less than four minutes to play.

title: Market Place; Timber Assets: Luster Fades
description: FORESTRY companies are still drawing attention as acquisition targets, but it is the faster-growing companies with relatively little timber, not the more static companies that grow lots of trees, that are thought to be the best buys. For example Potlatch, which is among the more profitable forestry companies when business is good, has to buy 45 percent of its timber. Yet Potlatch is regarded as a takeover candidate.

title: Death Is Different
description: The Supreme Court continues its earnest, thus far unavailing search for humane ways to mete out capital punishment. Last week's decision in the case of Eddings v. Oklahoma dramatized the uneven progress, and perhaps the futility, of that quest.

title: U.S. Links Drug Trader In Miami to Raul Castro
description: Federal agents and the Dade County police said today that the Government in Cuba had helped a Miami drug trafficker smuggle weapons to leftist guerrillas in South America.

title: Clemson Invited
description: Representatives of Clemson, which finished the season as the nation's No.1-rank ed college football team, have received an invitation to visit wi th President Reagan at the White House Wednesday.

title: 49ers HOLD OFF BENGALS, WIN SUPER BOWL, 26-21
description: Showing a disrespect for football traditions, the San Francisco 49ers had fun in Super Bowl XVI today. They defeated the Cincinnati Bengals, 26-21, in an often dramatic game that was the first Super Bowl appearance for either team.

title: MONDAY, JANUARY 25, 1982; The Economy
description: The liquor, gasoline and tobacco industries are protesting proposed higher excise taxes, asserting that sales would fall and offset revenue gains. Retailers appear less alarmed, while private economists approve such rises to help cover the projected huge increase in the Federal budget deficit. (Page D1.) Howard H. Baker Jr., Senate majority leader, said it seemed unlikely President Reagan would accept his recommendation for raising taxes on some ''nonessential'' items. (D5.)

title: MUSIC: ELISABETH SOEDERSTROEM SINGS
description: JENNY LIND was known as the ''Swedish Nightingale'' when she came to the United States more than 100 years ago, sponsored by Phineas T. Barnum. Elisabeth Soederstroem has also established a worldwide reputation - despite her having focused her career on her native Sweden - and at her recital yesterday afternoon in Alice Tully Hall she offered two songs associated with the Swedish Nightingale.

title: TIMING OF THE SECOND CHILD
description: Questions about whether, why and when to have a second child are of more than theoretical interest to the 37 million Americans of the immediate postwar baby-boom generation. ''No small number of them are poised on the brink of deciding whether to conceive a second child, or are trying to conceive a second child, or are about to deliver a second child,'' said Pamela Daniels, a research associate at the Wellesley College Center for Research on Women in Wellesley, Mass.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: FOOD FOR THOUGHT

title: Tow Runs Wild, Sinks Barge
description: A owboat went out of control at the juncture of the Mississippi and Ohio rivers Saturday, and rammed another vessel, the Coast Guard said. A construction barge was sunk and the tow was heavily damaged, causing a spill of 500 gallons of diesel fuel. No injuries were reported.

title: A.T.&T. Plan Is Criticized
description: A consumer organization concerned with telecommunications issues has called for rejection of the settlement proposal signed by the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and the Justice Department.

title: Second of two articles.
description: Israel has reportedly warned that it would react with force if Egypt broke agreements on Sinai. Page A4. By LESLIE H. GELB Specia l to the New York Times

title: CONCERT: ST. CECILIA CHORUS
description: EVERY holiday season, David Randolph presents a clutch of ''Messiah'' performances in New York, and nearly every year, those performances are greeted by a critical yawn. For so active a local choirmaster, Mr. Randolph has a decidedly tepid critical reputation. His interpret ations are faulted for mannerism, prosaicness and awkward compr omises between tradition and musicology; his choruses for a lack of force and tonal focus.

title: QUEENS WOMAN SLAIN BY MUGGER NEAR HER HOME
description: A 38-year-old Queens woman walking home along a residential street after a visit to her sister Saturday night was stabbed to death in what the police termed a bungled robbery.

title: Tennis Tourney To T.C.U.'s Tate
description: Unseeded Dave Tate of Texas Christian University defeated eighth-seeded Brad Gilbert of Pepperdine, 6-2, 7-6, to win the Prince indoor intercollegiate singles tennis championship at Jadwin Gym today. Tate won the tiebreaker, 7-4. Georgia's Ola Nalmqvist and Allen Miller defeated Richard Gallien and John Van Nostrand of Pepperdine, 6-3, 3-6, 6-3, in the doubles final.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The people up there, they got hit three times in two weeks.

title: Advertising; Magazines' Struggle With TV
description: IN a move unparalleled in memory, seven major women's service magazines - bitter enemies at best - have joined forces to combat television's advertising power.

title: BRIEFING
description: T HERE seems no end to following some of the most tender advice of Lincoln, carved above the entrance to the Veterans Administration: ''To care for him who shall have borne the battle and for his widow and his orphan.''

title: Pentagon Reports Desertion Reached 14-Year Low in '81
description: Total military desertions and absences without leave dropped in 1981 to the lowest point in 14 years, the Pentagon has reported.

title: Libyan Leader's Visit Takes Tunisian Officials by Surprise
description: Muammar el-Qaddafi, the Libyan leader, met today with Prime Minister Mohammed Mzali and other Government ministers during a surprise visit that apparently embarrassed Tunisian officials.

title: Staley's Profit Plunges 49.5%
description: The A.E. Staley Manufacturing Company reported yesterday that net income in its first quarter, ended Dec. 31, plummeted 49.5 percent, to $16.5 million, or 73 cents a share, from $32.7 million, or $1.48, in the similar period a year earlier.

title: THE FEAR OF BEING 'ON STAGE'
description: T URBULENT stomach, shaky hands, parched throat, wobbly knees, accelerated heartbeat, sweaty palms. The symptoms are familiar to people in love, students before exams, lawyers in courtrooms, athletes before a contest. But performers must confront them night after night, as the first step in building the complex relationship between artist and audience.

title: PLAN TO OPEN PRISON REVIEWS TO PUBLIC IS REJECTED
description: A move to eliminate secrecy and compel public involvement in prison evaluations created a controversy here and was rejected at meetings of the Commission on Accreditation for Corrections. The commission sets the minimum standards of quality and performance for corrections institutions and organizations across the nation.

title: Washington Watch; A Protest Over Tax Increases
description: WASHINGTON THE spirited march across Lafayette Park last Thursday from the headquarters of the United States Chamber of Commerce to the White House represented merely one campaign in the fierce ideological warfare being waged over taxes and the budget deficit.

title: Chinese Contracts
description: Several foreign companies have signed 32 business contracts and agreements worth $160 million for projects on China's Hainan Island, the official New China News Agency reported. The contracts cover projects to develop tropical and subtropical crops, industry and tourism on the island, 300 miles southwest of Hong Kong, the agency said Friday. One project is a 19,760-acre oil palm plantation financed by a Singapore concern, it added.

title: Commodities; Taxing Eurodollar Contracts
description: A POTENTIALLY explosive problem has suddenly developed in the tax treatment of gains and losses in the new Eurodollar futures contracts.

title: News Analysis
description: Two recent court decisions and other disclosures have raised a host of questions about the conduct of Representative Frederick W. Richmond as a public and corporate official.

title: The U.N. Today; Jan. 25, 1982; GENERAL ASSEMBLY
description: Ad Hoc Committee on the Drafting of an International Convention Against the Training of Mercenaries - 3 P.M.

title: 49ERS' SUPER DAY
description: haired coach turned the Silverdome's artificial turf into his own green chalkboard yesterday as the San Francisco 49ers won Super Bowl XVI.

title: GENETIC RESEARCHERS ANXIOUS LEST RARE PLANT TYPES VANISH
description: Could a cotton plant be bred to exude a chemical that repels boll weevils? Could a rare Alpine plant's ability to produce a medicinal compound be transferred to a plant that flourishes in New Jersey soil?

title: NEW YORK BANKS END STRONG
description: For the nation's 15 leading bank holding companies, last year's fourth quarter was the best of times and the worst of times. The best was represented by J.P. Morgan & Company, which earned 94 cents on each $100 of average assets during the quarter. This was the highest quarterly return recorded during the three years in which The New York Times has been compiling such figures. The previous high, 87 cents, also was set by Morgan, in the fourth quarter of 1980.

title: Pedroza Retains Title for 14th Time
description: Eusebio Pedroza of Panama overcame 1-point penalties in two rounds and scored a unanimous decision today over Juan LaPorte of New York, retaining his World Boxing Association featherweight crown. It was his 14th successful defense of the title.

title: Phone Message to Congress
description: For Congress, there's no more keeping the phone company business on ''hold.'' The Reagan Administration's deal with American Telephone and Telegraph makes the long-delayed revision of the Communications Act of 1934 an urgent matter. Three major areas of concern are already obvious.

title: L.I. MAN IS SEIZED IN BEATING OF HIS WIFE'S DIVORCE LAWYER
description: A 38-year-old Long Island man was arrested today and charged with trying to kill his estranged wife's divorce lawyer, the Nassau County polcie said.

title: TV: BERNSTEIN BEGINS SERIES ON BEETHOVEN
description: IN his opening remarks for the series ''Bernstein/Beethoven,'' beginning tonight at 9 on WNET-TV, Leonard Bernstein confesses, ''I have been a compulsive teacher all my lif e,'' but promises that, as far as this project is concerned, he has ''no intention of lecturing you on Beethoven.'' If the flamboyant conduct or-composer seems disconcertingly humble, his admirers should n ot be overconcerned. Note, if you will, who gets top billing in th e title.

title: ICE FISHING DERBY, A HARDY CHALLENGE
description: IF a desire to go ice fishing has stirred within you recently, you might wish to blend it with a weekend outing in New Hampshire and participation in that state's Great Winnipesaukee Fishing Derby Feb. 6 and 7.

title: No Headline
description: Opinions on Roosevelt Are Favorable in Poll

title: SOVIET REBUKES PORTUGUESE FOR EXPULSION OF 2 DIPLOMATS
description: The Soviet Union rebuked Portugal today for expelling two of its diplomats and said the action would have severe consequences on relations between the two countries.

title: 4 Exiled Chileans Banned From Ex-Chief's Funeral
description: The police ousted four exiled Chilean leaders who arived today for the funeral of former President Eduardo Frei Montalva while hundreds of onlookers chanted Down with Pinochet!

title: Debbie Brill Jumps To an Indoor Best
description: Debbie Brill said she didn't feel in top condition and was just plain tired. But the measuring tape indicated she was the best in the world.

title: NEW EPISCOPAL PRIEST, BLACK AND FEMALE
description: The air was sweet with incense and with bluesy gospel songs of a sort not ordinarily sung in the Cathedral of St. John the Devine. Yet the music was fitting for the ordination of Sandra Antoinette Wilson as the first black female priest in the Episcopal Diocese of New York and the fourth in the nation, and that is why she chose it.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Sports World Specials; A & M Whodunit
description: Speculation has been rife in College Station, Tex., over who was responsible for dismissing Tom Wilson and replacing him as head football coach at Texas A & M with Jackie Sherrill, the former coach at Pittsburgh.

title: Armenian Suspect Is Sentenced in France
description: EN-PROVENCE, France, Jan. 24 (Reuters) - A man suspected of being an Armenian guerrilla was sentenced to two years in prison Saturday night for trying to kill the Turkish Ambassador to Switzerland in Bern two years ago. Court officials said the prisoner, Max Kilnajian, a French citizen, would be freed almost immediately because of the amount of time he spent in jail awaiting trial.

title: Strike Halts British Railroad For a Sixth Time in 12 Days
description: Striking locomotive engineers shut down Britain's rail network today for the sixth time in the last 12 days. Managers of British Rail said the state-run railroad might have to close on Sundays voluntarily to save money paid to nonstriking workers.

title: PRODUCERS DENOUNCE A TAX RISE
description: Proposals being debated within the Reagan Administration to increase Federal excise taxes on gasoline, liquor and tobacco have raised a gale of protest from many manufacturers of those products, mild objections from retailers who sell them and a nod of approval from private economists.

title: Edward V. Mallon, 75, Dead; Lawyer for Import Company
description: Edward V. Mallon, a retired Manhattan lawyer who had headed the legal department of the Park & Tilford Import Corporation for 20 years, died Saturday at Mountainside Hospital in Montclair, N.J., after a long illness. He was 75 years old and lived in Montclair.

title: Mary Smart Churba Married to Sanford Kitrosser
description: Mary Smart Churba of Hartsdale, N.Y., daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Smart of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Sanford W. Kitrosser, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Irving Kitrosser of New York. Rabbi Murray Grauer of the Hebrew Institute of White Plains performed the ceremony at the Miss Churba's home.

title: Mrs. Chisholm Weighs Retiring From Congress
description: Representativ e Shirley Chisholm said today that she was ''very politically depress ed'' and did not know ifshe would seek re-election.

title: AVOIDABLE BIRTHS
