description: I was reared a Roman Catholic, and I am intimately familiar with the religious doctrine that preaches protection for the fetus regardless of consequences for woman or child. I have seen its impact on families and women. I have been employed in the social and health field in New York City since 1947 and know the lengths women will go to avoid bearing a child they cannot care for. I know the consequences of illegal, clandestine abortion and of compulsory child-bearing.

title: Play With 2 Characters May Be a Film With 64
description: Jack Gilhooley is a playwright who longs to write movies, and, at first glance, his play, ''The Brixton Recovery,'' would seem an ideal vehicle for a low-budget film.

title: CHARLES CAIN JR.
description: Charles Cain Jr., who retired in 1963 as executive vice president and head of the international department of the Chase Manhattan Bank, died at Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville, N.Y., last Monday. He was 83 years old and lived in Bronxville.

title: A Haig Inaugurated
description: The star of the show at Le Moyne College, in Syracuse, was the Rev. Frank R. Haig, who was inaugurated as the Roman Catholic college's seventh president, so his famous brother kept his own presence as low-key as he could.

title: LIFE IN CHICAGO: 20 DEGREES CAN FEEL WARM ENOUGH TO THAW OUT FROWNS
description: A large patch of velvet white snow came cascading off the ste ep roof of a Mr. Taco restaurant on E ast Walton Place, covering three unsuspecting passers-by with a flour -like coating that turned them ghostly white.

title: Officials Accused by Nyerere Of Being Corrupt and Greedy
description: President Julius K. Nyerere has accused Tanzania's bureaucracy of being corrupt and greedy, The Sunday News, a Government-owned newspaper, reported.

title: CONCERT: THE BALTIMORE SYMPHONY
description: THE concert given by the Baltimore Symphony Orchestra in Carnegie Hall on Saturday night was its second performance after a five-month labor dispute in which the orchestra's board locked out the players. A new contract was agreed upon only two weeks ago.

title: BAKER HAS DOUBTS ON TAX RISE
description: Howard H. Baker Jr., the Senate majority leader, said today it seemed unlikely that President Reagan would accept his recommendation for increasing some excise taxes.

title: Zhou Enlai's Widow Recuperating From Illness
description: She's had a recent stay in the hospital, but Deng Yingzhao, the 78-year-old widow of Zhou Enlai, former Prime Minister of China, is apparently well on her way to recovery.

title: EXPANSION OF CBS NEWS IS RESISTED
description: CONTINUING opposition from CBS-TV's affiliated stations may yet doom the network's plan to expand its evening news from 30 minutes to an hour early next year.

title: U.S. INVESTIGATORS STUDY DC-10 CRASH
description: A team of 10 investigators for the National Transportation Safety Board arrived here this morning to determine why a World Airways DC-10 failed to stop after landing at Logan International Airport Saturday night, breaking in two as it skidded into Boston harbor.

title: Offer for Reagan House
description: Since it came on the market a year ago for $1.9 million, no suitable buyer has been found for President Reagan's former home in Pacific Palisades, Calif.

title: HENRY CLAY WARD
description: Henry Clay Ward, a former president of Holmes Protection Inc., a private security concern, died Friday at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. Mr. Ward, who lived in Great Neck, L.I., and Charlotte, Vt., was 85 years old.

title: Aqueduct Halted After Four Races
description: Racing at Aqueduct was called off yesterday after the fourth race because of poor track conditions, and 13,019 fans were issued passes good for admission on another day.

title: TELEVISION FOR RICH, AND POOR
description: The three major commercial television networks, ABC, C BS, and NBC, who have dominated the United States' viewing habit s ince the 1940's, are slowly backing out of over-the-air b roadcasting.

title: TRIAL OVER ARTICLE ON FORD MEMOIRS BEGINS TODAY
description: Two venerable publishing enterprises, Harper & Row and The Nation magazine, will confront each other in Federal Court this morning over issues that would normally bind them together: free speech and creative freedom.

title: Geraldine Chanin, Teacher, Wed to Herbert L. Sedler
description: Geraldine Klein Chanin, a teacher-trainer in the Manhattan regional office for special education of the New York City Board of Education, was married yesterday to Herbert L. Sedler, president of Paper Enterprises Inc. Rabbi Alan Miller of the Society for the Advancement of Judaism performed the ceremony in Mr. Sedler's Manhattan apartment

title: HOPE HAMPTON, OPERA SINGER AND FIRST-NIGHTER, DIES AT 84
description: Hope Hampton, actress, opera singer and devoted first-nighter, died of a heart attack on Saturday. She was 84 years old. Miss Hampton starred in silent films - 28 of them - and in the 1930's sang with the Philadelphia Grand Opera. In her later years, she worked to sustain her reputation as another kind of performer: an indefatigable first-nighter with a frankly unabashed eye for publicity.

title: Travels of Lemaire
description: At the end of the 1978-79 National Hockey League season, when the Montreal Canadiens had bagged their fourth consecutive Stanley Cup, Jacques Lemaire decided ''I had to go crazy once.''

title: Powers's New Identity
description: Yes, Richard Todd, there is a Richie Powers doing television sports coverage. And, yes, it is the same Richie Powers who over a 22-year stretch became one of the ablest and most respected referees in the National Basketball Association.

title: NO LOW DEDUCTION CAP ON MORTGAGE INTEREST
description: To the Editor:

title: O. William Goepner, of Navy; In Early World War II Attack
description: Capt. O. William Goepner of the Navy, retired, who was believed to have fired the first shot for the United States against the Japanese in World War II, died at home Tuesday of a heart attack. He was 70 years old.

title: AND NOW IN MICHIGAN, RETURN TO REALITY
description: PONTIAC, Mich. FINALLY, at long, long last, it is over. Super Bowl XVI and Super Bowl Week are now a part of history, of some kind. It took three years to plan for the week and, to some here, it seemed that the week lasted three years.

title: WHY U.S. CONSUMERS BUY IMPORTED CLOTHES
description: To the Edito r: I am still shaking my head in disbelief over the statements contained in Jack Werner's letter of Jan. 8 commenting on your recenteditorial ''T he Textile Industry's New Clothes.''

title: Drug Makers Welcome Cold
description: The cold and cough remedy industry laughs at winter, and the extreme cold wave rolling over the nation this winter has infused it with optimism.

title: Harlem Dance Theater Will Honor Lena Horne
description: Lena Horne will receive the Dance Theater o f Harlem's 1982 Emergence Award on Sunday at 7:30 P.M. at the City Center-55th StreetTheater, where the ballet company is performi ng through Feb. 14. The award was created in 1976 to ''celebrate an i ndividual or organization whose public-spirited achievemen ts bring beauty to our world and provide a source of enrichment to a ll humanity.''

title: NEW DUTIES FOR INSILCO'S PRESIDENT
description: Donald J. Harper, 53, president of the Insilco Corporation, a conglomerate based in Meriden, Conn., has been elected to the additional post of chief executive officer, effective at the annual meeting in April. He will succeed Durand B. Blatz, 63, who will continue as chairman.

title: HAIG WILL ASSAIL SOVIET ON POLAND
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. said today that he would tell the Soviet Foreign Minister, Andrei A. Gromyko, of the ''outrage that is felt in my own country and in Western capitals'' at the Soviet involvement in the crackdown in Poland.

title: Dr. Betty E. Herr, Psychiatrist, Is Wed
description: Dr. Betty Ellen Herr, a psychiatrist on the staffs of the Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston and the Mount Auburn Hospital in Cambridge, Mass., was married yesterday to Fredric Jay Hopengarten, president of Channel One Inc. in Lincoln, Mass., distributors of satellite television receiving systems.

title: Challenge at Varityper
description: The new president of the Varityper division of the financially troubled AM International, Joseph A. Verderber, knows that he has his work cut out for him.

title: Bates Leads Blazers Over Celtics, 123-119
description: Billy Ray Bates scored 16 of his season-high 26 points in the fourth quarter today, leading Portland to a 123-119 victory over the Boston Celtics that snapped the Trail Blazers' losing streak at three games. It was the first time this season that the Celtics, who were beaten by the Seattle SuperSonics Friday night, have lost two straight games.

title: Another Mayor Asserts P.L.O.  Should Recognize the Israelis
description: The Mayor of Gaza, Rashad Shawa, echoed a call today for the Palestine Liberation Organization to recognize Israel. He told the Israel radio in an interview that he agreed with the position outlined last week by his Palestinian colleague, Mayor Elias Frej of Bethlehem.

title: POP: POLICE, ENGLISH TRIO AT GARDEN
description: EXCEPT for the Rolling Stones' appearances here last fall, no other rock event in the last year has aroused such high expectations as the arrival of the Police, the English trio that was at Madison Square Garden on Friday. Augmented for their tour by three South Jersey horn players who call themselves the Chops Horns, the Police put on one of the most exciting arena concerts that this observer has seen in a long time.

title: Measles Cases at New Low, With Total Down 77% in Year
description: A record low of 3,032 cases of measles were reported in the United States last year, down 77 percent from the previous low, reached in 1980, according to the national Centers for Disease Control.

title: Poland Makes Debt Payments
description: Walter B. Wriston, chairman of Citibank, acknowledged publicly yesterday that Poland had recently paid his bank some of the interest due in 1981 on the country's debt.

title: U.S. Share of Revenue Of Private Colleges Up
description: Private colleges and universities got one-sixt h of all their revenue from the Federal Government in 1980, anew survey re ports.

title: 49ers ARE STANDOUTS ON GOAL LINE STAND
description: Coach Bill Walsh and his San Francisco 49ers seemed to disagree only on the key play of their 26-21 Super Bowl victory today over the Cincinnati Bengals.

title: Power Failure Starts Jail Riot
description: Inmates at the Santa Rita Rehabilitation Center here threw stones at guards, broke down compound fences and set fires Saturday night, the authorities said. An Alameda County Sheriff's officer blamed a temporary power failure for the riot. Police from nearby towns were c alled to patrol to prevent escapes.

title: SEMINAR TO AIR DANCE TROUPE PROBLEMS
description: ''How to Be a Dance Company and Live Through the 80's,'' a two-day seminar, will be held Friday and Saturday at the New York Hilton. Edward Villella will be the keynote speaker.

title: Prism Theater Troupe Staging 2 One-Acters
description: The Prism Theater Company will present ''Sheepskin'' and ''Bottom of the Ninth,'' two one-act plays by Victor L. Cahn, directed by Victor Argo, Feb. 4 at the Perry Street Theater, 31 Perry Street in Greenwich Village. Previews will begin Saturday.

title: MEMORY OF WAR AND SURVIVAL LEADS SOME TO HELP NEEDIEST
description: Memories of World War II and the freedom that its end brought to imprisoned American servicemen and survivors of Nazi Germany's concentration camps are often recalled by donors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: FEW SURVIVE
description: As Congress ends its long vacation, it returns to face stacks and stacks of unpassed bills and resolutions that, laid end to end, would stretch nearly a mile and a half, from the Capitol to the Washington Monument.

title: THE I.R.S.'S MANDATE ON RACIAL DISCRIMINATION
description: To the Editor:

title: Virginia Beats Louisville
description: Ralph Sampson led a 10-3 spurt at the beginning of the second half that carried Virginia to a 74-56 victory over Louisville today.

title: Poland Criticizes Conference
description: Poland has prot ested Western plans to discuss its internal problems during the East -West Conference on Security and Cooperation next month, the East German press agency said today. The agency said that Poland argue d that discussion of Polish problems would contravene the Helsinki accords.

title: No Headline
description: ISRAEL SAID TO SINK LEBANESE BOATS

title: DANCE: HARLEM TROUPE OFFERS 'EQUUS' AS BALLET
description: THIS season at the City Center-55th Street Theater, the Dance Theater of Harlem is attempting to diversify its repertory with some strongly dramatic ballets. It has already revived Valerie Bettis's ''A Streetcar Named Desire,'' inspired by Tennessee Williams. And on Thursday night it offered the New York premiere of Domy Reiter-Soffer's ''Equus: The Ballet,'' based on Peter Shaffer's play ''Equus.''

title: Belgium Issues Protest To Guatemala on Clerics
description: Belgium has protested to Guatemala after the second disappearance this month of a Belgian missionary in the Central American country.

title: 1 INTERCEPTION PLUS 1 FUMBLE ADD UP TO PFFT
description: PONTIAC, Mich. THEY had come so far, the players and the fans. The Cincinnati Bengals had escaped from the depths of the Central Division and their fans had driven four hours due north into the frozen flatlands.

title: RALLY AT FORT BENNING DEPLORES THE TRAINING OF SALVADORAN TROOPS
description: A crowd of nearly 200 demonstrators gathered at this huge army post today to protest the training here of 600 Salvadoran officer candidates.

title: PAVAROTTI, SINATRA JOIN IN BENEFIT
description: They kissed. They hugged. They embraced each other's sizable egos. And they joined in song in one of the warmest scenes ever to heat the stage of Radio City Music Hall.

title: 49er Plan Smarter, Two Analysts Say
description: Even though the four turnovers in the Super Bowl were in favor of the winners and were decisive in the scoring pattern, the San Francisco 49ers won because they were smarter when it came to tactics and strategy. That was the view of two coaching analysts who saw the game on television and presented their comments to The New York Times.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Ashland O il Inc. has elected Carl A. Dull Jr., chief executive officer of it s wholly owned subsidiary, the Integon Corp., to the additional po st of chairman of that subsidiary. James R. Ridley was named preside nt and chief operating officer.

title: DECEMBER TOOL ORDERS DOWN 49.2%
description: New orders for machine tools, an indicator of the economy's wellbeing, fell 49.2 percent in December compared with December 1980, according to a trade association report yesterday. New orders for the full year dropped 36.8 percent below the year before.

title: GLOOMY GATHERING OF BUILDERS
description: There was the usual convention hoopla - balloons, bands and fireworks - but the mood at the opening of the National Association of Home Builders's annual meeting was decidedly downbeat.

title: Crash Injures G.O.P. Official
description: Frederick Biebel Jr., deputy national chairman of the Republican Party, broke two ribs in a multivehicle accident on the Connecticut Turnpike, officials said today. The 55-year-old Mr. Biebel, who lives in Stratford, was hurt Saturday on his way to Washington. A bus skidded into a car behind Mr. Biebel's and then hit both his car and a third car, the state police said.

title: OPERA: JULIA MIGENES-JOHNSON SINGS MUSETTA
description: JOHNSON sang her first Musetta with the Metropolitan Opera on Friday, in the company's 11th performance this season of its new production of Puccini's ''La Boheme.'' Her lively second-act cha racterizat ion, capped by an appealing, but not quite spellbinding,account of '' Quando me'n vo','' showed Musetta as a mildly temperamental flirt rather than the high-voltage vamp she sometimes is made out t o be.

title: TOWN BAND'S MEN-ONLY POLICY IS CHALLENGED
description: The Chatham town band, a Cape Cod institution for more than half a century and a bastion of all-male harmonies, may have to choose between losing some of its members or its municipal financing following a complain t of sex discrimination filed by a lo cal woman.

title: LANDMARK STATUS IS PROPOSED FOR THE WOOLWORTH BUILDING
description: The Woolworth Building - gleamingly refinished in a $20 million rehabilitation - has been proposed again as a city landmark. Although there was no official comment from the owners when the proposal was made public late last week, they have opposed landmark status twice in the past.

title: ISRAELIS SAID TO WARN EGYPT AGAINST A SINAI MILITARY BUILDUP
description: Defense Minister Ariel Sharon has reportedly made it clear to the United States and Egypt that any Egyptian violation of the demilitarized status of Sinai after Israel's withdrawal in April would set off an Israeli military move into the peninsula.

title: ONLY 3 NEW CORPORATE OFFERINGS SET
description: Few corporations are willing to test the high-interest-rate environment of the bond market, and this week only three issues have been announced, totaling $230 million.

title: Changing of the Guards Helps Tennessee
description: Tennessee was regarded so lightly before the season that the Volunteers were expected to finish fifth or sixth in the 10-team Southeastern Conference. When the two starting guards were lost because of academic difficulties, Tennessee was considered for last place.

title: HOW MRS. WOOLF FELT ABOUT MR. JOYCE
description: JAMES JOYCE and Virginia Woolf - two 20th-century literary titans who inhabited totally different worlds - are brought together in death as they never were in life in an unusual exhibition opening today in the Berg Collection at the New York Public Library. For their devoted readers, this is a rare chance to trace the roots of their creativ ity, the intrusions and frustrations and, above all, thededication of two dissimilar individuals to the printed word.

title: News Summary; MONDAY, JANUARY 25, 1982
description: International The Roman Catholic Church spoke out on behalf of the Polish people. The Roman Catholic Primate of Poland, Archbishop Jozef Glemp, said in a sermon broadcast over the national radio that Poles had the right to honest information from the Government-controlled news media and the right to know why they were being deprived of civil liberties. The sermon was followed by a pastoral letter read in churches all over Poland that warned of the dangers of civil war and said workers had the right to organize independent trade unions. The sermon and the letter indicated that the church hierarchy was united in an effort to put intense pressure on the military rulers on the eve of a major address to Parliament by Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Polish leader. (Page A1, Col. 6.) The Kremlin turned against Italy's Communist leaders after years of increasing tension brought to a head by events in Poland. A 5,000-word editorial in Pravda accused the Italian party leaders, who had condemned the use of ''force and repression'' in Poland, of following a policy of ''aid to imperialism,'' tantamount in Marxist terms to treason. (A1:5.)

title: DANCE: THUNDERBIRD GROUP IN CHOREOG RAPHIC POWWOW
description: THE Theater for the New City became a friendly meeting place Saturday night. At one point, the audience was invited to join in the performance. Cooking smells permeated the auditorium. And hot corn soup and sweet-potato pie were available in the lobby.

title: SPINOFF CASTS DOUBTS ON LOCAL BELL UNITS
description: In explaining why the American Telephone an d Telegraph Company agreed to settle the Federal antitrust suit, the chairman, Charles L.Brown, has said that the company wanted to es cape from being surrounded by a ''fence with a one-way hole.' '

title: A REWARD FOR DEVOTED FANS
description: Finally, the Super Bowl came in from the cold. Instead of an abstract non-event scattered all over the Detroit area, it became a throbbing, human spectacle -warm and clean and, for the most part, happy.

title: JAZZ: VOICE OF ANNE MOSS
description: ANNE MARIE MOSS has been on the verge of ''arriving'' for more than 20 years - when she came to the United States from Canada singing with Maynard Ferguson's band in 1960; later as a replacement for Annie Ross in the singing trio that became, with her presence, Lambert, Hendricks and Moss, and still later as part of a singing duo with Jackie Paris, to whom she was married.

title: JARUZELSKI'S ONLY WAY
description: To the Editor:

title: COSTS OF HEALTH CARE INCREASED 12.5 PERCENT IN 1981
description: The cost of medical care increased 12.5 percent last year, the largest such increase since the Federal Government began reporting on medical costs in 1935. One main item alone, the cost of hospital rooms, was up by 17 percent.

title: Manila Fire Hoax Kills Five
description: An unidentified hoaxer shouted ''Fire!'' inside a packed moviehouse in a Manila suburb today, setting off a stampede that left five moviegoers trampled to death and injured at least four others, the police said. Those dead consisted of three boys ranging in age from 5 to 12, an unidentified teen-ager and a 23-year-old woman.

title: Oilers 7, Rockies 4
description: Glenn Anderson scored once and had three assists, and Jari Kurri connected for two goals for Edmonton. The Oilers continued to show that they were more than a one-man team, getting goals from six players, none of them Wayne Gretzky. In regaining sole possession of the overall league lead with 69 points, they scored five straight goals in the second and third periods.

title: News Analysis
description: The American Bar Association, characteristically gray, pin-striped, businesslike, and traditionalist as its mid-year convention plods through a frigid weekend here, is uncharacteristically worried about the future of the legal system.

title: KISSINGER SAYS NATO WILL BRE AK UP IF RIFTS ARE NOT MENDED
description: Former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger said today that NATO would ''disintegrate'' unless basic differences among the allies were not resolved soon.

title: McCaffrey & McCall Makes Title Changes
description: At McCaffrey & McCall, where David B. McCall, the creative director, is also the chairman, the three co-creative directors have been raised from senior vice presidents to executive vice presidents.

title: Fans Late for Game Think About Party
description: An hour before the kickoff, Moe and Gary Parent and their friends were snuggled in their warm car a half mile from the Silverdome with a reserved parking ticket in their possession. They weren't worried about arriving on time for the start of the Super Bowl because they had given up hope of moving through the snarled traffic.

title: TRADERS ARE WARY ON MONEY SUPPLY
description: Rapid growth in the nation's money supply has created a minor furor in the credit markets, where interest rates have been generally rising since the end of November.

title: Too Icy to Run
description: For the first time in its 23-year history, the New York Road Runners Club was forced to postpone a race yesterday when icy conditions prevented the staging of a 20-kilometer run at Central Park. The Long Island Road Runners Association was forced to cancel a similar race at Eisenhower Park in East Meadow because of an icy course.

title: CITY CONFLICT CASE SETTLED BY $29,115
description: A former Transit Authority general manager who accepted a job with a major contractor has agreed to pay New York City $29,115 in a settlement of conflict-of-interest charges.

title: Lewis, Sprinter, Ineligible
description: Carl Lewis, the outstanding sprinter and long jumper, has been declared academically ineligible for the spring semester at the University of Houston.

title: Soviet Official Says Moscow Favors Meeting With Reagan
description: A high-ranking Soviet official says Moscow does not believe its support of martial law in Poland should rule out a meeting this year between President Reagan and the Soviet leader, Leonid I. Brezhnev.

title: Bridge: Strength in an Enemy Suit Can Be No-Trump Prelude
description: A good player will often reject a three no-trump contract because of a weakness in a suit bid by an opponent. He will choose instead a major-suit contract with a seven-card fit or a minor-suit contract with an eight-card fit that would not appeal in normal circumstances.

title: LEGAL POLICY COUNCIL IS BEING ESTABLISHED IN REAGAN'S CABINET
description: President Reagan has decided to establish a Cabinet council to coo rdinate legal and law enforcement policies that affect several departments, a White Hous e spokesman said today.

title: Lincoln Center Head Honored at St. John's
description: As the president of the Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, John W. Mazzola is not ordinarily thought of as a businessman, but to St. John's University in Jamaica, Queens, he is just that.

title: CONGRESS, TAKE CONTROL
description: What should Congress do now that it's back in s ession? The answer is simple. Congress must take over the G overnment. Anyone who saw President Reagan's news conference last T uesday has to realize, or at least strongly suspect, that he lacks t he ability and knowledge to get us out of the trouble we're in. He i s a pleasant, lazy, superficial man whose policies have produced a r ecession that could very easily and very quickly turn into somethingm uch worse.

title: The Bryce Canyon Compromise
description: The spectacular vistas and unusual silence of Utah's Bryce Canyon National Park will remain undisturbed a while longer, thanks to Federal District Judge David Winder.

title: Sarah Doctor Sets 3 Skating Records
description: Sarah Doctor, 19 years old, of Madison, Wis., set two world junior speed skating records at an international meet today, giving her three records for the weekend.

title: A SUBWAY TRAIN DERAILED AT CENTRAL PARK
description: A subway derailment, the fifth in less than two months on New York City's aging subway system, temporarily knocked out service on the lines running beneath Central Park West yesterday afternoon.

title: TELEPHONE SURVEY PRECEDED SELECTION OF THE JURY FOR VON BULOW
description: About two weeks ago, George Waldo Emerson says, he was sitting comfortably at home here one afternoon near the Breakers, the old Vanderbilt mansion, when the telephone rang and, as he remembers it, ''a very pleasant female voice'' told him that she was calling for a market research firm in New Jersey. Could she ask him some questions, please?

title: POPE BACKS POLISH PRIMATE'S CALL ON HUMAN RIGHTS
description: Pope John Paul II strongly associated himself today with the demands of the Roman Catholic Primate of Poland for an end to martial law and the restoration of civil liberties there.

title: Lillian Rose Nass Is Married
description: Lillian Rose Nass, a junior at Hunter College, and Bruce Ranes, an audio production engineer with DIR Broadcasting Corporation in New York, were married yesterday at Temple Rodeph Sholom. Rabbi Gunther Hirschberg performed the ceremony, with Cantor Efraim Biran assisting. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Nass of New York. Mr. Ranes is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Ranes of the Bronx.

title: HARVARD DISPUTED ON FAKERY
description: An article in Science magazine has challenged Harvard Medical School's explanation of an incident in which a doctor was caught fabricating research data.

title: Jackson Enjoys the Spotlight
description: By the side of the running track at Crandon Park on Key Biscayne today, a bronzed young man in red bathing trunks sidled up to Reggie Jackson and asked him where he was going to play next year.

title: WEST SIDE LANDLORD GETS 70 DAYS FOR VIOLATING ORDER ON HARASSING
description: The owner of a five-story rooming house on the Upper West Side of Manhattan has been sent to jail for 70 days for violating a court order to ''cease threatening tenants.''

title: IN MOSCOW, A FAST TAKES A NEW TURN
description: Two of the seven Siberian Pente costalists who took refuge i n the American Embassy three and a half years ago began a total hunge r strike today to press their demands for emigration.

title: Lefton to Buy H iggins Assets
description: The Al Paul Lefton Company has agreed to acquire the physical assets of Harrison Higgins Inc., which has billings of $7 million. About 12 of the 25 Harrison people will be moving into Lefton space, where they will continue to serve their old clients under their old name providing creative work and management, while the Lefton people supply the rest.

title: LET THE PORTMAN AND THE THEATERS COEXIST
description: To the Editor:

title: Lord, Geller Wins Insurance Account
description: Lord, Geller, Federico, Einstein has been named the agency for the Life Insurance Company of Virginia. The client, which will be spending about $1 .5 million, is consolidating its advertising assignments. Th ey were previously handled by Brand Edmonds Bolio in Richmond an d Tucker Wayne & Companyin Atlanta.

title: Guards Attacked by Inmates
description: Several dozen unarmed convicts at the Graterford state prison attacked a group of guards today, injuring eight and touching off a three-hour disturbance in a cellblock. The guards, most of whom suffered broken noses or cuts and bruises, were released after hospital treatment. A prison spokesman said the inmates mostly just broke up game tables in the noisy disturbance.

title: Pennzoil Gives Land To U.S. Forest Service
description: The Pennzoil Company has donated 100,000 acres of ranchland in northeastern New Mexico to the Forest Service, Agriculture Secretary John R. Block has announced.

title: Christenson Signs With Phils Again
description: Larry Christenson, who had been a free agent, has re-signed with the Philadelphia Phillies, General Manager Paul Owens confirmed today.

title: 3 Owners of Store Shot By Robbers in Brooklyn
description: Two men who robbed a grocery store at gunpoint in Brooklyn's Flatbush section late Saturday night turned their weapons on the store's three proprietors and shot them ''for no reason,'' the police said yesterday. The wounded men were in critical condition at Kings County Hospital.

title: Talent Scout
description: Marty Blackman, a talent consultant who is the middle man between pro athletes and the advertising agencies who want to make use of them in commercials, expects to be very busy this week. With Super Bowl XVI completed, many ad executives are spending today in ''skull sessions,'' making plans for commercials that will make use of some of the outstanding players in yesterday's game.

title: Canada a Winner
description: Francois Bessette scored three goals and assisted on another to lead Canada to a 10-4 triumph over China today in the final of a world hockey tournament.

title: N.F.L. Fines Todd $1,500
description: Richard Todd, the Jet quarterback, has been fined $1,500 by the National Football League for an incident in which he shoved and slightly injured a New York Post reporter.

title: Gayle Rose Is Married To Peter Nelson Berns
description: Gayle Linda Rose, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin D. Rose of Chicago, was married there yesterday to Peter Nelson Berns, son of Barrie Berns Silberblatt of New York and the late Mike Berns. Rabbi Frederick Schwartz of Temple Sholom in Chicago performed the ceremony in his chambers.

title: The Calendar
description: Monday Congress returns today from its long winter recess, so the political pulse of the city will quicken this week, especially after President Reagan delivers his State of the Union Message at 9 P.M. tomorrow. Republican House and Senate leaders will no doubt get an advance peek at the State of the Union Message when they dine with the President at the White House tonight. Democrats will try to counter the speech after its delivery with a film on national television. View From the Other Side of 65: A weeklong meeting of the American Association of Retired Persons at the Sheraton-Carlton Hotel will feature talks by Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve System, Michael Pertschuk of the Federal Trade Commission, Senator John Heinz, Republican of Pennsylvania, and Representative James C. Wright Jr., Democrat of Texas. They'll look at proposals to restructure Social Security and at block grants and monetary policy. Tuesday East Meets West: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. meets in Geneva with Andrei D. Gromyko, the Soviet Foreign Minister. Under discussion: Poland and arms control. Mr. Haig goes to Jerusalem Wednesday for talks with Prime Minister Menachem Begin. On Thursday it's Cairo and a meeting with President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt. View From Overseas: Senate Foreign Relations Committee meets to hear testimony on Poland's $27 billion debt to United States and other Western nations. 2 P.M., Room 4221, Dirksen Office Building. Wednesday Voting Rights: Battle lines will be drawn when the Senate Judiciary Committee convenes a hearing on extension of the Voting Rights Act, due to expire in August unless Congress acts. 9:30 A.M. Room 2228, Dirksen Office Building. President Reagan supports extension of the legislation, with qualifications. Question: Will the Administration offer its own bill? Congressional Revels: James S. Brady, the White House press secretary, who is still recovering from wounds suffered in the attempted assassination of President Reagan, will be the honored guest at tonight's annual Washington Press Club Congressional Dinner. Thursday Bicameral Salute: With the help of the Army Band, the Air Force Band, the Marine Drum and Bugle Corps, the Naval Academy Glee Club, Arthur Schlesinger Jr., W. Averell Harriman, Leontyne Price and James Roosevelt, Congress will commemorate the 100th birthday of Franklin Delano Roosevelt in a joint session today at 11 A.M. President Reagan will hold a White House luncheon for members of the Roosevelt family, former members of the Roosevelt Administration and members of Congress. Saturday evening, after a 35-year absence, the F.D.R. Birthday Ball returns to the Mayflower Hotel. As in the 1930's and 1940's, proceeds go to March of Dimes. Progress Report: Government's index of leading economic indicators is due. Watch for first sign that recession may be ending. Urban Angst: Mayors from 140 cities as varied as Anchorage, Honolulu, Atlanta and Phoenix gather at L'Enfant Plaza Hotel for twoday mid-winter meeting of United States Conference of Mayors. Keep an eye on their reaction to Cabinet members' briefing on new fede ralism. Friday Farmers' Fate: Agriculture prices for mid-January come out. Consumers may get good news on beef prices but bad news on fruit a nd vegetables because of bad weather conditions. Saturday Still Celebrating: The Inaugural Committee co-chairmen, Charles Z. Wick and Robert K. Gray, are going to do it all over again with a ''First Anniversary Inaugural Ball'' at Washington Hilton. Black tie and $40 will get you in.

title: CITY EXHAUSTING ITS SNOW-REMOVAL FUNDS
description: After two snowy weeks that left some New York City streets clogged with ice and slush, the Sanitation Department said yesterday that its emergency efforts had used up nearly all of the $9 million allocated for snow removal this winter.

title: DAVIS ASKS ARBITRATION
description: Ron Davis, the Yankee reliever who pitched ineffectively in the World Series after a strong season, says he has filed for salary arbitration. He called the club's offer insufficient.

title: WAVES OF LEAKS AND THE SHIP OF STATE
description: In the inexorable rhythms of political Washington, each new Administration reaches a time - as the Reagan Administration now has - when the President becomes alarmed or angered over news reports and orders a clampdown against leaks, in the name of national security, although officials concede that less exalted motives are often involved.

title: OFFICIAL AT A.T.& T. STRESSES NEW LINES
description: When the American Telephone and Telegraph Company announced a change in its upper management organization last week - placing its four most senior officers in charge of overall corporate planning and giving each of five executive vice presidents responsibility for a distinct business segment - attention was focused on Charles Marshall.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: I have been told that there is such a thing as an air dribble. What is it?

title: Bengals Hurt Early by a Case of Nerves
description: He's a pro, his team's leading receiver, and he has played in important games in front of packed stadiums before. ''But this was crazy,'' said Dan Ross, the tall, mustachioed Cincinnati Bengal tight end. ''When I came out of the tunnel and onto the field of the Silverdome, I couldn't breathe. It was like I was star-struck''

title: CABARET: 4 SINGERS AND JEROME KERN
description: THE series of salutes to composers for the musical theater that have been presented in the King Cole Room of the St. Regis-Sheraton Hotel for several years has, somewhat belatedly, got around to Jerome Kern - belatedly because Kern was the key figure in giving musical theater an American identity.

title: CHINA AGAIN MAKES ITS POINT ON TAIWAN
description: A prominent official of C hina's Communist Party today reiterated that Peking would not allow anyone to obstruct the reunification of the Chinese mainland with Ta iwan.

title: 'Pump Boys' Is Moving
description: ''Pump Boys and Dinettes,'' a country-western rockabilly musical revue, which opened at the Colonnades Theater on Oct. 13, will move Feb. 4 to the Princess Theater, 200 West 48th Street.

title: CHEESE DISTRIBUTION FOR NEEDY FAMILIES IN JERSEY IS STARTING
description: Two tons of surplus cheese were to be distributed to families in four counties in northern New Jersey Monday at the start of the Federal Government's nationwide effort to help poorer families.

title: LAYNE: N.F.L.'s PATRON DEVIL
description: Before the opening kickoff of Super Bowl XVI today, th e ceremonial coin was flipped by Bobby Layne, a patron devil of pro football. Layne was the Detroit Lions' quarterback on their Nationa l Football League championship teams in 1952 and 1953. Saturday nigh t that 1952 team had a reunion at the Hyatt Regency Hotel in near by Dearborn.

title: Robert Pursell Is Dead at 26; Acted in 'Under the Rainbow'
description: Robert Pursell, a 26-year-old dwarf who appeared last year in the feature film ''Under the Rainbow,'' apparently committed suicide by hanging himself from a tree near his home in Bucks County home, the police said.

title: Mahre Clinches Cup Ski Title
description: Forget the mathematical loophole: Phil Mahre has won the World Cup skiing title for the second year in a row, this t ime clinching it barely halfway through the season.

title: PRESIDENTIAL REALTY; Household Magic
description: Sometimes an object has virtue in and of itself. It is beautiful, unique, rare or very old, the beginning of a trend or its apotheosis.

title: Venezuela Loan Pact
description: Venezuela's Banco Nacional de Ahorro y Prestamo, the central bank for the country's savings and loan associations, has signed a $750 million medium-term loan agreement comprising certificates of deposit and a syndicated loan, Citibank, which serves as agent, said yesterday.

title: NOTES ON PEOPLE
description: Seeing a New Future It had taken months to find a compatible donor, but from the looks of little Lauren Toohey yesterday, the 2 1/2-year-old girl and her new liver make a perfect match.

title: MIDLAND-ROSS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After $2.4 million foreign currency loss; C-includes $1.2 million foreign currency gain

title: WHITTAKER IN BID FOR BRUNSWICK
description: The Whittaker Corporation, a diversified manufacturing company, announced yesterday a $668 million tender offer for the Brunswick Corporation, a major producer of recreational products.

title: BROCKWAY GLASS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Yr-ago results include a credit of $733,000 for the qr and the yr for the closure of a plant in 1978

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Chase Manhattan Bank has appointed the following as vice presidents: Fran,coise Richards, Roger W. Robinson, Thomas E. Ruddy, Thomas C. Schipani, L. Courtney Schroeder, Stephen J. Shook, Richard E. Smith 3d, Arthur L. Spicer, Peter Sterling, James M. Van Nostrand, Regina A. Vinci, John N. Watt Jr., Ralph R. White and Alla Steffen Wright.

title: JOHNSON CONTROLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CEAUSESCU'S TIGHTROPE
description: Rumania is experiencing an e conomic crisis, and hopes for the United States' cooperation in p ostponing repayment of its $10 billion hard-currency debt to the W est. Bucharest argues that its difficulties stem largely from its e fforts to reduce its dependence on Moscow - efforts that should r eceive support from Washington. In light of the limited options a vailable to our diplomacy, unfortunately it seems advisable to help B ucharest.

title: STAGE: 'KEYSTONE,' MUSICAL-COMEDY MACK SENNETT
description: or rather, Edendale - when Mack Sennett was King of Comedy, movies were made on a whim and a shoestring. If a parade passed by, Sennett would mobilize his troupe of comedians and technicians and improvise on camera. This anarchic spirit is occasionally evident in ''Keystone,'' a new musical at the McCarter Theater.

title: ITALIAN COMMUNISTS REPLY TO SOVIET CHARGES WITH A FIERCE ATTACK
description: The Italian Communist Party, responding to Sunday's criticism from Moscow, countered tonight with a policy statement that denounced Soviet polices around the world.

title: DANCER WAS 86
description: Ragini Devi, an American-born dancer who introduced India's classical dances to many in this country and who played a leading role in their revival within India itself, died Saturday at the Actors Fund Home in Englewood, N.J. She was 86 years old.

title: 50 INJURED IN EXPLOSION AT COLLEGE IN CAMDEN
description: An explosion shattered a basement classroom at Camden County College's Urban Center today, injuring 50 students and faculty members.

title: AUTO SALES BY BIG 3 DOWN 14%
description: The nation's Big Three auto makers reported today that sales of new American-made cars declined 14 percent in mid-January to their lowest level for the period in 21 years.

title: DON'T TINKER WITH PUERTO RICO'S STATUS
description: To the Editor:

title: JUDGE REJECTS A BID TO DELAY THE SENTENCING OF WILLIAMS
description: A Federal judge rejected yesterday a request to postpone the scheduled sentencing today of Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. for his bribery conviction stemming from the Abscam investigation into political corruption.

title: PAKISTANI REPEATS NUCLEAR PLEDGE
description: President Mohammad Zia ul-Haq, the head of Pakistan's military Government, said here today that his country had no intention of acquiring a nuclear arsenal.

title: SAN FRANCISCO GETS SUPERHIGH AS 49ERS VICTORY MAKES IT THE CITY OF CHAMPIONS
description: There were elements that were peculiar to this city they call Baghdad-by-the-Bay: The San Francisco Chronicle assigned the Maximum Beatnik Lawrence Ferlinghetti to provide ''A Poet's View of the Super Bowl,'' the Mayor's Office included the city's Gay Marching Band in the official parade roster along with the Army and Navy Bands and some revelers could not resist the opportunity to t hrow a few bottles at the police. But for the most part this sop histicated city took its victory just like any other. Itwent nuts.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: By Susan Bolotin FDR 1882-1945. A Centenary Remem- brance. By Joseph Alsop. Picture sec- tions compiled and written by Roland Gelatt. Photo research by Laurie Platt Winfrey. 255 pages. Viking. $25.

title: MEDIA GENERAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Pratt & Whitney Adds to Layoffs
description: Pratt & Whitney Aircraft will lay off more than 900 hourly and salaried workers at its four Connecticut plants on Friday, company officials announced today.

title: EASTMET CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
TUBE CORROSION A PROBLEM IN ATOMIC POWER PLANTS
description: Most commercial nuclear power plants in operation today are similar in design to the one at Ontario, N.Y., where a ruptured tube yesterday caused the release of radioactive steam into the atmosphere outside the plant's steel-lined concrete containment building. Moreover, the older plants of this design have long been considered susceptible to potentially dangerous leaks.

title: Aircraft and Ozone
description: Attention in recent years has focused on fluorocarbons, such as the Freons used for refrigeration, as possible threats to the stratospheric ozone, which protects the earth from dangerous wavelengths o f solar radiation. Now, the World Meteorological Organization has warned that large fleets of subsonic aircraft could also deplete the ozone, which is concentrated in the altitudes from 8to 30 miles.

title: CYTOX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
AMERICAN BRANDS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
RANCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Chess: Kasparov and Psachis Tie For 1981 U.S.S.R. Honors
description: Gari Kasparov, an 18-year-old grandmaster, and Lev Psachis, a 22-year-old international master, won the 1981 Soviet championship in Frunze, each scoring 12 1/2-4 1/2.

title: LEAK ON, O SHIP OF STATE
description: It was as predictable as the sunrise, or the changing t ides: about one year into his term, President Reagan would get his d ander up over news leaks. He did, and the results of his efforts to s top them are predictable, too: a brief slowdown in the flow of news,a resumption fairly soon of business-as-usual between the press and i ts sources.

title: OCEAN DRILLING & EXPLORATION CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
GROW GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $227,000 for the quarter and $378,000 for the 6 months; the share earnings reflect a 5% stock dividend to the distributed Jan 29

title: No Headline
description: Waving orange and black pennants and shivering in a slushy snowfall, about 4,500 fans waited for the Bengals to arrive at a rally at downtown Fountain Square today. They cheered as a replay of a radio account of the highlights, for Cincinnati, of the Super Bowl loss blared from a loudspeaker.

title: GOLDEN WEST FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NUCLEAR METALS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
Inco Unit to Cut Nickel Output
description: Inco Ltd., a leading nickel and copper producer, said its subsidiary P.T. International Nickel Indonesia would reduce production from its Soroako nickel project beginning next Monday. The company attributed the production reduction to the ''continued depressed world market conditions in the nickel industry.''

title: PEERLESS MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
200 Killed in Peru After Torrential Rains
description: About 200 people were reported drowned when rivers burst their banks in the Peruvian jungle after torrential rains, civil defense officials said today.

title: Owner on the Move
description: Peter Gilbert, the Buffalo businessman who owns the Colorado Rockies, has long been unhappy with Denver as the team's home, a circumstance that led him to make overtures to the Meadowlands late last year. But the Rangers' insistence that New Jersey is their territory makes the Rockies' move there appear increasingly unlikely, and so Gilbert is busy scouting other locales. Yesterday he was in Ottawa, where he met with Mayor Marion Dewar in exploratory talks aimed at determining whether that city could support a major league hockey franchise.

title: No Headline
description: Topics Presidential Realty Capital Losses

title: Air Florida Stamp Plan Is Expanded
description: Air Florida said it would extend its Green Stamp bonus program, which had been available only to passengers flying within Florida, to all its United States routes.

title: NEW LIFE STARTING FOR A HERO
description: Joe Montana's life as a Super Bowl hero began today. He was up early to appear on the morning shows of the three major television networks - NBC's ''Today,'' ABC's ''Good Morning America'' and ''CBS Morning.'' At a luncheon here, he accepted a bright red 1982 Pontiac Firebird Trans Am from Sport magazine as the Super Bowl's most valuable player.

title: A.& P. Store Sales
description: The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company plans to sell 21 of its supermarkets in metropolitan Louisville and southern Indiana, according to officials of the United Food and Commercial Workers International Union. The union, which represents workers at the stores, said the stores will be closed Feb. 13. Malone & Hyde Inc., a Memphis-based food wholesaler, has agreed to buy the stores for an undisclosed price, the union officials said.

title: MAYS CHAIN FILES UNDER CHAPTER 11
description: J.W. Mays Inc., the budget-priced department store chain that operates in New York City and the suburbs, yesterday filed a petition for reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code. The company will close its five suburban stores but continue to operate its four stores in New York City, according to Mays's lawyer, William Kahn of Whitman & Ransom.

title: 3 BIG OIL COMPANIES REPORT LARGE GAINS
description: Three of America's leading oil companies yesterday announced sharply higher earnings for the fourth quarter of 1981, despite the current sluggish state of the petroleum products market.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: A.T.& T. CHIEF ESTIMATES RISE IN LOCAL RATES OF 8-10% A YEAR
description: Charles L. Brown, chairman of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, today defended its antitrust settlement with the Justice Department. He asserted that local phone rates were likely to climb ''only 8 percent to 10 percent a year over the next few years.''

title: CROWN ZELLERBACH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including a gain of $16.2 million for the quarter and the year on the early retirement of debt and a $10.9 million writedown for the quarter and the year of an investment in an affiliated company; c-Including a gain of $20 million for the quarter and the year on involuntary conversion, a gain of $35 million for the year on disposal of an investment and a $31.9 million charge for the year from the company's share in the operating losses and writedown of investment in a 50% owned affiliate

title: CONTROL DATA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results include extraordinary credits equal to 2 cents a share for the latest year and 3 cents a share for the previous year

title: MONTANA-DAKOTA UTILITIES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-includes $3,428,000 gain from a change in accounting

title: Year's Pact for Kemp
description: Steve Kemp, the outfielder acquired recentl y from Detroit for Chet Lemon, signed a one-year contract with the Ch icago White Sox. The 27-year-old Kemp, who is eligible for free ag ency after the coming season, had been reported seeking $1 million, but although exact terms were not disclosed, Eddie Einhorn, the White Sox president, said the agreement was for ''considerably les s.'' While with the Tigers, Kemp twice took salary disputes to ar bitration and won both times. His last salary in Detroit was $600,00 0.

title: RETURNING CONGRESSMEN TELL OF DOUBTS AT HOME
description: In Milwaukee, the automobile frames outside the A.O. Smith plant are piled three stories high because the company cannot sell them to financially troubled Ford and Chrysler. And to the Congressman from that district, F. James Sensenbrenner, a conservative Republican, those unsold frames symbolize a problem that is looming for President Reagan and his allies on Capitol Hill.

title: HOUSING RECOVERY TIED TO INFLATION
description: Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, told home builders today that their best hope for a housing recovery was in lower inflation rates.

title: POLAND'S LEADER, IN MAJOR SPEECH, ASSAILS SANCTIONS
description: Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski today attacked the economic sanctions imposed by the United States, insisted that martial law was justified to avoid civil war and called for ''sacrifice and labor'' from the people to lead Poland out of its crisis.

title: Suffolk Downs Shut
description: Suffolk Downs canceled its thoroughbred racing program today because frozen dirt on the track created a hazard.

title: TOYOTA TO TAKE OVER ITS MARKETING AFFILIATE
description: To overcome lagging growth and internal friction, the Toyota Motor Company, Japan's largest auto maker, announced today that it would acquire its marketing arm, the Toyota Motor Sales Company.

title: MPO VIDEOTRONICS reports earnings for Yr to Oct 31
description: B-Includes $13,524 extraordinary credit; C-Includes $22,638 extraordinary credit

title: BAR URGED TO JOIN FIGHT ON POLITICS IN THE COURTS
description: Attorney General William French Smith today asked several hundred lawyers to join him in urging the courts to stop ''political policy-making,'' which, he said, undermines ''popular support for our legal system'' and ''threatens the legal profession'' as well as the courts.

title: Still 'The Prisonhouse of Peoples'
description: It is by now a sad and predictable pattern. When the temperatures drop in East-West relations, the locks freeze on Jewish emigration from the Soviet Union. In 1979, 51,320 Jews were allowed to leave, a record exodus in the postwar years. Last year, after Afghanistan and the advent of President Reagan, the number plummeted to 9,447. In Soviet diplomacy Jewish lives are a form of blood barter.

title: COMPUTER AUTOMATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
COOPERWELD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
COMSHARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $97,100 for the quarter and $237,000 for the 6 months; results for the latest 6 months have been restated to reflect a change in accounting for foreign currency translations which reduced net income by 4 cents a share

title: SMITH KLINE INCREASES 19.9%
description: The Union Carbide Corporation, hurt by foreign currency exchange translation, reported yesterday that net income in the fourth quarter of 1981 dropped 6.2 percent, while sales fell 9 percent.

title: KNAPP FIGURE'S CONVICTION IS UPHELD
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that William R. Phillips, a former New York City police officer who was a star witness during the Knapp Commission investigation of police corruption more than a decade ago, was not entitled to a new trial on the murder charges on which he was convicted in 1974.

title: MONEY MANAGEMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes $161,039 gain from an accounting adjustment

title: SCOPE IS WIDENED AT ATLANTA TRIAL
description: Judge Clarence Cooper of Fulton County Superior Court said today he would allow the prosecution in the murder trial of Wayne B. Williams to introduce evidence that could link Mr. Williams with the deaths of 10 black youths in addition to the two he is accused of killing.

title: ST. JOHN'S CONQUERS SETON HALL
description: Dan Callandrillo is doing everything possible to carry the load for the Seton Hall basketball team, which has lost three starters recently because of academic deficiencies.

title: ARMSTRONG WORLD INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After $600,000 foreign currency translation loss for the qr and $1.3 million or 5 cents a shr gain for the yr from the purchase of ax benefits from another company...C-After $1.4 million foreign currency translation loss

title: PHILADELPHIA ELECTRIC O reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
HIGH COURT SAYS INDIAN TRIBES CAN TAX EXTRACTED MINERALS
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that Indian tribes have the right to impose severance taxes on mining and drilling by outsiders on reservation lands unless the taxes are explicitly prohibited by Congress.

title: MIDDLE SOUTH UTILITIES INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: 1980 results reclassified to conform with current classification

title: SIMPSON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: 1980 results include results of Teer Wickwire & Co acquired on Oct 1 1981 on a pooling of interest basis

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Man cannot live by cheese alone.'' - The Rev. J. C. Crawford, of Newark. (B3:6.)

title: Mortgage Loan Delinquencies
description: The rate of mortgage loan delinquencies at the nation's savings and loan associations rose above the 1 percent mark for the first time in nearly six years, the United States League of Savings Associations said today.

title: Soldier, 20, Is Shot Dead In Training Accident
description: One soldier was shot to death and four were injured in an accident at the National Training Center here, the Army said today.

title: Mets' Allen Among Arbitration Seekers
description: A record total of 95 players, including Neil Allen of the Mets, applied for salary arbitration yesterday as the annual filing deadline passed.

title: Midland-Ross Net Off
description: The Midland-Ross Corporation, the world's largest maker of industrial heat-treating furnaces and railroad car couplers, said today that its fourth-quarter earnings fell 41 percent from a year earlier, to $5.5 million, or 45 cents a share, from $9.4 million, or 80 cents a share. Sales for the three-month period were $231.1 million, down slightly from $231.8 million a year earlier.

title: SENIOR OFFICIAL DIES IN 17-STORY PLUNGE FROM U.N. BUILDING
description: Johannes Raven, a senior United Nations official, plunged to his death today from the 18th floor of the Secretariat building. He was 57 years old.

title: SEMICON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 3
MISSION INVESTMENT TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes $61,000 extraordinary gain for the quarter and $669,000 credit for the year; C-includes $408,000 extraordinary gain for the quarter and $1,460,000 extraordinary credit for the year

title: BANGOR HYDRO-ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
EARLY-MUSIC CONCERT AT CATHEDRAL TONIGHT
description: The concert of Max van Egmond, baritone, and Paul O'Dette, flutist, sche duled by the Early Music Foundation for last Saturday at Alice Tully Hall-an d postponed because of travel problems, will take place at 8 o'clock to night at the Synod Hall of the Cathedral of St. Johnthe Divine, A msterdam Avenue and West 112 Street.

title: AMERICAN EXPRESS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: All results include operations of Shearson-American Express Inc which merged with the company on June 27, 1981

title: Reunion in Berlin for a Meter Maid and a Musician
description: A few weeks ago, when the Juilliard String Quartet was playing in Berlin's Philharmonic Hall, the cellist Joel Krosnick suffered what he later called ''instant shock'' when he recognized a woman sitting in the center of the first row.

title: Article 187662 -- No Title
description: A bettor put down $2 at Hialeah Park today and won $382,344.80, the largest $2 payoff in American racing history, track officials said.

title: MYLAN LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CUT IN ARMS URGED BY SOVIET GENERAL
description: A senior Soviet general said today that the Reagan Administration's arms spending program was ''doomed to failure'' because the Soviet Union would never allow the military balance to shift against it.

title: PROGROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 2
NATIONAL BERYLLIA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 2
PSYCHIATRISTS ON HOMOSEXUALITY: VIGOROUS DISCORD VOICED AT MEETING
description: NEARLY a decade after American psychiatry deleted homosexuality from its list of mental illnesses, the profession remains polarized in its views, to judge by the vigorous debate at a major symposium on homosexuality last weekend.

title: CONTINENTAL COPPER & STEEL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec
description: B-After loss from discontinued operations of $2,773,000; C-Including income from discontinued operations of $110,000, or 3 cents a share; D-Net income including income from discontinued operations of $2,863,000, or 75 cents a share

title: MYSTERIOUS THYMUS GLAND MAY HOLD THE KEY TO AGING
description: and perhaps even caused by - gradual failure of the immunological defense system that fights invasion from the outside and subversion from within.

title: TELEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CHILDREN CONTRIBUTE SAVINGS TO THE NEEDIEST CASES FUND
description: For many contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, giving can be a family affair, with the younger members sharing their savings or allowances.

title: KYLE TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Schenley Assigns Beverage Accounts
description: Schenley Industries, a subsidiary of Rapid American, has assigned a couple of agencies the alcoholic beverage brands that Daniel & Charles resigned when it acquired F. William Free & Company, which has all that Heublein business.

title: ELIXIR INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
Wadkins Wins by 6 Strokes
description: Lanny Wadkins, motivated by an unintended slight, took charge of the final round of the Phoenix Open today, and from the seventh hole on it was only a contest for second place. He won by six strokes.

title: TV: 'SEGUIN,' TRAPPED BY TEXAS REVOLUTION
description: ''SEGUIN,'' tonight's ''American Playhouse'' production on WNET-TV at 9 o'clock, tells the story of Juan Nepomuceno Seguin, a littleknown but important figure in the early years of Texas. Seguin was born in San Antonio in 1806 when the area was still part of the Spanish empire. In 1821, Mexico wrested its independence from Spain. Seguin and Texas became Mexicans, precipitating cultural problems that would leave both of them scarred.

title: Genes and Autism
description: Autism is one of the most disabling mental disorders. Its victims usually do not speak or use any other form of social communication.

title: FIRST CITY FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-There are no year-ago comparable figures since First City only became public on May 28

title: U.S. Fines Priests $1,000 For 1980 Cuban Boatlift
description: Two Episcopal priests were put on probation for six months and fined $1,000 each today for transporting 411 Cuban refugees to Key West in the 1980 boatlift.

title: CARPENTER TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
YANKEES' JOHN FILE GRIEVANCE
description: Tommy John, who has pitched more victories than any other Yankee in the last three years, has filed a grievance that could result in his becoming a free agent.

title: Polish Debt Move by Bank
description: A subsidiary of one of West Germany's major banks said today that it had made substantial provisions in its accounts to cover possible nonpayment of loans made to Poland.

title: TUESDAY, JANUARY 26, 1982; The Economy
description: A bill that would raise minimum taxes for corporations and individuals, bringing in $8 billion a year in Federal revenues, is being drafted by Senator Robert Dole, according to his aides. He is said to want to meet criticism that the 1981 tax law favored the wealthy as well as to help reduce budget deficits. The Reagan Administration would apparently not oppose higher corporate minimums. (Page D1.)

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: J OHN P.A. MULQUEEN looked like the happiest Irishman on Seventh Avenue. The occasion was the introduction of his summer collection last Tuesday, with all three shows overflowing with buyers despite the weather. From a collection of more than 600 garments, Fast Jack Mulqueen, the Knockoff King of Seventh Avenue, showed 110. It took almost an hour, but the pace never flagged.

title: H.D.F. Kitto, Expert On Greek Literature
description: H.D.F. Kitto, an authority on classical Greek literature, died last Thursday at his home in Bristol. He was 84 years old.

title: Legion Backs Memorial For Vietnam Veterans
description: The American Legion has pledged $1 million for the Vietnam Veterans' memorial to be built on the Mall, Jan Scruggs, president of the memorial fund, said today.

title: TUFTS SCHOOL IS AIMING FOR A NEW KIND OF VETERINARIAN
description: GRAFTON, Mass. THE patient, anesthetized and prepared for surgery, lay motionless as he was rolled on a wheeled platform under the bright cones of light in the operating room. Attending surgeons checked an instrument tray as medical students, wearing green gauze masks and caps, watched attentively. On the operating table, as big as a barn door, the patient's four legs protruded from under the white sheet and his thick black tail hung down from the table end.

title: Dietzel Under Fire
description: With an athletic-department deficit of $1 million and fears that it could grow to $3.5 million by the end of the decade, Louisiana State's board of supervisors has ordered an investigation on Athletic Director Paul Dietzel's spending policies. ''I have absolutely nothing to be ashamed of,'' said Dietzel. But Chancellor James Whorton said it was a good thing that the rest of the university was not run the same way as the athletic department.

title: Help for a Hoosier
description: A north-side Indianapolis restaurant has been donated to the Indiana University Foundation.

title: ROAD SALT'S YET-UNKNOWN POTENTIAL HAZARDS
description: To the Editor:

title: POP: B.B. KING AND 7-PIECE BAND
description: OUT of all rock music's founding fathers, including Ray Charles, Muddy Waters and Chuck Berry, B.B. King is probably in the best musical shape these days. He is 56 years, and his guitar playing and singing have the passion and dynamism of a man half his age.

title: THRIFTIMART INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 3
SAVOY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-net loss after $66,000 loss from discontinued operations

title: SWITCHING ERROR DELAYS THOUSANDS ON L.I.R.R.
description: Most of the 100,000 daily riders of the Long Island Rail Road suffered long delays this morning after an Amtrak passenger train from Washington was mistakenly switched onto a wrong track and tore down an overhead power line.

title: Advertising; Gallagher Filled With Confidence
description: DETROIT'S woes are pretty far reaching. And although they have had a negative impact on the already small billings figure of the Gallagher Group, James J. Gallagher, president, continues a man full of confidence, your basic optimistic adman.

title: JET DATA DISCLOSED IN CAPITAL CRASH
description: First readings from the flight data recorder recovered from the Air Florida jetliner that crashed in Washington Jan. 13 indicate that the plane took about 15 seconds longer than normal to take off, the National Transportation Safety Board disclosed yesterday.

title: KIMBERLY-CLARK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CORRECTION
description: An article about the Rangers-Capi- tals hockey game in some copies of SportsMonday yesterday gave an in- correct career statistic for Dennis Maruk of the Capitals. He has 500 points - his total of goals and assists.

title: Israeli Soldiers Donate Pay
description: Lieut. Gen. Rafael Eytan, the Israeli Chief of Staff, has started a program under which soldiers are donating a day's pay each month to help defray military costs. The money, which is distributed by the Israel Security Fund, a public body set up in September 1980, is being used to teach illiterate recruits to read and write, expand training programs and develop new weapons.

title: KNAPE & VOGT MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ABOUT EDUCATION
description: THE Andrew W. Mellon Foundation last week pledged a $24 million investment in a graduate fellowship program for humanities students. For each of five years, beginning in September 1983, 100 to 125 outstanding young scholars - graduating college seniors or recent graduates - are to be appointed as Mellon Fellows to replenish the pool of top-level talent that, the program's sponsors fear, may otherwise dry up by the mid-1990's and beyond.

title: GCA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 3
description: Results reflect the acquisition in June 1981 of Par Systems and a 50% stock distribution in May 1981

title: FLORIDA POWER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
GROMYKO BARS POLISH TOPIC IN HAIG MEETING TODAY
description: Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union said here today that he has ''no intention whatsoever'' of discussing the Polish situation when he meets with Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr.

title: CINCINNATI BELL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results for the latest qr and yr reflect the effects of revised depreciation rates and practices prescribed by the F.C.C. in Jan 1982, retroactive to Jan 1, 1981

title: Q&A
description: Q. Why do certain cloud formations often cause turbulence for airplanes?

title: ASHLAND OIL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
GIDDINGS & LEWIS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
REPORT ON STOUFFER'S FIRE DISPUTED BY PROSECUTOR
description: An assistant district attorney said today that a state investigator had never given ''a definitive opinion as to the origin or cause'' of a fire in 1980 at Stouffer's Inn in Harrison in which 26 persons died.

title: COMDISCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BOLT TECHNOLOGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CULLUM COMPANIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 29
DOES NEW YORK NEED A CITY COUNCIL?
description: To the Editor:

title: Alfredo Ovando Dead; Ex-President of Bolivia
description: Former President Alfredo Ovando Candia of Bolivia, who led the military campaign in which the Cuban revolutionary Che Guevara was killed in 1967, died Sunday of a stomach illness.

title: Rio Tinto-Ward Link
description: Rio Tinto-Zinc Corporation Ltd. said today that it now holds a more than 50 percent stake in Thomas W. Ward Ltd. when both direct hol dings and takeo ver bid acceptances are combined. Rio Tinto said that its takeover of fer for Ward, which has a 42 percent stake in Tunnel Holdings Ltd. wo uld remain open until further notice.

title: THEATER: FAYE DUANWAY RETURNS
description: THIS much can be said for the star, Faye Dunaway, and the author, William Alfred, of ''The Curse of an Aching Heart'': they are not playing it safe. Mr. Alfred has tried to write a drama that remakes kitchen-sink naturalism with bold, impressionistic sleight-of-hand. Miss Dunaway, leaving her recent Hollywood viragoes behind, attempts to impersonate a working-class Irish girl who travels between the ages of 14 and 33. As it happens, both playwright and star fail - but not ignobly. If ''The Curse of an Aching Heart'' has the same leaden gait as this season's other female star vehicles, it does at least yearn to soar.

title: CHANGES AT A.T.& T. VIEWED BY EX-CHIEF
description: From the moment that the Justice Department filed its antitrust suit against the American Telephone and Telegraph Corporation in 1974 until he retired in 1979 at the age of 63 as chairman and chief executive officer, John D. deButts was vehemently opposed to any settlement. He said that A.T.& T. would fight the suit ''to the end,'' and he declared that ''we are going to come out of this action in one piece.''

title: Mexico Gas Import Rise Is Weighed
description: The six United States pipeline companies importing natural gas from Mexico have discussed increasing those imports to 600 million cubic feet a day, from 300 million, a Tenneco Inc. official said.

title: ADVERTISING RESTRICTIONS ON LAWYERS INVALIDATED
description: In its strongest ruling to date on the rights of professionals to advertise their services, the Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that lawyers' advertising may not be restricted as long as it is not ''misleading.''

title: Satellite's New Job
description: A satellite use d by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration to che ck cloud cover for weather forecasters is now being used to watc h for forest fires. The satellite, NOAA-7, is equipped with an infrar ed sensor and is capableof detecting ''hot spots'' on the ground 540 miles away.

title: 4 Agencies Begin Hallmark Cards Bid
description: The four agencies in competition for the Hallmark Cards are finally getting down to business this week. They will be making their longawaited presentations.

title: TEN INSTEAD OF ELEVEN DIDN'T HURT NINERS
description: The San Francisco 49ers had only 10 men on the field for at least one key play in Sunday's 26-21 victory over the Cincinnati Bengals in Super Bowl XVI. Precise details are still in debate, and even Coach Bill Walsh of the 49ers said today that he was not sure how many plays were involved.

title: News Summary; TUESDAY, JANUARY 26, 1982
description: International Martial law in Poland was defended by Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the country's leader, in a speech to Parliament. General Jaruzelski did not say when martial law would be lifted, but said he wanted it to end ''as soon as possible.'' He reiterated that martial law was necessary to avoid civil war, attacked the United States economic sanctions and urged Poles to pull tee country out of its crisis. He was vague about what role, if any, the suspended Solidarity trade union would play in the future. (Page A1, Column 1.) Poland will not be discussed by Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union when he confers today in Geneva with Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr., who has said that his purpose in his talks with Mr. Gromyko is to express directly the West's ''outrage'' over Poland. Mr. Gromyko said he had ''no intention whatsoever'' to discuss the Polish situation. Mr. Haig responded: ''Well, I think it could be a very short meeting then.'' (A6:1-6.)

title: Conference on the Law Is Set Up for Writers
description: Volunteer Lawyers for the Arts and the Columbia University Law School will sponsor a two-day conference on ''Writers and the Law'' on Feb. 26 and 27 at Columbia.

title: Stocks Retreat on Rate Fears
description: Stock prices declined yesterday amid renewed fears of rising interest rates. These worries were touched off by the Federal Reserve report after the close of Friday's trading that the nation's money supply rose by $700 million. Wall Street had been expecting a decline of about $4 billion.

title: Bridge: Dramatic Defensive Plays Escape an Average Player
description: There are some dramatic defensive plays that are part of the expert repertory but would never be considered by an average performer. One of them is the play of the trump king by a player who knows that the ace is on his right and the queen on his left.

title: News Analysis
description: New York's Conservative Party, whose influence two years ago was decisive in the selection of Alfonse M. D'Amato as the conservative Republican challenger to Senator Jacob K. Javits, is now gambling that it can force the Republican Party to accept its candidate for governor.

title: TREASURY BOND PRICES RISE
description: The Treasury bond market shrugged off news of higher short-term interest rates yesterday and by late in the day prices were more than a point higher with the bellwether 14 percent bonds due 2011 offered at 98 1/2 to yield 14.21 percent.

title: TWO GIRLS ARE MOLESTED IN HARLEM PUBLIC SCHOOL
description: Two 9-year-old girls were sexually molested by an intruder in a bathroom at Public School 57 in Harlem last Thursday afternoon, according to the police and school authorities. The girls were not physically injured and the incident is under investigation.

title: Furry Fun Is for Profit
description: The cartoonist Edward Koren says he has no objection to the use in advertising of his furry creatures, which appear mostly in The New Yorker and Harper's magazines, so long as he gets paid for it.

title: PUSHING REACTORS
description: Manufacturers of nuclear-power plants, in a push f or third-world markets, are reducing the size of their wares.

title: KAUFMAN & BROAD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-including $300,000 tax debit for the quarter and $300,000 tax credit for the year; C-including tax credits of $2 million for the quarter an $2.7 million for the year

title: CHALLENGE OF SIBERIA: CONQUERING RICHES AND COLD
description: The center of Neryungri is known as ''Stary Gorod'' - ''the Old City.'' It's all of 10 years old. The name is used with only a trace of irony. By the standards of the towns and industries springing up along the track of the Baikal-Amur Mainline, known by its initials, BAM, Neryungri is indeed almost old.
