CONSUMERS' GROUPS ISSUE REPORT CRITICAL OF REAGAN'S POLICIES
description: A coalition of seven national consumer groups issued a report today strongly critical of President Reagan's programs of regulatory relief and budget redu ctions.

title: Broker Loan Rates Rise
description: The Contine ntal Illinois Bank and Trust Company and the United States Trust Company said yesterday that they had raised their brokerloan rates to 15 1/2 percent from 14 percent, effective immediately.

title: TEXAS FEDERAL SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Deke Slayton Leaving the Space Program
description: The last of the original seven American astronauts still active in the space program, Donald K. (Deke) Slayton, plans to retire before he turns 58 on March 1.

title: New Top Officer Named For Interstate Bakeries
description: Dale C. Putman, 54 years old, has been elected president and chief executive officer of the Interstate Bakeries Corporation, a major national wholesale baking company that recently moved its headquarters from Hartsdale, N.Y., to Kansas City, Mo. The presidency had been vacant, while the chief executive officer's title had been held by Bertram J. Cohn, 56, who continues as chairman.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rate payable by savings institutions.Salomon Brothers estimates for Bellwether issues

title: MALAYSIAN GIANT SEEKS ACQUISITIONS
description: After surviving the difficult period of shifting from British to Malaysian control, Sime Darby, the diversified rubber producer, is again on the acquisition trail.

title: DILLON COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 2
description: Year-ago share earnings have been adjusted for an 8% stock dividend paid in October 1981

title: Required Reading Anti-Antitrust
description: ''Two's a Crowd: The F.T.C.'s Redundant Antitrust Powers,'' by Ernest Gellhorn, professor of law at the University of Virginia. Published in Regulation magazine.

title: UNESCO MEETING BACKS AID FOR THIRD-WORLD JOURNALISM
description: A Unesco-sponsored meeting opened an ambitious program today to bolster journalism in developing nations, but was forced to trim down its immediate expectations to fit a budget of less than $1 million for 1982.

title: Slow Dancing
description: Senator Strom Thurmond, Republican of South Carolina, hailed it as ''a tremendous piece of legislation.'' The Senate majority leader, Howard H. Baker Jr. of Tennessee, praised it as ''momentous.''

title: Spanish King Visiting India
description: King Juan Carlos of Spain began a weeklong state visit to India today and met with President Sanjiva Reddy and Prime Minister Indira Gandhi. The King, who is accompanied by Queen Sofia, is making the first state visit to India by a Spanish head of state.

title: PEERLESS TUBE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
76 in Sicily Accused Of Drug Trafficking
description: Michele Sindona, the Sicilianborn financier, and 75 others accused of being Mafia heroin traffickers were ordered to stand trial today on charges of criminal association, trafficking in illegal drugs and other crimes.

title: Three Ronald Reagans
description: One President Reagan has, in his first year, been an amiable, effective sensation, slashing taxes and slaying a herd of sacred cows in the Federal budget. Another Ronald Reagan has been a defensive bumbler, misinterpreting anecdotes and bruising facts. A third Ronald Reagan has, for all his personal compassion, behaved like a rigid, even unfeeling ideologue.

title: Record Set Straight On P.& G. Logo
description: Only people who have had dealings with hyper-proper Procter & Gamble can appreciate the humor in a United Press International dispatch from Los Angeles last week.

title: American Express Rose 8.2% in 4th Quarter
description: The American Express Company, reporting that almost all major segments contributed to a strong showing, said yesterday that fourthquarter profits rose 8.2 percent, to $132 million, or $1.41 a share, from $122 million, or $1.35 a share, in the comparable quarter a year earlier.

title: OWLS HEAD'S RESIDENTS BOAST OF ITS BITTER COLD
description: Make no mistake about it. It can get cold here. The temperature is up around zero today because it's snowing. But a few nights ago it was really cold. How cold?

title: Market Place; Delisted Stock: Holdout Woes
description: Everyone knows that the New York Stock Exchange occasionally delists a stock. But apart from mergers, corporations have been delisted mostly because of receiverships or because relatively few shares remained in public hands. The narrow ownership usually occurs after a tender offer.

title: WITH SALVADOR'S REBELS IN COMBAT ZONE
description: El Salvador's political and military leaders call them ''terrorists'' and blame Communist subversion for the war here. United States officials agree with what those leaders say: that Cuba and Nicaragua are supplying weapons, training and men.

title: PRESIDENT IS SAID TO DECIDE AGAINST NEW EXCISE TAXES
description: President Reagan has rejected the nearly unanimous advice of his top advisers and decided not to propose increased excise taxes in his State of the Union Message Tuesday night, Administration officials said today.

title: AMERICAN MONITOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
INDIAN PRESIDENT HAS HARSH WORDS FOR NATION
description: Citing what he called a slide in moral values in India's public life, President Sanjiva Reddy today warned of ''frightening consequences'' to the nation if the problem was not firmly handled.

description: B-including a gain of $2,023,000 for the quarter and 9 months on the sale of stock in a subsidiary

title: Track Star's Alternative
description: Carl Lewis, the University of Houston track star who has been declared acad emically ineligible to compete for the school this semester, say s he will stay at Houston and compete unattached. Lewis, who la st year completed a rare double by winning the long jumpand 100-meter dash title at the N.C.A.A. championships, said: ''Maybeit's good I w on't have the pressure of running for the school.'' All the attention he received in the last year ''hurt my studies,'' he said.

title: INTERNATIONAL RESEARCH & DEVELOPMENT GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec
CONCERT: BARENBOIM PLAYS BEETHOVEN
description: WHEN Arthur Rubinstein was well into his 80's and still storming through whole programs of the biggest, thorniest piano concertos he could find, he recorded the Beethoven cycle under the baton of Daniel Barenboim. Mr. Barenboim, it must be suspected, took some inspiration from the association. At any rate, he is coming to resemble his peerless elder in certain fascinating ways, possibly by design or possibly not. Tone, temperament, expansiveness of approach, and much else.

title: STARFISH THAT DEVOURS CORAL IS NOW SEEN AS BLESSING IN
description: DISGUISE By JAMES P. STERBA TOWNSVILLE, Australia LOCAL headlines, such as ''Starfish Plague Returns'' and ''Starving Millions Are Eating the Great Barrier Reef,'' have sounded the alarm once again here on Australia's northeastern coast.

title: INTERFACE MECHANISMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Conrac Unit Sale
description: Lear Siegler Inc., a manufacturer of aerospace, electronics and automotive equipment, machine tools and farm equipment, announced it had agreed to buy the Conrac Avionics Systems Corporation, a wholly owned subsidiary of the Conrac Corporation, for an undisclosed amount of cash. Conrac Avionics, based in Fairfield, N.J., had sales of about $30 million last year.

title: TWIN DISC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CHAIRMAN ABOUT TOWN
description: After years of political exile, Frank Sinatra, whose friendships with Presidents date back to John F. Kennedy, has once again become a fixture on the Washington scene.

title: KOCH SUGGESTS HE MAY WEIGH GOVERNOR'S RACE
description: Mayor Koch, freshly returned from an eight-day vacation in Spain, suggested yesterday for the first time that he might consider seeking the Democratic nomination for Governor.

title: GEO INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago results have been restated to reflect pooling of interests

title: BRIEFING
description: A little over two weeks ago, Richard M. Walden picked up the phone in his office in Beverly Hills and called the Polish Embassy in Washington. He asked for the commercial attache and, after introducing himself as executive director of a group called ''Operation California,'' said bluntly: ''I'd like to fly a planeload of medical supplies into Poland.''

title: CAPITAL SOUTHWEST CORP reports earnings for As of Dec 31
description: B-Adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in Sept... Asset figures represent net assets

title: Panthers and Diet
description: How are researchers to learn what an endangered, reclusive, seldom seen animal eats? In the case of the Florida panther, whose numbers are thought to be about 20, wildlife researchers from the Florida State Museum in Gainesville have devised a system that will enable them to identify the big cat's menu.

title: ALUMINUM'S WEAK MARKET
description: Aluminum, once so rare that Napoleon chose it rather than gold on which to serve meals to his jaded guests, became a mainstay in American life in the 1950's, eventually finding its way into everything from soda cans to autos.

title: FINK ASKS FUND FOR CLEANING UP OF TOXIC WASTES
description: Assembly Speaker Stanley Fink proposed today a fund to clean up toxic waste sites in New York State and complained that the Federal Government had backtracked on its $1.6 billion toxic waste cleanup program.

description: Yr-ago results have been restated for accounting changes regarding foreign currency translations

title: HBO & CO (ATLANTA, GA) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
STATES DISREGARDING FEDERAL LAW LIMITING WELFARE FAMILIES' ASSETS
description: Hardly any states are vigorously enforcing a new Federal law that prohibits welfare payments to any family with more than $1,000 worth of assets. State welfare officials generally say they do not have the staff orthe money to make detailed assessments of the property owned by welfare recipients. Their decision, in effect , lifts the threat that local officials would regularly visit the hom es of welfare families to inspect their possessions.

title: A-PLANT MISHAP BRIEFLY RELEASES NUCLEAR STEAM
description: A tube burst in an upstate New York nuclear power plant yesterday, causing small puffs of radioactive steam to spurt into the atmosphere and thousands of gallons of radioactive water to spill into a drainage area on the plant floor.

title: LIBYAN LEADER'S VISITS UPSET ALGIERS AND TUNIS
description: The weeklong visit to Algeria and Tunisia by Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi of Libya, which ended here Sunday, has generated con cern and puzzlement in both countries, according to the officials and Western diplomats in Tunis and Algiers.

title: Searchers Find 2 Bodies In Defunct Carolina Mine
description: Searchers descended into an abandoned copper mine today to look for the body of a kidnapping victim.

title: CAIRO, IN A POSSIBLE OVERTURE TO MOSCOW, REQUESTS 66 TECHNICIANS
description: The Egyptian Government has asked the Soviet Union to provide 66 experts to assist on major industrial projects in Egypt.

title: SINGER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes $7.1 million gain for quarter from sale of tax benefits, foreign currency losses of $20 million for quarter and $36 million for year and $21.4 million gain for year from sale of property; C-includes $4 million foreign currency gain for both periods and gains of $3.1 million for quarter & sale of property

title: ZARZUELA: JOSEPH IN THE PHARAOH'S COURT
description: THERE is evidently more to the story of how Joseph became the Pharaoh's adviser than was reveale d in the Ol d Testament. At least that seems to have been the starting point fo r the authors of ''La Corte de Faraon,'' a comic zarzuela set in an cient Egypt, with music by Vicente Lleo, that has been appearing in r epertory at the GramercyArts Theater. The zarzuela, which opened in S eptember, is a production of Repertorio Espanol, a professio nal company based at thetheater.

title: DOUBLED QUOTA FROM MEXICO AND CANADA SOUGHT
description: The Reagan Administration, eager to improve relations with neighboring countries, today proposed doubling to 40,000 a year each the number of legal immigrants to the United States from Canada and Mexico.

title: ANALYSTS INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
JACOBSON, ACCUSED OF HORSE NEGLECT, LOSES LICENSE
description: David Jacobson's licenses to own and train race horses were revoked yesterday because of his reported neglect of Hugable Tom, a 6-yearold gelding who was humanely destroyed last September.

title: UNIFLITE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
SPORTS PEOPLE
description: Will He or Won't He? The no-trade clause in the contract of Ozzie Smith, the San Diego Padres' Gold Glove shortstop, has held up for the last several weeks a much-anticipated trade that would send him to St. Louis for Garry Templeton. Now his agent, Ed Gottlieb, reports that Smith will announce this afternoon a once-and-for-all decision whether he is willing to play for the Cardinals. St. Louis has been negotiating with him since the two clubs first tried to make the trade, and now there is this further inducement: the Padres have notified Smith that if he forces t hem to renew his old contract, including the no-trade clause, they will cut his annual salary the m aximum 20 percent allowed under baseball rules, from $300,000 t o $240,000.

title: Jail Terms Begin for Two Guilty of Vietnam Spying
description: David Truon g and Ronald L. Humphrey,the only people convicted by American courts of Vietnam War-era spying, surrendered today and began serving 1 5-year prison terms.

title: THE ALL-AROUND SHIRT MAKER
description: Although Seventh Avenue has thrived by turning women into preppies, few of its purveyors are either female or noticeably button-down. Then there is Mary Sprague.

description: B-Includes $5,292,000 extraordinary credit; C-After $10,355,000 extraordinary charge relating to the writeoff of operating rights; year ago results have been restated due to an accounting change

FILM: ITALY ITS WOMEN OF THE 20's
description: ''CARELESS'' is a 1962 film by Mauro Bolognini that is only now being released, at the Public Theater. Why? ''Careless'' isn't up to the high standard of that theater's other revivals. Even by comparison to Mr. Bolognini's other works, this one is ponderous and disappointing.

description: * American Can Co. said it had completed the acquisition of 1,754,320 common shares and 490,000 shares of convertible preferred stock of Associated Madison Cos. pursuant to an agreement with five large institutional investors. The value of the shares was not disclosed.

title: 3 Sailors Die in Mishap On Cruiser at San Diego
description: A Freon gas line ruptured on a nuclearpowered guided missile cruiser today, killing three sailors and injuring at least seven others, the Navy said.

title: U.S. Carrier in Kenyan Port
description: The United States aircraft carrier Constellation, which is part of the American naval presence in the Indian Ocean, dropped anchor at the Kenyan port of Mombasa today for a good-will visit, the United States Embassy said. The 60,100-ton carrier is scheduled to remain at Mombasa until Saturday.

title: Ayer Campaign For Stren Fishing
description: Under the creative direction of Orrie Frutkin, a team at N.W. Ayer has produced both television and magazine advertising with the theme ''The Best Fishing is Stren Fishing.''

title: A TRUE ROOSEVELTIAN HAD ALBANY ORIGINS
description: Leo O'Brien remembers a politician so cagey he would smilingly deny a known fact. Dorothy Rosenman remembers a gracious host in the Governor's mansion the night the Democrats nominated him for President. Louis J. Lefkowitz remembers an exacting executive, up on his job but hard to feel close to.

title: People
description: * Robert Wells elected a senior vice president at Lord, Geller, Federico, Ein stein Inc.

title: DETROIT EDISON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
STRONGER MINIMUM TAX SOUGHT
description: Bob Dole, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, is drafting legislation that would raise $8 billion a year in new Federal tax revenues by broadening the current minimum taxes paid by corporations and individuals, committee aides reported today.

title: EXCERPTS FROM TALKS BY TWO IN POLAND
description: Following are excerpts from the speech by Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, the Polish leader, to the Parliament in Warsaw yesterday as monitored and translated from the Polish by the British Broadcasting Corporation and distributed by The Associated Press, and excerpts from a sermon Sunday by Archbishop Jozef Glemp, the Roman Catholic Primate of Poland. The sermon was broadcast by Warsaw radio and was monitored and translated from the Polish by the Foreign Broadcast Information Service, a United States Government agency.

title: Israel's Plan on Sinai Rejected by Parliament
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin's Government sustained a rare parliamentary defeat today when Parliament rejected a plan to pay more than $250 million in compensation to 5,000 Israelis who are to be displaced from their homes in Sinai.

title: 'TRAP' DESCRIBED ON INFILTRATING RICHMOND STAFF
description: The lawyer for a Brooklyn man being arraigned on charges of selling cocaine contended in court yesterday that Federal agents had sought to '''trap'' his client into becoming ''an agent of the Government to infiltrate'' the staff of Representative Frederick W. Richmond.

title: Holders Tender Howden Stock
description: Alexander & Alexander Inc., one of the nation's largest general insurance brokers, said that its tender offer last November to acquire Alexa nder Howden Group Ltd., a London-based insurance brokerage, fo r more than $250 million in securities had been accepted by t he majority of Howden's stockholders.

title: 'Johnny Jones' to Open In the Alvin March 4
description: ''Little Johnny Jones,'' a new production of the 1904 George M. Cohan musical, will open March 4 at the Alvin Theater.

title: NEW EDITOR OF T.L.S. TO 'BROADEN COVERAGE'
description: According to Jeremy Treglown, the new editor of The Times Literary Supplement, there are plenty of people in the world clever enough to read the weekly tabloid of The Times of London. ''We're definitely not going to go down-market,'' responded the boyishly looking 35-year-old to suggestions that he might try to popularize Britain's leading literary periodical, a compilation of erudite book reviews and cultural commentary that few British authors or publishers would dare ignore.

title: LINDBERG CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
State of Union Talk On Networks Tonight
description: President Reagan's State of the Union Message will be broadcast live at 9 o'clock tonight on the ABC, CBS, and NBC television networks and on CNN, the Cable News Network. It will be broadcast on radio in New York City on WABC, WNBC and WCBS-AM.

description: B-After $11.3 million net provision for restructuring of certain European operations

A FEDERALISM WHOSE TIME IS NOW
description: Last September, someone at a White House meeting raised with David A. Stockman the idea of transferring welfare, food stamps and other programs to the states in return for a Federal takeover of Medicaid.

title: REUNION OF EX-HOSTAGES IS 'SENTIME NTAL JOURNEY'
description: The crowds were sparser and the yellow ribbons fewer along ''Freedom Road'' from Stewart Airport to West Point, but for the 16 former hostages who retraced their steps on the first anniversary of their return from captivity in Iran, the magic had not dimmed.

title: TANIA, 58, DESIGNED PAINTINGS ON CITY WALLS
description: Tania Milicevic Mills, an artist who design ed wall paintings in Times Square, on the New York University camp us and in vest-pocket parks in the Bronx and Brooklyn, died of canc er Sunday in her home inBrooklyn. She was 58 years old.

title: Week's Steel Output Up
description: Steel production rose to 1.686 million tons in the week ended last Saturday, an increase of 2.6 percent from the previous week's 1.643 million tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. The industry's production amounted to 57.2 percent of capacity during the week, compared with 55.8 percent in the previous week.

title: Scott Paper Project
description: The Scott Paper Company said it would spend $80 million to modernize a plant in Mobile, Ala., plant to handle tree-length logs.

title: Fewer Quakes Reported in '81
description: The number of major earthquakes around the world was down sharply last year with a death toll about half normal, the United States Geological Survey reported today.

title: HUGHES TOOL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MARTIN MARIETTA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MAYFLOWER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
DURABLE GOODS ORDERS UP
description: New orders for manufacturers' durable goods rose 1.6 percent in December, the second moderate gain after a 9.8 percent plunge in October, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Reagan Seeks Approval Of Arab Satellite Sale
description: The Reagan Administration res ubmitted toCongress toda y a controversial proposal to sell communications satellites to an Arab consortium that includes Libya and the Palestine Lib eration Organization.

title: NATIONAL STEEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
GOING OUT GUIDE
description: DRAWING CARD

title: JERSEY GIVING AWAY CHEESE AMID SOME CONFUSION
description: Federal plans to give away one million pounds of surplus American cheese to the poor of New Jersey began smoothly today at the parking lot of a cold and windy waterfront dock on Newark Bay.

title: FRENCH MASTERS OF NUCLEAR POWER PRODUCTION
description: To the Editor:

title: Co-Separation at Columbia
description: The problem was that Columbia College wanted marriage while Barnard wanted, well, an arrangement. Both, however, are so fiercely attached to their curriculums and faculty standards that neither would accept the other's terms. So the male and female colleges of Columbia University will try to have it both ways. It promises to be a lively experiment.

title: BLUE-CHIP UNDERDOGS
description: We all like to think of ourselves as being on the side of t he underdog. It's as American as Harold Stassen. Yet sometimes - with regret - one has to come down against the little guy. Like the struggling Ban k of New York or the investment house of Smith Barney.

title: DANCE: POLISH FOLK TROUPE PERFORMS AT POST
description: IF art can often directly reflect or criticize life, art can also seem to have a life of its own apart from the tumult of the everyday world. Thus thrones may topple, yet ballet companies still stage ''Swan Lake.'' And though Poland remains under martial law, there nevertheless was a jolly Sunday night performance by Mazowsze, the Polish State Folk Dance Company, at the C.W. Post Center of Long Island University in Greenvale.

title: CRANE CO reports earnings for qtr to Dec 31
GETTY OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BOWMAR INSTRUMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
REID-PROVIDENT LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Rating Firm Cuts B ell Unit Rankings
description: McCarthy Ried Crisanti & Maffei Inc., a private credit rating firm, cut its ranking for the short-term debt of five Bell System operating companies.

title: Talking Business with Stewart of Arthur Andersen; Tax Leasing: New Rules
description: The thorniest issue facing the Financial Accounting Standards Board in recent times is the drafting of accounting rules for buyers and sellers of tax benefits under the new liberalized tax leasing rules. An initial exposure draft issued in October was revised both in December and in January, and a final decision is expected this spring.

title: EDUCATION
description: TROY, N.Y. RESPONDING in part to the dramatic successes of Japanese industry, American engineering schools are making substantial changes in their curriculums and research activities in an effort to promote increased productivity and quality control.

title: Delorean Motor Reported in Financial Straits
description: DeLorean Motor Cars, the company making sports cars in Belfast for the American market, is in serious financial difficulty, the British Cabinet minister responsible for Northern Ireland said today.

title: NEW HAVEN FARES MAY RISE BY 25%
description: The General Assembly approved a final round of spending cuts today that would require a 25 percent fare increase for Connecticut commuters on Conrail's New Haven Line.

title: LOBBYIST, JOBLESS, ACCUSES WATT AIDE
description: A Washington lobbyist for a Texas energy company says he was dismissed after Interior Department officials complained to his employers about a letter he wrote to Interior Secretary James G. Watt.

title: LAWYERS GROUP VOTES TO BAR BIAS BY PRIVATE CLUBS
description: Over the vocal objections of many of its members, the American Bar Association House of Delegates voted today to support legislation barring discrimination by private business clubs on the basis of race, religion, sex or national origin.

title: JUSTICES STAY DECISION AGAINST RIGHTS AMENDMENT
description: The Supreme Court entered the constitutional dispute over the status of the proposed Federal equal rights amendment for the first time today, taking tw o steps that the measure's supporters hailed as victories.

title: SONICS TROUNCE KNICKS
description: The SuperSonics were successful at almost anything they tried against a Knick team that offered little resistance last night, and the result was a 113-99 Seattle victory at Madison Square Garden.

title: FOR LOSERS, A SAD AFTERMATH
description: The souvenir shop in their hotel lobby had started to discount Cincinnati Bengals' T-shirts by 9 o'clock this morning. They had gone from $9 to $6. Yet many of the players smiled and appeared animated as they held children and talked to wives. Had it not been for the size of the men, the gath ering could have been mistaken for a tour group preparing to board buses for the next vacation spot.

title: COMMONLY MISLABELED EUROPEAN COMMUNITY
description: To the Editor:

title: MULTIYEAR AIR FORCE PACT SET
description: The Air Force and the General Dynamics Corporation are scheduled to sign on Tuesday the first of a series of four-year contracts sought by the Reagan Administration in an effort to make military procurement less expensive. Until now, defense contracts have been of one-year duration.

title: Dispute Over Gloves Threatens Boxing Card
description: Three boxers, including Hector Camacho, the star of the show, told Madison Square Garden yesterday that they would not fight at the Felt Forum on Friday night if they had to wear the new thumbless gloves made mandatory here by the New York State Athletic Commission.

title: FINANCIAL BRIEFS
description: * Cincinnati Gas and Electric Co. filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a previously announced offering of 3 million common shares, to be sold through a Morgan Stanley group.

title: FOOTBALL'S NEW PASS MASTER
description: PONTIAC, Mich. IN the National Football League, it's really armball now. The ball is thrown more than it's run. In the five years since the N.F.L. altered a few rules to make it easier to complete a pass and therefore easier to score touchdowns instead of field goals, the pass has developed into pro football's primary weapon. And now Bill Walsh of the Super Bowl champion San Francisco 49ers has developed into a coach for his time. If not the coach of his time.

title: MUSIC: WATTS TEAMS UP WITH TREGER, VIOLINIST
description: A FEW listeners at Sunday's Colden Center recital by Andre Watts, the noted pianist, and Charles Treger, the violinist, may have wished they were elsewhere watching the Super Bowl. One decided right at the start that it didn't make any difference, and, as the pianist seated himself, yelled from the back of the hall, ''Turn the piano around - we can't see your fingers!''

title: Storage Technology Breaks Off Merger
description: The Storage Technology Corporation, a manufacturer of computer data storage equipment, announced today that it had called off a proposed merger with Magnuson Computer Systems Inc.

title: N.& W. Profit Advances 15%
description: The Norfolk & Western Railway Company, citing strong coal traffic, said today that its fourth-quarter profit rose 15 percent from a year earlier.

title: Connecticut Man Guilty In Attack on Umpire
description: A man from Ansonia, Conn., was convicted yesterday for having attacked an umpire during a night baseball game at Yankee Stadium last fall.

title: Vice President Named A t Main U.S. Steel Unit
description: When the United States Steel Corporation announced yesterday that Jimmy Hill was assigned responsibility for its largest business segment, he was away from his Pittsburgh headquarters, attending the semiannual meeting of the company's officers.

title: ANRET PROPERTIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
NAPCO SECURITY SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
News Analysis
description: The Federal Reserve Board and its chairman, Paul A. Volcker, do not need any reminders of the difficult position the nation's central bank is in this year - a year in which the Administration needs a strong economic recovery to retain public confidence for the Congressional elections coming in November.

title: INTERNATIONAL RECTIFIER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net income including net income from discontinued operations of $88,000 for quarter and $68,000 for 6 months; results for latest 6 months have been restated to reflect retroactive application of FASB Statement No 52 regarding accounting for foreign currency translations; year-ago results have been restated to reflect discontinuance of metallurgical alloys business segment

title: VON BULOW LOSES MOVE FOR DISMISSAL OF CASE
description: Superior Court Judge Thomas H. Needham refused today to dismiss a grand jury indictment charging Claus von Bulow with twice attempting to murder his wife, the wealthy Martha (Sunny) Crawford von Bulow. That the state's evidence was originally gathered in private hands does not make it ''a private prosecution,'' the judge said.

title: CEDAR RAPIDS SHOWS CONCERN ON JOBS
description: The business leaders of Cedar Rapids have undertaken a new program to attract industry and jobs to their city, and it is a testimony of how good things used to be around here that they did not feel the need to get around to it until now. Some may also find irony in the fact that a city that used to be synonymous with middle-American prosperity

title: REPORT ABSOLVES HARVARD FACULTY OF BLAME IN FAKERY BY RESEARCHER
description: A special committee investigating the falsification of research data by a promising young doctor at the Harvard Medical School has concluded that the physician manipulated results in three experiments but has absolved senior Harvard faculty members of any blame.

title: SAFECO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-includes gains from the sale of real estate of $18,288,000 for the quarter and $21,719,000 for the year; C-includes gains from the sale of real estate of $356,000 for the quarter and $1,701,000 for the year

title: ATLANTIC RICHFIELD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SALVADORAN LAND PLAN HAILED BY U.S. DESPITE 'DEFICIENCIES'
description: The State Department said today that there were ''deficiencies'' and ''implementation problems'' in the land redistribution program in El Salvador, but added that it nonetheless constituted a ''remarkable success.''

title: PARGAS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
COUTURE OPENINGS: THE MOOD IS OPULENT
description: In its second season under socialism, the haute couture is looking more aristocratic than ever. Let the proletarian ready-to-wear industry offer a choice between long and short, full or skinny clothes. The couture makes these decisions itself.

title: COMMODORE INTERNATIONAL LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including a $300,000, or 3 cents a share, tax credit; year-ago share earningshave been restated to reflect stock splits in 1980

title: EXXON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The 1981 and 1980 revs are in thousands

title: WILLIAMS GIVEN SENTENCE DELAY DUE TO SURGERY
description: The sentencing of Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. of New Jersey on his Abscam bribery conviction was postponed for at least two weeks yesterday because of a hernia condition that his doctor said suddenly required emergency surgery.

title: Mitsui-Iran Deal Cited
description: Mitsui and Company Ltd. has signed a contract to import 150,000 metric tons of fuel oil, worth about $23 million, from the National Ir anian Oil Company, the Japanese news agency Kyodo reported today. Mitsui will also shortly conclude a contract to e xport chemical products, such as synthetic resin materials, to Iran in exchange for the fuel oil, Kyodo reported.

title: FLUTIST: RAMPAL DISPLAYS BAROQUE REPERTORY
description: PLAYING fast and loose with the music of Handel, Vivaldi, Telemann and four other 18th-century composers, Jean-Pierre Rampal offered seven sonatas and a set of variations to a nearly full house in Avery Fisher Hall Sunday evening, in performances shot through with insufficiencies of execution and interpretation. The recital, in which John Steele Ritter participated as harpsichordist, was a particularly vivid example of the celebrated flutist's flair for showboating the Baroque repertory without coming to grips with the expectations of period style or, frequently, with the musical content of the works themselves.

title: SEOUL UNITY OFFER REFUSED BY NORTH
description: North Korea today rejected South Korea's latest proposal for reunification, insisting that United States troops be withdrawn from South Korea first.

title: AMENDMENT FOR DEATH PENALTY IS SOUGHT
description: Supporters of death-penalty legislation that has been vetoed five times in five years by Governor Carey today proposed an amendment to the New York State Constitution, which would not require the concurrence of Governor.

title: PITFALLS IN BONN-MOSCOW DEAL
description: To the Editor:

title: HIGHLIGHTS OF THE MESSAGE
description: Following are highlights of President Reagan's State of the Union Message: TAXES: Despite projected deficits that the President acknowledged were ''still too high,'' Mr. Reagan said he would neither ask Congress to approve new taxes nor retreat from his program of tax reductions. THE ECONOMY: Mr. Reagan said his Administration would continue to rely on what he called the four ''common-sense fundamentals'': reducing the growth of Federal spending, preserving tax reductions designed to stimulate saving and investment, limiting Government regulation, and working to maintain a healthy dollar. FEDERALISM: Mr. Reagan said he hoped to give responsibility to states and localities for Federal programs now worth $47 billion. As a major element of this proposal, Washington would assume full responsibility for Medicaid while the states assume responsibility for Aid to Families with Dependent Children and food stamps. TRUST FUND: The Federal Government would apply the proceeds from certain excise taxes to a temporary trust fund of $28 billion; states could use their trust fund allotment to pay for the programs being assigned to them or use it as they see fit. SPENDING REDUCTIONS: The President said he would press to dismantle the Departments of Energy and Education, cut spending and reduce the number of Federal workers by 75,000. THE DEFICIT: The President said he expected the Federal deficit to be under $100 billion in the fiscal year l982 and to decline thereafter because of elimination of tax abuses, renewed economic growth and budget reductions.

title: IMPERIAL OIL LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including a special gain of $81 million resulting from changes made by the Alberta Petroleum Marketing Commission

title: No Headline
description: Connors Wins, Fibak Oust ed

title: MASSACRE OF HUNDREDS REPORTED IN SALVADOR VILLAGE
description: From interviews with people who live in this small mountain village and surrounding hamlets, it is clear that a massacre of major proportions occurred here last month.

title: NANCY OF THE NEEDLES
description: The news that Nancy Reagan accepts expensive designer clothing as loans and gifts from elegant fashion houses has upset the usual people.

title: CONSOLIDATED FREIGHTWAYS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including $922,000 income for the qr and $8,485,000 loss for the yr from discontinued operations, a $71,547,000 gain for the yr on the sale of discontinued operations and a $14,235,000 gain for the yr from extraordinary items...C-After losses from discontinued operations of $2,096,000 for the qr and $10,438,000 for the yr and a loss of $32,102,000 for the yr from extraordinary items

title: STANDARD OIL CO OF CALIFORNIA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Wilson Scores a Point
description: The Federal Court ruling that barred the quarterback Dave Wilson from playing a second year of football at the University of Illinois was voided yesterday by the 7th United States Circuit Court of Appeals. A three-judge appeals panel ruled that United District Judge Robert Morgan of Peoria should not have accepted jurisdiction of Wilson's lawsuit seeking a second year of eligibility and $9 million in damages from the Big Ten Conference.

title: 1. Currency Calculator
description: The lunch check may read 100 francs in Paris or 24,000 lire in Italy. How much is that in dollars? If you're planning a trip abroad and are not a math whiz, it might be a good idea to equip yourself with a money converter calculator. Saks Fifth Avenue has one no bigger than a credit card. It is simple enough to operate. You punch in the rate of exchange, then the amount of money and finally you hit a button denoting whether you are converting dollars into local money or local money into dollars. The calculator, called TecXon MX 85, comes in a case that acc ommodates credit cards and a small notebook. It's $32 in the statio nery department, main floor.

title: Careers; Engineers Needed In Theaters
description: TECHNOLOGY has made such inroads in the theater that a new career is beginning to open up there - for engineers. At Purdue University, Van Phillips, director of theatrical design and technology, heads a graduate-level program that provides a master of fine arts degree in the field of engineering for the theater. The program is the only one in the country, according to Mr. Phillips. It is primarily for students who have an engineering background, preferably a bachelor of science degree in mechanical, electrical or civil engineering.

title: POETRY BOOK WINS NEWBERRY
description: For the first time, a volume of poetry has won the Newbery Medal, the annual award for children's books. ''A Visit to William Blake's Inn: Poems for Innocent and Experienced Travelers'' by Nancy Willard of Poughkeepsie, N.Y., was selected by the Association for Library Service to Children as the ''most distinguished contribution to American literature for children published in the United States during the preceding year.''

title: PROFITS FALL AT 3 OIL COMPANIES
description: Citing poor earnings in refining operations, the Exxon Corporation, the Standard Oil Company of California and the Standard Oil Company (Indiana), three of the nation's six largest oil companies, yesterday reported earnings declines for the last quarter of 1981.

title: John R. Mahoney, 65; An Admiralty Lawyer
description: John Regan Mahoney, a New York lawyer who specialized in international transportation, died Monday at his home in Syosset, L.I. He was 65 years old.

title: News Analysis
description: Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski's speech to Parliament Monday was more a politician's document than one that might have been expected from a military leader.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: THERE is nothing more frightening than being unable to get enough air into your lungs to sustain normal activities. Yet for more than nine million Americans, shortness of breath is a chronic problem that interferes with work and play and even such basic activities as eating and dressing.

title: Continental Air
description: Continental Air Lines said it is laying off 1,500 employees and plans to seek concessions on work rules from those remaining in an attempt to offset an expected 1981 deficit of $60 million.

title: ECONOMIC UPTURN IN WEST FORESEEN LATER IN YEAR
description: Battered by a continued housing slump that depressed the forest products industry, a bad year for cattle producers and a softening in the electronics industry, the normally recession-resistant West fared little or no better than the rest of the country in 1981.

title: Texas Is Upset
description: The power rebounding and shooting of Ozell Hall, and Terry Teagle's second-half scoring surge carried Baylor to a 69-59 Southwest Conference victory over Texas tonight, knocking the Longhorns from the unbeaten ranks. Missouri (16-0) of the Big Eight Conference remains the only undefeated major team.

title: FIRST LINCOLN FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Inflation Rate Forecast
description: The nation's rate of inflation is likely to decline substantially this year, to as low as 6 percent, and fall further in 1983, the Chase Manhattan Bank's chief economist, J. Richard Zecher, said in New York yesterday. ''There are underlying forces supportive of a substantial decline in inflation, and I wouldn't be surprised to see inflation below 6 percent'' this year, he told reporters. Among the factors contributing to lower inflation are weakness in commodity prices and an easing in wage pressures, as evidenced by discussions on renegotiation of labor contracts in the auto industry, he said.

title: News Analysis
description: With his far-reaching initiative for shifting Federal programs to the states, President Reagan has signaled his determination to press forward with ''the Reagan revolution'' in government and has moved to try to dominate the legislative agenda in the face of recession and a restless election-year Congress. In a State of the Union Message that culmin ated weeks of internal debate, Mr. Reagan overruled the White House staff and economic advisers who urged him to combat ballooning F ederal deficits by increasing excise taxes. And he took the risk that later this year Congress would see deficits as its top priori ty and try to take the political initiative from him.

title: Bankeno Mines Bids for Merland
description: Bankeno Mines Ltd., a dormant shell corporation controlled by Turbo Resources Ltd., a Canadian oil and gas producer, said today that it had offered to acquire all outstanding shares of Merland Explorations Ltd. of Calgary in a deal valued at about $260.6 million (United States).

title: BONN'S RULING PARTY SEEKING VETO POWER ON NATO MISSILES
description: Leaders of West Germany's governing Social Democratic Party have given preliminary approval to a proposal that would permit the party to veto plans to deploy new medium-range nuclear missiles here.

title: 2 I.R.A. Backers Refuse To Enter Pleas in Buffalo
description: Two Irish Republican Army supporters refused to enter pleas today to an indictment charging them with trying to enter the United States illegally.

title: PROPOSAL WOULD ALTER LABELING OF GROUND BONE
description: THE United States Department of Agriculture is expected soon to adopt a regulation that will allow the meat industry to include bits of ground-up bone in processed meats without labeling it as such. If the regulation is adopted, it would be the latest move in a fiveyear-old controversy involving meat processors, who say they are now unfairly restricted in what they can use in their products, and a number of vocal consumers, who contend that the regulation would allow meat companies to mislead shoppers. The Agriculture Department has sometimes sided with the consumers in the dispute and sometimes with the producers.

title: NUCLEAR-PLANT LEAKS: ALREADY AN EPIDEMIC
description: The nuclear power industry would like us to believe that the accident in Upstate New York on Monday was not serious. Only about 8,000 gallons of radioactive coolant spilled from a leaking steam generator to the plant floor. Measurements of radioactivity on and off the site were only 1 to 12 millirems (a chest X-ray involves about 20). The accident will cost only millions.

title: CARTER-WALLACE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BRITISH JOBLESSNESS TOPS 3 MILLION FOR FIRST TIME
description: The British Government announced today that unemployment in January passed three million for the first time. The news touched off a fresh storm of criticism of the economic policies of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher.

title: 4 YANKS AND 2 METS SEEK ARBITRATION
description: Four Yankees and two Mets were among 96 players who asked salary arbitration yesterday, but the Chicago White Sox led the list with nine as the deadline of midnight Monday passed.

title: BUT CITY IS HANDLING THEM FASTER
description: The city has received nearly as many heat-related complaints so far this winter as it received during all of last winter, housing officials said yesterday.

title: SAN-BAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes $437,000 pretax gain from the sale of real estate; shr earnings reflect 3-for-2 stock split

title: METPATH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes $147,000 gain from the sale of property

title: OPERA: MONK AS ESCHENBACH
description: ALLAN MONK has been an honored member of the Metropolitan Opera for several years - the recipient of so many glowing reviews in subsidiary roles that some have wondered why he had not been offered bigger parts. At Monday's performance of Wagner's ''Tannhauser,'' he got the chance to sing the leading baritone role of Wolfram von Eschenbach for the first time in the house, although he had already done it during a Met tour.

title: Justice Dept. Rejects Texas Redistricting Plan
description: The Justice Department today rejected the redistricting plans for the Texas Legislature. Assistant Attorney General William Bradford Reynolds, head of the department's civil rights division, said the department could not approve the plan at this time because of concerns about its effect on minority voting strength.

title: HEADED ATHLETIC COMMISSION
description: Edwin B. Dooley, an All-American football player at Dartmouth who went on to become chairman of the New York State Athletic Commission and a three-term member of the House of Representatives, died Monday in Boca Raton (Fla.) Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived in Boca Raton.

title: Ban on Costa Rica Tuna Ends
description: The United States has lifted a two-year-old embargo on tuna imports from Costa Rica, the Foreign Ministry announced today. The embargo, lifted Monday, was imposed in February 1980 in reprisal for the seizure of two American tuna boats in Costa Rican waters.

title: MIDLAND GLASS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Ozzie Smith Spurns Deal
description: Ozzie Smith, San Diego's Gold Glove shortstop, rejected a trade to St. Louis today and expressed hope that a long-term agreement could still be reached with the Padres.

REGIONAL OFFICIALS UNCERTAIN ABOUT EFFECTS OF REAGAN PLAN
description: Officials from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut were uncertain tonight about what financial effect President Reagan's proposals for a realignment of state and Federal responsibilities would have on the region.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Atlantic American Corp. said it had increased its holdings in Rhodes Inc. to 9.2 percent, or 424,900 shares. * Crystal O il Co. said it had agreed in principle to sell seven gasprocessing pl ants to Damson Oil Corp. of New York for $27.5 million.

Owens-Illinois Drops
description: Owens-Illinois Inc., a major glass producer, sai d today that earnings for the fourth quarter of 1981 declined to $ 30.5 million, or $1.02 a share, from $37.9 million, or $1.28 a share , in the comparable period in 1980. Sales were also downfor the quart er, totaling $928.1 million, compared with $977.8 million.

title: IOWA LOVES RON, LOVED HERB
description: Here's how Ronald Reagan's budget-cutting will affect Iowa this year: The state will lose $191 million in Federal funds and $225 million in various loan programs.

description: Year-ago results have been restated to reflect a change in accounting for foreign currency translations; revenue figures represent shipments

description: In a nightclub filled with smoke and reggae music, several young Ethiopians gathered recently, and their talk was punctuated with anger and fear.

title: WESTMORELAND DENIES HE UNDERESTIMATED ENEMY
description: Gen. William C. Westmoreland and a number of his associates during the Vietnam war today indignantly denied the suggestion in a television documentary broadcast that there had been a ''conspiracy'' to alter and suppress intelligence on the size and strength of enemy forces.

title: Management Shifts At Merrill Lynch
description: William A. Schreyer, the 54-year-old chairman and president of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith, the world's largest securities firm, with annual revenues of more than $4 billion, has been elected to the additional post of president and chief operating officer of Merrill Lynch & Company, its parent corporation. He succeeds Roger E. Birk, 51, who gives up the presidency while continuing as chairman and chief executive officer of the parent, a giant financial services concern whose interests also include real estate and insurance.

title: Dr. James Smart Dies; Authority on the Bible
description: Dr. James D. Smart, professor of biblical interpretation at Union Theological Seminary in New York from 1957 to 1971, died Saturday at his home in Rosedale, Ontario. He was 74 years old.

title: Mutuel Clerks Approve 3-Year N.Y.R.A. Pact
description: Mutuel clerks employed by the New York Racing Association yesterday ratified a three-year contract retroactive to New Year's Day. The vote was 257 to 145.

title: CAREY OFFERS A PROGRAM TO FIGHT UNEMPLOYMENT
description: Governor Carey today proposed a wide range of measures to combat unemployment. They included a ''work sharing'' program to permit employees whose workweeks are cut back to collect unemployment benefits, state insurance for loans to small businesses and a cutback in state regulations on a variety of industries.

title: THREE M CO reports earnings for Qtr toDec 31
DELOREAN TO CONTINUE EFFORTS FOR BRITISH AID
description: The board of directors of the cash-short DeLorean Motor Cars company, meeting in New York yesterday to discuss the sports car maker's uncertain future, indicated it planned to continue its efforts to secure additional financial assistance from the British Government.

title: INTEREST RATES MOVE LOWER
description: Short- and long-term interest rates declined yesterday, as market participants became more confident that the nation's money supply will soon decline, allowing the Federal Reserve to make credit more available to the banking system, thereby lowering interest rates.

title: BANTA, GEORGE, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 2
EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Allied Corporation, Morris Township, N.J., has named Thomas P. Lawton Jr. president of the Fisher Scientific Company, an operating unit, to succeed Edward G. Perkins, who has resigned.

description: ''I feel like a babe in the wool!''

description: MOST ordinary oven th ermostats are untrustworthy. Out of curiosity I have tested them for accuracy and have found that ovens vary from the set tempe rature by as much as 50 degrees.

title: German Bank Growth
description: West German savings banks recorded balance-sheet growth of 7 percent in 1981, the lowest annual rate since 1949, Helmut Geiger, president of the Savings Bank Association, said here today. In a speech to bankers, he said the sluggish growth reflected more cautious personal borrowing and credit growth of only 8 percent, stemming from cyclical factors and high interest rates. The savings banks themselves also borrowed more cautiously, he said, because of poorer opportunities for refinancing.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Contrary to some of the wild charges you may have heard, this Administration has not and will not turn its back on America's elderly or America's poor.

title: 7 Straight for Rams
description: Fordham rolled to its seventh straight triumph last night as Bill Calhoun scored 18 points and Mike Cooper 15 in beating Manhattan, 73-56, in a Metro-Atlantic Conference game. Fordham (11-6 and 3-0) hit 15 straight points midway through the second half to open a 59-44 lead. Calhoun led the way with 7 points. The Rams used their stronger front line to score inside repeatedly. They built a decisive margin at the foul line, converting 23 of 31 attempts to Manhattan's 12 of 15. Tim Cain led Mahattan (8-8 and 1-2) with 19 points.

title: 35 YEARS FOR BERWID IN SLAYING OF WIFE
description: Adam Z. Berwid, the mental patient who was convicted of killing his estranged wife, Ewa, in December 1979 while on a one-day pass from the Pilgrim Psychiatric Center in West Brentwood, L.I., was sentenced Tuesday to 35 years to life in prison.

PARIS COUTURE: UNGARO'S COLORFUL PRINTS
description: The front row told the story. Olimpia de Rothschild was chatting animatedly with Princess Caroline of Monaco, the paparazzi's delight. Both attractive young women, with dark hair and a casual manner, represent the future of the couture. To the Princess's right was Jacqueline de Ribes, one of the French fashion plates of all time. A few seats to the left was Nan Kempner, her American counterpart. It was clear that Emanuel Ungaro's position was indeed secure in the highest circle of fashion.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Have you ever sampled a delicious Fre nch vegetable puree called fermiere? Can you tell me how it is made?

title: WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 27, 1982; The Economy
description: President Reagan, vowing to stand by his tax cuts, proposed a sweeping plan to transfer $47 billion in Federal programs to state and local governments. In his first State of the Union address , Mr. Reagan suggested that the Government turn ove r to the states the food-stamps and aid-to-dependent-children pro grams, taking upon itself, in return, all responsibility for Med icaid. (Page A1.) The fiscal policy Mr. Reagan outlined would produ ce larger budget deficits than his advisers recommended. (A19. ) Business executives, with few exceptions, gave the President high marks for his comments. (A19.)

title: TRANSCRIPT OF PRESIDENT'S STATE OF THE UNION MESSAGE TO NATION
description: Following is the transcript of President Reagan's State of the Union Message to a joint session of Congress last night, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: GOOD THINGS HAPPENING AT STATEN ISLAND
description: The results of the weekly Division III N.C.A.A. basketball poll do not arrive at the College of Staten Island each week in quite the same manner as in the big time. If the news does not travel by word of mouth, and if it is not discovered in the tiniest newspaper type, it arrives on Coach Evan Pickman's desk in an envelope from Shawnee Mission, Kan., the N.C.A.A. headquarters, nearly a week after the fact.

title: SOUTHERN RY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Washington's Farewell
description: Kermit Washington of the Portland Trail Blazers said yesterday that because he hurt too much in too many places he was retiring from professional basketball after nine seasons. Washington, a 30-year-old journeyman at power forward, said recurrent injuries to his back, hip, knee and ankle had led to the decision.

title: NEW TAX POLICY COVERING CO-OPS DROPPED BY CITY
description: New York City officials, in an abrupt reversal, decided yesterday not to change the method by which they compute the value of cooperative apartment buildings for tax purposes.

title: Superior Fears Takeover Bid
description: The Superior Oil Company, the nation's largest independent oil and gas producer, said it had retained the New York investment banking firm of Morgan Stanley & Company to help defend it in the event of a takeover attempt.

title: CABOT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
WITNESS IN ATLANTA KILLINGS LINKS DEFENDANT TO VICTIM
description: A 15-year-old black youth testified today that Wayne B. Williams fondled him after taking him for a ride in his automobile and that, five months later, he saw Mr. Williams pick up another young black, Lubie Geter, 14, whose partially clad body was found about a month later alongside a county road.

title: 'Princess Ida' Feb. 10-21 At Eastside Playhouse
description: The Light Opera of Manhattan will present Gilbert and Sullivan's ''Princess Ida'' Feb. 10 to 21 in the Eastside Playhouse, at 334 East 74th Street.

title: An Elderly Couple Slain in Jersey
description: An elderly couple were slain and their 35-yearold daughter critically wounded during an argument in their home here with the daughter's estranged husband, according to the police.

title: McGregor Campaign
description: McGregor Brand, which does not make anything but does license its well-known name to sportswear manufacturers, is going to be doing some marketing for the first time and has retained the Saxon Communications Group for help.

title: U.S. AIDES BAR RIGHTS EXEMPTION FOR SCHOOLS
description: Federal officials have rejected, at least for the time being, a proposed change in the definition of ''financial assistance'' that would have exempted more than 1,000 colleges and vocational schools from civil rights requirements.

title: Accounts
description: * Ozalid Corporation to D'Arcy-MacManus & Masius/New York.

title: NEW YORK TESTING LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: These figures are corrected from the incorrect figures the company reported in November

title: CBS TAPE SUBMITTED TO JUDGE
description: CBS News today delivered a tape recording to Judge Stanley Golde of Alameda County Superior Court as part of a compromise to end a confrontation over the California law protecting certain First Amendment rights for reporters.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: IT is one of the more curious facts of contemporary pop life that the sounds and images of dead rock stars are selling more records, magazines and books than most of their living competition. Albert Goldman's sensationalistic biography of Elvis Presley is a bestseller, as a somewhat less offensive but badly written Jim Morrison biography was a season ago.

title: RCA to Sell Hertz
description: The Hertz Corporation, the nation's largest car and truck rental and leasing company, is for sale, its parent, the RCA Corporation, said. RCA, which acquired the rental company in 1967 for $185 million, said that it had held several preliminary discussions with companies interested in acquiring Hertz. The company has been hurt by rising interest costs to finance its huge vehicle fleet, as well as an earnings decline because of the recession and the resultant drop in its car and truck rental and leasing business.

title: Trial Is Due for Six Suspects In Salvador Slaying of Nuns
description: A high-ranking Government spokesman said today that the six suspects in the 1980 murders of four American churchwomen will go to trial ''within a very few days.''

title: DEMOCRATS HOLD REAGAN'S THEME HAS BEEN UNFAIRNESS TO THE NEEDY
description: The Democrats challenged President Reagan's assertions of progress tonight, contending that the basic theme of the first year of his term had been ''unfairness'' - to the poor and the elderly, to young families seeking homes, to small businessmen and to farmer s.

title: REACTION IN CONGRESS TURNS ON POLITICS AND ON IDEOLOGY
description: Partisan and ideological differences on Capitol Hill proved the major factors tonight in the wide range of Congressional reactions to President Reagan's proposed ''new federalism,'' which would give the states responsibility for more than 40 programs now administered by the Federal Government.

title: Jackson Looks to Modest Role
description: Reggie Jackson said today he doesn't plan to be a team leader with the California Angels, but simply ''one of the guys.''

title: PLAN IS FILED FOR '800' PHONES
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company has announced a proposal to enhance its 800 service, which now allows a business to receive calls from a designated region without charge to the caller.

title: Nets Subdue Jazz in Overtime
description: Buck Williams and Ray Williams sparked the Nets in overtime tonight as New Jersey defeated the Utah Jazz, 138-129.

title: BAKER INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
THE FOOD OF CHINA'S WANDERING TRIBE

title: Reagan's Rhetoric
description: It should come as no surprise to the nation's Democrats, but an expert on Presidential speech has given President Reagan a high mark for rhetoric during his first year in office.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rate payable by savings institutions.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Petty Officer Acquitted In Death of Recruit
description: A military jury today acquitted a Navy petty officer, Master at Arms First Class Wilbur L. Coffman, 34 years old, of charges of involuntary manslaughter and negligent homicide in the death of Seaman Recruit Paul Trerice, 21, who died of heat strokeand cardiac arrest on April 14 in the aircraf t carrier Ranger's correctional custody unit.

HAIG HAS WON BATTLES, BUT STILL FACES THE WAR
description: As he travels on diplomatic missions this week from Europe to the Middle East, Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. seems to be in a stronger position than at any time since the beginning of the Reagan Administration. Yet, ironically, his views and his personal power may be at their point of greatest vulnerability, to hear people in and close to the Administration talk about the situation.

title: CENTRAL BANKING SYSTEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PROPOSES $47 BILLION TRANSFER OF SOCIAL PROGRAMS TO STATES
description: President Reagan, in his first State of the Union Message, vowed today to stick with the tax cuts that lie at the heart of his economic recovery program, and he announced a sweeping plan to give states and localities control over Federal programs that now cost $47 billion a year.

title: Good News, Bad News
description: When Dr. K. Buol Heslin is not performing delicate eye surgery at the New York Eye and Ear Infirmary, he can be found creating delicate sauces for some of the dishes he learned to cook at Simone Beck's famed cooking school in Mougins, France.

title: ROBERTSHAW CONTROLS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
THEATER: 'BRIXTON RECOVERY,' A MEETING OF OPPOSITES
description: THE prizefighter hero of Jack Gilhooley's ''The Brixton Recovery'' is an indestructible loser. Even as he battles his way to the bottom of the record books, he does not lose his sanguine disposition. After still another defeat, he meets a barmaid, a black emigre from Jamaica to England who is going to night school and is dreaming about a career in politics.

title: True Story Is Telling Its Story to Trade Press
description: In its own behalf, True Story magazine, not exactly the most highbrow of publications, will be doing some name-dropping in the advertising trade press.

title: MAYOR PLANS DECISION ON RUNNING IN MONTH
description: Mayor Koch, who on Monday declined to rule himself out of this year's race for Governor, said yesterday that he would decide in a month whether he would run.

title: Bowmaker Sale
description: Marsh & McLennan Companies, a leading insurance brokerage concern based in New York, said that Lloyd's and Scottish had agreed to purchase Bowmaker, the finance subsidiary of C.T. Bowring & Company, a subsidiary of Marsh & McLennan, for about $150 million.

title: WESTERN PACIFIC RAILROAD CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ISLANDERS ROUT PENGUINS, SCORING 5 IN OPENING 4:08
description: Just 1 minute 31 seconds into the game tonight at Nassau Coliseum, Duane Sutter put the Islanders ahead of the Pittsburgh Penguins, 1-0. About a minute later, John Tonelli made it 2-0. Then Bryan Trottier scored twice in 45 seconds, followed by Sutter's second goal at 4:08 to give New York a 5-0 lead.

title: Bridge: A Student of Bidding Finds Material on Subject Scarce
description: Those who wish to prepare for battle by practicing play and defense at home can make use of a wide range of excellent literature. But the materials needed to test bidding skills are far more limited. Helping to remedy this dearth are two recent booklets.

title: BALL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Real Estate; Shopping Malls: An Enthusiast
description: ABOUT a month ago, Charles Grossman, president of the Schroder Real Estate Corporation, a company that has been investing in commercial properties in the United States for the last eight years on behalf of British and European pension funds, bought another shopping center in Bakersfield, Calif. The event w ould hardly be worth noting, except that with a sluggisheconomy and a slowdown in consumer spending, Mr. Grossman's sustainedenthusiasm fo r shopping centers as a good investment might seem unusual. With 13 shopping centers now in the company's portfolio, Schroder rank s among the top 20 owners of shopping centers in the country.

title: THE ODD COUPLE BREAKS UP
description: IT began as a love affair, and it ended the way love affairs often do, with the biggest truths known but unspoken. Openly and adoringly, Reggie Jackson once carved his initials in the apple tree. Reggie loves the Yankees. Five years later, George Steinbrenner no longer wanted Reggie Jackson around - probably not even as a designated hitter. If he had, Steinbrenner would have been able to keep him.

title: 2 AIRLINE COMPANIES CITE LOSSES
description: Two major airline companies, Eastern Air Lines and the Trans World Corporation, yesterday reported losses for the fourth quarter with Eastern showing a loss of $65.9 million for the full year of 1981.

title: SAUDI BANKS FOR WOMEN THRIVING
description: In the male-dominated society of Saudi Arabia, religion, government, business, finance and the media are the almost exclusive preserves of men. In tradition and still largely in fact, women are expected to hide behind a black veil and stay at hometo rear the c hildren who represent the future of this thinly populated kin gdom.

title: O'SULLIVAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings represent a 25% stock distribution paid Aug 31, 1981

title: A SOVIET FABLE
description: Comrades: As is well known, I, Leonid Brezhnev, unlike President Reagan, have no obligation to report annually on the state of the union of the Soviet Socialist Republic. This shows the wisdom of Marxist-Leninist thought, for the state of our union is not quite as good as we would like it to be.

title: VOLCKER CAUTIONS THAT BIG DEFICITS IMPERIL RECOVERY
description: Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, warned the Administration and Congress today that the prospect of continued large Federal budget deficits threatens the economic recovery President Reagan has forecast for this year.

title: OTHER ACCIDENTS PREDICTED
description: Officials declared an end to the emergency at the damaged Robert E. Ginna nuclear power plant here today. But a Federal official called the accident ''a severe failure'' and warned that he would ''expect it to occur again'' somewhere in the nation.

title: HE VOWS POLICY OF CONTINUITY
description: Prime Minister Mauno Koivisto easily won election today as Finland's first leftist President as he received 167 of the 301 votes in the electoral college.

title: GUILFORD MILLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
R.P.I. CENTER PROPOSED FOR INDUSTRIAL RESEARCH
description: Governor Carey proposed legislation here today that could, by the year 2000, make the Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, the country's oldest engineering college, as much a research facility for private industry as a an institution of higher learning.

title: Iraq and Iran Agree To Visits for P.O.W.'s
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar announced an agreement today between Iran and Iraq for reciprocal visits by families of military prisoners seized by both sides in the 16-month-old Persian Gulf war.

title: TO HONOR A DEAD HERO
description: To the Editor:

title: SENSE OF 'FAMILY' HELPS DELTA AIR
description: Marvin Shaw, a mechanic in the hangar where Delta's jets are refurbished, recalled that he has worked in many departments since he joined the airline in 1973 and had never been laid off.

title: Poetic Justice for the E.R.A.
description: With an unusual order, the Supreme Court undoes the mischief of an Idaho judge whose sweeping edict would have killed the equal rights amendment outright. The order, which goes beyond the pleadings of any party, stays the impact of the lower court's decision until the high court has a chance to examine it thoroughly.

title: CONSOLIDATED EDISON CO OF NY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

description: Two faiths now vie in Poland and both plead openly for the West's support.

title: MUSIC: SCHULLER LEADS 'KLEE'
description: GUNTHER SCHULLER led the American Symphony Orchestra in some very familiar music Sunday at Carnegie Hall, including his ''Seven Studies on Themes of Paul Klee.'' Nadja Salerno-Sonnenberg, winner of the 1981 Naumburg Competition, was the soloist, and she hurled herself into the Tchaikovsky Violin Concerto without regard for her safety or for its.

title: 2 MISSING FROM JET IN BOSTON HARBOR
description: Two passengers are unaccounted for and may have drowned in Boston Harbor after a World Airways DC-10 jet skidded off the end of an airport runway into the water, officials said Tuesday.

title: Economic Scene; 'Federalism,' Reagan-Style
description: WHAT will be the impact of the ''new federalism,'' outlined by President Reagan last night in his State of the Union address, on the income and growth of different states and regions? Interstate and interregional differences are already very large, generally favoring the states in the South and West to the disadvantage of those in the Northeast and Middle West, especially those in the Great Lakes region.

title: The Space Below the Bridge
description: One of the handsomest interior spaces in New York is hidden beneath the Manhattan approach to the Queensborough Bridge. Its vaulted ceilings are covered with the same rare Guastovini tiles that grace passageways and restaurants of Grand Central Station.

title: JAPAN WILL EASE TRADE BARRIERS
description: In an effort to ease friction with its major Western trading powers, Japan plans to eliminate or significantly reduce 67 nontariff barriers to its market, two Japanese Government ministers said today.

title: WEYERHAEUSER UP
description: The Procter & Gamble Company reported yesterday that earnings in the second fiscal quarter ended Dec. 31 increased 20.9 percent, aided by an exchange of its common stock for long-term debt. Sales were up 3.6 percent.

title: Head of Optical Concern
description: John Lawrence, 70, a former head of Dresser Industries and chairman of Recognition Equipment Inc., a manufacturer of optical character recognition equipment, has been temporarily named president and chief executive officer of Recognition Equipment. He succeeds Jay Rodney Reese, 55, who resigned from the company, which is based in Dallas.

title: CITICORP RATING CUT BY MOODY'S
description: Reflecting the changing configuration of the nation's financial institutions, Citicorp's bond rating was lowered yesterday, and the bond ratings of Shearson/American Express Inc. and of the Bache Group Inc. were raised.

title: KOCH CITES F.D.R ERA IN A TRIBUTE
description: It was a tribute to Franklin Delano Roosevelt, and yesterday the 32d President was remembered as a ''man whose genius and whose humanity went hand in hand.''

title: BUILDING DESIGN COMPUTERS
description: Until a few months ago, it took Sam Romerstein, an architect, a few hours to ''move'' a wall inside a building he was designing. He would have to erase his existing floor plan, draw the new configuration, then wait for new schematics to be printed.

description: Tests were performed on gas found at the scene of an exp losion in a Camden County College bu ilding, but a utility spokesman said that they were inconclusive.

title: EXECUTIVES PRAISE REAGAN'S REMARKS
description: Business executives, with few exceptions, gave President Reagan strong support for his first State of the Union Message last night. Despite some feeling that the President had little new to offer, or that the transfer of Federal programs to the states or local communities might raise some difficulties, Mr. Reagan was given high marks - particularly for his pledge not to raise taxes.

description: Besides frostbite and hypothermia, the devastating winter of 1982 is causing another malady, cabin fever, which affects temperament rather than temperature, a University of Maryland psychiatrist said yesterday.

10 WINNERS, AGE 8 TO 18, WILL HAVE PLAYS STAGED
description: Ten young playwrights whose works were written at ages ranging from 8 to 18 are the winners of a search for talent by the Dramatists Guild. The five boys and five girls were selected from more than 700 writers, aged 18 and under, from all over the country. Their plays will be given productions in the first annual Young Playwrights Festival at the Off Broadway Circle Repertory Company from April 27 to May 16.

title: 2 Soviet Pentecostalists Ease Fast at Embassy
description: Two Soviet Pentecostalists have eased their hunger strike in the basement of the American Embassy and resumed drinking tea, juice and water, a relative said today.

title: HAIG AND GROMYKO HOLD 'SOBER' TALKS ON RANGE OF ISSUES
description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. met with Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union for eight hours today and said afterward that differences over Poland ''cast a long and dark shadow'' over all East-West issues.

title: Tickets Mystery
description: Federal postal inspectors are investigating the theft of Super Bowl tickets that were apparently taken from the mail and resold several times before turning up at a Michigan travel agency. Five residents of Grand Rapids, Mich., traveled to Pontiac for Sunday's game only to find their seats occupied and security personnel waiting for them, The Grand Rapids Press reported.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: THE inspiration for the dishes that I prepare varies widely. It may be a remembrance of something on which I have recently dined in this country or abroad, or it may be a reproduction of classic French cooking, something that is made according to Escoffier.

title: DOW DECLINES BY 1.24, TO 841.51
description: The stock market declined slightly yesterday as investors awaited details of President Reagan's State of the Union Message scheduled for delivery last night. In the absence of any compelling news developments, many stocks responded to the latest earnings announcements.

title: MUSIC: SOFIA'S ALL-BULGARIAN ORCHESTRA PLAYS DVORAK
description: DIFFERING orchestral traditions would seem to be threatened in our cosmopolitan music world. International concert tours, international music competitions, internationally staffed schools for virtuoso performance, internationally distributed recordings. All that international culture has created more musical homogeneity than every before in history.

title: SOME 'FOREIGN AID' FOR NEEDIEST CASES FROM DISTANT SPOTS

title: PARALYSIS BARS A WEDDING

title: PIANIST: ELLIS OFFERS SCRIABIN
description: WHEN the smoke had cleared and the time came to take stock of Monday's Merkin Concert Hall recital by Van Zandt Ellis, pianist, there was no need to hunt for descriptive imagery. It was still possible to see the lid of the piano shaking from the impact of Mr. Ellis's chordal assaults in the Busoni transcription of Bach's Chaconne in D minor, and to hear the loose strings ringing at the end of Prokofiev's Sonata No. 7 (Op. 83).

Purely by coincidence, the vintage of 1978 happened to be very good in both northern California and Bordeaux, and the wines are now widely available all over the country.

title: Gretzky Tops List

Gretzky, the Edmonton Oiler center, was named as the only unanimous choice for the Campbell Conference team that will play the Wales team in the National Hockey League's All-Star Game in two weeks at Landover, Md.

title: RUNDGREN'S MUSIC-VIDEO
description: TODD RUNDGREN, who is probably the most talented American rock musician to translate the Beatles' romantic psychedelia into a distinctively American idiom, has become immersed in video projects during the last several years at his studio in Bearsville, N.Y. At the Savoy on Friday and Saturday, Mr. Rundgren presented a mixedmedia program of music and video that was impressive enough to suggest that he has it in him to become more than a cult hero refining the mystique of an earlier decade.

title: TV: DECOY POLICE WORK AS FILMED FOR HBO
description: AS pay-cable channels such as Home Box Office and Showtime are expanding to 24-hour-a-day operations, they are facing increasing pressures to find programming other than movies. There are only so many feature films, old or new, to stretch across their schedules. Sports are attractive, of course, but existing contracts between sports organizations and the commerical networks and stations severely limit the possibilities for cable.

title: News Summary; WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 27, 1981
description: State of the Union The President will stick to the tax cuts that are the basis of his economic recovery program, he vowed in his first State of the Union address, in which he also announced a sweeping plan to transfer $47 billion in Federal programs to state and local governments. Proposing to change the relationship between the Federal Government and the states with ''a single, bold stroke,'' Mr. Reagan called for a ''financially equal swap.'' The Government would exchange its responsibility for food stamps and payments to poor families with dependent children, for the Medicaid program. (Page A1, Column 6.) Continued large budget deficits threaten the economic recovery President Reagan has forecast for this year, Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said at a hearing of Congress's Joint Economic Committee. Rejecting recent criticism of the Fed by the President and Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan, Mr. Volcker said that big deficits - not the Fed's tight monetary policy - were a key cause of continued high interest rates and the chief threat to recovery. The President, in his State of the Union address, asked Congress to approve a program that included major spending cuts but a smaller package of tax increases than his advisers had recommended to reduce the deficit. (A1:3.)
