title: HOW THE 'LIGHT' FOODS ARE CONQUERING AMERICA
description: SO many new ''light'' products have appeared on the market in recent months that light foods and beverages represent the major growth field in the American food industry. Such items as light canned fruit, light pancake mix, light spaghetti sauce, light salad dressing, light ketchup, light frozen dinners, light wine and light cocoa mix can be found on supermarket shelves. Other light fare - it generally contains about a third fewer calories than comparable products - that is to appear soon includes potato chips, snack foods, fruit drinks and cookies.

title: More Robots in Soviet
description: The Soviet Union has decided to increase its production of industrial robots to 8,000 a year, the official Tass press agency reported today. The report did not say when this level would be reached, or what the current level was, but introduction of robots in Soviet industry is just beginning. Tass said a factory in Leningrad was making improved automatic control systems for robots that would be used for assembly, welding, painting, drilling and other operations.

title: NEW YORK REGION WARY OF U.S. PLAN

If successful, Mr. Bradley would become the nation's first elected black governor.

description: WASTING no time, Sears, Roebuck & Company, which said Tuesday that it would consolidate its three apparel accounts at one agency, began talking to Chicago agencies yesterday in its Chicago headquarters. The account - for women's, men's and children's clothing - comes to $30 million.

title: Musical Chairs
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: In your article ''How to Deal Lively Dinner Companions,'' Jan. 21, I noted a ''practice that appears to be growing is that of repositioning half the guests after the main course.'' Some might regard this as discriminatory.

title: CAPITAL IN SNOW: SOME THINGS NEVER CHANGE
description: Most everyone in the nation's capital knows the aphorism: one flake of snow or a few drops of rain and gargantuan traffic jams, scores of fender benders and a fall in Government productivity quickly result.

title: Alexander Abusch Dies at 79; Former East German Official
description: Alexander Abusch, a former East German Deputy Prime Minister and Culture Minister, died today, the East German press agency said. He was 79 years old.

title: RCA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes gains of $3.9 million for the quarter and $9.1 Statement No 52; net income for the quarter and year also includes $10.5 million gain from the sale of tax credits by the company's Hertz corp unit; net income also reflects a $150 million special net charge for the year from the decision to restructure or dispose of certain assets

title: MOBIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: All comparisons of this year's figures with last year's exclude an extraordinary gain of $459 million from Mobil's sale of its interest in Belridge Oil Co in the first quarter of 1980

title: MERRILL LYNCH GIVES MET $300,000 FOR TOUR
description: FOR the first time, the Metropolitan Opera has obtained corporate support for its annual spring tour. Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith Inc., the financial services firm, is contributing $300,000 to the Met to help underwrite the 99th annual tour.

title: WRONG MESSAGE ABOUT FOREIGN DOCTORS
description: To the Editor:

title: News Summary; THURSDAY, JANUARY 28, 1982
description: International Talks on Palestinian self-rule moved into a new phase as the United offered some new formulas to Israeli leaders. Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. met with Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel in an effort to overcome the Israeli differences with Egypt, which have for more than 2 years blocked an accord. (Page1,Column 2.) Peasants in El Salvador are being trained by the Farabundi MartiLiberation Front to become guerrilla fighters. In a school run by the front, Marxist political principles are an integral part of the curriculum for the peasant soldiers, few of whom are more than 24 or 25 years old. (A1:2-4.)

title: Record Bonn Surplus
description: West Germany last month recorded its largest monthly balance of payments surplus, according to official figures issued today. An Economics Ministry spokesman said that the preliminary report of a current account surplus equal to $2.1 billion for December was a sign that the country was ''on the right road.'' December's surplus cut West Germany's 1981 deficit in world trade to the equivalent of $7.6 billion.

title: Streak at 54 Games
description: Louisiana Tech extended its winning streak to 54 games tonight as Pam Kelly scored 18 points to lead an 83-60 victory over Georgia. Louisiana Tech (20-0) led, 35-24, at halftime. Angela Turner scored 12 of her 14 points in the first 11 minutes of the second half to help Louisiana Tech to a 23-point lead.

title: Chrysler Set to Pay Its Final Bank Debt
description: The Chrysler Corporation said today that it will make a $47 million payment to a consortium of banks six weeks ahead of deadline, thus removing the final $1.3 billion in bank debt from its books.

title: VARIAN ASSOCIATES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 1
WATKINS-JOHNSON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Reflects a nonrecurring charge equal to 13 cents a share related to provisions for various claims against the company

title: DU PONT CANADA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After a special charge of $38,242,000 for the quarter and year on withdrawal from polyester textile filament business; C-Net income including a special gain of $7,916,000 for the quarter and year on the sale of an investment; the companyis listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges

title: UNITED TELEVISION INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 27
Bates to Acquire U.S. Oil Assets
description: The Bates Oil Corporation, a subsidiary of the London and Scottish Marine Oil Company, has agreed to buy oil production assets in Kansas, Louisiana and Texas for $29.2 million, the parent company said.

title: Around the Nation; 2 Changes Are Ordered In DC-10 Wing Devices
description: The Federal Aviation Administration has ordered changes in wing devices on DC-10 jetliners that provide extra lift on takeoff and landing to prevent a failure similar to one that contributed to a 1979 Chicago crash that killed 273 persons.

title: Klenetsky to Seek Moynihan's Job
description: Melvin Klenetsky, who picked up 4 percent of the vote in last year's Democratic primary election for Mayor of New York City, announced yesterday that he was a candidate for the United States Senate seat now held by Daniel Patrick Moynihan.

title: HARVARD STUDENT'S DISAPPEARANCE BAFFLES POLICE
description: Joan Webster, a 25-year-old architectural student at Harvard University's Graduate School of Design, returned to her home her e in a bouyant mood last Novem ber, delighted that a design project had won an excellent critique from her professors. HerThanksgiving weekend began with a family dinn er and a trip to Manhattan for a Broadway show. It ended in da rk mystery in Boston.

title: Bernard Barker to Retire From Miami Job Early
description: Bernard L. Barker, who led the burglars who broke into Democratic National Committee headquarters in the Watergate complex, has decided to take early retirement from his job in Miami rather than fight charges that he had been loafing and taking three-hour coffee breaks. If it had not been for his Watergate connection, he said, ''it would go unnoticed.''

title: TALKS ON LOANS WORRY POLAND
description: Poland expects to reach an agreement next month with Western banks to reschedule Warsaw's large loans from these creditors, but the Government here is deeply concerned about the suspension of talks on the debt owed to Western governments, according to a Finance Ministry official.

title: HOUGHTON MIFFLIN CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results for the latest year reflect a charge equal to 12 cents a share for a LIFO provision

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I liked it better when the actors kept their clothes on.'' - Ronald Reagan. (B8:5.)

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article yesterday about a Young Playwrights Festival incorrectly iden- tified the president of the Dramatists Guild. He is Peter Stone.

title: INTERNATIONAL SHIPHOLDING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including an extraordinary tax credit of $4,622,000; C-Net loss including a nonrecurring gain of $2,953,000 from the sale of vessels; year-ago revenues have been restated to exclude a gain on the sale of vessels

title: TIDEWATER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results restated to include the accounts of RL Frailey Inc acquired in June 1981

title: Costa Rica Parties in Clash
description: Supporters of two political parties in the Feb. 7 presidential elections clashed here with sticks and stones on Tuesday. Five youths were taken to a hospital with minor injuries.

title: ELCOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
US F&G CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company formerly was named US Fidelity & Guaranty

title: MERGER OF 2 YEMENS BLOCKED BY IDEOLOGY, KUWAIT OFFICIALS SAY
description: Kuwaiti officials who helped negotiate an agreement in 1979 for the eventual merger of pro-Western Yemen and Soviet-backed Southern Yemen say ideological and other differences between the two countries appear to be a major obstacle to unity.

title: BEAR CREEK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
VALVE'S FAILURE LET A BUBBLE BUILD UP IN UPSTATE REACTOR
description: The failure of a crucial valve during the nuclear accident in Ontario, N.Y., Monday allowed a steam bubble to form in the reactor vessel, officials of Rochester Gas and Electric said yesterday.

title: MEAD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
INGERSOLL-RAND reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company adopted FASB Statement No 52 regarding foreign currency translations effective Jan 1 1981; for the 1981 year share earnings were favorably affectedby $1.17 a share as a result of the accounting change

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL BOSTON (AL) - Announced that Glenn Hoffman, a shortstop who had sought arbi- tration, agreed to a one-year contract.

title: UNION TRUST BANCORP (BALTIMORE, MD) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FIRST WESTERN FIANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SURGEON TERMED SUSPECT IN ATTACK ON ASSISTANT AT A BRONX HOSPITAL
description: The Bronx District Attorney said yesterday that a surgeon at Montefiore Hospital was a suspect in a near-fatal hammer attack New Year's Eve on a woman who worked with him.

title: Transit Report
description: L.I.R.R.: Of 134 trains scheduled in the morning rush hour, 42 were late, the tardiest by 25 minutes. CONRAIL: Of 29 Hudson Division morning-rush trains, one was canceled and 20 were late, with the 6 o'clock from Croton-Harmon, due at Grand Central at 7:05, running 72 minutes late.

title: BROOKLYN UNION GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
AGAINST INDEXING TAXES TO INFLATION
description: Congress and the country know how much President Reagan values consistency. His report on the State of the Union reveals that it is essential to his perception of Presidential power and leadership.

title: AMP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results reflect reductions from foreign currency translations equal to 1 cent and 21 cents for the latest quarter and year and 5 cents and 7 cents for the year-ago quarter and year

title: GUERRILLAS HIJACK COLOMBIA AIRLINER
description: Guerrillas hijacked a Colombian airliner today and forced it to fly to Cali, where they released 47 of the 128 people aboard.

title: RCA NET OFF 26.9% IN QUARTER
description: The RCA Corporation announced yesterday that its earnings for last year's fourth quarter fell 26.9 percent, while profits for the full year plummeted 82.9 percent - the second-largest annual decline in the company's 63-year history.

title: News Analysis
description: In his first State of the Union Message, President Reagan conceded that the recession had wrecked his Administration's early economic forecasts. But he once again asserted that his program, based first and foremost on supply-side economics, would work.

title: UNIVERSAL SECURITY INSTRUMENT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net income; share earnings for 1980 nine months reflect 3-for-2 stock split as of the June 25, 1981

title: YANKEE OIL & GAS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
A String of Luck for a Ventriloquist
description: It's not easy for a newcomer to break into show business in New York, and nobody knows that better than Ronn Lucas, a ventriloquist, whose specialty has not been much in demand.

title: A CONGRESSIONAL REFUSAL TO SHARE THE SACRIFICE
description: To the Editor:

title: PHILIP MORRIS RISES BY 11.1%
description: Philip Morris Inc. reported yesterday that strong growth in its cigarette and beer operations helped lift earnings in the fourth quarter of 1981 by 11.1 percent, while revenues advanced 6.3 percent.

title: GOVERNORS SPLIT OVER REAGAN PROPOSALS
description: The nation's governors, who ordinarily avoid party lines on issues of state power, divided in unusually partisan ranks today in assessing President Reagan's proposals for shifting programs between the state and Federal governments. Democratic criticism was somewhat more solid than Republican support.

title: CPT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

title: South African Gold Output
description: Gold production in South Africa, which is facing a record deficit in its balance of payments, fell by 2.5 percent last year, to 657 tons from 674 tons in 1980, according to figures released today by the Chamber of Mines.

title: STRUGGLE LOOMS OVER MINERS' LEADERSHIP
description: Another potentially bruising battle for the presidency of the United Mine Workers of America began taking shape today on the ashes of the union career of Jack Perry, for nine years the regional president of the union's D istrict 17.

title: Large Gift for Olympics
description: Don King gave the financially hard pressed United States Olympic Committee a multimillion-dollar boost by promising to donate part of each ticket sold at major championship fights that he promotes. King, who recently joined the U.S.O.C. as a fund-raising adviser, said $1 from each ticket sold for the live gate and 25 cents from each ticket-holder attending a closed-circuit showing would be earmarked for the committee, beginning with Saturday's fight between Wilfred Benitez and Roberto Duran for the World Boxing Council junior middleweight title. The committee's executive director, F. Don Miller, said King's donation was ''the single largest contribution in the history of the U.S.O.C., and we've been around since 1896.''

title: Military Analysis
description: NATO analysts are becoming increasingly concerned over what they regard as the alliance's deteriorating situation on its southeastern flank, anchored on

title: DELMARVA POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Marlborough to Display Larry Rivers Abstracts
description: A show of recent work by Larry Rivers, ''The Continuing Interest in Abstract Art,'' will open at the Marlborough Gallery on Tuesday at 6 P.M. The exhibition, a benefit for the Poetry Project at St. Mark's Church, will continue until Feb. 28.

title: WESTERN AIR LINES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
The Police Blotter
description: Three teen-agers were arrested and charged with smashing in the front door of a single-family house in St. Albans, Queens, at 11 A.M. yesterday and robbing and sexually molesting an 83-year-old woman who lived alone there. They were identified as Almando Richardson, 19; Joseph Basset, 17, and Tapel LeCount, 15, all of St. Albans. ... The body of a man about 24 years old was found with stab wounds in his apartment at 40 Sherman Avenue in the Inwood section of Manhattan at about 1 P.M. yesterday. His name was not rele ased by the police.

title: JB'S RESTAURANTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 20
SEARLE, G D, & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes $9 million gain for quarter and year from reduction of 1977 discontinued business reserve and $4.3 million charge for quarter from accounting change; net income for year also includes $2.5 million loss from operations, $32.5 million loss on disposition of operations and $6.2 million loss from accounting change; C-After losses from discontinued operations of $3.1 million for quarter and$16 million for year and $13 million tax credit for year

title: MANY FAMILIES IN EAST HARLEM SEEK FOOD AID
description: East Harlem has experienced a dramatic increase in the number of people who say they have inadequate food supplies for themselves and their families, a study by a coalition of voluntary agencies suggests.

title: No Headline
description: REBELS DAMAGE PLANES AT MAJOR BASE

title: THEATER CHAIN SHOWS A DRAMAMTIC SAFETY FILM
description: People who go to one of eight K-B Theaters here this weekend expecting to see ''The Story of O,'' ''Venom'' or ''Raiders of the Lost Ark'' may be surprised when the curtain opens to an utterly serious short film dealing with facial injuries sustained in automobile accidents.

title: SAINT LAURENTS GIVENCHY SHINE
description: It is the year for anniversaries for the haute couture. The spring and summer collection this morning of the stillboyish Yves Saint Laurent marked the designer's 20th year as head of his own couture house. In the afternoon, the elegant, silver-haired Hubert de Givenchy celebrated his 30th year as a couturier. For both designers it was a moving occasion.

title: PUBLIC LIBRARY GETS $375,000
description: Two gifts totaling $375,000 have been given to the New York Public Library. One is earmarked to preserve books on hand and to acquire more, and the other to enable the Central Research Library at Fifth Avenue and 42d Street to remain open six days a week instead of the present five.

title: KALLUR INJURED
description: Anders Kallur tore the ligaments in his right knee in the second period and never returned. Clark Gillies was back on Long Island with his wife, who gave birth tonight to their third daughter. And Bob Bourne was out with a bad back. Three left wings out of commission for the Islanders.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rat e payable by savings institutions.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: U.S. TO SELL $10 BILLION OF DEBT
description: The Treasury yesterday announced a $10 billion financing package for sale next week - a record borrowing and a vivid reminder to the credit markets that the Federal budget is deeply in deficit.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Adams-Russell Co. has named John J. Lynch, president, to the additional post of chief executive officer, succeeding Gerald J. Adams, who remains chairman.

title: LTV CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
COOPER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $4,812,000 for quarter and $15,884,000 for year and $27,391,000 gain for quarter and year on sale of a unit;C-Including income from discontinued operations of $3,758,000for quarter and $13,786,000 for year; results for latest year include operations of Krisch Co, acquired on April 1, 1981 and accounted for as purchase; year-ago results have beenrestated to include Crouse-Hinds Co on pooling of interests basis

title: HAIG IS IN ISRAEL WITH NEW IDEAS FOR WEST BANK
description: The United States opened a new phase today in the drawn-out negotiations on Palestinian self-rule by offering Israel some new formulas for resolving differences with Egypt.

title: REAGAN SAYS HAIG MET KEY CUBAN
description: President Reagan said today that Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr., on a visit to Mexico last fall, met secretly with Vice President Carlos Rafael Rodriguez of Cuba.

title: VULCAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FAVORITE FAILS AT HIALEAH
description: Aloma's Ruler took the lead at the top of the stretch and went on to win the $38,550 Bahamas Stakes at Hialeah Park today, beating a field of 3-year-olds that included las t year's 2-year-old champion, Deputy Minis ter.

title: THURSDAY, JANUARY 28, 1982; Markets
description: The Treasury announced a $10 billion financing package for sale next week, higher than securities dealers had expected. They said they expected strong demand despite high interest rates. Prices of outstanding Treasury notes and bonds declined modestly after the announcement. (Page D1.)

title: FOOD TOWN STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results are for 12 weeks and 52 weeks for the latest periods and for 13 weeks and 53 weeks for the year-ago periods

title: Soybean Futures Rally; Grain, Gold Also Up
description: Soybean futures prices rallied strongly and pulled grains up with them yesterday as traders focused again on drought conditions in Brazil.

title: RESTORING KEEN'S: IT JUST LOOKED EASY
description: IT seemed to Kiki Kogelnik and Dr. George Schwarz that it would be a cinch to reopen one of New York's oldest restaurants, Keen's Chop House, at 72 West 36th Street.

title: GREIF BROS CORP reports earnings for Yr to Oct 31
description: Share earnings are per Class A stock; the company is listed on the Midwest Stock Exchange

title: SHELL OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Yugoslav Office Is Bombed
description: A bomb wrecked the front of a Yugoslav cultural office today, causing $22,000 in damage.

title: Ex-Yale Instructor Faces Deportation
description: NEW HAVEN (AP) - The United States Justice Department began deportation proceedings here against a former Yale University instructor who the Government contends was a Nazi propagandist in World War II.

title: I.R.S. Seeks Tax From Form Maker
description: The Reynolds & Reynolds Company, a manufacturer of business forms, said that the Internal Revenue Service had charged it with an income tax deficiency of $1.4 million plus interest for 1977 and 1979.

title: POLISH PRIMATE EXPECTED TO VISIT POPE NEXT WEEK
description: A Polish source at the Vatican said today that Archbishop Jozef Glemp, the Primate of Poland, would arrive on Feb. 4 to report to Pope John Paul II on the Polish situation.

title: Charles Frost Craig, 86, Brigadier General, Dies
description: Brig. Gen. Charles Frost Craig, for whom the Berlin Wall's Checkpoint Charlie is named, died Saturday in Asheville, N.C., after a long illness. The general was a resident of Asheville.

title: Fire Kills Mother T rying to Save Son
description: YONKERS (AP) - A 40-year-old mother of three was killed Wednesday when she dash ed back into her blazing home in a futile attempt to rescue her 7- year-old son.

title: DANCE: TALE OF 'POSTWAR' BY TIM MILLER
description: ON Tuesday night, the very night that President Reagan delivered his State of the Union message, Tim Miller examined the state of the Union choreographically and found it not to his liking. He even made President Reagan - at least, a facsimile thereof - part of the cast of ''Postwar,'' his dance-theater piece at the Bessie Schonberg Theater.

title: MAGNUSON CHAIRMAN RESIGNS
description: Joseph L. Hitt, chairman of troubled Magnuson Computer Systems, resigned unexpectedly, the company announced today.

title: ELECTRONICS CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
ARO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
3 Children Are Killed In a Blaze in Brooklyn
description: Three children were killed yesterday in a fire on the top floor of a three-story building in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn. The children's mother was able to rescue a fourth child, authorities said.

title: NORTHERN CALIF SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Dow Up on Higher Volume
description: Stock prices edged higher yesterday after showing modest declines in the three previous sessions. President Reagan's State of the Union Message on Tuesday night exerted ''little impact'' upon the market, according to Lee H. Idleman, research director of Dean Witter Reynolds Inc.

title: SALVADOR'S REBELS BID REAGAN ACCEPT A NEGOTIATED SOLUTION
description: In an open letter to President Reagan, the five commanders of El Salvador's guerrilla movement have called on the United States to change its policy and accept a negotiated solution to the civil war.

title: POLAND REPORTED PAYING DEBT UNAIDED BY SOVIET
description: Administration economic officials said today that the Soviet Union, contrary to speculation, had not been making international debt payments for Poland, but the Polish Government, from its own resources, had managed to pay since mid-December $100 million in overdue interest to Western banks. Robert D. H ormats, Assistant Secretary of State for Economic and Business Affa irs, and Marc E. Leland,

title: St. John's and Duke Triumph
description: In a game that the winning coach said ''wasn't a Mona Lisa,'' St. John's used all 13 members of its basketball team and defeated Army, 67-54, tonight.

title: Home Sales Off 19% in '81
description: Sales of existing houses fell 19 percent last year from 1980 levels but were picking up, at least slightly, as the year ended, a real estate trade group reported today.

title: HEBREW SYMBOLISM SPURRING DONATIONS TO AID THE NEEDIEST
description: Because the two Hebrew letters in the word ''chai,'' or ''life,'' are the eighth and 10th of that alphabet, the number 18 as an expression of goodwill and good wishes often appears in messages enclosed with contributions to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: INTERPACE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After a loss of $871,000 for the quarter and a gain of $202,000 for the year from discontinued operations; C-including income from discontinued operations of$2,580,000 for the quarter and $6,184,000 for the year; year-ago results have been restated to reflect discontinued operations

title: Joseph Raskin, 84, an Artist And Co-Author of 10 Books
description: Joseph Raskin, an artist, etcher and co-author with his wife, Edith, of 10 books for young adults, died in Manhattan on Tuesday. He was 84 years old.

title: HARLAND, JOHN H, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Around the Nation; Oglala Sioux Tribe Seeks Old Hearst Gold Mine
description: A 106-year-old claim to the gold mine that helped finance the Hearst newspaper empire has become the object of a $6 billion lawsuit by the Oglala Sioux tribe in its attempt to regain the land from the Homestake Mining Company.

title: FL OOD SWEEPS AWAY 17 VILLAGES IN NORTHEAST PERU
description: At least 600 people, and possibly as many as 2,500, were dead or missing after the flooding of the Chontayacu River over the weekend, according to reports reaching here today.

title: RANCHERS SAY YELLOWSTONE'S ELK HERD IS TOO MUCH AT HOME ON THEIR RANGE
description: This winter, more and more of the great herd of elk that live in the northern part of Yellowstone National Park have been fording the cold, crystal river that tumbles along its northern boundary and wandering across public and private grazing lands and fields in sea rch of forage.

title: PAINE WEBBER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Q & A
description: Q. I recently purchased a house that has a basement that is finished with wood paneling. This paneling has heavy black mildew stains on it. What can I do to remove these stains, and how can the panels be refinished to prevent a recurrence? -P.E.G., White Plains, N.Y.

title: SENATE PANEL IS TOLD REAGAN SUPPORTS VOTING RIGHTS ACT
description: The Reagan Administration, in testimony before a Senate Judiciary subcommittee today, supported extension of key provisions of the Voting Rights Act, saying there was a continuing need to protect the rights of voters who are members of minority groups.

title: GERBER PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After an extraordinary charge of $3,627,881 for the quarter and 9 months; C-Including an extraordinary credit of $1,797,000

title: Kuwait in Talks On Oil Refinery
description: Kuwaiti oil officials are discussing the possible purchase of the Gulf Oil Corporation's British refinery, according to industry sources here.

title: WETTERAU INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
HERS
description: ''Tell me all about yourself! What do you think of me?'' This is how my mother used to parody a woman in town - let us call her ''Mimi'' - whom she often met at social functions. It was terribly funny, my mother's act, because she caught to perfection the way this woman cocked her head and blinked a mile a minute while rushing through the traffic of amenities in order to get home to herself.

title: No Headline
description: MRS. REAGAN'S OUTFITS' POSSIBLY TAXABLE ITEMS

title: AIRLINES SET INCREASES IN SOME EUROPE FAR
description: Several major airlines, trying to revive a system of agreement on North Atlantic fares, have come up with a series of fare increases - averaging about 7 percent - and some fare cuts on major routes between the United States and Europe. They hope to put the changes into effect March 1.

title: PHILIP MORRIS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BAIRNCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CARTER-WALLACE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After approximate foreign currency translations losses of $375,000 for quarter and $150,000, for 9 months and $1.6 million, or 21 cents a share, gain for 9 months on sale of investment; results for latest periods reflect adoption of accounting change for foreign currency translations which reduced net income by approximately $60,000, or 1 cent a share, for quarter and increased net income by $1,250,000, or 16 cents a share, for 9 months

title: McEnroe, Sandy Mayer And Gerulaitis Advance
description: Top-seeded John McEnroe won his first-round match, and Vitas Gerulaitis and Sandy Mayer posted second-round victories tonight in the $300,000 United States pro indoor tennis championships.

title: American Can
description: The American Can Company said that about 4.56 milllion of its shares were tendered under an offer made Jan. 12 to buy back 2 million of its shares. The company said it had accepted for payment 2.2 million shares, including about 93,000 shares tendered by odd-lot holders, and had elected not to accept any additional shares.

title: THE STAGE: SURREALISTIC 'WHITE ANT'
description: SNOO WILSON is, along with David Hare, Howard Brenton, Howard Barker and others, one of a wave of young, politically aware English playwrights. However, in contrast to his peers, he is a Surrealist and a fantasist. His plays, such as ''The Soul of the White Ant,'' at the New York Theater Studio, are filled with turnabouts, the theatrical equivalent of reverse somersaults.

title: FEDERAL PAPER BOARD CO INC reports earnings for 17 wks to Dec 31
description: Results are for 17 weeks and 53 weeks for the latest periods and 16 and 52 weeks for the year-ago periods

title: New President Named At Smith & Wesson
description: Lee J. Deters has been named president and chief executive officer of the Smith & Wesson subsidiary of the Bango r Punta Corporation, which is based in Springfield, Mass. He succe eds James L. Oberg, who remains a senior vice president of Bangor Pun ta.

title: LTV POSTS A 94.8% GAIN
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation, the nation's second-largest steelmaker, reported that earnings in the fourth quarter dropped 44.3 percent from the comparable 1980 period.

title: COLLAGEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Agency Plans Bid To Control Spencer
description: Agency Rent-A-Car Inc. said that it planned to increase its interest in the Spencer Companies by making a cash tender offer, subject to certain conditions and regulatory approval, for up to 250,000 shares of Spencer stock at $15 a shar e.

title: Semiconductor memory market Market Place
description: Semiconductor Hopes for Intel IT'S no sec ret that the Intel Corporation, the creator of semiconductor memory, has fallen far behind in this developing technology. L ast year, the company decided that its entry in the growing 64,00 0-bit random access memory business was unsatisfactory. Intel withdre w as competitors raced to exploit their own 64K RAM devices.

title: PHILADELPHIA BULLETIN WILL CEASE PUBLICATION WITH ISSUE ON FRIDAY
description: The Bulletin, a Philadelphia institution for 134 years and once the country's largest afternoon newspaper, will cease publication with its Friday issue.

title: Mideast Investment
description: Finance ministers of the six-nation Gulf Cooperation Council decided in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, to set up a Gulf investment corporation wi th initial capi tal of $3 billion, the official Qatar news agency said today. The mi nisters also formed five committees of experts to work out detail s on putting into effectan economic agreement along the lines of the European Economic Commission, the agency said. The council comp rises Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, Oman, Bahrain, Qatar and the United A rab Emirates.

title: Two Survive as Jet Crashes
description: An Air Force F-111 jet fighter on a routine flight burst into flames today and crashed in a rural field southwest of this town in northern California, but the two crew members parachuted to safety, officials said. The crew members were identified as Maj. Tadziu Sienicki and Capt. Jack Leslie.

title: Technology Magazine Set for New York State
description: A company called Consultech Communications has been formed in Troy, N.Y., to publish a bimonthly magazine called Technology NY that will deal with high technology in the Empire State.

title: CONTINUUM CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings have been adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split in January

title: FINAL REPORT ON U.S. LAETRILE STUDY SAYS DRUP HAS NO VALUE
description: The drug laetrile has produced ''no therapeutic benefit'' against cancer, according to the final report of a Government-sponsored study.

title: FINANCIAL CORP OF SANTA BARBARA reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
The New Old Deal
description: In one sense, the President has truly become Franklin Delano Reagan.

title: JEAN OUTLAND CHRYSLER
description: Jean Outland Chrysler, wife of Walter P. Chrysler Jr., the founder and chairman of the board of the Chrysler Museum in Norfolk, Va., died Tuesday at Norfolk Ge neral Hospital.

title: AMERICAN INDEMNITY FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago per share figures have been adjusted to reflect the 10% stock dividenddeclared in January 1981

title: NEW DATA ON SHROUD OF TURIN
description: A comparison of the images of Jesus on a sixth-century Byzantine icon and on a seventh-century coin with the image on the Shroud of Turin show ''astonishing'' si milarities that raise anew speculation that this cou ld be Christ's burial cloth, a Duke University professor rep orted yesterday.

title: INA Earnings Flat in Quarter
description: The INA Corporation reported yesterday that it had operating income of $72.1 million, or $1.79 a share, in the fourth quarter of 1981, essentially unchanged from $71.8 million, or $1.79, in the quarter a year earlier.

title: Appeal Rejected
description: The University of Nevada-Las Vegas Intercollegiate Athletic Council rejected an appeal by Michael Burns, a senior basketball player who was ruled ineligible Jan. 15 for ''flagrant disregard'' of academic requirements because he failed to attend class regularly and did not take final examinations. . . . Kelly Tripucka, a rookie for the Indiana Pacers, will replace Dan Roundfield of the Atlanta Hawks on the East squad in the NBA All-Star Game at Brendan Byrne Arena in the Meadowlands on Sunday. Roundfield has two sore hamstring muscles and a sore Achilles' tendon.

title: SOURCES OF INFORMATION
description: An excellent source of information on buying life insurance is ''Consumers Union Report on Life Insurance,'' coordinated and written by John Dorfman ($7.50 plus $1.75 for postage and handling, from Consumer Reports Books, Box C-719, Brooklyn, N.Y. 11205; an edition published by Holt Rinehart & Winston is available in bookstores).

title: Paine Webber Has Lower Net
description: Paine Webber Inc., citing lower brokerage commissions, said yesterday that its profit in the fiscal first quarter fell 31 percent from a year earlier, despite a 3 percent rise in revenues.

title: REAGAN EXPECTED TO BACK MORE AID FOR SALVADOR JUNTA
description: Despite reports of a large-scale massacre of civilians by Government troops in El Salvador, President Reagan is still expected to certify that the Salvadoran security forces are making a ''concerted and significant effort'' to respect human rights.

title: WEST GERMANY, TOO, IS FACING A CRISIS OF THE CITIES
description: For many West Germans, this city has a cruelly dismal reputation as just another Ruhr town, a workaday place in a valley of smoke and smog and sweat.

title: YOU WON'T BELIEVE WHAT I JUST HEARD
description: President Reagan has discovered it. Lyndon B. Johnson was masterly in using it. John F. Kennedy was eager to hear it. And Franklin Delano Roosevelt had a rule about it: The first item of business at his daily staff meeting was a run-down on the latest gossip.

title: INTERNATIONAL DAIRY QUEEN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Cross-Ownership Ban In N.F.L. Struck Down
description: A Federal appeals court ruled against the National Football League yesterday, deciding that owners of N.F.L. teams have a legal right to own interest in other pro sports teams.

title: I.M.F. Loans In 1981 Noted
description: The International Monetary Fund pledged $17.5 billion in loans to poor countries last year, more than double the 1980 figure, but only $4.25 billion of the promised sums was paid, according to figures released today.

title: PANHANDLE EASTERN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After tax credits of $48.3 million in 1981 and $38.2 million in 1980

title: Brunswick Opposes Whittaker Offer
description: The board of directors of the Brunswick Corporation of Skokie, Ill., a major producer of recreational products, voted unanimously yesterday to recommend that shareholders reject a $668 million acquisition bid from the Whittaker Corporation, a diversified manufacturing company based in Los Angeles.

title: SYRIANS FAIL TO UNITE ARABS ON GOLAN ANNEXATION
description: Arab and Western diplomats say Syria has been forced to give up another attempt to bring about a unified Arab position against Israel's annexation of the Golan Heights.

title: REAGAN CALLS NEW MOVIES TOO RISQ UE
description: President Reagan today denounced the profanity and nudity encountered in current motion pictures and praised the voluntary self-censorship the film industry practiced when he was an actor.

title: PARKWAY CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
REYNOLDS & REYNOLDS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MR. ZERO GOES TO WASHINGTON
description: Among all the legal problems facing the Reagan Administration and the country, Attorney General William French Smith sees one alarming threat. That is the failure of the Supreme Court and other Federal courts to exercise ''judicial restraint.'' Three times in the last three months Mr. Smith has made major speeches on the subject. He charged the courts with expanding their interpretation of constitutional rights, lowering the barriers to lawsuits, substituting ''judicial judgment for legislative judgment.'' This week he told the American Bar Association it was time judges stopped their ''political policy-making.''

title: ST REGIS PAPER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
3 Banks Offering 'Art Lobby' Exhibition
description: The lobbies and windows of three banks in the financial district will be adorned with conceptual art works in ''Art Lobby,'' an exhibition coordinated by the Lower Manhattan Cultural Council.

title: GLOBAL MARINE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Woman, Shot by Bow, Dies
description: A 30-year-old woman, Michelle Rae Powers, died today nearly a week after an unknown assailant shot her in the chest with an aluminum shaft from a crossbow, a powerful weapon dating to medieval times. She was shot last Thursday outside her home.

title: Fund Drive at Nebraska
description: Football boosters at the University of Nebraska have opened a drive to raise $100,000 for Coach Tom Osborne and his staff.

title: BELL'S BREAKUP SPLITS FAMILY
description: The first of four generations of Kincys in the Bell System - 17 people in all - went to work for the telephone company here on New Year's Day, 1898, not quite 22 years after Alexander Graham Bell invented the telephone.

title: Forum B oxing Ca nceled
description: Tomorrow night's six-bout card at the Felt Forum was canceled yesterday because six fighters refused to wear the thumbless boxing gloves that became mandatory for nontitle bouts in New York State Jan.15.

title: 8.4% Hall Stake Held by Ryder
description: The Ryder System Inc., a Miami-based truck leasing and transportation company, said it had increased its stake in Frank B. Hall & Company to 8.4 percent of the common stock outstanding. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Ryder said it and its subsidiary, JCB Inc., now hold 969,100 of Hall's common shares, including 123,500 shares purchased for $3.3 million between Jan. 6 and Jan. 25.

title: PEABODY INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes gain equal of 75 cents a share from operations spun off, discontinued and sold

title: Golf Course for China
description: Arnold Palmer said he had reached agreement with representatives from Peking to build in Canton what will reportedly be China's first golf course. Palmer said 4,000 Chinese would be hired to construct the course, which he expects to be ready by October. . . . Ray Volpe, commissioner of the Ladies Professional Golf Association, resigned after seven years, saying he thought that his job of building a strong organization had been completed. He will be replaced on April 15 by John Laupheimer, the association's executive director.

title: POP: DEPECHE MODE AT RITZ
description: MECHANICAL, heavily synthesized pop music has become such a commonplace that the American debut last week end at the Ritz of Depeche Mode, a young English answer to Kraft werk, was less than overwhelming. Consisting of four young men, three synthesizers and a tape recorder playing prerecorded rhythm tracks, Depeche Mode makes gloomy merry-go-round music with a danceable beat.

title: BRUNSWICK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
RATING THE THINGS AMERICANS VALUE
description: OWNING a ni ce home, a car or other material possessions is less important to Americans than certain intangible personal values, according to the results of a Gallup Poll officially released today. Those who res ponded to the survey listed having a good family life, physical heal th, self-respect and happiness as more important.

title: BULLETIN SUCCUMBING TO TV, NEW WAYS OF LIVE AND AGGRESSIVE COMPETITION
description: For decades, long enough to make the slogan a catch phrase in the city, the newspaper's advertisements said: ''In Philadelphia, nearly everybody reads The Bulletin.''

title: No Headline
description: KNICKS ROUTED BY 131-99 AFTER A 10-POINT QUARTER

title: Congress; IS THERE LIFE AFTER THE SENATE?  MANY SAY YES
description: It's one of those delicate subjects that senators, especially veteran senators, rarely discuss in public. But among themselves, in the privacy of The Club, in Capitol cloakrooms and at small dinner parties, the topic comes up increasingly: retirement. Voluntary retirement, that is, rather than the kind administered by the voters.

title: By Sports of The Times; Sam Huff in Hall of Fame
description: TWO years ago Sam Huff was about to be interviewed by a radio announcer, who introduced him as a member of the Pro Football Hall of Fame.

title: Oilers 3, Hawks 3
description: CHICAGO (UPI) - Wayne Gretzky scored his 63d goal of the season on a power play with 9:21 remaining to gain the tie for Edmonton.

title: FRANTZ MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Around the Nation; Police on Coast Detail 'Russian Mafia' Cases
description: Police officials today provided details of two criminal cases involving Russian immigrants to bolster a report that a ''Russian Mafia'' posed a growing threat that could embarrass the United States during the 1984 Olympic Games.

title: WHAT JESUS THOUGHT OF PUBLIC PRAYERS
description: To the Editor:

title: PIANO: SCHEJA IN 19TH CENTURY
description: STAFFAN SCHEJA, the Swedish pianist, played a program of 19thcentury piano music at Alice Tully Hall Monday night, including the Beethoven A-flat Sonata (Op. 26), Schumann's ''Kreisleriana,'' two Liszt pieces and two of the Chopin Ballades.

title: F.C.C. SETS REVIEW ON SATELLITE POLICY
description: The Federal Communications Commission will begin a re-examination on Thursday of its policies governing satellite services and will rule on the legality of private carriers auctioning satellite circuits to the highest bidder.

title: Around the World; Finn Assumes Office; N otes Soviet Friendship
description: Mauno Koivisto, the new President, was sworn in today at a ceremony before Parliament.

title: Whalers 3, Flames 1
description: HARTFORD (UPI) - Ron Francis, Blaine Stoughton and Pierre Larouche scored a goal apiece tonight to lead Hartford to victory despite a fine effort by the Calgary goalie, Rejean Lemelin, who stopped 44 shots.

title: HONDURAS INSTALLS A CIVILIAN LEADER
description: A moderate conservative, Dr. Roberto Suazo Cordova, today became the first civilian President of Honduras in a decade, raising hopes that this backward Central American republic could escape the political violence affecting much of the region.

title: BRUSH WELLMAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Punch Line Theater Holding Gala Tuesday
description: Comedians, authors and actors will participate on Tuesday in ''Salute to M etropolitan Comedy,'' a benefit for the Manhattan Punch Line Theater. The show will be given on the balcony of the Port Authority Bus Terminal annex at 42d Street and Eighth Avenue.

title: SAVOY INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: B-Net loss after $66,000 loss from discontinued operations

title: Around the World; Upper-Caste Hindus Kill Family of Untouchables
description: Upper-caste Hindus attacked and killed 13 members of a family from an untouchable community in the state of Madhya Pradesh, officials said today.

title: New Train Engineers' Strike H alts British Railway System
description: Harassed commuters struggled to and from work today as Britain's 25,000 train engine ers staged their third 48-hour strike over a pay and productiv ity dispute.

title: Again and Again; Repetition Is the Key, Repetition Is the Key
description: ''Copy gets dull if you have to listen to a minute of it over and over,'' Jack Lawrence was saying Monday. ''What attracts the ear is the repetition of a musical phrase.''

title: Greece Seeks 2 Exxon Units
description: The Greek Government plans to nationalize refining and petrochemical companies owned by the Exxon Corporation, the Minister of Industry and Energy, Anastasios Peponis, said today.

title: BUTLER MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $537,000 for the quarter and$1.6 million for the year; C-Including $2,950,000 income from discontinued operations; year-ago results have been restated to reflect an accounting change

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: THE spray attachment built into many kitchen sinks is designed to shut off water flowing from the faucet and divert it to the spray head when a lever is depressed on the spray head. In some models the faucet water is shut off completely, but in many a slight trickle from the spout is normal while the spray is in use.

title: ATLAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including tax credits of $1,006,000 for the quarter and $1,938,000 for the 6 months; C-Including tax credits of $222,000 for the quarter and $302,000 for the6 months

title: HIGH TIME TO RAISE DOG LICENSE FEES
description: To the Editor:

title: Clippers' Owner Tells Of Financial Problems
description: Donald Sterling, the owner of the San Diego Clippers, has notified the National Basketball Associati on thathe has financial problems, Russell T. Grant, the league's general counsel, said today.

title: SYSCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 2
COUNSEL FOR PUBLIC INQUIRIES
description: Benjamin A. Matthews, a lawyer who participated in public investigations that ranged from an inquiry into draft evasion in World War I to one into political corruption in New York State in the early 1950's, died Monday at his son's home in Jamesville, N.Y. He was 91 years old and had moved to Jamesville in 1980 after more than 65 years in M anhattan.

title: Nets Defeated, 130-116
description: Kiki Vandeweghe scored 17 of his seasonhigh 29 points in the third quarter tonight and the Denver Nuggets breezed to a 130-116 victory over the New Jersey Nets.

title: A BOYCOTT OF TV ADVERTISERS IS AGAIN THREATENED
description: For the second time within a year, the Coalition for Better Television is threatening a boycott of one or more companies that advertise on prime-time television, but this time without the support of its most prominent member, the Moral Majority.

title: MONTANA POWER CO reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
On the Origins of Snobs
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: Gail Godwin's amusing piece on snobs (''Hers,'' Jan. 7) tempts me to wonder why she so readily swallowed the notion that snob came from Old Norse.

title: No Headline
description: The Reagan Administration today opened a campaign to sell its ''new federalism'' initiative with an assurance that the proposed transfer of 43 different programs to the states would be accompanied by a requirement that current benefits for the poor be maintained for at least five years.

title: INA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Net income; C-includes $304 million gain from disposal of operations

title: IN SALVADOR CLASS, MARTIAL ARTS AND MARXISM
description: Twenty-four peasants were receiving their first formal military training near here as members of the sixth class of the Farabundi Marti National Liberation Front's military school for the Eastern Front.

title: Stocks of Oil Slip in Japan
description: Japan, which imports almost all its crude oil, reduced its stocks of crude and petroleum products slightly last year because of a steady decline in domestic demand, the Ministry for International Trade and Industry said today.

title: SAN FRANCISCO REAL ESTATE INVESTORS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
A SENSATIONAL ENDING-BUT IT CAME TOO LATE
description: MUSIC critics sometimes seem to be grumpy negativists incapable of liking anything. But beneath the crusty surface of almost any one of them you will find a confirmed music-lover who really wants all the performers he hears to be successful in every way. And, more often than might be supposed, the critic is saddened by a performer's failure to make the most of the opportuniti es at hand.

title: FORT DEARBORN INCOME SECURITIES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
COMPTROLLER DEFENDS NOTE SHIFT
description: New York State's decision to drop the powerful Bank of America National Trust and Savings Association as underwriting manager for note sales was defended yesterday by Edward V. Regan, New York State Comptroller, amid rising criticism of the action by many bankers.

title: 2 I.R.A. SUPPORTERS ORDERED BY A JUDGE TO GET OUT OF U.S.
description: Two Irish nationalists, indicted on charges of trying to illegally enter the United States from Canada, were ordered deported today by a Federal immigration judge.

title: FOR FIXING UP A TRUNK
description: IF you have an old trunk you want to fix up, there are several mail-order sources for locks, handles, staves, nails with decorative heads and all the other components necessary to restore a trunk.

title: Dollar Finishes Mixed, While Gold Advances
description: The dollar turned in a mixed performance yesterday, falling in Tokyo and Europe but rising as trading shifted to the United States later in the day.

title: Halle's to Shut 16 Stores in Chain
description: The 16 Halle's department stores in Ohio and Pennsylvania will be shut down because of ''continuing losses,'' the chain's new owners announced.

title: SPS TECHNOLOGIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago results restated to reflect accounting change

title: FIRST SAVINGS & LOAN SHARES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
EARLY TAX ON INTEREST PROPOSED
description: The Reagan Administration announced today that it would ask Congress to impose a 5 percent withholding tax on dividend and interest payments, something the lawmakers have often refused to do.

title: Aide Says Reagan Will Run For a Seco nd Term in 1984
description: Edwin Rollins, new White House political director, predicted today that President Reagan ''is going to be a two-term president.''

title: CALENDAR OF EVENTS: SCENT BOTTLE SHOW
description: Small Wonders, Steuben Glass, Fifth Avenue at 56th Street.

title: POSSIBLE ERROR WEIGHED IN BRINK'S HOLDUP ARREST
description: The Rockland County District Attorney said today that his office was investigating whether the identification of Eve Rosahn as the woman who rented a red van used in the Oct. 20 Rockland County armored-car robbery was a mistake.

title: FIGGIE INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Sisters of Missing Journalist Assail State Dept. Decision
description: The two sisters of an American journalist missing in El Salvador today expressed dismay with the State Department's refusal to grant political asylum to a man who said he knew what happened to their brother.

title: RANGERS SET BACK CAPITALS
description: The Rangers overcame two surges by the Washington Capitals tonight to win the first game of their eight-game road trip, 5-4.

title: SOUTHWEST BANCORP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec31
description: B-Operating earnings; C-net income

title: A Great Swap Masks a Great Danger
description: The President's design for the future of federalism is, if nothing else, consistent. For years he has advocated turning back more government to the states. Now he proposes a Great Swap, exchanging domestic burdens with governors and mayors and enabling Washington to get out of welfare, food stamps and other programs. He begins with an enticing promise: state and local governments will be no worse off financially. But that masks a profound realignment of responsibility. Local governments may or may not be worse off; poor people are sure to be.

title: ROOTING INDOOR CUTTINGS FOR THE OUTDOORS
description: AT this time of year, any activity that hints of spring is welcome. And gardeners have an advantage: They can nudge the outdoor growing season closer by rooting cuttings indoors.

title: Searle Income Climbs by 48%
description: G.D. Searle & Company, the diversified pharmaceuticals company, announced yesterday that net income in the fourth quarter, aided by a $9 million extraordinary gain, rose 48 percent, to $45 million, or 87 cents a share, from $30.4 million, or 57 cents a share, in the fourth quarter of 1980.

title: Bowa Traded to Cubs
description: The Philadelphia Phillies settled their contract dispute with Larry Bowa, the shortstop, by trading him and a minor-league infielder, Ryne Sandberg, to the Chicago Cubs yesterday for Ivan DeJesus, the Cubs' starting shortstop, who is 29 years old. Bowa, 36 years old, wanted his contract extended for three years with a raise from $300,000 to a reported $400,000 a year.

title: SPERRY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results reflect foreign currency translations

CANRAD-HANOVIA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including tax credits of $43,500 for the quarter and $488,600 for the year relating to discontinued operations; C-Including $73,600 income from recovery on discontinued operations

title: 'Just a Mockery!'
description: There was bitter reaction in London to the news that an arbitration panel had upheld the appeal by John McEnroe of the $5,000 fine that had been levied on him by the International Professional Tennis Council for his behavior at Wimbledon last July. ''Just a mockery!'' The Daily Telegraph said in a headline.

title: Brownstone Stoops
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: Permit a student of the brownstone stoop to add to your article on the subject (''The Front Stoop Makes a Comeback,'' Jan. 7). Our New York stoop derives from the Dutch custom of elevating the principal floor above the (sometimes flooded) ground level, although it was on this continent that the resulting ''basement'' was developed into a full story for occupancy.

title: DON'T STUNT FLOYD BENNETT FIELD'S FUTURE
description: To the Editor:

title: EAGLE-PICHER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
THE NEWEST FEDERALISM
description: ''After a third of a century of power flowing from the people and the states to Washington,'' said the President, ''it is time for a New Federalism in which power, funds and responsibility will flow from Washington to the states and to the people.''

title: Around the World; Denial of Jets to Taiwan Tied to Peking Pressure
description: Walter J. Stoessel Jr., the Deputy Secretary of State-designate, said today that the United States had decided against selling advanced F-16 jets to Taiwan because of a danger of rupture with Peking.

title: Texaco Executives Exchanging Posts
description: James W. Kinnear, a 53-year-old executive vice president of Texaco Inc., has been named to the additional post of president of Texaco U.S.A., the corporation's largest division, which is based in Houston. At the same time Annon M. Card, a 62-year-old executive vice president who previously held the presidency of Texaco U.S.A., will return to the Harrison, N.Y., headquarters to oversee many of the international activities of the company that Mr. Kinnear previously supervised.

title: Michigan Utilities
description: The Michigan Supreme Court today freed the state's two major electric utilities to auction more than $2.6 billion in securities, rejecting arguments by Frank Kelley, Michigan's Attorney General, and the Michigan Citizens Lobby that the sales are unnecessarily expensive and unjustified. The Detroit Edison Company had asked to sell $2 billion worth of stocks and bonds to pay for final construction of a coal-fired plant and a nuclear generator. The Consumers Power Company wants to sell $625 million in securities to finance a nuclear power plant.

title: Around the Nation; Teen-Ager Found Guilty In Concealment of Body
description: A juvenile court judge has ruled that a Milpitas, Calif., youth was guilty of helping another teen-ager conceal the body of a slain junior high school student.

title: Lady Mendl's Treasures
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: I was very interested to read your article on Lady Mendl, Elsie de Wolfe (''Lady Mendl's Last Treasures Are Sold,'' Dec. 10). I thought that you and your readers would be interested to know that Lady Mendl left her fortune to the Elsie de Wolfe Foundation, a charitable foundation.

title: NATIONAL DISTILLERS & CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
The Big Deficit Is a Big Gamble
description: There are several possible explanations for President Reagan's new indifference to big budget deficits. He may be passing the buck, hoping to make Congress take the blame for raising taxes. He may see the deficit as a lever to force more reductions in Federal spending. Or he may simply prefer to wait until after the 1982 elections before swallowing the painful medicine of tax increases.

title: CHASE AGREES TO BUY TRAVELER'S CHECK UNIT
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation announced yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Visa traveler's check business of the First National Bank of Chicago.

title: DESIGNING FOR TWO: WHEN SON MOVES INTO FATHER'S STUDIO
description: based architect, recently found himself part of a trend. Like many divorced fathers, he wanted to find a way to make his son, Ivan, feel at home even though he lived in a studio apartment in Kips Bay.

title: Concern to Repair Brooklyn Shuttle
description: A $380,275 contract was awarded yesterday to a Queens construction company to make repairs on the Franklin Avenue Shuttle.

title: REGAN ASSAILS FED, STRESSES RATE ROLE
description: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan, criticizing the Federal Reserve Board's management of the money supply, told Congress today that lower interest rates are essential to a strong economic recovery and to the success of President Reagan's economic policies.

title: PHELPS DODGE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including an extraordinary gain of $10.8 million, or 51 cents a share, from the exchange of debt; C-Includes a net gain of $18.4 million, or 88 cents a share, from the disposition of the company's equity interest in the Consolidated Aluminum Corp to Swiss Aluminum Ltd

title: QUESTIONS ON PRESIDENT'S PROPOSALS ON SHARING STATE AND U.S. PROGRAMS
description: President Reagan left many questions unanswered when he proposed a comprehensive reshuffling of Federal and state responsibilities for domestic social programs.

title: TRIAL OVER ARTICLE ON FORD MEMOIRS NEARS A CLOSE
description: Most of the testimony was completed yesterday in the trial of a copyright dispute about a magazine article based on a book of memoirs by former President Gerald R. Ford.

title: GULF CANADA LTD reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
American Folk Theater Is at Riverside Church
description: The American Folk Theater has moved from the Holy Name Church Community Center on West 97th Street to the Riverside Church at West 120th Street and Riverside Drive.

title: BELL JOINS G.O.P. FOR THE SENATE IN JERSEY
description: Jeffrey Bell, the conservative Republican who defeated Senator Clifford P. Case in the Republican primary in 1978 and then lost to the Democratic candidate, Bill Bradley, in the general election, announced today that he would seek the Senate seat held by Harrison A. Williams Jr.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of a production error, a section of the transcript of President Reagan's State of the Union Message was misplaced in some editions yesterday. The misplaced paragraphs began with the subheading ''Energy and Education Dept.'' and ended with the subheading ''Problems Through Growth.'' They should have followed a paragraph that began ''We must cut out'' and ended with ''the Federal work force by 75,000.''

title: GROMYKO REGRETS ARMS TALK DELAY
description: Andrei A. Gromyko, the Soviet Foreign Minis ter, expressed unhappiness today with the refusal of Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. to agree to a date for renewing negotiations onthe limitation of strategic arms.

title: NEW ELECTION FEB. 18
description: The Irish Cabinet was defeated on a vote in Parliament today, forcing Prime Minister Garret FitzGerald to resign. A new election will be held Feb. 18.

title: LOUISIANA LAND OFFSHORE EXPLORATION CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Gas Leak Blamed I n College Blast
description: An explosion that tore through a classroom building at Camden County College last Monday and injured 52 persons was caused by a leak in a line carrying natural gas, fire officials said yesterday.

title: HOME BEAT
description: IT'S the kind of decorating book that makes you want to take up paintbrush, fabric scissors and stapler almost immediately - maybe because Diana Phipps, a London-based interior decorator, is a kind of irresistible Pied Piper of her craft.

title: Rebels Raid Guatemala Town, Blowing Up Three Buildings
description: Terrorists attacked the town of Santa Ana Huyistla 150 miles northwest of here, blowing up the city hall, the post office and an educational institute, authorities reported today.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: A PERENNIAL

title: DETECTION SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings reflect the sale of 200,000 shares in a public offering in July 1981

title: 10.8% Drop at St. Regis
description: The St. Regis Paper Company announced yesterday that its profits in the fourth quarter fell 10.8 percent, to $33.8 million, or 98 cents a share, from $37.8 million, or $1.09 a share, the year before.

title: SHELLER-GLOBE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Lever Returns To Agencies
description: Lever Brothers, one of the country's major advertisers, confirmed yesterday that it is returning media planning responsibility to its agencies but retaining the actual buying function in the in-house operation it established in 1976.

title: Turner Cable TV Gets N.C.A.A. Football Pact
description: College football games will be televised live on cable television for the first time under an agreement announced today between the National Collegiate Athletic Association and Turner Broadcasting Inc., which is owned by Ted Turner.

title: U.S. Trust Broker Rate
description: The United States Trust Company said yesterday that it had lowered its broker loan rate to 14 percent from 15 percent, effective immediately. The rate at other banks ranges from 14 1/2 percent to 15 1/4 percent.

title: GAS SERVICE CO reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
CITY WILL ADD 400 TO NIGHT PATROLS IN SUBWAY TRAINS
description: In an effort to reduce rising subway crime, New York City will again assign transit police officers to most trains from 8 P.M. to 4 A.M., officials said yesterday.

title: WASHINGTON GAS LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BALLET: HARLEM'S FRANKIE AND JOHNNY'
description: AS its final company premiere for its New York season, the Dance Theater of Harlem revived a well-known, if too rarely performed, American classic Tuesday night at the City Center.

title: BRADY GUEST AT PRESS DINNER
description: James S. Brady, the White House press secretary who is still recovering from wounds he received in an assassination attempt on President Reagan last year, attended a Washington Press Club ''Salute to Congress'' dinner tonight.

title: EVIDENCE FROM VON BULOW CLOSET MAY BE USED IN TRIAL, JUDGE RULES
description: A black bag containing a used hypodermic needle and drugs can be used as evidence against Claus von Bulow in his trial for attempted murder, Judge Thomas H. Needham of Superior Court ruled today.

title: News Analysis
description: The Koch administration decided to back away from its plan for a sharp increase in real-estate taxes on cooperative apartment buildings mainly because it would not generate enough money to justify the controversy it aroused, a number of city and state officials said yesterday.

description: Last week Irving Lang was an acting State Supreme Court justice presiding over the trial of Jack Henry Abbott, the convict-author found guilty of manslaughter in the death of a waiter in a dispute over the use of a restaurant bathroom.

description: B-Including $203,000 income from discontinued operations and a $663,000 gain onthe sale of a subsidiary

title: U.S. SAYS COAST RING IMPORTED 30 ALIENS TO WORK IN 'SLAVERY'
description: Federal officials said today they had discovered a ring that illegally brought 30 people to the United States to work for wealthy residents of Los Angeles and Beverly Hills under arrangements one official described as ''pretty close to slavery.''

title: Cruise Line, Hotel Have New Agencies
description: There are a couple of travel-oriented accounts to report on. AC&R Advertising will be going aboard with Sun Line Cruises, while Ash/LeDonne is checking in with Helmsley Hotels.

title: ATTLES COACHES IN A PERSONAL WAY
description: Almost everything was in its proper place on the court in the Oakland Coliseum one recent morning. The Golden State Warriors were preparing for a game that evening. So John Bach, the assistant coach, meticulously maneuvered the tall, lean bodies through a series of plays.

title: Sony Announces Pocket Television
description: The Sony Corporation said that it h ad developed a f lat television receiver that can be carried in a pocket or in a handb ag and be watched anywhere at any time.

title: Technology; A New Assault On Shoplifters
description: SUPERMARKET shoplifters may soon face a new obstacle. Price tags may be secret security devices that will trigger an alarm when they leave the store.

title: ISSUING OF DATA DISPUTED ON NUCLEAR POWER PLANT
description: Rosemary S. Pooler, a member of the state's Public Service Commission, said today that she would defy a majority vote of the commission and release an analysis of hearings held to determine whether the Nine Mile Point II nuclear power plant should be built.

title: SUSPECT IN ATLANTA SLAYINGS IS LINKED TO ANOTHER VICTIM
description: A young, aspiring songwriter provided some of the most damaging testimony to date against Wayne B. Williams today when he linked the murder suspect to yet another of Atlanta's 28 slain or missing young blacks and, along with other witnesses, provided a glimpse at the mental state and musical milieu in which the defendant existed at various times in the last two years.

title: BLUES: THREE JAZZ GROUPS
description: TWO weeks ago, the Bottom Line started its ''Blue Monday'' series of blues programs with a triple bill featuring Mose Allison, Danny Kalb and Charles Earland. On Monday, the second program featured the New England band Roomful of Blues, a Bottom Line perennial; the tenor saxophonist Houston Person with the singer Etta Jones, and the Legendary Blues Band, which was Muddy Waters's backup band through the 1970's.

title: FINGERPRINTING CUTS BURGLARIES ON S.I.
description: Officer Charles Dunn brushed a feather duster over the white plastic jewelry box. The black ash on the duster began to cling, and suddenly the pattern was unmistakable - four fingerprints splayed across the top.

title: A Word on Solar
description: TO THE HOME SECTION: In your article ''Problems Turn Up With Solar Houses,'' Nov. 5, citing problems of overheating and condensation, Andree Brooks failed to report that, nonetheless, we found passive solar homeowners to be overwhelmingly satisfied with their homes.

title: CBS TRYING TO SELL FAWCETT BOOKS TO BALLANTINE
description: CBS is negotiating to sell its Fawcett Books Group, apparently to Ballantine Books, the mass-market subsidiary of Random House. Neither party would comment on the reported sale, which has been widely rumored for two weeks, but lawyers for both sides were trying to hammer out final details yesterday, and a formal announcement was said to be imminent.

title: RATH PACKING CO reports earnings for 13 wks to Jan 2
TRIAD SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Briefing
description: G EN. DAVID C. JONES, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, is due to retire in June, and he wants to leave behind a series of proposals on military reform that seek, unsurprisingly, to strengthen the leverage of the officers of the joint staff.

title: People
description: * Harry Wenthen appointed to senior vice president at Smith/Greenland Inc.

title: REAGAN IS SAID TO BACK WEAKER EDUCATION AGENCY
description: President Reagan has approved Education Secretary T.H. Bell's plan to convert his department into a foundation, despite opposition from Congress, department sources said today.

title: Head of UOP Plans Focus On Research
description: Robert M. Baratta has been elected president of UOP Inc., a diversified manufacturer of products for the energy and environmental industries formerly known as Universal Oil Products. He succeeds James V. Crawford, who continues as chairman and chief executive officer of the Signal Companies' subsidiary, which is based in Des Plaines, Ill.

title: Sick-Pay Inquiry Brings an Arrest
description: A former city worker was charged with making up doctors' notes to justify 22 paid sick days in less than a year.

description: Two Irish nationals were deported to Canada today after bail had been posted on criminal charges that they attempted to enter illegally from Canada on Jan. 21.

title: Market Place; Whittaker Bid For Brunswick
description: THE Whittaker Corporation's efforts to acquire the Brunswick Corporation might seem counterproductive to people who admire the way Whittaker has streamlined its operations by getting rid of 89 businesses. Whittaker began dropping lines in 1970, but investors did not take much notice until the end of the great bear market.

title: CRAY RESEARCH INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
6 Reprieved in Liberia
description: The Liberian head of state, Samuel K. Doe, reprieved six student leaders today who were scheduled to be executed by firing squad Friday for treason. Mr. Doe, who was a master sergeant when he seized power in a coup in 1980, said in a radio broadcast that the students had been ''tied up in an unfortunate incident.'' The students were sentenced to death for breaching a ban on political activities.

title: UNION GAS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange

title: Notes on People; Robert Kennedy Jr. to Marry in Indiana
description: The wedding of Robert F. Kennedy Jr. and Emily Ruth Black will not take place in St. Patrick's Cathedral after all, but in a Protestant church in Bloomington, Ind., in which the bride-to-be was baptized.

title: A PANEL THAT WON'T WRITE A REPORT
description: Whenever there's a problem too urgent to ignore but too hard to solve, the Federal Government acts like any other American institution: It appoints a study group.

title: ITEK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After a loss from the disposal of discontinued operations of $286,000...C-After a loss from discontinued operations of $642,000...D-AFter losses from discontinued operations of $1.6 million and $1.2 million for the latest yr and 1980, respectively, and losses from the disposal of discontinued operations of $551,000 and $135,000 for 1980 and 1981, respectively; the 1980 figures were restated forthe spinoff of the company's vision business

title: EMBRYO 'DONATION' CRITICIZED
description: Dr. Robert Edwards and Dr. Patrick Steptoe, who developed the technique that resulted in the birth of the world's first ''test tube'' baby, plan to freeze ''spare'' embryos for donation to infertile women.

description: Results include operations of Bentley Laboratories, Abbey Medical and Airlife which were acquired during 1981
