title: Siemens Plans U.S. Changes
description: Siemens, West Germany's biggest electrical company, will streamline its United States operations in the wake of last year's 19 percent decline in worldwide earnings, according to company officials. Small plants in America are to be closed, and production will focus on a few centers of heavy output.

title: NORTH AMERICAN COAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After an $8.3 million after-tax charge as a provision for estimated losses and close-downs expenses related to the company's previously reported closing of three coal mines; also a $1.2 million gain from the settlement of income-tax claims for the yrs 1969-1976...C-Net income...D-Net income was reduced by $9.4 million by the provision for mine closedowns

title: NUCLEAR SUPPORT SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Wronged on Voting Rights?
description: Ronald Reagan recoils from the suggestion that he's indifferent to the needs of black Americans. He's being wronged, he says. He was an outspoken supporter of civil rights even before it was called that. As Governor of California, he sought out blacks for appointed positions. And now, as President, he vigorously supports a 10-year extension of the Voting Rights Act.

title: COMMUNICATIONS INDUSTRIES reports earnings for QTr to Dec 31
description: Results for the latest yr include a gain of $344,000 from the sale of the company's interest in Answer-Page Inc in Mar 1981

title: The Evening Hours
description: O NE need not necessarily be saddened at the prospect of leaving New York for Budapest, even if one is not Hungarian. This was the feeling at the farewell-welcome party at the Italian Consulate up on Park Avenue the other night.

title: Bridge: Runner-Up for McKenney Made the Race a Close One
description: In the final days of 1981 the battle for the McKenney Trophy, awarded to the player winning the most master points in a year, was between Mel Skolnik of Newport Beach, Calif., who won, and Barry Crane of Hollwood, Calif.

title: FOR THE YEAR-ROUND RESIDENTS OF OLD LYME, WINTER'S THE SEASON OF
description: CONTENT By SAMUEL G. FREEDMAN The Talk of Old Lyme

title: BOSTON EDISON CO reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
SADAT'S PREOCCUPATION
description: To the Editor : Prof. Herma nn Frederick Eilts's letter, ''The Syrians Have Been Been Their Ow n Worst Enemies'' (Jan. 12), vociferously protests that ''had it not been for Syrian intransigence, Sadat would probably not have made the trip to Jerusalem.'' That trip, as we all know, launched Egyp t on the path toward the current Egyptian-Israeli treaty.

title: Marshall Dodge Dies; 'Bert and I' Humorist
description: Marshall Dodge, a Maine humorist best known for his ''Bert and I'' records, has died after being hit by a vehicle while bicycling. He was 45 years old.

title: AMERICAN SHIPBUILDING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Brunswick Suit To Block Bid
description: The Brunswick Corporation filed a lawsuit today in the Federal district court to block a $320 million takeover bid by the Whittaker Corporation.

title: BENDEL'S TRYOUT FOR DESIGNERS
description: The line begins forming at 9:30 A.M., and sometimes stretches down the block, past the movie theater and around the corner. But it is frigid outside on a recent Friday, and shortly before 10 A.M. only a handful of people are huddling in the dingy corridor near the freight elevators. The telephone rings. ''O.K., Al,'' says the voice on the other end, ''let's get those kids up here.''

title: A General Free, a Consul Slain
description: The rescue of Brig. Gen. James Dozier, mercifully unharmed, and the arrest of five Red Brigade suspects is wonderful news.

title: Chief Executive Elected at Braniff
description: Howard D. Putnam, 44 years old, who joined the financially troubled Braniff International Corporation four months ago as president and chief operating officer, was elected yesterday to the additional position of chief executive officer. He succeeds John J. Casey, 63, who continues as chairman of the Dallas-based airline.

title: NATIONAL HEALTH ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
News Analysis
description: Officials in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut believe President Reagan's ''new federalism'' proposals hold potentially devastating consequences for their states and for New York City, even though the Reagan Administration insists that there would be no winners or losers.

title: News Analysis
description: The Red Brigades, Italy's most feared terrorist organization, may have suffered the most stunning blow in its 11-year history when policemen burst into a Padua apartment today and liberated Brig. Gen. James L. Dozier unharmed despite the presence of five armed terrorists. The kidnapping of General Dozier 42 days ago was the most ambitious operation the Red Brigades have carried out since they abducted former Prime Minister Aldo Moro in March 1978 and killed him 54 days later.

title: CALUMET INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
STEEL IMPORTS UP 5.2% IN DECEMBER
description: Steel imports increased by a modest 5.2 percent in December, compared with the same month in 1980, while imports for the full year jumped 28 percent, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

title: John J. Liney, Cartoonist, 69; Drew the 'Henry' Comic Strip
description: John J. Liney, who drew the ''Henry'' comic strip for 44 years, is dead at the age of 69. Mr. Liney, who retired because of ill health in 1979, died of a heart condition at the Ridge Crest Convalescent Center in Feasterville Jan. 20. For the last year he was a resident of Redeemer Village retirement community in Huntingdon Valley.

title: Withdrawal Rate Rises; Savings Outflow Rate Up
description: Americans withdrew a record $25.5 billion more than they put into savings and loan associations last year, an outflow that helped push the industry's net worth to its lowest level in more than three years, the Government reported today.

title: KNICKS SET BACK BULLETS WITH ASSIST FROM DEMIC
description: The Knicks found a hero tonight to help them pull out a 102-98 victory, only their third in the last 12 games.

KIMBALL INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The figures restated are the 1980 qr and 6 mos and the 1981 6 mos

title: No Headline

title: FNI INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Kallur Out Four Weeks
description: Anders Kallur, the Islander left wing who was injured Wednesday night in Pittsburgh, will miss about four weeks with a torn ligament in his right knee, the team said yesterday. Kallur was hit by Ron Stackhouse, a Penguin defenseman, in the second period of the Islanders' 6-3 victory after having scored two goals.

title: OGDEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Around the Nation; Sharp Drop Reported I n F.D.A. Enforcement
description: A consumer affairs group said today that enforcement of Food and Drug Administration regulations had been curtailed by 45 percent in President Reagan's first year in office. A report measured the decline from the four-year Carter Administration average.

title: Landlord Is Fined $52,500 Over Heat
description: A Brooklyn landlord was fined $52,500 yesterday in Brooklyn Landlord and Tenant Court for failing to provide heat and hot water to his tenants for more than a month. City housing officials said the fine was the largest ever levied against a l a ndlord for that reason.

title: JOAN HITCHCOCK
description: Joan Hitchcock, a flamboyant San Francisco social figure who said she once had an affair with John F. Kennedy, has died Wednesday of cirrhosis.

title: MARK TWAIN BANCSHARES INC (ST LOUIS, MO) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 3
BILL WOULD DIVERT U.S. RESEARCH AID TO COMPANIES
description: A bill that would divert hundreds of millions of dollars from basic scientific research in American universities into small technological businesses has gained an apparently unstoppable momentum in Congress.

title: Notes on People; Effort to Honor Native Nebraskan Thwarted
description: Despite its good intentions, the Nebraska Legislature apparently will not be able to name the part of Interstate 480 that passes through Omaha after one of the state's most famous natives, Gerald R. Ford.

title: Miss Walliser Ski Victor
description: Maria Walliser of Switzerland, who has never won a Wo rld Cup race, won the d ownhill phase of the women's combined competition at the world ski ing championships today.Cindy Nelson of Reno, Nev., and Doris de Agos tini of Switzerland tied for second place. Miss Walliser, 19, had a time of 1 minute 39.17 Miss de Agostini and Miss Nelson each c locked 1:39.41.

title: REAGAN COALITION PERILED BY UNEASE ONBUDGET DEFICIT
description: The winning political coalition that President Reagan put together in Congress last year is threatened by widespread uneasiness among Republicans as well as Democrats over the huge bud get deficits contemplated by the Administration.

title: WRONG MEDICINE
description: To the Editor:

title: TUDOR CITY PARKS AGAIN IMPERILED BY HELMSEY'S DEVELOPMENT PLAN
description: Harry Helmsley announced yesterday that, based on the Koch administration's rejection of a proposed land exchange, he would try again to build on two parks at the Tudor City apartment complex on Manhattan's East Side.

title: TRADE GAP NARROWED LAST MONTH
description: The nation's merchandise trade deficit narrowed in December to $1.59 billion, the smallest since July, mostly because the recession reduced imports more sharply than exports, the Commerce Department said today.

title: BORG-WARNER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Shr earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in Nov

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Marvelous, O.K., police.'' - Gen. James L. Dozier, to Italian rescuers. (A8:5.)

title: LOUISIANA-PACIFIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ART: ZABRISKIE OFFERS A SCULPTURE TWIN BILL
description: It is the Year of the Dog in Chinatown, but the month of sculpture at the Zabriskie Gallery, with ''Flat and Figurative'' through Feb. 6 at the main gallery, 29 West 57th Street, and an invitational show through Feb. 17 at the western annex, 521 West 57th Street. Though not exactly representational, each of the 30 or so pieces in ''Flat and Figurative'' refers to the figure and is flat enough to hang on a wall. While not a survey of the 20th century , the show spans the years 1909 to 1981 and includes artists from Elie Nadelman to young contemporaries like Jedd Garet, and so it can be counted a crosssection of sorts.

title: Championship Event For Sled-Dog Teams
description: Under lowering skies, with light snow predicted, more than 100 sled-dog drivers gathered here today for the annual international championships.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Metropolitan Report on Wednesday omitted the name of a Midwood High School student in Brooklyn who was chosen as a finalist in the Westinghouse Science Talent Search. She is Reena B. Gordon.

title: The Supreme Court; JUSTICE O'CONNOR IS MOSTLY WITH THE MAJORITY
description: It has been four months since Sandra Day O'- Connor took her seat on the Supreme Court, and the outlines of her approach to the job and to the law have begun to emerge. From more than two dozen decisions the Court has issued so far this term, it is apparent that the newest Justice feels at home with the Court's conservative center but is willing on occasion to strike out on her own.

title: TI-CARO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 2
Rorem at Piano at Y
description: The composer and pianist Ned Rorem will accompany singers at a recital of his works tomorrow night at 8 in the 92d Street Y on Lexington Avenue.

description: The 1980 sales were reclassified

title: DANCE: GROSSER AND MORGAN
description: PHILIP GROSSER and Anthony Morgan presented an odd evening of dance on Wednesday at the Theater of the Riverside Church. Most of the time it was hard to tell the choreographers apart without a look at program notes.

title: FINANCIAL BRIEFS
description: * Atlantic Richfield Overseas Finance N.V. is offering $500 million zero coupon notes due 1992 at price of 25.75 percent, to be offered through a Salomon Brothers group.

title: Briefing
description: YEAR politics is the art of never having to say you're sorry. In a matter of a few days after Congress reconvened this week, Senator William Proxmire's office had close to 50 quiet inquiries from other lawmakers' offices about the Senator's bill to repeal the new tax breaks Congress just mandated for itself.

FIRST UNION REAL ESTATE EQUITY & MORTGAGE reports earnings for Qtr to Dec

title: DESIGN DISPUTE HOLDS UP REOPENING OF BEAUMONT
description: Because of differences between I.M. Pei, the architect, and Cyril Harris, the acoustician, the $6.5 million interior renovation of the Vivian Beaumont Theater at Lincoln Center has been delayed; the reopening, scheduled for the fall, has been postponed until at least until next winter.

title: The City; Columbia Creates Post in Radiology
description: Columbia University received $1 million from the James Picker Foundation to create its first professorship in radiology, the university announced.

title: Monberg Goes to Bache After His Firm Is Closed
description: Lawrence Monberg Jr., 40, the Florida stockbroker who surprised Wall Street last August by picking up some of the pieces of John Muir& Company and forming his own brokerage firm, has joined Bache HalseyStuart Shield s Inc., a major securities concern, in its Fo rt Lauderdale, Fla., office. His move marks the ninth time th at Mr. Monberg has changed firms since starting his securities in dustry career in 1970.

title: SUN CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes gains for the quarter of $119 million from the sale of the company's Corpus Christi Texas oil refinery and related assets and a $180 million gain from the sale of 25% of the company's Canadian subsidiary, Suncor, to the Ontario Energy Corp; net income for the year includes $135 million gain from the sale of the company's Sperry-Sun oil filed services subsidiary; C-Results for the quarter and year are after a one time charge against earnings resulting from termination of new ship construction partially offset by a gain on the sale of the Duncan Okla oil refinery; these two items decreased 1980 net share by $62 million; share earnings are fully diluted

title: INDIANA GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
No Headline
description: HOOPER DEFEATS TANNER IN PRO INDOOR BY 6-4, 7-6

title: Auctions; George II era at Christie's.
description: CHRISTIE'S will auction some important English and Continental furniture, clocks and objects of art tomorrow at 10 A.M. Up for bidding are two George II-era lots from the 1750's - a walnut clothes press, which may bring as much as $80,000, and a pair of giltwood side tables, up to $60,000. A pair of George III commodes attributed to John Cobb, with marquetry of harewood and fustic (the wood of a tropical American tree), may sell for up to $60,000. And two lots of George I chairs - a pair of side chairs of gilt metal and walnut, made after 1724 for the fourth Earl of Scarsdale, whose coat of arms is painted on glass on the chair backs, and a pair of walnut-burl side chairs (up to $60,000 a pair). Among mirrors up for bidding is a George II giltwood piece from about 1740 (up to $40,000).

title: 2 Face Execution in Florida
description: The Florida Supreme Court refused today to stay executions scheduled Tuesday for two killers, Ernest John Dobbert and Anthony Antone, leaving their fates in the hands of Federal judges. No one has been executed in Florida since John Spenkelink, convicted of killing a traveling companion in a Tallahassee motel, was put to death May 25, 1979.

title: Merrill Will Issue Homeowners Credit Backed by Equity
description: Merrill Lynch & Company said yesterday that it was starting a new service to help property owners tap the funds built up in their homes over the years.

title: Sports People; Glove Compromise Seen
description: John Condon, president of Madison Square Garden's boxing department, said after speaking with Chairman Jack Prenderville of the St ate Ath letic Commission yesterday that he expected a compromise on the thumbless-glove controversy in time for the Garden's next scheduled show, March 15. The Garden had to cancel tonight's car d at the Felt Forum when six fighters refused to wear the new glove s, which had been made mandatory for nontitle bouts in New York by t he commission.

title: PENOBSCOT SHOE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PARK CHEMICAL CO reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
Short-Term Rates Off Sharply
description: Short-term interest rates fell sharply yesterday, encouraging securities dealers to raise prices and lower yields for longer-term issues.

title: Bobbie Brooks
description: Bobbie Brooks Inc., the sportswear manufacturer that filed for reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Code earlier this month, said it has entered into a factoring arrangement with the Meinhard-Commercial Corporation. Under terms of the agreement, Meinhard will advance sums of money to Bobbie Brooks against invoices. The agreement also provides additional financing of up to $10 million to be used by the sportswear maker for working capital and as a letter of credit facility.

title: Auto Layoffs Rise
description: The number of American auto workers on indefinite layoff rose this week to 243,500, from 229,275 last week, and planned car production by domestic auto makers dropped 11.9 percent, according to industry reports released today.

title: PLIGHT OF THE HOMELESS IN COLD STIRS CONTRIBUTORS TO NEEDIEST
description: With impoverished victims of winter cold coming to public attention almost daily, many contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund are asking that their gifts be used to help the homeless poor who are often found destitute and decrepit on the city's streets.

title: CONSOLIDATED-BATHURST LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After a special charge of $2.1 million for the qr and a special gain of $10.3million for the yr; the company is listed on the Montreal and Toronto stock exchanges

title: MANAGEMENT SCIENCE AMERICA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
A PIONEER IN GROUP PRACTICE
description: Dr. Russel V.A. Lee, who helped make group practice an important part of American health care, died Wednesday at his home in Portola Valley, Calif. He was 86 years old and had been in declining health for five years.

title: A NIBBLER'S GUIDE TO THE BEST IN FREE HORS D'OEUVRES
description: FOR New Yorkers who like to spend Friday evenings toasting the start of a weekend at a pub, a cocktail lounge or a restaurant, there are more satisfying alternatives than a cube of American cheese speared on a toothpick or a bowl of peanuts to keep the hunger pangs away. A number of establishments around town are offering free hors d'oeuvres of surprising quality.

title: WIFE OF KEY ABSCAM FIGURE IS FOUND HANGED IN FLORIDA
description: The wife of a key witness in the Federal Bureau of In vestigation's Abscam investigation, who had recently asse rted that her husband had lied under oath, was found dead here tod ay, apparently a suicide.

title: MEDEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CONCERT: JUPITER PLAYS SPOHR
description: JENS NYGAARD is one of those rare conductors who enjoy programming offbeat works, and in the Jupiter Symphony concert he led at Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday night there were two examples. The first and biggest was Louis Spohr's ''Historical'' Symphony, a work dating from 1839. It derives its name from the fact that it recapitulates, more or less, 120 years of the history of musical composition.

title: The Times Names Vecsey To Write Sports Column
description: George Vecsey will join Dave Anderson as a regular writer of the Sports of The Times column, A.M. Rosenthal, executive editor of The Times, announced yesterday.

title: SATELLITE DEAL VOIDED
description: The Federal Communications Commission today invalidated the first attempt by a communications satellite operator to auction transmission channels to the highest bidder.

title: Advertising; TV Guide Ad Director Promoted to Publisher
description: Eric G. Larson, 57-year-old veteran advertising director of TV Guide, has been promoted to publisher, filling a post vacant since the death of Jame s T. Quirk in 1969.

title: Lennon Book Acquired
description: William Morrow & Company and Bantam Books have jointly acquired North American publishing rights to an unwritten biography of John Lennon by Albert Goldman. A seven-figure deal between Morrow and Avon Books, hard-cover and paperback publishers, respectively, of the Hearst Corporation, collapsed last month. A disagreement between Walter Meade, publisher of Avon, and John Hawkins, Mr. Goldman's literary agent, about whether Avon had an agreement to publish the book in paperback in advance of any British edition was the reason for the breakdown.

title: Around the Nation; 26 in 'Slavery' Case Held as Witnesses
description: A Federal magistrate today ordered 26 Indonesians held as material witnesses in a Federal grand jury investigation of assertions that they were brought into the country illegally by a ring providing servants for wealthy residents of Los Angeles and Beverly Hills.

title: A BATTLE-HARDENED GENERAL
description: Brig. Gen. James L. Dozier, who won a Silver Star and a Bronze Star with two Oak Leaf Clusters for heroism in combat during the war in Vietnam, may never have been closer to death than he was yesterday when

title: GULF STILL SEARCHING FOR OIL UNIT TO BUY
description: The Gulf Oil Corporation, which last year explored the possibility of acquiring the Marathon Oil Company, has expanded its search to acquire a domestic oil company, security analysts were told by company officials here today.

title: TV Weekend; ROOSEVELT AND THE NEW DEAL YEARS
description: TOMORROW is the 100th anniversary of Franklin Delano Roosevelt's birth, and television is continuing its weeklong spurt of retrospectives and reviews concerning the President who led this country through the Great Depression and most of World War II.

title: Sports People; Bowie Starting Practice
description: Sam Bowie, absent this season from Kentucky's basketball lineup, will begin practicing with his teammates today, Coach Joe B. Hall said yesterday. ''We'll look at him through next week, work him into practice, see what kind of progress he's making and still keep up his weight training and running,'' Hall said. Bowie, a junior, has been sidelined since X-rays in late s ummer reveale d a hairline fracture inhis left leg.

title: OGLEBAY NORTON CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Sports People; Farmer, Phils Agree
description: Ed Farmer, a relief pitcher who played with the Chicago White Sox, has agreed to terms on a guaranteed three-year contract with the Philadelphia Phillies. Farmer, 32 years old, was 3-3 with a 4.58 earned run average and 10 saves with the White Sox last season before deciding to become a free agent.

title: Restaurants; Ex-SoHo favorite thrives in Chelsea.
description: THE reopening of the Ballroom, the popular cabaret-restaurant, is welcome news to the many devotees of this bright, lively and very original establishment. Opened in SoHo in 1973, the Ballroom closed two and a half years ago when its rent soared. After a long search, the owners found and decorated new quarters. Renamed the New Ballroom and installed in a handsome setting on 28th Street between Seventh and Eighth Avenues in Chelsea, the restaurant offers the same combination of entertainment along with diverting, innovative food.

title: SONAT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
TURKISH DIPLOMAT IS SLAIN ON COAST
description: Two gunmen assassinated the Turkish consul general in Los Angeles this morning as he sat alone in his automobile at a busy intersection in the Westwood section.

title: Cannon Holders Accept Share Offer
description: The major stockholders in the Cannon Mills Company, who own 27 percent of the 9.4 million shares outstanding, said they had agreed to sell their stock to the Pacific Holding Company, which is owned by David Murdock, the Los Angeles financier.

title: SECOND COURT ESCAPEE SEIZED IN A FRIEND'S BROOKLYN HOME
description: A second prisoner of the nine who escaped from a Brooklyn courthouse on Jan. 14 was recaptured yesterday by detectives who found him hiding behind a couch in a friend's apartment.

title: Richard Jones Jr., 72; Chief of Tulsa Tribune
description: Richard L. Jones Jr., president and board chairman of The Tulsa Tribune and a former vice president of The Associated Press board of directors, died Wednesday at St. Francis Hospital after suffering from cancer for months. He was 72 years old.

title: BASKETBALL SOLID IN RIGHT GARDEN
description: THE Super Bowl is over and George Steinbrenner's midwinter boot camp begins Feb. 9. That leaves two weeks for the professional basketball season.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Berkshire Hathaway Inc. said it had increased its share of Arcata Corp. to 7 percent of the common and preferred shares.

title: VARCO INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for QTr to Dec 31
COX BROADCASTING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $9.1 million for the qr and $9.9 million for the yr

title: ARTS CHIEF DELAYS GRANTS
description: Frank S.M. Hodsoll, the new chairman of the National Endowment on the Arts, said today that he had held up hundreds of grants already approved for applicants; but he added that he expected most of them to be awarded later.

title: LACLEDE GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
GRANT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Advertising; New Wyse Account
description: Wyse Advertising in Cleveland plans to paint the town red and for good reason: It has just landed the Sherwin-Williams Company account, which for a couple of years was served by Doyle Dane Bernbach in New York. Billings last year were $5 million to $6 million. The assignment is from the company's stores division and is for paint, stains and associated products, wall coverings, floor coverings and window ''treatments.''

title: Spot Prices F or Oil Weak
description: The continuing oversupply of crude oil depressed prices sharply this week on the spot, or noncontract, market, signaling new problems for several producers struggling to find buyers.

title: CARRUTHERSES RETAIN PAIRS SKATING TITLE
description: Kitty and Peter Carruthers tonight won their second consecutive title in the pairs competition of the UnitedStates figure skating championships.

title: STAGE: NICOL WILLIAMSON IN BROADWAY 'MACBETH'
description: LAST season the Lincoln Center Repertory Company gave us a ''Macbeth'' with no Macbeth, some vibrant supporting players and a lot of sound and fury signifying terribly little. Last night the Circle in the Square unveiled a ''Macbeth'' with an eccentric, if fitfully intriguing, Macbeth, and nothing else. Is this an improvement? Not really, but, seen in succession, these two vastly different productions at least prove one academic point: if a great play can accommodate all manner of exciting interpretations, so does it allow room for all kinds of wrongheadedness.

title: CLEVELAND-CLIFFS IRON CO reports earnings for QTr to Dec 31
description: Results for the latest yr reflect investment writedowns; yr-ago results includea nonrecurring gain from the sale of property

title: SYNTHEMED CORP reports earnings for Yr to Oct 31
description: The 1980 results are for a four month period ended Oct 31

title: Chrysler Tank S ale Seen Near
description: The Chrysler Corporation may sell its tank-making unit to the General Dynamics Corporation in a day or two, according to a source at a company that had been in the bidding.

title: PRESIDENT URGES AID TO SALVADOR IN WAKE OF RAID
description: The Reagan Administration said today that the United States ''must be prepared to increase'' aid to El Salvador after a guerrilla attack Wednesday on the country's biggest air base in which ''several'' aircraft were destroyed or damaged.

title: ZOELLER AND MILLER GET 65'S TO SHARE LEAD
description: On numbers alone, Johnny Miller and Fuzzy Zoeller shared the first-round lead of the San Diego Open today with 65's, but according to Miller, the real leader was Mark Lye with 66.

title: FRIDAY, JANUARY 29, 1982; International
description: Japan detailed 67 areas in which it will liberalize trade policy to open its domestic markets to foreign goods. The changes, in response to pressures from the U.S. and Europe, will affect such products as cosmetics and pharmaceuticals, medical equipment, motor vehicles, electrical appliances and sporting goods. Administration reaction was cautiously optimistic. (Page A1.) The Economy

title: TEXACO AND SOHIO UP SLIGHTLY
description: More oil companies reported yesterday that earnings had been sluggish in the last quarter in 1981. Texaco Inc., the nation's third-largest oil company, reported a 1.4 percent gain and the Standard Oil Company (Ohio), No.13, reported an even smaller rise.

title: GOOD TIMES, GOOD CAUSES: A TALE OF TWO PARTIES
description: It was Wednesday night and probably the safest party in town. The place was swarming with police, both in and out of uniform. And why not? It was, after all, at Police Headquarters.

title: MONETARISTS AND SUPPLY-SIDERS CAN BE FRIENDS
description: To the Editor:

title: WESTERN PERSPECTIVE OF POLAND AND A POLE
description: To the Editor:

title: RODGERS AWARD FOR NEW PLAY
description: ''Portrait of Jennie,'' a musical based on the 1940 novel of the same name by Robert Nathan, has won the second Richard Rodgers Production Award. The book was adapted by Enid Futterman and Dennis Rosa; the music was by Howard Marren and the lyrics by Miss Futterman.

title: PPG INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Astor Place on Foot
description: Once the home of the Astor and Vanderbilt families, the Astor Place section of the city will be explored in a walking tour Sunday at 2 P.M., sponsored by Adventure on a Shoestring.

title: HOMESTEAD FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Kratos Signs Merger Plan
description: Kratos Inc. announced it had signed a merger agreement under which it would acquire the Keuffel & Esser Company, which makes precision drafting equipment and supplies and microfilm equipment, for about $55 million.

title: 'ICE CAPADES': SPECTACLE BEGINS VISIT TO GARDEN
description: TO New Yorkers who have been skidding all over town this week in the vast outdoor ice spectacle in the streets, the idea of paying to see others slide around in an indoor ice spectacle might not seem worth it. A trip to Madison Square Garden, where the annual freeze of ''Ice Capades'' has set in and will not thaw before Feb. 7, will change the mind, however.

title: LUNDY ELECTRONICS & SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NORTHWEST NATURAL GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Around the Nation; Catholic Officials Change Stand on Man's Marriage
description: Officials of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Joliet said today that they endorse the marriage of a paralyzed man who was refused the rite by two priests.

title: PLANNING RESEARCH CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NATIONAL DISTILLERS & CHEMICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $7.8 million for the qr and $7.3million for the yr; the company said that the 1980 earnings were reduced by charges equal to 87 cents a shr resulting from closing of an unprofitable brass mill

title: STAFF AT REACTOR WILL TRY TO FIND SOURCE OF LEAK
description: Workers at the Robert E. Ginna nuclear power plant in Ontario, N.Y., spent yesterday preparing to open a steam generator in an attempt to find the source of a leak that led to the release of radioactive steam from the plant on Monday.

title: F.D.R.'S VOICE STIRS EMOTIONS AT CAPITOL
description: Franklin D. Roosevelt came back to Capitol Hill today, in voice and in spirit, evoking laughter, applause and even a tear or two from a gathering of a few who once knew him and others too young to remember.

title: MILITARY-INDUSTRIAL COMPLEX ASSAILED IN RICKOVER SWAN SONG TO CONGRESS
description: Adm. Hyman G. Rickover, the stern father of the nuclear Navy, spoke his mind to Congress today for the final time as an officer on active duty, combining a sharp attack on the military-industrial complex with philosophical musings about the past and the future.

title: CENTRAL NATIONAL BANK (CHICAGO) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Operating earnings...C-AFter $338,000 loss for the qr and yr from discontinued operations, $209,000 extraordinary charge for the qr and $187,000 extraordinary credit for the yr...D-Net income including $15,000 extraordinary credit...E-After $4,513,000 loss from discontinued operations and $33,000 extraordinary credit

title: Miss Penneys Recital
description: Rebecca Penneys, pianist with the New Arts Trio, will give a recital Sunday night at 8 in Alice Tully Hall, Broadway and 68th Street.

title: DELTA AIR LINES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Shr earnings have been adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split paid in Dec 1981

title: AVERY INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
News Summary; FRIDAY, JANUARY 29, 1982
description: International Brig.Gen. James Dozier was freed 42 days after his abduction from his home in Italy by left-wing terrorists. A raid by Italian police on an apartment in Padua led to the safe release of the American officer. According to the American ambassador, Maxwell Rabb, General Dozier was unhurt and in ''excellent health.'' (Page A1, Column 6.) America's gratitude to Italy for rescuing General Dozier was expressed by President Reagan. Interrupting a luncheon honoring President Franklin Delano Roosevelt, the President applauded the courage of the captured general, saying, ''His country and our allies can be very proud of this gallant man.'' (A8:4.)

title: Advertising; Accounts
description: * Weinerschnitzel International's new photo-developing franchises to Wells Rich Greene/Townsend. which for a couple of years was served by Doyle Dane Bernbach in New

title: MAN, 83, WHO HELPED CRIME VICTIM IS REFUSED MONETARY AWARD BY CITY
description: More than a year ago, Abraham Newman risked his life to aid a woman in trouble. He has been paying for it ever since. Mr. Newman, then 83 years old, was walking on the boardwalk at Brighton Beach in Brooklyn on Oct. 16, 1980, when he tried to help a woman who was being assaulted by a young man. The assailant grabbed Mr. Newman's cane, beat him and broke his hip.

title: UAL LOSES $65 MILLION IN QUARTER
description: UAL Inc., which owns United Airlines, the nation's largest airline, yesterday reported a loss of $65.1 million for the fourth quarter and a loss of $70.5 million for 1981.

title: Six Grand Prix Drivers Fined $10,000 for Strike
description: The International Auto Sports Federation today fined six Formula One drivers $10,000 each for their roles as leaders in a one-day strike during practice for the South African Grand Prix last week. The 23 other drivers who struck, including all the other top competitors, were fined $5,000 each.

title: SQUARE D CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: 1980 results restated to include acquisition of General Semiconductor Industries Inc on a pooling of interest basis

title: WILLIAMS IS LINKED TO TWO OTHERS SLAIN IN ATLANTA
description: A grandmother, a fast-food waitress and a confessed drug addict nicknamed ''Cool Breeze'' today joined the parade of witnesses purporting to link Wayne B. Williams with slaying victims in Atlanta's string of missing and murdered young blacks.

title: NEW DEFECTIONS SHAKE SPANISH REGIME
description: Prime Minister Leopoldo Calvo Sotelo's shrinking parliamentary base was further eroded today when three legislators announced they were leaving the badly splintered Government party to join a right-wing coalition.

title: Questions Remain for Knicks
description: ''Tell me,'' said Bob Cousy, the former Boston Celtic star, ''is my friend Red Holzman in trouble?'' Cousy's question came after the Knicks' 131-99 defeat Wednesday night in Boston, and it was an obvious one, since the first thing losing teams often do is dismiss the coach. And the Knicks have been a losing team this season, with a 20-24 record after beating the Washington Bullets, 102-96, tonight. The Knicks have lost nine times in their last 12 games.

title: 600 Troops Leave Ulster
description: Six hundred British paratroopers, sent to Northern Ireland after the slaying of a Protestant politician by the Irish Republican Army in November, have been withdrawn, the army said today. Regular British troop strength in the province is now 10,500.

title: PRATT-READ CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 3
description: B-Includes recovery of $8,322 from discontinued operations

title: BETZ LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CALIFORNIA WATER SERVICE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NUCLEAR MEDICAL SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Around the World; Medical Group Penalized Over South Africans
description: The United Nations World Health Organization has broken ties with the largest international medical association over the admission of doctors from South Africa.

title: FRIEDMAN INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Record TV Rating
description: CBS reported yesterday that its telecast of the Super Bowl last Sunday gained a Nielsen rating of 49.1 and a 73 percent share of the audience. The rating was the highest ever for a live program and the third highest for a program of any kind, behind the ''Who Shot J.R.?'' segment of ''Dallas'' (53.3 rating) and the final episode of ''Roots'' (51.1).

title: 2 Guilty in Spanish Tragedy
description: Two men were convicted of gross negligence today in connection with a tanker truck explosion that killed 215 people at a campsite in July 1978. The two were given one-year suspended prison sentences. Four other men also accused of gross negligence were acquitted.

title: LYNCH CORP reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
description: B-After $170,000 tax credit...C-After tax credit of $350,000

title: RB INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MAJOR CLASHES ERUPT IN 6 SOUTH LEBANON VILLAGES
description: Large-scale clashes broke out in six southern vill ages today between Lebanese leftists and Shiite Moslems who regard Ay atollah Ruhollah Khomeini of Iran as their spiritual leader. The G overnment said it was concerned that the violence might spread to Bei rut.

title: By Robert Curvin
description: The Editorial Notebook Sit!

title: HAIG'S SWING UPWARD
description: Teetering on the brink of resignation or dismissal seven months ago, Alexander M. Haig Jr. today is in a position to dominate foreign policy making.

title: DAYTON POWER & LIGHT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CITY BALLET: 'MAGIC FLUTE' AND RETURN OF 'GATHERING'
description: PETER MARTINS'S ''The Magic Flute'' is all about being young and having improbable adventures. And it certainly had appropriate performers in Jock Soto and Katrina Killian, dancing the lead roles of the hero Luke and his pretty Lise, when the New York City Ballet performed the new work at the New York State Theater.

title: Sports People; 3 More in Hall of Fame
description: In addition to Sam Huff, whose selection was reported earlier, Merlin Olsen, George Musso and Doug Atkins have been elected by a committee of sportswriters to the Pro Football Hall of Fame, bringing to 114 the number enshrined at Canton, Ohio. Olsen, now the star of the television series ''Father Murphy,'' was the second member of the Los Angeles Rams' old ''Fearsome Foursome'' defensive line elected, following Deacon Jones, who was chosen two years ago.

title: CHART HOUSE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
REAGAN LAUDS SPIRIT OF RELEASED GENERAL AND THANKS ITALIANS
description: President Reagan today applauded the courage of Brig. Gen. James L. Dozier and expressed gratitude to Italy for rescuing him from the Red Brigades.

title: SEX ASSAULTS AT SCHOOL WORRY HARLEM PARENTS
description: Worried parents met twice this week with officials of Public School 57 in East Harlem as they tried to come to terms with the emotional impact of an incident last week in which two 9-year-old girls were sexually molested by an intruder in the girls' bathroom. The assaults occurred during school hours.

title: HAYES-DANA INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
DEPOSIT GUARANTY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Yr-ago results have been restated for a pooling of interests acquisition in June 1981

title: CHARGE AGAINST DEFENDANT IN BRINK'S HOLDUP DROPPED
description: Acting at the District Attorney's request, a Rockland County judge today dismissed the indictment against Eve Rosahn that had accused her of being involved in the Brink's robbery and murders Oct. 20.

title: JAPAN DETAILS EASING ON IMPORTS
description: Japan today detailed the measures it would take to open its markets to more foreign goods. The measures are part of its response to increasing pressures from the United States and Western Europe, which are suffering high unemployment while running huge trade deficits with Japan.

title: DATASCOPE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Shr earnings are fully diluted

title: NORTHEAST BANKSHARE ASSOCIATION reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MET PRESENTS WORKS BOUGHT FOR UNDER $5,000 EACH
description: UNDER an unalluring title, ''Curators' Choices: Museum Purchases From Under $5,000,'' the Metropolitan Museum of Art has mounted an exhibition that is at once very unusual and very appealing. Approximately 100 objects acquired during the last four years by 17 curatorial departments of the museum have been brought together in a veritable flea market of a show designed to illustrate the esthetic merit of so-called ''minor'' works of art that would not in the ordinary course of things find their way into the limelight.

title: Heublein Denies Planning Merger
description: Heublein Inc., the food and wine conglomerate, strongly denied that it is involved in any talks about being acquired by another company.

title: Rebecca Smith, Who Said No
description: One could say that it's Rebecca Smith's fault that she died on a windy corner in Manhattan's Chelsea neighborhood Tuesday. Rebecca Smith couldn't stand living in a house. She did, however, build herself a kind of hut out of a big cardboard box and some newspapers.

title: ALICE AND HER CREATOR IN MORGAN LIBRARYLAND
description: WHAT is it about Lewis Carroll? Why is it that whereas many a very good Victorian children's book has long ceased to take off, in terms of the mass market, ''Alice's Adventures in Wonderland'' is as beguiling as ever? It takes a very hardy classic in the children's domain to be stronger than ever after more than 100 years, but the evidence is there for all to see. Alice has been translated by Vladimir Nabokov (in Berlin, in 1923, for the equivalent of $5), by the French Surrealist poet Louis Aragon and by a polyglot troop less well known to us.

title: EECO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including income from discontinued operations of $2.9 million or $1.19 a shr

title: LURIA, L, & SON reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BANCOHIO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
ENTEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
HARD TIMES IN VENDING FIELD
description: Choice Vend used to be called the Cadillac of vending machines, a company that turned out top-of-the-line models for bottlers willing to pay a little extra.

title: Article 192508 -- No Title
description: Purex Industries said late yesterday that its directors had approved an a greement in principle for the acquisition of Purex for $31.50 a share by a privately held company to be formed by Gibbon, Green, Van Amerongen, an investment banking firm in New Yo rk City that specializes in leveraged buyouts.

title: WURLITZER CO reports earnings for QTr to Dec 31
description: B-Includes $523,000 adjustment for the qr reversing all the net foreign exchange losses previously reported in the current fiscal yr; net income for the 9 mos also includes $808,000 tax credit...C-Includes $3,226,000 tax credit

title: Japanese Auto Exports Rise
description: Despite Government restrictions and economic stagnation in major overseas markets, Japan's vehicle exports rose 1.4 percent in 1981, a trade group said today.

title: JACK NICHOLSON IN 'THE BORDER'
description: AFTER 11 years of marriage, Charlie Smith (Jack Nicholson) is fed up with living in a dreary trailer with his pretty, bubble-brained, Texas-born wife, Marcy (Valerie Perrine), and with his job as a member of the United States Border Patrol stationed in Los Angeles. During the day, Charlie makes token arrests of docile, mostly frightened, illegal Mexican immigrants, who supply L.A.'s small businesses with below-minimum-wage labor, and then goes home to drink beer and listen to Marcy, who dreams of living in splendor in her very own duplex.

title: CATHEDRAL HAS KEY ROLE IN ST. JOHN'S 'EVERYMAN'
description: In a balcony high above the floor of the cavernous Cathedral of St. John the Divine, amid the huge trumpet pipes of the organ, an imposing figure in robes got an elocution lesson. ''Drowned in sin, they know me not for their God,'' he declared, his unamplified voice carrying with surprising volume to a visitor below. ''God-duh,'' the director, James Keeler, called up to him. And Fulgencio Saturno, who plays God in ''Everyman,'' the medieval morality play, said the line again.

title: College to Celebrate Joyce at 100 for a Week
description: Dance, music, drama, film and literary analysis will be the highlights of ''Portrait of the Artist,'' a weeklong observance at the State University of New York College at Purchase of the 100th anniversary of the birth of James Joyce on Feb. 2, 1882.

title: WESTERN PERSPECTIVE OF POLAND AND A POLE
description: To the Editor:

title: COMPUTER SCIENCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
At the Movies
description: SEAN CUNNINGHAM directs and produces movies; Susan Cunningham, his wife of 15 years, works as his editor. Despite so much togetherness, they appear to be flourishing.

title: G.M. AND UNION FAIL IN TALKS DESPITE EARLIER BROAD ACCORD
description: Negotiations between the United Automobile Workers and the General Motors Corporation on an early contract broke down late tonight, and a union official said no new contract would be possible until the agreement expires Sept. 14.

title: TOLERATING BIG DEFICITS
description: THE President's critics thought they had him cornered. Unemployment hit 8.9 percent in December and seemed to be headed higher. The Federal deficit was soaring toward $100 billion in the fiscal year 1982, perhaps $160 billion in 1983, and possibly still higher in what the cliche of the day calls the ''out years'' - presumably years one could do without.

title: BROWNING-FERRIS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SAMUEL G. BARTON, 68, A MARKETING SPECIALIST
description: Samuel G. Barton, a market-research executive, died Saturday at his home in Manhattan after a long illness. He was 68 years old.

title: ITALIAN POLICEMEN FREE U.S. GENERAL, WHO IS UNHARMED
description: Antiterrorist forces stormed an apartment in Padua and freed Brig. Gen. James L. Dozier today, 42 days after he was abducted by the Red Brigades.

title: Books of the Times; Books Of The Times
description: By Christopher Lehmann-Haupt THE MAKING OF THE REPRESENTA- TIVE FOR PLANET 8. By Doris Less- ing. 144 pages. Knopf. $11.95.

title: VICTIM OF ATTACK 'SURE' SURGEON IS INNOCENT
description: Clara Vanderbilt, an administrator who survived a near-fatal hammer attack at Montefiore Hospital in the Bronx, yesterday came to the defense of the surgeon authorities have identified as the principal suspect.

title: GRANITEVILLE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Notes on People; Suit on Paternity Leave Dismissed
description: A follow-up: A Federal district judge in Manhattan has dismissed a sex discrimination suit filed by an NBC engineer who said he had been denied a child-care leave last August to help his wife take care of their newborn baby. The company, he said, grants such leave to women.

title: NATIONAL STANDARD CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
SISYPHUS IN ORWELL'S DECADE
description: In the following excerpt from Gunter Grass's forthcoming novel, "Headbirths or The Germans Are Dying Out," Harm Peters and his wife, Dorte, are young German high school teachers traveling through Asia in a Volkswagen bus on a trip organized by the Sisyphus Tourist Bureau. The narrator imagines making a film about their trip. Brokdorf is a small village near Hamburg, where, in 1977 and 1981, environmentalists and citizens' action groups demonstrated against work in progress on a nuclear power plant.

title: Around the World; U.S. and Soviet Resume Geneva Arms Talks
description: United States-Soviet negotiations on limiting medium-range nuclear missiles in Europe resumed today after a review of the talks this week by Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. and Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko.

title: Weekender Guide; Friday; MENUHIN IN BROOKLYN
description: Yehudi Menuhin will join a protegee of his, Edna Michell, when he appears with the Brooklyn Philharmonia, conducted by Lukas Foss, tonight and tomorrow at 8 and Sunday at 3 P.M. in the Brooklyn Academy of Music. They will be the soloists in Bach's Concerto in D minor for Two Violins and Strings. Mr. Menuhin will be the solist for Ernest Bloch's Concerto for Violin and Orchestra. Also on the program are two arrangements of Bach: selections from William Malloch's ''The Art of Fuguing'' and Anton Webern's version of the Ricercata from the ''Musical Offering.'' Tickets: $6 to $10.50, at the box office, at the Edison Theater, Broadway and 47th Street, or through Chargit: 944-9300 ($3 for those younger than 22 and the elderly an hour before performance). Travel and other information: 636-4100.

title: DIVERS FIND NATURAL 'OIL REFINERIES'
description: Natural ''oil refineries'' have been discovered in a series of nine dives along the centerline of the Gulf of California. The oil is being formed from the unusually rapid breakdown of organic debris by extraordinarily intense heat flowing through the sediments, offering scientists a singular opportunity to see how petroleum is formed.

title: In the Nation; AN UNNEEDED HORROR
description: President Reagan apparently is ready to notify Congress that he has ordered a multibillion dollar program to produce binary nerve gas for chemical warfare - the worst possible answer to the Soviet Union's unconscionable ''yellow rain.''

title: Sports People; N.H.L. Suspends Mann
description: A 10-game suspension, the longest imposed by the National Hockey League this season, was given yesterday to Jimmy Mann, the Winnipeg Jet wing who broke the jaw of Paul Gardner of Pittsburgh in a game two weeks ago by punching him after Gardner had turned away. The suspension, which takes effect immediately, was announced by Brian O'Neill, the league's executive vice president, who found that Mann was guilty of ''deliberate injury.''

title: REAGAN BUDGET SAID TO SHOW LARGE DEFICITS THROUGH '84
description: The Reagan Administration, in the budget to be presented to Congress Feb. 8, will project deficits of $96 billion for the fiscal year 1982, $90 billion in 1983 and $78 billion in 1984, Congressional sources said today.

title: WELCOME SIDE EFFECTS OF HELPING THE DISABLED
description: To the Editor:

title: CABARET: VINTAGE ARLO GUTHRIE AT BOTTOM LINE
description: IT hardly seems as though 15 years have passed since Arlo Guthrie's anti-war ballad, ''Alice's Restaurant Massacree,'' established him as counterculture's most promising folk humorist. And since that time, Mr. Guthrie has grown into a folk-music institution whose impeccable taste in songs is matched by a zany style of entertainment that's one-part absurdist post-hippie wisecracking and the other part populist storytelling.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption yesterday incorrectly identified John L. Lewis's role in the United Mine Workers. He was president of that union and later helped found the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

title: TIME INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $7.85 million for the qr and $20.9 million for the yr...C-After $35.7 million loss from discontinued operations

title: In Bosendorfer Series

title: BUSH PLEDGES FORCEFUL POLICY ON SOVIET JEWS
description: Six leaders of major Jewish organizations met with Vice President Bush today to seek assurances that the Reagan Administration would strengthen its efforts in negotiations with the Soviet Union to allow the free emigration of Soviet Jews.

title: REVAMPING OF AIR CONTROL SYSTEM IN NEXT 20 YEARS PROPOSED BY U.S.
description: The Reagan Administration today put forward a 20-year plan to modernize the aging air traffic control system and said the cost, up to $9 billion for the first decade, would be met chiefly through taxes on tickets, fuel and other items.

description: ''Emergency'' Special Session Meets at 11 A.M. and 3 P.M.

description: Time Inc. reported yesterday that earnings from continuing operations in last year's fourth quarter rose 13.1 percent, to $53.1 million, from $47 million during the similar 1980 period.

R.J. Reynolds Bond
description: R.J. Reynolds Industries is raising a 10-year, zero-coupon Eurobond for a nominal $400 million through its overseas finance unit, bond market sources said here today. The bond is priced to yield 14.64 percent and will provide $102 million, excluding commissions, they added. The Dillon, Read Overseas Corporation is lead manager.

title: Life Begins 10 for Some Race Horses
description: When John Henry nosed out Peat Moss to win the Jockey Club Gold Cup last October, much was made of the fact that two 6-year-olds had defeated the best field of the year. But in human years - determined by tripling a horse's age - it was only a case of 18-year-olds defeating rivals who were 9, 12 and 15.

description: B-Includes $613,300 gain from the disposal of certain segments

title: HAIG, IN CAIRO, CALLS SIDES STILL FAR APART
description: After presenting the new American ideas for breaking the impasse in Palestinian self-rule negotiations to Israel and Egypt, Secretary of State Alexander M . Haig Jr. said today that despite ''som e progress'' the sides were still far apart.

title: Around the Nation; Wealthy Rancher Guilty In Drug Case in Texas
description: Rex Cauble, a millionaire rancher, was convicted today on charges that he financed and profited from an elaborate smuggling ring that used shrimp boats to ferry 106 tons of marijuana from Colombia into Texas.

title: Man Held in Mother's Killing
description: A Co-op City man was charged yesterday with killing his mother with a cleaver, the police said.

title: The City; Shooting Suspect Facing a Hearing
description: A man arrested in Miami on charges of shooting a probationary police officer on a Brooklyn street Dec. 7 was returned to New York yesterday to face a charge of attempted murder.

title: CAREY OUTLINES PLAN TO FINANCE REPAIRS FOR STATE HIGHWAYS
description: Governor Carey today detailed plans for rehabilitating some of the state's deteriorating highways, bridges and mass-transit systems by increasing fees and taxes.

title: ECONOMIC INDEX RISES BY 0.6%
description: In a sign that the economic recession may be abating, the Commerce Department today reported a modest rise last month in a statistic intended to signal turns in the business cycle.

title: HEAD START'S 'PERILS OF PAULINE'
description: For advocates of Head Start, President Reagan's latest promise not to cut the program was a major victory.

title: Johnstone, Vickers Encouraged by Goals
description: Steve Vickers and Eddie Johnstone, the veterans whose quick sticks were essential to the Rangers' 5-4 victory Wednesday night over the Washington Capitals, think that the rest of the season can only be better for them.

GIDON KREMER, RISING STAR OF VIOLIN
description: Gidon Kremer, the Latvian-born violinist who recently performed to much acclaim at Carnegie Hall as a soloist with the English Chamber Orchestra, conceded rather disarmingly the other day that there is more to life than playing solos. ''Being a violinist can be a little boring - especially for me,'' he said, explaining why he is devoting a good deal of his time to chamber music. He will make his first New York appearance in a chamber setting Sunday night at 8 at the 92d Street Y.

title: APPEALS PANEL QUERIES BOTH SIDES ON COOKE'S PLAN TO ROTATE JUDGES
description: A five-judge panel pressed hard with questions yesterday during arguments from both sides in an appeal by District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau of Manhattan against a decision upholding a new system for awarding temporary judgeships.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A picture caption on page A1 on Wednesday incorrectly gave Vice President Bush's Senate title. He is the president of the Senate.

title: THE GAVEL BRINGING SENATORS TO ORDER
description: It was one of those late night sessions in which some senators, sometimes after a nip or so too many, had become a bit raucous. The Vice President, trying to restore order, rapped the gavel sharply.

title: PUBLISHING: UNEARTHING GEMS IN THE 'SLUSH PILE'
description: THE odds against an unknown author getting a manuscript published by simply sending it directly to a publishing house are astronomical. When the novel ''Ordinary People'' by Judith Guest was plucked out of the so-called ''slush pile'' of Viking Press in the mid-1970's - the first unsolicited manuscript to be accepted by Viking in 27 years - it was treated as a major event. Even the author, who had addressed her covering letter simply to ''The Editors,'' was surprised. When Viking's telegram of acceptance arrived, Miss Guest broke into tears of joy, prompting her youngest child to ask if somebody had died.

title: Valentine Gets $50,000 Raise
description: Ellis Valentine, who hit .208 last season, won a raise of more than $50,000 yesterday when he signed a one-year contract with the Mets and withdrew his salary dispute from arbitration.

title: REAPPORTIONMENT UPHELD ON COAST
description: The California Supreme Court today gave indirect approval to Democratic reapportionment plans for the StateLegislature and the state's 45 Congressional seats by ordering that primary and general elections this year be conducted on the basis of district lines drawn last summer by the Legislature.

title: Notes on People; Case of Missing Parka (and Missing Mints)
description: In December 1980, when Mayor Koch led a City Hall entourage on a journey to the Middle East, they left New York with 26 pieces of luggage.

title: 'IT'S NEVER TOO COLD TO SNOW'
description: To the Editor:

DOW, UP 21.59, SCORES BEST GAIN IN 10 MONTHS
description: The Dow Jones industrial average soared 21.59 points yesterday to score its best advance in 10 months as investors, for one dramatic session at least, shrugged off fears of high interest rates and a stumbling economy.

title: Money Fund Assets Drop
description: Assets of the nation's 163 money market funds declined $360 million for the week ended Wednesday, to $187.7 billion, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.

title: AMERICANS RETURN TO CHAD, DISCREETLY
description: Each morning, John P. Blane, the United States charge d'affaires here, clambers aboard a boat to cross the Shari River from Kousseri, Cameroon, where he lives, to Ndjamena, where he works, joining many other commuters who are poled and paddled across the muddy waters in dugout canoes.

title: JAZZ THRIVING IN THE CITY IN BIGGEST SURGE SINCE 40'S
description: WOULD anyone in his or her right mind mistake Manhattan for paradise? If the person in question were a jazz fan, the mistake would be understandable; it might not even be a mistake. Two major new jazz clubs - the Blue Note and Lush Life - have opened since last October, swelling the number of establishments regularly presenting jazz artists of the first rank to well over a dozen. The Bottom Line in Greenwich Village, once the city's major rock venue, now presents more jazz than rock, and the Beacon Theater on the Upper West Side has instituted a series of important jazz concerts.

title: STEIGER TRACTOR CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
7th Victim in School Blast
description: A 10-year-old girl today became the seventh person to die from a water heater explosion at Star Elementary School in suburban Spencer. The death of Angela Martin came nine days after the blast.

title: XEROX NET FELL IN QUARTER, BUT GREW 5.9% IN YEAR
description: The Xerox Corporation yesterday said profits fell 6.6 percent in the fourth quarter of 1981, but were up 5.9 percent for the year. The copier maker said its earnings were depressed by unfavorable currency translation, heavy investment in new products and expenses related to layoffs designed to raise productivity and make the company more competitive.

title: Transit Report
description: L.I.R.R.: Of 134 morning rush-hour trains, 17 were late. CONRAIL: On the Hudson Division, one of the 29 trains in the morning rush was canceled and nine were late.

Vaughn, 72, who continues as chairman of the Evansville, Ind., utility, whose territory encompasses eight counties in southwestern Indiana.

description: Fire erupted in a high-rise oceanfront condominium today, injuring 19 persons and forcing the evacuation of hundreds of apartments. Sixteen residents and three firefighters were injured in the blaze.

title: India Seeks Soviet Loan
description: India has asked for a $560 million loan from the Soviet Union to build an alumina plant in southern India, R. Ganapati, mines secretary, told a news conference today.

title: Sports People; Orioles Trade DeCinces
description: Doug DeCinces, who replaced Brooks Robinson at third base in Baltimore, was traded by the Orioles yesterday to the California Angels for Dan Ford, a hard-hitting outfielder. The 32-year-old DeCinces, who hit .263 with 13 homers and 55 runs batted in during the 1981 season, will probably be replaced in Baltimore by Cal Ripken Jr., son of the Oriole third-base coach.

title: JET'S ICING DEVICE WAS TURNED OFF
description: An anti-icing device in the engine system of an Air Florida passenger jet had been turned off when the plane plunged into the Potomac River in a snowstorm Jan. 13, the board investigating the crash said today.

title: HAWKEYE BANCORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
3 Teen-Agers Held In Queens Attack
description: Three teen-agers were charged with robbery, burglary, unlawful imprisonment and assault in an attack on an 83-year-old woman in her home in St. Albans, Queens, Wednesday morning.

ISRAELI DOWNED IN '56 PAYS POIGNANT VISIT TO SINAI
description: Occupied Sinai, Jan. 27 - On the desert flats not far from the strategic Strait of Tiran, is the bullet-riddled wreckage of an old Mustang fighter plane. The faded outline of a Star of David is still visible on the fuselage. Around the site, low metal posts have been set in the ground to mark this remnant of the 1956 Sinai campaign.

title: Average N.F.L. Salary Is $90,102, Survey Says
description: An annual survey conducted by the National Football League shows that the average salary of an N.F.L. player last season was $90,102, with quarterbacks averaging the highest, $160,037.

title: TO RUN, ROLL AND LEAP WITH WOODBERRY DANCERS
description: ''O.K., group,'' David Woodberry said quietly. ''We're going to go through the material.'' Dressed in layer upon layer of sweaters and sweatpants against the studio's chill, the dancers straggled up from the squares of sunshine they'd appropriated for their pre-rehearsal stretches. ''Yea!'' one called back teasingly. ''Now,'' Mr. Woodberry said. ''Run, leap, walk, and go.'' He began, darting across the vast floor in a broken run with the dancers flowing behind him, a flock of sandpipers with sunlight lapping at their feet. ''And go. Take a dash to over here. Lean, back, lean.''

description: AUTO RACING FISA - Fined six Grand Prix drivers $10,000 and 23 others $5,000 in connection with a drivers' strike at South African race.; BASEBALL METS (NL) - Agreed to terms of one- year contract with Ellis Valentine, out- fielder. Valentine's arbitration was with- drawn. BALTIMORE (AL) - Acquired Dan Ford, outfielder, from California (AL) for Doug DeCinces, third baseman, and Jeff Schneider, pitcher. WRITER WHO FABRICATED STORY TELLS OF PRESSURE 'TO BE FIRST'
description: Janet Cooke, a Washington Post reporter who won a Pulitzer Prize last year for a fabricated report about a young heroin addict, says she made up the story because she had spent two months looking for such a person and ''if I did not produce a story, then how was I to justify my time?''

title: NEIGHBORHOOD HELPS 'VILLAGE' CHURCH PUT ROOF OVER HOMELESS
description: St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church in Greenwich Village has begun sheltering 10 homeless men a night, becoming the first church to act on Mayor Koch's suggestion that churches and synagogues take in the homeless.

title: Around the Nation; Medical Records Called Vital in Von Bulow Trial
description: Charges that Claus C. von Bulow tried to kill his wife will have to be dismissed if a jury is prevented from hearing medical evidence that she was injected with insulin, a prosecutor said today.

title: EVENING GLAMOUR, SPORTY DAYS
description: The last day of the haute couture showings here is traditionally reserved for the two newest designers, Hanae Mori and Per Spook, and the most revered, Alix Gres.

title: REAGAN'S MEDICAID PLAN IMPERILS CAREY PROPOSAL
description: President Reagan's proposal to have the Federal Government assume the costs of the Medicaid program could doom a key portion of Governor Carey's 1982 legislative program, high legislative officials said today.

DOZIERS HUG AND CRY AT HOSPITAL REUNION
description: Gen. James L. Dozier hugged his wife Judith and daughter Cheryl, and the family exchanged New Year's greetings delayed until today by the general's abduction by the Red Brigades, military sources reported.

title: COBE LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Notes on People; First Love
description: For 28 years, Fred Porcelli has worked at the ''21'' Club, most of them as a host at the restaurant on East 52d Street. He said yesterday, ''I suppose I've met, conservatively, about 5,000 of the most celebrated people in the world.''

title: WHEN A SMALL 'COSI' MEETS A BIG MET
description: Colin Graham's job this week is to fit something small into something big without seeming to do so. Mr. Graham is in charge of the Metropolitan Opera's new production of ''Cosi fan tutte,'' which opens tonight, and the problem of keeping Mozart's lean proportions and intimate message intact amid the vastness of the 3,800-seat house has been much on his mind.

title: Books: Rich Man's Tale
description: JOCK. The Life and Times of John Hay Whitney. By E. J. Kahn Jr. 339 pages. Doubleday. $19.95.

title: Williams Debate on Feb. 23
description: The Senate will start debate on whether to expel Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr, on Feb. 23, Senator Howard H. Baker Jr., the majority leader, said today. The New Jersey Democrat was convicted on bribery and conspiracy charges in the Abscam inquiry into political corruption. He underwent emergency surgery for a hernia condition Tuesday.

title: POLES DESCRIBE 9 AS AGENTS OF C.I.A.
description: The Polish Government accused the United States today of espionage in Poland and said the Central Intelligence Agency had played a significant role in creating anti-Government opposition.

title: SONG RECITAL: JANET BAKER AT CARNEGIE
description: JANET BAKER'S annual New York recitals are rather like state visits from some distantly regal monarch, occasions for automatic genuflection. Not that Miss Baker (or Dame Janet in English usage) is unworthy of such honors. It is just that the already formidable formalities of a song recital are transcended: Even in the light songs, Miss Baker is serious.

title: PPG OFF 41.6%
description: Nabisco Brands Inc. said yesterday that strong gains by its bakery and domestic foods divisions helped lift earnings 14.2 percent in the fourth quarter of 1981.

title: About Real Estate; FOR QUEENS BLIGHT, PREVENTIVE MEDICINE
description: The reality underlying the truism that housing blight, if left untreated, will spread, infect and eventually destroy a neighborhood has long been observable in New York City. Housing experts know that, given certain factors, blight can strike stable, middle-class neighborhoods just as rapidly and effectively as impoverished ones.

title: Connecticut's Stratford Files for Bankruptcy
description: The American Shakespeare Theater in Stratford, Conn., has filed under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy code, which will allow the financially troubled organization to continue operations while reorganization and fund-raising drive are begun.

title: PINK SLIPS LAUNCH A NEW JOB SEARCH
description: For 935 workers at the Pratt & Whitney Aircraft Company, there were packets telling them how to apply for unemployment insurance, where to look for another job and how to write a resume. Today was their last day on the job.

title: De Gustibus; TEAROOM FARE LIVES ON IN 'NEW' AMERICAN CUISINE
description: Proud to think of themselves as the avant-garde of what is being celebrated as the New American Cuisine, many young chefs and restaurant owners would be indignant were their establishments to be described as latter-day tearooms. Yet that seems to be the direction in which many are headed, albeit without recognizing it.

title: HUBERT (HUB) PRUETT
description: Hubert S. (Hub) Pruett, a left-handed pitcher who was once a nemesis of Babe Ruth, died Thursday at his home in suburban Ladue. He was 81 years old.

title: Around the World; Moscow Hunger Striker Said to Be Deteriorating
description: A Pentecostalist on a hunger strike is in deteriorating condition at the American Embassy and will soon be handed over to the Soviet Union for treatment, a United States spokesman said today.

title: Deputy Minister's Ankle Bruised and Wrenched
description: The injury to Deputy Minister, the 1981 2-year-old thoroughbred champion, was diagnosed today as a severely bruised and wrenched right front ankle.

title: KEY PROTESTANT SLAIN IN BELFAST
description: A gunman tonight killed the leader of the Red Hand Commandos, an illegal paramilitary force of hard-line Protestants in Northern Ireland, the police reported.

title: Reagan Home on Coast Said to Have Been Sold
description: The Pacific Palisades home where President Reagan lived for 25 years has been sold for an undisclosed sum, the real estate concern handling the sale said today. The house had a $1.9 million price tag.

description: Secretary of State Alexander M. Haig Jr. returned to Washington from the Middle East today convinced that an early agreement between Israel and Egypt on Palestinian self-rule was out of the question.

Hess Earnings Down 54.8%
description: Amerada Hess, the nation's 18th-largest oil company, reported yesterday that its net income in the fourth quarter of 1981 fell by 54.8 percent, to $48.2 million, or 58 cents a share, from $106.6 million, or $1.27 a share, in the last quarter of 1980. Revenue rose slightly, to $2.34 billion, from $2.25 billion.

title: MA BELL'S CLOSE FAMILY TIES
description: Arthur Flaherty, a placid man with lank dark hair and a welltended mustache, works on the 36th floor of the New York Telephone Company headquarters at 42d Street and the Avenue of the Americas. His office is a fast elevator trip and several bumpy miles from the downtown base of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company. Still, Mr. Flaherty feels the lo oming presence of Mother Bell every da y. She sends him 1,400 bills a year.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: An article Monday about the Luciano Pavarotti-Frank Sinatra benefit concert at Radio City Music Hall incorrectly identified Thomas O. Enders, a guest at a dinner-dance, and incorrectly named his wife. Mr. En- ders, now Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, was for- merly Ambassador to Canada. His wife's name is Gaetana.

title: OTTER TAIL POWER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
LEAKS ARE FOUND AT 3 MILE ISLAND
description: Steam generator leaks at Three Mile Island's undamaged Unit 1, described two months ago as likely to delay the restarting of the nuclear reactor until February, were acknowledged today to involve up to 4,000 faulty tubes that will require at least six months to repair. Unit 1 is the still-operable twin of Three Mile Island Unit 2, the reactor that suffered the nation's worst comm ercial nuclear accident on March 28, 1979. The announcement of the mo re extensive and potentially dangerous flaws in Unit 1 by offi cials of GPU Nuclear Inc., the operator of the nuclear power plant , was another serious setback to the company's hope to start up Uni t 1 to bring in much needed revenue.
