title: Around the World; School Bus Hijacker Held in Netherlands
description: A French teen-ager who commandeered a school bus and forced the driver at gunpoint to drive through three countries to his girlfriend's orphanage here was being questioned today as prosecutors awaited France's decision on his case.

title: STOCK PRICES CLIMB ON HEAVY VOLUME
description: Wall Street's expectations that money supply growth will be reduced and interest rates will decline enabled the stock market to post its second consecutive broad advance yesterday in the fourth-highest trading in history.

title: AID HALTED, DELOREAN IDLES 1,100
description: The crisis at the DeLorean Motor Company intensified today as the car manufacturer began to lay off 1,100 of its 2,600 workers amid a deluge of recriminations and counterrecriminations. One of the company's major headaches has been the decline of the auto industry in the United States, where DeLorean had hoped to sell many more cars.

title: Sports People; Sampson Gives a Sign
description: Ralph Sampson, Virginia's 7-foot-4-inch junior center, who twice has spurned lucrative professional offers, has applied for a room on the campus next fall, Athletic Director Dick Schultz said.

title: Sports People; Comings and Goings
description: President Reagan agreed to take part in the opening ceremonies at the 1984 Olympic Games in Los Angeles. The President met yesterday with Juan Antonio Samaranch, the president of the International Olympic Committee, and Peter V. Ueberroth, the president of the Los Angeles Olympic Organizing Committee, who offered the invitation. ... Angelo Trosclair, the jockey who was convicted in October of paying two other riders to hold back their mounts in a race at the Fair Grounds, was sentenced in New Orleans to 90 days in jail, five years' probation and a $2,500 fine.

title: TEXAS EASTERN CORP reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
Miss Zayak Loses Title to Miss Sumners
description: Elaine Zayak missed three of six triple jumps - a manuever in which she usually excels - and lost her women's national title tonight to Rosalynn Sumners at the United States figure skating championships.

title: JUDGES MUST SPEAK OUT
description: In 1922, Senator John K. Shields upbraided Chief Justice William Howard Taft for exerting pressure on Congress to enact a bill to enlarge the Federal judiciary.That was neither the first nor the last time that members of the Federal bench have been criticized for voicing their views on matters related to the administration of justice.

title: THREAT TO LOCAL PHONE SERVICE SEEN
description: A confidential staff study by the Federal Communications Commission asserts that local telephone companies could be undermined, or at least weakened, as a result of the proposed antitrust agreement between the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and the Justice Department.

title: David Kershner Dead; A Surgeon in Brooklyn
description: Dr. David Kershner, a Brooklyn surgeon for almost 60 years and former president of the Kings County Medical Society, died Monday at his Brooklyn home. He was 84 years old.

title: HOFSISS TO STAGE PLAY ON YALE WHIFFENPOOFS
description: Blanche Baker, who played the title role on Broadway in Edward Albee's ''Lolita,'' will be the only woman in the new Off Broadway production ''Poor Little Lambs.'' A play with music, ''Poor Little Lambs'' will open in mid-March in the basement theater at St. Peter's Church, in the Citicorp Building.

title: INTERMETCO LTD reports earnings for Yr to Oct 31
description: B-After $358,000 special gain...C-Net income

title: YEAR'S FALL IN FARM PRICES ENDS
description: After months of steady decline, prices paid to farmers for raw products rose an estimated 1.6 percent in January, the first time in more than a year that the index has risen, the Agriculture Department reported today.

title: NOBILITY HOMES reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
YELLOW FREIGHT SYSTEM INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-Including a credit of $16.8 million for the writeoff of operationg rights...C-Net loss after a charge of $34.8 million for the writeoff of operationg rights

title: BRUNSWICK RESISTS WHITTAKER MERGER
description: Mention the name Brunswick, and bowling balls and billiards equipment may come to mind. Not any more. That image of the suburban Chicago company is outmoded. The Brunswick Corporation is a well-mixed conglomerate that has diversified into technical, medical and military products as well as marine outboard motors.

title: SALVADOR PEASANTS PRAISE LAND POLICY
description: Officers of an organization representing peasants in E l Salvador praised the Government there this week for ''positive at titudes'' toward the troubled land-redistribution plan and for accep ting policy recommendations from the group.

title: EXCERPTS FROM ACCORD ON THEOLOGY
description: Following are excerpts from ''B aptism, Eucharist and Ministry,'' a theological a greement prepared by the World Council of Churches' Commission on Faith and Order: Incorporation Into the Body of Christ

title: RECORD PAN AM LOSS MEANS LAYOFFS
description: Pan American World Airways yesterday reported a loss of $82.7 million for the fourth qu arter, its largest q uarterly loss ever, and announced that it was eliminating about 200 o f its management jobs and taking other steps in an attempt to end c ontinuing losses.

title: WRIGHT, BARRY, CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results for the latest yr include a gain of $764,000 or 9 cents a shr on the sale of assets after the effect of the adoption of LIFO accounting

title: DRILLERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Halo Effect
description: To much of the present adult population of the United States, Franklin Delano Roosevelt was not merely the President but The President, the apotheosis of American leader, against whom all future Presidents would be measured.

title: SEAPORT MUSEUM TRIMS STAFF
description: The South Street Seaport Museum is cutting its staff by about 30 percent, letting 25 of its 75 employees go, John B. Hightower, president of the museum, said yesterday.

title: AVCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
GRAIN TOWN FEARS LOSS OF RAIL LINK
description: It was the railroad that bound together the awesome spaces of the West, tying tiny frontier towns to distant markets in a webwork of steel rails.

title: No Headline
description: McEnroe Advances; Hooper Tops Sadri

title: Salvadoran in Custody Is Tied to Death Squads
description: A former major arrested in connection with the kidnapping of a wealthy landowner is believed to have headed ''death squads'' totaling about 400 members, the police said today.

title: Around the Nation; Watt Extends Freeze On Wilderness Leases
description: Interior Secretary James G. Watt today extended a moratorium on oil and gas leasing in wilderness areas until after this year's Congressional elections.

title: Celeste to Run for Governor
description: Richard F. Celeste, a former Peace Corps director and onetime Lieutenant Governor of Ohio, announced his candidacy for the governorship today from the home of an unemployed neighbor, P.J. McCrone. Mr. Celeste, who is 44 years old, said he chose the site to announce his entry into the race for the Democratic primary to stress the urgency of unemployment in Ohio. In 1978 Mr. Celeste was narrowly defeated by Gov. James A. Rhodes, a Republican who is barred by law from running for a third consecutive term.

title: State Will End Races For New York Claimers
description: Claiming races at Aqueduct, Belmont Park and Saratoga that are restricted to horses bred in New York will be phased out by April, state racing officials announced yesterday.

title: Saturday News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 48.

title:
Patents;
5 Inventors Honored For Work
description: WASHINGTON FIVE men who received notable United States patents will be inducted into the National Inventors Hall of Fame at the Patent and Trademark Office, Arlington, Va., on Feb. 7. One inventor selected posthumously is Henry Ford, who will be honored for a patent entitled ''Transmission Mechanism,'' which was granted him in 1911.

title: Notes on People; A Double Debut
description: When the incidental music that Beethoven composed for Goethe's drama ''Egmont'' is given one of its relatively rare complete performances at the Beethoven Society's Alice Tully Hall concert tomorrow, an American actor will make his New York debut narrating what Goethe called ''short speech as a link between the scenes of action.''

title: Around the World; Iranian Firing Squads Execute 10 Leftists
description: Iranian firing squads executed 10 more leftist guerrillas, the official Iranian press agency reported today.

title: Ex-Treasury Chief Is Sued
description: The Italian Government filed suit yesterday in Federal court in New York against former Treasury Secretary David M. Kennedy on the ground that he had conspired to defraud a bankrupt Italian bank once controlled by the financier Michele Sindona.

title: BRADLEY, MILTON, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BALMY 40o SNAPS CITY'S LONG FREEZE
description: To the National Weather Service it was simple: A turnabout in the upper air patterns allowed warmer airflows from the west to prevail over Arctic winds.

title: Yanks Name Nettles Captain
description: Graig Nettles was named captain of the Yankees yesterday, the sixth in the team's history and the first since his friend Thurman Munson was killed in an airplane crash in August 1979.

title: British Court Blocks Appeal O n Rights of Canada's Indians
description: The Court of Appeal refused today to grant Canadian Indians permission to appeal to t he House of Lords, Britain's court of last resort, in their lega l fight for land rights.

title: CYCLOPS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Around the Nation; Missouri Officials Assess Natural Gas Damage
description: With a state of emergency still in effect, inspectors went door-to-door today to assess damage in more than 30 buildings where flames broke out Thursday after a surge of natural gas.

title: Rebels Kill 2 in Guatemala
description: Leftist guerrillas fired from a pickup truck into a bus today, killing two policemen and wounding seven commuters, the police said. The incident brought to seven the number of policemen killed since Wednesday in the capital. More than 300 people have died this month in fighting with guerrillas opposed to the military regime.

title: By Peter Passell
description: The Editorial Notebook Breathing Space in Cairo

title: EL PASO ELECTRIC CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
DOZIER SAYS HE WAS NOT MISTREATED BUT FELT CAPTORS PLANNED TO KILL HIM
description: Brig. Gen. James L. Dozier, looking fit and once again clean-shaven, crewcut and beri bboned, made his first public appearance today after his liberation Thursday from 42 days of captivity by Red Brigades terrorists.

title: IN SLUMP, LABOR 'WILL PLAY ITS PART'
description: With unemployment at the second highest level since World War II, some of the country's largest unions are now negotiating new contracts and discussing concessions on wages and benefits in the hope of protecting members' jobs.

title: Going Out Guide
description: FAN CLUBS

title: COKE REVIEWING PLAN TO ACQUIRE OUTLET INC.
description: The Coca-Cola Company disclosed today that it was reviewing its proposed takeover of Outlet Inc. in light of the bankruptcy of a debtor to the Rhode Island-based communications company.

title: Louisiana Tech Streak Ends
description: Old Dominion ended Louisiana Tech's record winning streak in women's college basketball at 54 games tonight with a 61-58 victory.

title: TAPES OF DOCTOR IN ASSAULT CASE GIVEN TO A JUDGE
description: Two tape recordings that District Attorney Mario Merola of the Bronx says ''may well hold the key'' to establishing who attempted to murder an administrator at Montefiore Hospital were turned over ''for safekeeping'' yesterday to a judge.

title: THE DAY I VISITED A CI B NK HOLD P
description: On Thursday , Jan. 14, at 2:45 P.M., I attended my first bank robbery. It was quite a success.

title: Miller Leads On 67-132
description: Johnny Miller took the lead today in the second round of the San Diego Open. He shot a 67, five under par for the south course of Torrey Pines. The day's best round, however, was by 46-ye ar-old Chi Chi Rodriguez, who tied the record of 64 on Torre y Pines's north course. With Thursday's 65 on the north course, Mil ler had 132, a record 12-under-par for the combined layouts. Fuzzy Zoeller, co-leader Thursday with Mill er, scored 70 on the south course for 135. Curtis Strange and Morr is Hatalsky, also on thesouth, shot 67 and 68 for 135's.

title: MOUNT VERNON MILLS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
U.S.  COURT REJECTS ONE-HOUSE VETOES USED BY CONGRESS
description: The Federal appeals court here today struck down the so-called one-house veto, which allows either house of Congress to block the policies of certain Federal agencies from taking effect.

title: Japan's Jobless Rate Up
description: The number of persons unemployed in Japan increased by 120,000 in 1981, to 1,260,000, the highest level since World War II, the Labor Ministry said today. The figure represented 2.2 percent of Japan's labor force, the highest rate since 1950, when it reached 2.5 percent, the ministry said. In contrast, the unemployment rate in the United States was 8.9 percent in December.

title: Brendel Recital Feb. 25
description: Alfred Brendel will give his only New York recital of the season at Carnegie Hall Feb. 25 at 8 P.M. He will play piano music by Mozart, Schumann, Liszt and Berg. Tickets are $12.50, $10, $8 and $6 and are available at the box office or through Carnegie Charge at (212) 247-7459.

title: PALDEN THONDUP NAMGYAL, DEPOSED SIKKIM KING, DIES
description: The deposed King of Sikkim, Palden Thondup Namgyal, who had been undergoing treatment for cancer in New York, died last night from complications following an operation at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. He was 58 years old. A family spokesman said his body was to be flown home to Sikkim for the funeral.

title: YOUTH, 19, HELD IN COAST SLAYING OF TURKISH AIDE
description: A 19-year-old has been arrested as a suspect in the assassination of the Turkish consul general. He was in police custody hours after the killing Thursday.

title: E-SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Spain Revalues Gold
description: The Bank of Spain said today that it revalued upward its gold reserves to $298 an ounce from $42.22 an ounce, effective Dec. 31.

title: WRONG 'BODY COUNT' FOR EL SALVADOR
description: To the Editor:

title: CROWN CARPETS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Notes on People; Not the Retiring Sort
description: His fellow workers in the Customs Service decided that they might as well give Ferdinand Gallozzi a retirement party this week, since he had ''absolutely no plans to ever actually retire.''

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day on Thursday about company earnings incorrectly reported Philip Morris's share of the cigarette market outside the United States. The share rose to about 6.4 percent in 1981.

description: Yr ago shr earnings and shrs outstdng have been adjusted to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split declared Feb 25, 1981

title: MURRAY OHIO MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Rangers Set Back Rockies by 5 to 2 O n 4 Goals in Third
description: The Rangers dawdled for two periods against the Colorado Rockies tonight, then overwhelmed the team with the worst record in the league with four third-period goals.

title: U.S. STANCE ON NICARAGUA ANGERS PARIS
description: Officials here reacted angrily today against what they interpreted as an effort by some Washington officials to magnify the significance of France's agreement to sell arms to Nicaragua.

title: 10 Hurt in Collapse Of a Tenement
description: At least 10 persons were injured, apparently none seriously, when a a six-story apartment building collapsed as it was being evacuated on Manhattan's upper West Side, authorities reported last night.

title: CITY OF TRADITIONS MOURNS BULLETIN, AN INSTITUTION
description: They still sold hoagies at the lunch counter at 15th and Arch Streets; pushcarts still peddled soft pretzels, and the old streetcars still rattled along Germantown Avenue, but for many in Philadelphia, the city would never again be quite the same.

title: THEATER: INDICTMENT OF ALL-AMERICAN FAMILY
description: Among the more bizarre news stories to haunt our culture in recent years are those follow-up features that appear after the arrest of a mass murderer. In these stories, reporters ask the neighbors of a Texas sniper or a so-called Son of Sam whether they noticed any odd behavior on the killer's part during his months of heinous crime. The answer is inevitably no. Right up until the end, it seems, these fellows were shy, well-mannered types who minded their own business and helped little old ladies with their groceries. In the very sick, very funny first act of ' 'The House Across the Street,'' a new play at the Ensemble Studio T heater, a young writer named Darrah Cloud examines the absurd dimens ions of this paradox. ''House'' is set in a Chicago suburb and is l oosely inspired by the John Wayne Gacy case. It tells of a typical a ll-American family, the Fortunes, who wake up to discover that the ni ce man across the front lawn has raped and strangled 31 boys and then buried them in every crevice of his home. Although the family's li ving-room window looks right into the murderer's house, no one ever noticed ''anything out of the ordinary.'' So what if the man poured a new concrete floor in his basement every week? Maybe he was just do ing his bit to keep up property values.

title: Sports People; Ford Trade Held Up
description: There was a snag yesterday in the trade that on Thursday had apparently sent Dan Ford from the California Angels to the Baltimore Orioles for Doug DeCinces and Jeff Schneider. Ford now says that he wants an extension on his contract, which runs out next season, or some other compensation before he will report.

title: 'Specimen Days' to Reopen
description: Meredith Monk's ''Specimen Days'' will reopen Feb. 11 at the New York Shakespeare Festival's Public Theater. It will play through Feb. 28.

title: FOR SAINT LAURENT'S ANNIVERSARY, A LITTLE PARIS FETE
description: It was a simple, elegant anniversary party at the Lido with a cast of a thousand. Yves Saint Laurent, the middle-class French boy from Algeria who came to Paris at age 16 to seek fame and fortune and w ent to work for Christian Dior the following year, was celebrating t he 20th birthday of his own couture house.

title: Answers to Quiz
description: Questions appear on page 13. 1. He is a freshman United States Representative from Connecticut who cast mo re votes last year against President Reagan than any othermember of the House.

title: Article 194897 -- No Title
description: Governor Carey submitted to the State Legislature today a $176 million deficiency budget that included money to cover increases in the prison population, along with programs in education,transportatio n and social services.

title: Around the Nation; Link Seen in Drinking And Breast Cancer
description: By The Associated Press Women who drink may be nearly twice as likely to develop breast cancer as nondrinkers, according to a preliminary study in today's issue of The Lancet, the British medical journal.

title: ATLAS HOTELS INC reports earnings for QTr to Dec 31
description: B-After a loss of $44,000 from discontinued operations

title: Temporary Order Bars A ll Dealings With Page
description: Butch Lewis, the boxing promoter, obtained yesterday a temporary restraining order barring any other promoter, including Don King, from arranging matches involving Greg Page, the undefeated heavyweight.

title: ABSCAM FIGURE'S WIFE MAILED DATA TO HER LAWYER
description: The estranged wife of the Government's chief witness in the Abscam prosecutions mailed a 19-page narrative to her attorney Monday detailing her accusations that the witness had perjured himself, and the attorney said today that he received it just an hour before he learned his client was found hanged Thursday in a Florida condominium.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Ski Racing Postponed
description: Continuous snowfall forced skiers at the world championships off the slopes and into indoor training facilities, indefinitely postponing the men's combined downhill race, which was to have been held today. The women's special downhill was still scheduled for Saturday, however.

title: U.S. SETS PLANTING REDUCTION
description: Farmers who wish to remain eligible for loans and subsidies on their grain and cotton this year must reduce plantings by 10 or 15 percent, Agriculture Secretary John R. Block said today.

title: TEXAS' DISTRICTING IS REJECTED BY U.S.
description: The Justice Department today rejected a Congressional redistricting plan for Texas, saying that it violated the Voting Rights Act by diluting the political strength of Mexican-Americans in the southern part of the state.

title: G. Heileman Suit
description: Nine Illinois retailers have filed a class-action suit against the G. Heileman Brewing Company, a major beer producer holding an estimated 30 percent of the Chicago-area market, and seven of its wholesale distributors, charging that the brewer engaged in price fixing and other unfair trade practices. The suit, filed in Federal District Court in Illinois, charged that Heileman and the wholesalers conspired to allocate exclusive sales territories in restraint of trade and attempted to monopolize the sale of Heileman products.

title:
Patents;
A Herpes Treatment
description: For treatment of herpes simplex, a sexually transmitted virus disease that produces blisters or sores, Dr. Samuel Soichet of Beth Israel Medical Center, in New York, proposes use of spectinomycin, an antibiotic often used for other ailments. He got patent 4,312,884 this week for the treatment, which he uses with patients. The spectinomycin or a nontoxic spectinomycin salt can be injected in muscles or applied as an ointment.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Crime Control Inc. is offering 725,000 shares of common stock at $10 a share, to be sold through a Thomson McKinnon Securities Inc. group.

title: PUBLIC TV TO SELL ADS AS A TEST
description: Ten public-television stations, including WNET-TV, Channel 13, were authorized today to try as an experiment new financing, including selling time for commercials.

title:
SPORTS OF THE TIMES;
LONESOME LOSERS
description: IT was early Monday morning -some 14 hours after the Super Bowl - and Coach Forrest Gregg and his band of Bengals were departing their hotel in Troy, Mich., for home in Cincinnati. There was no fanfare. The Bengals, after a good comeback in the second half, had lost to the 49ers in the championship game, 26-21.

title: 7 Million Visited China in '81
description: China had more than 7 million visitors in 1981, an increase of 1.3 million over 1980, and it plans to allow tourists into more cities and scenic areas in the future.

title: DISCRIMINATION SUBSIDY
description: To the Editor:

title: Erhardt To Direct Offense Of Giants
description: Ron Erhardt, dismissed last month as head coach of the New England Patriots, was hired by the Giants yesterday as their first offensive coordinator in nine years.

title: LTV Dividend
description: The LTV Corporation said it had reinstated its quarterly dividend and will distribute 12.5 cents a share on March 24 to holders of record March 3. It is LTV's first cash dividend since March 1970. The company also declared a dividend of 14.1625 cents a share of participating preference stock.

title: No Headline
description: The Lukens Steel Company, Coatesville, Pa., said it had signed a definitive merger agreement with General Steel Industries, of St. Louis. The agreement is to be presented for approval to a special meeting of General Steel shareholders March 18. Under the agreement, General Steel would become a subsidiary of Lukens.

title: 20 More Arrested On Fare Charges
description: The latest crackdown on subway-fare cheats resulted in the arrest of 20 persons at Grand Central Terminal, the Transit Authoriy announced.

title: Coquina Oil
description: The Fluor Corporation, an engineering and construction concern with operations in the oil, gas, chemical and mineral industries, said it was considering the sale of the Coquina Oil Corporation, a unit of the Fluor-owned St. Joe Minerals Corporation.

description: B-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,825,000 for the qr and $2,030,000 for the yr...C-After losses from discontinued operations of $911,000 for the qr and $2,201,000 for the yr

title: Japan Adopts Trade Policies
description: Japan today formally adopted a series of measures to open its markets to imports, in a move to reduce growing tensions with the United States and Common Market nations.

title: News Analysis
description: Two events this week, at first blush unrelated and each surrounded by speculation, have converged in a way that could significantly alter New York politics.

title: 8 ACCUSED IN COLUMBIA FRAUD
description: Eight persons, including three Columbia University employees, a former Columbia employee and a bank teller, have been arrested in a bogus-check conspiracy that, according to the police, has defrauded Columbia of more than $100,000 since October.

title: THE CENTENNIAL VIEW OF ROOSEVELT
description: When Franklin Delano Roosevelt was President, he was a figure of fierce controversy, loved and hated by many Americans.

title: News An alysis
description: The Reagan Administration and the Federal Reserve Board are drifting into an election-year feud that, some analysts contend, could make it more difficult for the Fed to do its job. The consequence, in turn, could make it more difficult for the Administration to get what its wants - lower interest rates.

title: BADGER METER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
TV Notebook; WNET WARY ON TELEVISING U.S. 'POLAND' PROGRAM
description: Wary of broadcasting a program that might be viewed as propagandistic, WNET-TV has not yet made up its mind about whether to carry ''Let Poland Be Poland,'' a 90-minute television event scheduled for tomorrow that is being paid for and produced by the United States International Communication Agency.

title: FOR NAZI SURVIVORS, LATE REUNION
description: Manya Nagelstzajn ran in one direction; her brother, Chaim, ran in the other. It was 1943 and a Gestapo squad had suddenly burst onto the streets of the Jewish ghetto of Hrubieszow, Poland.

title: Briefing
description: I T'S those tiny symbols of prestige that make all the difference. Take the Lapel Pin Crisis at the White House, for example. Within recent days, blue lapel pins and red ones have been quietly distributed to employees, blue pins for senior staff, red pins for middle-level staff, and, in some cases, no pins for, well, the lowest-rung of the ladder.

title: Pabst Dispute Hearing Set
description: A state administrative hearing has been scheduled for Feb.23 into possible violations of Wisconsin law by a Minneapolis businessman and his associates seeking control of the Pabst Brewing Company.

title: Mexico-Soviet Oil Exchange
description: Mexico and the Soviet Union have revived talks on a projected oil swap, Jorge Diaz Serrano, Mexico's Ambassador to the Soviet Union, said on Mexican television Thursday night.

title: ARMSTRONG RUBBER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
KING RADIO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Arrows Win, 5-3, to Keep First Place
description: The New York Arrows defea ted the Philadelphia Fever, 5-3, tonight at Nassau Co liseum and stayed in first place ahead of Pittsburgh in the Major Indoor Soccer League.

title: SYRIA SAYS SUPPORT FOR ISRAEL THREATENS U.S. VITAL INTERESTS
description: Syria warned the United States today that its support for Israel threatened Washington's vital interests. Abdel Halim Khaddam, Syria's Foreign Minister, made the remarks as the General Assembly began an ''emergency special session'' on Israel's annexation of the Golan Heights. He described Israel as a ''racist entity'' and compared the nation with the ''Nazis who resorted to all kinds of violence and aggression.''

title: Your Money; Aid in Finding College Grants
description: WITH the cost of college soaring and sources of aid drying up, a number of companies have sprung up to offer - for a fee - a computer search for scholarships and financial assistance.

title: Bridge: Partnership Demonstrates Some Bad Calls in Bidding
description: There are times when two members of a partnership appear to be indulging in a peculiar private competition. Perhaps betting in a fashion that is unlikely to win them the event, they seem to be trying to outdo each other in making the worst call.

title: News Analysis
description: The scene being played out this week at The Bulletin in Philadelphia has become increasingly familiar to journalists in recent years. It is a closing act that could be repeated soon in other major cities where the second-ranked newspapers, having lost readers and advertisers to rival papers and television, see the curtain lowering.

title: ENTERPRISE DEVELOPMENT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After a loss of $19,432 for the qr and a gain of $1,569,252 for the yr on thecancellation of interest notes payable and tax credits of $1,828,695 for the qrand $4,777,787 for the yr; the company is listed on the Philadelphia Stock Exchange

title: MRS. KORCHNOI: A PAWN IN A SOVIET POWER GAME
description: Until a new world championship proves otherwise, Bella Korchnoi's husband can claim to be the world's second-best chess player.

title: O'NEILL TO RUN FOR GOVERNOR IF HEALTH IS STRONG ENOUGH
description: In his first public appearance since leaving the hospital eight weeks ago after open-heart surgery, Gov. William A. O'Neill said today that he would run for election in November if his health permitted.

description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation reported yesterday that its earnings in the fourth quarter, hurt by provisions for financing transactions, dropped 23.1 percent. Sales, however, increased 39.1 percent.

description: New York State filed a $200 million lawsuit today against the Hooker Chemicals and Plastics Corporation, charging that it maintained toxic waste sites that led to the pollution of the Niagara River.

description: To the Editor:

title: New York; CANDOR AND COUPONS DON'T MIX
description: Edward Koch's repeated vows that he would never run for a public office other than Mayor of this city were so cast-iron that he made William Tecumseh Sherman look like an equivocator. Then Monday, on his return from an eight-day vacation in Spain, he said he was not ruling out running for Governor this year.

title: Hussein Bids Jordan's Youths Join Iraq in War Against Iran
description: King Hussein urged the young people of Jordan today to join Iraq in its war against Iran. Iran and Iraq have been fighting since September 1980 over territorial claims along the eastern end of the Persian Gulf.

title: MASSEY-FERGUSON SEES A GLOOMY 1982
description: Shareholders of ail ing Massey-Ferguson Ltd.were told today to expect another bad year. The forecast, by Massey's chairman, Victor Rice, and president, Vincent Laurenzo, came as common shareholders agreed to allow the useof $140 million (United States) of their equi ty to pay dividends to preferred holders.

title:
Patents;
Bell Planning a System For Locating People
description: The Bell System plans to establish a nationwide people locator system in the next few years. A centralized data base will be connected with a network of telephone switching offices through which inquiries can be made.

title: CLOPAY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Notes on People; Truman's Choice Still
description: He was President Harry S. Truman's choice to succeed Gen. Douglas MacArthur as commander of the United Nations forces in Korea, and now, 31 years later, Matthew B. Ridgway, the retired general who also served as the Army's Chief of Staff, is to receive the Harry S. Truman Public Service Award.

title: Around the Nation; Atlanta Suspect Linked To 6th Killing Victim
description: Two persons testified today that Wayne B. Williams, who is accused of two murders, was also linked with 17-year-old Billy Barrett, the 27th of 28 young blacks abducted and slain here over a period of two years.

title: Coppola to Release New Film Himself
description: Francis Coppola has decided to handle the initial distribution of ''One From the Heart'' himself, instead of waiting to conclude negotiations with a major studio for its release, a spokesman for Mr. Coppola's Zoetrope Studios has announced.

title: TEXACO CANADA LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Observer; THE TWO RONNIES
description: I dropped in on Two Ronnies. He was delighted. ''Great you could come by,'' he said. ''Let's just sit around with our feet up and smile and be nice folks.''

title: TANDY BRANDS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-After extraordinary gains of $12,000 for the qr and $367,000 or 17 cents a shr for 6 mos, respectively

title: Rangers Getting McClanahan
description: The Rangers are close to acquiring Rob McClanahan, a 24-year-old forward, from the Hartford Whalers for future considerations. The Rangers and Whalers have agreed on the deal, but, because Hartford acquired McClanahan in October on waivers from the Buffalo Sabres, league rules requ ire that the other teams inthe league mu st be given 72 hours to make possible claims.

title: LOVE OF CITY SPURS GIFTS TO NEEDIEST
description: New York City stirs happy thoughts, bright memories and even a sense of pride among some contributors to The New York Times Neediest Fund, and their gifts are made in gratitude for the city's special meaning to them.

title: Business Digest; SATURDAY, JANUARY 30, 1982; Companies
description: G.M. plans to cut the price of some of its cars and trucks by between $500 and $2,000, despite its failure to agree with the U.A.W. on wage and benefit concessions that would have offset such cuts. The price cuts, to run for 60 days, will be available on about half the company's vehicles, but will exceed $750 on only one model, the Cadillac Seville. (Page 1.)

Around the World; U.S. and Britain Sign Gold Pact With Czechs
description: United States, British and Czechoslovak officials signed an agreement today under which the West will return 18.4 tons of gold to Czechoslovakia.

title: More Transit Police Aren't Enough
description: Putting more uniformed police officers on New York's subway trains at night is a useful way to reassure a frightened public. Even the head of the transit authority acknowledges that trains are not safe at night. But the additional officers are more a symptom of the problem than a solution.

NALCO CHEMICAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
LANDMARK BANCSHARES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
LIBRARY CAMPAIGN EVOKES FONDNESS
description: In a short story called ''Only the Dead Know Brooklyn,'' Thomas Wolfe looked down his nose at the long blocks of two-family houses and wondered how any individual thought could develop in such a uniform atmosphere. Whatever Wolfe may have imagined, a great deal of creativity has come out of Brooklyn's neighborhoods over the years. Additional proof - if proof is needed - turned up recently from a traditional resource of information: the Brooklyn Public Library, which is now engaged in a fund-raising drive for its central building on Grand Army Plaza and for its 57 branch libraries.

title: Notes on People; A Return to the Court
description: Five weeks after she nearly lost a leg in a knife attack by a mugger, Carol Ligotino, one of the most promising young tennis players in the New York metropolitan area, walked out of Montefiore Hospital in the Bronx yesterday.

PACIFIC RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

description: A captured terrorist suspect's sudden decision to give information to interrogators four days ago provided the crucial break that enabled the Italian police to find and free Brig. Gen. James L. Dozier, according to Italian officials.

title: No Headline
description: PILOTS WERE TOLD TO SPEED TAKEOFF

GILBERT ASSOCIATES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Consumer Saturday; SELECTING A CAMP FOR A CHILD
description: T HE summer-camp season isn't as far off as it might seem. Now is the time for parents to decide where and how their offspring will be spending their vacations this year. To make the decision somewhat easier, the Walden School is holding its annual National Children's Camp Show tomorrow in conjunction with the American Camping Association and the Association of Independent Camps.

title: Rep. Rosenthal Visits Greece And Backs Premier's Stands
description: Representative Benjamin S . Rosenthal, Democrat ofQueens, said today that American fears of Pri me Minister Andreas Papandreou's foreign policy intentions were u njustified and that the Greek leader's demands of the United States a nd NATO were reasonable.

title: Man Is Charged In Harlem Slaying
description: A suspect described by detectives as a longtime burglar was charged yesterday with shooting to death Robert Clark, 77, during a Harlem burglary last Dec. 18.

title: News Summ ary; SATURDAY, JANUARY 30, 1982
description: International A captured Italian terrorist's tip provided the crucial break that enabled the Italian police to find and free Brig. Gen. James L. Dozier in Padua Thursday. According to Italian officials, the informer, who was arrested in northern Italy Monday, gave the addresses of several apartments and other places that terrorists had been using. The police located the hideout in Padua by Wednesday. (Page 1, Col. 6.) El Salvador's leaders were praised this week by an organization representing Salvadoran peasants for ''positive attitudes'' toward the troubled land redistribution plan and for accepting policy recommendations from the group, the Union C omunal Salvadorena. The group says it s speaks for more than 100,000 peasants. The favorable response to t he Government's stance was contained in a letter to William C. Do herty Jr., executive director of the American Institute for Free Labo r Development, an affiliate of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. that has supported the Salvadoran land program. (1:1.)

title: Around the Nation; Medical Data Admitted At von Bulow Trial
description: A judge ruled today that prosecutors may use the medical records of Martha von Bulow, who has been in a coma more than a year, in trying to prove that her husband attempted to murder her with insulin overdoses.

title: GENERAL HOUSEWARES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
A Place of Light, Refreshment and Peace
description: St. Joseph's is a small, old (1833) Roman Catholic church in Greenwich Village which was known until this week only to its neighbors, and to architecture buffs for its Greek Revival facade. But on Wednesday night, when it received 10 men from the Men's Shelter on the Bowery, it became the first New York City church to act on Mayor Koch's suggestion that churches and synagogues take in the homeless.

title: Spanish Steel Output
description: Spain's steel production reached 12.9 million tons in 1981, compared with 12.6 million tons the previous year, the National Union of Steel Plants said today. The report said that Spain exported 4.85 million tons of steel and imported 1.26 million tons in the first 10 months of 1981. Steel consumption in Spain last year was 8.5 million tons.

title: MONEY SUPPLY OFF $600 MILLION
description: The Federal Reserve yesterday announced a $600 million decline in the nation's basic money supply, a smaller-than-expected drop that did little to offset the increase of about $11 billion in the previous two weeks. The small drop in the money supply in the w eek ended Jan. 20 was a major shock to the credit markets, where shor t-term interest rates quickly rose half a percentage point and more as traders decided that the Federal Reserve was vigorously actin g to reduce money supplygrowth.

title: SHOP & GO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Jewish Leaders Meet Police On Reports of Russian Mafia
description: Seeking to quell the furor caused by a report that a ''Russian Mafia'' threatens to disrupt the 1984 Olympics, police officials have met with Jewish leaders.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Agfa-Gevaert Graphics Inc. said it had accepted, at $14 a share, up to 2.5 million common shares of Compugraphic Corp. tendered under its previously announced offer.

title: Nehemiah Sets Mark
description: Renaldo (Skeets) Nehemiah lowered his world indoor best time in the 50-yard hurdles to 5.92 seconds, and Bill Olson set a best of 18 feet 8 3/4 inches in the pole vault tonight at The Toronto Star Indoor Games.

title: TOUGHER CIGARETTE WARNINGS GAIN SUPPORT
description: ''If I felt smoking was really and truly detrimental to my health, there is no question I would stop smoking,'' said Milton Eldridge, a cabdriver who has chain-smoked while driving through Washington's streets for the last 40 years. What about the health warning that appears on every pack of cigarettes? ''I don't pay attention to it and I'm not sure it is meant for me,'' he said.

title: Key Rates
description: * Maximum rate payable by savings institutions.Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: FIRE DAMAGES TRUMP TOWER CONSTRUCTION
description: Flaming debris falling from the 28th floor of the building at 56th Street and Fifth Avenue.

title: BIDDER FOR CANNON SEEMS TO NEAR GOAL
description: David H. Murdock has won the approval of family interests in the Cannon Mills Company for his acquisition bid, and thus appears well on his way to gaining control of the 100-yearold concern, textile industry analysts said today.

title: NEW YORK CITY IN NEED OF PUBLIC RESTROOMS
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRISTIAN SECTS ACT TO RE SOLVE AGE-OLD CONFLICTS IN THOUGHT
description: An international panel of Protestant, Orthodox and Roman Catholic leaders has taken a major step toward resolving some of the theological disagreements that have divided the world's Christian churches for centuries.

title: FIRST BANCORP OF NEW HAMPSHIRE INC reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
Sports People; Unwitting Compromise
description: Mike Flanagan, one of three former winners of the Cy Young Award on the Baltimore pitching staff, could not reach agreement with the Orioles on a new contract this winter, so he decided to submit the dispute to salary arbitration. Just before arbitration, the player usually revises downward his initial demand, and the club comes up a little, then both sides submit their proposals in writing. An arbitrator hears the case and selects one figure or the other. Except that in Flanagan's case there will be no hearing, because there is no need for one. Jerry Kapstein, Flanagan's agent, submitted a demand of $485,000, and the Orioles submitted $500,000. This is only the second time in the seven-year history of baseball salary arbitration that a player has submitted a lower figure than the club. Two years ago, Tom Reich, agent for Mike Edwards, put in a salary of $50,000 for the Oakland second baseman, and Charlie Finley, then the owner of the A's, made the figure $58,000. Edwards signed a contract for $58,000, and Flanagan will now sign one for $500,000. ... Mike Jones, the Kansas City pitcher who suffered a severe neck injury last month when his car went off the road and into a tree near Rochester, pleaded guilty yesterday of driving while imp aired. He was fined $250, and his license was suspended for 90 da ys. Playing next season appears to be out of the question, but Jones said that ''I hope to bein a baseball uniform for the 1983 season.''

title: News Analysis
description: Beyond the iron gate at the United Nations lies a real world where nations behave according to their interests. But inside the United Nations complex, peculiar things happen, especially to third world countries, says Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the American delegate. There, the countries of Africa, Asia and Latin America tend to votein blocs that confound their national interests, according to Mrs. Kirkpatrick.

title:
Patents;
Apparatus for Weaving 3-Dimensional Articles
description: Robert A. Florentine of Norristown, Pa., was granted a patent this week on apparatus for weaving three-dimensional articles.

title: DIEBOLD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
West Virginia Victory Is Record 15th Straight
description: Greg Jones, a junior guard, sank two technical-foul shots with 14 seconds left that gave West Virginia a school-record 15th straight victory tonight, 48-45, over Pitt. The victory came after a disputed call earlier disallowed a tying foul shot by Steve Beatty.

title: PAKISTAN AND INDIA SEEKING NO-WAR PACT
description: Pakistan's Foreign Minister arrived here today for four days of talks on a proposal to have Pakistan and India forswear the use of force against each other.

title: EASTERN UTILITIES ASSOCIATES reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
SERVO CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
DURAN WILL TRY TO MAKE AMENDS
description: Coiba is a beautifully lush Pacific island 15 miles off the coast of Panama, surrounded by shark-infested waters, and deserted except for a government prison. When he arrived on the island last month to begin training for his super-welterweight title fight Saturday night against Wilfred Benitez, Roberto Duran said that Coiba reminded him of the island prison in the movie ''Papillon.''

title: FATHER OF MAYOR
description: Louis Koch, a retired furrier and the father of New York's Mayor, died Thursday night in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., after intermittent illnesses over the last two years. He was 87 years old.

title: SUSLOV BURIED AMID BOLSHEVIK HEROES
description: Mikhail A. Suslov, the ascetic overlord of Soviet ideology who died Monday at the age of 79, was buried close by the Kremlin wall today in the most elaborate state funeral since Stalin's.

title: FOGG WARNED ON SELLING ART
description: A proposal by Harvard's Fogg Art Museum for deaccessioning works of art to help pay operating expenses has strongly been condemned by the Association of Art Museum Directors. The association is made up of 150 directors of the largest art museums in the United States and Canada.

title: L.S.U.-Rice Meeting Is Planned for Tokyo
description: Louisiana State University tentatively agreed today to play Rice University's football team in the 1983 Mirage Bowl in Tokyo.

title: MCDONNELL DOUGLAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: B-AFter a $25.5 million provision for likely restructuring or default of some commercial aircraft financings...C-Includes $15.5 million gain on sale of real estate and $32 million writeoff in DC-9 aircraft program costs

title: Gala to Honor Basie M arch 7 at Music Hall
description: Count Basie, a jazz pianist for more than 50 of his 77 years, will be honored by the Black Music Association, Dionne Warwick and Stevie Wonder at ''To Basie With Love,'' a gala March 7 at Radio City Music Hall.
