title: REPUBLIC RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Yr to Oct 31
Oilers 3, Sabres 1
description: Wayne Gretzky's 64th goal of the season was the decisive one as Edmonton rallied to overcome a 1-0 deficit in the final period.

title: EXCERPTS FROM FAREWELL TESTIMONY BY RICKOVER TO CONGRESS
description: Adm. Hyman G. Rickover, 82 years old, testified before the Joint Economic Committee of Congress Thursday in his farewell appearance before his retirement Sunday. Following are excerpts from his testimony, questions by Senator William Proxmire, Democrat of Wisconsin, and the admiral's replies.

title: SCHMIDT SAID TO THREATEN TO QUIT
description: Chancellor Helmut Schmidt, who has won adoption of distasteful policies in the past by threatening to resign, was quoted today as saying that he would step down if groups in his coalition Government did not stop squabbling over proposals to stem growing unemployment.

title: MINIMUM WAGE WAIVER STUDIED FOR REAGAN'S BLIGHTED AREAS PLAN
description: The Reagan Administration's plan to encourage the creation of zones to revitalize blighted urban areas provides for waiving the Federal minimum wage for workers under age 21, according to officials who devised the program.

title: ZENITH NATIONAL INSURANCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Weapons-Case Figure C ontinues His Silence
description: A suspect being held on $1 million bail for illegal possession of an Uzi submachine gun and a .45 automatic continued his silence yesterday when antiterrorist experts from the Federal Bureau of Investigation tried to question him, the authorities said.

title: GIBRALTAR MINES LTD reports earnings for Yr to Dec 31
BANKS PLANNING TO DEFER PAYMENTS BY RUMANIA
description: A group of major American and European banks has quietly agreed in principle to ease Rumania's growing economic difficulties by giving that nation more time to repay its debts, some of the bankers involved said today.

title: DANCE: CITY BALLET PRESENTS FOUR BOURNONVILLE EXCERPTS
description: The New York City Ballet danced some light, quick choreography for the first time this season Wednesday night at the New York State Theater. No, it was not by Geo rge Balanchine, but by August Bournonville, the great 19th-century Danish choreographer. Although the company s pecializes in contemporary ballet, Mr. Balanchine has long admired Bournonville's choreography, and no wonder: the steps are light and quick and they also make perfect harmonious sense.

title: GETTIN' MILEAGE
description: A lot of people talk about new sources of fuel, but it took a business pioneer like Hank to bring them to the public. Here he comes now to take care of yet another customer at Hank's Alternative Fuel Station.

title: CITY SEEKS TO DELAY ASSESSMENT SUITS
description: The Koch administration wants to delay the start of a state law that will allow homeowners, especially those in poorer neighborhoods, to sue New York City in Small Claims Court over real-estate tax assessments.

title: City's Employees Cut Absentee Rate
description: The absentee rate for city government workers has reached a record low of 3.34 percent, according to a performance review released yesterday by the Koch administration.

title: KAISER CEMENT & GYPSUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results include equity in the earnings of unconsolidated companies of $1,751,000 and $6,066,000 for the latest qr and yr, respectively, and $2,846,000 and $9,065,000 for the yr-ago qr and yr, respectively; results also include gains of $6,404,000 and the latest yr and $2,852,000 for the previous yr on the disposal of investments and other assets

title: WALESA REPORTED WILLING TO START TALKS WITH POLISH REGIME
description: Lech Walesa is reportedly willing to start talks with the Government in the presence of legal advisers, Solidarity sources said today.

title: Post Completes Magazine Sale
description: Inside Sports, the Washington Post Company's money-losing magazine, said yesterday that the previously announced agreement to sell the magazine to Active Markets Inc., a publisher of magazines for children and young athletes, had been completed.

title:
ABOUT NEW YORK;
A SCHOOL'S BITTER LESSON IN LABOR RELATIONS
description: It has been nearly five months -the time it might take a high school junior to go from the opening salvos of algebra to quadratic equations, or from one boyfriend to another -since the teachers at Christ the King High School went out on strike.

title: OF IDEOLOGY, SUCCESSION AND SUSLOV'S BIG SHADOW
description: It should have been a time for the nation to mourn. But one of the striking things about the death last week of Mikhail Andreyevich Suslov, the longest-serving member of the Kremlin hierarchy, was the seeming indifference to it of the ordinary man.

title: Headliners; Thanks, but No
description: Perhaps it was a combination of an acute sense of survival on one hand and an inability to cope with notoriety on the other. Whatever the case, D.M. Thomas, a highly regarded British writer, abruptly resigned his post at American University in Washington last week and was scheduled to leave this morning for his home in Hereford, England. Mr. Thomas, whose celebrated novel, ''The White Hotel,'' has sold some 100,000 copies in hardcover in this country, was apparently disenchanted by the all the hype and hoopla surrounding his book and decided, after a week in America, that he'd had enough.

title: A CALL FOR A NEW CORRECTIONS POLICY
description: ON JAN. 19, Thomas H. Kean inherited an eight-year legacy of gubernatorial indecision and procrastination. In this executive vacuum, New Jersey's correctional system has drifted perilously close to catastrophe. Only the dedication of its administrators, supervisors and line officers has averted the tragedies witnessed in Arizona, Idaho and elsewhere during similar periods of neglect.

title: IF YOU'RE BUYING LUMBER, TAKE RULER, ASK ADVICE
description: Alex Nixon's grandfather was a carpenter and he gave the boy his first set of tools. By the age of 17 Mr. Nixon had restored an English surrey, built a four-poster bed and helped reconstruct two barns on his parents' property.

title: Business Conditions; WHY THEATERS THRIVE
description: There's no business like show business. After a bleak 1980, when income grew a paltry 1.5 percent from levels a year earlier, nonprofit theater bounced back in 1981.

title: TWO FREE BOOKLETS ADVISE ON 'LEMONS'
description: ALBANY Associated Press

title: SUBJECT OF AGE IS AGE-OLD
description: SUDDENLY, my friends and I, people I meet at parties, chance acquaintances, all seem to own old dogs. No matter how our conversation starts, we get around to them in the end.

title: CHINA REFUSES TO CRITICIZE SOVIET OVER POLAND
description: A senior State Department official has reported to Congress that China has refused to cooperate with the United States against the Soviet Union on the issue of Poland, according to Congressional officials.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; We Like Limbo, Say E.R.A. Allies
description: The fate of the equal rights amendment is still doubtful, but one thing at least is clear: It won't depend on an Idaho judge's ruling that would have led to almost certain death. The Supreme Court last week issued a stay of the ruling - a step that deprives it of legal effect - and said it would eventually hear an appeal.

title: THE SEARCH FOR THE IDEAL OTHELLO
description: In the darkened wings of the Parker Playhouse, James Earl Jones is ''becoming'' Othello for the 150th time in five months. Resplendent in his gold-shot velvet caftan, ''the noble Moor'' is thinking of the battles he has fought, of Aleppo, of Suleiman the Turk who remains to be conquered. At the same time, the actor is aware that with sevenand-a-half weeks left in this nine-city tour before opening night on Broadway, he still feels not so much in command of his role as in search of it. And James Earl Jones wouldn't have it any other way. ''Every performance,'' he has said, ''is one more chance to explore something. That, to me, is what acting is all about.''

title: The Sting of Salvador
description: One measure of America's pai nful predicament in El Salvador is the cynical humbu g it inspires. With a straight face, the Reagan Administratio n now certifies that El Salvador's record on human rights justif ies more American aid. Congress is assured that the junta is maki ng good-faith efforts to negotiate with its insurgent opposition an d promoting free elections and genuine land reform.

title: 'THE THOUGHTLESS ACT OF A SINGLE DAY'
description: To the Editor:

title:
GARDENING;
BRINGING A BIT OF SPRING INDOORS
description: SO your car stalled in a snowdrift during the last cold snap, and your fingers and toes were nearly frozen by the time you reached the phone booth to call for help. And you've just received the latest fuel bill and swear that you haven't seen numbers that large since the last time the national debt was printed in the newspaper.

title: On Language
description: We Wuz Robbed KIMBLE MEAD

title: SPLICING & SPLITTING
description: LIFE AFTER MARRIAGE Love in an Age of Divorce. By A. Alvarez. 269 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $14.50.WHEN ''The Savage God,'' A. Alvarez's study on suicide in literature, appeared, it was possible to recommend the opening chapter of the book for the strong personal material it contained about Sylvia Plath and the author, even if the literary survey that followed was fairly tedious. Now Alvarez has written a book on another big subject, marriage and divorce, and he has tried to play the roles not only of literary critic and memoirist, but also of pop sociologist, storyteller, historian of manners and laws, and conservative Jeremiah. None of these roles, however, is pursued with rigor, and the result is a confusing book which it is not possible to recommend for any of its parts.

title: VAST, STILL, TIMELESS, AWESOME
description: For Americans, Australia is a new world. Easier transportation has helped double the number of American visitors in recent years - to more than 120,000 in 1980. They find an island continent of contrasts, from the vast silences of the outback to the richness of the waters of the Great Barrier Reef to the brash sophistication of Sydney. COLLEEN McCULLOUGH, the Australian author of ''The Thorn Birds'' and ''An Indecent Obsession,'' lives on Norfolk Island, 930 miles from Sydney in the South Pacific. By COLLEEN McCULLOUGH

title: Politics; REAGAN PROPOSAL IMPERILS PLAN BY KEAN TO CUT THE STATE STAFF
description: TRENTON GOVERNOR KEAN'S p lans to reduce the size of the New Jersey bureacracy wi ll be reversed if Congress approves President Reagan's proposal to s end $47 billion in Federal categorical grant programs back to the s tates.

title: Reagan Revokes Ban on Use Of Poison to Control Coyotes
description: President Reagan has revoked a 10-yearold ban on the use of a poison against coyotes, although the action will have little immediate effect.

title: Stage View; A DOTTY OLD FRIEND IS BACK IN TOWN
description: Going to the revival of Neil Simon's ''Little Me'' was rather like running into a dotty old friend who'd dropped out of sight for a good 20 years and now needed to become acquainted with the city's streets and the city's people all over again. The sensation was quite odd. Here was the same funny, agreeably addlepated show - modified a bit, dated in spots, yet essentially the cuckoo-klatch I'd always been so fond of - groping somewhat to locate itself in space. And here, too, was the audience, quite ready to be entertained as soon as it got its bearings but, at the outset, not entirely certain what those bearings might be.

title: The Talk of Miami
description: The latest last straws for Arthur Patten were the ransacking of the office of his insurance company here, the theft of his .357 magnum from his briefcase, and four telephone calls threatening his life with his own weapon.

title: HAYAKAWA ABANDONS RACE FOR A SECOND TERM IN SENATOR
description: S.I. Hayakawa, who began his political career six years ago with election as a Republican Senator from California, announced at the state Republican Party convention here today that he was dropping his campaign for a second term.

title: FEWER LOCAL GROUPS PLAY WITHOUT PAY
description: LOIS AND MARK BARTON of Bellport are in danger of becoming obsolete. Not in their respective careers; so far, there are still openings for research librarians and nuclear physicists. Rather, their avocations are threatened.

title: Miss Jacoby Is Betrothed
description: Dr. and Mrs. Glenn E. Jacoby of Bridgewater, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Tarn Jacoby, to Rober t Randolph Clar k, son of Lieut. Col. Johnathan D. Clark, U.S.A.F., retired, and Mrs. Clark of Rochester.

title:
Dining Out;
A MELTING-POT AMERICAN MENU
description: ONE of the advantages of living in a state as steeped in history as New Jersey is the abundance of old country inns such as Pfenninger's Perryville Inn in Hampton. According to Murphy Pfenninger, who bought and restored the 169-year-old inn two and a half years ago, it was named for Commodore Oliver Hazard Perry, who defeated the British at Lake Erie the year that construction on the inn was completed.

title: Critics' Choices
description: CLASSICAL MUSICRossini's career as a composer of operas ended in 1829, when he was 37. His biography had been written five years before that, by no less a figure than Stendhal.

title: Physician Fiance Of Laura Mayer
description: Dr. and Mrs. Jean Mayer of Medford, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Laura Dearing Van Huysen Mayer, to Dr. Joseph Gerald Maloney, son of Mrs. Joseph G. Maloney of Arlington, Mass., and the late Mr. Maloney.

title: RETREADS CAPTURING GROWING SEGMENT OF THE TIRE MARKET
description: AKRON INDUSTRY officials in this rubber town say retreaded tires are no longer the last resort for people who cannot afford new tires for their automobiles.

title: Chess; SACRIFICING A PIECE
description: Positional piece sacrifices are rare for the obvious reason: A piece is a lot of material to have to get compensation for. Yet there are situations where such an offer is the only method of seizing the upper hand.

title: OHIO BUDGET FALLS $1 BILLION SHORT
description: For the third time in 14 months, the recession has turned Ohio's budget picture upside down, giving the state government the choice of raising taxes yet again or cutting almost $1 billion from an already bare-bones budget before June of next year.

title: Crafts
description: SOUTH ORANGE ONCE more, with its annual invitational Valentine Jewelry Show, Whichcraft Studio and Gallery here makes an appeal to the romantic instinct. The lure is a fresh batch of works in precious and nonprecious materials by 15 artists - actually 18, since some collaborate under one name.

title:
GARDENING;
BRINGING A BIT OF SPRING INDOORS
description: SO your car stalled in a snowdrift during the last cold snap, and your fingers and toes were nearly frozen by the time you reached the phone booth to call for help. And you've just received the latest fuel bill and swear that you haven't seen numbers that large since the last time the national debt was printed in the newspaper.

title: Travel Advisory; PROFUSION OF FLORA, HIJINKS BY MAMMALS; The Flowers T hat Bloom in Amsterdam
description: It is described as the biggest flower show in the world - a profuse blossoming, on 135 acres, of roses, tulips, daffodils, orchids, lilies, gladioluses, dahlias, chrysanthemums and more. Added to the flowers are fruit trees and other trees, among them willows, poplars, oaks, chestnuts, birches, maples and elms. Rock gardens, ornamental plants and shrubs, orchards and vegetable gardens are also on exhibit.

title: VEAL: PERFECT WITH ITALY'S RASION d'ETRE
description: VEAL has been called ''the chameleon'' of the kitchen. It adapts with ease to its surroundings and goes with almost any flavor, including sage, rosemary, thyme, tarragon, lemon, orange, tomatoes, white wine, Marsala, cream, prosciutto or Parmesan cheese. If these ingredients suggest Italy it is hardly surprising, considering that Italians eat the most veal of any nation, 15.4 pounds a year per person (compared with four pounds for Americans).

title: Israel Reports Capture Of Squad of Terrorists
description: Israel's military command tonight announced the capture of an Al Fatah terrorist squad after a 52-hour pursuit. Two of the three gunmen who had infiltrated from Jordan were said to have been wounded in an exchange of fire at a hideout near Tiasir, a village two miles east of the Jordan River.

title: CUTOFF OF DISABILITY BENEFITS CHALLENGED
description: CAROL MILLER of Syosset is 57 years old and suffers from ulcerative colitis. As a result, after she left her job as Medicaid coordinator at the Downstate Medical Center in Brooklyn two years ago, she underwent surgery to have her large intestine removed.

title:
THE LIVELY ARTS;
A NEW DANCE STEP: TV TO STAGE
description: WITH the vogue for dance on television, many choreographers are designing and redesigning works for the home screen. Reversing the trend, Edward Villella, artistic director of the Eglevsky Ballet and a new member of the production team of the Public Broadcasting Service's ''Dance in America'' series, has restaged excerpts from his Emmy-winning 1975 special, ''Harlequin,'' for the Eglevsky's performances Friday through next Sunday at the John Cranford Adams Playhouse of Hofstra University.

title: STARTING-BLOCKS FILL UP FOR JERSEY SENATE RACE
description: When Senator Harrison A. Williams slipped on the ice last week, he suffered injuries that resulted in delaying his sentencing for Abscam-related crimes and his possible expulsion from the United States Senate. But he had already taken his political fall, and if his sentencing and expulsion wer e delayed, the many efforts to replace him were not.

title: Miss Stacy Leads by 2 After a Difficult Round
description: Hollis Stacy held off JoAnne Carner today with a par 72 to take a two-shot lead after the third round of the $125,000 Championship of Deer Creek.

title: Television Week
description: A Faithful Quasimodo ''I try to stick as close as possible to the book, if it's dramatically feasible,'' said John Gay, the screenwriter, who has turned Victor Hugo's novel ''The Hunchback of Notre Dame'' into a television movie starring Anthony Hopkins as Quasimodo, the pathetically deformed bell ringer of the Paris cathedral. Produced by Norman Rosemont, it will be broadcast on CBS, Thursday from 9 to 11 P.M. Derek Jacobi plays Dom Claude Frollo, the evil archdeacon; Lesley-Anne Down portrays Esmeralda, the gypsy; John Gielgud is the sinister Charmolue; and Robert Powell is Phoebus, the captain of the royal archers.

title: Girlie Wins Searching Stakes
description: Girlie, who finished second to Polite Rebuff in the Busanda Stakes, won the $57,100 Searching Stakes at Aqueduct yesterday. Polite Rebuff, the 1-to-2 favorite ridden by Angel Cordero Jr., finished fourth, 12 1/2 lengths back, in the eighth running of the mile-andone-sixteenth event.

title: Extension of Contract Suggested for Majors
description: The executive committee of the University of Tennessee's athletics board has recommended extending the contract of Johnny Majors, head football coach, by two years, Athletic Director Bob Woodruff said today.

title: BLACK HISTORY MONTH GETTING UNDER WAY
description: MANY Westchester organizations will observe February's national celebration of Black History Month with an outpouring of films, concerts, lectures and special events.

title: IMPORTS' MARKET SHARE GROWS
description: DESPITE the ''voluntary'' import quotas on Japanese cars and the reluctance of the average American consumer to buy any car last year, foreign manufacturers again increased their share of the American automobile market in 1981.

title: 'THE THOUGHTLESS ACT OF A SINGLE DAY'
description: To the Editor:

title: Beth Handler, a Teacher, Is Engaged to Ian Devine
description: Mr. and Mrs. Melvin Handler of New York and Chandler, N.Y., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Beth Handler, to Ian Clark Devine, son of Mrs. L. Williams Devine of Delray Beach, Fla., and New Marlboro, Mass., and C. Robert Devine of New York. A June wedding will take place in Lenox, Mass.

title: GUIDANCE ON THE SEARCH FOR A CAR TO BUILD YOURSELF
description: People who are thinking of buying a kit car should consider the following tips:

title: Robbers Murder a Man On the Upper West Side
description: Two robbers shot a 45-year-old man to death last night in the doorway of his apartment on the Upper West Side, the police said.

title: THE DE LOREAN, ONCE A PREMIUM CAR, SELLS AT A DISCOUNT
description: THE first De Lorean sports cars arrived on the American market in June 1981. Four months later, an ad appeared in The Wall Street Journal offering the $25,000 car for $49,000.

title: AN IDEA WHOSE TIME IS GOING
description: TO the apparent surprise of most drivers, if not the oil companies, gasoline is relatively plentiful these days, which is putting a crimp in the aspirations of alternative-fuel proponents. These proponents had their heyday during an d since the 1973 oil crisis, which enabled them to feed on consume rs' fears that they would have nothing with which to fuel their c ars unless they sought out other sources of energy - among them gaso hol, methanol, propane, hydrogen and synthetic fuels.

title: Music: Debuts in Review
description: Veronica Jochum's enthusiasm tended to outrun her physical limits Thursday night at the 92d Street Y. As a result, listeners at this concert of piano music had to accept her good intentions on faith. Some of this material was just too tough for her technique to digest.

title: MACHU PICCHU
description: To the Editor:

title: WOMAN HELD IN KIDNAPPING
description: After a stormy four-day pretrial hearing, a 60-year-old woman has been bound over for trial on charges of kidnapping three elderly women who lived in a nursing home that she operated.

title: BALLET: 'IRISH FANTASY' ON BILL WITH 'CHACONNE'
description: ''Irish Fantasy,'' which could safely be called Jacques d'Amboise's best ballet, and ''Chaconne,'' which could just as confidently be termed one of George Balanchine's most surprising ballets, shared the New York City Ballet's program Thursday night at the New York State Theater.

title: Professor Director
description: To the Business Editor: As a member of the editorial board of The Nation, I was of course delighted to learn in ''Professor Director'' (Jan. 17) that we have as distinguished a reader as Dean Richard R. West of the Amos Tuck School of Business Management at Dartmouth. His criticism of the discussion of the relationship between the academy and society at the American Writers Congress, unfortunately, rests on an excessive simplification of the argument.

title: Phones and Justice
description: To the Business Editor: There is much wisdom in Paul W. MacAvoy's reflections in ''A.T.& T.: The Justice Department Blew It'' (Jan. 17) concerning the outcome of our agreement with the Justice Department. But I'm nonetheless compelled to challenge a conclusion he implies when he asks why this should ''lead the experts to predict higher rates on local service and stock market gains for the new Bell Long Lines.''

title:
Speaking Personally;
HOME IS WHERE YOUR WORDS FEEL COMFORTABLE
description: ROBERT FROST said, ''Home is the place where, when you have to go there, they have to take you in,'' and Ring Lardner said it is ''where you can always have coffee along with your meal.''

title: Council Committees To Meet This Week
description: The following City Council meetings this week are open to the public: TUESDAY: Committee on Education, City Hall, 10 A.M.; Committee on Youth Services, City Hall, 1 P.M. WEDNESDAY: Committee on Economic Development, City Hall, 10 A.M.; Committee on Environmental Protection, City Hall, 1 P.M. THURSDAY: Committee on Consumer Affairs, City Hall 10 A.M.; Committee on Housing and Buildings, City Hall 1:30 P.M. FRIDAY: Committee on Transportation, City Hall, 10 A.M.

title: No Headline
description: Rutgers 78, Rhode Island 71

title: By STEVEN RATTNER
description: LONDON I T was just a small change, but a symbolic one. In the stolid halls of the Barclays Bank headquarters here, brass letters reading ''Investment Managers Office'' have been removed, replaced by a similar sign nearby that reads ''Large Corporate Division.''

title: Linda Perez Married to Steven Howard Pittleman
description: Linda Julia Perez, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Pedro A. Perez of New York, was married yesterday to Steven Howard Pittleman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving W. Pittleman of Louisville, Ky. The Rev. Louis Gioia, a Roman Catholic priest, and Rabbi Charles Lippman performed the ceremony at the Carlyle Hotel.

title: SYDNEY: A GIFT FOR COLOR AND MOVEMENT
description: FRANK DEVINE, formerly a journalist and editor in Australia, is now a senior editor of Reader's Digest. By FRANK DEVINE

title: Leisure; START WITH SEED AND GROW SUMMER'S BEGONIAS AT HOME
description: Raymond S. Rusak, a supervisor in manufacturing, is an amateur gardener. By RAYMOND S. RUSAK

title: A Word on Smoking By a Smoker
description: Throughout Kay McKemy's diatribe (''A Nonsmoker Describes Daily Struggle for Clean Air,'' Opinion Page, Ja n. 10), she implies that she writes as a nonsmoker. More aptly, one wo uld describe her as an antismoker! She isn't satisfied that she has avoided the ravages of her perceived enemy, ''smoke,'' but must pres ume to wage a malicious crusade against all who indulge or disagree. She characterizes nonsmokers as persons with ''running eyes and drippy noses,'' frantically attempting to escape the cigarett e smoke she alleges to be responsible for the condition. In more tha n half a century of smoking two packs of cigarettes a day my cont act with nonsmokers suffering such dewy attacks usually indicated a head cold or hay fever. A head count of those about you who ar e suffering ''running eyes and drippy noses'' will attest to the la ck of validity in this farfetched comment.

title: Machu Picchu
description: To the Editor:

title: Children's Books
description: SONG OF THE HORSE By Richard Kennedy. Illustrated by Marcia Sewall. Unpaged. New York: Dutton/Unicorn. $9.50. (Ages 7 to 10) By ELAINE EDELMAN

title: Edward Lanphier 2d to Wed Cameron McClellan
description: Mr. and Mrs. Pelham L. McClellan Jr. of Pel ham Manor, N.Y., have announced the engagement of Mr. McClellan's d aughter, Cameron Adrienne McClellan, to Edward Oliver Lanphier 2d, son of Robert C. Lanphier 3d of Springfield, Ill., and Mariann e M. Lanphier of Honolulu. Miss McClellan is a daughter also o f the late Mrs. Oakley Everitt McClellan.

title: FUEL FOR OLDER CARS PRESENTS CHALLENGE
description: With premium leaded gasoline gone the way of the slide rule, care and feeding can be a problem for owners of big old cars. Cars manufactured before 1970 often had higher engine-compression ratios than today's cars, requiring leaded fuel with an octane rating in the medium to high 90's for proper engine performance as against the typical mid- to high-80's rating of most regular leaded fuel.

title: Sports' Religion Not Inspirational
description: To the Sports Editor: It's still hard for me to believe that The Times printed Charles Prebish's treacle ''Spirit of Sport Inspires New Faith'' (Jan. 17, 1982).

title: LOUGHLIN RUNNERS FIRST, SECOND IN 600-YARD RUN
description: Ilya Jackson led Bishop Loughlin High School to a near-sweep of the 600-yard run by winning with a time of 1 minute 15.5 seconds yesterday in the 21st annual Iona Games at the 102d Engineers Armory. Kinney Wilson of Loughlin was second in 1:16.1, Herve Dumont of Archbishop Molloy third in 1:16.5 and Chris Wilson of Loughlin fourth in 1:17.5.

title: CITY'S LONG ICE SEIGE TAKING ITS TOLL
description: Despite moderating temperatures and occasional glimpses of the sun, the sidewalks of New York yesterday remained a melancholy and slippery patchwork of dirty ice and encrusted snow, the frozen remnants of howling storms and Arctic cold that assailed the metropolitan area in January.

title: CONCERT: FIVE PREMIERES BY MUSICAL ELEMENTS
description: Musical Elements has proved itself one of New York's worthier newmusic groups, and on paper its program Thursday night at the Abraham Goodman House looked promising. In practice, it proved an awkward, overextended grab-bag.

title: AUTHOR CALLS ARMS SALES A MAJOR POLICY TOOL
description: A newly published book contends that the sale of military weapons and equipment has become the major instrument of foreign policy for both the Western powers and for the Soviet Union.

title: No Headline
description: KINGS WIN ONE AFTER 16 GAMES

title: WINNIE THE PUCHATKA
description: To the Editor:

title: KOCH, REAGAN, AND THE PO OR
description: To say that the churches and synagogues of this country can assume responsibility for the care of the poor is naive and dangerous. During the last Christmas season, when our hearts were full of Christian charity and ashamed that there was no room for Jesus at the Inn, Mayor Koch made this statement:

title: BENITEZ OUTPOINTS DUR AN UNANIMOUSLY, KEEPS TITLE
description: Wilfred Benitez gave Roberto Duran a sample of his versatility tonight as he retained his World Boxing Council junior middleweight title with a unanimous 15-round decision.

title: No Headline
description: FRIAS KEEPS CROWN; DOCTOR HALTS FIGHT

title: TENANTS ASSERT RENOVATIONS CAUSED BUILDING TO COLLAPSE
description: Authorities yesterday were investigating charges by tenants that renovations in a ground-floor store had led to Friday's collapse of a city-owned apartment building in upper Manhattan in which 13 persons were injured.

title: Ford Approves Trade Fr om Angels to Orioles
description: The outfielder Dan Ford has approved a trade by the California Angels that will send him to the Baltimore Orioles.

title: On Health Advocacy: The Nurse's Position
description: Regarding the article ''Health Advocates Play a Vital Role,'' on Jan. 3, the advocacy role is inherent in the professional practice of the nurse. Nurses are taught to practice this role as a vital part of their care delivery to patients. That little of this is done is unfortunately true, but the reason this is true is known to nurses but not to the general public. Neither the hospitals nor physicians want nurses to inform patients, they do not want patients to be making their own independent decisions nor do they want nurses supporting patients in their right to make decisions.

title: Pamela A. Leary Will Be Married
description: Joanna R. Leary of Bronxville, N.Y., and James F. Leary of Dallas have announced the engagement of their daughter, Pamela Ann Leary, to Duncan E. Goldie-Morrison, son of Mr. and Mrs. Keith Goldie-Morrison of London and Bradden, England. A December wedding in New York is planned.

title: Children's Books
description: THE GLASS SLIPPER Charles Perrault's Tales of Times Past. Translated by John Bierhorst. Illustrated by Mitchell Miller. 114 pp. New York: Four Winds Press. $14.95. (Ages 9 and Up) By MICHELE SLUNG

title: Tenants Suffer More
description: To the Editor:

title: C.D. Kirby Weds Judith A. Martin
description: Judith Anne Martin and Christopher Dennis Kirby were married yesterday at the Brick Presbyterian Church by the Rev. Dr. Herbert Anderson.

title: RAIN MEANS ANOTHER DAY LOST AT WORLD SKIING
description: With Doug Powell officiating, Cindy Nelson, Holly Beth Flanders and other American ski racers held a volleyball game this morning in a local gymnasium. There was little else to do while a steady rain turned this ski resort into a depository of slush, interrupting the program of the 1982 world Alpine skiing championships for the second straight day.

title: Follow-Up on the News; For Men Only
description: Since its founding in 1872, the Bohemian Club of San Francisco has had some illustrious men as members. But never any women.

title: Sound; HOME RECORDING UNDER FIRE
description: If Mickey Mouse has his way, the sheriff will be riding into town, impounding all tape recorders as contraband. Mickey, as we all know, has never shied away from scrapping with even the fattest cats, and in his corporate guise as Walt Disney Productions, Inc., he is now tackling Sony Corporation in an attempt to outlaw home taping of video programs. This fight has direct implications for audio fans, because private sound recording of video broadcasts may be construed - both logically and legally - as falling into the same category as private video recording.

title: Realty News
description: The Equitable Life Assurance Soci-ety of the United States, the nation's third largest insurance company, has acquired an interest in Tishman Speyer Properties, a national real es-tate development firm.

title: CAMPUS RESEARCH: FUTURE PAYOFF
description: ''RESEARCH is what makes a university a university,'' says Barbara Selick Dawson, news service director at Rutgers, the State University. And Allen J. Sinisgalli, Princeton's director of research and project administration, says matter-of-factly: ''Our major programs live or die with outside funding.''

title: HE IS NEEDED 'NOW MORE THAN EVER,' CAREY SAYS
description: The 100th anniversary of Franklin D. Roosevelt's birth was celebrated here today at the Hudson River estate where he was born and buried.

title: Library 'Exercises': Additional Chapters
description: Being an academic librarian and having recently worked for the Great Neck Public Library, I read with interest Harry Schatz's article of Jan. 10 (''Exercising by the Book,'' Opinion Page).

title: WASHINGTON BIRTHDAYS
description: To the Editor:

title: Follow-Up on the News; Leonardo Chase
description: What happened to Leonardo da Vinci's mural ''The Battle of Anghiari''? For years, scholars searched for the long-lost work, painted about 1505. In November 1979 two American researchers, H. Travers Newton, then with Harvard's Fogg Art Museum, and John R. Spencer, chairman of the art department at Duke University, believed they might have found it.

title: ISLANDERS CAPTURE 5TH STRAIGHT
description: ''When you hear all those dings off the goal posts,'' Billy Smith, the Islander goalie, was saying tonight at Nassau Coliseum, ''it usually means two things: I've been a lucky goaltender, and, two, we probably won the game.''

title:
ART;
THE FASCINATION OF THE FIGURE
description: SETAUKET DEPICTION of the human figure is perhaps th e most ancient and enduring preoccupation of art. From prehistor ic fertility carvings to photo-realism, artists have exploited the vitality and emotional impact of the human image, and some of the mo st resolute abstractionists have clung to it tenaciously.

title:
Theater;
MINOR CLASSIC, FLAWED HYBRID
description: PLAINFIELD TWO questions are raised by the New Jersey Theater Forum's production of ''Ladyhouse Blues'': 1) Is Kevin O'Morrison's play something of a minor classic? 2) Is there a better ensemble performance in the state right now?

title: Mary Clonan Is Bride Of William J. Pearson
description: Mary Genevieve Clonan, daughter of Merritt Pierce Clonan of Wilton, Conn., and the late Genevieve Mary Clonan, was married yesterday to William Jackson Pearson, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Maddox Pearson of Atlanta. The Rev. Stanley Slingerland, an uncle of the bride, performed the ceremony at the Central Presbyterian Church in New York.

title: No Headline
description: THE NUCLEAR BARONS By Peter Pringle and James Spigelman.578 pp. New York: Holt, Rinehart & Winston. $16.95. NUCLEAR WITNESSES Insiders Speak Out. By Leslie J. Freeman. 330 pp. New York: W.W. Norton. Cloth, $16.95. Paper, $5.95.

description: To the Editor:

title: Connecticut Journal
description: WITH their robes and legal language and rituals of the bench in which they sometimes appear to assume an almost regal status, judges have tended to be the most aloof and probably least understood of all public officials. While the public generally has opinions on the worth of Presidents and governors and lawmakers, judges seem to exist in a world apart if not above run-of-the-mill mortals.

title: Personal Finance; WHERE TO RETIRE IN THE REAGAN ERA
description: A KEY to a secure retirement may lie in identifying those parts of the country where living expenses are low and where governments are least likely to suffer from reduced Federal aid. That process may become more important in light of President Reagan's proposals, outlined in the State of the Union Message last Tuesday, on rearranging the relationship between the Federal Government and the states.

title: Teamsters' Bargaining Panel Approves Pact With Truckers
description: The top bargaining panel of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters has approved a tentative contract settlement with the trucking industry, clearing the way for a ratification vote, a union spokesman said Friday.

title: Sunday Observer
description: Sound Advice PATRICK MCDONNELL

title: No Headline
description: Brian Orser overcame two shaky jumps and a stubborn challenge from Brian Pockar tonight and won his second straight senior men's title in the Canadian figure skating championships.

title: Easy Women
description: To the Editor:

title: Westchester Journal
description: THE opening of the final section of the Sprain Brook Parkway on Oct. 28, 1980, has produced shifts of traffic on the county's roads, much of it for the better, and encouraged construction in the mid-Westchester area, according to authorities on the subject.

title: Nonfiction in Brief
description: NOBODY HERE BUT US CHICKENS By Marvin Mudrick. 299 pp. New York & New Haven: Ticknor & Fields. $16.95.

title: Marathoner Sets Record
description: Andy Holden of Britain won the Hong Kong Marathon today in an event-record time of 2 hours 17 minutes 43 seconds. Second was Gary Hand of Australia in 2:18:49.

title: No Headline
description: STIPANOVICH LEADS 18-0 MISSOURI PAST KANSAS STATE

title: France Again Halts Imports Of Inexpensive Italian Wine
description: France has suspended imports of inexpensive Italian wine for the second time in six months, defusing a wave of violent protest by French winegrowers but risking condemnation by the Common Market.

title: AN INSTRUMENT MAKER IN TUNE WITH THE TIMES
description: WINSTED ''AT least 50 percent of the people I come in contact with have never seen it before,'' David Marks was saying. Next to him on a long table, lined up like a rank of soldie rs, were a dozen dark-wood boxes, highly polished, with curves instead o f corners.

title: FORGERY ALLEGED IN DEAL ON REAGAN'S COAST HOME
description: An agreement to sell President Reagan's house in Los Angeles collapsed suddenly two weeks ago after a savings and loan executive discovered two sets of closing papers bearing different sale prices.

title: A 'MERCEDES' IN FORD'S FUTURE
description: THERE was only minor shilly-shallying. Well, yes, the company official said, Ford Motor Company was going after that segment of the luxury market that had always been conceded to Mercedes-Benz and the other expensive imports.

title: Environews
description: THE American Lung Association of New Jersey has asked the state's Department of Environmental Protection for assurances that proposed revisions in air quality standards will not increase emissions of sulfur dioxide, a lung irritant associated with pulmonary ailments and a major component of acid rain.

title: 'THEY WEIGH THE ALTERNATIVES AND CHOOSE NUCLEAR POWER'
description: THE most interesting question that is raised by the recent Opinion Page article ''A Tale of Two Power Plants'' and the statements of the three nuclear opponents who responded on the Opinion Page of Jan. 17 is ''whom to believe.'' Obviously, someone is misinformed .

title: Other Business; ADVENTURES IN DINING AT PAINE WEBBER
description: Paine Webber Inc., the investment firm, has been thriving of late financially. Net earnings for the year ended in September were $15.9 million as opposed to a net loss of $6.9 million in 1980. But that doesn't mean Paine Webber's stockbrokers are eating any better.

title: January 31, 1982
description: NONFICTION AGON: Towards a Theory of Revisionism. By Harold Bloom. 8 AMERICA NOW: The Anthropology of a Changing Culture. By Marvin Harris. 7 GETTING SAVED FROM THE SIXTIES.

title: McEnroe, Connors Gain Final
description: Lawrence Barrett Hooper 3d, recently out of college and ranked 236th in the world, carried Jimmy Connors to four sets tonight before yielding in the semifinal round of the United States Professional Indoor tennis championship.

title: UNLIKELY SOLUTION TO TEEN-AGE PREGNANCIES
description: To the Edit or: In their Ja n. 22 letters, Marilyn Bowie and Alfred Moran speak of the need for contraceptives to alleviate the growing teen-age pregnancy pro blem. During a WABC radio broadcast last Nov. 26, I pointed out t o Mr. Moran, a Planned Parenthood executive, that studies and s tatistics do not support this contention:

title: SUSHI AND SASHIMI JOIN TEMPURA
description: LONG before the current proliferation of restaurants serving authentic Japanese food began on the Island, Sapporo, in New Hyde Park, held the fort against the tide of popular hibachi steakhouses with performing chefs. It was, for many years, the only place on the Island that served not only te mpura but also some of the traditional foods cooked in broth, such as yosenabe, or cutlets, such as tonkatsu.

title: Article 159931 -- No Title
description: The operators of an eastern Kentucky coal mine where two explosions killed 26 men in March 1976 have agreed to pay penalties totaling $236,400, the largest civil assessment ever imposed by the Federal mine safety agency in a single disaster.

title: HOW SAFE ARE THE WORLD'S AIRPORTS?
description: JOHN NOBLE WILFORD is a science news reporter for The Times. By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD

title: 'Sholom' Delays Opening
description: The opening of ''The World of Sholom Aleichem,'' starring Jack Gilford - originally scheduled for Feb.4 - has been postponed to Feb. 11, although preview performances will continue. An article about the revival at the Rialto theater in the Arts and Leisure section today and the listing in the the Arts and Leisure Guide, having been printed before the postponement, carry the earlier opening date.

title: Art; CURRIER & IVES: A MONTCLAIR COUP
description: MONTCLAIR WHEN asked to cite famous artists of our country, Americans might mention many names, but they would probably forget two of the most famous: Nathaniel Currier and James Merritt Ives, whose prints of 19th-century American life were once among the most popular images in the United States.

title: TWO OF DOZIER'S KIDNAPPERS ARE LINKED TO MORO KILLING
description: At least three of the five terrorists who kidnapped Brig. Gen. James L. Dozier are longtime members of the Red Brigades who were involved in major terrorist operations in the past, police officials said today.

title: Families in Transition: Helping Hands
description: It was with great interest that we read ''When Single Parents Have a Date'' (Jan. 3). The National Council of Jewish Women, Peninsula Section, is an educational service and advocacy organization dedicated to meeting human needs in our community. We are very proud of our input of operating funds and providing volunteers, both adults and teenagers, which enable the Peninsula Counseling Center's Families in Transition Program. SHEILA JACOBSON President, Peninsula Section National Council off Jewish Women Lawrence

title: By Sports of The Times; The Yankees' Captain Quip
description: HE hits home runs and he turns doubles down the third-base line into double plays. He's been a Yankee longer than any other player on their revolving-door roster. And now Graig Nettles has been knighted as the Yankees' new captain.

title: DRIVE FOR STATEHOOD OPENS IN CAPITAL
description: The District of Columbia, the nation's ''last colony,'' according to leaders of a statehood movement here, today swore in 45 delegates to a constitutional convention as the first step toward an application to become the 51st state.

title: SUBWAY ODYSSEY
description: Paul Theroux, whose latest novel, ''Mosquito Coast,'' will be published next month, lives in London. By Paul Theroux

title: 14 Die in Chilean Bus Crash
description: Fourteen people died and 70 were injured early today when two buses collided and plunged into a 60-foot gorge on the outskirts of the Chilean capital, the police said.

title: COPING WITH THE COLD FRONT
description: ''IT'S been cold the last couple of weeks, but it's been colder before,'' said Harold Gibson, the meteorologist in charge of the New York office of the National Weather Service. He was recalling the winter of 1976-1977 and that of 1978-1979, when more than 12 inches fell in one snowfall in January, topped in early February by 24 more inches of snow.

title: Peter Goldmann Fiance Of Barbara M. Wohler
description: Barbara M. Wohler and Peter D. Goldmann plan to be married on June 20 in Peekskill, N.Y. Their engagement has been announced by the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Wohler of Yonkers. Mr. Goldmann is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert B. Goldmann of New York.

title: KUWAITI PARLIMENT LEGALIZES SOME ABORTIONS
description: Kuwait has become the first Arab nation on the Persian Gulf to permit abortion. The all-male Parliament approved the measure Tuesday night while Kuwaiti women marched outside demanding the right to vote. It permits abortions if the pregnancy would result in ''gross physical harm'' to the woman or if the fetus has brain damage ''beyond hope of treatment.''

title: Daniel Gumport to Wed Sarah Danysh
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Alexander Danysh of Carmel, Calif., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sarah Amanda Constantina Danysh, to Daniel R. Gumport, son of Dr. and Mrs. Stephen L. Gumport of New York and Nantucket, Mass.

title: A VISIT WITH LEWIS CAROLL
description: Morton Cohen portrays Lewis Carroll as a shy mathematician who felt most comfortable in the company of children, but he fails to show Lewis Carroll's relationship with Alice in its historical context. Had he done so, it would have become clear that since Victorians idealized innocence and purity, it was common for young men to entertain girls as young as 9 or 10, and invite them to their rooms for tea. Lewis Carroll's friendship with Alice, then, was not unusual, as Victorians commonly celebrated a cult of the little girl. JUDY SCHWARTZ Providence

title: Topics Hard Cheese, Free Speech; Giveaway
description: In the land of no-frills packaging and the art form of ''couponing,'' a giant cheese giveaway is a natural. But this largesse is not for everyone: you have to be poor to qualify for a five-pound loaf of processed American spread.

title: THE ETHICS OF BUSINESS FACE CHALLENGE
description: BUSINESS ethics is a good conversation starter at cocktail parties these days. Of course, some confuse the term with minority businesses, since a few martinis often make ethics sound like ethnics. A term open to many meanings, ethics seems more like a new code of etiquette for the business lunch to some managers. One way or another, business ethics gets mixed reviews in the business community.

title: WANT TO FEEL LIKE ROYALTY? TAKE A RIDE IN A ROLLS-ROYCE
description: FRET not, Leonore Annenberg: The abuse directed at you by your fellow countrymen for curtsying to Prince Charles was, at the least, hypocrisy. Many of them are guilty of much more than a simple bending of the knees in honor of royalty. Before another British institution, the Rolls Royce, some Americans melt like butter.

title: Photography View; EXPLOITING THE GLUT OF EXISTING IMAGERY
description: Fundamental to the contemporary condition of art that has become known as post-modernism is the belief that we are contaminated by received images. According to this belief, our perception of the world is largely predetermined by signs and symbols we inherit and absorb from outside sources. All images, whether from high or low culture, are said to have meanings encoded in them. Thus, artists have to contend not only with the accumulated imagery of hundreds of years of art history, but also with a lifetime's exposure to the mass media. To consciously confront this glut of imagery, in the hope of freeing us from our preconceptions, is now one of art's primary energizing impulses.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Laetrile Verdict: It's the Pits
description: Over the last few years, 24 states have legalized the use of Laetrile as an unorthodox cancer treatment, despite the warnings of orthodox medical experts that the drug, a derivative of apricot pits, doesn't work. Now, the skeptics have what they believe to be conclusive evidence - a multi-institutional study showing not only that Laetrile doesn't work, but that in sufficient doses it may be toxic.

title:
Antiques;
THE POWDER HORN AS FOLK ART
description: TODAY many antiques collectors regard almost any small handmade wood object or any example of whalers' inventiveness as folk art. Decorated powder horns, however, have been collected strictly as historical artifacts, as examples of Americana rather than as examples of the folk art which they also are.

title: 150 AT FAIR IN BRONX ARE GIVEN FREE JUICE AND CHECKUPS, TOO
description: The posters around the South Bronx read on top in bold letters, ''FREE: BREAD AND JUICE.'' Below those words, and almost as an afterthought, the signs invited people who had rarely had a medical examination to visit the Belvis Medical Center on 142d Street for a free checkup yesterday.

title: Allison A. Mellor Wed To Brian Park Mitchell
description: Allison Annette Mellor, an assistant vice president with the Bankers Trust Company, was married yesterday to Brian Park Mitchell, a producer of television commercials in New York. The Rev. Mario Costa performed the ceremony at the St. Paul the Apostle Roman Catholic Church in Brookville, L. I.

title: VAST DAMAGE CITED IN BALTIC OIL SPILL
description: A Moscow insurance executive has disclosed tha t a little-publicizedoil spill on the Soviet Union's Baltic coast two months ago has caused as much as $900 million in damage, mak ing it apparently one ofthe most serious spills ever.

title: MUSIC: NIERENBERG LEADS JUILLIARD FESTIVAL
description: There was a time when a composer's subject, the material for his art, was the same as the novelist's or poet's -the comfort of religious faith, the feel of a dream caught at the edge of wakefulness, the drama of a soul wrestling with experience. Whatever the formal techniques involved, from Josquin to Schonberg, music was a tool for expression.

title: Other Business; A NEW STAMP HONORS A BANKER; IT TOOK A WHILE
description: Robert Morr is helped finance the American Revoluti on with his own vast fortune, and he signed the Declaration of Independence. He had a vision, the creation of a central banking system, which was decadesahead of its time.

title: REAGAN THREATENS GRADUATES' LOANS
description: President Reagan's budget for the next fiscal year would make graduate and professional students ineligible for guaranteed student loans, their primary source of Federal aid, Administration officials say.

title: Around the World; Syrian Chief Said to Fo il An Attempted Coup
description: A Kuwaiti newspaper, quoting Jordanian sources, said a group of Syrian Army officers had failed in an attempt to overthrow President Hafez al-Assad. Syria denied the report.

title: 500 Handmade Cars - at $78,500 Apiece
description: The Clenet Series III, a handmade two-passenger luxury car, is the third in a series of ''limited-edition'' offerings from Clenet Coachworks of Santa Barbara, Calif.

title: CITY'S OFFICE MARKET STABILIZES AFTER POST-RECESSION SURGE
description: Millions of people are unemployed, the automobile and housing industries are suffering, the economic slump is troubling all sorts of people and business, but through it all the Manhattan commercial real estate market is holding its own.

title: Mailbox; Volvo Masters Cheats the Fan
description: To the Sports Editor: Although considered to be a major tournament worthy of attracting not only the best players but also network television as well, the Volvo Masters has made a habit of cheating the tennis fan. The double-elimination format has created situations where players can afford to lose a match and therefore just ''go through the motions.''

title: 2 MAJOR AUTO MAKERS PLAN TO ENTER THE DIESEL-CAR FIELD
description: IN the next three years, American Motors, Chrysler and Ford, having decided that the market for diesel-powered passenger cars is sound, plan to enter the race against the new diesel front-runner, General Motors, and three imports, Mercedes-Benz, Volkswagen-Audi and Peugeot.

title: Headliners; The Long Voyage Home
description: Owning land is one thing, but keeping track of what's on it is quite another. Ask Rex Cauble. The Texas millionaire cattle rancher was convicted last week of financing an elabor ate smuggling ring thatshipped marij uana from Colombia to High Island, Texas in six shrimp boats, each c arrying from 35,000 to 40,000 pounds of the drug.

title: MORE WRESTLING WITH FOREBEARS
description: AGON Towards a Theory of Revisionism. By Harold Bloom. 336 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $19.95.''AS soon as a man begins to see everything,'' G.C. Lichtenberg observed in an aphorism Harold Bloom sets at the head of an essay on Emerson, ''he generally expresses himself obscurely - begins to speak with the tongues of angels.'' The statement surely applies as aptly to Mr. Bloom as to Emerson, and, indeed, Mr. Bloom is so shrewdly self-conscious a writer that it seems altogether likely he intended to hint at the personal application.

title: OUTLET BOOKS BUYS ARLINGTON
description: The Outlet Book Company, the promotional arm of the Crown Publishing Group, has purchased Arlington House Publishers, including its Nostalgia and Conservative Book Clubs.

title: ENDURING IMAGES
description: Contemporary trends of thought imagine that art is like a fountain, whereas it is a sponge. They have decided that art should gush forth, whereas it should absorb and become saturated. They think it can be broken down into methods of depiction, whereas it is composed of organs of perception. The proper task of art is to be always an observer, to gaze more purely than others do, more receptively and faithfully. - BORIS PASTERNAK. Is it possible in this age of publicity for a photographer to be both famous and obscure at the same time? The anomalous career of Evelyn Hofer suggests that it is. In a period when photography is said to have finally ''arrived'' - when museums are showing it and collectors are buying it and critics are hailing its every accomplishment - Miss Hofer remains an unusual figure.

title: PIANIST: MORDECAI SHEHORI
description: Wednesday's recital at the 92d Street Y by the Israeli-born pianist Mordecai Shehori gave a large audience the opportunity to hear some unusually thoughtful and thought-provoking playing, even if the program's major offerings - Schubert's expansive Sonata in B flat (Op. Post.) and Mussorgsky's ''Pictures at an Exhibition'' - found Mr. Shehori attempting too often to be a miniaturist in canvases that demand something of the muralist as well.

title: THE REFINED GLITTER OF THE PLACE VENDOME
description: SUSAN HELLER ANDERSON is a reporter for the Style section of The Times. By SUSAN HELLER ANDERSON

title: THE SAUDIS BUILD A PITTSBURGH
description: with its bustling bazaar, 300-year-old coral houses and elderly men smoking strong Oriental tobacco from tableside water pipes in cafes - harkens to the fabled Arabian past.

title: About Greenhouses And Solar Heating
description: As Carl Totemeier points out in his Nov. 29 article, greenhouses are being promoted as passive solar-energy collectors to supplement home-heating systems. They should be. When properly designed and installed, the solar greenhouse will supply most of its own heat and substantial amounts of heat to the home.

title: Douglas E. Woodbury to Marry Carolyn C. Nevius
description: Mr. and Mrs. R. Foster Nevius of Essex Fells, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Carolyn C. Nevius, to Douglas Elliot Woodbury, son of the Rev. and Mrs. Newton Edgar Woodbury of Wayne, Pa.

title: Isabel W. Gould Will Be Married
description: Mr. and Mrs. George M.L. Gould of Sewickley, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Isabel Williard Gould, to Peter Tiffany Hoversten, son of Mr. and Mrs. Moris T. Hoversten of Lake Forest, Ill.

title: Liggett Gives $30,000 To Durham Festival
description: The American Dance Festival has received a $30,000 challenge grant from the Liggett Group. The Durham, N.C.-based summer dance festival, a major force in American modern dance since its founding in 1948, must meet $5,000 of the award with an equal amount raised from Durham County residents, and the remaining $25,000 with $50,000 in new funds from companies doing business in North Carolina.

title: Massapequa Man Surrenders After 30-Shot Shooting Spree
description: A Massapequa man used two high-powered rifles to spray 30 bullets across his house and front lawn early today before the police and his wife persuaded him to surrender.

title: California Senate Reprimands Lawmaker Over Name-Calling
description: State Senator John Schmitz has been formally reprimanded by the California Senate for his namecalling attack last month on abortion-rights advocates.

title: News Summary; SUNDAY, JANUARY 31, 1982
description: International Congress will be asked to increase aid to El Salvador this year by $100 million, and the Administration will seek more increases in the next fiscal year, officials said. Military aid for the current fiscal year amounts to $25 million and all forms of economic aid total about $110 million. The economic and military aid request for fiscal 1983, which begins in October, is to be made in the President's budget presentation next month and is expected to be about $300 million. (Page 1, Column 6.) Hospital care for a Soviet woman who has been on a hunger strike in the United States Embass y in Moscow, where sh e was among seven Pentecostalists given asylum three and a half years ago, was ordered by embassy officials. Lidiya Vashchenko who w ith the others had been seeking to emigrate, was accompanied to a hos pital by American officials. (1:4-5.)

title: Politics; AN END RUN ON BUSINESS TAX REPEAL
description: HARTFORD MOST of the chalkboards with the X's and O's may have been put away after the Super Bowl last Sunday. But some of the maneuvering in the closing days of the General Assembly's special session would have delighted an armchair football strategist.

title: The Postman
description: To the Business Editor:

title: NUREYEV'S FIGHT AGAINST TIME
description: As one of the dance critics who has recently been decrying Rudolf Nureyev's poor performances, I would like to explain that most of us are embarrassed to see his present condition, as compared with his earlier brilliant accomplishments.

title: Dallas Has President's Nod For 1984 G.O.P Convention
description: Dallas is President Reagan's clear ''first choice'' as the site of the 1984 Republican Convention, says the chairman of the Republican National Committee.

title: THE RITZ THEN AND NOW
description: A.E. HOTCHNER is the author of ''Papa Hemingway'' and ''Sophia''; hismost recent b ook is a novel, ''The Man Who Lived at the Ritz,'' forthcoming f rom Putnam. By A.E.HOTCHNER

title: LARGER DONATIONS TO NEEDIEST INSPIRED BY INCREASE IN WANT
description: Many contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund have explained donations larger this year than last with such words as ''because the need is greater.''

title: Nathalie Potter, Lawyer, Fiancee
description: Mrs. L. Appleton Potter of Ipswich, Mass., and the Rev. Benjamin Franklin Potter of Kentfield, Calif., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nathalie Appleton Potter, to Richard A. Maio, son of Mrs. Anthony F. Maio of Ridgewood, N.J., and the late Mr. Maio.

title: Around the Nation; No Laws Held Violated In Nuclear Plant Incident
description: The authorities said today that an environmental group involved in a ''mock attack'' on a nuclear power plant at Zion, Ill., did not break Federal laws.

title: Pro Basketball Notebook; Laker Contracts Criticized
description: The owners of the National Basketball Association teams spent much of Friday night and yesterday in the league meetings at the Grand Hyatt Hotel, and afterward several classified the tone of the sessions as, ''Where are are we going? That's a good question.''

title: TITLE TO HAMILTON IN FIGURE SKATING
description: Scott Hamilton, the 5-foot dynamo from Denver, turned in a polished, energetic performance tonight and won a gold medal for the second straight year at the national figure skating championships before 15,100 at the Market Square Arena..

title: U.S. Ends Registration In January for Aliens
description: Sunday is the first Jan. 31 in more than three decades that has not marked the deadline for aliens living in the United States to register with the Immigration and Naturalization Service.

title: HARTSDALE DRUMMER FINDS NICHE IN JAZZ
description: SEVEN years ago, the drummer Butch Miles was depressed. He had recently completed three and a half years playing for Mel Torme, but now was out of a job, living with his parents in Washington, D.C., and working as a court reporter. To ease a particularly bleak night, he went to see ''Blazing Saddles,'' a film he especially liked for a scene in which Count Basie's orchestra plays ''April in Paris'' in the desert.

title: Deborah Slawter Married
description: Deborah Slawter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul B. Slawter Jr. of Garden City, L.I., and Alan Kochbarski, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Kochbarski of Paterson, N.J., were married yesterday. Canon John W. Davis performed the ceremony in St. George's Episcopal Church in Hempstead, L.I.

title: Westchester Housing; SOME PREDICTIONS ON THE INDUSTRY
description: BUYING a new house 10 years from now may be like buying a car: ordering a model from a national manufacturer and deciding on options, such as color and equipment.

title: Dance View; HARLEM DANCE THEATER STEPS OUT
description: Quite suddenly, a still young and very special company is on the threshold of another American success story. In its current season atthe City Center, the Dance Theater of Harlem has visibly taken a dramatic turn -in more ways than one. For the first time, it has emphasized dance-dramas over neo-classical pl otless ballets among its premieres. In doing so, it has proclaimed a pronounced shift in its artistic policy.

title: Luanne Dunkle Is a Bride
description: Luanne Elizabeth Dunkle, daughter of Mrs. James L. Harris of York, Pa., and Richard B. Dunkle of Gardenville, Pa., was married yesterday in Trinity Episcopal Church in Solebury, Pa., to C. Anthony Dwyer.

title: Sarah Bucknell To Wed in June
description: Announcement has been made by Prof. and Mrs. Edward C. Carter 2d of Wayne, Pa., of the engagement of Mrs. Carter's daughter, Sarah Harlan Bucknell, to James Dempsey Treco, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank S. Treco Jr. of Gates Mills, Ohio.

title: MURDER OF COUPLE AND INFANTS LEADS TO $10 MILLION IN DRUGS
description: A Colombian couple and their two infant children were slain execution-style early yesterday in an automobile on the Grand Central Parkway in Queens. The resulting investigation led the police to more than $10 million worth of cocaine and nearly $1 million in cash in an expensive Jamaica Estates apartment, authorities said.

title: The Region in Summary; The Train for The Pained
description: Power failures, standing-room-only crowds and timetables fractured by icy weather haven't made the New Haven Line much of a bargain this winter. Last week, commuters in Connecticut learned it might be even less of one come summer.

title: Bridge; KEEPER OF THE FLAME
description: The most dedicated lover of the game to compete in the recent Fall Nationals in San Francisco was surely Dr. C.P. Chang of Shanghai, a physician of great professional distinction. For almost half a century he has been the only resident of the Chinese mainland to be a member of the American Contract Bridge League. He learned the game in 1924 as a student at the Peking Union Medical College. His medical career took him to the United States in the 30's, where he played with success in Philadelphia and Chicago.

title: PATIENCE IS A VIRTUE IN RACE FOR LAWYERS' TOP POST
description: Carole Bellows, a Chicago trial lawyer, could well become president of the American Bar Association. So could James J. Bierbower, a Washington lawyer; M. Roland Nachman Jr. of Montgomery, Ala., or Wall Street's Robert MacCrate - if any of them live long enough to get elected.

title: The Nation in Summary; Auto Tal ks End On Wrong Side Of B reakthrough
description: ''It just didn't go together,'' Douglas A. Fraser, president of the United Automobile Workers, announced in Detroit last week just after his union's extraordinary round of early contract talks with the General Motors Corporation had blown a gasket.

title: New Jersey Journal
description: THEY still may be flying on a wing and a prayer, but Eagle Flight Post 290 of Orange is being considered for a $10,000 grant from the New Jersey State Department of Health, Division of Narcotics and Drug Abuse Control. The post, a Boy Scout Explorer troop, gives its 35 members - boys and girls 13 to 18 years old - experience in aviation. They can earn a single-engine pilot's license after completing a ground school and flying course.

title: FOR ISRAELIS, BAR KOCHBA ISN'T ANCIENT HISTORY
description: Later this year, in great pomp and ceremony, Israel will hold a state funeral for one of the nation's most controversial military heroes. But the funeral, in this case, is also a revival, for Shimon Bar Kochba, the general to be honored, died almost 2,000 years ago. He was the commander-in-chief of the second Jewish revolt against Rome in 132 A.D. which briefly established a free Jewish state in the land of Israel, but was eventually crushed.

title: Cora L. Nutt to Be Married To David Brien Chemidlin
description: Mr. and Mrs. David T. Nutt of Scotch Plains, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Cora Louise Nutt, to David Brien Chemidlin, son of Mr and Mrs. Frederick J. Chemidlin Jr. of Fanwood, N.J. The wedding is planned for September in Scotch Plains.

title: Christina Pennoyer Married
description: At Trinity Episcopal Church in New York yesterday, Christina Lee Pennoyer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Morgan Pennoyer of New York, was married to R. Scott Greathead. He is the son of Edwin Burton Greathead of Santa Barbara, Calif., and Carolyn Craig Greathead of Smith River, Calif.

title: AMTRAK ACTION POSES PROBLEM FOR STATE
description: AFTER months of delay, the Federal Department of Transportation has finally named David W. Marston, former United States Attorney from Philadelphia, president of the newly formed Amtrak commuter subsidiary.

title: To Some, It Is
description: To the Sports Editor: I wish to affirm that for many of us sport is indeed a religion, with tennis participants comprising one of the largest congregations.

title: THE MAGICAL REEF ABOVE AND BELOW
description: ROBERT REINHOLD is a science reporter in The Times Washington bureau. By ROBERT REINHOLD

title: EVALUATING THE PROS AND CONS OF BUYING A DIESEL CAR
description: Auto buyers considering whether to buy a diesel-powered passenger car must evaluate the diesel's pros and cons against those of the traditional gasoline-powered car.

title: Julia B. Middleton Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Henry Bentivoglio Middleton of New York and Greve-in-Chianti, Italy, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Julia Bentivogli o Middleton, to Ottavio Serena di Lapigio, an assistant vice president in the world corporate department of the Bankers Trust Company in New York and son of Baron and Baroness Fabrizio Sere na di Lapigio of Rome.

title: Jacobson Sets Record Straight on His Critics
description: The article ''Jacobson Reflects on Role in Energy'' (Jan. 17) was a bit imprecise. As a consequence, I turned out more complimentary of my critics than I intended to be.

title:
GARDENING;
BRINGING A BIT OF SPRING INDOORS
description: SO your car stalled in a snowdrift during the last cold snap, and your fingers and toes were nearly frozen by the time you reached the phone booth to call for help. And you've just received the latest fuel bill and swear that you haven't seen numbers that large since the last time the national debt was printed in the newspaper.

title: No Headline
description: NO. 2 NORTH CAROLINA TROUNCES NORTH CAROLINA STATE BY 58-44

title: The Greater New York Automobile Show
description: The show runs through Feb. 7 at the New York Coliseum, 59th Street and Broadway, from 11 A.M. to 10:30 P.M. tomorrow through Saturday, and 11 A.M. to 8 P.M. today and next Sunday.

title: ALBANY PANEL SUGGESTS PLAN FOR THE COURTS
description: Major revisions in New York State's criminal-justice system are being recommended by the State Senate Committee on Investigations and Taxation.

title: WIRETAP DECISION UPSET ON APPEAL
description: A law that helps defendants find out if they were subjected to illegal wiretapping by law-enforcement agencies applies only to Federal cases, not state cases, the Federal appeals court in Manhattan has ruled.

title: Kiri Te Kanawa
description: To the Editor:

title: A NEW TIMELINESS FOR SOME OLD LURES
description: DETROIT THE American automakers, reacting to a widespread feeling here that they have overshot the mark in their drive for greater fuel efficiency, are turning back to lures that brought in the buyers before gasoline prices soared: high technology, aerodynamic styling and higher performance.

title: TRUE CONFESSIONS: I FELL FOR AN APARTMENT SWINDLE
description: What I wanted in an apartment, after my separation 13 years ago, proved to be far easier to describe than to find. It had to be relatively near the Riverside Drive apartment I was leaving, so that I wouldn't be too far from my two children. It also had to be small enough to be affordable, and yet large enough for the children to stay o vernight comfortably.

title: WRITERS OF THE PURPLE SAGE
description: Was it really necessary for Russell Martin to throw buffalo chips at Louis L'Amour in order to show how good some ''contemporary'' Western writers are?

title: Andrew Silk's Courage
description: I was saddened to read of the death of Andrew Silk (''The Struggle of Andrew Silk: A Young Man Confronts Cancer,'' by Andrew Silk, Oct. 18). I know that I am but one of many who was touched by Mr. Silk's story.

title: Conservationist Says Water Will Control Regional Growth
description: The president of the National A udubon Society has p redicted that demand for water could lead to a shift in growth patter ns from the Sun Belt to the Snow Belt.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''They're a bunch of dedicated people. They're smart. They believe in what they're doing, and they're very serious about it.''

title: U.S. EMBASSY IN MOSCOW TRANSFERS PENTECOSTALIST TO A SOVIET HOSPITAL
description: One of seven Pentecostalists who have been in sanctuary at the United States Embassy here for the last three and half years was taken to a Moscow hospital today to be treated for the effects of a nearly monthlong hunger strike.

title: FUTURE UNSURE FOR RESEVOIR PROPERTY
description: LARCHMONT OCCASIONAL flocks of Canada geese alight in the quiet of sunset on the thick ice of the Larchmont Reservoir. They stand as if waiting for water to open beneath them and, when it doesn't, take off, forming their V's in the air.

title: LAYOFF AT G.M. POINTS OUT CONCERNS OF VILLAGE OFFICIALS
description: NORTH TARRYTOWN WHEN General Motors sneezes, the village of North Tarrytown may not catch cold, but village officials like to keep a thermometer handy just in case.

title: BUTTER FOR BIG GUNS
description: The American taxpayer will spend about $200 billion this year to bolster national defense. What he may not know is that a hefty porti on of this money will pay for lobbying to secure those defense contr acts in the first place.

title: MUBARAK, DUE IN U.S., STARTS HIS TOUR
description: Hosni Mubarak left Cairo today on his first round of state visits as Egypt's new President. Nearly half of his 10-day trip will be taken up with talks in Washington.

title: The World in Summary; Seal of Approval For El Salvador
description: The Reagan Administration still chooses to see El Salvador as a test case of ''Communist subversion'' rather than human rights. Last week it dismissed reports of the slaughter of civilians by the Salvadoran Army as impossible to prove and, as expected, certified that the Salvadoran junta was making a ''concerted'' effort to protect huma n rights, had achieved ''substantial control'' over its security forc es and was making progress in implementing political andeconomic refo rms.

title: Music; HIGH-PRICED QUALITY AT LOW OR NO COST
description: IF the high cost of concert-going is starting to get you down, take heart: free concerts in the county seem to be on the upswing, and quite a number of other fine programs are available at about the cost of a movie ticket.

title: MILLER, WITH 68-200, LEADS BY 3 STROKES
description: Johnny Miller, who says candidly that he is the best front-runner in professional golf, is exactly where he likes to be - in the lead - after three rounds of the San Diego Open.

title: Politics And Intellectuals
description: To the Editor:

title: Connecticut Housing; COMPLEX GETS ITS NEWS ON TV
description: WHENEVER Dorothy Spencer turns on the small television set in the kitchen of her condominium in Oronoque Village in Stratford nowadays, she invariably tunes in Channel 10 first, ''just to see what's been going on.''

title: THE PROBLEMS OF REDRESSING INEQUITIES IN SCHOOL FUNDS
description: Pocantico Hills, an affluent corner of Westchester County with corporate office buildings and large, comfortable homes valued at hundreds of thousands of dollars, spends $8,995 in property taxes to educate each of the 600 children in its public school. In western New York, the community of Frewsburg, property values averaging a more modest $34,000, spends $1,878 for each of the 1,055 youngsters attending its public schools, though Frewsburg's tax rate is 25 percent higher than in Pocantico Hills.

title: Antiques Vie w; TINY TREASURES MADE OF GLASS
description: One of the most seductive exhibitions of decorative arts is ''Small Wonders: The Scent Bottle Through History.'' The show, which opened Wednesday and remains at Steuben Glass, Fifth Avenue at 56th Street through Feb. 20, presents some of the most superbly crafted, arresting and wittily conceived glass vessels, dating from 1500 B.C. through the 1940's. As presented, this assemblage of tiny treasures adds up to an impressive, telescoped history of glassmaking.

title: A MONTH OF EVENTS FOR BLACK HISTORY
description: BY some accounts, it dates from the 1920's, but many people believe it actually got started when the author Carter G. Woodson founded Negro History Week in the 1930's, designating it the second week in February.

title: Children's Books
description: PORTRAIT: TRINA SCHART HYMAN By Trina Schart Hyman. Illustrated. 32 pp. Reading, Mass.: Addison-Wesley. $8.95. (Ages 8 to 11) By MARILYN KAYE

title: DEPARTURE OF CAREY OPENS DOORS TO MANY OFFICES
description: Governor Carey's decision not to seek a third term has produced a prodigious number of potential Democratic nominees. The day Mr. Carey announced his decision, David Langdon, an adviser to Assembly Speaker Stanley Fink, showed up in the Capitol press room periodically to ask for a ''body count'' of potential candidates, whose numbers multiplied by the hour.

title: Critics' Choices
description: JAZZ/POP Singing pianists in cocktail lounges, restaurants and bars are inclined to work with a repertory of requests - current pop tunes, currently fashionable show tunes and a few old sing-along standards. Amy Duncan, whose piano is squeezed in between the bar and the restaurant at the New Ballroom, 253 West 28th Street, takes a different approach.

title: G.M.'s 'FAMILY CAR OF THE 80's' GROWS BIGGER AND ROOMIER
description: WHEN General Motors introduced its front-wheel-drive X-cars in April 1979, Elliot M. Estes, who was then the company's president, brought some samples to New York and showed them to the press.

title:
Camera;
A FRESH LOOK AT BLACK-AND-WHITE
CARL NIELSEN WRIT SMALL
description: ''It is a fact,'' Carl Nielsen wrote in his diary as a young man, ''that he who brandishes the hardest fist will be remembered longest. Beethoven, Michelangelo, Bach, Berlioz, Rembrandt, Shakespeare, Goethe, Henrik Ibsen and the like have all given their time a black eye.'' Well, Carl Nielsen's music may still be highly honored in his native Denmark, but he has not joined that illustrious company. His own fist, brandished during the early decades of this century, has had at most a gloved impact. He began battling under the influence of Brahms; he may have finished his own man, but he left few descendants and only faint impressions on the mainstream of European music.

title: Whitbread Racers Prepare for Final Leg
description: WHEN the bell rings atop the Yacht Club Argentina, signaling the arrival of a yacht in the 27,000-mile Whitbread Round-the-World Race, thousands of bathers leave the Playa Grande, the most fashionable beach in this seaside resort, and rush to the adjoining pier to watch it dock. Cameras click, and youngsters scramble to hang on mooring lines and plead to be taken aboard.

title: Donald McAllister Jr.  Weds Ellen Brenton
description: Ellen Griffith Brenton and Donald H. McAllister Jr., officers with the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company in New York, were married yesterday in Kingston, Pa. The Rev. Lyle E. Scott performed the ceremony at Grace Episcopal Church.

title: DENNIS BRUTUS HAS EARNED A PLACE IN AMERICA
description: To the Editor:

title: POLL FINDS REAGAN POPULARITY RATING MISLEADS
description: Democrats should not worry about attacking President Rea gan and his policies because he is not so popular as they have fea red, four Democratic polltakers have told senators, representativ es and the Democratic National Committee.

title: Around the Nation; U.S. Reaches Agreement On Kentucky Integration
description: The Department of Education, in a step toward settling a discrimination complaint, has provisionally accepted Kentucky's plan to eliminate traces of segregation in its colleges.

title: COURT WEIGHS PROSECUTOR'S ACTIONS IN STOUFFER'S FIRE INQUIRY
description: A former police executive who coordinated the investigation of the 1980 Stouffer's Inn fire in which 26 persons died said this week in Westchester County Court that ''we felt we had an ironclad case'' against Luis Marin.

title: Dr. David Mitchell Press To Wed Marian D. Hersh
description: Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Hersh of Fair Lawn, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Marian Deborah Hersh, to Dr. David Mitchell Press, son of Dr. and Mrs. Seymour Press of Clifton, N.J.

title: Sara M. Landers To Wed March 27
