description: Mr. and Mrs. John M. Landers of Greenwood, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sara Major Landers, to Richard Gregg Malconian, son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard L. Malconian of Needham ,Mass.

title: The Region in Summary; Riding Shotgun On the Subways
description: Apart from the unprecedented rate at which it occurs, New York subway crime is hardly new. Neither was a plan proposed last week to put transit police officers on evening trains.

title: Ann Crittenden Bride Of John B. Henry 2d
description: Ann Crittenden, a reporter for The New York Times, was married yesterday to John B. Henry 2d, chairman and president of Crop Genetics International, N.V., a plant-genetics company in New York. The ceremony was performed by Justice Arnold G. Fraiman of the State Supreme Court in his chambers.

title: Carey Names a Panel To Monitor Nutrition
description: Governor Carey has appointed a Nutrition Watch Committee to monitor the effect of Federal cutbacks in food programs on the diets of New Yorkers.

title: THEY COULD AGAIN
description: In the year between President Reagan's inauguration and his first State of the Union Message last week, a remarkable change has taken place in the state and local governments that he wants to shower with authority. It is a change that could be critical to the success or failure of his ambitious plan to turn over the bulk of Federal programs to state capitals.

title:
Dining Out;
NEW ARMONK SPOT MAKING A MARK
description: OPEN only six weeks, Covington in Armonk has already earned a reputation as a congenial gathering place and as a serious restaurant offering innovative and often superior dishes. Adjoining the beautiful imported English pub, the dining room repeats its intimate ambience in the dark paneling, deep red and dark green walls. Upstairs, the main dining room with pale walls, blond furniture and soft classical music is less moody and has its own charm.

title: HAITIANS ATTRACT SYMPATHETIC NOTICE
description: CONNECTICUT, a state settled by waves of immigrants, is beginning to fathom the size, needs and problems of its latest newcomers, the Haitians.

title:
Investing;
IN STOCKS, DON'T FOLLOW THE LEADER
description: T HE Denver Western Petroleum Corporation is a tiny oil and gas company with nine employees. A year ago, for the week that ended Jan. 16, 1981, trading volume in its stock totaled 1,933,000 shares, putting it second among the 10 most actively traded stocks in the over-the-counter market. It closed the week at a bid of 1 3/8.

title: Washington; A VIEW FROM THE ALPS
description: President Reagan sent a cheerful message to many world political and business leaders meeting here this week at the European Management Forum. It arrived during the worst snowstorm of the year here and got a rather chilly response.

title: The Nation in Summary; Flights of Fancy At the F.A.A.?
description: As if it needed another headache, the Federal Aviation Administration learned last week that its parent agency, the Department of Transportation, will investigate charges of cheating and grade manipulation at the F.A.A. air traffic controllers academy in Oklahoma City. The inquiry was requested by the House Post Office and Civil Service Committee, whose own investigation has turned up evidence of 26 cases of grade rigging.

title: De Paul Beats Syracuse, 92-87
description: The crowd of 26,143, the second largest to see a college basketball game in a campus arena, worked overtime to provide the Syracuse Orangemen with imagination and inspiration today. The Orangemen, pushed by the crowd and in a rare role as an underdog in their Carrier Dome, played beyond themselves.

title: ROCHESTER TRIPS, REGION MAY STUMBLE
description: If Murphy had been a nuclear engineer, he might have written his law about ''steam generators.'' That deceptively simple but crucial part of most of the nation's nuclear power plants can -and has - gone wrong with a distressing frequency. It did it again last week, when a tube in a generator burst at the Robert E. Ginna reactor in upstate New York, leading to the worst accident since Three Mile Island.

title: Banker Is Fiance Of Martha Reilly
description: Mr. and Mrs. Francis X. Reilly Jr. of Barrington, Ill., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Martha Jane Reilly, to William Rossiter Hinchman Jr., son of Mrs. Hinchman of Little Silver, N.J., and the late Mr. Hinchman.

title: ON THE CENTENARY OF JAMES JOYCE
description: ON Tuesday, whether or not the groundhog sees its shadow, we shall all have occasion to meditate on the long shadow of James Joyce (born Feb. 2, 1882; died Jan. 13, 1941). Writing as we know it is unthinkable without him; imagine physics without Einstein.

title: CREDIBLE IS NOT THE SAME AS VIABLE
description: IHAVE two basic beliefs about public financing of election campaigns: It is good public policy and it is not a cure for what ails New Jersey politically.

title: A NOVEL OF CATHOLICISM IN ENGLAND
description: SOULS AND BODIES By David Lodge. 244 pp. New York: William Morrow & Co. $12.50THE person who writes about religion must inevitably discuss sex, marriage, children, authority, free will, death and all the other cheery ingredients of conventional satire. When this novel by David Lodge appeared in Britain in 1980, its title was ''How Far Can You Go?'' - that horribly simple question asked by sexually frustrated Catholics in the 1950's. That title sets the tone better than ''Souls and Bodies.'' This is for the most part a gently humorous novel about the social implications of Catholicism for an English person over the past 30 years. Mr. Lodge invents a dozen or so characters - he is quite frank about his inventing - and allows them to illustrate various aspects of Catholic bewilderment, disillusionment, doublethink and paradox. The novel begins like a fun-poking magazine article about churchgoing students (''Why have they come here, and what do they expect to get out of it?''), continues in a schematic way, partly as novel and partly as an essay (''Patience, the story will resume shortly.''), and then all the loose ends are bound up in the novelties of Catholic modernism and the author tips his readers a wink.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; The Bulletin Lowers Its Flag
description: There has been another death in the afternoon. The Bulletin, a Philadelphia institution for 134 years and at one time America's largest P.M. newspaper, ceased publication last week for reasons that have become all too familiar.

title: 'MEN CAN'T FEEL GUILTY FOREVER'
description: THERE is a new protest in the land. Its voice is somewhat confused, somewhat angry, but it is steadily gathering strength. Men are slowly emerging from post-chauvinist shock and are asking questions. They have learned that they are people, too, and are beginning to demand a piece of the liberated pie.

title: Moon Guide
description: To the Editor:

title:
Art;
2 SHOWS: PHOTOS AND DRAWINGS
description: THE Photo Graphics Workshop in New Canaan has until Tuesday an interesting retrospective exhibition of the photographs of Larry Colwell, a founder of the workshop who died in 1972.

title: ITALIAN COMMUNISTS LOOK GOOD BY BEING BAD TO MOSCOW
description: The diatribes last week between the Muscovite and Roman Communists - the largest Communist parties of Eastern and Western Europe - are receiving intense attention, not only in Rome and Moscow, but in Paris and Prague and other European capitals. Many commentators in the United States and Western Europe, analyzing the bitter exchanges in the party newspapers, are reminded of the Soviet ruptures with Yugoslavia in 1948 and with China in the 1960's, which raised specters of war a nd froze relations between those Communist countries in enduring chills.

title: The World in Summary; Haig, Gromyko Talk 'Soberly'
description: Diplomacy sometimes consists of going through the motions - trading familiar arguments, expecting no breakthrough, watching for a sign that the wind could be shifting. Alexander M. Haig Jr. and Andrei A. Gromyko kept the East-West ball rolling last week through eight hours of ''very sober'' talks in Geneva.

title: CHINESE ON L.I.: THE YEARS OF CHANGE
description: WEST HEMP STEAD TIEN KOU, the ''heavenly hound,'' represent s faithfulness and dependability in Chinese mythology. So when t he members of the Chinese Center on Long Island gather tomorrow evening at the House ofChang restaurant in Valley Stream to celebrat e the Year of the Dog, they know that they have been faithful to the ir cultural heritage, just as their parents would have wished them to be.

title: JAPANESE CARS HELD LESS SAFE, BUT REPORT IS CRITICIZED
description: ARE Japanese small cars less safe than American cars of comparable size?

title: IT WAS TOUGH MEDICINE, BUT G.D. SEARLE BREATHES EASIER NOW
description: SKEPTICISM and trepidation abounded at G.D. Searle & Company when Donald H. Rumsfeld took charge in 1977 as president and chief executive. There was trepidation because he was known as an ax man. There was skepticism because Mr. Rumsfeld had no corporate business experience, whatever the number of top Government posts he had held, and he was also an outsider - the first non-Searle to head the company in its 90-year history.

title: A REMATCH IN PRO BOWL
description: Honolulu, Jan. 30 (AP)- A rematch of the Super Bowl XVI quarterbacks will be featured in the Pro Bowl Sunday, with Joe Montana leading the National Football Conference against Ken Anderson and the American Football Conference.

title:
Numismatics;
BIG AUCTIONS SCHEDULED
description: The coin market, like the weather, has been cold and inhospitable lately; prices have been ''sub-freezing'' and activity has been sharply reduced. But now, like a midwinter thaw, comes the prospect of two important auction sales which should help induce chilled collectors and investors to take their funds out of cold storage.

title: WRITERS OF THE PURPLE SAGE
description: Decades ago, as a graduate student in American literature at Columbia University, I chose, as the subject of my master's thesis, Zane Grey. My advisers dismissed my choice as ''not being important enough.'' I'v e never forgiven them. MARCIA MAGILL New York City

title: CENSUS UNIT PLANS FURTHER CUTBACKS
description: The Census Bureau, which has had to cancel or delay some of its population reports because of budget cuts, is planning new layoffs of 500 employees and partial furloughs for the remaining 5,400. The furloughed employees would be off without pay one day out of every 10 working days for at least 100 days.

title: Paperback Best Sellers; MASS MARKET
description: Mass-market paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: Bureaucracy and Love in China
description: As an American with a Chinese wife, who spends his vacations at her family's homes in Canton, Shanghai and Hankou, I can appreciate the tribulations of Judith Shapiro, but find her ideas unusual (''The Rocky Course of Love in China,'' Dec. 13). For example, Heng's desire to be close to a foreign woman is no different from that of countless young Chinese.

title: Around the Nation; 2 White Policemen Freed In Black Suspect's Death
description: A judge on Friday dismissed reckless homicide charges against two white police officers in the death of a 22-year-old black man in their custody last July.

title: HISTORY TAUGHT BY A SURVIVOR
description: JOSEPH GITMAN of Great Neck might well be a bitter man. In 1939, a few weeks after his graduation from the Warsaw Theological Seminary, the Germans invaded Poland. It was the end of his plans to follow the footsteps of his father, Eliot, into the rabbinate. In the wartime years that followed, all of his family - his father; his mother, Rebecca, and his two sisters and a brother - were killed by the Germans.

title: A NOT SO FOND FAREWELL TO REGGIE JACKSON
description: IAM a high school English teacher. My department chairman, Don Ryan, often s ays, ''No one acts out of character.'' I thought of these words i n the last week with the loss to New York of Reggie Jackson.

title: DESPITE PULLOUT, QADDAFI STILL HAS AN EYE ON CHAD
description: Despite his withdrawal of troops from Chad, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi of Libya still seems intent on influencing events here, and African and Western diplomats acknowledge that this involvement could become sharper when he becomes chairman of the Organization of African Unity in mid-1982.

title: Miss Regan, A Teacher, To Be Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. John MacVeigh Regan Jr. of New York and Watch Hill, R.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Prudence Rindell Regan, to Peter Seth Hallarman, son of Dr. and Mrs. Edwin Hallarman of Roslyn, L. I., and Boca Raton, Fla.

title: PRESIDENT'S PLAN MUST QUIET DOUBTS CONCERNING FAIRNESS
description: FOR months, the suspense had been building. Would Ronald Reagan would remain true to himself? The surprise last week was how true he turned out to be.

title: The Nation in Summary; Opening the Book On Agent Orange
description: The herbicides that the Air Force let fly during the Vietnam war are still spreading consternation. The New York Times reported last week that Vietnam veterans had obtained most of an unpublished Air Force history of Agent Orange and other chemicals, used to destroy vegetation shielding Vietcong forces and later blamed by American veterans for a variety of physical and genetic ills.

title: A Visit With Lewis Carroll
description: I greatly appreciated Morton Cohen's article, ''Christmas With Lewis Carroll'' (Dec. 20). But couldn't he have squeezed in the greatest accolade of all time from a father to a son? And hast thou slain the Jabberwock? Come to my arms, my beamish boy! O frabjous day! Callooh! Callay! He chortled in his joy.

title: IS IT TIME FOR A 'PORGY' AT THE MET?
description: To the Editor:

title: WHAT'S DOING IN KEY WEST
description: Key West has been lazing through the pleasant interval between the year-end holidays and the start, tomorrow, of Old Island Days, which coincide with the height of the winter season. The lull gave Conchs (pronounced conks), native Key Westers, time to refurbish for the busy days when visitors swell the population from 30,000 to nearly 100,000.

title: THEY WORK ON KIBBUTZIM AND TOUR THE WORLD
description: Israel's Kibbutz Chamber Orchestra happily juggles questions no other ensemble would dream of asking: Would, for example, Mira Tischler's hand - injured while driving a tractor -heal in time for the orchestra's current tour of the United States? It did, and she will play principal flute at its Carnegie Hall concert next Wednesday night.

title: Magazines
description: To the Business Editor Magazine publishers were stunned when they read ''The Gloss Fades From Magazines'' (Jan. 10). Stunned because it gave your readers a very false impression of the health of our industry.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: ''MOMUS,'' my old friend the 11th edition of the Encyclopaedia Britannica tells me, ''in Greek mythology'' was ''the son of Nut (night), the personification of sensoriousness. He is frequently mentioned in Lucian as the lampooner of the gods. He is represented sometimes as a young, sometimes as an old man, wearing a mask and carrying a fool's bauble.''

title: Miss Parkinson, Brant R. Smith To Wed June 19
description: Mr. and Mrs. Samuel D. Parkinson of Syosset, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Terry Parkinson, to Brant Richard Smith, son of Capt. Richard C. Smith, U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. Smith of Springfield, Va.

title: PRICE OF U.S. BEEF EXPECTED TO HOLD UNTIL SUMMER
description: Although the number of beef cattle in the nation's feeding pens this week was the lowest in five years, the total supply of fattened beef was not dropping. Retail prices were not expected to rise until early summer, and not by very much then.

title: HOOFERS ARE ON TAP IN A MOVIE PREMIERE
description: ''WHEN the old timers go, when those old hoofers go, it'll be sad unless someone tries to keep it alive,'' said Phil Black. ''I danced like the white and the colored,'' said John Bubbles. ''I could do forward and back slides like the white folks. In 1919, we went to New York, I had to put blackface on and the white dancers put cork on their faces to look black. You had to be everything other than what you were to get on the stage.''

title: NEW ENTHUSIASM SURPRISES FEMINISTS
description: WOMEN in Connecticut are signing up in large numbers to work for what has become a last-ditch effort to save the proposed equal rights amendment.

title: CONSUMER RATES

Dance;
RONDO COMPANY REVIVES 2 WORKS
description: WATCHING veteran modern dancers from the 1940's revive their works is an unusual treat, but it is one that Westchester's Rondo Dance Theater will provide in a performance Tuesday at 8 P.M. at Marymount College in Tarrytown. The program will be repeated March 5 and 6 on the Purchase campus of the State University of New York.

title: Detroit REMEMBER "souped-up"? Peel out, lay rubber, agitate the gravel?  The Little Old Lady from Pasadena?
description: They live on, not just in memory, but out there in the street and on the strip. Like the hunted remnants of some deposed royal family, American hot-rodders - feared close to extinction not long ago - are surviving and even thriving by skillfully adapting to the hostile world of fuel-economy rules, safety regulations, antipollution devices, and they would point out, a gradual crushing of the spirit of American individualism.

title: PHILANTHROPIC COALITION TO EXPAND AID ABROAD
description: In recent years, American philanthropies have given low priority to foreign assistance and international issues, but a group of key foundations and corporate contributors have now joined to stimulate interest and financial support for these activities.

title: Fashion; CREATED WITH A LEG TO STAND ON
description: Lucky is the lady with good-looking legs, for this may be one of her finest fashion hours. Influential designers in Paris, Milan and New York have included decidedly shortened hemlines in their spring collections.

title: No Headline
description: This Week:

title:
Antiques;
FINE OLD LINENS COMING BACK INTO FAVOR AGAIN
description: RUTHERFORD FOR many older people, fine linens and laces never went away. For a middle generation, they were swept away by World War II, women leaving the home to work and turning to the clean lines of ''modern design.''

title: HIGHBROW MUSIC TO HUM
description: This Thursday, Feb. 4, at the Dorothy Chandler Pavillion in Los Angeles, the flutist James Galway will step before the Los Angeles Philharmonic and retell in music the legend of the Pied Piper of Hamelin.

title: A KIND WORD FOR WINTER
description: Eleanor Perenyi, the author of ''Green Thoughts; a Writer in the Garden,'' lives in Stonington, Conn. By Eleanor Perenyi

title: Connecticut Guide; ICE HARVEST FESTIVAL
description: The iceman cometh this winter as in few win ters past. Several oldfashioned ice-harvesting festivals have be en the result, includingone to be held from noon to 2 this afternoon at The Inn, Lake Waramaug, in New Preston.

title: MILITARY TOLD TO LOWER BARRIERS TO WOMEN'S SERVICE
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger has ordered the services to break down barriers against the use of women in the military at the same time the Pentagon has limited the number of women who may enlist. Mr. Weinber ger, in a memorandum to civilian leaders of the Army, Navy and Air Force, said, ''This department must aggressively break down those re maining barriers that prevent us from making the fullestuse of the ca pabilities of women.''

title: HIGHER DOG LICENSE FEES SOUGHT
description: Three of the five animal shelters operated in New York City by the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals - the only shelters in the city that accept all unwanted animals -were closed yesterday.

title: BONN IS REVIEWING POSITION ON SOVIET
description: The West German Foreign Ministry, acknowledging in an internal report that mistrust has grown among the allies about Bonn's policies toward Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union, has started a re-examination of possible contradictions in its positions.

title: READING & MISREADING
description: ON LEARNING TO READ The Child's Fascination With Meaning. By Bruno Bettelheim and Karen Zelan. 306 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $13.95.

title: JACK GILFORD REVISITS 'ALEICHEM'
description: Jack Gilford is a comedian turned actor, which is neither to put him down nor to elevate him to some starchy pantheon. It is merely to put forth the paradox of a man who, as stand-up, never did the oneliners that were comic staple, but, in theater, delivered a one-liner so powerful that it proved to be a show-stopper. And now, nearly 30 years later, he is doing it again, and more, in a revival of Arnold Perl's ''The World of Sholom Aleichem,'' which opens Thursday at the Rialto.

title:
LONG ISLAND HOUSING;
FORECLOSURE HOMES OPEN DOORS TO MANY BUYERS
description: HOUSES that are attractively priced and financed are available from the Department of Housing and Urban Development and the Veterans Administration.

title:
Business Forum;
JOBS AND IMPORTS: WE CAN'T HAVE BOTH
description: I AM president and chief executive of National Industries Inc. in Montgomery, Ala. Our company's primary products are electrical wiring assemblies and electric antennas for the United States automobile industry. Our sales last year were about $28 million.

title: U.S. Energy Policy And L.I.'s Role
description: The very survival of our nation and the free world is inexorably linked to the availability of energy at a cost that permits its use without jeopardizing our economic stability. I, therefore, view the proposals of the Reagan Administration in this vital area as tantamount to national suicide.

title: Headliners; California Dreamin'
description: Political challenges come in all shapes and sizes, but for Los Angeles Mayor Tom Bradley, each one is basically the same: an obstacle to be met and surmounted. So no one was really surprised last week when Mr. Bradley announced his campaign to become Governor of California.

title: Business Conditions; RAISING MONEY ABROAD
description: Paced by a sharp increase in Canadian placements, activity in international bond markets rose 24 percent last year, to $47.7 billion, according to a survey by Salomon Brothers, the investment banking firm.

title: Reading and Writing; THE READER STRIKES BACK
description: A popular Polish writer in Warsaw who appeared on television to extol martial law found that a number of people expressed their objection to his views by coming to his apartment and returning their copies of his books. I see this as the beginning of a healthy trend, one which will bring the writer and his audience into closer contact. Here are just a few of the variations we may expect. *

title: Mary L. Hanavan Engaged to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Taylor W. Hanavan of Wilmington, Del., have announced the engagemen t of their daughter, Mary Lizbeth Hanavan, to James Hofman, son o f Dr. and Mrs. Emil T. Hofman of South Bend, Ind.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in the Winter Survey of Education on Jan. 10 incorrectly described admissions requirements for the School of General Studies at Columbia University. A high school diploma or an associate degree is a ''minimum'' requirement but not the only one. Students in the program attend regular classes with other Columbia and Barnard College students.

title: Ulysses F. Rible, an Architect Of Los Angeles City Hall, Dies
description: Ulysses F. Rible, a retired architect who helped design the Los Angeles City Hall, has died in a hospital here.

title: Tara Beauregard, Paralegal, Affianced
description: Dr. and Mrs. William H. Crocker of Washington, have announced the engagement of Mrs. Crocker's daughter, Tara Maria Michelle Beauregard, to John Van Husan Whitbeck, son of Mr. and Mrs. Brainerd H. Whitbeck of New York.

title: OPERA: THE MET PUTS ON A NEW 'COSE FAN TUTTE'
description: The chances of anybody's opera company putting together an altogether satisfactory ''Cosi fan tutte'' are not great. Fine Mozart singers are always hard to come by in half-dozen bunches. Conductors with a firm grasp of Mozart's style, with its frequent shifting of mood but over-all unity, seem to be members of a vanishing tribe. Directors with the good sense and refinement to keep out of the way of the music are scarcer than Indian head pennies. Most of all, how can any company nowadays afford the rehearsal time necessary to build a genuine Mozartean ensemble?

title: PARIS'S HARD LINE ENDS WHERE PIPELINE BEGINS
description: ''A Jacobin who becomes a minister doesn't necessarily become a Jacobin minister,'' the French saying goes. It goes more frequently when a new government takes over, since it refers to the chilling effect of office on ideology. It has been a hard few weeks for the French Socialists, the hardest since they took office last spring. First, the Constitutional Council rejected part of their nationalization program and they were forced to rewrite it, at the cost of money, embarrassment and bickering within the ranks. Next, they lost three Assembly seats in by-elections. And finally, with the announcement of the Soviet gas deal, they lost a chunk of mystique.

title: R.M. Blau Fiance Of Linda Wallace
description: Mr. and Mrs. Philip Hansen of Winchester, Mass., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Hansen's daughter, Linda Wallace, to Russell M. Blau, son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Blau of White Plains.

title: Index; International
description: Egyptian chief begins trip to five nations, including U.S. 3 Mrs. Gandhi says India will never attack Pakistan 3 Around the World 4 For Filiponos, salaries are high overseas but so are the abuses 6 Kuwait is first Arab nation on Gulf to permit abortion 7 Soviet says an oil tanker spill caused $900 million of damage 9 West Germany is rethinking its policies toward the Soviet bloc 11 China refuses to criticize Soviet over Polish situation 13 Government/Politics Patience is a virtue for aspiring leaders of bar association 18 Administration to propose limits on habeas corpus petitions 19 Tenants say store renovations preceded collapse of building 37 Wiretap decision upset on appeal - conviction reinstated 45 Albany Notes: Carey's departure opens many doors 47 General Slaying of couple and infants leads to $10 million in cocaine 1 Around the Nation 24 Roosevelt centennial celebrated at Hyde Park 32 Suspect in killing of trooper placed on 10 most-wanted list 47 Industry/Labor Mine operator ordered to pay $236,400 fine in 1976 disaster 23 Education/Welfare End of graduate student loan pro- gram planned 28 Report stress es success of minor- ites studen ts in City University 50 Arts/Entertainment Outlet Book Company buys Ar- lington House Publishers 50 Mordecai Shehori gives piano re- cital at 92d Street Y 50 Margarethe von Trotta film stud- ies two ''Sisters'' 50 Musical Elements gives program of premieres 50 City Ballet offers ''Irish Fanta- sy'' and ''Chaconne'' 50 ''The Workroom.'' postwar re- flections, is staged 50 Met Opera presents Mozart's ''Cosi fan tutte'' 50 Museum of American Folk Arts seeks zoning change 51 Roger Nierenberg directs 4th event in Juilliard Festival 51 Style

title: Writers of the Purple Sage
description: Russell Martin's ''Writers of the Purple Sage'' (Dec. 27) was a healthy corrective to Northeastern smugness: John Updike's implying that to be a serious contemporary writer one must live between Portsmouth, N.H., and Washington, D.C.; William Styron's referring to ''North Dakota or one of those other states that doesn't exist.''

title: EMPLOYERS DEFENDED IN COAST 'SLAVERY' CASE
description: Several of the Los Angeles-area residents suspected of using Indonesian aliens as ''slave'' labor in their homes and businesses are Indonesians themselves, an attorney representing them said today.

title: HABEAS CORPUS CURBS SOUGHT BY REAGAN AIDE
description: The Reagan Administration will propose major restrictions on the rights of convicts to file habeas corpus petitions asking Federal courts to review their cases, Attorney General William French Smith said today.

title: WASHINGTON
description: BEFORE the speech, the Democrats talked about the economy. After the speech, the Democrats talked about the economy. And anyone who thinks the Democrats are likely to switch and start emphasizing their differences with President Reagan over grand concepts of federalism just hasn't been reading the same polls they have.

title: MONEY, POLITICS TO SHAPE REGULAR SESSION
description: HARTFORD ON the heels of a turbulent special session that lasted nearly 10 weeks and only partially solved the state's fiscal problems, the General Assembly will convene here Wednesday for a three-month regular session that could be almost as contentious.

title: TARANTULA HOBBYIST SPINS WEB OF INTEREST
description: THE county press office will be revising its list of most unusual visitors to County Executive Alfred B. DelBello's ninth-floor office, following last week's visit by more than 100 tarantulas. The visitors included a large example of the largest species of tarantula, known as the Theraphosi leblondi. This particular guest was a hefty female with a 10-inch legspan who spent much of her time sulking on a large piece of white poster board, conveniently provided for the benefit of photographers. Madame Leblondi, it seems, did not like Westchester's cold weather or did she appreciate all the attention.

title: Music; DEBUTS: ADDED SPICE
description: THREE conductors are to make their area debuts with major symphony orchestras this week. On Tuesday and Wednesday, the Hartford Symphony's baton will be wielded by the Danish maestro Ole Schmidt, much acclaimed for his first American performances on the West Coast a few seasons ago and renowned in audiophile circles as conductor of the London Symphony's cycle of symphonies by Carl Nielsen, a fellow Dane. Not surprisingly, Mr. Schmidt has chosen a Nielsen symphony, the dramatic Fifth, as a focal point of his first Hartford concert. This will be accompanied by Handel's ''Water Music Suite'' and Glazunov's Violin Concerto. Making his Hartford debut at these programs will be the gifted young American violinist Joseph Swensen. Both concerts begin at 8:15 P.M. in Bushnell Memorial Hall. The reservations number is 278-1450.

title: Beaux Arts Trio Concert
description: The Beaux Arts Trio will play trios by Haydn, Ives and Tchaikovsky at the Abraham Goodman House, 129 West 67th Street, on Feb. 22, at 8 P.M.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; Bar Stands Up For the Be nch
description: Raising what may become the legal profession's battle cry for 1982, the head of the American Bar Association last week called on the group's 290,000 members to ''join as partners and companions in arms'' in opposing curbs on the power of the courts.

title: 58 FOOD ESTABLISHMENTS CITED
description: The Copper Hatch II, a restaurant at 380 Amsterdam Avenue that was listed by the New York City Health Department as a violator of the health code, should not have been placed on the list, the department now says.

title: WHY BUSINESS WON'T INVEST
description: EUPHORIA swept through the business community last January when President Reagan took office. Finally, executives figured, rebuilding America's industrial might had become something more than a vision. In a matter of months, fewer government regulations and smaller tax bills would create an investment boom that would eventually make American manufacturers competitive again.

title: Why a Juror Must Wait and Wait
description: The proper and plaintive plea posed by Elaine Hauptman (''Doesn't a Juror Have Rights Too?,'' Opinion Page, Jan. 10) warrants a serious and sympathetic response. As an attorney with 40 years at the trial bar, most of which has been in all Nassau and Suffolk County courts, may I attempt a reply.

title: N.B.A. THINKS ABOUT CHANGES
description: L ARRY O'BRIEN was looking very relaxed, indeed very commissionerlike amid the simple elegance of his office 15 floors above a bustling and breezy, cold Fifth Avenue in midtown. Outside, darkness began to cover the view of St. Patrick's Cathedral to the south and Rockefeller Center to the west. A hectic day was nearing an end. So, his head was back, his collar and tie hung loose and his feet rolled lazily atop his slightly cluttered desk.

title: FLAWLESS SUBWAY SYSTEM PRESCRIBED FOR CITY
description: Imagine a single subway car, without conductor or motorman, silently gliding into an almost-deserted station as soon as passengers step off an escalator to the platform.

title: By Gary R. Goldstein; A scuba diver's guide
description: I have been to major scuba-diving destinations all over the world, but have never seen fish so large or so abundant as around Heron Island in the Great Barrier Reef.

title: Music View; THE STRUGGLE BETWEEN KNOWING AND FEELING
description: Did you ever sit at a concert knowing that the performance was wrong but feeling it was right? Or, as the late pianist and psychologist Jimmy Durante put it: ''Did you ever have the feeling that you wanted to go, and still have the feeling that you wanted to stay?'' That sort of conflict between knowing and feeling is regularly felt by serious listeners who go to hear music with firmly based preconceptions. In many ways, these people are among the brightest, if not invariably the best, of music listeners. Some of them are music critics, for whom the firm preconception is invaluable - one of the tools of the trade.

title: Gretzky on Way To Howe Record
description: To the Sports Editor: With the current offensive explosion in the National Hockey League, there is no reason why Wayne Gretzky shouldn't double the career scoring record. It took the career leader, Gordie Howe, 26 years to set the standard of more than 1,800 points.

title: CONTINENTAL IS LEAGUE OF HOPE
description: The Continental Basketball Association, which held its All-Star Game at Byrne Meadowlands Arena today, is the kind of league that allows one of its franchises to accept grain in exhange for season tickets.

title: LIBRARY 'EXERCISES': ADDITIONAL CHAPTERS
description: I was amused by and sympathetic to Harry Schatz in ''Exercising by the Book.'' Reading the titles of books on both top and bottom shelves is indeed a problem not only for the public, but also for the library's staff.

title: CRIME
description: Perhaps David Keith Cohler is trying too hard in his second novel, FREEMARTIN (Little, Brown, $12.95). It has none of the promise shown in ''Gamemaker,'' which was published in 1980. The locale is New York, and the hero is Sam Knight, head of the Special Operations Squad of the N.Y.P.D. The daughter of a wealthy man is murdered and mutilated in the third such murder of its kind. So the big brains of the Special Operations Squad set to work. Everything is too pat, including the portentous and stagey diary of the criminal.

title: CONTRARY TREE GETS REPRIEVE
description: IT is 30 years old. From one of three fragile twigs stuck in the ground it took root. It survived all the vicissitudes of poor soil, drought, winterkill and neglect. Its companions gave up the struggle. This hopeful sprig made it. It wasn't in the best spot, but it flourished. From its base three main trunks put out, divided by more as it stretched skyward. Over the course of years one had to be lopped, after a small tornado, for the safety of the house.

title: STABLE ARCHITECTURE: FROM STARK TO ELEGANT
description: LITCHFIELD ''A HORSE,'' said Leland Stanford, a Govern or of California and a founding partner of the Central Pacific Railr oad, ''should be treated like a gentleman.''

title: WILLIAMS OF KNICKS DRAWS SUSPENSION
description: Sly Williams, a starting forward for the Knicks, was suspended indefinitely yesterday by Coach Red Holzman. Holzman decided on the suspension after a lengthy meeting yesterday with David A. (Sonny) Werblin, president of Madison Square Garden Corporation, which owns the Knicks, and Eddie Donovan, the general manager, during the National Basketball Association meetings at the Grand Hyatt Hotel. Those three, plus Jack Krumpe, the new Knick president, also discussed the Williams situation at a dinner meeting Friday night.

title:
GARDENING;
BRINGING A BIT OF SPRING INDOORS
description: SO your car stalled in a snowdrift during the last cold snap, and your fingers and toes were nearly frozen by the time you reached the phone booth to call for help. And you've just received the latest fuel bill and swear that you haven't seen numbers that large since the last time the national debt was printed in the newspaper.

title: There Is a Better Bet
description: ''Watch out for the pea and the shells,'' said a voice inside the Reagan Administration. Just so.

title: THE COMPUTER NOW COMES TO THE COCKPIT
description: In what would be one of the largest nonmilitary projects undertaken by the nation, the Federal Aviation Administration last week proposed a 20-year multibillion dollar overhaul of the aging air traffic control system. The program would replace ground control computers, now subject to breakdowns because of increasing demands on their services, with newer, faster machines designed to improve safety while using fewer human supervisors.

title: Gallery View; 'THE HAIRY WHO' AND OTHER MESSAGES FROM CHICAGO
description: Something astonishing in the way of art, music or literature must one day come out of the great wind-bruised city of Chicago. Andrei Biely's novel ''Petersburg'' has to find its equivalent in Chicago, for instance. Saul Bellow got near to it, more than once. The buildings are there. The people are there. The landscape is there, and the waterscape, too. The implacable climate is there. Chicago in literature is still one of the great unfulfilled subjects.

title: 2 Chosen for Pulitzer Board
description: James Hoge, the publisher of The Chicago Sun-Times, and Eugene L. Roberts Jr., executive editor and senior vice president of The Philadelphia Inquirer, have been elected to the Pulitzer Prize Board. Their election was announced by Michael I. Sovern, president of Columbia University, which administers the prizes, given annually for journalism, music, drama and letters. Lee Hills, editorial chairman emeritus of Knight-Ridder Newspapers, will retire from the board in April, Mr. Sovern said.

title: Economic Affairs
description: L AST March, I wrote a column on Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's economic policies and asked whether our war on inflation would result in the same economic devastation as hers. I suggested that we might escape with fewer casualties, because we started with less severe problems.

title: Best Sellers
description: Jx FICTION 1 1 15 AN INDECENT OBSESSION, by Colleen McCullough. (Harper & Row, $13.50.) A nurse and her charges in a special-care ward of a World War II hospital. 2 5 11 SPRING MOON, by Bette Bao Lord. (Harper & Row, $14.95.) Tradition and revolution in modern China seen through the life of an upper-class family. 3 2 20 THE HOTEL NEW HAMPSHIRE, by John Irving. (Dutton/Henry Robbins, $15.50.) Life with an eccentric family. 4 6 15 RABBIT IS RICH, by John Updike. (Knopf, $13.95.) Harry Angstrom of ''Rabbit, Run'' returns in the chips but unfulfilled. 5 3 39 NOBLE HOUSE, by James Clavell. (Delacorte, $19.95.) A British-Chinese struggle for control of one of Hong Kong's oldest trading houses. 6 7 13 REMEMBRANCE, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $14.95.) An Italian princess, in quest of romance, finds frustration, then fulfillment in America. 7 8 25 CUJO, by Stephen King. (Viking, $13.95.) Monsters haunt a New York family seeking peace in rural Maine.

title: BEVERLY REID IS ENGAGED
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles Nash Reid Jr., of Armonk, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Beverley Willis Reid, to Cameron Arthur Hatt on , son of Mrs. Elemer Horvath of Mahopac, N.Y., and the late Charles Hatton of Washington, D.C. The wedding is planned for May.

title: Things Are Seldom What They Seem
description: My ex-self sympathizes with Jacqueline Shaheen in her frustrations expressed in her Jan. 3 piece, ''Has Fakery Become Reality?'' My new self is becoming resigned to the increasing Kafkaesque quality of life in Amerika, where things are seldom what they seem.

title: U.S. ECONOMIC WOES CLOUD CANADIAN PARLEY
description: The United States is casting a deep shadow over a meeting next week of federal and provincial leaders that will try to find a way out of one of Canada's worst economic recessions since the Great Depression of the 1930's.

title: The Nation in Summary; Intent Matters On Voting Rights
description: Though President Reagan professes to be perplexed about his low standing among black Americans, last week provided a good example of why. He went out of his way to say in his State of the Union that he strongly supports a 10-year extension of the Voting Rights Act, but Attorney General William French Smith urged the Senate to substantially revise the version of the act that was overwhelmingly approved by the House of Representatives and had already been endorsed by almost two-thirds of the Senate.

title: Future Events Across the River
description: Tickets to the following events may be obtain ed from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated.. See it Now Feb. 4 - Get a jump on the Joneses at a private screening of Ken Burns's ''Brooklyn Bridge'' at Bargemusic, Fulton Ferry Landing in Brooklyn. The 55-minute documentary produced for the 1983 centennial celebration wont't be shown on public television till spring. There'll be a gala reception beforehand at the nearby River Cafe and cake and coffee afterwards. Proceeds from the evening will help support the capital campaign of Bargemusic, a converted coffee barge serving as a center for the presentation of chamber music and other cultural and community events. Tickets, $125, include limousine service from the Waldorf-Astoria and back. Call 643-4030.

title: MOON GUIDE
description: To the Editor:

title: A NOVEL OF TERRORISM IN GERMANY
description: THE SAFETY NET By Heinrich Boll. Translated by Leila Vennewitz. 314 pp. New Y ork: Alfred A. Knopf. $13.95.1949 Heinrich Boll published his first book, a short novel called ''The Train Was on Time,'' which was about a German soldier traveling to what he knows will be his death on the Russian front. Two years later a short story of his won a prize given by Group 47, the writers' organization formed in 1947 that would be at the center of German writing for the next 20 years. Since that time, after a steady output of novels, stories, radio plays and essays, Boll has become West Germany's most widely read serious writer, a Nobel laureate (1972) and, along with Gunter Grass, one of the world's most prominent representatives of German literature.

title: The Week in Business; LEADING INDICATORS RISE; G.M. CUTS PRICES
description: Leading indicators of the economy rose six-tenths of a percent in December after several months of declines, the Commerce Department said. The rise signaled a possible climb out of recession. New orders for durable goods rose 1.6 percent in December.

title:
Comment;
ON GETTING STARTED
description: I BELIEVE I surpass ''Harvard's Student Entrepreneurs'' (Jan. 17) for I started a business when I was 13 years old. One need not be so old to remember the slaughter and meat-packing houses on First Avenue where the United Nations now stands. Among the giants of the industry, Swift and Armour and U.S. Dressed Beef, was a small one-story stall run by A. Cucuzzo. He did not handle lambs, calves or even chickens. He dealt only in rabbits, living and dead, and sold them to the French and Italian residents of the neighborhood. His little van also made deliveries to the German housewives in uptown Yorkville.

title: Wren's Epitaph
description: To the Editor:

title: Alabama 77, Tennessee 72
description: Cliff Windham scored 7 of his 15 points in overtime to help Alabama (16-2 and 8-2) hand Tennessee (14-4 and 9-1)its first loss in the Southeastern Conference . With 12 seconds remaining in overtime and Alabama holding a 7 5-72 advantage, Alabama's freshman guard Ennis Whatley steppe d to the foul line to shoot a one-and-one.

title: Topics; HARD CHEESE, FREE SPEECH; Inspections
description: ''We have decided that we are not going to inventory pots and pans.'' The reaction of Michigan's director of social services is that of many state officials to a new Federal law that bars welfare for people with assets of $1,000.

title: THE ADMIRAL VS. THE NAVY
description: RICKOVER By Norman Polmar and Thomas B. Allen. Illustrated. 744 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $20.75.

title: Paperback Talk
description: The games came. Like creatures from outer space, they've invaded the length and breadth of America, finding homes in arcades, bus terminals, gas stations, pizza parlors and delicatessens. They bear bizarre names like Pac-Man, Berzerk, Gorf, Asteroids, Space Invaders and War Lords. They emit strange sounds and flash colorful lights on their screens as millions of teen-age boys and hundreds of thousands of grown men stuff them with quarters to play a video game.

title: Catharine Stevenson Betrothed to Jeffrey Sturgess
description: Mr. and Mrs. James D. Stevenson of Cleveland Heights, Ohio, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Catharine Morley Stevenson, to Jeffrey Charles Sturgess, son of Charles T. Sturgess of Branford, Conn., and Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and the late Jane J. Pastorfield.

title: DAY OF PROTEST ON THE POLISH CRISIS GETS MODEST RESPONSE WORLDWIDE
description: The worldwide day of protest against military rule in Poland proclaimed earlier this month by President Reagan attracted lessthan-capacity crowds yesterday at sites throughout the United States and in Europe and Japan. In Chicago, about 8,000 of the 15,000 seats in the International Amphitheatre were filled for a speech by Secretary of State AlexanderM. Haig Jr. a t a rally in support of the Solidarity labor union in Poland. While speakers assailed the imposition of martial law in Poland last m onth, protesters stood with placards containing slogans such as ''Rus sians Keep Your Bloody Hands Off Poland!'' U.S. Produces a TV Program

title: Film View; JUST WHO DESERVES THE PRAISE (OR BLAME)?
description: Afriend of mine recently bristled with impatience when I described a film as having started off so well that I was doubly disappointed when it went off the track long before it was over. ''Would you say that about someone you'd met for the first time at dinner?'' asked the friend. ''That she'd had a most entertaining beginning over drinks, was very funny and vulnerable over soup, and then turned obvious with the fish? You don't talk about people that way. Why do it with movies?''

title: DO-IT-YOURSELF DREAM CARS GAIN BACKERS
description: Only a decade ago, it was possible to walk into an automobile showroom and order the convertible of one's dreams or a muscle car that set the adrenaline pumping. Those days are gone, and a growing number of people disenchanted with today's production-line offerings are taking things into their own hands. The result is a boom in kit cars - cars you build yourself.

title: THE 'ELECTRONIC CHURCH' RUNS INTO RATINGS TROUBLE
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Richard Zoglin is the television critic for The Atlanta Constitution. By RICHARD ZOGLIN

title: MISS VON TROTTA'S 'SISTERS'
description: Maria (Jutta Lampe) is the more independent of the two siblings in Margarethe von Trotta's ''Sisters,'' and Anna (Gudrun Gabriel) is the more delicate. Miss von Trotta, who co-wrote and directed the film, defines their differences constantly, and does it in a crisp, efficient manner much like Maria's own.

title: 'THE SHOREHAM GETAWAY'
description: I WONDER if I am alone in my confusion and doubt over the introduction of nuclear power to Long Island. I study the informed opinions about Lilco's Shoreham plant very carefully, like the discussions in ''A Tale of Two Power Plants'' and ''Readers Reply'' on the Opinion Page. I am still mixed up, probably b ecause I am just another sorry cynic.

title: DREAM FULFILLED FOR A 'DREAMGIRL'
description: SHERYL LEE RALPH had a dream and she wasn't going to defer it, not even on graduation day. Instead of attending commencement exercises at Rutgers University, where she had been a pre-med student, she got on a bus and went to New York to try out for a commercial.

title: U.S. IS SAID TO PLAN $100 MILLION RISE IN SALVADORAN AID
description: The White House will ask Congress to increase military and economic aid to El Salvador by about $100 million this fiscal year and will seek further increases in the next fiscal year, according to Administration officials. Military ai d for the current fiscal year stands at $25 million and all forms of economic aid total about $110 million. The economic and military aid request for the next fiscal year, which begins Oct. 1, will be in th e President's budget presentation next month and is expected to b e about $300 million.

title: Dr. Carol Landau, Psychologist, Wed
description: Dr. Carol Landau and the Rev. David Atwater Ames were married yesterday at the Manning Chapel at Brown University in Providence, R. I. Bishop George N. Hunt 3d, of the Episcopal Diocese of Rhode Island, and the Rev. Charles A. Baldwin, university chaplain, performed the ceremony.

title: The Need for Black Colleges
description: Dena Kleiman's article, ''Can Black Colleges Survive?'' (Dec. 20), gave the impression that black colleges are needed, if at all, for black students who can't make passing grades in most white colleges. The truth is that the best of the black colleges have academic standards as high as the best white colleges.

title: Theater; 'NIGHT MUST FALL,' VINTAGE '36 THRILLER
description: STAMFORD ''NIGHT MUST FALL'' dates back to 1936, when the playwright Emlyn Williams appeared in his own play opposite May Whitty on Broadway. She went on to Hollywood to recreate her role for the screen opposite Robert Montgomery and Rosalind Russell, with the other roles played by the Broadway cast. Not too long ago, a second but not successful film version, starring Albert Finney, was released.

title: Around the World; Armenian Group Ends Attacks on French Sites
description: An Armenian guerrilla group said today that it would suspend terrorist operations against France because the French authorities had promised a fair trial and political prisoner status for four Armenians jailed in Paris.

title: Q&A
description: Question:I am planning a trip to Italy for five weeks, from the last week in June to the end of July. I would like to find a charter flight to go from Baltimore or Washington or New York to Rome and return. Can you tell me how to go about finding a such a flight? - M.B., Baltimore, Md. Answer:You should begin by consulting a travel agent. You may want to check with an agent in an Italian neighborhood or parish; it is quite possible to find what you want from an ethnic travel agency, that is, one that is situated in an area with lots of people who regularly visit their homel and.

title: EX-INMATES OFFERED RAIL FARE
description: RIVERHEAD THE Riverhead Rotary wants to give prisoners released from the Suffolk County Jail a free ride out of town on the Long Island Rail Road.

title: ALFRED DOOLITTLE IN 'MY FAIR LADY'
description: Stanley Holloway, the actor who gained wide recognition for his portrayal of Eliza Doolittle's father in the original Broadway and London productions of ''My Fair Lady,'' died today in the Nightingale nursing home in Littlehampton, Sussex. He was 91 years old.

title: FOR SOME, A WAR NEVER ENDS
description: JERSEY CITY ALTHOUGH almost 10 years have passed since American military forces left Vietnam, ex-G.I.'s at the Vet Center here are still fighting a stereotype that pictures them as poorly educated psychotics, hooked on drugs, prone to violence and unable to obtain or hold jobs.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A picture caption on page 23 of the Arts and Leisure section today incor- rectly gives the time of a concert to be presented at Carnegie Hall by Shirley Verrett and Grace Bumbry. It is at 3 this afternoon.

title: AUSTRALIAN INSPIRES 300 IN YOUTH TENNIS
description: MOUNT KISCO WHEN John James, an Australian who emigrated to this country seven years ago, talks to young tennis players in the winter program at the Saw Mill River Courts here, they pay close attention. When he has them sweating and puffing in hard drills, they grit their teeth and carry on. They do so out of respect for his credentials.

title: PORTRAIT OF A FAMILY IN HOLOCAUST DAYS
description: ARANKA SIEGAL's first book, ''Upon the Head of the Goat,'' has almost sold out its first printing, the School Library Journal has given it the Best Book of the Year Award and a film crew from the Netherlands has flown to her home in Tarrytown to film her story. On Jan. 25, at the midwinter convention of the American Library Association, the book was selected as the Newbery Honor Book for 1981. This award is one of the most prestigious given for children's literature.

title: Dalkey
description: To the Editor:

title: Art View; FIRST COMES CELEBRITY, THEN THE MONOGRAPH
description: The institution of the expensive, glossy monograph - those profusely illustrated and lavishly produced volumes that are regularly devoted to the works of living artists - is now so much a fixture on the contemporary art scene that its appearance can no longer be counted on to cause much excitement, or even much interest, outside the immediate circle of the artist whose work constitutes its s ubject. It i s more or less assumed that when artists nowadays achieve a cer tain celebrity and affluence, their position on the scene will br ing them - along with invitations to posh dinner parties and r equests for donations to worthy causes -an opportunity to have such a book consecrated to their work. It goes, as they say, with the terr itory.

title: Ideas & Trends in Summary; A Step Closer To Christian Common Ground
description: Ecumenicism has needed a boost and last week it got one. Meeting in Lima, Peru, an international panel of more than 100 Protestant, Orthodox and Roman Catholic theologians endorsed a major document in which they agreed to try to agree.

title: G.M. AND FORD ENTER THE MARKET FOR SMALL PICKUP TRUCKS
description: THOUGH times have gone from dim to grim for much of the auto industry, people are still buying small pick-up trucks.

title: Correction
description: In a Personal Finance graphic on Jan. 3, entitled ''Peformance of Tax-Managed Mutual Funds'' the dates of the funds' performance were transposed. The first column represented 1981 and the second 1980.

title: STAGE: 'THE WORKROOM,' POSTWAR REFLECTIONS
description: Jean-Claude Grumberg's ''The Workroom'' (''L'Atelier'') at the Long Wharf Theater describes, in the author's words, ''ordinary moments in ordinary lives.'' However, the characters in this tailor's workroom have survived a most extraordinary event - World War II fought on their own native soil. It is the memory of that event that is the subtext of a play that reverberates beyond its deceptively narrow boundaries.

title: QUEENS RESIDENTS SALUTE AN 'EVERYDAY HERO'
description: When President Reagan spoke of the ''countless quiet, everyday heroes of American Life'' in his State of the Union Message on Tuesday, he might have been talking about Geraldine Westerberg.

title: VON TROTTA: BY SISTERS OBSESSED
description: -------------------------------------------------------------------- Annette Insdorf, an associate professor at Yale, is writing a book on film and the Holocaust. By ANNETTE INSDORF

title: FOREIGN ACCIDENTS DECLINE, BUT THE U.S. IS STILL SAFEST
description: AMERICANS on the road, unlike Americans in the streets, wreck less havoc on each other than do drivers anywhere else in the world. According to a study by the Motor Vehicle Manufacturers Association, an industry trade group, auto-related deaths in the United States in 1978 numbered 3.4 per million miles traveled, as compared to 7.9 in Germany, 7.2 in France, 5.2 in Japan and 11.9 in Belgium.

title: REPORT STRESSES SUCCESS OF CITY U. MINORITY STUDENTS
description: The role of the City University of New York as a vehicle for the upward mobility of minority students is the underlying theme of a new report on a survey of the graduates of 1979.

title: AN UNCOMFORTABLE, BUT NEEDED, DECISION
description: ILIKE to think of myself as a good-hearted, open-minded liberal. When I consider that perhaps I'm not, I become uneasy. Some people will brand me a narrow-minded segregationist when they hear that, come next September, I will send my daughter, Faye, to private kindergarten at a Hebrew day school.

title: REALIGNING RESPONSIBILITIES MEANS DISMANTLING THE PAST
description: Even as Congress last week marked the 100th anniversary of the birth of Franklin Delano Roosevelt, it took up President Reagan's proposal to dismantle major elements of the Roosevelt legacy.

title: THE HOMELESS FIND WINTER A TRIAL
description: THE death last week of an elderly woman who lived in a cardboard box in Manhattan brought to public consciousness the plight of the homeless poor, who drift like phantoms through cities everywhere. For them, winter is a time of trial.

title: JAZZ: STAN GETZ PLAYS
description: Stan Getz, who turned 55 years old on Feb. 2, has reached a stage in his career when his own experience encompasses a large part of the history of jazz for the last 40 years.

title: More Britons Are Seeking Better Life Abroad
description: ''We want a better life,' ' Moirag Knowles said as she explained why she and her fiance had d ecided to move to Australia. ''It's quite tough here and it's g etting tougher.''

title:
The Careful Shopper;
Some Select Choices An d Prices in Hartsdale
description: First-quality name brand and designer clothing for men and women is carried at discount prices in Hartsdale by Annie Sez, the only New York branch of a New Jersey chain of six stores under that name. Tickets show a ''before discount'' price that represents the average charged at four competing stores, plus gradual reductions and the current price.Final-sale items are not returnable, but other items, including clearly marke d irregulars, can be returned within two weeks for a refund or sto re credit. Sizes are small to extra large for men and 3 to 16 for wom en.

title: A LEVY ON NONRESIDENTS WORKING HERE
description: THE State of Connecticut is faced with an i ncreasing need to improve and expand its transportation system, which affords not only our citizens but also the citizens of other s tates mobility, jobs andeconomic well-being.

title: THE MAKING OF A SECURITIES ANALYST
description: NOTHING quite prepared Robert K. Urquhart for the stack of books on the chemical industry that his boss, Charles Cahn, a senior research analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein & Company, put in front of him last July.

title: AL GREEN FORGES NEW LINKS BETWEEN SECULAR AND SACRED
description: In the early 70's, Al Green was an enormously popular soul singer; indeed, in 1972 he was the best-selling male singer of any style in this country. His hits included ''(I'm So) Tired of Being Alone,'' ''Let's Stay Together,'' ''I'm Still in Love with You'' and ''Look What You Done for Me.'' But his popularity declined in the late 70's, even while his critical reputation was growing higher than ever: his 1978 album, ''Belle,'' made most rock critics' 10-best lists.

title: Cynthia Tufts To Be Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Donald W. Tufts of East Greenwich, R.I., and Annisquam, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Cynthia Ann Tufts, to James Tyner Anderson, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Anderson 3d of Greenwich, Conn.

title: Dining Out; A 'BISTRO' EFFECT IN WESTPORT
description: WESTPORT AMBIENCE in a restaurant is sometimes like sleight of hand to a magician. It goes a long way in disguising what's really going on. Such seems to be the case at Chez Pierre, an old-timer on the Westport restaurant scene.

title: MRS. GANDHI OFFERS TO SIGN PAKISTAN PACT
description: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi offered today to sign a friendship treaty with Pakistan and pledged that India would never attack its neighbor.

title: TV 'DISH' GETS NEW HEARING
description: OYSTER BAY A HEARING on Thursday by the Town of Oyster Bay's Zoning Board of Appeals on the proposed erection of a television transmitting tower holds varying significance to different participants and observers. The hearing is more accurately described as a rehearing on an application from Communications Leasing Inc. that was previously denied by the board.

title: Laurie Hays Sets Wedding in April
description: Laurie Hays and Joseph Fenwick Montaigne, reporters for The Times-Picayune/The States-Item in New Orleans, plan to be married in April. Dr. and Mrs. Richard M. Hays of Greenwich, Conn., have announced their daughter's engagement to the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Montaigne Jr. of Wilmington, Del., and Avalon, N.J.

title: Miss Fleischmann Will Be Married To R. E. Planitzer
description: Mrs. Benno C. Schmidt and Peter F. Fleischmann, both of New York, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ruth Gardner Fleischmann, to Russell Edward Planitzer, a partner of J.H. Whitney & Company, a venture capital investment concern.

title: HOW SUBLETTING POWERS HAVE CHANGED
description: To the Edit or: I am the su btenant in the Conrad v. Third Sutton Realty case cited in the articl e on subletting (''New Issues Rise As Tenants' Power to Sublet Grows, '' Jan. 17). Unlike the extreme situations where tenants have in essence become speculators for personal profit, in this case the sublet rent was exactly the same as the stabilized rentthe landlord would have received if Miss Conrad were still in occupancy.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: THE oldest Roman Catholic school on the Island, St. Boniface Parochial School in Elmont, is celebrating its 125th anniversary this year. Not only is the anniversary a significant event, but also the school can also claim an unusual living link to its past - the 102-year-old daughter of the first teacher at the school.

title: No Headline
description: NEHEMIAH'S 6.82 BREAKS 60-YARD HURDLE MARK

title: Claude D. Fichette, 61, Dead; Ex-Reporter and Cuomo Aide
description: Claude D. Fichette, a political reporter and columnist who became a special assistant to Lieut. Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, died at his home here Thursday, apparently of a heart attack. He was 61 years old.

title: The World in Summary; General Dozier Freed in Major Brigades Defeat
description: Italy's Red Brigades gambled big when they kidnapped an American general Dec. 17 and they lost even bigger. Not only did police last week free Brig. Gen. James L. Dozier, but the 42-day hunt for him turned up scores of terrorist suspects and documents that led to more arrests.

title: THE RIGHT MEDICINE
description: A THEORY OF MEDICAL ETHICS By Robert M. Veatch. 387 pp. New York: Basic Books. $20.95. IN the spri ng of 1972, with American campuses still feeling the aftershocks o f demonstrations against the atrocities in Vietnam, another, smaller protest went almost unremarked. A substantial numberof the graduating class of Harvard Medical School refused to take the Oath of Hippocrates, that ancient affirmation, full of apparentlynoble commitments, which is at once the physician's promise to be good and the traditional, solemn and ultimate rite of passage into the professio nal fold. (''You do solemnly swear, each man by whatever he holds most sacred, that you will be loyal to the profession of medicine and just and generous to its members....'')

title: FILIPINOS ARE FLOCKING TO TAKE OVERSEAS JOBS
description: Some mornings, there are such large crowds outside placement centers for overseas jobs that traffic cannot pass. Unemployment is high here, and a worker can earn up to eight times more abroad than he can make in the Philippines. More than 110 countries recruit workers from this country of 50 million people. The Iraqi Oil Minister, for example, is looking for truck drivers. Japanese nightclubs are hiring entertainers. European families are looking for maids.

title: FOOD
description: THE DUE PROCESS OF BEATING EGG WHITES

title: FEAR OF CRIME IS NOW WOVEN INTO THE FABRIC OF CITY LIVES
description: For New York City residents, wealthy as well as poor, crime is no longer something that happens to other people. It pervades the city, and it has forced changes - some subtle, some dramatic - in the way people live their lives.

title: The Nation in Summary; Williams Trial Broadens Scope
description: A steady drizzle of evidence turned into a downpour last week when Judge Clarence Cooper allowed the prosecution in the murder trial of Wayne B. Williams to introduce evidence that could link Mr. Williams with the deaths of 10 black youths as well as two he is accused of killing.

title: LAMBERTVILLE TRYING TO RECAPTURE ITS OLD LUSTER
description: LAMBERTVILLE BETTER known to some people as the town across the Delaware River from New Hope - an artists' colony that attracts tourists to its restaurants, galleries and shops - this city has nontheless managed to retain its own character.

title: COMMUNIST PAPERS: U.S. SHIFTS POLICY
description: The Treasury Department, facing a lawsuit by the American Civil Liberties Union and other groups, has withdrawn regulations that required American subscribers to journals from four Communist countries to have a Government license.

title: Architecture View; THE PORTMAN PROJECT: IS IT AN ASSET O R AN ALBATROSS?
description: It was a summer's day in 1973 when John Portman, the architect, stood next to John Lindsay, the Mayor, in the Blue Room of City Hall. They were surrounded by elaborate renderings for a building that looked like a concrete skyscraper made over into a Buck Rogers space station, with a multi-storied atrium inside and a revolving, flyingsaucer-like protrusion at its top.

title: ON REAL ARMS TALKS
description: The Reagan Administration is pursuing inconsistent nuclear-weapons policies that endanger our security and threaten the foundations of the Atlantic alliance.

title: Editors' Choices
description: in-law's funeral in Rumania realizing on the spot the harshness of that country and in flashback the violent decay of human decency in his own country.

title: Sports of The Times; Boxers Don't Always Know Best
description: IN the coal mines deep under the Appalachian hills, the miners were convinced that the owners would trade health for profits any time. But when the Government came around to ban smoking in the mines, or suggested cloth curtains to keep coal dust from spreading, the miners bristled at that, too. No outsider was going to tell them how to do their business, buddy. The miners knew best.

title: Follow-Up on the News; Waiver for Katie
description: Four months after birth, Katie Beckett contracted viral encephalitis and entered St. Luke's Hospital in Cedar Rapids, Iowa. She was partly paralyzed, unable to swallow.

title: Critics' Choices
description: DANCE Dancemobile is usually to be found sending up a shower of sparks on city streets in the sizzling summer heat. The touring dance festival, a fixture of city summers since 1967, will dance indoors this week, but the sparks are likely to keep on flying.

title: TV View; WHY THIS 'BRIDESHEAD' IS MEMORABLE
description: ''Brideshead Revisited'' will certainly be ranked as one of the most memorable television productions of the decade. The story of Charles Ryder's assorted involvements with members of the aristocratic Marchmain family has been adapted with exquisite care. John Mortimer's screenplay is painstakingly faithful to the Evelyn Waugh novel. The direction, which started under Michael Lindsay-Hogg and then, because of his stage commitments, was switched to Charles Sturridge, manages to be both intelligent and imaginative. And the casting is superb, from the leads (Jeremy Irons as Charles, Anthony Andrews as Sebastian Flyte, Diana Quick as Julia Flyte) to the supporting roles (Nicholas Grace as Anthony Blanche, Phoebe Nicholls as Cordelia Flyte, Simon Jones as Lord Brideshead, John Grillo as Mr. Samgrass, Charles Keating as Rex Mottram, Jeremy Sinden as Boy Mulcaster, Jane Asher as Celia Ryder) to the glittering guest stars (John Gielgud as Charles's father, Ed ward, Laurence Olivier as Sebastian's f ather, Lord Marchmain, Claire Bloom as Lady Marchmain, Stephane Audr an as Cara, Marchmain's mistress, Mona Washbourne as Nanny Hawkins ). Derek Granger, the producer for Britain's Granada Television, h as assembled, on every level, a splendid array of talent.

title: BARCLAY'S HIGH AMBITIONS FOR THE AMERICAN MARKET
description: B ARCLAYS, in the view of its American competitors, makes so much money from its operations in Britain that it can spend with abandon to expand in the United States. And indeed, Barclays does have lofty ambitions for the American market.

title: Critics' Choices
description: ART The cold stone passageway of the City University Graduate Center Mall (33 West 42d Street) is an unlikely place for a rose garden, particularly in the dead of winter. But that's how Mary Ann Unger describes her sculptural environment of plywood brightly painted in warm spring tones, and titled ''Paradise as a Garden.''

title: The Issues Are Old
description: To the Editor:

title: PHILHARMONIC'S ENERGETIC NEW PRESIDENT
description: Constance Hoguet's long love affair with music began quietly 40 years ago at Smith College, gradually intensified during three decades of tireless activity in various musical organizations and reached a crescendo recently when she became the first female president of the New York Philharmonic Society.

title: PROTESTERS INTERCEPT WASTE BARGES
description: foot trawler, the Rainbow Warrier, into Raritan Bay last week and sent out rafts to protest ocean dumping.

title: About Westchester
description: IT is, at first, a startling sight: four small children being rewarded with mouthfuls of cracker crumbs for responding to their own names and looking someone directly in the eye. Then one sees that the tasks also include piecing together puzzles and identifying objects, and that the food is accompanied by smiles and hugs and is eventually phased out in favor of verbal praise.

title: MARGIOTTA FIGHTS TO KEEP 3 POSITIONS
description: HIS career jeopardized by his conviction in a Federal court, Joseph M. Margiotta is turning to the state courts in an effort to stave off, at least temporarily, his ouster as Nassau Republican chairman, disbarment as a lawyer and revocation of his insurance brokerage license.

title: HOW TO AND HOW NOT TO INSULATE AN UNFINISHED ATTIC
description: MOST of the instruction pamphlets that tell how to install insulation in an unfinished attic describe the procedures involved in putting the insulation down on the floor, between the ceilings joists. If the attic has some type of flooring down on top of these joists, then the insulation is either blown in under the floorboards (using loose-fill fiberglass or cellulose), or enough of the flooring is pulled up so that regular batts or blankets can be slid underneath. All this is fine for an attic that is to be left unfinished, but how is insulation installed if the attic is to be finished sometime in the not too distant future - that is, if walls and ceilings are to be paneled or finished in order to create one or more additional rooms up there? Insulation on the floor will not be of much help in keeping the attic rooms warm. It is needed up between the roof rafters and in the walls that will enclose the newly finished rooms. However, this may call for some carpentry -even though the attic will not be actually finished for some time. Additional two-by-fours may have to be installed before the insulation is put up so that the insulation can be placed where it will do the most good for the present, as well as in the future (when the rooms are actually finished). This does not mean that all the walls or partitions have to be framed out before the insulation is put up - just those two-by-fours that will form the short outside ''knee walls'' that will separate the finished rooms from the unfinished parts of the attic (over the eaves). Also, you may have to put up the collar beams across the top that will eventually form the ceiling of the new rooms (both are shown in the accompanying drawing). In many homes, collar beams are already in place because they are part of th e roof's structural framing (they p revent the rafters from spreading the walls outward under the weight of the roof). However, in some types of construction they are not ne eded, so the builder maynever have put them in and you will have to a dd them yourself. As shown in the drawing, they are nailed to the sides of each rafter so that insulating blankets or batts can be stap led up between them as they go horizontally across on top of the roo m. In addition, the collar beams will serve as the framework for the ceiling panels when you are ready to put them up. If insulation were put up between the rafters in an attic that had no collar beams, the insulation would have to run all the way to the peak -an undesirable alternative. When insulation goes all the way up to the peak (as it does in some cathedral ceilings, unfortunately), there is no air space above the insulation to provide ventilation, but this is important to prevent problems with condensation in cold weather. Stapling the insulation to the collar beams solves this problem. It creates a small area under the peak that can be ventilated by means of louvered openings installed in each end wall, up near the peak. When installing these collar beams in an attic that now has none, position them about one-third the length of the rafter down from the peak. Or locate them high enough so that there will be adequate headroom when the ceiling panels are installed by nailing them up against the collar beams. To provide a level nailing surface that will also be at a uniform height from one side of the room to the other, use a long straight edge to line up the bottom edges of each beam before nailing it in place. The two-by-four knee-wall studs (you can use two-by-threes instead) are nailed up after first nailing down a horizontal two-by-four that will form the bottom of the wall (this is called the bottom plate). Each short vertical stud is then nailed to the side of the roof rafter as shown, with its lower end resting on top of the bottom plate. To determine the position of the bottom plate, and the kneewall studs that will rest on top of it, some preliminary plans for the attic will have to be established - at least those that will show where these outside walls will be located. The insulat ion, with the vapor barrier toward the heated side, thengoes up betwe en these studs, under the roof between the overhead rafters, acro ss the collar beams at the top, then down the other sidetill it meets the floor again. The occupied area of the attic will beinsulated and kept warm, while the space in back of the walls will not be insula ted. However, in that space part of the attic floor willstill be expo sed (over the ceiling of the room below), so that part of the floor should be insulated to keep heat from escaping through the ceiling o f the rooms below.

title: Topics; HARD CHEESE, FREE SPEECH; Liberty Unlicensed
description: The Treasury Department has quietly lifted a Customs embargo on Cuban publications addressed to American subs cribers. So ends, one hopes, a misbegotten effort to protect Americ ans from free speech.

title:
Stamps;
FDR'S 100TH BIRTHDAY
description: The first commemorative of 1982 from the United States has just been issued at Hyde Park, N.Y. to mark the 100th anniversary of the birth of Franklin Delano Roosevelt, who as the 32d President,guided the nation through the greatest depression and the greatest war in its history. It is also the 50th anniversary of his first election in 1932.

title: Business Conditions; HOUSING HELPS CUT THE C.P.I.
description: A much-reduced rate of inflation was one of the economy's few bright spots last year. As measured by the Consumer Price Index, inflation declined more than three percentage points in 1981 from levels a year earlier, to 8.9 percent.

title: The Region in Summary; 'Unusual Event' And Worse, at Nuclear Plant
description: Thirty-one hours after a plume of radioactive steam swirled into the frigid skies near Rochester last week, the accident at the Robert E. Ginna nuclear power plant was declared at an end. But the questions it raised aren't likely to be resolved soon.

title: Anna E. Collins, a Nurse, Bride of William K. Guild
description: Anna E. Collins, a nurse with the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, was married yesterday to William Kenneth Guild, a partner in the New York law firm of Nims, Howes, Collison & Isner. The Rev. Paul F. M. Zahl performed the ceremony at Grace Episcopal Church.

title: ONE OF CITY'S HOMELESS GOES HOME- IN DEATH
description: When Rebecca Smith was found frozen to death in a makeshift cardboard hut on 10th Avenue last week nothing was known about her but the name she went by. For the elderly woman, like thousands of other homeless people on New York's streets, the loss of an address had also meant the loss of an identity.

title: Musical Measures
description: To the Editor:$

title: N.Y. PLANS PHOTOS ON DRIVER'S LICENSE
description: ALBANY United Press International

title: HOW THE JUDSON THEATER CHANGED AMERICAN DANCE
description: Twenty years ago, some dancers got together in a Greenwich Village church on a hot summer night and offered a program that helped change the course of American dance. The participants were members of an experimental composition workshop led by Robert Dunn who were eager to find space in which to try out ideas. Eventually, usable space was found at the Judson Memorial Church, a Baptist church on Washington Square noted for its liberal theological and political views which, in the early 60's, was already the home of the Judson Art Gallery andthe Judson Po ets' Theater. And at Judson on July 6, 1962, occurred the first of many concerts by the Judson Dance Theater.

title: KENNAN, KISSINGER AND POLAND
description: To the Editor:

title: WASHINGTON
description: LAST week, the President described his main urban initiative - revitalizing derelict urban areas by spurring creation of so-called enterprise zones - as nothing less than an effort to ''save America.'' It is the direct opposite of previous efforts to revive blighted cities.

title: DOWNHILL SKIING CLOSE TO HOME
description: TO SKI, or not to ski, that is the question. And once a decision is made to ski, the question becomes ''where?'' Last year, for more one million down-hillers, the answer was ''New Jersey.'' With nine areas to choose from - ranging from Vernon Valley/ Great Gorge with its 1,033-foot drop to Holly Mountain's 88 feet - New Jersey can cater to both beginner and expert.

title: RUNNING IS FOREVER, AND EVERYONE
