description: W HEN I took up running at the age of 45 I joined a high school cross-country team. I had to. There were no older runners in my area and extremely few competitive events. So, I kept my gear in my car and would cons ult the local paper for the time and place of the meets.

title: MUBARAK'S TIME OF TESTING
description: William E. Farrell is chief of The Times's Cairo bureau. By William E. Farrell

title: Canal Cruising
description: To the Editor:

title: Amy Cohn Betrothed To Daniel S. Wyzan
description: Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Cohn of Edison, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Amy Sara Cohn, to Daniel Stuart Wyzan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Wyzan of Stamford, Conn.

title: NATIONAL TROUBLES
description: AMERICA NOW The Anthropology of a Changing Culture. By Marvin Harris. 208 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $12.95.

title: HOLLOWAY HELPS ST. PETER'S BEAT FORDHAM COACH HE LEFT, 59-56
description: Tyronne Holloway, a Fordham basketball player until he transferred because he said he had disagreements with his coach, was proudest as a Peacock yesterday when St. Peter's rallied from 12 points behind to upset Fordham, 59-56, at Rose Hill Gym in the Bronx.

title: Around the World; Japan Formally Agrees To Ease Trade Barriers
description: The Cabinet formally approved a plan today to make it easier for foreign goods to reach Japanese markets.

title: SUFFOLK TESTING CHILD HEALTH PLAN
description: TAKE a child to the average pediatrician on the Island and the fee is likely to be about $25 to find out whether that screaming in the night was because of an ear infection. A follow-up visit might cost a few dollars less.

title: AFTER JOYCE, THERE'S NO WORLD WITHOUT JOYCE
description: ''My God, what a clumsy olla putrida James Joyce is!'' wrote D.H. Lawrence, shortly after ''Ulysses'' appeared. ''Nothing but old fags and cabbage-stumps of quotations from the Bible and the rest, stewed in the juice of deliberate, journalistic dirty-mindedness.'' A hundred years after Joyce's birth - he was born February 2, 1882 -and 60 years after the publication of ''Ulysses,'' a remarkable change in critical and popular response to his work has taken place. Joyce has not only spawned a thriving academic industry, but his books, issued by Penguin and Modern Library, have become unquestionable classics, influencing several generations of writers and forming a part of the educated person's literary equipment.

title: The Nation in Summary; Rickover's Last Salvo
description: Hyman G. Rickover, as of 2400 hours tonight a civilian for the first time in 63 years, struck his colors last week on Capitol Hill. Testifying for the last time as a four-star admiral, he maintained that disarmament should have a high priority, adding that he would gladly sink the nuclear-powered fleet he devoted much of his career to building.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: THE BOOK OF EBENEZER LE PAGE, By G.B. Edwards. Avon $6.95. As John Fowles explains in an introduction, the manuscript of this novel was found among the effect of Gerald B. Edwards (1899-1976), and during the author's lifetime it had been turned down by many publishers. Our reviewer Guy Davenport found this ''incredible,'' because it is ''one of the best novels of our time.'' In it, an elderly bachelor not unlike Edwards recalls, in a gossipy style that is faithful to spoken English, the passionate relationships of the residents of the Channel Island of Guernsey as its pastoral culture wanes, as it is occupied by the Germans during World War II and, finally, as it is conquered by the forces of ''progress.''

title: USED, AND EVEN ABUSED, CARS DEVELOP A GROWING FAN CLUB
description: According to the Motor Vehicle Manufacturer s' Association, the average age of cars on the road today is 6.6 years, compared with 5.5years in 1970. According to me, that's just f ine.

title: Music: Debuts in Review; Christina Kiss, Pianist, Plays Bartok and Liszt
description: Christina Kiss, a young Hungarian pianist and a winner in many music competitions around the world, played Bartok and Liszt last Sunday evening at Alice Tully Hall. Miss Kiss's technical reliability in all this music was unshakable.

title:
LONG ISLAND GUIDE;
MOZART IN MELVILLE
description: With David Golub once more at the piano, the Orchestra Da Camera continues its Mozart Festival at 3 P.M. today at West Hollow Junior High School in Melville. Under James Conlon's direction, the concert will offer the Overture to ''The Marriage of Figaro,'' Symphony No. 35 in C (K. 385), Sinfonia Concertante for Oboe, Clarinet, Horn and Bassoon in E flat (K. Anh 9) and the Piano Concerto No. 18 in B flat (K. 456). Tickets are $10; the school is at Route 110 and the Long Island Expressway. For reservations, call 249-7868.ART AND WAR HISTORY

title: Design; ART FARM
description: Among city folk, there is a common fantasy that repairing to a farm is the ultimate antidote for the tensions of urban life. Few have opportunity to test the dream, but one who has - with surprising results - is Stephen Mazoh, a Manhattan art dealer who in 1974 bought a 270-acre farm in the Hudson Valley.

title: AN INDUSTRY PAYS PRICE FOR OB EDIENCE
description: THE owners of Connecticut's metal-finishing plants complain that Federal regulations are putting their livelihood, and those of their employees in danger. About 5,000 men and women are employed in do zens of sma ll factories throughout the state

title: The Region in Summary; Koch Is Serious About Albany?
description: Life in Albany may be ''a fate worse than death,'' as Mayor Koch once opined, but with President Reagan proposing to shift more cash and authority there, the Statehouse could be gaining on City Hall as a preferred business address. So it seemed when Mayor Koch suggested last week that he might consider a run for Governor.

title: STATE TASK FORCE PROPOSING CHANGE IN AID FOR SCHOOLS
description: A New York State task force set up to recommend basic changes in the way public education is financed has decided to present Governor Carey this week with seven different options that would cost an additional $500 million to $1.5 billion a year.

title: About Books and Authors
description: A Former Citizen of Poland

title: The World in Summary; Done In In Dublin
description: In only seven months in office, Irish Prime Minister Garret FitzGerald moved boldly on the two key issues -the bloody troubles of the North and what he called ''an economic and financial crisis more grave than any this state has previously faced.'' His ideas on the first issue aroused controversy; his program to resolve the second brought down his coalition Government last week.

title: THE MEANING OF TRUE GRITS
description: TURNER CATLEDGE, former executive editor and vice president of The New York Times, lives in New Orleans. By TURNER CATLEDGE

title: A SOCIETY APART: YALE'S HOLMES CLUB
description: NEW HAVEN TO the untrained eye, the Yale Sherlock Holmes Society seems a solemn, tightly knit group. Composed primariy of academics, the 10-year-old society has all the trappings of stodgy intellectualism - official stationery, a loyal membership and even a coat of arms complete with Latinate motto.

title: HEADED U. OF MINNESOTA
description: Malcolm C. Moos, a political scientist who wrote speeches for Pr esident Eisenhower and later headed the University of Minnesota forse ven years, was found dead Thursday in his lakeside cabin in Ha ckensack, Minn. He was 65 years old. Dr. Moos ha d lived since last year in the cabin on Ten Mile Lake, 200 miles nor th of Minneapolis, where he wrote and did research in academic affa irs.

title: A GUIDE TO THE ISLAND CONTINENT
description: Australia is the largest island but the smallest continent in the world. It covers nearly 3,000,000 square miles - almost the size of the continental United States - and is divided into six states and two territories: the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory.

title: Theater; 'NIGHT MUST FALL': SIMPLE THRILLS
description: FOR the record, ''Night Must Fall'' dates to the year 1936, when the playwright Emlyn Williams appeared in his own play opposite May Whitty on Broadway. She went on to Hollywood to recreate her role for the screen opposite Robert Montgomery and Rosalind Russell, with the other roles played by the Broadway cast. Not too long ago, a second but not successful film version was released starring Albert Finney.

title: AN 'ACT OF LOVE' FOR FOUNDER OF HUDSON RIVER SCHOOL
description: Two New York City art dealers have bought the studio and home here of Thomas Cole, the founder of the Hudson River School of painting in the early 19th century, to maintain as ''a sort of museum'' and exhibition hall.

title: A Remembrance of L.I.  For Those Who Moved
description: Joan Marans Dim's article, ''Remembrance of Things Pastrami'' (Opinion Page, Jan. 3), was a delightful and enjoyable item. My daughter, who moved to Arizona because her husband got a professorship in a college there, was the first one to receive a copy of the article. I also sent copies to a friend who moved to Reading, Pa., and to another friend who moved to Israel. SYLVIA H. LEVIN Rego Park

title: DRUG AND ALCOHOL PROGRAM SET
description: ON March 1, through the efforts of the Alcohol and Drug Awareness Program of the Tarrytowns, 25 community leaders, including 17 members of the staffs of the high school and jun ior high, will begin a week of intensive training on alcohol and drug abuse. The program, conducted by the Maxwell Institute of Bronxville, will cover assessment of alcohol and drug use, its medical implications, the treatment pro cess and intervention with adolescents.

title: MUNICIPAL TROUBLES
description: SETTING MUNICIPAL PRIORITIES, 1982 Edited by Charles Brecher and Raymond D. Horton. 444 pp. New York: Russell Sage Foundation. $29.95.''SETTING M UNICIPAL PRIORITIES, 1982'' is the third in a series of annual volume s on New York City sponsored by New York University, Columbia Univ ersity, the Department of Commerce and several private foundations. The idea for the books is taken from the admirable Brookings Ins titution series ''Setting National Priorities,'' which reviews the P resident's annual budget statement to discern what our nation, throu gh its government, has decided to do and not to do. This approach requires modification for New York City. Monumental as its budget is , the city is not a fully independent actor; a network of participan ts share in its fate, particularly the national and state governm ents, which provide a very substantial share of its budget, and a variety of independent or semi-independent agencies managing tran sit, public housing, hospitals and other key city functions. An d perhaps most important of all, the city cannot run in the red with the easy assurance of the Federal Government, which knows that wh atever the deficit, it will be and can be made up, and there is no o ne to say otherwise.

title: VEAL: PERFECT WITH ITALY'S RAISON d'ETRE
description: VEAL has been called ''the chameleon'' of the kitchen. It adapts with ease to its surroundings and goes with almost any flavor, including sage, rosemary, thyme, tarragon, lemon, orange, tomatoes, white wine, Marsala, cream, prosciutto or Parmesan cheese. If these ingredients suggest Italy it is hardly surprising, considering that Italians eat the most veal of any nation, 15.4 pounds a year per person (compared with four pounds for Americans).

title: WHAT'S IN A NAME? WOMEN FIND OUT
description: When Terri Tepper, a teacher in a Barrington, Ill., elementary school, married Lawrence Weiner, a lawyer, in 1964, she automatically assumed that she would henceforth be known as Mrs. Weiner.

title: Passing Rules Modified
description: Defensive fouls committed away from the area of a catchable ball no longer will be construed as pass interference, according to a new rule adopted by the N.C.A.A. Football Rules Committee. That was one of several new interpretations announced today as the committee made the first significant rules changes affec ting college football's passing game in 20 years.

title: MEN AND WOMEN ARE NOT THE SAME
description: The essential feature of democracy is not that all people are the same but rather that opportunities not be denied nor discrimination practiced because of differences among people.

title: NEW YEAR FEAST, VIETNAMESE STYLE
description: PATCHOGUE ''IN Vietnam we would have celebrated the new year for three days, but working here makes that pretty difficult,'' said Dr. Luong Phan of Patchogue. But Dr. Phan, who works at the Brookhaven National Laboratory, did ask for a holiday last Monday, the first day of the Lunar New Year traditionally observed in Viet nam.

title: SLED RACING: DOG AND DRIVER
description: Sled dog racing is a marvelous marriage between the driver and his animals. It is also a rapidly growing sport that attracts an unusual array of competitors: hunting and fishing guides, teachers, doctors, lawyers, telephone linemen, skiers, housewives, people of every conceivable background who somehow, somewhere, were caught up in the fascination of moving in near-silence over the white landscape behind a team of eager, powerful, fast-moving dogs.

title: Practical Traveler; SPECIALIZED NEWSLETTERS
description: Despite all the colorful brochures in travel agency racks and all the guidebooks on bookstore or library shelves, vacation planners often complain of difficulty in getting guidance they can trust. A small assortment of independently published newsletters, however, offers to provide the sort of information and advice that can make the task easier.

title: CENSORSHIP ISSUE DEBATED ON SUFFOLK CAMPUS
description: BRENTWOOD SIX years ago, two professors of English, Jeffrey Silverstein and Jeffrey Kluewer, helped students at the western campus of Suffolk Community College start a school newspaper, The Western Student Press, and became advisers to the monthly tabloid.

title: POLISH 'NORMALIZATION' DEPARTS FROM THE EAST EUROPEAN NORM
description: At a recent news conference, a Western journalist asked a Government spokesman if it wasn't a bad idea to use the word ''normalization'' to describe what was going on in Poland.

title: SPECIAL GUEST STARS: A FLOCK OF CANADIAN GEESE
description: To the Editor:

title: Westchester Guide; HARPSICHORD FOR CHURCH
description: G. Roy Brotherhood, a physicist from Mount Kisco, with the help of his daughter Leslie and son-in-law Charles Dickinson, has built a harpsichord for his church. The Flemish-style instrument was constructed over a period of about a year, and it will be heard in its first recital at 4 P.M. today in The Church of Saint James the Less, on Church Lane and Crane Road in Scarsdale.

title: FOLK MUSEUM PROTESTS REZONING PROPOSAL
description: The Museum of American Folk Art announced Friday that it would seek the revision of a proposed zoning regulation affecting the building of its new home on West 53d Street.

title: French Aide in Saudi Arabia
description: Defense Minister Charles Hernu of France arrived in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, tonight at the start of a twice-postponed trip to discuss military cooperation, the official Saudi press agency said.

title: SPELLS, WISHES, GOLDFISH, OLD SCHOOL HURTS
description: THIS is about reading; a drugstore in winter; the gold leaf on the dome of the Boston State House; also loss, panic, and dread. First, the gold leaf. (This part is a little like a turn-of-the-century pulp tale, though only a little. The ending is a surprise, but there is no plot.) Thirty years ago I burrowed in the Boston Public Library one whole afternoon, to find out - not out of curiosity - how the State House got its gold roof. The answer, like the answer to most Bostonian questions, was Paul Revere. So I put Paul Revere's gold dome into an ''article,'' and took it (though I was just as scared by recklessness then as I am now) to The Boston Globe, on Washington Street. The Features Editor had a bare severe head, a closed parenthesis mouth, and silver Dickensian spectacles. He made me wait, standing, at the side of his desk while he read; there was no bone in me that did not rattle. Then he opened a drawer and handed me $15. Ah, joy of Homer, joy of Milton! Grub Street bliss!

title: IS IT PRETENSE OR PROGRESS ON NAMIBIA?
description: The white minority Government of South Africa, which abhors the idea of majority rule in theory and practice, last week put its imprimateur on a set of constitutional guidelines for the neighboring territory of South-West Africa that promises a new wrinkle on pre-independence African elections. Instead of the familiar ''one man, one vote,'' it would be one man, two votes.

title: PROFESSORSHIPS' PAY PUT IN PERSPECTIVE
description: To the Editor:

title: SUSPECT IN KILLING OF TROOPER PLACED ON F.B.I. WANTED LIST
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation today placed one of two suspects in the murder of State Trooper Philip J. Lamonaco on its list of the 10 most-wanted persons. The New Jersey trooper was killed Dec. 21 after he stopped a car for a routine check on Route 80 near the Pennsylvania state border.

title: Nureyev's Fight Against Time
description: It is about time that Rudolf Nureyev's picture was featured on the cover of the The New York Times Magazine (''Nureyev's Fight Against Time,'' by John Lombardi, Dec. 13).

title: Nancy Cohen Fiancee Of Natan Wekselbaum
description: The engagement of Nancy Augusta Cohen to Natan Wekselbaum has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Avron Cohen of Schenectady, N.Y., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Mrs. Israel Luski of Miami Beach and the late Samuel Wekselbaum of New York.

title: New Jersey Guide; THE DIVINE SARAH
description: Ella Fitzgerald, a formidable talent herself, once said, ''The greatest singing talent in the world today is Sarah Vaughan.'' Miss Vaughan, celebrating her 40th anniversary in show business this year, has been described as ''a jazz musician's singer.'' But her repertory goes beyond jazz, to pop and even opera.

title: Around the World; 53 Protesters Arrested In West German Clashes
description: The police arrested at least 53 people today in clashes at the Frankfurt airport and then in downtown Frankfurt with demonstrators protesting construction of a new runway, the authorities said. Officials said about 30 people were injured, including 15 po licemen.

title: LIBYAN TROOPS ARE REPORTED IN POLAND FOR TRAINING
description: Amid signs of a new warmth in relations between Poland and Libya, Libyan troops are arriving in Poland to undergo special training, according to Western sources.

title: 'SLIVER OF LIVER': STORIES FATHER TOLD
description: NOW that the cold shadows of winter cross and recross the land, I often think of my deceased father, who long ago told his five children lengthy, sad, sentimental stories that made us weep. A good and kind man, I don't believe he wished to inflict emotional pain upon us or traumatize us for the rest of our days, but I vividly recall that he never seemed happier than when after a story session he sent us off to bed heavy with emotion.

title: PAUL B. RELLE IS FIANCE OF ALISON JANE VOORHIS
description: Mr. and Mrs. Russell C. Voorhis of Wilton, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Alison Jane Voorhis, to Paul Botond Relle, son of Dr. an Mrs. Matyas Relle of Endicott City, Md.

title: AN EXPERIENCED NEIGHBOR OF RUSSIA FEARS FOR POLAND
description: FINLAND last week elected its first new President in a quarter of a century. He is Mauno Koivisto, a carpenter's son whose down-to-earth style and economic common sense have won him a far wider following than the Social Democratic Party to which he belongs.

title: Prospects
description: The Heat on the Fed

title: Authors to Discuss Role Of Writers in Poland
description: Stanislaw Baranczak, a Polish dissident poet; Joseph Brodsky, an exiled Soviet poet, and Susan Sontag, the American critic, will hold an open discussion on the role of the writer in Poland tomorrow at 8 P.M. at the Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street.

title: Headliners; Getting the Spirit
description: Ordained last week as the first black female priest in the Episcopal Diocese of New York, Sandra Antoinette Wilson says that for the time being her toughest job is deciding what to be called. ''It's a real quandary, and a problem that will be here for a long time'' the graduate of Union Theological Seminary and Vassar College said.

title: THE SWAP
description: WASHINGTON ''T HERE is nothing more difficult to take in hand, more perilous to conduct, or more uncertain in its success, than to take the lead in the introduction of a new order of things.'' The world's premier political consultant, Niccolo Machiavelli, rendered that advice more than 400 years ago. Whether President Reagan heard a similar message, he seemed to be acting last week on the premise that installing a new order in Federal-state relations would be easier than his original goal of cutting taxes, increasing military spending and balancing the budget all at the same time.

title: AWARDS FOR MEDICAL RESEARCH
description: Sixteen $100,000 awards - including five at the Columbia College of Physicians and Surgeons - have gone to researchers in medical schools in the New York metropolitan area to finance a broad range of scientific investigations.

title: The World in Summary; Italians Condemn Moscow Model
description: Led by the Italians, Western European Communist parties began distancing themselves from the Kremlin after Moscow crushed Czechoslovakia's ''socialism with a human face'' in 1968. The big French party joined the ''Eurocommunist'' heresy for three years in the mid-1970's.

title: Patrice Lynn Sayre Wed
description: The marriage of Patrice Lynn Sayre, daughter of Mrs. George Susskind of Del Ray Beach, Fla., to Alan David Handler, son of Dr. and Mrs. Archie Handler of Passaic, N.J., took place yesterday in a loft at 126 Fifth Avenue.
